name: La Présidente. –
text: I have an announcement to make in agreement with the political groups.I submit to you this proposed modification of the agenda.Due to its adoption in the Committee on Budgets last night, Mr Negrescu's report on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund, following a request from Estonia, is added to the vote on Wednesday.Are there any objections?There are not any.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Sophia in 't Veld, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, containing recommendations to the Commission on the creation of a mechanism for the'Union for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights (2015/2254 (INL)) (A8-0283 / 2016).

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I am very pleased that we are having this debate here today because we have travelled quite a road since we decided a year and a half ago to draw up this legislative initiative report. First of all, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and my co-rapporteur on the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO). These are not just hollow words; I think that we have had a very fruitful and constructive cooperation, and the result of that cooperation is before you and will, hopefully, command a large majority when we vote later today. I note that the only party that is actively campaigning against my report is the Front National, which I find reassuring in a way. The European Commission will today present its working programme for 2017. Commissioner Timmermans always says that the European Commission has to be big on big things, and I very much agree with that. But I do think that democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are a big thing. We Europeans have something to be proud of: we have been leading for many decades in the area of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, so we have a heritage that we can be proud of. So let us now take the opportunity to further deepen and strengthen that culture of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the European Union as a whole, because the EU is more than the sum of Member States. Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights (or DRF, if I may coin a new abbreviation in EU jargon) is key to the functioning of the European Union. It is key to policy areas like police and justice cooperation, and asylum and refugee policies, but also the internal market and, as we have seen recently, international trade. We are all aware of the so-called Copenhagen dilemma. In other words, when a country wants to join the European Union, it has to meet the highest standards – but Member States of the European Union cannot be held to those standards. We do not really have sufficient means to enforce our standards of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, but we do feel that the need for a mechanism for upholding DRF is growing. One of our colleagues, Viviane Reding, who was a Commissioner at the time for that purpose, took the first steps to the creation of the rule of law framework, which is now triggered by Mr Timmermans. We have seen the creation of the Rule of Law Dialogue in the Council, the creation of the friends of the Rule of Law Group in the European Council, and Mr Timmermans, when you were still a Minister of foreign affairs in the Netherlands, you yourself called for the creation of a rule of law mechanism. We have the European Commission Rule of Law Framework, and that is very important. I think it is very good that you have triggered it in the case of Poland, but that same case also illustrates the weaknesses and the shortcomings of that mechanism, and therefore the European Parliament has proposed the DRF pact. The principles, I hope, will find their way into the proposals that the Commission will, hopefully, put forward. The principles are that the pact, or the mechanism, should be applied to all Member States equally. They should all be assessed on the same basis, and also the EU institutions. It should be a permanent mechanism and not crisis-driven, as we have now in the case of Poland. There should be ongoing monitoring. It should be objective, evidence-based, and not politically motivated, and it should also be building on existing instruments and be realised under the current treaties. Finally, our mechanism foresees close involvement of the national parliaments. I am very much looking forward to the debate, and I very much hope that the European Commission will join the big majority in the European Parliament and come forward with proposals that build on the report that we will adopt today.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Parliament for today’s debate on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In particular, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Sophia in ‘t Veld, for her personal engagement and the important work that has gone into the preparation of the report. She is passionate about this and we could see her passion reflected in the report. We can all fully agree on the objective underlying the report, which is to ensure that our common values and rules are respected and, if need be, enforced. The key issue for discussion is not about the objective itself but about the best means to achieve that objective. There is much in the report I can fully agree with, such as the suggestion to follow an inclusive approach with all stakeholders – EU institutions, Member States and civil society. The idea of an interparliamentary dialogue between the European Parliament and national parliaments equally merits support. National parliaments are involved in many of the rule of law related problems that we witness in Member States today. We need to work towards a common understanding of our values at national and at European level. This interparliamentary dialogue could, as a first step, lead to a discussion on the different options and means which are currently on the table to ensure that our common values are respected and enforced. The Commission and I assume that the Council will want to be involved as well. However, there are also a number of points in the report on which I have questions and I would very much like to hear your views. For instance, I have questions about the need and the feasibility of an annual report and a policy cycle prepared by a committee of experts. I also have doubts about the feasibility of an interinstitutional agreement on this matter. Some elements of the proposed approach, such as the central role attributed to an independent expert panel in the proposed pact, also raise questions of legality, institutional legitimacy and accountability. Moreover, from a practical and political point of view, it may also be very difficult to find common ground on such an interinstitutional agreement between all the parties concerned. I hope we can all agree that a long institutional debate on new mechanisms is the last thing we need right now. We have a range of existing tools and actors that already provide a set of complementary and effective means to address rule of law issues. Duplication of existing mechanisms is something I think we should avoid, and if I understood Mrs in ‘t Veld’s introduction correctly, this is something she wants to avoid as well. As you know, in March 2014 the Commission adopted a rule of law framework. We are currently applying this framework in the case of Poland for the first time. Mrs in ‘t Veld referred to this.  The Commission takes protecting the rule of law very seriously. We are grateful for the support Parliament has shown in its resolution of 14 September and we need that support if we are to be successful in our approach. The Commission also organises an annual fundamental rights colloquium, involving European institutions, Member States, international organisations and civil society. This year the colloquium will take place on 17 and 18 November and will be devoted to the topic of media pluralism and democracy.  As you know – and as Mrs in ‘t Veld mentioned – in December 2014 the Council established a rule of law dialogue to debate rule of law issues and – as Mrs in ‘t Veld has said – in a previous capacity as Foreign Minister, I was one of the people who took the initiative, together with the Foreign Ministers of Denmark, Germany and Finland. We also have a number of other actors, apart from the Council – the Council of Europe, the Venice Commission, the Agency for Fundamental Rights and a host of NGOs active in the field of fundamental rights. They all contribute to the monitoring of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in our Member States. We should make their contributions stronger. We should also make the best possible use of these existing instruments, evaluate them, look where we see deficiencies and then take steps towards the creation of a new mechanism – only after that evaluation, I would say.  I very much look forward to hearing your views. Let me assure you that the Commission will examine your request for a proposal very carefully, in line with Article 225 of the Treaty, and give this report the serious response it deserves. But let me also stress again what I think is crucial. We need to avoid division around our common values as clearly set out in the Treaties and work with our various partners to build a consensus. Protecting the fundamental values of the Union is a collective responsibility of all institutions. The existing treaties give us the tools so let us use them. At the end of the day, this is a very political process.  But let me repeat here what I said last week in the committee discussion we had on that in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). Without full integral application of the rule of law across the European Union, the European Union is doomed because the rule of law is the fundament upon which this construction is built. If we disregard the rule of law, there is nothing to keep the European Union together, other than naked power politics. That will be to the detriment of the smaller, of the minorities, of the weaker, and of the individual citizens. We cannot let that happen.

name: György Schöpflin
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, thank you Vice-President and also incidentally very much my thanks to the rapporteur and everybody else who has worked very hard on this dossier. A human rights mechanism has three necessary conditions to meet if it is to be successful, and this is what I would very much like to see myself. First of all, it must have a legal base, giving it immunity from political interference. It follows that this mechanism will only acquire legitimacy if it is not used to target Member States in order to punish them. Secondly, the mechanism must be completely even-handed as between Member States. The slightest hint of different treatment will delegitimise it, so no cherry picking, no opportunistic targeting. This, of course, will require continuous monitoring. The third is consistency of implementation, but here a balance has to be struck between subsidiarity and all European practice. Too much of the latter runs a danger of centralisation – the Jacobin temptation. If the Jacobins get their way, there is no chance at all that the rule-of-law culture will take root in the European Union.

name: Frank Engel
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to start by expressing my sincere thanks to the rapporteur Mrs in ’t Veld for a remarkably inclusive approach that she has had throughout this process and which has allowed maximum convergence throughout this Parliament on a text which I believe is fundamental.  It is even more fundamental if I hear the First Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans, telling us that there may be difficulty to find common ground on the topic throughout the institutions. That to me is the best proof that this is exactly the moment in which we need to kick off a process of engagement towards finding a veritable and a true European logic of governance, because we may not be there yet, as we discover far too often when we see governance trends in certain European countries, as has been the case over the last month and as may be the case again.  Who, at the end of the day, is going to protect us from what happened in the inter-war period – when one country after another, for reasons of their own, drifted off into extremely problematic governmental orientations – with what we have now. With the generalised unanimity requirement that is on the table to engage whatsoever with respect to any sort of state, we would be doing essentially nothing and that would be dramatic.  It would be dramatic as a sign to the millions of Europeans who nowadays look towards Europe and to this House as the only – the only – buoy of stability; if it is about guaranteeing that elections in the future change policies, yes, but not the nature of their state. This is something that is aimed at ensuring continuity of statehood, of institutions, of impartiality of state against electoral result, if need be, and against those who believe that saving the Occident is more important than saving their own citizens from arbitrary governance.  This is a necessary mechanism. This is something that we can now embrace. This is something that we now should embrace and this is something for which Parliament has taken time to converge towards but it is good that it has finally done so.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová
text: for the group S & amp; D. - Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, first of all, but also the whole team of shadow rapporteurs for the excellent work we have done together at many meetings. The rapporteur presents as much as possible, what we need and what is also the answer to your speech, Mr Timmermanns. You mentioned what the European Commission and the European institutions have at their disposal today. But the result is that it is not all working, and that is why this report is here, and that is why this new proposal is here. There are currently several negative pieces of legislation that are being prepared in several Member States of the European Union. Poland has already been mentioned here, in the past it was also Hungary. However, their consequences are that they threaten and undermine the protection of the fundamental rights of citizens of the rule of law. And I must tell you that I will honestly watch very closely how the procedure you initiated against Poland begins or ends, because I am more pessimistic about this. These are also changes to media laws, an amendment to the Civil Service Act, or insufficient protection for the fundamental rights of the LGBTI and many others. The European Commission's existing monitoring and regular evaluation tools, including the cooperation and verification mechanism, anti-corruption reports and media monitoring, which already exist today and which you yourself mentioned, are put in place and do not sufficiently guarantee sufficient protection of fundamental rights and values. which the European Union professes. The European Union therefore does not currently have any legally binding mechanism that can successfully monitor the compliance of Member States' legislation with Union values ​​and fundamental values. Although there are instruments that you have mentioned, they are currently unable to draw attention to the serious risk of infringing fundamental rights and freedoms, and we must focus on a clear and precise definition of criteria that are sufficiently binding on infringers and discouraging to be more prompt in the future. could prevent the violation of the rule of law, fundamental rights. At the same time, I would like to thank those who - although they know that this report could be perhaps even stricter, perhaps tougher - understand that in such a broad quorum that we have here, we have really been looking for the maximum possible, and I believe that this support the report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! I am a big supporter of the rule of law and the legal libertarian tradition, but I cannot support Mrs in 't Veld's report. Europe needs a genuine voluntary dialogue on this matter, a dialogue based on trust, on the exchange of experiences, focused around the essentials, but also using the good acquis of individual European Union countries. This report, however, gives us an arbitrary, supervisory, permanent mechanism, and at the risk of a biased interpretation of the very concept of the rule of law. While working on the report, I made proposals that were more in keeping with the ideas of trust, mutual trust and dialogue between states. I wanted an annual pan-European conference with European institutions and governments. I would also like to point out, responding to the voice of my predecessor, who called for a binding and effective mechanism, that such a mechanism is defined by the Treaty of Lisbon. It is the Council of the European Union itself that has the right to assess violations by individual states, and this is a legal and binding mechanism. We should avoid actions without a legal basis and which multiply distrust between states - which is why I cannot support this report.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, we do not settle for apparently comfortable situations. The European Union Pact on Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights, which we will call the DRF from now on, is thinking big, Mr Timmermans. The truth is that I am very pleased to be able to thank Mrs. in 't Veld for the work that she has been doing for years. There is a long way to go to this report and there is going to be a long way to go since the vote, today, by the Commission, and I hope led by Mr Timmermans. We shake off the self-satisfaction that yes, that we are European, that we have built a long period of peace and prosperity, that we have strong values. But, look, I was born in a place where the solid values ​​of peace and coexistence did not exist, where people were persecuted for having different ideas, where the rule of law was turned upside down. And we need these mechanisms because - as a Spanish intellectual says - the crisis we are experiencing is not limited to the terrifying disorder of our financial system or the breakdown of a model of economic growth. We also suffer the consequences of a loss of pulse with respect to our values. And that is why it is good to update; and that is why it is good to ask ourselves these problems; and that is why it is very good that Mrs in 't Veld had the courage and enthusiasm to shake off the harshness that we usually have in these institutions. This type of mechanism is necessary. Today begins a part of the path that you are going to have to travel and, if you don't, we are going to be vigilant to tell you that you must do it. Look, it may happen that there are societies that confirm with their votes the corrupt, the deniers and even the murderers. We do not want a permissive or indifferent approach. We want - as Mr Schöpflin said -, without opportunism, a mechanism with objective criteria, with the collaboration of all actors and civil society. Mr. Timmermans, we're going to pass the buck to you in a bit.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too thank Sophia 't Veld, your resolution is important because for the first time we are not dealing with rights outside the Union but we are asking ourselves whether we ourselves respect the rule of law that we claim to embody. The new mechanism has this purpose and for this reason I consider it positive, since the beginning of the great crisis there is no talk of anything other than doing homework, but the tasks are only economic, constitutional democracy is almost never among the primary duties. I hope that the mechanism shifts the accent a little, that it helps to recognize the effects of austerity on rights, such as that to health, to work, to transparent and blameless institutions. A similar mechanism was missing. Article 7 of the treaty is unusable because it is in the hands of governments, therefore not impartial. In the negotiations, I asked that the European institutions be screened like the States. The result satisfies me only in part, because such vigilance is promised but not guaranteed. We will be tabling amendments that add these guarantees. The European institutions are seen by citizens with growing mistrust because they are opaque and intrusive, if we showed genuine vigilance towards them this mechanism that is emerging would be less suspicious of interference in the policies of the States.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Mr First Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! How often we hear these days that European values ​​are in danger! But if it happens then - as is now the case with the rule of law procedure against Poland - then it means: No, the EU must not do that. The intervention of the European Union is negative. We don't want that, we want to preserve our sovereignty. Many governments and many in the population forget that we created these European values ​​together - the Charter of Fundamental Rights, everyone agreed to it at the time. And we have to defend that. In the past we have not succeeded in creating a sense of togetherness with the existing procedures; that the index finger is no longer pointed at a state, a government, but that we say together: We want to change that, because we do not want democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law to be in danger. It is also important to me, with this report, with this request, to make it clear that this is not only going against the so-called new Member States - that is, Poland and Hungary. There are also things that are not in order in the old Member States: the state of emergency in France, the ban on demonstrations in Spain or, under Berlusconi, the media power of the Prime Minister at that time a few years ago. That wasn't okay either. We need such a joint pact. We have to do this together. Only in this way will we be able to convince the citizens again that this Union is there for them and not just for a few. I am pleased that we have succeeded in making this report like this. It is a pity that we did not succeed in this traffic light system with the colors. That would be important for visibility. But I am also pleased that we have really found a large majority here in committee, and hopefully also at lunchtime today, and the only ones who were really against it was the ENF. I would like to thank Sophia in 't Veld warmly - yes, also for your courage and your passion to bring this forward - but also to all the other shadow reporters. It was really a great cooperation. And to Mr Timmermans: follow what Sophia in 't Veld did. Dare to think big! Have the courage to continue on this path with the European Parliament!

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, well, first of all I too would like to thank my colleague Sophia in 't Veld for her excellent work and all the colleagues and shadow rapporteurs. We had already discussed this during the report on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union, of which I was the rapporteur, and it was already agreed there that this mechanism was necessary. It was necessary because, despite Europe's ancient tradition in the field of the protection of fundamental rights, despite the rule of law, fundamental rights, the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which has been adopted, unfortunately there are different institutional actors and several non-governmental organizations that continue to denounce the numerous violations occurring on European territory. It is evident that a duplication of mechanisms is not necessary, something new is not necessary, but something new is not necessary when what exists works. To date, if these violations continue to occur, it is clear that something is wrong and it is clear that we need something different. This mechanism is necessary because it must be prevented. When it comes to fundamental rights, we cannot wait for the violation to occur and then take initiatives, we must prevent and protect fundamental rights throughout Europe. That is why I express my full support for this report, I congratulate my colleague once again and I think it is extremely important to have such a mechanism to give substance to what is written in the treaties.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union provides for a sanction mechanism against Member States which do not respect human rights. The in 't Veld report now claims to supplement it. This report poses both a legal and a political problem. The legal problem arises from the fact that it upsets Article 7. As the Council's legal service explained in an opinion of 27 May 2014, Article 7 in effect gives the Council, and it alone, the power find that a member state violates human rights. However, the in 't Veld report disregards this exclusive competence of the Council by seeking to give the Brussels Commission concurrent powers of assessment by adopting reports and recommendations. On the other hand, the in 't Veld report poses above all a political problem by dealing a new blow to the sovereignty of States. It allows experts without democratic legitimacy to rate states as children according to three degrees of rating symbolized in its initial presentation by a set of three colors: green for good students, yellow for those who can do better and red for those who must be sanctioned. However, in the spirit of the in 't Veld report, the states which must be sanctioned are obviously those which dare to resist the diktat of the European Union. The report does not even hide it since it openly aims to punish two states: Hungary, guilty of resisting the Union's migration policy, and Poland, guilty of refusing to allow its family policy to be dictated by the LGBTI lobby. The in 't Veld report therefore constitutes an additional stage in the forced march towards the sovietization of the Union. This is why I tabled an amendment rejecting this liberticidal text.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Madam President, Mrs in 't Veld's report is based on a formidable contradiction. It is a matter of putting European democracies under surveillance in the name of democracy, of having legitimately elected governments monitored by experts with suspect legitimacy, all while putting in place, in the name of the treaties, a mechanism which is in it. - even, as has just been said, a violation of treaties. It is the Brezhnev doctrine of limited sovereignty, revisited, supported by the so-called liberals, the Greens, the socialists, the Christian Democrats, the Communists, all united. Mr Juncker, I believe, said after Syriza's victory in Greece in January 2015: "There can be no democratic choice against European treaties", clearly meaning that no change of government could induce a change of policy . Today it is up to Hungary and Poland to attack, not because human rights are allegedly daily or systematically violated, but to punish these two countries for having elected governments skeptical of the benefits of the crazy European policy of forced redistribution of millions of so-called refugees. The real threat to democracy is the European institutions, which despise the expression of the peoples who do not accept to submit to the Europe of Brussels or to globalism. Yesterday, we got the parliaments to vote on texts rejected by the people. Today, we explain to these same parliaments, when they take citizens' aspirations into account, that their only option is to vote "yes" to an obscure free trade agreement negotiated by the Commission. I think that tomorrow or the day after tomorrow, perhaps, the NATO tanks will be sent first to restore order ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Today we know that if, for example, the organization of the judiciary, according to the principle of subsidiarity, falls within the exclusive competence of a Member State, it can be reorganized in such a way that judicial independence will be limited, the separation of powers will be virtually eliminated, free media and the impartiality of the civil service will be limited. Therefore, the proposed mechanism for assessing democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is Parliament's call for the effectiveness of European institutions against the most serious violations in the Member States. It is a call to fulfill the hopes of those Europeans who, losing a chance to protect their rights at home, expect more effective protection from European institutions. And of course, the draft essentially provides for an excess of dialogue - dialogue between the European Parliament and national parliaments, interinstitutional dialogue, dialogue between 28 experts. Of course, it is debatable whether it makes sense to use the evaluation mechanism every year, whether it should be implemented less frequently or more often, instead of a panel of 28 experts, or not to use, for example, the experience and professionalism of the Venice Commission. But it is in dialogue that these matters can surely clash. Let us remember that without democracy there would be no European Union, therefore the Union must effectively guarantee it. This is what the proposed mechanism serves.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: - Madam President, we cannot have a Europe that invests all its energies in monitoring a tenth of a budget deficit, but closes its eyes to serious violations of the rule of law and fundamental rights that call into question European essential values. That is why, even before any revision of the Treaties, we need a more effective mechanism to prevent, identify and correct these situations, going further than the procedure established, and well, by the Commission and which is being applied, by first time in the case of Poland. The report we are discussing here proposes this mechanism, with a regular and independent assessment of the situation under the rule of law, which would then make it possible to draw up recommendations by country. It seems like a good solution, provided that, and this is a fundamental point, ensure that it is a mechanism aimed at serious and systemic violations of fundamental rights and the rule of law and does not become a gratuitous invasion of the Member States' margin of governance. .. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: - Madam President!Mr Timmermans, you were right to say: Without rule of law the European Union is doomed.But I also believe that the European Union cannot be maintained without decency.The German President of this Parliament has called the action of the democratically elected parliament in Warsaw a coup.Instead of dealing with Poland over and over again, how about dealing with the numerous breaches of contract by the Eurogroup - keyword: Maastricht - or the breach of contract by the German government - keyword: Dublin Treaty?Time and again it is Germans who think they have to save the global climate, the euro and the world's refugees.Now they think they have to save Polish democracy.Instead of putting the Poles in the dock, the German government should be put on a psychologist's couch.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: - Madam President! In recent years, we have seen how country after country in our Union has ignored citizens' rights. Freedom of the press and expression, the opportunity to love whoever one wants and many of the rule of law's most fundamental principles have been put out of play by powerful and populist leaders in the various countries. So the work that once built Europe strongly in the ruins after World War II has begun to wither and crumble. People are confronted with people and populists and nationalists who want to divide us, separate us and cultivate fear and suspicion instead of building trust. We Liberals have for many years, and in all different countries, pushed the issue of creating a kind of rights mechanism that would ensure that our fundamental rights are guaranteed. That is why I am, of course, very happy and pleased today that my colleague, Sophia in 't Veld, can present this excellent report. Now, however, it is important that the Commission follows up and gives concrete legislative proposals, so that we can move forward. For fundamental rights should not be nice words on a paper that you do not care about in the member states. Governments must now actually take responsibility. For rights means something in practice, and rights are the individual's protection against the collective. We have achieved a lot in Europe and now we are taking the next step.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, when we see the evolution of citizens' confidence in European institutions, we begin to dream of another Europe based no longer on free and undistorted competition, but on respect for democracy, rule of law and human rights, that is, on the so-called values ​​of the European Union. However, in practice, the Commission is as quick to recall the rules of the budgetary pact in Portugal and Greece in particular, and now those of free trade in Wallonia, as much as Poland and Hungary, to name but examples. the most spectacular, sit on fundamental rights, the Commission procrastinates to activate the slightest infringement procedure. In short, we can sit on democracy and even help flout it, but no question of touching the dogma of ultra-liberalism. This is the famous Copenhagen dilemma. This report makes concrete proposals, but I fear that it will not be followed up with more effect than the Tavarès report, and I regret it, Mrs in 't Veld. So yes, Mr Timmermans, let us ask the NGOs for their opinion and act! Act finally! Stop letting states violate the rule of law!

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, events in Hungary, Poland and some other Member States highlighted a significant loophole in the legal system of the European Union. There are no effective tools for gradual sanctioning the breaches of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Parliament has several times requested to change this situation, as in the Tavares report and the Ferrara report and on some other occasions as well, so it is clear that it is high time to create a new mechanism. But this is effective only if there is no room to apply them in a politically biased way. This has actually already happened. The Commission has started a rule of law procedure against Poland but failed to do the same against the Hungarian Government, although its action is gradually damaging democracy and political freedoms. Apparently it seems that political affiliation matters. Law and Justice in Poland are not members of the European People’s Party, but Hungarian Fidesz is. Double standards clearly exist. This must be stopped. Any measures will make sense only if the political groups stop denying the obvious and stop protecting the unprotectable.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, this report calls for an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It is an own-initiative report – an MEP’s wish list. It has no legislative effect; it is just hot air. It was pointless to write and equally pointless to debate. However, Britain needs no lessons in democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Britain had a democracy founded on parliamentary government that evolved over 800 years. Our democracy was undermined by transferring supremacy of law-making from our parliament to the European Union. We had the rule of law – our law – which evolved over a thousand years. The rule of our law was undermined by EU law and the supremacy of the European Court of Justice. We had fundamental rights, established under such things as Magna Carta, the common law, habeas corpus and the Bill of Rights. Our rights and freedoms are being destroyed by such things as the European Arrest Warrant that allows British citizens to be arrested, extradited and imprisoned in corrupt foreign countries merely on the basis of vague accusations without any supporting evidence. If the British people want their democracy, the rule of their law and their fundamental rights back, then we must leave the European Union as quickly as possible. Brexit means now, not in two and a half years’ time or longer.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: - If the historically acquired existence of Western democracies on our European continent originally served as an incentive to cooperate and to strive together for democracy in what were then still communist dictatorships, that cooperation has now completely degenerated.While the Member States should each be the source of the rule of law and democracy from the bottom up, they are now placed under the glorified bureaucratic receivership of the European Union and the concepts that formed the basis and richness of European cooperation are now becoming the standardized rules of BigBrother in the European Union version, a so-called panel of experts at the head of an EU inquisition system.The original wealth of human rights and democracy is now becoming a weapon in your EU dictatorship.It is impossible for me to contribute to that.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Madam President, the Union's mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is invalid and illegal because, on the one hand, it provides for Article 7 of the Treaty and, on the other, it violates the principle of interinstitutional agreements. It is another attempt by professional manipulators to drive the national policies of the Member States. It is unacceptable and undemocratic to delegate power to a new authority to control the Member States, and it is a waste of resources, as there are already international organizations monitoring the violations of fundamental rights. Commissioners Jourová and Timmermans have repeatedly stated that there are no violations of fundamental rights. Nevertheless, there is a constant effort of political sovereignty over the Member States, just as was the case in Greece with the implementation of rescue memoranda or in the cases of Poland and Hungary and the legal constitutional amendments and referendums, respectively. Remember that, under Article 4 of the Treaty, the Union is obliged to respect the national identity of the Member States "which is inherent in their fundamental political and constitutional structure, which includes regional and local government".

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, the rule of law, democracy, fundamental rights are fundamental values ​​of our Union. It is these common values ​​that hold our union together. We ourselves voluntarily subscribed to these values ​​in the founding Treaties. It is therefore necessary that we not only declare our common values, but also act on them. It will certainly not benefit the legitimacy of the European Union if we question the existence of its fundamental values ​​and if it is clear that there are no tools available to promote these values. It is not about imposing values, so to speak, from Brussels, but about fulfilling values ​​as defined in the Treaties. However, allow me to express some doubts, especially with regard to the part of the report which contains recommendations for possible future amendments to the Treaties. I think we are going too far here, and some of these recommendations are, in my opinion, currently too radical and, as a result, counterproductive. I am of the opinion that it is necessary to slow down and really first thoroughly evaluate the possibilities of existing, even interconnected, mechanisms.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would also like to thank Sophia in ‘t Veld and the other shadow rapporteurs. I agree with the First Vice-President that it is a very political process, and the rule of law is the key fundamental framework of our Union. If that fails, our democracy is seriously threatened.  I very much agree with my colleagues that we need to kick off by finding institutional agreement on establishing a mechanism like this that is in fact a manifestation of our common European values. Let me remind you, Commissioner Timmermans, that in 2013 you, together with your colleagues, wrote to the former President of the Commission, Mr Barroso, asking him for the establishment of such a mechanism that would protect our fundamental values. We have today an excellent chance to make it happen. In general, I do not support the idea of duplicating mechanisms with tools that already exist, but I do not feel that today we have such mechanisms that are effective. Looking at the situation in Poland or Hungary, socialists and democrats have for a long time been pushing for the establishment of a democracy scoreboard. Today we ask the accession countries to meet the Copenhagen criteria, but the Member States can simply do whatever they want. So I very much support the idea of establishing such a mechanism on democracy that would stop various violations of the treaties, for example freedom of the media, which we heard mentioned several times. So this mechanism is really needed.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Dear citizens, imagine that the European Parliament uses a non-existent right of initiative to force all of us back into a new EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which does nothing other than democracy, the rule of law and Override your fundamental rights. Sounds strange, but that's how it is. And we will vote on it tomorrow. I vote against I contradict the colleague who spoke in front of me. The EU has sufficient instruments to protect democracy and the rule of law. The instruments have high hurdles - that's a good thing! It cannot be that a few branding entire countries simply because they do not like their right nostrils. The Hungarian EPP colleagues certainly know what I mean. This report is a new fog bomb by the left-wing liberals past the citizens. Goal: cement power. Undemocratic? I agree! They destroy subsidiarity, question sovereign states, they make themselves the stirrup holder of Euroscepticism and nationalist tendencies. Your mechanism against democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is an absolute misconstruction.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE).
text: - There are many examples in the European Union today of how much we need the mechanism we are discussing. From restrictions on media freedom and ambiguous constitutional reforms, through discrimination in the mobility of workers, to a ban on the use of one's mother tongue in election campaigns. Europe is at a crossroads and needs to rethink and dust off the values ​​on which it is built. The mechanism for democracy - the rule of law and fundamental rights - would give us the restart we need. I find it particularly important that it will also replace the piecemeal EU instruments, such as the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism, which has been applied for 10 years only to Bulgaria and Romania, with clear and objective criteria for all Member States and thus eliminate the double standard in the evaluation of both countries.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, in the European Union there are first-rate laws, which the European Commission already ensures that they are complied with, the threat of expulsion from the euro area through; and there are second-rate laws, which can be systematically violated by the Member States without absolutely anything happening. For example, the first is the Pact for Stability and Growth, by which in the Spanish State we have been suffering cuts in our public services for more than six years and for which we are now required to make a new sacrifice of more than 5 billion of euros. Second, or even third, is the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and, therefore, in the Spanish State there may be a "gag law"; For this reason, there may be hot returns in Ceuta and Melilla; For this reason, there may be xenophobic laws in Hungary, or restrictions on the sexual and reproductive rights of women in Poland or Ireland; Or, because of that, there may be homophobic laws in Lithuania. Rather, they care less about fundamental rights and I believe that it is not due to a lack of mechanisms, but because respect for fundamental rights is contrary to their economic and migration policies.

name: Diane James (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, all too often what the EU has in mind is either obscure or opaque, ensuring that the media and Member States’ citizens are left in the dark. Let us be absolutely clear about what we are talking about this morning. We are talking about a report that seeks to establish a group of so-called independent experts who will monitor Member States to ensure that they are upholding the values of EU Treaties. Seemingly there is nothing wrong with that, but in fact there is – and there is plenty. Let me go through what is wrong. There is absolutely no legal nor Treaty mandate to establish this mechanism. The EU has therefore absolutely no right even to propose it. Thirdly, there is nothing that can be cited to justify or validate such a mechanism, and the timing should make everybody suspicious. Call me cynical, but might it just be a knee—jerk reaction to circumstances in Poland and Hungary – two Member States – probably two out of 28 that would like to do much the same – which are, quite rightly, exercising their sovereign right to curtail EU influence and control in the areas of democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights? That is what sovereign nationhood is all about. If the European Union really wishes to add more substance to accusations of covert federalism and emerging Big Brother statehood, then go ahead, but there is absolutely no way anybody who believes in democracy should support this.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: - Madam President, seeing the peoples of Europe escaping your control, from England to Hungary, you infantilize them and decide to place them under tutelage. Your so-called mechanism for democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights will bring our states under the control of so-called independent experts from the Council of Europe, an organization that includes such exemplary democracies as Turkey and Europe. 'Albania. You constantly talk to us about democracy, but it is no longer in your mouths a sort of mantra that you repeat the better to accuse your opponents of your own turpitudes; adversaries that you qualify as populists because they make themselves the spokespersons of the people you no longer want to listen to. Democracy is the power of the people. Democracy is the right of peoples to dispose of themselves. However, you want to delete Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights on subsidiarity and national sovereignty. On Sunday, our former colleague, Mr Duda, now President of Poland, celebrated with the Hungarian Prime Minister the sixtieth anniversary of the uprising in Budapest against the Communist dictatorship. Today, the time has come for the peoples of Eastern and Western Europe to rise up against the tyranny of Brussels.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!It is clearly evident that one-sided action is to be taken here - against Poland, against Hungary - that a Lex Poland is to be created here by those who are silent - keep silent about everything that is currently happening in Europe: in many member countries, wherePatriots are persecuted in Greece, where MPs are imprisoned, where parties are to be banned.In my country alone, in the Federal Republic of Germany, 1,200 patriots are in prisons just because of their opinions.You don't talk about these subjects.But you want to regulate other states because you don't want to guarantee them independence, that they regulate the future of their people according to their own style.Stop Interfering!Let the peoples be peoples and take care of their domestic affairs themselves!

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - The Union does not need a Pact on Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights. All this is in the treaties that the Member States have committed themselves to. We also have a mechanism in the Treaties that deals with cases where a Member State fails to honor its commitment. The guardian of the Treaties is the Commission. Not the UN, the OECD, the Council of Europe or professional and industry associations. If the Commission is convinced that a Member State has infringed the Treaties, it should turn to the European Court of Justice. We can talk about whether the Commission is making good use of its powers. Whether, as a precaution, it prefers to avoid more fundamental disputes or, conversely, whether it does not react too sensitively to less important differences in the view of democracy. We may ask why the Commission has not yet used Article 2 of the EU Treaty as a legal basis in its indictment against a Member State. Alternatively, ask for her opinion on the possibility of developing a so-called A "joint action" to address a possible systemic problem of democracy and the rule of law in a Member State. Such a debate would make sense. But let us not invent new structures, rallies, reports and commissions, which will result in only a lot of papers and hours of empty speech for taxpayers' money. I cannot support such an idea.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Historians may one day say that the Sophia in 't Veld own-initiative report put the Union in the hands of an effective instrument of stabilization at a difficult hour. The LIBE committee passed the report with a clear majority and has shown once again that the Members of this House are capable of reaching substantial compromises. If you put the politically controversial cases aside, then two problem areas emerge. With the Copenhagen criteria there is a very strict mechanism for becoming a member of the Union. Once this happens, there are hardly any adequate means of punishing non-compliance or willful violation, especially when it comes to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The existing instruments are not targeted enough to influence threatening developments at an early stage. When they finally end up at EU level, criticism is often stylized by the Member States concerned as an external threat and problem solving is very difficult. The report suggests interlinking existing instruments, starts at an early stage and puts all Member States - the old and the new Member States - on an equal footing. With the Democracy Scoreboard, a format is being developed that opens up opportunities for comparison. I think that this is a step towards being able to act, and I hope that the Commission will recognize this opportunity and take it.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Madam President!The author of the report rightly criticizes the current practice of checking the rule of law, writing that in some cases the inconsistent use of such instruments is perceived by many as politically motivated, arbitrary and unfair to some countries.So it is.In the European Parliament, too, certain Member States have been attacked repeatedly arbitrarily, unfairly and politically in a politically motivated manner, while others, such as the Netherlands, with its inhuman euthanasia plans, have been spared.The integrated mechanism proposed by this report is inconsistent with the European treaties and the principle of subsidiarity and would serve not so much to defend democracy as to replace it with a post-democratic left-wing and liberal meritocracy, the best expression of which is the proposed "areopact" - this representative team of independent experts on democracy, the rule of law and rightsbasic.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, the European Parliament's motion for a resolution establishing a European Union mechanism that periodically examines the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the Member States has a positive starting point, as these are the founding principles of the Union. However, the devil is in the details and the sentence contains unclear points. Further specification is needed on the guarantees of impartiality of the proposed mechanism and the type of sanctions against Member States where they infringe fundamental citizens' rights. The issue of infringements of social rights, in particular, arising from the requirements of the Union institutions vis-.-Vis Member States in the context of fiscal surveillance, also needs to be addressed. For example, the European institutions are effectively preventing the Greek government from enforcing court decisions that deem some pension cuts unconstitutional. Interest in rights should not be selective.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF).
text: - Madam President, Madam Rapporteur, you are calling for the creation of a Union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It would be more honest to name things by their name rather than twist these basic notions. You invoke the rule of law but describe the interference of the European Union - interference more and more rejected by the peoples of Europe. You call for the reinforcement of democracy in Europe, but you organize the submission of all to tyrannical whims. Do you really think about strengthening democracy by appointing a group of experts responsible for judging whether such or such law passed by sovereign national parliaments is in line with your ideal of democracy? The Poles and Hungarians answer you curtly and reject your tutelage. Is it your conception of democracy to appoint Turkish judges to decide the destiny of our nations? Dear colleagues, this text is a betrayal, betrayal of peoples, their culture and their history. It is a betrayal of the mission that is ours within this assembly, namely: to serve and not to enslave. Do not submit to all of our peoples your fantasies, the fantasies of so few. If that were to be your choice, it would be a dangerous and disturbing drift. This legislative initiative must end up in your trash, Commissioner Timmermans.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Europe is not only a single market opportunity, but also common foundations. It is a duty to keep them stable. It is precisely the independent judiciary, civil liberties and media impartiality that separate democracy from dictatorship or great politics from populist pettiness. The solutions contained in the report treat all countries equally, they consolidate rather than duplicate the existing tools, and are in the treaty mandate. They do not violate the principle of subsidiarity, because the essence of civil liberties lies beyond national borders. Democracy is not just an election result that gives the winners a temporary advantage. Wins do not give a mandate to undermine the foundations. Therefore, it is important to have a mechanism for measuring and evaluating whether democracy and the rule of law are respected everywhere. Establishing a Pact for Democracy and an interinstitutional agreement is crucial here to ensure that, while safeguarding the sovereignty of states, the principles which bind the Union are not violated, and when assessing the situation in countries by experts appointed by national parliaments, threats and violations, systemic shortcomings are noticed, prevent bad practices. This is not about penalties, but about an early warning and dialogue mechanism. The Council, the Commission and the European Parliament need effective and objective tools in this process. Work on the EU mechanism is only just beginning. There are frames, procedures, deadlines, tools, areas. There must be political will.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Ms. President! Democracy, the rule of law, fundamental human rights and European values ​​are the essence and the foundation of the European Union. Commonplace, yet it must be said, the rule of law is not an abstract idea, but the most important guarantee of the rights of the individual and communities. When we defend the rule of law, we stand up for the rights and freedoms of European citizens. This report is a very important step in this direction. There is a need for more effective integration and complementarity of existing instruments, continuous monitoring and, where necessary, sanctions. At the same time, I was one of those who wanted to see a slightly more radical wording and procedure than at present. After all, there are now governments in the Member States that are consciously confronting common European values, proclaiming a cultural counter-revolution, seeing the independence of the judiciary as a political tool, interpreting the rule of law according to their own whims and preferences. These governments, the European far right, want to upset an open, inclusive, culturally diverse Europe and instead create a closed, nationalist, authoritarian world. It is our political and moral duty to defend the rule of law, democracy, fundamental rights, because if we do not do so, we will one day have to face the fact that we ourselves have contributed to the destruction of the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, democracy and the rule of law have not fallen from the sky for the citizens of European countries.They have been building and perfecting them for centuries, often sacrificing themselves to defend their rights.Modern times and tremendous technological advances have brought some new challenges to our societies, but that is not the reason why we should allow disregard for the fundamental principles of our civilization.I therefore agree that it is our obligation to preserve democratic processes and ensure the rule of law, but I do not think that is why we need some uniform mechanism.We must not forget that the Member States of the European Union have emerged from different traditions and gone through different development paths, and accordingly have different ways of protecting these values.The European Union’s uniform mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights at this point can only widen the gap between the national and European levels of government and that is why I think it is a step in the wrong direction.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President Timmermans, dear colleagues, respect for the rule of law is a fundamental principle of the European Union, we demand it as a condition of entry into the Union, it is one of the Copenhagen criteria. But we are less effective in ensuring this after the Member State becomes the Member State of the European Union and we know that in several States this principle is going through difficult times. It is true that we have Article 7 of the Treaty on the Union, but that is a limit situation and we have a set of mechanisms, in Parliament, in the European Commission and in the Council, of little consequence and no articulation. The initiative that we are discussing today is, therefore, a good impulse that goes in the right direction, calling for an integrated action of those three institutions. But even now, we are taking the first steps of what will certainly be a long process. I congratulate rapporteur Sophia in 't Veld and EPP shadow rapporteur Frank Engel, among others, for their commitment and work, but let us be clear from the beginning, this is not an exercise in bureaucracy, it is not an attack on the sovereignty of States Member States, it is certainly not against any people. To protect the rule of law is to defend each and every European citizen, each and every nationality that is part of this Union. It is to reaffirm that the Union is not just an economic construction but that it has values ​​and that it knows how to preserve and defend them.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D).
text: - Madam President, dear Vice-President Timmermans, ladies and gentlemen! The EU Commission has initiated proceedings against the Polish government because of the threat to the rule of law in the country. OK then. Unfortunately, however, in the case of Hungary she has so far not shown the same determination - not good because there is suspicion that the Hungarian government is under the protection of its party friends, the EPP. Independent experts, objective criteria and an automatic reaction by the EU Commission as guardian of the treaties are therefore the right approach to leave party politics out of this fundamental question for the EU. The pact for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights that Parliament is proposing does just that. However, I do not want to hide the fact that this proposal needs further discussion. At one point or another, I definitely see a need for improvement. Just one example: the proposed indicators for measuring democracy and the rule of law, for example, would have to be formulated more precisely and with more selective focus. The number of 19 indicators is also quite high, while the threshold proposed at the same time for intervention is too low. Nevertheless, with the vote on the pact, Parliament will send out an important signal. Our common European values ​​must not only be put to the test during the accession process of a country; Of course, they must apply to every Member State even after a country joins the European Union, and equally to all of them.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - I have been working for a long time to establish an effective mechanism for monitoring the functioning of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the Member States. I believe that a politically independent mechanism is one of the key measures for the rule of law in the European Union so that it is no longer abused, especially in transition, post-socialist countries. It is known that in Slovenia, for example, opposition leader Janez Janša was imprisoned without evidence three weeks before the parliamentary elections, and after the elections and six months in prison he was acquitted of all charges. And the story is over. In such severe abuses, the Union should react immediately, but it is not, because it does not seem to have an appropriate mechanism. It will probably get it with this proposal, but care must be taken not to use it for political purposes, as has happened in the past in the case of Hungary and elsewhere. If we fail to ensure the impartiality of the use of this mechanism, the citizens of the European Union will reject such European Union intervention, and Euroscepticism will continue to grow.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Commissioner Timmermans, I thank Mrs in 't Veld for her report on such an important issue: the European Union must be a model of democratic values ​​for all. The recognition of fundamental rights, to which many countries look with great interest, is based on an essential condition, respect for the rule of law. And the European Commission is responsible for ensuring that the Union's founding values ​​are respected, observed and protected throughout Europe and by all Member States. The approval of free legal aid a few weeks ago is a concrete example of the fact that we are working to build and strengthen the rule of law within the Union and we cannot allow, also given the particular political moment, that recognition be undermined fundamental rights or that these are half implemented. I therefore look favorably on an independent mechanism which, again in the context of the treaties, can monitor the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the more I hear from some colleagues, the more I am in favor of this report, also because it is not as if one can be part of the European Union when there is something to be done, while becoming autonomous and independent when there is to give. Currently there is not even duplication because this mechanism on rights, fundamental rights and democracy is on demand, instead translating and moving this mechanism into a permanent mechanism that involves all the Member States is already this principle of impartiality and democracy. Therefore, I believe that it is important and fundamental for the European Union to equip itself with this instrument, which can then be perfectible, as always, but it must be done, also because there is currently the Venice Commission. Venice 47 States. So I believe that acceptance is important, notwithstanding, as Timmermans said, the criticality that exists on this group of experts.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner Carpenter! I would like to begin by thanking Sophia in 't Veld for a very ambitious report on a very, very important issue. I think that is one of the most important issues before us. We call it fundamental rights through the EU system, and that is exactly what it is. Human and civil rights are the basis. Therefore, the defense of these rights must also take precedence over all other considerations. Unfortunately, we often see that it is the opposite. That is why I am glad that this report today leads us to focus on the foundations of EU construction: fundamental rights, where the rule of law is also the basis of democracy. There is a lot of talk about Poland and Hungary today. It is quite true that the development has gone far too far in the wrong direction in these countries. I believe that an Article 7 procedure must be initiated against both of them if the EU is to continue to be taken seriously as a defender of the Union's own fundamental rights. It is important to recall that violations of fundamental rights can occur in all Member States. France deports EU citizens. Sweden restricts free movement with border controls. The Czech Republic and Slovakia segregate children in schools. In 2000, EU sanctions against Austria ended in failure. Almost 17 years later, we are in practically the same situation. Long before I took my seat in the European Parliament, I was on the Barrosso Commission on the candidate countries' respect for human rights. I wondered how the Commission intended to ensure that the new Member States respected human rights. Barroso replied that it is much better if they are involved. It is our duty to protect human rights.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! I have been a Member of the European Parliament since 2004, and unfortunately since then I have seen bitterly the fact that the concern for the rule of law and human rights is measured by a rather double standard, a game of daily political intentions and power relations. For example, in the last 13 years, no infringement of a serious national minority has been understood or echoed by the Commission. The omission was justified by reference to the competence of the Member States. In the same way, no violation was established in 2006, just 10 years ago, when atrocities and brutal violence were perpetrated against people peacefully celebrating in Budapest, as evidenced by the people of the then socialist government. At that time, EU decision-makers were not worried about the state of the Hungarian rule of law. In contrast, there has often been a campaign of the rule of law since then, when the political interest so desires and Hungary can be unjustly attacked, while no specific violations can be identified. All this proves that as long as there is no objective, consensual definition of the concept of the rule of law, all this mechanism remains the breeding ground for double standards.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: - Madam President, each country which becomes a member of the European Union undertakes to respect the famous Copenhagen criteria enshrined in the European treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. This does not mean that he can forget them the day after his accession, because the Union of Values ​​and Law is not à la carte. The rule of law is not a cosmetic principle but a pivotal element on which the European Union is built. However, the latter does not have the means to ensure that the rule of law is respected at all times by its member states. The mechanism proposed by Sophia in 't Veld, which I fully support, seeks to fill this loophole by instituting systematic monitoring of the protection of fundamental rights within the Union. It is not a question of sanctioning such and such a State but of reflecting on the establishment of a positive Europe, which dialogues and protects. Finally, this report is not a legislative text with binding legal effects but a political initiative intended to send a strong message to the Member States and to the Commission. Fundamental rights and values ​​cannot be compromised.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: - (NL) Mr President, like you and most colleagues, I received this letter last week: vote against the In 't Veld report, because the EU is trying to take over political control over the Member States. The letter concludes that the vote will be published this afternoon in our own Member States. That will undoubtedly be intended as a kind of threat, but it is actually a nice piece of transparency that the anonymous letter writer could have used as an example. I will be delighted to explain in my own Member State why it is so important that fundamental rights in the EU are discussed in a structural, objective, constructive and balanced way and why they are removed from the domain of the scare tactics and the taboo sphere of this writer must be achieved. Let's face it: if we as the European Union - on the world stage and in our immediate environment - are to play the role of advocate for fundamental freedoms, we must first of all get our own affairs in order.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: -  Ms. President! The EU Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights would be about an integrated control mechanism covering all Member States and the three main institutions. There would be virtually no need for such a mechanism, as the Member States undertook to guarantee fundamental human rights, including the rights of minorities, during the accession negotiations. However, practice shows that there has been a serious reorganization in this area after accession. The monitoring reports of the Council of Europe and the possible convictions of the European Court of Human Rights do not have any systemic consequences. Fearing the reactions of the Member States, the Union did not deal at all with those completely obvious infringements. We hope that this mechanism will usher in a new era based on the principle that EU citizens enjoy the same fundamental rights throughout the EU.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the Mechanism for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Human Rights is an extremely important tool that will ensure the preservation of the democratic values ​​on which the European Union is built in all Member States. It will ensure equality of states and propose pan-European solutions. I believe that this mechanism will strengthen the foundations of democracy and thus we will be able to overcome the Euroscepticism and populism of recent years. For my country, Bulgaria, this mechanism is extremely important, because it will not only replace the mechanism for cooperation and verification imposed on us, but will also remove the unjustified stigmas on us caused by this type of discrimination. The Cooperation and Verification Mechanism has repeatedly been misused to point the finger at problems that exist in all Member States. It is also a completely wrong obstacle to our Schengen membership. That is why I believe that the Mechanism for Democracy and the Rule of Law, with its objective evaluation criteria, will make it possible to see the real problems in the European Union, and we will all have the leverage to guarantee democracy in Europe through European support and solidarity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the proposed European Union mechanism for democracy and the rule of law and fundamental rights is not in line with the fundamental treaties of the European Union, nor with the very principles of the EU Charter of Human Rights it proposes as a legal basis for legislative measures, including sanctions . Such a mechanism calls into question the principle of subsidiarity and the powers of the Union and thus calls into question the respect for the rule of law by the European institutions. The provisions of the Charter of Human Rights apply to Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, and to the Member States only when implementing Union law. The Charter does not extend the scope of Union law beyond the powers of the Union, does not establish a new power or task for the Union, nor does it change the powers and tasks as set out in the Treaties. The mechanism proposed by this report is not acceptable because it is not in line with the fundamental treaties of the European Union and the Charter of Human Rights of the European Union and violates the principle of subsidiarity of sovereign Member States.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Mr. Vice-President, my speech is addressed to those who protest against this necessary mechanism of the rule of law, claiming a lack of legal basis or subsidiarity to hide their prejudices against the foundations of the European Union. Because the rule of law mechanism is not a threat to the constitutional tradition of any Member State, but a guarantee of reinforcement of Union law, which is something more than a market. In this Union we are seeing terrifying setbacks in judicial independence in some Member States, in democratic pluralism and in informational pluralism; or attacks on the sexual and reproductive rights of women. And let's not say against the rights of foreigners, including the rights of citizens of the Member States, in a wave of reactionary nationalism and xenophobic, europhobic and rampant populism. Many have the impression that we are dealing with a European Union that relentlessly punishes a deviation of one hundredth of the deficit but that ignores or turns its back on the setbacks or the regression in the founding values ​​of the European Union. And, therefore, the rule of law is not a threat to democracy, it is a guarantee.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, Mr Timmermans, as you know, democracy, the rule of law and human rights are directly linked to the economy and are being undermined by poverty and social exclusion. This is exactly what is happening in Greece, where a troika and a memorandum have led 3,885,000 Greeks to live below the poverty line, while the armies of the unemployed are a disgrace to the so-called "European social model". Moreover, Mr. Timmermans, in Greece the systematic violation of the social rights of Greek citizens who refuse for reasons of religious conscience to receive the AMKA, the Social Security Registration Number, ie refuse to number their face and identify themselves on the basis of a single number. Their refusal is punished by the Greek state and more than 100,000 Greek citizens are now deprived of medical care, as well as the payment of pensions and other benefits. This matter must end, Mr Timmermans, and I will send you a letter on this matter.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank Sophia in 't Veld for her realistic and workable proposal to be able to improve democracy in the Union. An objective annual report, independent and open to citizen participation on the subject, as well as forecasting and correction measures, is essential, because there is much to improve. I think that with mechanisms of prior dialogue for prevention it would be more difficult for a European government to ignore the recommendations of the United Nations to repair victims of its own dictatorship; that a minister of the interior conspired to invent criminal proceedings against his political rivals; or that a president announced to a defendant for illegally financing the party they share that he would provide him with trusted judges, and that such promise would be kept. Mr Timmermans, all these things are happening today in a Member State which, moreover, does not respect basic framework decisions for the creation of a common area of ​​freedoms, such as the mutual recognition of penalties, something that could already be corrected with today's mechanisms. I thought that in our Union these things were impossible. You have to get at least some price, and correct them.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, we are facing yet another unacceptable assault on the sovereignty of States, deepening the federalization mechanisms of the European Union. Three notes: the first, the European Union has no legitimacy to give democracy lessons to anyone. Your concept of democracy is, among others, that of sanctions, which, in fact, the report defends and profoundly, is that of blackmail and pressure. CETA negotiations or threats of sanctions against Portugal are a good example of this. The second: the intention of harmonizing the so-called fundamental rights for countries like Portugal, with a progressive Constitution, constitutes an unacceptable negative pressure, leveling down the standards of social and labor rights. The third: the plot of European treaties and legislation is an obstacle to the legitimate sovereign decision of each people to decide their destinies, an obstacle to the effective implementation of the Portuguese Constitution and the conquests of the revolution that the Portuguese people, sooner than later, will be able to resume. and impose, freeing themselves from the constraint of treaties.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, from the outset I want to say that I support the report and the pact for democracy. We all say that the Union is based on the values ​​of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law. Member States should set an example. But what do we do, Commissioner, when officials in some countries accept discrimination in violation of citizens' rights regarding, for example, the movement of workers, stigmatizing less developed countries? What are we doing, Commissioner, with a Member State like the Netherlands, the country you come from, which has for years opposed the entry of Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia into the Schengen area, on political, not technical, grounds, discriminating against citizens of excluded from the Schengen area? The same thing happens with the MCV for Romania and Bulgaria. You have asked for a response to some of the proposals in the report, Commissioner. I answer: yes, you, the Commission, have to have an annual report in the European Parliament. We represent the citizens, we have been elected to represent them, you have been appointed to make the European Union an internal market that defends the rights of citizens in all respects.
