That is what the citizens of my country are waiting for, and that is why I agree with this report, as a first step, and we will continue.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: - I support this brilliant report and I fully support it.It will allow us to monitor more effectively the exercise and practice of undermining fundamental rights in some of our member states.However, I would just like to add one more to these fundamental values, which the report and today's debate speak of.I think it is also right to talk about the pursuit of peace as an activity in favor of one of the fundamental rights of people who are particularly interested in a time when we have wars all around us, when talking about war has become almost talking about some real perspective.that awaits us.People in Europe are afraid and more needs to be done for peace.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, when in States like Spain and others the standards of democracy are manifestly lower than those that the European Union advocates and in theory defends, it is necessary to act. And this report, although it could be improved, goes in the right direction, for example when it proposes an independent and comprehensive group of experts to analyze and monitor the Member States. But let us not forget that the European institutions are also 'traceable' and, of course - as my colleague Spinelli emphasizes - social and economic rights. It is time to abandon double standards - depending on whether we look outside or within the Union - and the report sets the right course on this point. The same happens when it brings citizens access to the Court of Justice of the European Union. Any mechanism that makes it possible to improve the functioning of the Union in terms of democracy is a step forward. And, Mr Timmermans, if the current framework worked, this report would not be on your table today.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, the mere fact that we are currently discussing the need to create a mechanism for the protection of democracy and the rule of law is a clear acknowledgment that in almost all the countries of the European Union the basic principles on which the creation was based are being violated. of. As is well known, of course, the European Union is also approaching this issue in the wrong way. While initially tolerating this situation, it is now seeking to set up an enforcement body of a leading group of the European Union in its Member States. The aim, of course, is to deprive states of the powers and independence which the European Union owes and is obliged to respect under international law and treaties. With the possible creation of this mechanism, an attempt is made to legitimize the targeting of various states and the imposition of sanctions on them. Now we have Poland and Hungary, previously we had Greece in which, in the form of punishment, harsh memoranda were imposed. The hypocrisy in the whole affair is shown by the fact that the European Union is discussing to ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Europe that is bullying Portugal, Greece and Spain for tenth budgets and turns a blind eye to the offensive against fundamental rights of immigrant citizens in Hungary and Poland fails to cry out.An interinstitutional pact for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as proposed by the rapporteur Sophia in t 'Veld is necessary.The rule of law, the cornerstone of the legitimacy of the European project, needs to be defended with robust mechanisms, supervision and control to intervene and sanction violating governments.Only in this way will we be able to regain the confidence of citizens in Europe.I hope that the Commission and the Council will not block this proposal from Parliament.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: - The judge sees that this proposal is based on ideological change and not on justice and democratic mechanisms. It is not possible to punish non-compliance with the values ​​set by some, because we in Czechoslovakia, for example, experienced the dictated rule of values ​​in 1948 with the onset of the communist government and it ended with the revolution in '89, which was very good. In the European Union, we already have a democracy protection mechanism and it works well. It provides good limitations, if a problem arises, it judges the matter on the basis of facts, not ideology. We have five mechanisms that work well together, and the next one will only complicate the system of their effectiveness and limit what they can achieve and create confusion. We do not need another tool in this proposal, because it creates the image that the European Union wants more competences, it wants more authority, and some governments that may join Europe soon, e.g. in France, they can really enjoy it because it gives them another reason to leave the European Union. If you want to sanction the glasses of ideology, then you have to leave such an association. I don't want to experience another February 1948 in Czechoslovakia either, because we are a union of cooperation, not coercion.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, everyone complains about Hungary and Poland, but the real issue is whether this House and the EU are ready to fight for fundamental rights in Western Europe as well. In Spain the Constitutional Court is led by an ex-member of the Popular Party. Judicial independence is non—existent. In Spain, under Popular Party governments, newspapers have been closed and political parties have been banned. The former President of Catalonia, Artur Mas, is now facing a political trial for organising a symbolic vote on independence three years ago. And yesterday a pro—independence member of the town hall from Vic, Joan Coma, was sentenced to eight years in jail by Spanish justice merely because of a pro-Catalan independence speech in his town hall. I hope that the mechanism will be established and that the EU will react to defend democracy everywhere in the EU.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). - Mr President, on a proposal from the European Parliament, another reactionary EU mechanism is being introduced. In the name of democracy and the rule of law, the European Union is launching an industry of pretexts for its forthcoming imperialist interventions. With a system it will now promote attitudes, sanctions and crude interventions in those Member States that it deems not in line with its plans. It is a tool of pressure and competition, which in any case aim to prepare both the European Union and the monopolies against any danger of their power by the popular factor. That is why the European Union does not consider the persecutions and bans of communists in a number of its member states to be violations, as a result of the unhistorical assimilation of communism with the monster of fascism, adopted by the European Union. But this is also the European Parliament: the waiter of the most reactionary mechanisms of intervention, which the people with their struggles can and must useless to take power by freeing themselves from the chains of the European Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the European Day of Justice we rediscover the Union founded on the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights, absolute values that shape the culture of the 28 Member States.There is a risk of serious violation of the rule of law in our democracies, so much so that the same principle is no longer perceived as identifying us European citizens.There are numerous judgments of the Court of Justice that cite the Charter, from 43 in 2011 to 210 in 2014, and a clear substitute activity of the Court and a corresponding responsibility of the national European legislator who struggles to place at the center of the legal construction of theFundamental rights union.We therefore welcome the promotion of a proposal for a Union pact to promote good governance, transparency and accountability, finally aware of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I just want to make a few points. First of all, the realisation that free societies rest on a tripod – democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights – pre-dates the European Union. It pre-dates the Treaty of Rome and is something that free European societies at the end of the 1940s came to realise as a consequence of what they had seen happening before and during the war, when democracy was used to impose tyranny and the rule of law was used to take away fundamental rights from individuals. So what I want to say is that when we talk about democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, we should make it very clear that this is what free societies are based upon, having been established at the end of the 1940s within the Council of Europe, when the Iberian Peninsula was suffering under dictatorship, the Iron Curtain was coming down and half of Europe was under Communist oppression. That is when free societies realised that we need to avoid the mistakes of the past and bring freedom to everyone – the tripod of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. And whenever one tries to use democracy against the rule of law or against fundamental rights or vice versa things will go wrong: that, I believe, is the basis upon which we should found our work.  Because at the end of the day everyone in Europe belongs to a minority. Whether you are a minority or a majority depends only on your perspective. It depends on where you stand. At the end of the day in a democracy you may be in the majority today, but you will be in the minority tomorrow if the voters so decide. And if you use the majority to marginalise or push away the rights of the minority you might receive the same treatment yourself after the next round of elections. So we have a fundamental reason to fight for this tripod and the need is going to be permanent, because there are always going to be challenges.  Now, what do we need to reach that goal? That is the question that we need to discuss today. I have listened very carefully to all the points made today. After your vote we in the Commission will think about how we will react, but let me make it very clear that, to my mind, the goals which we share should not dictate the means that we use to reach those goals. We will be constructive in discussing the report with the European Parliament, but, speaking as a pragmatic man, I believe that we should work towards a position in which we can make sure that fundamental rights, the rule of law and democracy are protected everywhere in the European Union and look for the best means to do that.  I say this also against the backdrop of xenophobic incidents increasing across the European Union – east, west, north and south. I say this in a public debate which is turning sour in quite a number of Member States, putting minorities, and sometimes even majorities, on the receiving end. Women and political, ethnic, religious, and sexual minorities are all under pressure today, and we have the obligation to make sure that everyone’s rights are protected.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for a very interesting debate and for all the support. I would just like to briefly say to that side of the House (which has largely disappeared incidentally): I have heard a lot of hysterical language about dictatorships and imposing values, tyranny, submission, treason. I would just like to point out that 28 countries decided to join the European Union voluntarily.  They signed up to the Treaties voluntarily and the Treaties include Article 2. For those who have read the articles: Article 1 in the Treaties basically says ‘Hello, everybody’ and then Article 2 is about what we are all about as a European Union – a community of values.  The irony is that we have endowed the European Union with the instruments to enforce all the other policy areas: competition policies, police and justice cooperation, foreign policies, etc. But our core values are not protected by instruments that are sufficiently strong to make sure that the values are upheld throughout the European Union.  I very much concur with what Commissioner Timmermans just said: it is all about the objectives and not so much about the means. But I do hope that I misunderstood when I thought I heard you say in your initial presentation, Commissioner Timmermans, that you think that the existing tools are sufficient, because there I disagree and I think that has been echoed by everybody in the House.  I think that we all expect that the mechanism you have triggered against the Polish Government is not, unfortunately, going to lead to an improvement in the situation in Poland. Nobody expects that by the end of this week the Polish Government is going to say: we are going to follow up on your recommendations. I would have hoped that they would, but they are probably not going to do that. So we do need a mechanism that has a preventative arm that applies to all the Member States. I think that is really a key principle. Also, in response to your question: yes, I do think it should be on a regular, preferably an annual, basis and not be incident-driven, because if it is incident-driven then there is the inherent risk that decisions to intervene will be politically motivated, and we want to avoid that. One final remark about the panel of independent experts: I hear people expressing concerns about this. I would recommend people read the text because it is very clear that the lead is with the Commission. The Commission will adopt the annual report but it will do so in consultation with the panel of independent experts that will be partly nominated by the Member States and partly by this Parliament. Finally, I would like to remind the Commission, and colleagues, that it is not as if we are reinventing the wheel. We already have the justice scoreboard, the corruption report, the corruption and verification mechanism (CVM) for Bulgaria and Romania, the media pluralism monitor, the fundamental rights report, the reports on access to documents, the Schengen evaluations, etc. These mechanisms also include panels of independent experts and country-specific recommendations, so we are not inventing something new.  I look forward to the Commission’s proposal. I hope that we can have a constructive dialogue, as we have had inside this House in the political groups, the same dialogue between the institutions and come up with something that will really serve democracy, the rule of law, and fundamental rights throughout the European Union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place today, Tuesday 25 October 2016, at 12 noon.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I have of course approved this own-initiative report which proposes the creation of an annual mechanism to monitor respect for fundamental freedoms and the rule of law by the Member States and the institutions of the Union. To this end, the report invites the Commission to present, by September 2017, a draft interinstitutional pact for the rule of law and fundamental freedoms which would include: an annual report on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights including country-by-country recommendations, an annual interparliamentary debate on the basis of this report, and procedures for dealing with potential risks or violations as provided for in article 7. The fundamental values ​​contained in article 2 of the Treaty are at the heart of the European project. Each Member State must respect them. The current situations in Poland and Hungary demonstrate that permanent monitoring of compliance with these values ​​is necessary and the application of this report would allow this to be the case and therefore rapid reactions to be possible. This is a vital issue for the future of Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have heard my colleagues denounce the abuses in Poland and Hungary and while I share some of their concerns, I am surprised that our honorable assembly uses exactly the methods that it claims to denounce. Like you, I am very attached to the principle of the separation of powers and that is why I can only understand the European Parliament, rather than advocating the strengthening of national institutions or thinking about a more coercive and relevant use of instruments existing Europeans demands new rights which lead straight to a concentration of powers. The European Parliament exists to legislate on priority subjects for citizens: employment, the protection of our borders, the environment, reindustrialisation, economic and commercial reconquest ... It would be mistaken to think that it should also to be judge of Freedoms and guardian of treaties. I think that this report does not respond to the demands of citizens who demand stable and effective national counter-power mechanisms and not a strengthening of systematic surveillance by European institutions in which they do not see themselves. That is why, if I understand the principle, I cannot support a report whose recommended method is legally questionable and inapplicable.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - Since 2010, we have witnessed a return to democratic rights in many EU Member States. In some Member States, this has deteriorated to the point where they would now apply for EU membership, almost certainly not. We have to admit that this came as a surprise to us in the European Union. Therefore, we do not even have an appropriate EU legal framework in case an EU Member State already deviates from the path of democracy, using EU funds only for its own enrichment. Therefore, the establishment of a European democracy control mechanism that protects EU citizens if their governments trample on their rights cannot be delayed. The European Union is much more than an economic alliance, we are also a community of values. The EU is not some kind of external power, but we are. If a national government turns its back on these values, the EU must intervene in the interests of its citizens. It is not a political weapon, but a mechanism based on objective criteria that affects everyone, whether left-wing or right-wing, to the same extent. Such an EU Pact for Fundamental Rights is essential in the light of what has happened in recent years.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: written. - We must ensure that Member States honor their commitments on fundamental rights. Fundamental rights are inalienable and indivisible. They cannot be taken from anyone - not by a decision of the authority or with the person's own consent. The rights are also indivisible. The rights should be realized at the same time. At present, the EU does not have the legal tools to address arbitrary violations of fundamental rights in member states. The report on the establishment of an EU system for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights draws attention to this shortcoming. We must monitor the implementation of fundamental rights in the Member States. We need a mechanism for the EU to look at serious threats or risks to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In addition, the binding nature of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the prohibition of discrimination must be extended to all aspects of life through the adoption of the Equality Directive. For example, accessibility to urban environments, healthcare or education must be ensured. The prohibition of discrimination should extend to such forms of discrimination as, for example, age or disability. It is in everyone's interests to be able to ensure that Member States respect common values ​​and fundamental rights.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - This report is important and very timely, as it has been indebted to Parliament and the Juncker Committee since its inception by providing a legal basis for effective action against Member State governments that violate common European democratic standards. We also share the frustration that has unfortunately manifested itself most precisely in our inertia towards the leadership of my country, as the EU’s policy of disregarding the Orbán government’s repeated violations, European norms and the fundamental rights of its own citizens is the EU’s right EU legal basis and mechanism. without intention - still unable to prevent and sanction. That is why I urge that the proposed legislation and interinstitutional agreement establishing the new mechanism also provide an effective EU response to the cynical legal tricks of the Orbán regime: address the situation where a major parliamentary majority seeks to conceal or subsequently legalize violations. , and even uses it for constitutional amendments. I note that we face another similar challenge: the EU would also need much more effective common tools to tackle systemic government corruption in the Member States; unfortunately, Orban is at the forefront in this area as well, setting shameful examples.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - Mr President, European traditions in the field of the rule of law and civil rights have a very long history, dating back to the days of Athenian democracy and Roman law. The European Union has enshrined the rule of law in its treaties. It is unfortunate that they did not include references to the Christian roots of Europe, which were so much talked about by the founders Schuman, Adenauer, De Gasperi. That is why the EU is experiencing a crisis of values ​​and respect for rights, having lost the right starting point that existed at the time of the formation of the European Community. The treaties are lifeless, so it is no surprise that so many Member States and their citizens do not accept the technocratic enforcement of the rules and regulations enshrined in the EU treaties. The proposals in the report, which, with the help of the EU institutions, in particular the European Commission, are trying to give the Member States a decisive say on issues relating to values ​​and norms, are not a good solution. The societies of individual states must be given the opportunity to decide their own destiny through referendums or constitutional revisions without undue outside interference. If the Union is to survive the current crisis, it must respect the national identities of all the Member States, which are their main historical and cultural heritage. And, most importantly, in order to uphold the rule of law, the Union, and the Commission in particular, cannot break the laws that we have encountered in the cases of Hungary and Poland.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on internal security in the EU - progress so far in implementing the adopted security measures and future challenges (2016/2955 (RSP)).

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, before I start I would like to say how much we are looking forward to cooperating with the Commissioner. It is the first occasion that we have had to meet here in the margins of this important debate. Commissioner, your portfolio is extremely important for the Security Union and we, as a Presidency, are very keen to work together with you. Honourable Members, many thanks for giving us the opportunity to express the views of the Council on this very important issue. I would like to start by recalling what the honourable Members Hohlmeier and Gonzales Pons have mentioned recently, to the effect that we have managed within the last year ‘remarkable legislative progress’ to prevent and fight terrorism. I think this is very important and should be recognised right at the beginning.  But, of course, the urgency of putting in place measures to prevent and fight terrorism, while maintaining an open and free society, has only increased following the many attacks which have taken place since then. Even if security is, let me say, primarily the Member States’ responsibility, political expectations for the EU and its citizens to deliver and ensure security are very high. The first point I want to make is on information exchange. The Council is highly committed to implementing the renewed Internal Security Strategy for the years 2015-2020, and one of the most important elements here is improving information exchange and accessibility, especially by ensuring the interoperability of different information systems.  The Council in June endorsed a roadmap on information exchange and information management in the Justice and Home Affairs area, and will regularly review its implementation. It contains 50 practical short and medium-term actions and long-term orientations. Their aim is to make sure that practitioners, such as policemen and border guards, have speedy and effective access to high quality information.  A number of actions of the roadmap will be taken forward by the High—Level Expert Group on information systems and interoperability. This group will play an important role in developing a long-term vision for the future architecture of the EU information systems and databases by ensuring their interoperability. While of course we should never be complacent, I daresay that there has been substantive progress over the past year. Let me give you two examples: (1) via the Europol Information System (EIS) and (2) the Schengen Information System. In the EIS, the number of terrorism-related objects has increased in the third quarter of this year by 20% (to a total of over 13 000) in comparison to the second quarter. The number of searches, and this is important, conducted in the EIS in the third quarter sets a new record, and brings the total number of searches performed this year to more than one million for the first time in the history of the system. As for the Schengen Information System (SIS), the number of alerts on persons under Article 36 of the SIS II Decision has nearly doubled since 2014, reaching almost 90 000. As regards information sharing by the security services, Europol has created the possibility for counter-terrorism units to communicate bilaterally using the secure information exchange network, SIENA, and is now upgrading it to EU confidential level. The European Counter Terrorism Centre (ECTC) has been operational since January 2016 and is also contributing to stepping up information-sharing and operational cooperation. The second point, on radicalisation: this must obviously be addressed, primarily by the Member States, but also, in order to be effective, by coordinated support at European level in accordance with the Treaties. As a follow-up to the Commission communication of June this year, the Education Council that will take place in November will adopt conclusions on preventing radicalisation leading to violent extremism. These conclusions reflect the broad approach that we need to take and highlight also the preventive role of education and youth work. Another important conference will be organised by the Radicalisation Awareness Network (RAN), in cooperation with the Commission, and it will also take place in November. Furthermore, it is crucial to focus on online initiatives and the work of the Europol Internet Referral Unit. Cooperation with service providers has proven successful, and approximately 90% of the content considered illegal was taken down by service providers. We look forward to the new initiatives of the EU Internet Forum to be launched by the Commission in December this year. In order to fight online radicalisation, nevertheless, we need to build the most effective partnership between government and industry.  I would like to mention two more issues very quickly – I am aware of the time limit, but it is important. First, on the victims of terrorism, the recent terrorist attacks have once again reminded us that our emergency services must be prepared for rapid and efficient interventions in very difficult security conditions. This requires enhanced cooperation between different actors at national and EU level, including emergency and security services.  Terrorist attacks are likely to cause a high number of victims requiring very specific medical treatment, not to mention psychological support which has to be provided, not only to survivors, but also to the families of the victims and to the witnesses of the events. I could continue on this but I would like to say we are paying attention also to the consequence management of terrorist attacks. Let me remind you of the Union Civil Protection Mechanism which was adopted in 2013. Secondly, and this is my last point, on irregular migratory flows, which is also very important in the current context of the migratory crisis, the Council has, in particular via the Integrated Political Crisis Response mechanism, worked intensively with relevant Member States, the Commission and EU agencies, to ensure an adequate response to the possible abuse of refugee and migration routes by terrorists. Of course, the most important points when it comes to the current routes are in Greece and Italy, but there are different types of security checks going on here and they are conducted in the various places on the work floor in these hotspots. One of the priorities in this area was the recruitment by Europol of national police officers who will be deployed together with Europol officers in the Greek hotspots, and also in Italy, as soon as possible.  Mr President, I took a bit longer than expected, but this is a very complex issue. There are many more important elements that should be mentioned, but this was the most important part, which I wanted to share with you.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very glad to be here this morning to discuss the first of a series of monthly reports on progress towards building an effective and sustainable Security Union. I hope this will become a regular fixture for future plenaries. My colleague Dimitris Avramopoulos would very much like to have been here this morning, but he sends his apologies. So this first report looks at the period from the Commission’s April 2016 communication, which also launched the Security Union, up until October, and it focuses on home and justice areas in particular. In future, the scope of these reports will be broader, given the cross-cutting nature of the Security Union, which is, as you know, an initiative that encompasses a broad swathe of the Commission’s work. Indeed it brings together more than 20 directorates-general. President Juncker’s idea when he created this role was to drive the delivery of work in this vital area, and I will work with my colleagues across the Commission to make sure that we deliver what we have all signed up to, to plug the gaps, and to make sure that our response keeps pace with the constantly shifting threats we face. We need to act simultaneously on two fronts. First, to close down the space in which terrorists and criminals operate and to deny them the means they use – money, munitions, movement. This also includes working on prevention of terrorism and working to counter radicalisation. Second, to build our resilience, to strengthen our information systems by making them more joined up, and to reinforce our critical infrastructure, particularly our transport, energy and cyber security, which are too often targeted by terrorists and criminals. As I have said before, all of this only works if it respects our fundamental rights and values. These are the very rights and values that terrorists in particular are setting out to destroy. In terms of the fight against terrorism, I welcome the commitment of this Parliament to conclude as soon as possible the negotiations on the counter-terrorism directive. I would like also to assure you of my strong support for your efforts to finalise the work on systematic checks on external borders. It is important that we do this, given the risks associated with the possible return of foreign fighters. As regards the means used to support terrorism, I am glad the co-legislators have started work on the amendments to the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive. The majority of measures in the action plan against the illicit trafficking and use of firearms and explosives have now been implemented or are in hand. The implementing regulation on firearms deactivation entered into force in April this year and will cut substantially access for terrorists to such firearms. But I wanted to add that the co-legislators now urgently need to close the remaining gaps in the trilogue, which I think is taking place today, to reach agreement on the revision of the Firearms Directive, to take military assault weapons off the streets. It is nearly a year since the Paris attacks. The Commission produced its proposals rapidly and they have been thoroughly discussed. Our citizens will simply not understand a continuing delay. Fighting terrorism also means tackling the causes of terrorism, including radicalisation. We have to fight ideas with ideas. Identifying and taking down terrorist propaganda is vital, as has been said, but developing persuasive counter-narratives that offer a clear alternative vision, backed up by opportunities and incentives, is the only way of tapping into the same idealism which radicalisation exploits. We have to target the people the recruiters are targeting and offer them a different and better path. That means education, employment and inclusion. The Commission is helping – funding work on counter-narratives through the RAN, through targeted use of Erasmus+, the Youth Guarantee, and financial support through the European Social Fund. Tackling this challenge takes time. I visited Mechelen, near Brussels, earlier earlier this month, a place with similar demographics to Molenbeek – but in the case of Mechelen there are no foreign fighters. This reflects 15 years’ worth of investment led by grassroot initiatives, combining a tough approach on law enforcement with sustained work on prevention and deradicalisation that has given young people a greater sense of self-worth and a greater sense of their community. I am happy that this long-term sustained approach is shared by Parliament, and I am looking forward to contributing to the debate which the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) will hold on combating radicalisation later in November. As well as taking the fight to terrorists and criminals, we need to build our resilience, to protect our citizens and our society, to strengthen our information systems, as has been mentioned, to reinforce our infrastructure, to reduce vulnerabilities. This means work on the interoperability of our information systems, where will be accelerating the work of the High Level Experts Group to produce an interim report and actions before Christmas. It also means developing a system of robust risk analysis, security research and the systematic cooperation between law enforcement agencies and the private sector. During my hearing I was very clear about the need to ensure appropriate implementation of what we have already agreed. We have got to deliver what we agreed, however hard and occasionally unglamorous that may be. The Commission is ready to support national authorities with technical assistance, exchange of best practice and, in many cases, financially, but Member States need to do their part. The PNR Directive is a case in point. This is a key instrument in the fight against terrorism, with the transposition deadline of May 2018. Few Member States yet have in place the necessary infrastructure to handle the data. A number have plans and projects underway, but 11 Member States have yet to start work. In other cases where the deadline for Member States’ transposition has already passed, the Commission will not hesitate to launch infringements – as was the case this September, when for the first time the Commission initiated infringement procedures for non-transposition of elements of the Prüm Network. Finally, let me stress another recurring theme. We need to make full use of the existing instruments we have at our disposal. Our agencies need to be strengthened and their support should be better used. For example, after the Paris attacks, Europol assigned 60 officers to support the French and Belgian investigations in Taskforce Fraternité. Data provided to Europol by Belgium and France enabled it to come up with 800 intelligence leads and more than 1 600 leads on suspicious financial transactions. Eurojust also played a key role in the aftermath of these attacks in what were legally complex cross-border investigations, and the new Europol regulation that will enter into application in May 2017 offers us new opportunities that we should seize. I realise I have spoken for too long, but as you can see, this is a broad range of work that we are reporting on, and initiating a monthly reporting cycle should allow us to be able to discuss specific issues in more depth in the future and ensure that all institutions have an updated picture on the state of implementation of these important initiatives. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear Presidency, dear colleagues! First of all, I would like to thank you for giving you the impression, at least for the first time, that something is really going on, where we discussed information exchange years ago, about the use of the SIS system, that actually the relevant people or also Things are registered. That the member states inform each other better that Europol can function better as a coordination body - that seems to be getting underway step by step and is becoming much more complete. What I am still concerned with is the fact that I am observing the negotiations a great deal - I will now take my own terrorism directive - the difficulty of the Member States making commitments. For example, if I take the exchange of information and, in addition, the obligation of the Member States to exchange relevant information, the Member States are still very reluctant to commit. When I think of the question of how we deal with the fact that we have a huge number of weapons that, from the former so-called Yugoslav war up to the present day, play into terrorism and the arms trade - and on an unbelievable scale - then I believe that we not only have to observe the arms trade as a whole, but above all the Darknet, and prevent that huge amounts of trade are carried out within the Darknet that we do not want to have.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. -  Mister President! In order to fight cross-border crime, including terrorism, the cooperation between our Member States needs the exchange of relevant information. What is decided jointly on this must also be implemented everywhere. I remember - it has already been mentioned - the Prüm decision on the exchange of vehicle and DNA data. The implementation should take place in August 2011. Here the Commission had to initiate infringement proceedings against 5 Member States. There is also a lack of implementation and information exchange in other areas. It is therefore imperative that we focus our work on applying the measures that have been decided. But in fact something new is always asked for. Example: European Passenger Name Data Collection - insanely important, or maybe not. This is because 11 member states are currently unable to meet the 2018 implementation deadline. I myself consider this directive in its adopted form to be contrary to fundamental rights and that brings me to a further challenge. Terrorist attacks target our open societies, freedom and democracy. But it is precisely these that need to be sustainably strengthened and defended. Massive collections of more and more data potentially suspect all citizens. The simultaneous neglect of data security and data protection offers criminals attack surfaces and endangers our fundamental rights. Particularly when it comes to the interoperability of data collections, their necessity and data protection issues must be carefully examined. In principle, the discussion about new measures and more and more surveillance carries the risk of creating a latent feeling of constant uncertainty. That, too, can nurture the soil for far-right forces - including hatred, threats and violence. In fact, politicians and their families, voluntary citizens, people with a migration background, police officers and many others are currently being massively threatened from the right - probably not only in Germany. The killing of a police officer in Bavaria last week is just terrifying evidence. The fight against organized crime and terrorism must not obstruct the view of other challenges. The defense of the rule of law and open societies does not need action, but a sense of proportion, because whoever gives up freedom in order to gain security can ultimately lose both.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - When we talk about security within the Union, I am also thinking of certain marginalized population groups in which the phenomenon of Muslim extremism unfortunately occurs prominently, for example young people from high-risk neighborhoods, who are encouraged by criminal friends or charismatic radicalized figures. Terrorism often follows crime, but community and the sense of identity also play a significant role. The terrorist Abdeslam, for example, moved to Brussels after the attack in Paris and immediately found shelter with a family: with a father, mother and son in Molenbeek. That is why I wondered how those communities can be taken out of marginality. Since 2005, the EU has systematically supported Member States in their efforts to combat violent extremism. The 2015 Security Agenda builds on this, after which the Commission launched seven new priorities in mid-2016. A toolkit was also announced to better detect and combat extremism and thus keep our society open, free and inclusive. It is important that victims and disillusioned terrorists are also involved. These are good measures, but the best means for a cohesive society is nevertheless activation and participation in the form of language training and counseling in finding work. Mandatory integration is also an absolute key point in the fight against terror. In Brussels, for example, an integration program is still not compulsory. This is thanks to our French-speaking PS colleagues. As if Europe can solve everything with a magic wand!

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his update. Commissioner, I very much welcome your intention of giving us a monthly update. On the evaluation, I also very much appreciate your emphasis on the need for evaluation of the implementation, and indeed the PNR case demonstrates that. Although I personally voted against the directive, I think it is extremely silly to pass laws which are not then implemented. I also wonder where the rush came from, if now the Member States are not acting six months after the adoption. I think we should also get a bit more information about the – in total now – EUR 130 million which are being spent on PNR. But we should not only evaluate the implementation but also the effectiveness. If you compare it to the war on drugs, that has failed dramatically. Is the war on terror any more successful? I do not know, because we have passed so many laws and spent so much money, and the threat levels seem to be going up, not down. We seem to get less of a grip on the phenomenon, not more. We should also evaluate the impact on fundamental rights and the rule of law, as you have mentioned. But I would also like to see included in your monthly updates the need for democratic and judicial oversight and more transparency and accountability, because I think that is sorely lacking. While defending our democracy and rule of law against terrorist attacks, we seem to be throwing the baby out with the bathwater. So I really hope that you are going to focus more on that. Three final remarks. First of all, on prevention: I also welcome your statements on that, because I think that so far we have done a terrible job on prevention. I think we have made matters worse by creating deep divisions in society. Secondly, we all agree on the urgent need for more information-sharing. But, as I said in the previous debate, information-sharing is a lot more than just interconnectivity. That is the technical side of things, but we now need to actually share information, and not on a voluntary, ad hoc, random basis, but systematically. Finally, in the report that this House adopted in 2011, we stressed already very heavily the need to invest a lot more in what they call HUMINT – human intelligence, people on the ground. I think that the situation in Belgium and the investigation that they did has shown that the real problem is insufficient capacity. So, rather than spending zillions on megalomaniac IT systems, we should be investing in people on the ground.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. -  Mister President! I was really curious today what the Council and the Commission have to say to us. But what you shared with us is neither new nor does it have any system. You have no internal security strategy at all. Because the minimum requirement is the evaluation of all existing security instruments, their testing for suitability, for success, for accuracy. Instead, they hoard billions of data for illustrious security measures, such as a magpie collects glittering objects in its nest. And you think a lot helps a lot. Your policy really suffers from two fundamental flaws: On the one hand, you invest incredibly little in the preventive area, which you thankfully talked about today, but you rely almost exclusively on repression. Both prevention and repression are disproportionate, and you are doing nothing really relevant to drying up the sources of finance for terrorism. Your friendship with Saudi Arabia and all the other dictators is worth a lot more to you. On the other hand - and this is very important to me - you do not have the proportionality between security and fundamental rights on your agenda. Fundamental rights such as the right to informational self-determination are being sacrificed for security without hesitation, billions of data from citizens are stored and filtered, fundamental judgments of the European Court of Justice are ignored, and citizens simply become a minor figure. You don't trust the citizen, but you ask to be trusted. And that is a fatal mistake!

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, this first report on the progress made in the field of security has at least one merit: it illustrates wonderfully the hypocrisy of the Member States. On the exchange of information, the PNR or the “anti-terrorism” directive, states are constantly playing a double game. Last spring, they told us that it was urgent to adopt the PNR, hinting at us as irresponsible. This report reveals that almost no Member State has made progress in its implementation. Ditto for the “anti-terrorism” directive, on which we are currently working. While the Member States urge us to adopt it as soon as possible and believe that we do not have time to carry out an impact assessment, these same States want a transposition period of two years instead of . There is only urgency in front of the cameras. This report is welcome, but when will the Commission finally decide to publish a report on the effectiveness of existing instruments? It would be useful to know what really works rather than piling up devices, further criminalizing behavior and continually expanding the collection of personal data, to the detriment of fundamental freedoms. The report issued by the police surveillance committee for Belgian deputies already gives us clues as to the deficiencies to be corrected. No lack of data, but a glaring lack of resources. Several members of the Paris commando had been identified but could not be the subject of an adequate follow-up for lack of personnel or transmission of information between the various services. Let's stop throwing dust in the eyes! What we really need is to strengthen cooperation between Member States and to give additional resources to the judiciary and the police, which are sorely lacking.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all care about the internal security of the Union. Yet we cannot help but forget the flaws in the information exchange system between the police and judicial authorities of the Member States which have dramatically emerged after the attacks in Paris and Brussels. We have heard many times, even in public hearings, that the data and information were there, but then the exchange didn't work. Here, as denounced in my report on the fight against organized crime that will be voted on today, cross-border police and judicial cooperation is characterized by excessively long and bureaucratic procedures, which hinder its efficiency with serious consequences in terms of internal security. Union. It is therefore necessary to strengthen cooperation, the sharing of information between Member States, ensuring common procedures, mutual admissibility of evidence and using joint investigation teams. Finally, I would like to remind you that the links and the growing convergence between terrorism and organized crime constitute an increasingly serious threat to the Union and in this sense too it is necessary to strengthen the transnational fight against organized crime.

name: Mara Bizzotto
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are discussing the progress of the security of the European Union. But what are they? I don't even see one. In the last year, Islamic terrorism has carried out massacres and attacks in every corner of Europe. And what is your answer? Zero, nisba, nada, practically nothing! The secret services around the world tell us that Islamic terrorists are hiding among the illegal immigrants who land in Italy every day; and the Renzi government, what does it do? Since the beginning of the year, it has welcomed 157,000 immigrants, two out of three are illegal immigrants and are not refugees. But does it seem normal to you? That's enough! Citizens are tired of being made fun of, they are tired of being invaded by thousands of illegal immigrants who steal, peddle, commit crime. It is hell! The only solution to bring security back to Italy is to do what other European states are already doing: defending the borders and expelling illegal immigrants. Let's stop the invasion before it's too late!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). - Mr President, is there internal security in Europe? In fact, each Member State of the Union has a different level of internal security, depending on factors, the majority of which depend on the internal conditions of each state and the form of its society. The European Union has done nothing more than add problems to countries. One can very easily start from the Balkans and find oneself in Denmark by road, transporting all kinds of illegal goods, from drugs to weapons, ready to be used in terrorist attacks. The so-called border controls that have been imposed, apart from creating traffic congestion at the border, serve nothing more, as they are not just controls. Finally, how many of you in here can responsibly say that we have seen the end of terrorist attacks? Worse, how many can say that we have done or are ready to do everything in our power to prevent past or future terrorist attacks? Unfortunately, Europe is facing a huge security gap, a gap that will not be filled if some are unwilling to leave behind ideologies and entanglements that serve no purpose.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (
text: PPE). - Mr President, Commissioner, it is certain that steps have been taken, but we still have a long way to go. My view is that we need to focus on updating, terrorism and prevention. Who are our enemies? How do they equip themselves? How do they recruit new members? Where do they get funding from? How do they work together? How do they organize? We know very well that we have an asymmetric threat, as we know we are vulnerable. You just said that there are eleven Member States that do not yet have sufficient or no infrastructure to implement the PNR. But what interests the European Union and us here is which Member States do not want, do not have the will or are unable to implement what we decide. It is certain, Commissioner, that the policies we are pursuing run counter to some ideologies that want to believe that personal freedoms are being falsified by security measures. What we all need to understand is that, wherever terrorists come from, this threat is to the European Union, to the European mentality, to the way of thinking, and that the greatest security, organized security, is itself the one that ensures civil liberties.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: - Security is a value that is very important to European citizens. In a recent Eurobarometer survey, more than 80 percent of citizens said they wanted more action at Union level. But security is multifaceted for me: security against junk food, protection of privacy, independence of the media, effective rule of law. And we must not forget another aspect, namely protection against excessive security, which would infringe on fundamental rights. In its response to the terrorist attacks, the Commission has responded with a number of new measures. While I welcome proportionate, truly necessary and effective measures, many are also moving in the direction of undermining fundamental rights. And I believe that the very fragile relationship between security and other measures in the Union has already been broken. We need to make much more effort, as you yourself mentioned, to combat the radicalization of young people. Suburbs like Moellenbeck are a big challenge and we have good practices in the European Union, Denmark for example, on how to help young people who are pushed to the margins of society. Commissioner, at our meeting and in the LIBE Committee, you called for a thorough review and evaluation of the effectiveness of all existing security measures. We at the European Parliament will keep your word - we are still awaiting this review. And until there is cooperation between the security intelligence services, the authorities, the police and the judiciary, no new measures will help us. The same applies to the pointless establishment of a series of databases if personal systems are not interconnected. In Europe, we are somehow building, these days it seems, a fortress, impermeable borders. We are renovating the asylum system, which will be completely inaccessible to people in need of protection. And Mr King, I very much regret that the Commission will take a positive decision today on the extension of internal border controls, although you yourself acknowledge that there are no valid reasons for them. Headless rushing and passing legislation without the right teacher does not increase security, but merely a sense of apparent security, which can have serious negative consequences.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Thanks. I would like us all to take on the security of our citizens and the security of the European Union. Terrorist attacks will not stop, but will intensify. It has been said here that the PNR is not applied by the Member States. I remind you that in this Parliament I kept the PNR, not me, but colleagues of mine, for three years, until I adopted it. Of course, the Member States did not sit idly by and made bilateral relations with each other and shared this data on passengers. So this is not an argument. Let's adopt the legislation and do our job, even if a Member State does not do its job, because we will be responsible for that. Security Commissioner Julian King, who is here, and I am glad about that, warned of the risk of ISIL fighters heading for Europe in their attack, in the context of the battle for Mosul. Finally, I would like to insist on the adoption this year of the Regulation amending the Schengen by strengthening borders.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, welcome among us and good work, because you will not miss work. First project: the necessary, even imperative, interoperability between the databases that we have created. God knows if we have created any! Without interoperability, it's money wasted. Second project, Commissioner: you have recognized that the Member States must respect their commitments. It is a scandal that to date there is only one Member State which has a fully operational PNR, and the paradox wants, Commissioner, that it is that of your country, which has just decided to leave the Union. Third project: while Parliament proposed a compulsory exchange of PNR data, the Member States preferred to only have to exchange the data they deem relevant. If terrorism-related data is not security relevant, what data will be? Fourth project, Commissioner: given the number of terrorists who are citizens of the Union, it is necessary to step up checks at the external borders of the European Union. These checks are all the more necessary as there is a sharp increase in the use of false identity cards. In this regard, Commissioner, I look forward to, and I hope you will take care of, a Commission proposal to harmonize the security features of European identity cards. Fifth project: according to my information, the Commission will very soon propose a revision of the regulation on the Schengen information system. This will be an imperative opportunity to improve the accuracy of the reports of persons suspected of terrorism.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fences of fortress Europe do not seem to be enough to stop the migration drama. Attempts to get there are far from diminishing, generating more and more deaths directly related to our border and security policy. A big business of xenophobia, which benefits the defense industry on one side of the border and human traffickers on the other. The miracle of the multiplication of border controls then takes place, and with them the political declarations that link irregular migration with organized crime, terrorism or trafficking in human beings intensify, encouraging punitive populism, as we have seen in this very Chamber. Thus, Fortress Europe is constituted not only in a racist project that violates rights and freedoms but also in a great business that has not stopped growing in recent years: the xenophobia business that is fueled by the security strategies of this Europe that looks the other way before this crisis.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues! I would like to propose three points in order to achieve greater security in the European Union. First: We need a high degree of perceived security. That is what is always desired, and that is also correct. We need an environment where people can feel safe and there are lots of little things that can be done about that. You need a police force close to the citizen, that gives people a feeling of security. Second, we need an effective security policy and measures. The studies show very clearly that the investigation rates and crime statistics will remain at about the same level if we continue to rely on surveillance without cause, if we rely on data collections on unsuspecting people. If we start specifically with incident-related investigations, cross-border investigations, there will be improvements, and if we invest more in the police. Last, third point: structural security. We need an environment of an open society that defends civil liberties and civil rights. That creates security and a secure infrastructure - both analogue and digital - and back doors are definitely not part of that.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the European Union is threatened and it has to protect itself, it has to activate prevention and repression tools. Repression avoids impunity. The safety of Europeans must be a priority in Union policies. Terrorist attacks, organized crime, drug trafficking, money laundering, corruption, trafficking and illicit trafficking offer us deadly scenarios every day that must be faced with determination and subordinate to our laws and our guarantees. We have launched a multitude of instruments and a multitude of tools — all of you have referred to them—: from ECTC to EC3, Prüm, PNR, inputs and outputs, etcetera, etcetera. However, I believe that the so-called political cycle must be activated immediately and updated. The political cycle is five years old and has to be updated. Ladies and gentlemen, future challenges are linked to the increase in terrorism. The weaker the terror is in the occupied territories and in failed states, the more it will hit Western targets. The security of a Member State is the security of the Union as a whole. Therefore, we must give a global response. But first of all we must tell ourselves the truth: we do not have a common security policy; we don't have an intelligence community; we do not have a common judicial space; we do not have a common defense policy. Our borders are vulnerable. We do not have a TFTP. A long way to go. Many successes, Commissioner.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Mr President, this first monthly report can be a good initiative to provide effective responses to the security imperative of our citizens, which cannot be achieved without European cooperation. In that sense, we are negotiating the anti-terrorism directive, the fourth revision of the money laundering directive, the fifth in which we strengthened Europol and the coast and border guard, we created the RAN and the European Union Internet Forum. But none of this substitutes for the investment that the Commission and the Member States, strangled by self-inflicted austerity policies, have not made in smart and close programs to prevent radicalization. I also visited Mechelen, Commissioner King, and in fact, the more youth jobs are destroyed, the more inclusive social policies are destroyed, the more recruits the European Union Member States are offering to violent extremist groups. The Council may well be concerned with the return of foreign fighters or the infiltration of migrants. The terrorists who hit us in Paris or Brussels were European-made. In addition, by fueling the business of traffickers' networks and organized crime associated with the lack of opening up legal and safe access routes to Europe for immigrant refugees, in addition to the serious human rights violations that we have already experienced on European soil, including thousands of unaccompanied minors who have disappeared, all this only demonstrates the inconsistency, ineptitude of the so-called anti-terrorist policies of the Member States. Two other fundamental problems persist: firstly, the resistance of States to share information, to interoperate services, as Commissioner King said. The PNR Directive, so often presented as a success, demonstrates the lack of application by Member States, data sharing is not even mandatory, the control of private flights is not mandatory and then there are questions of the dimension of foreign policy , as already mentioned by other colleagues.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, internal security in the European Union is under unprecedented threat today. The reason for this is the wrong policy pursued by the European Commission and some European countries. The debate is fundamentally wrong because the concepts have been changed and because there are empty talk, probably caused by a guilty conscience from colonial times. Internal order and security are under pressure from the threat of Islamist terrorism. The wrong policy pursued by the European Commission calls Islamist terrorism a "cultural difference". Europe raises, feeds and sustains those who attack it. This is an unprecedented and serious danger. We need a new policy - a policy of repelling illegal emigration, a policy of calling things by their real names, a policy that clearly states and distinguishes invasion and terror from human rights. New behavior is needed by all European leaders.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the EU has to ensure internal security and has to fight terrorism. This is undeniable, but in a democratic society this can only be done while keeping in mind the main goal of protecting and reinforcing civil liberties and the human rights of citizens. When we do not do so, we are falling into the trap set by terrorism, which plans to have us caught in fear, resentment and diminishing democracy. Has the EU really evaluated which of the security initiatives taken against terrorism really work and which do not? I am afraid this has not been done so far. It is urgent to do so. A lot has been said on this during this debate, but I would like to insist that we should only accept more security measures if they mean a better protection of freedom, not a disruption of it.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the fight against terrorism and organized crime cannot be tackled at Member State level alone, which is why citizens rightly expect the European Union to ensure their security at the level of its powers. In the last two years, we have adopted two regulations that allow the collection of passenger data, information on transfers of funds that could be used to finance terrorism. At Europol level, the amount of data shared is multiplying and a European counter-terrorism center is being set up. We are aware of the need to prevent, combat radicalization and also the need for intolerance of manifestations of radical Islam, watching content on the Internet, and therefore we want to prevent its spread through audiovisual services. Ladies and gentlemen, the list of these activities that we are doing at European Union level is not exhaustive, it is not enough, but it is a clear signal that the safety of citizens is our priority.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: - First of all, I would like to congratulate Commissioner King on his appointment. I am pleased that we in the European Union now finally have a Commissioner who deals solely with security. That is an important signal of how high this is on our list of priorities. I have three points, the first of which is Passenger Name Record (PNR). I am genuinely surprised and disappointed that 11 Member States have still not done anything at all to implement the PNR Directive. You would think that the need for this is already clear. Unfortunately not. I would therefore like to ask the Commissioner whether he considers it possible to say at a certain point with the Member States that have already taken major steps: we are already starting and the others can join when they are ready? A second question: at your hearing, Mr King, you said that if the UK government decides to opt out of the new Europol mandate, it would leave unwanted gaps in European security policy until new agreements can be made. In preparation for this, are you working, at least on behalf of the European Commission, to ensure that these gaps do not arise and that the 500 million citizens can count on complete security? Last point: criminal organizations in the border region. We increasingly see that criminals still know how to find our borders, even though they have disappeared on paper. We need to cooperate more, share more information and do more work on cross-border confiscation and freezing of assets. I would like to call for the permanent deployment of cross-border investigation teams to tackle those structural dangers. I would like to hear your opinion on that.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the inquiries into the most recent attacks and the statements by the counter-terrorism coordinator testify that recruitment processes, especially online ones, are accelerating. Thus, in addition to harmonizing the criminal law framework, the real challenge for an effective fight against terrorism will be the definition of a long-term strategy on preventing radicalization and promoting integration. But more generally, I believe that all the problems linked to the internal security of the Union must be tackled with legislative proposals that commit the States to concrete, real cooperation; I am thinking, in particular, of the exchange of information - and this also in the context of the directive to combat terrorism which, I hope, will deliver us a text that will help break the bond existing between organized crime and terrorist groups which is increasingly consolidated. The anti-money laundering directive needs to be updated with rules that prevent terrorist groups from financing themselves and specific rules on confiscation and freezing are needed ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: – Mr President, 82% of Europeans believe that the Union should act more decisively against terrorism, according to our Eurobarometer Survey published this July. There are still many challenges ahead of us. Information exchange has to be stepped up, interoperability of the existing databases must be ensured. It is important that all persons crossing the European Union’s external borders are checked against the relevant databases. In order to keep the Schengen system borderless, we have to prove to our citizens that we are in control of our external borders. More has to be done in order to prevent and fight radicalisation, which is due to failed integration, through the means of the Internet is occurring faster and faster. Security lies at the heart of the European project and there can be no freedom without security.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I see an advantage in the appointment of Commissioner King as head of Security - there is already an immigration official, Commissioner Avramopoulos - and that is to say quite clearly that this false identification that is false and deeply damaging for European integration claims that the cause of insecurity is immigration. Because those speeches that are often heard here, in this European Parliament, are close to the one we hear in the constitutional and political debate of the United States before the elections, led by Donald Trump, who claims to raise a border or a fence or a Barrier against immigration is the guarantee against insecurity, while defending the Second Amendment, which causes 30,000 deaths a year from firearms in the United States. No, the cause of terrorism in Europe does not come from immigration. The terrorism that has hit us the most in Europe was perpetrated by citizens who carried European passports, who resided in European capitals and who lived among us. Therefore, the security strategy has to be perfectly distinguished from the immigration strategy.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this first opportunity, following the publication of the first of this series of monthly reports, to have this debate. If, as one or two people have said, this were to become a regular feature in plenary, as far as the Commission is concerned that would be very welcome. A number of detailed points have been raised in discussion. I am obviously not going to be able to respond to all of those now, but we have taken very careful note and, through this iterative process of reporting and debating, I hope that we will be able to come back and address all of the points that have been raised. I will also have an opportunity myself to go into a little bit of detail on some of these points with the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) early in November.  As Mrs Fajon said, more than 80% of our citizens are looking for more reassurance from EU—level activity in support of our Member States on the security agenda. As Mr Albrecht said, people want to feel more secure and there are a range of things that we can do at EU level to help and support Member States. I am reassured that Mrs Hohlmeier thinks that we are starting to get some things done on terrorism, on cybercrime and on organised crime, as Mrs Ferrara underlined. We need to do what we have collectively agreed. I am in no doubt about that. As Mrs in 't Veld and Mr Deprez, among others, underlined, that is crucial not only because of the importance of the individual measures, but also to reassure people about the credibility of our work in this field. I am also absolutely convinced that we need to focus on what works and that involves a critical assessment of what we have been doing. Mrs Joly and others underlined that. I take that very seriously. I gave a commitment during my appearance in front of the LIBE Committee that we would work on an evaluation of this policy area, and we will. I agree with Mrs Stevens, Mrs Gomes and others that we need to continue with an intelligent and sustained approach to prevention, as well as taking the fight to terrorism and serious criminality. In all of that I am completely committed to full respect for fundamental rights, because we have a clear objective. Our objective, as many of you have said, is to defend our open societies and that is to act grounded in the rule of law.  I will make two points in response to questions that have come up. On implementation and the particular case of the implementation of PNR underlined by Mrs Sippel and various others, we are not in infringement territory because the transposition date is Spring 2018, but we do need to work together with all the Member States to achieve the common shared objective of effective implementation by that date. To that end, I am going be producing an implementation roadmap in November, which will set out in concrete terms the steps that need to be taken and how we can work together to achieve them. My last particular point has regard to a number of comments made this morning about the relationship between migration and terrorism. I want to agree one hundred percent with the last speaker, Mr López Aguilar. We should not conflate the challenges associated with migration, on the one hand, with terrorism and the problems it poses on the other. To do so is to play into the hands of Daesh.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: amtierender Ratspräsident. – Herr Präsident! Darf ich damit beginnen, wie ich mich gefreut habe, dass mehrere Abgeordnete einfach anerkannt haben, dass wir Fortschritte im legislativen Bereich gemacht haben. Das hat Frau Hohlmeier gesagt, und dafür möchte ich mich bedanken. Sei es im Bereich Informationsaustausch oder Interoperabilität – mehrmals wurde erwähnt, dass uns die Kommission auf monatlicher Basis eine Aktualisierung gibt, wo wir stehen. Das bringt mich aber dazu, dass ich auch die Stimmen sehr sorgfältig gehört habe, die darauf hingewiesen haben ... that the implementation is extremely important and therefore the Slovak Presidency wants to assure you that we will not allow ourselves any complacency in this area. That is why we are organising an extraordinary, or additional, Interior Council on 18 November where we will have an exchange of views and try to generate momentum in the whole complexity of this area of security union.  Secondly, radicalisation is extremely important too; we will put it on the agenda of the Educational Council. Here in the area of education I think we need to make progress to face and fight radicalisation. I know also about the interests of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) in having an exchange on radicalisation. Finally, we are making very good progress when it comes to the directive on combating terrorism, with a good prospect that we will close it towards the end of our Presidency.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: in writing. - There are two vectors of EU security to which you should pay attention: both internally and externally, they cannot be separated. In the internal dimension, the most important problem is the crisis related to successive waves of refugees and terrorist attacks. Both of these issues are closely related to foreign security issues around the EU's borders. This is undoubtedly a question of the disastrous Arab springs and the decisions of the French, British and Italian authorities to support the rebels. Another equally important factor is the hybrid war that Russia has waged against the West. I do not only think about Ukraine, but also about cyber attacks and disinformation directed at the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, including my homeland, Poland. So far, EU institutions have not managed to come up with any solution to any of these threats - and that's good, because such solutions are created only within the Member States. Security was, is and will be an inherent domain of sovereign states. Contrary to the dreams of communists, Eurosocialists and fanatics of the European federation, a common security policy does not exist.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Measures taken to improve internal security in the EU are not well received by the public. Program items: information on the movement of foreign terrorist fighters, prevention of radicalization and the fight against radicalization, sanctions against terrorists, better exchange of information and more are fine, but the public negatively perceives the nonsense of another attempt to criminalize possession of firearms. This proposal has raised many legitimate doubts among sport shooters, hunters and other professional groups about its meaning and purpose. The protection of citizens and critical infrastructures has been translated into investment measures at the entrance to some public buildings. In France, they are accompanied by a state of emergency. In Belgium, we see soldiers with automatic weapons in a number of public places. The authorities are still trying to interfere with the freedom of the Internet and deepen the monitoring of their own citizens. I believe that the public welcomes the efforts to step up the fight against terrorist financing and any indication of strengthening the protection of the EU's external borders. It is desirable to cooperate not only with the countries of the Mediterranean on counter-terrorism measures. Without truly effective action, the internal security of the EU countries will not improve. The Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs and Citizenship says that the EU should be an area of ​​freedom, security and justice for its citizens without internal borders. Unfortunately, the actions of the European Court of Justice, national courts and the European Commission make the EU an area without external borders. Is that what we want?

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
