text: in writing.- This report is something that is very important for today's EU, the protection of our European values, democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.That is the basis of our community and our confidence in the functioning of the Union as a whole.If these values are not complied with, we must have effective tools to ensure that they are complied with.However, this must in no case be to the detriment of the sovereignty of the Member States, to the detriment of their political situation, to the detriment of their voluntary participation in the European Union project.That is why the issue of subsidiarity and the sovereignty of the Member States is crucial to me in this report.In the first instance, they are the ones responsible for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in their country.The EU must play the role of partner and helper on this issue, not a controller who will tell the Member States what and how to do.That in itself would be undemocratic.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. - The terrorist threat in the EU is growing, which is confirmed by the number of victims of the attacks. We have therefore rightly increased the competences of Europol and Eurojust, since a more effective fight against terrorists requires a revival of international cooperation. However, the problem of controlling the effectiveness of the newly introduced solutions remains. For example, after long discussions, it was decided that the EU countries and the United States would automatically exchange information about air passengers. But what turns out today - 11 out of 28 EU Member States are not able to quickly - for technical and organizational reasons - provide other countries with information about air passengers. This should lead us to important reflection. Before we decide to extend the powers of the police and services, let us first check how the existing competences are used. The key today is not to multiply instruments to fight criminals, including terrorists, but to implement and make optimal use of existing solutions.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, my point of order is based on Article 150 thereof and Articles 8 and 9 of the Protocol on the immunities of the European Union. Mr President, yesterday I complained about the lack of debate in the three cases of parliamentary immunity before us. But today, it's even better, or rather even worse. I learned that it will not even be possible to give an explanation of vote or even to express a dissenting opinion on the infamies with which the committee is covered, whose role is nevertheless to protect the freedom of expression of the deputies. I therefore ask you, solemnly, to allow oral explanations of vote on these requests for the lifting of parliamentary immunity, which are an essential point in the guarantee of the freedom of expression of deputies on the part of 'an institution which prides itself on respect for fundamental rights and which claims to give the whole world lessons in this area.

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr. Deputy, yesterday the President explained the procedure well.Therefore, we will vote and everyone will vote as they see fit.So you can vote whatever you want.The plenary will decide what to do.Parliament will choose.

name: Presidente. –
text: Voting time is suspended.

name: President. –
text: It is my pleasure to welcome the members of a delegation from the US Congress who have taken their seats in the diplomatic gallery. (Applause) The delegation is in Strasbourg to meet with their counterparts from the European Parliament with the proposal of deepening their knowledge and understanding of our legislative and institutional procedures. I wish the delegation well for the remainder of their stay in the European Union.

name: Presidente. –
text: We resume voting time.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the continuation of the voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I am a little ashamed of the European Parliament.I do not know if anyone has read the texts you voted for, but you have rejected, for example, the rejection of executions for juveniles in Iran, freer elections or the combination of economic interests and human rights issues.Ladies and gentlemen, my grandfather was in a concentration camp, and I am ashamed of voting against these amendments and proposing that they be rejected.

name: Presidente. –
text: Honorable, it was not a request on the agenda.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I do not think it was clear to everybody whether we were voting on the third part of recital A or the final vote on the resolution. Can we take the vote again so that it is clear to everybody?

name: Presidente. –
text: He said it very clearly, but we can reverse it if there is any doubt.If it said on the screen that there was a vote on the resolution, we can vote on the third part.Voting is open.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is actually an oral amendment which is in line with the Council decisions. I will repeat, after paragraph 9: ‘Calls for swift processing in collaboration with third countries of transit and origin and of return for those who do not qualify for asylum and protection in the EU’. That is the oral amendment after paragraph 9.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: – Mr President, then we have after paragraph 10: ‘Calls on key origin and transit countries for irregular migration to the EU to fully and effectively implement existing bilateral readmission agreements’. I hope at least ‘existing bilateral admission readmission agreements’ can be accepted. (Brief comment by the President) They are calling to disobey existing law. Let us be very clear: they call for disobeying existing legislation.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I thank my colleague Gahler for his intervention.I would just like to remind him that we are not the Council but the European Parliament;that in my report we repeat the positions of the European Parliament as a whole;and finally, that he is a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee.Therefore, it is very late to wake up.Mr Gahler could have tabled amendments in the Foreign Affairs Committee rather than submitting us to this debate.I thank all the colleagues who supported me in this report and I regret the little last-minute shenanigans.

name: Presidente. –
text: This concludes the voting round.Let us now turn to the explanations of vote.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- This consultation decision authorizes Denmark to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA for the purpose of automated consultation and comparison of DNA data, as part of wider cross-border cooperation in the fight againstterrorism and transnational crime.This procedure can only take place after the implementation of the general data protection provisions into national law, which Denmark has correctly carried out.For these reasons, I voted in favor.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non-legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against all these data exchange mechanisms, due to the absence of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the aim is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Consequently, my vote of rejection.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report provides for the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark. It calls for the unnecessary collection and sharing of personal data that is highly invasive, expensive and unwarranted in scope and nature. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this draft Council implementing decision which aims to allow Denmark to receive and provide personal data for the purposes of automated DNA data search and comparison under the Treatyby Prüm.Denmark has indeed carried out a successful pilot project and complied with all data protection regulations.We therefore believe that Denmark is ready to take part in this treaty.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision on the launch of automated DNA data exchange in Denmark, as it is an important step in the effort of cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the EU.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - The transmission of personal data provided for by the said decision can only take place after the implementation in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general provisions relating to data protection. Denmark replied to the questionnaire concerning data protection and the one concerning the exchange of DNA data. A general evaluation report, comprising a summary of the results of the questionnaire, the evaluation visit and the pilot test relating to the exchange of DNA data, was presented to the Council. On July 12, 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions. Therefore, for the purpose of automated DNA data consultation, Denmark should be allowed to receive and transmit personal data. Having the greatest reservations about exchanging DNA data of French citizens in an EU system, but unwilling to cast a vote that could be considered hostile to Denmark, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this technically non-legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report as the exchange of DNA data is essential in deepening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and crime.The pilot test carried out with the Netherlands was conclusive and confirms my decision.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- This implementation of the Council Decision by the Council aims to allow Denmark to receive and provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615 / JHR through automated DNA search and comparison.This will improve cooperation with other countries in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non-legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- This is a report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated data exchange relating to DNA data in Denmark.On 12 July 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark had fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA.Therefore, for the purpose of automated DNA data consultation, Denmark should be allowed to receive and transmit personal data.We have the greatest reservations about exchanging DNA data of French citizens in an EU system, but I abstained on this vote so as not to cast a vote that would appear hostile to Denmark.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I approved this report which proposes that Denmark could participate in the exchange of DNA data within the framework of the Prüm convention.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: written.- The decision to establish automated data exchange regarding fingerprint data in Denmark implies progress in strengthening cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the Union: the application of the 'Prüm Decision' and the European Modelfor the Exchange of Information.Therefore I have voted in favor of it.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the Moraes report on the launch of automated DNA data exchange in Denmark.This is an important text, which is being approved at a time when Europe is facing the growing threat of international terrorism.It represents a crucial step towards strengthening cross-border cooperation in the field of judicial investigations and crime prevention.The guarantee of data protection in Denmark and the results achieved in the pilot project carried out in the same country confirm the positive opinion on the proposal, which will mark a strengthening of the action to combat not only terrorist activities but also organized crime.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the contracting parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has fulfilled, according to the Council, the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE in relation to the Prüm Decision, we have voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control, and it deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- The fight against organized crime - not only against terrorism, but against other phenomena such as trafficking in human beings - requires that we optimize the possibilities that forensic science and criminology offer today.In this area of freedom and security that is Europe, the automatic exchange of data from DNA banks, which facilitates this objective, is a must.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report concerns the automated exchange of data relating to DNA data in Denmark. This transmission of personal data provided for by the decision under consideration can only take place after transposition into national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general provisions relating to data protection. The verification must aim at compliance with the mentioned condition, in accordance with an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test. Denmark has carried out a pilot test with the Netherlands. On July 12, the Council concluded that Denmark had implemented general data protection provisions and should therefore be allowed to receive and transmit personal data. Since I have the greatest reservations about exchanging DNA data, I decided to abstain in order not to cast a hostile vote against Denmark.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am convinced that fighting organized crime and terrorism must be one of our priorities.This text is part of those measures aimed at enhancing cross-border cooperation and necessary to allow the police forces to have new and increasingly effective tools at their disposal to combat all forms of crime, which is why I intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - In accordance with Article 25 (2) of Decision 2008/615 / JHA, the transmission of personal data pursuant to said Decision may only be initiated when, in the territory of the Member States participating in said transmission, there have been The general provisions on data protection established in Chapter 6 of said Decision have been incorporated into domestic law. On July 29, 2015, the Council concluded that Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Therefore, for the purposes of automated consultation of DNA data, Denmark should be empowered to receive and transmit personal data under Article 9 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. That is why I have voted favorably on this report necessary to approve the exchange of DNA-related data with Denmark, in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the automatic exchange of DNA data in Denmark.The Council Working Party shall draw up a questionnaire for each case of automatic data exchange and, where a Member State considers that it fulfills the conditions for sharing the relevant category of data, it shall reply to the relevant questionnaire.Denmark replied to the questionnaire on data protection and the questionnaire on the exchange of DNA data.The Council was provided with a joint evaluation report summarizing the results of the DNA data exchange questionnaire, the evaluation visit and the pilot test of the system, and Denmark should therefore be entitled to receive and provide personal data for the purpose of automated DNA search.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported this proposal on the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark, as it seeks to further strengthen law enforcement cooperation and thus greater security for EU citizens, especially in the field of terrorism and cross-border crime.A common DNA database allows for faster access and thus more efficient screening of crime suspects.It is an accurate and secure identification technology that does not allow abuse.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this report.The implementing draft Council Decision aims to authorize Denmark to receive and transmit personal data for the purposes of automated search and comparison of DNA data.Given that Denmark has launched a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the provisions on personal data protection, I believe that it meets all the conditions for the implementation of the Prüm Treaty.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- I advocate the virtue of prudence on this matter and I therefore have the greatest reservations about the exchange of DNA data of French citizens in an EU system.This would mean that Denmark would be allowed to receive and transmit DNA data from French nationals and its own nationals.It is a matter of principle to protect the DNA information of the citizens we represent.However, I do not wish to cast a vote which could be considered hostile to Denmark.I therefore abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision to launch an automated exchange of DNA data with Denmark. The goal consists of facilitating cross-border cooperation especially with regard to the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. I believe this decision will also strengthen the cross-border law-enforcement cooperation in the EU.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The transmission of personal data may take place only after the implementation of the provisions relating to data protection which are found in the provision of the national legislation of the territories of the Member States concerned with the transmission. This provision does not apply to Member States where the transmission of personal data has already started under the Prüm Treaty (2005). The verification of whether the conditions for automated data exchange are met should be conducted on the basis of an evaluation report, which includes a questionnaire developed by the Council working group on automated data exchange, an evaluation visit and a test pilot. Denmark completed the data protection questionnaire and the DNA data exchange questionnaire and successfully carried out a pilot experience with the Netherlands. In addition, an evaluation visit to Denmark took place. Therefore, it is agreed that the conditions allowing the Council to conclude that Denmark has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection have been met. The European Parliament approves the Council's plan to start the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report foresees the launch of the automated data exchange relating to DNA data with Denmark.This transmission of personal data can only be considered after the implementation of the general provisions on data protection in the national law of the Member State concerned.However, on July 12, 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark fulfilled the necessary conditions to transmit and receive this personal data.Nevertheless, we express the greatest reservations about the automated exchange of DNA data with the other Member States of the European Union.This is the reason why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of the report on the automated exchange of data on DNA data in Denmark because I believe that an automatic change of data is needed to avoid the bureaucracy that currently exists in the exchange, but especially to reduce the time to change. Article 39 (1) of the Treaty on European Union, presented to the Commission in its current form after the amendment of the Treaty of Amsterdam, and Article 9 of Protocol No. 36 on transitional provisions, but last but not least and the Council Decision provide for enhanced cross-border cooperation , especially in the field of counter-terrorism and forensics. The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs shall inform Parliament of its intentions if it departs from the approved text or if it intends to make substantial changes to the Commission proposal.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report because I believe that, for the purposes of the automated exchange of DNA data, Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. In the light of Article 20 of the aforementioned decision, the evaluation report must be carried out on the basis of a questionnaire. As regards the automated data exchange, in accordance with Chapter 2 of the Decision, the evaluation report must also be based on an evaluation visit and a pilot experience. The questionnaire concerns each of the automated data exchanges and must be completed by the Member State when it is considered that the preconditions for data exchange in the relevant category can be fulfilled. Denmark completed the data protection questionnaire and the DNA data exchange questionnaire. Denmark submitted the declaration on national DNA analysis files in accordance with Article 2 (3) of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Denmark has successfully carried out a pilot experience with the Netherlands. In fact, an evaluation visit took place in Denmark and a report was drawn up on it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. This implementing Council decision follows from the 2008 Prüm Decision on the stepping up of cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The supply of personal data provided for under that Decision may not take place until the general provisions on data protection set out in that Decision. These include: (i) an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, (ii) an evaluation visit and (iii) a pilot run. Denmark has met these conditions. These two Council implementing Decisions authorise the automated exchange of DNA and dactyloscopic (fingerprints) data to and from Denmark. Sinn Fein has always voted against Prüm and its implementing decisions as it is based on a unilateral repressive and surveillance-based approach.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non-legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report which sets out the launch of automated data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark as a way of stepping up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- This consultation decision authorizes Denmark to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA for the purpose of automated consultation and comparison of DNA data.As part of Decision 2008/615 / JHA on enhancing cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and transnational crime, the transmission of personal data under Decision 2008/615 can only be implemented after implementation into national lawon the territory of the Member States concerned by the transmission of the general data protection provisions referred to in this Decision.On the basis of the general assessment report, the Council concluded on 12 July 2016 that Denmark has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection.My vote was in favor.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing.- In the framework of the Prüm Treaty, the member countries have committed themselves to strengthening cross-border cooperation in the field of judicial investigations and crime prevention.The agreement introduces the automated exchange of DNA data in order to help combat terrorism and organized crime, issues that represent one of the priorities of the Union's action in the field of security.I considered to vote in favor of the proposal granting Denmark access to such data through an automated search process in the light of the results achieved in the pilot project carried out in the country and the positive assessment received by the European Commission regarding data protection inDenmark.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the report and believe that, for the purposes of automated DNA data retrieval, Denmark should have the right to receive and provide personal data.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The report on the draft Council Implementing Decision on the launch of automated DNA data exchange in Denmark is part of an effort to intensify cooperation between states and agencies in the fight against crime and beyond.I think that, although the initial thought is positive, we must be very careful when it comes to processing and recording personal data.As this is not the case with this report, I decided to vote against it.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing.- Positive opinion for this report which effectively pursues the enhancement of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and crime.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - I can only praise a measure aimed at strengthening cross-border cooperation: today, more than ever, it is unthinkable not to include the fight against terrorism among the EU's priorities through the closest possible collaboration between states. In light of the attacks of the last year, we have been able to ascertain the weakness of the dialogue between the national authorities and, therefore, the need to create an unstoppable flow of information between them to prevent very deep wounds. Through this provision, therefore, we are witnessing the addition of a piece to the Treaty of Prüm, signed in 2005 and which Italy joined in 2009. Indeed, the improvements made to the exchange of data and their specificity do not only allow for better identification of potential threats, but they allow to extinguish unsolved cases, or to give a name to unidentified victims. Having established this, it emerges that the transmission of the data is necessary, provided that it is at the same time proportionate and based on particular circumstances that give reason to think that crimes will be committed. Far be it from us to make choices that can somehow limit the freedom of citizens. Finally, I would like to recall here how the National DNA database began to function actively in Italy last June.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Decision no. 2008/615 / JHA on deepening cross-border cooperation substantially incorporates the Prüm Treaty into the Community legal order, maintaining the objective of encouraging greater cooperation between the security forces of the Member States, especially through greater exchange of information. As I have said several times, this exchange of information is essential in the field of security, as well as a requirement for a result of greater mutual trust. Therefore, certain requirements must be respected, namely the principles of necessity and proportionality and respect for fundamental rights. Thus, in order for automated DNA data exchange to take place, each Member State must ensure that data protection standards are implemented. This Council decision rightly authorizes the start of the automated exchange, since Denmark has proceeded with its correct implementation.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report because Denmark has successfully completed the implementation process of the general rules on data protection contained in chapter VI of decision 2008/615 / JHA, has proceeded to demonstrate that the conditions contained in the aforementioned chapter are respected in thescope of automatic data exchange, as foreseen in Chapter II of the decision, and obtained the authorization of the Council on the automatic exchange of DNA data to provide and receive personal data in accordance with Articles 3 and 4 of Decision 2008/615 /GAI.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against all these data exchange mechanisms, due to the absence of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the intention is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Consequently, my vote of rejection.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- Cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the EU, in particular in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal migration, is an essential element in fostering the implementation of the European agenda on security.Therefore, I welcomed the Council decision on starting the automated DNA data exchange in Denmark.The cross-border comparison of data should open a new dimension in the fight against crime and offer Member States new approaches to investigations, enabling them to play a crucial role in assisting their law enforcement authorities.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the report on automated data exchange for DNA data in Denmark because of its detailed as well as technical nature.The aim of the report is to ensure security in Europe as automated exchanges are intended to help in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.So important in this regard is the fact that Denmark will share DNA code data with the Schengen countries, so I voted in favor.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of implementing Council Decision 2008/615/JHA 2007/0804(CNS) with regards to automated data exchange based on DNA data in Denmark.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text for the automated exchange of data relating to DNA data in Denmark.In order to strengthen European cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, the exchange of these DNA data is an important source of information.However, this must obviously be done in strict compliance with the provisions relating to the protection of personal data.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - The transmission of personal data can only take place after the implementation of the general provisions relating to data protection in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission. The verification must be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, which obtained the necessary answers, on an evaluation visit, which took place in Denmark and on a pilot test, the latter having took place with the Netherlands. On 12 July 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark had fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Therefore, for the purpose of automated DNA data consultation, Denmark should be allowed to receive and transmit personal data. We have the greatest reservations about exchanging DNA data of French citizens in a European Union system, nevertheless we do not wish to cast a vote which could be considered hostile to Denmark as a state. Also, I abstained on this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- The act demonstrates that commitments in the field of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other.The agreement does not really reinforce the risk-based approach, nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default.

name: Édouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention: we have the greatest reservations about exchanging DNA data of French citizens in an EU system, but we do not want to cast a vote that could be considered hostile to Denmark.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Following the entry into force of the Treaty (signed between Belgium, Germany, Spain, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Austria) on deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism , cross-border crime and illegal migration - the so-called “Prüm Treaty” - a Decision (2008/615 / Council JHA) was approved in 2008 with the aim of incorporating the content of the Prüm Treaty into the EU legal framework . The report on the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark is part of this framework and the serious security measures that have been implemented under the so-called "fight against terrorism", posing serious risks to rights, freedoms and citizens' guarantees. At issue is the deepening of the framework for police cooperation, joint operations, mutual assistance and even the possibility of police services from one Member State in the territory of another, as well as the exchange of a vast range information, including personal data. We proposed amendments - rejected by the majority - that aimed to prohibit the processing of personal data that reveal racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, party or union affiliation or relating to health or sex life. We voted against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the automated exchange of DNA data for those moving within the Schengen area in Denmark.I believe this to be a very important step in cooperation between Member States to fight international crime and terrorism, ensuring acceleration and greater security in the use of data between countries.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- In this particular case, it is another of the many elements for increasing the security of the citizens of the European Union by introducing an automated exchange of DNA data with Denmark.However, there will be no exchange of any confidential private information about individual citizens, as the LIBE Committee has remembered that their right to privacy should be protected.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report with a view to strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- The act demonstrates that commitments in the field of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other.The agreement does not really reinforce the risk-based approach nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default.For these reasons I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft Council implementing Decision aims to authorise Denmark to receive and supply personal data for the purposes of automated searching of dactyloscopic (fingerprint) data under the Prüm Treaty. Denmark has run a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the data protection provisions, and the Commission has evaluated the results and found Denmark ready to take part in Prüm. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, convinced of the need to continue advancing in deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, and the automated data exchange agreement regarding dataDNA in Denmark represents a step in this direction.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council Implementing Decision on starting the automated DNA data exchange in Denmark as the last bureaucratic step, so that Denmark also becomes part of Decision 2008/615 / JHA of the Council on enhancing cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. This decision by the Council is even more felt today, given the well-known need to increase collaboration between the investigative authorities of the Member States in the fight against terrorism. From this point of view, the Council's implementing decision completes a long procedural process, aimed at assessing the compliance of Danish rules and procedures with data protection rules, and which involved a questionnaire, an on-the-spot verification and finally a pilot project. It is essential that all EU countries cooperate with each other in the exchange of information and data, the only real weapon in the fight against terrorism. The exchange of DNA data is an important tool for identifying potential criminals using false documents and a very effective weapon against the problem of forgery of identification documents.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Council's draft implementing decision on the start of the automated exchange of DNA data with Denmark, because I consider the exchange of DNA materials and other modern search techniques to be essential, particularly when it comes to combating international crime.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- I support the automated exchange of DNA data with Denmark as it strengthens the cross-border cooperation of law enforcement authorities in the EU.We must use all means at our disposal effectively to fight cross-border crime quickly and efficiently.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this consultation allowing Denmark to take part in Prüm, for the purpose of automated searching and comparison of DNA data.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the contracting parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has fulfilled, according to the Council, the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE in relation to the Prüm Decision, we have voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control, and it deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of the report. Denmark has run a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the data protection provisions, the Commission has evaluated the results and found Denmark ready to take part in Prüm.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The Council stated that Denmark answered to the questionnaire prepared by the Council Working group regarding data protection and on DNA data exchange issues. After the evaluation report by the Council as well as the evaluation of Denmark’s systems on data protection and DNA data exchange, it came to the conclusion that Denmark is granted the access on DNA data exchange.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Council decision seems to prove that Denmark has a decent data security system and therefore authorizes the exchange of personal data (in this case, DNA data) to and from Denmark. Our group generally has a negative attitude towards the Prüm decision and its executive decisions, as they are based on a unilateral repressive approach and the belief that the collection of more and more data is good policing. For these reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Council Implementing decision to launch the automated data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark. According to Decision 2008/615/JHA on the stepping up of cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, the supply of personal data provided for under that Decision may not take place until the general provisions on data protection set out in that Decision are adhered to. Council Decision 2008/616/JHA on the implementation of Decision 2008/615/JHA confirms that the above condition has been met with respect to automated data exchange on the basis of: (i) an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, (ii) an evaluation visit and (iii) a pilot run. Denmark completed the questionnaire on data protection and the questionnaire on DNA data exchange. A successful pilot run was carried out by Denmark with the Netherlands. An evaluation visit also took place in Denmark. An overall evaluation report was presented in which the Council concluded, on 12 July 2016, that Denmark had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection. This implementing Decision aims to authorise Denmark to receive and supply personal data pursuant to Decision 2008/615/JHA as from the date of the entry into force of this Decision.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections against it.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the Council's proposal to set up an automated data exchange relating to DNA data in Denmark as part of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organized crime.I am convinced that enhanced cooperation between national law enforcement authorities is essential to combat these phenomena which are spreading beyond national borders and which threaten the integrity of our territories.Above all, I reiterate my call for the immediate implementation of the Prüm decision by all signatory states which allows the exchange of DNA data, fingerprints and vehicle registration plates.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The initiative authorises Denmark to receive and supply personal data for the purposes of automated searching and comparison of DNA data under the Prüm Treaty, which establishes a legal framework to further develop cooperation among Member States in combating terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. Denmark has fulfilled all the data protection provisions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Draft Implementing Decision of the Council on the launch of automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark, as this adopts the Draft Council.The exchange of information is of particular importance, especially when it comes to cross-border cooperation in combating terrorism and crime.Automated data exchange between EU Member States leads to stronger Union action in this area.However, I believe that it is necessary to take special care of the protection of personal data and the protection of the rights of each individual.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- Basically, I am opposed to the disclosure of DNA data of French citizens within a European system.On the form, I would regret if a negative vote is interpreted as a sign of mistrust by the Danish people.So, I abstained.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Launching of automated data exchange with regard to DNA in Denmark will contribute to more effective monitoring of movements within the European Union. It will authorise the state to receive and supply personal data and thus to help to prevent cross-border crime. With respect to current migration crisis and combating terrorism, I voted in favour of stepping up strengthening of EU’s cross-border cooperation and achieving better control over European Union’s territory.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Claude Moraes authorizing the exchange of DNA data in Denmark.In order to strengthen the effectiveness of cross-border cooperation, in particular in the case of the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, this authorization was necessary.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I am voting for the report.The transfer of DNA data in the investigation and fight against crime and terrorism is absolutely desirable and cooperation in this area should be strengthened.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Denmark has run a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the data protection provisions, the Commission has evaluated the results and found Denmark ready to take part in Prüm.

name: Stelios Kouloglou
text: (GUE/NGL), in writing. ‒ This report is aimed at strengthening unilateral repressive practice set up by Prüm Convention, consistently opposed by my political group. I voted against since the quantity of data does not necessarily make policy implementation better.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - I supported the report on automated data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark, as the country has fully complied with the general data protection provisions, from which it should have the right to receive and provide personal data. I believe that automated exchanges will support cross-border cooperation, increase the security and protection of citizens and support security structures in the fight against cross-border crime, in particular those who pose a threat to national security, those who engage in illegal activities and misuse of personal data.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the 2016 draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark. The decision is in line with previous Council decisions on the intensification of cross-border cooperation in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. It also takes into account the previous resolution of 10 October 2013 on enhancing law enforcement cooperation in the EU and the 2015 resolutions of the European Parliament on the European Security Agenda. Cooperation in the field of biometric data exchange fits well with projects and commenced implementation processes in the field of smart borders and strengthens the possibilities of control in the era of criminal activities facilitated by the development of technology, consisting in counterfeiting documents. Effective control of people traveling in the euro area free of borders is, in turn, important from the perspective of the need to preserve the most important freedoms and values ​​of the European Union, which include the freedom to travel and work in teams of different nationalities and cultures.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, brutal terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels showed that the EU has not been prepared to prevent the growing threat of cross border terrorism and crime. Therefore, in the aftermath of the attacks the EU has been actively trying to boost cross-border cooperation between its Member States. In this regard, it is very important to improve exchange of information and intelligence between law enforcement authorities of the Member States of the European Union for the purpose of detecting and investigating terrorism and terrorist activities. I warmly welcome automated data exchange with Denmark because this represents another step in combating cross-border terrorism and crime.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - With regard to the report on the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark, it must be premised that the transmission of personal data can only take place following the implementation of the provisions relating to the protection of the same provided for by the national legislation of the territories of the Member States concerned with the transmission . In accordance with Article 20 of Decision 2008/616 / JHA, the verification of compliance with the above conditions must take place on the basis of an assessment report based on a questionnaire. This questionnaire must be drawn up by a competent group of the Council and must concern each of the automated data exchanges, which in turn will be completed by a Member State as soon as it considers that all the preconditions for the exchange of data are met. On the basis of the above directives, the Council concluded that, for the purpose of the automated exchange of DNA data, Denmark has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection, and therefore Parliament approves the Council draft. Therefore, for these reasons, I support this report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on the automated exchange of data relating to DNA data in Denmark.The report finds that this country meets the criteria for data protection, on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test.I have the greatest reservations about the exchange of DNA data of French citizens in a European Union system, but I do not want to cast a vote that could be considered hostile to Denmark.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing.- This draft decision provides for allowing the transmission of personal data, after implementation in the national law of the States concerned.These provisions are monitored on the basis of a report based on a questionnaire, an assessment visit and a pilot test.In this case, Denmark responded to the questionnaire on data protection and DNA data exchange, a pilot test was carried out with the Netherlands and an evaluation visit took place.The Council therefore concluded that Denmark had met the requirements set.However, being very reserved on the exchange of DNA and personal data in an EU system, especially for French citizens, I abstained in order not to cast a vote which could have been interpreted as hostile to Denmark.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report approving the Council's draft on the establishment of an automated data exchange in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism, in this case with DNA in Denmark.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against this data exchange mechanism, due to the absence of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the aim is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Consequently, my vote of rejection.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written.- In the present draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council Implementing Decision on the establishment of automated data exchange regarding DNA data in Denmark, the Council draft is approved and the Council is requested toinform and consult about any changes made to the text.The aforementioned text, alluding to the fact that the Council has concluded that Denmark has implemented the general provisions on data protection, authorizes Denmark to receive and transmit personal data for the purposes of automated consultation and comparison of data from theDNA.I vote in favor because cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime will be strengthened by this measure.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I have refrained because I want to leave it to Denmark to provide and receive DNA data from other countries, or to store this data in connection with criminal investigations.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the proposal to launch the automated data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark. Denmark had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection. I fully support this suggestion.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision on the introduction of automated DNA data exchange in Denmark because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained for this text.The objective of this text is the agreement of the European Parliament on the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark.In reality, it is DNA data of citizens of Member States.This report therefore directly affects the data security of French citizens.This is the reason why we have expressed strong reservations.It should be noted, however, that Denmark has carried out a positive pilot test with the Netherlands, which leads us, in addition to the diplomatic relations with Denmark, to abstain.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark. With the rise of terrorism and automated data exchange taking place over the last years in continental Europe, will be useful to have a database exchange, assisting in identifying potential dangerous people.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This draft implementing decision deals with the exchange of DNA data in the investigation and fight against crime.This data is also used to combat terrorism.Denmark has fully implemented all necessary data protection regulations.I therefore agree to this draft implementing decision.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I support the decision to give Denmark access to the EU database currently being set up, which automatically exchanges DNA data.The accession of Denmark will improve the work of law enforcement authorities in investigating and preventing crime, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.2015Within the framework of this project, Lithuania exchanges the available DNA data with 13 EU Member States.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This is to allow Denmark to receive and transmit the personal data of citizens, in this case DNA data, from its police files with those of other Member States. The legislation in force certainly includes a point on data protection and the limits of its use, but the flaws in these laws are known. In France, the CNIL is also worried. Above all, this file is part of a general tendency to record both delinquents and European citizens and migrants. These data contained, for example, on biometric passports are subsequently crossed with other files to determine “profiles” of each citizen. A Big Brother supposedly to fight terrorism, an argument Snowden has largely demonstrated to be ineffective. Above all, it is a means of increasing the amount of data on citizens and making them available to the United States. While despite the spy revelations the EU offers no guarantees. I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing.- This draft decision provides for allowing the transmission of personal data, after implementation in the national law of the States concerned.These provisions are monitored on the basis of a report based on a questionnaire, an assessment visit and a pilot test.In this case, Denmark responded to the questionnaire on data protection and DNA data exchange, a pilot test was carried out with the Netherlands and an evaluation visit took place.The Council therefore concluded that Denmark had met the requirements set.However, being very reserved about the exchange of DNA and personal data in an EU system, especially for French citizens, I abstained in order not to cast a vote which could have been interpreted as hostile to Denmark.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- This report is very important for strengthening cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the EU.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because I believe Member States’ individual law enforcement authorities require all the tools possible in order to increase the exchange of information and combat crime.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing.- In the context of the fight against terrorism, the exchange of information is a necessity.It is therefore with conviction that I welcome the adoption of this dossier, which aims to establish the automated exchange of data in terms of DNA data with Denmark.Since the guarantees in terms of data protection are sufficient, States must now collaborate more.The information available in one State can sometimes be a centerpiece in the investigation taking place in another Member State.Such an agreement today with Denmark can therefore only be welcomed.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Council has drawn up a draft implementing decision on the launch of an automated exchange of DNA data with Denmark.Under the Treaty on European Union, the Council is required to consult Parliament before adopting a draft.The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament approve the Council's draft.I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- We have the greatest reservations about the exchange of DNA data of French citizens in a Union system, even if there is no reason to suspect Denmark of misuse.It is best to abstain.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing.- I advocate further cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime.In this sense, the automatic exchange of DNA data in Denmark is essential.I believe that this decision is an important step in cross-border collaboration.Therefore, the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark has my vote in favor.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- Denmark carried out a successful pilot test with the Netherlands on the exchange of personal data.An evaluation visit took place in Denmark and then the Dutch evaluation team drew up a report which they forwarded to the relevant Council working group.However, we have the greatest reservations regarding the exchange of DNA data of French citizens in an EU system.This is the reason why I abstained.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this legislative resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark.By approving the Council's draft, the European Parliament authorizes Denmark to receive and transmit DNA data with its partners in order to fight terrorism and cross-border crime more effectively.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing.- I expressed my support for the provision on the draft Council Implementing Decision concerning the launch in Denmark of the automated exchange of DNA data with the aim of facilitating its circulation but still guaranteeing its security for the protection of citizens.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing.- In today's vote, two data exchange agreements also received the green light.I welcome the automated exchange of dactyloscopic as well as DNA data with Denmark.I consider it essential that there be a rapid and efficient exchange of data between the Member States of the European Union.In the fight against terrorism and other organized crime groups, we can only count on each other.Cooperation should start with the sharing of information between law enforcement agencies.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report concerning the launch of automated data exchange with regard to DNA in Denmark that will improve cross-border law enforcement cooperation in combating terrorism.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that the transmission of DNA data (genetic information, genes) is very important in investigating and combating crime and terrorism.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.The purpose of the decision is to authorize Denmark to obtain and release personal data for DNA searches and comparisons in order to step up the cross-border fight against terrorism and crime.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non-legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- There is no doubt that, with regard to the exchange of sensitive data, problems arise regarding the security of information and the protection of the persons directly concerned.However, it must be considered that an automated exchange, where correctly carried out, would allow to facilitate and facilitate the circulation of sensitive information as in the case submitted to us.Therefore, I thought it appropriate to express myself positively.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I agree that Denmark is empowered by the Council to receive and send personal DNA data under Decision 2008/615 / JHA. The report clearly shows that it has fulfilled all the preconditions to confirm the fulfillment of the general security requirements for the protection of this same data through a questionnaire-based evaluation report, an evaluation visit and an initial experiment in which it exchanged data with the Netherlands. The possibility of automated exchange of personal DNA data is very important in various processes, especially criminal ones, so that through this data it is easier to find and identify wanted persons and is therefore crucial in strengthening security throughout the European Union. Denmark can thus get involved in the European, but also the global fight against crime, which is the task of all member states in the European Union. If we take into account the current migrant crisis and the still poorly controlled arrival of migrants in Europe, such and similar security measures are extremely important in order to preserve the security of European citizens and identify criminals.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing.- I have the greatest reservations regarding the exchange of personal data of French citizens in an EU system, but Denmark has taken a number of precautions on the subject and I respect this democratic country.Under these conditions, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written.- The intention of the draft implementing decision of the Council is the authorization of Denmark in receiving and submitting personal data for the purpose of automated search and comparison of DNA data, as defined in the Prüm Agreement.Denmark has implemented a successful pilot project and fulfilled all data protection measures.The Commission assessed that Denmark was ready to take on commitments from Prüm.I accept the Council's Draft and call on the Council to consult Parliament again if it intends to amend the text adopted by Parliament substantially.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The present report is part of the serious security measures that have been implemented under the so-called "fight against terrorism", constituting an attack on the rights, freedoms and guarantees of citizens. At issue is the deepening of the framework for police cooperation, joint operations, mutual assistance and even the possibility of police services from one Member State in the territory of another, as well as the exchange of a vast range information, including personal data. In due course, we tabled amendments that stated that "the processing of personal data that reveals racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs or party or union affiliation or that are related to health or sexual life will be prohibited ", a proposal that the majority of the EP refused. Consistent with the positions already taken in the past on this issue, and because we believe that this mechanism compromises citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees - the “fight against terrorism” and crime begins in combating the causes, and in these the EU has responsibilities that are not recognized here - we voted against.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft Council implementing Decision aims to authorise Denmark to receive and supply personal data for the purposes of automated searching and comparison of DNA data under the Prüm Treaty. I am happy to announce that Denmark has run a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the data protection provisions, Commission has evaluated the results and found Denmark ready to take part in Prüm. With the successful pilot and no controversial issues within Parliament, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- This report validates the proposed implementing decision for the transmission of DNA data from and to Denmark.This is a major step in the fight against crime, and specifically terrorism.I support this decision.I will remain attentive so that all means are implemented to strengthen our cooperation in police and judicial matters.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non-legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor, as I consider all forms of intra- and inter-EU cooperation to be positive, especially in matters of security and combating terrorism, as long as the fundamental rights of citizens are respected.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing.- Only Denmark is authorized to receive and transmit personal data (DNA) pursuant to Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA from the date of entry into force of this Decision.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - In accordance with Article 25 (2) of Decision 2008/615 / JHA, the transmission of personal data pursuant to said Decision may only be initiated when, in the territory of the Member States participating in said transmission, there have been The general provisions on data protection established in Chapter 6 of said Decision have been incorporated into domestic law. On 29 July 2015, the Council concluded that Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Therefore, for the purposes of automated consultation of DNA data, Denmark should be enabled to receive and transmit personal data pursuant to Article 9 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. I have therefore voted favorably on this report necessary to approve the exchange of DNA-related data with Denmark, in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange relating to DNA data in Denmark.In the context of the fight against terrorism, such an exchange is essential.Denmark having fully implemented Directive 2008/615 / JHA which contains in particular the conditions to be fulfilled relating to data protection, we can ensure that these exchanges will respect all the European rules in force.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- The agreement on the automatic exchange of DNA data is an important tool that can help in the fight against crime and terrorism.At the same time, I would like to emphasize the importance of ensuring that such tools, which in the long run can create personal databases for all EU citizens, do not become a mechanism of universal control or be used for purposes incompatible with human rights and freedoms.The current draft agreement gives rise to the expectation that this will not be the case, but at the same time I would like to call on the European Parliament to ensure that the legislation under consideration and the mechanism it creates are used only for primary purposes, the fight against crime and terrorism.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's report on the draft Council decision, whose main objective is to initiate data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark. This draft Council Implementing Decision aims, for the purpose of automated consultation and comparison of DNA data, to authorize Denmark to receive and transmit personal data pursuant to Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA on furthering cross-border cooperation, in particular with regard to combating terrorism and cross-border crime, as from the date of entry into force of this Decision. Taking into account the global assessment report, in which the Council concluded that Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions that are provided for in the said Decision and that it complied with the other conditions provided for therein, there are no reasons that preclude approval. this report, so I voted in favor.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the contracting parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has fulfilled, according to the Council, the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE in relation to the Prüm Decision, we have voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control, and it deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against all these data exchange mechanisms, due to the absence of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the intention is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Consequently, my vote of rejection.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the proposal for a Council decision authorizing Denmark for the automated exchange of DNA data in the area of cross-border cooperation, considering it to be an important tool for combating terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution, which endorses the Council's proposal to launch an automatic exchange of DNA data with Denmark.Approval of this proposal will help strengthen cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the EU, so I support allowing the automatic receipt and provision, retrieval and comparison of DNA data in Denmark.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing.- I supported the launch of an automated exchange of DNA data between the EU and Denmark, as this measure will contribute to greater internal security in the Union.This Council implementing decision is linked to our ongoing efforts to increase cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.The decision taken so far by the EU in this case did not allow for the exchange of this sensitive personal data with Denmark.In order to be able to introduce this procedure also in relation to Denmark, it was necessary for the country to meet several conditions.According to the report, Denmark fulfilled these conditions, developed a questionnaire on the exchange of DNA data and carried out a pilot test of this system in cooperation with the Netherlands.As Denmark has fully implemented the measure, I do not see any obstacles to putting this implementing decision into practice.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- The European Parliament was recently informed about the automatic exchange of data related to DNA data in Denmark.In accordance with the second paragraph of Article 25 of Council Decision no.2008/615 / JHA of 23 June 2008 on the promotion of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the Council must decide unanimously whether the conditions relating to data protection are met.The European Parliament has in the past opposed such an approach (in case C-116/15 Parliament v. The Council before the Court of Justice), arguing that Parliament should give its opinion on the matter.The EU Court of Justice has ruled that the Council must obtain Parliament's consent in any such case.As early as 2008, the Greens / EES group insisted on the inclusion of data protection standards in Council decisions and in consultation with Parliament.Given that all the prescribed data exchange standards are met in this case, I supported the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The exchange of data between the police and security services of the Member States will contribute to the faster detection of criminals and will also make it possible to combat terrorism more effectively and to control the movement of suspects.However, we must be sure that the data collected in this way will not be misused and only authorized persons and institutions will have access to it.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on the “Draft implementing decision of the Council on the start of the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark”.While data exchange may be permissible in a specific case, I consider the automated exchange of data to be dubious.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written.- Effective police cooperation is one of the key elements of the European Union's existence in terms of freedom, security and justice, based on respect for fundamental rights with a view to preventing, detecting and investigating criminal offenses in the European Union.Deepening cross-border cooperation is important in terms of combating terrorism and cross-border crime.Taking into account the Resolution of 10 October 2013 on strengthening cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the European Union, the implementation of the Prüm Decision and the European Information Exchange Model, I support the report on the Council's Draft Implementing Decision on launching automated DNA data exchange in Denmark.for civil liberties, justice and home affairs.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision on the launch of automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark.Denmark will thus be entitled to receive and send personal data for the purposes of automated search and comparison of DNA data.If we want to improve the European Union's action in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, we must deepen cross-border cooperation.Denmark has fulfilled all the conditions, is also implementing the general data protection provisions and has successfully passed an evaluation visit to Denmark.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Council decision seems to prove that Denmark has a decent data security system and therefore authorizes the exchange of personal data (in this case DNA data) to and from Denmark. Our group has serious concerns about the Prüm decision and its executive decisions, as they are based on a unilateral repressive approach and the belief that the collection of more and more data is good policing. For these reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- The act demonstrates that commitments in the field of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other.The agreement does not really reinforce the risk-based approach nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
