text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the adoption of the decision so that the rules on the exchange of DNA data on European law enforcement cooperation can also be applied to Denmark, an EU Member State, as soon as possible.I am convinced that, in the light of new developments in international organized crime and terrorism, the European institutions and the Member States must work more closely and effectively together in this important area for the security of their citizens.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The Schengen Convention ensures the application of the principle of free movement at European Union level, including as regards the citizens of the Member States. However, the application of the Convention's provisions on the movement of persons and nationals of third countries, respectively, can pose a number of problems in ensuring European security. Preventive measures are needed, including the exchange of personal DNA data between Member States. However, the application of that measure must respect the rights and freedoms of citizens which underlie the European project. Denmark's acceptance among the Member States that have adopted these measures is likely to contribute to strengthening European security, especially after the successful completion of the pilot project on data protection. I believe that the adoption of this document is a step towards strengthening the security of European citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text by my eminent colleague Claude Moraes on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of data relating to DNA data in Denmark.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ EU automated data exchange relating to DNA is used to step-up cross border cooperation, particularly in the combat against terrorism and cross-border crime. I voted in favour of the automated data exchange with regard to DNA in Denmark because it will allow for the searching and comparison of DNA data, authorising Denmark to receive and supply personal data from other EU participants. This effort will render Europe better equipped to tackle trans-border crime and terrorism and with better cooperation, will render Europe safer and more competent.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I supported the report on the automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark, which is exclusively of a technical nature.Namely, with the entry into force of the provisions of this report, Denmark will share DNA data with members of the Schengen area.I believe that in this way, significant progress will be made in the fight against terrorism that the European Union is facing, but also in the fight against cross-border crime.In this way, an automated search of DNA profiles and an automated comparison of DNA profiles will be performed.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark.In accordance with Article 36 (2) of Decision 2008/615 / JHA, Denmark has notified the General Secretariat of the Council of the national DNA testing databases to which Articles 2 to 6 of that Decision apply and of the conditions for automated searches referred to in Article 3 (1).) of that Decision.Denmark completed a questionnaire on data protection and a questionnaire on the exchange of DNA data.Denmark has passed a successful test with the Netherlands.An evaluation visit was carried out in Denmark, on which the Dutch evaluation team prepared an evaluation report and sent it to the relevant Council working group.On 12 July 2016, the Council noted that Denmark was fully implementing the general data protection provisions of Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the contracting parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has fulfilled, according to the Council, the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE in relation to the Prüm Decision, we have voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control, and it deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing.- I advocate the virtue of caution on this issue regarding the exchange of DNA data of French citizens in a system set up by the EU.This would mean that Denmark would be allowed to receive and transmit DNA data from French nationals and from its own nationals.It is a matter of principle to protect the DNA information of the citizens we represent.However, Denmark being by no means a politically or geopolitically hostile country, I therefore abstain on this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- Effective combating of terrorism and cross-border crime requires intensified cooperation between the police and judicial authorities of the European Union countries.The launch in Denmark of automated data exchange with regard to DNA data will allow online access to the country's database.In this way, it serves to strengthen law enforcement cooperation and to more effectively detect crimes in the European Union.So I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- It is necessary and important to strengthen cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the Union.That is why I supported it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the contracting parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has fulfilled, according to the Council, the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE in relation to the Prüm Decision, we have voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control, and it deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report following the recommendations of the Committee on Rights and Freedoms.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to DNA data in Denmark. According to Article 25(2) of Decision 2008/615/JHA, the supply of personal data provided for under that Decision may not take place until the general provisions on data protection have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States involved in such supply. The verification that the above condition has been met with respect to automated data exchange is to be done on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot run. An evaluation visit has taken place in Denmark and a report on the evaluation visit has been produced by the Dutch evaluation team and forwarded to the relevant Council Working Group. The Council concluded that Denmark had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection. Therefore, Denmark should be entitled to receive and supply personal data pursuant to Articles 3 and 4 of Decision 2008/615/JHA.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: written.- Through this decision, the European Parliament approves the Commission's proposal to adapt the automated exchange of data regarding DNA data in Denmark, as a result of progress in deepening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorismand cross-border crime as well as the application of the Prüm Decision and the European model for the exchange of information.For this reason, I believe it appropriate to vote in their favor.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against all these data exchange mechanisms, due to the absence of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the aim is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Consequently, my vote of rejection.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- These two reports give approval to the automated exchange of personal data, DNA and fingerprints, which are themselves increasingly recorded automatically in the States parties to the Prüm Treaty.Far from setting up the concerted consultations between responsible authorities on a case-by-case basis, which should be the norm, this is an automated comparison of personal data, without national safeguards.The risk of profiling is therefore increased on the pretext of combating terrorism and cross-border crime.Opposed to the proliferation of data exchanges, especially when they are automated, I vote against these two reports and reaffirm the need to protect the personal data of all those who live on the territory of the EU and the principles of necessityand proportionality

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The reports now in question, on the automated exchange of DNA data and fingerprint data, in Denmark, fall within this framework and the serious security measures that have been implemented under the so-called "fight against terrorism", comprising serious risks to citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees. At issue is the deepening of the framework for police cooperation, joint operations, mutual assistance and even the possibility of action by police services from one Member State in the territory of another, as well as the exchange of a vast body of information. , in particular personal data. In a specialized committee, the PCP proposed that "the processing of personal data that reveal racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs or party or union affiliation or that are related to health or life will be prohibited sexual". In line with the positions already taken in the past on this issue, and because we believe that this mechanism compromises citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees more than it promotes the “fight against terrorism” and crime, we voted against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- In times of threat from international terrorism and transnational crime, an exchange of DNA data within the Union is necessary and useful.An audit based on an assessment report has shown that Denmark has met all the criteria and fully implemented data protection regulations.A successful test run was also carried out with the Netherlands.I therefore approved the decision.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported Mr Moraes's report on the proposal for a Council implementing decision on launching an automated exchange of DNA data with Denmark.It was a technical report aimed in particular at facilitating cooperation with Denmark in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.I think that, in the light of the deteriorating security situation and the recent attacks that have taken place in the European Union, it is very important to join forces and try to prevent prevention as effectively as possible.I believe that the automated exchange of DNA data will help to achieve this goal.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Report on the draft Council Implementing Decision on the launch of automated exchange of DNA data in Denmark, as I support efforts to strengthen cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the EU, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- This consultation decision authorizes Denmark to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA for the purpose of automated consultation and comparison of dactyloscopic data (fingerprints), as part of wider cross-border cooperation tofight against terrorism and transnational crime.This procedure can only take place after the implementation of the general data protection provisions into national law, which Denmark has correctly carried out.For these reasons, I voted in favor.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non—legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against this mechanism for the exchange of fingerprint data, due to the lack of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the aim is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Hence my negative feedback.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report provides for the automated exchange of dactyloscopic (fingerprint) data in Denmark. It calls for the unnecessary collection and sharing of personal data that is highly invasive, expensive and unwarranted in scope and nature. We therefore voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this draft Council implementing decision which aims to allow Denmark to receive and provide personal data for the purposes of automated DNA data search and comparison under the Treatyby Prüm.Denmark has indeed carried out a successful pilot project and complied with all data protection regulations.We therefore believe that Denmark is ready to take part in this treaty.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision to launch the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark, as this is an important step in the cross-border co-operation effort for EU law enforcement.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - The transmission of personal data in the context of the fight against organized crime and terrorism can only take place after the implementation in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general provisions relating to to data protection. Denmark replied to the questionnaire concerning data protection and the one concerning the exchange of fingerprint data. Denmark carried out a pilot test with Germany, which was successful. On 12 July 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Therefore, for the purpose of the automated consultation of fingerprint data, Denmark should be allowed to receive and transmit personal data. Having, with my colleagues from the National Front, the greatest reservations about the exchange of personal data of French citizens in an EU system, but not wanting to cast a vote which could be considered hostile to Denmark, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this technically non-legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report as the exchange of fingerprint data is essential in deepening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and crime.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- This implementation by the Council of the draft Decision aims to allow Denmark to receive and provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615 / JHR through an automated search of dactyloscopic data.This will improve cooperation with other countries in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- This is a report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated data exchange relating to fingerprint data in Denmark.On 12 July 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA.Therefore, for the purpose of the automated consultation of fingerprint data, Denmark should be allowed to receive and transmit personal data.I abstained on this vote in order not to cast a vote which seemed hostile to Denmark.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I approved this report which proposes that Denmark can participate in the exchange of fingerprints within the framework of the Prüm Convention

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: written.- The decision to establish the automated exchange of data regarding fingerprint data in Denmark implies progress in strengthening cross-border cooperation in law enforcement in the Union: the application of the "Prüm Decision" and the ModelEuropean for the Exchange of Information.Therefore I have voted in favor of it.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the Moraes report concerning the launch in Denmark of the automated exchange of fingerprint data.This is an important text, which is being approved at a time when Europe is facing the growing threat of international terrorism.Thanks to it, the procedure for the collection and exchange of information on fingerprints and palmtops and their models stored and processed will be simplified thanks to the use of an automated database.The text represents a crucial step towards strengthening cross-border cooperation in the field of judicial investigations and crime prevention, a positive result also supported by the data protection guarantee in Denmark and the results achieved in the pilot project.The proposal will undoubtedly guarantee a strengthening of the action to combat terrorist activities and those of organized crime.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the Contracting Parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has, according to the Council, fulfilled the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE regarding the Prüm Decision, I voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control and deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- The fight against organized crime - not only against terrorism, but against other phenomena such as trafficking in human beings - requires that we optimize the possibilities that forensic science and criminology offer today.In this area of freedom and security that is Europe, the automatic exchange of fingerprint bank data, which facilitates this objective, is an obligation.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report concerns the automated exchange of data relating to fingerprint data in Denmark. This transmission of personal data in the context of the fight against organized crime and terrorism can only take place after transposition into national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general provisions relating to protection. Datas. As with DNA, the verification of conditions should be carried out on the basis of an assessment report based on a questionnaire, an assessment visit and a pilot test. On July 12, the Council concluded that Denmark had implemented general data protection provisions and that it should therefore be allowed to receive and transmit personal data. Since I have the greatest reservations about exchanging DNA data, I decided to abstain in order not to cast a hostile vote against Denmark.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am convinced that fighting organized crime and terrorism must be one of our priorities.This text is part of those measures aimed at enhancing cross-border cooperation and necessary to allow the police forces to have new and increasingly effective tools at their disposal to combat all forms of crime, which is why I intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - In accordance with Article 25 (2) of Decision 2008/615 / JHA, the transmission of personal data pursuant to said Decision may only be initiated when, in the territory of the Member States participating in said transmission, there have been The general provisions on data protection established in Chapter 6 of said Decision have been incorporated into domestic law. On 29 July 2015, the Council concluded that Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Consequently, for the purposes of automated fingerprint data consultation, Denmark should be enabled to receive and transmit personal data under Article 9 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. That is why I voted favorably on this report necessary to approve the exchange of fingerprint data with Denmark, in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark.The Council Working Party shall draw up a questionnaire for each case of automatic data exchange and, where a Member State considers that it fulfills the conditions for sharing the relevant category of data, it shall reply to the relevant questionnaire.Denmark replied to the questionnaire on data protection and to the questionnaire on the exchange of dactyloscopic data.A general evaluation report summarizing the results of the dactyloscopic data exchange questionnaire, the evaluation visit and the pilot test of the system was submitted to the Council.Thus, in 2016.July 12The Council concluded that Denmark had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection and that Denmark should therefore have the right to receive and supply personal data for the purpose of automated searches of dactyloscopic data.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- As with the previous proposal on the exchange of DNA data, I also supported the exchange of dactyloscopic data, as it seeks to further strengthen cooperation in law enforcement and thus greater security for EU citizens, especially in the field of terrorism and cross-border crime.Fingerprints, like DNA, are unique to each person and thus suitable for effective identification.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this report.The implementing draft Council Decision aims to authorize Denmark to receive and transmit personal data for the purposes of an automated "fingerprint" under the Prüm Treaty.Given that Denmark has launched a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the provisions on personal data protection, I believe that it meets all the conditions for the implementation of this Agreement.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- On this report concerning the automated exchanges of data relating to personal data in Denmark, the principle of protection of the personal data of our fellow citizens seems to me to be essential.Indeed it is the responsibility of the state to protect these sensitive data of citizens.While it is important that targeted exchanges take place in the context of the fight against organized crime and terrorism, this cannot concern all of our fellow citizens.However, I do not want to cast a vote which could be considered hostile to Denmark.I therefore abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this resolution because it allows Denmark to exchange dactyloscopic data with the other EU Member States in order to facilitate cross-border judicial cooperation. I strongly believe this resolution, together with the one on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to DNA data, will improve the EU capacity to tackle terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - Pursuant to Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA, the transmission of personal data can only take place after the implementation of the data protection provisions of Chapter 6 of the Decision into the national law of the territories of the Member States concerned with the transmission . This provision does not apply to Member States where the transmission of personal data has already started under the Prüm Treaty (2005). Verification of compliance with the condition must be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire. The questionnaire drawn up by the competent Council group concerns each of the automated data exchanges and must be completed by a Member State as soon as it considers that it fulfills the preconditions for the data exchange. Denmark completed the data protection questionnaire and the fingerprint data exchange questionnaire and successfully carried out a pilot experience with Germany. An evaluation visit to Denmark also took place. It is agreed that Denmark has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection and therefore the European Parliament approves the Council's draft on the exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report foresees the launch of the automated data exchange relating to fingerprint data with Denmark.This transmission of personal data can only be considered after the implementation of the general provisions on data protection in the national law of the Member State concerned.However, on July 12, 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark fulfilled the necessary conditions to transmit and receive this personal data.Although this transmission of data relating to fingerprint data is part of the fight against organized crime and terrorism, we express the greatest reservations regarding the exchange of personal data with the other Member States of the United States.'European Union.This is the reason why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Article 39 (1) of the Treaty on European Union, presented to the Commission in its current form as amended by the Treaty of Amsterdam, and Article 9 of Protocol No. 36 on transitional provisions, but last but not least and the Council Decision provide for enhanced cooperation especially in the field of counter-terrorism and forensics. The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs shall inform Parliament of its intentions if it departs from the approved text or if it intends to make substantial changes to the Commission proposal. I voted in favor of the report on Automated Data Exchange for fingerprint data in Denmark because I believe that an automatic change of this data is needed to avoid bureaucracy in making exchanges, but especially to reduce exchange time.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the report on the Council's implementation plan for the launch of automated fingerprint data exchange in Denmark. We are talking about fingerprint and handheld images and models of such images that are stored and processed in an automated database. With today's vote, we pledge to strengthen cross-border cooperation between the police and judicial authorities of the countries of the European Union, with the aim of fighting terrorism and cross-border crime more effectively. Denmark successfully completed the questionnaire on automated data exchange, also carrying out a pilot experience with Germany and fully implementing the general data protection provisions set out in Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Therefore, in order to also include Denmark in the system for receiving and transmitting this information and data, I voted in favor of the project.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This implementing Council decisions follow from the 2008 Prüm Decision on the stepping up of cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The supply of personal data provided for under that Decision may not take place until the general provisions on data protection set out in that Decision. These include: (i) an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, (ii) an evaluation visit and (iii) a pilot run. Denmark has met these conditions. These two Council implementing Decisions authorise the automated exchange of DNA and dactyloscopic (fingerprints) data to and from Denmark. Sinn Fein has always voted against Prüm and its implementing decisions as it is based on a unilateral repressive and surveillance-based approach.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report in agreement with the Council position to the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Denmark as a way of improving security in Europe and of stepping up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- This consultation decision authorizes Denmark to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA for the purpose of automated consultation and comparison of fingerprints (fingerprints).As part of Decision 2008/615 / JHA on enhancing cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and transnational crime, the transmission of personal data under Decision 2008/615 can only be implemented after implementation into national lawon the territory of the Member States concerned by the transmission of the general data protection provisions referred to in this Decision.On the basis of the general assessment report, the Council concluded on 12 July 2016 that Denmark has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection.My vote was in favor.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing.- In the framework of the Prüm Treaty, member countries have committed themselves to strengthening cross-border cooperation in the area of judicial investigations and crime prevention.The agreement provides for the automated exchange of fingerprint data, in order to combat terrorism and organized crime, priority issues in the Union's action on security.I considered to vote in favor of the proposal granting Denmark access to fingerprint data through an automated search process in the light of the results achieved in the pilot project carried out in the country and the positive evaluation received by the European Commission on data protection inDenmark.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We agree with the report, as, for the purposes of automated fingerprint search, Denmark is entitled to receive and provide personal data.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the draft Council Implementing Decision to launch the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark is part of an effort to intensify cooperation between States and services in the fight against crime and beyond. I believe that, although the initial thought is positive, we must be very careful when it comes to processing and recording personal data. As this is not the case with this report, I decided to vote against it.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing.- Positive opinion for this report which effectively pursues the strengthening of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and crime.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - I very much welcome the start of the exchange of fingerprint data, indeed it represents a significant step towards a new and incisive page in European security and I hope that the member countries still lacking such measures will speed up their adoption. In the past, the mere idea of ​​automated databases seemed almost science fiction, moreover at a European level. Today, however, these represent everyday tools capable of allowing immediate comparisons and, consequently, of speeding up investigations of considerable complexity. Thanks to a continuous and effective exchange of DNA and fingerprint data between Member State authorities, citizens will be able to feel safer across the Union. I voted in favor of the measure in the hope that through the vision of these extremely pragmatic measures, citizens will understand how the EU is anything but an enemy to fight or an unpunished criminal. It is a harbinger of stable and lasting peace, as well as a source of tangible responses to the needs of citizens, since an easy and quick identification of criminals is not only reflected in the resolution of judicial cases, but also in the prevention of possible terrorist threats.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Denmark and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Decision 2008/615 / JHA on deepening cross-border cooperation substantially incorporates the Prüm Treaty into the Community legal order, maintaining the objective of encouraging greater cooperation between the security forces of the Member States, especially through greater information exchange. As I have said several times, this exchange of information is essential in the field of security, as well as a requirement for a result of greater mutual trust. Therefore, certain requirements must be respected, namely the principles of necessity and proportionality and respect for fundamental rights. Thus, in order for automated data exchange to take place, each Member State must ensure that data protection standards are implemented. This Council decision rightly authorizes the start of the automated exchange, since Denmark has proceeded with its correct implementation.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report because Denmark correctly implemented the general rules on data protection contained in Chapter VI of Decision 2008/615 / JHA and demonstrated that the conditions contained in this chapter are respected in the context of automated exchangedata in accordance with chapter II of the decision, obtaining the authorization to send and receive personal data in the field of automated search of fingerprint data according to Article 9 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against this mechanism for the exchange of fingerprint data, due to the lack of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the intention is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Hence my negative feedback.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- To ensure efficient international cooperation, it is of fundamental importance to be able to exchange accurate information quickly and effectively.Therefore, I welcomed the Council decision on starting the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark.Cross-border comparisons of data should open a new dimension in the fight against crime and offer Member States new approaches to investigations, enabling them to play a crucial role in assisting their law enforcement authorities.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the report on automated data exchange for dactyloscopic data in Denmark because of its specific and technical nature.The aim of the report is very important in the context of ensuring security in Europe, as the exchange covered by the report is intended to improve the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.It is important that Denmark, together with the Schengen countries, will share fingerprint data, so I voted in favor.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of implementing Council Decision 2008/615/JHA 2007/0804(CNS) with regard to dactyloscopic data in Denmark.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the launch of the automated data exchange for fingerprint data, i.e. fingerprints, in Denmark.The exchange of fingerprint data within the European Union is an important instrument in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, in particular for apprehending terrorists and dangerous individuals.However, this exchange must obviously take place in compliance with the rules for the protection of personal data.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - The transmission of personal data can only take place after the implementation of the general provisions relating to data protection in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission. The verification must be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, which obtained the necessary answers, on an evaluation visit, which took place in Denmark and on a pilot test, the latter having took place with Germany. On 12 July 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark had fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Therefore, for the purpose of automated DNA data consultation, Denmark should be allowed to receive and transmit personal data. We have the greatest reservations about the exchange of fingerprint data of French citizens in a European Union system, nevertheless we do not wish to cast a vote which could be considered hostile to Denmark as a state. Also, I abstained on this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- The act demonstrates that commitments in the field of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other.The agreement does not really reinforce the risk-based approach, nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention: we have the greatest reservations about the exchange of DNA data of French citizens in an EU system, but we do not want to issue a vote that could be considered hostile to Denmark.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Following the entry into force of the Treaty (signed between Belgium, Germany, Spain, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Austria) on deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism , cross-border crime and illegal migration - the so-called “Prüm Treaty” - a Decision (2008/615 / Council JHA) was approved in 2008 with the aim of incorporating the content of the Prüm Treaty into the legal framework of the HUH. The report on the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark falls within this framework and the serious security measures that have been implemented under the so-called "fight against terrorism", with serious risks to rights, freedoms and citizens' guarantees. At issue is the deepening of the framework for police cooperation, joint operations, mutual assistance and even the possibility of police services from one Member State in the territory of another, as well as the exchange of a vast range information, including personal data. We proposed amendments - rejected by the majority - that aimed to prohibit the processing of personal data that reveal racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, party or union affiliation or relating to health or sex life. We voted against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of launching in Denmark the automated exchange of data relating to the fingerprints of those who move within the Schengen area.I believe this to be a very important step in cooperation between Member States to fight international crime and terrorism, ensuring acceleration and greater security in the use of data between countries.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- As with the automated exchange of DNA data, Denmark has embarked on this mechanism to increase and improve the exchange of information between Member States, thus helping to increase the security of the citizens of the European Union.There will be no exchange of any confidential private information about individual citizens, as the LIBE Committee has remembered that their right to privacy should be protected.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report with a view to strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- The act demonstrates that commitments in the field of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other.The agreement does not really reinforce the risk-based approach, nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default.For these reasons I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft Council implementing Decision aims to authorise Denmark to receive and supply personal data for the purposes of automated searching of dactyloscopic (fingerprint) data under the Prüm Treaty. Denmark has run a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the data protection provisions, Commission has evaluated the results and found Denmark ready to take part in Prüm. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report, fully convinced of the need to continue advancing in the deepening of cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, because the automated data exchange agreement regarding dataFingerprinting in Denmark represents a positive step in improving the collective security of the EU.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council Implementing Decision on starting the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark as the last bureaucratic step for Denmark to also become part of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. This decision by the Council is even more strongly felt today, given the well-known need to increase collaboration between the investigative authorities of the Member States in the fight against terrorism. From this point of view, the Council's implementing decision completes a long procedural process, aimed at assessing the compliance of Danish rules and procedures with data protection rules, and which involved a questionnaire, an on-the-spot verification and finally a pilot project. It is essential that all EU countries, even those who are furthest from the idea of ​​a federal Europe like Denmark, cooperate with each other in the exchange of information and data, the only real weapon in the fight against terrorism.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the draft implementing decision of the Council on the start of the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data with Denmark, because I consider the use of the most modern technologies to be necessary in the fight against international crime.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- Just like the exchange of DNA data, I support the exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark.Here, too, it is important to fight internationally active crime and international terrorism with all available means.The automated exchange of fingerprints should only be a first step here.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the Contracting Parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has, according to the Council, fulfilled the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE regarding the Prüm Decision, I voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control and deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of the report. Denmark has run a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the data protection provisions, the Commission has evaluated the results and found Denmark ready to take part in Prüm.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. After the revision of results submitted by Denmark for the Council, it was concluded that Denmark fulfilled all necessary criteria and is granted a permission regarding automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Council decision seems to prove that Denmark has a decent data security system and therefore authorizes the exchange of personal data (in this case, fingerprint data) to and from Denmark. Our group generally has a negative attitude towards the Prüm decision and its executive decisions, as they are based on a unilateral repressive approach and the belief that the collection of more and more data is good policing. For these reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Council implementing decision to launch the automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Denmark. According to Decision 2008/615/JHA on the stepping up of cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, the supply of personal data provided for under that Decision may not take place until the general provisions on data protection set out in that Decision. Council Decision 2008/616/JHA on the implementation of Decision 2008/615/JHA confirms that the above conditions have been met with respect to automated data exchange on the basis of: (i) an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, (ii) an evaluation visit and (iii) a pilot run. Denmark completed the questionnaire on data protection and the questionnaire on dactyloscopic data exchange. A successful pilot run has been carried out by Denmark with Germany. An evaluation visit also took place in Denmark. An overall evaluation report was presented in which the Council concluded that Denmark had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection. This draft Council implementing Decision aims, for the purposes of automated searching of dactyloscopic data, to authorise Denmark to receive and supply personal data pursuant to Decision 2008/615/JHA as from the date of the entry into force of this decision.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections against it.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the Council's proposal to set up an automated data exchange relating to fingerprint data in Denmark as part of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organized crime.I am convinced that enhanced cooperation between national law enforcement authorities is essential to combat these phenomena which are spreading beyond national borders and which threaten the integrity of our territories.Above all, I reiterate my call for the immediate implementation of the Prüm decision by all signatory states which allows the exchange of DNA data, fingerprints and vehicle registration plates.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: In written form. - Mr President, I support the proposal for a Council Decision on the launch of automated exchanges of dactyloscopic and DNA data in Denmark, as this will lead to better synergies with regard to the exchange of information. Having said that, I would like to emphasize that I believe that the exchange of information and cooperation are just as important as the collection of data and possible measures to improve the exchange of data must be supported in full respect of existing provisions and case law on protection of personal data.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The initiative authorises Denmark to receive and supply personal data for the purposes of automated searching of dactyloscopic (fingerprint) data under the Prüm Treaty, which establishes a legal framework to further develop cooperation among Member States in combating terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. Denmark has fulfilled all the data protection provisions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the Draft Implementing Decision of the Council on the launch of automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark, as this adopts the Draft Council.I hold that it is certainly necessary to take into account the needs of the individual within the protection of personal data.In this context, automated data exchange contributes to enhanced cross-border cooperation and more effective combating of terrorism and crime, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- Basically, I am opposed to the disclosure of personal data of French citizens within a European system.On the form, I would regret if a negative vote was interpreted as a sign of mistrust by the Danish people.With this in mind, I abstained.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing.- The introduction of automated dactyloscopic data exchange in Denmark entitles the state to collect and use personal data, in this case dactyloscopic.Given the current migration crisis and also in the wake of increased terrorist activity, there is a need to improve cross-border cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and to improve the exchange of information between them.I supported this proposal from the Council, because the enhanced ability to collect and use personal data will help Denmark to make control of its territory more effective, and therefore in the European Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Claude Moraes authorizing the exchange of fingerprints in Denmark.In order to strengthen the effectiveness of cross-border cooperation, in particular in the case of the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, this authorization was necessary.I am delighted that this report was adopted by a large majority.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I am voting for the report.The transfer of fingerprint data in the investigation and fight against crime and terrorism is absolutely desirable and cooperation in this area should be strengthened.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Denmark has run a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the data protection provisions, the Commission has evaluated the results and found Denmark ready to take part in Prüm.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - I supported the report on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Denmark, as the country has fully complied with the general data protection provisions, from which it should have the right to receive and provide personal data. I believe that automated exchanges will support cross-border cooperation, increase the security and protection of citizens and support security structures in the fight against cross-border crime, in particular those who pose a threat to national security, those who engage in illegal activities and misuse of personal data.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the 2016 automated data exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark. Cross-border cooperation in the field of data exchange is a necessary element in ensuring security, combating terrorism and cross-border crime. Especially in a situation of a large influx of people without documents and verified identity to Europe, as well as tens of thousands of people without the right to stay in it, and thus without access to support systems and legal functioning on the market, which exposes them to the influence of the criminal world, it is necessary developing cooperation in the field of data exchange. Responsible and effective control is necessary to undertake adequate security policies in the Member States and to maintain one of the most important values ​​of Europe, which is the free movement of people and cultural diversity

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing.- Denmark, in addition to completing the questionnaire on automated DNA data exchange, has also completed the questionnaire on automated fingerprint data exchange.As for the automated exchange of DNA data, Denmark has complied with the conditions set out and dictated by Article 20 of Decision 2008/616 / JHA, and on the basis of these a comprehensive assessment report has been presented to the Council summarizing theresults of the questionnaire, the evaluation visit and the pilot experience on the exchange of fingerprint data.In light of Denmark's successful work, the Parliament decided to approve the Council draft.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained from the automated exchange of data relating to fingerprint data in Denmark.The report finds that this country meets the criteria for data protection, on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test.I have the greatest reservations about exchanging DNA data of French citizens in a European Union system, but I do not want to cast a vote that could be considered hostile to Denmark.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing.- This draft decision provides for the transmission and exchange of personal data after implementation in the national law of the States concerned.These provisions are monitored on the basis of a questionnaire-based report, an assessment visit and a pilot test.In this case, Denmark responded to the questionnaire on data protection and the exchange of fingerprint data, a pilot test was carried out with Germany and an evaluation visit took place.The Council therefore concluded that Denmark had met the requirements set.However, being very reserved on the exchange of personal data in the EU system, especially for French citizens, I abstained in order not to cast a vote which could have been interpreted as hostile to Denmark.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report approving the Council's draft on the establishment of an automated data exchange in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism, in this case on fingerprint data in Denmark.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against this mechanism for the exchange of fingerprint data, due to the lack of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the intention is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Hence my negative feedback.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written.- This text approves the Council's draft on the establishment of automated data exchange for fingerprint data in Denmark.Thus, the country, always pursuing the purposes of automated consultation of fingerprint data, is authorized to receive and transmit personal data.It should not be forgotten that the Council itself verified that Denmark has implemented all the general provisions regarding data protection.I vote in favor of the motion for a resolution as this measure will help increase cooperation between the Member States in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I have refrained because I want to leave it to Denmark to provide and receive fingerprint data from other states, or to retain this data in connection with criminal investigations.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the proposal to launch the automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Denmark. A successful pilot run has been carried out by Denmark with Germany. I support this proposal.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision initiating the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark because it is incomplete and undocumented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained for this text.This text envisages cooperation between the Member States in the field of the automated exchange of fingerprint data.On 12 July 2016, the Council concluded that Denmark had fully implemented general data protection provisions, and that it should therefore be allowed to receive and transmit personal data from other statesmembers.Indeed, cooperation in the field of the exchange of fingerprint data is necessary to improve the effectiveness of the fight against organized crime and terrorism.Nonetheless, we will have reservations about the exchange of personal data of French citizens in an EU system.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: per iscritto. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Denmark. This proposal is important to enhance cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This draft implementing decision deals with the exchange of dactyloscopic data in the investigation and fight against crime.This data is also used to combat terrorism.Denmark has fully implemented all necessary data protection regulations.I therefore agree to this draft implementing decision.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I support the decision to give Denmark access to the EU database currently being set up, which automatically exchanges dactyloscopic data.The accession of Denmark will improve the work of law enforcement authorities in investigating and preventing crime, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.2015Within the framework of this project, Lithuania is exchanging available dactyloscopic data with 12 EU Member States.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This is to allow Denmark to receive and transmit the personal data of citizens, in this case fingerprint data, from its police files with those of other Member States. The legislation certainly includes a point on data protection and the limits of its use, but the flaws in these laws are known. In France, the CNIL is also concerned about this legislation. Above all, this file is part of a general tendency to record both delinquents and European citizens and migrants. These data contained, for example, on biometric passports are subsequently crossed with other files to determine “profiles” of each citizen. A so-called Big Brother to fight terrorism, an argument Snowden has largely demonstrated to be ineffective. Above all, it is a means of increasing the amount of citizen data to make it available to the United States. I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing.- This draft decision provides for the transmission and exchange of personal data after implementation in the national law of the States concerned.These provisions are monitored on the basis of a questionnaire-based report, an assessment visit and a pilot test.In the present case, Denmark responded to the questionnaire on data protection and the exchange of fingerprint data, a pilot test was carried out with Germany and an evaluation visit took place.The Council therefore concluded that Denmark had met the requirements set.However, being very reserved about the exchange of personal data in the EU system, especially for French citizens, I abstained in order not to cast a vote which could have been interpreted as hostile to Denmark.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- The adoption of this report is very important for deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the area of combating terrorism and cross-border crime.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which allows Denmark to both provide and receive dactyloscopic data for use in criminal investigations as Denmark has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing.- In the context of the fight against terrorism, the exchange of information is a priority.It is therefore with conviction that I welcome the adoption of this dossier, which aims to establish the automated exchange of data with regard to fingerprint data with Denmark.This is data related to a person's fingerprints.Since the guarantees in terms of data protection are sufficient, States must now collaborate more.The information available in one State can sometimes be a centerpiece in the investigation taking place in another Member State.Such an agreement today with Denmark can therefore only be welcomed.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Council has drawn up a draft implementing decision on the launch of an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data with Denmark.Under the Treaty on European Union, the Council is required to consult Parliament before adopting a draft.The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament approve the Council's draft.I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- We have the greatest reservations about exchanging fingerprint data (i.e. fingerprints) of French citizens in a Union system, even though there is no reason to suspectDenmark of misuse.It is best to abstain.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing.- I advocate further cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime.In this sense, the automatic exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark is essential.I believe that this decision is an important step in cross-border collaboration.Therefore, the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark has my vote in favor.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- Denmark replied to the questionnaire concerning data protection and the one concerning the exchange of fingerprint data.Denmark carried out a pilot test with Germany, which was successful.This transmission of personal data in the context of the fight against organized crime and terrorism could make sense.However, we have the greatest reservations regarding the exchange of personal data of French citizens in an EU system;exchange of data which would not necessarily guarantee public freedoms.This is the reason why I abstained.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this legislative resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark.By approving the Council's draft, the European Parliament authorizes Denmark to receive and transmit fingerprint data with its partners in order to fight terrorism and cross-border crime more effectively.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing.- I expressed my support for the provision on the draft Council Implementing Decision concerning the launch in Denmark of the automated exchange of fingerprint data, since it is important to facilitate and improve the circulation of data but at the same time always guarantee and protectinterests of our citizens.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing.- In today's vote, two data exchange agreements also received the green light.I welcome the automated exchange of dactyloscopic as well as DNA data with Denmark.Europe is threatened by threats such as terrorism, cross-border crime, human trafficking and more.Achieving a common goal clearly requires joint action.Denmark has been a member of the European Union for many years and enjoys my full confidence.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report concerning the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic in Denmark that will improve cross-border law enforcement cooperation in combating terrorism.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I also spoke out positively in favor of this report, since the transmission of dactyloscopic data can help in investigating and combating crime and terrorism.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.The aim is to step up the cross-border fight against terrorism and crime.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- With regard to the proposal under consideration, I felt it my duty to express myself in favor.The issues related to the exchange of sensitive data have always been a sensitive issue since it is necessary to find a balance between the protection of the privacy of the persons directly concerned and the improvement of the service in question.If this balance is respected, there will be significant benefits for the community.Therefore, I voted positively.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - The exchange of dactyloscopic data is crucial in strengthening security throughout the European Union. I believe that dactyloscopic data available in national fingerprint databases should be available to all EU Member States for review and search, and that dactyloscopic data should be constantly exchanged between countries, as this would avoid lengthy investigations and searches for perpetrators of certain crimes. Such an exchange would successfully help detect and prevent organized crime, which is more and more present in Europe, and terrorism, which has unfortunately become a global threat. Denmark can thus get involved in the European, but also the global fight against crime, which is the task of all member states in the European Union. If we take into account the current migrant crisis and the still poorly controlled arrival of migrants in Europe, with which come those who pose a security threat to the EU, such and similar measures are extremely important to preserve the security of European citizens and identify criminals and especially possible terrorists.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing.- I have the greatest reservations regarding the exchange of personal data of French citizens in an EU system, but Denmark has taken a number of precautions on the subject and I respect this democratic country.Under these conditions, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written.- The intention is the Draft Implementing Decision of the Council of Authorizations of Denmark for receiving and submitting personal data for the purpose of automated search of dactyloscopic data (fingerprints), as defined in the Prüm Agreement.Denmark has implemented a successful pilot project and fulfilled all data protection measures.The Commission assessed that Denmark was ready to take on commitments from Prüm.I accept the Council's draft and call on the Council to consult Parliament again if it intends to amend the text adopted by Parliament substantially.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The present report is part of the serious security measures that have been implemented under the so-called "fight against terrorism", constituting an attack on the rights, freedoms and guarantees of citizens. At issue is the deepening of the framework for police cooperation, joint operations, mutual assistance and even the possibility of police services from one Member State in the territory of another, as well as the exchange of a vast range information, including personal data. In due course, we tabled amendments that stated that "the processing of personal data that reveals racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs or party or union affiliation or that are related to health or sexual life will be prohibited ", a proposal that the majority of the EP refused. Consistent with the positions already taken in the past on this issue, and because we believe that this mechanism undermines citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees - the “fight against terrorism” and crime begins in combating the causes, and in these the EU has responsibilities that are not recognized here - we voted against.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft Council Implementing Decision aims to authorise Denmark to receive and supply personal data for the purposes of automated searching of dactyloscopic, otherwise known as fingerprint, data under the Prüm Treaty. I am again happy to announce that Denmark has run a successful pilot project and fulfilled all the data protection provisions, and the Commission has evaluated the results and found Denmark ready to take part in Prüm. So, with the successful pilot and no controversial issues within Parliament, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- This report validates the proposed implementing decision for the transmission of fingerprints from and to Denmark.This is a major step in the fight against crime, and specifically terrorism.I support this decision.I will remain attentive so that all means are implemented to strengthen our cooperation in police and judicial matters.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this technically non legislative consultation. UKIP believe that agreements on data exchange should be made on a bilateral basis by sovereign nations.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor, as I consider all forms of intra- and inter-EU cooperation to be positive, especially in terms of security and combating terrorism, as long as the fundamental rights of citizens are respected.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing.- Only Denmark is authorized to receive and transmit personal data (fingerprint) pursuant to Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA from the date of entry into force of this Decision.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - In accordance with Article 25 (2) of Decision 2008/615 / JHA, the transmission of personal data pursuant to said Decision may only be initiated when, in the territory of the Member States participating in said transmission, there have been The general provisions on data protection established in Chapter 6 of said Decision have been incorporated into domestic law. On July 29, 2015, the Council concluded that Denmark has fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. Therefore, for the purposes of automated fingerprint data consultation, Denmark should be empowered to receive and transmit personal data pursuant to Article 9 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA. I have therefore voted favorably on this report necessary to approve the exchange of fingerprint data with Denmark, in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this draft resolution, which concerns the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange relating to fingerprint data in Denmark.This provision fully meets the objective of deepening cross-border cooperation with a view to combating terrorism and cross-border crime contained in Directive 2008/615 / JHA.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- The agreement on the automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data is an important tool that can help in the fight against crime and terrorism.At the same time, I would like to emphasize the importance of ensuring that such tools, which in the long term can create personal databases for all EU citizens, do not become a mechanism of universal control or be used for purposes incompatible with human rights and freedoms.The current draft agreement gives rise to the expectation that this will not be the case, but at the same time I would like to call on the European Parliament to ensure that the legislation in question and the mechanism it creates are used only for primary purposes, the fight against crime and terrorism.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The purpose of this report is to initiate the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Denmark. The European Parliament's role in this matter is non-binding consultation, before the adoption of the act by the Council. Underlying this report is Decision 2008/615 / JHA on deepening cross-border cooperation, especially with regard to combating terrorism and cross-border crime, by providing personal data through this data exchange, based on a report of prior evaluation in the form of a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test. Bearing in mind that Denmark fulfilled these three conditions and that, in the overall assessment report, the Council concluded that this country had fully implemented the general data protection provisions of the above Decision, there are no reasons to prevent approval the Council's decision to authorize Denmark to receive and transmit personal data through the automated exchange of fingerprint data. In view of the above, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the Contracting Parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has fulfilled, according to the Council, the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE regarding the Prüm Decision, I voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control, and it deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against this mechanism for the exchange of fingerprint data, due to the lack of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the intention is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Hence my negative feedback.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the proposal for a Council decision authorizing Denmark for the automated exchange of fingerprint data in the area of cross-border cooperation, considering it to be an important tool for combating terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
