text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution, which approves the Council's proposal to launch an automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data with Denmark.The approval of this proposal will help to strengthen cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the EU, so I support allowing the automatic receipt and provision, retrieval and comparison of dactyloscopic data in Denmark.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing.- I supported the launch of an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data between the EU and Denmark, as this measure is also linked to the automated exchange of DNA data and is intended to contribute to greater internal security in the Union.This Council Implementing Decision follows on from efforts to enhance cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.The decision taken so far by the EU in this case did not allow for the exchange of this sensitive personal data with Denmark.In order to be able to introduce this procedure also in relation to Denmark, it was necessary for the country to meet several conditions.According to the report, Denmark fulfilled these conditions, developed a questionnaire on the exchange of dactyloscopic data and carried out a pilot test of this system in cooperation with Germany.As Denmark has fully implemented the measure, I do not see any obstacles to putting this implementing decision into practice.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- The European Parliament was recently informed about the automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark.In accordance with the second paragraph of Article 25 of Council Decision no.2008/615 / JHA of 23 June 2008 on the promotion of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the Council must decide unanimously whether the conditions relating to data protection are met.The European Parliament has in the past opposed such an approach (in case C-116/15 Parliament v. The Council before the Court of Justice), arguing that Parliament should give an opinion on this.The EU Court of Justice has ruled that the Council must obtain Parliament's consent in any such case.As early as 2008, the Greens / EES Group insisted on the inclusion of data protection standards in council decisions and consultation of Parliament.Given that all the prescribed data exchange standards are met in this case, I supported the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The free movement of persons within the European Union also brings with it cross-border crime.The rapid exchange of data between police services brings about more effective investigation and is one of the factors increasing citizens' confidence in the European project and state institutions.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on the "Draft implementing decision of the Council on the start of the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark".While data exchange may be permissible in a specific case, I consider the automated exchange of data to be dubious.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written.- Effective police cooperation is one of the key elements of the European Union's existence in terms of freedom, security and justice, based on respect for fundamental rights with a view to preventing, detecting and investigating criminal offenses in the European Union.Deepening cross-border cooperation is important in terms of combating terrorism and cross-border crime.Taking into account the Resolution of 10 October 2013 on strengthening cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the European Union, the implementation of the Prüm Decision and the European Information Exchange Model, I support the report on the Council's Draft Implementing Decision on launching automated fingerprinting data exchange in Denmark, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark.Denmark will thus be entitled to receive and send personal data for the purposes of automated retrieval of dactyloscopic data.I welcome the fact that Denmark is fully implementing the general provisions on data protection, which is a particularly sensitive area.Denmark successfully completed the questionnaire, underwent an evaluation visit by a German assessment team and a dactyloscopic data exchange test.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Council decision seems to prove that Denmark has a decent data security system and therefore authorizes the exchange of personal data (in this case, fingerprint data) to and from Denmark. Our group has serious concerns about the Prüm decision and its executive decisions, as they are based on a unilateral repressive approach and the belief that the collection of more and more data is good policing. For these reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- The act demonstrates that commitments in the field of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other.The agreement does not really reinforce the risk-based approach nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the adoption of the decision so that the rules on dactyloscopic data exchange in European law enforcement cooperation can also be applied to Denmark, an EU Member State, as soon as possible.I am convinced that, in the light of new developments in international organized crime and terrorism, the European institutions and the Member States must work more closely and effectively together in this area, which is important for the security of citizens.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The adoption of the Schengen Convention is one of the main achievements of the European integration process. Ensuring free movement at European Union level, including for the citizens of the Member States, is a definite gain. However, the application of the provisions of the Convention on the Movement of Persons, including Third-Country Nationals, can pose a number of problems in ensuring European security. For this reason, preventive measures are needed, including fingerprinting and the exchange of such data between Member States. The application of this measure must respect the civil rights and freedoms that underlie European construction. Denmark's acceptance among the Member States that have adopted these measures is likely to contribute to strengthening European security, including this Nordic country between the parties to the Prüm Convention. For these reasons, I believe that the adoption of the current document is necessary and is a step towards strengthening European security as a whole.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text on the draft Council implementing decision concerning the launch of the automated exchange of data relating to fingerprint data in Denmark, thereby following the recommendations of my colleague Claude Moraes.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the aim of stepping-up cross border cooperation, particularly in the combat against terrorism and cross-border crime, the automated exchange of data, particularly regarding dactyloscopic data is essential. I voted in favour of the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data, or fingerprints in Denmark because it will allow for the searching and comparison of fingerprint data among participating states, authorising Denmark to receive and supply personal data from other EU participants. This effort will render Europe better equipped to tackle trans-border crime and terrorism.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on the launch of an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data between Denmark and the countries belonging to the Schengen area.With the adoption of this Regulation, all countries concerned will have to ensure the availability of reference data from the files of national automated fingerprint recognition systems.I believe that in this way a step forward will be made in the prevention and investigation of criminal offenses.In this way, an automated search for dactyloscopic data will be enabled and it is clearly stated that the reference data should include only dactyloscopic data and a reference number.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark. Article 20 of Council Decision 2008/616 / JHA provides that verification of whether or not the above condition regarding automated data exchange in accordance with Chapter 2 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA is met shall be carried out on the basis of an assessment report based on a questionnaire, evaluation visit and test. Denmark completed a questionnaire on data protection and a questionnaire on the exchange of dactyloscopic data. An evaluation visit was carried out in Denmark, on which the German evaluation team prepared an evaluation report and sent it to the relevant Council working group. A comprehensive evaluation report summarizing the results of the questionnaire, the evaluation visit and the dactyloscopic data exchange test was submitted to the Council. On 12 July 2016, the Council decided that Denmark should fully implement the general data protection provisions of Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615 / JHA.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the Contracting Parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has, according to the Council, fulfilled the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE regarding the Prüm Decision, I voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control and deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report concerns the automated exchange of data relating to personal data in Denmark.The principle of protecting the personal data of our fellow citizens is essential, but it is the responsibility of the State to protect this data.While it is important that targeted exchanges take place in the context of the fight against organized crime and terrorism, this cannot concern all French citizens.However, I do not want to cast a vote which could be considered hostile to Denmark.I therefore choose to abstain.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- Effective combating of terrorism and cross-border crime requires intensified cooperation between the police and judicial authorities of the European Union countries.The start of automated data exchange in Denmark with regard to fingerprint data will allow online access to the country's database.In this way, it serves to strengthen law enforcement cooperation and to more effectively detect crimes in the European Union.I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- It is necessary and important to strengthen cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the Union.That is why I supported it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The Moraes reports refer to the application to Denmark of Council Decision 2008/615 / JHA (Prüm Decision); a legal framework to deepen cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal immigration. More specifically, it provides for the exchange between the Contracting Parties of DNA profiles, fingerprint data, vehicle registration records and personal and non-personal data related to cross-border police cooperation. The purpose of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate the exchange of information between authorities. Denmark has fulfilled, according to the Council, the requirements established to apply this legal framework (evaluation report and visit, and pilot test) to conclude that it fully applies the general provisions on data protection. However, following the criteria of the GUE regarding the Prüm Decision, I voted against it, as it is a treaty that, from the outset, was negotiated and adopted in a non-transparent way and without serious democratic control, and it deepens the conflict in which it is intended to reinforce security to the detriment of freedom.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report following the recommendations of the Committee on Rights and Freedoms.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Denmark. According to Article 25(2) of Council Decision 2008/615/JHA, the supply of personal data provided for under the Decision may not take place until the provisions on data protection set out in Chapter 6 of the Decision have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States involved in such supply. The Council must unanimously decide whether this condition has been met. Denmark has completed the questionnaire on data protection and the questionnaire on dactyloscopic data exchange. I voted in favour because, according to the Council, for the purposes of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data, Denmark has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection of Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: written.- Through this decision, the European Parliament approves the Commission's proposal to adapt the automated exchange of data regarding fingerprint data in Denmark, as a result of progress in deepening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism andcross-border crime, as well as the application of the Prüm Decision and the European model for the exchange of information.For this reason, I believe it appropriate to vote in their favor.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have opposed and voted against this mechanism for the exchange of fingerprint data, due to the lack of effective safeguards that guarantee the fundamental right to privacy in this type of exchange.With this vote, the intention is to incorporate Denmark into a system in which the different security bodies of the Member States exchange citizen data without any type of judicial or political control or transparency, favoring the storage of private data and storingthose of people who have not committed any crime or are suspected of it.Hence my negative feedback.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- These two reports give approval to the automated exchange of personal data, DNA and fingerprints, which are themselves increasingly recorded automatically in the States parties to the Prüm Treaty.Far from setting up the concerted consultations between responsible authorities on a case-by-case basis, which should be the norm, this is an automated comparison of personal data, without national safeguards.The risk of profiling is therefore increased under the pretext of combating terrorism and cross-border crime.Opposed to the proliferation of data exchanges, especially when they are automated, I vote against these two reports and reaffirm the need to protect the personal data of all those who live on the territory of the EU and the principles of necessityand proportionality

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The reports now in question, on the automated exchange of DNA data and fingerprint data, in Denmark, fall within this framework and the serious security measures that have been implemented under the so-called "fight against terrorism", comprising serious risks to citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees. At issue is the deepening of the framework for police cooperation, joint operations, mutual assistance and even the possibility of police services from one Member State in the territory of another, as well as the exchange of a vast range information, including personal data. In a specialized committee, the PCP proposed that "the processing of personal data that reveal racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs or party or union affiliation or that are related to health or life will be prohibited sexual." In line with the positions already taken in the past on this issue, and because we believe that this mechanism compromises citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees more than it promotes the “fight against terrorism” and crime, we voted against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- In times of threat from international terrorism and transnational crime, an exchange of dactyloscopic data (fingerprints) within the Union is necessary and useful.An audit based on an assessment report has shown that Denmark has met all the criteria and fully implemented data protection regulations.A successful test run was also carried out with Germany.I therefore approved the decision.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported Mr Moraes's report on the proposal for a Council implementing decision on launching an automated dactyloscopic data exchange with Denmark.Again, as in the case of the report on the automated exchange of DNA data, this was also a report of a technical nature, aimed in particular at facilitating cooperation with Denmark in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.I think that, in the light of the deteriorating security situation and the recent attacks that have taken place in the European Union, it is very important to join forces and try to prevent prevention as effectively as possible.I believe that the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data will help to achieve this goal.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Report on the draft Council Implementing Decision on the launch of automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Denmark, as I support efforts to deepen cross-border cooperation in law enforcement in the EU, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Chinese citizens must have a visa when traveling to the Schengen area in the same way that EU citizens need a visa to enter China.The agreement establishes visa waiver for all EU citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport who travelin the territory of the counterparty for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180 day period.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this legislative agreement. UKIP do not support the EU making agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the issue of migration.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Regretting that it is a measure that only benefits a minority of people in possession of this type of diplomatic passports, I have voted in favor of this agreement between the Union and China, because we understand that the obstacles that prevent access must always be reducedeffective right to free movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the report providing for the agreement on the exemption from short-stay visas between the EU and China for holders of diplomatic passports, the rapporteur clearly paving the way for full and reciprocal exemption visas for holders of a classic passport. This decision is in no way intended to hamper good relations between our two territories, but it is necessary to raise a problem that France and our European friends have to face: industrial espionage of our flagships, leading to large-scale counterfeiting and increased competition in areas previously reserved. Indeed, China is illustrated in terms of economic espionage: a recent example shows us how at Areva two interns from the Middle Kingdom were able to photocopy thousands of documents, the management only discovering the leak because of 'too much paper consumption. Internationalization is forcing, large groups are employing more and more foreign interns and the government has decided to take advantage of this. Therefore, we should keep a close eye on the comings and goings of our respective compatriots, between the constituent territories of the European Union and that of the People's Republic of China.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This recommendation is to allow a waiver of visas for holders of diplomatic passports from China, allowing them to stay in the EU for short periods without a visa. While these short-term visa waivers can be useful, due to the serious questions raised about China’s human rights record, we voted to abstain. It should be noted that these waivers would only apply to diplomatic passport holders, so they will not affect the ability for the likes of NGOs to travel visa free.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this recommendation.The visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports represents a step forward in establishing a full reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports.The abolition of visas will reduce the waiting time at consulates and the costs associated with travel.It will facilitate people-to-people contacts, an essential condition for the steady development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties, and will intensify people-to-people contacts.In any case, visa liberalization will have to go hand in hand with improvements in human rights and fundamental freedoms in China.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports, because is an important step in the future for the introduction of full and reciprocal visa exemption for holders of common passports, as it brings tangible benefits in various fields, such as the economy, science and culture.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: written.- The Commission drafted a proposal for the Council on December 15, 2015, which it adopted on January 26, 2016.Negotiations began on September 21 of this year and a decision is expected on November 3.This is a visa-free stay in China for all EU citizens who hold a diplomatic passport or a laissez passer of the EU, as well as for citizens from China who hold a valid diplomatic passport and want to travel to European soil.The maximum length of stay without a visa is 90 days within a 180-day period.I support this proposal, since the lifting of the visa requirement will make direct personal contacts easier, which is an essential prerequisite for the steady development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - The proposed decision seeks the approval on behalf of the Union of the agreement between the European Union and China on short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime of up to 90 days in any 180-day period for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or laissez-passer. pass from the Union and in favor of Chinese nationals holding a valid diplomatic passport who are going to the territory of the other contracting party. The rapporteur hopes that the short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports will represent a step towards achieving full and reciprocal visa exemption for holders of conventional passports. We are in full ideological delirium: “It should facilitate contacts between peoples, an essential condition for the regular development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties, and intensify contacts between peoples. "We are not opposed to diplomatic relations, but given the problems of industrial espionage in particular, this is a sensitive matter. I therefore voted against.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against giving consent to this legislative agreement. UKIP do not support the EU making agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the issue of migration.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I decided to vote for this text because it will facilitate contacts between peoples, an essential condition for the regular development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- Given that the EU-China dialogue on migration and mobility is a framework for an exchange of views and cooperation between the two sides,it was agreed to start negotiations on a reciprocal visa-free regime for holders of diplomatic passports.I agree that the abolition of visas will reduce the time spent at consulates and reduce travel costs.It will also create conditions for direct human communication, which is an essential condition for the balanced development of economic, cultural and scientific relations.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this legislative agreement. UKIP do not support the EU making agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the issue of migration.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. - This is a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on visa waiver short stay for holders of a diplomatic passport. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime of up to 90 days in any 180-day period for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or laissez-passer. pass from the Union and in favor of Chinese nationals holding a valid diplomatic passport who are going to the territory of the other contracting party. I voted against this report because if we are not opposed to good diplomatic relations with China, there are too many industrial espionage problems today for us to take any more risks. Moreover, this agreement is part of a crazy policy of all-out visa liberalization, which I condemn with all the more force as we are going through a terrible migratory crisis.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this agreement which provides for a visa-free travel regime of up to 90 days in any 180-day period in favor of Union citizens holding current diplomatic passports.of validity or of a Union laissez-passer and in favor of Chinese nationals holding a valid diplomatic passport who are traveling to the territory of the other contracting party.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: written.- China is one of the countries whose nationals are required to have a visa when traveling to the Schengen area.The Agreement establishes visa exemption for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or Union safe-conduct, as well as for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party., when the stay does not exceed 90 days for each period of 180 days.With this report in which I voted in favor, the Agreement that allows for progress in relations between the two countries is welcomed.In order to guarantee equal treatment, Article 6 of the Agreement states that China may only suspend or denounce the Agreement with respect to all member States of the Union and, in turn, the Union may only suspend or denounce the Agreementwith respect to all Member States.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the Valero report on the EU-Peru agreement on short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. The text establishes an exemption for Union citizens and Chinese citizens who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. It only applies to people in possession of valid diplomatic passports or EU passes, allowing them to reduce their waiting times at consulates and lower travel costs. Although this is a measure that involves only a small group of users, I am convinced that it can pave the way for more intense collaboration in the hope of being able to enter into an agreement in the future that has as its object visa waiver holders of ordinary passports. China is a key economic partner and a global player of growing importance and a strengthening of relations can only be a positive result in view of an increasingly fruitful political dialogue

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor, because we consider that the visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports represents progress towards the establishment of full reciprocity in visa exemption for holders of ordinary passports.The importance of visa liberalization is considerable, given that its benefits are tangible, such as reducing the waiting time before the consulates and the costs associated with travel, facilitating contacts between citizens and favoring the stable development of relationships.Furthermore, this agreement is positive that it also includes holders of a Union laissez-passer.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text concerns the approval, on behalf of the Union, of the agreement between the European Union and China on the exemption from short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports.The rapporteur of the text hopes that the short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports will represent a step towards achieving a full and reciprocal visa exemption for holders of conventional passports.This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days for EU citizens and Chinese nationals.We are not opposed to diplomatic relations, but given the problems of industrial espionage in particular, this is a sensitive matter and I therefore decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- This agreement establishes visa waiver for EU citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer, and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passportthey go to the counterparty's territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180 day period.Given the field of application, there are no critical issues and I therefore intended to vote in its favor.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - China is one of the countries whose nationals need a visa to enter the Union. Reciprocally, European citizens also need to comply with the visa process to travel to China. In 2013, a dialogue on mobility was established, aimed at achieving mutual exemption from the visa requirement for those who hold a diplomatic passport. The agreement reached with China refers to short stays of a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days for European or Chinese citizens who are in possession of a diplomatic passport. I voted in favor of this agreement as it represents a first step towards phasing out the visa requirement. Facilitation in this area is positive, because it eliminates burdensome requirements for travelers and helps to improve people-to-people contact, which in turn helps the economy, culture, scientific research and trade flourish. However, progress towards full liberalization will always be contingent on the progress China can make on human rights and public freedoms.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this recommendation for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. In accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 China is one of the countries whose citizens must have a visa when entering the Schengen area. EU citizens traveling to China must also have a visa. In addition, in 2015 October 12 The Visa Information System (VIS) has officially become operational in China and, since then, all Chinese applicants have been required to provide their biometric data when applying for a Schengen visa. The EU-China dialogue on migration and mobility is a framework for the two sides to exchange views and discuss opportunities for cooperation on issues of mutual interest related to their respective migration policies. This dialogue was launched in 2013. October month. and during its development, it was agreed to start negotiations on an agreement on a reciprocal visa-free regime for holders of diplomatic passports. To this end, in 2015 September 14 The Council adopted a decision authorizing the Commission to open negotiations and negotiate negotiating directives for the abolition of short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree that EU Member States need to maintain effective relations with China, one of the world's leading economic powers. The recommendation adopted today on an agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports will help to deepen diplomatic relations with China. Under the agreement, citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer may enter the territory of China for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period, and Chinese nationals may enter the territory of the Union in similar circumstances, who have a valid diplomatic passport. The agreement takes EU-China relations to a new level, which is why I voted in favor of the recommendation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported this visa agreement between the EU and China because visas for people with a diplomatic passport are unnecessary and hinder migration from both the EU to China and vice versa.Just a year ago, I had a rather bad experience in obtaining a visa, although as a holder of a Slovenian diplomatic passport I did not need it at all.Unfortunately, the process was much longer and more complicated than one would have liked.The removal of visa barriers increases the effectiveness of mutual cooperation between EU Member States and China, where economic cooperation is already so strong.The abolition of visas will reduce the waiting time at consulates and all related costs.Direct contacts between people in diplomatic circles will also be facilitated.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this report.China is one of the countries with a visa regime with the European Union, and this Agreement provides for a visa-free regime for Union citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport or EU passport, as well as for Chinese citizens with a valid diplomatic passport in the European Union, for a period ofmaximum 90 days in any period of 180 days.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text proposes the approval, on behalf of the Union, of the agreement between the European Union and China relating to the exemption from short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports.The rapporteur hopes that the short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports will represent a step towards achieving full and reciprocal visa exemption for holders of conventional passports.I am, of course, not opposed to diplomatic relations but with regard to the problems of industrial espionage, this subject is sensitive.I therefore voted against.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution supporting the results of the negotiation of the agreement between the European Union and the People’s Republic of China regarding the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. This decision has been taken in order to facilitate the travel of diplomats and strengthen the development of friendly relations between the EU and China.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The agreement between the EU and China on mutual visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports for short stays was signed by the EU and China chief negotiators on 3 and 4 November 2015. It establishes the '' Visa exemption for EU citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer and for Chinese citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport who travel to the territory of the other party to a maximum period of 90 days in any 180 day period. The agreement takes into account the specific situation of the United Kingdom and Ireland which, therefore, will not participate in the agreement. Furthermore, an attached joint statement refers to Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Lichtenstein, whose authorities are invited to conclude visa waiver agreements with China. The agreement also contains provisions relating to France and the Netherlands, so it only applies to the European territories of these two Member States. The European Parliament welcomes the conclusion of this agreement as it will facilitate contact between people and this is fundamental for the development of economic, cultural, scientific and other links.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text aims to give the approval of the European Parliament on the agreement with China on the exemption of short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports.Concretely, this agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for a maximum of 90 days over any 180-day period in favor of Union citizens and Chinese nationals holding a valid diplomatic passport onthe territory of the other contracting party.On the one hand, this agreement is a step towards full visa exemption for Chinese nationals, which will strengthen legal immigration to Europe.On the other hand, it is not at all opportune to ratify such an agreement at a time when China is suspected of industrial espionage in EU member states.That’s why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - According to the Council Regulation no. 539/2001, China is one of the third countries whose citizens are required to have a visa when they want to travel to the Schengen area. The same rule applies to EU citizens wishing to enter Chinese territory. The EU-China dialogue on migration and mobility is also the framework in which third parties exchange best practices and opportunities for cooperation on issues of common interest. According to the Council Decision of 14 September 2015, the Commission is authorized to negotiate for the conclusion of a short-stay visa waiver agreement for diplomats, so that this agreement leads to progress in establishing a full mutual exemption from diplomacy. visa requirement for all persons holding ordinary passports. I voted in favor of the report on the EU-China Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver for diplomatic passport holders because it will significantly reduce both the time it takes to obtain a visa and the travel costs.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the agreement establishing visa waiver for citizens of the European Union who hold a valid diplomatic passport or EU passport and for citizens of China who hold a diplomatic passportvalid that travel to the counterpart's territory.I hope that the visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports represents a step towards the establishment of a full reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports.The importance of visa liberalization is considerable, as it brings tangible benefits.The abolition of visas will reduce waiting times at consulates and travel costs and facilitate contact between people, an essential condition for the constant development of economic, cultural, scientific and other links, as well as for intensificationcontacts between citizens.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. Under Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, China is among those countries whose nationals are required to hold a visa when travelling to the Schengen area. EU citizens also need a visa to enter China. The Migration and Mobility Dialogue between the EU and China is the framework under which both parties exchange views and discuss possibilities for cooperation on issues of mutual interest on their respective migration policies. This Dialogue was established in October 2013, and it was agreed to initiate negotiations for a reciprocal visa—waiver agreement for holders of diplomatic passports, and it resulted in an agreement in November 2015. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. While I am in favour of reducing restrictions on travel but have serious concerns about China’s human rights situation, I did not vote in favour but abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this legislative agreement. UKIP do not support the EU making agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the issue of migration.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent for an agreement to provide for visa-free travel for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement was made possible under the aegis of the Migration and Mobility Dialogue between the EU and China. This is the framework under which both parties exchange views and discuss possibilities for cooperation on issues of mutual interest on their respective migration policies.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- As part of the dialogue on migration and mobility between the EU and China, negotiations for the mutual visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports have started and the agreement was concluded on 25 November.According to the same, up to a maximum period of 90 days out of a period of 180 days, holders of diplomatic passports do not require a visa.Parliament is called upon to give its consent and I voted in favor.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing.- The agreement, for which I have voted in favor, establishes visa exemption for EU citizens holding a diplomatic passport or EU passport and for Chinese citizens holding a diplomatic passportvalid who travel to the counterpart's territory for a maximum period of 90 days out of a period of 180 days.I believe that this visa exemption, while affecting a limited portion of users, could represent a step towards the possible future establishment of a total reciprocal exemption also for holders of ordinary passports.It is clear, in fact, that the abolition of visas, in addition to promoting interaction between cultures (an essential condition for the development of economic, cultural or scientific ties), will make it possible to reduce waiting times at consulates and totravel-related costs.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the report, as we believe that visa liberalization is extremely important, as it brings tangible benefits.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The Recommendation on the Agreement between the European Union and the People 's Republic of China on the short - stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports is a positive attempt to further support relations and cooperation between the two parties.That is why I decided to vote for her.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is through a vote in favor that I express my position on this agreement as I believe it is vital for the EU to achieve ever more precise and firm relations with the People's Republic of China. In this sense, I agree with the establishment of a mixed committee of experts for the management of the agreement, which is especially appropriate considering the scarce information on the procedures for issuing Chinese diplomatic passports and the number of them. In any case, the signed agreement will allow a reduction in waiting times at the consulates and in the costs associated with it, but above all it will facilitate contact between people. It is therefore a considerable opportunity to make the development of economic, cultural and scientific links between the two countries constant. Focusing on this orientation, I am particularly sorry to note the non-accession of Ireland and the United Kingdom, which seems to want to confirm in every way its desire to leave the EU as well as, in this context, an isolationist path.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People’s Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing.- To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to be in possession of a visa, in this case of short duration.However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation, as they fulfill a set of criteria approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council and which include respect for fundamental rights, the security of the visa issuance system or riskillegal immigration.The visa exemption, in this case, only applies, however, to holders of diplomatic passports.The European Parliament is responsible for giving its approval to the agreement, which is thus given.I vote in favor of concluding this agreement with the People's Republic of China.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report because the agreement between the EU and China represents a step forward in relations between the two parties and a facility for those who have a European or Chinese diplomatic passport or a European passport.According to the agreement, those who possess the aforementioned documents will be able to travel to the territory of the contracting parties without having to apply for a visa for up to 90 days in any 180 day period.Attached to the agreement is a statement for the interpretation of this 90-day period out of a 180-day period.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I have spoken in favor of this agreement regarding the exemption from visa for holders of diplomatic passports if a short-term stay is foreseen, ie not exceeding 180 days.This is an agreement that ensures full level playing field between European and Chinese representatives, which will allow for a streamlining and speeding up of bureaucratic procedures whenever it is necessary to move from Europe to China and vice versa in the case of a diplomatic post on the spot.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Regretting that it is a measure that only benefits a minority of people in possession of this type of diplomatic passports, I have voted in favor of this agreement between the Union and China, because we understand that the obstacles that prevent access must always be reducedeffective right to free movement.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- The facilitation of travel by recognizing holders of diplomatic passports and EU laissez-passers of visa-free entry conditions for short stays can only foster relations between China and the European Union on the basis ofprinciples of equality and reciprocity.Therefore, I intended to vote positively on this resolution, which could be a forerunner towards the establishment of a full reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: signed up.- China is one of the countries whose citizens must obtain a visa when traveling in the Schengen Area.Union citizens also need a visa to enter China.This Agreement provides for the possibility to travel without a visa for citizens of the European Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU free pass permit, as well as for Chinese citizens holding a diplomatic passport.I voted in favor of this report, which could become a first step towards free movement between China and the EU.This abolition of visas will lead to a reduction in waiting time in front of consulates, as well as a reduction in travel costs.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the recommendation for an agreement between the EU and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for diplomatic passport holders, as in my opinion there are only benefits to this agreement.It is very important for China to be a partner on many levels of the EU.Allowing visa-free travel for holders of diplomatic passports would undoubtedly be helpful in maintaining contacts between these countries.Therefore, I voted in favor.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I am in favour of this recommendation as visa liberalisation brings tangible benefits. Both European and Chinese diplomats would benefit from the short-stay visa waiver as until now China has been among those countries whose nationals are required to hold a visa when travelling to the Schengen area and EU citizens also need a visa to enter China.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Although I am supportive of an EU-China Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports, the UK does not participate in the Schengen Area or the visa-free area. It believes that the Schengen Member States are best placed to determine these policies and therefore I abstained with the rest of the UK delegation.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and China on short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports.Indeed, such an agreement will strengthen our exchanges and diplomatic relations with China while establishing a limited and supervised visa exemption.Only holders of diplomatic passports will then be exempt from visas for a stay of up to 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text aimed to approve the agreement between the European Union and China relating to the exemption from short stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports, for a maximum duration of 90 days over any period of 180 days.The text sees it as a step forward towards achieving a total and reciprocal visa exemption for passport holders.This would include "facilitating contacts between peoples, an essential condition for the regular development of economic, cultural and scientific ties".We are not opposed to diplomatic relations, but in view of the risks of espionage, especially in industrial matters, I voted against.

name: Angel Dzhambazki (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this agreement. I approve of the visa-free travel for holders of diplomatic passports.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- China is a strategic partner of Russia and the EU 's close operational cooperation with China is important in the context of diplomatic exchanges and visits.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - China is one of the countries whose nationals must hold a visa when traveling to the Schengen area. EU citizens also need a visa to enter China. The Council adopted a decision authorizing the Commission to open negotiations and to address the negotiating directives for the conclusion of an agreement on short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement provides for a visa waiver for citizens of the European Union, who hold valid diplomatic passports or EU transit passes, and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period 90 days for each 180 day period. Abolishing visas will reduce waiting time in front of consulates and the costs associated with travel. It will facilitate contact between people - an essential condition for the stable development of economic, cultural and scientific ties, as well as other ties, as it intensifies contact between people.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Vote against: we are not opposed to diplomatic relations, but given the problems of industrial espionage in particular, this is a sensitive matter.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - In accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No. 539/2001, China is one of the countries whose nationals must be in possession of a visa when traveling to the Schengen area. Citizens of EU Member States also need a visa to enter China. In addition, the Visa Information System (VIS) officially went live on October 12, 2015, in China. Since then, all applicants from China must provide their biometric data when applying for a Schengen visa. In this context, on 14 September 2015, the Council adopted a decision authorizing the European Commission to open negotiations and to address the negotiating directives for the conclusion of an agreement on short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement provides for a visa waiver for citizens of European Union Member States who hold valid diplomatic passports or free passages of the EU, and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. We voted in favor.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports, as it feeds the dialogue, which has now begun, on migration and mobility between the EU and China.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- Since 2013, the European Union has been negotiating a reciprocal agreement with China, which will bring about the abolition of visa requirements for holders of diplomatic passports.This agreement will allow European Union citizens holding valid diplomatic passports or European Union cards and Chinese citizens holding valid diplomatic passports to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.A joint statement concerning the interpretation of that 90-day period within any 180-day period is attached to the Agreement.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- Vote in favor of short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I vote in favor of the EU-China agreement, as China is a strategic partner of Russia and the EU's close operational cooperation with China is important in the context of diplomatic exchanges and visits.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The significance of visa liberalisation is considerable as it brings tangible benefits. The visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports represents a step forward in the establishment of full reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports. The significance of visa liberalisation is considerable as it brings tangible benefits. The abolishment of visas will reduce the waiting time in front of consulates and the costs associated with the travelling. It will facilitate people-to-people contact – an essential condition for the steady development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties as well as it will intensify contacts between people. Of course, visa liberalisation should go hand-in-hand with improvements in respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing.- The recommendation to be adopted today on an agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports will help to deepen diplomatic relations with China.Under the agreement, citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer may enter the territory of China for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period, and Chinese nationals may enter the territory of the Union under similar conditionswho have a valid diplomatic passport.The agreement takes EU-China relations to a new level, which is why, as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I vote in favor of adopting the recommendation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Recommendation establishing visa exemption for citizens of the European Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or Union safe-conduct, as well as for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport travelingto the territory of the other party, when the stay does not exceed 90 days for each 180-day period.I hope that the visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports represents progress towards the introduction of full reciprocity in visa waiver for ordinary passport holders, as the importance of visa liberalization is considerable, given thatits advantages are tangible for all citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver duration for holders of diplomatic passports, because I think it is an important first step that improves relations between the parties and brings tangible and immediate benefits to the citizens of both blocs. I think that the visa waiver for diplomatic passport holders who travel to the counterpart's territory for a period of less than 90 days greatly facilitates diplomatic work, avoiding the exhausting bureaucratic procedures in front of consulates. This measure can therefore be a first experiment to get in the future the elimination of visas for ordinary citizens, thus allowing the development of closer cultural, economic and scientific ties between China and the EU. Obviously, our attention to the issue of the protection of human rights in China remains high and I think that visa liberalization will have to go hand in hand with progress in this area by the Beijing authorities. Parliament will monitor this closely.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the very technical decision on the EU-China agreement on the exemption of diplomatic passport holders from the visa requirement for short stays.This makes it easier for the small number of those affected to have regular diplomatic contact, from which, conversely, European leaders also benefit.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report ratifies an agreement signed in March 2016, which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the Union and for the citizens of China, holders of a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer, when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I voted in favour thereof.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor, because we consider that the visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports represents progress towards the establishment of full reciprocity in the visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports.The importance of the liberalization of the visa regime is considerable, given that its advantages are tangible, such as reducing the waiting time in front of the consulates and the costs associated with travel, facilitating contacts between citizens and favoring the stable development of relations.Furthermore, this agreement is positive that it also includes holders of a Union laissez-passer.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is simply ratifying an agreement that was signed in March 2016.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. In the context of the EU-China Mobility and Migration Dialogue, the EU and the People’s Republic of China agreed on a cooperation package of measures in the area of irregular migration and visa policy, including a reciprocal visa waiver agreement for holders of diplomatic passports. Negotiations on the Agreement were opened on 21 September 2015 and were successfully finalised.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - China is among those countries whose nationals are required to have a visa when traveling to the Schengen area. The same goes for EU citizens when they want to enter China. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens holding a diplomatic passport or EU transit permit, as well as for Chinese nationals traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days per 180 year period. days. The abolition of visas for holders of diplomatic passports is therefore a positive step towards the introduction of full exemption from the visa requirement for holders of common passports. For these reasons, we voted in favor of the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement between the European Union and the People’s Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This is significant and will bring tangible benefits to both sides. The fact that the proposed agreement also covers, for the first time, the holders of European Union’s ‘laissez-passer’ is very welcome. I believe that this represents a step forward in the establishment of full reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports. It will facilitate people—to-people contact – an essential condition for the steady development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties and will intensify contacts between people. I also believe that visa liberalisation should go hand-in-hand with improvements in respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms. However, I was happy that the rapporteur queried the practice of signing visa waiver agreements and applying them provisionally before the European Parliament has approved them.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections against it.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: In written form. - Mr President, I support the agreement between the European Union and China on the abolition of short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports, as the agreement reached is in the interest of the Union and satisfies the negotiating objectives set by the Council. The agreement provides for the short-term abolition of visas for EU visits only to holders of diplomatic passports and contains the necessary safeguards in relation to cases of misuse. To this must be added the fact that it provides for the reciprocal abolition of visas for holders of European diplomatic passports. On the EU side, according to the Commission, this concerns between 100,000 and 120,000 passports in circulation, and on the Chinese side the figures are for 30,000 passports in circulation. That is why I believe that the agreement will favor relations between China and the European Union, which will further support it.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports represents an important first step in the establishment of full reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports. I believe that the significance of visa liberalisation is considerable as it brings substantial benefits.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's Draft Legislative Resolution on the Draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China exempting short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passportsagreement.The agreement, which allows travel in the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum of 90 days, will certainly simplify, at least in part, certain procedures and shorten waiting times.Visa liberalization, which has not been fully achieved, brings certain benefits, such as the stable development of tourist, cultural and economic ties, and provides real benefits.Respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms should certainly be taken into account when concluding such agreements, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- It seems to me that this agreement goes in the direction of a definitive and reciprocal exemption from visas.I am not opposed to contact between peoples, a laudable and desirable intention, but to the modalities as described in this proposal.In addition, we cannot ignore the risk of espionage, especially industrial espionage, that such an agreement with China would pose to our companies.I voted against.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing.- Citizens of the People's Republic of China need a visa to enter the Schengen area, just as citizens of the European Union are required to obtain a visa to stay in China.In the framework of the European Union's negotiations with China on cooperation in the field of migration and mobility, the two sides are in favor of future cooperation and agree that the abolition of short-stay visas for diplomats is of common interest to both countries.The Council Decision proposes the abolition of the visa-free requirement for a period of 90 days for a maximum period of 180 consecutive days for holders of diplomatic passports.I voted in favor of the recommendation to abolish these visas because it represents an administrative simplification in diplomatic relations between the People's Republic of China and the European Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Bodil Valero on the exemption from short stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports under the EU-China agreement.This exemption will be formalized by a maximum stay of 90 days in the territory.This provision will facilitate and increase diplomatic exchanges with our Chinese partner, and thus strengthen economic, cultural and scientific cooperation between our two regions.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the EU-China visa waiver agreement for holders of diplomatic passports.The agreement provides for visa-free travel for Union citizens holding a valid European Union passport or laissez-passer and for Chinese citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport when traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum ofperiod of 90 days per period of 180 days.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I am voting against this report.The competence to approve short stays without a visa should remain with the member states.In addition, approval would represent a further step towards visa liberalization for ordinary passport holders.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is simply ratifying an agreement that was signed in March 2016.

name: Stelios Kouloglou
text: (GUE/NGL), in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since removal of any travel formalities is bilaterally beneficial both for our and third countries’ citizens. Introduction of visa waiver for European and Chinese diplomats will contribute to creating an atmosphere of trust and confidence between EU and its strategic partner PRC.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - I support the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement supports our strategic partnership with China and will facilitate two-way exchanges and closer cooperation, as well as an expression of goodwill on both sides. The abolition of visas will reduce waiting times in front of consulates and travel costs. It will facilitate contacts between people - an important condition for the stable development of economic, cultural, scientific and other relations.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. Looking from this perspective, it can be argued that the agreement has great importance since it has been the first international agreement between the EU and China in the field of Home Affairs. In light of this, the agreement represents a real opportunity for both sides to develop economic, cultural, scientific and other ties between them. Therefore, I fully support it. Last but not least, I would like to stress strongly that visa liberalisation should go hand-in-hand with improvements in protection and promotion of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Visa Information System (VIS) entered into force in China in October 2015. From that date, all Chinese applicants are required to provide their biometric data from the moment they apply to access the Schengen area.The agreement in question establishes a visa exemption for citizens of the European Union holding a valid diplomatic passport and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport who travel to the territory of the other party toa maximum period of 90 days in any 180 day period.The European Parliament, on the basis of the guidelines expressed by the agreement, gives its consent to its conclusion.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the EU-China agreement on short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports.This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime of up to 90 days in any 180-day period for EU citizens with diplomatic passports and Chinese nationals with passports.diplomatic.In her text, the rapporteur Ms Valero hopes that the short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports will represent a step forward towards achieving a total and reciprocal visa exemption for holders of a classic passport.This is simply absurd.I am not opposed to diplomatic relations, but given the problems of industrial espionage in particular, this is a sensitive matter.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing.- This decision aims to exempt Chinese holders of diplomatic passports from short-stay visas.The rapporteur expressed the hope that this progress might tend towards a total and reciprocal exemption from visas for holders of traditional passports.I am obviously not opposed to diplomatic relations with China, but in view of the various industrial espionage cases and the direction in which this agreement is heading, I therefore voted against.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: written. - China is one of the countries whose nationals need a visa to enter the Union. Reciprocally, European citizens also need to comply with the visa process to travel to China. In 2013, a dialogue on mobility was established, aimed at achieving mutual exemption from the visa requirement for those who hold a diplomatic passport. The agreement reached with China refers to short stays of a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days for European or Chinese citizens who are in possession of a diplomatic passport. I voted in favor of this agreement as it represents a first step towards phasing out the visa requirement. Facilitation in this area is positive, because it eliminates burdensome requirements for travelers and helps to improve people-to-people contact, which in turn helps the economy, culture, scientific research and trade flourish. However, progress towards full liberalization will always be contingent on the progress China can make on human rights and public freedoms.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this agreement between the Union and China, because I consider that it is in the common interest of both to facilitate high-level political relations, in this case, with the exemption of visas for short stays for holders ofdiplomatic passports.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written.- This recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the exemption of visas for short stays for holders of diplomatic passports, establishesvisa exemption for both Union and Chinese citizens holding diplomatic passports for stays of no more than 90 days per 180-day period.It should be remembered that Chinese nationals are required to have a visa to enter the Schengen zone and, on the other hand, citizens of the Union are required to have another to enter China.I vote in favor of the recommendation.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor.This agreement allows people with a diplomatic passport from the EU a visa-free visit to China for up to 90 days and people with a diplomatic passport from China a visa-free visit to the EU Schengen area.If such an agreement proves successful, visa-free travel could be extended to other citizens, making it easier for people to travel between the EU and China for tourism and trade.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party. It is very important to make easier travelling between EU and China.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- I agree with the agreement, which allows EU and Chinese citizens holding diplomatic passports to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period.This Agreement shall not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland and, in the case of France and the Netherlands, shall apply only to the European territories of those countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports,because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This text aims to approve the agreement between the European Union and China on visa waiver.The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime of up to 90 days for diplomatic passport holders from China and EU member states.The rapporteur of the text is pleased that the short-stay visa exemption (for diplomats) may one day evolve into the complete liberalization of visas between China and European countries for holders of a classic passport.We obviously oppose this concept.Indeed, even if we are not opposed to diplomatic relations with China, we remain wary of such liberalization.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: written.- My support for the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the exemption of visas for short stays for holders of diplomatic passports.This agreement supports our strategic partnership with China, while facilitating reciprocal exchanges and closer cooperation, and is a gesture of goodwill on both sides.In addition, the abolition of visas will reduce the waiting time before the consulates and the costs associated with travel and will facilitate and intensify contacts between citizens, aspects that will promote the stable development of economic, cultural, scientific and other relationships.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This draft of a decision of the Council on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the exemption of holders of diplomatic passports from the visa requirement for short stays constitutes an interference with the competences of the member states. I therefore reject this draft.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report because I hope that the visa-free regime for holders of diplomatic passports will be a step towards full reciprocal visa-free travel for holders of ordinary passports.Visa liberalization is very important.Abolishing visas will reduce time spent at consulates and reduce travel costs.Conditions will be created for direct human communication, which is an essential condition for the balanced development of economic, cultural and scientific relations.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- After years of negotiations, the EU has finally lifted the visa requirement for Chinese diplomats.This agreement is reciprocal.Europeans with diplomatic passports will also be able to travel to China without a visa.I agree with the rapporteur's criticisms of the procedure for these bilateral negotiations carried out by the Commission on behalf of the Member States.In particular, she denounces the provisional application of the agreement before the approval of the European Parliament, which demonstrates the lack of respect for democracy by the EU.Finally, she denounces the fact that Parliament is not informed of the progress of these bilateral negotiations, which would even be contrary to the Treaties.I am voting for this agreement, however, because it will facilitate exchanges, cooperation and mutual trust between our States and China by abandoning an indelicate and vexatious demand.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
