text: in writing.- This decision aims to exempt Chinese holders of diplomatic passports from short-stay visas.The rapporteur expressed the hope that this progress might tend towards a total and reciprocal exemption from visas for holders of traditional passports.I am obviously not opposed to diplomatic relations with China, but in view of the various industrial espionage cases and the direction in which this agreement is heading, I therefore voted against.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- This Agreement provides for a visa waiver for citizens of the European Union who are holders of valid diplomatic passports or EU passports, and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for onemaximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.EP approval of this agreement is required, hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union who hold a diplomatic or laissez-passer and for the citizens holding a diplomatic passport from China when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to enhance cooperation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I welcome the approval given by the European Parliament to the EU-China agreement on short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports.This is a further step in the dialogue between the European Union and China on mobility issues.More generally, this visa waiver agreement should help strengthen the ties that exist between the two parties.As subjects of mutual interest to the Union and China cover many issues and themes, it is essential to deepen our partnership and maintain an ongoing dialogue with China.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - By its decision of 14 September 2015, the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with the People's Republic of China and to draw up negotiating directives for an agreement on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. Negotiations began on 21 September and took the form of a written exchange of notes. The parties initialed the agreement on 3 and 4 November 2015 respectively. The Council adopted a decision on 26 January 2016 to ratify the agreement, subject to the consent of the European Parliament. Under the agreement, Union citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer and Chinese citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport may enter the territory of the other Contracting Party without a visa for a maximum period of 90 days. have. The United Kingdom and Ireland shall not be subject to the provisions of this Agreement and, in the case of France and the Netherlands, shall apply only to the European territories of the two States. The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. - The proposed decision seeks the approval, on behalf of the Union, of the agreement between the European Union and China on short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime of up to 90 days over a period of 180 days for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or a laissez-passer. -Pass from the Union and in favor of Chinese nationals holding a valid diplomatic passport who are going to the territory of the other contracting party. The rapporteur hopes that the short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports will represent a step towards achieving full and reciprocal visa exemption for holders of conventional passports. We are not opposed to diplomatic relations, but given the problems of industrial espionage in particular, this is a sensitive matter. The vote will therefore be unfavorable.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing.- This Agreement provides for a visa waiver for EU citizens with valid diplomatic passports or EU passports, and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a periodmaximum of 90 days for each 180-day period.I hope that this agreement, in addition to facilitating exchange and closer cooperation with the People's Republic of China, will be a step forward in establishing a full and reciprocal visa waiver for holders of a common passport.I endorse the rapporteur's position on the abolition of visas, which will reduce waiting times and red tape, and will facilitate economic, cultural and scientific ties.However, it is important to note that visa liberalization must be accompanied by improvements in the respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- The proposed decision aims to approve, on behalf of the Union, the agreement between the European Union and China on short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports.We are not opposed to diplomatic relations and their improvement, but given the problems of industrial espionage in particular, this is too sensitive a matter to exempt holders of diplomatic passports from visa requirements.This is the reason why I voted against.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the Union and for the citizens of China, holders of a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer, when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the exemptionshort-stay visa for holders of diplomatic passports.By approving this agreement, the European Parliament is making it easier for European citizens with diplomatic passports to travel to China.Conversely, it facilitates the movement within the European Union of Chinese nationals holding a diplomatic passport.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report as the agreement between the European Union and China on visa waiver for short stays represents a step forward in relations between the two parties which facilitates both communication and collaboration.The agreement establishes visa waiver for citizens of the European Union who are holders of a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China who are holders of a valid diplomatic passport who travelin the territory of the counterparty for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180 day period.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing.- We consider China to be one of the European Union's most important trading partners.Today, products from Chinese factories are part of our daily lives.The Visa Waiver Convention is a diplomatic step forward that can bring positive results in terms of economic, cultural and international cooperation.Visa-free travel can boost mutual dialogue and even strengthen EU-China relations at regional level.We have already concluded visa waiver agreements with many countries, which have worked great ever since, and I am convinced that this will not be the case for China.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report that will provide visa-free travel for both citizens of the EU and China holding a diplomatic passport when travelling to each other’s territory for a period of maximum 90 days during any 180 day period.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report, which endorses the substantive negotiations between the European Commission and the People's Republic of China on waiving the need to hold short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports or EU free pass permits.I consider it an extremely important step forward in relations between the EU and the People's Republic of China, and I hope that it will be followed by negotiations on improving respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and negotiations on the possible abolition of visas.At the same time, I support the rapporteur's position on the importance of transparency in these future negotiations and the inclusion of the European Parliament in these discussions, in order to ensure good cooperation and cooperation between the European institutions.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I spoke out against this report because the competences should lie with the Member States themselves.In my opinion, consent would be a further step towards visa liberalization for holders of ordinary passports.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I abstained.I do not think the timing of such a step is right yet.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EU-China agreement, which provides for visa-free travel for Union citizens holding a valid European Union passport or laissez-passer, and for Chinese citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport. passport, for a maximum period of 90 days per period of 180 days, since the abolition of visas will reduce both the waiting time in front of the consulates and the costs associated with the trip. This abolition will facilitate interpersonal contact between citizens, which is a prerequisite for the stable development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties, which will intensify contacts between peoples. Of course, visa liberalization must be accompanied by improvements in respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. The abolition of visas for holders of diplomatic passports is a step forward in establishing full exemption from the visa requirement for holders of common passports.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this legislative agreement. UKIP do not support the EU making agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the issue of migration.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- With regard to the proposal under consideration, I felt it my duty to express myself in favor.The agreement between the EU and China on short-stay visa waiver appears to be an important step forward to strengthen relations between Europe and the People's Republic of China.The visa for holders of diplomatic passports would make communication and collaboration between the two powers easier.With this proposal it is hoped that the visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports will be only the first step towards the establishment of a full reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports.Therefore, I voted positively.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – China is a major partner of the European Union. As a member of the delegation for China I supported this agreement, because I believe that the abolishment of visas will facilitate and intensify people-to-people contact (an essential condition for the steady development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties) and reduce the waiting time in front of consulates.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - The People's Republic of China is one of the largest industrial producers in the world and a global economic factor. Thus, diplomatic relations between the European Union and the People's Republic of China are extremely important. It is important to nurture good relations, but also to establish as simple and efficient a form of diplomatic action as possible. That is why I support this Agreement, which allows travel and short stays without a visa for a period of 90 days for Union residents who have a valid diplomatic passport or EU passport and Chinese residents who have a valid diplomatic passport while traveling to other countries covered by the Agreement. This Agreement is a very important step towards simple and effective diplomacy. It supports, even intensifies human-to-human contact, which is essential for the constant development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties. This Agreement is important, but it is not the end of the story, but the first step towards the final goal - the abolition of visas for holders of ordinary passports. Such an abolition would open up exceptional business and tourism potential. Since I come from a country where tourism is one of the most developed branches, I know how important tourist openness is for the entire European Union, and I hope for this final result.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing.- The proposed decision seeks the approval on behalf of the Union of the agreement between the European Union and China on short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports.The rapporteur hopes that the short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports will represent a step towards achieving full and reciprocal visa exemption for holders of conventional passports.We are in full ideological delirium: “It should facilitate contacts between peoples, an essential condition for the regular development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties, and intensify contacts between peoples.We are not opposed to diplomatic relations, but it is essential to maintain control of borders and of those who cross them in the current global context.I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - I welcome the fact that the proposed agreement covers EU pass holders for the first time. I encourage the bodies of the EFTA members to conclude similar conditions as in that Agreement. The Agreement establishes a Joint Committee and I draw attention to the fact that the European Union is represented in the Joint Management Committee of the Agreement only by the European Commission. The European Parliament could participate in the work of the Joint Committee or at least receive regular notifications of the outcome of meetings. I hope that this is a step forward in terms of achieving a full mutual exemption for holders of ordinary passports. Visa liberalization is of great importance, as it provides real benefits. Waiting time in front of consulates will be reduced, as will travel-related costs. It will facilitate interpersonal contacts, which is a key condition for the stable development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties, and will also contribute to the intensification of contacts between people. Visa liberalization should, of course, go hand in hand with the introduction of improvements in the area of ​​respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. As a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, I believe that the Proposal should be approved, as it supports our strategic partnership with China, facilitates two-way exchange and closer cooperation, and is an expression of goodwill on both sides.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - In accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No. 539/2001, China is one of the countries whose nationals must be in possession of a visa when traveling to the Schengen area. EU citizens also need a visa to enter China. In addition, the Visa Information System (VIS) officially went live on October 12, 2015, in China. Since then, all applicants from China must provide their biometric data when applying for a Schengen visa. In this context, on 14 September 2015, the Council adopted a decision authorizing the Commission to open negotiations and to address the negotiating directives for the conclusion of an agreement on short-stay visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement provides for a visa waiver for citizens of the European Union, who hold valid diplomatic passports or EU transit passes, and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period 90 days for each 180 day period. We voted in favor.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ China still belongs among those countries whose nationals are required to hold a visa when travelling to the Schengen area, while EU citizens also need a visa to enter China. I must stress as a Social Democrat that the significance of visa liberalisation is considerable, as it brings tangible benefits. The October 2013 mobility dialogue has resulted in the Council adopting a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations and address negotiating plans for a short-stay visa waiver agreement for holders of diplomatic passports. The Council decision now requires the consent of the European Parliament. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The abolishment of visas will facilitate people-to-people contact, which is an essential condition for the steady development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties as well. However, I would like to point out on this occasion that visa liberalisation should go hand-in-hand with needed improvements in respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. - China is listed among the countries whose citizens must be in possession of a visa when traveling to the Schengen area. Citizens of the European Union, in turn, need a visa to enter China. In addition, the European Visa Information System (VIS) officially became operational in China on 12 October 2015 and since that date all Chinese applicants are required to provide their biometric data when applying for a visa for the area. Schengen. The agreement establishes visa waiver for citizens of the European Union who are holders of a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China who are holders of a valid diplomatic passport who travel in the territory of the counterparty for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180 day period. The rapporteur welcomes the fact that, for the first time, the proposed agreement also concerns holders of the European Union pass. The abolition of visas will reduce waiting times at consulates and costs related to travel, also facilitating contact between people, an essential condition for the constant development of economic, cultural, scientific and other links. I voted in favor of approving this recommendation.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. - The EU and China started a dialogue on migration and mobility in 2013. In this context, a visa-free regime for diplomatic passport holders is now being proposed. The Council has already approved the agreement in January 2016. Under the agreement, visa-free travel is allowed for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The measure concerns the Schengen area and does not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. In the case of France and the Netherlands, the agreement only applies to European territories. Both China and the EU can suspend or terminate the agreement only for all EU Member States together. This means that situations like the US and Canada, which only require visas for some, not all, EU Member States will not be possible. The agreement applies to all holders of diplomatic passports, including members of the European Parliament who hold diplomatic passports. I hereby supported the recommendation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because it provides for visa waivers for short stays of Chinese diplomats in France and Europe, but also European diplomats in China.It is a necessity to facilitate our diplomatic relations.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - Currently, and in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No. 539/2001, China is one of the countries whose nationals must be in possession of a visa when traveling to the Schengen area. Citizens of the European Union (EU) also need a visa to enter China. This Agreement provides for a visa waiver for EU citizens who are holders of valid diplomatic passports or EU passports, and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period 90 days for each 180 day period. It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in the agreement and are not subject to the provisions of the agreement. The rapporteur warns that the abolition of visas will reduce waiting times in front of consulates and the costs associated with travel. I voted in favor, because the provisions of this report will facilitate contact between people, a necessary condition for the stable development of economic, cultural and scientific ties.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against giving consent to this legislative agreement. UKIP do not support the EU making agreements with third countries, particularly when this concerns the issue of migration.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor, as the agreement provides for a visa waiver for citizens of the European Union, holders of valid diplomatic passports or EU passports, and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the otherContracting Party, for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.Abolishing visas will reduce waiting time in front of consulates and the costs associated with travel.It will facilitate contact between people - an essential condition for the stable development of economic, cultural and scientific ties, among others.Obviously, visa liberalization must be accompanied by improvements in the respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - China is one of the countries whose nationals need a visa to enter the Union. Reciprocally, European citizens also need to comply with the visa process to travel to China. In 2013, a dialogue on mobility was established, aimed at achieving mutual exemption from the visa requirement for those who hold a diplomatic passport. The agreement reached with China refers to short stays of a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days for European or Chinese citizens who are in possession of a diplomatic passport. I voted in favor of this agreement as it represents a first step towards phasing out the visa requirement. Facilitation in this area is positive, because it eliminates burdensome requirements for travelers and helps to improve people-to-people contact, which in turn helps the economy, culture, scientific research and trade flourish. However, progress towards full liberalization will always be contingent on the progress China can make on human rights and public freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report in which the European Parliament gives its consent to the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the exemption of short-stay visas for holders of'a diplomatic passport.This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime of up to 90 days in any 180-day period for Union citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport or laissez-passer.of the Union and of Chinese nationals holding a valid diplomatic passport who are traveling to the territory of the other contracting party.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- The EU-China dialogue on migration and mobility is a very important process that is in the interest of both parties.I welcome and support the initiative of both countries to stop requiring short-stay visas from holders of diplomatic passports.At the same time, I very much regret the fact that the European Union's negotiators have not been able to negotiate visa-free travel for EU citizens to China.I am well aware and pleased that China, on its own initiative, is allowing EU citizens up to 5 days visa-free transit in certain cities, but I am convinced that a visa-free regime, at least for EU citizens, is necessary for a wider dialogue between the two economies.That is what I call on the European Commission to pursue.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - China is one of the countries whose nationals must hold a visa when traveling to the Schengen area and vice versa. In 2013, a Dialogue on Migration and Mobility between the EU and China began, with a view to concluding a reciprocity agreement on visa waivers for diplomatic passport holders. This agreement provides for a visa waiver for citizens of the European Union with valid diplomatic or free passports and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the European Union, for a maximum period of 90 days (in each 180 days). I voted in favor of this recommendation, as I agreed with the rapporteur on the importance of visa waiver as an important step in facilitating and bringing people together - an essential condition for the stable development of diplomatic and intergovernmental (and obviously cultural) ties and also the reduction of waiting time at consulates, as well as the costs associated with these trips.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor, because we consider that the visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports represents progress towards the establishment of full reciprocity in visa exemption for holders of ordinary passports.The importance of visa liberalization is considerable, given that its benefits are tangible, such as reducing the waiting time before the consulates and the costs associated with travel, facilitating contacts between citizens and favoring the stable development of relationships.Furthermore, this agreement is positive that it also includes holders of a Union laissez-passer.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the EU-China agreement on the exemption of diplomatic passport holders from the visa requirement for short stays.The agreement enables EU citizens who have a valid diplomatic ID or a laissez-passer of the EU to stay for up to 90 days without a visa.This also applies to Chinese citizens who can show a valid diplomatic ID when visiting the country with which the agreement was negotiated.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Regretting that it is a measure that only benefits a minority of people in possession of this type of diplomatic passports, I have voted in favor of this agreement between the Union and China, because we understand that the obstacles that prevent access must always be reducedeffective right to free movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing.- The agreement between the European Union and China providing for visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports for short stays, up to 90 days, could be an effective measure to strengthen the strategic partnership betweenthe two countries.The liberalization of such visas could in fact facilitate bilateral exchanges and contacts between people, allowing the development of important economic, cultural and scientific links.I have therefore decided to express myself in favor.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the EU-China Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of China, holders of a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer, when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing.- I support the conclusion of an agreement between China and the EU on the short-stay visa waiver.This agreement allows Union citizens holding valid EU diplomatic passports or cards and Chinese citizens holding valid diplomatic passports to travel without visa to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.I voted in favor.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I welcomed the EU-China visa waiver agreement. I believe that visa liberalization is bringing tangible results and is very beneficial for improving relations between countries. Following the consultation, individual Member States also commented on the work of the Working Party on Asylum and Migration. EU citizens, as well as Chinese citizens holding diplomatic passports, will be able to enter the territory of the EU or China for a period of 90 days upon the entry into force of this agreement. I also supported this agreement because it is a first step towards the complete reciprocal visa waiver. This abolition of the visa requirement at diplomatic level indicates an improvement in relations between European countries and China. In addition, the abolition of visas will reduce waiting times in front of consulates and reduce travel costs. In addition, people-to-people contacts will be facilitated and intensified. However, the Commission should take into account the reservations of the AFET Committee, which considers that the EU should have more information on the issuance of diplomatic relations and the number of potential holders of such passports in China. In any case, I believe that this initiative is a good signal, and I hope that it will lead to a deepening of mutual relations.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Chinese diplomats will be able to travel to the Schengen area without visas, and European Union diplomats will also be able to travel to China without a visa.Although human rights concerns remain in China, such an agreement is a sign of a first step towards a visa-free regime with China in the future.The agreement provides for visa-free travel for all citizens of the European Union and citizens of the People's Republic of China with a diplomatic passport.In both cases, this applies for a period of up to 90 days in any 180-day period.The abolition of visas for diplomats will reduce certain costs and make it easier for them to carry out their tasks.I find the change welcome and a step towards an easier visa regime for all EU citizens, so I supported the recommendation.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- China is an important trading partner for Europe.I welcome the simplification of contacts between holders of diplomatic passports, but the European Union should seek to conclude similar types of agreements with as many countries as possible, provided that they do not pose a security risk.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on the "Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the exemption of holders of diplomatic passports from the visa requirement for short stays on behalf of the European Union".I see no reason to treat diplomatic passport holders better than other citizens.If a state meets the requirements for a visa waiver, then this should apply to all citizens and not just to a select privileged group.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written.- In September 2015, the Council authorized the Commission to start negotiations and consideration of negotiating directives for an Agreement on the exemption from the obligation to hold a short-stay visa for holders of diplomatic passports.In particular, it allows European Union pass holders and citizens of the European Union and China with a valid diplomatic passport to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any period of 180 days.This approach certainly alleviates administrative difficulties, reduces costs and facilitates mobility and travel.It is a step further in terms of strengthening international and strategic relations with China.I support the recommendation on the Draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports on behalf of the European Union.The agreement will upgrade the strategic partnership with China and enable bilateral exchanges and closer cooperation.The agreement thus allows EU and Chinese citizens to travel to the territory of the other party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing.- Today, I supported the consent of the European Parliament to the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the EU-China Agreement on short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports.This consent shall be given after the Member States have given their consent to the draft agreement.This consent shall be preceded by Member States an assessment of all risks related to the introduction of a visa-free regime for holders of a particular type of travel document, including an assessment of the quality of security of travel documents of the other Party against forgery.I believe that the conclusion of a visa-free regime for holders of diplomatic passports is a standard step in international relations and can thus also be negotiated with China.Moreover, in a situation where it is a reciprocal agreement and its possible termination by China, it can only be done against all EU Member States at once.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - China is among those countries whose nationals are required to have a visa when traveling to the Schengen area. The same goes for EU citizens when they want to enter China. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens holding a diplomatic passport or EU transit permit, as well as for Chinese citizens traveling to Member States for a maximum of 90 days per 180-day period. The abolition of visas for holders of diplomatic passports is a positive step towards the introduction of full exemption from the visa requirement for holders of common passports. For these reasons, we voted in favor of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- China is a strategic partner of Russia and the EU 's close operational cooperation with China is important in the context of diplomatic exchanges and visits.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of Parliament's recommendation for a draft Council decision on the EU-PRC agreement, according to which, in future, holders of diplomatic passports (or EU laissez-passer) will be able to stay in each other's territory for short periods (up to 90 days) without a visa, which will certainly have a positive effect on the mutually beneficial development of political, trade and business relations. At the same time, I would consider it important that the Council should also obtain the consent of the European Parliament before concluding agreements of this type and weight. In such an approach, I do not share the rapporteur's hope that the facilitation for holders of diplomatic passports will automatically prepare for similar visa-free rules for private passports. Given the many other aspects of EU-China relations, I believe that such a move should be the subject of further political consideration by the EP.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The European Union's relations with the People's Republic of China have developed steadily in recent decades in all areas. Despite this, the citizens of both sides still need visas when traveling on the territory of the other. In order to remedy this impediment, a dialogue on mobility was opened in October 2013, with a view to mutual renunciation of visas. Two years later, the Council authorized the Commission to negotiate an agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports. This step further enhances the good relations between the diplomatic corps of the two parties and is likely to contribute to an in-depth dialogue on areas of cooperation. The European Parliament, as the direct representative of European citizens, is called upon to approve this agreement. The implementation of this measure is likely to be only a step towards the total abolition of visas for nationals of both parties, when the concrete conditions allow. The abolition of visas will directly contribute to the increase of direct contacts between the citizens of the two parties and to the development of economic, cultural, scientific and other relations. This is a welcome measure, which I wholeheartedly support.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted for the text.The short-stay visa waiver for diplomatic passport holders will represent a step towards achieving full and reciprocal visa waiver for conventional passport holders.The relaxation of the visa regime is a development of considerable importance, as it brings tangible benefits.Eliminating the visa requirement will reduce the waiting time at consulates and the costs associated with travel.It will facilitate people-to-people contacts, an essential condition for the steady development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties, and will intensify people-to-people contacts.Of course, the relaxation of the visa regime must go hand in hand with progress in the field of human rights and fundamental freedoms, as required by Article 1 of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 ofAdvice.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of the EU-China Mobility and Migration Dialogue (2013), the EU and China cooperation package included a reciprocal visa waiver agreement for holders of diplomatic passports. The agreement is to provide visa-free travel for citizens of the EU holding diplomatic passports, as well as a EU laissez-passer for citizens of China holding a diplomatic passport. I voted in favour of the agreement because of I recognise the importance of the project to support the bilateral dialogue and the strong momentum to advance EU-China cooperation on migration and mobility issues.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I supported the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the exemption from the obligation to hold a short-stay visa for holders of diplomatic passports.This exemption allows EU citizens and Chinese citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport, as well as EU citizens holding an EU pass, to travel visa-free to the other Contracting Party to reduce waiting times at consulates.The agreement stipulates that visa-free travel can last a maximum of 90 days, and I believe that its application will reduce travel costs and facilitate people-to-people contacts.Although the agreement is concluded for an indefinite period, a very important provision is that it may be suspended in whole or in part for reasons of public order, protection of national security or public health, illegal immigration or reintroduction of visa requirements by one of the parties.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - On behalf of the European Union, I supported the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. EU citizens need a visa to enter China. The agreement allows Union citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport or EU pass and Chinese citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The Agreement shall be accompanied by a joint statement of interpretation of this 90-day period in any 180-day period. The agreement establishes a joint committee of experts to manage it. The abolition of visas will reduce waiting times at consulates and travel-related costs. Direct contacts between people, which are an essential condition for the stable development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties, will be facilitated, while contacts between them will be strengthened.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor, because we consider that the visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports represents progress towards the establishment of full reciprocity in the visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports.The importance of the liberalization of the visa regime is considerable, given that its advantages are tangible, such as reducing the waiting time in front of the consulates and the costs associated with travel, facilitating contacts between citizens and favoring the stable development of relations.Furthermore, this agreement is positive that it also includes holders of a Union laissez-passer.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing.- This text aims to approve the agreement between the EU and China relating to the exemption from short-stay visas for holders of diplomatic passports.The rapporteur hopes that the visa waiver will represent a step towards achieving a full and reciprocal visa waiver for holders of a conventional passport.Considering the problems of industrial espionage in particular, this visa waiver seems somewhat premature.I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- The agreement on the waiver of short-term visas for holders of diplomatic passports can be considered one of the fruits of the dialogue that the European Union and China have been conducting since 2013 in the field of migration and mobility.It is worth noting that under this agreement, China will not be able to suspend or terminate visa-free travel only in relation to selected EU Member States.The Council approved the agreement in January 2016. I believe that the European Parliament should give its consent to the conclusion of this agreement, especially as it covers all holders of diplomatic passports.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- The agreement provides that citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and citizens of China who have a valid diplomatic passport or EU laissez-passer may enter the territory of the other Contracting Party without a visa for a maximum period of 90 days.have a valid diplomatic passport.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor, because we consider that the visa exemption for holders of diplomatic passports represents progress towards the establishment of full reciprocity in visa exemption for holders of ordinary passports.The importance of visa liberalization is considerable, given that its benefits are tangible, such as reducing the waiting time before the consulates and the costs associated with travel, facilitating contacts between citizens and favoring the stable development of relationships.Furthermore, this agreement is positive that it also includes holders of a Union laissez-passer.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Diplomats from China will be able to travel to the Schengen area without visas, and the EU diplomats - to China. Although the concerns about human rights in China remain significant, I regard this agreement as a first step towards visa-free regime with China for all citizens.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People’s Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports. China is among those countries whose nationals are required to hold a visa when travelling to the Schengen area. EU citizens also need a visa to enter China. The Migration and Mobility Dialogue between the EU and China is the framework under both parties exchange views and discuss possibilities for cooperation on issues of mutual interest on their respective migration policies. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU laissez-passer and for citizens of China holding a valid diplomatic passport when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I voted in favour because I believe that waiver for holders of diplomatic passports represents a step forward in the establishment of full reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: written.- From the conviction that enabling citizens with diplomatic passports to travel without a visa (for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180 period) will facilitate and intensify direct contact between people and reduce the waiting time in front of consulates;In a way that ultimately contributes to the effective development of economic, cultural, scientific and other relations between the Union and China, I have voted in favor.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Regretting that it is a measure that only benefits a minority of people in possession of this type of diplomatic passports, I have voted in favor of this agreement between the Union and China, because we understand that the obstacles that prevent access must always be reducedeffective right to free movement.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report gives a recommendation for approval of the reciprocal visa exemption, for a maximum period of 90 days, in favor of citizens of the Union holding a valid diplomatic passport or a laissez-passer of the Union and in favor of Chinese nationals holding a valid diplomatic passport, granted between the two parties. This practice is consistent with diplomatic practices. I would nevertheless like to denounce, even if it is for the form, the fact that this agreement, like others, is implemented even before receiving the recommendation of the European Parliament concerning it. The European Parliament should not be a check-in fund and it is useful to remember it.I am also surprised to discover that some of my colleagues are more sensitive on human rights issues when it comes to liberalization diplomatic visas for China only when it comes to free trade or the externalization of migratory flows with other countries little known to respect these same rights.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- In accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No. 539/2001, China is one of the countries whose nationals must be in possession of a visa when traveling to the Schengen area.EU citizens also need a visa to enter China.In addition, the Visa Information System (VIS) officially went live on October 12, 2015, in China.Since then, all applicants from China must provide their biometric data when applying for a Schengen visa.The agreement provides for a visa waiver for citizens of the European Union with valid diplomatic passports or EU passports, and for Chinese nationals holding diplomatic passports traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, for a maximum period of90 days for each 180-day period.We voted in favor.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- The competence over visa regulations should in principle rest with the Member States.Such an agreement would represent a further step towards central European visa liberalization - also for holders of ordinary passports.I have therefore rejected this report.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports.The EU-China agreement establishes the possibility to travel without a visa for EU citizens holding a valid diplomatic passport or an EU free pass permit, as well as for Chinese citizens holding a diplomatic passport, when traveling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for astay of maximum 90 days during any period of 180 days.A joint statement on the interpretation of this 90-day period during any 180-day period is attached to the Agreement.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the agreement between the European Union and China on the abolition of the visa requirement.Of course, this is not an agreement on the complete abolition of visas, but it will only apply to short-term (maximum 90-day) stays and only to holders of diplomatic passports.Negotiations leading to this agreement began as early as 2013, and the Member States within the Council also approved the agreement earlier this year.I therefore think that the agreement has met all the requirements for its conclusion and will help to maintain diplomatic relations between the EU Member States and China.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of concluding the agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of China on the short-stay visa waiver for holders of diplomatic passports on behalf of the European Union.I hope that the abolition of the visa requirement for holders of diplomatic passports heralds the establishment of a complete reciprocal visa waiver for holders of ordinary passports as well.I believe that visa liberalization is very important, as it promotes the stable development of economic, cultural, scientific and other ties between the EU and China.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The draft report provides for the extension of the co-financing mechanisms to Greece and Cyprus (due to their difficulties related to the crisis) in relation to the ERDF and ESF programs beyond 2016 and up to the end of the programming, but without any change in the amountappropriations.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against this legislative report because we do not feel that British taxpayers’ money should be used to prop up vanity and propaganda projects in Europe. We note that the alleged financial difficulties in southern Europe that are being used to justify this additional support are largely to blame on the EU and its failing and doomed Euro currency. We fail to see how the EU, which created this mess, could possibly solve it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because its practical implementation contributes to slightly reducing the consequences of the cuts applied in Member States such as Greece or Cyprus, which have extremely affected the most vulnerable socio-economic classes.With this amendment to the Regulation, payments for Member States experiencing budgetary difficulties are increased.Although it is an insufficient measure, it is a palliative, and this must be the orientation taken by the institutions to mitigate the effects of the economic crisis and not the application of sanctions and suspension of payments with which the Council and the Commission threaten Spain andPortugal.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: in writing.- In view of their indebtedness, the Member States concerned by this text are unable to finance public investments conducive to the revival of economic growth.Although these increases may prove to be positive in the short term, they in no way resolve the structural problems of the Greek and Cypriot economies (competitiveness deficit, over-indebtedness) but on the contrary aim to make them even more dependent on European structural funds within the framework ofausterity policies imposed by the commission.Finally, I abstained on this text because, with constant payment appropriations, these increases will be made to the detriment of other Member States such as France, which will suffer even more substantial payment delays.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report, which supports amending the regulation on financial management for Member States experiencing serious difficulties with financial stability where this is affecting these countries’ ability to co-fund regional projects.  Specifically, it addresses temporarily increasing payments under ESIF programmes for Greece and Cyprus. This ‘top—up’ doesn’t affect the overall ESIF allocations in 2014-2020. For Greece, because of the ongoing difficulty it is facing with implementing the austerity measures of the ‘economic adjustment programme’, it allows interim payments 10 percent above the co-financing rate for the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund, EAFRD and EMFF.  While Cyprus exited its ‘adjustment programme’ in March, the report also recognises the ongoing fragility of the economy of Cyprus, and therefore extends a co-financing rate of 85 percent for all operational programmes supported by the ERDF and ESF in Cyprus until the closure of those programmes.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which provides for an 85% extension of funding until the end of the 2014-2020 financial year for aid to Cyprus and Greece.We must not forget the recent financial and economic crisis is putting pressure on national economies.National budgets are under pressure.Consequently, in many Member States, European Structural Fund investments remain fundamental for the survival of these economies.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No.Council Regulation (EC) No 1303/2013 on certain financial management provisions for certain Member States facing or experiencing serious financial stability difficulties, as I consider it to be a favorable development given thedue to the financial crisis.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: written. - According to the umbrella regulation, the EU Commission should examine the so-called top-up, which was introduced in 2010 for the member states with the greatest budget difficulties, before June 30, 2016. This means that those Member States that are implementing adjustment programs or have had to implement one since 2007 will receive additional payments of 10% on all declared expenditure on request and will continue to receive payments 10% above the maximum co-financing rate during the implementation of the program. This enables EU payments to be brought forward compared to the original financing plan. It is true that this leads to a reduction in the overall financial volume for the respective country, but I support this proposal, as it enables additional liquidity to continue or terminate projects that are already running, leads to a reduction in the necessary additional national funding and thus relieves the burden on national budgets the risk of losing funds is reduced.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - It is in a context of austerity policy that Regulation n ° 1303/2013 provides for an increase in the rate of co-financing of States which have received financial assistance from the European Union after the 31st / 12/2013. The current proposal would allow the European Commission to continue making increased payments to any Member State receiving financial assistance after 30/06/2016 without modifying the overall allocation of the ESI Funds for the period 2014/2020. . These increases concern Greece, which is continuing its adjustment program, and Cyprus, which benefits until 30 June 2017 from an exceptional co-financing rate of 85% for all operational programs resulting from the ERDF and the ESF. In debt, these Member States are unable to finance public investments conducive to economic recovery. Although these increases may turn out to be positive in the short term, they in no way solve the structural problems of the Greek and Cypriot economies (competitiveness deficit, over-indebtedness) but instead aim to make them even more dependent on European structural funds. Finally, these increases will be made to the detriment of other Member States such as France, which will suffer even more substantial payment delays. I therefore abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it makes it easier for the EU to fund struggling EU countries.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I approved this report because the Commission proposal provides a precise and budgetary neutral solution to the temporary liquidity problems encountered by two Member States.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- During the financial and economic crisis, Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets.Greece and Cyprus are facing particular economic problems.In this situation, therefore, the main EU funding instruments, and most importantly the implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds (EFSI), need to be ensured.The purpose of Articles 24 and 120 (3) of the General Provisions Regulation (CPR) is to help Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial assistance to make the most of the investment opportunities available under the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020.during the programming period.I therefore agree that, depending on the economic situation in the countries concerned, the period during which additional support may be provided could be extended.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. - The report is about amending the provisions on co-financing by the Structural Funds. The amendment is made in order to increase the co-financing of less developed countries in financial difficulties by 10 percentage points from the usual 50 per cent. Under the European Structural Funds Regulation, co-financing can be increased to this extent for countries with temporary budgetary difficulties, but in some cases the level of co-financing may be higher. Greece is subject to the adjustment program and will therefore receive the related financial assistance until the third quarter of 2018. However, as Greece is still facing serious difficulties in terms of financial stability, the application of the increase in payments should be extended for Member States with temporary budgetary difficulties. Cyprus' adjustment program ended in March 2016. However, the economic situation in Cyprus remains precarious, as reflected in its slow growth rate, declining investment, high unemployment and the volatility of its financial sector. In order to alleviate the pressure on the national budget and to accelerate the highly desirable investments, the 85% co-financing rate for the supported Cypriot programs should be extended until the closure of the operational program. In my opinion, the increased co-financing is justified because these countries have already made serious sacrifices to meet the unrealistic economic policy expectations of the Union's leadership, which is why I supported the motion.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- Given their indebtedness, these Member States are unable to finance public investments conducive to the revival of economic growth.Although these increases may turn out to be positive in the short term, they in no way resolve the structural problems of the Greek and Cypriot economies (competitiveness deficit, over-indebtedness) but on the contrary aim to make them even more dependent on European structural funds.Finally, with constant payment appropriations, these increases will be made to the detriment of other Member States such as France, which will experience even greater payment delays.I abstained on this report which does not propose a viable solution.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - Until 30 June 2016, Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties and having benefited from financial assistance could apply for an increase of 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate usually applicable under the European structural and investment funds (ESI Funds: ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund, EAFRD and EMFF). In order to ensure that Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties can continue to implement programs under the ESI Funds, the European Parliament proposes in particular to cover the period up to 30 June of the year following the calendar year during which the Member State ceases to receive financial assistance, thus allowing the eligibility period to be extended up to a maximum of 18 months. Given the difficulties that Europe is encountering in recovering from the consequences of the financial and economic crisis of 2007 and the need to make the European Union a project more focused on solidarity between Member States, I voted in favor of this text.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - At a politically difficult time for the EU, committed to tackling the outcome of the vote in Great Britain and the severe migrant crisis, some Member States are still suffering from the heavy effects of the economic and financial crisis that has shocked the world since 2008. The problem of growing debt and the succession of austerity maneuvers, adopted to restore balance sheets, have aggravated an already complex situation which, to be resolved, would require not only balance sheet consolidation procedures but above all investments for supporting growth and employment. I voted in favor of the Mihaylova report because I believe it is essential to ensure that Member States in serious difficulties receive financial aid to make the most of the investment opportunities offered by the ESI Funds. To date, only Greece benefits from an assistance program. With the approval of the amendment to Regulation (EU) 1303/2013, the extension of this provision will also apply to countries such as Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal. These are necessary measures and will not affect the Union budget because the temporary increase in appropriations will be offset by a reduction in payments towards the end of the 2014-2020 programs.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this Commission proposal, as it is a temporary solution to alleviate the liquidity problems of the Member States, in particular the Commission proposed to amend the Regulation on the financial management of Member States experiencing serious difficultiesregarding your financial stability.The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have adopted austerity measures to balance their budgets.Since national budgets are under stress, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budget difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- We agree with this specific and budget neutral solution to the transitory liquidity problems faced by Greece and Cyprus.In times of great pressure on these states' own budgets, every effort must be made so that their restrictions do not affect their ability to participate in European programs especially focused on development policies.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - With the austerity policies wanted by the European Commission and the limitation of de facto investments, many countries are no longer able to co-finance projects eligible for European structural funds. Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 provides for an increase in the rate of co-financing of States which have received financial assistance from the European Union after 31 December 2013. The current proposal would allow the Commission European Union to continue to make increased payments in favor of any Member State benefiting from financial assistance after 30 June 2016 without modifying the overall allocation of the ESI Funds for the period 2014/2020, in particular with regard to Greece and Cyprus. Although these increases are good in the short term, they do not solve the structural problems of the economies of these countries; they make countries more dependent and cause even greater payment delays for other countries such as France. I therefore abstained.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- Although the aim of the report is to increase the allocation of EU funds to member countries in budgetary difficulties, this proposal does not solve the basic problem called the euro.As long as the Member States are imprisoned in the constraints of the single currency, a wrong currency that suffocates our entrepreneurs and savers, any attempt to ease the euro burden will be insufficient.The only solution is to go back to national currencies to restart our economy.For these reasons I preferred to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies, and states have resorted to austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this context, it is essential to guarantee an optimal execution of the European Funds. With national budgets under pressure, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budget difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of projects. Article 24 and Article 120 (3) of the Regulation on European Funds were created to help those States experiencing transitional budgetary difficulties. Greece is currently the only country benefiting from a financial aid program. Since the economic situation in Greece remains very fragile, the Commission has proposed to extend the provisions on the supplement. On the other hand, Cyprus has been experiencing economic difficulties and a reduction in investments for a prolonged period, for which a higher percentage of co-financing - 85% - was granted between January 1, 2014 and June 30, 2017, whose extension is also proposed until the closure of the 2014-2020 programs. I have voted in favor of this proposal.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR), which allows the Commission to make higher payments (so-called additional payments) to countries in economic difficulties. The financial and economic crisis is a burden on national economies, so Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this context, it is important to ensure the smooth implementation of the main EU funding instrument, namely the European Structural and Investment Funds (EFSI). Due to the heavy burden on national budgets, it may be difficult for countries in budgetary difficulties to find sufficient funding for national co-financing of regional policy projects. The purpose of the Common Provisions Regulation is to help Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial assistance to make the best possible use of the investment opportunities available under the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020. during the programming period. Under this legislation, it has been clarified that the Commission will carry out a review by 2016. June 30 and that, if the economic situation in the countries concerned so requires, the period during which additional support may be granted could be extended. 2016 June 27 The Commission has submitted a legislative proposal to the European Parliament and the Council for this extension.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing.- The financial, economic crisis and subsequent austerity measures have put pressure on national budgets.Countries with budgetary problems may have difficulty in providing sufficient resources for the national co-financing needed for cohesion policy programs.In order to ensure the smooth use of the Cohesion Fund, Articles 24 and 120 of the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) provide assistance to Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties and receive financial assistance.As the Commission's proposal is a targeted and budget-neutral solution for Member States with temporary liquidity problems, I voted in favor of Parliament's report in plenary.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported this report because the implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds programs is demanding, but also requires greater flexibility and the possibility for the Commission to respond more quickly.The proposal seems to me to be proportionate, mainly because of the crisis that is still ongoing in some places and, consequently, further efforts are still needed to improve this mechanism.As long as Member States show progress in addressing the budget deficit and there is an effort to improve public finances, we can also give them some more time to address the shortcomings.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this report.The recent financial and economic crisis has put great pressure on national economies and national budgets have been overstretched.In many Member States, investments by the European Structural and Investment Funds are the main, if not the only, source of investment.However, for countries with budget deficits, it is difficult to find funds at all for national co-financing of cohesion policy projects.Therefore, I support this Report on Financial Assistance to Member States with Budget Deficits.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- Here we are faced with a situation of arsonist: after bringing the economies of Cyprus and Greece to their knees, the European authorities are concerned, in this regulation, with increasing the co-financing rates applicable to the European structural funds forthose countries.However, as I am in favor of helping these people taken hostage, I will not vote against it.I therefore abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this resolution on the proposal to amend EU Regulation No 1303/2013 because I think it is important to financially sustain Member States which have temporary budgetary difficulties. Indeed, this resolution proposes to increase payments from the European Structural and Investment Funds by 10 percentage points. In particular, I believe that Greece needs our solidarity and the EU has to commit to helping it in its economic recovery.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - The continuing economic and financial crisis that began globally in 2008 is weighing on national financial resources while Member States pursue the necessary fiscal consolidation policies. In this context, it is particularly important, in terms of investments for growth and jobs, to ensure that the implementation of programs receiving support from the ESIF (European Structural and Investment Funds) is smooth. At the present time, however, such implementation is difficult both due to procedural problems and due to liquidity problems deriving from fiscal consolidation. This is particularly true for the Member States most affected by the crisis which have received financial support through an adjustment program. It would perhaps help if a temporary mechanism were established at EU level to allow the Commission to increase reimbursements on the basis of expenditure certified under the ESI Funds and to recognize a higher co-financing rate for all operational programs of countries in difficulty. receiving support from the ERDF and the ESF.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - Under pressure from the European Commission, Member States are implementing austerity plans to reduce their budget deficit to 3% of GDP. Austerity which has caused a drop in public investment, particularly in the countries of southern Europe, which are no longer able to co-finance public investment projects eligible for obtaining European structural funds. It is in this context that this report calls for the extension of the mechanism to increase the co-financing rates in Member States receiving financial assistance after June 30, 2016. Only Greece and Cyprus are affected by this mechanism. Although these increases may prove to be beneficial in the short term, they do not solve the structural problems of the Greek and Cypriot economy in any way, but will instead make them dependent on European structural funds. Furthermore, with constant payment appropriations, this mechanism will accentuate payment delays in other Member States to the detriment of beneficiaries of structural funds. This is the reason why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Even though a few years have passed since the economic crisis that affected all the states of the world, it still puts pressure on national economies. EU Member States need to take austerity measures to balance their budgets, and the implementation of European Structural and Investment Funds is needed. These funds are needed when national budgets are under pressure and countries are having difficulty finding sufficient funding to co-finance regional policy projects. Changing the amount of payments could be very beneficial for states facing economic difficulties, which involves a temporary increase in payment appropriations. I voted in favor of the report on certain Member States that are facing or are threatened with such difficulties as regards their financial stability because I believe that the EU needs to come to the aid of all Member States facing financial instability, This is beneficial primarily for states that need these loans, but not least for the EU.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: signed up. - Following this period of financial and economic crisis in which Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets, the EU needs to implement its main financing instrument: the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) for to help them in regional policy. In addition to Romania, four other Member States (Ireland, Portugal, Cyprus and Greece) were eligible for an increase in payment under Article 24 of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011. 1303/2013. Romania, Ireland, Portugal and Cyprus have completed their economic adjustment programs. Of these, only Greece is still subject to an adjustment program and receiving related financial assistance until the third quarter of 2018. Given that Greece continues to face serious difficulties in terms of its financial stability, it should extended the duration of an increase in the amount of payments for Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties. I therefore support the Commission's proposal without amendment in an accelerated procedure.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the amendment to Regulation (EU) 1303/2013 on financial management for some Member States which allows countries that are most in financial difficulties to benefit from more support from Europe. At a time of severe economic crisis, it is important to ensure that they need smooth implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds. The amendment of the regulation in question makes it possible to increase the so-called "reintegrations" in favor of those countries that need to regain financial stability such as Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal. At this moment only Greece benefits from a financial assistance program and therefore the extension of these provisions will also apply to the above countries. Supporting consolidation and investment efforts will allow these countries to have more time to reach a balanced budget, efficiently manage EU-guaranteed financing projects and lead to greater development of the national economy. The changes will not affect the EU budget, as the temporary increase in payment appropriations will be offset by a reduction in payments towards the end of the 2014-2020 programs.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The Commission proposed amending the regulation relating to financial management for Member States experiencing serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability. As national budgets are under strain, it may be hard for countries experiencing budgetary difficulty to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects. The proposed regulation allows the Commission to make increased payments under ESIF programmes to these countries. At the request of a Member State, interim payments may be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each priority for the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund, or to each measure for the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). The ‘top-up’ does not change the overall ESIF allocations in 2014-2020. This concerns the case of Greece. For the case of Cyprus, the Commission proposed that the period of eligibility for Cyprus for the co-financing rate of 85% will continue until the closure of the 2014-2020 programmes. This will give Cyprus more time to balance its budget and at the same time run the ERDF and ESF projects.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this legislative report because we do not feel that British taxpayers’ money should be used to prop up vanity and propaganda projects in Europe. We note that the alleged financial difficulties in southern Europe that are being used to justify this additional support are largely to blame on the EU and its failing and doomed Euro currency. We fail to see how the EU, which created this mess, could possibly solve it.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the extension of the provisions for financial assistance after coming under economic adjustment programmes due to the persistent fragile nature of the economies of both Cyprus and Greece. I believe that the Commission proposal is a focused and budget-neutral solution to the temporary liquidity problems faced by both EU Member States. I therefore voted in favour of the Commission proposal without any amendment.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report which accepts, without amendments, the Commission's proposal to amend Articles 24 and 120 of the Common Provisions Regulation, proposing the extension of the top-up of co-financing to Greece and Cyprus (due to their difficultiesrelated to the crisis) for the ERDF and ESF programs beyond 2016 and until the closure of the programming.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted on the report on financial management for some Member States facing or threatened with serious difficulties in terms of their financial stability.In recent years, Europe has faced the difficulties of the economic crisis and we have all realized the importance of such situations.We must support Member States that are threatened by financial instability.Therefore, I voted in favor.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - Voting in favor of extending interim payments from the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds to Member States experiencing persistent and burdensome budgetary difficulties is not an option to depart from. In fact, the crisis that has pervaded the EU for years must be eradicated as soon as possible by any means.
