Therefore, facilitating the implementation of the ESI Funds, the main financing instrument available to the Union, is a categorical imperative, as long as the total appropriations foreseen for the 2014-2020 period are not changed. Likewise, if this is true, as well stated by the provision, it must also be recognized that medium and long-term financial support is feasible only if accompanied by adequate macroeconomic adjustment programs. Consequently, I agree, in line with the provisions of Regulation (EU) no. 1303/2013 that the Union support to requesting States does not exceed the public expenditure of the latter, since putting a country in a position to walk on its own legs must not mean spoiling it by paying past debts or unrealized development reforms.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 as regards certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The economic and financial crisis put strong pressure on national economies, with Member States taking adjustment measures to balance their budgets. With pressure on national budgets, it may be difficult for countries in budget difficulties to have sufficient resources to nationally co-finance projects in the area of ​​regional policy. Accordingly, with the amendments made to Regulation 1303/2013, aid is granted to Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties. The aim is to increase payments to a Member State under an adjustment program, by applying a 10 percentage point supplement to the co-financing rates applicable to the program priorities. It is also proposed to change the period during which the country receives financial assistance and is eligible for additional payments. For the 2014-2020 period, the Commission has proposed to continue the eligibility of a Member State until 30 June of the year following the calendar year in which the Member State no longer receives financial assistance. The increase in co-financing will have a positive effect on the economies of the Member States concerned, which are in a position to mobilize more resources to complement investment efforts. For this reason, I supported this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the measure as Article 24 CPR allows the Commission to increase payments of ESI Fund programs, the so-called top-ups, to countries facing budgetary difficulties.The financial and economic crisis has put a strain on national economies and Member States have taken austerity measures to rebalance their budgets.Faced with this situation, it is important to ensure a smooth implementation of the main EU funding instruments, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds), also in the face of national budgets which are under pressure and makecountries that are in financial difficulties, find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because its practical implementation contributes to slightly reducing the consequences of the cuts applied in Member States such as Greece or Cyprus, which have extremely affected the most vulnerable socio-economic classes.With this amendment to the Regulation, payments for Member States experiencing budgetary difficulties are increased.Although it is an insufficient measure, it is a palliative, and this must be the orientation taken by the institutions to mitigate the effects of the economic crisis and not the application of sanctions and suspension of payments with which the Council and the Commission threaten Spain andPortugal.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: signed up.- The financial and economic crisis is putting pressure on national economies, and Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets, leading to budgetary difficulties in finding sufficient funds to co-finance regional policy projects.Countries such as Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal were eligible for additional payments from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2016. Greece is the only country where a financial assistance program is currently applied, the others exceeding the application period..I voted to change the period in which a country receiving financial assistance is eligible for additional payments.This may lead to an increase in administrative capacity to achieve greater absorption of funds.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the proposal to deal with the problem in Member States facing or threatened with serious difficulties with regard to financial stability.Given the consequences of the financial and economic crisis faced by Member States, it becomes so important to implement the European Structural and Investment Funds efficiently.I believe that the proposed solution, which will not change the annual ceilings of the multiannual financial framework for commitments and payments, is the best response to the temporary liquidity problems in the Member States.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies. Therefore, it is important to ensure the smooth implementation of the main EU funding tool, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF). In many Member States, investments by the European Structural and Investment Funds are the main source of investment, and thus we must ensure a beneficial implementation of the Fund.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The report accepts without amendments the Commission's proposal to allow five Member States (Romania, Ireland, Portugal, Cyprus and Greece) to benefit from increased payments as they are in the process of implementing economic adjustment programs. In practice, it is proposed to extend the top-up of co-financing for the ERDF and ESF programs beyond 2016 and up to the end of the programming, but without any changes to the EU budget. Therefore, I welcome the proposal from the European Commission, and therefore also the rapporteur's report, as I did last year for the provision to advance pre-financing to Greece. At such a difficult time, a higher co-financing rate is essential to finance those public investments that can help the country and the population, and these Commission proposals are moving in the right direction. The Five Star Movement has always shown itself in favor of measures of this type, giving voice to the needs of citizens and supporting the governments that know how to listen to it. The fight against austerity is one of our priorities against European myopia and, as we expected, the facts are proving us right.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- The financial situation of Cyprus and Greece is such that without assistance from the European Union, the sustainability of projects, co-financed by these States and European funds, would no longer be guaranteed.In order to preserve these projects, I voted in favor of the report on the financial management of certain Member States which are experiencing serious difficulties or the threat of serious difficulties with their financial stability.The temporary increase in Union payments, linked to this additional aid, is expected to be offset by a decrease in payments before 2020.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - The financial, economic crisis and subsequent austerity measures have put pressure on national budgets. Countries with budgetary problems may have difficulty in providing sufficient resources for the national co-financing needed for cohesion policy programs. In order to ensure the smooth use of the Cohesion Fund, Articles 24 and 120 of the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) provide assistance to Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties and receive financial assistance. Cyprus has been given a more developed regional classification in the current cohesion policy and would normally receive 50% co-financing for ERDF-ESF programs. However, given that Cyprus is experiencing economic difficulties and investment has been declining for a long time, it will receive a higher co-financing rate of 85% under Article 120 (3) of the CPR for the period from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2017. The Commission has decided to propose an extension of the 85% co-financing eligibility until the end of the 2014-2020 programs, as it sees a further deterioration of the economic situation in Cyprus. As the Commission's proposal is a targeted and budget-neutral solution for Member States with temporary liquidity problems, I voted in favor of Parliament's report in plenary.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national budgets. Countries with budgetary problems may find it difficult to provide sufficient resources for the national co-financing needed for cohesion policy programs. In order to ensure the smooth use of cohesion funds, assistance will be provided to those Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial assistance. Between 1 January 2014 and 30 June 2016, Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal were eligible for this additional support. Greece is the only country that is currently a beneficiary of the aid scheme. Given that the economic situation in Greece remains fragile, the Commission has proposed to continue the additional support. Cyprus has been given a more developed regional classification in the current cohesion policy and would normally receive 50% co-financing for ERDF-ESF programs. However, given that Cyprus is experiencing economic difficulties, it will receive a higher co-financing rate of 85% under Article 120 (3) of the CPR for the period from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2017. The Commission has decided to propose an extension of the 85% co-financing eligibility until the end of the 2014-2020 programs, as it sees a further deterioration of the economic situation in Cyprus. As the Commission's proposal is a targeted and budget-neutral solution for Member States with temporary liquidity problems, I voted in favor of Parliament's report in plenary.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - At the request of the European Commission, Member States are implementing austerity policies aimed at reducing their fiscal deficits to 3% of GDP, causing a decline in public investment, particularly in Greece, Portugal and Cyprus. These countries are no longer able to co-finance projects eligible for European funds. It is in this context that Regulation 1303/2013 provides for an increase in the rate of co-financing of States which have received financial assistance from the EU after 12/31/2013. The text would allow the Commission to continue to make increased payments to any Member State receiving financial assistance after 30/06/2016 without modifying the overall allocation of the ESI Funds for 2014/2020. Although these increases may turn out to be positive in the short term, they in no way resolve the structural problems of these economies (competitiveness deficit, over-indebtedness). On the contrary, they aim to make them even more dependent on European structural funds. Finally, with constant payment appropriations, these increases will be to the detriment of countries like France, which will suffer even more substantial payment delays. Also, I abstained.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- We are voting in favor of the report.Although the report is essentially about Greece, we are opposed to any assistance from the Union, which puts our aid even deeper into the nets of the Memorandum.When we say we are against the Memorandum, we are against the whole Memorandum, even the slightest positive predictions that result from it.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. - Countries with budgetary problems may have difficulty in allocating sufficient resources to co-finance cohesion policy programs. In order to ensure the smooth use of the Cohesion Fund, Articles 24 and 120 of the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) provide assistance to Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties and receive financial assistance. Between 1 January 2014 and 30 June 2016, Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal were eligible for this additional support. The financial assistance programs for Cyprus, Ireland, Portugal and Romania expired during this period, with Greece being the only country still a beneficiary of the assistance program. Given that the economic situation in Greece remains very fragile, the Commission has proposed to continue the additional aid. Cyprus has been given a more developed regional classification in the current cohesion policy and would normally receive 50% co-financing for ERDF-ESF programs. Cyprus is experiencing economic difficulties and a long period of declining investment, receiving 85% co-financing under Article 120 (3) of the CPR for the period from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2017. The Commission has decided to propose an extension of the 85% co-financing eligibility until the end of the 2014-2020 programs. As the Commission's proposal is a targeted and budget-neutral solution for Member States with temporary liquidity problems, I voted in favor of Parliament's report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The economic and financial crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States to adopt austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this context, it is important to ensure the correct implementation of the EU's main financing instrument, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF). With national budgets under pressure, it may be difficult for countries in budget difficulties to find sufficient resources for national co-financing of projects in the field of regional policy. The legislation clearly indicates that the Commission would carry out a review before 30 June 2016 and that, if the economic situation of the countries concerned so required, the period for providing additional support would be extendable. The Commission has submitted a legislative proposal to the European Parliament and the Council on this extension, which I agree with as it is a precise and budget-neutral solution to the temporary liquidity problems facing two Member States.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention: in view of their indebtedness, these Member States are unable to finance public investments conducive to the revival of economic growth.Although these increases may turn out to be positive in the short term, they in no way resolve the structural problems of the Greek and Cypriot economies (competitiveness deficit, over-indebtedness) but on the contrary aim to make them even more dependent on European structural funds.Finally, with constant payment appropriations, these increases will be made to the detriment of other Member States such as France, which will experience even more substantial payment delays.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The economic and financial crisis, as a result of the application of EU policies, has called into question the ability of States to respond to the co-financing requirements of structural and investment funds - which are, in fact, the only (insufficient) vector of investment in most of these countries. In this context, at the request of a Member State, interim payments may be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each priority for the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Maritime Affairs and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). The measure is identical in content to the one already adopted for the countries intervened by the troika. It now applies exclusively to Greece and Cyprus. We voted in favor, even though we believe that this measure could be extended to other countries. However, it is, of course, a mere palliative that does not resolve the fundamental issue of the constraints that prevent adequate investment flows in these countries. These constraints - which are increasingly necessary to remove - are related to the policies and instruments of submission of States by the EU, of which the Euro and Economic and Monetary Union are a greater example.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- The economic and financial crisis has placed considerable pressure on the national economies of the EU Member States, forcing them to undertake austerity measures to restore balance sheets.In this delicate situation, I believe it is essential that the EU guarantees adequate implementation of the main European financing instruments, namely the European Structural and Investment Funds.I voted in favor of the report because it proposes changes that could increase the level of payment appropriations, providing concrete help to the liquidity problems of some Member States, and at the same time would not profoundly alter the Union budget.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am abstaining from the report because, despite some positive steps, I am still convinced that the necessary measures to be taken are those concerning the overcoming of the single currency.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report A8-0292 / 2016.Although it essentially concerns Greece, I am opposed to any help from the Union, which helps us to go even deeper into the nets of the Memorandum.When we say we are against the Memorandum, we are against the whole Memorandum, even the slightest positive predictions that result from it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recent financial and economic crisis puts pressure on national economies. National budgets are under strain. Consequently, in many Member States, investments by the European Structural and Investment Funds are the main or sole source of investment.  However, for countries experiencing budgetary deficits, it might be difficult to find funds for the national co-financing of cohesion policy projects. Articles 24 and 120(3) of the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) intend to help Member States receiving financial assistance and experiencing budgetary deficits. Article 24 allows for so-called ‘top-ups’ – increased payments under ESIF. Currently, only Greece has a financial assistance programme in place under Article 24 of the CPR. Given the fragile economic state of Greece, the Commission proposed the continuation of top-up provisions which would otherwise have stopped if the Commission had not come forward with a legislative proposal before the end of the accounting year (30 June 2016). After a review, the Commission had to come up with a proposal for a possible extension of co-financement rate for Cyprus before 30 June 2016. The legislative proposal foresees the extension of 85% of co-financement until the end of 2014-2020 financial period. I supported the proposal in the Plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - The financial, economic crisis and subsequent austerity measures have put pressure on national budgets. Countries with budgetary problems may have difficulty in providing sufficient resources for the national co-financing needed for cohesion policy programs. In order to ensure the smooth use of the Cohesion Fund, the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) provides assistance to Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial assistance. Between 1 January 2014 and 30 June 2016, Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal were eligible for this additional support. The financial assistance programs for Cyprus, Ireland, Portugal and Romania expired during this period, with Greece being the only country still a beneficiary of the assistance program. Given that the economic situation in Greece remains very fragile, the Commission has proposed to continue the additional aid. As the Commission's proposal is a targeted and budget-neutral solution for Member States with temporary liquidity problems, I voted in favor of Parliament's report in plenary.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. - The financial, economic crisis and subsequent austerity measures have put pressure on national budgets. Countries with budgetary problems may have difficulty in providing sufficient resources for the national co-financing needed for cohesion policy programs. In order to ensure the smooth use of the Cohesion Fund, Articles 24 and 120 of the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) provide assistance to Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties and receive financial assistance. Between 1 January 2014 and 30 June 2016, Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal were eligible for this additional support. The financial assistance programs for Cyprus, Ireland, Portugal and Romania expired during this period, with Greece being the only country still a beneficiary of the assistance program. Given that the economic situation in Greece remains very fragile, the Commission has proposed to continue the additional aid. As the Commission's proposal is a targeted and budget-neutral solution for Member States with temporary liquidity problems, I voted in favor of Parliament's report in plenary.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report bearing in mind that the financial and economic crisis has put great pressure on national economies, and Member States have resorted to austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this situation of particular need, it is important to ensure the successful implementation of the Union's main financing instrument - the European Structural and Investment Funds - as, with national budgets under pressure, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budgetary difficulties finding sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects. At the request of a Member State, interim payments can be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each priority, which is of vital importance in those States that are suffering the consequences of budgetary adjustments.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the proposal for regulation (EU) no. 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions relating to Member States in financial difficulty, to address the liquidity problems particularly felt in certain Member States as a result of the economic and financial crisis and to facilitate the implementation of the programs provided for in the framework European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds), as in some Member States they are the only possible sources of investment. Specifically, articles 24 and 120 of regulation (EU) no. 1303/2013 can be used to help Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties and consequently receiving financial aid to make the most of the investment opportunities offered by the ESI Funds and to implement the programs they have set for themselves, by providing funds to projects, through an increase in the share co-financed by the European Commission. I strongly supported the Committee on Regional Development's proposal to accept the Commission's proposal to extend Greece's eligibility for top-up payments for a certain period and to extend these provisions to all Member States who need and benefit. financial assistance after joining an economic adjustment program.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: written.- For the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No. 1303/2013 on certain rules for financial management in relation to certain difficulties or difficulties with regard to their financial stability.Member States that are seriously threatened by serious difficulties voted to call for the Commission's proposal to be rejected at first reading.The Commission wants to give itself freedom here beyond parliamentary control, which I will not endorse.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- I consider European solidarity in times of crisis to be a special achievement of our community of values.Such solidarity is reflected, among other things, in the granting of higher payments to Member States with temporary budget difficulties.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed modifications because the legislation might temporarily increase payment appropriations, which would be offset by lower payments towards the end of the 2014-2020 programmes. There should not be any changes to the multiannual financial framework annual ceilings for commitments and payments, which are set out in Annex I to Regulation 1311/2013.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because this is the cohesion policy we want and we recognize and work for. Co-financing is a crucial aspect of the use, especially good use, of the structural funds. There are many local administrations that encounter enormous difficulties in putting their share of financing into projects to be implemented with the structural funds. Increasing the co-financing rates for those countries that are in the greatest economic difficulties means enabling them to be able to make the investments necessary for growth, investments that would never be made without cohesion policy. It is an important measure, but we need to go further. The next step must be the unbundling of co-financing from the Stability Pact, in order to truly untie the chains of administrations and relaunch investments. And precisely those who, like me, understand the cohesion policy at the service of the territories that need it can only condemn a priori the possibility that the Commission "sanctions" Spain and Portugal with the suspension of structural funds to punish them for their excessive deficit. Cohesion policy is not a weapon in the hands of the Commission, but a right, a privilege of being Member States of a Union that must be coherent and courageous.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: in writing.- Noting the budgetary and financial difficulties encountered by certain Member States in the co-financing of projects relating to regional development, the report proposes to increase the payments made to Member States engaged in an adjustment program after June 30, 2016 and to extendthe exceptional rate of co-financing of 85% under the ERDF and the ESF in Cyprus until the closure of the programs for the period 2014-2020.However, it appears that these measures in no way resolve the structural problems encountered by Greece and Cyprus, but above all risk making them even more dependent on European structural funds.In addition, other Member States may have to suffer the consequences of these increases.For these reasons, I abstained on this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this Commission proposal, as it is a temporary solution to alleviate the liquidity problems of the Member States, in particular The Commission proposed to amend the Regulation on the financial management of Member States experiencing serious difficultiesregarding your financial stability.The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have adopted austerity measures to balance their budgets.Since national budgets are under stress, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budget difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed modifications because the legislation might temporarily increase payment appropriations, which would be offset by lower payments towards the end of the 2014-2020 programmes. There should not be any changes to the Multiannual Financial Framework annual ceilings for commitments and payments, which are set out in the Annex I of Regulation 1311/2013.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because it should help countries facing real budgetary difficulties to make the best use of the structural funds.Indeed, the crisis is straining national budgets, threatening, in some Member States, the co-financing of regional policy projects.We must therefore avoid the double penalty for these states, the investment made possible by European funds often being a key element for growth.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The current proposal would allow the Commission to continue making increased payments to any Member State which will benefit from financial assistance after 30 June 2016 for the period it will be under this support mechanism, without modifying the overall the European Structural and Investment Funds allocation in 2014-2020. Until now programme implementation has been often challenging, not least as a result of the liquidity problems resulting from fiscal consolidation. This is particularly the case for those Member States which have been most affected by the crisis.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. - The financial and economic crisis and the subsequent austerity measures have put severe pressure on national budgets. Countries with budgetary problems may find it difficult to provide sufficient resources for the national co-financing needed for cohesion policy programs. In order to ensure the smooth use of the Cohesion Fund, Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties will be assisted under Articles 24 and 120 of the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR). Between 1 January 2014 and 30 June 2016, Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal were eligible for this additional support. The financial assistance programs for Cyprus, Ireland, Portugal and Romania expired during this period, with Greece being the only Member State still benefiting from the assistance program. Given that the economic situation in Greece remains very fragile, the Commission has proposed to continue the additional aid. Cyprus has been given a more developed regional classification in the current cohesion policy, so it would receive 50% co-financing for ERDF-ESF programs. However, given the economic difficulties in Cyprus and the long-term decline in investment, it will receive a higher co-financing rate of 85% under Article 120 (3) of the CPR for the period from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2017. The Commission has decided to propose an extension of the 85% co-financing eligibility until the end of the 2014-2020 programs, as the economic situation in Cyprus has further deteriorated.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The report provides substantial support for the Council 's legislative proposal, which will allow Cyprus to implement a maximum co - financing rate of 85% instead of 50% due to the fragile state of our economy.At the same time, it suggests a 10% increase in interim payments in countries such as Greece.For these reasons, we voted in favor of the report

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very happy to support the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 as regards certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability. The proposal for a regulation amends the Common Provision Regulation of European Structural and Investment Funds, with the aim of increasing the co-financing rate for interim payments from 85% to 95% (top—up) for Greece and from 50% to 85% for Cyprus regarding funds from ERDF and ESF until both programmes close. I am happy that the Commission proposal is focused and neutral in terms of budget and will help to solve temporary liquidity problems faced by the two Member States. Thankfully, there is no impact on the MFF annual ceilings for commitments and payments.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: written. - The legislative report by Bulgarian MEP Iskra Mihaylova from the liberal ALDE group provides for higher payments for Member States with temporary budget difficulties under EU cohesion policy. At the request of a Member State, interim payments can be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each ERDF, ESF and Cohesion Fund priority or EAFRD and EMFF measure. To this end, the relevant Council Regulation No. 1303/2013 is to be amended. Such an approach should be viewed critically, as the focus is not placed on necessary measures by the Member States with regard to budget consolidation, the provision of professional administrative capacities and the implementation of sustainable projects and programs. Rather, as with the EFSI, attempts are being made to offset existing structural problems in the member states with more money. Such an approach is not serious, which is why I reject this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) no.1303/2013 as regards certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States which are in difficulty or which are threatened with serious difficulties with regard to their financial stability, given that, these countries are provided with more favorable conditions for the use of funds from the European Structural and Investment Funds.For example, the co-financing rate for projects in Cyprus is 85% instead of 50%, while in Greece the percentage is 95%.Such a measure would remain until the end of the 2014-2020 programming period.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- Member States are in such a debt situation that it is difficult for them to boost economic growth through public investment.Moreover, this policy would only have the effect of reinforcing the dependence of the most fragile economies on European structural funds, and would not resolve the deep shortcomings of the beneficiary states.Finally, these increases must not be made to the detriment of other economies which are already showing late payments.Consequently, I abstained.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the EU regulation on the review of increased advances on dividends from the European Structural and Investment Funds.The report focuses on the financial management of some EU Member States that are experiencing or are facing serious difficulties with financial stability.I welcomed this proposal because it offers a budget-neutral way out of the temporary liquidity problems in these countries.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Iskra Mihaylova on the extension of aid granted to States facing temporary financial difficulties.Certain Member States such as Greece and Cyprus are in fact not in a position to find sufficient resources for the national co-financing of European regional policy projects.However, measures are provided for in the regulations to help Member States in financial difficulty to maximize the opportunities offered by European funds.The Mihaylova report thus endorses the European Commission's proposal to ensure that European funds are not lost for countries in difficulty, in particular by increasing co-financing rates without impacting the European budget.This proposal is indeed budget neutral.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: in writing. - The financial and economic crisis is putting pressure on national economies and Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this situation, it is important to ensure the smooth implementation of the EU's main financing mechanism, namely the European Structural and Investment Funds (GRNET). I voted in favor of this report, as I support so-called "supplementary" payments, under GRNET programs, in countries facing financial difficulties.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- Since this is a budget-neutral solution to cushion temporary liquidity problems in the financing of regionally important projects and funding from the ESI funds, I am voting in favor of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed modifications because the legislation might temporarily increase payment appropriations, which would be offset by lower payments towards the end of the 2014-2020 programmes. There should not be any changes to the Multiannual Financial Framework annual ceilings for commitments and payments, which are set out in the Annex I of Regulation 1311/2013.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: written. - The legislative report by Bulgarian MEP Iskra Mihaylova from the liberal ALDE group provides for higher payments for Member States with temporary budget difficulties under EU cohesion policy. At the request of a Member State, interim payments can be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each ERDF, ESF and Cohesion Fund priority or EAFRD and EMFF measure. To this end, the relevant Council Regulation No. 1303/2013 is to be amended. Such an approach should be viewed critically, as the focus is not placed on necessary measures by the Member States with regard to budget consolidation, the provision of professional administrative capacities and the implementation of sustainable projects and programs. Rather, as with the EFSI, attempts are being made to offset existing structural problems in the member states with more money. Such an approach is not serious, which is why I reject this report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - The financial, economic crisis and subsequent austerity measures have put pressure on national budgets. Countries with budgetary problems may have difficulty in providing sufficient resources for the national co-financing needed for cohesion policy programs. In order to ensure the smooth use of the Cohesion Fund, Articles 24 and 120 of the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) provide assistance to Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties and receive financial assistance. Cyprus has a more developed regional classification in the current cohesion policy and would normally receive 50% co-financing for the ERDF and ESF programs. However, given the economic difficulties in Cyprus and the long-term decline in investment, it will receive a higher co-financing rate of 85% under Article 120 (3) of the CPR for the period from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2017. The Commission has decided to propose to extend the eligibility for 85% co-financing until the end of the 2014-2020 programs, as it sees a further deterioration of the economic situation in Cyprus. As the Commission's proposal is a targeted and budget-neutral solution for Member States with temporary liquidity problems, I voted in favor of Parliament's report in plenary.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - I supported the report with the proposal for a regulation on financial management for certain Member States which are experiencing serious difficulties in relation to their financial stability or are at risk of such difficulties. I believe that increased EU co-financing will help countries experiencing budgetary difficulties to allocate funds for additional investment in regional policy projects and will have a positive effect on the economies of these countries. In the context of the financial and economic crisis, countries are forced to take measures to financial constraints in order to stabilize their national budgets. Additional funding from the Commission will help countries that are still experiencing major economic difficulties and are at risk of not being able to make full use of the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the event of temporary budgetary difficulties that Member States may find themselves in, the possibility is envisaged of being able to fully exploit the investment opportunities offered by the European Structural Investment Funds. In order to ensure the effective use of these funds, the possibility is foreseen for the Commission to integrate payments in a given time period, for example from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2016 for those countries which have received financial assistance since from 21 December 2013. In the case of Greece, where the economic situation is still very fragile, the Commission proposes to extend its eligibility for top-up payments. As the proposed changes to the compression ratio (DRC) do not bring any additional honor to the EU budget, and due to the fact that these funds aim to reduce the gap between the most advanced and least advanced regions, I am in favor to their prediction.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on the report on Member States experiencing serious difficulties or threatening serious difficulties with regard to their financial stability.This report proposes to continue the policy aimed at increasing the co-financing rates in favor of the Member States receiving financial assistance (Greece and Cyprus).This can be positive in the short term, but does not address the roots of the economic problems (over-indebtedness, competitiveness deficit).With constant payment appropriations, these increases risk increasing payment delays in the other Member States, in particular in France.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing.- As part of the austerity policies put in place by the EU and aimed at reducing the state public deficit to 3% of GDP, some states are no longer able to co-finance projects eligible for European structural funds.This is why this regulation provides, in particular for Greece and Cyprus, which have already received financial assistance from the EU, an exceptional co-financing rate of 85% for operational programs from the ERDF and the ESF.Even though these adjustments may be beneficial in the short term, they do not in any way address the structural problems of these States (over-indebtedness, lack of competitiveness, etc.).In addition, with constant payment appropriations, these increases will be made to the detriment of the other Member States, including France.Therefore, I abstained on this proposal for a regulation.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because its practical implementation contributes to slightly reducing the consequences of the cuts applied in Member States that are victims of adjustment programs run by the Troika, as in this case Greece and Cyprus (and, previously, Romania, Irelandand Portugal), by reducing the co-financing requirements of the European Structural and Investment Funds.It is worth remembering the perverse effect of these requirements, since on many occasions they have prevented European funds from reaching where they are most needed, as the national (or regional) authorities do not have sufficient resources to cover their part.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written.- In this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament, the latter approves the Council's first reading position on the proposed amendment to Regulation (EU) No. 1303/2013.The amendments are intended to help those Member States that are experiencing transitional budgetary difficulties and that receive financial support so that they can take full advantage of the investment opportunities provided by the European Structural and Investment Funds in the 2014 programming period.-2020.In this sense, it is possible to increase the percentage of co-financing, which can lead to positive results such as improving budgetary consolidation and investment efforts.I give my vote in favor as it is a concrete solution that will help Member States in difficulty.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: written. - The legislative report by Bulgarian MEP Iskra Mihaylova from the liberal ALDE group provides for higher payments for Member States with temporary budget difficulties under EU cohesion policy. At the request of a Member State, interim payments will be able to be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each ERDF, ESF and Cohesion Fund priority or EAFRD and EMFF measure. To this end, the relevant Council Regulation No. 1303/2013 is to be amended. Such an approach should be viewed critically, as the focus is not placed on necessary measures by the Member States with regard to budget consolidation, the provision of professional administrative capacities and the implementation of sustainable projects and programs. Instead, as with the EFSI, efforts are being made to compensate for existing structural problems in the member states with more money. Such an approach is not serious, which is why I reject this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted against.The proposal increases subsidies from the Structural Funds to EU countries that have run into problems with over-indebtedness and are borrowing from the EU (such as Greece).The share of contributions from EU funds to project financing increases by 10 percent.In my opinion, if the co-financing of EU programs drives countries into over-indebtedness, then the share of payments from EU funds should increase and the share of co-financing from national sources should be reduced for all countries, and not just for Greece.I do not support proposals that are in favor of one at the expense of the Czech taxpayer.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: signed up. - The financial crisis continues to put pressure on national economies. Under this pressure, countries are facing difficulties in accessing European structural and investment funds. If the funds are not absorbed, Member States may receive additional financial assistance. The Commission shall carry out an evaluation and, if the economic situation in the countries concerned so warrants, the financial assistance shall be extended. Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal were eligible for extended financial aid from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2016. Financial aid for all these countries, except Greece, has expired. I support this report which contains the Commission's proposal because it proposes to change the length of time a country is eligible for additional payments. The Commission also proposes that Member States continue to be eligible until 30 June of the year following the calendar year in which they cease to receive financial assistance.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of proposal is to help those Member States mostly affected by the financial crisis to be able to continue with the implementation of the programmes on the ground, hence injecting funds into the economy. I welcome the Commission proposal as a focussed and budget-neutral solution to the temporary liquidity problems faced by two Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- The purpose of the regulation is to assist and support certain Member States in the implementation of projects financed by the Structural Funds.These are countries with budgetary problems, including Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal.Under this Regulation, support may be increased at their request by 10% above the co-financing rate for projects financed by the European Social Fund, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund, or for each measure for the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund.fund.This additional assistance will help address the serious economic problems of these countries linked to the financial and economic crisis.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I vote in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No.Council Regulation (EC) No 1303/2013 concerning certain financial management provisions for certain Member States facing or experiencing serious difficulties in terms of their financial stability because it is sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained for this text.This proposed regulation provides for an increase in the co-financing rate, as well as interim payments from the structural funds for Greece and Cyprus.These two countries have benefited from financial assistance from the European Union since 2013, following the financial difficulties caused by the economic crisis of 2008 and the implementation of the European austerity policy.Without this increase, Greece and Cyprus will not be able to use the structural funds granted to them and finance public investments.On the other hand, this remains a short-term solution and risks making the Greek and Cypriot economies even more dependent on European funds.Moreover, this increase, which takes place without changing the annual budget, may delay payments for other Member States, in particular France.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- This report supports the Commission's proposal to amend the Regulation on the financial management of Member States with serious difficulties with regard to their financial stability, as a neutral budgetary solution to the temporary liquidity problems faced by the two Member States,Greece and Cyprus.As national budgets are under tension, it is difficult, if not impossible, for countries with budgetary difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects.For these reasons and with the proposed regulations, the Commission will be allowed to increase payments under ESIF programs for countries that are in economic difficulties.I voted in favor.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: written.- The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have resorted to austerity measures to balance their budgets.With national budgets under pressure, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budget difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects.My support for the amendment of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 as regards a series of provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States that suffer or are at risk of serious difficulties in relation to their stabilityfinancial since in this way we will be able to guarantee the proper execution of the main financing instrument of the Union, such as the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This report deals with the budget problems of individual member states that implement the ESIF program.This ESIF program supports, mainly projects in rural areas.This is a budget-neutral solution.I therefore support this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported the proposed amendments to the regulation, as they will help Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial support to make the most of investment opportunities.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Article 24 and Article 120 (3) of the Common Provisions Regulation (CDR) were designed to help Member States which encounter temporary financial difficulties. The proposed text aims to extend these specific financial arrangements for Greece and Cyprus as they face a difficult economic situation. The proposal notably provides for the possibility of increasing interim payments by 10% above the co-financing rate applicable to the various European funds (ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund, EAFRD, EMFF). It also allows an increase in the co-financing rate of 85% (instead of 50%) under the ERDF and the ESF until the closure of the programs. This is certainly an adjustment and not a modification of the financial envelope allocated to these two Member States, but I note that these provisions could be applied to other countries which would experience the same situation. I vote for this text so that these provisions come into force as quickly as possible

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing.- As part of the austerity policies put in place by the EU and aimed at reducing the state public deficit to 3% of GDP, some states are no longer able to co-finance projects eligible for European structural funds.This is why this regulation provides, in particular for Greece and Cyprus, which have already received financial assistance from the EU, an exceptional co-financing rate of 85% for operational programs from the ERDF and the ESF.Even though these adjustments may be beneficial in the short term, they do not in any way address the structural problems of these States (over-indebtedness, lack of competitiveness, etc.).In addition, with constant payment appropriations, these increases will be made to the detriment of the other Member States, including France.Therefore, I abstained on this proposal for a regulation.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing.- The prolonged financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national financial resources, as Member States have adopted the necessary fiscal consolidation policies.In this context, ensuring the smooth execution of the programs supported by the ESIF (European Structural and Investment Funds) is of particular importance for investment in growth and jobs.This proposal will allow the Commission to continue to make higher payments to Member States receiving financial assistance after 30 June 2016, for as long as it benefits from this support mechanism, without changing the overall ESI Fund allocation in 2014-2020.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution, as it is essential that members of the Union show solidarity in times of difficulty. The proposed measures would allow Cyprus and Greece to be given top-ups to enable European Structural and Investment Funds to be sufficiently co-financed and bring the most benefit to citizens.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - To face the economic and financial crisis, MS had to adopt austerity measures. However, the countries which have budgetary difficulties (Greece and Cyprus) also have difficulties in finding the necessary resources to ensure the national co-financing of regional policy projects which make it possible to provide assistance to the real economy. In order not to undermine the proper functioning of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the regulation on common provisions authorizes the commission to make additional payments by increasing them by 10% above the co-financing rate applicable to the funds. European (ERDF, ESF, cohesion funds, EAFRD, EMFF), without modifying the overall allocation of ESI funds. It foresees for Cyprus an increase of the co-financing rate of 85% instead of 50% of the ERDF and the ESF for the period 2014-2020. By increasing co-financing rates, we are also helping these countries to make investments that are conducive to recovery and create jobs. I support this report, which aims to help Greece and Cyprus, which are currently lacking in liquidity, and beyond any Member State which finds itself in the same situation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Commission has proposed to the Parliament and the Council to amend Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 as regards the provisions relating to the financial management of certain Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to financial stability.In its report, the Committee on Regional Development proposes that Parliament adopt the draft regulation as amended at first reading.I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. - The proposal would allow the European Commission to continue to make increased payments to any Member State receiving financial assistance after 30 June 2016 without modifying the overall allocation of the ESI Funds for the period 2014/2020. These increases concern Greece, which is continuing its adjustment program, and Cyprus, which benefits until 30 June 2017 from an exceptional co-financing rate of 85% for all operational programs from the ERDF and the ESF. In view of their indebtedness, these Member States are unable to finance public investments conducive to the revival of economic growth. Although these increases may turn out to be positive in the short term, they in no way solve the structural problems of the Greek and Cypriot economies (competitiveness deficit, over-indebtedness), but on the contrary aim to make them even more dependent on European Structural Funds. With constant payment appropriations, these increases will be made to the detriment of other Member States, such as France, which will experience even more substantial payment delays. I refrain.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing.- The economic and financial crisis has forced Member States to adopt austerity measures to balance their budgets.The EU's main financing instrument, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), needs national co-financing of projects in the field of regional policy, and with national budgets under pressure, some Member States find budgetary difficulties in finding sufficient resources.I believe that this proposed amendment to the legislation could temporarily increase payment appropriations, which would be offset by a decrease in payments at the end of the 2014-2020 programs.I endorse the rapporteur's position that the Commission's proposal addresses the temporary liquidity problems that two Member States face.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- Regulation n ° 1303/2013 provides for an increase in the co-financing rate for States having received financial assistance from the European Union after December 31, 2013. At constant payment appropriations, these increases will becarried out to the detriment of other Member States such as France, which will suffer even more substantial payment delays.Moreover, these increases will not solve anything since the euro and austerity, responsible for the economic difficulties of these States, are maintained as they are.This is the reason why I abstained.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text on the amendment of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 with regard to certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States experiencing or at risk of experiencing serious difficulties in the pointin view of their financial stability.This budget neutral text aims to help Member States such as Greece and Cyprus which are experiencing financial difficulties to implement projects co-financed by European funds at national level.Concretely, this involves increasing the European co-financing rate applied to ERDF, ESF and Cohesion Fund projects for these countries.This will make it possible to relaunch projects that have been stopped due to the difficulties encountered in mobilizing national funds.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Articles 24 and 120(3) of the Common Provisions Regulation (CPR) were designed, following the financial and economic crisis that has put pressure on EU Member States’ economies, to offer support to help take advantage of the investment opportunities given by the European Structural and Investment Funds during the 2014-2020 programming period. I am in favour of this report, which will extend the provisions for making increased payments under ESIF programmes to Member States experiencing economic difficulties.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: In written form. - As a result of the policy of "tightening the belts" imposed at European level, a large part of public investment in Member States experiencing budgetary difficulties has been discontinued. Against this background, the European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds have become a major driver of the economies of those countries in which the private sector refuses to invest since the onset of the global financial and economic crisis. I believe that if the EU wants to get out of the crisis it is in, it must provide adequate assistance to the Member States, not abandon them in times of difficulty. In my opinion, the possible suspension of ESI Funds in economies that have been experiencing serious financial difficulties for almost a decade will not only deepen the crisis in these countries, but will also provoke a chain reaction in other parts of Europe. That is why I support the amendments to Articles 24 and 120 of Regulation (EU) № 1303/2013, which do not interrupt the ESI Funds for Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties, but on the contrary help to maximize the investment opportunities provided through the program. period 2014 - 2020

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I spoke out in favor of this report because it is a budget-neutral solution to cushion temporary liquidity problems for these regionally very important projects and subsidies.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.The European Structural and Investment Funds are intended to promote regional policy, and Member States have the opportunity to apply, provided that they also have national co-financing.The resolution will allow the Commission to adapt the criteria for funding the funds so that Member States harder hit by the financial crisis can better apply for grants.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Countries facing budgetary difficulties find it difficult to allocate sufficient funds to co-finance regional policy projects. Articles 24 and 120 (3) of the Regulation on common provisions are intended to provide assistance to Member States which are experiencing financial difficulties and receiving financial assistance. The change in the time period in which a country receiving financial assistance will be eligible for additional payments and the fact that a Member State continues to be eligible until 30 June of the Financial assistance through a macroeconomic adjustment program is a step in the right direction. In Cyprus, which under normal circumstances would receive 50% of the co-financing for the ERDF & amp; ECB, 85% co-financing is provided, because it faces financial difficulties and reduced investment. Increased co-financing will have a positive impact on the Cypriot economy, as it will reduce the amounts available for national co-financing and support fiscal consolidation and investment efforts. That is why I voted in favor of this report.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - The procedural amendment of the regulation on European funding funds for countries facing "serious economic difficulties", such as Greece and Cyprus, does not concern any increase in funding, but the acceleration of payments scheduled for later payments. This is another facility for business groups to which European funds - which come from the savage taxation of peoples - are mainly directed through various programs and funds (European Regional Development Fund, European Social Fund, Cohesion Fund, etc.), providing them with immediate liquidity for investment and increasing their profitability. The triumphs of the bourgeois parties are a challenge. The workers, the unemployed have experience: the absorption of funds, in which the SYRIZA-ANEL government has a great performance, inflates the accounts of business groups with subsidies, hot money for their profitability, while the people suffer. As for the jobs they invoke, if and when they are created, they offer the familiar galley jobs with flexible employment and crumbs of the order of 400 - 500 EUR, three - five month (voucher) contracts with even less and without insurance. That is why the people have nothing to expect from the EU and governments and must fight against their policies that give birth to and reproduce the exploitation and generalized attack on workers' popular rights.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this legislative report because we do not feel that British taxpayers’ money should be used to prop up vanity and propaganda projects in Europe. We note that the alleged financial difficulties in southern Europe that are being used to justify this additional support are largely to blame on the EU and its failing and doomed Euro currency. We fail to see how the EU, which created this mess, could possibly solve it.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- There is no doubt that the economic crisis has severely affected national financial resources and forced the States of the Union to implement fiscal consolidation policies.In this context, it is essential to pursue a program that promotes growth and employment.This proposal would provide additional financial resources thus allowing the necessary budgetary flexibility and facilitating the implementation of the ESI (European Structural and Investment Funds) programs.Therefore, I voted in favor.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Among my priorities is the promotion of  funding and investment opportunities for projects in the Member States. In this regard I consider it important to ensure the smooth implementation of one of the main EU funding tools, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF). For this and other reasons I supported the Commission’s proposal.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - It is clear to everyone how much the financial crisis has affected the European Union, but also each individual member state. It has put particular pressure on national economies and Member States have been forced to take austerity measures to balance their budgets. The best form of assistance to damaged economies are the main financing tools of the European Union - the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), and their smooth implementation must be guaranteed. But for countries still experiencing budgetary difficulties, it may be difficult to find sufficient funding for national co-financing of regional policy projects. They need help with that. Therefore, Article 24 and Article 120 (3) of the Common Provisions of the Regulation (CPR), which are designed to ensure that Member States, which are subject to temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial assistance, receive most of the investment opportunities provided by ESIFs during the programming period, are relevant. 2014-2020 The Union's understanding of the problems of individual Member States is evident, as the legislation states that, in the event of a questionable and worrying financial situation in individual Member States, the timeframe for providing additional financial support will be extended. I welcome this report and hope that assistance to the Member States will continue to be a priority for the Union. It is definitely worth fighting for.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: in writing. - Under pressure from the European Commission, the governments of the Member States are implementing austerity policies in order to reduce their public deficit to 3% of GDP, which has caused a drop in public investment, especially in Greece, in Portugal and Cyprus, where the national authorities are no longer able to co-finance projects eligible for obtaining European structural funds. Regulation 1303/2013 provides for an increase in the rate of co-financing of States having received financial assistance from the European Union after 12/31/2013. In view of their indebtedness, these Member States are unable to finance public investments conducive to the revival of economic growth. Although these increases may turn out to be positive in the short term, they in no way solve the structural problems of the Greek and Cypriot economies (competitiveness deficit, over-indebtedness) but instead aim to make them even more dependent on European structural funds. Finally, with constant payment appropriations, these increases will be made to the detriment of other Member States such as France, which will experience even more substantial payment delays. Under these conditions, I therefore prefer to abstain because I disapprove of this senseless policy but do not wish to penalize the peoples that the EU makes suffer.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The financial and economic crisis has burdened national economies and Member States have introduced austerity measures to balance their budgets. Because national budgets are burdened, it may be difficult for countries with budgetary difficulties to find sufficient funding for national co-financing of regional policy projects. I am concerned that the Member States have so far not used the European Structural and Investment Funds sufficiently under this programming period, and I welcome any attempt to guarantee greater and faster compensation to the Member States. I recognize the positive effect that an increase in co-financing would have on the economies of the Member States concerned, which could allocate more resources to additional investment. I welcome the Commission's proposal, which I consider to be a targeted and budget-neutral solution to the temporary liquidity problems that these two Member States are facing. It is clear that an increased co-financing rate would have a positive impact on the Cypriot economy, as it would reduce the amounts earmarked for national co-financing and therefore support financial consolidation and investment efforts. Cyprus will have more time to achieve a balanced budget, while at the same time being able to successfully implement ERDF and ESF projects. However, it is of the utmost importance that the Member States concerned by the proposal have sufficient administrative capacity to deliver results in line with the increase in funding.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing.- The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets.In this context, it is important to ensure the smooth implementation of the EU's main financial tool, the European Structural and Investment Funds.The proposed changes to the legislation may result in a temporary increase in payment appropriations, which would be offset by lower payments towards the end of the 2014-2020 programs.This should not entail changes to the annual ceilings of the multiannual financial framework for commitments and payments as set out in Annex I to Regulation (EU) No 1311/2013.I hereby support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- This report validates a legislative proposal from the Commission aimed at facilitating an additional support mechanism in the establishment of the Union's regional policy for countries experiencing serious financial difficulties.They do not have sufficient means to co-finance these programs.If no decision was taken, regional policy would have declined only partially in these territories.I am happy to have voted for this report, the final budgetary impact of which is neutral.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - The recent context of economic and financial crisis has put pressure on national economies and has forced Member States (MS) to adopt austerity measures in order to balance their budgets. Ensuring the correct implementation of the main EU financing instrument, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), has become a task of crucial importance, because, due to the pressure on national budgets of countries in greatest difficulty, these could not finding sufficient resources to guarantee national co-financing of projects in the field of regional policy. The amendment to Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 will allow some interim payments to be increased, as well as the period during which countries receiving financial assistance are eligible for the additional payment. This proposal aims to be a fair and budget-neutral way of making it easier for economies most affected by extraordinary economic conjectures to overcome their liquidity problems and make the best use of Community programs. As it is a measure that expresses well the term 'European solidarity' in economic matters and because, unfortunately, we are well aware of the reality that this amendment aims to address, I voted in favor.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this legislative report because we do not feel that British taxpayers’ money should be used to prop up vanity and propaganda projects in Europe. We note that the alleged financial difficulties in southern Europe that are being used to justify this additional support are largely to blame on the EU and its failing and doomed Euro currency. We fail to see how the EU, which created this mess, could possibly solve it.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor, recognizing that the economic and financial crisis has put pressure on national economies and that Member States have adopted austerity measures to balance their budgets.In this context, it is important to ensure the correct implementation of the EU's main financing instrument - the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF).With national budgets under pressure, it may be difficult for countries in budget difficulties to find sufficient resources for national co-financing of projects in the field of regional policy.The proposed changes to the legislation could provisionally increase payment appropriations, which would be offset by a decrease in payments at the end of the 2014-2020 programs.There should be no changes to the annual ceilings of the multiannual financial framework for commitment and payment appropriations.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing.- The recent economic and financial crisis has put pressure on national economies and their budgets.Consequently, in many Member States, the European Structural and Investment Funds are the main or the only source of investment.The Committee on Regional Development accepted the Commission's proposal as a neutral budgetary solution to overcome liquidity problems in the Member States and thus help the states most affected by the financial crisis to continue with implementation programs on the ground by injecting funds into the economy.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies, and states have resorted to austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this context, it is essential to guarantee an optimal execution of the European Funds. With national budgets under pressure, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budget difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of projects. Article 24 and Article 120 (3) of the Regulation on European Funds were created to help those States experiencing transitional budgetary difficulties. Greece is currently the only country benefiting from a financial aid program. As the economic situation in Greece remains very fragile, the Commission has proposed to extend the provisions on the supplement. On the other hand, Cyprus has been experiencing economic difficulties and a reduction in investments for a prolonged period, it was granted a higher percentage of co-financing of 85%, between January 1, 2014 and June 30, 2017, which was It also proposes to extend until the closure of the programs for the period 2014-2020. I have voted in favor of this proposal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on a regulation amending Council Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 which concerns certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States which are experiencing serious difficulties or a threat ofserious difficulties with their financial stability.Indeed, as the rapporteur points out, this is a precise and budget neutral solution to the temporary liquidity problems faced by Greece and Cyprus.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- This short but much needed regulation will help Member States in difficulty to balance their public finances.This is particularly important given that European Union investments are co-financed by Member States, which often invest their funds initially and only then recover part of them from EU funds.This creates significant budgetary tensions, especially in countries such as Cyprus, which is not only suffering from financial difficulties, but has also moved from one group of cohesion policy countries to another due to its level of economic development.I therefore support this legislation as an example of European solidarity and a precedent that I hope will be used by other EU Member States in difficulty.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The national budgets of some Member States are under pressure following the economic and financial crisis and the consequent austerity measures taken to balance their budgets, making it difficult for these countries to find sufficient resources for national co-financing regional policy projects. It is therefore important to ensure the correct implementation of the EU's main financing instrument - the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF). Articles 24 and 120 (3) of the Common Provisions Regulation (DRC) are designed to assist Member States that face temporary budgetary difficulties and that benefit from financial assistance to explore investment opportunities offered by FEEI. The European Commission assessed whether the economic situation of the countries concerned required an extension of the deadline for providing additional support, and subsequently presented a legislative proposal with amendments that will provisionally increase payment appropriations in the case of Greece and the co-financing rate to 85 % in the case of Cyprus, possibly giving access to the Cohesion Fund if the nominal Gross National Income per capita of Cyprus is less than 90% of the average. As I agreed with the proposal presented by the Commission, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report which amends Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 on the financial management of certain Member States which are experiencing serious difficulties with their financial stability. Today, some Member States are experiencing budgetary difficulties and are no longer able to ensure national co-financing of projects related to cohesion policy, formerly regional policy. It is important to stress that European law provides for the possibility for the European institutions to help Member States in financial difficulty. This text aims to extend the deadline for the granting of additional support by the Commission. Thus, thanks to this report, the Commission will be able to supplement payments to a Member State under an adjustment program, by adding up to 10 percentage points to the co-financing rates applicable to the priorities of the European Social Fund programs. , the European Regional Development Fund or the Cohesion Fund. It is important to clarify that this extension has no budgetary impact.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
