text: written.- I voted in favor of this Commission proposal, as it is a temporary solution to alleviate the liquidity problems of the Member States, in particular The Commission proposed to amend the Regulation on the financial management of Member States experiencing serious difficultiesregarding your financial stability.The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have adopted austerity measures to balance their budgets.Since national budgets are under stress, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budget difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Commission's proposal on financial management with regard to the Member States which are facing serious difficulties or are threatened with serious difficulties in terms of their financial stability.The aim of the regulation is to help Member States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial assistance in order to make the most of the investment opportunities offered by the ESI Funds.This has been particularly important since the financial and economic crisis in order to ensure the smooth implementation of the EU's main financial instruments.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because its practical implementation contributes to slightly reducing the consequences of the cuts applied in Member States such as Greece or Cyprus, which have extremely affected the most vulnerable socio-economic classes.With this amendment to the Regulation, payments for Member States experiencing budgetary difficulties are increased.Although it is an insufficient measure, it is a palliative, and this must be the orientation taken by the institutions to mitigate the effects of the economic crisis and not the application of sanctions and suspension of payments with which the Council and the Commission threaten Spain andPortugal.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the proposed modifications because the legislation might temporarily increase payment appropriations, which would be offset by lower payments towards the end of the 2014-2020 programmes. There should not be any changes to the multiannual financial framework annual ceilings for commitments and payments, which are set out in Annex I to Regulation 1311/2013.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing.- The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have therefore had to introduce austerity measures to balance their budgets.In this situation, it was important to ensure the smooth implementation of the main EU funding instrument - the European Structural and Investment Funds.As countries are co-financing projects, it was necessary to introduce the possibility to increase the co-financing rate by the European Commission (for a certain period) for countries that had serious difficulties with their financial stability.This period has been extended in the case of Cyprus following this resolution.I voted in favor.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - The changes we have adopted in the Committee on Regional Development are a budget-neutral solution for Member States at risk of a lack of liquidity. As in the REGI Committee, I voted in plenary in favor of adjusting the conditions for drawing on the Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) for certain EU countries. The consequences of the financial and economic crisis are still affecting national economies and national budgets are tight. Therefore, we have decided to relax the conditions for drawing ESI Funds for Romania, Ireland, Portugal, Cyprus and Greece. Increasing payments for these countries will give their economies more resources for investment incentives, as ESI Funds resources still remain the main investment tool in these countries. By modifying the common provisions of the ESI Funds, we want to increase the share of project financing from European sources so that countries with budget deficits do not have to allocate additional funds from their budgets to co-finance cohesion policy. Increased payments will continue for Greece, which is still subject to a financial assistance program. In the case of Cyprus, which is classified as a developed region and would therefore only be eligible for 50% co-financing, this level will increase to 85% by June next year. The volatile economic situation in some Member States is still a source of concern, so we need to direct investment to where it is most needed.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - Some Member States still have financial difficulties, so extending the additional funding of these Member States under the adjustment programs and continuing the higher co-financing rates for Cyprus is welcome, as it will allow for more than the necessary investments. In order to ensure the absorption of funds from the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), the Commission is allowed to supplement the so-called funding from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2016 for countries that have received financial assistance after 21 December 2013. In accordance with these According to the rules, five countries were eligible for such financial assistance - Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Romania. Greece remained included in the program until the end of June, while additional funding from the said program will only be available to Cyprus until 30 June 2017. In the meantime, the Commission will have to analyze the provisions and make a new proposal if necessary. I believe that additional funding for Cyprus is justified, as it is based on clear rules and principles set by the Commission, and such additional funding is only used in exceptional cases. For these reasons, I supported the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: written. - The legislative report by Bulgarian MEP Iskra Mihaylova from the liberal ALDE group provides for higher payments for Member States with temporary budget difficulties under EU cohesion policy. At the request of a Member State, interim payments will be able to be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each ERDF, ESF and Cohesion Fund priority or EAFRD and EMFF measure. To this end, the relevant Council Regulation No. 1303/2013 is to be amended. Such an approach should be viewed critically, as the focus is not placed on necessary measures by the Member States with regard to budget consolidation, the provision of professional administrative capacities and the implementation of sustainable projects and programs. Instead, as with the EFSI, efforts are being made to compensate for existing structural problems in the member states with more money. Such an approach is not serious, which is why I reject this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The necessary degree of solidarity with Member States facing financial difficulties must not go beyond necessity and temporality.Each country is responsible for its own finances, and the European Union should rather encourage them to implement the necessary reforms and to pursue a responsible budgetary policy.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written.- The resolution of the EU Parliament on the "Proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No. 1303/2013 of the Council with regard to certain provisions for financial processing with regard to certain of serious financial stabilityMember States affected by difficulties or seriously threatened by serious difficulties ”I did not agree.It is about financial relief through the back door, in order to make the amount of necessary financial aid in the context of rescue programs appear lower or to achieve a faster exit from these programs through follow-up financing in other ways.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - In the midst of the economic crisis and the burden on national budgets, financial stability is being ensured with funds for financing regional policy projects. Article 24 of the CPR may, at the request of a Member State facing economic difficulties, increase payments by so-called additional funding under an adjustment program to Member States by applying an additional 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each ERDF priority, ESF and the Cohesion Fund or, for each measure, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. Due to the volatile and fragile economic situation of Greece as well as other Member States in need of financial assistance, the Commission proposes to extend the period for additional funding. I support the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) no. 1303/2013 as regards certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States which are in difficulty or at risk of serious difficulties with regard to their financial stability.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the regulation as regards certain provisions on financial management for certain Member States which have or are facing serious difficulties as regards their financial stability.The Commission's proposal will thus provide additional funding for a Member State with financial stability problems under the European Structural and Investment Funds programs.The Commission's proposal will have no budgetary implications, as it would be offset by lower payments at the end of the 2014-2020 programming period.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The report provides substantial support for the Council 's legislative proposal, which will allow Cyprus to implement a maximum co - financing rate of 85% instead of 50% due to the fragile state of the Cypriot economy.The report also suggests a 10% increase in interim payments in countries such as Greece.For these reasons, we voted in favor of the report

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- Although the report essentially concerns Greece, we are opposed to any assistance from the Union, which puts our aid even deeper into the nets of the Memorandum.When we say we are against the Memorandum, we are against the whole Memorandum, even the slightest positive predictions that result from it.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. - The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national budgets. Countries with budgetary problems may find it difficult to provide sufficient resources for the national co-financing needed for cohesion policy programs. In order to ensure the smooth use of cohesion funds, assistance will be provided to those Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial assistance. Between 1 January 2014 and 30 June 2016, Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal were eligible for this additional support. Greece is the only country that is currently a beneficiary of the aid scheme. Given that the economic situation in Greece remains fragile, the Commission has proposed to continue the additional support. Cyprus has been given a more developed regional classification in the current cohesion policy and would normally receive 50% co-financing for ERDF-ESF programs. However, given that Cyprus is experiencing economic difficulties, it will receive a higher co-financing rate of 85% under Article 120 (3) of the CPR for the period from 1 January 2014 to 30 June 2017. The Commission has decided to propose an extension of the 85% co-financing eligibility until the end of the 2014-2020 programs, as it sees a further deterioration of the economic situation in Cyprus. As the Commission's proposal is a targeted and budget-neutral solution for Member States with temporary liquidity problems, I voted in favor of Parliament's report in plenary.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because I agree that the financial and economic crises are putting quite a lot of pressure on the Member States, and in this case, pan-European interests must be taken into account. Due to the crises, the European Structural and Investment Fund is the only source of investment in many Member States, and national co-financing of cohesion policy projects can also be a problem. The report amends certain provisions of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 concerning the financial management of Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability. Under Article 24 of the Regulation, several Member States were entitled to an increased salary, of which only Greece is covered by the adjustment program until the end of 2018. With all these changes, we can ensure the smooth implementation of the EU's main financing instrument, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESB Funds), while the changes are targeted and a budget-neutral solution for the two Member States facing temporary liquidity problems.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The financial and economic crisis that the states of the European Union have gone through in recent years has led to the vulnerability of some of them and the need for their support by the Union. For many of them, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI) are the main financing instrument. In order to ensure the greatest possible impact of these funds, the Common Provisions Regulation (DRC) has been adopted. If the economic situation in those countries persists, additional support measures may be extended and the amount of payments may be increased. This was the case for Greece, Cyprus, Ireland, Romania and Portugal between 2014-2016. Greece is currently the only country where such a program is still in place, as its economic situation is still very fragile. However, even in the case of Cyprus, the application of such measures would be justified, due to economic difficulties and a sharp decline in investment. Because the temporary supplementation of payment appropriations will take place in the period 2014-2020, the budgetary impact will be minimized towards the end of the period. It is a welcome measure to deal with the temporary liquidity problems of the two states. I support the adoption of this document.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - The economic and financial crisis has put pressure on national economies, and Member States have adopted austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this situation, it is important to ensure the smooth implementation of the Union’s main financial instrument, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds). As national budgets are strained, it can be difficult for countries facing budgetary difficulties to find sufficient resources for national co-financing of regional policy projects. The proposed legislative changes are likely to give rise to a temporary increase in payment appropriations, which would be offset by reduced payments towards the end of the programs for the 2014-2020 period. There should be no change in the annual ceilings of the multiannual financial framework established for commitments and payments.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for a regulation relating to financial management for certain Member States experiencing, or threatened with, serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability aims to increase co-financing by the European Structural and Investment Funds to 95% for Greece and to 85% for Cyprus. I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that the EU’s initiative to support regional development in Member States experiencing, or threatened with, serious financial difficulties, such as Greece and Cyprus, is a vital aspect of what the EU stands for in terms of integration and cooperation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal to extend the financial assistance they receive to Member States facing temporary budgetary difficulties, in order to make the best use of the investment opportunities offered by the European Structural and Investment Funds. In this particular case, this applies to Greece and Cyprus. In fact, the conditions for additional funding between 1 January 2014 and 30 June 2016 were met by Romania, Ireland, Portugal, Cyprus and Greece. With Greece still facing serious difficulties in relation to its financial stability and the Cypriot economy still fragile and characterised by a slow growth rate, falling investment, high unemployment rate and a burdened financial sector, the European Commission has proposed extending the duration of financial assistance to these Member States. I think the proposed measures are extremely useful as they represent long-term solutions that aim to reduce pressure on national budgets and accelerate the necessary investments, and I welcome the fact that the proposal will not affect the Financial Budget of the European Union.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 as regards certain financial management provisions for certain Member States which are or are at risk of serious difficulties with regard to their financial stability.  In times of austerity, it is important to ensure the smooth implementation of the EU's most important financial tool – the European Structural and Investment Funds. Article 24 of the CPR allows the Commission to alloe more resources (so-called additional funding) to countries in financial difficulty under the Es iFF programmes.  Interim payments may be increased at the request of a Member State by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each priority from certain Funds. The additional funding does not alter the overall allocation of european Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020.  Cyprus has the status of a more developed region in the current cohesion policy and would, under normal circumstances, be subject to a co-financing rate of 50 % for programmes co-financed by the ERDF and the ESF. The proposed changes to the legislation could temporarily increase payment appropriations, which would be offset by lower payments at the end of the 2014-2020 programming period.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Commission proposal, as it is a temporary solution to alleviate the liquidity problems of the Member States, in particular the Commission proposed to amend the Regulation on the financial management of Member States which are experiencing serious difficulties with regard to their financial stability. The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets. Since national budgets are under strain, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budgetary difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The legislative report by Bulgarian MEP Iskra Mihaylova of the liberal ALDE Group provides for higher payments for Member States with temporary budgetary difficulties under EU cohesion policy. Thus, at the request of a Member State, interim payments should be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each ERDF, ESF and Cohesion Fund priority or to each EORand and EMFF measure. To this end, The relevant Council Regulation No 1303/2013 is to be amended. Such an approach must be considered critical in principle, as the emphasis is not on the necessary measures taken by Member States with regard to fiscal consolidation, the provision of professional administrative capacity and the implementation of sustainable projects and programmes. Instead, as with EFSI, an attempt is being made to make up for existing structural problems in the Member States with more money. Such an approach rewards bad economic policy, which is why I reject this report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text provides for the granting of aid and waivers in the European financial regulation system to Member States which are experiencing serious difficulties with their financial stability. While these increases may be positive in the short term, they do not solve the structural problems of the Greek and Cypriot economies in particular.  On the contrary, they aim to make them even more dependent on European structural funds.  Therefore, I chose abstention for this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The economic crisis has shaken the economies of the Member States of the European Union. Despite austerity policies, many still face, at least temporarily, serious difficulties in terms of financial stability and require support. To this end, we should activate funds from the Structural and Investment Funds. The proposed amendments to the Regulation will ensure a temporary increase in payment appropriations. At the same time, such a move should not entail negative changes to the annual ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework. Growth will be offset by smaller payments at the end of the implementation of the 2014-2020 programmes and will therefore remain budget neutral. In view of the above arguments, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have introduced austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this situation, it is important to ensure the smooth implementation of the EU's main financing instrument, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds).  I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Commission proposal, as it is a temporary solution to alleviate the liquidity problems of the Member States, in particular the Commission proposed to amend the Regulation on the financial management of Member States which are experiencing serious difficulties with regard to their financial stability. The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies and Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets. Since national budgets are under strain, it can be difficult for countries experiencing budgetary difficulties to find sufficient funds for national co-financing of regional policy projects.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, hoping that the tool can be used immediately for States in situations of financial difficulty.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 as regards certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability. The financial and economic crisis has put pressure on national economies, and Member States have undertaken austerity measures to balance their budgets. In this situation, it is important to ensure the smooth implementation of the main EU funding tool, the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF). Article 24 of the CPR allows the Commission to make increased payments under ESIF programmes – so—called ‘top-ups’ – to countries which are experiencing economic difficulties. The Commission is also proposing a modification to the to the time period over which a country receiving financial assistance is eligible for the top-up that might temporarily increase payment appropriations, which would be offset by lower payments towards the end of the 2014-2020 programmes. I voted in favour because I believe that the proposal is a focused and budget-neutral solution to the temporary liquidity problems faced by certain Member States.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The economic and financial crisis has increased the pressure on Member States to balance their budgets. In the light of this situation, it is important to ensure the effective implementation of the Union's main financing tool, which is implemented in the Structural and Investment Funds. This regulation was designed to help States experiencing temporary budgetary difficulties and receiving financial assistance to make the most of the investment opportunities offered by the Union in the period 2014-2020. I therefore vote in favour of the Commission's proposal.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because its practical implementation contributes to a slight reduce in the consequences of the cuts applied in Member States such as Greece or Cyprus and which have extremely affected the most vulnerable socio-economic classes. This amendment to the Regulation increases payments for Member States experiencing budgetary difficulties. Although it is an insufficient measure, this should be the guidance taken by the institutions to mitigate the effects of the economic crisis and not the application of sanctions and the suspension of payments with which the Council and the Commission threaten Spain and Portugal.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The economic and financial crisis and austerity measures have called into question the ability of states to respond to the co-financing of the Structural and Investment Funds – which are, moreover, the only vector of economic and social investment in most of these countries. In this context, at the request of a Member State, interim payments may be increased by 10 percentage points above the co-financing rate applicable to each priority for the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund or the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAGF) and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). This measure is frankly positive because, as has been said, it will allow the flow of cohesion funds to be maintaining, which is still the only sources of investment that states have.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal includes a budget-neutral solution to mitigate temporary liquidity problems for projects and grants that are very important to regionally. Austria also benefits greatly from this fund, which is why I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1303/2013 as regards certain provisions relating to financial management for certain Member States which face serious difficulties or are threatened by such difficulties with regard to their financial stability. The financial and economic crisis is putting pressure on national economies, and Member States have taken austerity measures to balance their budgets. As national budgets are under pressure, it is important to find solutions for co-financing regional policy projects.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The procedural amendment of the Regulation on European funding funds for countries facing "serious economic difficulties", such as Greece and Cyprus, is not about increasing funding but about speeding up payments planned for later. This is another facility for the business groups to which European funds are basically directed - derived from the savage tax avoidance of peoples - through various programmes and funds (European Regional Development Fund, European Social Fund, Cohesion Fund, etc.), providing them with direct liquidity to invest and increase their profitability. The triumphs of the urban parties are a challenge. Workers, the unemployed have experience: the absorption of funds, in which the SYRIZA-ANEL government is even performing well, inflates the accounts of business groups with subsidies, hot money for their profitability, while the people suffer. As for the jobs they claim, although they are created, they offer familiar working-class jobs with flexible employment and crumbs of the order of EUR 400 - 500, three-month - five-month voucher contracts with even less and without insurance. For this reason, the people have nothing to expect from the EU and governments and must fight against their policy, which breeds and reproduces exploitation and widespread attack on labour rights.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Mihaylova report because I agree with the Commission's budget proposal to address the temporary liquidity problems faced by Member States with serious difficulties in financial stability. In this respect, I would like to support for countries in budgetary difficulties to find sufficient resources for the national co-financing of regional policy projects, in particular through additional payments.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 as regards certain financial management provisions for certain Member States which are or are at risk of serious difficulties with regard to their financial stability.  The legislative proposal allows for the continuation of financial assistance to Cyprus and Greece, which are facing financial difficulties and investment falls. The financial resources to be allocated to national co-financing of regional policy projects are a budget-neutral solution to the temporary liquidity problems of those Member States.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of publicly inciting racial hatred in a video posted on the Internet on June 6, 2014. In view of the fact that there is no link between the declaration at issue and the parliamentary functions of Jean-Marie Le Pen and that he has therefore not acted in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the rapporteur has requested the waiver of parliamentary immunity for this criminal procedure. I share the rapporteur's view that I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP decided to vote to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, because the decision made by Patrick Bruel – who is a French singer and who is Jewish – not to perform in a town that has a National Front mayor was met by Mr Le Pen with the following comment, ‘That does not surprise me. Listen, we’ll put them all in the oven together next time’.  Mr Bruel believes that these words were aimed at ‘the Jewish community’, suggesting that some of its members should be eliminated in the same way as had been practised in the Nazi regime. It is important to maintain an element of free speech, but this comment is unacceptable.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of parliamentary immunity to Jean-Marie Le Pen since he has been denounced in France for his clearly Nazi-Nazi-Nazi statements. Although Le Pen himself wanted to appeal to his parliamentary immunity, the facts have nothing to do with his parliamentary work, since they are but the expression of his deplorable far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to racism and hatred.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted to waive immunity in this instance. The MEP in question was recorded making violently anti-Semitic remarks in a 2014 video. Sinn Féin stands against racism and hate speech of any kind. The waiver will allow the National Office for Vigilance against Anti-Semitisim in France to bring a case against him.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr Le Pen's immunity. The immunity of MEPs in the European Parliament is based on the principles and values of the Treaties of the European Union. Hate speech clearly violates these principles and values. Hate speech cannot be justified by freedom of expression. The statements in question cannot in any way be construed as related to the fulfilment of Mr Le Pen's parliamentary mandate and therefore cannot and should not be protected.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the lifting of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity. The prosecution of him in France is a crime of opinion and the interpretation of his words is ridiculous. By voting for the lifting of immunity, the European Parliament has once again demonstrated that its commitment to freedom of expression varies according to political circumstances and colours is an illusion.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Jean-Marie Le Penn is accused of publicly inciting racial hatred. There is no connection between the statement in question and his work as a Member of the European Parliament and he was therefore not acting in his capacity as an MEP.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. Attorney General at the Court of Appeal of Paris in 2016 on 14 March, he referred applications for waiver of the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, which relate to two cases pending before the Paris District Court of the Pre-Trial On the Promotion of Racial Hatred (2211/15/21 and 2226/15/9) relating to the same facts and which were published in plenary on 8 June 2016. Members of the European Parliament have, in principle, the right to freedom of expression, but this right does not confer the freedom to defame, insult, incite hatred or insult honour or to express opinions which infringe Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. It was therefore decided to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved Jean-Marie Le Pen's request to waive parliamentary immunity brought by the Attorney General to the Paris Court of Appeal for inciting racial hatred.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of withdrawing the parliamentary immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, currently accused of inciting racial hatred on several occasions outside his parliamentary activity. French justice called on the European Parliament to suspend this privilege by being accused of charging a series of insults to several artists in 2014, including the Jewish singer Patrick Bruel, who said: "Next time, a load of oven will suffice." It is the fourth time since he entered the Eurochamber in 1984, that his parliamentary immunity has been withdrawn. Parliamentary immunity cannot be used for defamation, let alone to incite racial hatred and xenophobia.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen. The request was made by two investigating judges of the Paris Court in relation to an alleged crime: the MP was accused of publicly inciting racial hatred in a video posted on the Internet on June 6, 2014. The Commission has verified that there is no link between the declaration at issue and the parliamentary functions of Jean-Marie Le Pen and, not suspecting the presence of fumus persecutionis, has decided to waive his immunity.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. Fully in accordance with the legal assessments which, guaranteeing the principle of not harming the political activity of the Member concerned, allow to investigate an alleged crime of incitement to racial hatred. The facts to be investigated have nothing to do with the mandate of Deputy as such. The criminal type to investigate is particularly worrying at the time we live and deserves the utmost attention to prevent more serious crimes.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision to suspend Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary immunity in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which finds that two investigating judges of the Paris Court of First Instance have requested such a suspension in connection with an alleged criminal offence — Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of having publicly incited racial hatred in a video recording published on 6 June 2014 on the Internet. that there is no link between jean-Marie Le Pen's opinion and parliamentary functions, so there is no indication to harbor well-founded suspicions of fumus persecutionis, that is, of intent to harm the Political Activity of the Member.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the request to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen. Two judges of the pre-trial investigation of the Paris Regional Court have applied for the parliamentary immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen to be waived on suspicion of criminal activity. Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of inciting racial hatred in an online video posted on 6 June 2014. The fact that there was no link between the contested statements made by Jean-Marie Le Pen and his parliamentary activities did not affect him as a member of the European Parliament.  The European Parliament therefore decides to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen and instructs the President to forward this decision and the report of the committee responsible to the French authorities without delay.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support Jean-Marie Le Pen's request to lift his immunity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to waive immunity in this instance. The MEP in question was recorded making violently anti-Semitic remarks in a 2014 video. Sinn Féin stands against racism and hate speech of any kind. The waiver will allow the National Office for Vigilance against Anti-Semitism in France to bring a case against him.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to vote to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, because the decision made by Patrick Bruel – who is a French singer and who is Jewish – not to perform in a town that has a National Front mayor was met by Mr Le Pen with the following comment, ‘That does not surprise me. Listen, we’ll put them all in the oven together next time’.  Mr Bruel believes that these words were aimed at ‘the Jewish community’, suggesting that some of its members should be eliminated in the same way as had been practised in the Nazi regime. It is important to maintain an element of free speech, but this comment is unacceptable.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of publicly inciting racial hatred in a video posted on the Internet. Since there is no link between the declaration at issue and the parliamentary functions of Jean-Marie Le Pen and therefore he has not acted in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity, as he is accused of inciting racial hatred in a video posted on the Internet on 6 June 2014.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the request for the waiver of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity. As the request for waiver of immunity concerned activities outside the European Parliament, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for waiver of immunity because the offence alleged against Mr Syderman was not a serious offence. Jean Marie Le Pen took place outside the performance of her duties as a Member of the European Parliament and, since the immunity guaranteed by the European Parliament for acts, opinions and activities during the performance of her duties, there was no valid reason to maintain the immunity of the Member.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the suspension of parliamentary immunity to Jean-Marie Le Pen as he has been denounced in France for his clearly Nazi-Nazi-Naziscist statements. Although Le Pen himself wanted to appeal to his parliamentary immunity, the facts have nothing to do with his parliamentary work, since they are but the expression of his deplorable far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to racism and hatred.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving the parliamentary immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen for incitement to racial hatred in a video posted on the Internet. Indeed, although Article 26 of the Constitution French and Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union protect the right of Members of Parliament to freedom of expression in the performance of their duties, I believe that this right must be interpreted in the light of the values and objectives of the European Treaties. Therefore, freedom of opinion and expression cannot be a licence for slander, defamation, hate speech or slanderous statements, in violation of Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted in favour of the request to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen because that is how I wish to express my disapproval of the behaviour of this MEP. It is simply unsued and unacceptable to admit acts such as incitement to discrimination, hatred and violence against a person or group of persons on the grounds of their origin or ethnicity. Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of publicly inciting hatred against people on a racial basis, and a video posted online on June 6, 2014, was presented as evidence in the case. Although this situation is not closely related to the role of Member of the European Parliament, in my opinion such behaviour should be condemned and I therefore voted in favour of the request for immunity to be waived.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen as there is a request for the waiver of his parliamentary immunity by the Examining Magistrates at the Paris Regional Court.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. Jean-Marie Le Pen has built his career on mystification and outrage. He is now caught up in comments inciting racial hatred on the internet. This is, of course, contrary to the spirit of European integration - based on messages of peace and brotherhood among peoples - in the aftermath of the Second World War. It is in the light of the values, objectives and principles of the European treaties that we have voted to lift immunity.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Freedom of speech and thought are inalienable human rights. It is not possible in 2016 to prosecute a person for their opinion. We consider the prosecution of Mr Le Pen to be of a political nature.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of publicly inciting racial hatred in a video recording published on 6 June 2014 on the Internet, and there is no link between the express opinion and parliamentary functions of Jean-Marie Le Pen and, therefore, Jean-Marie Le Pen did not act in the performance of her duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  I therefore agree with the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jean Marie Le Pen in proceedings brought before the Court of First Instance in Paris. The motive relates to an accusation of incitement to discrimination, hatred and violence with respect to a person or group of persons, taking into account their ethnic, national, racial or religion origin. On June 6, 2014, Le Pen responded to statements by Patrick Bruel, a singer who said he would not perform in cities that had a National Front president, saying, "That doesn't surprise me. Listen, we're going to put them all in the oven together next time."  The right to freedom of expression enjoyed by Members of the European Parliament in principle does not mean that they can defame, slander, incite hatred or make defamatory allegations.  It is considered that the deplorable statements made – which qualify the character, his party and political project – and the process itself have no connection with Mr Le Pen's status and parliamentary activity. We agree with the waiver of parliamentary immunity. As for the rest (which does not fit under this report): to the dustbin of history what should never come out of there!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the request for the waiver of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity. Freedom of speech and thought are inalienable human rights. It is not possible in 2016 to prosecute a person for their opinion. I believe that the prosecution of Mr Le Pen is of a political nature.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The immunity of the Members of the European Parliament is based on the principles and values of the European Union Treaties. Hate speech clearly violates these principles and values, and cannot be justified by freedom of expression. The statements in question can in no way be construed as being linked to fulfilment of the mandate, and therefore cannot and should not be protected.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity, which is the basis for a transparent, fair trial.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request to waive immunity as I agree with the reasons set out in the proposal.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive immunity.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Jean-Marie Le Pen was accused of promoting racial hatred in an online video on 6 June 2014. Due to the fact that there is no connection between the issue of Jean-Marie Le Pen’s statements and his parliamentary activity, he did not act as a Member of the European Parliament. That is why the European Parliament should decide to waive Jean-Marie Le Pen’s immunity and instruct its President to forward the decision and the report by the committee to the French authorities.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity, because it is hate speech and because there is no link between his public statements and parliamentary activities.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the decision on Jean-Marie Le Pen's request to lift parliamentary immunity. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. A review of the case showed that the facts alleged against Mr. Le Pen were unrelated to his parliamentary mandate, thus allowing the lifting of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive immunity.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, since parliamentary immunity is aimed solely at ensuring the smooth and uninterrupted work of MEPs and not at granting them a licence for crime (hate speech). Any abuse of immunity jeopardises the legitimacy of granting this very special status.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of parliamentary immunity to Jean-Marie Le Pen since he has been denounced in France for his clearly Nazi-Nazi-Nazi statements. Le Pen wanted to appeal to his parliamentary immunity, but the facts have nothing to do with his parliamentary work, so I voted in favour of lifting his parliamentary immunity so that he could be judged on his incitements to racism and hatred.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The investigating magistrates in Paris asked the EP to waive the immunity of the Member for France, Jean-Marie Le Pen, in connection with his actions in incitement to racial hatred. The request and the proposal are in line with the EP Rules of Procedure and the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the request for the waiver of Mr Le Pen's immunity, because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases and, consequently, I will continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Members of the European Parliament may not be questioned, detained or held liable for opinions or votes expressed in office, but this right does not confer the freedom to defame, insult, incite hatred or insult the honour. The judges of the Pre-Trial Hearing of the Paris District Court have asked for the parliamentary immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen to be waived because of accusations that he incited racial hatred in a video posted online in 2014. In view of this, and given that there is no link between the contested statements by Jean-Marie Le Pen and his parliamentary activities, he did not act as an executive member of the European Parliament, I support the EP's proposal to waive jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity and thus to enable law enforcement authorities to investigate the case.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report calls for the lifting of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity. The far-right MP is being prosecuted for "public incitement to discrimination, hatred or violence against a person or group of people because of their origin or membership or non-membership of an ethnic group, nation, race or religion" following a video posted on the Front National website. In the offending video, Mr Le Pen says about Patrick Bruel, who has announced that he does not want to sing in the cities where the town hall is in the FN, "It doesn't surprise me. Look, next time we'll make a batch of it." Since there is no link between the contested statement and the parliamentary work of Jean-Marie Le Pen and that, in the eyes of French law, anti-Semitism is not an opinion but a crime, I vote for the lifting of immunity.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In this case, MEP Jean-Marie Le Pen is alleged to have publicly incited racial hatred in a video recording published on 6 June 2014 on the Internet.  There is no link between the opinion expressed and the parliamentary functions of Jean-Marie Le Pen and, therefore, Jean-Marie Le Pen did not act in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  There is no indication of suspicion of fumus persecutionis, i.e. an attempt to undermine the parliamentary activities of Jean-Marie Le Pen.  I therefore vote in favour of lifting Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Two requests for the lifting of Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary immunity, by the Attorney General at the Paris Court of Appeal, were made in connection with two proceedings pending before the investigating judges of the Paris High Court for inciting racial hatred. Jean-Marie Le Pen carried out anti-Semitic attacks in a video recording published on the internet on 6 June 2014. Considering that the alleged offence at the origin of the prosecution does not concern an opinion or vote issued by the Member in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, and also considering that there is nothing to suspect a fumus persecutionis , I decided to vote in favour of lifting Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary immunity.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused in the Paris regional court of using a video posted online on June 6, 2014 to make a public appeal calling for racism. Two investigating judges at the Paris regional court therefore requested the waiver of Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary immunity.  The Committee on Legal Affairs notes in its report that there is no link between the controversial statement and Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary activities, so Jean-Marie Le Pen did not act in the performance of her duties as an MEP and there is no suspicion that she would have attempted to interfere with Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary work. For all these reasons, he proposes that Parliament suspend the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, once all the legal procedures required have elapsed and the fact that the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member, and because there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the decision that Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity would soon be suspended. I do not think it is right for an MEP to publicly call his followers to racism, thereby trampling on European standards that have been built up over many years. I trust that the competent authorities will consider this matter at their best discretion, which should no longer be hindered by the european Parliament's immunity.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report in accordance with the evaluation made by the Legal Affairs Committee.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against the waiver of Mr Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity, as freedom of expression must not lead to the waiver of immunity.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Jean-Marie Le Pen's request for immunity to be waived so that he could be tried by the French Court of Justice for statements deemed to incite racial and racist hatred. , without, however, allowing them to make abusive, defamatory and defamatory claims, incite intolerance or make claims about a person's honour and reputation or any other statement contrary to Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to vote to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, because the decision made by Patrick Bruel – who is a French singer and who is Jewish – not to perform in a town that has a National Front mayor was met by Mr Le Pen with the following comment, ‘That does not surprise me. Listen, we’ll put them all in the oven together next time’.  Mr Bruel believes that these words were aimed at ‘the Jewish community’, suggesting that some of its members should be eliminated in the same way as had been practised in the Nazi regime. It is important to maintain an element of free speech, but this comment is unacceptable.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The immunity of Members of the European Parliament is based on the principles and values of the Treaties of the European Union. Hate speech clearly violates these principles and values. He cannot be tolerated under freedom of expression.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is called for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of The Jean-Marie Le Pen in the context of a legal action brought before the Court of First Instance in Paris for criminal offence: charges of incitement to discrimination, hatred and violence with respect to a person or group of persons taking into account their ethnic, national, racial or religion origin.  On June 6, 2014, Jean-Marie Le Pen responded through different online platforms to the statements of Patrick Bruel, a singer, who said he would not act in cities that had a President of the National Front.  Jean-Marie Le Pen replied: "That doesn't surprise me. Listen, we're going to put them all in the oven together next time."  The right to freedom of expression enjoyed by Members of the European Parliament in principle does not mean that they may defame, slander, incite hatred, racism and xenophobia, or make defamatory allegations or any other statement that may infringe Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  The statements made and the case itself are considered to have no connection with the statute and parliamentary activity in the EP, nor is it suspected that it is political persecution. The rapporteur proposes to lift immunity, an analysis we are monitoring. We voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. "We'll make a batch next time." Here are the comments made by Jean-Marie Le Pen in June 2014 in response to the positions of French celebrities who had indicated their wish to leave France in the event, one day, of victory of the National Front. I voted in favour of lifting Mr Le Pen's parliamentary immunity: this is a classic procedure, considered by the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, which considered that the comments made were not part of the extremist leader's duties as an MEP. Thus, the lifting of his immunity, for the purposes of the judicial procedure in France, is therefore a normal step.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided to vote to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, because the decision made by Patrick Bruel – who is a French singer and who is Jewish – not to perform in a town that has a National Front mayor was met by Mr Le Pen with the following comment, ‘That does not surprise me. Listen, we’ll put them all in the oven together next time’.  Mr Bruel believes that these words were aimed at ‘the Jewish community’, suggesting that some of its members should be eliminated in the same way as had been practised in the Nazi regime. It is important to maintain an element of free speech, but this comment is unacceptable.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. The Attorney General of the Paris Court of Appeal requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, a Member of the European Parliament, in the context of two cases pending before judges of the Paris Regional Court for incitement to racial hatred. Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of publicly inciting racial hatred in a video recording published on 6 June 2014 on the Internet, but there is no link between the expressed opinion and parliamentary functions of Jean-Marie Le Pen and therefore Jean-Marie Le Pen did not act in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. In view of the fact that the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no reason to suppose that the intention behind the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, this request, which I voted in favour of, decides to lift the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of First Instance in Paris requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen in the context of an alleged criminal offence.  Jean-Marie Le Pen is alleged to have publicly incited racial hatred in a video recording published on June 6, 2014 on the Internet. In the context of no link between the opinion expressed and the parliamentary functions of Jean-Marie Le Pen, the European Parliament decides to lift the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision to suspend Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary immunity in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which finds that two investigating judges of the Paris Court of First Instance have requested such a stay in connection with an alleged criminal offence - Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of having publicly incited racial hatred in a video recording published on 6 June 2014 on the Internet- that there is no link between jean-Marie Le Pen's opinion and parliamentary functions, so there is no indication to harbor well-founded suspicions of fumus persecutionis, that is, of intent to harm the Political Activity of the Member.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity so that the French justice system could carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, on the understanding that the facts in question (nasty statements inciting racial hatred in a video) have no direct link to Mr Le Pen's office as an MEP. Freedom of expression in no way allows for defamatory, honour-impairing assertions. Moreover, this request for the lifting of immunity is not motivated by any desire to interfere with the parliamentary work of the person concerned.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Accusations of incitement to hatred are extremely serious, especially when they are made to a Member of the European Parliament. We cannot allow European immunity to hide from responsibility for incitement to hatred, especially when there is footage supporting such accusations. I am therefore voting in favour and I hope that French law will quickly clarify the validity of these accusations.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Attorney General's Office of the Paris Court of Appeal submitted, on 14/03/16, two requests for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Jean-Marie Le Pen, relating to two cases in which he is accused of incitement to racial hatred, in a video recording published on 06/06/14 on the Internet. In detail the provisions of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, the other legislative instruments in question and the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which I endorse, I consider that there is no causal link between the opinion expressed in that recording and the parliamentary functions performed in the European Parliament, so that there is no indication of persecution or intent to prejudice his parliamentary duties, I voted in favour of this report to lift the immunity of Mr Le Pen.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of parliamentary immunity to Jean-Marie Le Pen since he has been denounced in France for his clearly Nazi-Nazi-Nazi statements. Although Le Pen himself wanted to appeal to his parliamentary immunity, the facts have nothing to do with his parliamentary work, since they are but the expression of his deplorable far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to racism and hatred.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the request for waiver of the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, because two investigating judges at the Paris District Court requested that immunity be waived in relation to the alleged commission of a crime allegedly committed in connection with incitement to racial hatred. Jean-Marie Le Pen faces charges that he publicly called for racial hatred in a video posted online on June 6, 2014. Since these controversial statements by Jean-Marie Le Pen have nothing to do with his parliamentary office, and therefore Jean-Marie Le Pen has not acted as a Member of the European Parliament in the exercise of his mandate, and since there is no suspicion of attempting to impede Jean-Marie Le Pen in his work as a Member, we have decided to waive the immunity of the appointee so that the law enforcement authorities can properly investigate the case.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The case concerns MeP Jean-Marie Le Pen and is considering a request for waiver of immunity, which was referred to the Paris Court of Appeal on 14 March 2016 by the French Attorney General.  Two proceedings are now pending in Paris before an investigating judge in the district court for inciting racial hatred. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, a member of the European Parliament may not be investigated, detained or prosecuted for an opinion or a vote which he has given in the performance of his duties.  Such absolute immunity of Members relates to the opinions expressed by them at parliament's official staff, as well as to opinions expressed elsewhere, provided that there is, of course, a link between the opinion expressed and their parliamentary duties. There is no link between The Controversial Declaration and Mr Le Pen's parliamentary duties, so the report proposes to waive immunity.  The Reasoning of the European Parliament in this report seems to me to be absolutely correct. I believe that this kind of expression of hatred should certainly not be covered by parliamentary immunity, which is why I supported the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is unacceptable for a Member of the European Parliament to commit insulting citizens on the basis of their race, religion or belief. We must combat such manifestations uncompromisingly, both at national and European level.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Members of the European Parliament in the territory of their own Member State enjoy immunity equivalent to the immunity granted to members of parliament of that Country. Two investigative judges at the High Court in Paris have applied for Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity to be lifted over a contentious racist remarks in a video posted online on June 6th. Given that the statement at issue is not related to Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary duty, having failed to act in the course of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, I support the report on the application for the waiver of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity to the Legal Affairs Committee.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Freedom of speech and thought are inalienable human rights. It is not possible in 2016 to prosecute a person for their opinion. We consider the prosecution of Mr Le Pen to be of a political nature.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting this Member's immunity so that he could explain himself to the courts of his country.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen. Mr Le Pen suggested in an Internet video, published on his own website and on YouTube, ‘putting them all in the oven together next time’ when asked about the Jewish French singer Patrick Bruel. As there was no link between his public statements and his parliamentary activities, I believe that his immunity should be waived. Furthermore, the incitement to racial hatred was not covered by the freedom of expression clause.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ French MP Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of committing the offence of incitement to discrimination, hatred or violence against a person or group of people based on their origin or belonging to a particular ethnic group, nation, race or religion in a video clip published online. Given that the charged video clip published online on 6 June 2014 is not related to his position as a Member of the European Parliament, i.e. there is no direct or obvious link to the performance of his duties as a Member, I support the rapporteur's view that Le Pen's immunity be lifted and that he be given a fair and impartial trial.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision on the request for the waiver of the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen. The Paris District Court's investigating judges have requested that Ms Le Pen be deprived of parliamentary immunity for allegedly commiting a crime.  Members of the European Parliament enjoy, in principle, the right to freedom of expression, but at the same time this right does not mean that they are allowed to slander, defame, incite hatred or make claims that damage reputation or other statements contrary to Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In view of the suspicion of a criminal offence, I have decided to up to the request made by the investigating magistrates at the Court of Great Instance in Paris. Parliamentary immunity is an additional safeguard for freedom of expression, so that judicial proceedings do not block the courageous parliamentary work of active Members. But the exercise of this freedom takes place within certain limits, which determines respect for the rights and freedoms of others.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. Two investigating judges at the Paris regional court have asked for Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary immunity to be waived in connection with a suspected crime. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity, as in all cases of this kind.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the request to waive the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen. Two examining magistrates at the Paris Regional Court have requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen in connection with an alleged criminal offence. Jean—Marie Le Pen is accused of having publicly incited racial hatred in a video clip published on the internet on 6 June 2014. The purpose of Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union is to ensure that Members of the European Parliament have the right to freedom of expression, but this right does not provide a carte blanche for slander, defamation, incitement to hatred or libellous assertions or any other statement which infringes Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. I voted in favour of the Report because I think that there is no connection between the statement at issue and the parliamentary work of Jean-Marie Le Pen, and there is no evidence suggesting an attempt to prevent Jean-Marie Le Pen from performing his parliamentary work.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of parliamentary immunity to Jean-Marie Le Pen since he has been denounced in France for his clearly Nazi-Nazi-Nazi statements. Although Le Pen himself wanted to appeal to his parliamentary immunity, the facts have nothing to do with his parliamentary work, since they are but the expression of his deplorable far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to racism and hatred.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Parliamentary immunity is not used to protect ordinary crimes.  Jean-Marie Le Pen is accused of public incitement to discrimination, hatred or violence against a person or group of people because of their origin or membership or non-membership of an ethnic group, their nation, race or religion.  It is customary in fact and has already been convicted eleven times for facts similar to those alleged.  The European Parliament is very vigilant about requests to waive parliamentary immunity and ensures strict enforcement of the rules in this area regardless of political affiliation, which I welcome.  I therefore voted to lift Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity in accordance with the proposal of the Parliament's legal committee and at the request of the Paris Prosecutor's Office.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliamentary immunity is intended to guarantee the right to freedom of expression enjoyed by Members of the European Parliament in principle. However, this right does not mean that they may defame, slander, incite hatred or make defamatory allegations or any other statement likely to infringe Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. In this particular case, Jean-Marie Le Pen is alleged to have publicly incited racial hatred in a video recording published on June 6, 2014 on the Internet.  In this sense, we support the waiver of immunity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Since there is no direct and obvious link between Jean-Marie Le Pen's statements and political duties, I voted against the motion and therefore in favour of the protection of immunity.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In this case, Mr Le Pen is accused of inciting discrimination, hatred or violence against a person or group on the basis of their origin, or belonging to an ethnic group, nation, race or religion. The case was supposed to happen via a video posted online in 2014. The report therefore proposed waiving the immunity of the Member. In these cases, when voting, I am governed by the general conditions under which a Member of the European Parliament may enjoy parliamentary immunity, provided that the case has already occurred while he was a Member and is related to the exercise of his mandate. Since, in this case, it is clear that the incident in question is unrelated to the exercise of the mandate, I voted in favour of the report which proposed the waiver of immunity.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen. A MEMBER of the European Parliament is under criminal proceedings for allegedly committing an offence of inciting racial hatred.  I support the request for the waiver of Jean-Marie Le Pen's immunity because , as the Report notes, there is no link between the contested statement and Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary duties and there is no indication that it is an attempt to obstruct Jean-Marie Le Pen's parliamentary work. The immunity of Deputies provided for in Article 8 of the Protocol shall apply only to opinions expressed by a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The question of maintaining the immunity of UKIP MP Jane Collins has been raised following criminal defamation proceedings over claims she made about a child abuse scandal in the English province of Rotherham. Specifically, he accused Labour MPs Kevin Barron, John Healey and Sarah Champion of being aware of the scandal before it was made public in the press, and was later sued by the three Labour MPs for defamation. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. MEP Jane Collins is being subject to civil proceedings in the United Kingdom for statements made in her constituency that are not covered by Article 8 of the Protocol, that is, that they have no connection with her parliamentary activity. For this reason, I voted in favour of the suspension of Jane Collins' privileges and parliamentary immunity.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted to waive the immunity of this UKIP MEP, who is accused of making defamatory and libellous statements against three Labour MPs with regard to an ongoing criminal and administrative inquiry. As the statements were not made in the course of this MEP’s parliamentary duties, I voted to waive her immunity so that parties could be given the opportunity to establish the truth and clear their names, if need be by due process of law.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Jane Collins' immunity. The immunity of MEPs in the European Parliament is based on the principles and values of the Treaties of the European Union. Freedom of expression cannot and should not go beyond these values.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. On 26 September 2014, Jane Collins, a UKIP candidate who was then an MEP, made comments that the applicants considered defamatory. In this case, some Labour Party leaders were reportedly informed of paedophile crimes and did not follow up on them. His comments are part of the freedom of expression that every politician should enjoy. However, in view of the seriousness of the accusations and the fact that Mrs Collins made her remarks in the context of an internal campaign in the United Kingdom, therefore without any direct and obvious connection to her mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ My colleague Jane Collins was acting in her capacity as an MEP when raising concerns in relations to child abuse in Rotherham. Rotherham falls into the European constituency she represents. Furthermore it is said that Jane Collins was not acting in her professional capacity as an MEP but was merely a UK Parliamentary candidate in the run up to the UK General Election in May 2014.
