This was not the case as she was not selected to stand as a UK Parliamentary candidate until January 2015.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. In plenary on 11 May 2016, the President announced that he had received a request from Jane Collins to defend her immunity on 3 May 2016. According to the explanation of the action, as amended by Judge Warby's order of 29 April 2015, Mr Collins gave and published a speech at the UK Independence Party conference in Doncaster on 26 September 2014, which was made in the media and the general public (including live broadcast of the event on a BBC television channel for Parliament) and offended the honour and dignity of the uk MPs who brought the action. In view of the absence of a direct and obvious link between the contested statements and the duties of Jane Collins as a Member of the European Parliament, since they do not relate to her activities as a member of the European Parliament or in the policies of the European Union and have been expressed in the context of national political debate, it has therefore been decided not to defend the privileges and immunities of Jane Collins.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. His comments are part of the freedom of expression that every politician should enjoy. However, in view of the seriousness of the accusations and the fact that Mrs Collins made her remarks in the context of an internal campaign in the United Kingdom, therefore without any direct and obvious connection to her mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, I have decided to abstain.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which proposes not to defend the privileges and immunities of Mrs Collins.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I supported the position expressed by the rapporteur, Mr Zwiefka, of refusing to defend the privileges and immunities of Jane Collins. This is a request made as part of the civil proceedings pending against him before the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court in London and linked to a defamation and slander complaint at a party conference. According to the committee, Jane Collins' statements have no direct and obvious connection with her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, having been made in the context of a national political debate. The contested declarations are therefore not protected by Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The conduct to be investigated relates to a defamation and slander lawsuit concerning certain allegations that Jane Collins made at a UKIP conference. Collins claimed that some British MPs were aware of many of the details of the sexual exploitation of minors in Rotherham over sixteen years - during which time an estimated 1,400 children were raped, beaten, subjected to alcohol and drugs and threatened with violence – and did not intervene to prevent it. Immunity does not proceed in this case, because statements have nothing to do with Collins' mandate as an MEP. It is also necessary to encourage those accused of such serious crimes to have the opportunity to replenish their honour at the court office.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this request to defend the privileges and immunities of Jane Collins, UKIP candidate and MEP, because of comments considered defamatory by the applicants, made on 26 September 2014 that some Labour Party leaders had been informed of paedophile crimes but had not acted on them. His comments are part of the freedom of expression that every politician should enjoy. Nevertheless, given the seriousness of the accusations and the fact that Mrs Collins made her remarks in the context of an internal campaign in the United Kingdom, therefore without any direct and obvious connection to her mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, I have preferred caution.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by which Parliament decides not to cover the privileges and immunities of Ms Jane Collins in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs. MEP Jane Collins spoke, published and disseminated in the media and to the general public defamatory expressions against MEPs during a ukIP party conference in Doncaster, which is being investigated by the London Supreme Court. These facts do not have a direct and manifest relationship with her parliamentary activity in the European Parliament, so there is no need to defend the immunity of the Member.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the request to defend the privileges and immunities of Jane Collins MEP. Jane Collins has asked for her privileges and immunities to be defended in a civil case against her in the Royal Division of the High Court in London. That part of the request relates to the fact that Jane Collins was allegedly already prevented from going to parliamentary meetings by appointing court hearings before her. It also alleges that Jane Collins brought a civil action in the United Kingdom for damages (including serious damage) caused by defamation and insults, as well as an action against her for the cessation of the action, requiring that the allegations which are being challenged be stopped. In the absence of a direct and obvious link between the contested statements and the duties of Jane Collins as a Member of the European Parliament, since they do not relate to her activities as a member of the European Parliament or in the policies of the European Union and have been made during national political debates, the European Parliament decides not to defend the privileges and immunities of Jane Collins.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Jane Collins Privilege and Immunity Claim Report.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Jane Collins is accused of making defamatory remarks for saying that some Labour Party leaders were informed of paedophile crimes without taking legal action. Of course, these comments are part of the freedom of expression that all MEPs and politicians must enjoy. Nevertheless, in view of the seriousness of jane Collins' accusations and the fact that she made her remarks in the context of an internal campaign with no direct and obvious connection to her mandate as an MEP, I abstained on her request to defend privileges and immunities.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to waive the immunity of this UKIP MEP, who is accused of making defamatory and libellous statements against three Labour MPs with regard to an ongoing criminal and administrative inquiry. As the statements were not made in the course of this MEP’s parliamentary duties, I voted to waive her immunity so that parties could be given the opportunity to establish the truth and clear their names, if need be by due process of law.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which decides not to defend the privileges and immunities of Jane Collins.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on Jane Collins' application for the protection of immunity and parliamentary privileges concerned issues arising outside the activities of the European Parliament. As I believe that we must respect the procedures of justice, I was in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the request for defence of the privileges and immunities of Jane Collins and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the offence alleged against Mr Syod/80 would not be a good one. Jane Collins has allegedly been prevented from travelling to parliamentary meetings by the scheduling of the court proceedings being brought against her. However, the parliamentary immunity conferred by Article 8 of the Protocol applies to opinions expressed by Members of the European Parliament only in the performance of their duties. I voted in favour because I am of the opinion that there is no direct, obvious connection between the contested statements and Jane Collins’s duties as a Member of the European Parliament, as they do not relate to her activity as a Member of the European Parliament or to the policies of the European Union and were made in the context of national political debate.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. MEP Jane Collins is being subject to civil proceedings in the United Kingdom for statements made in her constituency that are not covered by Article 8 of the Protocol, that is, that they have no connection with her parliamentary activity. For this reason, I voted in favour of the suspension of Jane Collins' privileges and parliamentary immunity.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliamentary immunity is intended to guarantee the right to freedom of expression enjoyed by Members of the European Parliament in principle.  However, this right does not mean that they may defame, slander, incite hatred or make defamatory allegations. The complaint in question relates to libel and defamation and relates to accusations made by Jane Collins during a party conference. Since the statements made by Members of the European Parliament outside the premises of the European Parliament cannot be regarded as made in the performance of their duties, we support the decision not to defend the privileges and immunities of Jane Collins.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. On 11 May 2016, Jane Collins submitted a motion in plenary for the protection of her privileges and immunity in connection with civil proceedings pending before an administrative court in London. Since there is no direct and obvious link between the statements and the political duties, I voted against the motion and therefore in favour of the protection of immunity.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mrs Collins has requested the defence of her parliamentary immunity in proceedings in which she is prosecuted for defamation. The case happened in 2014 and it is clear that it is not related to the performance of her parliamentary mandate as a Member of the European Parliament. In these cases, when voting, I am governed by the general conditions under which a Member of the European Parliament may enjoy parliamentary immunity, even if the case has already occurred when he was a Member and is related to the exercise of his mandate. Since, in this case, it is clear that the case is unrelated to the exercise of the mandate, I voted in favour of the report, which proposed not to protect Mrs Collins' immunity.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of The Member Jane Collins. The MP is in court for alleged libel and defamation.  I support jane collins' request for waiver of immunity because , as the report notes, there is no direct, obvious link between jane collins' controversial statements and her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, as they are not related to her activities as a Member of the European Parliament or to the policies of the European Union. Parliamentary immunity applies only to opinions expressed by a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of her duties.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 MEP Mario Borghezio has asked the European Parliament to defend his immunity against proceedings initiated by the Court of Milan, criminal section, for the crime of "discrimination, hatred or violence on racial, ethnic, national or religious grounds" provided for in Article 1(a), Law 205/1993. In particular, Mr Syoobroucke (L), president of the Committee on The Borghezio has been accused of spreading ideas based on racial hatred during the radio broadcast "La Zanzara" against congresswoman Cecilia Kyenge. I voted in favour of the withdrawal.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP decided not to vote on this issue.  Whilst the words mentioned by Mr Borghezio were abhorrent, the Court of Milan has failed to follow due process in staying the proceedings brought against Mr Borghezio until the vote in Plenary has taken place.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Mario Borghezio's parliamentary immunity, since he has been denounced in Italy for his clearly racist statements regarding the then Italian minister of integration. These statements by Borghezio are not an isolated fact, but the expression of his deplorable racist and far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to xenophobia, racism and hatred.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted to waive the immunity of this MEP, who made a series of racial slurs following the appointment of a Congolese-born Minister for Integration in Italy. It is unacceptable for statements inciting racial or ethnic hatred to be made by anyone, most of all in the public sphere. For these reasons, we voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mario Borghezio's immunity. The immunity of MEPs in the European Parliament is based on the principles and values of the Treaties of the European Union. Hate speech clearly violates these principles and values and cannot be justified by freedom of expression. Moreover, the statements in question cannot in any way be construed as related to the fulfilment of Mr Borghezio's mandate and therefore cannot and should not be protected.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Mario Borghezio, a guest on a satirical radio programme in his capacity as an MEP, commented on the competence of the Italian Minister of Integration, whose portfolio included certain aspects of immigration policy. He is accused of conveying ideas based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred. The migration issue is at the heart of its parliamentary activities, as can be seen in its European work. Mr Borghezio has therefore acted in the performance of his duties as an MEP. On the other hand, it is important to put his words back in context. The MP spoke during a debate between politicians during a satirical broadcast. He also publicly apologized for hurting Ms. Kyenge. As a result, his statement is part of the strict framework of freedom of expression according to the ECHR case law. Moreover, in terms of internal procedure, the Public Prosecutor's Office has not applied to the European Parliament for the waiver of immunity and the Milan Court has not even taken into account the proceedings before it. This approach is extremely shocking and proves the existence of a fumus persecutionis. Therefore, I voted against lifting immunity.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote for technical legal reasons.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. Mario Borghezio applied on 5 January 2016 to defend his privileges and immunities in a criminal case pending before a Court in Milan. According to a report by the Public Prosecutor's Office, Mr Borghezio is suspected of promoting ideas based on supremacy and racial and ethnic hatred through a radio broadcast. It is apparent from the facts of the case, which emerged from the documents submitted to the Committee on Legal Affairs and at the previous hearing, that mr Borghezio's statements made during the interview are not directly and manifestly related to his activities as a Member of the European Parliament. Since these statements infringe Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, they cannot therefore be regarded as having been made in the performance of their duties as a Member of the European Parliament and it has therefore been decided not to defend the immunity and privileges of Mario Borghezio.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The issue of migration is at the heart of our parliamentary activities. In this case, the offending statement has a direct and obvious connection to this theme. Mr Borghezio can therefore be considered to have acted in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and that is why I have opposed the lifting of his parliamentary immunity. It should also be noted that another politician made statements that could be considered much more serious against Ms. Kyenge and that the case was closed.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs which proposes not to defend the privileges and immunities of Mr Borghezio.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported the request to withdraw the parliamentary immunity of Northern League MEP Mario Borghezio. He is being investigated by the Italian authorities for racist statements against Italian Integration Minister Cécile Kyenge.  These statements were made outside of their parliamentary activity and cannot therefore be armed by their parliamentary immunity to avoid Italian justice. This privilege is not designed to protect ultra-deputies from their racist and xenophobic comments.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I supported the position expressed by the rapporteur, Mr Dzhambazki, to refuse the request to defend the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio. This is a request made in the context of the criminal proceedings pending before the Court of Milan, in which the honourable Member is accused of touting, during a radio programme, ideas based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred. According to the committee, the statements have no direct and obvious connection with the functions of Member of the European Parliament, having been made as a comment on the appointment of a new member of the Italian Government, the newly elected Minister for Integration. The contested declarations are therefore not protected by Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 Qualifying a cabinet government "bonga bonga" to discredit a minister of color who participates in it or to say of her that she may be "a good housewife, but she does not minister" has nothing to do with the role of an MEP. The Borghezio case meets the legal requirements for impunity to be lifted.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported the defence of the parliamentary immunity of my colleague Mario Borghezio, An Italian MEP from the Northern League and a member of my ENF group, in the name of defending freedom of expression. Mario Borghezio, a guest on a satirical radio programme in his capacity as an MEP, commented on the competence of the Italian Minister of Integration, whose portfolio included certain aspects of immigration policy. He is accused of conveying ideas based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred. The MP spoke during a debate between politicians during a satirical broadcast. He also publicly apologized for hurting Ms. Kyenge. As a result, his statement is part of the strict framework of freedom of expression (see ECHR jurisprudence). Moreover, in terms of internal procedure, the Public Prosecutor's Office has not applied to the European Parliament for the waiver of immunity and the Milan Court has not even taken into account the proceedings before it. This approach is extremely shocking and proves the existence of a fumus persecutionis.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by which Parliament decides not to cover the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which finds that the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Milan Court has initiated criminal proceedings against Mario Borghezio in which he is accused of having defended on a radio programme ideas based on racial or ethnic superiority or hatred , statements made concerning the appointment and competence of a new member of the Italian Government — the then new Minister of Integration — who have no direct and manifest relationship with his parliamentary activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the request to defend the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio, a Member of the European Parliament. According to the report submitted by the Public Prosecutor's Office, Mr Borghezio is suspected of promoting ideas based on supremacy and racial and ethnic hatred through a radio broadcast, which is the responsibility of italian law. On that radio show, Mario Borghezio was asked to comment on the appointment and competence of a new Member of the Italian Government, the new Minister for Integration. It is apparent from the facts of the case, which emerged from the documents submitted to the Committee on Legal Affairs and at the previous hearing, that mr Borghezio's statements made during the interview are not directly and manifestly related to his activities as a Member of the European Parliament. Thus, the European Parliament decides not to defend the immunity and privileges of Mario Borghezio.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report on the Application for Protection of Privileges and Immunity of Mario Borghezi.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Mario Borghezio is accused of conveying ideas based on racial or ethnic hatred during a satirical radio show. These comments are part of a commentary on the competences of the Italian Minister of Integration, whose portfolio encompasses certain aspects of immigration policy. However, the migration issue is at the heart of its parliamentary activities, as evidenced by its European work. It is therefore clear that Mario Borghezio acted in the performance of his duties as an MEP. Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union is a reminder that MEPs cannot be prosecuted because of the words and votes cast in the course of their duties. Finally, we point out that the Public Prosecutor's Office has not even made a request to waive immunity in the European Parliament. That is why I voted against Mario Borghezio's request to lift his parliamentary immunity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to waive the immunity of this MEP, who made a series of racial slurs following the appointment of a Congolese-born Minister for Integration in Italy. It is unacceptable for statements inciting racial or ethnic hatred to be made by anyone, most of all in the public sphere. For these reasons, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided not to vote on this issue.  Whilst the words mentioned by Mr Borghezio were abhorrent, the Court of Milan has failed to follow due process in staying the proceedings brought against Mr Borghezio until the vote in Plenary has taken place.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mario Borghezio has asked the European Parliament to defend his immunity against proceedings initiated by the Court of Milan for the crime of "Discrimination, hatred or violence on racial, ethnic, national or religious grounds" provided for in Article 1(a) of Law 205/1993. In particular, he was accused of spreading ideas based on racial hatred during the radio broadcast "The Mosquito" against Congresswoman Kyenge. In view of the fact that there is no link between the declaration at issue and the parliamentary functions, I voted in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which decides not to defend the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on Mario Borghezio's application for the protection of immunity and parliamentary privileges concerned issues arising outside the activities of the European Parliament. As I believe that we must respect the procedures of justice, I was in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the request for defence of the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio and noted no objections.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the suspension of Mario Borghezio's parliamentary immunity, as he has been denounced in Italy for his clearly racist statements regarding the then Italian Minister for Integration. These statements by Borghezio are not an isolated fact, but the expression of his deplorable racist and far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to xenophobia, racism and hatred.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of suspending the immunity of MEP Mario Borghezio, in line with the resolution on the European Parliament's decision not to defend its privileges and immunities. On the one hand, I believe that the fact that the discriminatory statements made by Mr Borghezio in a radio interview have no connection with his parliamentary activities excludes the possibility of immunity under Article 8 of Protocol No 8. 7 and the opinion of the Court of Justice, and, on the other hand, that those statements addressed to the newly elected Minister for Integration and based on racial or ethnic superiority and hatred, as well as being punishable under Article 1(a) of Italian Law No 205/1993, are inadequate to the dignity of Parliament itself.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I supported maria Borghezia's request for the defence of the privileges and immunities of members of parliament in connection with the criminal proceedings against him in Italy. The proceedings relate to a statement in which Mario Borghezio expressed a racist attitude and spread hatred, which enthused Mr Kashetu (born in Congo), who was appointed Minister of Integration in Italy. Since this statement took place in 2013, it has nothing to do with Maria Borghezia's duties as an MEP. I therefore voted in favour of this MEP's request for the privileges and immunities of this MEP.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Mario Borghezio, a guest on a satirical radio programme in his capacity as an MEP, commented on the competence of Italian Minister Kyenge in charge of integration and certain aspects of immigration policy. He has been accused of conveying ideas based on racial or ethnic superiority. However, the migration issue is at the heart of its parliamentary activities. Mr Borghezio can therefore be considered to have acted in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. However, MEPs "cannot be sought, detained or prosecuted because of the opinions or votes cast by them in the performance of their duties". On the other hand, Mr Borghezio publicly apologized for the injury to Ms. Kyenge. His statement is therefore part of the strict framework of freedom of expression. Finally, the Italian prosecutor's office did not apply for the waiver of immunity and the Milan Court did not even take into account the proceedings before it. It should be noted that another politician made statements that could be considered much more serious against Ms. Kyenge and that the case was closed. I also voted against the lifting of Mr Borghezio's immunity.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Freedom of speech and thought are inalienable human rights. It is not possible in 2016 to prosecute a person for his opinion or for the tone of his voice. We believe that the prosecution against Mr. Borghezio is of a political nature.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. 'u2012 THE MEMBER of the European Parliament, Mario Borghezio, has applied for the protection of his parliamentary immunity, in relation to an ongoing criminal proceedings before the Court of Milan; that, according to the notification made by the Public Prosecutor's Office, Mr Borghezio is accused of having defended ideas based on racial or ethnic superiority or hatred in a radio programme. It is apparent from the facts of the present case that the statements made by Mario Borghezio during the interview are not directly and manifestly related to his parliamentary activity, and Mario Borghezio cannot therefore be regarded as acting in the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and the European Parliament therefore decides not to protect the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the lifting of parliamentary immunity: the process proves the existence of a fumus persecutionis.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mario Borghezio requested the defence of his parliamentary immunity in the context of the criminal proceedings pending before the Court of Milan.  According to the order of prosecution of the public prosecutor, Mr Borghezio has defended ideas based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred during a radio show, behavior that is punishable under Italian law. Article 8 of Protocol No 7 states that "members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties". During the radio programme in question, Mario Borghezio was invited to comment on the appointment and competence of a new member of the Italian Government, namely the new Minister for Integration. Opinions were expressed on the national political situation.  They are deplorable statements – as the character who utters them – that do not have a direct and obvious link with their parliamentary activities. We agreed to the waiver of immunity.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Freedom of speech and thought are inalienable human rights. It is not possible in 2016 to prosecute a person for his opinion or for the tone of his voice. I believe that the prosecution against Mr. Borghezio is of a political nature. I am voting against the report on the request to defend the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The immunity of the Members of the European Parliament is based on the principles and values of the European Union Treaties. Hate speech clearly violates these principles and values, and cannot be justified by freedom of expression. The statements in question can in no way be construed as being linked to  fulfilment of the mandate, and therefore cannot and should not be protected.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the request for protection of the privileges and immunity of Mario Borghezio, in which we state that Mario Borghezio's immunity and privileges should not be protected, paving the way for a number of open proceedings against him.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The European Parliament has decided not to defend the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio, MEP. According to a report, Mario Borghezio was asked on a radio show to comment on the appointment and competence of the new Minister for Integration in the new Italian Government. Given his comments during the show, he is suspected of having promoted ideas based on superiority and racial and ethnic hatred – and under Italian law can be held liable for such behaviour. Mr Borghezio’s statements did not appear to relate to him as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the request for the protection of the privileges and immunity of Mario Borghezi, as this decides not to protect the immunity and privileges of the Member concerned. In his remarks, Mr. Borghezio allegedly advocated ideas based on superiority, racial and ethical hatred, and such statements are in no way besod political dialogue.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Mr Borghezio's statement has a direct connection to his parliamentary activities and his status as a Member of Parliament: therefore, he is protected by Article 8 of Protocol 7. In addition, Mr Borghezio's remarks, for which he publicly apologised to Ms. Kyenge, were made during a satirical television programme. It is therefore by enjoying his right to freedom of expression that Mr Borghezio is subject to a scandalous procedure that the Public Prosecutor's Office and the Tribunal themselves have not chosen to engage against him. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Angel Dzhambazki's report on Mario Borghezio's request to defend parliamentary privileges and immunities. The Committee on Legal Affairs found that, to the extent that the court in which Mr Borghezio was implicated did not ask for the lifting of his immunity and the facts were unrelated to his parliamentary mandate, the defence of Mr Borghezio's privileges and immunity was not justified. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of maintaining Mr Borghezio's immunity. The facts, as set out by the committee, are not one to justify an annulment.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the request. The immunity of the Members of the European Parliament is based on the principles and values of the European Union Treaties. Hate speech clearly violates these principles and values, and cannot be justified by freedom of expression.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of not defending Mario Borghezio’s immunity, since a Parliament representing half a billion Europeans has a strong moral obligation to fight against racism, discrimination and hate speech.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Mario Borghezio, invited to debate with other politicians during a satirical radio programme, as an MEP, is accused of conveying hateful ideas. In practical terms, he mocked the competence of the Minister of Immigration, who claimed that he was referring to her origins. Mr Borghezio publicly apologised for injuring the minister in question. Mr Borghezio's comments were therefore made in the context of his mandate. Moreover, the public prosecutor's office did not request the lifting of immunity in the European Parliament and the Milan court did not take into account the proceedings. I therefore voted in favour of Mario Borghezio's request for the defence of parliamentary immunity.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Mario Borghezio's parliamentary immunity, since he has been denounced in Italy for his clearly racist statements regarding the then Italian minister of integration. These statements by Borghezio are not an isolated fact, but the expression of his deplorable racist and far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to xenophobia, racism and hatred.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italian MEP Mario Borghezia has asked for the protection of his prerogatives and immunities in connection with criminal proceedings conducted in Milan concerning his ideas based on supremacy and racial or ethnic hatred expressed on radio in relation to the appointment of a new member of the Italian Government. According to the court's ruling, immunity under the Protocol on the Protection of Privileges and Immunities applies only to cases in the performance of the duties of an MEP, which therefore presupposes a requirement for a link between the opinion expressed and the parliamentary tasks. Therefore, I cannot agree that the EP should grant immunity protection to a Member.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs not to defend the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio in this report.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the lifting of parliamentary immunity. Mario Borghezio is being lifted from immunity following comments made as an MEP during a satirical programme. These comments were directed at the competence of the Italian Minister of Integration on migration policy. However, the migration issue is, as evidenced by his work in the European Parliament, at the heart of his activity: he has therefore acted in the performance of his duties. Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union states that 'Members of the European Parliament cannot be sought, detained or prosecuted because of the opinions or votes cast by them in the performance of their duties'. In addition, his remarks, which were made on a satirical programme and were the subject of a public apology for injuring the minister, are part of freedom of expression. Finally, the Public Prosecutor's Office did not apply for immunity in the European Parliament and the Milan court ignored the proceedings, both facts which prove the existence of a sufficiently serious presumption and specify that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of harming the political activity of the Member who, coincidentally, is part of the ENL group.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Members of the European Parliament may not be questioned, detained or held liable for opinions or votes expressed in office, but this right does not confer the freedom to defame, insult, incite hatred or insult the honour. In a criminal case pending before a court in Milan, Mr Borghezio is suspected of promoting ideas based on supremacy and racial and ethnic hatred through a radio broadcast. In this context, I support the EP's proposal to waive Mr Borghezio's immunity and thus to enable law enforcement authorities to investigate the case.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for the lifting of Mario Borghezio's immunity. Indeed, this Italian mp for the Northern League is accused of conveying ideas based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred during a radio broadcast. I consider that these statements were not made in the course of parliamentary duties and are therefore not covered by parliamentary immunity. Moreover, as they are clearly a racist offence and not a mere political opinion, I vote for the lifting of immunity.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Mario Borghezio, invited to debate with other politicians during a satirical radio programme, as an MEP, is accused of conveying hateful ideas. In practical terms, he mocked the competence of the Minister of Immigration, who claimed that he was referring to her origins. Mr Borghezio publicly apologised for injuring the minister in question. Mr Borghezio's comments were therefore made in the context of his mandate. Moreover, the public prosecutor's office did not request the lifting of immunity in the European Parliament and the Milan court did not take into account the proceedings. I therefore voted in favour of Mario Borghezio's request for the defence of parliamentary immunity.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the mandate of a Member of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament, and that independence cannot be called into question. In this case, during a radio programme, Mr Borghezio was invited to comment on the appointment and competence of a new member of the Italian Government, in particular the new Minister for Integration.  The statements allegedly made exceed the tone generally used in a political debate and, moreover, are of a nature deeply contrary to the parliamentary nature. The declarations are contrary to Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and therefore cannot be considered to have been made in the performance of her duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  I therefore vote in favour of the waiver of Mario Borghezio's immunity.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Mr. Mario Borghezio was accused of disseminating ideas based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred during a radio broadcast, a behaviour repressed by Italian law 205/1993. It was in this context that Mario Borghezio applied for his parliamentary immunity on 5 January 2016. In accordance with Article 8 of Protocol 7, Members of the European Parliament cannot be sought, detained or prosecuted because of the opinions or votes cast by them in the performance of their duties. However, Mario Borghezio was asked to comment on the appointment and competence of a new member of the Italian government, statements that have no direct and obvious connection to his parliamentary activities. Undermining the integrity of a person is incompatible with our European humanist and democratic values and is thereby flouting the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. That is why I have decided to vote for the lifting of Mr Mario Borghezio's immunity.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. Rep. Mario Borghezio is accused in the milan court of sharing views based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred on a radio show. The Member requested that his privileges and immunity be maintained on the grounds that, because of their opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties, members of the European Parliament could not be prosecuted, detained or prosecuted. However, the Committee on Legal Affairs notes in its report that the statements allegedly made during the interview are not directly and manifestly related to the Member's parliamentary activities and are contrary to Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and cannot therefore be regarded as being made in the exercise of the office of a Member of the European Parliament. It cannot therefore be presumed that Mario Borghezio has exercised his position as a Member of the European Parliament in the matter at hand and therefore proposes that his immunity and privileges should not be up to Parliament.  At the same time, the report recommends that Parliament express its disapproval of the milan court's decision to suspend the proceedings against Mr Borghezio, even though it has been informed that proceedings to maintain the Member's privileges and immunities are pending in accordance with Parliament's Rules of Procedure. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Mr Borghezio made remarks in a satirical programme, which led to his prosecution when it seems clear that this was an abusive procedure with political connotations.  As a result, the vote will be against the request to waive immunity.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, since the offence in question is in no way related to the performance of the functions of a Member – because it does not have a direct and obvious link with its parliamentary activities. I support the rapporteur's position, regretting that the Court of Milan, contrary to the case-law of the Court of Justice in this regard, refused to suspend the proceedings brought against Mr Borghezio.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The freedom of expression of a parliamentarian must be protected, which is why I voted against it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in accordance with the evaluation made by the Legal Affairs Committee.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided not to vote on this issue.  Whilst the words mentioned by Mr Borghezio were abhorrent, the Court of Milan has failed to follow due process in staying the proceedings brought against Mr Borghezio until the vote in Plenary has taken place.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The MP spoke during a debate between politicians during a satirical broadcast. He also publicly apologized for the injury to Ms. Kyenge. As a result, his statement is part of the strict framework of freedom of expression. Moreover, in terms of internal procedure, the Public Prosecutor's Office has not applied to the European Parliament for the waiver of immunity and the Milan Court has not even taken into account the proceedings before it. The process of lifting immunity is therefore shocking and proves the existence of a fumus persecutionis. Finally, it should be noted that another politician made statements that could be considered much more serious against Ms. Kyenge and that the case was closed. In these circumstances, I therefore vote against the report calling for the lifting of Mr Borghezio's immunity.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The facts of the case suggest that the statements made by the Member during the interview are not directly related to his parliamentary activities and potentially exceed the tone of the normal political debate and are inconsistent with the spirit of Parliament. The immunity of Members of the European Parliament is based on the principles and values of the Treaties of the European Union.  Freedom of speech must not ignore and exceed those values. The Court of Justice of the European Union has confirmed that in the case of proceedings brought against Members of the European Parliament before a national court and the court's awareness of the initiation of proceedings to protect the privileges and immunities of that Member, that court must halt the judicial proceedings and ask Parliament to publish its opinion as soon as possible.  In Milan, where the court brought against Mr Borghezi was brought, the Court refused to halt the proceedings and ordered it to proceed despite Mr Borghezi's request on the basis of the relevant case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union. I regret that, despite the relevant case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, the Court of Justice refused to halt the proceedings and I expect the Italian authorities to always respect the principle of the Court of Justice of the European Union as regards the obligation of the competent court to halt legal proceedings if an application is made to protect the privileges and immunity of Members of the European Parliament.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mario Borghezio requested the defence of his parliamentary immunity in the context of the criminal proceedings pending before the Court of Milan.  During the radio programme in question, Mr Borghezio was invited to comment on the appointment and competence of a new member of the Italian Government, namely the new Minister for Integration. Opinions on the national political situation were expressed, including the defense of ideas of racial superiority, the defense of racial or ethnic hatred, knowingly and freely spreading racist and xenophobic views, and promoting discrimination.  These statements do not have a direct and obvious link with their parliamentary activities. They are also statements contrary to Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  The evaluation of the committee responsible, which we are accompanying, is not to defend immunity, as it concludes that the statements expressed cannot be considered to have been made in the performance of their duties as a Member of the European Parliament. We do not follow the criticism made in the report to the Court of Milan that, according to Community law, the proceedings should have been suspended, because we believe that it is a sovereignty body which should not be subdued to any decision of the European Court of Justice, the supranational body which we do not recognise. We voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This classic procedure is first discussed in the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) before being voted on in plenary. In this case, the JURI committee did not recommend the defence of the privileges and immunity of the parliamentarian.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP decided not to vote on this issue.  Whilst the words mentioned by Mr Borghezio were abhorrent, the Court of Milan has failed to follow due process in staying the proceedings brought against Mr Borghezio until the vote in Plenary has taken place.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. The Italian Public Prosecutor's Office has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mario Borghezio, a Member of the European Parliament, as part of the initiation of an investigation procedure relating to an alleged offence.  The action involved is the speech he gave on a radio show where he defended ideas based on racial hatred and the superiority of race. Given that the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no reason to suppose that the intention underlying the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, this request, which I voted in favour of, decides to lift the immunity of Mr Borghezio.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. An Italian court has requested the lifting of Mario Borghezio's parliamentary immunity for statements of alleged "hate speech".  Hate speech violates European principles and values. The European Parliament decides to refuse the defence of parliamentary immunity.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by which Parliament decides not to cover the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio in the light of the report prepared by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which finds that the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Milan Court has initiated criminal proceedings against Mario Borghezio in which he is accused of having defended on a radio programme ideas based on racial or ethnic superiority or hatred , statements made concerning the appointment and competence of a new member of the Italian Government — the then new Minister of Integration — who have no direct and manifest relationship with his parliamentary activity.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Mario Borghezio's immunity so that the Italian justice system could carry out its work in strict respect for the rights of the defence, on the understanding that the facts in question (allegedly discriminatory statements made during a radio interwiew) have no direct connection to Mr Borghezio's office as an MEP and are not motivated by any desire to harm. It is essential to remember that the right to freedom of expression does not allow everything; and in no way to make defamatory statements based on racial hatred.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposed resolution, in which the European Parliament refuses to defend the immunity and privileges of my colleague Mario Borghezio in the trial of Milan. In this case, Maria Borghezio is accused of defamation, and the trial in Italy itself does not prevent him from performing his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to the request for the defence of parliamentary immunity requested by MEP Mario Borghezio, following a criminal action brought against him before the Court of Milan, for defending ideas based on superiority and racial hatred during a radio programme, which is likely to constitute a crime punishable under Italian law. Having regard to the content of the report, the statements made by the MEP relate to allegedly discriminatory opinions, contrary to what should be the parliamentary spirit and what is enshrined in Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and they cannot be considered to have been given in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. In view of the foregoing, I consider that it is not defensible to maintain his parliamentary immunity in the present case, although i must regret the failure of the Court of Milan to refuse to suspend proceedings against the Member, contrary to what is the settled case-law of the Court in this matter, hoping that this is an isolated and non-recurrent case in the future.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Mario Borghezio's parliamentary immunity, since he has been denounced in Italy for his clearly racist statements regarding the then Italian minister of integration. These statements by Borghezio are not an isolated fact, but the expression of his deplorable racist and far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to xenophobia, racism and hatred.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 MEP Mario Borghezio asked for the protection of his parliamentary immunity in connection with criminal proceedings in a court in Milan, since, according to the prosecutor's office's announcement, Mario Borghezio allegedly expressed on radio broadcasts ideas based on supremacy and racial or ethnic hatred, which is criminal under Italian law. The facts of the case — as is apparent from the documents provided to the Committee on Legal Affairs and from the hearing in that committee , show that the statements made by Mario Borghezio during the interview have no direct or unambiguous connection with his parliamentary work. These statements are, by their very nature, imparatic and contrary to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and cannot therefore be regarded as statements made in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament. That is why, by voting, we have chosen not to protect the immunity and privileges of MEP Mario Borghezio.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Mario Borghezio, a Member of Parliament, has requested the protection of his parliamentary immunity in accordance with Article 8 and 9 of Protocol No 7 in connection with criminal proceedings before the Milan court, claiming in a radio broadcast the idea of superiority and racial or ethnic hatred, which is a criminal offence in Italy.  The Court has held that this is not a situation where a Member expresses his views in the performance of his duties, nor is there any link between his views and the parliamentary duties he performs in the European Parliament. In particular, such statements do not come with a tone that can be met in political debates in the European Parliament and, moreover, are, by its very nature, completely at odds with what the representatives of European citizens should be in favour of.  As I believe that Mr Borghezio has undoubtedly not acted in the course of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the report, which proposes that his immunities and privileges not be protected.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the European Union, all expressions of racial hatred are inadmissible. All the more so if they are committed by a member of the European Parliament, thereby reducing the seriousness and reputation of the whole institution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Mario Borghezi is being prosecuted at a court in Milan for allegedly advocating ideas based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred expressed in a radio programme. The statements at issue are contrary to Article 21 of the European Parliament. Charters of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and are completely unrelated to the values advocated by the European Parliament, so it cannot be argued that they were imposed during the duties of a Member of the European Parliament.  Therefore, Mario Borghezi's request to protect his privileges and immunity cannot be accepted. Accordingly, I support the report on the request for protection of the privileges and immunity of Mario Borghezi of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Freedom of speech and thought are inalienable human rights. It is not possible in 2016 to prosecute a person for his opinion or for the tone of his voice. We believe that the prosecution against Mr. Borghezio is of a political nature.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting this Member's immunity so that he could explain himself to the courts of his country.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request to refuse the defence of the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio. Mr Borghezio is facing criminal proceedings pending before the Court of Milan, as, during a radio programme, he allegedly advocated ideas founded on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred, and that is punishable under Italian law. The statements made by Mr Borghezio exceeded the tone generally tolerated in political debate and were profoundly un-parliamentary in nature and contrary to Article 21 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. They cannot, therefore, have been made in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported a report refusing to grant immunity to Italian MP Mario Borghezi. The Borghezio MP is accused of promoting hatred and racism on a radio show on April 29, 2013. He allegedly attacked Congo-born Ms Kyenge Kasheta, who had been appointed Italy's integration minister, with his speech. He is accused of uttering opinions deemed unpleasant and offensive.  While MEPs have the right to freedom of expression, I believe that this freedom does not relate to defamation, incitement to hatred and derogatory claims. Since the accusations have no direct and obvious link to the performance of his activities as a Member of the European Parliament, I voted to strip Borghezi of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision on the request for the protection of the privileges and immunities of Maria Borghezio. Mario Borghezio has requested the protection of his parliamentary immunity in accordance with Articles 8 and 9 of Protocol No 7 relating to criminal proceedings before the Milan Court.  According to the notice given by the Public Prosecutor's Office, Mario Borghezio defended in a radio broadcast the idea of superiority and racial or ethnic hatred, which is a criminal offence under Article 1(a) of Italian Law No 205/1993.  The Court has held that, in order to be granted immunity, an MEP must express his opinion in the performance of his duties, which requires a link between the opinion expressed and parliamentary duties, and that that link must be direct and obvious.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report. The purpose of the provisions governing the privileges and immunities of Members of the European Parliament is m.in. to ensure that they are not investigated, subject to legal proceedings or that they are not detained because of an opinion or position taken in the performance of their duties. It is clear from this that freedom of expression is protected, but only if there is a link between the conduct in question and parliamentary activity. According to a court in Italy, MEP Mario Borghezio made racist and ethnic hatred during a radio show. Under Italian law, this constitutes a criminal offence and a basis for initiating criminal proceedings. At the same time, the statement was contrary to the prohibition of discrimination set out in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. It cannot therefore be accepted that Mario Borghezio's views were expressed in the performance of his duties as a Member.  I therefore believe that he should not enjoy immunity in criminal proceedings against him.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mario Borghezio requested the maintenance of his own privileges and immunity in connection with his pending criminal proceedings in the Milan court (RGNR No 41838/13 and RG GIP No 12607/14). I supported it by the decision of the group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. I understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate a political court chase.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity, as it is a complaint for an action that cannot be understood as proper to your parliamentary activity.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the request for defence of the privileges and immunities of Mario Borghezio. A Member of the European Parliament, Mario Borghezio, has requested the defence of his parliamentary immunity under Articles 8 and 9 of Protocol No 7, in connection with criminal proceedings pending before the Court of Milan. According to the notice served by the Public Prosecutor’s Office, Mr Borghezio is alleged to have advocated ideas founded on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred during a radio programme. The Court of Justice has held that, in order to enjoy immunity, an opinion must be expressed by a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties, thus entailing the requirement of a link between the opinion expressed and the parliamentary duties, and that link must be direct and obvious. However, during the radio programme in question, Mario Borghezio was asked to comment on the appointment and competence of a new member of the Italian Government. I voted in favour because I believe that the facts of the case indicate that the statements he made during the interview have no direct and obvious connection with his parliamentary activities.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Mario Borghezio's parliamentary immunity, since he has been denounced in Italy for his clearly racist statements regarding the then Italian minister of integration. These statements by Borghezio are not an isolated fact, but the expression of his deplorable racist and far-right position. I have therefore voted in favour of lifting your parliamentary immunity so that you can be judged on your incitements to xenophobia, racism and hatred.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliamentary immunity is intended to guarantee the right to freedom of expression enjoyed by Members of the European Parliament in principle.  However, this right does not mean that they may defame, slander, incite hatred or make defamatory allegations.  The complaint in question relates to the fact that Mr Borghezio defended ideas based on superiority and racial or ethnic hatred during a radio programme. Since the statements made by Members of the European Parliament outside the premises of the European Parliament cannot be regarded as made in the performance of their duties, we support the decision not to defend Mr Borghezio's privileges and immunities.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. After it was established that there was no direct link between the questionable statements made during an interview with a radio station and parliamentary activity, I voted against the motion and thus in favour of the protection of his immunity and his privileges.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mep Borghezio has requested the defence of parliamentary immunity in connection with criminal proceedings brought against him in Italy. As part of this criminal proceedings, he is accused of promoting hatred and racism, having commented on the nomination of the Italian Minister for Integration in 2013. In these cases, when voting, I am governed by the general conditions under which a Member of the European Parliament may enjoy parliamentary immunity, even if the case has already occurred while he was a Member and is related to the exercise of his mandate. Since, in this case, it is clear that the incident in question has no apparent connection with its parliamentary activities, I voted in favour of the report which proposed not to protect its parliamentary immunity.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a report amends Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics. The changes concern the optimization of the use of existing information that can be used for statistical purposes. It is therefore stipulates that the Commission, after consulting the Committee on the European Statistical System, must send a report to the European Parliament and the Council by 31 December 2020 and every four years following the implementation of the regulation. The Commission will have to take into account all relevant information provided by the Member States concerning the quality and methods used. The data will be collected and disseminated by Eurostat in consultation with the Commission, which is responsible for defining the details by means of delegated acts. I agree with the importance of monitoring and collecting data in this important area and voted against the rejection amendment.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted for the rejection amendment on this legislative motion for a resolution. By the EU’s own admission, the EU has spent millions on the ERTMS deployment without any concrete results, due to irregular deployment and delays in the deployment.  Therefore, we cannot allow the EU to put legislation in place and still waste the taxpayers’ money.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report completes and improves rail transport statistics in the field of data collection on goods, passengers and accidents. Despite my reservations about the use of this data, as I fear that they will serve as technical support for the liberalisation measures of the Union's rail package, I believe that there is no reason to oppose its collection by denying its parliamentary approval.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This is an ordinary legislative procedure, at second reading, amending the existing regulation to update and simplify the existing legal framework for European statistics on rail transport, including increasing the collection of general statistics (not personal data) on the transport of goods and passengers by rail, and on rail safety, and establishing cooperation agreements to this end.  This report is a technical part of the fourth railway package, which, as a whole, moves towards a single more competitive, liberalised railway sector and aims to replace national vehicle authorisation and safety authorities with a single European Railway Agency, among other things. While Sinn Féin is opposed to the fourth railway package, this change to the regulation deals solely with general statistics that will contribute to safety and transport planning, and we therefore voted to support it.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement with the Council which will ensure that data collected by the European Railway Agency (ERA) or DG MOVE can be used for statistical purposes and be easily accessible to the public.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on freight and passenger transport as well as accidents across the EU's rail network. It has little interest, but it is mandatory to go before Parliament. There is no major reason to oppose it, but neither is there any reason to vote in favour of this report, which does not bring anything positive to French rail transport. However, UKIP MEPs have proposed a rejection amendment based on the eu's refusal in principle to meddle in rail statistics, which is legitimate. So I voted in favour of this amendment.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal to reject the European Council’s position. By their own admission the EU has spent millions on the ERTMS deployment without any concrete results due to irregular deployment and delays in the deployment.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council and Parliament have agreed that the most effective and cost-effective way to avoid the double work of Eurostat, the Commission and the European Union Railway Agency is to strengthen the work of these institutions and to ensure that statistics relating to EU policies are easily accessible to EU citizens and stakeholders. These Memoranda of Understanding are not only important tools for optimising the use of existing information and reducing administrative burdens. they would ensure and meet the requirements put forward by the co-legislators in relation to the better use of rail transport statistics. They will provide all categories of consumers with easily accessible data and reliable information on progress in EU rail sector policy.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I see no major reason to oppose it, but neither do I see any reason to vote in favour of this report, which does not seem to me to bring anything positive to the French rail sector: I have therefore abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this legislative proposal, which included extending the scope of the Rail Transport Statistics Regulation to cover infrastructure data, in particular the deployment of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), which was one of the priorities of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T), as it is extremely important to have a clear vision for the development of ERTMS in the European Union. Indeed, the EU has spent millions of euros to finance this type of infrastructure with no concrete results to date, as the system is not operational in Europe due to irregularities and delays in deployment. The European Parliament has also decided that Eurostat should publish data on stations accessible to people with reduced mobility and people with disabilities, as well as on the use of cross-border rail infrastructure. After negotiations between Parliament and the Council, it was also decided to strengthen cooperation between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency in order to avoid overlap between their activities.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. In 2012 Despite the initial discrepancies between Parliament and the Council, an agreement has finally been reached between the two institutions and I voted in favour of this report. Following the agreement, Parliament's request that the public be able to access such data with ease was guaranteed. A new recital has also been added emphasizing the need for close cooperation between the Commission and the competent entities to provide Union citizens and other stakeholders with useful and easily accessible information on the safety of rail transport and on the interoperability of the rail system. Parliament further decided that Eurostat should provide available statistical data on stations providing barrier-free access to persons with reduced mobility and persons with disabilities, as well as on the use of cross-border rail infrastructure.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Cramer report on rail transport statistics. This is an important text rose from the agreement between Parliament and the Council on the collection of data on goods, passengers and rail accidents. According to the text, the amendments to the existing regulation will lead to the extension of the scope of transport statistics to infrastructure data, finally making it possible to assess the development of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), which has so far proved ineffective due to delays and irregularities in application. Crucially, there is the strengthening of cooperation between the Commission, Eurostat and the European Railway Agency, in order to ensure statistical data on EU policies that are easily accessible to citizens and all stakeholders. The signing of the two memor memories of understanding between Eurostat and the Commission and between Eurostat and the EFE, demonstrates the commitment in this direction and ensures not only the optimisation of the use of existing information but also a reduction in the administrative burden.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which lays the groundwork for improving the collection of data on the transport of goods and passengers by rail through the Union as a whole, as well as accidents occurring and other serious incidents. The dual purpose is to generate reliable and comparable databases and simplify the task of collecting-systematizing competent authorities in the Member States.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. We support this report because it breaks down one more barrier than our Union subtly follows and prevents us from properly assessing the results of our strategic investments and improving the results of our policies. Data on the actual results of the deployment of the ERTMS network or those of railway accidents should serve this objective and should be made available to citizens and stakeholders. That solving this problem has required a long and hard negotiation speaks of how needy we are of true European leadership.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This text for second reading concerns the collection of transport statistics by rail, including the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. This report does not mention the Commission's delegated acts and has little interest, but since there is no major reason to oppose it, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support with my vote the proposal for a rejected.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution, by which Parliament adopts the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on statistics on rail transport, as regards the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. After lengthy negotiations, the Council and Parliament agreed that the most efficient and cost-effective way to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Union Railway Agency was to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and to ensure that statistical data on Union policies are easily accessible to citizens and stakeholders, cooperation which has resulted in the signing of two memorandums of understanding between Eurostat and the Commission (27.4.2016) and between Eurostat and the EA (12.5.2016).

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation on the Council's position with a view to adopting a regulation on rail transport statistics as regards the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. During its deliberations with the Council, the European Parliament decided that the scope of the Regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to include infrastructure data, in particular on the deployment of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), which was one of the priorities of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T). Parliament underlined the importance of having a clear impression of the development of ERTMS in the Union, as the EU has spent millions of euros to finance this type of infrastructure, but due to inconsistent deployment and delays in deployment, no concrete results have been achieved in terms of the technical requirements for the use of the system. Parliament also decided that Eurostat should provide statistics on stations accessible without hindrance to persons with reduced mobility and persons with disabilities, as well as on the use of cross-border railway infrastructures. As regards the disasters proposed by the Commission to be excluded from the scope of the Regulation, Parliament considered that statistics on rail disasters should continue to fall within the scope of the Regulation, which should even be extended to include disasters and incidents involving the transport of dangerous goods and disasters at level crossings. Parliament considers it essential that EU citizens have easy access to data related to the implementation of EU policies, according to the one-stop shop.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its 2014 revision of the Rail Transport Statistics Regulation, the European Parliament weaed a number of important elements into the legal material, such as the issue of track sections equipped with the ERTMS system, accessible stations or even statistics collected on accidents. The report approved today reflects the positive results of interinstitutional consultations. The European Union has spent millions of euros to put the ERTMS rail system into effect with more or less success. It is therefore important to get a true picture of the railway sections on which the system operates and on which it can be introduced in the near future. From the point of view of the disabled, the list of accessible stations is very important, for which reliable statistical data are essential.
