Unlike the European Commission, Parliament believes that the collection of data on railway accidents is also essential and important, paying particular attention to accidents involving the transport of dangerous substances. Cooperation between Member States and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (ERA) is essential in order to achieve a common objective. This will allow the Commission to improve rail safety controls. Cooperation shall allow the parties concerned to complement each other's data and not to create a double-licitation in the data collection process or to impose an excessive administrative burden on any institution. Against this background, I voted in favour of the adoption of the legislation.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Rail Transport Statistics Report on the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If I am very concerned about rail accidents, I do not see the point in dealing with these issues at European level rather than in each Member State. Therefore, although I believe that this report is full of good intentions, I voted in favour of the amendment rejecting the proposal tabled by the EFDD group.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At first reading, Parliament decided that the scope of the regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to infrastructure data, in particular the application of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS). Parliament stressed that it was extremely important to have a clear vision of the development of ERTMS in the Union and considers it very important that European citizens have easy access to data on the implementation of EU policies. In order to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency (EAA), it is necessary to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and to ensure that statistical data on EU policies are easily accessible to citizens and stakeholders. Agreement on a simplification of the regulation on rail transport statistics was possible after the signing of two memor memor arrangements between Eurostat and the Commission and between Eurostat and the EAFE. These memories of understanding are important tools for optimising the use of existing information and reducing administrative burdens and are useful for meeting requirements for better use of rail transport statistics.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report gives the Commission the power to collect statistical data on goods, passengers and accidents across the European Union's rail network. We see no problem with the Union collecting statistics for studies on the efficiency of national rail systems. However, we point out that this text does not clearly refer to the acts delegated to the Commission, that is, the powers that arise from explicit authorisation from the legislation adopted by Parliament and the Council. Moreover, this report will not bring anything positive to French rail transport. I therefore voted in favour of the rejection proposal.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of amending this regulation because it improves, through a series of measures, the instruments aimed at developing rail transport statistics. Firstly, it extends the scope of transport statistics to infrastructure data and finally makes the application of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS) concrete in terms of operability, which to date has proved ineffective due to delays and irregularities in application.  Secondly, it authorises the publication of statistical data on stations by Eurostat without architectural barriers, in order to facilitate access for people with disabilities and therefore unable to use the service.  Finally, it provides for close cooperation between Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (EAA) in order to ensure the improvement of statistics on rail accidents, including accidents occurring with the transport of dangerous goods and involving level crossings.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an ordinary legislative procedure, at second reading, for amending the existing regulation to update and simplify the existing legal framework for European statistics on rail transport, including increasing the collection of general statistics (not personal data) on the transport of goods and passengers by rail, and on rail safety.  The changes include establishing appropriate cooperation agreements between the Commission and relevant entities. Data collection requirements are set out for Member States.  This report is a technical part of the fourth railway package, which, as a whole, moves towards a single more competitive, liberalised railway sector, which Sinn Fein opposes. However, I am not opposed to the collection of statistics.  I voted against the UKIP amendment to reject this report (only that amendment was put to the vote).

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for the rejection amendment on this legislative motion for a resolution. By the EU’s own admission, the EU has spent millions on the ERTMS deployment without any concrete results, due to irregular deployment and delays in the deployment.  Therefore, we cannot allow the EU to put legislation in place and still waste the taxpayers’ money.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of approving a first-reading agreement with the Council of Ministers once it had been accepted that the most efficient and cost-effective way to avoid overlapping between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency (ERA) would be to strengthen cooperation between those institutions and ensure that statistical data related to EU policies would be easily accessible to EU citizens and stakeholders. This was possible only after the signing of two memoranda of understanding (MoUs), which are especially important instruments, as they will also enable better use to be made of rail transport statistics. These will provide all categories of users with easily accessible data and reliable information on the progress of European policies in the rail sector.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to amend a previous regulation with the aim of optimising the use of information that can be used for statistical purposes. The Commission has the main role together with Eurostat and every four years it has to draw up a report on the implementation of the regulation. I had no doubt that I was voting in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Good data collection on goods, passengers and accidents and the development of targeted statistics are necessary tools to allow timely monitoring of rail transport. Only through proper monitoring can we identify the most important challenges to be faced in this area and implement a common transport strategy. I believe, in particular, that these statistics are essential for strengthening European action in the field of transport safety. I therefore believe that the European Commission's Directorate-General for Mobility and Transport and the European Railway Agency must extend the scope of data collection to include timely information on infrastructure and in particular on the application of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS). I welcome the fact that the report calls on Eurostat to present and make public data on railway stations providing assistance to people with disabilities or reduced mobility. I hope that Eurostat and the European Railway Agency will be able to further strengthen their cooperation in order to ensure consistency in the methodology of data collection and analysis.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We believe that Eurostat should have statistical data on barrier-free stations accessible to persons with reduced mobility and people with disabilities, as well as on the use of cross-border rail infrastructure. As regards accidents, statistics on rail accidents should remain within the scope of the Regulation, which should be extended to include accidents and incidents involving the transport of dangerous goods and accidents involving level crossings. We also believe that Eurostat and the European Union Railway Agency should work closely together to improve statistics on rail accidents and to ensure, in particular, methodological consistency with regard to accident data in other modes of transport.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because it is a very simple technical measure, but it has been stranded for two years due to member states' refusal to publish rail transport statistics (RTS) data.  I believe that the availability of this specific, detailed and timely and necessary data on rail freight and passenger transport is essential, in order to monitor and develop the common transport policy. Furthermore, given that accidents have become a priority problem in the European Union's transport policy, together with the other undesirable effects of transport (such as pollution and CO2 emissions), I believe it is essential to collect and disseminate data on accidents, deaths, serious injuries and damage caused to the environment in all modes of transport. I therefore decide to support this proposal with the aim of simplifying and optimising the current legal framework for European rail transport statistics and bringing it into line with the new institutional framework.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics, as regards the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents, and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is to amend Regulation No 91/2003 with a view to updating, simplifying and optimising the existing regulatory framework for European statistics on rail transport. I support this recommendation for second reading, as the creation of a genuine European internal market in transport is essential for the revitalisation of the rail sector which will help to make rail freight and passenger services more competitive and attractive, as well as to increase its annual share of transport. To develop and monitor the common transport policy, the European Commission needs detailed statistical data on rail freight and passenger transport. To this end, two memoranda of understanding were signed: one between Eurostat and the European Commission and the other between Eurostat and the European Railway Agency. These two memoranda are important for optimising the use of existing information and reducing administrative burden, while also meeting the requirements of the co-legislators regarding the better use of rail transport statistics. These statistics will allow all categories of users easy and reliable access to data on the progress of European policies in the rail sector.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because by strengthening cooperation between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency (EFE), implemented with two memorized memorized protocols on the optimisation of information already held by the authorities and the reduction of administrative burdens, it could be possible to offer all categories of users concerned a range of easily accessible statistics and data on the state of European policies for the rail sector. The compromise was reached after a series of lengthy negotiations, in which the European Parliament pursued its position of greater transparency of data on the rail sector, which should include, among others, those relating to infrastructure such as the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), those relating to stations without architectural barriers for disabled people and persons with reduced mobility and accident statistics.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report completes and improves rail transport statistics in the field of data collection on goods, passengers and accidents. Despite my reservations about the use of this data, as I fear that they will serve as technical support for the liberalisation measures of the Union's rail package, I believe that there is no reason to oppose its collection by denying its parliamentary approval.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The availability of detailed and timely statistical data on rail transport is increasingly important, given the Commission's adoption of data-based policies and the need to monitor progress towards the objectives set out in the 2011 Transport White Paper.  By voting in favour of this resolution, I intend to support the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the collection of data on goods, passengers and rail accidents. I welcome the priorities identified by Parliament with regard to monitoring the regular application of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS) and the publication of Eurostat data on stations without architectural barriers and rail accidents, including those relating to the transport of dangerous goods. Finally, I support the efforts of the European institutions to avoid duplication of work (with regard to data collection and administrative burdens) between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency (EAA) and to make EU policy statistics accessible to EU citizens and stakeholders.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the proposal to collect data on goods, passengers and accidents in the context of rail transport. In this subject, a balance needs to be made between ensuring greater safety for passengers and the railways themselves and overburdening Member States that are required to collect data. In my opinion, it is clear from the content of the proposal that there is a high risk of overburdening the state, and I am opposed to bureaucracy. These arguments prevailed when I decided to vote against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this recommendation for second reading on the Council position with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament as regards the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents, is it updates, simplifies and optimises the existing legal framework for European statistics on rail transport. This data would also help to develop the common transport policy.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on railway transport statistics, which has the overall objective of improving the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. The agreements signed between Eurostat and the Commission, as well as between Eurostat and the European Railway Agency, have enabled a new and effective division of tasks for the collection of statistics. In order to ensure the proper implementation of existing European rail policies and to better prepare for future policies, particularly on passenger safety, it is essential that the legal framework be changed to take account of these institutional developments.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its 2014 revision of the Rail Transport Statistics Regulation, the European Parliament weaed a number of important elements into the legal material, such as the issue of track sections equipped with the ERTMS system, accessible stations or even statistics collected on accidents. The report approved today reflects the positive results of interinstitutional consultations. Unlike the European Commission, Parliament believes that the collection of data on railway accidents is also essential and important, paying particular attention to accidents involving the transport of dangerous substances. In order to reduce the number of fatalities in rail transport accidents, it is necessary to improve the data collection system. Cooperation between The Member States and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (ERA) is essential in order to achieve a common objective of making statistics on rail transport as accurate and transparent as possible and to make the data collected easily comparable to other modes of transport. To this end, it was necessary to sign two Memoranda of Understanding between Eurostat and the Commission, as well as era and commission, which will allow the parties concerned to complement each other's data and avoid duplication in the data collection process and that this does not impose an excessive administrative burden on either institution. Against this background, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the legislation.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that access to rail transport data should be a priority for the trans-European transport network (TEN-T). At the economic level, it has the advantage of improving trade and promoting the development of businesses and services to citizens. At the social level, the publication of statistical data on railway structures facilitates access for persons with reduced mobility and disabilities, as well as the use of cross-border rail infrastructure. I welcome Parliament's indication of the cooperation of Eurostat and the Railway Agency to improve statistics on rail accidents. These reasons led me to vote in favour.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on freight and passenger transport as well as accidents across the European Union's rail network. There is no more reason to oppose it than to vote in favour of this report, which does not bring anything positive to French rail transport. Also, I abstained.

name: Angel Dzhambazki (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Although the negotiations took a while, a firm position on not extending the categories for data collection etc. was successfully upheld. This enabled us to prevent the Commission’s proposal from exceeding its scope. I support the agreement to improve access to available data through better cooperation and statistical activities.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the Recommendation. The Council's position gives the Commission super powers and at the same time does not ensure that statistics are collected in the best possible and most directly usable way.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union has spent millions of euros to put the ERTMS rail system into effect, with more or less success. We need to get a true picture of the railway sections on which the system operates and on which it could be introduced in the near future. From the point of view of the disabled, the list of accessible stations is important, for which reliable statistical data are essential. Unlike the European Commission, Parliament believes that the collection of data on railway accidents is also essential and important, paying particular attention to accidents involving the transport of dangerous substances. In order to reduce the number of fatalities in rail transport accidents, it is necessary to improve the data collection system. Cooperation between The Member States and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (ERA) is essential in order to achieve a common objective of making statistics on rail transport as accurate and transparent as possible and to make the data collected easily comparable to other modes of transport. This will allow the Commission to improve rail safety controls. For this purpose, it was necessary to sign two Memoranda of Understanding between Eurostat and the Commission, as well as era and commission, which would allow the parties concerned to supplement each other's data and avoid double data collection and not to impose an excessive administrative burden. Against this background, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the legislation.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. It is vitally important to have a clear vision of the development of the European Rail Traffic Management System in the Union, as it has made a strong investment to finance such infrastructure.  The Council and Parliament together agreed that the most efficient and cost-effective way to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Union Railway Agency (EFSA) was to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and ensure that statistical data on Union policies were easily accessible to citizens and stakeholders. The results obtained are important tools for optimizing the use of existing information and reducing administrative burden, and also meet the demands of co-legislators for better use of rail transport statistics, providing all categories of users with easily accessible data and reliable information on the advancement of European policies in the railway sector.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament decided that the scope of the Regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to include data on infrastructure, in particular on the deployment of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), because it considered it imperative to have a clear vision of the development of this system in the European Union, as it spent millions of euros on financing this type of infrastructure without any concrete result , so far, in terms of system operability across Europe, due to irregular deployment and delays. Parliament also decided that Eurostat should provide statistical data on barrier-free stations accessible to people with reduced mobility and people with disabilities, as well as on the use of cross-border rail infrastructure.  Parliament believes that it is extremely important for EU citizens to have easy access – as a one-stop shop – to data relating to the implementation of EU policies.  I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: it has little interest but passage before Parliament is mandatory. There is no major reason to oppose it, but neither is there any reason to vote in favour of this report, which does not bring anything positive to French rail transport.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an essentially technical text (although it cannot be isolated from a given context and policy options), the communication of information on rail transport by Member States to the Commission, with regard to goods, passengers and accidents, allowing a supranational analysis of the sector – also compared to other means of transport – and operationalising the "European rail system" in the wake of the 4th Railway Package. Recognising that the exchange of statistical information could help the development of rail systems and that, while issues such as privacy are assured, it is a permissible (or even desirable) issue, the context in which it is proposed here deserves our repudiation, with successive rail packages being the main instrument of EU policy that has promoted the privatisation and total disorganisation of the companies responsible for rail transport; promoting the deregulation of labour and increased labour exploitation in the sector; which has resulted in increased tariffs for users and the degradation of infrastructure and reduced railway safety. In the document there are references that are in line with this policy and with the centralising options that underlie it, such as strengthening the role and action of the European Railway Agency in the field of safety.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Citizens of the European Union must have easy access in the future to data relating to the implementation of European Union policies. An agreement on the simplification of the Regulation on rail transport statistics was only possible after the signature of two memoranda of understanding, namely between Eurostat and the Commission and between Eurostat and era. These memoranda are not only important tools for optimising the use of existing information and reducing administrative burdens, but also meet the co-legislators' requirements for better use of rail statistics. All categories of users can obtain easily accessible data and reliable information on the progress of European rail policies.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the proposal to reject it because I agree with the text presented at first reading.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, as the Council's position gives the Commission over-responsibility and at the same time does not ensure that statistics are collected in the best possible and most directly usable way.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement reached with the Council will ensure that data collected by the European Railway Agency (ERA) or by DG MOVE can be used for statistical purposes and made easily available to the public. It was linked to the signing of an amendment to the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between Eurostat and the ERA regarding the transfer of data on rail transport safety and interoperability. An MoU between Eurostat and DG MOVE to identify the main European statistics needed for the programming and implementation of EU mobility and transport policies was also signed before the agreement was reached. I supported the recommendation in plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its 2014 revision of the Rail Transport Statistics Regulation, the European Parliament weaed a number of important elements into the legal material, such as track sections equipped with a single European Rail Traffic Management (ERTMS) system, accessible stations or even statistics collected on accidents. The report approved today reflects the positive results of the interinstitutional consultations, so as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has spent millions of euros on the ertms rail system, with more or less success. It is therefore important to get a true picture of the railway sections on which the system operates and on which it can be introduced in the near future. From the point of view of the disabled, the list of accessible stations is very important, for which reliable statistical data are essential. Unlike the European Commission, Parliament believes that the collection of data on railway accidents is also essential and important, paying particular attention to accidents involving the transport of dangerous substances. In order to reduce the number of fatalities in rail transport accidents, we need to improve the data collection system. Cooperation between The Member States and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (ERA) is essential in order to achieve a common objective, namely to ensure that statistics on rail transport are as accurate, transparent as possible and that the data collected can be easily compared with other modes of transport. This will allow the Commission to improve rail safety controls.  To this end, it was necessary to sign two Memoranda of Understanding between Eurostat and the Commission, as well as era and commission, which would allow the parties concerned to complement each other's data and avoid duplication in the data collection process and not to impose an excessive administrative burden on either institution. Against this background, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the legislation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Recommendation within the scope of the Regulation on rail transport statistics, which should be expanded to include data on infrastructure, in particular the deployment of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), which is one of the priorities of the trans-European transport network. It is vitally important to have a clear vision of the development of ERTMS in the EU. Similarly, it is key to work in the most efficient and cost-effective way to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Union Railway Agency, to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and to ensure that statistical data on Union policies are easily accessible to citizens and stakeholders.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from the vote on the recommendation for the second reading on 'Statistics of rail transport – collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents', as I see the need to collect the data, but in this case I am not convinced that this goes hand in hand with the necessary steps to reduce red tape.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation, which increases the availability of clear and transparent data on the performance of European goods and passenger railway services. Such information is vital to ensure continued improvements to safety, accessibility and general performance of rail services across the EU. The new rules will simplify data collection procedures and reduce overlapping between statistical agencies, enhancing the quality of data available without imposing any additional burdens on Member States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which lays the groundwork for improving the collection of data on the transport of goods and passengers by rail through the Union as a whole, as well as accidents occurring and other serious incidents. The dual purpose is to generate reliable and comparable databases and simplify the task of collecting-systematizing competent authorities in the Member States.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation, as it increases the availability of clear and transparent data on the performance of European goods and passenger railway services. Such information is vital to ensure continued improvements to safety, accessibility and general performance of rail services across the EU. The new rules will simplify data collection procedures and reduce overlapping between statistical agencies, enhancing the quality of data available without imposing any additional burdens on Member States.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation. The European Parliament has decided that the scope of the regulation on rail transport statistics should be expanded to include data on infrastructure because it is extremely important to get a clear impression of how the EU has developed the European rail traffic management system. Also, Parliament has stated that statistics on rail accidents should remain within the scope of the regulation, which can even be extended to include accidents involving dangerous goods and disasters. It is important that EU citizens should have easy access to data related to the implementation of EU policies.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its 2014 revision of the Rail Transport Statistics Regulation, the European Parliament weaed a number of important elements into the legal material, such as the issue of track sections equipped with the ERTMS system, accessible stations and statistics on accidents. The report approved today reflects the positive results of interinstitutional consultations. The European Union has spent millions of euros to put the ERTMS rail system into effect with more or less success. It is therefore important to get a true picture of the railway sections on which the system operates and on which it can be introduced in the near future. Unlike the European Commission, Parliament believes that the collection of data on railway accidents is also extremely important, paying particular attention to accidents involving the transport of dangerous substances. In order to reduce the number of fatalities in rail transport accidents, it is necessary to improve the data collection system. Cooperation between Member States and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (ERA) is essential in order to achieve a common objective. This common objective is to collect statistics on more accurate, transparent rail transport and to make the data collected more easily comparable to other modes of transport. To this end, it was necessary to sign two Memoranda of Understanding between Eurostat and the Commission, as well as era and commission, allowing the parties concerned to complement each other's data, thereby avoiding duplication in the data collection process.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against an amendment to reject this report and close the legislative procedure. Thankfully, this was defeated in plenary and the second reading was successful. The existing legislative framework (Regulations (EC) Nos 91/2003, 1192/2003, and 332/2007) for the generation of Union rail transport statistics sets up a double system, offering the possibility for ‘detailed reporting’ and ‘simplified reporting’. The data collected contain information on passenger and goods transport, as well as on traffic flows and accidents. The Commission proposal’s primary aim is to update, simplify and optimise the existing system. That information is necessary to monitor and develop the EU transport policy. Having sound rail transport statistics is necessary and important for monitoring rail transport and its development. I welcome the simplification of the reporting procedure and favour the extension of data collection to include rail infrastructure.  The text agreed in the trilogue is accompanied by an amendment to the existing Memorandum of Understanding between Eurostat and the European Railway Agency, to include statistics on the deployment of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), and by a Memorandum of Understanding between EUROSTAT and DG Move to ensure that there is better data sharing and no duplication of data collection.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement will ensure that data collected by the European Railway Agency or by DG MOVE can be used for statistical purposes and made easily available to the public.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending the Railway Statistics Regulation on the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents, as I support the simplification of the reporting process and the extension of data collection to rail infrastructure as well.  I believe it is necessary to provide citizens with easy and easy access to data on the implementation of EU policies, and therefore I support this recommendation for a second reading.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. In my view, this proposal has no significant interest in promoting the rail transport sector in France, although the merits are not criticised. However, I am choosing to support the EFDD group's amendment to oppose the European Union's desire to interfere in the statistical affairs of Member States' rail transport. So I voted for it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal because I am of the view that statistics on rail transport should be open to EU citizens. Improving the accessibility of data on goods, passengers and accidents will not only provide all categories of users of rail transport with trustworthy information, which will enable them to observe the progress of European policies in the rail sector, but also allow stakeholders to better evaluate developments in the sector and react accordingly. For instance, statistics can bring useful evidence-based information to survey rail safety.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Michael Cramer's report on the collection of data on goods, travellers and accidents. This text supports the collaboration between Eurostat and the European Railway Agency to improve statistics on rail accidents and ensure consistency in the methodology adapted to other modes of transport. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. – The extension of the Regulation to include statistics on accidents occurring in rail transport is necessary. In addition, it is necessary to extend the statistics to include data on the ease of accessibility to rail transport by people with disabilities.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report endorses the Council's position on the existing regulation and calls for an extension of the scope of rail transport statistics to include infrastructure data and data on accidents and incidents.  The results of the negotiations can be welcomed. Collecting and evaluating data for the European rail system could indicate the need for action on investments. That is why I am voting in favour of adopting the Council's position.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation, as it increases the availability of clear and transparent data on the performance of European goods and passenger railway services.  Such information is vital to ensure continued improvements to safety, accessibility and general performance of rail services across the EU. The new rules will simplify data collection procedures and reduce overlapping between statistical agencies, enhancing the quality of data available without imposing any additional burdens on Member States.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE)
text: Writing. Good legislation must be based on sufficient, reliable and accurate facts and figures. Such information requires answers to questions as to whether legislation that has already been in place is being complied with and is sufficient, or which "gaps" still need to be filled. Unfortunately, EU Member States have often been unwilling or unable to provide such data. Rail transport must continue to increase its attractiveness and efficiency in order to be better used by citizens and businesses. It is therefore important to include aspects such as the number of passengers and accessibility information at stations. The application of ERTMS is important for the development of a single European railway area. In order to make a safe means of transport even safer, data on accidents and near-accidents are also important. It is gratifying that the two declarations of intent between Eurostat and the European Commission on the one hand and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (ERA) on the other have finally come to an end in the years of negotiations. What is less pleasing, however, is the fact that these declarations were necessary in the first place in order to reach an agreement. I welcome the text adopted today, as it simplifies the requirements for the supply and use of data, reduces the administrative burden and thus optimises European statistics on rail transport.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its 2014 revision of the Rail Transport Statistics Regulation, the European Parliament weaed a number of important elements into the legal material, such as the issue of track sections equipped with the ERTMS system, accessible stations or even statistics collected on accidents. The report approved today reflects the positive results of interinstitutional consultations.  The European Union has spent millions of euros to put the ERTMS rail system into effect with more or less success.   From the point of view of the disabled, the list of accessible stations is very important, for which reliable statistical data are essential.  Unlike the European Commission, Parliament believes that the collection of data on railway accidents is also essential and important, paying particular attention to accidents involving the transport of dangerous substances. In order to reduce the number of fatalities in rail transport accidents, it is necessary to improve the data collection system. Cooperation between The Member States and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (ERA) is essential in order to achieve a common objective of making statistics on rail transport as accurate and transparent as possible and to make the data collected easily comparable to other modes of transport. For this, it was necessary to sign two Memoranda of Understanding between Eurostat and the Commission, as well as between era and commission. Against this background, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the legislation.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because there is no doubt that the EU needs statistics and data on transport infrastructure and rail transport of passengers as well as on rail accidents in order to ensure the monitoring and development of the common transport policy and preparatory measures in the field of transport safety. I warmly welcome the signing of the two memoranda of understanding (MoUS) between Eurostat and the Commission (27 April 2016) and between Eurostat and the ERA (12 May 2016). MoUs are important instruments for optimising the use of existing information and avoiding overlapping between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency (ERA). They will ensure that statistical data related to EU policies are easily accessible to EU citizens and stakeholders.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The current proposal aims to amend Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 in order to update, facilitate and optimise the existing legal framework for European rail transport statistics, bringing it into line with the new institutional framework. It is a system for the management, control and protection of rail traffic and its signalling on board, designed with the aim of replacing the multiple systems of circulation and safety of European railways, guaranteeing new high-speed rail networks. With this measure, Parliament also wanted to stress the importance of having a clear vision on the development of ERTMS/ETCS (European Rail Traffic Management System/ European Train Control System), for which a great deal of resources have been invested. I am therefore voting in favour of Mr Cramer's report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I support the report on railway transport statistics on the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on freight and passenger transport, but also on accidents across the European Union's rail network.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is an authorisation given to the Commission to collect statistical data on rail freight and passenger transport as well as accidents across the EU network. It does not bring anything positive to French rail transport. Since the English of the EFDD (Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy) group had proposed a rejection amendment, I voted for this amendment (and therefore against the report).

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is its mission to update the framework and adapt the new provisions on delegated and implementing acts on rail transport.  Parliament demanded that the collection of statistical data on accidents be kept in the regulation. Also introduce new data and variables such as the number of kilometers of network with the ERTMS system, kilometers of abandoned cross-border lines to be collected statistically and make this information available to the public. In addition, in order to avoid duplication between Eurostat, the Member States and the Railway Railway Safety Agency, two MOUs have been signed.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report completes and improves rail transport statistics in the field of data collection on goods, passengers and accidents. Despite my reservations about the use of this data, as I fear that they will serve as technical support for the liberalisation measures of the Union's rail package, I believe that there is no reason to oppose its collection by denying its parliamentary approval.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament, the European Parliament adopts the Council's position at first reading on the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics with regard to the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents.  After negotiating with the Council for a long time, an agreement has been concluded which seeks to alleviate the workload of Eurostat, the Commission and the European Union Railway Agency (EFSA) through cooperation between these institutions, as well as ensuring that data relating to Union policies are more accessible to these institutions and citizens. My vote is favourable as Parliament's position has been respected, so that, for example, statistics on rail accidents remain within the scope of the Regulation and are even extended to incidents of transport of dangerous goods and accidents at level crossings.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is very important to get statistics on the transport of goods and passengers by rail in order to monitor and develop the common transport policy. To this end it is necessary to update, simplify and optimise the existing legal framework for European statistics on rail transport and to align it with the new institutional context.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the amendment rejecting the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In the case of the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents, this Regulation should therefore be published in the Official Report.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This text allows the Commission to establish statistics in the field of freight and passenger transport, and rail accidents in the EU network. This text does not bring anything positive to French rail transport and imposes a new mandatory passage before Parliament, which we oppose.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Citizens of the Union should have easy access, through a one-stop shop, to data relating to Union policies. In this area, I support the amendment of the regulation on rail transport statistics with regard to the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents, which encourages collaboration between various entities such as Eurostat, the Commission and the Union Railway Agency. This new approach will optimize the use of existing information and reduce the administrative burden, while en allowing access to reliable data and information on the advancement of European policies in the railway sector.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be published in the Official Statistics on Rail Transport. Accident statistics should remain within the scope of the Regulation, which should be extended to include accidents and incidents relating to the transport of dangerous goods and accidents involving level crossings. I would like to stress that it is important to have a clear picture of the development of ERTMS in the EU, as the EU has spent millions of euros to finance infrastructure of this type.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is the first reading for the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics with a view to collecting data on goods, passengers and accidents. This report is to be welcomed, as the collection of data can indicate a need for action and the impact of investment can be shown or put into perspective.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP's report on amendments to the regulation in the field of rail transport statistics. On the basis of these amendments, the scope of the Regulation should be extended to include infrastructure data, in particular on the deployment of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), which was one of the priorities of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T). This will give a clear impression of the development of ERTMS in the Union, as the EU has spent millions of euros to finance this type of infrastructure, but due to inconsistent deployment and delays in deployment, no concrete results have been achieved in terms of the technical requirements for the use of the system.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This is the implementation of the "technical" component of the 4th rail package. This report aims to simplify and improve European statistics on rail transport. But the purpose of these statistics is explained by the Commission: "the main objective of the EU's transport policy is to establish an internal market by drawing up common policies to promote a high degree of competitiveness".  This is a bad logic: statistics should focus on data important for user safety and the ecological bifurcation of transport (by incorporating, for example, piggyback statistics). That is not the case here. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is an authorisation given to the Commission to collect statistical data on rail freight and passenger transport as well as accidents across the EU network. It does not bring anything positive to French rail transport. The English of the EFDD group having proposed a rejection amendment, so I voted in favour of this amendment.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of the European Union's transport policy is to create an internal market by promoting common policies that encourage a high level of competitiveness and the harmonious, balanced and sustainable development of economic activities. The creation of a genuine internal market is essential for the revitalisation of the rail sector and will contribute to making rail freight and passenger services more competitive and attractive and increasing their modal share of transport.  The aim of this proposal is therefore to amend Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 with a view to updating, simplifying and optimising the existing regulatory framework for European statistics on rail transport and harmonising that Regulation with the new institutional context. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this legislative resolution going to a second reading, as the measures will lead to better use of the data collected and reduce the administrative burden on the institutions responsible whilst also ensuring that there will be no overlapping.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The most comprehensive access of EU stakeholders and our citizens to statistical data on EU policies is one of the European Parliament's priorities. It has therefore decided to extend the scope of the Regulation on Railway Transport Statistics, thereby amending Regulation (EC) 91/2003, to cover data on more fields, such as infrastructure, passengers and rail accidents. I believe it is essential that all citizens and stakeholders involved, from near and far, in the rail transport sector be entitled to know, for example, the current state of the deployment of the European rail traffic management system - a project which the European Union has financed so much. They are also entitled to consult the railway accident archives or to find out about the infrastructure available, in each European station, for people with reduced mobility. This is in order to have, in the long run, a clear vision of the existing infrastructure and policies in the Union's railway sector. That is why I am in favour of extending the regulation on railway transport statistics.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council an amendment to Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics as regards data collection on goods, passengers and accidents. At first reading, Parliament adopted the Commission's proposal with significant amendments. As a result, informal trilateral consultations and then informal negotiations were held to reach an early second reading agreement. Finally, on 24 May 2016, during the second informal trilogue, the negotiating team of Parliament and the Council reached an agreement on the matter. The text containing the results of the negotiations was approved by the Committee on Transport and Tourism on 15 June 2016, recommending in its report to Parliament that it agree with the Council's position at first reading. I voted as proposed in the report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At first reading, the European Parliament decided that the scope of the Regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to include infrastructure data, in particular on the implementation of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS). It also decided that Eurostat should provide statistical data on stations without barriers, accessible to people with reduced mobility and persons with disabilities, as well as on the use of cross-border railway infrastructure, and, with regard to accidents, Parliament defended the idea that statistics on rail accidents should be maintained within the scope of the Regulation and should now include accidents and incidents involving the transport of dangerous goods and accidents that have occurred at level crossings.  I advocate enhanced cooperation between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency to ensure that statistical data relating to EU policies are easily accessible to EU citizens and that processes are more efficient and cost-effective to avoid duplication of work.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on freight and passenger transport, but also on accidents across the Member States' rail network. There is no major reason to oppose it, although this report does not bring anything positive to French rail transport. So I voted for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation increases the availability of clear and transparent data on the performance of European goods and passenger railway services. Such information is vital to ensure continued improvements to safety, accessibility and general performance of rail services across the EU. The new rules will simplify data collection procedures and reduce overlapping between statistical agencies, enhancing the quality of data available without imposing any additional burdens on Member States.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the amendment of the regulation (EC) No. 91/2003 on railway transport statistics, with regard to the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. The aim is to simplify and optimise the collection of statistical data on rail transport at European level. These statistics are necessary to enable the Commission to better assess and adapt European transport policy, particularly in the major area of rail safety.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – I have always considered it very important to support decisions that directly facilitate the daily lives of European citizens. The collection and processing of transport data makes it possible to develop effective and accurate strategic plans that, by focusing on the relevant areas, will make a major contribution to a good transport network for the European Union. Such statistics, for example, can be used to track rail utilization in each region, and the results highlight existing shortcomings and necessary changes. Again, I'm bringing up interrail tickets for 18-year-olds. What better way to connect Europeans than to have all the Member States at their fingertips?

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report, which will enable cooperation between Eurostat, the Commission, and the European Railway Agency (ERA), ensuring that statistical data related to EU policies are easily accessible to EU citizens and stakeholders.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main aspiration of European rail policy is to establish fast, safe, secure and energy-efficient transport, convenient for passengers and providing good conditions for the development of European industry that creates jobs and economic prosperity. In order to achieve this objective, the EU needs to analyse a certain amount of data that will serve to develop a streamlined strategy that takes into account railway development in different Member States. In this context, a key motive for the amendment of the Regulation is the simplification of data collection in order to reduce unnecessarily duplicate statistics. In this way, data collection work will be more effectively distributed between Member States, national statistical authorities, railway representatives, as well as competent European authorities. This in turn will accompany the faster development of a streamlined rail transport strategy in the EU. I have given my support to the amendment of this Regulation because I believe that streamlining the European railway strategy will save financial resources that have not been used optimally so far.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it has already made extensive investments in infrastructure without any concrete results. The collection and analyse of data for the European rail system clearly shows a need for action and the impact of investment must be presented transparently.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. Cooperation in the sharing of railway statistics between the Commission, Eurostat and the European Railway Agency is essential for the railway network to develop more efficiently and that information on rail transport, accessibility for persons with disabilities and general accidents be shared and accessible between Member States. The vote was set up as non-supportive of the report, which would have delayed its entry into force.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted.  In particular, greater efforts are needed to create a properly functioning internal market that will help to revitalise the rail sector. Freight and passenger rail services must become more competitive and attractive. They should also be included as strongly as possible in the intermodal sector. Fair and objective data on statistics on rail freight and passenger transport are essential for the proper monitoring and development of the common transport policy and, at the same time, for a common railway area to be established. In order to reduce the administrative burden, statistics must be transparent, public and accessible to the public. In addition, the legal framework for European statistics on rail transport should be updated, optimised and simplified as far as possible in order to be flexible and adapt appropriately to changing conditions.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's decision to extend the scope for statistics on rail transport to include data on infrastructure and in particular on the development plan of the European Railway Traffic Management System (ERTMS), as well as to provide a clear picture of the development of ERTMS, as the EU has spent millions of euros to finance infrastructure of this type without any , so far, a concrete result in terms of the functionality of the system, due to irregularities and delays in the development of the system, and Parliament's decision that Eurostat should have statistical data on barrier-free stations accessible to persons with reduced mobility and people with disabilities, as well as on the use of cross-border rail infrastructures is in the right direction so that there is a better analysis of all data and better use of statistics. An important achievement is to strengthen cooperation between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Union Railway Agency (ERA), with a view to ensuring that European citizens and other stakeholders have easy access to data related to EU policies. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for the rejection amendment on this legislative motion for a resolution. By the EU’s own admission, the EU has spent millions on the ERTMS deployment without any concrete results, due to irregular deployment and delays in the deployment.  Therefore, we cannot allow the EU to put legislation in place and still waste the taxpayers’ money.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the Council's position on the adoption of a regulation on rail transport statistics with regard to the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents, I believe that these protocols can be of considerable use. These are, in fact, memorized protocols aimed at optimizing the use of existing information and reducing administrative burdens and benefiting the community. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that good statistics will help create a well-functioning common transport policy and system. I supported a solution based largely on the signing of two memoranda of understanding, i.e. (1) between Eurostat and the European Railway Agenda and (2) between Eurostat and DG MOVE, in order to guarantee the availability of data on ERTMS, the accessibility of stations to persons with reduced mobility and disabled persons, and on cross-border sections.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Rail transport is a great asset of the European Union. It is the simplest and cheapest mode of transport, giving great mobility to citizens of the European Union, but also to those outside it. It is therefore necessary to take constant care of the quality of rail transport and the needs of users in order to maximase the efficiency of this transport.  I support the recommendation regarding the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents, as it goes precisely in the aforementioned direction. The collection of passenger and goods travel data and goods by rail is necessary to upgrade, simplify and optimise the existing legal framework for European rail statistics. Quality data enable timely and efficient action towards improving infrastructure, organisation and railway services in general.  In order to achieve as much data accuracy as possible, and thus as good a customer service as possible, cooperation between the Commission services and other competent authorities is needed, which this recommendation encourages. Also, good statistics would allow the Commission to monitor and develop a common transport policy and elements of transport found in policies related to regions and trans-European networks. It is clear that the benefit of accepting this recommendation is manifold.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to enable the Commission to collect statistical data on freight and passenger transport as well as accidents across the UNION's rail network. It does not refer to the Commission's delegated acts. It has little interest, but it is mandatory to go before Parliament. I have no major reason to oppose it, but neither is there any reason to vote in favour of this report, which does not bring anything positive to French rail transport. On the other hand, I support the amendment proposed by the EFDD Group which refuses to grant this additional power to the Commission.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ It is of utmost importance to have a clear vision for the development of ERTMS in the Union, as the EU is investing millions of euros in financing this type of infrastructure, but so far with no concrete results on the operability of the system in Europe due to improper application and delays in application. In order to effectively and cost-effectively avoid overlapping work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency, cooperation between these institutions should be strengthened and statistics on EU policies to citizens and stakeholders in the European Union should be ensured.  I think it is very important that EU citizens have easy access to eu policy enforcement data that would be available in one place. The agreement on simplifying the Railway Statistics Regulation only became possible after the signing of the two memoranda and they are not only important instruments for optimising the use of existing information and reducing the administrative burden, but also meet the conditions of co-responders in terms of better use of rail statistics.  This will provide all categories of users with readily available data and reliable information on the progress made by European policy in the rail sector.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is an essentially technical text, of communicating information on rail transport by Member States to the Commission on goods, passengers and accidents, allowing a supranational analysis of the sector – also compared to other means of transport – and operating the "European railway system" in the wake of the 4th Railway Package. We recognise that the exchange of statistical information can help the development of rail systems, provided that issues such as privacy are ensured. What worries us is the context of this proposal, which deserves our repudiation because it is one of the pillars of EU policy that has promoted the privatisation and total disorganisation of the companies responsible for rail transport; promoting the deregulation of labour and increased labour exploitation in the sector; which has resulted in increased tariffs for users and the degradation of infrastructure and reduced railway safety.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this proposal is to amend Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 in order to update, simplify and optimise the existing legal framework for European rail transport statistics and bring it into line with the new institutional framework. I think it is very useful to provide policy-makers with reliable figures in such a way as to facilitate their work in the interests of European transport policy. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which updates and simplifies the legal framework for European rail transport statistics. This is of paramount importance, particularly in order to ensure and prepare for new rail safety legislation. Establishing reliable and timely data will also enable citizens and authorities to better understand the evolution of rail transport in their territories.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal provides that the scope of Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics should be extended in order to update, simplify and optimise the existing legal framework. The European Parliament and the Council agreed that the most cost-effective way to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency is to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and ensure that statistical data relating to EU policies are easily accessible to EU citizens and stakeholders. This was possible after the signing of two memoranda of understanding between Eurostat and the Commission (27-04-2016) and between Eurostat and EFE (12-05-2016).  These memoranda of understanding are important tools for optimizing the use of existing information and reducing administrative burden. Rail transport statistics are necessary for the Commission to monitor and develop a common transport policy, as well as to design regional and trans-European network policies.  I support this proposal.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for the rejection amendment on this legislative motion for a resolution. By the EU’s own admission, the EU has spent millions on the ERTMS deployment without any concrete results, due to irregular deployment and delays in the deployment.  Therefore, we cannot allow the EU to put legislation in place and still waste the taxpayers’ money.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, considering that the scope of the Regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to include infrastructure data, in particular on the implementation of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), one of the priorities of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T).  Parliament stressed that it was imperative to have a clear vision of ertms' development in the European Union, as it has spent millions of euros on financing this type of infrastructure without any concrete result so far in terms of system operability across Europe due to irregular deployment and delays. The Council and Parliament recognised that the most cost-effective way to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency is to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and ensure that statistical data relating to EU policies are easily accessible to EU citizens and stakeholders.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The EP decided that the scope of the Regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to include infrastructure data, in particular on the implementation of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), one of the priorities of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T).  The European Parliament stressed that it was imperative to have a clear vision of ertms' development in the European Union, as it has spent millions of euros on financing this type of infrastructure without any concrete result so far in terms of the operability of the system across Europe due to irregular deployment and delays. The EP believes that it is extremely important for EU citizens to have easy access – as a one-stop shop – to data relating to the implementation of EU policies.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative resolution by which Parliament approves the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on statistics on rail transport, as regards the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. After lengthy negotiations, the Council and Parliament agreed that the most efficient and cost-effective way to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the Union Railway Agency was to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and to ensure that statistical data on Union policies are easily accessible to citizens and stakeholders, cooperation which has resulted in the signing of two memorandums of understanding between Eurostat and the Commission (27.4.2016) and between Eurostat and the EA (12.5.2016).

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of amending the railway transport statistics regulation for the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. This data collection is particularly important in order to enable the Commission to prepare and monitor the EU's actions in the area of transport safety. Reliable, quality data is crucial to adopting the most appropriate policies.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased that parliament's position on the harmonisation of the regulation of railway statistics has easily coincided. Indeed, the adoption of this document will reduce the volume of statistical collection work, as the Railway Agency and Eurostat will no longer have to do the same work. At the same time, it is good that the scope of such an important task as the collection of accident information has not been reduced. I believe that this document will directly contribute to both better regulation and better railways in Europe.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament decided at first reading that the scope of the Regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to include data on infrastructure, in particular on the deployment of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS) – one of the priorities of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T).  In fact, it is a system where a large amount has been invested and which to date has not presented any concrete results due to delays and irregularities in its implementation, but which is considered extremely important for EU citizens to have rapid, easier and reliable access to data related to the implementation of European policies. To this end, there should be greater cooperation and close contact in the methodological coherence between Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (EFS) with regard to accident data in other means of transport, which was possible thanks to the signing of two memoranda of understanding (between Eurostat and the European Commission and Eurostat and eFSI) which allowed an agreement to simplify the Regulation , meeting the objectives proposed by the co-legislators following two formal trilogues, and I therefore voted in favour of this Report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which lays the groundwork for improving the collection of data on the transport of goods and passengers by rail through the Union as a whole, as well as accidents occurring and other serious incidents. The dual purpose is to generate reliable and comparable databases and simplify the task of collecting-systematizing competent authorities in the Member States.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on rail transport statistics with a view to collecting data on goods, passengers and accidents, as it simplifies, optimises and updates the existing legal framework for European statistics. The statistics are necessary to monitor and develop rail transport. This also applies to the area of railway safety and allows the European Commission to better monitor and introduce measures.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation increases the availability of clear and transparent data on the performance of European goods and passenger railway services. Such information is vital to ensure continued improvements to safety, accessibility and general performance of rail services across the EU. The new rules will simplify data collection procedures and reduce duplication of work by different statistical agencies, enhancing the quality of data available without imposing any additional burdens on Member States.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the EP and the Council amending Regulation 91/2003 on rail statistics as regards the collection of data on goods, persons and accidents. Parliament decided at first reading that the scope of rail statistics should be extended to provide data on infrastructure, as the EU has spent millions of euros funding this type of infrastructure. Parliament also decided that Eurostat should provide data on barrier-free stations accessible to persons with reduced mobility and persons with disabilities, as well as on the use of cross-border rail infrastructure. Finally, the Council and Parliament agreed that duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency can be avoided most effectively and cost-effectively by strengthening cooperation between the three institutions and ensuring easy access for EU citizens and stakeholders to eu policy statistics.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has recently proposed to amend Regulation 91/2003/EC, while creating common rules for the management of statistics in the field of rail transport. The aim of the regulation is to simplify the collection and transmission of data (by Member States) on goods and passengers travelling on the railways.  Accident statistics are to be kept by the European Railway Agency in accordance with the regulation. The Regulation extends the obligations of States to inform regard to types of locomotives operating on certain relationships, on passenger flows, as well as on the accessibility of railway infrastructure for disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility.  In the future, the Commission should step up its work on passenger data on certain routes in order to integrate rail routes in regional and cross-border areas where there are missing links in the future.  I believe that progress is needed in this area, and we should make better use of the potential offered by railways within the European Union, which is why I supported the recommendation.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of rail transport is one of the important factors in meeting the European Commission's objectives of reindustrialising Europe, connecting regions, increasing labour mobility and reducing air pollution by exhate from cars and trucks. In order to be able to adopt effective legislation, we need reliable data on the real state of play in this transport sector.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In order to avoid inefficient overlapping of the affairs of Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency, it is important to strengthen cooperation between institutions, including making statistics easier for citizens of the European Union. This optimises the use of existing information and aims to reduce the administrative burden while providing all stakeholders with easily accessible data and information on progress made by European policy in the rail sector. A vote for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 91/2003 Rail transport statistics concerning the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents of the Transport and Tourism Committee have been postponed to the next plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on rail transport statistics concerning the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents.
