I support the proposed compromise between the Commission and the European Parliament, which will avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency, while strengthening cooperation between them, thus approaching EU policy statistics.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council's position gives the Commission super-powers and at the same time does not ensure that statistics are collected in the best possible and most directly usable way.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its 2014 revision of the Rail Transport Statistics Regulation, the European Parliament weaed a number of important elements into the legal material, such as the issue of track sections equipped with the ERTMS system, accessible stations or even statistics on accidents. The report approved today reflects the positive results of interinstitutional consultations. From the point of view of the disabled, the list of accessible stations is very important, for which reliable statistical data are essential. Unlike the European Commission, Parliament believes that the collection of data on railway accidents is also essential and important, paying particular attention to accidents involving the transport of dangerous substances. In order to reduce the number of fatalities in rail transport accidents, it is necessary to improve the data collection system. Cooperation between The Member States and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (ERA) is essential in order to achieve a common objective of making statistics on rail transport as accurate and transparent as possible and to make the data collected easily comparable to other modes of transport. To this end, it was necessary to sign two Memoranda of Understanding between Eurostat and the Commission, as well as era and commission, which will allow the parties concerned to complement each other's data and avoid duplication in the data collection process. Against this background, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the legislation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of your draft legislative resolution on rail transport statistics, which strengthens cooperation between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency, thereby ensuring easier access for EU citizens to statistics on EU policies.  It is to be welcomed that the memoranda of understanding between Eurostat and the Commission and Eurostat and the European Railway Agency will contribute to better use and easier access to rail transport statistics by optimising the use of existing information and reducing administrative burdens.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation in line with the ALDE integrated line, as clear statistics help the development of rail transport and are an important basis for cooperation between EU countries.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament has reached an agreement with the Council ensuring that data collected by the European Railway Agency (ERA) or by DG MOVE can be used for statistical purposes and also made available to the public. The agreement is linked to two memoranda of understanding signed by Eurostat with the ERA and DG MOVE.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. After lengthy negotiations, the Council and the European Parliament agreed that the most effective and cheapest way to avoid duplication between the activities of Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency was to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and to ensure that statistical data related to EU policies were readily available to EU citizens and stakeholders. An agreement on simplifying the regulation on rail transport statistics was only possible after the signing of two Memorandums of Understanding, one between Eurostat and the Commission (27 April 2016) and the other between Eurostat and the European Railway Agency (12 May 2016). These Memorandums of Understanding are not only important instruments for optimising the use of existing information and reducing the administrative burden, they also respond to the need for co-legislators to make better use of rail transport statistics. This will give all categories of users easily accessible data and reliable information on the evolution of European policies in the rail sector.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement reached with the Council and the Commission. The text aims to update the current legislative framework and facilitates the collection of data on rail transport, all of which is necessary for better planning and law-making in the transport sector.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The Report on rail transport statistics on the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents simplifies the rules for collecting statistics on Rail Transport of the European Union and encourages close cooperation between Eurostat and the European Railway Agency to avoid duplication of work between these authorities. This proposal improves the availability of train stations to people with limited mobility and persons with disabilities without collecting additional data, i.e. without imposing additional burdens on Member States and other relevant actors, and also aims to reduce administrative barriers. That's why I voted in favor.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft legislative resolution on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 of 16 December 2002 on rail transport statistics concerning the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents.  The scope of the Regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to infrastructure data, in particular the establishment of the European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS), which is one of the priorities for the trans-European transport network (TEN-T).  It is extremely important that EU citizens have easy access, under the one-stop shop, to data on the implementation of EU policies. After lengthy negotiations, the Council and Parliament agreed that the most effective and cost-effective way to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency is to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and make EU policy statistics easy for EU citizens and stakeholders.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which lays the groundwork for improving the collection of data on the transport of goods and passengers by rail through the Union as a whole, as well as accidents occurring and other serious incidents. The dual purpose is to generate reliable and comparable databases and simplify the task of collecting-systematizing competent authorities in the Member States.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on freight and passenger transport, but also on accidents across the EU's rail network.  It is not a problem for the Commission to collect this data.  So I voted for it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 More statistics can contribute to better transport policy planning and to increased rail safety. On the other hand, a balance must be struck between these benefits and the possible burden on Member States and respondents that results from the collection of additional data. The compromise reached stipulates that no new categories of data will be collected. However, access to data that already exists and which concerns, for example, the accessibility of stations for persons with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility will be facilitated. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 After lengthy negotiations, the Council and Parliament agreed that the most effective and cost-effective way to avoid duplication of work between Eurostat, the Commission and the European Railway Agency (ERA) is to strengthen cooperation between these institutions and to ensure that statistical data on EU policies are easily accessible to EU citizens and stakeholders. I did not support the efdd proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation which lays the groundwork for improving the collection of data on the transport of goods and passengers by rail through the Union as a whole, as well as accidents occurring and other serious incidents. The dual purpose is to generate reliable and comparable databases and simplify the task of collecting-systematizing competent authorities in the Member States.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against the only amendment with the aim of getting the text approved.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics, as regards the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. At first reading Parliament decided that the scope of the regulation on rail transport statistics should be extended to cover data on infrastructure. Parliament stressed that it was of the utmost importance to have a clear view on the development of ERTMS in the Union, as the EU has spent millions of euros to fund this type of infrastructure without any concrete result so far in terms of operability of the system. Parliament was also of the opinion that Eurostat and the European Railway Agency should closely cooperate in improving statistics on rail accidents and in particular ensure the methodological consistency with regard to accident data on other modes of transport. I voted in favour because I believe that it is very important that EU citizens have easy access to data related to the implementation of EU policies.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report completes and improves rail transport statistics in the field of data collection on goods, passengers and accidents. Despite my reservations about the use of this data, as I fear that they will serve as technical support for the liberalisation measures of the Union's rail package, I believe that there is no reason to oppose its collection by denying its parliamentary approval.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is an essentially technical text, of communicating information on rail transport by Member States to the Commission on goods, passengers and accidents, allowing a supranational analysis of the sector – also compared to other means of transport – and operating the "European railway system" in the wake of the 4th Railway Package. We recognise that the exchange of statistical information can help the development of rail systems, provided that issues such as privacy are ensured. What worries us is the context of this proposal, which deserves our repudiation because it is one of the pillars of EU policy that has promoted the privatisation and total disorganisation of the companies responsible for rail transport; promoting the deregulation of labour and increased labour exploitation in the sector; which has resulted in increased tariffs for users and the degradation of infrastructure and reduced railway safety.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. By approving this Council position, the existing Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics with a view to collecting data on goods, passengers and accidents is amended to extend the scope of rail transport statistics (including the inclusion of infrastructure data and data on accidents and incidents). The negotiations have shown that it is important to have a clear approach to the development of the ERTMS (European System for Managing and Managing Rail Transport on the Trans-European Networks Routes), as extensive investments have already been made in infrastructures without yet getting any concrete results.  Through declarations of intent by the key players involved, EuroStat, the Commission and ERA (The European Union Railway Agency), the relevant negotiators of the Council and the EP believe that they can effectively prevent unnecessary duplication of work.  The results of the negotiations can be welcomed. Collecting and evaluating data for the europ. Rail system could indicate a need for action and show or put into perspective the impact of investment. I have therefore voted against the amendment so that the Council decision can be adopted.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the recommendation for second reading on the Council's first reading position with a view to adopting the regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 91/2003 on rail transport statistics, as regards the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. At first reading, Parliament decided that the scope of the Regulation on rail statistics should be extended to include infrastructure data, in particular data on the introduction of the European rail traffic management system, which was one of the priorities of the trans-European transport network - TEN-T. After negotiations, the Council and Parliament agreed on the simplification of the Regulation on rail statistics.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of this proposal is to amend Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 in order to update, simplify and optimise the existing legal framework for European statistics on rail transport and to align it with the new institutional context. These statistics are necessary for the Commission to be able to monitor and develop the common transport policy, as well as the transport elements in the policies relating to trans-European regions and networks.  Rail safety benefits from these statistics so that the Commission can prepare and monitor Union action in the field of transport safety, a very important element in the Union. My vote is in favour of the proposal, as I believe that harmonisation of the legal framework at European and international level is essential. A proposal that facilitates and simplifies procedures is always positive for European citizens.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the regulation on rail transport statistics in the European Union. In the current financial perspective, we rightly emphasise investment in railways. They should relieve the burden on road transport and protect the environment by improving the smoothness of rail transport. This growing investment, amounting to tens of billions of euros in the European Union, also requires a review of the way in which the funds are spent, which is not possible without reliable statistics. However, it appears that the information collected must not relate solely to the number of passengers carried and the goods transported. Infrastructure data, in particular on the rail traffic management system, would be equally important. Improvements in this area are essential for the operationality of the rail transport system in Europe. Another problem is cross-border investment, which improves rail traffic between countries. It therefore appears that the statistics need to allocate a specific part on investment in cross-border railway infrastructure.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a recommendation on the Council's position with a view to adopting a regulation amending the rules on rail statistics as regards the collection of data on goods, persons and accidents. In particular, this proposal aims at simplifying the rules for generating rail transport statistics and thus reducing the burden on the Member States in this area.  In this case, this was already a number of attempts in the process of adopting the new rules. I believe that the original requirements, as put forward by the Commission, were not set in accordance with the principle of proportionality. They requested the collection of a number of data which would burden the Member States without the resulting statistics demonstrating significant efficiency. Of course, it is possible that they would make a small contribution to better planning and a higher level of rail transport, but I do not think that the effort that the Member States would have to exert to generate these statistics would be comparable to that of the result. That is why I did not agree with the first texts of the regulation. However, after the negotiations on the final text resulted in the current compromise that no additional data would be collected, I decided to support the report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament legislative resolution on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 91/2003 on rail transport statistics concerning the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents.  I agree with Parliament's view that it is necessary to allow EU citizens easy access, under a one-stop shop, to data on the implementation of EU policies. The proposed Regulation on railway transport statistics allows all user groups to have easily accessible data and reliable information on the progress of European policies in the rail sector, including statistics on barriers-free stations accessible to persons with reduced mobility and disabilities, and on the use of cross-border rail infrastructure

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This was a second reading and no vote was required. The UK has a derogation (exemption) in regards to inland waterways, because there is no international or transit inland waterways transport, only national transport. If, however, the UK was not exempt, UKIP would vote against this legislation because it is allowing the Commission to utilise delegated powers.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report completes and improves statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways, in the field of the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. That is why I have not opposed your parliamentary approval.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement with the Council which will ensure that data collected by the European Railway Agency (ERA) or DG MOVE can be used for statistical purposes and are easily accessible to the public.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal navigation network. The text also redefines the nature and scope of the Commission's delegated acts in this area. This report is of little interest, but it is mandatory to go before Parliament. That the Commission has statistical tools in terms of navigation is not a problem. Delegated acts are more problematic, but in this case they are limited in scope and duration. Since this concerns a regulatory power of the Commission against which FN MEPs are opposed in principle, they cannot vote in favour of this secondary report. But, as far as a second reading without a rejection amendment, this report was adopted without a vote.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was approved without a vote.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report as recommended by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 At first reading, Parliament extended the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the carriage of goods by inland waterway to include passenger transport. In Parliament's view, a successful policy to strengthen inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering the transport of both goods and passengers. Extending the scope of the regulation currently in force would be subject to the same conditions for inland waterway transport as the maritime, air and road transport sectors where statistics are collected covering both goods and passengers. In addition, Parliament has limited and better defined the powers conferred on the Commission.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote: that the Commission has statistical tools in terms of navigation is not a problem, except that it amounts to giving more power to the bureaucrats in Brussels, to the detriment of our sovereignty.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which should extend the scope of inland waterway transport statistics to the transport of passengers, not just goods, and to determine and frame the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts in this area. Like my colleagues in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I believe that in order for our policy to strengthen the role of inland navigation in the transport sector to be effective, it must be based on reliable statistics for the transport of goods and passengers.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has repeatedly stressed that the success of a policy aimed at enhancing the role of inland waterway transport in the transport sector must be based on the use of reliable statistics, including both goods and passenger transport. My support for the Eickhout report on statistics on inland waterway freight transport is based on this conviction. The proposed amendments to the regulation place inland waterway transport on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors as regards data collection. According to the approved provisions, the Commission will first have to develop a methodology for compiling statistics on inland waterway passenger transport, then launch pilot studies to verify the feasibility of the new data collections and submit them to Parliament and the Council. The text also provides for a limitation of the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts, reserving them only to adapt the Regulation to changes in coding and nomenclature at international level and to increase thresholds.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation is designed to improve the collection of data on the transport of goods in the inland waters of the Union as a whole. I also voted for it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. Another achievement to evaluate, measure and build the knowledge necessary to make a true system of intelligent intermodality for the movement of people and goods possible. The success of the policy of promoting the role of inland navigation within the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering both freight and passenger transport. Inland waterway transport should be for this purpose on an equal footing with maritime, air and road transport, sectors in which statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. This is pursued by this report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the statistics of domestic waterway freight transport should enable the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal shipping network. The report also redefines the nature and scope of the Commission's delegated acts in this area. It is a report with little interest; having statistical tools on navigation by the Commission is not a concern, but delegated acts are more problematic because this is a regulatory power against which I am opposed in principle. So I decided to abstain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure being voted on is well thought out and does not present any obvious critical issues, so I wanted to vote in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution, by which Parliament approves the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways, as regards the allocation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. This adapts the new provisions in the Lisbon Treaty while developing a new methodology for producing statistics on the transport of inland waterway passengers and limiting the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation on the Council position with a view to the adoption of a regulation on the provisions concerning statistics on the carriage of goods by inland waterway.  During its deliberations with the Council, the European Parliament extended the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the carriage of goods by inland waterway to include passenger transport. In Parliament's view, a successful policy to strengthen inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering the transport of both goods and passengers. Extending the scope of the regulation currently in force would be subject to the same conditions for inland waterway transport as the maritime, air and road transport sectors where statistics are collected covering both goods and passengers. The European Parliament also agreed that, as regards delegated and implementing powers conferred on the Commission, the provisions of the Regulation should be brought into line with the provisions of the Treaty. However, Parliament has limited and better defined the powers conferred on the Commission.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Inland waterway transport has a significant role to play in remediation of railways and roads in several countries, reducing the number of accidents and transporting environmentally friendly goods. The policy to strengthen this role should be based on objective, comparable and reliable statistical data. The current statistics on inland water transport are insufficient to provide guidance and to allow an assessment of EU policy in this sector. At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation to include, in addition to freight transport, passenger transport. This has made inland waterway transport on an equal footing with maritime shipping, the air and road transport sectors, for which data are also collected for freight and passenger transport. This could significantly increase the safety and efficiency of inland water transport. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the regulation.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report on statistics on the transport of goods on inland waterways.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If I do not mind that the Commission has statistical elements, I am more reserved about the value of the Commission's delegated acts in this area, since I believe that the Member States are in the best position to deal with inland waterways. There was no final vote on this text because it was a second reading.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At first reading, Parliament extended the scope of the regulation on statistics on inland waterway freight transport to passenger transport. The extension of the scope of the current regulation would have placed inland waterway transport on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, where statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. Parliament and the Council agreed to consider inland waterway passenger transport within the framework of the regulation and set out the first steps towards integrating passenger transport data statistics. The Commission will have to develop a methodology for compiling statistics on inland waterway passenger transport and will have to launch optional pilot studies to verify the feasibility of the new data collections. The financing of these pilot projects should be supported by the EU budget. Parliament and the Council agreed to limit the Commission's powers to the adoption of delegated acts adopted only to adapt the Regulation to changes in coding and nomenclature at international level. The European Parliament approved the Council's position at first reading without amendment.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report gives the European Commission the power to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal navigation network. We see no problem with the European Union leaving statistical navigational tools to carry out studies on the efficiency of river transport systems in the Member States. Nevertheless, this report redefines the nature and scope of the acts delegated to the Commission, that is, the powers that result from explicit authorisation from the legislation adopted by Parliament and the Council. Although their scope remains limited, these delegated acts give the Commission the opportunity to add new rules or amend certain aspects of a legislative act. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I believe that the success of a policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport in the transport sector must be based on reliable statistics covering both goods and passenger transport.  The extension of the scope of the current regulation puts inland waterways on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, where statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. The Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a methodology for compiling statistics on inland waterway passenger transport and will launch optional pilot studies to verify the feasibility of the new data collections. The financing of these pilot projects should be supported by the EU budget. Parliament and the Council agreed to limit the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts. These acts should only be adopted in order to adapt the Regulation to changes in coding and nomenclature at international level and to increase the thresholds. The duration of the delegation has therefore been limited to five years.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. An existing directive lays down conditions and technical requirements for issuing navigation certificates for inland waterway vessels valid on all Community inland waterways, including the Rhine. The collection of statistical data is important in creating a sound basis for future decisions regarding the inland waterway transport sector. The data are needed to assess passenger vessel traffic – which has increased over the last few years, in particular on the Danube – as well as the technical improvements to vessels leading to ‘cleaner ships’. The rapporteur proposed to take this opportunity to extend the regulation’s scope to include additional variables on the transport of passengers, the modernisation of the fleet and inland waterway infrastructure. There was general agreement that it was important for the sector not to be overburdened by the increased data to be provided, and that there should be an assessment of data collected within other frameworks in order to avoid duplication. The first reading was in March 2014, and ongoing negotiations were pursued  through trilogues until July this year.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a second reading and no vote was required. The UK has a derogation (exemption) in regards to inland waterways, because there is no international or transit inland waterways transport, only national transport. If, however, the UK was not exempt, UKIP would vote against this legislation because it is allowing the Commission to utilise delegated powers.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a first-reading agreement with the Council of Ministers following an agreement to consider the transport of passengers by inland waterway within the scope of the regulation and to integrate statistics on passenger transport into the regulation. The Commission, in cooperation with Member States, will develop a methodology for compiling statistics on passenger transport by inland waterway. It will also launch voluntary pilot studies to test the feasibility of the new data collection systems. And finally, it will submit the results of those studies to Parliament and the Council and consider whether to propose a revision of the regulation. I agree that the financing of the pilot projects should be supported by the EU budget.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation concerns the production of statistics on freight transport via inland waterways. Parliament and the Council agreed that inland passenger transport should be dealt with within this regulation and therefore defined the first steps to supplement passenger transport statistics. I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We believe that a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport within the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering both freight and passenger transport. Broadening the scope of the existing regulation would place inland waterway transport in a position on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, for which statistical data on both goods and passengers are collected.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe it is heading in the right direction. It is indeed necessary to bring into line the powers and competences conferred on the Commission, which has undertaken to examine legislative acts that have not been adapted to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny before the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. I believe that the Commission should be given the power to adopt delegated acts in order to adjust the threshold for statistical coverage of inland waterway transport and to adapt existing definitions and adopt additional definitions, as well as in order to adapt the scope of observation of data collection and the content of the annexes.  I also believe it is essential to give the Commission implementing powers in order to guarantee uniform conditions concerning the provisions for the transmission of data to the Commission itself, and in order to develop and publish methodological requirements and criteria to guarantee the quality of the data obtained.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 on statistics on goods transport by inland waterway as regards the conferral of delegated and implementing powers on the Commission for the adoption of certain measures, and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The role of the inland waterway transport sector should be strengthened and, to this end, the European Union and the Member States need reliable statistics to develop appropriate specific policies. I am accompanying the intention to extend the scope of this Regulation to passenger transport. This sector will therefore be on an equal footing with road, air and sea transport, where statistical data are already collected for both goods and passengers. I believe that the joint development of methodologies between the EU and the Member States for the collection of statistical data is positive, as well as voluntary pilot studies attesting to the effectiveness of these methodologies. The implementation of these studies, which are part of cross-border transport, pursues an important objective of diversifying statistical instruments. After the results of the studies-pilot, I believe that the debate should be resumed, in line with what is proposed. At the political level, I would remind you that this regulation is one of the first legislative acts under the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation. It includes, in my view, a number of acts that should serve to assess the opportunity of this Agreement in the future. For the above, I support this draft resolution.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because the inclusion of passenger transport statistics in the regulation on inland waterway freight statistics will lead to a more reliable overall collection of data which will contribute to the objective of enhancing the role of inland waterway transport in the transport sector. Parliament and the Council have drawn up a programme for the integration of passenger statistics into the regulation to be implemented through the definition by the Commission, in consultation with the Member States, of a methodology for data collection and, secondly, with the launching of pilot studies by the Commission to verify the new data collection. Finally, the Commission will present the results of the studies to Parliament and the Council will consider the possibility of a proposal for a revision of the regulation. In addition, Parliament and the Council agreed to limit the adoption of delegated acts by the Commission to the adaptation of the Regulation to changes in coding and nomenclature at international level and to increase the thresholds. The duration of the delegation will be limited to five years.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report completes and improves statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways, in the field of data collection on goods, passengers and accidents. That is why I have not opposed your parliamentary approval.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The success of a policy to strengthen the role of inland waterways in the transport sector must be based on reliable statistics covering both goods and passenger transport. The extension of the scope of the current regulation puts inland waterways on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, where statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. The proposal to bring Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 into line with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEI) as regards delegated powers and implementing powers conferred on the Commission would allow the adjustment of the statistical coverage threshold for inland waterway transport and would ensure uniform conditions concerning data transmission provisions.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour when it comes to producing statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways. The aim of the proposal is to align the comitology provisions of Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 with delegated and implementing acts. In my opinion, it is important to try to bring the legislation into line with both delegated and implementing acts. I welcome the fact that, as agreed between the Bodies of the European Union, the carrying out of pilot studies (carried out to assess the feasibility and cost of carrying out such a study) will be voluntary. I am convinced that such a solution is beneficial for the EU transport economy, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this recommendation as goods and passenger data would strengthen the statistical coverage of inland waterways transport, with a view to ensuring uniform conditions on the arrangements for transmitting data to Eurostat.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways. The transport of passengers by inland waterways is still too little developed. In order to develop strategies to increase this activity, we need reliable statistics. It is therefore essential to integrate passenger transport into the scope of the inland waterway freight statistics regulation. In order for this integration to take place in a fair and optimal manner, it is important that the creation of a statistical methodology on passenger transport is gradual and that the powers delegated to the Commission are strictly supervised.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on objective, comparable and reliable statistical data. Current statistics on inland water transport are insufficient to provide guidance and to allow an assessment of EU policy in this sector. At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation to include freight transport as well as passenger transport. This has made inland waterway transport on an equal footing with maritime shipping, the air and road transport sectors, for which data are also collected for freight and passenger transport. Parliament and the Council also agreed to regulate the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts, the argument of which has been defined for 5 years.  I am pleased that this regulation has been adopted after more years of work, and I believe that the use of the statistical data collected will help to significantly increase the safety and efficiency of inland water water transport. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the regulation.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal navigation network. The report also redefines the nature and scope of the Commission's delegated acts in this area. This report is of little interest, but its approval by Parliament is mandatory. That the Commission has statistical tools in terms of navigation is not a problem. Delegated acts, however, are problematic, although in this case they remain limited in scope in terms of their duration and effect. However, I abstained, being opposed to the Commission's regulatory power in general.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the Recommendation. We are opposed to the surrender of additional powers once again to the Commission, which has so far shown no particular competence.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – The policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on objective, comparable and reliable statistical data. Current statistics on inland water transport are insufficient to provide guidance and to allow an assessment of EU policy in this sector. At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation to include freight transport as well as passenger transport. This has made inland waterway transport on an equal footing with maritime shipping, the air and road transport sectors, for which data are also collected for freight and passenger transport. Parliament, together with the Council, also agreed to regulate the Commission's competence in adopting delegated acts, the validity of which has been determined over a period of five years. I am pleased that this regulation has been adopted after years of work, and I believe that the use of the statistical data collected will help to significantly increase the safety and efficiency of inland water water transport. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the regulation.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. Parliament considers that a successful policy to improve the role of inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistical data covering both goods and passengers. Parliament and the Council agreed to consider the transport of passengers by inland waterway under the Regulation.  On the other hand, in a first stage, the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a methodology for compiling statistics on the transport of passengers by inland waterways. In a second stage, the Commission will launch voluntary pilot studies to test the feasibility of new data collections. As a final step, the Commission will present the results of these studies to Parliament and the Council to consider making a proposal for a regulatory review. The financing of pilot projects should be supported by the Union budget.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has extended the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway to passenger transport, considering that a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics including both freight transport and passenger transport.  As a first stage, the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a methodology for compiling statistics on inland waterway passenger transport.  In a second phase, the Commission will launch voluntary pilot studies to test the feasibility of the new data collection.  Finally, the Commission will present the results of these studies to Parliament and the Council and consider submitting a proposal for a revision of the Regulation.  I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal navigation network. The issue concerns a regulatory power of the Commission against which FN MEPs are opposed in principle: they cannot vote in favour of this secondary report.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an essentially technical text (although not likely to be isolated from a given political context) on the communication of information on the transport of goods by inland waterways. It is recognised that the exchange of statistical information may be important to ensure the development of this transport route, while the need for the collection and providing of information by operators does not become a burden. This transport route is, in some contexts, strategic, and needs to be promoted. Obtaining and making available (in some cases it may be necessary to centralise) data and statistical information may be important to do so.  However, the development context is part of the EU's transport strategies, which aim at their liberalisation and the imposition of management models to the various realities. Even in a context where the European Commission's tasks have been limited by the European Parliament, concerns arise from the key policy options that inform the EU's approach to these issues.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report, as I am opposed to the surrender of additional powers once again to the Commission, which has so far shown no particular competence.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ By 645 votes to 24, with 3 abstentions, Parliament adopted a legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on statistics on goods transport by inland waterway as regards conferring delegated and implementing powers upon the Commission for the adoption of certain measures on statistical coverage. In order to strengthen the statistical coverage of inland waterway transport, Parliament stated that data collected must deal with both goods and passengers. The agreement reached with the Council took on board the EP position. The Transport Committee fully endorsed the compromise text. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on objective, comparable and reliable statistical data. Current statistics on inland water transport are insufficient to provide guidance and to allow an assessment of EU policy in this sector. At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation to passenger transport, in the case of freight transport. In doing so, it has made inland waterway transport on an equal footing with maritime shipping, the air and road transport sectors, where data are also collected for both freight and passenger transport. Parliament also agreed with the Council to regulate the Commission's competence in adopting delegated acts, the validity of which has been set at 5 years. I am pleased that this regulation has been adopted after years of work, and I believe that the use of the statistical data collected will help to significantly increase the safety and efficiency of inland water water transport. Therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the regulation.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on objective, comparable and reliable statistical data. Current statistics on inland water transport are insufficient to provide guidance and allow an assessment of EU policy in this sector. At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation to include freight transport as well as passenger transport. This has made inland waterway transport on an equal footing with maritime shipping, the air and road transport sectors, for which data are also collected for freight and passenger transport. Parliament and the Council also agreed to regulate the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts, the validity of which has been set at 5 years. I am pleased that this regulation has been adopted after more years of work, and I believe that the use of the statistical data collected will help to significantly increase the safety and efficiency of inland water water transport. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the regulation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Recommendation defining the first steps towards integrating passenger transport statistics into the Regulation. First, the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a methodology for producing statistics on the transport of inland waterway travellers. In a second stage, the Commission will launch pilot studies to assess the feasibility of new data collections. The success of the policy to promote the role of inland navigation within the transport sector must be based on reliable statistics covering both freight and passenger transport.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No I believe that this is a measure along the lines of the completion of the single market. Given the importance of inland waterway transport to the economy of many Member States, it is important to have a uniform statistical methodology and reliable data so that we can then make the right policy choices. Parliament's position of including both freight and passenger data in these collections is to be welcomed and I am pleased that the Council has fully accepted it. It is now up to the Commission to develop a methodology for compiling statistics on inland waterway passenger transport, verifying its feasibility and possibly proposing a proposal for a revision of the regulation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from the vote on the recommendation for the second reading on 'Statistics of freight transport on inland waterways (delegated powers and implementing powers)', as I see the need for such data collection, but I am not convinced that this is accompanied in parallel by measures of debureaucratisation.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on statistics on goods transport by inland waterway. Parliament sought to extend the scope of the regulation to include passenger transport. To test the viability of widening the scope, the Commission has agreed to launch voluntary pilot studies for the collection of relevant passenger data. Pending the results of those studies the Commission will consider whether to amend the regulation to cover passenger services. Parliament has also limited, and given a better definition of, the powers conferred on the Commission by delegated and implementing acts.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation is designed to improve the collection of data on the transport of goods in the inland waters of the Union as a whole. I also voted for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as the agreement defines the first steps towards integration of passenger transport statistics.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on objective, comparable and reliable statistical data. The current statistics on inland water transport are not sufficient to provide guidance and to allow an assessment of EU policy in this sector. At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation to include freight transport as well as passenger transport. This has made inland waterway transport on an equal footing with maritime shipping, the air and road transport sectors, for which data are also collected for freight and passenger transport. Parliament, together with the Council, also agreed to regulate the Commission's competence in adopting delegated acts, the validity of which has been determined over a period of five years. I think it was important that, after years of working together, this regulation was adopted, which, using the statistical data collected, will help to significantly increase the safety and efficiency of inland water water transport.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report at second reading, as did most Members of Parliament, although no official vote was recorded. This regulation aims to amend Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 on statistics of goods transport by inland waterways as regards conferring of delegated and implementing powers upon the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. It is now proposed to: - empower the Commission to adopt delegated acts in order to adapt the threshold for statistical coverage of inland waterways transport, to adapt the definitions and adopt additional definitions, as well as to adopt delegated acts in order to adjust the scope of data collection and the content of the annexes; - confer implementing powers on the Commission with a view to ensuring uniform conditions concerning the arrangements for transmitting data to the Commission (Eurostat), including data interchange standards, and for the dissemination of results by the Commission (Eurostat), and to developing and publishing methodological requirements and criteria designed to ensure the quality of the data produced, in accordance with the examination procedure laid down in Article 5 of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011. Following the first-reading vote, Parliament added a request for new data collection covering passengers, in addition to the data on goods transported, which are already collected under the regulation currently in force.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A successful policy to increase the role of inland navigation within the transport sector should focus on reliable statistics including both goods and passenger transport. This will put inland waterway transport on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, for which statistical data are collected, both for goods and passengers. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending the Regulation on statistics on the transport of goods on inland waterways in relation to the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures, as this accepts the Council's position at first reading.  In my view, the role of inland navigation within the transport sector needs to be strengthened in order to put inland waterway transport on an equal track. In addition, I support the Commission's restriction on the adoption of delegated acts, and therefore support this recommendation for a second reading.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I am not opposed to the collection of statistical tools made available to the Commission for a navigation network. On the other hand, there is no question of supporting a strengthening of the Regulatory Power under the Commission' Control. I abstained.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation because I think that it is important to create statistical standards for high-quality data collection to enhance the role of inland navigation within the transport sector and to help to foster EU’s inland waterway transport. This regulation ensures that high-quality data based on reliable statistics on inland navigation will be available to support EU efforts to create conditions for its optimal development.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Bas Eickhout's report on the transport of goods by inland waterways. By this vote, Parliament and the Council agree to take into account the transport of passengers by domestic sea in the context of the establishment of statistics. This initiative provides an equal impact on inland waterway transport and maritime, air and road transport for which statistical data are already collected. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. – Extending the scope of the Regulation to include inland passenger transport elements is a particularly key development, especially for states such as Greece with a high number of passenger traffic by sea. Policies relating to the internal movement of passengers by sea should be based on a strong background of quantitative data, which has unfortunately so far been lacking. It is of course necessary to examine whether the methodology for collecting the data proposed meets the specific needs.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report extends the collection of statistical data to include goods and passenger transport by inland waterways, which has hitherto been excluded from data collection. Collecting and evaluating data for transport on European inland waterways could indicate the need for action on investments, as well as the potential of these often overlooked transport routes. That is why I am voting in favour of adopting the Council's position.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as the agreement defines the first steps towards integration of passenger transport statistics.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on objective, comparable and reliable statistical data. Current statistics on inland water transport are insufficient to provide guidance and allow an assessment of EU policy in this sector. At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation to include freight transport as well as passenger transport. This has made inland waterway transport on an equal footing with maritime shipping, the air and road transport sectors, for which data are also collected for freight and passenger transport. Parliament and the Council also agreed to regulate the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts, the argument of which has been defined for 5 years.  I am pleased that this regulation has been adopted after years of work, and I believe that the use of the statistical data collected will help to significantly increase the safety and efficiency of inland water water transport. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the regulation.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, since the recommendation is coming at the right time to respond to the new challenges related to increased passenger vessel traffic and the public demand for safer environment-friendly transport.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. With mr Bas Eickhout's proposal, Parliament has called for the scope of the regulation on inland waterway freight statistics to be extended to include passenger transport. Extending the scope of the current regulation would mean bringing inland waterways into an egalitarian state with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, where statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. Parliament and the Council agreed to consider inland waterway passenger transport within the framework of the regulation. I therefore support the adoption of this measure.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I do not support the report on statistics on inland waterway freight transport (delegated powers and enforcement powers). This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal navigation network. It also redefines the nature and scope of the Commission's delegated acts in this area. That the Commission has statistical tools in terms of navigation is not a problem. Delegated acts are more problematic. This is a regulatory power of the Commission to which I am, like all FN Members, opposed.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is an authorisation given to the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight transport across the EU's navigation network. These delegated acts constitute a regulatory power of the Commission, to which Front National deputies are opposed in principle. Therefore, I abstained on this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this regulation which aims to improve the framework governing statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways. The agreement provides that the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a methodology for producing statistics on the transport of inland waterway passengers and, secondly, will launch pilot studies to assess the feasibility of new data collections.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report completes and improves statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways, in the field of the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. That is why I have not opposed your parliamentary approval.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament, the European Parliament adopts the Council's position at first reading on the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway, as regards the allocation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  Thus, from now on, the Commission, in collaboration with the Member States, will draw up statistics on the transport of inland waterway passengers and studies to assess the feasibility of this information, and then submit the results of these studies to Parliament and the Council. We have also agreed to limit the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts, so that the duration of these powers is limited to five years, while reducing the Commission's scope of action in the field of the Regulation.  My vote is favourable because Parliament's position has been respected.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to strengthen the statistical coverage of inland waterway transport, Parliament stated that data collected must deal with both goods and passengers. I support this proposal.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In the case of the commission's delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures, it is sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text allows the Commission to establish statistics in the field of transporting goods by inland waterways, which we do not object to. On the other hand, it redefines the nature and scope of the Commission's delegated acts and, although they remain limited (duration and scope), we oppose the Commission's regulatory power.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The success of the policy of promoting the role of inland navigation within the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering both freight and passenger transport and placing it on an equal footing with maritime, air and road transport. I therefore support the extension of the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway to passenger transport, as well as the development of a methodology for producing statistics on the transport of inland waterway passengers and the launch of pilot studies to assess the feasibility of new data collections.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. I believe that a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on reliable statistics covering both freight and passenger transport. It should be noted that broadening the scope of the existing regulation would place inland waterway transport in a position on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, for which statistical data on both goods and passengers are collected.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a regulation for the statistical recording of freight traffic on inland waterways. As such a survey is already taking place in most other areas of the transport sector, I welcome this position.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report, which supports the Council's position to extend the application of the regulation on statistics on the carriage of goods by inland waterway to include passenger transport. In Parliament's view, a successful policy to strengthen inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering the transport of both goods and passengers. Extending the scope of the regulation currently in force would be subject to the same conditions for inland waterway transport as the maritime, air and road transport sectors where statistics are collected covering both goods and passengers.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission's main objective is to give the Commission new powers (delegated acts and enforcement acts) in the area of statistics on the transport of goods and passengers by inland waterways. It is based on the Lisbon Treaty against which I fought and which the French people refused in a referendum by a majority of almost 55%. Nicolas Sarkozy imposed this new treaty on the French, against the will they had expressed through the ballot box. Nor did I tolerate this trampling of popular sovereignty in 2009, I do not tolerate its effects in 2014, even on a purely statistical and technical subject. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is an authorisation given to the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight transport across the EU's navigation network. These delegated acts concern a regulatory power of the Commission, against which FN MEPs are opposed in principle. Therefore, I abstained on this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the alignment of Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 6 September 2006 on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway, by the new TFEU rules, the implementing powers currently conferred on the Commission by that Regulation should be taken into care, giving the Commission powers to adopt delegated and/or implementing acts.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution, as I support Parliament’s efforts to include inland waterway passenger transport in the regulation on inland waterway goods transport. Parliament is striving to ensure that inland navigation can play a larger part in the transport network and statistical information would help in that endeavour.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. This resolution amends Regulation (EC) 1365/2006 on statistics on inland waterways by extending data from the field of inland navigation, no longer primarily for the transport of goods, but also for passenger transport. In this way, inland waterway transport would be put on an equal footing with maritime, air and road transport, areas in which statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. We believe that full efficiency in the inland shipping sector can only be achieved as long as it is based on reliable statistics for the transport of goods and passengers. We also wanted to limit the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts under the Inter-Institutional Agreement on Better Legislation.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – A successful policy strengthening the position of inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistical data covering both the transport of goods and persons. Updating the current Regulation would put inland waterway transport on an equal footing with air, sea and road transport, where similar statistics are already collected. The statistics will enable the Commission to monitor and further develop the common transport policy. The Commission would have the power to adopt delegated acts in this area for a period of 5 years.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council an amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 on statistics relating to the transport of goods by inland watertight with a view to adopting certain measures with regard to delegated and implementing powers to be conferred on the Commission. At first reading, Parliament adopted the Commission's proposal with significant amendments. As a result, informal tripartit negotiations were first held and then negotiations to reach an early second reading agreement. Finally, the negotiating team of Parliament and the Council reached an agreement on the matter by written procedure on 11 May 2016. The text containing the outcome of the negotiations was approved by the Committee on Transport and Tourism on 24 May 2016, recommending in its report to Parliament that it agree with the Council's position at first reading. I voted as proposed in the report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal navigation network. It also redefines the nature and scope of the Commission's delegated acts in this area. That the Commission has statistical tools in terms of navigation is not a problem. Delegated acts are more problematic but in this case remain limited in their duration and scope. Since they relate to a regulatory power of the Commission to which FN MEPs are opposed in principle, they cannot vote in favour of this secondary report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway to passenger transport.  Parliament also supported the alignment of the Regulation with the provisions of the Treaty (Articles 290 and 291) with regard to the delegated powers and implementing powers conferred on the Commission. However, Parliament has limited and better defined the powers assigned to the Commission. I advocate the integration of statistics on passenger transport data under the Regulation. I would also point out that this Regulation is one of the first legislative acts to implement the provisions on delegated acts, in line with the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation. For the foregoing, this recommendation has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the Member States' internal navigation network. This report has little interest, does nothing to bring anything to the river systems of the Member States, but the passage before Parliament is mandatory. Delegated acts under the text are more problematic, but in this case they remain limited in scope, although they give the Commission regulatory authority. That is why I abstained.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. At first reading, Parliament sought to extend the scope of the regulation to include passenger transport, on the grounds that statistical data in this area could be truly useful only if they covered goods and passenger services. Including both types of services would also put inland waterways on the same footing as other transport modes, for which statistics on goods and passenger services are collected as standard. To test the viability of widening the scope, the Commission has agreed to launch voluntary pilot studies for the collection of relevant passenger data. Pending the results of those studies it will consider whether to amend the regulation to cover passenger services. Parliament has also limited, and given a better definition of, the powers conferred on the Commission by delegated and implementing acts.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the amendment of the Regulation (EC) No. 1365/2006 on the statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways, with regard to the allocation of delegated powers and enforcement powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. The aim is to improve at European level the collection of statistical data on the flow of goods transported by waterways, but also to enable the launch in the voluntary Member States of pilot studies on passenger transport via these same routes.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report, which will develop a methodology for compiling statistics on passenger transport by inland waterway. The Commission will also launch voluntary pilot studies to test the feasibility of the new data collection system. Following the submission of those studies to Parliament and the Council, they will consider them when revising the regulation on statistics on goods transport by inland waterway.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 will encourage the collection of statistics not only on the carriage of goods by inland waterway, but also on the carriage of passengers. The collection of statistics on passenger transport is an important addition, as it will contribute to the study of the development of inland waterway transport and in particular river tourism. Until now, the study of inland waterway transport remains underdeveloped compared to other modes of transport, such as maritime, air and road. Thus, the reliability of river tourism as an economic sector also remains undisclosed. This puts my country Bulgaria in a special situation, which is a major part of pan-European transport corridor No7, which runs through the Rhine-Main – Danube river channel. Bulgaria has a 471 km section of the Danube river, which passes through a number of beautiful Bulgarian cities and provides the opportunity for international trips. However, the lack of statistics on the carriage of passengers in Europe by inland waterways prevents my country from analysing in detail the opportunities that can be derived from the development of river tourism. It is for this reason that I stand by the amendment of this Regulation.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on inland waterway freight statistics because it concludes the procedure for amending the regulation in this area, while extending its application to passenger transport. The obligation to collect data on passenger transport by inland waterway is an important step in strengthening the role of this type of transport in relation to maritime, air and road transport.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. A regulation of the statistical recording of freight traffic on inland waterways is, in my opinion, to be welcomed, as such a survey is already taking place in most areas of transport. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The addition of the Regulation puts inland waterway transport on an equal footing with the maritime, air and rail transport sectors, which provide an opportunity to collect statistics on goods and passengers. The aim is to improve union-wide transparency through reliable statistical data.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted.  I believe that inland navigation can only become a strong and competitive part of the transport sector based on reliable and objective statistics. It is therefore essential to ensure that statistics are collected on both the goods transported and the passengers. It is essential to ensure that a common methodology for the compilation of statistics on the carriage of passengers by inland waterway is applied throughout the EU. The procedures, structure, periodicity and comparability elements applicable to quality reports should therefore be laid down. In order to achieve the objectives set, delegated and implementing powers should be conferred on the Commission, while at the same time defining their scope and duration. Delegated acts should only be adopted in order to adapt the Regulation to changes in coding and nomenclature and nomenclature at international level, as well as limit values.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a second reading and no vote was required. The UK has a derogation (exemption) in regards to inland waterways, because there is no international or transit inland waterways transport, only national transport. If, however, the UK was not exempt, UKIP would vote against this legislation because it is allowing the Commission to utilise delegated powers.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
