text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the Council's position on the adoption of a regulation on statistics on the carriage of goods by inland waterway, I believe that these memorized protocols are aimed at optimising the use of existing information and reducing the administrative burden and benefiting the community. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. –in 2012 Europe abounds in rivers and canals suitable for developing the transport sector. Inland waterways in much of our continent have a strong direct impact on economic activity, but of course we should not neglect their potential in the field of passenger transport either. Any policy of developing an area should be based on reliable statistics, and therefore precise data on this aspect of inland navigation should be available to strengthen passenger transport.  Parliament has therefore decided at first reading to extend the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the transport of goods on inland waterways and on passenger transport, and steps have now been agreed to develop a concrete methodology on data collection and assessment of their enforceability.  In my view, we need to ensure an equal footing for inland transport for the marine, air and road transport sectors for which statistics are collected for both goods and passengers. I support today's proposal and hope that the results of its implementation will ultimately lead to a stronger development of this form of passenger transport.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal navigation network. It also redefines the nature and scope of the Commission's delegated acts in this area. This report has little interest, but it is mandatory to go before Parliament. That the Commission has statistical tools in terms of navigation is not a problem. Delegated acts are more problematic but in this case remain limited in their duration and scope. In these circumstances, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. At first reading, Parliament considered that a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland navigation within the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering the transport of goods and passengers. By extending the scope of the existing Regulation, inland waterway transport would be put on an equal track with the marine, air and road transport sectors.  Parliament and the Council agreed on this and set out the first steps towards including statistics on passenger transport in the Regulation. First, the Commission, in cooperation with Member States, will develop a methodology for collecting statistics on the transport of passengers on inland waterways. In the second step, the Commission will launch voluntary pilot studies to examine the feasibility of new data collection methods and will submit the results of these studies to Parliament and the Council, and will consider submitting proposals for a revision of the Regulation.  Funding for these pilot projects should be supported by funds from the EU budget. Parliament and the Council agreed to limit the Commission's power to adopt delegated acts. Delegated acts should only be adopted to adapt the Regulation to changes in labelling and nomenclature at international level and to increase thresholds. The duration of delegation is limited to five years.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an essentially technical text, for the communication of information on the transport of goods by inland waterway. This transport route is, in some contexts, strategic, and needs to be promoted. Centralising data and statistical information can be important to this end. However, the development context is part of the EU's transport strategies, which aim at their liberalisation and the imposition of management models to the various realities.  Even in a context where the Commission's tasks have been limited by Parliament, it is understood that some caution should be taken.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation on statistics on inland waterway freight transport. Subsequently, Parliament and the Council agreed to consider inland waterway passenger transport within the framework of this regulation. In addition, the two institutions have defined the first steps towards the integration of statistics on passenger transport data. This is a good agreement which reflects the general interest of the inland waterway transport sector. For this reason, I have chosen to vote in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which was intended to validate inter-institutional discussions to update methods for collecting data on goods by inland waterways. In particular, we wanted to advance the idea of including statistics on passengers transported by inland waterways. Agreement has been reached on the modalities (pilot studies).

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The extension of the scope of the current Regulation provides for inland waterway transport to be placed on an equal footing with road, air and sea transport, sectors for which statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. This time, the first steps towards the integration of statistics on passenger transport data under the Regulation were defined through a methodology for compiling statistics, such as the launch of voluntary pilot studies to test the feasibility of the new data collection. I believe that, for a policy aimed at strengthening the role of inland navigation in the transport sector to be successful, it should be based on reliable statistics that include both freight and passenger transport.  I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a second reading and no vote was required. The UK has a derogation (exemption) in regards to inland waterways, because there is no international or transit inland waterways transport, only national transport. If, however, the UK was not exempt, UKIP would vote against this legislation because it is allowing the Commission to utilise delegated powers.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as the European Parliament has extended the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway to passenger transport.  A successful policy to strengthen the role of inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics including both freight and passenger transport.  Extending the scope of the current Regulation would put inland waterway transport on an equal footing with road, air and sea transport, sectors for which statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. As a first stage, the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a methodology for compiling statistics on inland waterway passenger transport.  In a second phase, the Commission will launch voluntary pilot studies to test the feasibility of the new data collection.  Finally, the Commission will present the results of these studies to Parliament and the Council and consider submitting a proposal for a revision of the Regulation.  The financing of these pilot projects should be borne by the EU budget.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Eickhout report on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways, because it will improve the framework governing those statistics, with minimal impact on our country. It adapts the new provisions in the Lisbon Treaty, and includes the development of a methodology that produces statistics on the transport of inland waterway travellers and the implementation of studies to assess the feasibility of these statistics collections.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of amending the regulation on inland waterway freight statistics, which concerns the allocation of delegated powers and enforcement powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. The aim of this amendment is to bring the Treaty Regulation in line with the functioning of the European Union with regard to the allocation of delegated powers and enforcement powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that at first reading Parliament succeeded in extending the scope of the regulation on statistics on the carriage of goods by inland waterway to include passenger transport. In my opinion, a successful policy to strengthen inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering the transport of both goods and passengers. Extending the scope of the regulation currently in force would be subject to the same conditions for inland waterway transport as the maritime, air and road transport sectors where statistics are collected covering both goods and passengers.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway to passenger transport.  The European Parliament considers that a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics including both freight and passenger transport. The extension of the scope of the current Regulation will place inland waterway transport on an equal footing with road, air and sea transport, sectors for which statistical data are collected for both goods and passengers. Parliament and the Council have agreed to consider the carriage of passengers by inland waterway under this Regulation.  Thus, following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading in March 2014 and the decision of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) to open negotiations in October 2014, an informal trilogue was organised in November of the same year and an agreement was subsequently reached through a written procedure. In agreeing with this report, I voted in favour.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation is designed to improve the collection of data on the transport of goods in the inland waters of the Union as a whole. I also voted for it.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the agreement on statistics on freight transport on inland waterways. The Commission's proposal focused on the issue of pilot studies to be carried out voluntarily by the Member States in order to provide data under the Regulation on freight transport on inland waterways. The aim of the studies is to assess the feasibility of these new data collections, the cost of data collection and the quality of statistics.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report completes and improves statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways, in the field of the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. That is why I have not opposed your parliamentary approval.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on statistics on goods transport by inland waterway. Parliament has sought to extend the scope of the regulation to include passenger transport. To test the viability of widening the scope, the Commission has agreed to launch voluntary pilot studies for the collection of relevant passenger data. Pending the results of those studies it will consider whether to amend the regulation to cover passenger services. Parliament has also limited, and given a better definition of, the powers conferred on the Commission by delegated and implementing acts.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the EP and the Council amending Regulation No 1365/2006 on statistics on the carriage of goods by inland waterways as regards the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission with a view to adopting certain measures. A successful policy reinforcing the role of inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering both the carriage of goods and the carriage of passengers. Extending the scope of the current Regulation would put inland waterway transport on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, where statistics on goods and passengers are collected. The Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, shall first develop a methodology for collecting statistics on the carriage of passengers by inland waterways. The Commission will then launch voluntary pilot studies to verify the feasibility of new data collection. Finally, the Commission will present the results on the basis of which the revision of the Regulation will be considered.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to amend Regulation 1365/2006/EC as regards statistics on land waterways and the transport of goods by land. At the first reading of the European Parliament, the idea of monitoring passenger traffic statistics on these routes (in particular on river ferries) was added to the proposal.  The amended Regulation should also collect data on the cleanliness of waterways, ships and cross-border shipping. The European Parliament recommends that the Commission draw up a study on the usefulness of passenger data (for ships and ferries) and on cross-border traffic in general.  The Commission will first develop, in cooperation with the Member States, a methodology for collecting passenger statistics, and will then launch pilot studies on the feasibility of collecting all passenger data.  The final results of the studies will be forwarded by the European Commission to the European Parliament and the Council, which will propose amendments. I think that in this part the Commission has set out a good plan for the further management of statistics and possible future changes, which is why I supported the recommendation.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As well as the development of rail transport, the development of waterways is a way to increase the volume of goods transported while reducing discharges of exhalate. In order to allocate financial resources effectively to modernise existing ones and to set new inland waterways, we need to be aware of the current state of load and volume of goods transported.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation on inland waterway transport statistics as regards the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  Following the first reading, in which the European Parliament reached an extension of the scope of the Regulation on inland waterway transport statistics for passenger transport, Parliament and the Council set out the first steps for the inclusion of statistics on passenger transport in the regulation.  The Commission will thus develop a methodology for data collection and launch pilot studies on the feasibility of new databases.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. We are opposed to the surrender of additional powers once again to the Commission, which has so far shown no particular competence.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on objective, comparable and reliable statistical data. Current statistics on inland water transport are insufficient to provide guidance and to allow an assessment of EU policy in this sector. At first reading, the European Parliament extended the scope of the regulation to include freight transport as well as passenger transport. This has made inland waterway transport on an equal footing with maritime shipping, the air and road transport sectors, for which data are also collected for freight and passenger transport. Parliament also agreed with the Council to regulate the Commission's competence in the adoption of delegated acts, the validity of which was set at 5 years. I am pleased that this regulation has been adopted after years of work, and I believe that the use of the statistical data collected will help to significantly increase the safety and efficiency of inland water water transport. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of the regulation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has previously supported, at first reading, a resolution on the uniform application of technical requirements for inland water vessels within the EU. In this resolution, the European Parliament asked the European Commission to extend the scope of the Regulation on statistics on inland water water transport to passenger transport.  I share the view that a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics, including data on freight and passenger transport. In view of this, an agreement was also reached with the Council, so that the relevant commission fully supported the compromise text. As far as the process is concerned, the first steps for the integration of passenger transport statistics into the Regulation should be defined. To this end, the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a method for collecting statistical data, and the Commission will launch voluntary pilot projects to test the feasibility of new types of data collection. The Commission will then send the results of these projects to Parliament and the Council and will consider submitting a proposal for a revision of the Regulation. Against this background, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation in accordance with the ALDE Integrated Line, as statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway make light of the movement of goods within the EU and statistics are an important basis for action.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament overwhelmingly endorses the proposal for a regulation on statistics on goods transported by inland waterway. This will strengthen the statistical coverage of inland waterway transport, particularly if the data collected deal with both goods and passengers.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of this text. Parliament and the Council have agreed to take into account the transport of passengers by domestic sea as part of the regulation. They outlined the first steps towards integrating passenger transport statistics into the regulations. Firstly, the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a methodology for the establishment of statistics on the transport of passengers by inland waterways. The Commission will then launch pilot studies on a voluntary basis to assess the feasibility of this new data collection. Finally, the Commission will present the results of these studies to Parliament and the Council and will consider formulating a proposal for the revision of the regulation. These pilot projects should be funded from the EU budget. Parliament and the Council have agreed to limit the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts. Delegated acts should only be adopted in order to adapt the regulation to changes in international codes and nomenclature and to increase thresholds. The duration of the delegation was limited to five years.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement reached with the Council and the Commission. The updated regulation aims to align current legislation with the most recent developments and so enables the Commission to take the necessary measures to ease the data collection process in the inland waterway sector, for instance by adapting existing definitions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a report on the statistics on the transport of goods on inland waterways, as this provides the basis for the development of this type of transport. I support a proposal that adapts existing definitions and adjusts the scope of data collection and the content of annexes, and by extending the scope to passenger transport, this type of transport will be on an equal footing with other transport sectors. Negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council agreed that the Commission, in cooperation with Member States, would develop methodologies for collecting statistics on the transport of passengers on inland waterways and launch voluntary pilot studies to test the feasibility of new ways of collecting data. In this way, I believe that the balance between the needs of users and the reduction of the burden increase at national level has been taken into account.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft legislative resolution on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 on statistics on the carriage of goods by inland waterway concerning the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  Parliament has extended the scope of the Regulation on inland waterway transport statistics to passenger transport. Parliament considered that a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics covering the transport of goods and passengers.  Extending the scope of the existing Regulation would equate inland waterway transport with the maritime, air and road transport sectors for which statistics are collected for goods and passengers. Parliament and the Council agreed that inland waterway passenger transport falls within the scope of the Regulation.  Parliament and the Council agreed to limit the Commission's powers to adopt delegated acts. Delegated acts should only be adopted to adapt the Regulation to changes in coding and nomenclature at international level and to increase thresholds. The duration of the delegation of power shall be limited to five years.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation is designed to improve the collection of data on the transport of goods in the inland waters of the Union as a whole. I also voted for it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report allows the Commission to collect statistical data on river freight across the EU's internal navigation network. It is not a problem for the Commission to collect this information. However, I am opposed to the regulatory authority component of the Commission for Delegated Acts. So I choose abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament and the Council agreed to consider the inclusion of inland watertight passenger transport in the framework of the Regulation. The first steps in integrating passenger transport statistics into the Regulation have been identified. As a first step, the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will develop a method for collecting statistics on inland watertight passenger transport. As a second step, the Commission will launch voluntary pilot projects to test the feasibility of new data collection. Finally, the Commission will send the results of these projects to Parliament and the Council and will consider submitting a proposal for a revision of the Regulation. I supported the report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation is designed to improve the collection of data on the transport of goods in the inland waters of the Union as a whole. I also voted for it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this technical report.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 on statistics of goods transport by inland waterways as regards the conferral of delegated and implementing powers on the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. At first reading Parliament extended the scope of the regulation on statistics on goods transport by inland waterway to include passenger transport. Broadening the scope of the existing regulation would put inland waterway transport on an equal footing with the maritime, air and road transport sectors, for which statistical data are collected both for goods and passengers. Parliament and the Council have agreed to limit the powers of the Commission to adopt delegated acts, which should be adopted only to adapt the regulation to changes in coding and nomenclature at international level and to increase thresholds. I voted in favour because I believe that a successful policy to enhance the role of inland navigation within the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics encompassing both goods and passenger transport.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The objective of the Commission's proposal is to bring Regulation (EC) No 1365/2006 in line with the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union in this area. It underlines the introduction of a new provision for pilot studies which can be launched by the Commission, 36 months after the entry into force of this regulation, voluntary pilot studies which can be carried out by Member States with the aim of determining the feasibility of new data collections, their costs and their statistical quality. So, I voted for it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report completes and improves statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways, in the field of the collection of data on goods, passengers and accidents. That is why I have not opposed your parliamentary approval.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an essentially technical text, for the communication of information on the transport of goods by inland waterway. This transport route is, in some contexts, strategic, and needs to be promoted. Centralising data and statistical information can be important to this end.  However, the development context is part of the EU's transport strategies, which aim at their liberalisation and the imposition of management models to the various realities.  Even in a context where the Commission's tasks have been limited by Parliament, it is understood that some caution should be taken.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. A regulation of the statistical coverage of freight transport on inland waterways is to be welcomed, as such a survey is already taking place in the maritime, air and road transport sectors and a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland waterway transport should be based on reliable statistical data. I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 1365/2006 on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway as regards the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. At first reading, Parliament extended the scope of the Regulation on statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterway to include passenger transport. Parliament considered that a successful policy of strengthening the role of inland navigation in the transport sector should be based on reliable statistics, including both freight and passenger transport. Parliament and the Council agreed to take into account the transport of passengers by inland waterway under the Regulation.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The main problem addressed in interinstitutional discussions was the introduction of pilot studies and their nature. These types of studies have been proposed as a compromise solution, in response to the European Parliament's request to include additional variables on the transport of passengers by inland waterways of the Regulation. Pilot studies are voluntary and shall be carried out by Member States providing data, within the scope of this Regulation, on the availability of statistical data relating to the transport of passengers by inland waterways, including cross-border transport services. The new articles on the possibility/pilot studies, the reports on the implementation and exercise of the powers delegated by the Commission were supported by most political groups. My vote is therefore in favour of this report as I believe that it is an initiative which promotes the transport of goods, and therefore European trade.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that a successful policy to strengthen the role of inland navigation in the transport sector must be based on reliable statistics covering the carriage of goods and passengers.  Extending the scope of the existing Regulation would equate inland waterway transport with the maritime, air and road transport sectors for which statistics are collected for goods and passengers.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because the Customs Union is a great advantage for the European Union and is a necessary instrument for the single market. This is a further step forward, but much still needs to be done. Customs are the doors of our Union. Unfortunately, the impression is that, however, they are not sufficiently controlled. European trade policy is highly controversial. The system of subsidized or even zero-duty duties granted to certain goods from third countries are likely to cause serious damage to the European market if customs are not rigorously controlled and the already very permissive limits are respected. It is my battle a few months ago to make known the precise figures for the quantities, for example, of Moroccan tomatoes that have entered Europe from Spain. It was a numbers war between the Commission, the trade unions, the governments, the producers, yet customs should record everything. It is right to try to unify sanctions in the event of infringements, but before that we need to step up controls and produce certain data.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, when we have left the European Union we want, of course, to be good neighbours and keeping elements of the current Customs Union regime may be a part of that. For example, remaining part of the common regime on things like veterinary checks and anti-counterfeiting measures and so on.  But it must surely be clear even to people who voted ‘remain’ in the UK that it is necessary for us now to opt out of the common external tariff. Any doubt on that score has been removed by the vote in the Wallonian and now the Brussels regional parliaments. If the European Union cannot sign trade deals with the 165 states and territories in the world which will account for some 95% of growth in the 21st century, what is it for?

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the customs union is considered one of the foundations of the European Union and the backbone of the single market, there is currently no integrated approach to sanctions. In the single market we often have the same rules, but when these rules are broken, the penalties applied in the 28 Member States differ significantly. The Court of Justice recently stated that differences in sanctions have an effect equivalent to quantitative restrictions. The aim of this report is therefore to standardise the system of sanctions in this area. I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP opposes the ongoing harmonisation practices by the EU. Furthermore, UKIP supports the right for sovereign nations to have control over sanctions on customs infringements.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it ultimately represents a boost to the internal market through the harmonisation of tariff barriers. The report seeks an improvement in the functioning of sanctions applied, in order to avoid different types of dumping to the European market, with the selection of the importing country according to its sanctions regimes. This, from a technical point of view, is fully justified, however, in a context of the development of ambitious trade agreements, this directive may be a reinforcement for the implementation of trade agreements which run counter to the interests of European workers. That is why I have decided to abstain in this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. The directive in question aims to establish a common legal framework for the 28 members of the European Union to close the disparities between the different legal regimes applied and thus contribute to equal treatment between EU economic operators. The Commission would arrogate here the right to define the nature of the offences, to determine their minor or major character, and to take control and supervision of the application of the regulations by the Member States. I have positioned myself against the situation to the extent that the problems related to the internal market always follow the same logics. Member States have a common regulatory framework (EU) but the application of laws (transposition of directives...) is very disparate between states, depending on the interests of some or the economic and political (in)capabilities of others. Thus, distortions of competition are factually commonplace within the single internal market, whether social, environmental, financial, economic or political in nature. The chimerical implementation of a harmonised and homogeneous single internal market is therefore inevitably shattered by national and geographical realities.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to improve the fight against violations of EU customs legislation. In the EU, although customs legislation has been fully harmonised for almost 45 years, its application and the introduction of sanctions are a matter of national law. It is essential to close the gap between the different European legal regimes through a common platform of rules and to improve the conditions for competition between the economic operators of the Customs Union. Divergent sanctions pose problems for economic operators, creating unequal compliance costs and administrative burdens that make some Member States more "attractive" than others.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the UNION legal framework for customs infringements and related sanctions, because this proposal will bridge the gap between the different legal systems.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of the report is to harmonize national implementations and the different applications of EU customs legislation, which is already harmonised within the framework of the Customs Union. The application of this legislation and the legal imposition of sanctions are still the responsibility of the Member States and appear very disparate. The directive aims to establish a common legal framework for the 28 EU members to close the disparities between the different legal regimes applied and thus contribute to equal treatment between EU economic operators. The Commission would arrogate here the right to define the nature of the offences and their minor or major character, as well as the monitoring and supervision of the application of the regulations by the Member States. Member States have a common regulatory framework, but the application of laws (transposition of directives, etc.) is very disparate between states, depending on the interests of some or the economic and political (in)capacities of others. Distortions of competition are commonplace in the single market, whether social, environmental, financial, economic or political. The chimerical implementation of a harmonised and homogeneous single internal market is being undermined by national and geographical realities. So I voted against this report.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the Customs Union is considered to be one of the cornerstones of the European Union and the backbone of the single market, there is still no equal treatment for customs legislation, as well as enforcement of sanctions. This means that the rules are the same, but where they are violated, the sanctions imposed vary considerably, i.e. the company may lose the status of authorised economic operator in one country for the same infringement and not in another Member State. These differences lead to a lack of trust between administrations and the lack of trust and cooperation between customs authorities in order to manage the customs union well and protect the EU's financial interests. I therefore share the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs that the legal basis for the directive on infringements of Union customs law and sanctions in the legal framework should be Articles 33 and 114 TFEU, which would help to remove obstacles to the free movement of goods or the freedom to provide services or distortions of competition and to improve the system of cooperation between customs authorities.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP opposes the ongoing harmonisation practices by the EU. Furthermore, UKIP supports the right for sovereign nations to have control over sanctions on customs infringements.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The Directive aims to establish a common legal framework for the 28 (27) members of the European Union to eliminate the disparities between the different legal regimes applied and thus contribute to equal treatment between EU economic operators. The Commission would arrogate here the right to define the nature of the offences, to determine their minor or major character, and to take control and supervision of the application of the regulations by the Member States. That is why I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the current state of the European Customs Union, "passing Customs" is more or less expensive, in terms of the risks incurred, depending on the Member States, because the sanctions applied by EU states can range from a simple fine to a prison sentence. In view of the urgent need to harmonize customs sanctions at European level, in particular to avoid the risk of 'dumping' and to ensure that the sanctions imposed are deterrent, effective and proportionate, I have decided to vote in favour of this report to amend the Committee's proposal in this area. In particular, it is proposed to define as best as possible the list of offences, their characterization as major or minor offences, and the applicable criminal or non-criminal penalties depending on the nature and seriousness of the offence. My colleagues felt that this directive should also cover the obligations of Member States to the trading partners of the European Union, as well as to the World Trade Organisation and the World Customs Organisation, with a view to establishing a homogeneous and efficient internal market while facilitating trade and ensuring security.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The customs union and trade policy are two fundamental elements of the European Union, which therefore has exclusive competence in these matters. Although these are key elements of the single market itself, there is currently no integrated approach to both the application of customs legislation and customs sanctions. This phenomenon not only creates disparities when duties are fixed, but also poses a risk to companies operating in the European market. The Kallas report, which I supported today, addresses the issue of the legal framework to be adopted by aiming at the creation of an integrated approach to the application of customs legislation, including the sanctioning dimension. The establishment of common, clear and transparent rules will be a crucial step forward in strengthening the customs union and at the same time ensuring compliance with international rules. The EU Customs Code will facilitate trade and improve compliance with member countries' customs administrative practices.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report which aims to create a legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. I support some of the report's commitments, as they significantly improve the Commission's bad proposal. However, a number of issues remain troubling. Firstly, I do not support full harmonisation, which was the result of the final vote. The ratio sets minimum and maximum penalties and lists possible aggravating and mitigating circumstances. Moreover, the text not only contains an exhaustive list of infringements, but also determines how judges should calculate fines. The effects of this proposal on national criminal systems have not been sufficiently studied.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Kallas, for her work in bringing this report forward. A very important report on the LEGAL framework of the Union, for customs infringements and sanctions. Our single internal market is one of the pillars of the Union and needs to be further strengthened. That is why I voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Final vote postponed, I had planned to vote against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report on the EU legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions sets out the objective of ending the gap between the different legal regimes of the Member States, creating a common platform for rules for the application and imposition of sanctions, in order to avoid unequal compliance costs and administrative burdens that differ between Member States. This will improve a level playing field between the Union's economic operators. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions in the European Union. On 13 December 2013, the European Commission published a proposal for a Directive on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. Although the customs union is considered to be one of the cornerstones of the European Union and the backbone of the single market, there is still no equal treatment for the enforcement of customs legislation, as well as sanctions. This means that the rules are the same, but when they are violated, the sanctions imposed vary greatly. The customs union and trade policy fall within the exclusive competence of the European Union, so only the EU can develop a common approach to ensure the implementation of customs legislation. Member States have undertaken to pursue two objectives, in particular: such effective interaction and functioning of customs administrations as if they were a single administration, ensuring controls that produce the same results and support for legitimate business activities, while also ensuring the necessary protection of the Union's financial interests. However, it is quite clear that without an integrated approach to enforcement, including sanctions, it is impossible to make the customs administrations of the Member States act as one, in particular in view of the significant differences in member states' sanction systems as shown in the Project Group on Customs Sanctions report 2010.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report which is a compromise in addressing issues such as various sanctions that pose problems in economic operators, international trade relations, creating unequal compliance costs and administrative burdens that could make some Member States more "attractive".

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. While I am aware that the disparities in sanctions imposed on customs rule-breakers between States lead to disparities in competition, I am nevertheless strongly opposed to the Commission taking the right to monitor and supervise the application of this regulation by the Member States. The solution lies more in the search for cooperation between Member States. Therefore, I voted against the Commission's proposal.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Treaties, the customs union and trade policy are the exclusive competence of the European Union. However, without an integrated approach to the application of the rules, including sanctions, it is not possible for the customs administrations of the Member States to act as a single administration, especially in view of their considerable differences between the sanction systems. This is an important limitation that needs to be overcome by equipping the EU with a customs code that facilitates trade and improves compliance with member countries' customs administrative practices. Sustainability and proportionality must be the founding criteria of the Customs Code. The penalties must be proportionate and therefore cannot be based on the value of the goods, as this could lead to a disproportionate system whereing a minor infringement committed in relation to a high-value commodity could have disastrous consequences for the company. Rather, we need to link the extent of the sanction to the financial consequences of the infringement. Customs authorities should also take into account the costs of litigation, in particular for small and medium-sized enterprises, and, consequently, provide for the possibility of a transaction procedure, which should be defined in such a way as to ensure coherence throughout the European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This directive aims to harmonise the way Member States implement EU customs legislation. To achieve this, this directive sets out a common legal framework for the 28 EU Member States to reduce disparities between different legal regimes; disparities that would distort competition within the single market. On the one hand, the European Commission would, through this directive, arrogate the right to define the nature of the offences, the right to determine their importance and the right to monitor the application of the regulations in each Member State. On the other hand, distortions of competition arising from disparities between national legal regimes are much less harmful than those resulting from the social, environmental and fiscal dumping practised by some Member States within the European Union itself. Dumping helps accelerate deindustrialization in Western countries, resulting in increased unemployment, poverty and social inequality. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this directive providing an integrated approach to the application of customs legislation, including sanctions.  Without a common approach, it is not possible for the customs administrations of the Member States to act as a single administration, especially in view of the considerable differences between the sanction systems of the Member States. These differences create a lack of mutual trust between administrations, while trust and cooperation between customs authorities are essential for the proper management of the customs union and the protection of the EU's financial interests.  The directive aims to harmonise the application of customs legislation, to ensure uniform implementation of the sanctions regime and to allow economic operators to compete on an equal footing in the European Union. The final vote was not taken on this issue because the European Parliament's negotiating team was given a mandate to try to reach agreement at first reading in the trialogue.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the grounds that it amounts to a transfer of justice powers away from Member States and to the Commission. The underlying concern behind this Commission proposal is an assumption that different customs sanctions regimes in the 28 Member States create distortions and, in particular, encourage importers to operate in those Member States with the lowest penalties. This concern is shared by some WTO members, who claim there can be no customs union without a unified sanctions system. The Council stalled the proposal which was presented by the Commission two years ago.  The Committee on the Internal Market amended the Commission proposal on several points, the key one being that the Commission proposal tried to harmonise both administrative and criminal sanctions, while Parliament only proposes administrative sanctions and leaves criminal sanctions subject to national legislation. However, the text also determines how judges should calculate the fines, leaving no judicial discretion. The effects of this proposal on national criminal systems are not sufficiently investigated, but are likely to be significant. As I believe justice powers must remain as a competence of the Member States, I voted against the overall report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP opposes the ongoing harmonisation practices by the EU. Furthermore, UKIP supports the right for sovereign nations to have control over sanctions on customs infringements.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this proposal is to harmonise the approach to the enforcement of Customs legislation, particularly for infringements sanctions. The European Parliament and the EPP in particular sought to change significantly the initial Commission proposal in terms of its scope, category of infringements and corresponding sanctions. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the Customs Union is considered one of the foundations of the European Union, there is no integrated approach to sanctions. The European Court of Justice recently stated that differences in sanctions have an effect equivalent to quantitative restrictions and a proposal has therefore been prepared by the Commission. Parliament ( myself included) voted by a large majority in favour, but it is known that the file encounters strong resistance in the Council from some Member States.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The customs union and trade policy are the pillars of our European single market. An efficient customs regime requires clear rules, transparency and an integrated approach. I believe that the proposal for a directive on the Union's legal framework for infringements and customs sanctions goes in this direction, aiming precisely at the creation of an integrated approach to the application of customs legislation, including sanctions. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the differences between customs sanctions at national level are essentially considerable restrictions on the integration of the customs system: in a system based on common rules, it is not acceptable for Member States to apply different sanctions. Finally, convergence between sanction systems is necessary not only to enable the EU to comply with external obligations, especially within the framework of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), but also to effectively combat violations of European standards.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that the Member States are committed to working to achieve interaction, as well as to the performance of customs administrations in an effective manner as if they were a single administration, ensuring checks with equal results and supporting business, but also to protecting the Union's financial interests. However, it is clear that without an integrated approach in implementation, it is not possible for the customs administrations of the Member States to act as an entity.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the EU legal framework for customs infringements and related sanctions. This report contains some positive elements for better cooperation between the members of the Union, but also for more effective controls and sanctions. Nevertheless, I do not think that issues arising from full harmonisation and coordination of services have been resolved, while at the same time imposing a specific way of thinking and dealing with violations, which removes possibilities from the Member States. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal for harmonisation on infringements and customs sanctions because it was unacceptable to see a common customs policy not accompanied by the application of the same penalties. A Community approach is thus being achieved which will eliminate disparities which could jeopardize the smooth functioning of the internal market. Furthermore, this will also allow greater certainty for our companies: considering today's world where foreign trade is an essential element of success, knowing in depth the sanctions applicable to trade becomes essential. In this regard, I would like to point out that the PPE has waged a real battle to ensure that sanctions are not linked to the value of goods, but are proportionate to the value of the duties evaded. In addition, non-criminal sanctions are provided for in relation to customs infringements, while criminal sanctions are provided for where the nature and seriousness of the circumstance so require. Together with the above, a scale of penalties commensurate with the seriousness of the infringement itself is also being introduced, but a commitment is required on the part of the Member States to make the prepared authorities as competent as possible in deciding at the appropriate time.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision not to vote on the legislative resolution on this matter.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although customs legislation is fully harmonised and is the exclusive competence of the Union, the imposition of penalties for infringements is within the scope of National Law of the Member States, including 28 different sets of legal rules and different administrative traditions, i.e. Member States may impose sanctions which seem appropriate to them for breaches of certain obligations arising from harmonised Union customs legislation. With this new Directive, it is intended to harmonise this implementation framework so that there is an integrated approach to the implementation of customs rules, which, moreover, stems from the external obligations to which the EU is bound under the General Agreement on Tariffs. I support the Kallas Report, which I believe has achieved a balanced approach to the matter, respecting the principle of subsidiarity, by going into a logic of proportionality of sanctions, avoiding the criterion based on the value of goods. This ensures more legal certainty and transparency for operators, reducing the risks of market distortion and ensuring more convergence in member states' sanctioning systems.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the approach adopted in the report to combine the different national rules into a common legal framework. In order to resolve the difficulties encountered in enforcing the uniform customs legislation, a single set of sanctions is needed. In doing so, I attach great importance to ensuring that the Member States do not interfere beyond what is necessary.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amendments that improve the proposal for a directive because I consider the action taken to be important, the main objective of which is to harmonise the approach relating to infringements and customs sanctions so as to give greater regulatory certainty to companies by focusing on penalties proportionate to the duties evaded, thus protecting SMEs more.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it ultimately represents a boost to the internal market through the harmonisation of tariff barriers. The report seeks an improvement in the functioning of sanctions applied, in order to avoid different types of dumping to the European market, with the selection of the importing country according to its sanctions regimes. This, from a technical point of view, is fully justified, however, in a context of the development of ambitious trade agreements, this directive may be a reinforcement for the implementation of trade agreements which run counter to the interests of European workers. That is why I have decided to abstain in this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current disparity between the legal systems of the Member States in the field of customs infringements and penalties not only affects the optimal management of the customs union, but also prevents the creation of fair conditions of competition for economic operators as it affects their access to customs simplifications and facilities. I therefore believe that the establishment of a common legal framework for the treatment of customs infringements and related sanctions would close the gap between different legal regimes through a common regulatory platform and thus contribute to achieving equal treatment between economic operators in the EU, as well as the effective protection of the Union's financial interests and the application of customs legislation.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the EU legal framework directive on customs infringements and sanctions because it contains elements that are contrary to the principles of better regulation. In the context of the imposition of non-criminal sanctions, the aim of the Directive is to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States. In my opinion, the text of the directive does not meet the objective pursued and, moreover, I believe that the implementation of the new rules could result in practical problems and a lack of flexibility in contacts between Member States and trading partners. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the positive improvement noted in the amendments to the proposed Directive on the Union Legal Framework for Customs Infringements and Sanctions, there are still a number of serious problems that are still evident. There is also lack of clarity as to the cases wherein Member States can impose criminal sanctions. These problems pose various difficulties that require the introduction of new systems in the Maltese legal system. For these reasons I voted against the Commission proposal and in favour of referring back the report to Committee.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report, for although it is an improvement on the Commission proposal, it still proposes a harmonised sanctions regime across all 28 Member States of the EU, removing the possibility for national authorities to address infringements on a case by case basis, as the UK is currently free to do. There is a very real risk that the punitive and inflexible regime proposed in this report would damage trade, particularly amongst SMEs. For these reasons I cannot support this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on the EU's legal framework for customs offences and the sanctions that apply to them. It is unacceptable that the sanction of a customs offence in the Union depends on the border where it was committed. Moreover, the existence of different regimes is a hindrance to cooperation between national customs services. It creates potential differences in treatment that undermine mutual trust between Member States. With a common framework governing customs offences, the various customs services of the Member States will operate within the same system, enabling them to cooperate optimally.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The customs union is one of the first guarantees of the European single market, with its common tariff vis-à-vis third countries. Its rules cover all aspects of trade policy, such as preferential trade, health and environmental controls, common agricultural and fisheries policies, and the protection of our economic interests through non-tariff instruments and foreign policy measures. These common rules must be applied by all Member States. However, there are still disparities between Member States regarding customs control procedures, the definition of customs offences, the legal nature of these offences, or the penalties applied, which can range from a simple fine to a prison sentence. These disparities can threaten the interests of Europeans. That is why the harmonisation and simplification of these rules at European level is a step in the right direction.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this directive is to harmonize national implementations and the different applications of EU customs legislation, which is already harmonised within the framework of the Customs Union. The application of this legislation and the legal imposition of sanctions are still the responsibility of the Member States and appear very disparate. These national disparities provide an advantage to those who do not comply with the law in a Member State whose customs sanctions regime is lenient. The European Commission therefore wishes to define the nature of the infringements, determine their minor or major character and, finally, monitor and supervise the application of the regulations by the Member States. However, it is very disparate in different states, given the interests of one or the economic and political capacities of others. Distortions of competition are commonplace within the single internal market, whether social, environmental, financial, economic or political in nature. The chimerical implementation of a harmonised and homogeneous single internal market is being undermined by national and geographical realities. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union legislative framework in the field of customs infringements and penalties because, although the Directive represents a step forward, introducing more flexibility to the original proposal, I am highly sceptical of the approach on which the European Commission has chosen to act.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The divergences between the customs procedures of the Member States obviously exist in order to serve their interests, given the different conditions in force in each country. Economic operators and competitiveness should not be given priority, but the protection of national economies and consumers.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the Customs Union is regarded as one of the foundations of the European Union and the backbone of the single market, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, in particular sanctions. This means that the rules are the same but, when these standards are broken, the penalties applied vary considerably. If the differences between member states' sanctioning systems persist, this may mean that an undertaking may lose the status of authorised economic operator in a given country at the same time as, for the same infringement, another undertaking operating in another Member State will not lose that status.  This report therefore clarifies the scope of the Directive to ensure that only offences committed by negligence or intentionally constitute infringements, thereby removing the element of objective liability which does not require a degree of guilt.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: the chimerical implementation of a harmonised and homogeneous single internal market is being undermined by national and geographical realities.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to establish a common legal framework for the treatment of customs sanctions, with a view to brimsing the differences between the various legal regimes of the Member States, also with the aim of strengthening the common rules on the implementation of customs legislation. Currently, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, in particular sanctions. This means that, although the rules are the same, the penalties imposed as a result of the breach of the rules vary between Member States. Such a situation may mean that an undertaking may lose its status as an authorised economic operator in a given country at the same time as, for the same infringement, another undertaking which operates in another Member State will not lose that status. Our position is inextuly hung by the position we took earlier in the House of the Republic during the process of scrutinising and verifying the principle of subsidiarity by national parliaments. We believe that the proposal violates the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, which is why we voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single Market has immense potential for the European Union for the future. However, the problem is that the rules should be the same for all participants, but penalties for infringements vary greatly. Without an integrated enforcement procedure, including sanctions, it is not possible for Member States' customs administrations to act uniformly, in particular in view of the significant differences between Member States' sanctioning systems. This is increasingly relevant in view of the increase in e-commerce, in particular microenterprises and individuals, which require greater legal certainty as regards the consistency of systems and greater transparency in dealing with infringements by different customs authorities. In order to ensure that sanctions are effective, proportionate and dissuasive, we must leave the door open for the customs authorities to assess the relevant circumstances and, on this basis, decide on the most appropriate sanction, since such a procedure has proven to be an effective means of reducing the incidence of non-compliance.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The divergences between the customs procedures of the Member States obviously exist in order to serve their interests given the different conditions in force in each country. Economic operators and competitiveness should not be given priority, but the protection of national economies and consumers. That is why I am voting against the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and related sanctions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The main objectives of the proposal are to bridge the gap between different legal regimes through a common platform of rules and to enhance the level playing field between economic operators in the Customs Union. To this end, it includes a common list of infringements and establishes a common scale of administrative sanctions. Having divergent sanctions poses problems to economic operators, to international trade relations (pressure from WTO is quoted in the impact assessment), and creates uneven compliance costs and administrative burden that could make some Member States more ‘attractive’ (forum shopping). I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, it has been shown to me that the creation of a harmonised system of sanctions has become unavoidable for effective joint action. In any case, the rapporteur's proposals simplify and harmonise customs procedures, and the simplification and harmonisation of customs procedures can reduce the administrative and cost burden on European businesses, including Hungarian businesses.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report considering that the customs union is one of the foundations of the Union and the backbone of the single market. However, despite its importance, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, including sanctions. This means that the rules are the same, but when those rules are violated, the sanctions applied differ significantly. The customs union and trade policy are the exclusive competences of the Union, so only the Union can develop a common approach to the implementation of customs legislation. Without an integrated approach to implementation, including sanctions, it is not possible for Member States' customs administrations to act as a single entity, particularly in view of the significant differences between the sanctions systems of the various Member States. The Union Customs Code requires Member States to establish effective, proportionate and dissuasive customs sanctions systems. Consequently, the Directive should aim at improving the convergence of Member States' approaches to complying with Union customs legislation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union's legal framework in relation to customs infringements and sanctions, as it rejects the Commission's draft in its current form and calls for unnecessary tightening up.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions, as with the growth of international trade it becomes vital for Union customs legislation to be fully and properly enforced across Member States. It is imperative that Member States do not leave any loopholes, which can make it easier for criminals to avoid adhering to EU customs legislation.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Mrs Kallas' report is a typical example of the inevitably centralising drift of the European Union. The European Union is a customs union: customs rules are EU and set a legal framework for controls and cooperation between national administrations. As this regulation is based on guidelines, and therefore on an obligation of results, its application, like penalties for infringement, is the responsibility of the States (freedom of means). As a result, the definition of such offences and their sanction may vary from state to state depending on legal systems and administrative practices. This would, according to the Commission, create distortions of competition between international trade operators. To remedy this, European definitions are now being proposed, i.e. a harmonisation of criminal and administrative law, which goes far beyond the Commission's prerogatives. Moreover, this is all in order to comply with Article X paragraph 3 of the GATT agreements that require a uniform application by each of the parties to its customs regulations. I cannot vote for illegitimate harmonization under international diktat.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report which aims to create a legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. I support some of the report's commitments, as they significantly improve the Commission's bad proposal. However, a number of issues remain troubling. Firstly, I do not support full harmonisation, which was the result of the final vote. The ratio sets minimum and maximum penalties and lists possible aggravating and mitigating circumstances. Moreover, the text not only contains an exhaustive list of infringements, but also determines how judges should calculate fines. The effects of this proposal on national criminal systems have not been sufficiently studied.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because it is important to clarify the scope of the DIRECTIVE on the EU Legal Framework on customs infringements and related sanctions.  It is important to ensure that only infringements committed by negligence or intentional act constitute infringements, so the definition of negligent conduct plays a key role in this Directive. With regard to sanctions, it is important to have the same sanctions in the 28 states. I believe that there should be no disproportionateity of the penalties applied to the same type of mistake. We must no longer indirectly allow goods to be directed only to certain border points, where sanctions are lower or even non-existent. Through the report's proposals we can ensure that businesses better comply with the European Customs Code and also ensure an increase in fair competition in the internal market.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. With the growth of international trade it becomes vital for Union customs legislation to be fully and properly enforced across Member States. Member States should not leave any loopholes, which can make it easier for criminals to avoid adhering to EU customs legislation.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very happy to support this report on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. The proposal aims to establish a framework for breaches of the Union’s customs legislation and provide for penalties applicable where there are infringements. Despite the fact that customs legislation is fully harmonised, its enforcement and the lawful imposition of sanctions lie within the ambit of Member States' national law. Within the EU, the different enforcement of customs legislation makes the effective management of the Customs Union harder. For economic operators, the differences in the treatment of infringements of Union customs legislation have an impact on the level playing field, thus providing an advantage for those who breach the law in a Member State with lenient legislation for customs sanctions. Unfortunately, Member States have not been very receptive to the Commission proposal. Thankfully, the rapporteur has tried to find a broad compromise on these issues and I was happy that her proposal provides for the imposition of non-criminal sanctions for the customs infringements set out in the draft law, which clarifies the interlink between this proposal and the PIF Directive. In addition, Member States would be entitled to impose criminal sanctions, in accordance with national laws and EU law.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This Directive aims to impose non-criminal penalties for customs offences by approximating the laws of the Member States. It has been suggested that the various sanctions regimes in the 28 Member States are distorting and encouraging importers to operate in the countries with the lowest penalties ("forum shopping"). However, this thesis is not shared by the majority of EU countries, experts/trade representatives. Article 42 of the Union Customs Code , agreed in 2013, already contains provisions on appropriate and dissuasive customs penalties and currently Member States see no added value in introducing a new proposal. It calls for effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions in the event of customs infringements. What these look like is up to the EU states themselves. National sovereignty, in the Commission's view, is the Corpus Delicti. Problems arising from harmonisation are, for example, the lack of flexibility.B. Member States can decide for themselves whether and to what extent fines are to be paid. Cooperation instead of coercion should be in the foreground here. The proposed directive is not suitable for this purpose, as such provisions already exist and because a large number of elements run counter to EU principles of better regulation. I did not vote in favour of this dossier for the reasons set out above.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having divergent sanctions poses problems to economic operators and to international trade relations and creates administrative burdens. This report is a compromise text that aims at addressing these issues. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to refer the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Directive from Parliament and the Council on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions back to the committee responsible, following the position of the ALDE Group and the Rapporteur.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU is once again facing the test of the harsh reality. If the same regulatory framework governs all Member States, the laws apply to them differently, on the understanding that they are of varied economic, political, social, environmental and financial constitution. Thus, the illusory promotion of a single and harmonised internal market stumbles on a heterogeneity of national peculiarities. I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Legal Framework of the Union on the monitoring of customs infringements and sanctions, given that I believe that the single market and customs union, one of the foundations of the European Community, need to continue to be strengthened. An integrated approach to customs enforcement and sanctions needs to be put in place, thus deepening the harmonisation of the administrative and legal practices of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Kaja Kallas' report on customs offences and sanctions. I wanted to support this report, which aims to put in place a harmonised legal framework to end disparities between different economic operators in order to protect the Union's financial interests more effectively. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
