text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report by Ms Kallas as the Customs Union which is considered as one of the foundations of the European Union, and the backbone of the Single Market, still suffers from no integrated approach for the enforcement of customs legislation, including sanctions. This means that the rules are the same but when those rules are infringed, the sanctions applied significantly differ. This report moves in the right directions taking into consideration the requirements of the Union Customs Code, while facilitating and improving compliance and respecting the principle of proportionality.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. With the growth of international trade it becomes vital for Union customs legislation to be fully and properly enforced across Member States. Member States should not leave any loopholes, which can make it easier for criminals to avoid adhering to EU customs legislation.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This Directive aims to impose non-criminal penalties for customs offences by approximating the laws of the Member States. It has been suggested that the various sanctions regimes in the 28 Member States are distorting and encouraging importers to operate in the countries with the lowest penalties ("forum shopping"). However, this thesis is not shared by the majority of EU countries, experts/trade representatives. Article 42 of the Union Customs Code, agreed in 2013, already contains provisions on appropriate and dissuasive customs penalties and currently Member States see no added value in introducing a new proposal. It calls for effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions in the event of customs infringements. What these look like is up to the EU states themselves. National sovereignty, in the Commission's view, is the Corpus Delicti. Problems arising from harmonisation are, for example, the lack of flexibility.B. Member States can decide for themselves whether and to what extent fines are to be paid. Cooperation instead of coercion should be in the foreground here. The proposed directive is not suitable for this purpose, as such provisions already exist and because a large number of elements run counter to EU principles of better regulation. I did not vote in favour of this dossier for the reasons set out above.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I approve the proposal for a directive on the Union legislative framework in the field of customs infringements and penalties. Under domestic law, customs infringements in the 28 Member States are treated in 28 different ways. This leads to revenue losses for Member States and trade distortions. I support the intention to set out in this Directive a list of actions to be considered as infringements of Union customs legislation, because this will ensure the transparency and proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because there is a real need for EU’s legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. This need has been dictated by the fact that there is still no integrated approach for the enforcement of customs legislation, which consequently means that the rules are the same but when those rules are infringed, the applied sanctions significantly differ in Member States. Undoubtedly, these differences create a lack of mutual trust among Member States’ administrations, which is not good for the functioning of the Customs Union and the Single Market. Therefore, the EU should develop a common approach that enforces Customs legislation. Importantly, a proportionate system of sanctions should be in place in order to ensure that customs legislation is fully and correctly enforced. Last but not least, the EU should urge Member States to work towards improvement of the interaction and performance of customs administrations, ensuring controls with equivalent results and protection of the financial interests of the Union.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The measures contained in the proposal aim to harmonise the rules on infringements and customs sanctions. At present, the rules are applied equally across the EU, but there are still no rules to regulate infringements and penalties, creating a state of uncertainty for businesses. Convergence between the sanction systems is therefore considered necessary in order to enable the EU to comply with its external obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). This is the background to the Commission's proposal, which aims to generate a common approach in this direction. During the internal negotiations in Parliament we have seen several debates on the wording of this proposal, but I support the final text put to the vote. Indeed, I believe that in order to ensure that sanctions are effective, proportionate and dissuasive, it is important to leave the customs authorities sufficient leeway to assess the circumstances of the case.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. During the previous mandate, I had been rapporteur of the Regulation on the EU Customs Code, a real framework for regulating the flow of goods in Europe, which we wanted to be both more modern and simpler, and more effective in terms of security. Nevertheless, due to differences in the understanding and implementation of its provisions, which fall under each of the twenty-eight national customs authorities, the effectiveness of this reform that I have carried out could have been marked by numerous inconsistencies within the customs union and uncertainties for businesses. By voting in favour of the Kallas report, we have thus signalled our desire to achieve a better legibility of customs regulations, by clearly defining offences and by introducing a common and fairer scale of sanctions.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the EU's legal framework for customs offences and the sanctions that apply to them. The problems related to the internal market always follow the same logics. Member States have a common regulatory framework (EU) but the application of laws (transposition of directives...) is very disparate between states, depending on the interests of some or the economic and political (in)capabilities of others. Distortions of competition are commonplace within the single internal market, whether social, environmental, financial, economic or political in nature. The chimerical implementation of a harmonised and homogeneous single internal market is being undermined by national and geographical realities.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This directive aims to harmonize national implementations and the applications of EU customs legislation. However, this harmonization does not take into account the social, environmental, financial, economic or political realities of states. So I voted against this legislative proposal.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it ultimately represents a boost to the internal market through the harmonisation of tariff barriers. The report seeks an improvement in the functioning of sanctions applied, in order to avoid different types of dumping to the European market, with the selection of the importing country according to its sanctions regimes. This, from a technical point of view, is fully justified, however, in a context of the development of ambitious trade agreements, this directive may be a reinforcement for the implementation of trade agreements which run counter to the interests of European workers. That is why I have decided to abstain in this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This Directive aims to impose non-criminal penalties for customs offences by approximating the laws of the Member States. It has been suggested that the various sanctions regimes in the 28 Member States are distorting and encouraging importers to operate in the countries with the lowest penalties ("forum shopping"). However, this thesis is not shared by the majority of EU countries, experts/trade representatives. Article 42 of the Union Customs Code, agreed in 2013, already contains provisions on appropriate and dissuasive customs penalties and currently Member States see no added value in introducing a new proposal. It calls for effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions in the event of customs infringements. What these look like is up to the EU states themselves. National sovereignty, in the Commission's view, is the Corpus Delicti. Problems arising from harmonisation are, for example, the lack of flexibility.B. Member States can decide for themselves whether and to what extent fines are to be paid. Cooperation instead of coercion should be in the foreground here. The proposed directive is not suitable for this purpose, as such provisions already exist and because a large number of elements run counter to EU principles of better regulation. I did not vote in favour of this dossier for the reasons set out above.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The proposal tightens the customs procedure and importers will thus be at risk of higher penalties in case of omission and incorrect filling in or submission of forms and handling of goods. I am in favour of free trade and not higher penalties for importing goods.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the fact that customs legislation is fully harmonised, its enforcement and the lawful imposition of sanctions lie within the ambit of Member States' national law. The proposal sets a common legal framework for the treatment of customs infringements and sanctions. It aims to bridge the gap between different legal regimes through a common platform of rules and thus contribute to an equal treatment between economic operators in the EU, as well as the effective protection of the Union's financial interests and law enforcement in the field of customs.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Customs Union and trade policy fall under the exclusive competence of the EU. The persistent differences in customs administration and approach in the application and enforcement of customs legislation in individual Member States cause some mistrust between Member States. In the interests of legal certainty for all data subjects, it is therefore necessary to establish a uniform system for the application of the rules, including in the area of sanctions. A uniform system will help to increase compliance with and respect for the standards in force. I therefore support the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions, which provides for a single mechanism for sanctions in the event of customs infringements.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not support the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the UNION legal framework for customs infringements and related sanctions, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 October 2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. There is now a difference in the treatment of customs offences, resulting in unequal conditions of competition. In view of the very disparate applications of customs sanctions, this text provides for harmonising national and EU legislation by establishing a common legal framework for the 28 Member States. The Commission would then have the discretion to determine the nature of the offences, their minor or major character and, finally, the monitoring and supervision of the application of the regulations by the Member States. Thus, the European Union once again finds itself faced with the problems it creates on its own! It provides for common frameworks, but the application is disparate between Member States, depending on the interests of some or the economic and political (in)capabilities of others. The implementation of a harmonised and homogeneous single market is an illusion that we denounce.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Although the customs union is considered to be one of the foundations of the Union and the backbone of the single market, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, including sanctions. This aspect is particularly relevant in the face of the increase in e-commerce, which requires greater legal certainty and greater transparency in the treatment of infringements by the different customs authorities. That is why we support a common legal framework, which allows customs administrations to interact and function as effectively as if they were a single administration, ensuring checks with equivalent results and support for legitimate business activity, as well as the protection of the Union's financial interests.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council deals with customs infringements and sanctions relating to the legal framework of the European Union. I consider the harmonisation of sanctions at EU level to be critical. I therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the ep's proposed amendments to the Directive on the legal framework for Union customs infringements and sanctions. The EC proposal establishes a common legal framework for the assessment of customs infringements and sanctions, which sets out common rules, thus closing the gaps created by differences in legal regimes. This contributes to the uniform treatment of economic operators in the EU and strengthens the effective protection of the Union's financial interests and enforcement of law in the customs field.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The customs union does not have an integrated approach to the implementation of its customs legislation. This means that the rules are the same, but when there is a violation of these rules, the penalties applied differ considerably. This encourages importers to operate in the Member States with the lowest penalties, thus creating a distortion of the market. To remedy this, the Commission proposed in 2013 a directive on the EU's legal framework governing customs offences and the sanctions that apply to them. The report before us improves the Commission's proposal by distinguishing between administrative and criminal sanctions that remain subject to national legislation. But in the end, the directive largely encroaches on the judiciary. The directive sets minimum and maximum penalties, lists possible aggravating and mitigating circumstances. It also determines how judges will calculate fines, leaving no room for judicial institutions to manoeuvre. For these reasons, I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This directive aims to harmonize national implementations and the applications of EU customs legislation. However, this harmonization does not take into account the social, environmental, financial, economic or political realities of states. So I voted against this legislative proposal.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the Customs Union is regarded as one of the foundations of the European Union and the backbone of the single market, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, in particular sanctions. This means that the rules are the same but, when these standards are broken, the penalties applied vary considerably. Convergence between sanctioning systems is needed in order for the EU to fulfil its external obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the EPP Shadow Rapporteur on this file, I voted in favour of the amendments put forward by the Committee on the Internal Market aimed at improving the text of this proposal, such as by removing the possibility of strict liability customs infringements in line with the presumption of innocence principle.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. If the customs union is the basis of European integration and the internal market, we can only deplore the lack of an integrated approach to the implementation of the legislation in this area. Therefore, if customs legislation is the same everywhere, the penalties for infringement may differ from one Member State to another. It goes without saying that importers will choose the Member State that is most favourable to them, thus creating market distortions. This customs dumping, which is detrimental to the FINANCIAL interests of the EU, is in violation of the spirit of the treaty. That is why I am in favour of the EU Legal Framework Directive on customs offences and the sanctions that apply to them. The main aim is to harmonize sanctions systems and, therefore, to improve the functioning of the internal market.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The customs union is one of the cornerstones of the European Union and the backbone of the single market. Nevertheless, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, including the imposition of sanctions, i.e. although the rules are the same, the penalties applied are significantly different if they are breached. These differences undermine a level playing field between economic operators in the European Union, as they may lead to a company losing its status as an authorised economic entity in one country and another company committing the same infringement in another Member State. The Commission has submitted its proposal to Parliament. The Lithuanian and Swedish Parliaments have tabled a reasoned opinion that the draft legislative act is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. The Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, in consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee, proposes in its report that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal at first reading with 42 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of the directive is to harmonize national implementations and the different applications of EU customs legislation, which is already harmonised within the framework of the Customs Union. The directive therefore aims to establish a common legal framework for the 28 members of the European Union to eliminate the disparities between the different legal regimes applied and thus contribute to equal treatment between the EU's economic operators. The Commission would arrogate here the right to define the nature of the offences, to determine their minor or major character, and to take control and supervision of the application of the regulations by the Member States.  Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although customs legislation is harmonised and integrated within the competence of the European Union, the power to adopt legislative measures with regard to customs sanctions and infringements remains the responsibility of the Member States. I would argue that the appropriate legal basis for the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union legal framework for infringements of customs legislation and its sanctions should be made up of Articles 33 and 114 TFEU.  For the foregoing, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The text was ultimately not put to a vote, the latter having been postponed.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With the growth of international trade it becomes vital for Union customs legislation to be fully and properly enforced across Member States. Member States should not leave any loopholes, which can make it easier for criminals to avoid adhering to EU customs legislation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the proposed directive of the European Parliament and the Council on the EU's legal framework governing customs offences and the sanctions that apply to them. While customs regulations throughout the European Union are already harmonised (EU customs code), the same cannot be said for their application by the 28 Member States. The directive proposes, for example, a common scale of sanctions related to customs offences, while preserving the discretion and sovereignty of states.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growth of trade has made it increasingly necessary to crack down on customs infringements. The European Union enjoys complete harmonisation in the field of customs legislation, but its application, which also includes the imposing of customs sanctions, remains the responsibility of the Member States. We support this report because it aims, among other things, to reconcile the different legal regimes through a platform of common rules and to improve the fairness of the competitive arena between the different economic actors operating. We believe that this text is a good compromise, as it sets out a list of common infringements and establishes a common scale with regard to administrative sanctions. The existence of divergent sanctions is deeply problematic both for the operators themselves and for trade relations in general, since it creates, within the customs union, the possibility of arbitrage in terms of unequal administrative costs between Member States, making some more attractive than others. The aim of the proposed report is to avoid precisely these imbalances.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One of the foundations of the European Union as well as the backbone of the Single Market is the European Customs Union. I am in favour of this report that reiterates the need for an integrated approach with regard to the enforcement of Customs legislation as well as the standardization of applied sanctions when the rules are infringed.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote today the Report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union legal framework on customs infringements and related sanctions.  I believe that ensuring uniform enforcement of penalties for non-compliance with customs legislation is extremely important for all EU operators, but also for the stability and predictability of markets. The discrepancies that arise between the various Member States destabilise the competitive market, offering advantages only to some of the operators. This creates mistrust between Member States' administrations, but also at the level of companies or small entrepreneurs, as to the EU's ability to ensure fair competition.  I therefore support that report which supports the adoption of a directive harmonising the non-criminal penalties applied in the event of infringement of customs legislation.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report presenting the EP-Council agreements at 2nd reading. Due to ep pressure, an objective liability element has been discharged which does not require a degree of fault. However, the Directive should establish a framework to ensure that Member States have a uniform view of a mitigating and aggravating circumstances, from voluntary information on infringements to refusal to cooperate. The provisions on objective liability contradict this approach and, moreover, call into question certain fundamental principles of law, such as the presumption of innocence, since they do not require an element of fault for which a penalty is imposed. It is essential that the Directive approximates non-criminal sanctions, while the regulation of criminal sanctions is left to the Member States.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Customs legislation is already harmonised and falls within the competence of the European Union. Harmonisation of sanctions at European level should be viewed critically, as the implementation of the directives varies from state to state and the economic interests of the various Member States vary greatly. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP opposes the ongoing harmonisation practices by the EU. Furthermore, UKIP supports the right for sovereign nations to have control over sanctions on customs infringements.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal because I fully agree with the disparity in the legal systems of the Member States. This disparity, which concerns infringements and penalties, not only affects the optimum management of the customs union, but also prevents the creation of fair conditions of competition for operators. It should not be underestimated that, as a result of this unequal treatment, there is a lack of transparency as to the type and manner in which sanctions are applied in the different Member States. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it aims to harmonise the approach for the enforcement of Customs legislation, particularly for infringement sanctions. This will help remove the inconsistency within the EU Customs Union and uncertainty for businesses. The EP report provides more flexibility to Member States and their Customs authorities, as following EPP suggestion the report foresees the possibility for the Member States to impose criminal sanctions, in accordance with national laws, instead of non-criminal sanctions provided by the Directive where the nature and gravity  of the infringement so requires.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Union Legal Framework for Customs Infringements and Sanctions is particularly important in this day and age where the increase in e-commerce, in particular microentergies, requires greater legal certainty so as not to be so affected by different customs authorities and administrations. Although customs rules should already be the same everywhere, when faced with violations of these rules, there is a big difference in punishment.  Therefore, it is necessary to identify customs obligations that would give special attention and protection through the establishment of unpunicing sanctions for possible violation of these obligations. Such commitments would be harmonised within the European Union and would reduce the "ravine" between individual national law enforcement and establish a common platform of rules.  This would contribute to an equal and fair attitude towards all economic factors in the European Union and at the same time protect the economic interests of the European Union. I support this proposal because I believe that harmonisation of customs infringements and in particular sanctions for these infringements will contribute to the exercise of fairness and fundamental "freedoms" of the European Union.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Internal market issues always follow the same logics. Member States have a common regulatory framework (EU) but the application of laws (transposition of directives...) is very disparate between states, depending on the interests of some or the economic and political (in)capabilities of others. Distortions of competition are factually commonplace within the single internal market, whether social, environmental, financial, economic or political in nature. The chimerical implementation of a harmonised and homogeneous single internal market is being undermined by national and geographical realities. I therefore speak out against this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Eu ropean Union customs legislation has been fully harmonised for almost 45 years now, but its implementation and application of the relevant sanctions continues to be the responsibility of the Member States. The differences in the legal traditions of the Member States have thus led to a great difference in the way in which infringements are penalised in the various countries and, consequently, to a distortion of competition which penalises some companies more than others, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises. The customs union is one of the EU's most important successes, including from a symbolic point of view. It would, however, be a mistake to regard it as complete, when it is necessary to proceed in the direction of harmonizing the definitions of infringements, the related penalties and cooperation between the customs agencies of the Member States. The aim must be to improve the transparency and clarity of the system by ensuring that all economic operators are subject to the same conditions, as it should be in a genuine single market. I therefore support this resolution and trust that the Council will also be able to follow its political direction and constructive approach.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The purpose of this Directive should be to harmonise non-criminal sanctions in the event of a breach of customs legislation in order to achieve the most appropriate framework for increasing conformity and reducing the number of infringements. While the customs union is considered one of the cornerstones of the European Union and the cornerstone of the single market, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, including sanctions.  This means that the rules are the same, but in the event of a breach of those rules, the sanctions used vary considerably. It is clear that without an integrated approach from the customs administration, member states cannot act as one. Differences create a lack of mutual trust between administrations, which is essential for good governance of the customs union. If differences between sanctioning systems in the Member States persist, one company could lose its status as an authorised economic operator in one country, while another undertaking would not lose it in another Member State for the same infringement.  This is becoming increasingly important given the rise in e-commerce, especially in the case of microenterfies and individuals. We must also prevent the phenomenon of the so-called search for the most favorable jurisdiction. In order to ensure that sanctions are effective, proportionate and dissuasive, it is important to leave it up to the customs authorities to assess the relevant circumstances and decide on the most appropriate sanction based on that assessment. We must abide by the international commitments made under the WTO.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Directive aims to establish a common legal framework for the treatment of customs sanctions with a view to brimsing the differences between the various legal regimes of the Member States, also with the aim of strengthening the common rules on the implementation of customs legislation. Currently, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, in particular sanctions. This means that, although the rules are the same, the penalties imposed as a result of the breach of the rules vary between Member States. Such a situation may mean that an undertaking may lose its status as an authorised economic operator in a given country at the same time as, for the same infringement, another undertaking which operates in another Member State will not lose that status. The report follows the Commission's position, which violates the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. Moreover, in the field of criminal law, there is an explicit interference in the sovereignty of the Portuguese, enshrined in the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic. By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the customs union is considered to be one of the foundations of the European Union, as well as a pillar of the single market, there is still no integrated approach to the application of customs legislation with regard to sanctions. This means that the rules are the same but that, in the event of a breach, the penalties applied differ significantly. The customs union and trade policy are the exclusive competence of the European Union, which is why only the EU can develop a common approach that guarantees the application of customs legislation. This report clarifies the scope of the directive with a view to ensuring that only infringements committed through negligence or intentionally are considered criminal offences, thereby eliminating the twisted mechanism of objective liability, which does not provide for any element of guilt. Therefore, infringements committed intentionally may be criminally penalised above a specific threshold in order to allow Member States to take measures that are sufficiently dissuasive to punish fraudulent behaviour. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to include the proposal for a directive in the context of the agreement on trade facilitation. I voted in favour of approving this proposal for a directive.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade, I welcome the fact that we have been able to participate on customs issues, usually reserved for the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. This approach has been effective and complementary. I voted for this report because it is indeed important to take into account the place of the internal market in a global context. Because our partners have already pointed out the inconsistencies in our internal market. We can learn from it. We are going to put in place a major anti-offence strategy that gives a direction, a course for the economic world of the European Union. This type of initiative is useful in bringing coherence not only to the internal market, but also to our foreign trade. Because our customs do a great job but must be able to count on flexibility and rigour that is not uniform in Europe. Let us support these kinds of initiatives with the objectives of simplification, harmonisation, justice and firmness, which must be put forward in order to better understand the issues of the European Union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the proposal for a Directive of the European Commission, published on 13 December, the amendment of the Union legal framework on infringements of customs legislation and its sanctions is under discussion. Although the Customs Union is regarded as a major pillar of the single market and one of the foundations of the European Union (EU), there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, in particular sanctions. Since the Customs Union and trade policy are exclusive to the EU, it can only develop a common approach to the application of customs legislation. Differences in sanctions create a lack of mutual trust between administrations and undermine a level playing field for EU economic operators. They have been regarded by the Court as measures having an effect equivalent to fair restrictions.  For the reasons listed above, my vote is in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP opposes the ongoing harmonisation practices by the EU. Furthermore, UKIP supports the right for sovereign nations to have control over sanctions on customs infringements.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I consider it imperative that, in similar cases of infringement of customs rules, the penalties must also be the same. The differences between Member States' sanctioning systems create a lack of mutual trust between administrations, when trust and cooperation between customs authorities is central to the good management of the Customs Union and the protection of the EU's financial interests. In addition, they undermine the level playing field for economic operators in the European Union. In order to ensure that the sanctions are effective, proportionate and dissuasive, it is necessary to leave sufficient scope for the customs authorities to assess the relevant circumstances and, on the basis of them, decide on the most appropriate sanction, as this has proved to be an effective means of reducing cases of non-compliance.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, although the Customs Union is considered one of the foundations of the European Union and the backbone of the single market, there is still no integrated approach to the implementation of customs legislation, in particular sanctions. This means that the rules are the same but, when these standards are broken, the penalties applied vary considerably.  Without an integrated approach, it is not possible for member states' customs administrations to act in unison, in particular in view of the significant differences between member states' sanctioning systems. These differences create a lack of mutual trust between administrations, when trust and cooperation between customs authorities is central to the good management of the Customs Union and the protection of the EU's financial interests. In addition, they undermine the level playing field for economic operators in the European Union. If the differences between member states' sanctioning systems persist, this may mean that an undertaking may lose the status of authorised economic operator in a given country at the same time as, for the same infringement, another undertaking operating in another Member State will not lose that status.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In the Report on the EU Legal Framework for Customs Infringements and Sanctions, the objective of ending the gap between the different legal regimes of each Member State is set, creating a common platform for rules for the application and imposition of sanctions, in order to avoid unequal compliance costs and administrative burdens that differ between Member States. This will improve a level playing field between the Union's economic operators. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of violations of the EU customs law system and the legal framework for sanctions is really complex and it seems that we will not find a compromise between the two parties to the legislative process for some time. At the same time, I hope that the Council and the Commission will listen to the arguments put forward by representatives of EU citizens, in particular with regard to the need to strengthen harmonisation of the customs systems of the Member States and to harmonise the application of sanctions for infringements.  At the same time, I would also like to express my doubts about the appropriateness of Parliament's position, in particular by requiring Member States to obtain the possibility of imposing criminal rather than non-criminal sanctions under national law and EU law, where the nature and gravity of the infringement in question so require, in order to make the sanctions imposed dissuasive, effective and proportionate. I believe that the Commission's proposal providing for a comprehensive graduation of penalties was much more balanced.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. This report provides for the harmonisation of customs sanctions in the European Union. The customs union is one of the pillars of the internal market and one of the oldest integrated policies in the European Union. However, it suffers from a paradox: while the rules are common, their infringement does not lead to the same sanctions according to the Member States. This situation of great disparity therefore leads to more difficult fraud to control as well as customs dumping practices. The result is a shortfall for the European budget. Thus, harmonizing sanctions helps to balance and improve the functioning of the internal market. This report therefore sends a strong signal as to Parliament's position on this issue, at a time when the Council is reluctant. For all these reasons, I supported this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and the Council aimed at creating an integrated legal framework for infringements of customs legislation, and more specifically, with regard to sanctions which, unlike the rules set out in the European Customs Code, vary significantly between the various Member States. It is an exclusive EU competence in trade, which seeks to achieve better performance and greater effectiveness of customs administrations, while ensuring the protection of the Union's financial interests. To that extent, I have naturally been in favour of a proposal whose main objective is to promote convergence between sanctioning systems in the field of customs, so that the EU can also fulfil its external obligations under GATT - General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. At the same time, this report also clarifies the scope of the Directive, in particular in terms of the definition, typification and degree of responsibility of sanctions. This will simplify and standardise the system of sanctions and infringements in the customs field, making it more coherent, effective and credible across member states.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the harmonization of the approach to the application of customs legislation, particularly with regard to penalties for offences. Indeed, despite the existence of the European Union Customs Code which came into force in 2015, the application of the legislation responds to different administrative procedures in the 28 Member States. This leads to inconsistency in the application of EU legislation and ongoing uncertainty for businesses. This new directive is therefore important to consolidate the Customs Union, which is one of the founding and central elements of the European Union.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report which aims to create a legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. I support some of the report's commitments, as they significantly improve the Commission's bad proposal. However, a number of issues remain troubling. Firstly, I do not support full harmonisation, which was the result of the final vote. The ratio sets minimum and maximum penalties and lists possible aggravating and mitigating circumstances. Moreover, the text not only contains an exhaustive list of infringements, but also determines how judges should calculate fines. The effects of this proposal on national criminal systems have not been sufficiently studied.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on customs infringements and sanctions, as it advocates harmonisation of customs rules and sanctions in the 28 Member States. In order to avoid problems of inconsistency within the EU customs union and uncertainty for businesses, the Commission has established a common tiering of sanctions related to infringement.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it ultimately represents a boost to the internal market through the harmonisation of tariff barriers. The report seeks an improvement in the functioning of sanctions applied, in order to avoid different types of dumping to the European market, with the selection of the importing country according to its sanctions regimes. This, from a technical point of view, is fully justified, however, in a context of the development of ambitious trade agreements, this directive may be a reinforcement for the implementation of trade agreements which run counter to the interests of European workers. That is why I have decided to abstain in this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the ‘Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions’, as with the growth of international trade it becomes vital for Union customs legislation to be fully and properly enforced across Member States. Member States should not leave any loopholes, which can make it easier for criminals to avoid adhering to EU customs legislation.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the customs union is considered to be one of the foundations of the European Union and the cornerstone of the single market, there is still no uniform approach to customs enforcement, including sanctions. It is gratifying that customs enforcement rules, including sanctions, are the same within the EU, but I consider it a serious deficiency that there is no uniform approach to enforcing these rules. I regret that these differences distort the conditions for many economic operators in the EU and are also felt in the area of a level playing field that underpins the internal market. I believe that it is essential to correct and resolve the problems arising from the different systems governing customs offences and further sanctions within the European market. Although we have postponed the final vote, I believe that, under the new provisions, we will be able to strengthen not only customs legislation and sanctions, but also to eliminate distortions in the internal market by applying a single set of rules in all EU Member States. I expect member states' customs administrations to act uniformly in cases of customs infringements, thereby achieving the same level of control results and promoting legitimate business activity.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a directive on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions aims to ingucast administrative fees and fines in connection with customs in the EU.  The report seeks maximum harmonisation in this area, as, from the point of view of national customs infringement arrangements and sanctions, they are regulated very differently and thus treated as criminal sanctions or as offences in different Member States.  The proposal for a directive calls for the establishment of a scale of sanctions reflecting the gravity of customs infringements. The general objective of the directive advocated by the report is to ensure the effective enforcement of European Union customs legislation, and the report therefore calls on the Commission to submit a report on aspects of customs legislation at Union level.  The directive aims to strengthen the proper functioning of the internal market, to establish a framework for infringements of customs legislation and to prescribe the imposition of non-criminal sanctions on them by approximation of the provisions laid down by the legal regime and administrative measures of individual Member States. As the report highlights some important points of customs regulation that I welcome, I supported the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This Directive aims to impose non-criminal penalties for customs offences by approximating the laws of the Member States. It has been suggested that the various sanctions regimes in the 28 Member States are distorting and encouraging importers to operate in the countries with the lowest penalties ("forum shopping"). However, this thesis is not shared by the majority of EU countries, experts/trade representatives. Article 42 of the Union Customs Code, agreed in 2013, already contains provisions on appropriate and dissuasive customs penalties and currently Member States see no added value in introducing a new proposal. It calls for effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions in the event of customs infringements. What these look like is up to the EU states themselves. National sovereignty, in the Commission's view, is the Corpus Delicti. Problems arising from harmonisation are, for example, the lack of flexibility.B. Member States can decide for themselves whether and to what extent fines are to be paid. Cooperation instead of coercion should be in the foreground here. The proposed directive is not suitable for this purpose, as such provisions already exist and because a large number of elements run counter to EU principles of better regulation. I did not vote in favour of this dossier for the reasons set out above.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single European Market is based on a common customs policy vis-à-vis third countries. In order to protect it, it is important to have effective and rapidly applicable common rules, including sanction mechanisms for infringements.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the 'Proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the legal framework of the European Union in relation to customs infringements and sanctions'. The proposal for a directive is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity, as the parliaments of Sweden and Lithuania rightly pointed out in their opinion.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union may develop a common approach to the implementation of customs legislation through the interaction and operation of customs administrations in an equally effective manner as if it were a single administration, as customs legislation falls within the competence of the European Union. However, the adoption of legislative measures on customs infringements and sanctions remains the responsibility of the Member States.  Such differences are the cause of mistrust and lack of cooperation between administrations, which consequently undermine a level playing field for all economic operators in the European Union. For example, a company could lose its status as an authorized economic operator in one country, while a company in another state does not lose it for the same offense. Therefore, efforts should be made to transform Member States' approach to the implementation of EUROPEAN Union customs legislation. I support the report on the proposal for a Directive from the European Parliament and the Council on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. In addition to the same rules on the enforcement of customs legislation, we also need the same sanctions, which must be uniform in the event of infringements of the rules.  Despite the great efforts of the Member States to improve cooperation and the effectiveness of customs administrations and to ensure control with equivalent results, we will not make the same progress as we would if we had a comprehensive approach to enforcement, including sanctions. I believe that this directive will make an important contribution to the harmonisation of sanctions in the event of breaches of customs legislation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The divergences between the customs procedures of the Member States obviously exist in order to serve their interests given the different conditions in force in each country. Economic operators and competitiveness should not be given priority, but the protection of national economies and consumers.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU legal framework for customs infringements and customs sanctions, which aims to close the gap between Member States in the implementation of customs legislation, including the imposition of sanctions.  It is regrettable that, despite the fact that the customs union is one of the cornerstones of the EU, violations of the same rules are subject to different levels of sanctions within the Union. Furthermore, as in the report, I consider the lack of trust between public administrations to be a serious problem, which also stems from differences.  In order to create greater legal certainty and fair competition, uniform action by the customs authorities of the Member States is also needed in the area of sanctions, in order to avoid distortions of competition and effectively protect the Union's financial interests.  It is therefore in favour of the introduction of integrated rules envisaged by the report, taking into account the proposals for proportionality with a view to customs union sanctions.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Customs Union is considered to be an essential component of the European Union and the Single Market. However, there is currently no integrated approach to compliance with customs legislation including the application of sanctions, this area varying according to national law. As the regulation of the customs union and customs policy is an exclusive competence of the Union, a unified approach to compliance with customs legislation is needed to ensure a level playing field within its territory. The adoption of such an approach is also in line with the EU's WTO obligations to adopt convergent sanctioning systems.  The Commission's proposal calls on Member States to have efficient, proportionate and dissuasive customs sanctioning systems converged by the application of a modernised customs code and the use of electronic means. These measures would encourage trade and increase compliance, ensure penalties commensurate with circumvented taxes and distinguish between criminal and civil penalties. However, the customs authorities are the only ones in a position to decide on the application of mitigating or aggravating circumstances in the administration of sanctions, which raises the question of mutual trust between Member States. As this issue needs to be settled, I argue that the report should be referred back to the committee responsible for the adjustment.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the Kallas report. Customs union and trade policy are exclusive powers of the European Union. Therefore, only the European Union can develop a common approach to implementing customs legislation. Member States have committed to work towards two objectives in particular: to ensure that customs administrations interact and carry out their tasks as effectively as if they were a single administration, in order to ensure controls with equivalent results, and support for legal economic activities, but also to ensure the necessary protection of the Union's financial interests. However, it is quite clear that without an integrated approach to enforcement, including through sanctions, it is not possible for Member States' customs administrations to act as if they were a single administration, particularly in view of the significant differences in Member States' sanctions systems. These differences create a lack of mutual trust between administrations, while trust and cooperation between customs authorities are essential for the proper administration of the customs union and the protection of the financial interests of the European Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions aims to establish a framework for breaches of the Union’s customs legislation and provide for penalties applicable where there are infringements. Although customs legislation is fully harmonised, its enforcement and the lawful imposition of sanctions lie within the competence of Member States' national law, rendering the effective management of the Customs Union much more difficult to harmonise. For economic operators, the differences in the treatment of infringements of Union customs legislation have an impact on the level playing field, thus providing an advantage for those who breach the law in a Member State with more lenient legislation for customs sanctions. I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that in a true single market, we cannot let companies face different treatments depending on the country where they will be sanctioned. In the single EU market, the law should be the same for everyone.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against breaches of Union customs legislation has become central as trade increases at an important level as international trade grows. In the EU, despite the fact that customs legislation is fully harmonised, its application and the imposition of legal sanctions are a national competence. That is why I welcome this proposal, which aims to bridge the gap between the different legal regimes, through the creation of a common platform of rules and the improvement of a level playing field between economic operators in the Customs Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ This Directive allows for the imposition of sanctions for customs infringements by bringing closer to the provisions contained in the laws, regulations and regulations of the individual Member States of the Union. The same was proposed on the assumption that the different sanctioning regimes for customs infringements in force in 28 different Member States create confusion that allows importers to operate at the mildest penalties. Together with most Member States, experts and representatives of legitimate trade organisations, I disagree with that statement. Since Article 42 of the The Customs Code of the Union of 2013 imposes in an ur terms proportional customs sanctions in the Member States, I see no added value that the Union could provide to Member States or to trade stakeholders itself through this proposal. On the contrary, implementing it could only lead to problems in practice, in particular as regards the lack of flexibility that many Member States use on a daily basis in contact with their trading partners. Following logic, the proposal resulted in the express opposition of 15 of the 28 Member States of the Union in the Council. Although the original proposal was softened and modified by the requirement to seek only harmonisation of the maximum level of sanctions, I voted against it because I am always opposed to such attempts by the Commission, which undermine both elementary principles on which the European Union is founded.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the proposal to return the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions to the Committee.  The customs union is regarded as one of the cornerstones of the European Union and as the backbone of the single market, but we still do not have a coherent approach to the enforcement of customs legislation, including sanctions. This means that the rules are the same, but the sanctions adopted in the event of their infringements vary greatly.  The customs union and trade policy are the exclusive competence of the European Union, so only the EU can develop a common approach for the enforcement of customs legislation. If the differences between the sanctioning systems remained in the Member States, this would ultimately mean that an undertaking in one State could lose its status as an authorised economic operator as a result of the infringement and that another undertaking operating in another Member State would not lose it as a result of the same infringement.  In order to ensure a proportionate system of sanctions, the level of sanctions cannot be based on the value of the goods. Sanctions should be based on the level of evasion charges as they should be linked to the financial consequences of the infringement. The purpose of this Directive should be to harmonise non-criminal sanctions in the event of breaches of customs legislation as the most appropriate framework for improving compliance and reducing the number of infringements.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report which aims to create a legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. I support some of the report's commitments, as they significantly improve the Commission's bad proposal. However, a number of issues remain troubling. Firstly, I do not support full harmonisation, which was the result of the final vote. The ratio sets minimum and maximum penalties and lists possible aggravating and mitigating circumstances. Moreover, the text not only contains an exhaustive list of infringements, but also determines how judges should calculate fines. The effects of this proposal on national criminal systems have not been sufficiently studied.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. This Directive aims to impose non-criminal penalties for customs offences by approximating the laws of the Member States. The European Council considers that the various sanctions regimes in the 28 Member States create distortions and encourage importers to operate in the countries with the lowest penalties ("forum shopping"). However, this thesis is not shared by the majority of EU countries, experts/trade representatives. Article 42 of the EU Customs Code, agreed in 2013, already contains provisions on appropriate and dissuasive customs penalties. It calls for effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions in the event of customs infringements. What these look like is up to the EU states themselves. While the Member States see no added value in introducing a new proposal, the Commission believes that national sovereignty is the Corpus Delicti. I stand alongside the Member States on this issue and I am in favour of greater flexibility. There is a risk of over-regulation and a large number of proposed elements run counter to EU principles of better regulation. For these reasons, I rejected the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is part of the logic of implementing the single market through the harmonisation of customs sanctions to promote better competition in the market. It is clear that these legal differences in customs sanctions are due to the inherent differences between the countries of the European Union. Moreover, distortions of competition are factually commonplace within the single internal market. The chimerical implementation of a harmonised and homogeneous single internal market is being undermined by national and geographical realities. I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The customs union and trade policy are the exclusive competences of the European Union and therefore only the EU can come up with a common approach to the enforcement of customs legislation. Member States have undertaken to pursue two objectives, in particular to ensure that relations between customs authorities and the performance of customs authorities are as effective as if they were a common body, ensuring and supporting legitimate business with equal results and adequately safeguarding the Union's financial interests. It is quite clear, however, that uniform action by the customs authorities of the Member States is not feasible without an integrated approach to enforcement, including sanctions, in particular with regard to the significant differences between member states' sanctioning systems, as highlighted in the 2010 report of the Customs Sanctions Project Group. I supported the report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this report which aims to create a legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. I support some of the report's commitments, as they significantly improve the Commission's bad proposal. However, a number of issues remain troubling. Firstly, I do not support full harmonisation, which was the result of the final vote. The ratio sets minimum and maximum penalties and lists possible aggravating and mitigating circumstances. Moreover, the text not only contains an exhaustive list of infringements, but also determines how judges should calculate fines. The effects of this proposal on national criminal systems have not been sufficiently studied.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the amendments, which will mean that the report will return to the committee and continue with the trilogue.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. The European Commission published a proposal for a Directive on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions on 13 December 2013. Although the Customs Union is considered as one of the foundations of the European Union, and the backbone of the single market, there is still no integrated approach for the enforcement of Customs legislation. This means that the rules are the same but when those rules are infringed, the sanctions applied significantly differ, which creates a lack of mutual trust between administrations and undermines a level playing field for economic operators in the European Union. Should the differences remain, it will eventually mean that a company might lose the AEO status in one country whereas for the same infringement, another company operating in another Member State would not lose it. I voted in favour because I believe that Member States should ensure that persons dealing with customs and trade are actively informed on how to comply and how to maintain compliance with customs legislation.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. At present, customs legislation is common throughout the Union. However, in case of non-compliance, the applicable rules correspond to the 28 different frameworks governing each Member State. In order to establish a common framework for European sanctioning law, this text means taking a further step towards harmonisation in this area. In so far as such harmonisation will mean that foreign trade operators have a greater understanding of the legal consequences of their acts throughout the Customs Union, I voted in the affirmative.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it ultimately represents a boost to the internal market through the harmonisation of tariff barriers. The report seeks an improvement in the functioning of sanctions applied, in order to avoid different types of dumping to the European market, with the selection of the importing country according to its sanctions regimes. This, from a technical point of view, is fully justified, however, in a context of the development of ambitious trade agreements, this directive may be a reinforcement for the implementation of trade agreements which run counter to the interests of European workers. That is why I have decided to abstain in this report.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. 'Although the N-VA is in favour of the principle of a more uniform framework for punishing similar breaches of customs legislation in the EU, the delegation cannot agree with its concrete implementation as required by this report. The N-VA delegation thinks this is a missed opportunity. Many questions and ambiguities remain, for example about the scope of the directive and its legal basis.  The N-VA appreciates the efforts made by the Rapporteur of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) in the European Parliament, including to achieve a minimum system of sanctions. Nevertheless, the N-VA cannot agree with the Commission proposal that forms the basis for the IMCO document. It is therefore obliged to vote against this document.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions, as with the growth of international trade it becomes vital for Union customs legislation to be fully and properly enforced across Member States. Member States should not leave any loopholes, which can make it easier for criminals to avoid adhering to EU customs legislation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Directive was published by the European Commission in January 2013 and aims to establish a common legal framework for the treatment of customs sanctions, with a view to brimsing the differences between the various legal regimes of the Member States, also with the aim of strengthening the common rules with regard to the implementation of customs legislation. Under the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality, we are against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal calls for the standardisation of sanctions systems with regard to the customs system of the Member States. Customs legislation is already harmonised and falls within the competence of the Union. Harmonisation of sanctions at EU level must, however, be viewed critically, because the implementation of the current EU directive by the Member States is very different due to the different economic interests. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament's report on the Union's legal framework on customs infringements and related sanctions. The customs union and trade policy fall solely within the competence of the European Union; therefore, the EU is the only one that can develop a common approach to customs enforcement. Member States have committed themselves to endeavour in particular to achieve two objectives: to ensure the interaction and results of customs administrations as effective as if they were a single administration, to ensure controls with equivalent results and to support legal commercial activities, as well as the necessary protection of the Union's financial interests. However, without an integrated approach to enforcement, which includes the application of sanctions, Member States' customs administrations cannot act in a uniform manner, in particular in view of the major differences between Member States' sanctioning systems highlighted by the report by the 2010 Customs Sanctions Project Group. The European Commission published on 13 December 2013 a proposal for a directive on the Union legal framework on customs infringements and related penalties.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this proposal, which aims to harmonise member states' approach to customs enforcement and sanctions. Given that there is a single customs union in the European Union, I believe that there should also be uniform customs sanctions that are identical for all EU members. I believe that this proposal will lead to more understandable and transparent conditions, especially for the SMEs that form the backbone of the European economy.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: Written. \u2012 The European Commission considers that additional legislation in a subject within the competence of the Union automatically complies with the subsidiarity test. The PVV does not agree with this, nor do the parliaments of Sweden and Lithuania. The PVV therefore voted against.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on the proposal for a directive on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. This Directive is intended to make it possible to impose non-criminal sanctions for breaches of customs law by converging the law of the Member States. The directive was originally proposed in response to the fact that the different regimes of the Member States could cause circumvention, as importers could, in a targeted manner, choose the state that imposes the lowest sanctions as their country of official activity. However, in my opinion, this potential circumvention is already sufficiently treated in the current Customs Code, and I therefore believe that the adoption of further legislation is unnecessary and contrary to efforts to simplify European Union law. That is why I believe that the new directive would not bring any innovative solution and therefore no added value. Moreover, I consider that a number of its elements are contrary to European Union law.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions.  I support the proposal for a directive, which contains measures to unify legal measures in the event of customs infringements of the internal market, because differences between member states' legal systems lead to a lack of transparency on how infringements are sanctioned or not penalised, which jeopardises the functioning of the internal market.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the November 2015 attacks in Paris and March 2016 in Brussels, all European institutions reviewed their security needs in the short to medium term. Draft amending budget No 3 for the financial year 2016 therefore proposes to strengthen the budget for staff security - increasing cybersecurity and the overall security of buildings - for a total of EUR 15.8 million. For the European Parliament, the aim is to create 35 new posts for the recruitment of additional security agents in order to provide armed protection at strategic points in the three places of employment. Although I am aware of the importance of such a sensitive issue as safety, the Decision of the European Parliament, which, after the drivers, would like to internalise these 35 new units as officials, is nevertheless a matter of great concern. In my opinion, the security of the institutions should be guaranteed by the host countries, which benefit considerably from their presence; Moreover, even as a vocational preparation, it would seem more sensible to call on trained personnel or possibly certified security agencies. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this binding motion for a resolution. The motion was to give consent to the Commission proposal. The Commission proposal was to spend an extra EUR 15.8 million on security provisions for EU institutions. Some of the provisions were not objectionable, such as extra CCTV and x-ray machines. However, the only security proposal for the European Parliament was to create posts for 35 EU officials who will be armed and deployed within Parliament. If there is to be external security, it should be through professional private contractors or nation-state security, not through arming EU officials. The proposal would mean the acquisition of 7 new armoured vehicles for the European External Action Service and spending money on securing the private lodgings of EU Commissioners.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While welcoming the partial internalisation of the institutions' security service, I reject the continued condition of these changes on a linear target of cuts and new outsourcings affecting all workers in the European Parliament. I also believe that the discretion with which security measures have been taken in Parliament should be reviewed and I have therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – In principle we support the safety of ordinary employees and workers, in this context the institutions and the Brussels attacks earlier this year. However there were too many questions regarding this file and not enough answers. There was no access to detailed information nor was there any open or participative debate provided to the European Parliament, under the argument that there were ‘security issues’. This was a major concern in the BUDG Committee. Despite several attempts to try to discuss the matter in a more open framework the administration willingly refused to disclose information. The few details disclosed were that the Belgian authorities had been asked, that they informed that security inside the Union institutions was not their competence, nor were they willing or able (legally and financially) to ensure it. The other Member States supported Belgium authorities’ position, and they decided that the institutions should develop their security service. We are not favourable to any armed individuals inside the institutions, or the Institutions themselves militarizing what is effectively a security force that is potentially really only directly accountable to the institutions rather than the public. This is why we voted against.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft amending budget No. 3 for 2016, which refers to the new security needs identified by the EU institutions in the wake of the recent terrorist attacks. It proposes to strengthen the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million in European schools, Parliament, the Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. As far as the European Parliament is concerned, the draft amending budget aims to create an additional 35 permanent posts for the recruitment of security guards. These positions must be exempt from the 5% staff reduction target, as they correspond to a new activity.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Security of the institutions, because it proposes to strengthen the security budget following the latest terrorist attacks.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 3 for 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget of many EU institutions, following the attacks in Paris in November 2015 and Brussels in March 2016, amounting to EUR 15.8 million. 3.5 million euros for the protection of European schools, 200,000 euros for the European Parliament and the recruitment of 35 new security officers to provide armed protection of sensitive points at the three sites of the Parliament, 5 million euros for the security of the buildings and staff of the Commission. Finally, 2.5 million are granted for the European External Action Service, 2.1 for the Court of Auditors, 1.8 for the ECJ... However, the financing of these additional credits is ensured by a redeployment of available credits from the ITER operating line to avoid any overall impact on payments. I abstained on this text, considering that it could eventually lead to an increase in permanent posts even if the terrorist risk were to decrease considerably.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The majority of this amending budget is extra money for CCTV, X-ray machines and security personnel. The total cost of this is EUR 15.8 million. However I am concerned at the security measure proposing to hire 35 armed guards to be deployed within the Parliament. These 35 armed guards will me be from outside professional private contractors or the Belgian security forces but they will be EU officials carrying weapons.
