The cost for this is budgeted at EUR 225 383. This amending budget also proposes spending EUR 1.75 million to acquire seven new armoured vehicles for the European External Action Service. There is also a provision on ‘securing the private lodgings of several EU College members’ - EU Commissioners.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this amending budget because it is necessary, in view of the attacks at the heart of the European institutions in March 2016, to review the security needs of the various institutions.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2016 aims to create 35 additional permanent posts in order to recruit additional security staff in the European Parliament. Recent terror attacks have prompted the Institutions of the European Union to review their security needs and determine whether additional funds are needed as early as 2016. Draft amending budget amendment No 3/2016 proposes an increase in the security budget by a total of EUR 15,8 million. Euro.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text risks leading to the creation of permanent positions by the recruitment of new security guards, a cost that would then be carried over each year, even if the terrorist risk decreases. In addition, it would have been possible to reallocate staff without an increase in the number of staff in the EU institutions. However, considering that this is a redeployment of appropriations between headings without new budgetary impulses, I have decided to abstain.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this budgetary adjustment which proposes to raise the budget for the safety of European schools, the European Parliament, the Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service by a total of EUR 15.8 million.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks that have shocked Europe over the last two years, and in particular the one that struck the Belgian capital on 22 March, have led the EU institutions to re-examine their security needs. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report because I believe it is essential to strengthen the security budget within the institutions in this context. Thanks to the approval of amending budget No 3/2016, additional security measures will be taken and new security agents will be permanently hired.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this draft amending budget, which aims to allocate a departure for the recruitment of 35 new posts of armed security personnel after the attacks received in the European Union. While security is necessary, I think there are other measures to ensure it without having to resort to the militarization of all institutions. As set out in the report, this recruitment process was done without the proper Parliament. In addition to strictly sticking to increased security only by increasing armed personnel to monitor European institutions, regardless of other civil society that is also exposed to these attacks, or infrastructure security. That is why I do not support this report because of its exclusively securitarian approach, and I believe that these dangers must be tackled from a more inclusive approach and that conflicts are prevented and resolved from the outing, and do not result in a militarisation of our environment.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the draft amending budget related to security in institutions. We had to make certain decisions that involved certain changes and I have seen well the proposal that has come to us from the committee of budget. That is why I supported the report as presented and voted against the 3 amendments tabled.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the draft amending budget No. 3 for 2016 and proposes to strengthen the security budget of many EU institutions in the wake of the attacks in Paris and Brussels. The total amount is estimated at 15.8 million euros, ensured by a redeployment of available credits from the ITER operating line. We cannot vote against it, in the name of security, but this text risks leading to the creation of permanent posts by recruiting new security guards, a cost that would then be carried over each year, even if the terrorist risk decreases. However, this report has no budgetary impact, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although there are passages in the text that we can support, the modalities that led to this decision and some choices that I consider questionable, have led me to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution by which Parliament approves the Council's position on draft amending budget No 3/2016, increasing the budget to ensure safety in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service by EUR 15.8 million, in view of the new needs identified after the latest terrorist attacks.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the Council's position on the draft amending budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, which relates specifically to the security of the institutions. This draft amending budget proposes to increase the budget for security in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service by a total of EUR 15.8 million. The aim of the draft amending budget is to create 35 additional permanent posts in order to recruit additional security staff in the European Parliament.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent terrorist attacks in Europe have prompted the EU institutions to review their security needs as early as 2016 and identify their needs for additional resources. The draft amending budget No 3/2016 therefore proposes to increase the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. The Plenary Session of the European Parliament takes note of draft arrera act No 3/2016 in its form submitted by the Commission and approves the Council's position on it. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i strongly supported this draft amending budget, as recent terrorist events have required increased expenditure to ensure the necessary security and are necessary for further efforts to address these security risks. An additional argument is to reduce the number of European Union employees by 5 %, which should not apply to security staff.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Draft Budget Changes Report No. 3/2016 concerning new security needs identified by the EU institutions following the recent terrorist attacks.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I am very much in favour of strengthening the security of the European institutions, the obvious targets of terrorism. However, I think we could have achieved that goal without creating permanent positions. Indeed, if this exercise does not affect the overall budget, the same will not be true for the following years. For all these reasons, I abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on Amending budget No 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016 because it proposes to reinforce the expenditure for security of both European schools and institutions. We are facing hard times after the terrible terrorist attacks that held in Paris and in Brussels and mainly for that reason I think right security provisions have to be taken.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the attacks in France and Belgium, all institutions reviewed their security needs in the short and medium term. The draft budget for 2017 contains additional security-related elements for almost all institutions. In some cases, however, the need to accelerate the strengthening of safety measures and installations requires the allocation of additional resources as early as 2016. Draft amending budget (PBR) No 3 for the financial year 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million. This leads to an increase in non-differentiated expenditure in the 2016 budget for heading 5 (Administration). However, it is proposed to reallocate the necessary payment appropriations to the ITER operational line of heading 1a, in order to avoid consequences for the overall level of payments. If these additional investments can be made in 2016, the budget request for 2017 can be kept at almost the same level. Since the purpose of this PBR is non-differentiated appropriations, this amount must correspond to commitments.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 3/2016 aims to strengthen the security budget in many European institutions to the tune of EUR 15.8 million, following the attacks in Paris in November 2015 and Brussels in March 2016. Of course, the financing of these additional credits is ensured by a redeployment of available credits in order to avoid any overall impact at the level of payments. Nevertheless, this draft amending budget calls for the recruitment of new security guards. The creation of new permanent positions will result in a cost that will have to be borne each year. As such, it would have been preferable to reallocate staff without an increase in staff. However, I abstained on this text, which aims to strengthen security within the European institutions.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Against the background of recent terrorist attacks, new security needs have been identified and additional financial resources have been needed, even during 2016. Draft amending budget No 1 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 May 1999 on 3/2016 therefore provides for the strengthening of the security budget by allocating a total additional EUR 15.8 million to be used for security measures in various European institutions such as the European Commission, the European Economic and Social Committee, the European Court of Auditors. The draft amending budget also provides for the creation of 35 permanent posts to facilitate the recruitment of an additional number of security officers within the European Parliament. I have expressed myself in favour of draft amending budget No. 3/2016 because I consider it crucial to allocate the necessary resources to strengthen the security of the European institutions and to respond to the current challenges.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the recent terrorist attacks have led the EU institutions to review their security needs and identify the need for additional resources as early as 2016. Amending budget No 3/2016 therefore proposes to strengthen the security budget by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million, to be paid for the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. Amending budget No 3/2016 also provides for the creation of 35 additional permanent posts for the recruitment of additional security agents to the European Parliament. These posts, involving a new activity, should be retained in the 2017 budget and should therefore be excluded from the target of a 5 % reduction in staff.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. While of course I support the safety of employees and workers in the institutions given the context of the Brussels attacks earlier this year, I do not believe an increase in armed security in the institutions is an appropriate or effective solution. Further, at the Budget committee level, there was no access to detailed information on this proposal nor was there any open or participative debate about the proposal and its effect.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding motion for a resolution. The motion was to give consent to the Commission proposal. The Commission proposal was to spend an extra EUR 15.8 million on security provisions for EU institutions. Some of the provisions were not objectionable, such as extra CCTV and x-ray machines. However, the only security proposal for the European Parliament was to create posts for 35 EU officials who will be armed and deployed within Parliament. If there is to be external security, it should be through professional private contractors or nation-state security, not through arming EU officials. The proposal would mean the acquisition of 7 new armoured vehicles for the European External Action Service and spending money on securing the private lodgings of EU Commissioners.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this amending budget as I believe in the current security system within the institutions needs to be reinforced. The budget for security of several institutions was reviewed after the aftermath of the Paris and Brussels terrorist attacks of November 2015 and March 2016 respectively.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the November 2015 attacks in Paris and March 2016 in Brussels, the European institutions reviewed their security needs. Draft amending budget No 3 for the financial year 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million. Both cybersecurity and global building security are being increased. The European Parliament is called for the creation of 35 new posts of additional security officers active in the three for a. The impact on the general budget is neutral, as the additional resources come from a transfer of an underused budget line, but the proposal provides for the new security units to be framed as officials of the European institutions. On the other hand, it would be right, and probably even safer, for the security of the institutions to be guaranteed by the host countries - which benefit considerably from their presence - through the use of trained personnel or certified security agencies. I therefore voted against the proposal.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In light of the tragic terrorist attacks that have taken place in the European Union this year and, in particular, the dramatic attack in Brussels on 22 March 2016, which was an attack on the heart of Europe, security has become a priority outside and within the European institutions. The European Union is therefore obliged to review its security needs and to identify the need for additional resources within its structures. That is why I voted in favour of the report which strengthens the security budget within the institutions.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the report, as it is clear that, especially in the wake of the recent terrorist attacks, the Union institutions have had to review their security needs and it is considered that additional resources are needed as early as 2016.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Security of the institutions. It is a fact that this report has a positive basis and aims to improve the security conditions of the Union's institutions. However, as there are specific points which are not clear, while at the same time no detailed reports have been given on issues such as the way in which the security services are selected and the possibilities, I have decided to abstain.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote for this report, which aims to increase the current budget by EUR 15.8 million. While useful security measures stand out among the measures financed, there are many concerns about the decision to make additional recruitments through outsourced contracts.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On a cold January morning, Europe woke up rediscovering after years what fear and horror meant; on a Friday evening in mid-November, she then lived live the bataclan's crazy; finally, at the dawn of spring he witnessed inert the lives cut off in Zaventem. We suddenly noticed a vulnerability beneath the blanket of our culture and civilization. By voting in favour of increasing the appropriations for the security of the institutions, I hope that the prevention of possible terrorist attacks will bring us back to a state of serenity. The need for additional resources is thus essential and, as a result, the strengthening of EUR 15.8 million is inevitable. Of this amount, the largest part will be allocated to the European Schools so that we can guarantee the most serene and healthy environment possible for all those who decide to grow by embracing our cultural heritage. I would also like to take this opportunity to wish the 35 additional new security officers recruited by the European Parliament every success.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Security of the Institutions and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft amending budget provides for an overall strengthening of EUR 15.8 million for security issues in the European institutions. The private share allocated to the European Parliament (around EUR 200,000) is largely earmarked for the hiring of 35 more security officers, which is an exception to the target of reducing staff by 5 %. I welcome the €3.5 million increase in the safety of European schools. However, I believe that strengthening investment in security and increasing the number of staff in this area should pursue a objective of efficiency of means and seek not to undermine the access of European citizens to the institutions.  As far as the European Parliament is concerned, I hope that this strengthening of staff will increase the speed of reception of guests and visitors, improve the accreditation system and ensure the openness and extended access to facilities on the part of citizens. I believe it is essential to ensure the safety of all those who work or visit the European institutions and that the strengthening of the means must safeguard the good working conditions and reception of guests. For the above, I support this report by Colleagues José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as it was necessary to strengthen the security budget of several EU institutions also following the terrorist attacks in Paris in November 2015 and those of March 2016 in Brussels.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – While welcoming the partial internalisation of the institutions' security service, I reject the continued condition of these changes on a linear target of cuts and new outsourcings affecting all workers in the European Parliament. I also believe that the discretion with which security measures have been taken in Parliament should be reviewed and I have therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The attacks struck in the heart of Europe, in Brussels, the European capital with all its institutions. It is therefore necessary to invest more safely in the places of the European institutions in all its premises. I am voting in favour of this text, which emphasises the need for more security staff in all the institutions, and in particular in the European Parliament. The challenge to terrorism must be met in terms of long-term social and cultural integration, no doubt intelligence is the key to its success, but in the short term institutions have a duty to protect employees in their daily lives.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the amending budget of DAB 3/2016 on the security of the EU institutions in the context of the recent terrorist attacks in Europe. In my opinion, the issue of security is undeniably the most important issue, and I therefore believe that the EUR 15.8 million allocated to strengthening institutions, equipment and training to enhance security is appropriate. I voted in favour because there is really no price for ensuring security, especially when there is now a need to strengthen the security measures of the EU institutions.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, since, following the recent terror attacks, I believe that we need to reinforce the security of the institutions including European Schools, the Parliament, the Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Recent terrorist attacks in Europe have prompted the EU institutions to review their security needs and identify their needs for additional resources as early as 2016. The draft amending budget No 3/2016 therefore proposes to increase the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. The Plenary Session of the European Parliament takes note of draft arrera act No 3/2016 in its form submitted by the Commission and approves the Council's position on it. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 3 for 2016 proposes to strengthen the security appropriations of many EU institutions, following the attacks in Paris in November 2015 and Brussels in March 2016, amounting to EUR 15.8 million. These include the protection of European schools, the three sites of the European Parliament (Brussels, Strasbourg, Luxembourg) and the Commission. If we cannot vote against this text, at the risk of being accused of seeking to compromise the security of the European institutions, it risks leading to the creation of permanent posts by the recruitment of new security guards, a cost which would then be carried over every year, even if the terrorist risk decreased. In addition, it would have been possible to reallocate staff without an increase in the number of staff in the EU institutions. However, considering that this is a redeployment of appropriations between headings without new budgetary impulses, it is conceivable to abstain on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In my view, the increase in the security budget of the staff of the European institutions is justified. So far, I personally do not believe that the institutions are well guarded, and if the funds are the cause of this, then let's set aside a little more. Of course, let's use them correctly and track their application. Certain means without control are easily lost. I will also vote for a bigger security budget for every single citizen because we see that today is one of our main challenges. A better solution, however, will always be to eradicate the problem, for which me and my party are fighting very hard.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The achievement of a high level of security at the premises and premises of European agencies is achieved through the excellent cooperation of the security and protection services of the host State and the respective agencies' services and not by the recruitment of additional staff.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – Recent terrorist attacks in Europe have prompted the EU institutions to review their security needs and identify their needs for additional resources as early as 2016. The draft amending budget No 3/2016 therefore proposes to increase the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. The Plenary Session of the European Parliament takes note of draft arrera act No 3/2016 in its form submitted by the Commission and approves the Council's position on it. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The recent terrorist attacks have forced the Union institutions to review their security needs and identify the necessary additional resources as early as 2016.  The present proposal provides for the strengthening of EUR 15.8 million of the security budget for the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service.  This amendment will create an even 35 more permanent posts for the recruitment of new security officers from the European Parliament, posts that should be kept in the 2017 budget and exempt from the target of reducing staff by 5 % as they are intended for new activity.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: considering that this is a redeployment of appropriations between headings without new budgetary impulses, it is possible to abstain on this text.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes to strengthen the budget for the security of the EU institutions. This strengthening aims to improve infrastructure, strengthen IT security, training and staff recruitment. For the European Parliament, on a proposal from the Secretary-General and the Bureau, 35 additional permanent jobs are created for the recruitment of additional security officers, these posts should be maintained in the 2017 budget and exempt from the 5 % staff reduction target, as they correspond to a new activity. The European Commission proposes to offset the increase of EUR 15.8 million in appropriations in Title H5 by a reduction of the same amount as the ITER item. Following the terrorist attacks in Brussels, the competent authorities were invited to propose the internalisation of previously outsourced services. For our part, we always advocate the internalisation of services, right from the outset for reasons related to workers' rights and the prevention of situations of exploitation and precariousness. During the discussion in the Committee on Budgets, our group clarified that it was against any armed individuals within the institutions. In addition, it advocated the internalization of several other services (including, but not many, interpreters, translators, IT engineers).

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to increase the level of security of the European institutions in order to protect first and foremost those who work there, but also their symbolic value. The terrorist attack on Brussels on 22 March in Maalbeek station just metres from the headquarters of the EP, the EU Commission and the Committee of the Regions is proof of how sensitive the institutions are a sensitive target for terrorists.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This particular draft amending budget is a proposal to strengthen the security budget in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice of the European Union, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, and to increase it by a total of EUR 15.8 million. It will also include the creation of 35 additional recruitment posts for security staff in the European Parliament.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the text as I dispute a number of points concerning the increase in the security budget, but I agree with the issue of the safety of children in European schools.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Security of the institutions, as the achievement of a high level of security at the premises and premises of European agencies is ensured by the excellent cooperation between the security and protection services of the host State and the respective agencies' services and not by the recruitment of additional staff.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Draft amending budget N° 3 for the year 2016 refers to new security needs identified by the EU institutions following the recent terror attacks. It proposes to reinforce the budget for security by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the Parliament, the Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. As far as the European Parliament is concerned, the Draft amending budget aims to create 35 additional permanent posts for the recruitment of security agents. These posts should be exempt from the 5% staff reduction target, as they correspond to a new activity. I am in favour of Draft amending budget 3/2016.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent terrorist attacks in Europe have prompted the EU institutions to review their security needs and identify their needs for additional resources as early as 2016. The draft amending budget No 3/2016 therefore proposes to increase the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. In the light of the recent terrorist attacks, I see fit to introduce new security measures and voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent terrorist attacks in Europe have prompted the EU institutions to review their security needs and identify their needs for additional resources as early as 2016. The draft amending budget No 3/2016 therefore proposes to increase the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. The Plenary Session of the European Parliament takes note of draft arrera act No 3/2016 in its form submitted by the Commission and approves the Council's position on it. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, considering that the terrorist attacks have led the UNION institutions to review their security needs and to determine their additional resource needs as far as 2016. The draft amending budget proposes to increase the budget for safety in european schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service by EUR 15.8 million.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of draft amending budget No 3/2016: Security of the institutions, as I see the need to adapt security measures to the increased demands following the Paris and Brussels attacks. At the same time, in the case of the European Parliament, I stress that, in their current situation, I still consider the Brussels buildings to be completely unsuitable to meet the necessary security aspects. I call for a complete move by the European Parliament to the much safer and better-located Strasbourg.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Due to the increased risk of terrorist attacks against European Union institutions, amending budget No 3/2016 will be increased by a total of EUR 15.8 million. The security measures financed from these funds will in future protect European institutions, such as European Schools, the European Parliament and all other EU institutions.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following a recent review of security following the recent terror attacks, draft amending budget No 3/2016 proposes to reinforce the security budget by EUR 15.8m in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. Security is of paramount importance, and I duly voted in favour.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this draft amending budget which aims to allocate a departure for the recruitment of 35 new armed security personnel posts, following attacks in the European Union. While security is necessary, I think there are other measures to ensure it without having to resort to the militarization of all institutions. As set out in the report, this recruitment process was done without the proper Parliament. In addition to strictly sticking to increased security only by increasing armed personnel to monitor European institutions, regardless of other civil society that is also exposed to these attacks, or infrastructure security. That is why I do not support this report because of its exclusively securitarian approach, and I believe that these dangers must be tackled from a more inclusive approach and that conflicts are prevented and resolved from the outing, and do not result in a militarisation of our environment.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which proposes to reinforce the budget for security by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. This is in response to a recent review of security following the terrorist attacks.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The European Parliament approves that the budget to secure of the institutions should be reinforced by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service in order to raise the level of security against such threats as terrorists attacks.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent terrorist attacks in Europe have prompted the EU institutions to review their security needs as early as 2016 and identify needs for additional resources. The draft amending budget No 3/2016 therefore proposes to increase the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. The Plenary Session of the European Parliament takes note of draft arrera act No 3/2016 in its form submitted by the Commission and approves the Council's position on it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Council amendment to the budget to increase the security of the institutions. The recent terror attacks have led the Union institutions to review their security needs and to identify the need for additional resources already in 2016. Draft amending budget No 3/2016 consequently proposed to reinforce the budget for security by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. I believe this is required and that all institutions should be adequately secured. In particular, the amendment aims to create 35 additional permanent posts for the recruitment of additional security agents in the European Parliament. These posts should be maintained in the 2017 budget and exempt from the 5% staff reduction target, as they correspond to a new activity.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The third amending budget for the current financial year aims to increase funding by EUR 15.8 million and to create 35 new posts to increase security in the European institutions following the terrorist attacks in various European cities in recent months. As this is an unforeseen new edition, the ECR Group is in favour of this amending budget. Accordingly, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of Draft amending budget 3/2016, which refers to new security needs identified by the EU institutions following the recent terror attacks.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position on the draft amendment to budget No 2012/2013. 3/2016 of the European Union for the 2016 financial year: Security of institutions, as terrorist attacks have undue the safety of all citizens.  In this context, I think that additional resources are particularly important when it comes to European schools. I believe that all budget changes, including this No. 3/2016, must ultimately be well thought out, transparently implemented, efficient and in line with real needs.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. In my view, this corrective project risks increasing the cost of securing our institutions by increasing the number of staff and passing on the cost year after year. It would have been preferable to make a better allocation of staff. However, I do not intend to vote against a measure that is concerned about the security of institutions, even if its budgetary management is perfectable. So I chose to abstain.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In view of recent terror attacks, I believe it is crucial that European Union’s institutions review their security need and identify the urgency for additional resources already in 2016. The budget for security must be reinforced with regard to new activities connected to tackling terrorism threat, like for example the demand of the recruitment of additional security agents. That is why I supported this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez on the security of institutions. In the wake of the tragic attacks in Paris and Brussels, it was important that we strengthen the security of the Union's public buildings, which are potential targets. This report strengthens the security budget of several European institutions, totalling EUR 15.8 million. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the latest terrorist attacks, it is imperative to increase security measures for workers in European Union buildings and, therefore, to move budget funds to the security of the institutions is absolutely necessary.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report assumes that, although cuts are being made across the Member States, more money needs to be put into hand to meet the institutions' security needs. Soldiers are already patrolling the buildings, which are secured with bulletproof entrances. It is also to recruit more security personnel, while the operational staff of the institutions will be cut by five percent. The funds spent on this are missing from the budget allocation originally planned, as they have to be reallocated from other budget lines.  In the interests of sound financial management and a sensible approach to security, I therefore reject this proposal.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The third amending budget for the current financial year aims to increase funding by EUR 15.8 million and to create 35 new posts to increase security in the European institutions following the terrorist attacks in various European cities in recent months. As this is an unforeseen new edition, the ECR Group is in favour of this amending budget. Accordingly, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 25 October 2016, we voted in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on draft amending budget No 3/2016: the security of the EU institutions. This is a step that increases the appropriations in the budget chapter of the EU budget dedicated to security measures in the EU institutions. The need to strengthen security in the EU institutions came mainly after reports began to emerge in the media that some of the alleged perpetrators of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels had previously worked in the EU institutions as employees of external companies and service suppliers. As a follow-up, the competent authorities were asked to propose the internalisation of certain outsourced services so that they would never again be carried out by unprovered persons in those institutions. This appropriation is intended in particular to improve infrastructure, strengthen IT security, train and recruit new internal staff. Since I support this sensible reduction in security risk, but I no longer support further budget increases, and I am of the opinion that the current budget needs above all to be cleansed of an unnecessary agenda in favour of those in need, such as security, I have unfortunately had to abstain from the final vote.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported Draft amending budget No 3/2016 because it proposes to reinforce the security budget by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. There is no doubt that the budget for security should be increased particularly in the wake of the November 2015 attacks in Paris and those of March 2016 in Brussels. Another argument in support for security budget increase is the fact that EU institutions have reviewed their security needs and have found security lapses that should be addressed in short to medium term.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – Amending budget No 3/2016 provides for a transfer of appropriations from the 2016 European budget to strengthen the security budget and to adapt resources to the needs of the European institutions. Following the terrorist attacks of recent months, I believe it is necessary to increase security measures in our institutions too, which are indeed a place of work, but where we welcome thousands of European citizens who visit every year. I am therefore voting in favour of the transfer.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the draft amending budget No. 3/2016: institutional security. This draft amending budget proposes to strengthen the security budget of many EU institutions, following the attacks in Paris in November 2015 and Brussels in March 2016, amounting to 15.8 million euros. The allocation is as follows: 3.5 million euros for the protection of European schools, 200,000 euros for the European Parliament and the recruitment of 35 new security officers to provide armed protection of sensitive points on the three sites of the parliament, 5 million euros for the security of buildings and Commission staff. Finally, 2.5 million are granted for the European External Action Service, 2.1 million for the Court of Auditors, 1.8 for the ECJ, etc. Ensuring the security of all these places is very important, but this text risks leading to the creation of permanent positions by recruiting new security guards, a cost that would then be carried over each year, even if the terrorist risk decreased.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This budgetary correction number 3 for 2016 is devoted to strengthening the security resources of many EU institutions, amounting to EUR 15.8 million, through a redeployment of available funds. While this change does not affect the overall volume of the budget, there are concerns that positions created by new security guards will be deferred annually, even if the terrorist risk decreases. Therefore, I abstained on this draft amending budget.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The third adjustment of the 2016 budget provides for EUR 15.8 million to improve the security of the European institutions. Of this, EUR 3.5 million is earmarked for the European schools, EUR 5 million for the European Commission and EUR 0.2 million for the European Parliament. In the European Parliament, 35 armed security agents will be deployed to provide armed assistance from three strategically chosen posts in the building.  The additional 35 new security agents represent approximately 5% of the total staff of DG Safe of the EP. The Members of the N-VA agree to strengthen the buildings of the European institutions so that armed action can be taken by the security services in an emergency. Furthermore, the N-VA remains in favour of implementing the 5% reduction in the staff of all European institutions, in line with the agreements made within the multiannion financial framework 2013-2020.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report proposing to strengthen the budget for security in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service, as revised after the November 2015 attacks in Paris and Brussels this year.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While welcoming the partial internalisation of the institutions' security service, I reject the continued condition of these changes on a linear target of cuts and new outsourcings affecting all workers in the European Parliament. I also believe that the discretion with which security measures have been taken in Parliament should be reviewed and I have therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution of the European Parliament approves the Council's position on draft amendment No 3/2016, which aims to increase the security budget in various European institutions by EUR 15.8 million, such as the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, the European External Action Service, as well as the European Schools. I vote in favour of the motion for a resolution as the recent terrorist attacks have led us to review our security and, after an appropriate assessment, to conclude on the need for additional resources.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The third amending budget for the current financial year aims to increase funding by EUR 15.8 million and to create 35 new posts to increase security in the European institutions following the terrorist attacks in various European cities in recent months. As this is an unforeseen new edition, the ECR Group is in favour of this amending budget. Accordingly, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of reinforcing the budget for security in several of the EU institutions.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The proposal increases spending by the European Parliament, the Commission and other EU institutions on new cameras and security frames by EUR 16 million and proposes the hiring of an additional 35 EP armed personnel without the EU having to reduce the number of personnel in other areas by 35. The increased expenditure is at the expense of the Member States, which is why I voted against it.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report because we need more security for European citizens and for all people in Europe. This year's terrorist attacks have shown us several things: (a) Member States (MS) which do not send accurate and complete information on time or at all to European databases (SIS,VIS, EURODAC), Europol or to States with which they have bilateral relations in these areas; (b) a large proportion of the MS providing the Union's external border does not have the necessary resources and teams ready to deal with the migration and refugee crisis.  In these circumstances, and in the context of the recent adoption of rules for mobile applications for borders, strengthening borders, buying equipment at the airport and at other borders, we need further action. Draft amending budget No 3/2016 provides for the grantof EUR 15,8 million for additional security measures. Of this amount, EUR 3.5 million will go to the European Schools, 5 million to the Commission and 0.2 million to Parliament.  This amount of money allows the recruitment of 35 additional permanent posts of security guards in the institutions.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the November 2015 attacks in Paris and those of March 2016 in Brussels, all institutions have reviewed their security needs in the short to medium term. Draft amending budget No 3 for the year 2016 proposes to reinforce the budget for security for a total of EUR 15.8 million. I support the position that we have to find additional money for security.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Terrorist attacks in the Union, and in particular at the headquarters of its authorities, have also raised the issue of sufficient security and sufficient resources to protect them. This proposal strengthens the security budget in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service by a total of EUR 15.8 million.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Security of the institutions, because it is the duty of the State in which the EU institutions are based to ensure at its own cost the security of Members of the European Parliament and EU officials and not to pass these costs on to the Union budget and thus to European taxpayers. In addition, it should be noted that the States in which EU institutions are based are gaining increased economic advantages as a result of the establishment of these EU institutions there.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained for this text. The text proposes to strengthen the security budget of several European institutions in the wake of the 2015 and 2016 attacks. The amount envisaged is 15.8 million euros. We are, of course, in favour of the establishment of effective counter-terrorism mechanisms, but we are opposed to the creation of permanent posts because the cost would then be deferred every year, whatever the circumstances. However, this is a redeployment of appropriations between headings: there are no new budgetary impulses. So I abstained.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report affirms the need for internalisation of EU services. The grounds for the measures recommended in this report are not, in my opinion, the most correct. However, the internalization of services benefits workers more than outsourcing them, ensuring decent living conditions, as well as the prevention of well-known situations of exploitation and precariousness. I abstained.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for the increase of the security budget in the European institutions by EUR 15.8 million to enhance surveillance in the face of the threat of terrorist attacks. This heading will also allow the creation of 35 permanent posts for the recruitment of additional security agents in the European Parliament.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about the budget adjustment budget 3/2016, which concerns the security of the European institutions. These institutions would be, for example.B European schools, Parliament, the Commission, the ECJ, the Court of Auditors, etc. The necessary funds are to be generated by budget reallocations. It would be desirable if the European Union as a whole were to demand and implement more emphasis on security and not only on its own institutions. That is why I voted negatively.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the budgetary changes proposed by the Council to increase the funding for the security of the EU institutions in Brussels, in view of the terrorist attacks in 2016 and the growing threat of extremist acts.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This EU amending budget for 2016 aims to free up additional resources for the security of the European institutions in the context of a terrorist threat, particularly in France and Belgium. The need to ensure the security of institutions and those who work there can hardly be challenged on its merits. But why was it not taken into account before, as soon as the 2016 budget was adopted, let alone in the two amending budgets already voted in 2016? Unfortunately, the terrorist threat was already known. I therefore deplore once again the budgetary unprescing shown by the EU. With the Commission preparing its budget and the Council adopting it as its first officials. Obsessed with dogmatic criteria of austerity, the proposed budgets do not respond to the most basic emergencies of the moment. I also regret that the Union is concerned here only with dealing with the symptoms of terrorism rather than drying up its geopolitical causes. Nevertheless, in order not to deprive the institutions and their employees of any useful protection, I nevertheless vote for this report.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This budgetary correction number 3 for 2016 is devoted to strengthening the security resources of many EU institutions, amounting to EUR 15.8 million, through a redeployment of available funds. While this change does not affect the overall volume of the budget, there are concerns that positions created by new security guards will be deferred each year even if the terrorist risk decreases. Therefore, I abstained on this draft amending budget.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Following the Paris attacks in November 2015 and Brussels in March 2016, all institutions reviewed their security needs in the short and medium term.  The draft budget for 2017 includes additional security-related elements for almost all institutions. However, in some cases, the need to speed up the strengthening of security measures and facilities requires additional resources as early as 2016.  This draft amending budget (POR) No 3 for the financial year 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendments to increase the budget to heighten security at the Union’s institutions following the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the amending budget to ensure the security of the European institutions and its staff. In light of the recent attacks, we have had to increase our security and human resources needs. In this context, an additional 35 permanent positions will be created for the recruitment of new security officers to the EP. This adjustment of 15.8 million euros is well justified because it is a question of protecting not only the European institutions located in Belgium and France, but also the European schools and all the staff working within these institutions.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 30 June 2016, the Commission presented draft amending budget No 3/2016 proposing to increase the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service in the light of recent terrorist attacks. The Council adopted its position on this matter on 11 October 2016. In its report, the Committee on Budgets proposes that Parliament take note of draft arrerate No 3/2016 in its form submitted by the Commission and approve the Council's position on this.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 3 for 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget of many EU institutions, following the attacks in Paris in November 2015 and Brussels in March 2016, amounting to EUR 15.8 million. The financing of these additional credits is ensured by a redeployment of available credits from the ITER operating line to avoid any overall impact on payments. If we cannot afford to vote against this text, it risks leading to the creation of permanent posts by recruiting new security guards, a cost that would then be carried over each year, even if the terrorist risk decreased. It would have been possible to reallocate staff without an increase in the number of staff in the EU institutions. However, considering that this is a redeployment of appropriations between headings without new budgetary impulses, he will call for our abstention.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I endorse the rapporteur's position on the review of the needs of the European institutions in the field of security, following the most recent terrorist attacks, and to identify, further in 2016, the additional resources needed. I support the proposal to strengthen by EUR 15.8 million the budget for the security of the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service, as well as the proposal to create 35 more permanent posts for the recruitment of new security officers from the European Parliament. For the foregoing, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 3 for 2016 proposes to increase the security budget of many EU institutions by EUR 15.8 million following the attacks in Paris in November 2015 and Brussels in March 2016. This text risks leading to the creation of permanent positions by the recruitment of new security guards, a cost that would then be carried over each year, even if the terrorist risk decreases. To ensure the necessary security, it was possible to reallocate staff without an increase in the number of staff in the Union's institutions. That's why I abstained.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which proposes to reinforce the budget for security by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. This is in response to a recent review of security following the terrorist attacks.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 3/2016 for the 2016 financial year: institutional security. In the wake of the attacks in Paris and Brussels, the text plans to increase the security budget of several particularly threatened European institutions to the tune of 15.8 million euros (including 200,000 euros for the European Parliament).

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution that will reinforce the budget for security for the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the European Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of Regions and the European External Action Service following recent terror attacks that have led these institutions to review their security needs.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it simply raises more money to recruit people who are not affected by the 5% rule. With regard to the new driver service, the money will be missing elsewhere and must also be obtained from somewhere else.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The latest terrorist attacks have strengthened the security measures of the institutions, which require changes to the 2016 budget.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of past terrorist attacks and their future threat, the security of the institutions must be given due attention. I believe that the proposal to create additional permanent posts for safety staff is inappropriate. It is also essential that Parliament respects the 5% staff reduction target properly and in solidarity with the other institutions. Therefore, in order to ensure a maximum level of security, new security arrangements should be concluded for the conduct of monitoring inside and outside Union buildings and all additional staff should be recruited through external contracts.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding motion for a resolution. The motion was to give consent to the Commission proposal. The Commission proposal was to spend an extra EUR 15.8 million on security provisions for EU institutions. Some of the provisions were not objectionable, such as extra CCTV and x-ray machines. However, the only security proposal for the European Parliament was to create posts for 35 EU officials who will be armed and deployed within Parliament. If there is to be external security, it should be through professional private contractors or nation-state security, not through arming EU officials. The proposal would mean the acquisition of 7 new armoured vehicles for the European External Action Service and spending money on securing the private lodgings of EU Commissioners.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal. Recent events, i.e. terrorist attacks on European soil, have led the EU institutions to review their security needs and to strengthen the budget in this area. In view of these priorities, therefore, the institutions have made certain changes to the budget by providing for the creation of 35 permanent posts for the recruitment of security agents to the European Parliament. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. The European Union's priority is the safety of its citizens. She's certainly multidimensional, but lately she seems to be most at the threat of terrorist activity. This claim proved correct in the 2015 terrorist attacks on Paris and Brussels in 2016, which forced all institutions to review their security needs in a relatively short time frame.  Thus, the draft budget for 2017 takes into account the additional security needs of almost all institutions. However, some institutions need to act earlier and to accelerate the reinforcement of security measures. I support draft rebalancing budget No. 3. for 2016 because it shows concern about our present, but also about the future. The budget not only allocates significant resources to institutions concerning the Commission and Parliament, but also to the judiciary, which shows concern for the present and the harmonious regulation of relations within the EU.  In particular, I support the care for the future, which is clearly visible in the resources set aside to improve the security of European schools. It is in vain for us all the security of the European institutions, if we do not protect our smallest and most vulnerable. We should take special care of them in every situation and protect them from all adversity.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft amending budget No. 3 for 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget of many EU institutions following the attacks in Paris in November 2015 and Brussels in March 2016 to the amount of EUR 15.8 million. The text risks leading to the creation of permanent positions by the recruitment of new security guards, a cost that would then be carried forward each year, even if the terrorist risk decreased. In addition, it would have been possible to reallocate staff without an increase in the number of staff in the EU institutions. However, considering that this is a redeployment of appropriations between headings without new budgetary impulses and that security is currently a major issue, I do not reject this text and prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Due to recent terrorist attacks, the Union institutions have reviewed their security needs and found that additional resources are needed as early as 2016. It is proposed that the security budget in European schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice of the European Union, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service should be increased by a total of EUR 15.8 million.  The aim is to establish 35 additional permanent posts in the European Parliament to recruit additional security personnel. Parliament fully respects its 5% staff reduction statement annexed to the joint conclusions on the 2016 budget.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2016 proposes to strengthen by EUR 15.8 million the security budget of the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. It aims to create 35 more permanent posts for the recruitment of new security officers from the European Parliament. This amending budget aims to strengthen THE EU's security policy, instilling fear and completely devaluing the need to tackle problems on the ground. Solve the problems in the Middle East by ending aid to terrorist groups and Israel's criminal regime, and peace will surely return to the European continent with the end of the attacks.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 3 2016 concerns the security of the EU institutions in the light of recent terrorist attacks in Europe. DAB 3/2016 is a technical procedure providing EUR 15.8 million for the strengthening of institutions, including safety equipment and training. Of this amount, EUR 3.5 million will be allocated to the European Schools, EUR 5 million to the European Commission and EUR 0.2 million to the European Parliament. Strengthening Parliament involves the hiring of 35 additional security personnel providing armed protection for strategic points in Parliament's buildings. Although EUR 15.8 million in payments may be transferred from another budget line, the related commitment appropriations must be covered by a margin in the administrative section of the EU budget due to the higher than expected value of salaries and pensions last year. In view of the need to strengthen the security measures of the EU institutions, I supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which proposes to strengthen the budget dedicated to the security of certain European institutions. It is normal that the citizens and staff of these institutions, especially in Brussels for example, should be more protected.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Recent terrorist attacks have forced the Institutions of the Union to review their security needs and discuss and identify the additional resources needed.   Draft amending budget No 3/2016 provides for added security resources to the following institutions: European Schools, European Parliament, European Commission, European Court of Justice, European Court of Auditors, European Economic and Social Committee, Committee of the Regions and European External Action Service. I agree that the greatest strengthening is on European schools, as the education and training of young Europeans cannot be affected by a lack of security.  With regard to the increase in security funds in the European Parliament, which will aim at hiring 35 new permanent staff, I believe that this is a responsible and appropriate increase and that it will ensure greater security not only for the many employees of this institution but also for thousands of visitors who pass by every month.  I strongly support the report by Colleagues José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this binding motion for a resolution. The motion was to give consent to the Commission proposal. The Commission proposal was to spend an extra EUR 15.8 million on security provisions for EU institutions. Some of the provisions were not objectionable, such as extra CCTV and x-ray machines. However, the only security proposal for the European Parliament was to create posts for 35 EU officials who will be armed and deployed within Parliament. If there is to be external security, it should be through professional private contractors or nation-state security, not through arming EU officials. The proposal would mean the acquisition of 7 new armoured vehicles for the European External Action Service and spending money on securing the private lodgings of EU Commissioners.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recent terrorist attacks, which have forced the Union institutions to review their security needs and identify, as early as 2016, the additional resources needed to combat terrorism. One of the proposals is to strengthen by EUR 15.8 million the security budget for the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. And it aims to create 35 more permanent posts for the recruitment of new security officers from the European Parliament, considering that these posts should be kept in the 2017 budget and exempt from the target of reducing staff by 5 % as they are intended for a new activity.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent terrorist attacks have forced the Union institutions to review their security needs and identify, as early as 2016, the additional resources needed.  Therefore, draft amending budget No 3/2016 proposes to strengthen by EUR 15.8 million the security budget for the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service.  It also aims to create 35 more permanent posts for the recruitment of new security officers from the European Parliament. The European Parliament's report endorses the Council's position on draft amending budget No 3/2016.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution by which Parliament approves the Council's position on draft amending budget No 3/2016, increasing the budget to ensure safety in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service by EUR 15.8 million in view of the new needs identified after the latest terrorist attacks.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the draft amending budget No. 3/2016 because the recent terrorist attacks have prompted the EU institutions to review their security needs. This budget proposes, among other things, the recruitment of 35 security guards to the European Parliament. It is necessary that additional security resources be available to adapt to a new reality. The European Parliament is a particularly visited place and it is essential that the people who work or spend time there are safe. This is equally true for other institutions such as European schools, the Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service, for which this text calls for additional security resources to be allocated.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I doubt the need for this legislation. I agree that terrorist acts in France and Belgium have raised some concerns about public security, but national authorities are doing so. And engaged successfully. I certainly do not believe that there is a need to create some kind of European security service for MES institutions, or even to waste time discussing when there are more important jobs.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent terrorist attacks have led the Institutions of the European Union to review their security needs and, consequently, identify the additional resources needed to ensure that all conditions (logistical, material, human, budgetary or other) are guaranteed with regard to this important condition. Draft amending budget No 3/2016 proposes to strengthen by EUR 15.8 million the security budget for the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service.  In addition, this report envisages creating 35 more permanent posts for the recruitment of new security officers from the European Parliament (whereas these posts should be kept in the 2017 budget and exempt from the target of reducing staff by 5%). As this is an issue aimed at safeguarding the safety of all officials (and visitors) of the European institutions, as well as ensuring the regular functioning and dominant environment in them, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this draft amending budget, which aims to allocate a departure for the recruitment of 35 new posts of armed security personnel after the attacks received in the Union. While security is necessary, I think there are other measures to ensure it without having to resort to the militarization of all institutions. As set out in the report, this recruitment process was done without the proper Parliament. In addition to strictly sticking to increased security only by increasing armed personnel to monitor European institutions, regardless of other civil society that is also exposed to these attacks, or infrastructure security. That is why I do not support this report because of its exclusively securitarian approach, and I believe that these dangers must be tackled from a more inclusive approach and that conflicts are prevented and resolved from the outing, and do not result in a militarisation of our environment.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the draft amending budget on the security of the EU institutions, which was presented after the Paris attacks in 2015 and the attacks in Brussels in 2016. The total sum of EUR 15.8 million will be shared between the various European institutions.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While welcoming the partial internalisation of the institutions' security service, I reject the continued condition of these changes on a linear target of cuts and new outsourcings affecting all workers in the European Parliament. I also believe that the discretion with which security measures have been taken in Parliament should be reviewed and I have therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In light of the recent terrorist attacks in Europe, strengthening the security measures of the EU institutions becomes a necessity. I have therefore decided to approve the amending budget, which strengthens the security budget by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million, which will be invested, for example, in the recruitment of additional staff, the purchase of equipment and training, in order to improve the security of the European institutions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of Draft amending budget No 3/2016: Security of the Institutions. It proposes to reinforce the budget for security by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. This is in response to a recent review of security following the terrorist attacks.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The more the European Union tries to combat terrorism, the higher the risk to become a target for counterattack. Especially the European Institutions, which symbolise the EU and it is Member States approach to combat terrorism. After the recent terrorist attacks the need for additional security expenditures arose. This was not expected in 2015, but it is a reality now in 2016. Therefore I was in favour to support increasing the budget, for the purpose of strengthening security.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
