text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP motion for a resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 3/2016 for the financial year 2016: The security of the institutions. Recent terrorist attacks have led the EU institutions to examine their security needs and identify the need for additional resources as early as this year. For this reason, amending budget No 3 for 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million. In particular, the amending budget aims to create 35 additional permanent posts for the recruitment of additional security staff in the EP. At the same time, these posts should also be retained in the 2017 budget and should also be exempted from the 5% staff reduction target, as they correspond to a new activity and a new situation requiring such an adjustment of both the budget and the number of staff.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget by €15.8 million for the European Schools, the European Parliament, the Commission, the Court of Justice of the EU, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service.  The draft focuses in the European Parliament on the creation of 35 new posts with armed security guards, one of which is the legal status of the seconded security guards.  Security guards are expected to remain employed in Parliament for years to come, despite the fact that a 5% reduction plan was adopted some time ago. Since this is a new activity, there is no failure to comply with the declaration of a reduction of 5%. As I do not think there is a need for armed security guards in the European Parliament, I voted against the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The third amending budget for the current financial year aims to increase funding by EUR 15.8 million and to create 35 new posts to increase security in the European institutions following the terrorist attacks in various European cities in recent months. As this is an unforeseen new edition, the ECR Group is in favour of this amending budget. Accordingly, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Terrorist threats, which are not only physical but also of a cyber nature, have increased the security requirements of the European institutions. However, the resources to be allocated as part of the increase must be used effectively with a long-term positive impact, without limiting the smooth running of the institutions and their openness to the public.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Security of the institutions. The amending budget provides for the creation of 35 additional permanent posts for the recruitment of additional security staff in the European Parliament. These posts will be excluded from the objective of reducing staff by 5%. The posts required may be useful, may be filled within the framework of the existing establishment plan or replace posts in the corresponding area of the existing establishment plan.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒As the General Budget of the European Union for 2016 was finally adopted on 25 November 2015, and the recent terrorist attacks, the European Union institutions identified a lack of additional resources as early as 2016 by auditing the security of needs.  Draft budget amendment No. 3/2016 It is proposed that the security budget in European schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice of the EU, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service be increased by a total of €15.8 million.    I support the Council position report on the draft amendment to budget No 1009/2013. 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Security of institutions.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on the draft amending budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016: the security of the institutions. In the light of the changed security situation, the unstable neighbourhood and the recent terrorist attacks that we have seen in Europe, we need to increase security concerns.  I support the allocation of additional security funds for a total amount of EUR 15.8 million for the security of institutions. This will create 35 permanent jobs for the employment of additional security guards in the European Parliament.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The achievement of a high level of security at the premises and premises of European agencies is ensured by the excellent cooperation between the security and protection services of the host State and the respective agencies' services and not by the recruitment of additional staff.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's agreed resolution amending the EU budget for 2016 in the sense that EUR 15.8 million should be redeployed to this area in order to strengthen the security of the European institutions and, in view of the additional labour needs, the institutions should be exempted from the 5% redundancy requirement for security personnel.  I believe that the recent terrorist attacks in Brussels and elsewhere in Europe, as well as the increased threat to the European institutions (including the EP), their staff and objects, clearly justify the appropriate additional security measures and the provision of the necessary budgetary resources.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The increase in the intensity of the global terrorist phenomenon is directly reflected in the lives of every European citizen. The attacks in Brussels in March this year, just outside the European institutions, demonstrated the need to strengthen their security. The European Union, as a political project supporting fundamental rights and freedoms, the rule of law, democracy, prosperity and economic openness, has become a direct target of these radical-extremist groups, whose sole purpose is to spread global fear, ignorance and hate.  In this context, the Union institutions need, in concrete terms, to increase the security system by allocating a total additional amount of EUR 15.8 million to the budget for appropriate measures within the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. The European Parliament is talking about the creation of an additional 35 permanent posts of security guards, which are not covered by the provisions to reduce staff by 5%.  I believe that these measures are welcome and I support this much-needed initiative.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Gérard Deprez's report after talking about it at length with him again this morning. This report relates to the Council's position on the European Union's draft amending budget No. 3/2016 for the 2016 financial year: institutional security.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Recent terrorist attacks across Europe and in close proximity to the Institutions of the European Union have led to a review of the security of the institutions. The Commission's draft amendment to the European Union's security budget proposes additional funds for the institutions to recruit additional security personnel in various institutions such as European schools, the European Parliament and the European Commission. The European Parliament's Budget Committee proposed approving the Commission's draft without any changes. As I agree that security measures in the Eu institutions need to be further strengthened, I supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the motion for a resolution on the Council position on draft amending budget No 3/2016 for the financial year 2016 on the security of the institutions. Following the Attacks in Paris in November 2015 and March 2016 in Brussels, all institutions re-examined their security needs in the short and medium term.  The draft budget for 2017 includes additional security elements for almost all institutions. In some cases, however, security measures and devices need to be strengthened earlier and additional funding is required for 2016 as early as 2016. Draft amending budget (PSP) No 3 for 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget by a total of EUR 15,8 million.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this draft amending budget which aims to allocate a departure for the recruitment of 35 new armed security personnel posts, following attacks in the European Union. While security is necessary, I think there are other measures to ensure it without having to resort to the militarization of all institutions. As set out in the report, this recruitment process was done without the proper Parliament. In addition to strictly sticking to increased security only by increasing armed personnel to monitor European institutions, regardless of other civil society that is also exposed to these attacks, or infrastructure security. That is why I do not support this report because of its exclusively securitarian approach, and I believe that these dangers must be tackled from a more inclusive approach and that conflicts are prevented and resolved from the outing, and do not result in a militarisation of our environment.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text provides for the creation of new posts assigned to new security guards for the European institutions because of the risks associated with terrorism. This is a redeployment of appropriations between headings without new budgetary impulses and it is factual that the European Union cannot afford it in these times of economic crisis and over-indebtedness of states. It would also have been possible to readjust staff without an increase in the number of staff in the EU institutions. I chose abstention.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In view of the increasing terrorist attacks in Europe, including Brussels, security measures in the buildings of the EU institutions should also be strengthened. Additional staff, as well as equipment and training, will provide better protection for your most important places. The draft amending budget itself is a purely technical procedure. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent terrorist attacks have prompted the EU institutions to review their security needs as early as 2016 and identify their needs for additional resources. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this draft amending budget which aims to allocate a departure for the recruitment of 35 new armed security personnel posts, following attacks in the European Union. While security is necessary, I think there are other measures to ensure it without having to resort to the militarization of all institutions. As set out in the report, this recruitment process was done without the proper Parliament. In addition to strictly sticking to increased security only by increasing armed personnel to monitor European institutions, regardless of other civil society that is also exposed to these attacks, or infrastructure security. That is why I do not support this report because of its exclusively securitarian approach, and I believe that these dangers must be tackled from a more inclusive approach and that conflicts are prevented and resolved from the outing, and do not result in a militarisation of our environment.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as I do not see the need for recruiting armed security guards in the EP. I also deplore the opacity of the procedure from the initial request to the start of the recruitment process.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 3/2016 of the European Union for the financial year 2016: Security of the Institutions. Recent terror attacks have led the Union institutions to review their security needs and to identify the need for additional resources already in 2016. Draft amending budget No 3/2016 consequently proposes to reinforce the budget for security by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million in the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. In addition, it aims to create 35 additional permanent posts for the recruitment of additional security agents in the European Parliament.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Following what was agreed after the November 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris and March 2016 in Brussels, I support with my vote the proposal to strengthen the budget item aimed at ensuring security in the European institutions.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While welcoming the partial internalisation of the institutions' security service, I reject the continued condition of these changes on a linear target of cuts and new outsourcings affecting all workers in the European Parliament. I also believe that the discretion with which security measures have been taken in Parliament should be reviewed and I have therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 3/2016 proposes to strengthen by EUR 15.8 million the security budget of the European Schools, the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the Court of Auditors, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the European External Action Service. It aims to create 35 more permanent posts for the recruitment of new security officers from the European Parliament. This amending budget aims to strengthen THE EU's security policy, instilling fear and completely devaluing the need to tackle problems on the ground. Solve the problems in the Middle East by ending aid to terrorist groups and Israel's criminal regime, and peace will surely return to the European continent with the end of the attacks.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft provides for a subsequent reallocation of the budget adjustment budget 3/2016. The budget for security measures is to be increased by EUR 15.8 million as early as this year. This would entail significant additional costs in the long term. That is why I rejected this report.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the attacks in Paris and Brussels, all the European institutions reviewed their security needs in the short and medium term. Draft amending budget No 3 for the financial year 2016 proposes to strengthen the security budget by a total of EUR 15.8 million. In particular, cybersecurity and the overall security of buildings are being increased in order to better protect staff working within the EU institutions. For the European Parliament, the aim is to create 35 new posts for the recruitment of additional security agents in order to provide armed protection at strategic points within the buildings in the three service locations. The impact on the general budget is neutral, as the additional resources come from a transfer of an underused budget line. Although I am aware that the safety of the institutions needs special attention, I do not agree that Parliament, after the drivers, now also wants to internalise these 35 new units, which will be officially classified as officials of the European institutions. In my opinion, the security of the institutions should be guaranteed by the host countries or possibly by certified security agencies providing trained personnel.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: Written. The European institutions are allocating even more money for their own security, while in no way taking the increasing insecurity through open borders seriously or recognising that Islam is the source of inspiration for contemporary terrorism. It is only right that the institutions should suffer the same insecurity as the citizens on the streets. The PVV voted against this budget.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report on a small change in the 2016 budget. The amendment to the budget concerned the area of security of the buildings of the European institutions and was designed mainly as a result of the deteriorated security situation and the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels at the end of last year and earlier this year. Under this appendix, additional funding will be provided to strengthen the strategic points of the European institutions and will in practice be used for security equipment and training of security agents. Since I believe that the security situation cannot be underestimated in the light of the attacks in question, I agree with the adoption of additional security measures.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of Draft Amending Budget No 3/2016: Security of the institutions. Draft amending budget No 3/2016 foresees an increase in the security budget for terrorist attacks by a total amount of EUR 15.8 million to be used by the European institutions to ensure the safety of their employees.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report, unlike most colleagues in my faction, and i am therefore taking the opportunity to explain my position. I believe that this strategy, this report, is too accommodating to the Iranian regime. I think it was a mistake to reject a number of amendments that clearly justified the violations of human rights in Iran, and I believe that there has been a victory for the effort and desire to strengthen trade relations with Iran as opposed to the protection of human rights and freedoms, and that is a big problem for me. I did not vote for Iran to become a member of the WTO, I do not think there are conditions for this at the moment. If we look, for example, at the number of executions in Iran, including the children executed, then I do not think that Iran can be taken as a country that is a standard state with some principles of democracy and the protection of human rights. It is one of the three states in the world where the death penalty is most used, which is why I was against this report.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, what was the signature act of the Iranian revolution? It was the siege of the US embassy, right? Think of how extraordinary that was. I mean if the United States were to invade Cuba tomorrow we would expect diplomats to be peacefully evacuated through neutral third countries. The seizure of a legation building was sending out the clearest message imaginable: your notions of territorial jurisdiction and national sovereignty do not apply to us. And sure enough, the ayatollahs went on as they had started, refusing to recognise any notion of law between nations and sponsoring terrorist movements from the khanates of the old Silk Road to as far afield as Buenos Aires.  When you have a State that refuses by definition to operate within the norms of the comity of nations, that rejects the whole principle of national sovereignty, you cannot expect to do deals with it as you would a functioning civil state. And I cannot resist making the point that when you reject national sovereignty outright you set yourself on a very dangerous path. Almost every tyranny has begun by refusing to accept the legitimacy of national democracy.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as a Member of the Iranian delegation it was a pleasure to attend the debate here last night and indeed to observe the very pertinent and proper concerns expressed by Members regarding human rights in Iran. Having said that, it is also important to recognise the progress made and the road which Iran has travelled in getting the nuclear accord, so for that reason, as we move forward, we have to engage with Iran and develop trade relations so that economically it can benefit.  History shows that where there is economic benefit there is a greater tendency to move towards human rights so the two can go in tandem: economic relations being developed between the EU and Iran, but also, as many amendments pointed out today, their need to reform, especially in relation to human rights and the death penalty.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I, too, am among the smaller group of members of my faction who voted against this report. I believe that, of course, it is the duty of diplomacy to act, to eliminate contradictions and to reach certain agreements, compromises. However, I am not sure that this agreement actually brings real compromises and real benefits for the European Union and for the world at all. Maybe she was a little premature. Rouhani is portrayed in the West as a representative of the liberal mainstream in Iran, but if you look at the real numbers, he is actually even worse than the terrifying President Ahmadinejad when it comes to, say, the numbers executed. I fully believe that this agreement, which has been made, was premature and I think that the report was unilaterally aimed at supporting this agreement and not objectively assessing all the facts.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the future of EU-IRAN relations following the so-called 'nuclear agreement' (JCPOA). A constructive approach has been chosen without over-punishing the country for its still critical human rights record, hoping that an admissible relationship from the Iranian Government will be more useful to the moderate wing in its battle against the conservative government and can therefore lead to real progress in the medium term in terms of human rights and civil liberties in the country. I voted in favour for the following reasons: Iran has so far fully respected the nuclear agreement and there is a prospect of real change.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which represents further development of EU-Iran relations one year after the nuclear agreement between the international community and Iran. The report describes areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation security, academic exchanges, etc. And he deals extensively with the regional situation in the Middle East, sending the message, especially to Iran and Saudi Arabia, about the need to appease tensions and carry out diplomatic normalization. In addition, the report covers the human rights situation in Iran, emphasizing the Union's opposition to the death penalty and criticizing Iran for the very high number of executions and other human rights violations, such as arrests of dual EU-Iranian citizens, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression Etc. The report specifically calls on Iran to cooperate fully with UN human rights mechanisms.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non—binding report. UKIP does not support the development of an EU foreign policy and such does not recognise the legitimacy of the EU to engage in diplomatic relations with Iran. UKIP rejects the notion that the Iranian nuclear deal was a ‘success for EU diplomacy’ and opposes its attempted use by the EU as a justification for the further development of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, trade policy should be a matter for Member States and not the EU Commission. There are serious human rights concerns, both domestically in Iran and throughout the Middle East, propagated by the Iranian regime proxies. We have supported articles that purely discuss human rights and rejected those that contain calls for the EU to take action. This is more effectively left to appropriate international institutions and individual states.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to define the Union's strategy on Iran following the nuclear agreement signed in 2015, a permanent agreement between the parties to lift sanctions imposed on Iran by the United States, the Union and the United Nations, and Iran limits its long-term nuclear program. The report has positive but also negative elements, such as not asking for the full lifting of US sanctions or which, as is customary in Union reports and resolutions, is the hypocrisy of asking for the human rights of refugees and asylum seekers to be respected, when in its own territory the Union systematically infringes them. Despite this, I voted in favour as the report supports a return to active diplomacy and cooperation with Iran, based on mutual respect for international norms and principles, and recalls that "it is not intended to interfere in a country's domestic political elections". Moreover, the report argues that Iran can act as a mediator to seek a peaceful solution to the Syrian conflict. For all this, my vote has been positive.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We support dialogue and the normalisation of diplomatic relations with Iran and the fact that this report reiterated support for human rights and for Iran to take steps to address this where it is lacking. However there were still a number of problems with this report which raised significant concerns. The report also called for the liberalisation of Iranian economy as member of the WTO, there was too much ambiguity regarding what this would entail alongside the section regarding forging a bilateral investment treaty with Iran, considering the controversy around CETA and TTIP around the influence corporate investors will have with the introduction of ISDS, we could not blindly support this report and abstained instead.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted with my Socialist colleagues in favour of the Howitt report on the European strategy vis-à-vis Iran. We share the essence of the report's recommendations, which lay the groundwork for Iran's reintegration into the international community. The European Union must be open, while remaining lucid about Iran's regional and internal situation. That is why we voted in favour of the amendment explicitly conditioning the development of economic relations on progress in the area of human rights, women's rights and freedom of expression. This conditionality complements that of compliance with the nuclear agreement.  Our line is clear: all our relations with the countries of the region must aim at respect, security and security for the people of the Middle East and Europe.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement, because it stresses the need for Iran to meet its international commitments in various areas, such as human rights.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) is a good step towards mutual diplomacy, and both sides are now responsible for the successful implementation of the Action Plan. Any external relationship that promotes stability and therefore security should be supported. I am therefore voting in favour of this action plan.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This European Parliament report was prepared in response to the Iran-US nuclear agreement. Like all European texts on foreign affairs issues, this report constitutes an attack on the sovereignty of States. However, it should be noted that Representative Howitt (British Labour) made a relatively honest report, particularly on human rights issues. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. I do not support the European Council’s decision to lift all nuclear related sanctions again Iran. I voted in favour of Amendment 9 of the report calling for the immediate release of all political prisoners and others unjustly detained. The amendment calls for fair trials and due process standards to be upheld including access to a solicitor, access to doctors and an end to the systematic torture in prisons. The Iranian Government needs to reform and engage positively with the International community to build mutual trust. UKIP does not support the development of an EU foreign policy and such does not recognise the legitimacy of the EU to engage in diplomatic relations with Iran. UKIP rejects the notion that the Iranian nuclear deal was a ‘success for EU diplomacy’ and opposes its attempted use by the EU as a justification for the further development of an EU foreign policy.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. As a result of the Iran nuclear agreement and internal political developments in Iran, there are now opportunities for reform and improved relations with the European Union. This improvement includes better sectoral cooperation, which ultimately ensures regional security and better respect for human rights. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. The nuclear agreement with Iran has provided a breath of fresh air in relations between the West and this country so geostrategically and geopolitically relevant. It is undoubtedly a turning point in European diplomacy and a major contribution to the stabilisation of the region.  As important as this agreement, it is now consolidating a frank dialogue and establishing bilateral relations based on mutual trust, which can lay the foundations for long-term cooperation. The opening of an EU delegation in Tehran will be a key player in this process.  This report sets out important guidelines that meet these objectives, while reiterating the European Union's firm opposition to the death penalty, and therefore gives rise to my support.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As the Islamic Republic of Iran has fulfilled its obligations under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, the Council decision lifted all sanctions imposed against the country in connection with nuclear tests. I therefore support the resumption of relations with Iran and the development of a new cooperation strategy. There must also be a clear and principled fight to abolish the death penalty in Iran in order to ensure the EU's human rights and foreign policy objectives.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is a clear and well-founded interest in facilitating the expansion of relations between the European Union and Iran. The country is re-entering the international economic circulation and the EU and its Member States cannot be left out when the market is redebuted. The report takes a balanced approach to the recognition of results and the proportion of criticisms and expectations required, particularly in the human rights field. An important finding of the report is that the gradual expansion of relations should be based on a realistic assessment of common interests and differences. Accepting the difference also means acknowledging that they are people of different cultures, religions and traditions than Europeans. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report, which first of all recalls that the Council's decision to lift all nuclear-related sanctions against Iran allowed for the resumption of contacts with Iran. But the report stresses that the future progress of relations between the EU and Iran should go hand in hand with the implementation of the nuclear agreement. It calls for compliance with the EU's human rights guidelines and, in particular, an immediate moratorium on the application of the death penalty in Iran. The report also calls on Iran to take anti-corruption measures and to comply with FATF recommendations on issues such as the interruption of financial flows to terrorist organizations.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament has refused to incorporate in the report the defence of the main values and principles representing the Union. Parliament refused to incorporate paragraphs expressing concern about the high number of executions or the call to release political prisoners. Nor did it wish to incorporate a call for the extension of economic relations between the Union and Iran to be accompanied by improvements in the field of human rights, women's rights and freedom of expression, as well as the abolition of the death penalty. These principles are essential and conditioned my line of vote. That is why I voted against this report. The iran nuclear deal is a very important milestone. But we can't forget that we're still dealing with a regime of terror. A fundamentalist regime that practices systematic torture, denies the Holocaust and executes children. I believe in Iran's future because I believe in the Iranians. But I am absolutely against any form of appeasement with the regime and for renounting the defence of the fundamental values that represent the Union, the defence of human rights

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Iran nuclear deal represented a historic turning point in relations between the Asian country and other states, a crucial step that takes on even greater value given Iran's geopolitical and strategic importance in the Middle East region. The Howitt report, which I supported today, sets out the next steps that the European Union must take to make this phase even more fruitful. The text sets out a number of areas that should be considered in order to initiate fruitful cooperation with Iran: trade, development, security, environmental protection and education. These are just some of the main areas in which it could have its positive effects. However, as the text emphasises, there must be a firm condemnation of the constant violations of human rights. The Eu ropean Union's commitment today must be to strengthen cooperation and political dialogue in order to promote the rule of law in Iran.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a text which I believe is in the sense of building a common and standardised agenda between the Union and Iran, based on respect for sovereignty, multilateralism in the resolution of disputes, the joint search for processes that lead to progress in respect for human rights, the sustainable and sustainable development of the Iranian people and peace and security for all peoples of the Middle East. I am opposed, however, to Iran's consideration as a source of regional instability, to the establishment of relations guided predominantly by commercial criteria, to the presentation of trade liberalization per se as a panacea for the development of peoples such as The Iranian (who participate under asymmetrical and subordinate conditions in the global market) and to the use of fossil and nuclear energy as the basis of any country's productive and energy matrix.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. This is a balanced and common-sense report. Iran is a great country and the heir to this great Persian civilization which, in the years to come, can and must play a major role in the Middle East in order to counterbalance the predominant influence of the Sunni countries of the Muslim world. Yes, the nuclear deal must bring Iran into the concert of nations. Yes, a large economy like Iran must be able to join the WTO. Let us welcome this openness, even if not everything is perfect today in Tehran. The rapporteur is right to point the finger at the imperfections of the Iranian political and legal system. Of course, Iran is not yet a state of law as we see it. Too many political prisoners are still languishing in Iranian jails. But is it different from other countries in the region? Is Saudi Arabia, our great "ally," a rule of law? What about Yemen? What about Turkey? What about Qatar?

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mr Howitt for his work so that this resolution has been voted on and adopted today. The sign that Parliament gave today is very important. I am a signatory to some amendments calling for respect for human rights and the end of the harassment suffered by women and children. But I also think that Iran must be helped in its steps to put aside isolation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text on the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement contains some positive points, but several obvious issues remain, so I preferred to abstain.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the resolution. I believe that the nuclear agreement with Iran is a political and diplomatic success. The agreement reduces tensions in the region and increases the opportunities for peace and security. At the same time, I would like to underline the serious violations of human rights in Iran. These include the death penalty, torture, serious discrimination against women in many areas, serious restrictions on freedom of expression and assembly, not least against trade unions. In the recent dialogue with Iran, the EU and its Member States must clearly protest against these serious human rights violations and demand democratisation. The EU's trade policy, only if it is linked to clear requirements, could contribute to such a development in Iran.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution on the EU strategy on Iran following the nuclear agreement reached a year ago with the international community, which values the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action as an important achievement for multilateral diplomacy and European diplomacy that will not only significantly improve relations between Iran and the Union , but also promote stability throughout the region. In addition to recognising the successful role played by Vice-President Mogherini, the Resolution deals from a broad perspective with the human rights situation in Iran, positioning the Union against the death penalty in the country as well as against the multiple human rights violations committed therein: arrests of persons with dual Union citizenship and Iranian , gender discrimination, non-compliance with the rights of minorities, violation of freedom of expression, etc...  We call for a moratorium on the death penalty, while supporting full cooperation by Iran with all United Nations human rights protection mechanisms and calling for the release of all political prisoners.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the European Union's strategy towards Iran following the nuclear agreement. The joint comprehensive plan of action, otherwise known as the nuclear agreement with Iran, has been a major achievement in European diplomacy and should now not only significantly improve relations between the EU and Iran, but also bring about more stability throughout the region. It is now the responsibility of both sides to ensure its strict and full implementation. Parliament says it is important to develop the parliamentary dimension of EU-Iran relations and welcomes the renewed political dialogue between the EU and Iran, including human rights issues. also encourages the future involvement of representatives of the judiciary, the security forces and civil society in the context of human rights dialogue. The European Parliament considers that the full normalisation of relations can only take place in parallel with the continuation of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action through regular and continuous dialogue and that the immediate development of the scope of EU-Iran relations in areas for which there is consensus should be an immediate priority.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Strategy for Iran after the Nuclear Agreement report points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, which will enable stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region to be promoted. At the same time, however, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions could be reintroduced. In the area of respect for human rights, the report reiterates the Union's firm and principled position towards the death penalty. In this sense, it strongly condemns Iran for the frequent use of the death penalty and calls for an immediate moratorium on their implementation. Given that the long-term aim of this report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour of it.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I agree with the EU's submitted strategy towards Iran because the nuclear agreement has properly stabilised relations with Iran and made security in the wider region more common. It is a great international success for the European Union, which Iran sticks to, and thus shows its loyal aspirations.  Further cooperation and access of European products to the previously closed Iranian market will, however, enable GDP to grow and thus increase prosperity for both Europeans and Iranians. Nevertheless, we are watching closely what is happening in this country in the area of respect for human rights. Otherwise, I also personally condemn the worrying trend of criminal executions in this country.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report on the EU Strategy towards Iran following the nuclear agreement. The S&D Group has been at the forefront of the EU in normalising relations with Iran. In line with this approach, I support Federica Mogherini's leadership role in overseeing the implementation of the nuclear agreement, building trust and expanding relations in areas of common interest. Likewise, further pressure should be put on Iran to carry out international human rights obligations, to drastically reduce the number of executions of people and to work to free all political prisoners.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed the resolution on the EU strategy toward Iran after the nuclear agreement with the aim of strengthening our political dialogue and developing both trade and sectoral cooperation in specific fields such as energy, environment, aviation safety and migration. Secondly, I believe Iran might play a constructive role in solving the political crisis in Iraq, Yemen, Syria, Lebanon and Afghanistan. Lastly, I am glad that data concerning the characteristics of Iranian university’s students proved that the majority of them are women and I am glad that the President Rohani promised to present a charter for citizens’ rights. Nevertheless, I am still concerned about the practice of death penalty by Iran and I stand up for its abolition.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The action plan that led to the nuclear agreement with Iran was an important success of diplomacy and the multilateral approach to the problem. A significant component of the credit for this result is that of the European Union which, right from the start, has set as the founding principles of its action a peaceful and negotiating attitude and the will to stabilise the whole area. Today we must proceed along these lines, monitoring those who would like to undermine peace and the agreements reached, and therefore considering all parties as responsible for ensuring their strict and full implementation. To this end, the establishment of the Joint Committee, composed of representatives of Iran and the E3/EU+3 Group (China, France, Germany, the Russian Federation, the United Kingdom and the United States with the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy) is positive, and it is necessary to fully support European representation in the role of coordinator of the Joint Committee with the task of monitoring the implementation of all the terms of the agreement. Iran's openness to trade with the EU and the investment and development opportunities that open up for our businesses in the country that can lead to a mutually beneficial partnership in the medium and long term are also significant.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report welcomes the success of the Iran nuclear agreement and calls on the European Union to intensify its trade relations with Iran. Certainly, we welcome the lifting of the Iranian embargo and the improvement of diplomatic and economic relations between Iran and Western countries. Nevertheless, it is essential to remember that the joint comprehensive action plan is mainly the result of bilateral negotiations between the United States and Iran. The European Union had once again demonstrated that it had no diplomatic legitimacy in foreign policy. In addition, the report repeatedly undermines Iran's sovereignty, including a moratorium on the death penalty and the liberalization of its economy in order to accelerate its membership of the World Trade Organization. However, I abstained on this text, which serenely envisages the future of relations between the European Union and Iran.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Iranian nuclear agreement is an achievement of great importance for multilateral diplomacy and European diplomacy, which fosters the strengthening of relations between the European Union and Iran, but also contributes to the promotion of stability in the region.  I believe that the Union's relations with Iran must evolve at the same time as the implementation of the nuclear agreement, and there is a need for a renewal of relations between the Member States and Iran.  I welcome the openness in relations with Iran, in favour of the Report on the Union's strategy towards Iran following the conclusion of the nuclear agreement, because I believe that this strengthening of the partnership between the EU and Iran will bring a number of important benefits for both sides, both in terms of trade and economic aspects and in terms of stability in the region.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which represents further development of EU-Iran relations one year after the nuclear agreement between the international community and Iran. The report describes areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation security, academic exchanges, etc. And he deals extensively with the regional situation in the Middle East, sending the message, especially to Iran and Saudi Arabia, about the need to appease tensions and carry out diplomatic normalization. In addition, the report covers the human rights situation in Iran, emphasizing the Union's opposition to the death penalty and criticizing Iran for the very high number of executions and other human rights violations, such as arrests of dual EU-Iranian citizens, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression Etc. The report specifically calls on Iran to cooperate fully with UN human rights mechanisms.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Iran nuclear agreement and the country's internal political developments provide an opportunity for the European Union and Iran to engage in greater cooperation in various areas. This collaboration will have to go hand in hand with the implementation of the nuclear agreement. It is indeed important that this agreement is properly implemented by stakeholders. It is also essential that more progress and political reforms are put in place in Iran, particularly with regard to human rights and the prohibition of the death penalty. I voted in favour of this report, but I voted against some amendments on human rights. Although some of them reflect my position on human rights and the death penalty, their substance is already included in the text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement because the agreement reached last year is an important result that must be safeguarded and monitored so that it is fully respected. However, a new season of relations and peace between the European Union and Iran must necessarily be followed by a new course that iran will have to take with regard to respect for individual rights and freedoms. That is why Europe must strongly condemn the frequent use of the death penalty in Iran and call for an immediate moratorium on executions.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Sinn Féin supports dialogue and the normalisation of diplomatic relations with Iran, one of the main premises of this report. The report also reiterated support for human rights and called for Iran to take steps to address this where it is lacking. However there were a number of problems with this report which raised significant concerns. It called for the liberalisation of Iranian economy as member of the WTO, alongside a call for forging a bilateral investment treaty with Iran. Due to the strongly neoliberal aspects of the report, I did not vote in favour but abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not support the development of an EU foreign policy and such does not recognise the legitimacy of the EU to engage in diplomatic relations with Iran. UKIP rejects the notion that the Iranian nuclear deal was a ‘success for EU diplomacy’ and opposes its attempted use by the EU as a justification for the further development of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, trade policy should be a matter for Member States and not the EU Commission. There are serious human rights concerns, both domestically in Iran and throughout the Middle East, propagated by the Iranian regime proxies. We have supported articles that purely discuss human rights and rejected those that contain calls for the EU to take action. This is more effectively left to appropriate international institutions and individual states.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report encouraging a renewed relationship between the EU and Iran to ensure a more stable region and effective implementation of the nuclear deal without compromising on the human rights situation in Iran concerning amongst others the detention of political prisoners and women’s rights. Parliament believes all sides are now responsible for ensuring the strict and full implementation of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA).

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Iran nuclear deal is certainly a great diplomatic success that brings back to the negotiating table a regional player fundamental to the balance of the entire Middle East, such as Iran, perhaps one of the few successes of recent years. In fact, I voted in favour: a vote to encourage the progress that the current Haroni-led executive is making in the country. A vote that, however, does not forget the serious human rights situation, which does not forget the use of the death penalty even on minors, although, remember, it is certainly not the country with the highest number in the world, that is China, but it seems that many people forget it when it comes to the example of the ES MES China; it does not forget censorship either and does not forget holocaust denial. I believe, however, that we need a positive attitude, an attitude that led to the conclusion of the Treaty itself, an attitude that we must preserve so that the moderate wing prevails in its battle against the conservative wing.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the Howitt report because I believe that it has been a remarkable achievement for European diplomacy responsible for ensuring its strict and full implementation of the agreements concluded, but also for maintaining the spirit of the negotiations that benefit the people of Iran and the European Union. The report is the result of a long work done in the Foreign Affairs Committee and has been adopted in the spirit of compromise between the main political groups in Parliament. I hope that the adoption of this report will help to promote the gradual expansion of cooperation in a climate of confidence, especially for the benefit of the people of Iran and the European Union.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because I did not find it enough balanced. Yes, there is a progress in our relation with Iran, there is a deal reached in the area of nuclear, but this does not mean we should be blind to the fact that human rights are not fully respected in this country. The EU should remain critical on these issues and not to pretend the problems do not exist. They did not disappear after the nuclear agreement was reached.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report contains the European Parliament's contribution to the development of relations between the European Union and Iran, one year after the agreement on nuclear power signed between the Middle East country and the international community was reached. The report, for which I voted in favour, supports the agreement, which is an example of multilateral dialogue, achieved thanks to the contribution of Vice-President Mogherini, who had the difficult task of overseeing and implementing the outcome of the negotiations. I am convinced that cooperation with Iran offers great potential in areas such as trade, environmental protection, aviation safety and academic exchanges. I am pleased that the report has understood the need to relax diplomatic relations between Iran and Saudi Arabia in order to stabilise the political situation in the Middle East. I hope, however, that the start of lasting cooperation will be the starting point for a decisive improvement in the human rights situation in the country. There are still too many cases of executions, the detention of political prisoners and other serious violations of human rights in Iran.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote in favour of the report and welcome the opening up of relations with Iran. At the same time, we note that the development of EU-Iran relations must go hand in hand with the implementation of the Nuclear Agreement (JCPOA), while recalling that, in accordance with the provisions of the agreement, Iran's non-implementation may lead to the reintroduction of sanctions.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the European Union's strategy towards Iran following the nuclear agreement. I believe that we must be careful in our movements and, as the proposals in this report are moving in the right direction, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the agreements that have been reached, I recognise that this has not been easy and I hope that the text adopted will make it possible to achieve in full the objectives set by both sides. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, the International Nuclear Energy Agreement concluded with Iran in Vienna on 14 July 2015, represents an historic turning point in diplomatic relations, as well as a success of the European modus operandi. All this will only be true if there is strict contact on multilateral issues with civil society actors and NGOs, since an increase in trade relations is essential from the completion of the reforms promised by Iran. New fruitful outlets will only be opened up for our businesses if the Islamic Republic of Iran liberalises its economic system (currently 70% of the economy is in state hands). It should be considered that investment opportunities are present in several areas, primarily the energy sector, given the great potential of renewable energies. With regard to the role of iran as a stabiliser in the region, however, it represents an urgent need for the entire international community, which can only be achieved by adopting reforms on human rights and fundamental freedoms carried out by the Islamic Republic.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (PACG or Nuclear Agreement) should pursue the important objective of blocking Iran's nuclear military empowerment, but it should also include a generic dimension that allows closer political, economic (trade) or regional security and stability to be established. I express myself head-on against the application of the death penalty, either in absolute terms or in terms of its specific application to children under eighteen. I believe in the importance of establishing an EU delegation in Tehran as a way to improve the perception of the Iranian people about the EU and increase sectoral cooperation. On the economic front, despite the size of the Iranian market, we cannot disregard the urgency of combating the flow of funding to terrorist organisations, safeguarding the fundamental rights of workers (essential for supporting the country's membership of the WTO) or the need to open up the Internet. I would remind you that opportunities in the field of energy must take into account environmental concerns. I agree overall with the proposed resolution, but I would have appreciated that it was stronger in defending fundamental rights, so I abstained in the final vote.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I believe that the nuclear agreement (JCPOA) with Iran was an important achievement for European diplomacy and that it is now also Europe's responsibility not only to ensure its full implementation, but also to support the opening of EU-Iran relations for the benefit of both sides by strengthening bilateral and multilateral cooperation in a climate of mutual trust.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report aims to define the Union's strategy on Iran following the nuclear agreement signed in 2015, a permanent agreement between the parties to lift sanctions imposed on Iran by the United States, the Union and the United Nations, and Iran limits its long-term nuclear program. The report has positive but also negative elements, such as not asking for the full lifting of US sanctions or which, as is customary in Union reports and resolutions, is the hypocrisy of asking for the human rights of refugees and asylum seekers to be respected, when in its own territory the Union systematically infringes them. Despite this, I voted in favour as the report supports a return to active diplomacy and cooperation with Iran, based on mutual respect for international norms and principles, and recalls that "it is not intended to interfere in a country's domestic political elections". Moreover, the report argues that Iran can act as a mediator to seek a peaceful solution to the Syrian conflict. For all this, my vote has been positive.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement on Iran's nuclear programme has allowed diplomatic and trade relations between Iran and the international community to be reopened, thanks to the lifting of all nuclear-related sanctions against the Republic of Iran following the implementation of the commitments made in the agreement. This will not only improve EU-Iran relations from a political, economic and cultural point of view, but will also strengthen the country's role in regional stabilisation. This increased area of cooperation between Iran and the EU in order to address issues of mutual interest must not, however, neglect respect for human rights. I voted in favour of this resolution because, on the one hand, it takes into account the opportunities for cooperation between the EU and Iran - for example, promoting interparliamentary dialogue, setting up an Iranian task force by the EEAS to coordinate Iran's different lines of action, contributing to EU energy security and increasing trade to achieve Iran's target of an annual growth rate of 8%; on the other hand, it reiterates the EU's opposition to the death penalty, regardless of the circumstances and circumstances, and stresses that the abolition of this practice is a key objective of the EU's foreign policy and human rights.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Iranian nuclear agreement was a remarkable achievement for European diplomacy in particular, which not only improved relations between the EU and Iran, but also helped to promote stability throughout the region. Lifting all sanctions on nuclear activities imposed on the Islamic Republic of Iran allows for a re-launch of cooperation with Iran, which will create opportunities and benefits for both parties involved.  EU-Iran relations must develop at the same time as the nuclear agreement is implemented. Iran has the second largest economy in the Middle East, with a nominal GDP estimated at $397 billion in 2015, and EU-Iran trade currently stands at about $8 billion, estimated to quadruple it over the next two years.  I voted to respect the commitment made to Iran by lifting economic and financial sanctions, which will also lead to the resolution of the security crisis in the region.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – The report provides a comprehensive description of EU-Iran relations on the basis of a number of aspects. Following the Iran nuclear agreement and internal political developments in Iran, Parliament believes that there is now an opportunity to reform the country and improve relations with the European Union. The EU and Iran have decided to confront issues affecting both sides in a constructive manner; calls, therefore, for an EU strategy to re-engage Iran in cooperation, which could initially be based on confidence-building measures. Building the parliamentary dimension of EU-Iran relations is essential as part of a strategy to restore mutual trust. Despite the encouraging direction of the development of future relations, e.g. Parliament's support for Iran's membership of the WTO, the resolution states that, in addition to the booming economic relations and cooperation, the issue of the rule of law, democracy and human rights should be kept on the agenda beyond socio-economic issues; including the issue of the death penalty. Furthermore, the EP is concerned about the increase in the number of people imprisoned for belonging to or believing in a religious minority group; calls, therefore, on the Iranian authorities to respect the rights and legal protection of the rights of religious and ethnic minorities.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report, which I feel sets out the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement has been concluded in an inaccurate and vague manner. I believe that, on such important issues, we cannot afford to compromise. In return for the lifting of drastic sanctions against Iran, the EU has promised to curb nuclear activities. I do not understand the optimism with which the rapporteur assesses the ROLE of the EU in terms of nuclear arrangements and relations with the country. Bearing in mind the situation in the Middle East, human rights violations and regional conflicts, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which provides a balanced message about the EU’s relations with Iran. I believe that this report will offer the required support to HR Mogherini during her overseeing of the implementation of the nuclear deal, trust-building and expansion of relations in areas of mutual interest. However, we must ensure that Iran lives up to its international commitments on human rights. Having said that, we need to make sure that the number of executions in this country are addressed and all political prisoners released.

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE)
text: In writing. The draft report aims to normalise relations between the European Union and Iran after the signing of the Vienna nuclear agreements in July 2015.  The report as voted is good, balanced and relatively comprehensive. It makes recommendations for enhanced political dialogue, economic and trade cooperation, better cooperation on regional security in the Middle East and negotiations on social issues, such as the rule of law, democracy and human rights. The eleven amendments I tabled, including on the Iranian regime in power and Iran's foreign policy, were adopted in the Committee on Foreign Affairs and significantly improved the content of the text.  In the plenary vote, I did not vote in favour of certain human rights amendments. Indeed, most of these amendments are already included several times in the text. The others are not intended to be included in this type of report.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The signing of the historic nuclear agreement with Iran – the undisputed success of European diplomacy and the result of the work carried out by High Representative Federica Mogherini – has led to a gradual normalisation and a significant improvement in bilateral relations between the EU and Iran. An agreement that also had the merit of reopening the Iranian market to European companies, especially for Italian companies that moved in advance in the months immediately following the lifting of sanctions. In this new scenario, which I hope will allow further strengthening of economic cooperation to mutual benefit and increased regional stability, the Union will have to be able to take advantage of the many opportunities and opportunities that are offered to us – at the moment the EU's trade with Iran stands at 8 billion dollars, but is expected to quadruple in absolute value over the next two years. In particular, our country, with bonds of friendship and established trade relations, will thus be able to have the ambition to return to being Iran's main trading partner.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Union's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement signed on 14 July 2015. While recalling our concerns and differences on the death penalty, especially for minors, and on human rights, this report lays the groundwork for future relations between the European Union and Iran and identifies common priorities, namely strengthening political dialogue, trade and cooperation in the field of energy, aviation safety. , migration, regional issues, the fight against drugs or education, research and innovation.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report "THE EU strategy on Iran following the nuclear agreement" points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, which will enable stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region to be furthered. At the same time, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions may be reintroduced. In the area of respect for human rights, the report reiterates the Union's firm and principled position towards the death penalty. In this sense, it strongly condemns Iran for the frequent use of the death penalty and calls for an immediate moratorium on their execution. Given that the long-term aim of this report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour of it.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The strategy recognises the economic and political benefits for Iran and the EU following the Iran nuclear deal and the lifting of sanctions.  The line taken by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy supports both the advancement of economic trade and respect for human rights, particularly with regard to the death penalty. Iran is the country with the highest per capita rate of executions in the world, which practises the hanging of homosexuals and the stoning of women. The strategy calls for the abolition of the death penalty for children and drug traffickers. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the strategy.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the final version of this report, which sets out a number of principles in the framework of the European Union's relations with Iran after the nuclear agreement, as the issue of human rights, respect for women and freedom of expression could have been introduced after the parliamentary drafting. Iran is a central player in the region. It must be able to constitute, beyond the mere status of economic and commercial partner, a factor of stability and a power of peace, but its governance must evolve towards a true republic that is not under the influence of the religious in power.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I was unable to vote in favour of the report on the European Union's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement, because the report was completely unbalanced. Of course, we must welcome the nuclear agreement, which is a great success story for multilateral diplomacy, and European diplomacy in particular. Of course, this agreement will bring benefits to both sides, by offering European companies the prospect of re-entering the Iranian market. But just because the Iranian regime has ceased to be a nuclear offender does not mean that we must award it a prize for democratic and humanistic honour. Iran is now the world champion in terms of the number of executions in relation to its population. Under President Rouhani, more than 2,700 prisoners were executed. Iran executes children, in violation of the signed UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which it prohibits the application of the death penalty to young offenders. And I cannot understand why Members of the European Parliament were able to vote against an amendment to denounce it. Co-operate with Iran, yes, close your eyes, no!

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Iran's signing of the nuclear agreement in 2015 marked a turning point in relations between Iran and the international community. The Union must take this opportunity to lay the foundations for a renewed partnership with Tehran. Dialogue must be comprehensive, cooperative, critical and constructive. The Union has the opportunity to renew and develop its economic, trade and energy relations with Iran. A normalization of diplomatic relations with the Iranian government would encourage the country to support international initiatives to find political solutions to the conflicts in the region. Iran is an influential player and its mediation could prove valuable in resolving the Syrian crisis. This does not mean that Iran is still not complying with its human rights obligations to date. 966 executions were recorded in 2015, some of which involved minors at the time of the incident, contrary to the international convention on the rights of the child, of which Iran is a party.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is the European Parliament's reaction to the Iran-U.S. nuclear agreement. It undermines our sovereignty, as do all other European Union reports on foreign affairs. Nevertheless, I abstained, in view of the rare honesty of this report on the substance of the subject.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The signing of the agreement with Iran is a huge step forward in normalizing our relations with this country. I fully support the lifting of sanctions against Iran. These sanctions were an expression of the EU's own foreign policy, supporting not the interests of EU Member States but those of the US and Israel. However, I have decided to vote against the resolution on the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement, as I do not agree with some extreme statements in the text, such as that a comprehensive agreement with Iran should be signed requiring the country to accept Western norms and values and change its device and traditions. We have seen what the imposition of Western values on countries such as Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya has led to, and this is happening in Syria at the moment.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The way in which the Union wants to develop relations with Iran is wrong and serves mainly corporate interests and not the interests of the Member States and their citizens. The Union must refrain from intervening in the internal affairs of third countries. We believe that the suggestions about the justice system and how the internet works in Iran are more than unnecessary. International relations are a part that the Member States have to handle on their own, as the interests of each other differ in different ways.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – The REPORT ON THE EU Strategy for Iran following the Nuclear Agreement points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, enabling stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region to be promoted. At the same time, however, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions could be reintroduced. In the area of respect for human rights, the report reiterates the Union's firm and principled position towards the death penalty. In this sense, it strongly condemns Iran for the frequent use of the death penalty and calls for an immediate moratorium on their implementation.  Given that the long-term aim of this report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour of it.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. I acknowledge that the agreement on Iran's nuclear program in 2015 was a historic milestone in the country's relationship with the West. However, much still needs to be done in that country, particularly on issues relating to the death penalty, the military stability of that region, rights, freedoms and guarantees.  The steps taken so far are not enough for the EU to deepen its trade and political ties with Iran. The resolution of humanitarian disasters and latent conflicts in that region is an essential condition for moving forward with negotiations and conversions.  I therefore vote against it.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: this report, like all EU reports on foreign affairs, constitutes an attack on the sovereignty of states.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report deals with relations between the EU and Iran after the nuclear agreement concluded. About a year ago, Iran signed an agreement on Iran's nuclear program with six powers (THE US, France, Britain, Russia, China, Germany) that allowed the lifting of heavy sanctions imposed. The U.S. maintains the blockade.   Iran is a country of enormous geostrategic importance. He has influence in the Middle East and the Gulf region. It is the second largest economy in the Middle East and North Africa. It has the second largest gas reserves in the world and the fourth largest oil reserves. It also has enormous potential for solar energy exploration, interests that move the EU. Although we follow the report on the need to establish relations, we distance ourselves from the view of external interference and interference to which the report seeks to condition these relations: structural, judicial and democratic reforms. A vision aimed at feeding abroad, regime changes, which aim not the interests and legitimate aspirations of the Iranian people, but to meet the EU's economic and political objectives to destabilise and control the Middle East. In addition, the total bleaching of reality and distinct responsibilities and roles of those involved in the conflicts of that region. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution because I believe that the nuclear agreement concluded between the European Union and Iran does not present sufficient clarity on the impact it may have in the Middle East, with particular reference to the conflict between Iran and Saudi Arabia, the Syrian agreement and relations with Israel.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report in question represents the European Parliament's contribution to the development of relations between the European Union and Iran following the signing last year of a landmark agreement on the use of nuclear weapons between Iran and the international community. We must focus on areas where the European Union and Iran can cooperate in the future. This is particularly the case in the areas of trade, environmental protection, aviation safety and many others. Iran and Saudi Arabia must work in the future to improve relations and de-escalate tensions. It is very important that we also focus together on the situation of respect for fundamental human rights in Iran, as well as on ending the abuse of the death penalty institute and limiting the number of executions. Iran should respect and cooperate as far as possible with UN mechanisms to guarantee the protection of human rights.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The way in which the Union wants to develop relations with Iran is wrong and serves mainly corporate interests instead of the interests of the Member States and their citizens. The Union must refrain from intervening in the internal affairs of third countries. I think that the suggestions about the justice system and how the internet works in Iran are more than unnecessary. International relations are an area that Member States must handle on their own, as the interests of each other differ in various ways. For these reasons I am voting against the report on the EU strategy towards Iran following the nuclear agreement.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We must be at the forefront of the EU’s normalisation of relations with Iran. In line with this approach, we should support the leading role the HR/VP Mogherini in overseeing the implementation of the nuclear deal, trust-building and expansion of relations in areas of mutual interest. At the same time, we should emphasise the need for Iran to live up to its international commitments on human rights, and in particular, drastically reduce the number of executions and release all political prisoners.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Strategy for Iran after the Nuclear Agreement report points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, which will enable stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region to be promoted. At the same time, however, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions could be reintroduced. In the area of respect for human rights, the report reiterates the Union's firm and principled position towards the death penalty.  The report strongly condemns Iran for the frequent use of the death penalty and calls for an immediate moratorium on their implementation. Given that the long-term aim of this report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour of it.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
