text: Writing. \u2012 The report "THE EU strategy on Iran following the nuclear agreement" points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, which will enable stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region to be furthered. At the same time, however, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions could be reintroduced.  In the area of respect for human rights, the report reiterates the Union's firm and principled position towards the death penalty. In this sense, it strongly condemns Iran for the frequent use of the death penalty and calls for an immediate moratorium on their execution. Given that the long-term aim of this report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report considering that the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan was an important achievement for multilateral diplomacy and European diplomacy that will not only significantly improve relations between Iran and the Union, but also promote stability throughout the region. All parties must now ensure strict compliance with the agreements reached. From this moment on, we must constructively address the issues of concern to both sides, fostering mutual trust to pave the way, for more meaningful long-term cooperation, always acting for the defence of the interests and values of the Union, in particular respect for democracy, the rule of law and human rights in Iran.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which represents further development of EU-Iran relations one year after the nuclear agreement between the international community and Iran. The report describes areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation security, academic exchanges, etc. And he deals extensively with the regional situation in the Middle East, sending the message, especially to Iran and Saudi Arabia, about the need to appease tensions and carry out diplomatic normalization. In addition, the report covers the human rights situation in Iran, emphasizing the Union's opposition to the death penalty and criticizing Iran for the very high number of executions and other human rights violations, such as arrests of dual EU-Iranian citizens, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression Etc. The report specifically calls on Iran to cooperate fully with UN human rights mechanisms.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which represents further development of EU-Iran relations one year after the nuclear agreement between the international community and Iran. The report describes areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation security, academic exchanges, etc. And he deals extensively with the regional situation in the Middle East, sending the message, especially to Iran and Saudi Arabia, about the need to appease tensions and carry out diplomatic normalization. In addition, the report covers the human rights situation in Iran, emphasizing the Union's opposition to the death penalty and criticizing Iran for the very high number of executions and other human rights violations, such as arrests of dual EU-Iranian citizens, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression Etc. The report specifically calls on Iran to cooperate fully with UN human rights mechanisms.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank Mr Howitt for drafting this important report on the development of Europe-Iran relations since the nuclear agreement a year ago. I would also like to highlight and recall the important work of Federica Mogherini as chairman of the joint committee responsible for assessing the implementation of the agreement. The report highlights the different possible areas of cooperation with Iran, in particular trade, the environment, universities and aviation security. These areas of cooperation must not, however, be developed without concealing or concealing the many cases of human rights violations reported in Iran, and the Howitt report is therefore right to call for a concrete commitment to the implementation of international standards, in particular on the rights of oppositions, detainees and a moratorium on the death penalty.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement because I consider this to be a historic, fundamental and decisive agreement for world peace. Indeed, I believe that the EU's contribution to reaching the agreement and the work of high representative Federica Mogherini have been decisive in achieving this positive outcome. I therefore share the view contained in it that this agreement represents a success of multilateral diplomacy, although it must be implemented, but it can open the way to strong cooperation between Iran and the EU in many areas, such as energy sources, trade, environmental issues and aviation safety. Iran is in fact the middle east's second largest economy, and European investment will be key to accelerating the country's transition. Let us not forget, however, the problem of security and the balance of the region, and I therefore call on Iran and Saudi Arabia to enter into a dialogue for peace, avoiding any form of hostility and putting an end to the atrocities committed in various areas of the Middle East. Finally, we strongly call on Iran, as an indispensable condition for any further rapprochement, to pay greater attention to respect for human rights, freedoms and civil rights, and we will continue to monitor these behaviour closely.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the EU's strategy towards Iran following the conclusion of the nuclear agreement. While I welcome the successful efforts of the EEAS and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy in this international process and recognise them – I would even say that Europe has been in a constructive leadership role here for years – I do not share the absolute agreement with the outcome of the negotiations. Problems remain which, despite all the economic and political détente with Iran, we must continue to pursue.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome closer cooperation between Iran and the European Union. After the Iranian Government has cleared the way for a closer partnership by signing the nuclear agreement, the European Union should recognise and seize the historic opportunity and recognise Iran as a partner. For example, a further political dialogue with Iran should be conducted, with human rights violations and the abolition of the death penalty also playing a central role in Iran. Furthermore, the lifting of sanctions against Iran has created new trade and investment opportunities for European corporations in Iran that should be exercised. Further close cooperation between the European Union and Iran is also needed in the area of a regional security strategy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it endorses a step-by-step reopening of political, economic and human rights relations between Europe and Iran, and states that the European Union should play an enhanced diplomatic role to de-escalate tensions between Tehran and Riyadh, and promote the idea of a new regional security structure for the Middle East, one based on the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) model in Europe.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a text which I believe is in the sense of building a common and standardised agenda between the Union and Iran, based on respect for sovereignty, multilateralism in the resolution of disputes, the joint search for processes that lead to progress in respect for human rights, the sustainable and sustainable development of the Iranian people and peace and security for all peoples of the Middle East. I am opposed, however, to Iran's consideration as a source of regional instability, to the establishment of relations guided predominantly by commercial criteria, to the presentation of trade liberalization per se as a panacea for the development of peoples such as The Iranian (who participate under asymmetrical and subordinate conditions in the global market) and to the use of fossil and nuclear energy as the basis of any country's productive and energy matrix.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it endorses a step-by-step reopening of political, economic and human rights relations between Europe and Iran, and says the European Union should play an enhanced diplomatic role to de-escalate tensions between Tehran and Riyadh, and promote the idea of a new regional security structure for the Middle East based on the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) model in Europe.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement. This agreement is a notable success story of multilateral diplomacy, and european diplomacy in particular, which will improve EU-Iran relations, but also contribute to stability throughout the region. All parties are now responsible for its strict and comprehensive implementation; I hope it will be applied scrupulously. EU-Iran cooperation, particularly in the energy sector, must have as a systematic objective to improve environmental, social and economic benefits both in Iran and in the EU. While I condemn Iran's frequent use of the death penalty and other practices that violate human rights, it is essential to build a real dialogue between the EU and Iran. Finally, I would like to point out that I voted against some amendments tabled by other political groups because they were merely repeating what was already in the report, particularly on the defence of human rights.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The Iran Nuclear Deal was a notable achievement for multilateral diplomacy, and for European diplomacy in particular. The report stresses that trade and renewed access to the global rule-based trading system is a potential way to break Iran’s isolation, and that trade could be an important tool for strengthening the political dialogue and stimulating cooperation among countries in the region, with a view to increasing regional development, employment and stability in the wider region.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. "We Swedish Social Democrats welcome last year's nuclear agreement with Iran as an important step towards making the region and the world a safer place. We think it is important that the EU now sets out responsibly what the conditions are, and what requirements should be made, in order to make a constructive future relationship with the country possible. That is why we chose to vote in favour of the report on a strategy towards Iran after the deal. We would like to emphasise that respect for human rights must necessarily be the first and always guiding all eu relations with third countries, as the report on Iran also took note of. However, since we took the view that, despite their focus on human rights, several of the amendments did not add anything new, but rather reiterated what was already in the text, we chose not to vote in favour of them.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which represents further development of EU-Iran relations one year after the nuclear agreement between the international community and Iran. The report describes areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation security, academic exchanges, etc. And he deals extensively with the regional situation in the Middle East, sending the message, especially to Iran and Saudi Arabia, about the need to appease tensions and carry out diplomatic normalization. In addition, the report covers the human rights situation in Iran, emphasizing the Union's opposition to the death penalty and criticizing Iran for the very high number of executions and other human rights violations, such as arrests of dual EU-Iranian citizens, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression Etc. The report specifically calls on Iran to cooperate fully with UN human rights mechanisms.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Strategy for Iran after the Nuclear Agreement report points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, which will enable stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region to be promoted. At the same time, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions may be reintroduced. Given that the long-term objective of the report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns the EU's strategy towards Iran following the nuclear agreement. The agreement is a positive development, which we have also welcomed. We are in favour of a closer relationship between the EU and Iran, but we do not overlook the human rights situation in the country, the use of the death penalty, the violation of freedom of opinion and political persecution. These are very serious issues, in which any concessions cannot be made for the sake of any commercial and economic interests. We have abstained on this report, because in many respects it is trying to serve precisely these interests and not a relationship that will be beneficial to the people of Iran.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report for a number of reasons. Overall, the compromises do not reflect the present reality in Iran.  Likewise, there is a clear lack of balance in tone and substance when it comes to serious problems such as human rights violations, corruption, and the role of Iran in the region, in particular concerning its support for the Assad regime. Instead, there is too much emphasis on trade and investment, especially since there is already an opinion from Committee on International Trade covering those aspects in detail. I, along with my colleagues in ALDE, submitted a number of amendments to the report aimed at rebalancing the text and putting more emphasis on human rights, stronger condemnation of Iran’s negative role in the Middle East (particularly in Syria). Unfortunately, these amendments did not pass and therefore I was unable to support the report. Additionally, the wording on the death penalty, free and fair elections, protection of religious minorities and torture should be much stronger.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report outlining the future direction of the EU strategy towards Iran contains some positive elements, such as the importance of sectoral cooperation and the stabilisation of Iran's role in the region. However, due to the abysmal violation of human rights in Iran and the unconditional support of the Assad regime in the Syrian war, I, together with other members of the Alliance for Progress and Awakening, have decided to vote against the report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted AGAINST the Report on the EU Strategy towards Iran after the Nuclear Agreement (2015/2274(INI)), following the position of the ALDE Group, as the document did not take into account some proposals relevant to the ALDE Group.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Like all european Union reports on foreign affairs, it undermines the sovereignty of Member States and Iran. I note, however, the honest work of Mr. Howitt, which is sure to be controversial. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Richard Howitt's report on the EU's strategy towards Iran following the nuclear deal. The text is a first step towards normalizing relations with Iran for better implementation of the Iran nuclear deal signed in 2015. I support this initiative which demonstrates the EU's willingness to deepen and expand its relations with Iran in many areas without leaving room for our competitors. The agreement thus provides for enhanced economic and trade cooperation, better cooperation on regional security and negotiations on social issues such as human rights, a prerequisite for the signing of this text. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported Mr Howitt's approach as it is important for the EU to show a common and harmonised strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement. It is important that the rule of law and democratic principles are respected and that political dialogue is enforced for further developments. The respect of human rights is to be safeguarded and promoted. Relative reforms are welcome and that spirit should be part of all deals, trade or FDI-related, and international cooperation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the report. It is an important and right step towards further normalising, deepening and maximising economic potential in mutual interest between the European Union and Iran.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The religious dictatorship of Iran has a long track record of deception, breaking its international commitments and trying to obtain weapons of mass destruction. Therefore, any initiative to radically normalise relations with such a regime must be based on clear conditionality between developing economic relations on one hand and Iran’s progress in the field of human rights on the other hand. This crucial nexus was absent from the report in question. It remained unbalanced, full of wishful thinking and overdue optimism. Advancing first and foremost the economic interests will result in benefits for big EU companies and help Iran’s regime to survive, but can do little if anything to guarantee civil rights and rule of law. It is ironic that the rapporteur has tried to associate sound criticism of the report with ‘lobbying interests’. The opposite could be more true. The impact of powerful lobbyists might have made the text so ambiguous and generous for clerical dictators that any serious demands for genuine change in their behaviour on human rights were watered down. Therefore, after five amendments submitted by 76 Members were narrowly defeated, I had no option but to remain in harmony with my better conscience and to vote against the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it endorses a step-by-step reopening of political, economic and human rights relations between Europe and Iran, and says the European Union should play an enhanced diplomatic role to de-escalate tensions between Tehran and Riyadh, and promote the idea of a new regional security structure for the Middle East based on the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) model in Europe.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement. Iran is the second largest economy in the Middle East region, and it is crucial for the stability of the region that good relations between the EU and Iran develop. This dialogue opens up space for debates on the country's democratic leadership, human rights and a common vision of possible future cooperation. In general, there is scope for communication on many levels with a country that has been isolated so far, and I see this as a good step. Moreover, Iran can be a key partner in resolving the conflicts in Syria and Yemen, which is why it is good to develop relations with each other.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 "EU strategy on Iran after the nuclear agreement" points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, enabling stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region. At the same time, however, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions could be reintroduced.  In the area of respect for human rights, the report reiterates the Union's firm and principled position towards the death penalty. In this sense, it strongly condemns Iran for the frequent use of the death penalty and calls for an immediate moratorium on their execution. Given that the long-term aim of this report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Significant changes have taken place in Iran, which has led to a great deal of improvement in the country's international image. Instead of the previous high degree of isolation, there is now real competition between the EU, the US, China and Russia over who can build better economic and political relations with Iran. Everyone's there when the market is redebuted. This is also reflected in the tone of the report, which strikes a friendly tone in addition to the mostly moderate and real-world criticism. It is yet to be seen whether the former regional superpower, which has thousands of years of cultural bases, will take its rightful place, but they are on a seemingly perisable compromise path.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), also known as the Agreement on Iran's nuclear programme, is a remarkable achievement that should not only lead to a significant improvement in EU-Iran relations, but also promote stability throughout the region. Both sides must work closely together on bilateral and multilateral issues to ensure more stability in the region and effective implementation of the nuclear agreement. I believe that relations between the EU and Iran should be developed through a multi-layered dialogue involving political, diplomatic, economic, academic and people-to-people contacts, which include civil society representatives and human rights defenders. Trade and renewed access to the global trading system provide an opportunity to overcome Iran's isolation. This can be an important tool for strengthening political dialogue and stimulating cooperation between countries in the region, with a view to accelerating regional development and increasing employment and stability in the wider region. I call for full gender equality, I welcome attempts to draft a law to protect women from violence and I hope that the newly elected Parliament will consider legislation that fully criminalises violence against women.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 No doubt the completion of the nuclear agreement with Iran is a great success for the international community. On the one hand, it represents a triumph of diplomacy over the proliferation of nuclear weapons and, on the other hand, serves as a good basis for developing cooperation and constructive dialogue between the European Union and Iran. In fact, the European Union and Iran can cooperate in a number of areas, with a focus on the development of trade. However, concrete steps are needed to promote it. Iran needs to work and focus on respecting human rights, improving the situation of ethnic minorities, ensuring free internet access and abolishing the death penalty. In addition, the country must focus on reforms by liberalizing its economy and improving the country's business climate. I believe that in the long term, deepening EU-Iran relations will contribute to promoting peace and stability throughout the region, including the resolution of the military conflicts in Syria and Yemen.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. With this report, Parliament is encouraging the Eu ropean Union to establish a relationship of trust with Iran, leading to cooperation based on common interests, and reiterates the need for all Member States to work closely with Iran in order to create a stable relationship aimed at the effective implementation of the nuclear agreement. In addition, the report highlights the current situation in Iran, recalling that iran hosts the largest number of refugees in the world and, with reference to the recent UN report, expressing concerns about the degree of protection of human rights and calling for the measures proposed by the UN General Assembly to be implemented and for international laws to be respected. Following this, I am voting in favour of Mr Howitt's report.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to stimulate a new dynamic in relations between the European Union and Iran. This will ultimately allow us to strengthen our economic and commercial ties with this country. I think it is important to stress that this frank relationship will not obscure the subjects on which we have profound differences, for example with regard to human rights.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Iran has gradually established itself as a key player in the Middle East. As a demographic and energy power in the region, Iran managed the feat of dealing with the United States in Iraq and with the Russians in Syria at the same time. Its positioning does not go without criticism, but from Damascus in Syria to Sanaa in Yemen, through Hezbollah in Lebanon, Iran is part of the political solution to the ongoing conflicts. The gradual lifting of sanctions following the nuclear agreement allows it to return to the international scene and eventually it is a huge market that can reopen to European companies. This commercial enthusiasm, however, must not overshadow the necessary advances on human rights and Iran's accountability on the diplomatic scene. This great country must now use its renewed status as a regional power to stabilize the region and progress must be made in terms of human rights. That is why, while I supported the text, I also supported the amendments calling for the release of political prisoners, the cessation of executions of minors, and a link between improved human rights and economic relations.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which represents further development of EU-Iran relations one year after the nuclear agreement between the international community and Iran. The report describes areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation security, academic exchanges, etc. And he deals extensively with the regional situation in the Middle East, sending the message, especially to Iran and Saudi Arabia, about the need to appease tensions and carry out diplomatic normalization. In addition, the report covers the human rights situation in Iran, emphasizing the Union's opposition to the death penalty and criticizing Iran for the very high number of executions and other human rights violations, such as arrests of dual EU-Iranian citizens, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression Etc. The report specifically calls on Iran to cooperate fully with UN human rights mechanisms.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which represents further development of EU-Iran relations one year after the nuclear agreement between the international community and Iran. The report describes areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation security, academic exchanges, etc. And he deals extensively with the regional situation in the Middle East, sending the message, especially to Iran and Saudi Arabia, about the need to appease tensions and carry out diplomatic normalization. In addition, the report covers the human rights situation in Iran, emphasizing the Union's opposition to the death penalty and criticizing Iran for the very high number of executions and other human rights violations, such as arrests of dual EU-Iranian citizens, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression Etc. The report specifically calls on Iran to cooperate fully with UN human rights mechanisms.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to define the Union's strategy on Iran following the nuclear agreement signed in 2015, a permanent agreement between the parties to lift sanctions imposed on Iran by the United States, the Union and the United Nations, and Iran limits its long-term nuclear program. The report has positive but also negative elements, such as not asking for the full lifting of US sanctions or which, as is customary in Union reports and resolutions, is the hypocrisy of asking for the human rights of refugees and asylum seekers to be respected, when in its own territory the Union systematically infringes them. Despite this, I voted in favour as the report supports a return to active diplomacy and cooperation with Iran, based on mutual respect for international norms and principles, and recalls that "it is not intended to interfere in a country's domestic political elections". Moreover, the report argues that Iran can act as a mediator to seek a peaceful solution to the Syrian conflict. For all this, my vote has been positive.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This European Parliament resolution highlights the new opportunity to bring about reforms in Iran and improve its relations with the Union after the conclusion of the nuclear agreement and internal changes in iran.  Such relations must seek the effective implementation of that agreement and allow it to ensure a more stable region. Thus, it proposes that trade can serve both to end Iran's international isolation, as well as to strengthen political dialogue and encourage cooperation between countries in the region, with a view to regional development, employment and stability throughout the region. However, in this new framework which opens up in relations between the two entities, the Union cannot renounce its values and must continue to promote human rights, democracy, the rule of law and the abolition of the death penalty. I underline Parliament's demand that some representatives of the Iranian regime stop attacking Israel with their statements. I am voting in favour of the report, because we will be able to improve trade relations with the second largest economy in the Middle East and protect European investment, without leaving aside our values, which we will continue to defend.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report outlining the future direction of the EU strategy towards Iran contains some positive elements, such as the importance of sectoral cooperation and the stabilisation of Iran's role in the region. However, due to the abysmal violation of human rights in Iran and the unconditional support of the Assad regime in the Syrian war, I, together with other members of the Alliance for Progress and Awakening, have decided to vote against the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of improving EU relations with Iran to strengthen stability in the region and to ensure the effective implementation of the Nuclear Deal.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report "calls on the EU and its Member States to explore the possibility of using export credit guarantees in order to encourage trade, project financing and investment in Iran." I am against state guarantees for private investment abroad. This type of guarantee encourages companies to take risks at the expense of the taxpayer. The report "calls on the Commission to increase the amount of money spent on iranian students participating in the Erasmus programme." I see no reason why the European taxpayer should subsidise the travel of Iranian students to SCHOOLS in the EU.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to thank rapporteur Richard Howitt for a very balanced report. This report stresses all positive changes that have happened in Iran recently and outlines future cooperation between EU and Iran but, on the other side, it contains criticisms and highlights the challenges that we face. In spite of some unsolved problems, I would like to say that it is a success story for our diplomacy. In recent years European and Iranian diplomacy managed to raise our relations from a very low point and to give them a positive trend. The European Parliament should play an important role in the process of establishing friendly cooperation framework with Iran in which we can achieve positive results in the issues we are interested in or resolve problems we are concerned about. In this way we should be wise and patient and try to avoid a temptation to use offensive language.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The July 2015 nuclear agreement with Iran, which lifted sanctions against Iran and committed Iran to long-term curbs on its nuclear programme, also opened the way for the EU to have more intensive relations with the country, which will contribute to peace promotion and respect for human rights and freedoms. Cooperation with Iran can help resolve the conflict in Syria while at the same time tackling terrorism originating in the African continent. Cooperation in the field of trade and the economy will also be possible through political dialogue.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the EU strategy towards Iran following the nuclear agreement for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 October 2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained for this text. With this motion for a resolution, the European Parliament welcomes a "great success of European diplomacy", namely the Iran nuclear agreement. We therefore bear witness once again to the recklessness of the European Union, which seems to ignore the fact that foreign affairs remain the competence of national governments. The resolution therefore constitutes an infringement on our sovereignty. Moreover, this agreement, concluded by the United States, is only for its own interests. On the other hand, the rapporteur has written a relatively honest report by not submitting to pressure from the Liberals and the Greens on the issue of human rights.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the Union's Iran strategy, following the nuclear agreement that will promote cooperation and new opportunities and advantages for both sides, establishing the possibility of reopening the Iranian market to European companies. We need to move forward in this regard as Iran's consideration as a key player in the international energy market will allow synergies to be generated so that the Union can move forward in its commitment to diversify energy resources and develop new technological solutions, renewable energy and energy efficiency. We will also work towards inclusive and gender-balanced growth in Iran, as well as defending the abolition of the death penalty and the release of political prisoners.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft European Parliament resolution on the EU's strategy towards Iran is an important and correct step towards normalising EU-Iran relations. That is why I voted in favour of this draft resolution.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In July 2015, the members of the UN Security Council and Iran finally reached an agreement. It provides for the lifting of sanctions imposed on Iran by the United States, the European Union and the United Nations; in return, Iran restricts its nuclear program. This report supports the agreement and the normalization of relations with Iran. Of course, the aim is to encourage European companies to enter this new market, particularly in energy and transport. I regret that he is not asking the United States for the same thing and welcomes the Iranian agreement with Boeing or supports the country's accession to the WTO! This report, of course, strongly supports a strengthened dialogue with Iran, ending the international isolation of a key regional player in the fight against terrorism and extremism in Syria, Iraq and Saudi Arabia. But it remains ineffective and silent on the actions of the Islamist republic against individual freedoms and on its participation in the causes of war in the Middle East. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (GMA), also known as the Nuclear Agreement with Iran, was a remarkable achievement for multilateral diplomacy, and for European diplomacy in particular, and should allow not only a substantial improvement in relations between the EU and Iran, but also the promotion of stability throughout the region. All parties now have a responsibility to ensure that they are fully and strictly implemented. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the Union’s strategy towards Iran following the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. It is important that we acknowledge the diplomatic success of the JCPOA and build upon its successes in the hope of bringing stability to the region as a whole.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The Nuclear Agreement with Iran was an important turning point in the country's relations with the rest of the world. After all, Iran had gone in the direction of a nuclear race. Thanks to sustained diplomatic pressure and economic sanctions, Iran has finally put away its nuclear plans. The lifting of sanctions and the restoration of relations between Iran and the West opens up opportunities in the interests of both sides. However, a healthy democracy is not the fruit of the success of an efficient economy alone. Building trust with Iran involves more than just picking up economic relations. More trade between the EU and Iran does not mean that we should look away from the lack of democracy, of harrowing violations of human rights and of the fact that the region is still plagued by death and destruction every day. The authors of this report have missed the opportunity to send out stronger signals on respect for human rights, the abolition of the death penalty, the hostile statements about Israel and the need to engage constructively in the region for stability. All this has not been done enough, which is why this report has not received my approval.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Foreign Affairs points out in its report that following the Iran nuclear agreement and internal political developments in Iran, it is possible to reform the country and improve relations with the European Union. To this end, it proposes that Parliament welcome the establishment of the Iran nuclear agreement and proposes parliament's resolution on the issues of political, trade and economic cooperation, regional security, the rule of law, democracy and human rights in the development of the EU strategy on Iran. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the position that the Council's decision to lift all nuclear-related sanctions imposed on the Islamic Republic of Iran, as a result of the implementation of the commitments under the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan, will re-establish relations with Iran and create opportunities and advantages by providing the possibility of reopening the Iranian market to European companies. The eu's various statements to Iran focused on trade and economic ties. I believe that trade and access to regulated global trade are a potential way to break Iran's isolation and can be an important tool for strengthening political dialogue and stimulating cooperation between countries in the region with a view to increasing regional development, employment and stability throughout the region. It is important to stress that Iran needs inclusive growth while maintaining a balance between men and women. It is vital to pay special attention to the situation of women in Iran, as they are subject to legal discrimination, as well as to European women travelling to Iran, who can be deterred from travelling to Iran because of the obligation to wear religious symbols.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is an attack on our sovereignty, as are all EU reports on foreign affairs. However, it should be noted that Mr. Howitt made a relatively honest report. I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which provides political endorsement to the strategy which led to the nuclear agreement (the JCPOA) and the reopening of EU-Iran relations which is integral to that agreement. The report endorses a step-by-step reopening of political, economic and human rights relations between Europe and Iran, and says the European Union should play an enhanced diplomatic role to de-escalate tensions between Tehran and Riyadh, and promote the idea of a new regional security structure for the Middle East based on the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) model in Europe.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this balanced text on the relationship between the European Union and Iran following the Agreement on the Iranian nuclear programme. The resolution underlines on the one hand the great progress iran has made in normalising its relationship with the EU and regaining a place in the international community. On the other hand, it condemns with great firmness, through the amendments I have supported, the calls for the destruction of Israel by some Iranian leaders. She advocates for women's rights and against the death penalty. Finally, I objected to several amendments introduced by the Liberals, including on women's rights, simply because their content was already in the original text.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear deal. The agreement is an important milestone for multilateral diplomacy, which must promote, in accordance with the pacts, the development of Iran's relations with the contracting countries, as well as promote renewed geopolitical stability in the region; In particular, we welcome the establishment of the Joint Committee, composed of representatives of Iran and the E3/EU+3 Group (China, France, Germany, the Russian Federation, the United Kingdom and the United States with the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy). The European Union recognises that lifting sanctions is a necessary condition for the definition of a new era of diplomatic and economic relations with Iran. In this context, it takes note of the detailed guidelines given on the scope of the sanctions lifted and those that remain in force. In order for Iran to benefit fully from the lifting of sanctions, it is also important that they overcome obstacles relating to economic and budgetary policy, the business environment and the rule of law. With this vote, the European Parliament reaffirms its commitment to further developing relations with Iran.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. The nuclear deal with Iran strengthens the European Union's foreign policy. The partnership offers a myriad of opportunities for both parties. A common topic is the European Union's dependence on energy from a single supplier, which could change with iran's help, as the country has one of the largest gas and oil reserves in the world. I trust that we will successfully continue on the road to a well-functioning partnership and that we will succeed in motivating Iran to try to reach the level that the EU has held in respect of fundamental human rights. We must definitely let the country know that this is one of the basic conditions of the agreement.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution that calls for the improvement of EU-Iran relations following the nuclear agreement, providing stability across the whole region. The lifting of all nuclear-related sanctions against the Islamic Republic of Iran is the result of the successful implementation of its commitments under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, thus creating new opportunities and benefits for both sides.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe that its text is totally at odds with the precarious state of democracy in Iran and avoids reflecting repeated violations of respect for human rights by national authorities. I find it unacceptable that, in a document of the European Parliament, by using such a lenient tone against the regime in Tehran, all serious incidents in recent years in this country should be ignored and it should be forgotten that many of them continue to this day.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement because it did not go through the proposals pointing to human rights violations in Iran. These include expressing the utmost concern about the high number of executions of juveniles, recalling Iran's obligations under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which prohibits the use of the death penalty on juvenile offenders, and requiring that all juvenile offenders currently awaiting the death penalty be sentenced to be reduced. I find it very unfortunate and unjustifiable that Parliament has not supported these proposals.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as this agreement is an important step towards normalising relations between the European Union and Iran.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. While the Iran nuclear deal provides an opportunity to improve EU-Iran relations and ensure greater stability throughout the region, the improvement in relations is also conditional on the improvement of Iran's human rights situation for the better. This includes women's rights, freedom of expression and the abolition of the death penalty. The current report is weak on human rights and other important issues and focuses too much on promoting economic relations and not on the human rights situation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Iran is an important partner for the EU. It is therefore necessary to continuously develop relations between the EU and Iran, based on cooperation and mutual interest. Particular attention must be paid to areas such as trade, energy, human rights, civil nuclear cooperation, migration, the environment, the fight against international threats such as drugs, humanitarian cooperation, transport, research, education, culture and regional issues. In this context, it is important to implement a broad strategy that gradually establishes relations and is comprehensive. This strategy should contribute to trade, economic and social issues, ensure appropriate sectoral cooperation, regional security, the rule of law, democracy and the principles of respect for human rights. It should be noted that the council's decision to lift all anti-nuclear sanctions imposed on Iran will allow the resumption of relations with Iran and provide opportunities and benefits for both sides following iran's implementation of the provisions of the nuclear programme agreement.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report calls for efforts to reduce tensions between Tehran and Riyadh, but also to abolish the death penalty. Many believed that the country was developing a nuclear program, something Iran itself denies. There were also hostile statements about Israel and other countries, while the situation of human rights and democracy was tragic. Not everything has improved. However, Iran is on the right track. People with reform ideas have begun to be elected. There was the nuclear deal, which is a top victory for European diplomacy, but also an opportunity for Iran to become a member of the international community again, showing respect for international law. There are likely to be gains for human rights as well. Forces within Iran are pushing for their respect and we hope that our report will also be a lever of pressure in the same direction. We are clearly against the death penalty and only ending executions for drug-related offences can reduce the number of executions by up to 80%.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The report reflects fierce competition between the urban classes and parts of the capital within the EU, as well as with other imperialist centres and powerful capitalist countries, in particular the US, Russia, but also China for the control of markets, energy sources, raw materials and energy transport routes in the wider Middle East region, also linked to their attitude towards Iran , in light of the agreement on its nuclear programme. The European Parliament expresses the aspirations of EU monopolies to take advantage of the agreement to normalise EU-Iran political relations, which will facilitate their penetration into the Iranian market. These characteristics of the Iranian capitalist economy, based on the savage exploitation of Iran's working class, are a magnet for monopolies in the EU. This is what the report emphasises by designing their penetration with foreign direct investment, even focusing on specific sectors, such as automotive, aircraft manufacturing, energy infrastructure, RES, etc. On the other hand, 'human rights', as the EU perceives them, will continue to be a pretext for political pressure to facilitate the aspirations of business groups. The peoples of such competitions and agreements have nothing to look forward to. That is why they must strengthen their fight against the common enemy, their monopolies and their power.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report. I share the analysis that the European Union must step up its diplomatic action to promote a de-escalation of tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, in particular with a view to a resolution of the civil war in Syria. I also think it is essential to strengthen the dialogue between the EU and Iran on the issue of human rights, with the priority of ending the death penalty. In view of the European Union's efforts to reach a nuclear agreement with Iran, we now have the channels for discussion for a constructive relationship between the EU and Iran.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not support the development of an EU foreign policy and such does not recognise the legitimacy of the EU to engage in diplomatic relations with Iran. UKIP rejects the notion that the Iranian nuclear deal was a ‘success for EU diplomacy’ and opposes its attempted use by the EU as a justification for the further development of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, trade policy should be a matter for Member States and not the EU Commission. There are serious human rights concerns, both domestically in Iran and throughout the Middle East, propagated by the Iranian regime proxies. We have supported articles that purely discuss human rights and rejected those that contain calls for the EU to take action. This is more effectively left to appropriate international institutions and individual states.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the scope of the nuclear agreement with Iran, aimed at improving relations with Iran, I am pleased to note that this agreement is also intended to promote stability throughout the region. It should not be underestimated that Iran is the second largest economy in the Middle East and restoring access to the world trading system governed by general rules can become a way of breaking Iran's isolation and that trade can become an important tool for consolidating political dialogue and stimulating cooperation between countries in the region.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this strategy as I believe that the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), was a notable achievement for multilateral diplomacy, and for European diplomacy in particular. The strategy can help promote stability across the whole region while at the same time it makes a substantial improvement in EU-Iran relations possible. With this report, Parliament calls on the Government of Iran to address the substantive concerns on the situation of human rights in Iran, as well as the specific calls to action found in resolutions of the UN General Assembly.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ When voting on this resolution, we need to think carefully about the political message we want to send through our act and how our decision today will be received by people across Europe, but also in Iran itself. I am sure that we all agree that we must encourage the continuation of the restoration of relations between the European Union and the Member States with Iran, but by no means should we forget about those values that lie at the very foundations of our community when thinking about economic development.  The development of economic relations between the Union and Iran must be a process that will run parallel to the conduct of the nuclear agreement, but nor should it be forgotten the progress that Iran will show in the fields of human rights, women's rights, freedom of expression and the ban on the death penalty. Despite the messages of encouragement around Iran's progress in these areas that we in Europe consider a priority, I am not convinced that the extremely encouraging tone of the proposed resolution on the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear deal corresponds to the current situation in that country, and therefore abstained during the vote.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union has no legitimacy to deal with diplomacy. Because of this principle, I am opposed to this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action is a significant achievement of multilateral, in particular European, diplomacy, which should enable substantial improvement of EU-Iran relations and foster stability throughout the region. I welcome the establishment of a Joint Commission consisting of representatives of Iran and representatives of E3/EU+3 countries.  I support the High Representative of the Union as coordinator of the Joint Commission, the implementation of which remains of paramount importance. Iran has a large, relatively highly educated and young population, and its GDP composition is among the most diverse in the region, in need of many investments. The EU has been Iran's main trading partner and should seek to return to this position, so I support the expansion of the EU's trade relations with Iran.  I call on the Commission to look at ways in which ties could be strengthened so that Iran can better comply with WTO rules and protect European investment. Energy cooperation can play an important role in increasing the diversification of energy sources in the EU and reducing Member States' dependence on a single supplier. But Iran has the highest level of execution of the death penalty per capita in the world. I strongly oppose the death penalty and its abolition is the main objective of the EU's human rights policy and its foreign policy.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report deals with relations between the EU and Iran after the nuclear agreement concluded. About a year ago, Iran signed an agreement on Iran's nuclear program with six powers (THE US, France, Britain, Russia, China, Germany) that allowed the lifting of heavy sanctions imposed. The U.S. maintains the blockade.   Iran is a country of enormous geostrategic importance. He has influence in the Middle East and the Gulf region. It is the second largest economy in the Middle East and North Africa. It has the second largest gas reserves in the world and the fourth largest oil reserves. It also has enormous potential for solar energy exploration, interests that move the EU. Although we follow the report on the need to establish relations, we distance ourselves from the view of external interference and interference to which the report seeks to condition these relations: structural, judicial and democratic reforms. A vision aimed at feeding abroad, regime changes, which aim not the interests and legitimate aspirations of the Iranian people, but to meet the EU's economic and political objectives to destabilise and control the Middle East. In addition, the total bleaching of reality and distinct responsibilities and roles of those involved in the conflicts of that region. We voted against it.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The conclusion of an agreement on Iran's nuclear programme, followed by the partial lifting of sanctions and the relative positive internal developments in the country, have opened the door to improving eu-Iran relations. The agreed strategy represents a further step towards an ambitious agenda of bilateral relations between the EU and Iran. I believe that it is only through the development of mutual trust that it will be possible to overcome the prevailing antagonisms so far. This strategy should lead to finding a way to break Iran's isolationism. Developing the parliamentary dimension of relations and mutual cooperation in a number of areas including trade relations, the fight against terrorism, sectoral cooperation and, last but not least, regional security, are important means of achieving this objective. It is on this subject that we need to mention our key role in promoting the stability of the region and to reassure our other long-term partners in the region of our continued support. Iran's willingness to have a political dialogue with the EU on human rights is one of the essential elements, especially given that iran is still one of those that uses the death penalty in certain cases. In the future, the common strategy should provide Iran with sufficient technical assistance to reform its judicial system. This could help to find alternative forms of punishment, in particular for minor offences or offences committed by minors.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report stresses that the EU and Iran have decided to address issues of mutual interest constructively and that they intend to pave the way for long-term cooperation. Iran's revolutionary heritage and its nature as an Islamic republic, as well as the main differences in terms of political and institutional systems, must not be an obstacle to openness and the search for frank and direct dialogue, and to the search for common ground on issues relating to democracy, the rule of law and human rights. To this end, it should be emphasised that EU-Iran cooperation in the fight against terrorism and violent extremism is an extremely important part of the political dialogue between the two sides. I am confident that the nuclear agreement will pave the way for cooperation to resolve crises in the Middle East region. That is why I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Relations between the EU, its Member States and the international community and Iran are slowly thawing after the country's nuclear ambitions were successfully agreed in July 2015. Negotiations between Iran and the P5+1 group started in 2006, but have recently become more intense, resulting in a recent agreement. The P5+1 group wanted to limit Iran's nuclear activities. Under the Vienna Agreement, Iran's nuclear programme was removed from the list of hazardous activities. However, it remains unclear how these findings will affect the wider regional problems in the Middle East, including the proxy war between Iran and Saudi Arabia, the religious conflict between Shiites and Sunnis, the conflict in Syria, and relations with Israel.  The AFET report commends the EU, in particular for its role in the nuclear arrangements, and the assessment of relations with Iran as a regional entity is positive for the rapporteur. The EU has made rapid progress towards normalising relations with Iran, despite general reservations about the country's human rights situation and its role in the regional conflict. However, it would be necessary to ensure a more precise reflection of relations between the EU and Iran. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. As rapporteur for the EPP on the subject in the Committee on International Trade, I am very sensitive to the issue of relations with Iran. This country has tremendous potential for our businesses. In fact, many have made no mistake about it and have already won many contracts. In this, it is important to continue to invest this market to accompany it towards the return to normality of our relations. This does not mean being naïve and turning a blind eye to the situation of human rights in general and women's rights in particular. But our role is to be present as we have long been in this country. As such, one issue must be resolved quickly: that of US extraterritorial laws that hinder European investment. It is unfair that the United States can punish European companies for investments that American companies make themselves! I underline the very high quality of my colleague Pierre Lellouche's report to the National Assembly on this subject of extraterritorial laws.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that, despite Iran's revolutionary matrix and its character as an Islamic republic, as well as the profound differences in the political-institutional system between Iran and the EU, these should not constitute an obstacle to openness and dialogue on different matters.  The Joint Comprehensive Action Plan (GLL), also known as the Nuclear Agreement with Iran, sets out a remarkable achievement for multilateral diplomacy, and for European diplomacy in particular. This should allow not only a substantial improvement in relations between the EU and Iran, but also the promotion of stability throughout the region.  I would point out that all parties now have a responsibility to ensure the full and strict implementation of the GSM, and iran's non-implementation will lead to the reintroduction of the sanctions lifted.  The development of EU-Iran relations must continue, with plenty of room for understanding and cooperation on issues such as political dialogue, economic issues, sectoral cooperation and regional security. In the context of socio-economic issues, the rule of law, democracy and human rights, I must stress the importance of ending the application of the death penalty.  For the above, my vote is in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not support the development of an EU foreign policy and such does not recognise the legitimacy of the EU to engage in diplomatic relations with Iran. UKIP rejects the notion that the Iranian nuclear deal was a ‘success for EU diplomacy’ and opposes its attempted use by the EU as a justification for the further development of an EU foreign policy. Furthermore, trade policy should be a matter for Member States and not the EU Commission. There are serious human rights concerns, both domestically in Iran and throughout the Middle East, propagated by the Iranian regime proxies. We have supported articles that purely discuss human rights and rejected those that contain calls for the EU to take action. This is more effectively left to appropriate international institutions and individual states.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of considering that the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (GLL), also known as the Nuclear Agreement with Iran, was a remarkable achievement for multilateral diplomacy, and for The European One in particular, and should allow not only a substantial improvement in relations between the EU and Iran, but also the promotion of stability throughout the region, and all parties now have a responsibility to ensure its strict and strict implementation.  Relations between the EU and Iran should be developed through multi-level dialogue that includes political, diplomatic, economic, academic, technical and interpersonal contacts, including civil society actors, NGOs and human rights defenders. An extension of relations between the EU and Iran for the mutual benefit of both sides, on the basis of a realistic assessment of common interests and differences, and with a view to encouraging a gradual expansion of cooperation in a confidence-building climate, above all to benefit the peoples of Iran and the EU.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. This afternoon, MEPs adopted, by 456 votes to 174 and 67 abstentions, a resolution which I oppose as it stands, which aims to define the European strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement. The agreement, which came into force on 16 January 2016, after 12 years of negotiations between Iran, the European Union and the five permanent members of the UN Security Council, lifts sanctions imposed on Iran by major powers in return for a long-term restriction on its nuclear programme. Despite the adoption of some of the amendments I have co-signed, in particular on the reality of human rights and political prisoners in Iran, the persistence of the denial of the Holocaust and the State of Israel by the Iranian authorities, and their support for the terrorist organisation Hezbollah, the European Parliament's resolution remains unbalanced in tone and substance. It is a white-seing granted to Iran and it is regrettable that the economic prospects promised by the lifting of sanctions take a step over the political and geopolitical realities of the region. It is feared that such an attitude will contribute to isolating the European Union on the international stage.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. There is no doubt that this agreement with Iran was a remarkable event for multilateral diplomacy, and for European diplomacy in particular, and should represent a substantial improvement in eu-Iran relations and in promoting stability throughout the region.  The Council's decision to lift sanctions against Iran following this agreement will enable opportunities and benefits to be created for both sides by reopening the Iranian market for European business and investment. However, I cannot fail to say that this is also a sign of openness and an opportunity for Iran to make a clear and substantial progress in respect for human rights, democracy, the rule of law and gender equality.  The number of Iranian citizens executed in Iran, many of them minors, is frightening. The EU must be uncompromising in respect for human rights, including in the framework of its trade agreements.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which represents further development of EU-Iran relations one year after the nuclear agreement between the international community and Iran. The report describes areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation security, academic exchanges, etc. And he deals extensively with the regional situation in the Middle East, sending the message, especially to Iran and Saudi Arabia, about the need to appease tensions and carry out diplomatic normalization. In addition, the report covers the human rights situation in Iran, emphasizing the Union's opposition to the death penalty and criticizing Iran for the very high number of executions and other human rights violations, such as arrests of dual EU-Iranian citizens, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression Etc. The report specifically calls on Iran to cooperate fully with UN human rights mechanisms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the Howitt report, which encourages the European Union to make new efforts in its relations with Iran. There is always more urgency to ensure security for the entire Middle East, and this certainly also requires the encouraging agreement reached on the Iranian nuclear program. The Universal Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Tests, which is verifiable at the international level, is the best way to ban testing and any other nuclear explosion and cooperation between the EU and Iran will ensure the full implementation of the joint comprehensive action plan.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 THE EU's strategy towards Iran is like trying to reconcile two incompatible things: to punish the theocratic regime for human rights violations, to deter military expansion, while stimulating human relations with this old and extremely interesting civilisation. I support the draft strategy. I would even say that it may have focused more on the development of human relations, while indicating, of course, that the EU will not tolerate aggressive foreign policy and human rights violations within the country.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report on the signing of the Nuclear Agreement with Iran has prompted a number of reactions in opposite directions in this House. As a difficult dossier, it was not easy for the shadow rapporteur/rapporteur to obtain a minimally consensual text that could gather maximum support from Members. I therefore welcome the result of 456 votes in favour. I had the opportunity to intervene in plenary and propose 10 amendments to the report which I saw included in the final text. I also believe that a very balanced text has been reached, in accordance with the principle of 'change by rapprochement', which seems to me to be the most effective way to achieve the political stabilisation of a region marked by the existence of numerous conflicts that insist on maintaining themselves, causing a high level of suffering to various peoples of this wide territory. Although I believe that change is easier, faster and more solid through rapprochement and not through blind conditionality, I do not think we should compromise on the principles we believe in, and I therefore insist, asking Iran once again to immediately impose a moratorium on the execution of death sentences in your country.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out the thrusts of the European Union's strategy towards Iran after the signing of the nuclear agreement on 15 July 2015. It should be stressed that this agreement is an advance of European diplomacy, and allows the opening of relations between the European Union and Iran. The report reminds us that the progress of relations between the EU and Iran must go hand in hand with the implementation of this agreement. This agreement is an opportunity to strengthen cooperation between the two partners in economic, trade and energy matters. The development of relations between the EU and Iran must also have as a priority the stabilisation of the region. It is essential that a frank, structured and regular political dialogue be established to address all of these areas of cooperation. I also supported this report because it calls not only for a moratorium on the death penalty in Iran, especially for minors, but also because it condemns violations of democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights, particularly concerning the situation of women.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a text which I believe is in the sense of building a common and standardised agenda between the Union and Iran, based on respect for sovereignty, multilateralism in the resolution of disputes, the joint search for processes that lead to progress in respect for human rights, the sustainable and sustainable development of the Iranian people and peace and security for all peoples of the Middle East. I am opposed, however, to Iran's consideration as a source of regional instability, to the establishment of relations guided predominantly by commercial criteria, to the presentation of trade liberalization per se as a panacea for the development of peoples such as The Iranian (who participate under asymmetrical and subordinate conditions in the global market) and to the use of fossil and nuclear energy as the basis of any country's productive and energy matrix.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote in favour of the Howitt resolution on the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement is conditioned by the following considerations. Nothing in the text should be understood now or in the future as tending to encourage the EU or its Member States to include regime change as a component of their policy towards Iran. Evident or implied criticism of the Iranian Government’s internal and external policies should be taken as defining the parameters within which the European Union will undertake cooperation on all fronts with Iran. In no way should it be taken to mean that the EU proposes to intervene in Iran’s internal processes to influence decisions and policies there. Even when the EU makes critical submissions to the Iranian authorities about their decisions and policies, such submissions will be made in good faith. It is up to the Iranian people to decide about their national systems. Where in the past, the European Union and its Member States have supported or been a party to policies that were intended to promote regime change, results have been disastrous, both for the countries concerned and for Europe. The examples of Iraq and Libya stand out in this context.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU's strategy towards Iran following the conclusion of the nuclear agreement, as it promotes close cooperation between the EU and Iran on a more effective implementation of the nuclear agreement. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) is seen by Parliament as a remarkable success, especially in terms of European and multilateral diplomacy. According to the terms of the agreement, the failure to implement the action plan may lead to the reintroduction of sanctions.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to define the Union's strategy on Iran following the nuclear agreement signed in 2015, a permanent agreement between the parties to lift sanctions imposed on Iran by the United States, the Union and the United Nations, and Iran limits its long-term nuclear program. The report has positive but also negative elements, such as not asking for the full lifting of US sanctions or which, as is customary in Union reports and resolutions, is the hypocrisy of asking for the human rights of refugees and asylum seekers to be respected, when in its own territory the Union systematically infringes them. Despite this, I voted in favour as the report supports a return to active diplomacy and cooperation with Iran, based on mutual respect for international norms and principles, and recalls that "it is not intended to interfere in a country's domestic political elections". Moreover, the report argues that Iran can act as a mediator to seek a peaceful solution to the Syrian conflict. For all this, my vote has been positive.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 This European Parliament resolution is, in my opinion, too positive with regard to the future relations between Iran and the EU. It does not accurately reflect Iran's attitude and actions towards countries in the Middle East, including Israel, and western democracies. I therefore voted against.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although there is no democracy in Iran and Iran does not have an open market economy, I welcomed the lifting of all nuclear-related sanctions against the Islamic Republic of Iran, as this creates new opportunities for cooperation and reopening the Iranian market to European businesses. Already today, EU trade with Iran is around USD 8 billion and is expected to quadruple in the coming years. I consider very positive the results already achieved under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, e.g. an increase of 43% in the volume of trade between Iran and the EU during the first six months of 2016 compared to the same period in 2015. Although the Agreement on Iran's nuclear programme limits the threat of Iran's use of nuclear weapons and the agreement has opened up opportunities for better economic relations with that country, we must not forget that Iran holds first place in the world, not only in executions, but also in the imprisonment of journalists or juvenile executions. As paragraphs 40a and 41a have not been approved, which rightly draw attention to the imprisonment of juveniles and violations of human and women's rights, I did not support the motion for a resolution.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report seeks to establish cooperation and find new ways of connecting the European Union and Iran. The tone of the report is largely different from what was in the report prepared in April 2014, as there are still significant differences of opinion and attitudes between the various groups of deputies towards Iran in the European Parliament.  The report highlights the achievements of the Comprehensive Action Plan (JCPOA) in the field of multilateral diplomacy and European diplomacy in general. At the same time, it clarifies that the development of relations between the European Union and Iran should progress in parallel with the implementation of the nuclear deal, which is based on a comprehensive, cooperative and constructive dialogue between the two sides.  The report welcomes the establishment of the Iran Group within the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the preparations for the opening of the EU delegation in Tehran. At the same time, the report also addresses criticism of regulation and practice in certain areas in Iran – in particular freedom of expression and religion, workers' rights, corruption and money laundering, lack of political pluralism and the like.  Iran plays an important role in the region, so supporting its positive efforts is important. I believe that it is necessary to build on relations with third countries, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report outlining the future direction of the EU strategy towards Iran contains some positive elements, such as the importance of sectoral cooperation and the stabilisation of Iran's role in the region. However, due to the abysmal violation of human rights in Iran and the unconditional support of the Assad regime in the Syrian war, I, together with other members of the Alliance for Progress and Awakening, have decided to vote against the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
