text: Writing. \u2012 The nuclear agreement with Iran is a major breakthrough in international security policy. The European Union must be involved in controlling the implementation of its provisions, while seizing on the trade opportunities that are opened up after sanctions have been lifted.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the EU Parliament's resolution on the EU's strategy towards Iran after the conclusion of the nuclear agreement. I welcome the approach of improving relations with Iran. Firstly, however, it is not the EU's job to establish external relations in place of the nation states. Secondly, I deplore the fact that the European External Action Service is already making institutional changes in this regard. Thirdly, the report also insists on internal policy reforms, which, as much as I may welcome them in part, such as when it comes to criticising the death penalty in Iran, should not be the subject of the EU's external relations. Last but not least, fourthly, the report also calls for an EU trade and investment agreement with Iran, for which the EU lacks competence.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The implementation of the commitments under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, also known as the Iranian Nuclear Agreement, was followed by the lifting of sanctions, allowing for renewed cooperation with Iran. The economic benefits of opening up the Iranian market to European companies are mutual with a guarantee of increasing stability in the region.  Iran as the Second Largest Economy of the Middle East is an important trading partner of the European Union. Further institutional changes will foster better public information about the EU and understanding of culture, human rights and environmental sustainability. It also underlines the importance of developing a parliamentary dimension of EU-Iran relations aimed at countering terrorism.  In addition, the EU's political dialogue with Iran can seek a constructive role in resolving the political crisis in Iraq, Yemen, Syria, Lebanon and Afghanistan in order to respect international law and diplomacy based on political priorities as much as possible. I support the report on the EU strategy towards Iran following the Foreign Affairs Committee nuclear agreement.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement. Good and constructive relations with countries in the immediate and distant neighbourhood are in the interests of the European Union and its citizens. However, despite the sincere dialogue between the EU and Iran on matters relating to democracy, the rule of law and human rights, we must not stop pointing out Iran's unacceptable practices.  The fact that Iran has the highest per capita execution rate in the world as a result of the death penalty for crimes is really worrying. We must not stop pointing this out.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns the EU's strategy towards Iran following the nuclear agreement. The agreement is a positive development, which we have also welcomed. We are in favour of a closer relationship between the EU and Iran, but we do not overlook the human rights situation in the country, the use of the death penalty, the violation of freedom of opinion and political persecution. These are very serious issues, in which any concessions cannot be made for the sake of any commercial and economic interests. We have abstained on this report, because in many respects it is trying to serve precisely these interests and not a relationship that will be beneficial to the people of Iran.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The way in which the Union wants to develop relations with Iran is wrong and serves mainly corporate interests instead of the interests of the Member States and their citizens. The Union must refrain from intervening in the internal affairs of third countries. We believe that the suggestions about the justice system and how the internet works in Iran are more than unnecessary. International relations are an area that Member States must handle on their own, as the interests of each other differ in various ways.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Strategy for Iran after the Nuclear Agreement report points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, which will enable stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region to be promoted. At the same time, however, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions could be reintroduced.  In the area of respect for human rights, the report reiterates the Union's firm and principled position towards the death penalty. In this sense, it strongly condemns Iran for the frequent use of the death penalty and calls for an immediate moratorium on their implementation. Given that the long-term aim of this report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I adopted the report, which clearly analyses with a positive approach the situation after the agreement between Tehran and the international community on Iranian nuclear capacity, with the active involvement of the EU and the EEAS, and the political and economic prospects of relations between the Union and Iran. I agree that the lifting of sanctions, particularly in the commercial and energy fields, opens up a new perspective on cooperation.  At the same time, I consider it important for the Union to display conditionality in the report, as far as the internal political practice of the Iranian Government, in particular the death penalty and the treatment of minorities, is concerned. Nevertheless, I would have liked to have seen the EU and the EP take a stronger account of changes in European standards from the Iranian leadership, including on issues of Tehran's regional role, anti-Israel, anti-Semitism and human rights, including the situation of minorities and women.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Thanks to the Nuclear Agreement with Iran of July 2015 and the country's internal political situation, there has been an extraordinary opportunity to reform and improve relations with the European Union. On the one hand, European entrepreneurs will be able to invest in Iran after 10 years of complete freezing of trade relations, while on the other hand we have managed to eliminate a country that can possess nuclear weapons.  In addition, Iran has some of the world's largest oil and gas reserves, and deepening energy cooperation between the Union and the Republic of Iran can play an important role in diversifying energy supply sources to the EU and in reducing member states' energy dependency on a single supplier, Russia. However, the European Parliament's report rightly draws attention to the need to monitor the situation in Iran on a permanent basis, in particular as regards respect for human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law. Indeed, I believe that there are values more important than economic development and investment growth– peace and security.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I thought alde's line was realistic. It takes into account the achievement of very realistic relationships, but it can, however, raise problem issues to the surface. Iran's trade partnership is important for the EU, but it is important to take account of Iran's issues of democracy and human rights.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A year ago, the historic agreement on Iran's nuclear program was signed between the international community and the authorities in Tehran. The European Union has played a decisive role in this, through the key contribution made by the High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Federica Mogherini, to mediation efforts.  The signing of the agreement is the essential premise of the normalisation of relations between the EU and the Member States and Iran, a very important player in the Middle East region. The potential for expanding cooperation between the two parties includes key areas such as trade, environmental protection, aviation, security (including the energy component), academic exchanges. At the same time, Iran plays an important role in stabilizing the regional situation in the Middle East, alongside Saudi Arabia.  However, there are also a number of areas where the Tehran regime still has problems, particularly those related to respect for human rights. Thus, the EU is concerned about the large number of executions caused by the maintenance of the death penalty, the arrest of dual-citizen persons (Iranian and some EU states), gender discrimination, non-compliance with minority rights and freedom of expression. In order to remedy the situation, deep cooperation between Iran and the UN human rights structures is needed. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I support the Howitt report. The Joint Comprehensive Action Plan, also known as the Iran nuclear agreement, is a notable achievement of multilateral diplomacy and European diplomacy in particular, in that it will enable not only a significant improvement in EU-Iran relations but also the promotion of stability throughout the region. I believe that all parties are now responsible for its strict and comprehensive implementation. I welcome the creation of the joint committee made up of representatives of Iran and E3/EU-3 (China, France, Germany, the Russian Federation, the United Kingdom and the United States, with the VP/HR). I fully support the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy in her role as coordinator of the joint committee established under the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan, whose strict and comprehensive implementation is of paramount importance. However, I have tabled amendments to highlight the issues of human rights and gender equality!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the Iran Nuclear Deal and the internal political developments in Iran, there is now an opportunity for reforms in the country and for improvement of its relations with the European Union. However, I am of the opinion that overall the compromises in the agreement do not reflect the present reality in Iran.  There is a clear lack of balance in tone and substance when it comes to serious problems such as human rights violations, corruption, and the role of Iran in regional conflicts, in particular concerning its support for the Assad regime. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. After Iran's nuclear agreement with the major powers, it was necessary for the European Union to revisit its strategy with that country.  If the initial drafting suffered from an imbalance on the merits by enacting unconditional cooperation, on the one hand it made the European Union solely responsible for compliance with the nuclear agreement, and on the other hand economic cooperation did not include any conditionality. Moreover, the parts of the text on respect for human rights in Iran and regional security were less developed than those on economic cooperation.  The report presented to Parliament's vote strengthened the human rights and regional security side and some responsibilities for Iran's role in the region and the human rights situation were recalled. Our group has also added amendments on political prisoners and media surveillance, which are rebalancing and strengthening the rapporteur's resolution, and I have therefore voted for this report.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of more constructive relations with Iran must be governed by the country's progress on issues of regional interest such as the civil war in Syria and the fight against all forms of terrorism and the causes of this phenomenon, but also in areas such as economic development, trade agreements, the rule of law and the promotion of human rights. In particular, I am concerned about this last aspect because I have no progress to make on this issue. I hope that this will be given a thorough thought.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Strategy for Iran after the Nuclear Agreement report points out that the agreement is a significant achievement of international and European diplomacy, which will enable stability throughout the Middle East and Persian Gulf region to be promoted. At the same time, however, it stresses that if Iran does not implement the agreement, sanctions could be reintroduced.  In the area of respect for human rights, the report reiterates the Union's firm and principled position towards the death penalty. In this sense, it strongly condemns Iran for the frequent use of the death penalty and calls for an immediate moratorium on their implementation. Given that the long-term aim of this report is to lift Iran's international isolation, I voted in favour of it.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The relationship between the European Union, its Member States and the international community, related to Iran moved from an impasse after a successful agreement on nuclear armament ambitions. Negotiations between the European Union, Iran and the P5+1 group of the world's most powerful powers (USA, Russia, China, Germany, France and the United Kingdom), began in 2006 and have intensified recently.  The negotiations were aimed at limiting Iran's highly sensitive nuclear-related activities, in exchange for lifting restrictive sanctions. While I wholeheartedly support the Union's efforts and its role in the negotiations to prevent Iran from further nuclear arming, I must stress at the same time that the resolution adopted by the European Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee unfortunately did not place sufficient emphasis on the continuing human rights violations in Iran. Examples of the same are the executions of minors, the planned ban on cycling in public to women, the inability of the United Nations Human Rights Ambassador to enter Iran's territory, and many others. I call on the European Union to step up its efforts to address these and similar issues. So I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement. The Joint Action Plan, also known as the nuclear deal with Iran, is a particularly fine achievement of multilateral diplomacy and, in particular, European diplomacy, which should not only significantly improve EU-Iran relations, but also promote stability throughout the region.  The EU and Iran have decided to address issues of common interest constructively. The EU strategy for renewed contacts with Iran is first of all based on confidence-building measures in technical areas that would create positive examples of the joint work of the EU and Iran and allow for more important long-term cooperation.  The Council Decision on the lifting of all nuclear-related sanctions against the Islamic Republic of Iran on the basis of the implementation of the obligations under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action allows for renewed cooperation with Iran and will create opportunities and benefits for both sides, as it will provide the potential for the reopening of the Iranian market to European companies.  The value of the EU's trade with Iran is around USD 8 billion and is expected to increase fourfold over the next two years.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a text which I believe is in the sense of building a common and standardised agenda between the Union and Iran, based on respect for sovereignty, multilateralism in the resolution of disputes, the joint search for processes that lead to progress in respect for human rights, the sustainable and sustainable development of the Iranian people and peace and security for all peoples of the Middle East. I am opposed, however, to Iran's consideration as a source of regional instability, to the establishment of relations guided predominantly by commercial criteria, to the presentation of trade liberalization per se as a panacea for the development of peoples such as The Iranian (who participate under asymmetrical and subordinate conditions in the global market) and to the use of fossil and nuclear energy as the basis of any country's productive and energy matrix.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As a result of intense pressure from the international community, the Iranian authorities have agreed to negotiate to curb the country's nuclear programme. The Member States of the European Union have contributed significantly to the adoption of these arrangements and the normalisation of relations with Iran. Despite these achievements, we should continue to monitor the country's nuclear threat and strive to ensure that the European Union's relations with Iran are balanced, transparent and based on a real basis. As a forum for exchange of views and international debate, the European Parliament should not give up on making good reservations, especially in the event of human rights violations and the escalation of conflicts in the Middle East. Recommendations are also needed for the further progress of relations between the European Union and this country. The report does not meet these expectations. That is why I voted against the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Council Decision to lift all nuclear-related sanctions against the Islamic Republic of Iran as a result of the implementation of the commitments made in the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action provides an opportunity to re-open relations with Iran and creates opportunities and benefits for both parties by giving European companies the opportunity to reopen the Iranian market. In the final vote, I followed S&D's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a text which I believe is in the sense of building a common and standardised agenda between the Union and Iran, based on respect for sovereignty, multilateralism in the resolution of disputes, the joint search for processes that lead to progress in respect for human rights, the sustainable and sustainable development of the Iranian people and peace and security for all peoples of the Middle East. I am opposed, however, to Iran's consideration as a source of regional instability, to the establishment of relations guided predominantly by commercial criteria, to the presentation of trade liberalization per se as a panacea for the development of peoples such as The Iranian (who participate under asymmetrical and subordinate conditions in the global market) and to the use of fossil and nuclear energy as the basis of any country's productive and energy matrix.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), otherwise known as the Iran Nuclear Deal, was a notable achievement for multilateral diplomacy and for European diplomacy in particular, which should not only make a substantial improvement in EU-Iran relations possible but also help to promote stability across the whole region. All sides are now responsible for ensuring its strict and full implementation. Iran has the second-largest gas reserves in the world and the fourth-largest oil reserves and energy cooperation can play a significant role in diversifying the sources of energy supply to the EU and reducing Member States' energy dependency on single suppliers, thereby contributing to the EU’s energy security. I voted in favour because I believe that the nuclear deal opens the possibility for cooperation in resolving the region’s security crisis. Moreover, I am of the opinion that Iran can and should play a stabilisation role in the region.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report aims to define the Union's strategy on Iran following the nuclear agreement signed in 2015, a permanent agreement between the parties to lift sanctions imposed on Iran by the United States, the Union and the United Nations, and Iran limits its long-term nuclear program. The report has positive but also negative elements, such as not asking for the full lifting of US sanctions or which, as is customary in Union reports and resolutions, is the hypocrisy of asking for the human rights of refugees and asylum seekers to be respected, when in its own territory the Union systematically infringes them. Despite this, I voted in favour as the report supports a return to active diplomacy and cooperation with Iran, based on mutual respect for international norms and principles, and recalls that "it is not intended to interfere in a country's domestic political elections". Moreover, the report argues that Iran can act as a mediator to seek a peaceful solution to the Syrian conflict. For all this, my vote has been positive.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my EPLP colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it emphasises EU-Iran relations must be re-established, based on a clear understanding of where there are common interests but also where there is disagreement. It also supports the establishment of an EU delegation in Tehran, as well as re-establishing an interparliamentary dialogue with the Iranian Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. We voted on 11 resolutions on the human rights situation in Iran during the last mandate. Not one under this one. The trade and energy opportunities that are opening up to the EU as a result of the lifting of sanctions in the meantime are certainly not foreign to this novelty. This report, which looks at the EU's strategy with Iran after the nuclear deal, has the merit of detailing the catastrophic human rights situation in the country. In particular, it stresses the need to link the resumption of relations to a dialogue on human rights involving representatives of the judiciary, security forces and civil society. It is not possible to deny Iran's role in this part of the world and I would even say that it is in the EU's interest to better balance its relations in the Middle East. I therefore voted in favour, but I am surprised at the negative vote of some of my colleagues who are usually less committed to human rights and hope to see the same desire for respect for human rights shown in relations with other countries in the region, such as Saudi Arabia, for example. But I'm under no illusions.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. About a year ago, Iran signed an agreement on Iran's nuclear program with six more powers (USA, France, Britain, Russia, China, Germany). This agreement called jcpoa allowed the lifting of sanctions imposed by the US and the European Union. These sanctions have had negative impacts on the economy and life of this country. It should also be noted that Iran has already ruled at the United Nations that it is in no way benefiting from this lifting of sanctions and that the US has not yet complied with the agreement.  We are in favour of normalising diplomatic relations with Iran on the basis of mutual respect for the sovereignty of states. We do not follow in absolute any paranoid and security drift stemming from Iran that only contributes to avoiding any stabilization effort in the region.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The nuclear agreement concluded with Iran is an opportunity to promote domestic reforms and improve relations between Member States and Iran. The Islamic Republic is a major player in the Middle East and plays a crucial role in combating radical Islamism in Iraq and Syria and restoring stability in the region. That is why I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear deal. In particular, this report is a further contribution to the development of EU-Iran relations. The report strongly supports the plan as an example of successful multilateral diplomacy. The report outlines areas of possible cooperation with Iran, such as trade, environmental protection, aviation safety, academic exchanges, etc. Focusing on the human rights situation in Iran, the report condemns the death penalty as contrary to EU principles; criticises the high number of executions; as well as human rights violations such as the arrest of citizens with dual citizenship, gender discrimination, minority rights, freedom of expression, etc. Finally, it calls on Iran to cooperate fully with the UN human rights mechanism.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. The report to be voted on contains, despite a fundamentally positive assessment of the prospects for rapprochement between the EU and Iran, numerous impositions on Tehran, which have lost nothing in relations with a sovereign state. Regulations in the area of "human rights, democratic internal development, etc. are not appropriate on the part of the EU, as long as fundamental rights are repeatedly violated in EU countries in dealing with political dissidents: in at least two EU countries, prohibition proceedings against political parties are pending, in the Federal Republic of Germany, well over 10,000 cases against patriotic citizens are investigated every year, at least 1200 German patriots are imprisoned for offences of opinion and belief. Democracy teachings to Tehran are forbidden against this background. The EU's position is also unacceptable because of its intolerable imbalance: in the UNITED States and Israel, too, the death penalty is law, without the EU allowing itself to be addressed to these countries demands for their abolition. In both countries, the unlawful killing of people without any legal proceedings is commonplace without the EU sanctioning it. Nevertheless, in order to express the hope for a positive development of EU-Iran relations, the report was approved, with reservations.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is good that the nuclear agreement with Iran has been equipped with control mechanisms to check that it is meeting its obligations. However, despite the efforts of EU diplomacy, the agreement itself unfortunately does not cover human rights issues. It is therefore very good that they have been raised in the strategy that has just been adopted. It makes it clear that the Union will engage in a dialogue with Iran on the protection of human rights, which is facilitated by the opening of an EU delegation in Tehran. In this dialogue, on the other hand, the EU will make every effort to ensure that Iran does not apply the death penalty. Even abolishing it only for drug-related offences would reduce the number of executions by up to 80%. It is therefore important to use the dialogue platform currently adopted to persuade Iran to abandon its existing practices.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement, because I see it as an opportunity not only for Iran, which will certainly benefit from opening up to the world, but also for the EU itself, which is deeply attached to the idea of promoting the protection of human rights in the world.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Iran’s nuclear deal with the international community was a welcome step in de-escalating what could have turned into a dangerous conflict. The agreement has the potential to bring further stability to the region if all sides cooperate with the long-term interests of the region’s peoples in mind. This means that the EU and its Member States must put human rights at the core of the process, and engage in dialogue with Iran in order to bring about clear improvements in human rights conditions and an end to gross violations in Iran, including imprisonment of activists and human rights defenders, executions of minors, the systematic use of torture, and tolerance of gender-based violence. This must come about with clear human rights impact assessments, benchmarks and a monitoring framework, and full cooperation with UN mechanisms. Business and economic cooperation must go hand in hand with progress on human rights.  I voted in favour of this report, while actively working to include in it more compelling language on human rights with a clearer assessment of the current human rights situation, by supporting the amendments brought to the Plenary. The EEAS must see this report as a mandate to engage Iran on these issues.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted against the resolution because the approach towards Iran is not realistic considering the remaining challenges in Iran and there is no mention of the situation in Syria. The overall resolution is too positive and lacks a balance on Iran’s role in the region. There is too strong an emphasis on trade, disregarding human rights. It calls for cooperation between universities without mentioning the lack of academic freedom and is too vague with regard to juvenile executions. However, I am in favour of a dialogue concerning human rights and I support the immediate release of all political prisoners and others unjustly detained. I agree with open dialogues for nuclear safety and on energy diversification. I agree with condemning the fuelling of conflicts and the support of armed groups by Iran.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report adopted today addresses the future of EU-IRAN relations following the so-called Nuclear Agreement (JCPOA). The rapporteur has chosen to draft it constructively in the hope that an admissible relationship from the Iranian Government will be more useful to the moderate wing in its battle against the conservative part of government and will therefore lead to real progress on human rights and civil liberties in the country in the medium term. Iran has so far fully respected the nuclear agreement and there is a prospect of real change if the EU is able to make the most of the positive moment in bilateral relations created by the JCPOA. The references to the human rights situation are present, and while it is true that they could have been sharper and more incisive, I believe that the rapporteur is right when he says that this is the time to build, not destroy, in order to achieve in the future what the so many criticisms of the past have failed to achieve. For all these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to continue to have a constructive dialogue with Iran. Unfortunately, it has to be said that the EU's role has so far been too weak. In order to exploit the enormous potential of this bilateral relationship, Iran and the EU need to engage in a strategic dialogue that must go beyond the front-and-front aspects. It is in the interests of both sides to develop closer cooperation in areas such as the environment, migration management, transport and energy, education and humanitarian issues. What is at stake above all is the need to initiate and support a dialogue on a new security architecture for the Middle East. The issue of human rights is a vitally important issue that must be addressed in all possible forums. It is not acceptable to ignore the worrying use of the death penalty, the persecution of minorities, the arrests of activists and discrimination against women. I personally hope that iran's opening up to an international dimension will stimulate the improvement of the internal situation, and I believe that it is essential to establish a structured approach, devoid of paternalistic attitudes, in order to achieve more fruitful cooperation on these issues too.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report reflects fierce competition between urban classes and parts of the capital within the EU, as well as with other imperialist centres and powerful capitalist countries, not least the US, Russia, but also China to control markets, energy sources, raw materials and energy transport routes in the wider Middle East region, also linked to their attitude towards Iran , in light of the agreement on its nuclear programme. The European Parliament expresses the aspirations of EU monopolies to take advantage of the agreement to normalise EU-Iran political relations, which will facilitate their penetration into the Iranian market. These characteristics of the Iranian capitalist economy based on the savage exploitation of Iran's working class are a magnet for monopolies in the EU. This is what the report emphasises by designing their penetration with foreign direct investment, even focusing on specific sectors, such as automotive, aircraft manufacturing, energy infrastructure, renewable energy, etc. On the other hand, 'human rights', as the EU perceives them, will continue to be a pretext for political pressure, which will facilitate the aspirations of business groups. The people have nothing to look forward to from such competitions and agreements. That is why they must strengthen their fight against the common enemy, their monopolies and their power.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided not to support the EU strategy towards Iran. In my opinion, the European Union should take a more specific position towards Iran, particularly on respect for human rights. However, the strategy presented lacks deeper references to human rights, and i think its resulting form has even a slightly accommodating tuning towards Iran, which I do not find very happy. I am referring, in particular, to the expression of support for Iran's admission to the World Trade Organisation.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the successful conclusion of the nuclear agreement between the European Union and Iran, relations between Iran and the international community are slowly improving. As a result of the subsequent lifting of sanctions against the country, negotiations between the EU and Iran have intensified further. That is why the report dealt with the ideal form that relations between Iran and the European Union should gradually take. The report highlights the importance of relations with Iran, as well as Iran's overall role in bringing peace, stability and security to the region, which I fully agree with. However, it does not pay as much attention to human rights violations in Iran and, in my opinion, they deserve it. In fact, a number of executions are still being carried out in this country, including women and juveniles, with a large percentage of these executions being carried out as punishments for drug crimes. In the resolution, we therefore called on Iran to have an immediate moratorium on the death penalty, an end to torture, juvenile executions, but also a change in the law in favour of the complete abolition of the death penalty for drug crimes. As we have not succeeded in pushing through a number of amendments in the report to address the suppression of women's rights or political freedom, I did not support the final report in the final vote.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report, but I have two points there that I do not agree with, which is why I am using this institute to make it clear that an agreement is 90% acceptable to me, it is good that we are fighting corruption and strengthening cooperation between member states, but as I have already indicated, I have two objections. Firstly, I do not believe that what the agreement contains is right, that is to say, the unification of substantive criminal law at European level. Personally, I think, as someone who has devoted a lot of time to this topic in the past, that this is to some extent an illusion. Furthermore, I do not agree with the part of this material that supports the European Prosecutor's Office. But the majority of the document is good, it will strengthen the fight against corruption, which is why, despite these two objections, I ultimately supported this material.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, man is fallen. Some people in every society and every system will give into temptation. Corruption is, if you like, not a product of politics, it is the normal state of affairs. The amazing thing is that in Western, democratic societies we have found ways to constrain it and to incentivise people not just systematically to loot the state. But one thing we know is that you diminish the capacity for corruption when you take decisions as closely as possible to the people that they affect. This is the fundamental problem with our structures here and in Brussels. It is not that the European Union attracts bad people – of course, it attracts some bad people like everywhere else. It is that there is such a distance between people and decision-makers; there is such a tenuous link between taxation representation and expenditure that the system encourages, at best, negligent spending and, at worst, straightforward graft. The solution of course is to push powers downwards and outwards to national or local authorities, or better yet to individual citizens.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with the resolution because I believe that the issue of corruption is a fundamental issue for the future of the peoples of Europe and because I agree with the overall approach present in this resolution on the issue of combating corruption, understood as the fight against organised crime but also as a major social issue. The issue of combating corruption has very important social consequences, as we also see in the experiences of social anti-Mafia that have developed in my country, Italy. Some concrete proposals. We call on the Commission to publish its second report on the fight against corruption, which is expected at the beginning of 2016 but has not yet been received. We call for a change of approach in this report and also for the direct participation of the European institutions and not just of the individual Member States, as we call for the establishment of the European public prosecutor.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Organised crime, fraud, money laundering, corruption threaten the European economy. These are also channels for terrorist financing.  Fraud against the European Union budget, which we discuss every year, must be a crime throughout Europe. The VAT of the carousel with European money must be criminalised. That is why we urgently need the institution of the European Prosecutor, because at The Level of the Member States these offences are not investigated and are not followed by convictions at about the same level. There are ups and downs, very different figures. I hope that, at the latest, in the coming weeks, so the last of this year, we will have a clear answer for the completion of the negotiations on the European Prosecutor's institution.  One more thing: it is necessary to harmonise the limitation periods for the investigation and conviction of these acts of corruption, money laundering and fraud. If you allow me one last sentence, states that say they have no corruption, lie, because they have corruption, but they don't investigate it. Thanks.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is dócha gur maith an teideal é seo: troid i gcoinne na caimiléireachta, agus gan dabht, is troid é, agus troid is dócha nach mbuafar go deo, ach caithfimid ár ndícheall a dhéanamh. Agus is minic, go háirithe ar an Déardaoin, bímid ag caint anseo faoi chaimiléireacht agus ag cur isteach ar chearta daonna trasna an domhain uilig, agus a lán eiseamláirí de sin. Ach taobh amuigh den Aontas tá caimiléireacht ann freisin. I gcuid de na stáit, i mbaill den stáit, lucht gnó agus mar a chonaiceamar le déanaí, fiú amháin i ngluaiseachtaí spóirt. Chonaiceamar é maidir leis na Cluichí Oilimpeacha. Chonaiceamar é maidir le FIFA. Dá bhrí sin, tá sé ceart dúinn troid ina coinne, chun Cothrom na Féinne a thabhairt do gach uile dhuine agus go háirithe na daoine atá ag briseadh an dlí chun iad a stopadh. Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, although I consider the fight against corruption to some extent to be a political fetish. I think that humanity has been fighting corruption for so long that this is one of the longest fights it has fought, and the results are quite contradictory, but that's only marginal. I am also joining those who support enhanced cooperation between the Member States. Of course, in the fight against corruption, we should see, above all, the possibility of making decision-making processes as transparent as possible, opening them up. And how to have predictable rules, too, because if the principle of legal certainty applies, then, of course, it will be difficult to bribe if you know how a decision-making process will turn out. And I join my colleague Pospisil, because I, too, have long-standing reservations about the unification of substantive criminal law, which would then only be the unification of direct taxes, and that is only one step to the federation and also to the Office of the European Prosecutor.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – I am pleased that today we have had the opportunity to comment on the fight against organised crime. Corruption or money laundering is like a plague that is simply spreading in our countries and, unfortunately, is not avoiding our biggest political peaks at all.  I would therefore like to stress from this place that it is inconceivable that this area should be one of the main priorities of the Slovak Presidency in the Council of the European Union, and at the same time that our Slovak government officials themselves face legitimate suspicions of corruption of the highest dimensions on home soil. Such representatives probably have nothing to lead a MEMBER STATE of the EU, let alone have no moral right to talk about the fight against corruption at EU level.  I therefore share the proposal to adopt specific legislation to prevent and limit the activities of politicians who, although not members of criminal organisations, support them at various levels tabled in this resolution. At the same time, however, the principle of subsidiarity must be respected, which is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report makes proposals and recommendations to the European institutions and the Member States to strengthen actions to combat corruption and organised crime, including: the call for the mafia-style criminal association to be defined at European level, following the example of Article 416a of the Italian Criminal Code; recognition of the fundamental role of whistleblowers in the fight against corruption and unfair practices; the call for The Member States and the Commission to improve and ensure transparency in public procurement through the establishment of a computerised procurement system (e-procurement), by creating blacklists in which companies with proven links to organised crime can be included, by promoting the rotation of civil servants and by preventing those convicted of crimes related to organised crime or corruption from taking part in elections or working in public administration; measures to combat tax havens; increased penalties and the introduction of new categories of crime within the so-so-good environmental crimes. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. Organised crime, money laundering and transnational corruption are increasing criminal phenomena in the Union. The Ferrara report is important because it analyses what recommendations from those indicated by the European Parliament's Anti-Corruption Commission (CRIM) have been implemented and what is pending.  The report is very comprehensive and consists of eight sections. Each addresses a specific aspect of the fight against corruption and organized crime and calls for specific actions to be taken to achieve this. These points include monitoring the transposition of existing rules and their degree of implementation, the operational structure adopted in the fight against organized crime and corruption, the need to strengthen the legal framework for combating corruption, more effective judicial and police cooperation, confiscation of the assets of criminal organizations, preventing organized crime from penetrating the formal economy , the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a tool to combat this phenomenon and the identification of areas requiring further regulatory development. The report s meant identifying specific areas of failure in the legal system for preventing corruption to take steps to remedy it as soon as possible.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this non—legislative report. Whilst UKIP of course supports the continued fight against corruption and crime, we do not endorse the competencies of the EU to do this. More specifically, UKIP opposes further EU legislation and the expansion of Europol and, lastly, rejects calls for a European Public Prosecutor’s Office. UKIP MEPs have also voted against the EU calling for Member States to legislate on mandatory rules concerning the right to stand for election or work in public administrations. UKIP believe that it is not for the EU to dictate how Member States should run elections or who they may – or may not – employ in public administrative roles.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 Despite my position contrary to the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office which would generate a parallel system of justice without even physical resources to support it, I voted in favour of this resolution. I have done so because I understand that it contains very positive proposals in the fight against corruption and organized crime. Effective measures are proposed to states and the Union for the prevention of various offences carried out by the laxity of administrations, such as tax offences, trafficking in human beings, or environmental offences. In addition, specific punitive measures are proposed such as the prohibition of working in public institutions on persons convicted of corruption or money laundering offences, which I value very positively, hence my favourable vote.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report has significant positives in relation to fighting corruption, protecting whistle-blowers, the seizure of criminal assets, clamping down on tax havens and promoting fair trials. However, its references to the creation of a single European Public Prosecutors Office and its conclusion that no-one with a ‘serious’ criminal conviction can serve as an MEP make it impossible to support. We therefore abstained on this vote.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report by a large majority: Europe must have a sustained comprehensive strategy to deal with the increasing prevalence of organised crime and corruption in EU Member States.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on combating corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM Committee resolution, because it refers to the introduction of additional legislation to fill possible gaps in the fight against organised crime and corruption and aims to improve cross-border cooperation.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report recalls the ideas and recommendations presented in the 23 October 2013 resolution on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. In particular, it calls for the adoption of a European action plan to combat these crimes, which should be equipped with sufficient financial resources and qualified personnel to be effective. The text provides a relevant analysis of the extent of organised crime in all its forms, as well as the links between organised crime and terrorism, human trafficking, etc. However, rather than encouraging enhanced cooperation between Member States, the report calls for European solutions. In particular, he advocates the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, for the EU's accession to the GRECO (Group of States Against Corruption, as if the EU were a state), etc. In addition, it is also said that "the lack of legal migration channels and barriers to access to justice are among the main causes of human trafficking." Organised crime is in a way being used to strengthen the EU and further encourage non-European immigration. I obviously voted against this text.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because I believe that it is now necessary to adopt a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering, with sufficient financial resources and qualified personnel to be effective.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Corruption and money laundering account for 5% of the world's annual GDP and in developing countries the funds seized by illicit financial flows (NFS), including corruption, are approximately 10 times the amount of official development assistance (ODA) allocated to these countries. I therefore agree that the EU must assist developing or poor countries in the prioritisation of anti-corruption and organised crime measures and develop strong local and national systems and institutions to tackle corruption in line with their development agendas, i.e. the establishment of independent and competent regulatory and law enforcement systems and tax authorities, but also support NGOs, independent media and parliaments.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. Whilst UKIP of course supports the continued fight against corruption and crime, we do not endorse the competencies of the EU to do this. More specifically, UKIP opposes further EU legislation and the expansion of Europol and, lastly, rejects calls for a European Public Prosecutor’s Office. UKIP MEPs have also voted against the EU calling for Member States to legislate on mandatory rules concerning the right to stand for election or work in public administrations. UKIP believe that it is not for the EU to dictate how Member States should run elections or who they may – or may not – employ in public administrative roles.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report recalls the ideas and recommendations presented in its resolution of 23 October 2013 on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. In particular, it calls for the adoption of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering, which should be equipped with sufficient financial resources and qualified personnel to be effective. In addition, it is also said that "the lack of legal migration channels and barriers to access to justice are among the main causes of human trafficking." This is how organised crime is being used to strengthen the EU and further encourage non-European immigration: I have therefore, of course, voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have obviously approved this initiative report which calls for a genuine European plan against organised crime, fraud and corruption. In the area of corruption, the Commission is invited to draw up blacklists of companies with links to organised crime and engaged in corruption activities. They would no longer be able to operate in connection with the public authorities. Similarly, the report highlights the need for effective tools to freeze the assets of criminal groups and reuse them for social purposes. In particular, the Commission is invited to draw up a proposal for mutual recognition of asset forfeiture decisions.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. This report contains a number of vital measures to combat corruption and organized crime. From a call for greater cooperation in the criminal field to open support for the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office.  We call for urgent and incisive legislative measures at Community level to provide security forces with the necessary tools. Emphasize the establishment of a comprehensive Union-wide electronic public procurement system to reduce the risk of corruption. The development of "blacklists" of companies that have proven links to organized crime or involved in corrupt practices. Mandatory rules to disable those convicted of activities related to organised crime, money laundering, corruption, both to attend elections and to work for administrations, including Union institutions and agencies.  A common system for confiscating assets from criminal organizations and extending their use for social purposes, such as compensation to families and businesses affected by criminal or corrupt practices. We must move towards more Europe, because crime does not understand borders.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Organised crime is increasingly, thanks to its adaptability and tendency to diversify its activities, a global threat requiring strong action on the part of the European Union and its Member States. Over and above the greater dangers to public order linked to the manifestations of violence typical of criminal organisations, criminal penetration into the legal economy is particularly damaging, which is also achieved through the development of corrupt conduct towards officials and the consequent infiltration into institutions and public administration. The Ferrara report, which I supported today, reiterates the need to adopt a European action plan for the elimination of organised crime, corruption and money laundering. This requires not only adequate financial resources and qualified staff, but also a comprehensive and integrated approach to the problem. The transposition and correct transposition of existing rules must be ensured, their application monitored and their effectiveness assessed. Existing legislation needs to be reviewed in order to introduce effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions, and it is finally necessary to specify common definitions of offences and common methods for the seizure of property.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it has incorporated important amendments to issues of transparency, environmental aspects of corruption, better communication from judicial authorities, the need to address the labour exploitation of migrants and other relevant issues. The final text is balanced in its final wording on the most sensitive points such as the use of the internet or the links between organized crime and terrorism. Among the most positive aspects of the Report are: 1) An appeal to the Union to become a member of GRECO and the European Commission to publish its Anti-Corruption Report (including a section on the institutions of the Union) and to propose appropriate legislation; (2) Need for legislation to strengthen the rights of suspects and guarantees for a fair trial; 3) Call on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal on the protection of witnesses and whistleblowers by the end of 2017; (4) Requests the Union and the Member States to strengthen measures to locate, freeze and confiscate the product of crime and to prohibit fraudulent undertakings from accessing European public procurement procedures; 5) A firm declaration against tax havens.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. We support this report because it brings a European vision to the fight against corruption, one of the most destructive scourges installed in some Member States. It establishes guarantees for the correct transposition of European legislation, sets priorities, establishes improvements in police and judicial coordination against corruption, preventive measures to prevent infiltration into the legal economy and common methods for the seizure of goods obtained as a result of corrupt operations, all in line with our proposals presented in previous reports on the status of fundamental rights in the Union.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM commission resolution, and recalls the ideas and recommendations presented in the European Parliament resolution of 23 October 2013 on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. In particular, the report calls for the adoption of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering, which should be equipped with sufficient financial resources and qualified personnel to be effective. The analysis is relevant but the solution is Europeanist, to the detriment of cooperation between Member States. Here, the report uses crime to strengthen the EU and encourage more extra-European immigration. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I support it on many points, the report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the RESOLUTION of the CRIM Committee nevertheless contains some important critical issues that led me to abstain.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. Although I voted in favour of this report, I do not support the proposal concerning the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Nor do I support the call for mandatory rules that state that convicted persons should not be allowed to take political office or work in public administration. Such measures should be regarded as an additional sanction, which is normally only issued temporarily in court. Otherwise, the convicted persons are punished twice, which is contrary to the so-called ne bis in idem principle.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Organised crime, money laundering and transnational corruption are increasing criminal phenomena in the Union. The FERRARA report is important because it analyses what recommendations from those indicated by the European Parliament's Anti-Corruption Commission (CRIM) have been implemented and what is pending.  The report is very comprehensive and consists of eight sections. Each addresses a specific aspect of the fight against corruption and organized crime and calls for specific actions to be taken to achieve this. These points include monitoring the transposition of existing rules and their degree of implementation, the operational structure adopted in the fight against organized crime and corruption, the need to strengthen the legal framework for combating corruption, more effective judicial and police cooperation, confiscation of the assets of criminal organizations, preventing organized crime from penetrating the formal economy , the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a tool to combat this phenomenon and the identification of areas requiring further regulatory development. The report s meant identifying specific areas of failure in the legal system for preventing corruption to take steps to remedy it as soon as possible.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM Committee resolution. The European Parliament recalls that Member States should transpose and apply existing instruments at European and international level in order to combat organised crime, corruption and money laundering. Parliament asks the Commission to complete the assessment of such transposition measures as soon as possible, to keep it fully informed of the results and, if necessary, to initiate infringement proceedings. calls also on the Member States to properly transpose the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Investigation Order in criminal matters as a key tool for strengthening police and judicial cooperation in the European Union. The European Parliament regrets that the Commission has not yet published its 2nd anti-corruption report, which it was due to publish in early 2016. It therefore asks the Commission to present it as soon as possible and stresses that the anti-corruption report should not only review the situation in the Member States, but also the section for the Institutions of the European Union.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against corruption and its all forms has an extraordinary relevance in a democratic state. Corruption can only be tackled effectively in the long term and it is therefore very important that Member States implement their commitments in this area. The report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the CRIM Committee addresses a number of important issues. In particular, I agree with the emphasis on the importance of more effective police and judicial cooperation at EU level, as corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension. The designation of cybercrime as an area requiring special action is also to be welcomed, as the rapid development of the Internet has made cybercrime a major source of income for many criminal organisations. I agree with the need to strengthen EU legislation and cooperation between Member States and EU agencies in this area, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported this anti-corruption proposal, because corruption and other organised crime have an important interference with our democratic society. Organised crime is often cross-border and thus well adapted to the different legal systems, and therefore a coordinated joint response at European Union level is needed to prevent it.  It is necessary to ensure the correct transposition of the existing rules, to monitor their implementation and to assess their effectiveness. However, adequate financial resources and qualified staff must be provided for the success of this plan.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report, which reiterates the content and recommendations of my Resolution on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering. A European action plan against organised crime, corruption and money laundering is needed as soon as possible and adequate funding should be allocated alongside qualified staff in order to be as efficient as possible.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Instead of encouraging enhanced cooperation between Member States in the fight against organised crime, the report calls for European solutions. In particular, he advocates the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which I strongly oppose. I therefore objected to this text.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I cast my vote for this resolution on the fight against corruption because it reiterates the recommendations expressed in the 2013 CRIM resolution which I share. In particular, it calls for the adoption of a European Action Plan to eradicate organised crime, which I think should be adequately financed. Furthermore, it calls on the Commission to initiate infringement proceedings in case European and international instruments have not been adopted by the Member States. Indeed, I strongly believe that a serious approach to the fight against crime has to be adopted and a more coordinated response by the EU and the Member States needs to be delivered.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Organised crime, corruption and money laundering have a transnational dimension and cover a wide range of criminal activities. In order to eradicate this dimension, we need to introduce national databases, support for EU instruments and a European action plan, and we need active participation by international and regional organisations, in the public and private sectors, based on transparency and mutual responsibility. At present, corruption is one of the main obstacles to development, especially in developing countries, where it appropriates many of the funding they receive. The European Union should take a more active role in providing financial and technical assistance to these countries, developing a strong and comprehensive strategy for managing the risk of corruption in them. The Member States must make full use of the measures already envisaged against these crimes and it is essential to promote common investigative techniques. Progress must be made on international cooperation to combat trafficking in human beings from which crime profits a great deal. Transparency is the most effective means of combating abuse and fraud; Therefore, legislation needs to be improved by making it compulsory to publish data on all beneficiaries of EU funds.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is part of the resolution of 23 October 2013 and calls for the development of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering. Certainly, this report provides a relevant analysis of the extent of organized crime in all its forms. However, instead of encouraging Member States to strengthen their cooperation in the fight against organised crime, the European Union prefers as usual to create bureaucratic structures, which are costly to the taxpayer and whose effectiveness has yet to be demonstrated. In addition, the report uses organised crime as a pretext to strengthen the power of the European institutions. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Organised crime is one of the main global threats. Organisations made up of criminal groups have stepped up their illegal activities in recent years, and new action is needed to sanction their actions. As a result, it is necessary to create a framework for the correct transposition of existing rules, monitoring and evaluating their effectiveness. Thus, Member States should translate all existing instruments at European and international level into the fight against organised crime, corruption and money laundering. I was in favour of this report because I believe that a multidisciplinary approach is needed to prevent and combat organised crime and, at the same time, to achieve a strengthened partnership between the relevant national authorities and EU agencies.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Corruption poses a threat to democracy, the supremacy of law, social equity and justice, erodes the principles of effective administration, undermines the market economy and endangers the stability of state institutions. Most of the anti-corruption actions have mainly resulted in punitive measures to combat them, the effect of which has not been, by any means, the expected effect.  Global anti-corruption policy must be expressed, in the most effective way, through a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering.  I support the EP resolution proposal on the report on 'fighting corruption and follow-up actions to the CRIM resolution'. Eradicating corruption will stimulate economic activity. By doing so, the European Union will become stronger, the economic market of Member States more attractive to foreign investors, increase incomes in the private sector, improve the quality of services provided to the population and make it possible to promote social policy more effectively, develop the health and educational protection system. These actions are impossible without adequate support from the Commission, which must propose legislative measures that fill any gaps that may exist in the fight against organised crime and corruption and improve cross-border judicial cooperation.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. Organised crime, money laundering and transnational corruption are increasing criminal phenomena in the Union. The FERRARA report is important because it analyses what recommendations from those indicated by the European Parliament's Anti-Corruption Commission (CRIM) have been implemented and what is pending.  The report is very comprehensive and consists of eight sections. Each addresses a specific aspect of the fight against corruption and organized crime and calls for specific actions to be taken to achieve this. These points include monitoring the transposition of existing rules and their degree of implementation, the operational structure adopted in the fight against organized crime and corruption, the need to strengthen the legal framework for combating corruption, more effective judicial and police cooperation, confiscation of the assets of criminal organizations, preventing organized crime from penetrating the formal economy , the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a tool to combat this phenomenon and the identification of areas requiring further regulatory development. The report s meant identifying specific areas of failure in the legal system for preventing corruption to take steps to remedy it as soon as possible.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that criminal organisations have changed the way they work and are now availing themselves of the support of professionals, banking institutions, officials and politicians who, although not affiliated to the criminal organisation, support their activities at various levels. The danger of intimidating force resulting from simply belonging to an association is not a priority in relation to the fight against "fine crimes", crimes for which the association was created. This has left a regulatory and operational vacuum at European level, facilitating the transnational activities of organised criminal groups. The current EU political cycle to combat organised crime must therefore place the emphasis on combating associative crime and provide for the criminalisation of membership of a criminal association regardless of the consumption of fine crime. Among the priorities, in order to put in place a genuine European anti-corruption strategy, the fight against money laundering, corruption and trafficking in human beings must also be included. Cooperation between cross-border judicial police must be strengthened and information sharing facilitated at Member State level through Europol and Eurojust, thus ensuring greater use of joint investigation teams.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report contains a call for the EU to become a member of GRECO and for the Commission to publish its Anti-Corruption Report (including a section on the EU Institutions) and to propose adequate legislation. It stresses the need for legislation that would strengthen the rights of suspects and guarantees for fair trials; calls on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal protecting witnesses and whistle-blowers before the end of 2017; calls on the EU and the Member States to strengthen measures to trace, freeze and confiscate proceeds of crime and to ban fraudulent companies from European public procurement procedures; and contains a clear statement against tax havens. However, it also calls for the permanent loss of the right to be elected as MEP once convicted for a serious crime. I believe this is an additional sanction that can only be imposed by the courts in individual cases, and after careful consideration of all circumstances. The report also emphasises membership of a criminal organisation instead of the focus remaining on the actual acts performed. It also contains references to the proposal for a European Public Prosecutor, which I oppose. These concerns led me to abstain on the report while recognising its many positive aspects.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. Whilst UKIP of course support the continued fight against corruption and crime, we do not endorse the competencies of the EU to do this. More specifically, UKIP opposes further EU legislation and the expansion of Europol and, lastly, rejects calls for a European Public Prosecutors Office. UKIP MEPs have also voted against the EU calling for Member States to legislate on mandatory rules concerning the right to stand for election or work in public administrations. UKIP believe that it is not for the EU to dictate how Member States should run elections or who they may – or may not – employ in public administrative roles.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I attach great importance in the fight against corruption and crime. As a representative of EU citizens I take every opportunity to ensure that this principle is upheld in particular in my country. The draft report analyses the current situation in the EU regarding the fight against crime and makes proposals for combatting new forms of crimes with European instruments. The focus is amongst others on public officials and corruption, whistle-blower protections and use of EU funds.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My colleague's excellent report starts from the basis of the result of the CRIM Special Committee, which between 2012 and 2013 had worked to identify the actions needed to combat organised crime at European level. The report, starting from the aspects that have not yet been implemented, focuses on the major priority aspects for the current historical moment and makes proposals and recommendations. These include the call for the establishment at European level of mafia-style criminal associations and the recognition of the fundamental role of whistleblowers in the fight against corruption, measures to combat tax havens and the compilation of a black list of companies with proven links to organised crime in order to improve the system of public procurement management. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in the European Parliament support the fight against corruption, money laundering and organised and cross-border crime, including through European cooperation. There are parts of the proposal that fall under the Danish legal opt-out and others that we believe should fall within the competence of the Member States, such as when citizens can run for public office in their own countries and how long officials can hold them. Similarly, we support the idea of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, as long as it is for combating fraud against the EU's financial interests. Overall, however, we believe that the report sends a right signal on the fight against crime types, as mentioned above, and we have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote in favour of the report and stress that organised crime poses a global threat and that, as such, it requires a common and coordinated response on the part of the EU and its Member States.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on combating corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM committee resolution comes at a time when we all understand the importance of combating corruption in the public and private sectors. Although we must be particularly careful about the attribution of responsibilities and the sanctions imposed, I believe that the adoption of rules that work in the public interest is necessary more than ever. I have therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the resolution because I believe that the fight against corruption and organised crime is essential. Organised crime is an endemic and global threat, a cancer with metastases spread everywhere that requires joint, rapid and effective therapy through adequate financial resources and competent human resources. I renew my call on the Commission to publish the second report on corruption as soon as possible, including a focus on the European institutions to verify and monitor their presence. At the same time, I believe that it is the Commission's duty to draw up an in-depth study of the most advanced legislation on combating organised crime and corruption in such a way as to develop more efficient and state-of-the-art European legislation. In line with what I have voted for, I am deeply convinced of the increase in investments linked to the culture of legality, not only to make future generations more aware of the problem and therefore better, but at the same time to raise awareness of the human, social and economic damage caused by the phenomena in question. This will only become possible with the adoption of a strengthened legislative framework accompanied by vigorous police and judicial cooperation based on the quickest and most active cross-border cooperation.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the fight against corruption and follow-up of the CRIM resolution and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The fight against organised crime was a priority for the European Union from an early age. It is necessarily a key part of judicial and police cooperation in criminal matters, the origin of which lies in the Schengen agreement and free movement. It is also clear that, in particular in the last 15 years, organised crime has gained a new dimension, among others, it has become more cross-border, making greater use of new technologies.  This resolution, which I support and vote for, is the result of the work that has been developed by Parliament in this area since 2011. New problems are diagnosed, for example with regard to the misuse of funds, but also new paths, particularly with regard to environmental crimes.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Despite my position contrary to the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office which would generate a parallel system of justice without even physical resources to support it, I voted in favour of this resolution. I have done so because I understand that it contains very positive proposals in the fight against corruption and organized crime. Effective measures are proposed to states and the Union for the prevention of various offences carried out by the laxity of administrations, such as tax offences, trafficking in human beings, or environmental offences. In addition, specific punitive measures are proposed such as the prohibition of working in public institutions on persons convicted of corruption or money laundering offences, which I value very positively, hence my favourable vote.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Organised crime poses a global threat, requiring a common response, coordinated by the EU and its Member States. Organised criminal groups have demonstrated a particular tendency and capacity to diversify their activities, thus adapting to the geographical factor and different economic and social contexts, exploiting their weaknesses and vulnerabilities, acting simultaneously in different markets and taking advantage of differences in legislative provisions in the legal systems of the Member States.  Organised crime, corruption and money laundering pose serious threats to the EU economy, significantly reducing the tax revenues of Member States as well as the EU as a whole.
