Re-evaluating the legislative framework to fill any need is a priority. The phenomenon of organised crime has a cross-border dimension and requires more effective cooperation at EU level.  I voted for the creation of an appropriate system at EU level for the exchange of information between judicial authorities within the Union.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I do not support the report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM resolution, because, in my opinion, these actions are incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. I have always opposed the idea of creating an Office of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and eu membership of the Group of States Against Corruption. The faction to which I belong has proposed a number of amendments on this issue, but they have been rejected, and I have therefore voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as we need to recognise the importance of having an effective strategy which is backed up by a serious action plan to tackle organised crime and corruption, which is infiltrating many levels of society in the EU. I am in favour of the specific areas requiring action listed in this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am strongly in favour of measures to combat heinous crimes such as human trafficking, and serious organised crime, I cannot support that the establishment of the European Public Prosecutors’ Office is required to achieve this; instead we should use existing agencies such as Eurojust and Europol to achieve the same aims. We should resist moving towards an EU system that encroaches on national criminal justice systems.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the recommendations made by the Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering during the last mandate, which sets out a comprehensive action plan for measures to be implemented to combat organised crime in Europe. Of course, I regret that, as all too often in texts which are not legally binding, some political groups are advocating measures that are sometimes unrealistic and which undermine the principle of subsidiarity in Europe. However, many of the proposals in this text are crucial at a time when organised crime and money laundering are particularly benefiting terrorist organisations which pose a serious security threat to our Member States. I therefore reaffirm in particular my support for the creation of an effective European Public Prosecutor's Office in Europe, but also the duty of Member States to intensify cross-border police and judicial cooperation and information exchanges between them and through Europol and Eurojust.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the fight against corruption. I believe that it is essential to put in place European measures to combat organised crime, corruption and money laundering, because these practices do not take borders into account. They are a real scourge for our societies and there is an urgent need to take effective measures to eradicate them.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against corruption and its all forms has an extraordinary relevance in a democratic state. Corruption can only be tackled effectively in the long term, and it is therefore very important that Member States implement their commitments in this area.  The report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the CRIM Committee addresses a number of important issues. In particular, I agree with the emphasis on the importance of more effective police and judicial cooperation at EU level, as corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension. The designation of cybercrime as an area requiring special action is also to be welcomed, as the rapid development of the Internet has made cybercrime a major source of income for many criminal organisations. I agree with the need to strengthen EU legislation and cooperation between Member States and EU agencies in this area, and I therefore vote in favour of the adoption of this report as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This assessment report on the state of organised crime, corruption and money laundering in Europe paints an alarming picture of the situation in the Union. That is why Member States must quickly tackle the work of moralising public life. Part of the answer lies at European level; criminal organisations should no longer be able to take advantage of the lack of coordination between Member States. European agencies such as Frontex, Europol and Eurojust must be equipped to be able to combat these networks. And a European prosecutor's office to combat offences affected the Union's financial interests, as stipulated in the EU treaties, must be put in place quickly.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report recalls the ideas and recommendations presented in the 23 October 2013 resolution on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. In particular, it calls for the adoption of a European action plan in the context of this triple struggle, with sufficient financial resources and qualified staff. The text is lucid about the extent of organised crime in all its forms, as well as the links between organised crime, terrorism and human trafficking. However, instead of encouraging enhanced cooperation between states in the fight against organised crime, the report calls for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, or for the EU's accession to GRECO (Group of States Against Corruption) as if the EU were a state. In addition, the report deplores the "lack of legal migration channels" as a cause of human trafficking. Organised crime does not have to be used to strengthen the EU and further encourage non-European immigration. Also, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support colleague Ferrara's report on the fight against corruption and the actions resulting from the resolution of the Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering, as it contains some points with which I cannot agree. One of them is the call for concrete action at EU level, which I believe is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Organised crime has a cross-border dimension and includes a number of criminal activities, including drug trafficking, migrant trafficking, money laundering and trafficking in counterfeit goods, firearms, wildlife and cultural goods: The report fails to set a proper framework, as have the relevant international conventions and initiatives aimed at combating corruption and illicit financial flows , since they are unable to produce concrete results at the stage of their implementation.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – The fight against corruption and its action in all its forms has an extraordinary relevance in a democratic state. Corruption can only be tackled effectively in the long term and it is therefore very important that Member States implement their commitments in this area. The report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the CRIM Committee addresses a number of important issues. In particular, I agree with the emphasis on the importance of more effective police and judicial cooperation at EU level, as corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension. The designation of cybercrime as an area requiring special action is also to be welcomed, as the rapid development of the Internet has made cybercrime a major source of income for many criminal organisations. I agree with the need to strengthen EU legislation and cooperation between Member States and EU agencies in this area, and therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ people's delegation, I am voting in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I can broadly support this report, which stresses the importance of combating organised crime, corruption and money laundering. However, in the draft report, paragraph 42b states that people who have been found guilty of the crimes referred to in this resolution would not be able to stand as candidates in elections or be able to work for a public institution. For me, the order we have in Sweden in terms of opportunities to stand as a candidate in elections and seek public office is good and reflects well my position in principle. That is why I voted against paragraph 42b.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering must be in the EU's priorities, which, in order to be effective, must have adequate financial resources and qualified staff.  The fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering must be a political priority of the Union institutions and, for this reason, police and judicial cooperation between Member States is essential.  I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: rather than encouraging enhanced cooperation between Member States in the fight against organised crime, the report calls for European solutions. In particular, he advocates the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, for the EU's accession to the GRECO (Group of States Against Corruption, as if the EU were a state), etc.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a report on the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering, covering sectors such as smuggling, drug trafficking, gambling and match-setting sports results, tax havens, environmental crimes, cybercrime, organised crime and terrorism and trafficking in human beings and migrants. Broadly speaking, this report considers that police and judicial cooperation between Member States should be a political priority for THE EU. In agreement with the imperative need to combat the types of crime set out above, we essentially disagree with the approach adopted by the report and the advanced solutions, without prejudice to specific concrete measures which appear relevant. The report omits – and otherwise would not be expected – the intimate relationship that exists between the capitalist system, the policies that support it and the set of crime phenomena mentioned. The option is another: more integration in the field of justice and the police field, areas that touch at the heart of the sovereignty and independence of states, with new steps in amputating portions of this sovereignty, to concentrate power on the supranational structures of the EU, controlled by the major powers and at the service of reactionary and retrograde agendas, restrictive of rights, freedoms and guarantees.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report in question follows on from the European Parliament's report last legislative term on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. The main message of this report is that the European Union must step up its efforts in the fight against corruption, organised crime and money laundering. In future, we must work together to create a legislative instrument that successfully deals with criminal organisations, and also to think about whether banks that are able to launder money will be stripped of their licences or whether the European Public Prosecutor should investigate organised crime in the future.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because, despite many positive passages, there are still some critical points, such as the decriminalisation of soft drugs and the praise of the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Organised crime has a cross-border dimension and includes a number of criminal activities, including drug trafficking, migrant trafficking, money laundering and trafficking in counterfeit goods, firearms, wildlife and cultural goods. The report fails to set a proper framework, as have the most relevant international conventions and initiatives aimed at combating corruption and illicit financial flows, since they fail to produce concrete results at the stage of their implementation. For these reasons I am voting against the report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM committee resolution.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report is a follow-up to the Parliament report adopted in the last legislature on organised crime, corruption and money laundering (the ‘CRIM’ Report). The report was drafted in anticipation of the Commission’s 2nd Anti-Corruption Report (still not published), takes a fresh look at the recommendations set out in the CRIM Report, and seeks to draw conclusions on the recommendations which were followed up and those which were not. At a time when all the talk is of a ‘terrorist threat’, it is crucial not to forget the importance of having a serious strategy backed up by serious action to tackle the growing prevalence of organised crime and corruption infiltrating many levels of society in the EU. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against corruption and its all forms has an extraordinary relevance in a democratic state. Corruption can only be tackled effectively in the long term, and it is therefore very important that Member States implement their commitments in this area.  The report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the CRIM Committee addresses a number of important issues. In particular, I agree with the emphasis on the importance of more effective police and judicial cooperation at EU level, as corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension. I agree with the need to strengthen EU legislation and cooperation between Member States and EU agencies in this area, and I therefore vote in favour of the adoption of this report as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

I agree with the need to strengthen EU legislation and cooperation between Member States and EU agencies in this area, and I therefore vote in favour of the adoption of this report as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report considering that organised crime, corruption and money laundering pose serious threats to the Union economy by significantly reducing the tax collection of the Member States and the Union as a whole. We must develop effective and cutting-edge European legislation on the fight against organised crime and corruption. The phenomenon of organised crime, corruption and money laundering generally has a cross-border dimension that requires close cooperation between the competent national authorities and between national authorities and relevant Union agencies.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – Organised crime, money laundering and transnational corruption are increasing criminal phenomena in the Union. The FERRARA report is important because it analyses what recommendations from those indicated by the European Parliament's Anti-Corruption Commission (CRIM) have been implemented and what is pending. The report s meant identifying specific areas of failure in the legal system for preventing corruption to take steps to remedy it as soon as possible.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of Mrs Ferrara's report, to which I gave my full support, the European Parliament is taking a further step forward in the fight against corruption and organised crime. At such a sensitive time for Europe as the one we are experiencing, when we are dealing with the terrorist threat, it is urgent to come to terms with our inadequa contiguities and security gaps and, despite the great progress we have made, to push for integrity on the accelerator, calling for greater and stricter preventive control actions, the strengthening of judicial and police cooperation and maximum transparency and traceability in economic operations. , to curb money laundering and criminal permeability. Corruption is a threat, which also costs Europe around EUR 120 billion a year: the EU cannot wait, but it must respond urgently with a sound, homogeneous and shared plan.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on combating corruption and the follow-up to the RESOLUTION of the CRIM Committee, because I believe that following up the research and synthesis work through the final report of the CRIM Committee adopted by the EP during the last parliamentary term is significant because of the importance that the EP attaches to the fight against mafias and organised crime. The main purpose of organised crime is profit; It is therefore of paramount importance that law enforcement agencies have the necessary capacity to target funding channels, which are often inseparable from corruption, fraud, counterfeiting and smuggling. I therefore shared the need to make the fight against crime a priority, and in order to do so, Europe needs an operational structure to combat organised crime and corruption, but above all it is necessary to create a stronger legal framework in which priorities are defined in connection with European crime prevention policies and economic policies. , social, employment and education, ensuring the full integration of the European Parliament. Finally, I supported the call for the Commission to draw up minimum standards for the definition of offences and penalties.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM resolution. Combating corruption and full tax justice can only be achieved across borders, and the EU must play an active role here – for the benefit of its citizens and the honourable middle class.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The work of the Special Committee against Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering (CRIM) must continue after its expiry. Mrs Ferrara's report is particularly important in that it highlights the current situation of the European Union in the fight against corruption in the Member States, organised crime and environmental crime.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the fight against corruption and follow-up of the CRIM Committee resolution, as it reiterates the recommendations set out in the 2013 resolution on organised crime, corruption and money laundering and calls for the transposition and application of existing anti-corruption instruments by Member States.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it allows us to draw attention to some of the most terrible scourges afflicting our territories: corruption and organised crime. It is right that the European institutions should continue the path begun with CRIM (the Special Commission on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering) and to do more and better for more efficient police and judicial cooperation at EU level, a stronger legislative framework, more efficient police and judicial cooperation at EU level, and again to target the heritage of criminal organisations and facilitate their social re-use , as well as to prevent the infiltration of organised crime and corruption into the legal economy. We therefore await the publication of its second report on combating corruption from the Commission and strongly call for adequate resources to be allocated to the European action plan for the elimination of organised crime, corruption and money laundering. Furthermore, and I will end here, we need to invest more, including as individual Member States, in building a real culture of legality that is pervasive in our societies, because only in this way can we prevent the emergence of those grey areas in which organised crime has always flourished.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it has incorporated important amendments to issues of transparency, environmental aspects of corruption, better communication from judicial authorities, the need to address the labour exploitation of migrants and other relevant issues. The final text is balanced in its final wording on the most sensitive points such as the use of the internet or the links between organized crime and terrorism. Among the most positive aspects of the Report are: 1) An appeal to the Union to become a member of GRECO and the European Commission to publish its Anti-Corruption Report (including a section on the institutions of the Union) and to propose appropriate legislation; (2) Need for legislation to strengthen the rights of suspects and guarantees for a fair trial; 3) Call on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal on the protection of witnesses and whistleblowers by the end of 2017; (4) Requests the Union and the Member States to strengthen measures to locate, freeze and confiscate the product of crime and to prohibit fraudulent undertakings from accessing European public procurement procedures; 5) A firm declaration against tax havens.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it reiterates the recommendations set out in the 2013 resolution on organised crime, corruption and money laundering, and calls for the transposition and application of existing anti-corruption instruments by Member States. It also calls for the Commission to complete an assessment of the measures taken to transpose these instruments and recommends that the EU become a member of the Council of Europe’s anti-corruption monitoring body, GRECO.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. I support the establishment of a specialist Europol unit to combat organised criminal groups which operate in several sectors at the same time. Also, the Member States should set up secure and effective mechanisms in the current institutional framework to ensure that investigations into organised crime are properly coordinated and that mutual trust among law enforcement authorities in the Member States is fostered.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats voted in favour of the report on combating corruption and following up on the resolution of the Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering. Paragraph 42.b proposes a ban on persons convicted of certain offences or who have participated in organised crime from working in the public administration of the Member States and standing in general elections.  We understand that the idea behind the proposal is to combat corruption and prevent the influence of organised crime in elected assemblies, which is a problem in some Member States. However, we believe that rules on who can stand in general elections should be laid down in the Member States. In principle, we also believe that it is important that people convicted of crimes can be given a second chance. We therefore abstained in the vote on this point, but voted in favour of the report in the final vote.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. Organised crime, money laundering and transnational corruption are increasing criminal phenomena in the Union. The FERRARA report is important because it analyses what recommendations from those indicated by the European Parliament's Anti-Corruption Commission (CRIM) have been implemented and what is pending.  The report is very comprehensive and consists of eight sections. Each addresses a specific aspect of the fight against corruption and organized crime and calls for specific actions to be taken to achieve this. These points include monitoring the transposition of existing rules and their degree of implementation, the operational structure adopted in the fight against organized crime and corruption, the need to strengthen the legal framework for combating corruption, more effective judicial and police cooperation, confiscation of the assets of criminal organizations, preventing organized crime from penetrating the formal economy , the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a tool to combat this phenomenon and the identification of areas requiring further regulatory development. The report s meant identifying specific areas of failure in the legal system for preventing corruption to take steps to remedy it as soon as possible.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against corruption and its all forms has an extraordinary relevance in a democratic state. Corruption can only be tackled effectively in the long term, so it is very important that Member States implement their commitments in this area. The report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the CRIM Committee addresses a number of important issues. Of these, it is of the utmost importance to emphasise the importance of more effective police and judicial cooperation at EU level, as corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension. The designation of cybercrime as an area requiring special action is also to be welcomed, as the rapid development of the Internet has made cybercrime a major source of income for many criminal organisations. I agree with the need to strengthen EU legislation and cooperation between Member States and EU agencies in this area.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report is the necessary follow-up to the resolution adopted in October 2013 on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. It contains positive and negative elements. Some of the good recommendations contained in the report are the fact that the EU is being asked to become a member of GRECO and by the Commission to publish its anti-corruption report and propose appropriate legislation. It mentions the need for legislation that will strengthen suspects' rights as well as guarantees of a fair trial, and requires the Commission to submit a legislative proposal to protect witnesses and informants before the end of 2017. However, three key issues mentioned in the report tend to be worrying. Firstly, the permanent loss of the right to be elected as an MEP, once convicted of a felony, secondly, references to the need to place greater emphasis on participation in a criminal organisation than on crime, and thirdly, references to the European Public Prosecutor's Office. For these reasons, we abstained.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this motion. As a member of the European Parliament’s ITCO interest group, I believe it is vital to ensure the correct transposition of existing rules, monitor their application and assess whether they are effective. Further, I support the adoption of a European Action Plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering, which should have adequate financial resources and qualified staff in order to be effective.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report mirrors the topics and the recommendations of the October 2013 resolution, which was the result of the special committee on organised crime. Several aspects of the report were positive, such as the call for measures against human trafficking and more transparency of EU funds. However, there are many elements in the report that are alarming in terms of subsidiarity and respect for national competences, which is why I have voted against it.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, I support the report on the fight against corruption and action related to the fight against organised crime and money laundering, as I believe that we really need a review of existing legislation to combat organised crime and corruption in order to optimise it, from more police and judicial cooperation at European level, to improve information sharing between the justice services and Europol and to establish an effective European Public Prosecutor's Office with clearly defined powers to support national authorities.  According to the report, for 2014 the irregularities detected in relation to the European budget amounted to EUR 538 million. This value reflects only actual irregularities committed and does not take into account the negative impact of phenomena such as corruption, money laundering, tax avoidance.  I therefore again call on the Council to examine the remaining points at issue and to adopt a decision on the proposal for the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, the proposal for a directive on the fight against fraud to the Union's financial interests and the proposal for a regulation on the Agency for criminal justice cooperation Eurojust.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which draws attention to the importance of the legal system in preventing organised crime, corruption and money laundering. This report highlights the need for urgent regulatory action at European level on the spread of corruption and high-level criminal organisations. The overall objectives of the report are to ensure the existence of rules in this area and calls for a more holistic approach to organised crime and corruption.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Anti-Corruption and Follow-Up Report following the CRIM Resolution, as I consider organised crime to be a global threat and as such require a joint and coordinated response from the EU and its Member States.  This Report welcomes the 18-month Eu Council programme for the Dutch, Slovak and Maltese Presidencies, which makes a comprehensive and integrated approach to organised crime high on the list of priorities, and stresses that the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering must be a political priority for the EU institutions, and cooperation between the police and member states' judicial authorities is therefore essential. The EU needs to adopt action plans against organised crime, corruption and money laundering that need adequate funding and qualified staff to be effective.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I welcome the quality of Mrs Ferrara's report on the extent of organised crime, whatever its form, and its links to terrorism or human trafficking. Nevertheless, the solution he advocates seems to me to be false and manipulative: instead of encouraging cooperation between the Member States, this report wishes to entrust the management of this fight to the sole benefit of the EU, hence, for example, the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and the accession of the EU, as a state, to the Group of States against Corruption. Finally, I denounce the scandalous use of organised crime to justify a consolidation of the EU and increase immigration. I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Organised crime is a global threat and therefore requires an adequate coordinated response from the European Union and its Member States. Corruption and money laundering continue to grow in the EU and around the world, with a clear impact on the security of European Union citizens and entrepreneurship in Europe. I supported the resolution on combating corruption because tax evasion needs to be prevented and I believe that the steps proposed in it will lead to the elimination of organised crime, which is represented by corruption and money laundering.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up of the CRIM resolution is very positive as a whole. I just want to explain why I voted against paragraph 42, point b) of this report. Although I support the idea of prohibiting, for some time, persons convicted of corruption from holding public office or being elected, the text of paragraph 42, point b) is unfortunately not sufficiently clear and precise. Indeed, as drafted, it also applies to persons "who have participated" in acts of corruption, which does not in any way correspond to a well-defined category and thus undermines legal certainty. It would have been fairer to limit this proposal to only those "convicted" of corruption or organised crime. Moreover, the wording of paragraph 42, point b) is not sufficiently precise in that it may concern any person who is the subject of a conviction, whether or not it is related to corruption. Such a reading of the text could, for example, prevent some environmental activists or trade unionists from being elected or holding public office, which is obviously too restrictive and contrary to the intended purpose.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Although I voted in favour of this report, I do not support the proposals concerning the Office of the European Prosecutor. Nor do I support the call for mandatory rules establishing that convicted persons should not be eligible to stand for election or to work in or for the public administration. This type of measure should be seen as an additional sanction, normally only imposed for a limited time by the court. Otherwise, the convicted persons are punished twice which is a violation of the ‘ne bis in idem’ principle.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Laura Ferrara's report on the aftermath of the report on organised crime. The report, adopted in May 2016, makes proposals for new forms of crime, whistleblower protection and environmental crimes. The vote called for a concrete European action plan to eradicate organised crime, money laundering and corruption.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Ferrara's report because the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering must be a political priority of the EU institutions. For this reason, police and judicial cooperation between Member States is fundamental. The report recalls that Member States, in the context of the fight against organised crime, corruption and money laundering, should transpose into their national law and implement existing instruments at Union and international level.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. Although it contains, in principle, correct findings and conclusions on the roots and ways of combating organised crime and corruption, I still have concerns about the establishment and acceleration of the work of a European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it reiterates the recommendations set out in the 2013 resolution on organised crime, corruption and money laundering, and calls for the transposition and application of existing anti-corruption instruments by Member States. It also calls for the Commission to complete an assessment of the measures taken to transpose these instruments and recommends that the EU become a member of the Council of Europe’s anti-corruption monitoring body, GRECO.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in the European Parliament support the fight against corruption, money laundering and organised and cross-border crime, including through European cooperation.  There are parts of the proposal that fall under the Danish legal opt-out and others that we believe should fall within the competence of the Member States, such as when citizens can run for public office in their own countries and how long officials can hold them. Similarly, we support the idea of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, as long as it is for combating fraud against the EU's financial interests.  Overall, however, we believe that the report sends a right signal on the fight against crime types, as mentioned above, and we have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the report on the fight against corruption and the next steps following the CRIM resolution. This was due to amendments 51 to 54 concerning the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which unfortunately passed during the vote. Like the Czech Republic, I have long disagreed with the presented concept of how this office is to be set up, and the Czech Republic has even issued a so-called yellow card on this proposal under the member states' pre-warning system. However, as a whole, I consider the report on the fight against corruption to be quite solid, but in the context of the above, it was impossible for me to fully support the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against corruption and its all forms has an extraordinary relevance in a democratic state. Corruption can only be tackled effectively in the long term and it is therefore very important that Member States implement their commitments in this area.  The report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the CRIM Committee addresses a number of important issues. In particular, I agree with the emphasis on the importance of more effective police and judicial cooperation at EU level, as corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension. The designation of cybercrime as an area requiring special action is also to be welcomed, as the rapid development of the Internet has made cybercrime a major source of income for many criminal organisations. I agree with the need to strengthen EU legislation and cooperation between Member States and EU agencies in this area, and therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ people's delegation, I am voting in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – In my country, the necessary control bodies have little progress in their fight against corruption, which is not very surprising given the personal mergers and the specific system of government. Winners of public procurement procedures are often predictable. At the same time, it is because of the European Public Prosecutor's Office to be set up in the fight against corruption that there is a dilemma in support of the proposal for a resolution, while an organisation would be needed that would allow senior officials in the Member States to be held legally liable for corruption. There can be no compromise on the need for effective tools and unrespeatable determination to fight corruption.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the adoption of the proposal for a regulation on the fight against corruption and the actions resulting from the resolution of the Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering, as I share the view that a revision of the legislative framework is necessary to address any gaps in the fight against organised crime and corruption and to improve cross-border judicial cooperation. It is imperative to introduce effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions against the unlawful acquisition of any kind of financial and/or material benefit. Organised crime, corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension, which requires close cooperation between competent national authorities and between national authorities and relevant EU agencies, and the Regulation will contribute to enhanced police and judicial cooperation at European level. The adopted Regulation creates real conditions to prevent organised crime and corruption from entering the legitimate economy and calls for a comprehensive 'e-procurement' system to be introduced across the EU in order to reduce the risk of corruption in public procurement.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Transnational organised crime and corruption constitute major global issues. Looking from this perspective, the fight against both issues should be a top priority for the EU and its Member States. We should adopt and support common European Action Plan for fighting organised crime and corruption. There are several reasons for this. Firstly, the European Action Plan for fighting organised crime and corruption will facilitate effectively police and judicial cooperation between Member States. Secondly, it will break down national boundaries recognising the added value that the European legislation have. Thirdly, it will provide law enforcement authorities at European level with the necessary tools to properly fight organised crime group across Europe. Last but not least, in order our fight against organised crime and corruption to be effective, the Member States should set up secure and effective mechanisms in the current institutional framework to ensure that investigations into organised crime are properly coordinated and that mutual trust among law enforcement authorities in the Member States is fostered.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. We all agree on the need to step up our efforts to combat corruption and crime. Parliament's motion for a resolution adopted today is the result of the analyses carried out by the CRIM Committee on the Situation in Europe and, at the same time, contains a number of proposals for new policies and actions. Among the various recommendations, there is a call for a review of European anti-corruption legislation; to create European rules for the confiscation of the assets of criminal organisations and for the protection of so-called whistleblowers; to set up a specialised Europol unit to combat criminal groups; to draw up a list of all companies that have committed crimes and to ensure that they are excluded from all links with european public administration and funds; to establish laws prohibiting political candidacy and employment in the public administration by persons convicted of corruption offences. A call for a series of measures aimed at strongly combating corruption, the weight of which is borne not only by our institutions, but also by all the citizens of the Union.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the fight against corruption and followed the resolution of the CRIM committee. The report calls for the adoption of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering, which should be equipped with sufficient financial resources and qualified personnel to be effective. The text provides a relevant analysis of the extent of organised crime in all its forms, as well as the links between organised crime and terrorism, human trafficking, etc. However, rather than encouraging enhanced cooperation between Member States in the fight against organised crime, the report calls for European solutions. In particular, he advocates the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, for the EU's accession to the GRECO (Group of States Against Corruption, as if the EU were a state), etc. In addition, it is also said that "the lack of legal migration channels and barriers to access to justice are among the main causes of human trafficking." Organised crime is in a way being used to strengthen the EU and encourage non-European immigration.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The report aims to combat organised crime, corruption and money laundering. However, this objective is being hijacked to promote the EU, to the detriment of enhanced cooperation between Member States. This instrumentalization of the fight against organised crime led me to vote against this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Organised crime, money laundering and transnational corruption are increasing criminal phenomena in the Union. The FERRARA report is important because it analyses what recommendations from those indicated by the European Parliament's Anti-Corruption Commission (CRIM) have been implemented and what is pending.  The report is very comprehensive and consists of eight sections. Each addresses a specific aspect of the fight against corruption and organized crime and calls for specific actions to be taken to achieve this. These points include monitoring the transposition of existing rules and their degree of implementation, the operational structure adopted in the fight against organized crime and corruption, the need to strengthen the legal framework for combating corruption, more effective judicial and police cooperation, confiscation of the assets of criminal organizations, preventing organized crime from penetrating the formal economy , the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a tool to combat this phenomenon and the identification of areas requiring further regulatory development. The report s meant identifying specific areas of failure in the legal system for preventing corruption to take steps to remedy it as soon as possible.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. Organised crime, money laundering and transnational corruption are increasing criminal phenomena in the Union. The FERRARA report is important because it analyses what recommendations from those indicated by the European Parliament's Anti-Corruption Commission (CRIM) have been implemented and what is pending.  The report is very comprehensive and consists of eight sections. Each addresses a specific aspect of the fight against corruption and organized crime and calls for specific actions to be taken to achieve this. These points include monitoring the transposition of existing rules and their degree of implementation, the operational structure adopted in the fight against organized crime and corruption, the need to strengthen the legal framework for combating corruption, more effective judicial and police cooperation, confiscation of the assets of criminal organizations, preventing organized crime from penetrating the formal economy , the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a tool to combat this phenomenon and the identification of areas requiring further regulatory development. The report s meant identifying specific areas of failure in the legal system for preventing corruption to take steps to remedy it as soon as possible.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report identifies the seriousness of corruption, a phenomenon that adapts to new activities, different geographical, economic and social sectors and new markets, and wreaks serious havoc on the economy. Specifically, it is recalled that in 2014 1 649 irregularities worth EUR 538.2 million were identified as fraud in the European budget.  In this regard, we call on the Commission in this report to review existing legislation to establish effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions, to clarify common definitions of crime and, to give an example of transparency, to include in its report on combating corruption to the European institutions. I welcome the report because in order to end the scourge of corruption it is essential to foster a culture of legality and to encourage greater exchange of information on fraud between Member States.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that looks for new ways to combat crime using European instruments.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I consider the resolution to be legally diletant and contrary to the rule of law. The resolution 'calls on the Member States to adopt specific legislation and appropriate measures to prevent and combat the activities of professionals, banking institutions, officials and politicians at all levels who, while not members of criminal organisations, support this activity at different levels'. In this respect, it "calls for the imposition of criminal sanctions on managers and banks involved in cases where large amounts of money have been proven to be laundered." Criminal sanctions are to be imposed by a court on the basis of law and not on the basis of an ad hoc order of the European Parliament. A manager or banker like anyone else is to be convicted if they have committed a crime and not on the basis of a vague resolution "on involvement in cases."

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering must be a political priority for the EU institutions. It is necessary to fill gaps that may exist in the fight against organised crime and corruption and to improve cross-border judicial cooperation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Corruption is damaging the economy and economy of the Member States and the EU, is a source of illegal income, while harming competition and the business environment. The fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering must therefore be a priority. The forms and ways of this crime are constantly changing and becoming more sophisticated. That is why the Commission must review the law in force and carry out a study on the most elaborate and advanced legislation currently in the field of combating organised crime and corruption, so that this study can be the basis for the adoption of effective and modern European legislation in this area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the CRIM Committee, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 October 2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. It calls for the adoption of a European action plan to combat and eliminate organised crime, corruption and money laundering. This plan should then be provided with sufficient financial resources and qualified staff. The analysis on the extent of crime is relevant, but we oppose Europeanist solutions, where enhanced cooperation between Member States would allow both greater efficiency and a guarantee of respect for state sovereignty. For example, the text wants the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and the EU's accession to the GRECO (Group of States Against Corruption), which we oppose. Finally, there is mention of the "lack of legal migration channels." There is an instrumentalisation of organised crime to strengthen the EU, and encourage ever more non-European immigration.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the fight against corruption and follow-up of the CRIM resolution. Organised crime, corruption, fraud, and money laundering, among others, are serious issues that need to be tackled effectively as their impact is affecting European nationals and businesses alike.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report follows the resolution adopted in October 2013 on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. The report provides recommendations on the measures and initiatives to be taken on transparency, environmental aspects of corruption, better communication between judicial authorities, the need to address the exploitation of migrant work, greater protection of witnesses and whistleblowers, as well as other relevant issues in this area. However, the establishment of compulsory rules so that people accused of a crime or public offense cannot run for public office after the execution of their sentence is a pernicious argument. In this case, people like Nelson Mandela could never come to power. I abstained.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The eradication of organized crime, corruption and money laundering are priority aspects, so I am voting in favour of the implementation of measures to move forward in this area. To do this, we must work on transposing the rules in force to assess their efficiency. We also call for combating association offences and for this we call for the creation of a specialized Unit of Europol to combat organised crime groups active in different sectors. We are also committed to more effective judicial and police cooperation within the countries of the Union, as well as measures to prevent access to organised crime and corruption into the legal economy.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report deals with the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM resolution. The report contains correct findings and conclusions on organised crime, corruption and the fight against it. However, the report also contains a number of points, such as.B. the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which I take a critical view of. That is why I abstained.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report, which gives an overview of the most important problems in the fight against corruption. This report not only draws attention to the methods of the activities of criminal groups, but also calls on the Commission and the Member States to take concrete steps to set up a dedicated Europol unit to combat organised crime groups, which operate simultaneously in different sectors.  I support the report's provisions calling for a review of existing legislation in order to impose effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions; develop minimum standards for the detection and sanctioning of criminal offences; prevent criminal organisations and corruption from entering the legitimate economy.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for the adoption of "a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering".  There are good elements in this report. It encourages Member States to set up a European protection programme for whistleblowers and prosecution witnesses. It recommends the accession of the European Union to the Group of States Against Corruption (GRECO).  On the other hand, it also calls for the establishment of a European public prosecutor's office, the umpteenth supranational body to which I am opposed. Finally, above all, it does not say a word about cases of conflict of interest that could lead to suspected cases of corruption within the European institutions, whether in the case of former Commissioners José Manuel Barroso and Neelie Kroes or the role of the current President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, in the tax fraud system in place in Luxembourg. I abstain on this hypocritical text

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report aims to combat organised crime, corruption and money laundering. However, this objective is being hijacked to promote the Union, to the detriment of enhanced cooperation between Member States. This instrumentalization of the fight against organised crime led me to vote against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is intended a stronger commitment from the EU to achieve better results in the fight against corruption. The development of a genuine priority anti-corruption prevention strategy involves the intensification of police and judicial cooperation through the exchange of information between national authorities, greater attention in the field of public procurement and public-private partnerships, or the fight against corruption in sport, criminalising the manipulation of sporting events and strengthening the fight against illegal betting in the field of sports competitions; regulation of lobbyist activity and its relationship with official entities; the awareness that new instruments of organised crime are available; the emergence of new phenomena of organised crime, in particular of an economic nature, using cross-border associations, which requires the allocation of the technological, technical, logistical and financial means necessary for its development and combat, in an articulated way between Member States. It is now up to the European Commission to develop a legislative proposal to make the European Parliament's firm call to combat corruption and organised crime.  I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it calls for the Union to increase its efforts to combat corruption, organised crime, fraud and money laundering which remain a priority. We need greater cooperation between security services and law enforcement across the Union, this is a point that I have long supported and will continue to push for. I also support the rapporteur’s call for the Commission to release its second anti-Corruption report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. As with the fight against terrorism, it is essential to strengthen our capacity to effectively combat organised crime, especially since the two are intrinsically linked. In October 2013, the European Parliament made a series of recommendations on the fight against organised crime, corruption and money laundering.  Today, much remains to be done. MEPs are still waiting for a real European action plan with ambitious resources. Concrete action has yet to be taken. For example, Europol needs to establish a special unit as soon as possible in the fight against organised crime groups active in several sectors.  Member States must, as in the context of the fight against terrorism, exchange more data at their disposal. One example is the lack of automatic exchange of PNR data, which will also be used to combat organised crime. Finally, the European Parliament has once again stressed the need to create an ambitious European Public Prosecutor's Office which, in the long run, will have to fight cross-border crime. This is a strong commitment as we negotiate with the Council to ensure the independence and effectiveness of the future European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Although I voted in favour of this report, I do not support the proposals concerning the Office of the European Prosecutor. Nor do I support the call for mandatory rules establishing that convicted persons should not be eligible to stand for election or to work in or for the public administration. This type of measure should be seen as an additional sanction, normally only imposed for a limited time by the court. Otherwise, convicted persons are punished twice, which is a violation of the ‘ne bis in idem’ principle.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs points out that organised crime is a global threat and thus requires a common and coordinated response from the European Union and its Member States. It reviews international conventions on combating organised crime, including corruption, money laundering and fraud, as well as the decisions and proposals taken by the various institutions of the Union on this subject. It urges the proper transposition of existing legislation, the monitoring of their implementation and the evaluation of their effectiveness, as well as the swift drafting of legislation that is not necessary for effective combat. It considers it necessary to establish a stricter legislative framework, to cooperate more effectively at EU level in police and judicial affairs, to prevent the infiltration of organised crime and corruption into the legal economy, and attaches ummance to the swift setting up and endowment of the EPPO with appropriate powers. It also specifically issues such as counterfeiting, drug trafficking, betting, illicit influence on match results, tax havens, environmentally damaging crimes, terrorism, trafficking in human beings and trafficking in human beings.  I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report recalls the ideas and recommendations presented in the European Parliament resolution of 23 October 2013 on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. It calls for the adoption of a European action plan on these issues, which should be staffed with sufficient financial resources and qualified personnel to be effective. The text provides a relevant analysis of the extent of organised crime in all its forms, as well as the links between organised crime and terrorism, human trafficking, etc. However, rather than encouraging cooperation between Member States in the fight against organised crime, the report calls for European solutions. In particular, he advocates the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, for the EU's accession to the GRECO (Group of States Against Corruption, as if the EU were a state), etc. In addition, it is also said that "the lack of legal migration channels and barriers to access to justice are among the main causes of human trafficking". Organised crime is in a way being used to strengthen the EU and further encourage non-European immigration. Our vote will be unfavorable.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Organised crime has a transnational dimension and covers various types of criminal activities, such as drug trafficking, smuggling of migrants, money laundering and trafficking in counterfeit goods, firearms, wildlife and cultural goods.  The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development recognises the need to combat corruption in all its forms and calls on Member States to eliminate illicit financial flows, bribery and corruption, and to create effective, accountable and transparent institutions. I believe that the EU should impose a strong political will in the fight against tax evasion and planning, in accordance with the principle of policy coherence to promote development, enshrined in Article 208 TFEU. Developing countries are crucial to strengthen transparency and accountability in resource contracts, audits and financial reports of companies, as well as in the collection and allocation of revenues, as part of their anti-corruption agenda.  The EU should strengthen its assistance to resource-rich countries to implement the principles of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Instead of encouraging enhanced cooperation between Member States in the fight against organised crime, the report calls for European solutions. In particular, he called for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, for the EU's accession to GRECO, etc. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which reiterates the recommendations set out in the 2013 resolution on organised crime, corruption and money laundering, and calls for the transposition and application of existing anti-corruption instruments by Member States. It calls for the Commission to complete an assessment of the measures taken to transpose these instruments and recommend that the EU become a member of the Council of Europe’s anti-corruption monitoring body, GRECO (Group of States against Corruption).

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the fight against corruption and organised crime in the Union. The text calls for the adoption of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering. Indeed, EU legislation must adapt to better cope with new forms of organised and often cross-border crime.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because I condemn all forms of corruption. This is a problem that is having a major impact on the Visegrad Four, including Slovakia. If you look at the list of the most corrupt countries in the European Union, we are quick to realize that we are very high on it every year. I am always in support of the fight against corruption everywhere, and I believe that a unified EUROPEAN Union cross-border action can be effective in this case.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution that reiterates the need of a common and coordinated European Action Plan to combat organised crime, corruption and money laundering.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported Mrs Ferrara's report because organised crime poses a global threat to European citizens, requiring a common, coordinated response from the EU and its Member States. Organised crime groups have a variety of activities, one of their main qualities being the rapid adaptation to different geographical, economic and social conditions and their weaknesses. Much of the illicit proceeds of crime are laundered in the European economy. It should be noted that corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension, which requires close cooperation between competent national authorities as well as between national authorities and relevant EU agencies. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office would contribute to the fight against corruption in the EU and to the control of abuses of the EU's financial interests. Counterfeiting of various products in the EU, drug trafficking, tax evasion and organised crime and terrorism are just some of the activities of organised crime groups that we must counter. Bulgaria is one of the countries that still reports a high rate of organised crime, the level of corruption also remains elevated. I therefore believe that a multidisciplinary approach and the development of effective and innovative European legislation is needed to address these challenges.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of this report on combating corruption at the level of the Member States and the European institutions because I have supported and argue that the fight against corruption must take place within the limits of the rule of law both in Romania and in the rest of the Member States. I also appreciate the fact that this report succeeds in presenting the disaffected implications and ramifications of corruption for the economic and political stability of a state and for ensuring fair competition in the various markets. The implications of organised crime at various key points in the political, economic and judicial systems of some of the Member States through corruption puts the entire system of a state at risk.  In this respect, I support the rapporteur's request to the European Commission to submit as soon as possible the report on the situation of corruption in the Member States, but also in the European institutions.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the fight against corruption, i consider the part of it that is particularly important, which highlights the fact that corruption facilitates the penetration of organised crime into the legal economy, in particular through public procurement and public-private partnerships. I therefore agree that a comprehensive e-procurement system should be applied across the EU in order to reduce the risk of corruption in public procurement. Member States and the European institutions should establish a 'blacklist' of undertakings which are shown to have links to organised crime or engage in corrupt practices, should be excluded from all business relationships with the public administration and from the possibility of using EU funds, and there should be an automatic exchange of relevant information at European level.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the report contains, in principle, correct findings and conclusions on organised crime, corruption and the fight against it. International cooperation on smuggling is also to be welcomed. However, I have concerns about the establishment and acceleration of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. There are also a number of points in the report which must be revised.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Transnational cooperation is needed to combat cross-border organised crime and corruption. The report identifies a number of areas and makes recommendations to ensure cooperation at EU level to combat such criminal activities.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted. It should be noted that the primary responsibility for security lies with the Member States, but they can no longer provide security on their own. There is therefore a need first and foremost for joint and coordinated action, as organised crime threatens not only the EU but the whole world. The EU's internal and global security are closely interlinked. The fight against organised crime and terrorism is a shared Responsibility of Europe. It is therefore necessary to ensure the proper transposition, monitoring and evaluation of the effectiveness of existing legislation. In the fight against organised crime and corruption, the legislative framework must be more reliable and well-defined priorities and operational structures. More effective judicial and police cooperation at EU level needs to be promoted. The EU must strike a severe blow to the heritage of criminal organisations and encourage their continued use for social purposes and prevent criminal organisations and corruption from entering the legitimate economy. Attention should be paid to the special role of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. An independent European Public Prosecutor's Office must be set up as soon as possible, protected from political influence and pressure.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Organised crime poses a global threat and requires a common and coordinated response on the part of the EU and its Member States. In addition, organised crime, corruption and money laundering pose a serious threat to both the EU economy, significantly reducing the tax revenues of the Member States and the EU as a whole, as well as democratic control of EU-funded public works. I voted in favour of the report which focuses on specific areas where priority action is needed. For example, measures are needed to properly transpose existing rules, monitor their implementation and assess their effectiveness. It also calls for the establishment of a specialised Europol unit to combat organised crime and corruption, a stricter legislative framework, as well as more effective judicial and police cooperation at Union level. It also stresses the importance of preventing the infiltration of organised crime and corruption into the legitimate economy and the role of the European Public Prosecutor's Office in the fight against corruption in the EU. Finally, seizing the assets of criminal groups in the EU and facilitating their reuse for social purposes would be a deterrent for criminals.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on combating corruption, on the pretext of existing and in any case reprehensible phenomena of organised crime, money laundering, tax havens, drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, etc., promotes the strengthening of police and judicial cooperation (Europol and Eurojust) and the European Prosecutor's Office, by growing the vast network of mechanisms for repression, exchange of information and monitoring , to the detriment of the labour movement. It is typical that for the European Prosecutor's Office under recommendation, which is made with the convenient justification of 'fighting financial fraud against the EU', the report already calls for the extension of its powers to 'fight organised crime'. Corruption, tax havens, economic and other fraud are inherent in the capitalist profit and capitalist economy that serves it and which the EU and its established mechanisms not only leave untouched but in all ways premium and reproduce them. It turns out that workers must not be complacent and be on hand, strengthening their fight against old and new repressive mechanisms that are being shielded, the EU itself and the real adversary they serve, their monopolies and their power.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. Whilst UKIP of course support the continued fight against corruption and crime, we do not endorse the competencies of the EU to do this. More specifically, UKIP opposes further EU legislation and the expansion of Europol and, lastly, rejects calls for a European Public Prosecutors Office. UKIP MEPs have also voted against the EU calling for Member States to legislate on mandatory rules concerning the right to stand for election or work in public administrations. UKIP believe that it is not for the EU to dictate how Member States should run elections or who they may – or may not – employ in public administrative roles.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it was right to vote in favour of this proposal, as I fully agree with my colleague that organised crime is global and therefore requires a joint response from the European Union. Whereas criminal groups sometimes participate in administrative and political life with the aim of accessing the financial resources available to public administrations. I therefore believe that the Member States must step up their efforts to combat this negative phenomenon, coordinating in such a way as to provide a joint and effective response. Furthermore, convinced that it is up to the Union to promote the fight against organised crime by promoting greater cooperation between its members, I voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this report as corruption and organised crime in the European Union is a major problem that holds back the development of the national and EU initiatives and the well—being of EU citizens. This report analyses the current situation in the EU regarding the fight against crime and makes proposals for combating new forms of crimes with European instruments.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome this report, because I consider the fight against organised crime, which is particularly linked to tax fraud, money laundering and corruption, to be extremely important. Organised crime should be seen in its ongoing links to specific areas: crime that is taking off in the current migrant crisis; corruption and crime in the use of public funds; protection of witnesses and those who are in close cooperation with the judicial process and many other areas.  Member States and the European Commission have a legal obligation to fight fraud and organised crime. This can best be achieved with openness and cooperation so that Member States can share their own good practices for fighting crime. These practices should be incorporated into the European Plan for the Eradication of Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering and adequate resources should be provided for the implementation of it.  In addition to member states' efforts and assistance to them, it is necessary to verify and effectively monitor tax fraud at international level in order to ensure fair business and financial competition between legal authorities and to eradicate criminal activity that harms absolutely everyone.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report recalls the ideas and recommendations presented in the resolution of 23 October 2013. In particular, it calls for the adoption of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering, which should be equipped with sufficient financial resources and qualified personnel to be effective.  The text provides a relevant analysis of the extent of organized crime in all its forms, as well as the links between organised crime and terrorism, human trafficking, etc. However, rather than encouraging closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against organised crime, the report unsurprisingly calls for more and more Europe.  In particular, he called for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, for the Union's accession to the GRECO (Group of States Against Corruption, as if the Union were a State), etc. In addition, it is also said that "the lack of legal migration channels and barriers to access to justice are among the main causes of human trafficking". The fight against organised crime is thus being used to strengthen the Union and to put in place procedures that further promote immigration. In these circumstances, I am voting against this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential to keep a high focus on combating organised crime, corruption and money laundering, ensuring an effective strategy and action on these sensitive issues, in order to prevent their influence from spreading to the economy and throughout European society. At a time of economic difficulties and when all the attention seems to be focused on the terrorist threat, lowering our guard on these issues would be unforgivable. I am therefore pleased to note that, as this report shows, there is broad agreement on the need to give a new impetus to the fight against corruption, organised crime and money laundering, ensuring that the rules are applied and improved, eliminating existing loopholes. I therefore hope that, in a short time, effective and appropriate legislative instruments will be developed to combat mafia-type crime, which will prevent banks from being complicit in money laundering operations and, at the same time, that the long-awaited and fundamental European Public Prosecutor's Office will be established and implemented.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The first step in the fight against corruption is to transpose and apply existing instruments to combat various forms of crime into member states' national law. This is precisely why it calls on the Commission to carry out an assessment of measures to transpose such instruments as soon as possible, to inform Parliament of the results of that assessment and to initiate infringement procedures if necessary.  Organised crime, corruption and money laundering often cross the borders of a country and therefore require cooperation between competent national authorities and between national authorities and relevant EU agencies. It is important that the Commission takes concrete measures to improve European cooperation in this area. A provision of the Resolution concerning the confiscation of the property of criminal groups and the promotion of its reuse for social purposes should also be highlighted and supported. I believe that the European Public Prosecutor's Office is also an important element in the fight against corruption.  The resolution calls for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office that is independent from national and EU institutions and protected from political influence and pressure and asks the Commission to include the fight against organised crime among its powers. While it is justified that terrorism is in particular focus today, it must not be forgotten the importance of fighting organised crime and corruption.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is based on the pretext of just values such as combating fraud, corruption and money laundering, covering sectors such as smuggling, drug trafficking, gambling and match-making, tax havens, environmental crimes, cybercrime, organised crime and organised crime and trafficking in human beings and migrants.
