However, it transforms police and judicial cooperation between Member States in deepening a federalist and security vision, pursuing the European Union's policies in this area. This justifies the call for greater specialisation of EUROPOL and greater use of agencies such as EUROJUST, CEPOL or the European Judicial Training Network.  It validates the register of PNR, which we reject and voted against, as well as promoting the valorization and greater capacity of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, another supranational instrument which we do not accompany, as it contributes to the loss of member states' sovereignty in the field of justice.  By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that this report recaps the Parliament report adopted in the last legislature on organised crime, corruption and money laundering (the ‘CRIM’ Report) by taking a fresh look at the recommendations set out in the CRIM Report, and seeks to draw conclusions on the recommendations which were followed up and those which were not. It was drafted in anticipation of the Commission’s 2nd Anti-Corruption Report and is split into eight sections which deal with a specific aspect of combating corruption and organised crime and calling for specific actions or responses. The sections include also the importance of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) which has been strongly promoted by our group. I would also like to stress the importance of calling for a specific instrument to tackle ‘mafia-style’ criminal organisations and compromised on the legal basis for establishing an EPPO.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Organised crime represents a global threat which, as such, requires a joint and coordinated response from the EU and its Member States. Unfortunately, today, there is still a lack of full awareness of the complexity of the mafia-type associative phenomenon and of the danger arising from the infiltration of criminal associations into the social, economic-entrepreneurial, political and institutional fabric of the Member States. This resolution calls on the Commission to propose, on the basis of the assessment of the transposition and application of existing rules, legislative measures to fill any gaps in the fight against organised crime and to improve cross-border judicial cooperation. I believe that it is a priority to take concrete action with a view to better European coordination in the fight against organised crime, corruption and money laundering, as well as to raising awareness of the social and economic damage caused by these phenomena. The fight against organised crime must be pursued with determination by the common European institutions. I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Commission, set up in March 2013, was to analyse organised crime in Europe, assess the implementation of EU policies to combat organised crime and examine the role of the EU Home Affairs Agency. The result was a report adopted by the European Parliament on 23 October 2013.  The new own-initiative report, which follows an earlier working document, highlights the substance and recommendations set out in the resolution of 23 October 2013, focusing on concrete priority actions. The report has several aspects worthy of support, such as increased information exchange and law enforcement cooperation, better protection of so-called whistle-blowers, greater transparency and traceability of EU funds, links between organised crime and terrorism, or a call for specific measures to combat trafficking in human beings.  However, the report calls for concrete action at EU level that does not comply with the principle of subsidiarity, namely the swift establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, a recommendation for the EU to become a member of the Group of States Against Corruption (GRECO) established by the Council of Europe, or a call for EU action on the redistribution of criminal assets for re-use for social purposes. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Corruption, organised crime and money laundering must be eradicated within the European Union. It is in this spirit that I voted for this report which calls for the adoption of a European action plan to combat these scourges.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 25 October 2011, the European Parliament (EP) adopted a report on organised crime, following which a special committee was set up to examine organised crime in Europe. The output of this special committee resulted in a report adopted by the EP in October 2013, which this report continues. Organised crime is a global threat and therefore requires a joint and coordinated response from the EU and its Member States. It is therefore necessary for all Member States to ensure the proper transposition of existing provisions, to monitor their implementation and to assess their effectiveness.  The rapporteur notes that the phenomena of organised crime, corruption and money laundering often have a cross-border dimension, thus making police and judicial cooperation more effective at European level necessary. Corruption, in particular in the field of public procurement and public-private partnerships, provides privileged channels for infiltrating organised crime into the legal economy. I am voting in favour because I believe that the current political cycle should include among its priorities the fight against money laundering, corruption and trafficking in human beings.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non—legislative report. Whilst UKIP of course support the continued fight against corruption and crime, we do not endorse the competencies of the EU to do this. More specifically, UKIP opposes further EU legislation and the expansion of Europol and, lastly, rejects calls for a European Public Prosecutors Office. UKIP MEPs have also voted against the EU calling for Member States to legislate on mandatory rules concerning the right to stand for election or work in public administrations. UKIP believe that it is not for the EU to dictate how Member States should run elections or who they may – or may not – employ in public administrative roles.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, since there is still no full awareness of the complexity of the phenomenon of organised crime and the danger arising from the infiltration of criminal associations into the social, economic, business, political and institutional fabric of the Member States. Organised criminal groups have shown a tendency and great ease in diversifying their activities, adapting to different territorial, economic and social contexts, and taking advantage of their weaknesses and vulnerabilities, while acting in different markets and exploiting the disparity between the legislative provisions of member states' legal systems to make their activities prosper and maximise profits. Organised crime, corruption and money laundering pose serious threats to the EU economy, significantly reducing the tax revenues of Member States and the EU as a whole, as well as to the reliability of EU-funded projects, as criminal organisations operate in various sectors, many of which are subject to government control.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution reiterates the ideas and recommendations made in its resolution of 23 October 2013 on organised crime, corruption and money laundering.  It reiterates, in particular, its call for the adoption of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering, which, in order to be effective, must have adequate financial resources and qualified staff.  Expresses its wish to focus on specific areas requiring priority intervention in the current context: - Ensuring the proper transposition of existing provisions, monitoring their implementation and assessing their effectiveness; - Priorities and operational structure for the fight against organised crime and corruption; - A stronger legislative framework; - more effective police and judicial cooperation at European level; - Seize the assets of criminal organisations and encourage their re-use for social purposes; - Prevent the infiltration of organised crime and corruption into the legal economy; - Creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office; - Specific policy areas (contracourse, drug trafficking, tax havens, environmental crimes, cybercrime, organised crime and terrorism).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Organised crime, money laundering and transnational corruption are increasing criminal phenomena in the Union. The FERRARA report is important because it analyses what recommendations from those indicated by the European Parliament's Anti-Corruption Commission (CRIM) have been implemented and what is pending.  The report is very comprehensive and consists of eight sections. Each addresses a specific aspect of the fight against corruption and organized crime and calls for specific actions to be taken to achieve this. These points include monitoring the transposition of existing rules and their degree of implementation, the operational structure adopted in the fight against organized crime and corruption, the need to strengthen the legal framework for combating corruption, more effective judicial and police cooperation, confiscation of the assets of criminal organizations, preventing organized crime from penetrating the formal economy , the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a tool to combat this phenomenon and the identification of areas requiring further regulatory development. The report s meant identifying specific areas of failure in the legal system for preventing corruption to take steps to remedy it as soon as possible.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. By voting in favour of this report, the European Parliament is calling for new rules to combat organised crime and corruption. I am particularly pleased that this resolution was adopted by a very large majority. Indeed, if it is a non-binding resolution, the broad support it has received will oblige the European Commission to take it with the utmost seriousness.  Among the ideas raised in this text, I note in particular this new request from the European Parliament to be able to launch a legislative initiative to protect whistleblowers. There is an urgent need for the European Union to have the legislative arsenal necessary to protect these citizens.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Corruption is an essential problem for any administration. The development of good governance cannot be promised without the promise of corruption. Astonishingly, until now, the EU has not yet joined the GRECO group by declaring good governance as its priority. I fully support the document in question. I believe that progress in this area, both at Member State and EU level, should become a regular item on Parliament's agenda, which is being discussed at least once a year.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report by Laura Ferrara concerns the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering. We all know that corruption and organised crime take on a universal dimension and pose a global threat to the security of citizens, territories and the social, economic, political and institutional fabric of the various countries, requiring a concerted response from the EU and the Member States. It is in this fragile context that I strongly support the proposals contained in this report on those that should be the EU's priorities and the operational structure for the fight against organised crime and corruption, as well as for the implementation of a more robust and effective legislative framework and more competent and active police and judicial cooperation at European level. A word of appreciation for the idea of seizing the assets of criminal organisations and encouraging their re-use for social purposes, as well as the idea of creating a European Public Prosecutor's Office independent of national governments and european institutions.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the implementation of the European Parliament's 2013 recommendations on organised crime, corruption and money laundering. The report calls on the European Commission to ensure that existing legislation is properly implemented, monitors its application and assesses their effectiveness. It calls for the development of minimum rules on the definition of crimes such as corruption, participation in criminal organizations or money laundering, and related sanctions.  In this sense, it is crucial and urgent that judicial and police cooperation at EU level be more effective. Member States should thereby introduce, use and exchange all data deemed necessary for persons convicted of an offence related to organised crime. Finally, I supported this report because it calls for measures to directly target criminal organizations such as freezing and confiscating the proceeds of crime.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it has incorporated important amendments to issues of transparency, environmental aspects of corruption, better communication from judicial authorities, the need to address the labour exploitation of migrants and other relevant issues. The final text is balanced in its final wording on the most sensitive points such as the use of the internet or the links between organized crime and terrorism. Among the most positive aspects of the Report are: 1) An appeal to the Union to become a member of GRECO and the European Commission to publish its Anti-Corruption Report (including a section on the institutions of the Union) and to propose appropriate legislation; (2) Need for legislation to strengthen the rights of suspects and guarantees for a fair trial; 3) Call on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal on the protection of witnesses and whistleblowers by the end of 2017; (4) Requests the Union and the Member States to strengthen measures to locate, freeze and confiscate the product of crime and to prohibit fraudulent undertakings from accessing European public procurement procedures; 5) A firm declaration against tax havens.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in the European Parliament support the fight against corruption, money laundering and organised and cross-border crime, including through European cooperation. There are parts of the proposal that fall under the Danish legal opt-out and others that we believe should fall within the competence of the Member States, such as when citizens can run for public office in their own countries and how long officials can hold them. Similarly, we support the idea of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, as long as it is for combating fraud against the EU's financial interests. Overall, however, we believe that the report sends a right signal on the fight against crime types, as mentioned above, and we have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of combating corruption and continuing to debate the CRIM resolution. The draft report contains proposals taken on board by the work of a special committee on organised violence, corruption and money laundering. The proposals refer to the fight against crime with European instruments and are based on an analysis of the current situation in Europe.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 Despite my position contrary to the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office which would generate a parallel system of justice without even physical resources to support it, I voted in favour of this resolution. I have done so because I understand that it contains very positive proposals in the fight against corruption and organized crime. Effective measures are proposed to states and the Union for the prevention of various offences carried out by the laxity of administrations, such as tax offences, trafficking in human beings, or environmental offences. In addition, specific punitive measures are proposed such as the prohibition of working in public institutions on persons convicted of corruption or money laundering offences, which I value very positively, hence my favourable vote.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the report on the Fight against corruption and follow-up of the CRIM Committee resolution, as it reiterates the recommendations set out in the 2013 resolution on organised crime, corruption and money laundering and calls for the transposition and application of existing anti-corruption instruments by Member States.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although legal frameworks are very sophisticated at international and European level, corruption in many European countries is becoming a critical point for their economic and democratic development. In particular, I find it worrying that countries with non-transparent relations and high levels of corruption are achieving worse economic results and their economies are more vulnerable. Unfortunately, this undesirable phenomenon undermines public confidence in public and democratic institutions, increases inequalities that disproportionately affect the poorest and most vulnerable, reinforces violence and insecurity, and reduces the effectiveness of development aid. I am very sorry that the most important international conventions and initiatives aimed at combating corruption and illicit financial flow do not produce concrete results at the implementation stage. I supported the resolution because I see organised crime as a global threat and as such requires a joint and coordinated response from the EU and its Member States. I expect the Member States to apply even better the legal instruments aimed at combating corruption, which have already been adopted at European and international level, in order to combat corruption more effectively.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report on the fight against corruption and the next steps is a response to the final resolution adopted by the Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering in October 2013.  I look positively at this report because it calls, among other things, for the creation of a strong and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, with clearly defined duties, the adoption of a legislative proposal on a European framework for the protection of whistle-blowers by the end of 2017 and for emphasis on environmental crime.  Among the specific matters mentioned in the report can be the framework for the control of the rule of law, a more systematic exchange of information relating to organised crime, which operates across borders, the confiscation of criminal assets, the implementation of instruments for monitoring public procurement and the creation of a so-called blacklist of suppliers involved in organised crime or corrupt practices. The report contains important points, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against corruption must be one of the priorities of the European Union's internal policy. We need to scrutinise the management of European resources thoroughly and effectively, especially at national level. The identification and monitoring of financial flows that may result from such activity is also an important part of the fight against corruption.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament welcomes any proposal that contributes to the development of a safety culture. Although this report makes good points, we mainly note a number of problems. Our main concern is the chapter on the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO). We always vote against this, partly because it would be the third agency of its kind, resulting in a waste of taxpayers' money. It is also currently unclear what the agency's competence would be. This resolution also extends the power of the fight against fraud to organised crime. This is an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States that have jurisdiction in this area. The N-VA has considered these elements significant enough to abstain in the vote on this proposal.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on "Combating corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM resolution". In it, the European Parliament reiterates its call for the establishment, to be adopted as soon as possible with the participation of as many Member States as possible, of an efficient European Public Prosecutor's Office, independent of national governments and EU institutions, protected from political influence and political pressure.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Organised crime is today one of the most serious global problems that requires coordinated responses due to the complexity of the phenomenon of criminal associations, i.e. changing the way they act, diversifying activities by adapting to different social contexts, and the threat to the economy in terms of reducing Member States' tax revenues and accountability of EU-funded public projects. This is why the adoption of a European Action Plan against Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering is important, as well as an integrated approach by Member States with close cooperation between the police and judicial authorities in combating fraud, corruption and money laundering, which should be political priorities for the Institutions of the European Union.  I support the anti-corruption and follow-up report following a resolution by the CRIM Committee (2015/2110(INI)) of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM resolution. Organised crime, corruption and money laundering pose a threat not only to the freedom of economic activity and competitiveness, but above all to the security and freedom of all citizens.  If we want to successfully counter these threats, both at European and national level, we must no longer delay appropriate measures. Given the cross-border dimension of criminal groups, we need a uniform definition of crime and close cooperation between national authorities and European Union agencies.  The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, independent of national governments and EU institutions, is a real step towards a more effective fight against corruption

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report contains positive and negative elements. Some of the good recommendations contained in the report are that the EU is asked to become a member of GRECO and that the Commission publish its anti-corruption report and propose appropriate legislation. It also mentions the need for legislation that will strengthen the rights of suspects as well as guarantees of a fair trial, and requires the Commission to submit a legislative proposal to protect witnesses and informants before the end of 2017. However, two key issues mentioned in the report are particularly worrying. Firstly, references to the need to place greater emphasis on participation in a criminal organisation than on the crime itself, and also references to the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which is the central element in the fight against corruption, which implies the delegation of more and more powers and competences that Member States currently have in the EU. For these reasons, we abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Organised crime has a cross-border dimension and includes a number of criminal activities, including drug trafficking, migrant trafficking, money laundering and trafficking in counterfeit goods, firearms, wildlife and cultural goods. The report fails to set a proper framework, as have the most relevant international conventions and initiatives aimed at combating corruption and illicit financial flows, since they fail to produce concrete results at the stage of their implementation.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against corruption and its all forms has an extraordinary relevance in a democratic state. Corruption can only be tackled effectively in the long term and it is therefore very important that Member States implement their commitments in this area. The report on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the resolution of the CRIM Committee addresses a number of important issues. In particular, I agree with the emphasis on the importance of more effective police and judicial cooperation at EU level, as corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension. The designation of cybercrime as an area requiring special action is also to be welcomed, as the rapid development of the Internet has made cybercrime a major source of income for many criminal organisations. I agree with the need to strengthen EU legislation and cooperation between Member States and EU agencies in this area, and therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ people's delegation, I am voting in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, taking into account the importance of preventing the infiltration of organised crime and corruption into the legal order and national economy of each State for a reason. At the same time, the report also highlights the inability of the current European legal and instrumental system to deal with the phenomenon of corruption being made systemic by a particular political regime or government for the sake of its own power and the personal enrichment of its leaders, entrapment of self-serving legislation, as if legitimising the quasi-state corruption net. As a Hungarian Socialist and opposition MEMBER, this is an important aspect for me, because today, in the most obvious way, Hungary's economy suffers from this phenomenon, to which the EU legal order has not yet found a meaningful answer. Among the measures proposed, the setting up of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is a particularly important and urgent task, which can partly respond to such legal challenges, but I believe that only joint action by Member States, assuming the full unity and political determination of the European Council, can be effective against such governments in the future. I hope that the report that has just been adopted will also contribute to this recognition.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, which was clear and leads the fight against corruption in the right direction. It is important to take corruption into account both in the EU's cooperation with external stakeholders and within borders in our own institutions.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has approved a 5-star report by our colleague Laura Ferrara. The report focuses on a number of priority aspects for the current historical moment and makes proposals and recommendations to the European institutions and the Member States to strengthen actions to combat corruption and organised crime. For the first time in history, the report calls for the introduction at European level of the crime of association with mafia-type crimes, following the example of Article 416a of the Italian Criminal Code to combat mafia-related crimes. One of our proposals on the date of those convicted has been approved by the European Parliament: it calls for those who have been convicted of crimes related to organised crime, money laundering, corruption or other serious crimes against the public administration to not be able to stand for election or work in public administration ( including EU institutions, bodies and agencies). I believe that the adoption of this report is a great success for the movement that is showing that it is bringing honesty and the fight against the Mafia and corruption to the European institutions as well. My vote was therefore positive.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to step up the fight against corruption, organised crime and money-laundering, the report tries to ensure that rules that already exist are enforced, to close loopholes in existing legislative frameworks and to request a more holistic approach to organised crime and corruption. Although some issues in the report were controversial, such as the need for a specific instrument to tackle ‘mafia-style’ criminal organisations – an idea that the S&D Group sympathises with – all major political parties gave the green light to the report during the compromise phase. I support this report, as I believe that it is very important to have a serious strategy backed up by a plan of action in order to tackle the growing prevalence of organised crime and corruption in the EU. Although the focus today is on terrorist threats, the danger of organised crime and corruption should not be ignored.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of the text. It should be noted that the current cycle of EU policy-making in the fight against organised crime should place greater emphasis on the fight against the crime of association, not just the fight against crimes for which an association has been created. In particular, we believe that it is necessary to provide for the possibility of sanctioning an association of criminals regardless of the offences committed. It should also be remembered that the fight against money laundering, against corruption and human trafficking should also be included as part of a genuine European anti-corruption strategy.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In autumn 2013, the temporary committee on organised crime, corruption and money laundering (CRIM) adopted a final report that made a number of recommendations on actions and initiatives to be taken by the European Parliament. The CRIM committee report identified 21 concrete measures to fight organised crime and corruption, which need to be implemented in the period of 2014-2019. I voted in favour of the CRIM report, which will strive to improve available legal tools in the fight against corruption and organised crime. I believe that in forging a stronger link between organised crime and corruption, and law enforcement and prevention, as well as enhancing existing laws and rule, the EU can combat the dangers of the former. Organised crime is a global threat, which therefore necessitates a common, coordinated response by the EU and its Member States

name: Eleni Theocharous (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Increased information sharing and law enforcement cooperation, better protection of whistle-blowers, greater transparency and traceability of EU funds, links between organised crime and terrorism as well as the need for specific measures to combat trafficking of human beings are important measures in order to address the current situation regarding the fight against crime and are necessary in combatting new forms of crimes in the European Union

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's activities in the fight against crime are a key element in responding effectively to the phenomenon of organised crime. This is a global threat and as such requires a joint and appropriate response from the European Union and the Member States. The CRIM Committee has helped to broaden the debate on combating corruption at international level by providing clear indications on the legislative measures to be taken. In the EU, it is essential to establish a common definition of organised crime in order to make existing and future legislative instruments effective, it is not a question of prosecuting crime in a given state, it is a question of combating complex phenomena that are not limited to the national borders of one or other Member State. There is still no uniform definition of crime, in many countries there are no provisions on the fight against organised crime and it is clear that any action to combat crime at European and international level seems unworkable. The European Union must insist on combating the crime of association and that, within the framework of a genuine and comprehensive European strategy, efforts and resources on combating money laundering, corruption and trafficking in human beings must be common.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to it. There are several reasons for this, and the most important of these is the rise of organised crime, which today poses a global threat and requires joint and concerted action by the Member States in the European Union. Let us remember that this type of crime affects mainly economic issues and corruption among officials. The European institutions should therefore include legal and policy instruments for better exchange of information between countries and should promote a common approach to combating so-called cross-border crime.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ In the last parliamentary term, the European Parliament adopted a report on organised crime – this called for the establishment of a special committee to analyse criminal activities in the European Union (CRIM) and the role of home affairs agencies. After the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, I myself received the honor of being a member of the CRIM board and witnessed the final vote of the report in committee and plenary session. The own-initiative report, which is the current subject of voting, is a review of the core and most important recommendations of the CRIM committee, focusing in particular on those aspects of the report that are currently considered a priority. I support and hold useful many of the calls contained in the report, such as a call for enhanced information sharing between Member States, cooperation in law enforcement, better protection of "whistleblowers", greater transparency and the ability to monitor and monitor money from European funds, analyse the links between organised crime and terrorism, etc. However, they cannot support continued calls for concrete action at EU level, such as a call for the swift establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and a call for the redistribution of confiscated property from criminal activities for social purposes at eu level, as they constitute a gross breach of the principle of subsidiarity. So I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM resolution. Organised crime is a threat and requires a common and coordinated response from the EU and its Member States.  Organised criminal groups change their activities with great ease and adapt to different territorial, economic and social areas and exploit their weaknesses and weaknesses by simultaneously operating in different markets and exploiting the different laws of each Member State to develop their activities and increase profits.  Organised crime, corruption and money laundering pose a serious threat to the EU economy by significantly reducing the tax revenues of The Member States and the EU as a whole, and jeothes confidence in EU-funded public projects, as criminal organisations operate in different sectors, many of which are under government control.  In 2014, 1649 frauds were recorded in relation to the European budget of EUR 538.2 million. Member States should adopt and apply existing instruments at European and international level in the field of combating organised crime, corruption and money laundering. Coherence of the EU's internal and external policies is important.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it has incorporated important amendments to issues of transparency, environmental aspects of corruption, better communication from judicial authorities, the need to address the labour exploitation of migrants and other relevant issues. The final text is balanced in its final wording on the most sensitive points such as the use of the internet or the links between organized crime and terrorism. Among the most positive aspects of the Report are: 1) An appeal to the Union to become a member of GRECO and the European Commission to publish its Anti-Corruption Report (including a section on the institutions of the Union) and to propose appropriate legislation; (2) Need for legislation to strengthen the rights of suspects and guarantees for a fair trial; 3) Call on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal on the protection of witnesses and whistleblowers by the end of 2017; (4) Requests the Union and the Member States to strengthen measures to locate, freeze and confiscate the product of crime and to prohibit fraudulent undertakings from accessing European public procurement procedures; 5) A firm declaration against tax havens.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Organised crime is a global threat that requires a common strategy to confront it successfully, as organised crime, corruption and money laundering pose serious threats to the economy of the Union by significantly reducing tax revenues of Member States. It is therefore important that all Member States transpose and implement as quickly as possible the existing instruments at European level, such as the Fourth Directive against money laundering. We need judicial cooperation at European level, fraud prevention, a European Public Prosecutor and to define the specific fields of action. I hope this proposal and its multidisciplinary approach serves to effectively prevent and combat organised crime.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the adoption of a European action plan to eradicate organised crime, corruption and money laundering; plan that should be provided with sufficient financial resources and qualified personnel to be effective. However, rather than encouraging enhanced cooperation between Member States, the report calls for European solutions. In particular, he called for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, and insisted that too few migration channels were creating too much illegality. So we need more official channels, and therefore more immigration.  I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the resolution. The report submitted stresses the need for better exchange of information and cooperation between law enforcement authorities, greater transparency of EU funds, a look at the links between organised crime and terrorism and effectiveness in combating trafficking in human beings. The issues raised are undoubtedly important. At the same time, however, the report calls for very concrete action at European Union level. These include, in particular, the call to speed up work on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, as well as the recommendation that the European Union become a member of the Group of States Against Corruption (GRECO) established by the Council of Europe. The exercise of competences by the EU in this area also requires respect for the principle of subsidiarity and the powers of the Member States.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the current EU policy cycle on the fight against organised crime, emphasis should be placed not only on so-called profit-making offences (crimes for which such organisations have been set up), but also on combating criminal offences committed in criminal networks (belonging to a criminal organisation). I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it has incorporated important amendments to issues of transparency, environmental aspects of corruption, better communication from judicial authorities, the need to address the labour exploitation of migrants and other relevant issues. The final text is balanced in its final wording on the most sensitive points such as the use of the internet or the links between organized crime and terrorism. Among the most positive aspects of the Report are: 1) An appeal to the Union to become a member of GRECO and the European Commission to publish its Anti-Corruption Report (including a section on the institutions of the Union) and to propose appropriate legislation; (2) Need for legislation to strengthen the rights of suspects and guarantees for a fair trial; 3) Call on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal on the protection of witnesses and whistleblowers by the end of 2017; (4) Requests the Union and the Member States to strengthen measures to locate, freeze and confiscate the product of crime and to prohibit fraudulent undertakings from accessing European public procurement procedures; 5) A firm declaration against tax havens.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this INI report about the fight against corruption which is a follow-up to the final resolution adopted by the CRIM special committee in October 2013. It calls for important points such as setting up a strong independent EPPO with a clear competence in dealing with VAT fraud cases; adopting a legislative proposal on a European protection framework for whistle-blowers before the end of 2017; or focusing on environmental crimes.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of report on the fight against corruption and follow-up of the CRIM resolution. Organised crime is a global threat which therefore necessitates a common, coordinated response by the EU and its Member States. Nonetheless, we still do not fully understand the complex issue of organised crime and the danger arising from the infiltration of criminal associations into the social, economic, business, political and institutional fabric of the Member States. The report underlines that the phenomena of organised crime, corruption and money laundering usually have a cross-border dimension that requires close cooperation between the competent national authorities and between national authorities and the relevant EU agencies. As part of the fight against organised crime, corruption and money laundering the Member States should transpose and apply existing EU and international instruments. I voted in favour because I believe that there is a strong need for a multidisciplinary approach to prevent and combat organised crime effectively.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report proposal updates the crime-fighting situation in the Union, on the basis of the recommendations issued by the CRIM Special Commission, on the basis of which a new regulatory framework is proposed to take advantage of the tools available at European level to combat crime. Sharing the call that this proposal makes to greater cooperation in the criminal field (in particular in the areas of terrorism, cybercrime and smuggling), new forms of anti-corruption and support for the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, I have decided to vote in the affirmative.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 Despite my position contrary to the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office which would generate a parallel system of justice without even physical resources to support it, I voted in favour of this resolution. I have done so because I understand that it contains very positive proposals in the fight against corruption and organized crime. Effective measures are proposed to states and the Union for the prevention of various offences carried out by the laxity of administrations, such as tax offences, trafficking in human beings, or environmental offences. In addition, specific punitive measures are proposed such as the prohibition of working in public institutions on persons convicted of corruption or money laundering offences, which I value very positively, hence my favourable vote.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the report on the fight against corruption and follow-up of the CRIM Committee resolution, as it reiterates the recommendations set out in the 2013 resolution on organised crime, corruption and money laundering and calls for the transposition and application of existing anti-corruption instruments by Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report makes a series of strong proposals which I strongly support. These include the recommendation to join the GRECO as an effective member, the insistence that the EU institutions must lead by example in terms of transparency and ensure that effective and deterrent sanctions exist in this area and the need for better regulation of lobbying. I am particularly pleased that the text calls for a legislative proposal for the protection of whistleblowers before the end of 2017. While all these proposals explain why I voted for this text, I would nevertheless like to express my reluctance to sanction an association of criminals regardless of the crimes committed, as it is conducive to many abuses. I also warn of the increased risk of under-utilization of European funds if the preliminary investigations recommended by this report are implemented. As for the proposal to encourage the rotation of civil servants under the pretext of preventing corruption, it seems to me to be perfectly ineffective.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a report on the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering, covering sectors such as smuggling, drug trafficking, gambling and match-setting sports results, tax havens, environmental crimes, cybercrime, organised crime and organised crime and trafficking in human beings and migrants. Broadly speaking, this report considers that police and judicial cooperation between Member States should be a political priority for the European Union. In agreement with the principled position on the need for greater cooperation between States in combating these phenomena, we do not share the course which, on the one hand, centralises combat in supranational structures and, on the other hand, does not call into question the effects of the ongoing liberalisation policies, in particular at the level of the financial system and the capital market.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, the report contains accurate findings and conclusions on organised crime, corruption and the fight against it. However, the call for the speedy establishment of a 'European Public Prosecutor's Office' must be viewed critically. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office as the institutional centre of a European prosecution is a way of further unification and centralisation. The power to prosecute criminal offences should lie exclusively with the nation states (prosecution as a monopoly of the state). That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because it stresses the necessity of a common and coordinated response by the EU and its Member States to this issue. This is very important since criminal organisations have changed their modus operandi, availing themselves of the support of professionals and so demonstrating a high degree of adaptability. As a liberal, I believe in the pure values and strengths of a clean democracy, so I stand against corruption at any level.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the fight against corruption and organised crime, as these illegal activities pose a serious threat to the efficient functioning of the European economy. It is important that we set aside ourselves against all forms of organised crime, because at the end of the day it is taxpayers' money that is being lost. We must be aware that these criminal activities are in most cases of a cross-border nature and therefore closer cooperation between national authorities to combat organised crime is needed. Cooperation between police and judicial authorities at EU level must not only be self-evident and effective, but also relieved of lengthy bureaucratic procedures. At the same time, however, we must not forget about prevention in schools and shape young people in a spirit of honesty and fairness. Finally, I consider the positive and social dimension of this resolution, because it also thinks about the families of the victim and their compensation.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. This proposal for a report is a call for greater cooperation in the criminal field, new rules in the fight against corruption, open support for the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, with specific areas that require special support, including terrorism, cybercrime and smuggling, as well as support for third countries. Spain has always been particularly active in achieving a transposition as quickly as possible and in supporting the European Public Prosecutor's Office, and it must continue to be so. That is why my vote is in favour of this report, as it is essential to move forward on corruption and for greater communication and connection at the international level.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on combating corruption under the pretext of existing and in any case reprehensible phenomena of organised crime, money laundering, tax havens, drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, etc. promotes the strengthening of police and judicial cooperation (Europol and Eurojust) and the European Prosecutor's Office, by growing the vast network of mechanisms for repression, exchange of information and monitoring , to the detriment of the labour movement. It is typical that for the European Prosecutor's Office under recommendation, which is made with the convenient justification of 'fighting economic fraud against the EU', the report already calls for the extension of its powers to 'fight organised crime'. Corruption, tax havens, economic and other fraud are inherent in the capitalist profit and capitalist economy that serves it and which the EU and its established mechanisms not only leave untouched but in all ways premium and reproduce them. It turns out that workers must not be complacent and be on hand, strengthening their fight against old and new repressive mechanisms that are being shielded, the EU itself and the real adversary they serve, their monopolies and their power.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report because I believe that it is the right step towards an effective fight against corruption. Money laundering and organised crime are undoubtedly issues that have a national overlap and must therefore be debated at European level. I consider it necessary and desirable for the Member States to cooperate and jointly share both a common strategy and tools to combat corruption, as this report proposes.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution on combating corruption and following up on the resolution of the Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering (CRIM). This special committee was set up in 2012 on the basis of a report on organised crime adopted by the European Parliament. The main task of this committee is to analyse organised crime in Europe, as well as to evaluate the implementation of European policies in this area. In particular, the current anti-corruption report analysed the harmfulness of organised crime, corruption and money laundering and suggested possible ways to combat this crime. I agree that the report encouraged Member States to exchange information more effectively, to cooperate better in law enforcement, to ensure the protection of whistle-blowers or to make Euro funds more transparent. On the other hand, however, the report has, in my opinion, gone too far on some issues. For example, it also dealt with the legalisation of soft drugs as one of the solutions to drug crime or the redistribution of money derived from social crimes. In view of these reservations, I have therefore finally decided to vote against it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the Fight against Corruption and the follow-up to the CRIM resolution. Organised crime poses a threat and requires a joint and coordinated response from the EU and its Member States, and I therefore support efforts to establish a comprehensive and effective legislative framework requiring the active participation of international and regional organisations, state actors, the private sector and civil society in the fight against organised crime.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for giving me the floor again. I voted in favour of this report because the European Parliament must continue to express its opinion on a situation that only creates victims. The flow of migrants to Europe in recent years has put our reception system in great difficulty, overexposed some countries, such as my own, and forced them into major economic efforts. In other countries, on the other hand, it has led to the birth and, unfortunately, the progressive increase in populist and nationalist movements. This is the most dangerous aspect: yielding to fear and irrationality, identifying the weakest of the enemy. The response to the migrant emergency – which is no longer an emergency, as it is everyday life – exists and this Parliament has repeated it several times: agreements with African cooperation and partnership countries to intervene in the causes and redistribution of migrants arriving on our shores in the 28 Member States. The answer is not forced mackerel as happened in Calais, it is not walls and barbed wire, as in Hungary. This is not Europe. Europe is that of my region, Sicily: a Europe of welcome, and we expect there to also be a Europe of solidarity and sharing.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted whole much in favour of Mrs Vergiat's report, because I believe that this report finally raises the issue of the approach to the migration challenge by placing respect for human rights as a priority issue and not repression, rejections and evictions such as those that are unfortunately happening in Calais at the very present time. I believe that the agreement with Turkey is the emblem, the translation of the European Union's wrong approach to the issue of migrants. At the moment we are witnessing a proliferation of complaints from humanitarian organisations against the Turkish authorities' treatment of refugees. For us, the way is to open secure passages, to open humanitarian corridors, starting with those that are already being built from below, as the Mediterranean hope project has shown us.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I did not support this report, which is why I am also here explaining that being against this report does not mean that I do not want to help refugees and that I do not respect the protection of human rights. But the specific things in that report led me to believe that it could not be supported, because the report is full of various impossible utopian ideas. It is one thing to solidarity and to help refugees, and another is the specific text of this proposal, which contains such things as paragraph 32, where it is recommended that migrants be involved in all processes of taking social and political decisions. However, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this has nothing to do with solidarity. It is one thing to help those who lose their homes, and another is that citizens who pay taxes and are citizens of that country have the opportunity to be involved in decision-making in those countries. I also disagree with things like that illegal refugees can set up trade unions. And that is a number of things why I cannot support this report.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against this report because there is a great deal of hypocrisy here, where there is concern about discriminatory practices, which too often affect certain socio-cultural minorities, and for example, we do not promote this with us, where people like Jean-Marie Le Pen are being dragged to the courts every now and then for their statements in line with their beliefs. I believe that if there are very harsh anti-Russian statements and all nations should be treated the same, then anti-Semitic statements must be treated as well as anti-Russian statements. All nations should be treated equally, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. "This report on human rights and migration in third countries contains several elements that I support, including the focus on the vulnerable situation of women and children, as well as the importance of international responsibility towards victims of war and conflict. I also chose to go against my own group and vote in favour of wordings on legal routes for migration. However, there are a number of very problematic arguments in the text. Firstly, there is no clear distinction between the concepts of 'migrant' and 'refugee', as underlined by the fact that EPP proposals supporting the return of persons deemed to lack protection needs were rejected earlier in the process. This is unfortunate because clarity around the definition of who is a refugee and that a generous refugee policy does not include economic migration is a prerequisite for a sustainable migration policy and a generous refugee policy. I therefore voted against the report in the final vote.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report addresses the phenomenon of migratory flows in third countries in a coherent and balanced way, from an overview that takes into account the human dimension, including the positive aspect with regard to demographic evolution and economic development. The human rights approach is also highlighted by the call for Member States to ratify all major international human rights instruments and to apply the rules on the rights of migrants contained therein. The report stresses that the opening up of safe and legal channels of migration is the best means of preventing trafficking and trafficking in human beings. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it strongly and firmly calls for the effective defence and protection of the human rights of all persons who are forced, for various reasons, to migrate. The finally adopted text — despite the opposing vote of the groups on the right – places particular emphasis on special protection measures for the most vulnerable, in particular women and children, and calls for improvements for the integration of migrants into host countries and their access to basic services and the labour market. It also specifically addresses the situation of refugees and internally displaced persons – more than 65 million people today – whose dignity and human rights are flagrantly violated, and insists that there is no better means of preventing trafficking and trafficking in human beings than the opening of safe and legal avenues for migration. This report also calls on the Union and its Member States to set an example in the promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, especially within their borders, if they are to have credibility in discussions on migration and human rights with third countries.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non—binding report. The report contains various issues with which we cannot agree, such as the creation of migration channels into the EU. It also supports EU NAVFOR and freedom of movement, to which we are opposed. We are, however, supportive of various humanitarian aspects, but believe that the current EU approach is misguided. Support for genuine refugees would be best served with increased support as close to the country of origin as possible, to facilitate their quick return to their home country once the immediate danger has passed.  There is already a well-established and supported international regime for refugees, which should be adhered to, in particular in that asylum should be granted in the first safe country.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the right has sought to impose in the report the whitening of systematic human rights violations of migrants in the Union, such as returns to the country of origin against the will of the migrant person, this has been rejected and I have been able to vote in favour of the report. It contains a number of positive elements, which point to the systemic causes of migration and the need for a migration policy based on human rights and legal and secure access routes. I also voted in favour of the report, because it is a criticism of the Union's current model of border outsourcing and migration management by third countries, a model which I completely reject, as well as proposing effective measures for migrants' free access to the social and labour rights and public services of the countries in which they reside. Hence my support for the report.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report addresses the issue of human rights and migration in third countries. It is a good, solid, report on the rights of migrants. The report aims to address the root causes of migration, notes the importance of both physical and psychological violence suffered by migrants, including gendered violence. It highlights the importance of family reunification and of migrant children, especially the vulnerable situation of the many unaccompanied child refugees currently in Europe and elsewhere. It also highlights the importance of recognising migrants’ qualifications obtained in their countries of origin to help them find employment and better integrate. The report also recalls the importance of identifying and addressing the situation of stateless persons, amongst many other important points. This is an important report, focussing on appropriately understanding and meeting the needs of migrants and refugees, therefore we voted in favour.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution in which Parliament expressed its deep concern at the serious human rights violations suffered by many migrants in many transit and destination countries. We call on governments to do everything possible to ensure that the dignity and human rights of migrants are respected.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the report on human rights and migration to third countries because it refers to important issues, such as improving the quality of life of migrants and their economic and cultural independence, through their access to both health care and training and employment programmes.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. With this report, the European Union, true to its bad principles, seeks to force non-member countries to be forced to suffer the effects of German immigration policy to adopt European standards in terms of the rights of illegal immigrants. Together with my colleagues on the National Front, I believe that this is a serious attack on the sovereignty of third countries and Member States on the part of the EU. That is why I have logically opposed this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. This report is an unnecessary duplication of efforts already undertaken at UN level, who have already agreed Guiding Principles on this issue, unanimously agreed by all members. There are calls within the report for the creation of more EU legislation. I am supportive of the overall objectives in improving human rights but the EU is creating an unnecessary duplication.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the global economic crisis, international migration flows are increasing according to UN data, and cooperation and exchange of information and best practices between countries of origin, transit and entry are therefore necessary to prevent irregular migration and trafficking in human beings.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The french communist congressman's proposal on the state of human rights and migration in the third states shows a pro-immigrant approach. It examines everything from this point of view, calls for a path of full and legal migration, and only vaguely suggests that people smuggling must be tackled and root causes treated locally. It assumes from the misconception that economic immigration is a fundamental human right. It is attempting to extend the concept of refugees and related rights to all economic migrants on this erroneous international legal basis, and to further broaden this, which would place a new burden on European nation states. The report, which is extremely pro-migrant and does not solve anything, thumps the phrases of the already obviously failed 'Willkommenskultur', and contains nothing new in any meaningful way. It has everything that characterises the plan to eradicate traditional European nations. In view of the fore,I rejected the report.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU's aim is to force non-EU countries to suffer the effects of German immigration policy and to adopt EU standards in terms of the rights of illegal immigrants. I voted against it because it is, of course, a major attack on the sovereignty of third countries, in the same way that the Union is in other circumstances infringing on the sovereignty of the Member States, in the name of a mad immigrationist policy.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this initiative report, which reminds us that the majority of migrants worldwide are welcomed by developing countries. First, it stresses to states their international obligations on migration and the abolition of punitive legal frameworks that penalise migration. It recalls the particular vulnerability of certain groups of migrants such as un accompanied women and girls, migrant children, the elderly, people with disabilities and LGBTI migrants. The report stresses the need for the Union to strengthen its policies for peace and stability in regions where war and conflict lead to huge migratory flows. It also reminds us of the usefulness of resettlement programmes and thus underlines the importance of development assistance. Finally, MEPs call on the EU to adopt specific guidelines on migrant rights in addition to its human rights guidelines.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report of which I have been co-rapporteur. The report underlines the importance of integrating migrants into host countries, as well as respecting their most basic rights, i.e. health, education and the home. On this point, the report talks about the importance of avoiding discriminatory practices in access to the labour market. On the other hand, there are paragraphs that allude to gender-based violence, and to the situation of particular vulnerability of some groups, such as children and women.  Finally, I wanted to highlight the paragraphs that talk about the mobility of migrants. The report is committed to legal and secure immigration channels.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Migration is a complex and multidimensional phenomenon, a global reality that today involves about 244 million people. There are several factors that generate and condition migratory flows, but careful analysis of them allows us to anticipate the consequences and prepare appropriate policies. The Vergiat report, which I supported today, deals precisely with the issue of migration and links it effectively with that of human rights. The EU must guarantee the protection of migrants' rights in order to be truly credible in the debate on migration and human rights in third countries. Responding to the migrant crisis means fighting for respect for their rights in the first place today, while at the same time establishing appropriate measures and policies for the management of flows. Integration must be fostered by focusing on education and work, recognising and preventing those forms of discrimination and violence to which WOMEN AND LGBTI people are subjected. The European Union has a duty to work positively to eliminate the root causes of migration crises, and to do so it must necessarily resist the populist pressures that are manifested today in many of its Member States. The only possible way to strengthen its foreign policy action is through solidarity.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a report of our own initiative, carried out from our group and which addresses in a necessary and urgent way the humanitarian crisis that the Union is living in as a result of conflict, violence and repression in countries of origin of flows of forced mobility. The report calls without mitigation to comply with international conventions, in particular those on human rights, asylum and refuge, as well as to address in a comprehensive, urgent and sufficient manner, by the Member States and the Community executive, all the problems and vulnerabilities of different kinds, of which persons in mobility to and within the Union are victims , from a human rights-based approach.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. It is not by creating additional legal channels of immigration - there are in all the countries of the Union - that Europe will be able to control the migratory flows that former French President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, spiritual father of the aborted European Constitution, once described as an invasion. That is why this report is fishing for an angelism that our citizens no longer want. Even on the left, more and more voices are rising to say that migrants have not only rights, but also duties. The rapporteur seems to be living on another planet, even if she dares to argue timidly that we must create the necessary conditions to allow refugees to stay close to their country of origin and that we must address the root causes of migration. Migrants are the first victims, they have to live like uprooted people in a culture that is not theirs and they are given no means to acquire it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mrs Vergiat for her work on this report on human rights and migration in third countries. Very hard work has been done to get to the plenary and in that report there are very important points which have led me to vote in favour of it no more than the final vote.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report by Communist MP Ms Vergiat on human rights and migration in third countries. The aim is for the European Union to force non-EU countries to suffer the effects of German immigration policy. This is an attack on the sovereignty of third states as well as that of the Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on human rights in third countries is the usual advertisement in favour of the indiscriminate reception of various types of migrants, most of whom do not escape from any war or persecution. This is the usual good show of those political forces which claim to help the rest of the world but do not care in the slightest about the problems of European citizens, who are increasingly prey to unemployment and poverty, the consequences of the economic crisis. I have always fought to help our citizens, to ensure that this Union changes gears and deals first with our people and then with the rest of the world. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it strongly and firmly calls for the effective defence and protection of the human rights of all persons who are forced, for various reasons, to migrate. The finally adopted text — despite the opposing vote of the groups on the right – places particular emphasis on special protection measures for the most vulnerable, in particular women and children, and calls for improvements for the integration of migrants into host countries and their access to basic services and the labour market. It also specifically addresses the situation of refugees and internally displaced persons – more than 65 million people today – whose dignity and human rights are flagrantly violated, and insists that there is no better means of preventing trafficking and trafficking in human beings than the opening of safe and legal avenues for migration. This report also calls on the Union and its Member States to set an example in the promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, especially within their borders, if they are to have credibility in discussions on migration and human rights with third countries.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the human rights and migration situation in third countries. The European Parliament expresses solidarity with the people forced to leave their country, including through conflict, persecution, human rights violations and extreme poverty. It also expresses concern at the serious human rights violations that many migrants are experiencing in many countries of transit or destination. Parliament stresses that the European Union and its Member States must set an example in promoting and protecting the human rights of migrants, in particular on its own territory, so that they can be trusted when discussing migration and human rights issues in third countries. Parliament recalls the importance of identifying stateless persons in order to be able to provide them with the protection provided for in international law, and therefore urges states to develop stateless procedures and exchange good practices among themselves, including good practices in the application of legislation and practices relating to the prevention of newly emerging stateless children. Points out, moreover, that the European Union must constantly address the problem of statelessness, which must be part of its external relations policy, especially given that statelessness is one of the main causes of forced migration.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the report expresses exaggerated expectations for the management of migrants, which go beyond the financial means of the host countries. It does not make a sharp distinction between economic migrants and refugees from war zones. In fact, it encourages economic migration. At the same time, it raises important forward-looking questions, but for the time being the solution to the problem seems remote. In view of all this, in line with the EPP, I could not support the adoption of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to require Member States to put pressure on non-member states, which are forced to adopt EUROPEAN standards on the rights of illegal immigrants. I am strongly opposed to this major infringement on the sovereignty of these third states, as well as the sovereignty of the Member States. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on human rights and migration in third countries because I wanted to express my solidarity with persons who are forced to leave their countries. Moreover, I share with my colleagues the concern regarding human rights violations which are occurring especially in countries of transit. Thus, the Parliament stressed with this resolution the need to lead by example in the promotion of the human rights of migration in order to be credible in discussing with third countries.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 People forced to flee their country due to conflict, persecution, human rights violations, famine or deep economic poverty must be treated with respect and dignity in both transit and destination countries. We are well aware that only by stabilising the areas of origin of migratory flows can we stop – or at least cushion – the phenomenon and that this will take a long time: however, this cannot be an excuse to lower our standards and not protect the personal dignity of those who come to us in an objective need. The European Union must strengthen its foreign policy in order to be more present in crisis areas and take direct action to prevent the outbreak of regional instability. , hopefully in the near future also federal, this great challenge of the Third Millennium.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In a total violation of the sovereignty of non-EU member states, this report aims to force third countries to take their share of responsibility for the distribution of illegal migrants, particularly in Italy and Greece. The European Union has no legitimacy to impose on the Member States its crazy migration policy, which is exclusively within the competence of national governments. The European Union therefore has no power to compel national authorities in a third country to accept quotas for illegal migrants. I therefore voted against this scandalous report which seriously undermines the sovereignty of third countries.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it strongly and firmly calls for the effective defence and protection of the human rights of all persons who are forced, for various reasons, to migrate. The finally adopted text — despite the opposing vote of the groups on the right – places particular emphasis on special protection measures for the most vulnerable, in particular women and children, and calls for improvements for the integration of migrants into host countries and their access to basic services and the labour market. It also specifically addresses the situation of refugees and internally displaced persons – more than 65 million people today – whose dignity and human rights are flagrantly violated, and insists that there is no better means of preventing trafficking and trafficking in human beings than the opening of safe and legal avenues for migration. This report also calls on the Union and its Member States to set an example in the promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, especially within their borders, if they are to have credibility in discussions on migration and human rights with third countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
