text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on human rights and migration to third countries because decisive responses are needed to cope with the exceptional wave of migration. Europe needs to implement an integrated policy on migration. Most of these people are forced, on their migratory route through transit countries, to suffer serious human rights violations. It is essential to improve the exchange of good practice with third countries by providing training for humanitarian workers so that they can more effectively identify the various characteristics, backgrounds and experiences of migrants, in particular the most vulnerable. In short, the European Union must be able to build a genuine common partnership with third countries if it is to tackle the problem properly and coherently.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report contains various issues with which we cannot agree, such as the creation of migration channels into the EU. It also supports EU NAVFOR and freedom of movement, to which we are opposed. We are, however, supportive of various humanitarian aspects, but believe that the current EU approach is misguided. Support for genuine refugees would be best served with increased support as close to the country of origin as possible, to facilitate their quick return to their home country once the immediate danger has passed.  There is already a well-established and supported international regime for refugees, which should be adhered to, in particular in that asylum should be granted in the first safe country.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree on the importance of upholding the rights of migrants and fro states to recognise their obligations under international law, but in this particular report I was unable to vote in favour of the text as I felt it did not go far enough in terms of, amongst others, effectively implementing existing bilateral readmission agreements for those who do not qualify for asylum and protection in the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Vergiat's report stresses that the EU and its Member States must set an example in promoting and protecting the human rights of migrants, particularly within their borders, in order to be credible in the debate on migration and human rights in third countries. The text also stresses that the opening up of safe and legal channels of migration is the best means of preventing trafficking and trafficking in human beings and that development strategies must recognise migration and mobility as drivers of development for both the host country and the country of origin through economic remittances and investment. My vote was positive.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a lot of good things raised in this report, however I could not support it as a whole. The reason is very simple, I keep saying it over and over again. The migration problem cannot be solved by imposing quotas, it has to be tackled in a much more comprehensive manner. I see some positive movements in this direction on the EU level, however they were not fully reflected in the present report.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, for which I voted in favour, analyses the main causes of the mass migration phenomena we are witnessing today, and makes some welcome recommendations aimed at improving the reception conditions of these populations.  To date, some 65 million refugees are forced to leave their countries of origin for humanitarian reasons linked to armed conflicts or simply because of the dramatic conditions of poverty. I believe that the European Union, which is based on respect for the human rights enshrined in the Charter of Rights, must ensure that migrants are guaranteed a dignified reception, with attention to the most vulnerable people, such as children, especially unaccompanied minors, who are entitled to specific protection because they are often victims, even more defenceless, of traffickers and criminal organisations. To this end, It seems to me essential that all the Member States of the Union ratify the conventions and treaties, implementing the rules on the rights of migrants. I welcome the fact that the report introduces specific provisions to improve the quality of life of migrants by giving them access to the health system, training courses and the labour market in order to facilitate their integration and inclusion in civil society.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the report, as it contains several points of friction.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on human rights and migration to third countries. Especially since the outbreak of the refugee crisis, it has become clear to everyone how important it is for Europe to take the lead in protecting and supporting human rights, particularly for people who are forced to emigrate. As this report is directly related to similar issues, I think it has positive elements and, for this reason, I voted in favour of it.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting absolutely against this report, which advocates the importance of migration to combat the demographic crisis and as a means of solving problems linked to labour market shortages. In my opinion, the report is totally devoid of logic and is based on an unrealistic view of contemporary society.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because I believe that the report is unclear and does not take into account many aspects relating to the situation of migrants. I agree that particular attention should be paid to guaranteeing the rights of vulnerable groups such as women, children, people with disabilities and the elderly, who are most vulnerable to all types of danger, namely violence, trafficking or abuse, without neglecting all other categories of people. I do not believe it is necessary to attach greater importance to migrant associations, since integration should take place at a social level, without necessarily going through development programmes within communities, and I also do not agree with the creation and application of mechanisms for the protection of migrants in transit and in emergency situations at the EU's borders. I consider it unattrile to alleviate the debt of countries affected by poverty as it would not necessarily be aimed at developing public policies that guarantee respect for human rights. Migration should not be seen as a means of solving specific problems linked to shortcomings in the labour market, as this would lead to the unemployment of young Europeans.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union is committed to solidarity with all those who are forced to leave their country by armed conflict, political persecution, human rights violations and extreme poverty. The rights of migrants, whether in transit or destination countries, must be respected. I follow the concern with the situation of stateless persons and the need for greater effectiveness in their identification and protection. I believe that the mechanisms for granting the right of asylum are faster, more effective and concerted. In this regard, I advocate the sharing of good practice sums of national administrations, the training of officials and a balanced system of exchange of information. Member States must comply with the obligations of international law and European commitments in this area. I share the concern with specific segments such as women and children. Combating all forms of violence (especially sexual violence) must be a priority, as should the fight against trafficking in human beings and slavery. I believe that the issue of migration should be taken into account in EU foreign policy, in particular in neighbourhood policy, EU-ACP relations and development aid. I support this report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are well aware that the European Union has recently been facing serious difficulties with regard to the so-called 'migrant issue'. We must remind everyone of the precise role that Europe should play and that it is still struggling to play. Our credibility is lost if there are borderline situations or serious violations of human rights within our borders. That is why I support the Vergiat report. Situations such as the one that took place in Calais, to give an example to everyone, cannot be accepted. We cannot talk about the protection and promotion of human rights when we cannot secure it within our own borders. In order to achieve this objective, in order to give a concrete response, we must ensure that states ratify all international conventions and treaties on human rights. Safe and legal migration routes must be opened up. We must work to prevent trafficking in human beings and to stop the illegal routes that have been beaten up to now. We must change our attitude to the phenomenon of migration in and of itself, recognise it as a driving force for development and not as an obstacle to it. Development not only for the host country, but also for the country of origin.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Although the right has sought to impose in the report the whitening of systematic human rights violations of migrants in the Union, such as returns to the country of origin against the will of the migrant person, this has been rejected and I have been able to vote in favour of the report. It contains a number of positive elements, which point to the systemic causes of migration and the need for a migration policy based on human rights and legal and secure access routes. I also voted in favour of the report, because it is a criticism of the Union's current model of border outsourcing and migration management by third countries, a model which I completely reject, as well as proposing effective measures for migrants' free access to the social and labour rights and public services of the countries in which they reside. Hence my support for the report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rights enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights are universal and indivisible and go hand in hand with the right of all men to mobility. Therefore, every individual has the right to decide to leave the country in which he or she is located and to exercise his migratory choices in a dignified manner, without suffering treatment that penalises human rights, such as arbitrary detention, refoulement in third countries where there is a real risk of ill-treatment and torture, forms of forced labour and/or degrading working conditions in the countries of origin and arrival, the ghettoisation of migrants in urban areas and the lack of access to education. By voting in favour of this resolution, I wanted to recognise the need for the EU and its Member States to protect the human rights of migrants, asylum seekers, stateless persons, displaced persons and refugees - especially within their own borders and in particular with regard to vulnerable groups (women, children and LGBT) - in order to be credible in the debate on migration and human rights in third countries. In addition, the EU can make a positive contribution to eliminating the root causes of crises causing massive migration flows and amplifying the potential of legal migration as a factor for development.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Migration is a global and multidimensional phenomenon caused by a number of negative factors, but which can affect demographic and economic development. In this context, the European Union, as well as its Member States, must provide an example of the promotion and defence of human rights. Respect for the law of migrants, regardless of their status, is a priority for the Union.  I voted for closer cooperation with the international organisations competent to defend the rights of migrants. The identification of specific measures that can be taken by governments to increase the potential of legal migration is necessary to stimulate development.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on human rights and migration in third countries because, in my opinion, this report does not address problematic issues and, on the contrary, makes the matter even more complicated. I believe that this is a very important subject which requires an in-depth analysis. It cannot be approached irresponsibly, as I feel is in the report with regard to the issue of safe and legal access for migrants, permanent and compulsory relocation programmes and family reunification. If you don't have a specific idea of how to resolve this issue, you should not even try to discuss it. I therefore voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Migration is a global, multidimensional phenomenon caused by a wide variety of factors, I have always advocated the need to analyse and address the main root causes of migration in third countries. We need to address the human rights protection gap and this is why I am in favour of this report as it recognises that various challenges and risks in respecting the rights of migrants exist within the context of the current crisis such as segregation within hosting and detention, recognition for LGBTI refugees, access to employment and training, training for social skills, integration measures, economic and cultural dependence and voluntary returns. As in line with my position I voted against reference to abortion in this report.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, the European Parliament has once again confirmed its commitment to the protection of human rights and, in particular, the conditions of workers in third countries. In fact, the globalisation of trade and the opening of branches on all continents have increasingly made companies leading the way in ensuring respect for human rights through the promotion and protection of these rights within their production realities. In this context, therefore, international rules and cooperation are essential to prevent human rights violations in third countries. For this reason, Parliament called on the European institutions to take further measures to this end, and reminded corporate actors of their responsibility for respecting human rights in their operations worldwide, regardless of the location of users and compliance by the host state with its human rights obligations.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I rejected this text, without binding legislative value, on human rights and migration in third countries. This report presents the major failure not to distinguish between refugees, asylum seekers and migrants, even though these statutes confer different rights and obligations. This text, defended by the left-wing groups, then formulates a series of ideologized proposals that are out of step with the realities of the migration crisis in Europe. We have always defended, and continue to defend, respect for human rights in all circumstances, including migration. But the proposals in this text encouraging family reunification, criticising the forced return of irregular migrants or calling for a broad opening of legal migration routes in Europe, run counter to my political convictions.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report mainly concerns migration in third countries, outside the EU. I also welcome the focus on these issues, as well as the emphasis that the report places on the interaction of immigrants and on ensuring basic care. However, I do not fully agree with the recommendation that migrants be involved in all social and political decision-making processes. The process of integrating different cultures and environments is challenging and the long and immediate involvement of migrants in the decision-making processes of the destination state is not happy. In the long term, I also do not support the various forms of mandatory redistribution mechanisms that this report calls for. For these reasons, I voted against the report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a consequence of German immigration policy. It aims to force third countries to adopt European standards in terms of the rights of illegal immigrants. This is, of course, a major attack on the sovereignty of third countries as well as Member States. Also, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on human rights and migration in third countries. It contains many problematic points with which I cannot agree. Among the main problems is the complete lack of distinction between the concepts of "migrant" and "refugee". They are in no way mutually replaceable and it is unacceptable to put a sign of equality. On several occasions, the text observes that rights normally given to "refugees" have been extended to migrants, while not distinguishing between legal and illegal ones. The report also calls for the creation of "safe and legal" migration routes. Europe cannot afford to promote migration, as many countries currently have major problems with the social system, security systems, etc.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Migration is not a human right, but a symptom of a flawed economic system and the inability to find work in the country of origin. The Union should find ways to ensure the right to work and a decent life for all citizens of the Member States. What is written in the report, rather than addressing the problem, reinforces it, creating a vicious circle.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Migration is a global and multidimensional phenomenon, which has at its origin several causes, such as economic conditions, social and political conditions, working conditions, situations of violence, the security situation, the gradual degradation of the environment and the worsening of natural disasters. Currently, some 244 million people are considered international migrants.  I therefore agree with the taking of measures to combat the smuggling networks of migrants, the creation of legal and safe routes, including through humanitarian corridors, for people seeking international protection, the establishment of permanent and compulsory resettlement programmes and the granting of humanitarian visas to persons fleeing conflict areas, the improvement of the functioning of 'hotspots' and entry points at the Union's external borders and the creation of effective tools for coordination, alignment of information flows, collection, crossing and analysis of data.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: this is of course a major attack on the sovereignty of third states as well as Member States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report addresses the issue of human rights violations – as is customary – in 'third countries', as this is not something to discuss in relation to the European Union, and not for lack of such violations. The report contains positive elements. It refers and calls for the implementation of the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. It calls for the implementation of the UNITED NATIONS Global Compact, ongoing processes within the UN that we value. The general orientation is to hold companies more accountable for human rights violations. In the absence of a comprehensive approach to corporate accountability in terms of human rights, the report emphasizes the moral responsibility that companies must have in the field of human rights; proposes legislative and legal measures to protect and contribute to their reparation; underlines the duty of states to fulfil human rights and for companies established on European territory to respect human rights; values the legislative frameworks that have already evolved in this field; calls for the fulfillment of human rights in state enterprises. The set of kind recommendations will be based on the pious conviction that the report is imbued with, that it is possible to humanize capitalism. This is your biggest limitation.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The increasing number of refugees worldwide is overshadowed by an even greater number of displaced persons within the country's borders. These persons should not be discriminated against simply because they have tried to ensure security without crossing international borders, and stresses, therefore, that the rights of displaced persons, including access to healthcare and education, should be respected. Recently, cases of arbitrary detention and ill-treatment of migrants and refugees have been multiplying. Detention must be limited to absolutely necessary cases and appropriate protective measures, including access to appropriate judicial proceedings, must be guaranteed in all circumstances. In general, the mood and situation with migrants is reaching an unmanageable level, and several reports of ill-treatment and of tensions and non-respect for fundamental human rights are permeating.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report, the usual pro-immigration rhetoric.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Migration is not a human right, but a symptom of a flawed economic system and the inability to find work in the country of origin. The Union should find ways to ensure the right to work and a decent life for all citizens of the Member States. What is written in the report, rather than addressing the problem, reinforces it, creating a vicious circle. That is why I am voting against it.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I support a Europe-wide cooperation style agreement rather than forcing Member States to accept migrants when they do not have the capacity to do so. Additionally, the UK’s decision to take the most vulnerable refugees is a fairer solution than letting migrants walk across half the continent to seek asylum. Europe needs a more flexible approach for different Member States and a firm but fair policy on who to accept. This report does not deliver that.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report makes an analysis of the main root causes of the migration phenomena in third countries and stresses that according to the UNHRC, the 65 million displaced people are affected by humanitarian conflicts resulting from conflicts and worldwide economic situation and that they should see their dignity and human rights respected. Members call on governments to address the human rights protection gap, which migrants continue to face and to abolish punitive legal schemes which criminalise migration. The report also underlines that ‘the concept of safe countries of origin’ should not prevent individual assessments of asylum application and asks for migrants who need international protection to be identified and for their application to be considered. Moreover a call is made on States to ratify all international treaties and conventions and to apply the standards applicable to migrants’ rights which may be found in a variety of legal international instruments.  I supported the adoption of this report in the plenary.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I abstained in this report despite considering that human rights are inherent in all human beings, without distinction. Migration is a global and multidimensional phenomenon, which has its origins in multiple causes such as economic, social and political conditions, working conditions, violence and security, as well as progressive degradation of the environment. This phenomenon must be addressed in a coherent and balanced manner, within a global perspective that takes into account its human dimension. We must keep in mind that according to the United Nations, nearly 244 million people are currently considered international migrants. It is therefore essential to have effective mechanisms for monitoring and controlling the entry and exit of foreigners, as well as analysis and forecasting of the effects of migration, as a basis for the development of any policy for managing the migration phenomenon.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it strongly and firmly calls for the effective defence and protection of the human rights of all persons who are forced, for various reasons, to migrate. The finally adopted text — despite the opposing vote of the groups on the right – places particular emphasis on special protection measures for the most vulnerable, in particular women and children, and calls for improvements for the integration of migrants into host countries and their access to basic services and the labour market. It also specifically addresses the situation of refugees and internally displaced persons – more than 65 million people today – whose dignity and human rights are flagrantly violated, and insists that there is no better means of preventing trafficking and trafficking in human beings than the opening of safe and legal avenues for migration. This report also calls on the Union and its Member States to set an example in the promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, especially within their borders, if they are to have credibility in discussions on migration and human rights with third countries.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it strongly and firmly calls for the effective defence and protection of the human rights of all persons who are forced, for various reasons, to migrate. This report also calls on the Union and its Member States to set an example in the promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, especially within their borders, if they are to have credibility in discussions on migration and human rights with third countries.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is very important to adopt this report, which outlines the General Position of the European Parliament on a priority issue such as safeguarding, in the complexity of the phenomenon of migratory flows, security, dignity and respect for the rights of migrants, who are all too often violated. Europe reaffirms its role and founding values, ensuring that applicants for help and reception, who are fleeing conflict, degradation and poverty, can find in the Union reception and access to education and health care and opportunities for social integration, fair and indiscriminate.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on human rights and migration to third countries because I share its structure and contentment, and I join in the call for Member States to do more in terms of solidarity and welcome. I agree with the analysis made of the causes of migration, a lasting phenomenon that will continue until we are able to ensure a happy and dignified life in certain realities in the world. I agree even more with the call to ensure respect for human rights and the dignity of treatment for migrants arriving on our shores, fully applying international conventions and, above all, guaranteeing the safety of children. Indeed, there is still in some states, including the EU, criminalising the phenomenon of migration, which goes hand in hand with unscrupulous use of force and inhumane behaviour towards asylum seekers and refugees, and which the EU can no longer tolerate. The specific reference to the situation of women, who have greater difficulty in integrating into the host society, is also important.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on human rights and migration in third countries. It does not address the existing problems in the first place and sets completely the wrong accents.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I consider the definition of "safe countries of origin" to be an important step in the management of the refugee crisis. Since the report rejects the concept of 'safe countries of origin', I cannot agree with it.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. The title of Mrs Vergiat's report is an excuse to sing the praises of immigration, luck both for the migrants themselves, for the host countries and the countries of origin. His basic axiom is: "Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own." It is true that dictatorships, especially communist dictatorships, have always narrowly limited the possibility of obtaining passports to a handful of apparatchiks, the vast majority of the population being somehow under house arrest.  But the freedom to travel is not an absolute right to emigrate and to settle where you want to benefit from the many rights listed by Mrs Vergiat (training, employment, housing, health, etc.). Overwhelmed Western societies can no longer cope. Ms Vergiat called for developing countries hosting displaced populations to align themselves with the european Union's lax and outrageously generous regulations, even as they struggled to guarantee these rights to their own citizens. I demand for them what I demand for my country: the right to choose whether or not to take in migrants and to practice differences in treatment in favour of their nationals.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a report of our own initiative, carried out from our group and which addresses in a necessary and urgent way the humanitarian crisis that the Union is living in as a result of conflict, violence and repression in countries of origin of flows of forced mobility. The report calls without mitigation to comply with international conventions, in particular those on human rights, asylum and refuge, as well as to address in a comprehensive, urgent and sufficient manner, by the Member States and the Community executive, all the problems and vulnerabilities of different kinds, of which persons in mobility to and within the Union are victims , from a human rights-based approach.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it addresses challenges linked to migration in third countries and focuses on the respect of their human rights, such as children’s and women’s rights, non-discrimination, LGBTI rights, right to work. It makes clear recommendations, suggesting reintegration programmes for migrants returning to countries of origin, safe and legal migration channels and improving ‘hot spots’ at EU external borders.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report. I express my deep concern at the dramatic challenges and grave human rights violations faced by many migrants in numerous countries of transit or destination. I believe that the EU and its Member States must lead by example in promoting and protecting the human rights of migrants, in particular within their own borders, in order to be credible when discussing migration and human rights in third countries. The report did not present well situation of children in the light of human rights in third world countries which deserves in-depth analysis.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it strongly and firmly calls for the effective defence and protection of the human rights of all persons who are forced, for various reasons, to migrate. name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report contains many important elements and is also critical of existing EU policies. The report stresses that migration is a global and multidimensional phenomenon and that human rights are universal and non-discriminatory. It presents the overall picture of migration today, with some 244 million people considered international migrants. It also gives the dimension for domestic immigrants. Importantly, the report also deals with issues of integration of migrants into local communities, as well as reintegration programmes in their countries of origin. For these reasons, we consider this vote to be an appropriate stance.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the role that fundamental rights play within the EU, increasing globalisation and internationalisation of business activities and supply chains will make the role that corporations play in ensuring respect for human rights more important. Therefore, there is a urgent need to act in a continuous, effective and coherent manner at all levels, including national, European and international, in order to effectively address human rights abuses by international corporations, especially those based in the EU. I think it is imperative there are judicial, administrative, legislative or other appropriate means, that when such human rights violations occur and that those affected have access to an effective remedy, when a corporation based in the given states holds, directs or controls companies that are responsible for human rights violations in other countries. Accordingly, I have voted in favour of the above resolution.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by the left-wing MEP Marie-Christine Vergiat contains some positive elements. For example, the text states that human rights apply to all and that the EU should, among other things, give high priority to the protection of women and minors against violence and the fight against trafficking in human beings. However, the report contains a large number of unacceptable passages. This does not make a clear distinction between persecuted refugees, asylum seekers and economic migrants. Only the rights of migrants, such as education and work and family reunification, are emphasised, but not their obligations. In addition, the fairy tale that international migration can be used as a tool to combat labour shortages in European countries and allegedly helps to solve the demographic problem in Europe is re-listed. Moreover, there is a blanket impute to the fact that migrants contribute to Europe's cultural wealth. As a highlight, paragraph 4 even denys that there can be something like illegal migration at all. The report is thus peppered with left-green ideology, which prefers to ignore existing law, deny the duty of ownership and build a land that cannot be financed at the taxpayers' expense. I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against Mrs Vergiat's report, which does not fulfil its objectives and multiplies the incantations but does not propose an acceptable and realistic solution. Rather than insisting on the necessary cooperation between the EU and third countries in conflict resolution and development, this report focuses on the measures that EU Member States should take to ensure the reception of migrants on their territory. In addition, Mrs Vergiat confuses migrants, asylum seekers and refugees, erecting all categories of victims that our countries would have a duty to accept and integrate for the simple reason that migration has a positive influence on our societies, which are otherwise facing a demographic problem. I also pass the recommendations on legal immigration, family reunification and integration with proposals such as the translation of the employment contract into a language that the migrant understands, the association of migrants in all social and political decision-making processes or the automatic recognition of qualifications...

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on Human Rights and Migration in third countries, as migratory flows, which are increasing daily, have important economic, social and political implications for the home and destination countries of migrants. The European Union and its Member States must set an example when it comes to promoting and protecting the human rights of migrants, especially within their own borders, so that they can be credible participants in the debate on migration and human rights in third countries.  This Report, which I support, recognises the efforts made by third countries to accept migrants and refugees, and stresses that the support systems of these countries face major challenges, which can seriously jeopardise the protection of an increasing number of displaced people.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. It is my duty to condemn this proposal which undermines the sovereignty of Member States or not. They have the right, and even the duty, to choose and direct their destiny. I voted against it.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: Written. 'The PvdA delegation abstained from voting on the report 'Human rights and migration in third countries'. Of course, we are in favour of the protection of human rights worldwide, and EU migration policy must not be in breach of international and European law, such as the 1951 Refugee Convention. However, this report is inconsistent because it does not seem to make a difference between migrants and refugees. In our view, this distinction is important. In order to maintain support for the protection of refugees – who have been displaced from their homelands by war, violence and persecution – it is important that there is also an effective return policy for migrants who are not entitled to asylum, and have come to Europe with economic motives in particular.  Because of this lack of nuance, we could not accept this report. Because we do agree with the call not to lose sight of human rights in migration policy, the choice to abstain was the most obvious.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against my colleague Marie-Christine Vergiat's report on human rights and migrants. The text before us suffered from too many demagogic statements and a lack of concrete and realistic proposals to enable the Union to reconcile the protection of human rights in third countries with the fight against illegal immigration.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report of MEP Vergiat as it is of utmost importance to make sure that the human rights of migrants and refugees are respected across Europe. What is equally important is that the Member States understand the complexity of the issue and cooperate, so as to help the Member States receiving the refugees and immigrants by allowing the relocation mechanism to function. It is a collective approach that we need to adopt.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this report. It assumes that the best way to reduce illegal migration is to legalise it, thereby converting the problem of mass illegal border crossings into legal ones. It also calls for an increase in the influence of asylum NGOs in the drafting of measures and legislative proposals.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE)
text: Writing. The report put to the vote is, on the whole, unbalanced. The important differentiation between "migration" and "escape" has not been sufficiently taken into account. The terms were also repeatedly reversed and misunderstood. Especially on a complex and complex topic such as the migration and refugee challenges, a precise and differentiated debate is of great importance. A more balanced report also lacks the reference to the lawful repatriation of those who do not receive a positive asylum decision or the right to international protection. It has also been overlooked that countries of origin and transit also have a responsibility in the effective implementation of existing bilateral readmission agreements. There is also a lack of evidence of the importance of the European Border and Coast Guard for effective external border management, the importance of creating a common EU list of safe countries of origin and the impact of migration on the labour market. In order to make the report more balanced, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has requested a large number of separate and separate votes in the plenary vote. Mr Gahler has also tabled two oral amendments on the importance of repatriation and the implementation of bilateral readmission agreements. Since the outcome of these votes could not improve the text as a whole and Mr Gahler's oral amendments were not accepted, I decided to vote against the report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. We met real refugees in connection with the South Slavic war. The elderly, women and children came to Hungary. The men were protecting their country, so they didn't come. They had little money, since there was no movable property to sell in a war zone. They were genuinely happy with any kind of housing, food, clothes. They didn't make demands, they didn't threaten, they didn't litter. They quietly, modestly accepted what they were given. They didn't want to force their own habits on us. Not their religion. Where they could help. Then, when the time came for them to return to their own country, they said goodbye with gratitude. That's what real refugees are like. The current migrants hardly fit the above, so there are very big problems with this report. Just as there are and will be very big problems with teams of 80% young men disguised as refugees. Does anyone know how many of them have committed war crimes or common law crimes? Does the person who invited them in take responsibility for them? Or have you at least read the relevant passages of the Geneva Convention?

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Unfortunately, in recent years, many people have been forced to leave their countries and become migrants on account of conflicts, extreme poverty and particularly human rights violations. Far more disturbing, however, is the fact that as migrants they continue to face human rights violations in numerous countries of transit or destination. The EU and its Member States should lead by example in promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, notably within their own borders, in order to be credible partners when discussing migration and human rights with third countries. Therefore, the EU should identify specific actions that Member States should take to combat xenophobia and to facilitate social integration of migrants. With regard to human rights and migration in third countries, the EU should use various policy instruments in its relations with developing countries in order to protect human rights/rights of migrants there. In this context, the EU and its Member States should incorporate migration issues as a component of the political dialogue with third countries. The EU also should provide technical assistance to improve national and local human rights/migrants policies in third countries. Last but not least, the EU should work actively with NGOs and civil society in third countries.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The phenomenon of migration is a global phenomenon, not just a European one, which has been triggered by various factors, including economic, social, political, working, security and environmental conditions in the world. The eu as a whole, and not just the border states, has a responsibility to tackle this problem, especially from a human point of view, but combining the protection of fundamental rights with the need to guarantee the security of our citizens. Parliament's report, adopted today, highlights the defence of migrants' rights, including leaving their country and access to justice and effective redress. It focuses on violence against women and children, calling for the implementation of migration policies sensitive to the rights of the most vulnerable groups; recalls that economic, social and cultural rights should be guaranteed equally to all migrants, and stresses that the concept of a 'safe country' should not be discriminatory for any migrant when applying for political asylum. It is therefore called for each State to assume its responsibilities and to recognise its obligations under international law, for a Europe of solidarity and security.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Immigration is increasingly a South-South phenomenon and the number of refugees is on the rise. The report on migration out of Europe focused on refugees. Rather than outsourcing the management of migration flows to our neighbours by turning a blind eye to respect for human rights, the report advocates opening our eyes and leading by example. We propose: the signing by all Member States of the International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and their Families; Refusal of forced readmissions; Refusal of collective expulsions; respect for the right to family reunification and the right to leave and return to a country; working in depth with our partners to implement laws that respect the rights of migrants. This last point is crucial in the EU-Turkey agreement and the following ones based on it. That is why we are calling for parliamentary monitoring and evaluation of these agreements to ensure that fundamental rights are respected, when these agreements are often written in such a way as to avoid parliamentary scrutiny. I have obviously supported this report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report entitled "Human Rights and Migration in Third Countries. The aim is for the European Union to force non-EU countries that are forced to suffer the effects of Germany's immigration policy to adopt EU standards in terms of the rights of illegal immigrants. This is, of course, a major attack on the sovereignty of third countries as well as Member States. This is unacceptable.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to have EU standards adopted in terms of the rights of illegal immigrants by non-EU states. In addition to being an immigrationist report, it is a clear attack on the sovereignty of non-member states. I voted firmly and logically against it.
