name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the right has sought to impose in the report the whitening of systematic human rights violations of migrants in the Union, such as returns to the country of origin against the will of the migrant person, this has been rejected and I have been able to vote in favour of the report. It contains a number of positive elements, which point to the systemic causes of migration and the need for a migration policy based on human rights and legal and secure access routes. I also voted in favour of the report, because it is a criticism of the Union's current model of border outsourcing and migration management by third countries, a model which I completely reject, as well as proposing effective measures for migrants' free access to the social and labour rights and public services of the countries in which they reside. Hence my support for the report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by the left-wing MEP Marie-Christine Vergiat contains some positive elements. For example, the text states that human rights apply to all and that the EU should, among other things, give high priority to the protection of women and minors against violence and the fight against trafficking in human beings. However, the report contains a large number of unacceptable passages. This does not make a clear distinction between persecuted refugees, asylum seekers and economic migrants. Only the rights of migrants, such as education and work and family reunification, are emphasised, but not their obligations. In addition, the fairy tale that international migration can be used as a tool to combat labour shortages in European countries and allegedly helps to solve the demographic problem in Europe is re-listed. Moreover, there is a blanket impute to the fact that migrants contribute to Europe's cultural wealth. As a highlight, paragraph 4 even denys that there can be something like illegal migration at all. The report is thus peppered with left-green ideology, which prefers to ignore existing law, deny the duty of ownership and build a land that cannot be financed at the taxpayers' expense. I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The resolution 'calls on all States to recognise their obligations in the field of asylum and migration under international law and to adopt the national legislation necessary for the effective implementation of these obligations'. I consider this to be an EU pressure on the Member States to submit to migration quotas. The resolution 'calls for support for the launch of specific social and legal protection mechanisms for LGBTI migrants and asylum seekers'. I see no reason why gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender and intersex migrants should have specific social and legal protection mechanisms in the EU. I see no reason why someone should be granted priority asylum just because they claim to be bisexual. Nor do I agree with the call for the EU to define the term 'climate refugee' and automatically grant asylum to someone just because it is hot in their country.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ UNHRC estimates there are 65.3 million displaced and over 10 million stateless people worldwide. According to the UN, there are 244 million international migrants. Migration is therefore a global issue. Significantly, migration is a human right enshrined in the Geneva Convention and UNDHR. However, many refugees, asylum seekers and irregular migrants are criminalised and penalised. Development aid is key to tackling the migration crisis. Member States should honour their pledge of 0.7 GNI for development aid. This aid should consider the root causes of migration and its global context. The flow of migration is largely within the global south, with most refugees hosted by developing countries. Therefore, aid should address sources of conflict and migration in host and transit countries, and mostly in the countries of origin of the migrants.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to address the human rights protection gap which migrants face, we urged national governments and parliaments to abolish punitive legal schemes which criminalise migration. We requested the implementation of short, medium and long-term solutions to ensure safe conditions for migrants.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legal framework for the protection of migrants is given in the EU by the national, Union and international law by which member countries are bound. According to an estimate by the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, there are at least 10 million stateless persons, with instability, particularly in developing countries, coupled with the humanitarian crisis affecting more than 65 million refugees and displaced persons. At the same time, in view of current developments in the world, migration poses a high security risk and the penetration of illegal crime in the form of trafficking in human beings, smuggling, exploitation at work. At the same time, there is a population resettlement from EU countries, which will have negative impacts on the brain drain. Migration thus affects the economic and social situation of the countries from which migrants come and, at the same time, of the countries of destination. I support the proposal, which stresses the need to respect human rights and, at the same time, the consistent procedures of the Member States in granting asylum so as to protect the security, economic and economic interests of the countries of the Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on human rights and migration to third countries, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 October 2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text proves that the European Union no longer only wants to control the Member States and interfere in their internal affairs, but also to decide the affairs of third countries, and above all to impose its vision of migration policy. In particular, the text mentions 'standards in terms of the rights of illegal migrants'. It is the same vision that the Commission has been trying to impose on us for years, and which we oppose.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the report on corporate liability for serious human rights abuses in third countries. I agree that any activity in which the EU is involved should always be done in accordance with the core values and principles on which the EU is founded upon. The protection of human rights is one of the top priorities indeed.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is an important and necessary document for safeguarding the human rights of migrants, as human rights are inherent rights for all human beings, without distinction. The report calls on Member States to ratify all international human rights treaties and conventions and to apply the rules on the rights of migrants, including the right to health, education and housing, as well as the increased protection of unaccompanied children and young people. I voted for it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the growing weight of the phenomenon of migration, I support the report on human rights and migration in third countries, which states that both the Union and its Member States should become an example in the promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, regardless of their status. To this end, from the Union we must promote cooperation in the defence of the rights of migrants with the relevant international organisations, especially in the countries most affected, in order to ensure a dignified reception and respect for their rights. In addition, we must make an impact on joining forces to combat migrant trafficking.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the resolution on human rights and migration to third countries and I express my solidarity with those who are forced to leave their country, inter alia, because of conflict, persecution, human rights violations and poverty, and I stress that the EU and its Member States must set an example in terms of promoting and protecting the human rights of migrants , in particular within their borders, in order to ensure their credibility in the context of the debate on migration and human rights in third countries.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report by Marie-Christine Vergiat deals only superficially with the prospects for third countries and has serious shortcomings. That is why I rejected this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report, which gives an overview of the situation of human rights and migration in third countries. This report analyses a wide range of problems: the fight against smugglers and traffickers, the exploitation of migrants and stateless people, unaccompanied young people and children. I support the provisions calling for more effective coordination and evaluation of the implementation, impact and continuity of the various EU financial instruments, which are now distributed across different areas, such as migration policy, international development cooperation, external policy, neighbourhood policy and humanitarian aid, and have mobilised more than 400 projects for the implementation of more than 400 projects over the period 2004-2014. I am in favour of the fact that agreements with third countries must provide that a large part of this support must be allocated in order to overcome the social, economic and political crisis that is causing migration. This would help to reduce migration flows towards the borders of the European Union. I am also in favour of strengthening the protection and control of the EU's external borders and the role of the responsible EU institutions, Frontex and EASO.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report on the rights of migrants in third countries takes note of the European Union's responsibility, in particular for its trade policy, in the worsening of conflicts and inequalities in the world that generate the current migration flows. A fortiori, with global warming, these flows require a global and sustainable response. The report also reiterates the need for EU Member States to honour their international commitments and responsibilities and to ensure a dignified and humane welcome, far from the conditions of the Calais 'jungle'. It underlines policies of inclusion and integration through learning the language of the host country or respecting labour law. The right has still succeeded in making a demand to strengthen Frontex and return migrants by draining on development aid funds. In these circumstances, despite the work done by the rapporteur, I cannot vote for it. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to have EU standards adopted in terms of the rights of illegal immigrants by non-EU states. In addition to being an immigration report, it is a clear attack on the sovereignty of non-member states. So I voted against this one.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Migration is a global and multidimensional phenomenon, which has at its origin several causes, such as economic conditions (including changes in wealth distribution and regional and global economic integration), social and political conditions, working conditions, situations of violence, the security situation, the gradual degradation of the environment and the worsening of natural disasters.  This phenomenon must be addressed in a coherent and balanced manner, in accordance with a global perspective that take into account its human dimension, in particular its positive impact on demographic change and economic development.  Member States should set an example by ensuring the promotion and protection of migrants' human rights, particularly within their own borders, so that they have credibility in discussions on migration and human rights in third countries.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support the final version of this text as essential amendments regarding readmission agreements and the safe return of those who do not qualify for asylum and protection in the Union were not adopted.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The right to leave one's country is enshrined in Article 13 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The internal and external aspects of migration policy are closely linked. If Europe is to take responsibility, the countries of origin must take their own. It is about responding together to the common challenges of security and development. There will be no development without lasting peace and security as there will be no social, human and economic development without prosperity. It is not enough just to resettle refugees or meet their basic needs. There is a greater need for action in countries of origin to build resilience, improve stability and encourage development. Let us not forget that 1% growth in Africa yields more than all official development assistance. It is clear that trade, if accompanied by national policies and aid for trade, is an engine of growth. With regard to the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa, initially set up EUR 1.8 billion by the Commission, there is an urgent need for Member States and other donors to fulfil their commitments to double these amounts.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Migration is now a frequently discussed phenomenon influenced by various factors, be it economic, social and political conditions or conditions relating to work, violence, security, the deteriorating environment in a given country. Migrants' rights are legally enshrined in international conventions and their recognition is essential. Migrants have the right not to be returned to a country where they are at risk of ill-treatment and torture; their rights of access to justice must be respected. Women and children, the elderly and the disabled are particularly vulnerable among migrants and, more often among refugees. Individual Member States should implement comprehensive national migration policies on migrants and refugees, with an emphasis on gender issues, in the interests of the safety of these persons. The right to education, work and family life promotes the self-sufficiency of migrants and refugees and their faster integration. A well-organised concrete response from states in the field of migration can be an opportunity, both for individuals and for countries. Migration is a dynamic element, and if Europe can manage it effectively, it can be a counterweight to the demographic crisis that many countries are gradually facing. On the other hand, Europe must focus on helping to deal with the social, economic and political crises that trigger migration, which would also contribute to halting migratory flows towards the EU's borders.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution of the Committee on Foreign Affairs considers the human rights problems that arise in dealing with the migration crisis. It places great emphasis on a definite distinction between the concepts of migrant and refugee, and draws attention to the human rights problems arising from the washed-up of the two categories. It seeks to face ruthlessly the challenges and risks of respecting migrants' rights. It calls on eu bodies to put the rights of migrants and refugees on the agenda of dialogues with the third countries concerned as a separate element, and to prioritise the financing of European projects to protect vulnerable people and migrants' rights, human rights defenders, journalists and lawyers. I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim is to force non-EU countries to adopt European standards on the rights of illegal immigrants, on a lax model. This is, of course, a major attack on the sovereignty of third states on matters which are more than any other responsibility. The vote is, of course, negative.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Article 13 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights enshrines migration as a human right. The international community should respect this provision, as well as any relevant international obligations relating to refugees and migrants, and to recognise the positive contribution of refugees and migrants to our societies, benefiting countries of destination, transit countries and countries of origin, including developing countries. There is an urgent need to create mechanisms to combat human rights violations to which migrants are exposed, which are particularly serious in situations caused by security challenges and natural disasters. I support the need for strong awareness, especially in the countries of destination, to combat xenophobia and facilitate the social integration of migrants. I stress the importance of strengthening the guarantee of the rights of vulnerable groups such as women, children, LGBT people, people with disabilities and the elderly, who are especially vulnerable to all kinds of risks, including violence, trafficking in human beings and abuse.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Eu's aim is to force non-member states to suffer the deleterious effects of German immigration policy and to adopt lax European immigration standards. Moreover, this is of course a major attack on the sovereignty of third countries as well as that of the Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which addresses challenges linked to migration in third countries and focuses on the respect of their human rights, such as children’s and women’s rights, non-discrimination, LGBTI rights, right to work. The report makes a clear distinction between migrants, asylum-seekers and refugees. The report focuses particularly on problems linked to statelessness of migrants and on humanitarian conditions in of origin and transit countries. The rapporteur makes clear recommendations, suggesting reintegration programmes for migrants returning to countries of origin, safe and legal migration channels and improving ‘hot spots’ at EU external borders .

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this confusing, catch-all and completely disconnected report on human rights and migration in third countries. In particular, the text argued that variations in migration flows have significant economic, social and political benefits, that irregular migrants are the most in need of protection, or that migrants contribute to increasing the diversity and cultural richness of host countries.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the scale of the phenomenon, which today involves 65 million refugees and about 244 million migrants; whereas the complexity of the flows and, in particular, their transnational nature, assessed the broad spectrum of causes, from climate change to war, and their common denominator, hunger and despair; We are voting in favour of this report. The text, taking into account the multidimensional nature of migration, promotes a holistic approach that balances human dignity issues well with security principles. We also share the strong concern about respect for fundamental rights and the humanitarian conditions to which migrants are subjected in transit countries and, in this regard, we hope for the ratification and compliance with international conventions. In view of this, we recognise the great show of solidarity supported by some of these developing countries. We also stress the great importance of including the gender dimension in migration policies. Women, especially young women, are exposed to a higher rate of risk and violence. As the most vulnerable group to early pregnancies, forced marriages, sexual and physical abuse, and prostitution, we remain in need of protection and care, especially in the specialised health sector.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – In the relationship between third countries and migration, we are facing huge problems that need to be tackled in appropriate ways. I am not in support of serving war situations and humanitarian disasters by forcing development aid. Respect for human rights is one of the cornerstones of the European Union, and we must also convey it to third countries and support them when they need it. However, this requires effective and, above all, effective methods and tools.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution that stresses that human rights are essential to all human beings regardless of their ethnicity or religion, following the migration of persons that have been forced to leave their countries due to conflicts, persecution, violations of human rights and/or extreme poverty.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report highlights the difficulties migrants face both in their countries of origin, which is why they are forced to seek refuge in other countries, as well as in transit and destination countries. International law in general and human rights in particular provide for the right of every person to benefit from migrant status when the situation so requires and I support with my vote today the call on both EU Member States and the international community to make further efforts to protect these people and enforce their rights.  Also, as the report also points out, many of the migrants end up transiting or stopping in developing countries, which are having major difficulties in managing these flows. In this respect, I believe that supporting these states in ensuring adequate treatment for all migrants must continue to be a priority.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on human rights and migration in third countries, because, in my opinion, a number of proposals supported by the EP have gone too far. Among other things, the report calls for too broad protection and support for migration, including one that is not legal. An example is the emphasis on the need to recognise the rights of all migrants, including irregular migrants, to set up organisations to protect workers' rights, such as trade unions, and to become members of them.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it calls for further improvement of migrants and asylum seekers and this poses a significant threat to our society and social systems.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report focuses on ensuring human rights for those who are forced to leave their homes for various reasons and seek asylum elsewhere in the country. Calls are being made to abolish the criminalisation of migration in countries and also to pay attention to the large number of internally refugees. People in weaker situations, such as women, children and people with disabilities, need special attention. The solution to the global migration problem can only be in working for peace in foreign policy, and the EU has a major role to play here. It is essential that both UN members, the EU and EU Member States deliver on their financial commitments on humanitarian aid and that EU Member States contribute 0.7% of their GNP to development aid.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Each Member State must first take appropriate care of its own citizens, provide them with decent living conditions, social, healthy protection. The Union and its Member States must set an example in promoting and protecting the human rights of migrants, but this cannot be done at the expense of citizens and national interests. There is an urgent need to change the approach to migration policy in order to reduce the scale of migration. Real action is needed to address the root causes of crises that cause such mass migration. It is also appropriate to abandon the quota policy when redistributing the refugees from eu countries. The EU must strengthen its external borders by sending a clear message to economic migrants from third countries that they will be closed. Particular attention must be paid to the return of migrants to their countries of origin, where they can be taken in full safety, with full respect for all their fundamental and procedural rights.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Prolonged instability and conflict in some areas are responsible for a humanitarian crisis affecting more than 65 million refugees and displaced persons, according to the UNITED NATIONS High Commissioner for Refugees. The report calls on all governments to combat the lack of protection of human rights faced by migrants, as well as calls on them to abolish the punitive legal frameworks that characterise immigration as a criminal offence. In addition, it calls on states to ratify all international human rights treaties and conventions and to implement standards relating to the rights of migrants, which are in a number of legal instruments. For all the above reasons I voted in favour of the report, which also emphasises ways of improving the quality of life of migrants, as well as their economic and cultural independence, through access to medical care, employment and training.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report records findings of the hell experienced by refugees and migrants trying to escape the fire of war that the EU and its allies and competitors are causing. It refers to physical and psychological violence, restrictions and obstacles to decent housing and food, discrimination on the basis of religion, language, etc., violations of labour law, difficulty in accessing education and many others, without concrete measures, even to relieve refugees and migrants. But EU policy prevents them from reaching their final destination, making up butter on bread and for fascists, in order to drop their racist poison. From this point of view, the report's calls to the Member States to set an 'example' in terms of respect for human rights are inexpensive, when the decisions of the EU and the EU Member States have closed borders, resulting in more than 60,000 refugees and migrants being trapped in miserable living conditions in Greece, Italy. The European Parliamentary Group of the KKE voted white, stressing the need to strengthen the people's fight against the EU's repressive mechanisms, the Dublin and Schengen agreements, the unacceptable entrapment experienced by refugees and migrants.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report contains various issues with which we cannot agree, such as the creation of migration channels into the EU. It also supports EU NAVFOR and freedom of movement, to which we are opposed. We are, however, supportive of various humanitarian aspects, but believe that the current EU approach is misguided. Support for genuine refugees would be best served with increased support as close to the country of origin as possible, to facilitate their quick return to their home country once the immediate danger has passed.  There is already a well-established and supported international regime for refugees, which should be adhered to, in particular in that asylum should be granted in the first safe country.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While considering that the refugee crisis is one of the main challenges facing the European Union and that the problem of the serious human rights violations suffered by many migrants in the different countries of transit or destination raises particular concern. I believe that changes in migratory flows, particularly in times of crisis, have considerable economic, social and political repercussions both in the countries of origin and in the countries of destination of migrants. While I note the importance of this subject and, assuming that I will be following the development of this issue with interest, I do not believe that this objection corresponds to my thinking and I have therefore voted against it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on human rights and migration in third countries focuses on finding an appropriate solution to the frequent violation of the rights of third-country migrants. There is no doubt that the differences between migrants and refugees are decreasing today, and that due to their large number around the world, we can also talk about the global crisis affecting the EU, but it is also causing a humanitarian crisis for developing countries that are often not prepared for the consequences that such a crisis brings with it.  We agree that solidarity and compassion are needed with the victims of forced migration, but also to take actions that will provide a concrete response to this problem. Our actions must be guided by a quality analysis of the current situation and a consensus on the desired situation in the future. Sincere cooperation between the European Union, member states, member states, NGOs and human rights defenders and ultimately all CITIZENS of the European Union is expected on this issue.  Although this resolution is on the track of providing the right answers, I must unfortunately say that I am concerned about some parts of it and I do not think that it as a whole gives the right answer to these great challenges of our time and therefore I have not supported it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is that the EU can force non-member countries to be forced to suffer the effects of German immigration policy to adopt EU standards in terms of the rights of illegal immigrants. This is, of course, a major attack on the sovereignty of third countries as well as Member States, and I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully share the concern expressed in the report about the serious situation that millions of people face as a result of conflicts, persecution, human rights violations and extreme poverty that lead them to leave their countries and embark on long and dangerous journeys, during which they often suffer further abuses. I support the call for their human rights and dignity to be respected, and for the European Union to be the first to set a good example. The only real strategy that can have positive long-term effects is to promote real economic, social and democratic development in the countries of origin, thus addressing the root causes that drive millions of people to emigrate. At the same time, we are obliged to ensure, on the basis of international treaties and in the name of our own values, a dignified and independent life for refugees and migrants arriving in Europe. It is our duty to ensure access to health care, education, training and the labour market, starting with the most vulnerable groups such as women, children and the disabled, to whom particular attention must be paid, promoting inclusive and emancipation pathways.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Most refugees and migrants in the world are accepted by developing countries. While the efforts made by third countries to accept migrants and refugees are undeniable, these countries face major challenges that make adequate protection for the growing number of migrants questionable.  It is important that the European Union and the Member States work to address the various causes leading to mass migration. It is also important that Member States ratify all international agreements and conventions on human rights and apply standards relating to migrants and enshrined in a number of legal instruments. Access to health care, employment and training are key objectives to be promoted by host countries.  Two groups of migrants are particularly vulnerable, unaccompanied children and women. Unaccompanied children are entitled to an additional level of international protection and family reunification must be ensured whenever possible. Women or girls are also particularly at risk because they are most exposed to human trafficking, but they are also the most difficult to integrate. Greater efforts are needed to empower migrant women, providing them with the necessary knowledge and social skills, as well as the ability to learn languages, which is extremely important for sociocultural inclusion.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses one of the problems that currently marks the crisis of capitalism and the crisis in and of the European Union: the humanitarian crisis and gross violations of rights on European territory. With several positive points, the report shows shortcomings and is compromised by a set of negative references that the right and social democracy would impose, even if not to the extent they would like. The result of the vote is that expression. The causes of the problems and the direct and indirect responsibilities at their origin are omitted. The EU, with the US and NATO, is responsible for destabilising the entire Middle East and North Africa, feeding extremist groups, which they now say are fighting in the name of fighting terrorism.  It is very critical of Fortress Europe, while deanated by strengthening security and border management, notably frontex. It welcomes the EURONAVFOR MED mission and its role in combating trafficking in migrants and calls for these missions to be strengthened. An analysis from which we are vehemently distancing ourselves, so the reality it portrays has of criminal, imbued with the security vision of the EU.  The positive elements contained therein, as well as their origin, justify an abstention.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: Written. 'The PvdA delegation abstained from voting on the report 'Human rights and migration in third countries'. Of course, we are in favour of the protection of human rights worldwide, and EU migration policy must not be in breach of international and European law, such as the 1951 Refugee Convention. However, this report is inconsistent because it does not seem to make a difference between migrants and refugees. In our view, this distinction is important. In order to maintain support for the protection of refugees – who have been displaced from their homelands by war, violence and persecution – it is important that there is also an effective return policy for migrants who are not entitled to asylum, and have come to Europe with economic motives in particular.  Because of this lack of nuance, we could not accept this report. Because we do agree with the call not to lose sight of human rights in migration policy, the choice to abstain was the most obvious.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Migration is a global and very complex problem, which has various origins based, for example, on unsu compliant economic conditions, but also on a violent and conflicting environment. The UNHCR report estimates that more than 65 million people have had to flee their country of origin due to instability or humanitarian crisis caused by internal conflicts. I realize that simple solutions cannot be found on this problem. On the contrary, measures need to be taken that are effective in the long term. The adopted report seeks to address an important aspect of the migration crisis concerning respect for the dignity and human rights of refugees and calls on the Member States to abolish criminal law regimes criminalising migration. It also places great emphasis on the need for an individual assessment of each application and the identification and subsequent provision of migrants applying for international protection. The rights of refugees should also be ensured by improving their quality of life, in particular through their access to healthcare, education and employment. In this respect, particular attention must be paid to the weakest, and therefore to women and children, whose numbers are constantly increasing among migrants and refugees. Although I fully agree with all of the above requirements, I cannot support the text again, citing the mandatory distribution mechanism and, in my view, weakening the return policy. It is for these reasons that I abstained.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I also share the rapporteur's concerns about the fate of people forced to flee their country due to conflict, persecution, human rights violations and poverty. I believe it is necessary for the Member States to respect the dignity and human rights of all migrants. But the text proposed by the rapporteur provides a diametrically opposed reading of migration from my own and that of my political group. According to the rapporteur, the EU should not enter into readmission agreements with third countries and should not make its development cooperation funding conditional on effective cooperation by beneficiary states in border control and combating illegal emigration. In my opinion, however, the EU is one of the regions of the world that is doing the most in terms of reception and solidarity, and due respect for the rights of migrants must leave no room for confusion between asylum seekers and economic migrants and for the idea that emigration must always be accepted and that it is always a positive phenomenon. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report by GUE rapporteur Marie-Christine Vergiat contains several problematic issues. Almost complete confusion between the terms "migrant" and "refugee". In a few places, the rights usually granted to refugees have been extended to a wider category of migrants, without distinguishing between legal and illegal migrants. The report is part of controversial discussions on issues such as return and readmission, integration policy and labour market policies that fall outside the committee's remit. The report calls for 'safe and legal' access routes for migrants. It also calls for the creation of 'permanent and compulsory relocation programmes'. It calls for full rights, including housing and education, for irregular migrants and recognition of their qualifications, and for family reunification 'including for economic reasons' and 'including less skilled migrants'. There are also some positive elements, such as appropriate wording on paying particular attention to the rights of women, children and other vulnerable groups, or on funding for the UNHCR, FAO and other organisations helping to provide shelter to refugees near their country of origin. However, they do not offset the fact that in other areas the 'impassable limit' has been exceeded. It is extremely important to maintain the difference between the term 'migrant' and the term 'refugee'. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Protecting the rights of migrants is important. But it is the Member States, and especially the third countries, that must respect the fundamental principles to which they have subscribed under international law. This report, whose vote has been postponed several times, is really not concluded in the sense that major inaccuracies are punctuating its drafting. Migrant, asylum seeker, refugee, are confused. For the sake of consistency, and as the EPP Group as a whole has done, I voted against this initiative report.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. According to the United Nations, some 244 million people are currently considered international migrants. Migration should be regarded as a global and multidimensional phenomenon, which has at its origin several causes, such as economic conditions (including changes in wealth distribution and regional and global economic integration), social and political conditions, working conditions, situations of violence and, of course, the security situation.  I believe that this phenomenon should be treated in a coherent and balanced manner, in accordance with a global perspective that take into account its human dimension. I express my solidarity with people who are forced to leave their country due to conflict, persecution, human rights violations and situations of extreme poverty.  I also point out my deep concern at the serious human rights violations of many migrants in transit or destination countries.  However, I do not consider this report to include the most appropriate provisions for dealing with this phenomenon. I therefore vote is not in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report contains various issues with which we cannot agree, such as the creation of migration channels into the EU. It also supports EU NAVFOR and freedom of movement, to which we are opposed. We are, however, supportive of various humanitarian aspects, but believe that the current EU approach is misguided. Support for genuine refugees would be best served with increased support as close to the country of origin as possible, to facilitate their quick return to their home country once the immediate danger has passed.  There is already a well-established and supported international regime for refugees, which should be adhered to, in particular in that asylum should be granted in the first safe country.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU to show its solidarity with people who are forced to leave their country due to conflict, persecution, human rights violations and extreme poverty, among other factors. The Union and its Member States should set an example by ensuring the promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, particularly within their own borders, avoiding the serious human rights violations of many migrants in transit or destination countries, so that they have credibility in discussions on migration and human rights in third countries.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Syrian conflict reminds us every day, the civil war is compounded by an unprecedented humanitarian crisis with some 7.6 million internally displaced people and 4.2 million refugees in neighbouring countries. This means that the world is now facing the reality of migration, since according to the UN, almost 244 million people are considered international migrants. Victims of conflict, persecution, human rights violations and, more broadly, any form of misery. A complex problem which concerns the European Union as a host country, but also and above all third countries, the subject of the Vergiat report which I supported like a majority of MEPs this lunchtime. Beyond the resolution's observation of the difficult distinction between refugees, asylum seekers and migrants, the text specifies what should and still is not done. This concerns, as a priority, the opening of safe and legal routes of migration as a means of preventing trafficking and trafficking in human beings, as well as the special attention that the Union should give to the rights of migrants within the framework of country-specific human rights strategies.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur in this report, my concerns focused on a number of key points: 1. Ensuring the education of children in countries and reception centres; 2. ensure that women's rights are respected in host countries and centres and that the gender perspective becomes transversal to all relations with migrants; 3. Clarify the impact migrants can have on regional development and the social and economic relaunch of the European Union; 4. Ensure the safety of Europeans and migrants through the implementation of safe migration corridors; 5. to make economic aid dependent on third countries' progress in improving the quality of life of their people and of the migrants they welcome; 6. Ensure non-discrimination and equality before the law and equal protection of the law; 7. Promote the basic social rights of immigrants, including: right to shelter, right to health care, right to fair working conditions, right of organisation, right to education and training, right to minimum subsistence, right to family life, right to physical and moral integrity and right to legal aid; 8. Preventing and eliminating illegal movements and trafficking in migrant workers, particularly undocumented workers.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it strongly and firmly calls for the effective defence and protection of the human rights of all persons who are forced, for various reasons, to migrate. The finally adopted text — despite the opposing vote of the groups on the right – places particular emphasis on special protection measures for the most vulnerable, in particular women and children, and calls for improvements for the integration of migrants into host countries and their access to basic services and the labour market. It also specifically addresses the situation of refugees and internally displaced persons – more than 65 million people today – whose dignity and human rights are flagrantly violated, and insists that there is no better means of preventing trafficking and trafficking in human beings than the opening of safe and legal avenues for migration. This report also calls on the Union and its Member States to set an example in the promotion and protection of the human rights of migrants, especially within their borders, if they are to have credibility in discussions on migration and human rights with third countries.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on human rights and migration in third countries because it is an essential issue. Despite the fact that it contains several repetitions and is not arranged in the most relevant way, it points precisely to the urgency of setting up legal migration routes and draws attention to the need for the European Union to respect the right of migrants and to include this theme in its foreign policy.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The concept of human rights is indeed very questionable when the state is no longer present – when an individual dissolves in the waves of unrest-induced migration. The international community therefore has an important task of ensuring that, regardless of the international situation, the fundamental value of the EU, human rights, remains protected. I support the report that has been drawn up. At the same time, I would also like to point out that, however, more attention should be paid not to the treatment of the disease, but to prevention. We should therefore talk more about how the EU can help prevent or regularise conflicts. Refugees will then also be given less attention, simply because of the reduction of refugees.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite recognising good will and good intentions in the report adopted today only by 6 votes (339 in favour, 333 against and 25 abstentions), I voted against, following the line defined by my Political Group, by virtue of several amendments proposed by us and which we considered fundamental for balance, for feasibility and for the practical implementation of the resolution, have not been adopted. However, I would like to stress that I believe, as described in the report, that a concrete, well-organised and appropriate response to migration is an opportunity for migrants and the various countries involved.  I also agree with the rapporteur that this response should be based on the principles of eradicating poverty, sustainable development, respect for the rights and dignity of migrants and building on close collaboration between the countries of origin, transit and destination of emigration.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a report of our own initiative, carried out from our group and which addresses in a necessary and urgent way the humanitarian crisis that the Union is living in as a result of conflict, violence and repression in countries of origin of flows of forced mobility. The report calls without mitigation to comply with international conventions, in particular those on human rights, asylum and refuge, as well as to address in a comprehensive, urgent and sufficient manner, by the Member States and the Community executive, all the problems and vulnerabilities of different kinds, of which persons in mobility to and within the Union are victims , from a human rights-based approach.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on human rights and migration in third countries. Parliament draws attention to the difficult situation of women and underage migrants, who are often victims of violence. It also reaffirms that economic, social and cultural rights should be granted to all persons, regardless of their migration status. Access to employment and training opportunities are cited as key to the inclusion of migrant women. It also calls on Member States to meet their financial commitments for humanitarian aid in Syria.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the right has sought to impose in the report the whitening of systematic human rights violations of migrants in the Union, such as returns to the country of origin against the will of the migrant person, this has been rejected and I have been able to vote in favour of the report. It contains a number of positive elements, which point to the systemic causes of migration and the need for a migration policy based on human rights and legal and secure access routes. I also voted in favour of the report, because it is a criticism of the Union's current model of border outsourcing and migration management by third countries, a model which I completely reject, as well as proposing effective measures for migrants' free access to the social and labour rights and public services of the countries in which they reside. Hence my support for the report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the Report on Human rights and migration in third countries. Among other things, the report addresses challenges linked to migration in third countries and focuses on the respect of their human rights, such as children’s and women’s rights, non-discrimination, LGBTI rights, and right to work.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it dismissed the principle of subsidiarity in many places, and sought to impose migrant policies on all Member States without consistency. Throughout the report there was inconsistency between the words ‘migrant’ and ‘refugee’. It is a vital distinction for us to maintain the security of Europe, whilst offering real help to those who truly need it.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider universal human rights and democracy to be fundamental values of the Union and fundamental principles and objectives of external action. Although there are a number of instruments at international level, as well as at regional level, particularly within the European Union (EU), that regulate the rights and obligations of migrants, I, too, have personally encountered the fact that the human rights of migrants are grossly violated. Refusal of healthcare, legal aid, lack of possibility of asylum seekers and assessment of their status, insufficient standard of living – these are just some of the lack of basic guarantees for respect for the human rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. In the final vote, I did not support the motion for a resolution because some proposals that would contribute to improving human rights were not approved. I expect that during the Slovak Presidency it will be ensured that the agreed relocation measures are implemented effectively and in full compliance with human rights legislation. I also expect that migration agreements with third countries will not be ignored and that EU cooperation with third countries will be carried out in accordance with EU human rights.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution on rights and migration in third countries in the final vote. The European Parliament's initiative, which expresses concern about the serious human rights violations faced by many migrants in transit or destination countries, could be a useful appeal if it does not contain proposals that violate the principle of subsidiarity.  I agree with the need to respect the dignity and human rights of every human being, including migrants and refugees, and to prevent irregular migration and trafficking in human beings in every possible way. Unfortunately, however, I must say that the report, the main purpose of which should be the above, contains a number of redundant recommendations, which I cannot agree with. For example, the report pays particular attention to specific groups such as LGBTI, seeks to integrate gender issues into migration policies, or calls for the introduction of permanent and mandatory resettlement programmes. Moreover, the report often uses inappropriately in its text and confuses two distinct terms 'migrant' and 'refugee' from each other, which can seem confusing in its overall context. Passages of the text, which talk about the social and economic rights of migrants, can also be read by encouraging the payment of social benefits to all migrants across the board, which is not acceptable. The content of the whole text is also supported by a very close majority of 339 to 333 votes.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report represents the first real attempt to contribute to the very pressing debate on migration in the European Union. It focuses on the rights of migrants in third countries and the means to respect these rights within the framework of European Union policies and in wider international efforts.  The report represents progress in this area by focusing on a human rights-based approach, while stressing that migration is generally a positive phenomenon, as mobility is driven by development both in the countries from which migrants leave and in the countries to which they come.  Migration represents a complex and multilateral phenomenon, which requires a comprehensive approach by the competent authorities and most of society. The report stresses the need for Member States to respect their international obligations vis-à-vis migrants and put their dignity at the forefront of migrant policy.  It calls on the European Parliament to be more involved in the review of European policies in this area and stresses the importance of involving civil society in the implementation of the policies themselves. As I believe that migration poses a major challenge, but also an opportunity for the European Union, and because it is a very balanced and progressive report, I have decided to support the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report by the left-wing MEP Marie-Christine Vergiat contains some positive elements. For example, the text states that human rights apply to all and that the EU should, among other things, give high priority to the protection of women and minors against violence and the fight against trafficking in human beings. However, the report contains a large number of unacceptable passages. This does not make a clear distinction between persecuted refugees, asylum seekers and economic migrants. Only the rights of migrants, such as education and work and family reunification, are emphasised, but not their obligations. In addition, the fairy tale that international migration can be used as a tool to combat labour shortages in European countries and allegedly helps to solve the demographic problem in Europe is re-listed. Moreover, there is a blanket impute to the fact that migrants contribute to Europe's cultural wealth. As a highlight, paragraph 4 even denys that there can be something like illegal migration at all. The report is thus peppered with left-green ideology, which prefers to ignore existing law, deny the duty of ownership and build a land that cannot be financed at the taxpayers' expense. I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union promotes respect for human rights not only internally but also externally. Improving the situation of migrants and internally displaced persons in third countries has a direct impact on reducing illegal migration to the European Union and stabilising its immediate neighbourhood.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on 'Human rights and migration in third countries'. The report mixes asylum and migration. It calls, among many other things, for legal and safe entry routes to be created for people seeking international protection, including through humanitarian corridors. It also calls for permanent and mandatory resettlement programmes to be established. Last but not least, it calls for humanitarian visas to be issued to people fleeing crisis areas, including so that they can enter a third country in order to apply for asylum there.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ According to a UN estimate, international migration is on the rise. Changes in migration flows have important economic, social and political consequences as much as on the starting countries and on the destination countries of migrants. Integrating migrants in terms of education, work opportunities and family reunies is one of the most important conditions for achieving the full potential of life in society and avoiding isolated and unstable neighbourhoods for migrants, just as important as it is to focus on addressing the economic and political crises that are causing migration in third countries. However, reception and integration policy must not be destructive to the life of the migrant country of destination at the same time, as opening up migration routes is not an appropriate solution without an effective and coherent migration policy of development. Therefore, I do not support the report on human rights and migration in third countries of the Foreign Affairs Committee.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the adoption of the report on human rights and migration in third countries, as I believe that migration is a complex problem, but I no longer agree with many other starting points and proposals for these solutions. I believe that, in this day and age, the migration crisis, which is particularly affecting the Mediterranean region at the moment, needs to distinguish, above all, between migration in the broadest sense and the movement of people, many of whom are then granted international protection, whether in the form of asylum or supplementary protection. The Geneva Convention should be applied. However, I believe that, for example, to quote the part of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights that says that 'everyone has the right to leave any country, even his own' and 'return to his country', must be interpreted in the light, for example, of our experience of restricting freedom of movement in socialist Czechoslovakia, not as the right of anyone to move everywhere, regardless, for example, of visa requirements, residence time, etc. These interpretations will in no way contribute to the exercise of the right to asylum for those entitled to it.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report contains many important elements and makes good criticism of policies promoted by the EU. Surely there could be issues on which it is more pronounced, for example with regard to the negative role played by the US and some Member States, in order to lead to the current refugee crisis. There should also be more criticism of the policies promoted by the EU towards a fortress Europe. However, we voted in favour of the report because of its proper criticism on several points and because of the positive measures it promotes in dealing with the refugee crisis.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Migration is not a human right, but a symptom of a flawed economic system and the inability to find work in the country of origin. The Union should find ways to ensure the right to work and a decent life for all citizens of the Member States. What is written in the report, rather than addressing the problem, reinforces it, creating a vicious circle.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the state of human rights and migration in third countries, which gives a comprehensive picture of the challenges associated with migration. The report rightly recalls that a large part of the world's refugees and migrants are being accepted by developing countries, which puts great pressure on their aid systems. I welcome the reporter's call for national governments and national parliaments to eliminate criminal legal frameworks criminalising migrants and to apply short, medium and long-term solutions to ensure the safety of migrants. When considering my vote, the parts of the report dealing with the protection of migrant children played a major role. The text also takes into account concerns about the welfare of migrant children, girls and women from a number of aspects. Furthermore, it is commendable that the report also speaks of the threat posed by climate change. I also urge the EU and its Member States, in the context of the fight against climate change, to support the least developed countries in order not to exacerbate poverty in these countries and to accelerate the increase in the number of displaced persons due to environmental difficulties.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Migration is a global and multidimensional phenomenon with significant economic, political and social consequences. The recent migration crisis, the biggest migration crisis since World War II, has had a significant impact on the functioning of both the European Union and its individual countries.  It is therefore necessary that, in the face of such important challenges, Parliament adopts its unequivocal and firm position. Unfortunately, the report presented contains many illegible provisions, unrealistic objectives and is almost completely devoid of plans and priorities to counteract the current situation in Europe and its immediate neighbourhood.  Although the report rightly draws m.in. attention to member states' obligations regarding the rights of immigrants, or the problem of violence against women and children migrating to the European Union, the document also contains provisions on the obligation to recognise the qualifications acquired by migrants in their countries of origin or to provide work, which seems to be impossible. I have therefore chosen to vote against the report.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I think alde's line was balanced, which is why I voted in favour of the report. Human rights issues are important and are becoming increasingly important as migration increases and must be addressed at EU level.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Migration in general is a global, multidimensional phenomenon generated by a multitude of causes (economic, social, political), which also produces positive effects, resulting from globalisation and market interdependencies. Approached from a human perspective, migration contributes to demographic developments and to economic and social growth, if the fundamental rights of those who migrate are respected. For this reason, migration policies must contribute to the full integration of migrants into host countries communities so that they can benefit from their potential (social, cultural, economic, creative). Of course, these national policies must be coherent and comprehensive, taking into account all the dimensions and implications of the migration phenomenon, the result of the cooperation and cooperation of all those interested in this complex phenomenon.

name: Paul Tang (S&D)
text: Written. 'The PvdA delegation abstained from voting on the report 'Human rights and migration in third countries'. Of course, we are in favour of the protection of human rights worldwide, and EU migration policy must not be in breach of international and European law, such as the 1951 Refugee Convention. However, this report is inconsistent because it does not seem to make a difference between migrants and refugees. In our view, this distinction is important. In order to maintain support for the protection of refugees – who have been displaced from their homelands by war, violence and persecution – it is important that there is also an effective return policy for migrants who are not entitled to asylum, and have come to Europe with economic motives in particular.  Because of this lack of nuance, we could not accept this report. Because we do agree with the call not to lose sight of human rights in migration policy, the choice to abstain was the most obvious.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report underlines the need for urgent action to address all human rights violations faced by migrants, which are most acute in situations of pressure due to security challenges and natural disasters. According to the UNHRC, the 65 million displaced people are affected by humanitarian conflicts resulting from violent conflicts and worldwide economic situations. The report asks the European Union and its Member States to lead by example in promoting and protecting the human rights of migrants, notably within their own borders, and to systematically incorporate migration issues as a component of their political dialogue with all countries. The report calls on the EU to provide technical assistance to improve national and local migrant integration policies and to step up its foreign policies in bringing peace and stability to those areas where war and conflict trigger enormous migration flows to the European Union. I support this report as we need as much visibility and acknowledgement as possible towards the issue of human rights violations faced by migrants, as well as solutions to what triggers the enormous flows of migration to the European Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague's proposal, although I regret some of the compromises made with an un constructive EPP. Through this text, Parliament expresss its solidarity with those who are forced to leave their country because of conflict, persecution, human rights violations and a situation of misery, among other factors. It also expressed deep concern about the serious human rights violations suffered by many migrants in many transit and destination countries. Finally, it should be stressed that special attention must be paid to the dignity and human rights of migrants.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Migration is a global, multidimensional phenomenon caused by a wide variety of factors, such as economic conditions, social and political conditions, labour conditions, violence, security, and environment. If the EU and its Member States must lead by example in protecting the human rights of asylum seekers, economic migrants must be return to their country when their security is guaranteed. However, in this report, all the dimensions and the complexity of the migration issues are not covered and I believe that this report does not reflect the reality. If I believe that the EU, in keeping with its own value and norms, has the obligation to play a strong role in the protection of human rights, the migration phenomenon must be addressed in a coherent, balanced manner, based on a comprehensive approach, which is here not the case and this is the reason why I voted against this report.

name: Eleni Theocharous (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The international community is currently faced with one of its biggest challenges with regards to the migration crisis. People are forced to flee their homes on account of conflicts, persecutions, human rights’ violations and extreme poverty. The EU and its Member States should set the example in promoting full respect of human rights and human dignity and should be at the forefront in protecting those more vulnerable. Women and children migrants are subjected to extreme violence and discrimination and to that end a gender sensitive migration policy is needed. Economic, social and cultural rights should be enjoyed by everybody, regardless of migration status whereas access to employment and trainings are important for the inclusion and empowerment of migrant women.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of Marie-Christine Vergiat's report on human rights and migration in third countries. This report proposes a humanistic approach to the European Union, respectful of those fleeing their country because of war or misery.  By reaffirming the need to protect the rights of migrants and their families, including by providing them with a dignified welcome, this report demands that the European Union and its Member States protect them by welcoming them in a decent manner.  It stresses the protection of the most vulnerable people (women, minorities) and also offers support for employment, in order to ensure that migrants fully integrate into the host countries.  As human tragedies multiply, particularly in the Mediterranean, I hope that this report will be a first step towards a new European strategy on migration, which will eventually lead to the revision of the Dublin II rules.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The complexity of the migration issue is widely recognised, just as the limits of interventions following incomplete regulations are widely recognised, despite the commitments declared by the institutions. The flow of migrants to Europe in recent years has put our reception system in great difficulty and overexposed several countries. We need a strong response and a response that is first and most of all European. I find it unacceptable that there should be countries that call out. At the same time, we must act by agreeing cooperation and partnership agreements with third countries in order to intervene in the causes of the problem.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the report because it contains a number of problematic requests. I find it unacceptable the constant confusion between the term 'migrant' and 'refugee' which runs through the whole report in such a way that the rights granted to refugees under normal circumstances are extended to a much more extensive category of migrants – without doing a distinction between legal and illegal migrants. The only exception is the ECR Group amendment, which explicitly requires political decision-makers to distinction between the notions of refugees and migrants. In addition to the report encroaching deeply on spheres not under the authority of the Foreign Affairs Committee and the European Parliament's Human Rights Committee, such as labour market policies, it also calls for the establishment of safe and legal migrant routes, permanent and mandatory allocation schemes and full social rights for migrants.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I did not support the motion for a resolution on human rights and migration in third countries. Migration is a global and multidimensional phenomenon caused by a wide range of factors, such as economic conditions, social and political conditions, working conditions, violence and security conditions, the gradual deterioration of the environment and the frequency of natural disasters.  Currently, almost 244 million people are considered international migrants, and more and more women and children are among the refugees. International migration can address the shortage of specific labour in the labour market. Appropriate policies of accepting and integration ensure that migrants do not suffer the excessive or prolonged consequences of the traumas faced by many.  Socio-cultural development depends on integration, which requires a determined effort by both migrants, who must wish to adapt to host society without necessarily abandoning their original cultural identity, as well as institutions and communities in host countries that must be prepared to accept migrants and meet their needs.  The opening of safe and legal migration routes is the best way to combat people smuggling and trafficking in human beings, and development strategies should recognise migration and mobility as a driver of development, as remittances and investments promote development in both the host country and the country of origin.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a report of our own initiative, carried out from our group and which addresses in a necessary and urgent way the humanitarian crisis that the Union is living in as a result of conflict, violence and repression in countries of origin of flows of forced mobility. The report calls without mitigation to comply with international conventions, in particular those on human rights, asylum and refuge, as well as to address in a comprehensive, urgent and sufficient manner, by the Member States and the Community executive, all the problems and vulnerabilities of different kinds, of which persons in mobility to and within the Union are victims , from a human rights-based approach.

text: Writing. The own-initiative report by the left-wing MEP Marie-Christine Vergiat contains some positive elements. For example, the text states that the EU should give high priority to the protection of women and minors against violence and the fight against trafficking in human beings. However, the report also contains a large number of unacceptable passages. This does not make a clear distinction between persecuted refugees, asylum seekers and economic migrants. Only the rights of migrants, such as education and work and family reunification, are emphasised, but not their obligations. In addition, the fairy tale that international migration can be used as a tool to combat labour shortages in European countries and allegedly helps to solve the demographic problem in Europe is re-listed. Moreover, there is a blanket impute to the fact that migrants contribute to Europe's cultural wealth. As a highlight, paragraph 4 even denys that there can be something like illegal migration at all. The report is thus peppered with left-green ideology, which prefers to ignore existing law, deny the duty of ownership and build a land that cannot be financed at the taxpayers' expense. I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution and want to make reminder that this text calls on states to recognise their obligations under international law with regard to asylum and migration and to enact national laws for the effective implementation of those obligations. It recalls that migrants have the right not to be sent to countries where they risk ill-treatment and torture; recalls that collective expulsions and push—back are prohibited under international law; expresses concern at the treatment of migrants who are forcibly returned to their countries of origin or to third countries without adequate follow-up of their situation. It calls for the EU and the international community to identify specific measures that governments can take to increase the potential of legal migration as a development enabler; stresses that political leadership and strong advocacy are required, especially in destination countries, to combat xenophobia and to facilitate the social integration of migrants.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to require Member States to put pressure on non-member states to adopt EU standards on the rights of illegal immigrants. I am strongly opposed to this major infringement on the sovereignty of these third states as well as the sovereignty of the Member States. Therefore, I am voting against this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The scale of the migration crisis means that we must not lose sight of the human rights problem for refugees. I agree that particular attention should be paid to women and children among them. Organizations that help them also require financial support. In addition to these relevant observations, the report contains a number of issues that raise my doubts. Firstly, it blurres the line between 'refugees' and 'migrants'. Secondly, it does not focus on fundamental issues, but also covers issues such as integration policy and labour market policy. An example is the call for full rights, including housing and education, including for irregular migrants. In addition, the report calls for the creation of permanent and mandatory relocation programmes. These demands are too far-reaching and vague, which is why I voted against the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Migration is a global and many-dimensional phenomenon for a wide range of reasons, including economic conditions (e.g. development of wealth distribution and economic integration at regional and global level), social and political conditions, the situation with work, violence and security, the gradual deterioration of the environment and the worsening of natural disasters. I supported the report in accordance with the decision of the S&D Group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of a report of our own initiative, carried out from our group and which addresses in a necessary and urgent way the humanitarian crisis that the Union is living in as a result of conflict, violence and repression in countries of origin of flows of forced mobility. The report calls without mitigation to comply with international conventions, in particular those on human rights, asylum and refuge, as well as to address in a comprehensive, urgent and sufficient manner, by the Member States and the Community executive, all the problems and vulnerabilities of different kinds, of which persons in mobility to and within the Union are victims , from a human rights-based approach.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which constitutes the first real attempt by the PE to contribute to the EU-wide, vivid debate on the issue of migration (following a recent DROI report on trafficking in human beings). It aims to focus on the rights of migrants in third countries and on means to uphold these rights in EU policies and broader international efforts.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on human rights and migration in third countries.
