Migration is a global, multidimensional phenomenon caused by a wide variety of factors, such as economic conditions (including changes in wealth distribution and regional and global economic integration), social and political conditions, labour conditions, the situation with regard to violence and security, the gradual deterioration of the environment and the aggravation of natural disasters. Therefore, this phenomenon must be addressed in a coherent, balanced manner, on the basis of a comprehensive approach which takes account of its human dimension, including the positive impact it has on demographic trends and economic development. The report calls for the EU and its Member States to ensure efficient and effective Policy Coherence for Development and to prioritise respect for human rights in their migration policy in relation to third countries. The report equally underlines that migration and development are linked and that development cooperation in the field of education, health, labour law, poverty reduction, human rights, democratisation and post-conflict reconstruction are key factors in preventing forced migration. I voted in favour because I believe that development assistance programmes should not be used for purely migration and border management purposes.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the right has sought to impose in the report the whitening of systematic human rights violations of migrants in the Union, such as returns to the country of origin against the will of the migrant person, this has been rejected and I have been able to vote in favour of the report. It contains a number of positive elements, which point to the systemic causes of migration and the need for a migration policy based on human rights and legal and secure access routes. I also voted in favour of the report, because it is a criticism of the Union's current model of border outsourcing and migration management by third countries, a model which I completely reject, as well as proposing effective measures for migrants' free access to the social and labour rights and public services of the countries in which they reside. Hence my support for the report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the report on human rights and migration in third countries. Among other things, the report addresses challenges linked to migration in third countries and focuses on the respect of their human rights, such as children’s and women’s rights, non-discrimination, LGBTI rights, and right to work.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 On the report on human rights and migration in third countries, I finally abstained. Overall, the report contained a lot of important views on human rights issues and also on the root causes of migration, but as a whole I could not support its adoption.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on one of the problems that currently marks the context of the crisis of capitalism and, in particular, the crisis in and of the European Union. The report itself has some shortcomings, notably in an incomplete identification of the causes and those responsible for these causes: the capitalist system and the imperialist powers, where the US and the EU are included. In the causes, war can naturally be inserted, where there will necessarily also have to be a criticism of NATO. The critical component of EU migration policies is absent and we know the role the EU has played in this issue. By addressing European migration without specifying the causes of such migration and the heavy responsibilities of EU policy in this area, in particular with its economic and financial policy, financial assistance pacts, the report ends up going along side the essentials, although it contains important aspects that justify our abstention.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report identifies recommendations for action for third countries in dealing with migration and flight, with the main aim of increasing migration, legitimising illegal migration and increasing the influence of ASYLUM NGOs. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on human rights and migration to third countries. The report reminds corporate actors of their responsibility to respect human rights in all their global operations, regardless of where their users are and regardless of whether the host state respects its obligations in the protection of human rights. This report once again reaffirms its support for the guiding principles of the United Nations and their application worldwide.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to thank the authors of this report. It sets out a humane and compassionate strategy on migration and asylum. EU Member State governments, including the Tory government in the UK, should take notice and adopt this approach, instead of talking about macabre dental checks for children. This shows that EU institutions set out a plan, and national governments must therefore take action. Refugees are often subject to horrific abuse on their journeys, particularly vulnerable families, women and children. The EU and Member States must cooperate with third countries to provide capacities to deal effectively with refugees, while upholding their fundamental human rights and provide access to education, healthcare, and economic inclusion. We need to make sure that EU actions are in no way implicated in human rights violations in third countries, and that we continue to promote conflict resolution, sustainable development and dialogue to bring peace to war-torn regions.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, since in the liberal view, human rights and a well-managed migration process, are fundamental for the progression of society as a whole. Changes in migration flows, especially in times of crisis, have far-reaching economic, social, and political repercussions for migrants’ countries of origin and for their countries of destination, so it is really important to focus on this issue. This is one of the priorities of the EU and our Union will show again the great values of which it is made of. I agree with the resolution since it calls on states to recognise their obligations under international law with regard to asylum and migration and to enact national laws for the effective implementation of those obligations.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of migration is still topical and raises many questions. The refugee crisis we are facing is unprecedented in its short history and we should also avoid any simplification of this issue. The first and fundamental problem I see in the definition of a migrant and a refugee. It seems to me that this resolution does not sufficiently distinguish between these two different concepts. On the other hand, we categorise migrants in this report as several groups that have different rights. The assessment of asylum seekers should be based on the principle of equality. In any case, it must be realised that the refugee crisis also has a social dimension. In solidarity, the reception of migrants is the right decision; This situation creates tensions in society because it gives the impression that an asylum seeker is above an EU citizen.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report records findings of the hell experienced by refugees and migrants trying to escape the fire of war that the EU and its allies and competitors are causing. It refers to physical and psychological violence, restrictions and obstacles to decent housing and food, discrimination on the basis of religion, language, etc., violations of labour law, difficulty in accessing education and many others, without concrete measures, even to relieve refugees and migrants. But EU policy prevents them from reaching their final destination, making up butter on bread and for fascists, in order to drop their racist poison. From this point of view, the report's calls for Member States to be an 'example' of respect for human rights are inexpensive, when the decisions of the EU and the EU Member States have closed borders, resulting in more than 60,000 refugees and migrants being trapped in miserable living conditions in Greece, Italy. The European Parliamentary Group of the KKE voted white, stressing the need to strengthen the people's fight against the EU's repressive mechanisms, the Dublin and Schengen agreements, the unacceptable entrapment experienced by refugees and migrants.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided not to support this report. I would like to point out that the report does not deal with eu migration policy as such, but migration policy directly in third countries. That in itself would be no problem. However, the report contains numerous measures and procedures that are not realistically feasible and thus have de facto no benefits. At the same time, the report on human rights and migration issues goes too far and does not, in my view, correspond to how the dialogue between the European Union and third countries should take place.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support Mr Vergiat's report on human rights and migration in third countries. Although the report dealt with a subject that is very important and needs to be discussed in the light of the current refugee crisis, I do not think that this report has served its purpose. In many parts, the chaotic text failed to materially separate the concepts of refugee and migrant, referring in several places to a compulsory relocation system with which I disagree. And although the report also contained positive elements, such as improving the functioning of the so-called 'hotspots', improved cooperation between states and important international organisations, or a special emphasis on vulnerable groups, I do not think that it has served its purpose and brought added value. That is why I decided to vote against it in the final vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Vergiat report for sharing the analysis and proposals made on human rights and migration in third countries. I would like to say that the notion of 'safe country' and 'safe country of origin' should not prevent individual examination of asylum applications and therefore it is necessary to ensure, in all circumstances, the processing of asylum applications by migrants. I underline in this report the recommendations for training, vocational training and social skills for the integration of migrants into society.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. - I did not support the motion for a resolution on human rights and migration in third countries.  Migration is a global and multidimensional phenomenon caused by a wide range of factors, such as economic conditions, social and political conditions, working conditions, violence and security conditions, the gradual deterioration of the environment and the frequency of natural disasters. As the motion for a resolution does not provide a concrete, well-organised and appropriate answer to migration issues, I did not support it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Corrado report should go much further in promoting binding instruments for the control and sanctioning of companies that infringe human rights in the world. Existing mechanisms today are based on willfulness and are not sufficient.  It is essential to ensure coherence in European Union policies and not to sign trade treaties containing private judicial mechanisms for resolving investor-state disputes, as they do have and contain CETA (AECG) and TTIP (TTIP).  We also miss a greater reference to the responsibility of financial institutions that support transnational corporations in tax havens dotted with scandals such as Panama's papers.  The second session of the working group is currently taking place at the United Nations, developing a legally binding international instrument to establish responsibilities for transnational corporations and control corporate power. I have been able to participate and believe that the European Union and, in a specific way, Parliament and the Commission should take good note of the work of this group and support its recommendations and proposals, and not continue to stick sticks in the wheel.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted with conviction in favour of this resolution, as my previous colleague said, and I am absolutely in favour of the work that the United Nations is carrying out on a binding treaty that imposes an obligation on multinational companies to act responsibly and ensure their contribution to sustainable development. This is a key issue for opposition to major next-generation trade treaties such as TTIP and CETA, and we hope that Wallonia's resistance and the opposition of millions of citizens to CETA will be respected. I was the rapporteur in this Parliament for a report which put at the centre precisely the issue of a symmetry between the binding nature of the protection of investment law and investors in trade treaties and the non-binding nature of the defence of human rights, the defence of labour rights and environmental standards. This Parliament, as that report says, must increasingly urge the Commission to make respect for human rights binding, and respect for work and environmental standards binding.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: Thank you, thank you. I've seen shocking images from factories in India, China or Cambodia, where there are European fashion companies, for example. What we saw there: we basically saw slavery, we can call it modern slavery, but it's still slavery. I've seen people who work 18 hours a day, sometimes without pay, and people who get beaten when they protest.  Let it not be understood that I am against corporations, it is about respecting human rights in corporations, not only in Europe, but also when working in countries outside Europe. Of course we won't be able to regulate the minimum wage or we can't force entrepreneurs to kick out or how many to keep. But we can enforce respect for human rights for those who work. We must remember that the principles of the United Nations and the OECD on human rights must be applied non-discriminatoryly throughout the world, not only in Europe. Thanks.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses human rights, labour and environmental protection issues. Rules have been introduced which reaffirm the duty of companies to respect human rights and the consequent practical sanctioning of their violation, even when it takes place outside the territory of the EU. Member States are asked to lay down clear requirements regarding the need for companies domiciled in their territory and/or jurisdiction to respect human rights in all their operations and in each country and context in which they operate. Another important point in the report concerns the proposal to create an abuse-free label at EU level, which could be referred to it on a voluntary basis, subject to the monitoring of an independent body governed by strict rules and with inspection powers, competent to verify and certify that no infringements have been committed at any stage of the production chain of the product in question. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. This report is an unnecessary duplication of efforts already undertaken by the UN, who have already agreed on guiding principles on the matter, unanimously agreed by all members. There are calls within the report for the creation of more EU legislation. We are supportive of the overall objectives in improving human rights, but believe that the EU is an unnecessary duplication.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because the text recognises corporate responsibility and expresses concern about human rights violations committed in third countries, and calls for continued, effective and coherent action at all levels, also at national, European and international levels, in order to effectively combat human rights violations committed by international companies. It also explicitly calls on businesses, European and non-European, on their duty to respect human rights, and appeals to the Union and the Member States on their duty to guarantee and protect human rights. It precisely requires the Union, the Member States, third countries and all national and international authorities to adopt, as urgently and as widely as possible, binding instruments for the effective protection of human rights, and I voted in favour.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on making corporations that are in any way connected to the EU more socially responsible.  Positive aspects of the report include support for the mandatory labelling of conflict-related goods, national responsibility for corporate activity in third countries, national responsibility to rectify or remedy human rights violations in their territory, an acknowledgement of the differences facing SMEs and multinational corporations, restrictions on dual use products, and a consistent recognition of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I have expressed my support for this report, in which we remind companies of their responsibilities for respecting human rights in all their activities worldwide, regardless of where their users are located. The protection of human rights must continue to be a priority for the Member States and the European Union itself.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries, because it calls on all companies, European or not, to pay due attention to human rights issues, as well as to incorporate relevant findings into their internal policies with the appropriate allocation of resources.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report takes up the theme of corporate responsibility to extend the European Union's power over the policies of our firms. The free trade imposed by the EU on Member States as well as third countries has had more negative consequences in terms of human rights (the reappearance of some form of slavery) and social rights than the policies of the firms of our states. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The report contains various issues with which I cannot agree, such as the creation of migration channels into the EU. It also supports EUNAV FOR and freedom of movement, to which I am opposed. I am supportive of various humanitarian aspects, but believe that the current EU approach is misguided. Support for genuine refugees would be best served with increased support as close to the country of origin as possible, to facilitate their quick return to their home country once the immediate danger has passed. There is already a well-established and supported international regime for refugees, which should be adhered to, in particular that asylum should be granted in the first safe country.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because I believe that the increasing globalization and internationalisation of business activities and supply chains will increase the importance of the role of companies in ensuring respect for human rights and create a situation in which international standards, rules and cooperation are crucial to preventing violations of these rights by companies in third countries.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on corporate liability for serious human rights violations in third countries. Public limited companies are one of the main players in economic globalisation, financial services and international trade and must respect all applicable and existing legislation and international agreements and respect human rights. I therefore agree that the EU and the Member States should continue to pursue the objective of ensuring the best protection of human rights through the most effective means, and not just by redraating them with administrative and bureaucratic formal rules.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because the free trade that Europe imposes on Member States as well as third countries has had far more negative consequences in terms of human and social rights than any of our companies.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have, of course, approved this report which calls on the Union and member States to set out specific rules clearly stating that companies established on their territory and/or placed under their jurisdiction are obliged to respect human rights in their activities, including outside the Union.  To raise awareness among producers and consumers, the report suggests the creation of a voluntary identification label at EU level that respects human rights.  This label would be accompanied by an independent monitoring body with inspection powers to verify and certify that no violations have been committed at the various stages of the production chain of the products concerned.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Corrao report, which I supported today with my vote, addresses the issue of corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. Without a shadow of a doubt, international companies are now one of the main drivers of globalisation, promoting trade and the development of financial services on a global scale, and they play a crucial role in the economic system thanks to their activity, which must always take account of respect for international standards and human rights. Unfortunately, there have been serious incidents over time in which companies have been responsible for human rights violations and affect the rights of vulnerable groups. The text adopted today is based on the UN's guiding principles on economic activities and human rights and reaffirming the need for European companies operating in third countries to comply with international standards. Europe must take up this issue by promoting awareness-raising of its businesses; trade and investment policy in third countries must be based on ethical values by promoting corporate social responsibility.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour, not without acknowledging that it should have gone much further in promoting binding instruments for the control and sanction of companies that violate human rights. Existing mechanisms today are based on willfulness and are not sufficient. It is therefore essential to move towards a joint responsibility of parent companies throughout the value chain; it is necessary to ensure coherence in Union policies and not to sign trade treaties containing opaque and para-judicial mechanisms for resolving investor-State disputes. We miss a greater reference to the responsibility of financial institutions, which support transnationals and the need to specifically address the right to access to justice of the most vulnerable. We should also, as we proposed in amendments, promote the establishment of a Union agency for the supervision of the activity of transnational corporations in third countries, and sanction procedures in the event of crimes, in order to put the protection of human and environmental rights at the centre of Union action, without the business benefits.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. We support most of the measures contained in this report to ensure that there is an effective system of control and sanctions against companies that, in the exercise of their activity in third countries, commit human rights violations. In particular, we underline our agreement with the creation of labels that guarantee consumers that what they buy is free of such behaviour and that they will help to extend social debate and awareness of this problem.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report by EFDD Corrao addresses corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. In reality, it is a question of the EU using the theme of corporate responsibility to extend its power over the policies of our firms. While the subject is sensitive, the free trade imposed by the EU on states has had more negative consequences in terms of human and social rights than the policies of the firms of our states. Nevertheless, I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite a few passages that I can support, this report could open up to future critical issues, which is why I preferred to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Although some progress has been made in recent years (United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights), there is still no binding regime to respond to the defencelessness in cases of human rights violations by companies. The globalization of economic activities makes it increasingly necessary to establish common rules. This report addresses the necessary responsibility of companies for respect for human rights in their international activities, regardless of the level of compliance where they are present. In this regard, we support the Working Group established within the United Nations for the preparation of a future binding international treaty on business and human rights. We call on the EU for greater coherence and the development and effective implementation of international commitments in this area, and greater efforts by companies in the implementation of human rights due diligence, as well as greater transparency in their activities. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the liability of companies for serious human rights violations in third countries.  The European Parliament notes that the increasing globalisation and internationalisation of business and supply chains will contribute to the increasing importance of the role played by public limited companies in ensuring that human rights are respected and will create a situation in which international rules, rules and cooperation are essential to prevent human rights violations by public limited companies and businesses in third countries. Parliament is deeply concerned when individuals, public limited companies, non-state actors and states commit human rights violations in third countries, including those committed as a result of management decisions of public limited companies and businesses. It also reminds business entities of their responsibility to respect human rights in their global actions, regardless of the location of their users and whether the host country complies with its human rights obligations.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the increasing globalisation and internationalisation of business activities and supply chains makes the role of international companies more important in ensuring respect for human rights and a situation where the existence of international standards, rules and cooperation is crucial in order to avoid human rights abuses in third countries. Unfortunately, human rights violations are still being committed in third countries, due, inter alia, to the management decisions of certain EU companies and businesses, as well as to individuals, non-state actors and states. The report reminds corporate actors that they must respect human rights in their global activities, regardless of where users live and whether the host Member State complies with its own human rights obligations. It is therefore necessary to act continuously, effectively and uniformly at all levels, including at national, European and international level, in order to address immediately the human rights abuses committed by international companies and to effectively address the legal problems and uncertainties arising from the extraterrestrial dimension of companies and their behaviour. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, which reminds corporate actors of their responsibility to respect human rights during their own global operations, regardless of where their users are located and regardless of whether the host state fulfils its own human rights obligations. Like other European parliamentarians, I am deeply concerned about cases of human rights violations committed in third countries, including some EU corporations and businesses.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I am very concerned about the living conditions in the third world. However, I denounce the hypocrisy of the European institutions, which pretend to discover the problem of human rights abuses by obscuring the fact that the free trade they have helped to generalise is the main cause. Our companies are not responsible for this. Therefore, I vote against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on corporate liability for serious human rights abuses in third countries because I believe both states and companies play an important role in ensuring the protection of human rights. Therefore, this resolution commits the Parliament to pushing the EU, the Member States and third countries to adopt binding instruments devoted to the effective protection of human rights.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is now an urgent need for the EU to take continued action in the promotion and protection of human rights, so that it is effective and coherent at all levels, both at national, European and international level, to effectively address human rights violations by international societies as they occur and to address the legal problems arising from the extratertorial dimensions of societies and their behaviour , as well as the relative uncertainty regarding the allocation of responsibility for human rights violations. Globalisation, the internationalisation of trade and production, together with the creation of new jobs, cannot be an excuse for keeping quiet about the living conditions of the inhabitants of third countries. If Europe is to continue to be the world leader in the defence of individual rights, it must also continue its efforts to raise awareness of its businesses and to protect rights through partnership agreements and its global political influence.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report commits the responsibility of companies in EU Member States for human rights violations in third countries. It is true that it is scandalous that large groups in the Member States are resorting to unscrupulous human rights subcontractors. It is indeed their duty to ensure that all stakeholders, especially their suppliers, comply with the labour laws in force in the country of production. While we have been denouncing this modern slavery for many years, we do not absone the European Union of any responsibility for human rights violations in third countries. By multiplying free trade treaties and tariff concessions with countries that practice social and environmental dumping, the European Union is encouraging our companies that are subject to unfair international competition to relocate their activities to those states. The result is downward harmonisation of social protection systems and working conditions for employees. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are a number of binding acts aimed at businesses that provide for respect for fundamental sets of values in the field of human rights, but also in terms of labour standards. In the context that the intensification of the globalisation of commercial activities will lead to an expansion of the role played by corporations in ensuring respect for human rights, new regulations are needed to protect the rights of employees in third countries.  A number of human rights violations have been reported in third countries, which is why it is necessary to update the legal framework and improve existing regulations in order to prevent and punish cases of serious human rights violations.  I was in favour of this report because I consider it essential to take immediate action to find effective solutions to abuses committed by international corporations in relation to human rights.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the end of the economic crisis, the corporate sector has increasingly expanded to meet new demands, resulting in increased demand for labour, including for workers from countries outside the European Union. Unlike posted workers from EU Member States, those from third countries do not benefit from the provisions of the current labour legislation. This creates confusion as to both the rights of these persons and the obligations of their employers.  I support the EP motion for a resolution on the report on 'responsibility of enterprises for serious human rights violations in third countries'. Mandatory instruments are needed for the effective protection of human rights in this area and to ensure that all national and international obligations arising from the international rules referred to in that report are fully respected. Posted citizens from third countries must enjoy the same rights and conditions. I call for the adoption of the UN guiding principles, noting that these guiding principles were unanimously approved by the UN, with the full support of the EU Member States.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on corporate liability for serious human rights violations in third countries. The exploitation of labour is an issue that involves the responsibilities of governments but also of companies, which are often guilty of very serious violations of workers' rights. In many countries outside Europe there are still very serious situations of labour exploitation, including child exploitation, with restrictions on freedom of expression and assembly. In many cases, even workers are victims of physical violence and threats. The business community in third countries must respect human rights in all forms and the Union must be able to establish a trade and investment policy with third countries that is also based on ethical values and not just on the market.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this very good report that focuses on making corporations which are in any way connected to the EU more socially responsible. Positive aspects include support for the mandatory labelling of conflict-related goods, national responsibility for corporate activity in third countries, national responsibility to rectify or remedy human rights violations in their territory, an acknowledgement of the differences facing SMEs and multinational corporations, restrictions on dual use products and a consistent recognition of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. This report is an unnecessary duplication of efforts already undertaken by the UN, who have already agreed on guiding principles on the matter, unanimously agreed by all members. There are calls within the report for the creation of more EU legislation. We are supportive of the overall objectives in improving human rights, but believe that the EU is an unnecessary duplication.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I recognise the major importance of corporate responsibility to ensure that there are no human rights abuses when conducting operations in third countries. I believe that transparency and communication regarding measures taken to avoid human rights abuses in third countries are important in order to allow proper democratic oversight. It is important, though, that policies address company size and their coping mechanisms together with those companies dealing in raw materials from conflict-affected areas.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through this report, my colleague Ignazio Corrao wanted to ensure that Europe and the Member States act urgently, continuously and effectively at all levels, in order to address the legal problems arising from the extraterrestrial dimensions of societies and their behaviour, as well as the relative uncertainty regarding the allocation of responsibilities for human rights violations. In particular, the report calls on the Member States to lay down clear requirements regarding the need for companies domiciled in their territory and/or jurisdiction to respect human rights in all their operations and in every country and context in which they operate. It also calls for the introduction of rules reaffirming the duty of companies to respect human rights and the practical sanctioning of their violation. Thanks to this report, the 5-Star Movement lays the foundations for the removal of the causes that cause uncontrolled migratory flows. I was certainly in favour of it.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and reiterate the urgent need for action in a continuous, effective and coherent manner at all levels, including at national, European and international level, to effectively address human rights violations by companies.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries is a continuation of the European Union's effort to protect human rights. Recognition of corporate responsibilities in third countries is an important step towards further protection of citizens and, for this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. 12012 Vote to abstain for this report which, while pursuing sound objectives on the protection of the rights of workers operating in third countries, appears in all the actions to be taken too centralised at European Commission level.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a European and as an Italian, I express my support for the resolution, since not only respect for human dignity is one of the founding principles of the EU, but also because of my profound agreement with what is set out in Article 41 of our Constitution, namely that the economic initiative "will no longer take place in contravenous of social utility or in such a way as to harm security. , to freedom, to human dignity". Secondly, our companies do not only produce or export goods, because they export the same European ideals in their operations: products are accompanied by an intrinsic Community cultural baggage. As a result, European economic actors have a moral duty to respect human rights in their operations in third countries in order to free them from the exploitation of labour or resources. It should not be forgotten that an economic activity can only be successful by respecting and including those who participate in it, so ethical commitment is part of the value chain by proposing the use of new competitive paths and levers consistent with sustainable development for the community. It is therefore necessary to adopt guidelines on transparency and measures as soon as possible in order to prevent the violation of human rights in third countries.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on corporate liability for serious human rights abuses in third countries and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Safeguarding the fundamental rights of workers or all those who are somehow involved in the production chain is an obligation of the Union and all its Member States, whether within the EU or outside it. At international level, I welcome the adoption of the UN Guiding Principles, but I highlight the importance of the work for the conclusion of a binding UN Treaty on Business and Human Rights. The EU has a key role to play in this context, such as including concerns about this issue in its trade agreements. I understand the instruments based on Corporate Social Responsibility (CMR) as a way of defending human rights in third countries, so I support them to be strengthened and take into account the specificity of small and medium-sized enterprises. We should seek greater effectiveness and not an overload of bureaucratic standards. I advocate that responsibility is not only legal, but also moral, and I therefore advocate the existence of effective redress proceedings in the event of human rights violations in third countries by European companies. I welcome the concern with the labelling of 'conflict minerals'. I support this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I believe that companies now play a central and increasingly increasing role in ensuring respect for human rights, as trade agreements themselves can also help to strengthen human rights provisions. It is important that companies, both European and non-European, exercise due diligence on human rights and then integrate their results with internal policies and procedures, also giving adequate resources to ensure their implementation. Transparency and communication on measures taken to prevent human rights violations in third countries are essential to ensure proper control and to enable consumers to make increasingly informed choices.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because the text recognises corporate responsibility and expresses concern about human rights violations committed in third countries, and calls for continued, effective and coherent action at all levels, including at national, European and international levels, in order to effectively combat human rights violations committed by international companies. It also explicitly calls on businesses, European and non-European, on their duty to respect human rights, and appeals to the Union and the Member States on their duty to guarantee and protect human rights. It precisely requires the Union, the Member States, third countries and all national and international authorities to adopt, as urgently and as widely as possible, binding instruments for the effective protection of human rights, and I voted in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The increasing globalization and internationalisation of business activities and supply chains has made the role played by companies in ensuring respect for human rights more important. Companies are obliged to accept, support and implement, within their sphere of influence, a set of fundamental values in the areas of human rights, labour standards, the environment and the fight against corruption, committing themselves to these principles and integrating them into their business activities on a voluntary basis. I welcomed this resolution because I believe that the spontaneous and non-binding commitment of companies is not sufficient in itself and needs to be accompanied by binding and enforceable rules aimed at preventing human rights violations in third countries. From this point of view, I believe that the intelligent mix of regulatory instruments and voluntary actions makes it possible to structure continuous, effective and coherent action at all national, European and international levels, in order to effectively address human rights violations by international societies and to overcome the legal problems arising from the extraterrestrial dimensions of societies.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, as well as the rights of individuals. The intensification of the phenomenon of internationalisation of commercial activities has increased the importance of the role of corporations in ensuring and respecting human rights. States and undertakings have different but complementary roles in the protection of these rights.  I voted for the urgent adoption of binding instruments on the effective protection of human rights and the full assurance of all national and international obligations. Cooperation with international partners, in order to ensure, by legislative, judicial, administrative or other appropriate means, victims access to an effective remedy is necessary.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I have decided to abstain on the report on corporate liability for serious human rights violations in third countries. Of course, I agree that respect for human rights should be of major value to all Member States. The report aims to encourage Member States to ensure that rights such as human rights, labour and environmental standards and the fight against corruption by businesses are respected. However, I feel that the report raises issues that go beyond the content of the report. I therefore abstained.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it calls on the corporate actors to respect human rights throughout their global operations, regardless of where their users are located and independently of whether the host state meets its own human rights obligations. We need to address all types of human rights abuses in third countries. I fully support the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and their worldwide implementation. Each and every single life must be protected and not subject to a business enterprise management decision.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. The promotion and implementation of human rights is not a duty that is solely the responsibility of public institutions. The private sector is also the ambassador of European Union values abroad. It is therefore important for us Europeans to ensure that our companies respect the universal values of human rights regardless of where they operate. I consider that the principle of corporate social responsibility, which requires companies to voluntarily take measures to ensure respect for human rights abroad, establishes a solid foundation for corporate moral practices and I encourage its development.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to put an end to cases of human rights violations caused by companies and businesses and to make citizens aware of 'corporate responsibility' not only in the economic sector, but also in the political and legal field. I welcome European trade policies in developing countries that contribute to strengthening the trade system while promoting human rights and environmental protection.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Respect for human rights is a moral and legal obligation that must be imposed on European companies and their managers, regardless of where they operate, the size of the company or its sector of activity. In the event of non-compliance, victims from third countries must be guaranteed legal, administrative or legislative remedies. Future trade agreements with third countries should also include a passage reminding companies of their social obligations.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU is trying to use the issue of corporate responsibility to extend its power. Although the subject is sensitive, it must be kept in mind that the free trade that Europe imposes on Member States as well as third countries has had more negative consequences in terms of human and social rights than the policies of the firms of our States. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Human rights violations in third countries are a very important issue, but companies are not responsible. The few cases where there are indeed violations with corporate responsibility are always done with the tolerance of corrupt state or local authorities and, in most cases, the companies associated with such practices are multinationals. Small and medium-sized enterprises importing products from other countries cannot be called upon to take responsibility through procedures which, in many cases, are done remotely. If the Union wants to combat human rights violations in third countries, it can stop encouraging funding of repressive and criminal regimes, such as those of Turkey, the occupied countries of Cyprus, Saudi Arabia and Swaziland.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 An identification label indicating respect for human rights throughout a product production chain is one of the proposals included in the European Parliament's own-initiative report on corporate liability for serious human rights violations in third countries.  The European Union assumes itself as a defender of human rights and legislation requiring European companies to respect human rights abroad would send a strong message to the world.  The report is based on the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, focusing on respect for human rights in all production, distribution and exploitation of natural resources in third countries, especially in developing countries.  I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: the free trade that Europe imposes on Member States as well as third countries has had more negative consequences in terms of human rights (the reappearance of slavery) and social rights than the policies of the firms of our States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses one of the problems that currently marks the crisis of capitalism and the crisis in and of the European Union: the humanitarian crisis and gross violations of rights on European territory. With several positive points, the report shows shortcomings and is compromised by a set of negative references that the right and social democracy would impose, even if not to the extent they would like. The result of the vote is that expression. The causes of the problems and the direct and indirect responsibilities at their origin are omitted. The EU, with the US and NATO, is responsible for destabilising the entire Middle East and North Africa, feeding extremist groups, which they now say are fighting in the name of fighting terrorism.  It is very critical of Fortress Europe, while deanagging that it is necessary to strengthen the security and management of borders, in particular frontex. It welcomes the EURONAVFOR MED mission and its role in combating trafficking in migrants and calls for these missions to be strengthened. An analysis from which we are vehemently distancing ourselves, so the reality it portrays has of criminal, imbued with the security vision of the EU.  The positive elements contained therein, as well as their origin, justify an abstention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Human rights violations in third countries are a very important issue but companies are not responsible. The few cases where there are indeed violations with corporate responsibility are always done with the tolerance of corrupt state or local authorities and in most cases companies associated with such practices are multinational. Small and medium-sized enterprises importing products from other countries cannot be called upon to take responsibility through procedures which are in many cases done remotely. If the Union wants to combat human rights violations in third countries, it can stop encouraging funding of repressive and criminal regimes, such as those of Turkey, the occupied countries of Cyprus, Saudi Arabia and Swaziland. That is why I am voting against the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report reminds corporate actors of their responsibility to respect human rights throughout their global operations, regardless of where their users are located and independently of whether the host state meets its own human rights obligations.  I am deeply concerned by cases of human rights violations committed in third countries, including as a result of some EU corporations and business enterprises management decisions. In this report, we strongly reiterate our support for the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs) and their worldwide implementation and call for ‘companies, whether European or not, to carry out human rights due diligence’ as well as for the allocation of sufficient resources for this purpose.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, considering that the Union is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, and that its action on the international stage (including its trade policy) must be based on these principles. The violation of human rights by some companies is a global problem, even though all companies in the world have an obligation to respect human rights, just as the European institutions have as their main obligation to regulate the responsibility of companies that have connections with the Union. From the union institutions we must act continuously, effectively and coherently at all levels, in order to effectively combat human rights violations committed by companies, since they occur, and to address the legal problems arising from the extraterritorial dimension of businesses and their management.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The globalization of the market and the internationalisation of economic activities, generates a number of concerns about the responsibility of companies in cases of serious human rights violations in third countries. We want Europe to be a driving force and an example in the protection of human rights and to be vigilant and ready to take action, including with sanctions, if abuses or infringements are found. My support for Mr Corrao's report is therefore full and convinced.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries because with it the EP wanted to remind entrepreneurs of their responsibilities for respect for human rights in their actions at global level, regardless of where their business activities are located. The Un Global Compact states that companies are obliged to accept, support and implement, within their sphere of influence, a set of fundamental values in the areas of human rights, labour standards, the environment and the fight against corruption, and are required to implement these principles by integrating them into their commercial activities. That is why I strongly supported the call for the Commission to present a legislative proposal shortly on the control of exports of dual-use products, as technologies created by companies continue to cause human rights violations throughout the world. As well as the call for the EU and the Member States to establish clear rules under which companies established on their territory or jurisdiction respect human rights in all their operations and in each country.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As my group's responsible rapporteur, I abstained from voting on the 'Report on the responsibility of companies for serious human rights violations in third countries'. In principle, I strongly support the proposal for greater global corporate social responsibility. However, I cannot follow the report in all respects and consider some of the measures proposed to be ineffective.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. In a global world, European companies need to step up their due diligence obligations to workers in third countries. This is the guiding principle of the United Nations and the face-to-face of human rights violations against workers in third countries. Such an action against human rights violations against workers in third countries can be successfully confirmed by international trade agreements implementing international standards.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the protection of human rights, a priority that has always been a priority in the history of the EU, cannot in any way be subordinated to other objectives. That is why we are calling for it to be respected by third countries, we want to prevent european companies from having their own companies that are in favour of human rights violations. The concept of corporate social responsibility has been painstakingly developed worldwide, but it remains to be seen even better at national and European legislative level, with particular reference to SMEs, which are so essential to the economic fabric of our countries. I therefore voted in favour of the text we are also debating because it calls for due account to be taken of globalisation and the need for internationalisation of companies, which are in themselves positive if properly framed with a view to increasing world trade and respecting human rights. The latter cannot in any way suffer from the transactional dimension of a well-known case study, and it is therefore correct and necessary that we call on the Commission today to establish minimum standards for the definition of crimes and related sanctions in this area.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report claims to want to hold multinationals accountable for respect for human rights in third countries. Again, there is an obvious cynicism, since free trade and therefore the relocation of production to countries with low labour costs and lower social demands are greatly encouraged by European policies. Because it is out of the question that such a report should serve as a moral guarantor for a system that is intrinsically violating human rights, I voted against this report.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Everyone remembers the excitement of the 2013 collapse of Rana Plaza in Bangladesh, killing more than a thousand textile factory workers working for European brands. Companies, with little regard for the working and wage conditions of their subcontractors, such as the Bangladeshi authorities, using weak regulations to attract foreign investment, are certainly responsible. We also think of mining or massive deforestation, which destroys ecosystems but also lifestyles. But the root cause of such situations is savage globalization, the frantic race for profitability and at the lowest cost. Companies sometimes cynically play with the rules of a system that you support and want to develop by multiplying trade agreements. Rural exodus fuelling modern slavery with small underpaid hands there, mass unemployment and impoverishment here. The economic and social violence imposed on people by your forced free trade is terrifying. Of course, calling for corporate responsibility is in tune with the times. But if we don't change the rules of the game, all this will be a shad.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour, not without acknowledging that it should have gone much further in promoting binding instruments for the control and sanction of companies that violate human rights. Existing mechanisms today are based on willfulness and are not sufficient. It is therefore essential to move towards a joint responsibility of parent companies throughout the value chain; it is necessary to ensure coherence in Union policies and not to sign trade treaties containing opaque and para-judicial mechanisms for resolving investor-State disputes. We miss a greater reference to the responsibility of financial institutions, which support transnationals and the need to specifically address the right to access to justice of the most vulnerable. We should also, as we proposed in amendments, promote the establishment of a Union agency for the supervision of the activity of transnational corporations in third countries, and sanction procedures in the event of crimes, in order to put the protection of human and environmental rights at the centre of Union action, without the business benefits.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it reminds corporate actors of their responsibility to respect human rights throughout their global operations, regardless of where their users are located and independently of whether the host state meets its own human rights obligations.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. To ensure that whoever sells us a product does not have blood on their hands, that is why I voted for this resolution. I supported this text so that Parliament could be heard around the creation of a voluntary identification label at EU level, attesting to the respect of human rights for products made in third countries. This label must be accompanied by an independent monitoring body governed by strict rules and with inspection powers. The products to which this label has been granted should benefit from special advantages. Together with my colleagues, we call on the European Commission to launch a campaign to promote this label. More generally, the European Union and Member States must set out specific rules that make it clear that companies established on their territory and/or placed under their jurisdiction are obliged to respect human rights in their activities. We need political coherence in business and human rights, particularly with regard to EU trade policy.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Increasing globalisation and internationalisation of business activities and supply chains will make the role that corporations play in ensuring respect for human rights more important and create a situation in which international norms, rules and cooperation are crucial to avoid human rights abuses in third countries. However, I am very concerned by cases of human rights violations committed in third countries, including of some EU corporations and business enterprises management decisions. If companies are found to have caused or contributed to harm, they should take moral but also legal responsibility and must provide effective remedy processes for the individuals and communities affected.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries, because we consider it to be a first step in the right direction. This contains important parameters, which both the Commission and the Member States should follow. In addition, the report highlights the obligations of companies operating abroad and should respect human rights in all their activities. Despite our positive attitude, we are opposed to the fact that the report lacks any criticism of the very trade agreements concluded by the EU, which, in many cases by their very nature, violate basic human rights.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Migration is a global, multidimensional, multifaceted and cross-cutting phenomenon caused by a wide variety of factors, such as economic conditions (including changes in wealth distribution and regional and global economic integration), social and political conditions, labour conditions, violence and security conditions, as well as the gradual degradation of the environment and the growing virulence of natural disasters. The Union must adopt specific guidelines on the rights of migrants to complement its guidelines on human rights. There should be advocated close cooperation, to defend migrants’ rights, with the appropriate international organisations and other institutions. These measures are essential now, more than ever as a result of the migrant crisis throughout Europe.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Human rights are an important asset that all European institutions, not least the European Parliament, must uphold and protect worldwide. As a Member of the Alliance for Progress and Awakening, I stand by this. However, many of the stated demands in the report miss out on daily practice and thus do not fulfil the desired purpose for a targeted and clear outlawing of human rights violations in third countries. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Corporate Responsibility Report for serious human rights violations in third countries, because corporations are one of the main players in economic globalization, financial services and international trade and are obliged to respect all applicable laws and international agreements in force, and above all to respect human rights.  Trade and human rights can support each other, and the business community can also play an important stimulating role in promoting human rights, democracy, environmental standards and responsible business. The EU plays a leading role in negotiating and implementing a number of initiatives for global accountability, and these initiatives are closely linked to promoting and respecting international standards.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. It seems to me that the free trade policy imposed by the European Union on its Member States is far more detrimental to human rights than the policy pursued by our companies. The EU should not use this pretext to increase its grip on these same companies. I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Corporations, as major players in economic globalisation, financial services and international trade, have a moral duty and a legal obligation to respect human rights. Clauses on corporate liability for human rights violations should be included in EU trade and investment agreements. This is part of EU action to ensure effective protection of human rights also in the context of business activity. An independent body should verify and certify that no abuse has occurred at any stage of the production chain and consequently certify the product by so called ‘abuse-free’ label, an important one for the reputation of our companies. I see this report as a positive step towards a new way of approaching the exploitation of resources all over the world, especially in developing countries.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ignazio Corrao's report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. I wanted to support this initiative, which highlights the voluntary commitment of companies to the establishment of social responsibility in line with the guiding principles of the United Nations. The report also addresses the important issue of establishing a duty of care for companies using raw materials from conflict zones.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to protect the citizens of any country from human right abuses, even more when the initiator is a company. As the European Union we have tried to always get better with regard to respect for human rights. Corporate liability should be considered as the bare minimum for such occasions and this report moves to the right direction.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it reminds corporate actors of their responsibility to respect human rights throughout their global operations, regardless of where their users are located and independently of whether the host state meets its own human rights obligations.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. Human rights are an important asset that all European institutions, not least the European Parliament, must uphold and protect worldwide. As a Member of the Alliance for Progress and Awakening, I stand by this. However, many of the stated demands in the report miss out on daily practice and thus do not fulfil the desired purpose for a targeted and clear outlawing of human rights violations in third countries. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries, I voted in favour. The issue of respect for human rights has long been a theme that I am trying to promote, and this report is no exception. Moreover, I have been working for a long time on the issue of the liability of multinational corporations and I am also dealing with the problems that this causes in third countries. Violations of human rights by multinational supranational companies are a very common phenomenon and legislation aimed at limiting this behaviour is very welcome even among most of my colleagues. First and foremost, we must ensure that human rights violations do not occur on the territory of EU states, but we must not forget the global scope of multinational corporations and continue our efforts to constantly develop this issue.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – If we look far away, 1 500 people have died in 3 mass accidents in light industry in Bangladesh, largely in relation to inhumane employment conditions. If I appreciate the situation in my narrowest environment, it is astonishing that, in the context of the colonial-Devecseri red sludge tragedy, which has killed 10 people and left hundreds dead in the heart of Europe, no one has been held accountable to date and financial compensation is faltering, even though it has been six years since.  The report is clearly well-intentioned and forward-looking, offering solutions for certain cases and should therefore be supported. Much tougher means should be used to counter the all-out profit-making, but that's a different story.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. This report promotes the adoption of un guiding principles and supports their implementation globally. I believe that it is important for companies to implement the UN Guiding Principles, including through the establishment of due diligence policies and risk management safeguards, as well as by providing effective remedies where their activities have led to or contributed to adverse effects on human rights. I believe that member states need to adopt a coherent, comprehensive, effective and binding approach in their legislative work so as to fulfil their obligation to prevent, investigate and penalise human rights violations committed by corporations under their jurisdiction, including those committed in third countries, and to compensate victims.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution. There are reports that stress that transnational corporations and other business enterprises may at times cause or contribute to human rights violations in third countries, particularly affecting vulnerable groups such as minorities, indigenous people, women and children. Unfortunately, nowadays human rights violations by corporations are a worldwide concern. It is important to note that many transnational corporations, whether European or not, operating in third countries, have substantial business operations in Europe and/or may be owned by European corporations, have assets or goods in Europe, or control other corporations in Europe, or receive investments or use the financial services of institutions in Europe.  In this context, the EU and the Member States should lay down clear rules setting out that companies established in their territory or under their jurisdiction must respect human rights throughout their operations, in every country and context in which they operate, and in relation to their business relationships, including outside the EU. Thus, in this manner, the EU will have a leading role in setting up of clear liability standards for corporate involvement in human rights abuses.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union was founded on respect for human rights, human dignity, freedom and democracy, and as such we must ensure that these values are respected in all areas of citizens' lives. In this particular case, it is essential to remember that companies have an obligation to respect a set of fundamental values in the areas of human rights, labour standards, respect for the environment, the fight against corruption and social responsibility. Sometimes, however, we see some violations of these duties. Parliament's proposal therefore underlines the increasingly important role of companies in ensuring respect for human rights and the implementation of international standards, and recognises the importance of the concept of corporate social responsibility, welcoming the continued growth of implementations based on voluntary business engagement. It also reiterates the implementation by Member States of the UN guiding principles on economic activities and human rights and calls for greater attention to be paid to those companies that use raw materials that come from conflict zones. In the light of the above, I am voting in favour of the report on corporate responsibilities for serious human rights violations in third countries.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report entitled 'Corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries'. The aim is for the European Union to use the theme of corporate responsibility to extend its power over the policies of French and European firms. The free trade that the European Union imposes on Member States as well as third countries has had more negative consequences in terms of human and social rights than the policy of European firms.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report tends to use the theme of corporate responsibility to extend its power over the policy of our companies. The free trade imposed by the EU on Member States and non-member states having a strong negative impact on our businesses and our jobs, I objected to this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it addresses the necessary responsibility of companies for respect for human rights in their international activities, regardless of the level of compliance with those rights by the governments of the third countries where they are present.  There is no binding regime that responds to the defencelessness that occurs most of the time when a company is involved in serious human rights violations. The globalization of economic activities makes it increasingly necessary to establish common standards and standards at the international level. The report therefore calls on companies to make greater efforts in the implementation of human rights due diligence as well as greater transparency in their activities. While calling on the Member States and the Union for greater coherence, and the development and effective implementation of international commitments in this area.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because the text recognises corporate responsibility and expresses concern about human rights violations committed in third countries, and calls for continued, effective and coherent action at all levels, also at national, European and international levels, in order to effectively combat human rights violations committed by international companies.  It also explicitly calls on businesses, European and non-European, on their duty to respect human rights, and appeals to the Union and the Member States on their duty to guarantee and protect human rights. It precisely requires the Union, the Member States, third countries and all national and international authorities to adopt, as urgently and as widely as possible, binding instruments for the effective protection of human rights, and I voted in favour.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This resolution on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries recalls the principles on which the Union is based, including respect for human dignity and respect for human rights, and that its international staging must be based on these principles. In this regard, it should be noted that the Union has played an essential role in the negotiation and implementation of a number of globally respected initiatives aimed at promoting and respecting international human rights standards. But in the face of the challenge of globalization and internationalisation of business activities and supply chains, rapid technological progress and the multitude of obstacles to accessing judicial recourse routes faced by victims of human rights violations involving international companies, the Union must act on an ongoing basis , effective and consistent. I give my favourable vote as some of the measures aimed at, such as legislating at the national level, providing that companies established in that territory must respect human rights in their operations, can help to pursue the objective of ensuring human rights.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. Human rights are an important asset that all European institutions, not least the European Parliament, must uphold and protect worldwide. As a Member of the Alliance for Progress and Awakening, I stand by this. However, many of the stated demands in the report miss out on daily practice and thus do not fulfil the desired purpose for a targeted and clear outlawing of human rights violations in third countries. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which  acknowledges the contribution of corporations in ensuring international norms and upholding human rights.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The resolution "calls on the EU and the Member States to lay down clear rules that companies located in or under their jurisdiction must respect human rights in all countries and in any context in which they operate." EU Member States cannot be responsible for something they have no chance of detecting or influencing. States where companies operate must be responsible for complying with laws and human rights, not the countries where companies come from. Furthermore, the resolution 'calls on the Commission to present without delay a legislative proposal to control exported dual-use items, as technologies produced by European companies still cause human rights violations worldwide'. I do not agree with such restrictions on exports. A company that exports cameras or microphones cannot be held responsible for whether such goods are misused by the government of a third country for violations of human rights to privacy.
