Furthermore, the resolution 'urges the Commission to launch an EU-wide campaign to present and promote the 'abuse-free' label and to appeal to European consumers to vote for the products and companies that have received the label'. I do not agree with the EU doing any campaign promoting information labels on goods with taxpayers' money.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament reaffirmed the urgent need to act in a continuous, effective and coherent manner at all levels, including national, European and international, in order to effectively address human rights abuses by international corporations when they appear. I welcome the Commission’s active cooperation with the participation of Parliament and the Council together with other international bodies to achieve a fundamental convergence of CSR initiatives in the long term and the exchange and promotion of good corporate practice regarding CSR.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 October 2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text develops several positive aspects, including the fight against modern slavery in developing countries. On the other hand, it aims to extend the EU's power over European businesses. To achieve this objective, the European Parliament is using a pretext, that of the need to increase the level of corporate responsibility in respecting human rights in third countries, which we oppose.  Finally, we must not forget that the free trade imposed by the EU on Member States and third countries, by not allowing any form of protectionism, has more negative consequences in terms of human and social rights than the policies of the firms of our States.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Globalization and internationalization of business activities and supply chains make businesses play a key role in ensuring respect for human rights.  I therefore support the proposal to prevent violations in this area in third countries, emphasizing the importance of corporate social responsibility, taking into account the specific needs of SMEs.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. In a globalized economic environment, where the international division of labour has taken hold, goods go through several stages of manufacturing, in so-called 'global value chains'. This complexity translates into looser public control, which can only be resolved by greater accountability of the actors involved. In this context, the Corrao report, which I supported, rightly underlines the responsibility of some companies for human rights violations in third countries. To this, the text again opposes the concept of the 'duty of vigilance'. If corporate social responsibility is to become legally binding (for example, by being systematically included in the text of trade agreements), at the other end of the chain, information from end consumers is just as crucial. Thus, as the report proposes, I am a strong supporter of more accurate labelling of consumer products, via 'no maltreatment' labels or, conversely, labels indicating the origin of products from a 'conflict zone'. In today's information society, it is perfectly legitimate to advocate better traceability.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries and I confirm the urgent need for action in a continuous, effective and coherent manner at all levels, including at national, European and international level, to effectively address human rights violations by companies. Furthermore, I call on companies, European or not, to implement due diligence on human rights and to incorporate the relevant findings into their internal policies and procedures, with the appropriate allocation of resources and delegation of powers with due implementation.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report seeks to make companies more accountable for respect for human rights.  The violation of human rights should be easier to enforce in court and the possibilities for sanctions for companies should be tightened up. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I welcome this report, which calls on states to actively participate in the work of the United Nations in favour of an international treaty that requires multinationals to respect human rights. I have just returned from Geneva, where the second meeting of the working group on this treaty is currently taking place. I deplore the vote of the European Union at the time of the decision to form this working group. I denounce the devious obstruction by the European Union, with a laughable request to include 'all companies' coming from an entity that itself forbids social harmonisation. The report highlights the responsibility of states to enforce international standards by European companies, including when operating in third countries. Finally, it insists on legal remedies for victims of these violations or the associations defending them, also considering the "personal criminal responsibility" of a CEO. I regret, however, that the report does not call for the establishment of an international tribunal under UN jurisdiction to try these violations of human rights and ecological crimes, as I myself have defended before the United Nations. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report tends to use the theme of corporate responsibility to extend its power over the policy of our companies. The free trade imposed by the EU on Member States and non-member states having a strong negative impact on our businesses and our jobs, I objected to this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, and its action on the international scene (including trade policy) 'is based on [these] principles'.  Companies are one of the main players in economic globalisation, financial services and international trade, and they are required to respect all applicable legislation and existing international treaties and respect for human rights.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it acknowledges that corporations must play a leading role in protecting human rights due to the nature of international trade and global supply chains. The report notes the importance of the adoption of the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights whilst calling for corporations to carry out regular due diligence to flag any possible human rights abuses within their operations.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. I have adopted this report because it is in line with the previous initiatives I have taken in Parliament on the need to establish mandatory due diligence requirements and a regulatory framework for the extraction and supply chains of so-called conflict minerals and treasures from high-risk areas. This report makes recommendations to effectively achieve corporate social responsibility in a globalising economy, and in so doing it is in line with my ambition that human rights violations by companies are effectively and coherently prevented and prevented. In this context, progress must be made on the work of a binding UN Convention on Business and Human Rights. It is also recommended that the EU, its Member States and other countries apply enforceable trade rules for international companies in the event of human rights violations. Companies that today conduct all their business activities according to the principles of corporate social responsibility not only gain in social importance, but also strengthen the trust of their customers and of the consumer.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union is based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights and its international actions (including trade policy) are guided by these principles. At the same time, the draft resolution of the Committee on Foreign Affairs points out that businesses, including businesses within the European Union, sometimes cause or contribute to human rights abuses and have an impact on the rights of vulnerable groups such as minorities, indigenous peoples, women and children and contribute to environmental problems. It therefore draws attention to the obligations of companies, Member States and the Commission in the field of the protection of human rights and urges them to take the necessary steps to protect human rights.  I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The free trade that Europe imposes on Member States as well as third countries has very negative consequences for human rights (the reappearance of slavery in a modern form) and social. These issues of unbearable violation of human rights, however, must be resolved by States, the only legitimate actors; and this report therefore constitutes an infringement on their sovereignty. That is why I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which reminds corporate actors of their responsibility to respect human rights throughout their global operations, regardless of where their users are located and independently of whether the host state meets its own human rights obligations.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. The resolution reminds multinational companies of their moral and legal duty to ensure respect for human rights in the context of their activities in countries outside the European Union, but also the duty of Member States to enforce this obligation.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Combining economic needs with those of giving jobs to businesses and promoting employment are priorities of our policy choices. At the same time, it is a moral duty to put in place the protection and promotion of human rights in the workplace as well. That is why I welcomed the proposal for greater accountability of companies to protect human rights in third countries, in particular the rights of vulnerable groups, such as minorities, women and children. The protection of human dignity must, in fact, be essential throughout the production and distribution chain, both in Europe and in countries where European companies extend their activities, and the European institutions, within the framework of their competences, must act to ensure that it is respected. The proposal for an abuse free label for producers who guarantee these rights can be an incentive for the consumer who, by choosing, wants to be confirmed that there is this type of commitment. Corporate social responsibility must, however, be accompanied by clear choices by the political institutions, which must act by coordinating the needs of the productive sectors with the different realities of the Member States, so that human rights are in any case safeguarded.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, it is not only in third countries that we are witnessing serious human rights abuses by companies, we are also witnessing a large number of cases within the EU, but I welcome and support the report, because I believe that a human rights-based approach by large companies in third countries can help to reduce these violations. We must take measures that, for example, prevent and eradicate trafficking in human beings and trafficking in human beings, as these crimes cause serious harm and profoundly violate the human rights of victims.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution that calls on corporations, following the globalisation of business activities and supply chains, to ensure respect for human rights and create a situation where international norms, rules and cooperation are crucial in order to avoid cases of human rights abuses in third countries.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries, which is based on the finding that some human rights violations are caused by the behaviour of companies. It is therefore appropriate to call on the EU and the Member States to lay down clear rules that companies located in or under their jurisdiction must respect human rights in all countries and in any context in which they operate and in relation to their business relationships, including those outside the EU.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because there is nothing to prevent a possible improvement in the global human rights situation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Respect and guarantee of human rights is basic and also mandatory for businesses both in Europe and in third countries. Unfortunately, that is not the case. The report provides for various recommendations to improve the situation for both The Member States and the Commission, including the adoption of legislation, indication of the origin and method of manufacture of products, the imposition of a minimum penalty, access to legal aid, etc.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted. It is necessary to strengthen the liability of companies for serious human rights violations in third countries. Particular attention must be paid to the implementation of the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights worldwide. It is also essential that each Member State properly fulfils its duty to respect and defend human rights. Attention must be paid to the importance of corporate social responsibility. Companies should assume not only moral but also legal responsibility and properly implement restitution, compensation, rehabilitation and guarantee that the damage will not happen again. The Commission should also take urgent action to establish binding rules and mechanisms for the application and monitoring of sanctions. Every trade and investment agreement must be assessed in the light of its impact on human rights. In addition, these agreements must include provisions on human rights and guarantees to mitigate potential threats and negative consequences.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Companies are among the most important players in economic globalisation, financial services and international trade. They must therefore respect all applicable and applicable legislation and all applicable and applicable treaties and respect human rights, bearing in mind that trade and human rights are mutually reinforcing. Given that the business community is obliged to respect human rights, it may also have an important role to play in providing positive incentives to promote human rights, democracy, environmental standards and corporate responsibility. Businesses are invited to embrace, support and implement, within their sphere of influence, a set of fundamental values in terms of human rights, labour standards, the environment, the fight against corruption, and to commit themselves to respecting these values.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report entrusts the companies themselves with the responsibility of protecting human rights in their activities, within the framework of corporate social responsibility, in short, 'puts the wolf in the guard of sheep'. It cultivates the perception that most enterprises are 'good' and do not infringe human rights and, therefore, as a matter of priority, voluntary 'self-regulation' procedures are proposed for enterprises, by setting up mechanisms for so-called 'risk assessment', etc. Proposals to introduce and promote the "no violations" brand ensure additional free advertising on their products and new privileges. It is hidden that, at the same time, these companies will continue to take advantage of the wealth that workers generate for their own profitability and that this exploitation of workers is 'legitimate' for the EU and the urban governments serving their monopolies and interests. For this reason, the people must overthrow them in order to defend their most fundamental right, which is to live without being exploited, without stealing their toil, with their own power and economy, by leaving the EU.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. This report is an unnecessary duplication of efforts already undertaken by the UN, who have already agreed on guiding principles on the matter, unanimously agreed by all members. There are calls within the report for the creation of more EU legislation. We are supportive of the overall objectives in improving human rights, but believe that the EU is an unnecessary duplication.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the values on which the European Union is founded and its intervention on the international stage is based on these principles, I felt it was right to vote in favour of this proposal. In the international economic landscape, companies are among the main players in economic globalisation and trade and, as a result, they are required to respect all applicable and existing international laws and treaties and human rights. However, companies, in some situations, can sometimes be responsible for or contribute to human rights violations and affect the rights of vulnerable groups. As issues relating to the development and promotion of human rights are of fundamental importance in all EU policies, I believe that action is necessary. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The report highlights the increasing role of corporations in ensuring respect for human rights. It acknowledges that trade agreements can contribute to reinforcing the global rules-based trading system as well as human rights provisions. In this regard it recognises the major importance of corporate social responsibility and welcomes the growing use of instruments based on companies’ self-commitment. For this among other reasons I supported the report.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, as it is necessary to be aware that protecting human rights in the labour market is essential in order to achieve a double benefit - better work efficiency of workers in the work process, but also a sense of self-esteem and dignity of every worker. The European Union is a promoter of the protection of human rights, especially the rights of workers. I think it is important to vigilantly oversee the enforcement and protection of workers' rights, especially in large corporations.  Democratic oversight must exist and a clear legislative framework needs to be established at union and member state level, sanctioning any attempt or identified violation of human rights in corporate activity. The increasing globalisation and internationalisation of business activities and supply chains make it more important for corporations to play a role in ensuring respect for human rights and leads to a situation where international norms, rules and cooperation are crucial to prevent human rights violations in third countries.  A coherent legal system, which includes rules governing access to justice, jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judicial decisions in civil and commercial matters, applicable law and judicial assistance in cross-border situations involving third countries are the only promising direction for future ACTION by the European Union in the field of the protection of human and labour rights.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the guise of better monitoring the respect of human rights by companies in third countries, this is once again a text that seriously undermines the sovereignty of States. If it really wanted to combat abuses of power from multinationals, the EU would have been better off denying private arbitration tribunals in CETA and TAFTA... But that is not his goal because only the weakening of states interests him. This hypocritical use of human rights for unspeakable purposes is unacceptable. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of human rights must be a priority for the European Union and its Member States. And its international role, including trade policy, must be inspired by the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law. In this context, the adoption of the UN guiding principles on economic activities and human rights is therefore to be welcomed as a very positive step forward, and I agree with the call for businesses, European and beyond, to adapt to these principles and ensure their implementation. Businesses are among the main players in economic, financial and commercial globalisation and can therefore play an important role in promoting human rights, democracy and environmental standards. Trade and human rights can, and must, strengthen each other. I hope that Europe and its businesses will really succeed in set a good example and showing others the best way forward, ensuring transparency and accountability, in the interests of workers, consumers and businesses themselves. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Given the serious concerns about cases of human rights violations in third countries, including those resulting from management decisions of some EU corporations and companies, I think it was important to warn about the responsibility of corporations to respect human rights in their global activities, regardless of where their beneficiaries are located, and regardless of whether the host state fulfils its human rights obligations. This expresses the European Parliament's strong support for and implementation of the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.  Companies were invited, whether european or not, to provide due attention to the protection of human rights and to include their conclusions in internal policies and procedures and to allocate resources and powers accordingly and apply them properly. On the other hand, the Commission was also invited to launch an EU-wide campaign introducing and promoting the 'ethic business' label and giving relief to products awarded the 'ethic business' label.  European corporations should set an example for everyone else by implementing the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Addressing a pertinent and fair issue, the report departs from the wrong premise that it is possible to humanize capitalism. It is in the nature of the capitalist system, in its predatory and exploitation aspect, that the root of the problem is. Large companies and multinationals exploit, directly or indirectly, in the name of profit and ably, the natural resources of the peoples of third countries, without any itching of committing the most heinous environmental crimes against the populations, or of inhumanely exploiting workers. It is not surprising that references to the need to increase workers' rights, regulation of workers, better distribution of wealth, or the sovereign role of states in protecting workers, peoples and resources from the exploitation of large monopolistic capital are unnoticed or non-existent. A reference that is also absent, that of the need for trade policies that do not constitute new neocolonial instruments, rather respect the sovereignty of states and are based on an effective mutual benefit between equal parties. We value the references and call for the application of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, as well as the UNITED NATIONS Global Compact, principles to which the practice of EU policies escapes, because their class nature is contrary to it. For the foregoing, abstention.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We have to regularly keep corporate actors reminded of their responsibility to respect human rights throughout their global operations, regardless of where their users are located or whether or not the host state meets its own human rights obligations.  I, along with my colleagues, have repeatedly pointed out cases of human rights violations committed in third countries, including as a result of some EU corporations’ and business enterprises’ management decisions. I strongly support this report that strongly reiterates all MEPs’ support for the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs) and their worldwide implementation and calls for ‘companies, whether European or not, to carry out human rights due diligence’ as well as for the allocation of sufficient resources for this purpose.  Our Group tabled amendments insisting on the responsibility of European enterprises and on the lead by example that European corporates could take by implementing the UNGPs, and I am pleased that the voting went satisfactorily.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to preserve the Leading Role of the European Union in respect for human rights, including those of persons belonging to minorities, I believe it is right to stress the importance of corporate social responsibility. This report strongly emphasises that respect for human rights is a moral duty and a legal obligation of companies and their managers and that it should be integrated into a long-term economic perspective, wherever European companies operate and regardless of their size or industry. Having said that, I welcome the proposal to include human rights responsibilities in binding contractual requirements between companies and their suppliers. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Corrao's report cites the UN Guidelines on Business and Human Rights and the revised OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises, according to which corporations operating in third countries should voluntarily respect values in the areas of human rights, labour standards, the environment and the fight against corruption.  The report recognises that human rights are fundamental values of the EU and its Member States. The main objective of the report is to encourage Member States to apply these rights to undertakings whose owners are located in Member States which are established in member states or which carry out their activities there for a large part. The need to address legal problems and uncertainties as to where responsibility for human rights violations lies is reiterated.  It is also recalled that companies should assume legal responsibility. The EU, The Member States, third countries and all national and international authorities are called upon to adopt, as a matter of urgency and to the fullest extent possible, binding instruments for the effective protection of human rights in this field, and to give priority to the immediate establishment of a human rights due diligence obligation for companies owned or controlled by the State. Unfortunately, these statements are mostly ambiguous. I have hereby abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, which reminds us of the important role that companies can play in ensuring respect for human rights in third countries. As such, international trade and trade agreements can help strengthen fundamental human rights rules. For some, trade would be a permanent danger. In my view, it is an effective foreign policy tool to combine European interests and values. The problem of companies using raw materials from war or conflict zones (gold, tin, tantalum, tungsten for example) is also addressed in this report. In this context, controls on imports of minerals and metals must be strengthened.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. I am concerned about human rights violations committed by companies worldwide, as they are one of the main players in economic globalisation, financial services and international trade, and they must be required to comply with all applicable legislation and existing international treaties.  The business community must not only respect human rights but must also play an important role in offering incentives to promote them, as well as democracy, environmental standards and social responsibility. Because the EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights, and because companies must follow the same values, I support this motion for a resolution.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. This report is an unnecessary duplication of efforts already undertaken by the UN, who have already agreed on guiding principles on the matter, unanimously agreed by all members. There are calls within the report for the creation of more EU legislation. We are supportive of the overall objectives in improving human rights, but believe that the EU is an unnecessary duplication.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of considering that human rights violations committed by companies are a cause for concern worldwide and that all companies in the world have a duty to respect human rights, while the European institutions have a primary duty to regulate the responsibility of companies that have a link with the EU. Unfortunately, human rights violations committed by companies are constant and there is still no comprehensive holistic approach to corporate responsibility for human rights violations.  In turn, the EU has played a leading role in negotiating and implementing a number of global responsibility initiatives, which are combined with promotion and respect for international standards.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012There is still no comprehensive holistic approach to corporate responsibility for human rights violations.  Companies should adopt, support and implement a set of core values on human rights, labour standards, the environment and the fight against corruption, committing themselves to these values and integrating them into their business activities on a voluntary basis.  Companies are the main players of economic globalisation and they are required to comply with all applicable legislation and existing treaties. Trade and human rights can strengthen each other.  European companies operating within the EU and in third countries should set an example when it comes to respect for human rights.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. "U2012 Although some progress has been made in recent years (United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights), there is still no binding regime to respond to the defencelessness in cases of human rights violations by companies. The globalization of economic activities makes it increasingly necessary to establish common rules.  This report addresses the necessary responsibility of companies for respect for human rights in their international activities, regardless of the level of compliance where they are present.  In this regard, we support the Working Group established within the United Nations for the preparation of a future binding International Treaty on Business and Human Rights. We call on the Union for greater coherence and the development and effective implementation of international commitments in this area, and greater efforts by companies in the implementation of human rights due diligence, as well as greater transparency in their activities. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries as globalization and the increasing internationalization of business activities and supply chains increase the role of companies in ensuring respect for human rights. European companies (and others) as well as Member States must jointly ensure that human rights are respected in third countries. In this context, the resolution calls for the adoption of binding instruments to protect these rights.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Committed to the protection of human rights, the European Union cannot ignore the facts that occur when they are violated by European companies in third countries. This not only mentions the very concept of human rights, as if there were two types of people, but also hinders the harmonious development of those countries, only undemocratic regimes can tolerate human rights violations by transnational corporations. I welcome and support the report. I believe that this topic must be educated both in European society and in the world as a whole. The same large corporations cannot be left behind either– in many cases, human rights violations in their branches in third countries are also the result of the lack of social responsibility of the companies themselves and the lack of adequate local regulation.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The increasing globalisation and internationalisation of business activities and supply chains, in addition to making the role played in ensuring respect for labour rights, bring increased responsibilities to respect human rights, and the creation of international standards, rules and cooperation is all the more important. This report proposes measures to respect human rights and to prevent their violation in third countries as a result of possible management decisions of companies, individuals, non-state actors or government entities of the European Union, recalling the responsibilities that these entities have in carrying out their operations. Two of the proposals listed, with which I agree, state that: Trade Agreements are fundamental in strengthening the global trade system, based on values that strive for respect for human dignity; furthermore, that trade must evolve alongside values, as recently mentioned by the Commission in its new trade strategy entitled 'Trade for All'. Considering that the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for the dignity of the human person are fundamental values which we stand for, I have obviously voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour, not without acknowledging that it should have gone much further in promoting binding instruments for the control and sanction of companies that violate human rights. Existing mechanisms today are based on willfulness and are not sufficient. It is therefore essential to move towards a joint responsibility of parent companies throughout the value chain; it is necessary to ensure coherence in Union policies and not to sign trade treaties containing opaque and para-judicial mechanisms for resolving investor-State disputes. We miss a greater reference to the responsibility of financial institutions, which support transnationals and the need to specifically address the right to access to justice of the most vulnerable. We should also, as we proposed in amendments, promote the establishment of a Union agency for the supervision of the activity of transnational corporations in third countries, and sanction procedures in the event of crimes, in order to put the protection of human and environmental rights at the centre of Union action, without the business benefits.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries, as global trade makes them increasingly important in the area of social responsibility. An important part of this report is the definition of international standards and rules. Trade agreements can help strengthen the global trading system and human rights clauses. Transparency and communication with regard to measures to prevent human rights violations in third countries are important if there is to be real democratic control.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because the text recognises corporate responsibility and expresses concern about human rights violations committed in third countries, and calls for continued, effective and coherent action at all levels, also at national, European and international levels, in order to effectively combat human rights violations committed by international companies.  It also explicitly calls on businesses, European and non-European, on their duty to respect human rights, and appeals to the Union and the Member States on their duty to guarantee and protect human rights. It precisely requires the Union, the Member States, third countries and all national and international authorities to adopt, as urgently and as widely as possible, binding instruments for the effective protection of human rights, and I voted in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the Report on corporate liability for serious human rights abuses in third countries. The report reminds corporate actors of their responsibility to respect human rights throughout their global operations, regardless of where their users are located and independently of whether the host state meets its own human rights obligations.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is on corporate liability for serious human rights abuses in third countries. I fully support human rights; however, as they are not specified I cannot support just the concept, as that may include so-called rights I do not support. As the report also called for binding mechanisms, I abstained.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Many corporations operating at international level, whether European or within the Union, operating in third countries have concentrated significant business activities or are based in Europe. Although respect for human rights is a moral and legal obligation for corporations and their management and should be integrated into the long-term economic perspective, regardless of their place of activity, size or industry, we often see human rights violations that pose a global problem. I regret that there is still a lack of a global holistic approach as regards corporate responsibility for human rights violations and victims of human rights violations by international companies so often face many obstacles to access to judicial redress, including procedural obstacles to admissibility and the disclosure of evidence. I supported the resolution because I believe that, thanks to the measures taken, the EU and its Member States will strive to achieve the best possible protection of human rights, and not just by overburdening businesses with administrative and bureaucratic formal rules. I expect the Commission, together with all stakeholders, to thoroughly examine the existing obstacles to justice in proceedings before the courts of the Member States concerning alleged human rights violations committed abroad by EU-based enterprises, and will then take effective measures to remove or mitigate these obstacles.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Human rights are often overlooked in the global business of large corporations. It is important that the United Nations, which has already issued several recommendations and commitments in this area, should also be joined by the European Union.  The report highlights the legal obligations of corporations to respect human rights in their operation, regardless of their location. The text identifies a growing number of serious corporate responsibility challenges and lists a number of recommendations and requests from the European Union, in particular in the area of access to justice for victims of corporate abuse.  The report mentions that non-binding initiatives in this area do not constitute activities that produce sufficient results. As globalisation accelerates, it is becoming increasingly important to ensure respect for human rights, even in the context of extraterritorial dimensions, where new and new problems arise from the point of view of regulation.  At the same time, the report calls on corporations to raise standards of supervision in particular. There is also mention of regret about the obstructive behaviour of some Member States in relation to the effort to a binding UN agreement on business and human rights. I am pleased with the report and have supported it.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. Human rights are an important asset that all European institutions, not least the European Parliament, must uphold and protect worldwide. As a Member of the Alliance for Progress and Awakening, I stand by this. However, many of the stated demands in the report miss out on daily practice and thus do not fulfil the desired purpose for a targeted and clear outlawing of human rights violations in third countries. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is in our immediate interest that human rights be respected in third countries as well. This has a direct impact on the stability of the surrounding regions, which depends on the number of illegal migrations and the level of security threat to Europe.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. The liability of corporations for serious human rights abuses in third countries is a serious matter, which has already been addressed by the United Nations. Those who wish to go beyond the current framework can do so via inter-governmental agreements. Therefore EU commentary, instruction, or regulation is unnecessary in this area.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. As one of the main players of economic globalization, corporations are obliged to respect international agreements. By internationalising business activities, corporations' role in ensuring respect for human rights will be increasingly significant in terms of corporate social responsibility and international standards, rules and cooperation will be crucial to prevent human rights violations in third countries.  It is also important to ensure that policies on entrepreneurship and human rights are coherence at all levels, within and between the institutions of the European Union and its Member States. The European Union is based on the values of respect for human rights, therefore, I support the Corporate Responsibility Report on serious human rights violations in third countries of the Foreign Affairs Committee.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. I support the report, which stresses that we need continuous, effective and consistent action at all levels in order to effectively address human rights violations by international societies.  Companies must strive to include human rights due diligence in their policies. If we want to allow for proper supervision, we need transparency and information on the measures taken to prevent human rights violations in third countries.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries, because we consider it to be a first step in the right direction. The report contains important positive parameters, which should be followed by both the Commission and the Member States. In addition, the report highlights the obligations of companies operating abroad and should respect human rights in all their activities. However, despite our positive attitude, we are opposed to the fact that the report lacks any criticism of the very trade agreements concluded by the EU, which, in many cases by their very nature, violate basic human rights.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Human rights violations in third countries are a very important issue but companies are not responsible. The few cases where there are indeed violations with corporate responsibility are always done with the tolerance of corrupt state or local authorities and in most cases companies associated with such practices are multinational. Small and medium-sized enterprises importing products from other countries cannot be called upon to take responsibility through procedures which are in many cases done remotely. If the Union wants to combat human rights violations in third countries, it can stop encouraging funding of repressive and criminal regimes, such as those of Turkey, the occupied countries of Cyprus, Saudi Arabia and Swaziland.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Companies are among the most important players in the globalisation of the economy, financial services and international trade, so we should look increasingly carefully at their actions both at home and in the European Union, but also outside the Community. The European Parliament's report highlights the growing role of corporations in ensuring respect for human rights in third countries, while stressing that trade agreements can contribute to strengthening global rules and human rights. The document also pays particular attention to corporate social responsibility and the increasing voluntary commitments of companies in this area. The EP document also calls on the EU and the Member States to establish clear rules that companies established in their territory or under their jurisdiction must respect human rights in all their activities, in every country and in any business context, including outside the EU. I have chosen to vote in favour of the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 At EU level, it is important to address human rights violations and hold those who violate them accountable. I found the report uncomplicated, and I followed alde's clear position by advocating it.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Ignazio Corrao, which deals with human rights, labour and environmental protection issues. One of the main objectives of the report is to ensure that Europe and the Member States act urgently, continuously and effectively at all levels, in addressing the legal problems arising from the extraterrestrial dimensions of societies and their behaviour, as well as the relative uncertainty regarding the allocation of responsibilities for human rights violations. The report calls on the Member States to lay down clear requirements regarding the need for companies domiciled in their territory and/or jurisdiction to respect human rights in all their activities and in every country and context in which they operate, as well as to ensure that victims have access to effective redress. Another important point in the report concerns the proposal to create an abuse-free label at EU level, to which it could be adhered on a voluntary basis, and subject to the monitoring of an independent body. Thanks to this report, the 5 Star Movement lays the foundations for the removal of the causes that cause uncontrolled migratory flows.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The UN Global Compact (with the 10 Principles) called on businesses to accept, support and apply in their environment a set of fundamental values in terms of human rights, labour standards, the environment and the fight against corruption, which contributes to their acceptance by the socio-economic environment and, therefore, to their sustained development. However, over time, it is not often that corporations have caused or contributed to human rights violations, especially of vulnerable groups: minorities, indigenous peoples, women, children, or to the damage/destruction of the environment.  As, thanks to globalisation and business internationalisation, the role played by corporations in the development of human society is growing, the need for continuous, effective and coherent action at all levels (national, European, international) in order to find effective solutions to corporate abuses is complemented by the use of tools that can stimulate corporate social responsibility. Thus, the UN Global Compact, ISO 26000 standard on social responsibility, the IOM Tripartite Declaration establishing the Principles on Multinational Enterprises and Social Policy, and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises are effective and appropriate instruments.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report tackles the deep concern regarding human rights violations committed in third countries, including due to some EU corporations’ and business enterprises’ management decisions, as well as by individuals, non-state actors and states. The report reminds corporate actors of their responsibility to respect human rights throughout their global operations, regardless of where their users are located and independently of whether the host state meets its own human rights obligations. I support this report, as I believe that breaches of human rights by EU corporations, and others, in third countries are unacceptable and are contrary to the fundamental principles of the European Union. Furthermore, I would like to highlight the importance of the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs) and their worldwide implementation and call on ‘companies, whether European or not, to carry out human rights due diligence’ as well as the allocation of sufficient resources for this purpose.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament will put to a vote this afternoon on its proposal for clear EU rules to require companies established in the Member States of the European Union or under their jurisdiction abroad to respect human rights in all their global activities. We also offer a label certifying respect for human rights in third countries when making a product. The aim is clearly to promote own companies, as opposed to those, still too numerous, which are unscrupulous about the working conditions of their workers around the world.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on corporate liability for serious human rights abuses in third countries deals with several issues related to the responsibility of corporations to comply with the applicable laws and respect human rights, including, inter alia, global responsibility, positive incentives in terms of promoting human rights, liability of EU corporations, extra-territorial dimensions of companies, criminal liability, as well as the creation of a certified ‘abuse-free’ product label at EU level.  I voted in favour of the report because the EU’s founding values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, need to be reflected in its action on the international scene, including its trade policy, and should be guided by these principles.

name: Eleni Theocharous (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Respect of human rights is a core value of the European Union and to that end corporations have an increasing role in ensuring respect for human rights, abiding by international norms and rules applicable for everybody. Trade agreements can contribute to reinforcing the global rules-based trading system as well as human rights provisions. In this regard corporate social responsibility is highly important whereas worldwide implementation of the United Nation Guiding Principles (UNGPs) can be an effective tool.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Businesses have largely benefited from the globalization of the economy, creating jobs and ensuring profits and gaining power and influence in many developing countries. Unfortunately, these positive aspects are accompanied by flagrant violations of human rights which have exacerbated the situation of poverty and abuse to which many people are subject. It is also up to the European Union to promote policies that make it possible to create effective instruments to call companies to account or to ensure the protection and protection of workers. We must work on legislation to ensure that they are held accountable for the impact of their activities.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. The primary focus of this report is in the call for corporations operating in third countries to voluntarily embrace human rights values, working standards, environmental protection and the fight against corruption. The report contains completely legitimate calls that I wholeheartedly support such as taking on the legal responsibility of companies in terms of enabling the process of indemnifying individual and collectively damaged rights, adopting legally binding instruments dedicated to the effective and effective protection of human rights, the need to correct legal uncertainty regarding where exactly responsibility for human rights violations begins, etc. However, what I cannot agree with is a call for all proposed legitimate calls to be realised through the legislation of the EU institutions. I consider this to be a completely unnecessary breach of the principle of subsidiarity, as the regulation of this problem at Union level will not achieve any added value for individual Member States of the Union. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. The EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities.  Corporate human rights violations are a global problem, all companies in the world should respect these rights, and at the same time the primary duty of the European institutions is to regulate the responsibility of those companies linked to the EU by law and regulation.  There is still no comprehensive global approach to corporate responsibility for human rights violations and victims of human rights violations involving international companies face a number of obstacles to access to redress.  Continuous, effective and consistent action at all levels, including at national, European and international level, is urgently needed in order to deal effectively with human rights violations by international companies and legal issues arising from the extraterritorial dimension of companies and their behaviour, as well as the associated uncertainty as to who is responsible for human rights violations.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour, not without acknowledging that it should have gone much further in promoting binding instruments for the control and sanction of companies that violate human rights. Existing mechanisms today are based on willfulness and are not sufficient. It is therefore essential to move towards a joint responsibility of parent companies throughout the value chain; it is necessary to ensure coherence in Union policies and not to sign trade treaties containing opaque and para-judicial mechanisms for resolving investor-State disputes. We miss a greater reference to the responsibility of financial institutions, which support transnationals and the need to specifically address the right to access to justice of the most vulnerable. We should also, as we proposed in amendments, promote the establishment of a Union agency for the supervision of the activity of transnational corporations in third countries, and sanction procedures in the event of crimes, in order to put the protection of human and environmental rights at the centre of Union action, without the business benefits.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In this report, the European Union is to use the theme of corporate responsibility to extend its power over the trade policies of our firms.  The European Union simply wants to hide the fact that its excessive free trade policy is doing far more damage in terms of human and social rights than the actions of the firms of our States.  I therefore objected to this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In line with the UN Business and Human Rights Guidelines and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises, corporations operating in third countries should voluntarily respect human rights and labour standards values. The report submitted seeks to encourage the Member States of the European Union to enforce compliance with those rights and standards by undertakings whose owners are located in Member States which are established in Member States or which carry out their activities there for a large part. However, the report contains a number of general and ambiguous demands, including calls on the EU, the Member States, third countries and all national and international bodies to adopt as a matter of urgency and 'to the fullest extent possible' binding instruments for the effective protection of human rights in this field. The very title of the report also seems problematic. In view of these doubts, I have decided to abstain.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union is based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Its international actions (including trade policy) are guided by these principles. I supported the report.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on corporate liability for serious human rights abuses in third countries. The report underlines that the EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Corporations are one of the major players in economic globalisation, financial services and international trade and are required to comply with all applicable laws and international treaties in force and to respect human rights.  The report underlines that the business community, while obliged to respect human rights, may also have an important role to play in offering positive incentives in terms of promoting human rights, democracy, environmental standards and corporate responsibility. I voted in favour because I believe that the full observance of human rights in the production chain is fundamental and not just a matter of choice for consumers.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report encourages different stakeholders involved in the business- human rights relationship to launch initiatives and measures on the prevention of violations of business rights globally, highlighting the need for access to effective remedies. It also proposes moving towards the adoption of legally binding instruments or implementing new voluntary labelling demonstrating the traceability of respect for human rights throughout the production chain. The text recognizes the importance of corporate social responsibility and applauds the growing use of instruments based on the commitments made by the companies themselves. Sharing the need to prevent human rights abuses, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text because the text recognises corporate responsibility and expresses concern about human rights violations committed in third countries, and calls for continued, effective and coherent action at all levels, also at national, European and international levels, in order to effectively combat human rights violations committed by international companies.  It also explicitly calls on businesses, European and non-European, on their duty to respect human rights, and appeals to the Union and the Member States on their duty to guarantee and protect human rights. It precisely requires the Union, the Member States, third countries and all national and international authorities to adopt, as urgently and as widely as possible, binding instruments for the effective protection of human rights, and I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Multinational companies have had a significant influence on developments in international law.  Respect for human rights was far from their concerns.  I am therefore delighted to see a report by the European Parliament stressing that the voluntary private sector initiatives in this area are not sufficient and calling unrestricted for work on a binding UN treaty.  I also welcome the text's insistence on the duty of care in the supply chain (which must be applied urgently, particularly with regard to 'blood minerals') and the need to ensure effective access to justice for victims. I regret, however, that the text does not call for the gratuitousness of the procedures for those victims, when we know that it is first of all financial issues that hinder them. I also regret that there is no question of setting up a mechanism for arbitration tribunals to submit to the supremacy of human rights. I therefore vote for this report in the hope of a positive role for the EU at the UN, which has long refused to take part in the work in this area.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council of the United Nations Human Rights Council (HRC) approved on 26 June 2014 the launch of the process of developing new binding international standards on multinational companies and human rights. This initiative aims to end multinationalimpunity for human rights violations, directly or indirectly caused by their activities, and to ensure access to justice for victims. We are doubtful about the importance attached to SMEs, as well as the definition of a good behaviour label given by the European Commission, to whom we do not recognise political and moral legitimacy in the field of human rights and multinational companies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report provides for sanctions for companies responsible for serious human rights violations in third countries. In addition, respect for human rights should be easier to enforce in the future in court. In view of a possible improvement in the global human rights situation, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on corporate liability for serious human rights violations in third countries. Given that the EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy and equality, and whereas the UN guiding principles on economic activities and human rights apply to all states and all national and transnational companies, I believe that it is the task of the European institutions to regulate the responsibility of economic actors who do not respect human rights. The motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to carry out an in-depth examination, in consultation with all interested parties, including civil society and businesses, of the legal obstacles existing in cases brought before the courts of the Member States for alleged human rights violations committed abroad by companies established in the EU, and calls on the Council and the Commission to act in accordance with Article 83 TFEU , in order to establish minimum standards for the definition of offences and penalties in areas of particularly serious crime with a transnational dimension.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We live in a world dominated by large international corporations, and where many of our products, from the mobile phones in our pockets to the food in our supermarkets, and the clothes we wear come at the expense of enormous suffering, cruelty and abuse of human rights. This report is an important step forward in creating a corporate culture in which violations of human rights are simply unacceptable. Companies must play by rules that uphold human decency and basic dignity. As a supporter of the Alternative Trade Mandate, I believe that our economy must not put profit ahead of people and planet. I have also chosen to use a Fairphone (which is made without conflict minerals) and would recommend colleagues to do the same. Whilst corporations must do more, Member States must create due diligence and reporting rules, and also introduce criminal liability for companies operating under their jurisdiction that violate human rights in other countries. The international community must do more and move towards a binding treaty on business and human rights. I urge the EU national governments to work towards that goal.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, since I want these rules to become binding and enforceable towards corporations, and since EU technologies are still causing human rights violations. The EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. I strongly believe in these values and as a liberal, I believe that everyone should be treated fairly, also in the working environment. I agree that a global holistic approach to corporate liability for human rights abuses is still lacking.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the global problems of our time is also the issue of human rights violations by businesses and corporations in third countries. The EU is founded primarily on the values of democracy, freedom and respect for human dignity and respect for human rights, both in the sphere of political and commercial. A particular problem is responsibility for human rights violations and legal difficulties arising from the extraterritorial dimension of businesses and corporations. It is therefore necessary to take measures that move towards a coherent, lasting and effective way of addressing human rights violations at national, European and international level. Due attention should be paid to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) operating at regional and local level. It is desirable that The Union's corporate social responsibility policies take into account the specific needs of SMEs and follow the idea of 'think small first'. It is certain that trade and human rights are not being ruled out, quite the contrary – they must support each other. Globalisation itself further underlines the importance of corporations in respecting human rights. However, I believe that respect for human rights by corporations should not only be an obligation under legislation, but should be a moral obligation of all management in the first place. I therefore express my support for this resolution.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. This report raises a number of business and human rights initiatives. It proposes different measures aimed at preventing violations of these rights at the global business level. Member States, the Commission, the EESM and the companies themselves would be involved in this series of actions. Although the proposed measures are already taking place at different levels of the Union, this report proposes new ones focused on achieving an effective remedy for a possible infringement of rights and gaining comprehensive control of the situation throughout the production chain. Of course, I share the need to implement the necessary measures to protect citizens from possible abuse by businesses and for all this, I vote in favour of this report.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report entrusts the companies themselves with the responsibility of protecting human rights in their activities, within the framework of corporate social responsibility, in short, 'puts the wolf in the guard of sheep'. It cultivates the perception that most enterprises are 'good' and do not infringe human rights and, therefore, as a matter of priority, voluntary 'self-regulation' procedures are proposed for enterprises, by setting up mechanisms for so-called 'risk assessment', etc. Proposals to introduce and promote the "no violations" brand ensure additional free advertising on their products and new privileges. It is hidden that, at the same time, these companies will continue to take advantage of the wealth that workers generate for their own profitability and that this exploitation of workers is 'legitimate' for the EU and civil governments, which serve their monopolies and interests. For this reason, the people must overthrow them, in order to defend their most fundamental right, which is to live without being exploited, without stealing their toil, with their own power and economy, by leaving the EU.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support the report with my vote. In my view, it contributes appropriately to the debate on corporate social responsibility, especially multinational ones, which often have branches and production facilities in third countries. I consider it essential that human rights are respected all over the world and that binding standards are set for employers that clearly require respect for human rights. It is employers who can often fight violations very effectively and effectively.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Corporate human rights violations pose a significant problem, despite the fact that all societies in the world have a duty to respect human rights and to incorporate fundamental human rights principles and values into their activities. That is why we dealt with this issue in the report on corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries. Within this framework, we have reminded corporations that, in today's globalised and internationalised business environment, their role in protecting human rights is even greater and that they should be able to take responsibility for any violations. At the same time, we called on them to ensure an effective remedy if they cause harm and to guarantee that rights violations do not happen again. I believe that this is a subject that deserves appropriate attention, which is why I supported the report with my vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Corrao report because I believe that compliance with human rights rules by multinationals with global operations, wherever they operate, regardless of where they are based, is fundamental. I underline the great importance of corporate social responsibility, especially the practice of integrating the responsibility of respecting human rights into binding contractual requirements between companies and their customers and suppliers, whether these companies or individuals.  In this context, I also liketo point out the work begun to draw up a binding UN Treaty on Business and Human Rights, in which I hope that the EU and the Member States will participate constructively.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on Corporate Responsibility for Serious Human Rights Violations in Third Countries. Corporate human rights violations are a global problem and affect the rights of vulnerable groups such as minorities, indigenous peoples, women and children, or contribute to environmental problems.  Unfortunately, there is still no comprehensive global approach to corporate responsibility for human rights violations. I believe that human rights violations require effective remedies, and therefore a fairer and more effective system of remedies to deal with human rights violations committed by companies must be ensured through national and international legislation, as the report, which I supported, also calls for.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we have voted on a report on the European strategy on liquid natural gas and storage. But, in practical terms, what have we been talking about? The fact that we are going to import natural liquid gas from the United States of America, on the pretext that in doing so we will be sure that we do not stay in the cold. It is a pity that incontrovertible data tell us that: 1) gas demand in Europe is declining and that infrastructure is under-utilised, 2) the Mediterranean basin can and must become a global leader in the development of carbon-free energy resources, 3) we cannot overlook the dangers to the environment for human health caused by reassifications and storage activities, 4) there are specific COP21 targets that require the abandonment of fossil fuels. Nevertheless, the Commission uses the EFSI (EFSI), the European Fund for Strategic Investments, for large projects, to the benefit of the gas multinationals. On the contrary, we believe that it is urgent and a priority to concentrate all political and economic efforts in support of renewable energies, energy efficiency and sustainability. That is why we voted against.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are opposed to this report because we oppose the interests of the large gassers who want to speculate on our territories, our energy bill and our climate. In my country, Spain, there are multiple open conflicts because of Europe's plans to get American gas extracted by hydraulic fracturing or liquefied gas from Qatar to our territories. We have the examples of Beaver, which we are going to pay for among all, and Doñana, where a very important agri-environmental heritage is at risk, a matter on which the Commission has washed its hands this week, to make the game for Gas Natural.  But also pipelines such as The Midcat, storage infrastructures in urban areas, the overcapacity of plants such as Castejón. All of them dangerous and useless infrastructures that only add another fictitious cost to energy bills for the benefit of large energy oligopolies and to the clear detriment of people.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – As a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) and coming from a small island nation, this is a very important topic for me. I attended the debate here last night and I would like to commend both the rapporteur, Mr Gyürk, and Commissioner Cañete for their help in developing a very sensible strategy on liquefied natural gas (LNG) for the European Union.  Obviously the Russian developments, especially in Ukraine, woke us all up to how unreliable a partner it was and it is obviously not sensible to be depending on a partner like Russia for the majority of our gas. Also, of course, the availability of LNG means that we should avail of that opportunity as well to bring down prices and to improve security.  Of course, where we are concerned in Ireland, the fact now that the United Kingdom will be leaving the European Union; it is not sensible that we should be largely dependent on a connector from the United Kingdom. So these measures and the development of LNG in Shannon in Ireland would be of major importance and I thank the Commission particularly for their support of that.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is in favour of fossil fuels and completely neglects the issues of strategic dependence and infrastructure lock-in, made all the more perverse by the considerable degree of under-utilisation of existing European structures (on average 25%). It is also based on projections of EU gas consumption basically provided by ENTSOG, which are manifestly exaggerated and which have also been criticised by the Court of Auditors. Gas is presented as a relatively clean fuel, thus neglecting the problems arising from leaks with the corresponding contribution to the greenhouse effect, and the major problems posed by unconventional extraction methods. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. The report urges Member States to fully implement the Third EU Energy Package. UKIP rejects the implementation of EU energy policy legislation, it is the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, because this Strategic Union commitment on liquefied natural gas is a strengthening of energy dependence and environmental destruction. Rather than reinforcing the commitment to renewable energy and indigenous sources of energy production, the Union continues on the path of global resource hoarding, the same logic of oil applied to gas. Another aspect is the importation of gas through destructive techniques such as fracking, but it is no more serious than the international conflicts developed around this resource, the liquefaction of which allows its transport through smaller infrastructures. Gas is a fossil fuel with a high level of emissions and only benefits large multinationals that control its distribution. Because we need a balanced transition from the Union's energy production to renewable energy, that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this motion for resolution which seeks to boost the use of liquefied natural gas in Europe. I believe that it had an unbalanced promotion of the use of fossil gas which poses a serious threat for climate change and LNG should not benefit from taxpayers’ money. I was particularly concerned that this motion calls for the elimination of all barriers to global free trade in LNG including in TTIP whilst also welcoming the Commission’s work towards removing export restrictions on US gas to Europe. Shale gas, which accounts for more than half of US gas production, is very controversial in Europe and in Ireland, where widespread opposition has been voiced.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. I welcome the Commission's communication entitled 'A EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage'. Indeed, an internal energy market that fully integrates LNG and gas storage can only play a favourable role in achieving the ultimate goal of a resilient Energy Union. However, I regret in this report the reference to the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) on energy and raw materials for the Eu's energy security. I objected.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Union strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage, because the increase in liquefied gas on the world market is a good opportunity for the EU to diversify its energy supply.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
