text: Writing. The full integration of liquefied natural gas and the storage of gas will contribute massively to the goal of a resilient Energy Union in the future. To this end, priority should be given to market-based solutions and the use of existing LP infrastructure. In particular, a careful analysis of the alternatives and options for the supply of liquefied natural gas at regional level is preferable to a decision on new infrastructure. This would make more efficient use of the existing infrastructure.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is very clearly in favour of the gas sector- the only acceptable fossil energy in the long term - whose development should enable a smooth ecological transition, with good economic prospects at the key, especially in terms of jobs not relocated with biomethane. The text rightly stresses the opportunities of LNG as an alternative fuel in road and maritime transport. Nevertheless, in addition to the interference in our energy policy with strengthening the power of the Commission and its agencies, in addition to the systematic desire to liberalise the energy market, this report, which speaks four times of the EU's 'energy diplomacy', seems above all the result of geopolitical orientations in opposition to those defended by the National Front. The "solidarity" invoked on several occasions seems to have to be done at all costs with States that are doing everything to cut us off from this natural and strategic partner that is Russia. Or how to move from a dependence on Russian gas to allegiance to the United States (and Qatar) by making particular use of U.S. shale gas via the TAFTA, explicitly cited several times. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the report states that the elimination of regulatory obstacles would greatly improve the liquidity of Gas markets the report urges Member States to fully implement the Third EU Energy Package. I am in favour of transparency and eliminating EU regulation but I do not believe that the Third EU Energy Package will benefit the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which I believe is part of the process of rapidly transitioning to a sustainable energy system in the Union and ending dependence on external gas suppliers.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on an EU strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and storage of gas. Gas imports from Russia to the EU, which were 7% higher in 2015 than in 2014, remain a concern. One of the objectives of the EU's LNG and gas storage strategy is to meet the EU's ambition to move quickly towards elements of a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system and to no longer be dependent on external gas suppliers. This is crucial for reducing dependence on Russian gas.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In addition to interfering in our energy policy with the strengthening of the power of the Commission and its agencies, in addition to the systematic desire to liberalise the energy market, this report, which speaks four times of the EU's 'energy diplomacy', seems above all the result of geopolitical orientations that are not ours and which take the lead on any other consideration. Hence the constant call for diversification of sources of supply. If this text is not as caricatured as anti-Russian as algirdas Saudargas's text on "energy security" (surprisingly rejected in June 2015 thanks to the adoption in extremis of an amendment in favour of a moratorium on shale gas), "solidarity" - also invoked several times - seems to have to be done at all costs with States that are doing everything to cut us off from this natural and strategic partner that is Russia. Or how to move from a (relative) dependence on Russian gas - based on long-term contracts where suppliers and customers are mutually captive and therefore interdependent - to allegiance to the United States (and Qatar) by making particular use of US shale gas via the PTCI/TTIP/TAFTA, explicitly cited several times.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have endorsed this report, which first of all reminds us that the EU's strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage is an element of the Energy Union. It calls for better use of existing liquefied natural gas and gas storage capabilities, increased cooperation to build new facilities and enhanced support for less connected regions to diversify sources of supply.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. The global liquefied natural gas (LNG) market is in a phase of strong dynamism. Global LNG supply is expected to increase by 50% by 2020. The Union can benefit from the expansion of the global LNG market to strengthen its gas supply security and competitiveness. But always respecting environmental protection and gas independence to the fullest. That is why this report contains a number of measures in this regard. Among the amendments I have pushed, I would like to highlight the mainstreaming of the need to meet the objectives of greenhouse gas reduction, energy efficiency and renewable energy expressed in the Paris Agreement and the Union Energy Roadmap. At the same time, the call to raise awareness among global forums on free trade about the environmental, climate and social effects of LNG. The report also expresses the potential benefit that the ATCI could have for energy security, as removing import restrictions can significantly increase the Union's gas supply options. The report is complete and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Gyürk report on the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage. This is an important text which touches on the crucial issue of energy supply and the development of the European energy strategy. Already today, several EU Member States are fully dependent on gas imports, a condition generated both by the limited number of suppliers and by the lack of alternative supply routes. In the near future, it is estimated that this dependence will increase, which is why European action must be directed, on the one hand, to actively pursue the development of its own domestic conventional gas resources, such as those discovered in Cyprus, and, on the other, to facilitate the rapid transition to a secure and sustainable energy system. Only through the creation of an effective Energy Union, with a single energy market and a common energy policy, will it be possible to guarantee real energy security for the continent.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against the own initiative report on liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage, because it promotes, on the basis of market operation, the construction of new LNG, gas pipeline and gas storage terminals. Therefore, the promotion of gas use is at odds with the Union's climate objectives, as natural gas emits methane, a gas that has a heating potential 86 times greater than CO2. The energy security of the East and Baltic countries is not to replace imports of Russian gas with gas from other supposedly safer countries (even sometimes from fracking) but by a clear commitment to improving energy efficiency and developing renewables.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. This report stresses the need to streamline infrastructure investments for this alternative energy source, some of which are now oversized, and points to the potential of this fuel to alleviate dependence on the European market and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. We also share the special mentions that are made about the usefulness of this source in maritime transport. We also share the need to underline the Union's role, as the second largest buyer on the world market, in the field of trade in this fuel.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on an EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage is strongly geared in favour of gas. Indeed, it is the only acceptable fossil energy in the long term whose development should allow a smooth ecological transition, with good economic prospects at the key, especially for jobs not relocated with biomethane. The text focuses on LNG, including interconnections and storage, but it also emphasizes LNG as an alternative fuel, such as BGL and CNG. It is also about strengthening the diversification of sources of supply. However, this text marks an interference in our energy policy with the strengthening of the power of the Commission and its agencies, in addition to the systematic desire to liberalise the energy market. Moreover, it wants less dependence on Russian gas but more on the United States and Qatar, using shale gas (see TAFTA). I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with what is stated in the report on the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage and I believe that it moves even further towards the objective of promoting an EU energy union, a further attempt to control our territories from above. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I share the balanced vision on the EU strategy for liquefied natural gas that we adopted in the ITRE Commission. The report reflects both the situation and potential of LNG, taking into account its contribution to the security of energy supply in Europe and the benefits of a more competitive market. In addition, the LNG strategy is particularly relevant from the perspective of its qualities in reducing current environmental impacts, such as alternative fuel in transport, heating and electricity. I understand that LNG, as an energy source with extremely lower emissions than other fossil fuels and other natural gas sources, should not be penalized with labels that raise suspicions about its cleanness, questioning the opportunities and advantages of our companies worldwide, although the possible importation of LNG from hydraulic fracturing deserves more detailed attention under our international agreements. In short, I believe that Europe must make a firm commitment to LNG, as it is a source of energy beneficial to the european environment, economy and society, and the report has therefore deserved my vote in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which discusses the European Union strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and the storage of gas. The European Parliament welcomes the Commission communication entitled 'An EU strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and storage of gas' and considers that the internal energy market integrating the full use of liquefied natural gas and storage will play an important role in achieving the ultimate objective of a resilient Energy Union. The EU strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and storage is one element of the Energy Union, which aims to achieve the EU's ambition to move quickly towards a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system, and that one of its objectives is to no longer be dependent on external gas suppliers. Parliament stresses that one of the objectives of the Energy Union is to make the EU a world leader in renewable energy. In addition, Parliament is of the opinion that energy security can be ensured in the most efficient way through better coordination of national energy policies, through a genuine energy union with a single energy market and a common energy policy, and cooperation between Member States in this area, in accordance with the principles of solidarity and trust.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the International Energy Agency, the golden age of natural gas could come in the coming decades. Partly because of the development of the international market and partly because of the advantageous properties of natural gas, the role of natural gas in national energy mixes is expected to increase. As the cleanest fossil energy source, it is able to replace much more polluting fuels in both electricity generation and transport, thereby contributing to decarbonisation. Imports of liquefied natural gas may provide a solution to the expected significant reduction in production within the Union or lead to diversification of resources in Member States that depend on a supplier. The EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and storage is part of the Energy Union winter package. It aims to make the natural gas system more diversified and flexible, thereby contributing to a safer, more predictable and competitive supply of natural gas. The report points out that increasing the utilization of existing infrastructure is a top priority, but that the necessary new investments should also be made where necessary. In order to increase efficiency, we must pay particular attention to European gas storage facilities. It is also necessary to build and bidirectional the associated wiring network, in particular with regard to missing inter-outlets, and to apply appropriate transport tariffs. The necessary improvements could benefit gas diversification and gas competition outside the host countries. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has stated that it is crucial to resolve the situation in vulnerable Member States.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ratification of the Paris Agreements has created the conditions for the global energy transition, thus making the shift towards a low-carbon economy irreversible. In this transition period, the adoption of a common energy strategy would help support a rapid transition to a sustainable, safe and competitive energy system, limiting dependence on external gas suppliers. With a view to exploiting the Union's internal resources for greater energy self-sufficiency, the report presented today by the European Parliament underlines the fact that liquefied natural gas represents an opportunity for Europe in terms of greater competitiveness in the short term. Exploiting the potential of LNG and its storage would make the European system more diversified and flexible and contribute to a reliable gas supply, even for the most energy-vulnerable regions. In order to achieve this objective, greater cooperation and solidarity between Member States, as well as a more efficient and secure use of existing infrastructure and terminals, are necessary.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this REPORT on the EU Strategy for Blended Natural Gas and Gas Storage. The rise of LNG in the global market is a good opportunity for the EU to recast its energy supply. However, I believe that LNG is only a temporary solution, while we are in dire need of a long-term reduction of gas dependency within the EU to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and to reach the Union's climate and energy objectives.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Some of the ideas developed in this report are interesting, including the value of converting electricity into gas during periods of overproduction, but its geopolitical orientations are very partisan and very supportive of rapprochement with the United States rather than with the "bad" Russia. This report also calls for the liberalisation of the energy market and the increase in the Commission's power over the Member States in this area, which I am fighting. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this resolution on an EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage with the aim of developing a resilient Energy Union. Indeed, the Energy Union has the objective to make the EU more independent from the dependence on external gas suppliers. As a matter of fact, this resolution supports the integration of LNG and gas storage within the framework of the internal energy market and I strongly believe better coordination of national energy policies is needed in order to achieve it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gas can play a significant role in the Union's energy system, industrial production and as a source of heating in buildings and in support of renewable energy in the coming decades, pending the EU's achievement of its greenhouse gas emissions, energy efficiency and renewable energy targets and achieving the transition to a low-carbon economy , where the role of gas will gradually decline in favour of clean energy. Nowadays, however, several Member States are dependent on gas from abroad, which exceeds 90% of their average annual needs: this places serious limits both in terms of geopolitical, strategic, economic and environmental security. For this reason, any action which can reduce foreign dependence and improve the methods and means of supply is to be welcomed. Bridging the infrastructure gaps for gas storage and the transport of natural liquefied gas is a key step in strengthening the Union and increasing solidarity and energy efficiency. The Member States must support this process by promoting the Commission's action, the completion of cross-border gas networks and the implementation of the latest package of agreements for the completion of the single energy market.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report stresses the need to seize the opportunities offered by liquefied natural gas, liquefied biogas and compressed natural gas. The development of these alternative fuels, which can be used in particular in road and maritime transport, could indeed enable the smooth completion of the ecological transition with good economic prospects, particularly in terms of job creation. Of course, we share most of the findings in this text and we are also in favour of intelligent diversification of our gas supply sources. Nevertheless, we have objected to this report which constitutes an infringement on the sovereignty of Member States in terms of energy policy. European Union interference, in addition to geopolitical guidelines clearly aimed at marginalising Russia from our trade relations in order to increase our energy dependence on US shale gas. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Liquefied natural gas plays a significant role in the Union's energy system, in industrial production, as a source of heating of buildings and as support for renewable energy. Thus, the European Union's strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage aims to flesh out the Union's intention to move to a sustainable, secure energy system, but also to limit its dependence on external gas suppliers. Therefore, one of the main objectives with regard to the Energy Union is to make the Union the world leader in renewable energies, precisely in order to avoid dependence on a single energy supplier and, at the same time, to ensure energy security.  The EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage is intended to speed up the process of achieving the primary objective, namely to achieve a resilient energy union, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this initiative.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has the ambition to make the transition to a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system that treats energy efficiency as an energy source itself and develops low-carbon energy sources. Among the Commission's communications, the last one in February on the EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage comes to help achieve this goal. Energy security can best be achieved through better coordination of national energy policies, the establishment of a real energy union, a single energy market and a common energy policy, and cooperation between Member States in this area, in accordance with the principle of solidarity and trust. I support this report because I believe that the EU should work closely with its international partners and in international for a to ensure a free, liquid and transparent LNG market all over the world.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report expressing Parliament's position on the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage presented by the Commission last February. The report highlights the benefits of using LNG for a rapid transition to a sustainable, safe and competitive energy system and to end dependence on external gas suppliers. However, it notes some critical aspects, including the infrastructure aspect, highlighting the need to make a careful analysis of the alternatives and options regarding the supply of LNG from a regional perspective and from an environmental sustainability perspective, before deciding on the construction of new infrastructures, in order to improve energy security and ensure the most efficient use of existing infrastructures. It also notes that existing LNG infrastructure in the EU is significantly under-utilised and that gas demand in the EU continues to be overestimated. It therefore calls for planning for gas infrastructure based on a reduction in demand.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. This report sees Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) as the panacea for Europe’s energy issues and is particularly problematic when it comes to its paragraphs on trade, calling for a strong energy chapter in TTIP for a global LNG market, which means in practice that the US will be exporting its fracked gas into Europe. This report welcomes the Commission proposal on an energy security package, and the EU Energy Union concept is the premise for creating a common LNG strategy. It suggests that LNG and gas storage will facilitate a quick transition to a sustainable, secure and competitive energy market and end dependence on external gas suppliers, as some countries – including Ireland – are still dependent on a single supplier. It calls for the building of new LNG terminals and gas storage facilities, which also means building more supporting pipeline infrastructure. My GUE/NGL colleagues and others attempted to include aspects on access to energy, affordability of energy, energy as a public social good and the need to tackle energy poverty, objecting to further liberalisation and calling for a ban on hydraulic fracturing. However, none of these were included in the final report, while references to TTIP in relation to energy and trade remain.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. The report urges Member States to fully implement the Third EU Energy Package. UKIP rejects the implementation of EU energy policy legislation, it is the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report as I am convinced amongst others that safety rules and impact assessments are paramount where LNG (Liquefied Natural Gas) storage is concerned. I also agree that the added value of any new LNG infrastructure must first be ascertained. This is particularly important within Malta’s context whereby it is becoming increasingly clear that the new gas tanker which will be used as an LNG storage for the new gas power station is both unnecessary and less cost-effective than just using the recently built electricity interconnector which connects Malta to the European grid and the proposed gas pipeline project which will connect the island state of Malta to mainland Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is in favour of fossil fuels and completely neglects issues of strategic dependence. It is also based on projections of eu consumption of gases basically supplied by ENTSO gas, which were strongly criticised by the Court of Auditors, which found them to be completely exaggerated. The gas is presented as a relatively clean fuel, neglecting the problems related to leaks and the consequent very strong greenhouse effect; in addition, aspects relating to unconventional extraction methods are not taken into account. I could only vote against the report.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on a very important topic of energy security presents broad set of measures we need to consider in order to keep the EU regions energetically safe and stable. There is a need to diversify our resources in order to mitigate risks linked to the fact that some Member States are fully or largely dependent only on one supplier. This, in future, can turn into a very negative surprise. However, I have abstained at the final vote, as I am missing some parts of the strategy that I find important, such as better use of existing critical energy infrastructure or better links on the North-South basis.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report contains Parliament's contribution to defining a European strategy for liquefied natural gas (LNG) and its storage. The increase in LNG production planned for the next few years and the consequent fall in prices may represent an opportunity for the Union in terms of energy security that we must seize. This would benefit those Member States which have only one source of energy supply. I thought I voted in favour of this report because, in order to make Europe an attractive market for suppliers, we must ensure that the Eu ropean Union has adequate infrastructure. If we achieve this, we will also be able to derive an environmental advantage, given that LNG will be able to complement renewable sources in order to effectively replace more polluting conventional fuels for both road and sea transport.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I adopt and support this report not only because in its energy plans it includes my own country, Cyprus, but also more broadly the Mediterranean, which is a very important factor today, in order to be able to complete the issue of energy self-sufficiency, energy supply and energy support of the European Union, but, at the same time, because it proposes solutions with regard to the liquefied natural gas terminal , as essentially a small country, such as Cyprus, cannot alone invest and build such a large project and, for this reason, it is addressed to the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is important to use for these projects.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the European Union strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage fails to highlight the need for citizens to have access to these natural goods as a social issue. In particular, in the light of the economic crisis experienced by millions of European citizens in recent years, we must stress the need for a social policy against conservative choices. Therefore, I have decided to abstain.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against this report of the energy package proposed by the European Commission. In addition, the text is characterised by a strong Russophobic approach.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the validity of having a forward-looking energy and climate policy, I am voting in favour of the report. The EU committed itself at the Paris Climate Conference to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030, and a strategy on liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage is a real opportunity for Europe. In fact, it has been estimated that dependence on natural gas imports will increase and in this respect LNG would make it possible to achieve greater competitiveness since it would push down natural gas prices and strengthen security of supply. However, it must be recognised that at present the European internal energy market is far from integrated due to insufficient interconnections. Therefore, existing regional infrastructure for LNG conversion and gas storage must be renewed or implemented, just as, again in a regional dimension, alternatives to LNG must be provided where new entities need to be built.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure as I agree with the eu's strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage, as an internal energy market that addresses these issues by integrating them more and more effectively can lead to the achievement of the objective of an energy-resilient, safe, competitive and integrated EU, also through a more effective use of existing regional structures.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report, because this Union strategic commitment on liquefied natural gas is a strengthening of energy dependence and environmental destruction. Rather than reinforcing the commitment to renewable energy and indigenous sources of energy production, the Union continues on the path of global resource hoarding, the same logic of oil applied to gas. Another aspect is the importation of gas through destructive techniques such as fracking, but it is no more serious than the international conflicts developed around this resource, the liquefaction of which allows its transport through smaller infrastructures. Gas is a fossil fuel with a high level of emissions and only benefits large multinationals that control its distribution. Because we need a balanced transition from the Union's energy production to renewable energy, that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage is one of the elements of the Energy Union, which aims to give concrete expression to the EU's ambition to achieve a rapid transition to a sustainable, safe and competitive energy system and also to end dependence on external gas suppliers. I believe that liquefied natural gas, interconnections and gas storage are important elements and can help to eliminate any kind of energy insulation in the Member States and regions. With this in mind, it is all the more important to support the most vulnerable countries in their efforts to diversify their sources and supply routes through the creation of new LNG terminals, distribution and interconnection systems that can guarantee the security of maritime supply routes and strengthen member states' energy security by reducing demand through efficiency measures.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Strategy on Liquefied Natural Gas and its Storage presents one of the elements of the Energy Union, which aims to move quickly to a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system that is no longer dependent on external gas suppliers. This energy security can be ensured through better coordination of national energy policies, but also through a common energy policy. All EU citizens must have access to a secure, affordable energy supply. In 2015, gas imports from Russia were 7% higher than in 2014 and 41% of gas imports in 2015 came from Russia.  The storage of liquefied natural gas, as well as increased efficiency and the use of renewable energy, can play a vital role in reducing dependence on Russian gas. I voted to provide the necessary funding for research into technologies using liquefied natural gas, so that in the future we will also reduce global EMISSIONS OF CO2, SOx and NOx.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage, I decided to vote against. In my opinion, the strategy should focus on issues related to LNG and gas storage, which are helpful in creating a strong Energy Union, and in practice it refers to binding energy and climate targets for 2030. Which, in my opinion, is intended to undermine the future role of LNG and gas storage, and I therefore voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report since it lays down the EU’s strategy when it comes to LNG. LNG is the ideal transitory fuel for a number of Member States that need to move from a fossil-fuel based economy to a non-pollutant source of energy. LNG is a cleaner source of energy for a number of countries which are until today dependant on coal or Heavy Fuel Oil. We need to make sure to move away from pollutant energy sources and diversify our energy supply to ensure energy security and these points are all acknowledged in the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the report on the EU strategy for liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage. The European Union must promote credible solutions to meet its international commitments to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. LNG is one of these viable alternatives. LNG's low greenhouse gas emissions make it a good transition fuel for transportation, heat generation and electricity. In line with this report, I believe that EU citizens will benefit all the more from the benefits of LNG if Member States cooperate and include their thoughts on taming, transit and storage of LNG within a European framework.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to establish an internal energy market incorporating liquefied natural gas (LNG). It is a gas that cools to -161oC, condensed in a liquid state and therefore has advantages in terms of storage, transport, and respect for the environment. In particular, the report defends an energy policy in favour of the use of natural gases, through the exploitation of the EU's internal resources. It proposes concrete measures such as the development of LNG refuelling infrastructure for both ships and vehicles.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. According to the International Energy Agency, global natural gas consumption is expected to increase by 50% by 2035. Europeans must therefore step up their efforts towards a more sustainable, safe and competitive energy system. This will reduce our dependence on third countries for natural gas and will enable the development of the use of renewable energy, a sector of the future. However, the Union must ensure that such a transition is not accompanied by higher costs for consumers.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. According to the International Energy Agency, the golden age of natural gas could come in the coming decades. Partly because of the development of the international market and partly because of the advantageous properties of natural gas, the role of natural gas in national energy mixes is expected to increase. As the cleanest fossil energy source, it is able to replace much more polluting fuels in both electricity generation and transport, thereby contributing to decarbonisation. Imports of liquefied natural gas may provide a solution to the expected significant reduction in production within the Union or lead to diversification of resources in Member States that depend on a supplier. The EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and storage is part of the Energy Union winter package. It aims to make the natural gas system more diversified and flexible, thereby contributing to a safer, more predictable and competitive supply of natural gas. The report points out that increasing the utilization of existing infrastructure is a top priority, but that the necessary new investments should also be made where necessary. In order to increase efficiency, we must pay particular attention to European gas storage facilities. It is also necessary to build and bidirectional the associated wiring network, in particular with regard to missing inter-outlets, and to apply appropriate transport tariffs. The necessary improvements could benefit gas diversification and gas competition outside the host countries. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has stated that it is crucial to resolve the situation in vulnerable Member States.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is in favour of the gas sector, an acceptable fossil energy sector with good prospects, especially in terms of jobs that can not be relocated with biomethane. In particular, it encourages the conversion of electricity to gas to avoid losing excess electricity generation and rightly stresses the opportunities of LNG as an alternative fuel in road and maritime transport. However, this text seems to prefer to move us from a relative dependence on Russian gas to allegiance to the United States (and Qatar) by making particular use of US shale gas via the PTCI/TTIP/TAFTA, explicitly cited several times. Despite being Fidesz, Gyrk and his staff were clearly hostile to the ENL. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the report because, with the exception of a few points, it is not in the interests of the European peoples, but, on the contrary, it promotes further rupture with Russia, unpopular agreements with the United States and, in general, moves within the same framework of the deadlocked policies pursued in general.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. According to the International Energy Agency, the golden age of natural gas could come in the coming decades. Partly because of the development of the international market and partly because of the advantageous properties of natural gas, the role of natural gas in national energy mixes is expected to increase. As the cleanest fossil energy source, it is able to replace much more polluting fuels in both electricity generation and transport, thereby contributing to decarbonisation. Imports of liquefied natural gas may provide a solution to the expected significant reduction in production within the Union or lead to diversification of resources in Member States that depend on a supplier. The EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and storage is part of the Energy Union winter package. It aims to make the natural gas system more diversified and flexible, thereby contributing to a safer, more predictable and competitive supply of natural gas. The report points out that increasing the utilization of existing infrastructure is a top priority, but that the necessary new investments should also be made where necessary. In order to increase efficiency, we must pay particular attention to European gas storage facilities. It is also necessary to build and bidirectional the associated wiring network, in particular with regard to missing inter-outlets, and to apply appropriate transport tariffs. The necessary improvements could benefit gas diversification and gas competition outside the host countries. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has stated that it is crucial to resolve the situation in vulnerable Member States.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I am opposed to the import of fracked gas and because the report is very supportive of LNG expansion while neglecting the reality of climate change. It is in contradiction with the Paris Agreement and does not recognise the urgent need to phase out fossil fuels. In Wales there is huge opposition to fracking and many of my constituents have written to me expressing their concerns and opposition to this report.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. This own-initiative report takes important steps towards a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system within the Union. It also establishes the importance of getting away from dependence on external gas supplies, which can indirectly contribute to geopolitical tensions. It is essential that the EU does not prevent the emergence of other types of energy, including biogas, in order to take more steps towards a green transition. Access to LNG and improved infrastructure can also contribute to economic benefit as the supply on the market currently enables competitive energy prices. Prices that can encourage Member States to take the necessary steps in the right direction.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Azores archipelago, due to its geographical location, can function as an important fuel station for transatlantic liquefied natural gas routes. The Commission should therefore provide support funds for European projects for this purpose and to create a common project of 'blue LNG corridors for islands' in the maritime sector. The report stresses the importance of finding energy supply options, cost-efficient and environmentally sustainable, to increase long-term security of supply in the Iberian Peninsula and elsewhere in Europe, which are not sufficiently linked to or integrated into the internal energy market and deserve full EU support in the name of the principle of solidarity.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: "solidarity" - also invoked several times - seems to have to be done at all costs with States that are doing everything to cut us off from this natural and strategic partner that is Russia.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report – on the EU Strategy for Liquefied Natural Gas and Gas Storage – is perfectly framed in the so-called Single Energy Market and those that inspire it. It advocates strengthening the role of the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER). It explains the EU's geostrategic interests from the point of view of mastery of supply routes and energy production points. It advocates the removal of barriers to market integration, i.e. the creation of the single energy market, i.e. by opening the door to European-wide monopolistic concentration in the sector. It advocates the convergence of global gas markets, an inseparable position from the efforts that have been undertaken in the commercial field, through free trade and investment agreements, in particular with the USA and Canada (TTIP and CETA). These are paths and options from which we fundamentally diverge and oppose. Without prejudice to the recognition of the role of Liquefied Natural Gas in a future energy mix and guidelines that may be pursued at national level in this regard, which led us to vote in favour of the amendments on the role of Portugal (and particularly its Autonomous Regions in the case of the Azores), we voted against the report.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against this resolution because I believe that the text as presented may weaken the future role of liquefied natural gas and gas deposits. In fact, the report contains several references to binding climate and energy parameters, set as minimum targets for 2030, which do not fall within the scope and objectives set by the report itself and which therefore undermine its intent and scope.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's report in question is a response to the Communication of the European Commission in February this year, when it presented the European Union strategy for liquefied natural gas and its storage. Global liquefied gas reserves will increase dramatically in the future and its price will go down significantly as a result of oversupply, so it will be very important that Member States that depend on one supplier look for an alternative for the future. In future, we must focus on efficient and renewable sources in the area of investments in liquefied gas in the European Union, but we must also not forget that it has the potential and use as much as fossil fuel.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because improvements were needed on certain issues covered.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Union's strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage, as — with the exception of a few points — it is not in the interests of the European peoples, but rather promotes further rupture with Russia and unpopular agreements with the United States and, more generally, moves within the same framework of the deadlocked policies it pursues in general.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The global supply of LNG is expected to increase dramatically in the next few years (50%) and consequently the price of it will most likely go down, which according to the Commission represents a major opportunity for the EU, particularly when it comes to gas security and resilience, and especially for those Member States currently heavily reliant on a single supplier, and hence vulnerable to supply disruptions. The report recommends that in order to exploit the full potential of LNG and to make the EU an attractive market for suppliers, the Union needs to ensure that the necessary infrastructure is in place. However, as existing LNG infrastructure in the EU is currently heavily underused, the report underlines the need to, before supporting new regasification terminals and from a cross-border perspective, promote the most efficient use of existing LNG terminals, also to avoid technology lock-in or stranded assets in fossil fuel infrastructure. The EU should also step up its efforts to cooperate closely with international partners to promote free, liquid and transparent global LNG markets.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that gas can play an important role in the Union's energy system over the coming decades, in industrial production and as a source of heat in buildings and support for renewable energy, while the Union meets its ambitious greenhouse gas emission targets , energy efficiency and renewable energy, and makes the transition to a low-carbon economy, in which the role of gas must gradually diminish in favour of clean energy. Liquefied natural gas represents an opportunity for Europe both in terms of increasing competitiveness, putting down pressure on natural gas prices, and increasing security of supply, the latter being of great importance given the current geopolitical situation and the high dependence of certain Russian gas countries. There is no doubt that the Union must be able to take full advantage of an integrated internal energy market, so it is vitally important to strongly support interconnections, such as MidCat, and the full implementation of the third energy package.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on an EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage because I consider this to be a key issue for the EU's energy future, given the growing international rigidities and difficulties and the need to honour the Paris Agreement and to put in place coherent policies in favour of combating global warming. Liquefied natural gas can replace fossil fuels and it is therefore important for the EU to equip itself, as requested by the Commission, with its own strategy to diversify suppliers and sources of supply, a serious problem especially in some countries. I believe, however, that this choice cannot conflict with the need to avoid settlements in areas with the highest environmental and landscape value already classified as sites of Community interest, it must harm investment in renewable energies. Finally, I share the position of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (European Parliament) on the subject of infrastructure. There is no doubt that liquefied natural gas needs adequate infrastructure and technology, but the Member States have various structures that need to be fully exploited, including jointly and across borders, before building new infrastructures that can be harmful to the environment and displease citizens.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the 'Report on the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage', confirming my position, which is against any commitment or recommendation on the use of so-called fracking technology in the Member States.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The provision and use of liquefied natural gas is relentless for a resilient, europe-wide energy supply. I particularly support the regional solutions highlighted in the report and the use of existing infrastructures.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage as it is an important pillar to strengthen the EU’s energy security. While increasing security of energy supply, the EU strategy for LNG should crucially fit into the wider European climate and energy targets and priorities, and correspond to the COP21 agreement, putting a focus on reducing demand, improving energy efficiency and phasing out fossil fuels.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012Voto against the own-initiative report on liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage, because it promotes, on the basis of market operation, the construction of new LNG, gas pipeline and gas storage terminals. Therefore, the promotion of gas use is at odds with the Union's climate objectives, as natural gas emits methane, a gas that has a heating potential 86 times greater than CO2. The energy security of the East and Baltic countries is not to replace imports of Russian gas with gas from other supposedly safer countries (even sometimes from fracking) but by a clear commitment to improving energy efficiency and developing renewables.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage as it is an important pillar to strengthen the EU’s energy security. I strongly believe that the EU energy security strategy should be based on development of renewable and energy efficiency and fit into the wider European climate and energy targets and priorities, and correspond to the COP21 agreement; I believe that LNG should only be considered as a transitional fuel and that we should not lock ourselves in the development of stranded assets.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a European Union strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. Our internal energy market must fully integrate LNG and gas storage will play an important role in achieving the ultimate goal of an energy union resistant to geopolitical unforeseen events. Priority must be given to market-based solutions and the use of existing LNG infrastructure at the regional level. Finally, it is important to respect the objective of diversifying sources of supply to enable the EU to be more independent.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The EU strategy for LNG and gas storage is one element of the Energy Union, which aims to gives concrete expression to the EU’s ambition to bring about a quick transition to a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system, and also aims to end dependence on external gas suppliers. Therefore it is crucial that LNG and storage operators, in cooperation with national regulatory authorities, would develop new flexible products and services, compliant with the EU current legislation, in order to make LNG regasification and storing more attractive and maximise the utilisation of existing LNG and storage facilities.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. During the vote in favour of the report on an EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage, we voted, among other things, in favour of the wordings relating to Nord Stream 2. We generally share the concerns expressed in the report about the implications for security of supply, security policy and EU energy policy that the Nord Stream 2 project may entail. That is why it is important that this is taken into account in the report.  We also chose to abstain on wordings in the report, which refers to opportunities to increase energy trade relations with the UNITED States, including through TTIP. The TTIP negotiations are ongoing negotiations, we do not know what a possible final agreement will look like, and a large part of US gas is shale gas extracted through hydraulic fracturing, which can have a major negative impact on nature. An increased supply of liquefied gas on the global market offers opportunities to diversify the EU's energy supply, but at the same time our delegation would like to underline the importance of reducing the EU's dependence on gas in the long term in order to achieve its climate and energy targets.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the International Energy Agency, the golden age of natural gas could come in the coming decades. Partly because of the development of the international market and partly because of the advantageous properties of natural gas, the role of natural gas in national energy mixes is expected to increase. The necessary improvements could benefit gas diversification and gas competition outside the host countries. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has stated that it is crucial to resolve the situation in vulnerable Member States.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive reports are included in the report. It is stressed that both the exploitation of deposits in the Cypriot EEZ and the creation of a liquefaction terminal in Cyprus should be supported. It also stresses the need to ensure the right of access to affordable energy and to combat energy poverty. However, negative reports are included. While energy policy-making now falls within the competence of the Member States, the EU aims to have a common energy policy and to speak with one voice, which will of course serve specific interests. The proposal for institutional convergence and synergy of the Union's foreign policy with the common energy policy to be imposed on the Member States is also problematic. The aim is to make energy a tool of foreign policy and not part of a development policy to improve the quality of life. We do not want energy to serve the needs of the market with TTIP-type agreements, as proposed in the report, nor to be used to strengthen the dominant circles of the EU. We are fighting for energy to be guaranteed as a public social good, to which we will all have equal and cheap access. We call for enhanced state control, public infrastructure and international cooperation on the basis of mutual benefit, parity and solidarity. For these reasons, we have abstained.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I acknowledge the need to make the EU gas system more diverse and flexible and develop a strategy that aims at lessening EU gas dependency in the long term, as well as the need to promote, before supporting new regasification terminals, the most efficient use of existing LNG terminals from a cross-border perspective, so as to avoid technology lock-in or stranded assets in fossil fuel infrastructure and ensure that consumers do not have to bear the costs of any new projects. Further, the cross-border accessibility of gas storage is one of the key tools to implement the principle of energy solidarity during gas shortages and emergency crises. Therefore, I voted in favour of the above motion.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. As one of the richest continents and one of the main drivers of climate change, Europe has an extra responsibility to take the lead in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The Party for Animals believes that Europe must get rid of its addiction to fossil fuels. A healthy future lies in sustainable, decentralised energy supply. An EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage does not fit with that.  This strategy mainly talks about the liberalisation of the energy market, while not mentioning the negative effects of (liquefied) natural gas and gas storage. As a resident of the province of Groningen in the Netherlands, I know that the consequences of gas extraction can be disastrous. Every week we are confronted with earthquakes caused by gas extraction. This causes a lot of damage to buildings and unsellable and unsafe houses. Natural gas is not an innocent transition fuel. The gas tap must be closed as soon as possible. That is why I will vote against this proposal.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The increase of liquefied natural gas on the global market is a good opportunity for the European Union to diversify its energy supply. As liquefied natural gas is only an interim solution, the EU needs to diminish its gas dependency in the long run. The aim is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and to reach its climate and energy targets.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the EU Strategy report on sequestered natural gas and gas storage (2016/2059(INI)) as the internal energy market by incorporating sequestered natural gas and gas storage plays a significant role in achieving a resilient Energy Union.  The EU Strategy for Sequestered Natural Gas and Gas Storage is one element of the Energy Union in achieving a sustainable, secure, competitive and independent energy system. The EU Strategy for Blended Natural Gas must be aligned with the Framework Strategy for a Resilient Energy Union and contribute to greater security of energy supply, decarbonisation, long-term sustainability of the economy and favourable energy prices.  Greater cooperation between Member States is needed, in particular in the construction of new terminals, infrastructure connectivity and better utilisation of existing potentials, in particular by ensuring the supply of those countries dependent on one mode of supply. Cross-border cooperation should also be achieved in the gas storage sector. The construction of the internal gas market should continue and existing barriers should be lifted.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I take the use of the gas sector as a perfect way to promote a less tumultuous ecological transition and real economic potential, especially through biomethane. Encouraging diversification of sources of supply is a priority. Despite its good intentions, particularly on liquefied natural gas (LNG), this report is not satisfactory. There is no question of increasing the Commission's power of interference, of liberalising the energy market more than reason, nor of giving rise to so-called energy diplomacy whose geopolitical character would be the only, if not the main engine. Everything is done to move us away from Russia, a strategic and natural partner, and to replace our so-called Russian gas dependence with a genuine submission to the United States, via the future transatlantic treaty, vector of shale gas. I voted against it.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The INI report on an EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage was adopted today (415+/225-/15). Greens/EFA voted against the report as it is very much in favour of expansion of LNG and related infrastructure. Such developments – based on distorted projections – would result in stranded assets and lock the EU into carbon intense infrastructure. This would create unnecessary costs and delays in achieving energy transition and the decarbonisation of energy systems in the EU.  The Gyürk report also urges the establishment of new markets for LNG and the elimination of market barriers to a global free trade, which would lead to increased imports of fracked gas, regardless of the clear negative effects on the environment. Continued reliance on fossil fuels is also in conflict with the EU’s commitments made in Paris as part of the new global climate agreement. Unfortunately, progressive text proposals, such as on methane leakage and sustainable production conditions, were not included in the final report. In short, we voted against the report because it neglects the context of the EU energy and climate targets and the urgent need to tackle climate change and to phase out fossil fuels.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage, because it recalls that the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage is one of the elements of the Energy Union that transforms the EU's ambition to develop into a sustainable, safe and competitive energy system soon, and because it aims to end dependence on external gas suppliers and stresses that one of the the objectives of the Energy Union are to make the EU a world leader in renewable energy sources.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There is now a lot of discussion about non-renewable energy and its exhausting resources. It is estimated that the most popular deposits, such as oil and coal, will end around 2040. This increases the consumption of natural gas, the use of which at present accounts for only 20% of the world's total energy demand, and its deposits are still not fully exploited. It is usually found in the company of other minerals, but it can also appear independently. Most natural gas is found in Russia and in the Persian Gulf. At the same time, the European Union wants to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions that cause global warming and to ensure that it has permanent access to energy, so that it is no longer dependent on imports. The indirect solution is the use of liquefied gas (LNG), so that transport and storage costs will fall significantly. This is important because the current pipeline system in Europe is not fully harmonised, so that the full potential of this fossil cannot be exploited. In addition, liquefied form is much more environmentally friendly. In order to do so, it is necessary to fully integrate the energy policies of the individual Member States of the Union and to ensure a stable gas supply.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this report. I am well aware of the importance of LNG for diversifying Europe's gas supply, but supply must be based on market-based projects. Nord Stream II is one such project, which is designed, financed and built purely by companies, without using public funds. The open political rejection of this project led me to reject the report as a whole.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage as it is an important pillar to strengthen the EU’s energy security. While increasing security of energy supply, the EU strategy for LNG should crucially fit into the wider European climate and energy targets and priorities, and correspond to the COP21 agreement, putting a focus on reducing demand, improving energy efficiency and phasing out fossil fuels.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 25 October 2016, we voted in plenary on the report on the EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. The proposal under discussion is another in a series of EU efforts to create a slow-building Energy Union. This time, therefore, it is moving towards defining a unified strategy for all EU Member States for LNG. In the long term, I have been very reticent about building a single Energy Union, because I believe that the issue of energy, the energy mix and security belongs only to the exclusive competences of individual Member States. However, I try to be very open about this issue. The proposal put forward is moving towards a single gas market, which may not be a bad thing a priori. At the same time, however, the proposal mentions the transatlantic trade partnership, with which I deeply disagree. Moreover, like most documents on the Energy Union, it neglects the fundamental issues of access to and availability of energy, does not regard energy as a public good of a social nature, and does not try to combat so-called energy poverty, which is a fundamental flaw in a commodity such as gas, the price of which is still a socially sensitive issue in many countries. Moreover, the proposal is very benevolent on the issue of gas produced by so-called hydraulic fracturing, which destroys both our waters, biodiversity and the environment as a whole. For all these reasons, I therefore abstained.

text: Writing. \u2012 According to the International Energy Agency, the golden age of natural gas could come in the coming decades. name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – We are faced with a number of environmental problems, many of which are caused by fossil fuels. However, it is necessary to distinguish between the use of natural gas and the low level of pollutants compared to oil and coal, so that when burned it does not or does not burden our environment with heavy metals, sulphur compounds, nitrogen oxides, micro-granular soom. Therefore, and from a diversification point of view, the report contains eligible elements for liquefied natural gas, LNG. However, it is unacceptable that Ukraine intends to place the burden of supplying natural gas on the shoulders of EU taxpayers, so that we can buy expensive US LNG instead of cheap Russian gas and supply not only the Ukrainian population, but also their industrial companies, so that they can compete with EU petrochemical companies.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU LNG strategy and its storage plays a significant role in achieving the ultimate goal of building a European Energy Union. Given that gas imports from Russia were 7% higher in 2015 than in 2014, and 41% of natural gas imports from non-EU countries were from Russia in 2015, effective solutions need to be put in place to reduce dependence on Russian gas. The EU, and in particular Eastern Europe, need to diversify its energy supply, and this can be achieved through better alignment of national energy policies and the creation of an Energy Union with a single energy market and a common foreign policy. I think it is important to encourage the most efficient use of existing LNG terminals before supporting new re-gasification terminals.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is the largest energy importer in the world, importing more than half (54%) of the energy it consumes. This means the EU continues to be highly dependent on gas and oil imports from authoritarian regimes. Therefore, the establishment of an Energy Union is an important step on the road to achieve energy security through diversification of energy sources and energy routes to Europe. In a long term perspective, the establishment of the Energy Union will ensure that all EU citizens have secure, equal and affordable energy supply. In this context, the current developments on global liquefied natural gas (LNG) markets present a major opportunity for the EU to deliver lower energy costs, security and resilience to EU consumers. Therefore, the EU should focus its efforts on promotion and development of new LNG terminals, distribution systems, interconnectors, transmission corridors and storage stations. LNG is a particularly important element for the establishment of the Energy Union and will contribute significantly towards ending any kind of energy isolation or dependence of the EU Member States and EU regions.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage is part of the package outlining the future of EU energy policy, presented by the European Commission in February. The report argues that the promotion of an internal energy market that integrates liquefied natural gas and gas storage will enable the objectives of a resilient Energy Union to be achieved. It also stresses the need to take measures based on the market and the use of existing regional liquefied natural gas infrastructure and explains that a careful analysis of alternative options for the supply of liquefied natural gas should be carried out in order to ensure more effective use of infrastructure. The issue of energy and diversification of sources of supply are central issues at this time, when policies are emerging for the coming decades, where we will be committed to implementing regulations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and in the fight against climate change. Our energy policy needs to focus on an integrated, secure, competitive and sustainable system. And this strategy must be part of it.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the EU's strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. In addition to interference in the energy policy of the Member States, with the strengthening of the power of the European Commission and its agencies, in addition to the systematic desire to liberalise the energy market, this report, which speaks four times of the EU's 'energy diplomacy', seems above all the result of questionable geopolitical guidelines. The text advocates allegiance to the United States (and Qatar) with a particular use of U.S. shale gas via TAFTA, explicitly cited several times.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, which is rather favourable to the gas sector, deals specifically with the liquefied natural gas sector and in particular with interconnections and storage capacity. It promotes the conversion of electricity to gas as well as the use of LNG as fuel for road and sea transport. In addition to EU interference in energy policy, as well as its desire to liberalise the energy market, this report deals with the EU's 'energy diplomacy' and appears to be the result of geopolitical strategies that are not necessarily those of the states, and which therefore benefit other powers such as the United States with shale gas. For these reasons, I objected to this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Taking into account the Union's recent environmental commitments, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 by 80% to 95% below 1990 levels, liquefied gas can be a key player in the Union's energy system over the coming decades, while it transitions to a low-carbon economy in which clean energy plays a key role.  In this context, the resolution urges the Commission and the Member States to promote and encourage better and more effective use of existing infrastructures, as well as to diversify and make the Union's gas system more flexible with a view to achieving a safe, resilient and competitive gas supply. I am voting in favour of the resolution, because in the face of the environmental challenges we face, it is essential to develop a strategy aimed at reducing the Union's long-term gas dependence, in order to achieve our desired emission levels by 2050; in that sense, liquefied natural gas is a good transitional instrument.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report as natural gas has an important role to play in our energy mix in the medium term.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. Liquefied natural gas is a technology that enables the transport of gas usable for transport and production of electricity. This technology is used and expanded naturally and we do not need an EU strategy for this. I do not agree with the call for the EU and the Member States to create 'incentives' for the distribution of liquefied biogas. If biogas is to be competitive as a renewable source, it must be used on the market without subsidies and tax breaks, otherwise support for biogas risks ending up as much as support for solar and wind power – a huge burden on consumers and taxpayers.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The further diversification of the EU’s natural gas supply remains a key objective, particularly as domestic production in the EU will continue to decline in coming decades. But this diversification is not the aim. From my point of view the real aim has to be a low energy price for consumers. It is the real test of new initiatives.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The security of the EU's energy supply is a matter of paramount importance. To contribute to this, this report looks at the main pillars of the EU's strategy for liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage, recently presented by the Commission. The response of this report to these issues is only partially satisfactory. Its content is certainly positive when, recalling the commitments made with the Paris climate agreement, it refers to the binding targets repeated by the European Parliament for 2030 in terms of renewable energy, energy efficiency and emissions reduction. Nevertheless, I cannot agree with certain passages, notably the one concerning the opening of a chapter on energy and raw materials in the EU-US free trade agreement currently under negotiation. Concerned about the negative environmental impact of shale oil and gas developed across the Atlantic, I abstain on this text.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 October 2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the report on liquefied natural gas because the future European strategy in this area is one of the axes of the Energy Union. The EU requires removing dependence on external gas suppliers and building a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system. That is why I believe that doubling the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline would have a negative effect on the Energy Union, the need to ensure energy independence from the Russian monopoly. This project should not benefit from either European financial support or derogations from European legislation. The EU must focus on the full implementation of the Third Energy Package and on strengthening a well-connected gas network in gas markets to ensure an integrated single market. For projects of common interest, the Commission should fully include the Balkan countries in the planning for the future reconstruction of the gas pipeline and the TEN-E network. With regard to the Black Sea region, it must play a key role for infrastructure projects of strategic importance for the supply of LNG in the EU. The EU must give this region due geostrategic importance for ensuring energy security and diversifying its energy supply in the Caspian Sea, the Middle East and Central Asia.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. There are several problems with this solution. Firstly, it wants to impose geopolitical guidelines on Member States in terms of energy security. The European Union seeks to interfere in our policy by imposing systematic liberalisation of the energy market and deciding which sources we can use. These are not our choices. Nor are they aligned with France's vital interests. Secondly, this text seeks to strengthen the power of the Commission and its agencies. She even talks about the EU's 'energy diplomacy'! Finally, this text is very clearly against Russia by proposing to move from a dependence on Russian gas to allegiance to the United States (and Qatar), with a particular use of US shale gas through free trade agreements, notably TTIP (or TAFTA), which we strongly oppose.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on an EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. Gas plays a strategic role in the EU energy system that aims to reach energy security.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to outline an EU strategy for liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage, which is basically structured in the energy security package presented on 16 February 2016 by the Commission. This package is a proposal for the EU to be prepared for possible interruptions in energy supply in order to make the EU an attractive market for gas suppliers. This report does not fully address important issues such as access to energy, accessibility of energy, energy and a social public good, the need to combat energy poverty. I voted against it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. A domestic energy market that fully integrates liquefied natural gas and storage facilities will make a significant contribution to the Union becoming a global leader in renewable energy. That is why I support the Union's strategy for liquefied natural gas and its storage, which will enable a rapid transition to a sustainable, safe and competitive energy system and end dependence on external gas suppliers. To do this, we will need to complete the outstanding infrastructure, boost the internal gas market and influence the use of liquefied natural gas as an alternative fuel in transport, heat production and electricity.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage has a solid basic idea. However, I do not agree with the strategy on a number of points. That is why I have decided against this EU strategy.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and the storage of gas. Liquefied natural gas (LNG) enables Europe to increase competitiveness and security of supply by reducing the price of natural gas. The role of LNG and gas storage, together with increased efficiency and the use of renewable energy sources, is crucial in reducing dependence on Russian gas.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Natural gas currently accounts for about a quarter of the EU's gross domestic energy consumption. This report promotes liquefied natural gas (LNG) and the liberalization of the energy market. It mainly aims to diversify EU external suppliers in response to the Commission's concern about the share of Russian gas in European imports (41% in 2015). For example, it "welcomes the work done by the Commission to lift restrictions on US gas exports to the EU" when it is mainly shale gas, whose extraction leads to many environmental problems. Finally, he welcomes the future conclusion of TTIP and its chapter on energy and raw materials, to which I am opposed. I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, which is rather favourable to the gas sector, deals specifically with the liquefied natural gas sector and in particular with interconnections and storage capacity. It promotes the conversion of electricity to gas as well as the use of LNG as fuel for road and sea transport. In addition to EU interference in energy policy, as well as its desire to liberalise the energy market, this report deals with the EU's 'energy diplomacy' and appears to be the result of geopolitical strategies that are not necessarily those of the States and which therefore benefit other powers such as the United States with shale gas. It is for these reasons that I objected to this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. 'u2012 Gas can play an important role in the EU's energy system in the coming decades – in the industrial production sector as a source of heating in buildings and in support of renewable energy – while the EU meets its greenhouse gas emissions, energy efficiency and renewable energy targets and transitions to a low-carbon economy , where the role of gas will gradually decrease in favour of clean energies.
