The EU LNG and Gas Storage Strategy is one of the elements of the Energy Union which aims to translate in concrete terms the EU's ambition to move quickly to a sustainable, safe and competitive energy system, and which also aims to end the dependence of external gas suppliers.  It should be noted that one of the energy union's objectives is to make the EU the world leader in renewable energy. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that calls for a Union-wide strategy for LNG. The report focuses on permanent facilities for the safe storage of LNG and emphasises the need for safety. It also emphasises the need for impact assessments before any facilities are constructed and calls for stringent safety measures to be place when this fuel is stored.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The EU has the ambition to become a world leader in sustainable energy use in the long term. It does so in phases, including by developing a shock-resistant energy union that includes liquefied gas and gas storage. An EU strategy for liquefied gas and its storage is also vital to reduce our energy dependence on foreign suppliers. In this way, we guarantee that the invoice remains affordable for the customer. But natural gas remains a fossil fuel and its use contributes to the warming of our climate. That is why I have initiated a number of amendments to this report with some colleagues, which place the energy challenge in the wider environmental context. In these amendments, we stress that EU energy policy must be in line with the Paris environmental agreements. The ambition is to limit global warming to 1.5°C. By emphasizing the reduction of demand, optimising energy efficiency and phasing out the use of fossil fuels, including gas, we are joining the European climate and energy targets.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The EU Strategy for Liquefied Natural Gas and Gas Storage is part of the Package of Legislative Proposals on the Union's Energy Policy presented by the European Commission in early 2016. The strategy sets out objectives that would form part of building a resilient energy union that is sufficiently competitive with the American, Asian and Arab markets and would provide safe and affordable, environmentally friendly energy. The liquefied gas market is not yet sufficiently developed on EU territory, so it is essential that the Union intensively fulfils its plans for completing the missing infrastructure or using existing infrastructure efficiently. The situation is similar with regard to gas storage – streamlining this area is an ambition of several of the PCIs package, which use funds from EU strategic funds. If I see rightly the tuning of the Strategy towards promoting the development and application of renewable energy sources, as these are the ones that are supposed to account for 100% of European production in 2100, natural gas is seen only as a transition from heavy fossil fuels to cleaner energy sources. I support the report.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy considers the role of natural gas, including liquefied natural gas and its storage, in the European Union's energy policy, in particular with regard to the Union's energy dependency, security of supply, energy poverty, greenhouse gas emission reductions and the transition to a low-carbon economy. It takes into account the European infrastructure for the storage of natural gas and the re-conversion of liquefied natural gas. It urges the necessary steps to be taken to achieve an Energy Union that reduces the use of energy, in particular non-renewable energy.  I voted in favour of the draft resolution, although I missed the push for stronger measures to reduce the use of non-renewable energy.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In addition to the interference in our energy policy with the strengthening of the power of the Commission and its agencies, in addition to the systematic desire to liberalise the energy market, this report, which speaks four times of the Union's 'energy diplomacy', seems above all the result of geopolitical orientations which are not ours and which take the lead on any other consideration. That is why I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage as it is an important pillar to strengthen the EU’s energy security. While increasing security of energy supply, the EU strategy for LNG should crucially fit into the wider European climate and energy targets and priorities, and correspond to the COP21 agreement, putting a focus on reducing demand, improving energy efficiency and phasing out fossil fuels.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome Parliament's report on the European Commission's energy security package, which contains the necessary proposals to prepare Europe for the global energy transition, and it also presents new instruments to deal with possible disruptions in energy supply. The issue of energy security is the basis on which we can then build an energy strategy for the Union, as well as one of the priorities of this Parliament and the Juncker Commission. The set of rules presented by the Commission contains a wide range of measures to strengthen the EU's resilience should gas supplies stop. Among the most important measures are a reduction in energy demand, an increase in European energy production, further investment in a functioning and fully integrated energy market, as well as diversification of sources of supply, routes and suppliers. The package of measures is important because it is presented following the adoption of the Paris Convention of 12 December 2015, a global agreement to combat climate change. With the adoption of this measure, Parliament reaffirms its commitment to respect for the environment and the protection of the earth's ecosystem.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution that aims to make the EU gas system more diverse and flexible, contributing to the Energy Union objective of a secure, resilient and competitive gas supply, thus taking full advantage of the potential of liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the EU strategy for liquefied natural gas with today's vote because I believe that this resource is vital for the energy security of the whole Union. The targets for reducing greenhouse gases by 2050, increasing import dependency for some Member States to almost 100% and the limited number of suppliers available for these gases are very big challenges for many Member States.  In this context, I believe that the development and commissioning of an EU-wide strategy, which fully integrates both transport and LNG storage systems, is a priority for the EU. THE integration of LNG at Union level will also allow for better long-term management of the resources available at the moment and will provide a better negotiating position on gas imports, which will allow for a lower prices and a greater number of suppliers from secure sources.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the authors of the report that the availability of liquefied natural gas, including supporting pipeline infrastructure, could significantly improve the current security of supply situation, not only in terms of physical but also economic conditions, which would also contribute to more competitive energy prices. This should go hand in hand with ensuring greater diversification and flexibility of the EU gas system. At the same time, rather than building new refill terminals, it would be appropriate to promote the most efficient use of existing LNG terminals, which can also be used across borders, in order to avoid the risk of creating barriers to the use of technologies for non-fossil resources.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because there are some parts of the report which I cannot agree with. A strategy for liquefied natural gas and storage makes no economic sense if Russia is right next to it. All pipelines would have to be led, as the country does not have deep-sea ports.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important to speed up the establishment of energy interconnections between EU Member States and to diversify the range of energy sources, which would help to reduce dependence on non-EU providers.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted. The EU must implement a common and reliable strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and storage of gas, which will help to eliminate energy insulation and reduce the EU's gas dependency in the long term.  In particular, there is a need for better coordination of national energy policies, as further integration of energy policy benefits all Member States, taking into account their interests and the interests of citizens.   It should be noted that the use of existing and planned LNG terminals needs to be used as efficiently as possible. In order to ensure security of gas supply, competitiveness and resilience of the supply system, the EU gas system needs to be diversified and made more flexible.  Particular attention must be paid to the doubling of nord stream pipeline capacity at the bottom of the Baltic Sea and its threat to the eu's overall energy security.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Natural gas is a flexible backup source for renewable sources in electricity generation and the EU must actively pursue the development of its domestic conventional gas resources, such as those discovered in Cyprus. It is important to promote a comprehensive proposal for the exploitation of domestic energy sources, such as, for example, natural gas deposits in the Cypriot EEZ, and to support the creation of a natural gas liquefaction terminal in Cyprus in order to exploit the deposits of the wider region. This report will play a key role in achieving the ultimate objective of a resilient Energy Union. We also call for priority to be given to the production of natural gas in the Mediterranean, Black Sea and Caspian regions, as well as the interconnection of enclosed countries in Central and South-Eastern Europe. Finally, the use of small-scale liquefied natural gas technology in certain sectors, such as long-distance transport or high-efficiency industrial applications, could contribute to climate policy objectives.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The report serves to strengthen the internal capitalist energy market in the EU and the groups active in this field. It reflects the serious contrasts between the urban classes of the Member States and monopolistic groups, in particular vis-à-vis Germany, in relation to the international orientations of their 'energy alliances'. The majority of the capital's political representatives in the European Parliament appear to support the tendency to detox from Russian gas by turning to imports from the USA, which is why it is attacking the Nord Stream, the Russia-Germany submarine pipeline, which serves the business groups of these countries. A similar contrast is currently being expressed for the Russian-Turkish gas pipeline. Investments in transport, distribution, storage, infrastructure, re-gasification plants, etc. focusing on the South-Eastern Mediterranean and cross-venture projects are at the same time new profitable areas for monopolies, as is the use of liquefied natural gas in transport, mainly maritime (but also land). They require the construction of many large infrastructures, issues of serious concern and the shipowner's capital which sees in them new areas of profitable action. At the same time, energy is becoming an expensive, approachable commodity for workers, demonstrating the huge gap that divides popular interests and the designs of EU and urban governments, which are driven solely by the profits of monopolies.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. The report urges Member States to fully implement the Third EU Energy Package. UKIP rejects the implementation of EU energy policy legislation, it is the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal because I believe that gas can play a significant role in the Union's energy system, in industrial production and as a source of heating in buildings and in support of renewable energy. Given that the EU is not yet able to take advantage of the benefits of an integrated internal energy market due to a lack of sufficient interconnections and sufficient coherence and due to the incomplete implementation of the third energy package. Bearing in mind that liquefied gas represents a great opportunity for the EU in terms of greater competitiveness, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the REPORT on the EU Strategy for Blended Natural Gas and Gas Storage. I believe that the future of European energy policy is in the use of energy from renewable energy sources that is not generated by the use of fossil fuels and energy, which will be available to our citizens at appropriate prices. However, to achieve this objective of active work, it is necessary to develop ways that will make the European energy market independent by using different sources of energy supply and from as many different suppliers as possible.  I see LNG as one of the options to keep in mind. The Republic of Croatia has the potential to exploit gas from the Adriatic, which has been successfully working for years in cooperation with Italy. Croatia is proposing a site on the island of Krk to build an LNG terminal. In this way, it can ensure the safe reception and transport of this energy source in central Europe. Also, our possibilities for underground storage of natural gas are also not negligible, both for the stability of the domestic supply system and for the needs of neighbouring Member States.   It is precisely because of these opportunities proposed by this EU Strategy that I ask the newly elected Croatian authorities to start developing a new energy strategy as soon as possible in order to bring Croatia fully in line with the needs of today and to engage in the current flows of European energy and climate policy.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a text very clearly favourable to the gas sector, the development of which should allow for a smooth ecological transition, with good economic prospects at the key, especially in terms of jobs not relocated thanks to biomethane. In this case, the report deals more specifically with the LNG sector, particularly interconnections and storage capacity. It is also about strengthening the diversification of sources and supply routes; however, LNG offers even more flexibility. Nevertheless, the strengthening of the power of the Commission and its agencies in matters of energy policy seems to me to be contrary to the interests of France, as well as the systematic desire to liberalise the energy market. Moreover, the report speaks four times of the EU's 'energy diplomacy': geopolitical orientations which I dispute therefore take a step in the footsteps of any other consideration. For all these reasons, I am voting against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Gas will play an important role in the EU energy system for decades to come. Better coordination of national energy policies, the establishment of a genuine Energy Union with the Single Energy Market and a common energy policy will contribute to energy security. For the functioning of the Energy Union, good member connectivity in terms of pipelines and electricity grids is important.  Support should be provided to the most vulnerable countries in order to diversify their sources and supply routes. The EU should also actively seek to develop its own conventional gas sources, such as those detected in Cyprus. It is important to weaken the EU's dependence on imports of energy from authoritarian regimes that violate human rights, in line with the EU's core values. Significant gas reserves in north African countries and recent discoveries in the eastern Mediterranean give the region the opportunity to transport to a dynamic gas transport hub to Europe. The development of new LNG capabilities in the Mediterranean can be the basis for an infrastructure hub.  The EU, as the world's second largest importer of sequential natural gas in the world, must play a more proactive role in international energy diplomacy, regulation development and foster flexibility and convergence in global gas markets. The ultimate objective is to realise our aspiration to move quickly to a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system and end dependence on greenhouse gas emissions. We want to become a world leader in renewable energy.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is on the EU Strategy for Liquefied Natural Gas and Gas Storage and reflects the most negative aspects of the Union Energy Market. In other words, it favours the dominance of private monopolies, always with large public support, and does not have as its fundamental matrix the public control of these fundamental sectors as a way of ensuring sustainable management of resources and fair access to this fundamental good. On the other hand, it insists on the affront of the Russian Federation, rather than understanding the need for political dialogue and respect for the sovereignty of states.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Natural gas has great potential within the EU energy system and plays an important role in industrial production. I supported the report on the Liquefied Natural Gas Strategy, as it is one of the elements of the proposed Energy Union. This is a further step towards creating an energy system that is sustainable, secure and competitive. In order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to fully exploit the potential of LNG and to make the Union market more attractive to suppliers. A key aspect of the report is, in particular, the recommendations on the creation of the necessary infrastructure, but also the emphasis on the use of existing LNG terminals. The EU should also focus more on working closely with international partners to promote free and transparent global LNG trade. Liquefied natural gas also has great potential to become an alternative fuel to replace more polluting conventional fuels, both in road and maritime transport. However, although natural gas is a cleaner option compared to other fuels and is a flexible advance for electricity production, it should not become a full-fledged substitute for renewables. This is because it is not entirely harmless to the environment and there is still a need to minimise the transient methane emissions that are released throughout its life cycle.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report welcomes the Commission communication entitled 'An EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage'; It considers that an internal energy market that fully integrates liquefied natural gas and gas storage will play a significant role in achieving the ultimate goal of a resilient Energy Union. I believe that the issue of energy security must be the keystone of national energy policies and the EU's common strategy and that cooperation between Member States in this area must be applied in accordance with the principles of solidarity and trust. I believe it is necessary for Parliament to approve the following report because I am convinced that an internal energy market that fully integrates liquefied natural gas and gas storage will certainly have a positive impact on the EU economy and industrial policies. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This own-initiative report builds on the Commission's communication entitled 'EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage'. It should be seen as a guide with a set of key instruments on how to unlock the potential of LNG and gas storage in order to achieve the objective of a strong Energy Union and complete the internal energy market.  During the negotiations, a balanced compromise focused on LNG and gas storage issues was maintained. The S&D, ALDE and Greens have tried to extend the scope of this report by adding strands on energy efficiency, renewable energy sources and shale gas. The aim was to extend the scope of this report to undermine the future role of LNG and gas storage. Although the text adopted in the ITRE Committee is balanced, references to binding energy and climate targets for 2030 are still present. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I must appreciate from this point that the resolution contains criticism of the increase in the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline. That is why I support this resolution in the vote.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is a cooled natural gas, making it easier to store and transport, with one-third of the world's LNG gas transiting. Its advantages are multiple: reduced geopolitical problems because LNG does not pass through traditional pipelines, reduced isolation and energy dependence, increased cleanliness when it comes to fuel (less CO2, SOx and NOx). I voted for this text, which shows that an internal energy market fully integrated with LNG will contribute to the emergence of an efficient Energy Union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the European Union's Strategy for Liquefied Natural Gas and Gas Storage is part of the European Commission's Communication of February 2016 on the winter energy package.  In order to ensure that the objective of a resilient Energy Union is meeting, the rapporteur believes that a single energy market should integrate liquefied natural gas and gas storage. The priority should be to create market-based solutions and use existing liquefied natural gas infrastructure at regional level.  I believe that the most effective way of ensuring energy security is to better coordinate national energy policies, as well as the establishment of a genuine Energy Union, with a genuine single energy market, and a common energy policy, as well as cooperation between Member States in this area, in accordance with the principles of solidarity and trust.  I support this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against this non-legislative report on EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. The report urges Member States to fully implement the Third EU Energy Package. UKIP rejects the implementation of EU energy policy legislation, it is the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted favourably because I believe that liquefied natural gas (LNG) provides an opportunity for Europe, both in terms of increasing competitiveness, putting downward pressure on natural gas prices and increasing security of supply and also constitutes a flexible reserve for renewable energy in the context of electricity production. Current developments in international LNG markets show that oversupply has led to a reduction in prices and is an opportunity to offer energy at lower costs to EU consumers through cheaper gas supplies. Furthermore, the report advocates an LNG supply station in the Azores, which reinforced my positive vote. The most effective way to ensure energy security is to better coordinate national energy policies and establish a genuine Energy Union with a genuine single energy market and a common energy policy, as well as cooperation between Member States in this area, in accordance with the principles of solidarity and trust.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Let's put it this way, it is regrettable that the European Union uses only 20% of its liquefied natural gas (LNG) import capacity. Diversifying its sources of supply is always a win-win choice in the long run. Of course, there are objective reasons for this situation, such as the uneven distribution of LNG terminal locations on European territory. This should not prevent the Union from developing a genuine strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. A political choice to be made if it wants to be more competitive and less dependent tomorrow, especially with regard to Russian gas. The Gy-rk report adopted this afternoon also underlines the importance for the Union to begin this rapid transition to a sustainable energy system. But this LNG race must not be done without precaution or control. We all know that natural gas is a fossil fuel that can emit significant amounts of methane harmful to the ozone layer. This is a reason, if any, to include the Energy Union's strategy within the broader framework of the Paris climate agreement' objectives, with a focus on reducing demand and improving energy efficiency.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I share the balanced vision on the European strategy for liquefied natural gas (LNG) that we adopted in the ITRE Commission. The report reflects both the situation and potential of LNG, taking into account its contribution to energy security in Europe and the benefits of a more competitive market. In addition, the LNG strategy is particularly relevant from the perspective of its qualities in reducing current environmental impacts, such as alternative fuel in transport, heating and electricity.  I understand that LNG, as an energy source with emissions significantly lower than other fossil fuels and other natural gas sources, should not be penalized by labels that raise suspicions about its cleanness, questioning the opportunities and advantages of our companies worldwide. While the possible importation of LNG from fracking deserves more detailed attention under our international agreements. In short, I believe that Europe must develop a firm commitment to LNG, as it is a source of energy beneficial to the European environment, economy and society. So the report deserved my vote in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Union's liquefied natural gas strategy, which makes a series of recommendations to this effect. However, I would like to take this opportunity to reiterate my position on shale gas. As it stands, I strongly oppose the extraction of this gas given the adverse effects on the environment and citizens.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The question has a dual meaning. On the one hand, the report itself should be seen as written from a purely economic perspective, without taking into account the environmental impact of the increase in natural gas use. It is a pity that the rapporteur has failed to take into account the constructive proposals of the Greens.  On the other hand, the report highlights the very important issue of energy independence and identifies prospects for the creation of a natural gas market. This is particularly important for energy markets still separate from the rest of the EU, such as the Baltic states. Because of this divide between the irresponsible attitude of the rapporteur on the environmental impact of the issue, but at the same time, I cannot vote against or in favour of the very correct approach to the actualities of the natural gas market.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the European Union Strategy for Liquefied Natural Gas and Gas Storage. Specifically on the case of the Azores which, because of its condition and geostrategic importance, may prove to be an important location for the implementation of a fuel station for transatlantic liquefied natural gas routes and that is precisely the purpose of this report, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission to make available funds to support European projects that are capable of creating a common blue LNG corridor project for the islands. In terms of European strategy in this area, the importance of adopting alternative solutions to the current cost-effective and environmentally sustainable energy supply is highlighted. It is also important to stress that these solutions will ensure long-term supply throughout the European continent and particularly in the Iberian Peninsula and thus reduce the energy insulation currently existing.  To that extent, I believe that LNG can function as a good alternative fuel solution, both at sea level or at road level, and also contributing to reducing emissions of harmful gases into the atmosphere, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012Voto against the own-initiative report on liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage, because it promotes, on the basis of market operation, the construction of new LNG, gas pipeline and gas storage terminals. Therefore, the promotion of gas use is at odds with the Union's climate objectives, as natural gas emits methane, a gas that has a heating potential 86 times greater than CO2. The energy security of the East and Baltic countries is not to replace imports of Russian gas with gas from other supposedly safer countries (even sometimes from fracking) but by a clear commitment to improving energy efficiency and developing renewables.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage, as an internal energy market, in which liquefied natural gas and gas storage are fully integrated, will play an essential role in the objective of a resilient energy supply. Priority is given to the use of the existing liquefied natural gas infrastructure at regional level.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, because this Strategic Union commitment on liquefied natural gas is a strengthening of energy dependence and environmental destruction. Rather than reinforcing the commitment to renewable energy and indigenous sources of energy production, the Union continues on the path of global resource hoarding, the same logic of oil applied to gas. Another aspect is the importation of gas through destructive techniques such as fracking, but it is no more serious than the international conflicts developed around this resource, the liquefaction of which allows its transport through smaller infrastructures. Gas is a fossil fuel with a high level of emissions and only benefits large multinationals that control its distribution. Because we need a balanced transition from the Union's energy production to renewable energy, that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage as it is an important pillar to strengthen the EU’s energy security. While increasing security of energy supply, the EU strategy for LNG should crucially fit into the wider European climate and energy targets and priorities, and correspond to the COP21 Agreement, putting a focus on reducing demand, improving energy efficiency and phasing out fossil fuels.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In February this year, the Commission came up with a strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage, following estimates that the global supply of liquefied natural gas is expected to double in the coming years. As many EU countries still do not have their energy resources diversified, I supported this strategy. LNG gas can provide an opportunity for the EU to improve security of gas supply and increase resilience in cases of shortages. On the other hand, Member States should be aware that LNG is only a temporary solution. In the long term, Europe will need to reduce its dependence on gas consumption in order for the EU to meet the climate and energy targets to which it committed itself in the Paris Climate Agreement. The liquefied gas strategy itself foresees that the Commission will support the establishment of gas storage centres, for example in the Mediterranean. This should invest in LNG and gas infrastructure. LNG is also envisaged as an alternative fuel that could replace conventional fossil fuels in both road and maritime transport. However, it will be paramount that Europe is prepared for an increase in LNG supplies. It will therefore be necessary to improve the use of the current gas infrastructure and to pave the way for its expansion.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The field of management of natural resources, especially fuels, is very important for the environment. The report ignores reality in large part and does not contribute to the planned phasing-out of the use of fossil fuels.  On the contrary– it promotes the expansion of the use and storage of gas and related infrastructure, which represents a heavy financial burden for public coffers throughout the European Union. In the spirit of the recently signed Paris Climate Agreement, the whole of Europe should step forward and focus on environmentally sustainable resources and, consequently, invest in a "European energy transition".  The EU Strategy for LNG and Gas Storage is part of a so-called gas package published by the European Commission in February 2015. The report focuses more or less on the Commission's plan to treat gas as an environmentally sustainable and sustainable resource, but does not mention the Paris climate agreement and the European Union's energy and environment objectives. For this is why I voted against the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is our priority to look for new, efficient and environmentally friendly energy raw materials and thus reduce our dependence on Russia. We need to build new pumping terminals, storage facilities and invest in the development of infrastructure and penetration of cars for this type of propulsion in the European Union.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on an 'EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage'. The report is based on the assumption that CO2 emissions must be reduced because of supposedly man-made climate change. The report also classifies as worrying that 7% more gas was imported from Russia in 2015 than in 2014 and that 41% of gas imports from third countries came from Russia in 2015, while pointing out that the world market price for liquefied natural gas was relatively high and that the terminals needed for liquefied natural gas were barely utilized. Basically, it is a question of reducing the cheaper market alternative for liquefied natural gas in order to import less gas from Russia. The report then draws the wrong conclusion from this, to subsidise the lack of infrastructure conditions. However, with all due respect to countermeasures against a potential monopoly provider, subsidies are the wrong conclusion.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is the world's second largest importer of sequential natural gas in the world, so a more proactive policy in international energy diplomacy and better coordination of national energy policies is important for equal affordability of energy supply. The EU Strategy for Sequestered Natural Gas and Gas Storage contributes to the European Union's objective of moving to a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system as soon as possible, as well as to make the EU as competitive as possible on renewable energy globally. I support the report on the EU Strategy for Sequestered Natural Gas and Gas Storage by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for LNG and gas storage. I support the Commission's strategy of supporting the use of LNG as an alternative fuel to conventional transport fuel, which is a major polluter.  I support the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, which stresses that the EU strategy for LNG should be consistent with the framework strategy for a resilient Energy Union and that it should support greater security of energy supply.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. The report includes positive reports. It is stressed that the exploitation of deposits in the Cypriot EEZ and the creation of a liquefaction terminal in Cyprus should be supported. It also stresses the need to ensure the right of access to affordable energy and to combat energy poverty. However, negative reports are included. While energy policy-making now falls within the competence of the Member States, the EU aims to have a common energy policy and to speak with one voice, which will of course serve specific interests. The proposal for institutional convergence and synergy of the Union's foreign policy with the common energy policy to be imposed on The States is also problematic. The aim is to make energy a tool of foreign policy and not part of a development policy to improve the quality of life. We do not want energy to serve the needs of the market with TTIP-type agreements, as proposed in the report, nor to be used to strengthen the dominant circles of the EU. We are fighting for energy to be guaranteed as a public social good, to which we will all have equal and cheap access. We call for enhanced state control, public infrastructure and international cooperation on the basis of mutual benefit, parity and solidarity. For these reasons, we have abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report, with the exception of a few points, is not in the interests of the European peoples, but instead promotes further rupture with Russia and unpopular agreements with the United States and, more generally, moves within the same framework of the deadlocked policies it pursues in general.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the International Energy Agency, the golden age of natural gas could come in the coming decades. Partly because of the development of the international market and partly because of the advantageous properties of natural gas, the role of natural gas in national energy mixes is expected to increase. As the cleanest fossil energy source, it is able to replace much more polluting fuels in both electricity generation and transport, thereby contributing to decarbonisation. Imports of liquefied natural gas may provide a solution to the expected significant reduction in production within the Union or lead to diversification of resources in Member States that depend on a supplier. The EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and storage is part of the Energy Union winter package. It aims to make the natural gas system more diversified and flexible, thereby contributing to a safer, more predictable and competitive supply of natural gas. The report points out that increasing the utilization of existing infrastructure is a top priority, but that the necessary new investments should also be made where necessary. In order to increase efficiency, we must pay particular attention to European gas storage facilities. It is also necessary to build and bidirectional the associated wiring network, in particular with regard to missing inter-outlets, and to apply appropriate transport tariffs. The necessary improvements could benefit gas diversification and gas competition outside the host countries. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has stated that it is crucial to resolve the situation in vulnerable Member States.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree that liquefied natural gas reduces our dependence on conventional natural gas channels, but I fear that the approach offers only a short-term solution. I believe that, fundamentally, we should strengthen carbon-free energy production and energy efficiency. I agree that we should address this issue at EU level, but the report is not clear. On the one hand, it calls for action and investment at EU level and, on the other hand, it only occasionally urges caution. I consider the sustainability or energy efficiency logic to be low, even if this has changed somewhat in a positive direction at the final vote (e.g. by better emphasising the Paris climate agreement). Reducing dependence on some vendors is necessary and can lead to price decreases. I did not agree with the report's recommendation that the Union should provide the necessary infrastructure. I believe that it is unnecessary to spend billions of euros on a project that is likely to be replaced by renewable energy sources in a few decades' time. Instead of investing in fossil fuels, we should devote our resources to alternative energy sources.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In February 2016, the European Commission published a Communication on an EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage as part of the Sustainable Energy Security Package. The Commission believes that improving eu Member States' access to liquefied natural gas imports, as well as more efficient cross-border gas storage, will help to increase security of supply and reduce dependence on gas from a single supplier and enable Member States to benefit from low global LNG prices. The EP report on the EU liquefied natural gas strategy rightly draws attention to the need to create an internal market or to strengthen cooperation with international partners in order to create a genuine global LNG market. Parliament referred to the need for new infrastructure more carefully than the Commission in its proposal. There was a risk of stranded assets, excess storage capacity and additional import capacity. The report expresses particular concern about the EU's dependence on Gas from Russia and criticises the proposed Nord Stream II project. Reducing Europe's dependence on energy imports, especially from one eastern direction, should be a key element in building the European Union's energy security. In such a situation, it is difficult to regard the Nord Stream II gas pipeline as an investment in line with the interests of the Community, the foundations of the Energy Union and the European Energy Security Strategy.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is in favour of fossil fuels and completely neglects the issues of strategic dependence, and infrastructure lock-in, made even more perverse by the considerable degree of under-utilise of existing European structures that on average are used at 25%. It is also based on projections of eu consumption of gases basically supplied by ENTSO gas, which are manifestly exaggerated, which are even criticised by the European Court of Auditors. It raises hopes of a hypothetical re-flowering of the US shale gas market to flood the European market. It presents gas as a relatively clean fuel, neglecting the problems of leaks with the corresponding (very reinforced) greenhouse effect, and the great problems of unconventional extraction methods. In short, the report is simply unapproachable, which justifies our firm vote against.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the world's leading energy consumers. In these circumstances, Member States need the most efficient combination of energy sources, including liquefied natural gas (LNG). This source has been on the rise in recent years, offering appreciable quantities at an ever-lower price and with a low pollutant effect.  The EU has a significant infrastructure of gas pipelines, storage depots and regasification terminals, but it needs to be streamlined and complemented where necessary, in order to allow all Member States easy access to this resource and to avoid dependence on a single energy source or vulnerability to changes in international markets. The use of LNG would also lead to the replacement of traditional pollutant fuels in road and maritime transport.  The EU could promote a free, functioning and transparent LNG market at international level. At the same time, however, this must not affect the development of renewable energy sources and the Union's objective of reducing emissions of polluting gases. I believe that this is an important development in this area, providing a temporary solution to replace polluting energy resources.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted, in the end, in favour of the proposal on an EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. However, I spoke out against the paragraphs and amendments that promoted the extraction and importation of shale gas.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In February 2016 the Commission published a communication on an ‘EU strategy for liquefied natural gas  (LNG) and gas storage’ as part of its sustainable energy security package. The Commission considers that improving the access of EU Member States to imports of LNG, as well as developing more effective cross-border gas storage, would help to increase security of gas supply, reduce dependence on a single supplier, and allow the EU to take advantage of low global prices for LNG. I consider the EP report by András Gyurk to be a balanced and comprehensive one. I however do not support plenary Amendment 2, which calls for complete phasing out of gas in the long term. I consider gas to a be an important part of the EU’s energy mix. Moreover, gas can play a big role as a flexibility option complementary to development of RES. Therefore I decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Discussing energy and promoting European development and coordination policies are central actions for security of supply and the fight against climate change. When we invest in energy we are investing in our future. Liquefied natural gas, given its unique characteristics, has been the subject of an increasing interest rate from a commercial and geopolitical point of view. That is why I believe it is essential for the EU to have a strategy in this area. I also believe that a long-term sustainable energy mix, in addition to renewables, can only include natural gas, which, because of its characteristics and its wide availability, is fundamental to the full achievement of the post-COP21 climate targets.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the International Energy Agency, the golden age of natural gas could come in the coming decades. Partly because of the development of the international market and partly because of the advantageous properties of natural gas, the role of natural gas in national energy mixes is expected to increase. As the cleanest fossil energy source, it is able to replace much more polluting fuels in both electricity generation and transport, thereby contributing to decarbonisation. Imports of liquefied natural gas may provide a solution to the expected significant reduction in production within the Union or lead to diversification of resources in Member States that depend on a supplier. The EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and storage is part of the Energy Union winter package. It aims to make the natural gas system more diversified and flexible, thereby contributing to a safer, more predictable and competitive supply of natural gas. The report points out that increasing the utilization of existing infrastructure is a top priority, but that the necessary new investments should also be made where necessary. In order to increase efficiency, we must pay particular attention to European gas storage facilities. It is also necessary to build and bidirectional the associated wiring network, in particular with regard to missing inter-outlets, and to apply appropriate transport tariffs. The necessary improvements could benefit gas diversification and gas competition outside the host countries. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has stated that it is crucial to resolve the situation in vulnerable Member States.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The Report on the European Union Strategy for Blended Natural Gas and Gas Storage contains many useful determinants such as increasing energy security, integrating the European energy market, energy efficiency, decarbonising the economy and research, innovation and competitiveness.  I also agree with recognising the importance of using natural gas as an alternative fuel in transport and calling for close cooperation between national and regional operators to improve the multifunctionality and usability of infrastructure in maritime and river ports. But I cannot agree with the call for binding climate and energy targets for 2030. Since the targets under which greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union would be reduced by 40%, the share of renewable energy would be at least 30% and energy efficiency would increase by 40% I consider unichievable, I voted abstained.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the EU strategy for LNG and gas storage. The internal energy market will fully include LNG and gas storage, and will play an important role in achieving the ultimate objective of a solid Energy Union.  The EU LNG strategy must be consistent with the Framework Strategy for a Resilient Energy Union and must therefore support greater security of energy supply, decarbonisation, long-term sustainability of the economy and ensuring affordable and competitive energy prices.  The EU's gas system must become more diverse and flexible, contributing to the key objective of the Energy Union, that is, a reliable, resilient and competitive gas supply. Parliament calls on the Commission to develop a strategy to reduce the EU's dependence on gas imports in the long term, reflecting its commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 80-95% by 2050 from 1990 levels.  LNG has the potential of alternative fuels in road and maritime transport and the wider use of LNG in the transport of goods, in particular the wider use of LNG engines in maritime transport, could contribute to reducing global CO2, SOx and NOx emissions.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against the own initiative report on liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage, because it promotes, on the basis of market operation, the construction of new LNG, gas pipeline and gas storage terminals. Therefore, the promotion of gas use is at odds with the Union's climate objectives, as natural gas emits methane, a gas that has a heating potential 86 times greater than CO2. The energy security of the East and Baltic countries is not to replace imports of Russian gas with gas from other supposedly safer countries (even sometimes from fracking) but by a clear commitment to improving energy efficiency and developing renewables.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. – I fully support the use of LNG as an alternative source of gas supply, which contributes to the EU's energy security. Unfortunately, the adopted report contains a reference to binding energy-climate targets and other elements that mean a shift away from the balanced report. That's why I couldn't support her.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal for a more competitive energy strategy in Europe, as the diversification of energy sources and the interconnection of gas infrastructures will make a single integrated market and therefore the harmonisation of tariffs and reduction invoices to consumers. It is therefore important that all Member States comply with the third energy package, especially in the security of gas storage. In this sense I hope that this proposal will avoid any other case in Europe as the ‘Castor project’, that seem to not comply environmental or seismic regulations, and even that, this useless gas storage will have to be paid by Spanish consumers. To be successful, Member States have to finish the remaining infrastructure, invest more in R&D for LNG is an alternative fuel for transport, heat and electricity and complete the internal gas market: commercial, legal and regulatory aspects.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In this text, the rapporteur makes good recommendations, such as favouring domestic energy sources or promoting liquefied biogas. However, the rapporteur points out that the European Union must decide our energy policy in the name of energy diplomacy. This is unacceptable and highly critical, especially since this energy diplomacy targets US shale gas and Qatari liquefied natural gas against Russian sources, historical and reliable sources. So I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Lng terminals are an important building block of the European Union's internal energy market, providing yet another source of natural gas supply. This increases the energy security of Member States and their citizens. The potential of LNG is already demonstrated by the already operating terminals in Klaipeda and Świnoujście, among others. A coherent EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and storage is therefore needed. However, it cannot be helped not to notice that the report in question goes beyond this objective, referring to the binding energy and climate targets for 2030. For this reason, I have decided to vote against the report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 All EU citizens must have access to a secure and affordable energy supply. I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012Voto against the own-initiative report on liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage, because it promotes, on the basis of market operation, the construction of new LNG, gas pipeline and gas storage terminals. Therefore, the promotion of gas use is at odds with the Union's climate objectives, as natural gas emits methane, a gas that has a heating potential 86 times greater than CO2. The energy security of the East and Baltic countries is not to replace imports of Russian gas with gas from other supposedly safer countries (even sometimes from fracking) but by a clear commitment to improving energy efficiency and developing renewables.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which I believe is strongly neglecting reality (Paris Agreement, structural shift in gas demand due to successful EE/RES policies). Instead of tackling the truly needed phase out of fossil fuels, it very much promotes the expansion of liquefied natural gas and related infrastructure and supports paying for it out of tax payers’ pockets. Continued reliance on fossil fuels, like coal and gas, unnecessarily delays and makes much more expensive the transition to a renewable and efficient energy future.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Natural gas will play an important role at least in the coming decades for EU energy and industry, the integration of RES and the shift to a low-carbon economy based on clean energy sources. The EU's dependence on natural gas imports is growing and alternative sources and supply routes are needed to ensure energy security. In the field of transport without natural gas, an environmental breakthrough is unlikely to take place. This requires us to strategically look at liquefied gas and gas storage as an element of our security, competitiveness and manageability of our energy dependency. I therefore fully support the ideas proposed in the report to take account of the accessibility to LNG terminals in eu cross-border infrastructure gas projects, the most efficient use of existing infrastructure, a regional and geographically balanced approach in prioritising projects. It is obvious that we will neither reduce our dependence on the dominant supplier nor will we be able to build a market with competitive opportunities if liquefied gas and storage do not play a stronger role in the creation of the single gas market. I also support strong texts relating to the potential of liquefied gas as an alternative fuel for land and waterborne transport, which can easily contribute to reducing harmful emissions from transport.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on EU strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. Gas can play an important role in the EU energy system for the coming decades, in industrial production and as a source of heat in buildings and as a support to renewable energy while the EU meets its targets on greenhouse gas emissions, energy efficiency and renewables and makes the transition to a low-carbon economy in which the role of gas will gradually decrease in favour of clean energies.  The report underlines that all EU citizens must have access to a secure and affordable energy supply and that an EU strategy for liquefied natural gas must be consistent with the framework strategy for a resilient Energy Union, so as to contribute to increased security of energy supply, decarbonisation, the long-term sustainability of the economy and the delivery of affordable and competitive energy prices. I voted in favour because I believe that finding cost-efficient and environmentally sustainable solutions should be a key principle in reaching the EU and regional optimum.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The global liquefied natural gas market is undergoing a high-dynamic phase, with the global supply of this form of energy expected to increase by 50% by 2020. In addition, supply conditions are shifting from indexed long-term contracts to the price of oil to spot markets with referenced prices. The Union can benefit from the expansion of the gas market in order to strengthen its security of supply and competitiveness. To harness its full potential, this document suggests completing Community gas infrastructures so that all Member States can access it, as well as working on shaping the internal gas market, while promoting free, liquid and transparent global markets. From the full consideration that market integration offers potential advantages for security of supply, as well as for the convergence of regional energy prices, I support with my vote moving towards a fully functional and integrated internal gas market.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, because this Strategic Union commitment on liquefied natural gas is a strengthening of energy dependence and environmental destruction. Rather than reinforcing the commitment to renewable energy and indigenous sources of energy production, the Union continues on the path of global resource hoarding, the same logic of oil applied to gas. Another aspect is the importation of gas through destructive techniques such as fracking, but it is no more serious than the international conflicts developed around this resource, the liquefaction of which allows its transport through smaller infrastructures. Gas is a fossil fuel with a high level of emissions and only benefits large multinationals that control its distribution. Because we need a balanced transition from the Union's energy production to renewable energy, that is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained from voting on the Gyürk report. The delegation is convinced that LNG will play a crucial role in the European Energy Union in the coming years. Firstly, to ensure energy security. LNG enables us to diversify more with regard to our energy suppliers, and is a good alternative to other conventional energy sources for less accessible regions. Secondly, the delegation wishes to stress the importance of LNG and gas for the transition to a low-carbon society. Gas and LNG, if used properly, have significant environmental benefits compared to more polluting conventional sources, such as coal. Unfortunately, the text goes against the council's agreements on the 2030 targets. By setting the bar unrealistically high, Parliament is demonstrating how little it feels about the current economic, global and social realities. Moreover, the Nord Stream 2 project is being revisited, even though it has been made very clear that no European rules are being violated. It is purely a commercial agreement between different private companies.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the EU strategy for LNG and gas storage was voted on today. I am in favour of abandoning fossil fuels in the long term, but the report proposed an end to the use of gas in the long term, including biogas, which is important to Finland. I couldn't support this show. I also regard the Nord Stream 2 project, which was mentioned in the report, as an environmental issue, according to which I also voted.  My own views did not prevail on content issues, so that is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is on the EU Strategy for Liquefied Natural Gas and Gas Storage and reflects the most negative aspects of the Union Energy Market. In other words, it favours the dominance of private monopolies, always with large public support, and does not have as its fundamental matrix the public control of these fundamental sectors as a way of ensuring sustainable management of resources and fair access to this fundamental good. On the other hand, this hysteria persists against the Russian Federation, rather than understanding the need for political dialogue and respect for the sovereignty of states.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report has two key aspects here. On the one hand, the cross-border development of gas storage facilities is to become one of the key instruments for the implementation of the principle of energy solidarity in the event of a gas shortage and an emergency crisis. Secondly, strategies will be found to support facilities that can be used in the future to manage the transmission and storage of natural gas. However, since I consider the critical attitude, particularly with regard to the 'Nordstream project', to be a very bad solution, as I believe that Russia remains an important partner, particularly in matters relating to trade in liquefied natural gas, I voted against the report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The strategy discussed in plenary is a very important step towards the creation of a well-functioning Energy Union, a project of which Poland was, moreover, one of the originators. I am very pleased that it clearly highlights the potential doubling of the capacity of the Nord Stream gas pipeline, as this will only increase the EU's dependence on a single gas supplier, Russia.  With this in mind, liquefied natural gas (LNG) represents an opportunity to diversify gas supplies and thus increase the EU's energy security. The new EU strategy aims to facilitate the construction not only of LNG terminals, but also of an auxiliary pipeline infrastructure between Member States, which is one of the key tools for implementing the principle of energy solidarity in times of gas scarcity. On the other hand, 195 such projects have been identified by the Commission as of common interest and can be financially supported by the European Fund for Strategic Investments.  This is particularly important for Member States in central, eastern and southern Europe, which, unlike those in the western PART of the EU, do not have an extensive LNG infrastructure and are therefore most often dependent on a single supplier and are exposed to gas supply disruptions. I therefore supported the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage in today's vote.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the creation of an Energy Union and the integration of an energy policy. I support the reduction of gas dependency and the cutting of CO2 emissions. Moreover there have to be binding climate and energy targets and Ukraine should become more independent from Russian gas, possibly through switching to LNG. Investments for LNG infrastructures should be private and there should be a full implementation of the third energy package. I agree with the EU’s more active engagement in energy diplomacy. Gas is a really important resource and widely used in the region. That’s why a common plan and discussion are really important.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the report on the European strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage. With this strategy, we want to ensure access to liquid gas markets for all Member States, considerably expanding the range of gas suppliers. An attempt is therefore being made to improve European energy security, firstly by further diversifying our sources of supply and, secondly, by ensuring adequate flexibility in the system through the use of storage mechanisms. In the text approved by the House, I find numerous priorities of the S&D Group such as the need to ensure a more efficient use of existing infrastructures and the need to avoid non-recoverable assets (the so-called "Stranded Assets") i.e. infrastructure investments that lose their value prematurely because they are obsolete and non-performing. I will conclude by reaffirming my perplexity, which can also be seen in the approved report, with regard to the project to double the Nord Stream gas pipeline. This project, in my view, would increase Europe's dependence on Russian gas and call into question our security of energy supply.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report serves to strengthen the internal capitalist energy market in the EU and the groups active in this field. It reflects the serious contrasts between the urban classes of the Member States and monopolistic groups, in particular vis-à-vis Germany, in relation to the international orientations of their 'energy alliances'. The majority of the capital's political representatives in the European Parliament appear to support the tendency to detox from Russian gas by turning to imports from the USA, which is why it is attacking the Nord Stream, the Russia-Germany submarine pipeline, which serves the business groups of these countries. A similar contrast is currently being expressed for the Russian-Turkish gas pipeline. Investments in transport, distribution, storage, infrastructure, re-gasification plants, etc. focusing on the South-Eastern Mediterranean and cross-venture projects are at the same time new profitable areas for monopolies, as is the use of liquefied natural gas in transport, mainly maritime (but also land). They require the construction of many large infrastructures, issues of serious concern and the capital of the shipowner, which sees in them new areas of profitable action. At the same time, energy is becoming an expensive, approachable commodity for workers, demonstrating the huge gap that divides popular interests and the designs of EU and urban governments, which are driven solely by the profits of monopolies.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: Written. 'The EU's strategy of spending money on gas storage undermines member states' freedom to determine their own 'energy mix' guaranteed by the Treaty. After all, the budget is an integral part of that freedom. The PVV has therefore voted against.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the European Union's strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage is largely related to the problem we are facing more and more, namely the provision of a resilient Energy Union. Ideally, Member States should have more energy sources and should not be dependent on a single foreign supplier. That is why the report raises questions about liquefied natural gas. As an alternative to traditional energy sources, this can bring not only greater energy diversity, but also an environmentally sustainable energy source. That is why I believe that we should at least make a qualified discussion on this subject and carefully consider all its pros and cons while ensuring the highest environmental protection.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Gyürk report, for which I have submitted several proposals adopted as rapporteur for the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage within the Committee on the Environment, Health and Food Safety, to ensure diversification and energy security and to support a sustainable transition to an energy model based on renewable and clean energy. In this area, I would like to highlight the recommendation I have made to the report so that the Azores Archipelago, due to its geographical location, can function as an important fuel station for transatlantic shipping routes and for the Commission to make support funds available to European projects such as the above and to create a joint project of blue LNG corridors for the islands.   I would also like to point out the amendments tabled by the Socialist group to align the report with the targets set in Paris and the phasing-out of the use of natural gas to achieve these targets, without prejudice to the continued commitment to biogas which should play a decisive role in the EU's future energy mix. I regret that the wording of the amendments has not been more explicit in this regard.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. With this report, Parliament is calling on the European Commission to reduce the EU's dependence on gas supplies in the long term. However, the report is in favour of the use of fossil fuels and completely neglects to consider all issues of geopolitical strategic dependence and infrastructure lock-in. The report itself was conceived on the back of projections of eu consumption of gas supplied mainly by ENTSO gas, the same as those that have been strongly criticised by the Court of Auditors for exaggeration in numbers. Gas is presented as a relatively clean fuel without taking into account the whole problem created by leaks that significantly increase the greenhouse effect and unconventional extraction methods such as fracking, which certainly cannot be described as sustainable. An approach of this kind could only find my vote against.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the Report on the EU Strategy for LNG and Gas Storage.  As the Report notes, the EU is still unable to fully reap the benefits of an integrated internal energy market, both due to insufficient links and coherence and the incomplete implementation of the third energy package.  The EU's LNG strategy and gas storage is one element of the Energy Union, which aims to move the EU to a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system. Among other things, the report calls for smart investments in the energy sector, optimal exploitation of existing LNG terminals and the upgrading of missing infrastructure.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 A few months after the revision of the fisheries control regulation, the aim of the own-initiative report is to formulate the European Parliament's position on the subject. There are profound differences of control between Member States, but also between different fishing areas, which contribute to creating a feeling of injustice among those in the sector. In this regard, the rapporteur proposes several measures, including greater training of fishermen in terms of control and sanctions, the need to make controls against illegal fishing, the importance of the collection of quality data and a general simplification of the rules more homogeneous and effective, including through the use of new technologies. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it draws attention to the need to homogenise fisheries controls in the Union, establishing a single reference framework, and promoting identical sanctions in all Member States for identical infringements. The control of fisheries in the Union differs from one Member State to another, with differences in the procedures and types of sanctions applied for the same type of infringements , in some cases administrative and other criminal cases – differences in the level of resources used, lack of specialised inspectors, databases not always interchangeable between Member States Etc. The lack of approved treatment of fisheries controls creates a certain sense of inefficiency and injustice in the sector. To address this, inter alia, this report proposes the adoption of common control criteria, strengthening the role of the European Fisheries Agency, using greater resources and more modern means to provide more effective inspections or promoting European training of inspectors and fishermen.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against this non-legislative report because ‘one size does not fit all’ and it will extend the EU’s Kafkaesque fisheries bureaucracy to anglers and recreational fishing.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report submitted by the Committee on Fisheries for approval by the Plenary of the European Parliament contains many positive aspects: the recognition of discriminatory treatment in the conduct of controls within the sector, the non-adequacy of some of the European standards to reality, the defence of regional or autonomous community inspections for inland waters , national maritime fishing inspections in waters up to 12 nautical miles and Union inspections for the rest of the waters.  However, I abstained since the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring; the introduction of a point-based sanctions system, with implications for fishing licences. At the same time, the report reflects high centralisation and a Definition at Community level of technical and policy measures related to controls rather than cooperation between Member States, so I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained on supporting the inclusion of the reference to the impact of recreational fisheries into the revised Control Regulation as it raised concerns as it is not clear what that would entail. The report also states that it is against any mandatory video surveillance on board for all vessels.  While we believe that small-scale local fishermen are being criminalised by the state, especially in light of the unjustifiable raid earlier last month on fishermen in Castletowenbere in Cork, and that they should be excluded from such mandatory surveillance considering their low impact on stocks, we have still nonetheless called for increased surveillance regarding foreign operators of large scale industrial vessels such as supertrawlers fishing in Irish waters, so we cannot support that wording within the report. The report also reflects a high centralisation and an EU-level definition of the technical and political measures related to controls, which I oppose, rather than cooperation between Member States. These are the reasons why we abstained on the final vote.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. It is common to hear fishermen complain that fisheries controls are less stringent among neighbours. This sense of injustice raises an essential question. While the regulation is European, how can we accept that its application is not? A few months before the revision of the Fisheries Control Regulation, it was useful for the European Parliament to take up this issue. The aim is to highlight the flaws in the application of the rules which lead to a sense of unfairness and to propose solutions to harmonize the control of the common fisheries policy, one of the most integrated in Europe.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the report on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform, because I believe that simpler, more comprehensive and consistent legislation should be made a priority, while aimed at increasing transparency, cooperation, innovation and the protection of labour and environmental standards.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. There is a need to standardise fisheries control in order to sustainably manage living marine resources and ensure a level playing field among EU fleets. This report has been prepared in preparation for the forthcoming control regulation and calls, among other things, on the Member States to ensure the effective implementation of the control regulation. I voted in favour of this report because cooperation between local, regional and national authorities and EU agencies is important in order to make control more effective. What still stands in the way of the harmonisation of control capabilities is the lack of interoperability between the data collected at national level. In future, data exchange should take place in real time and in consultation with the EFCA and the Member States. To this end, the mandate of the EFCA should also be strengthened.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Some of the report's proposals are positive: for example, the implementation of economic sanctions, such as the ban on going out to sea, rather than criminal, equivalent controls on imported products and boats from third countries fishing in European waters, joint training of fishing inspectors, improving fishermen's information, exchanging data in all member countries or integrating a representative of the European Parliament into the European Parliament AECP. Other proposals are, on the contrary, unacceptable: this is the case of the generalisation of a points permit, even harmonised, and the increase in the budget of the AECP, mainly to recruit new agents. It is feared that many valid proposals will never be implemented (e.g. equivalent controls on imported products), while the most restrictive proposals will be. In general, this report is part of an ever closer monitoring logic of fishermen: these, between the multiple declarations, electronic and satellite instruments, the checks on board or at the landing, are closely monitored. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The title of this report says it all. Fisheries should not be under EU control and one size certainly does not suit UK fishermen. The report also wishes to bring in uniform regulation across the EU for recreational fishing.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Common Fisheries Policy is one of the most integrated policies in Europe. I voted in favour of this text because the control of fishermen in Europe must be done in a homogeneous way in order to be effective.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the unification of fisheries control in Europe.
