Fishermen often complain that fisheries control is much stricter than that of other fishermen, either in another Member State or in other fisheries. I therefore agree that EU fisheries rules must apply equally to all fishermen. It is also necessary to extend the controls to cover the entire production rumor and to designate an inspection at sea as a single authority in order to avoid repetitive controls.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 2009, a regulation regulating the EU fisheries control system has been in place, which in principle applies throughout the EU. However, its unification and the same interpretation of its paragraphs in all Member States have so far failed. The reporter toured the ports and fisheries institutions of the EU's most affected Member States, from Italy to France, Spain to Belgium and Germany. His experience on the ground has resulted in a very practice-oriented report in order to ensure an equal level of interpretation of fisheries controls. The monitoring of the continuation of fishing, the aequacy of the use of equipment, the quality control of fishery products and other elements of the product path show a very different picture in the Member States. There are also very significant differences in rigour and consistency, as well as in the application of sanctions. Fishermen, when they work in different ports, experience a different interpretation and application of the rules. This, by hurting their sense of justice, means that they do not take their observance seriously.  On the basis of all this experience, the report provides proposals for a thorough and practice-oriented solution to unify the control system for fishing activities within the EU, so I supported its adoption.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In general, this report is part of an ever-closer monitoring of fishermen: these, between the multiple declarations, electronic and satellite instruments, on-board or landing checks, are closely monitored and supervised at the expense of their activity, to which I cannot be in favour.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this initiative report which presents ways to improve fishing controls in Europe. In particular, it calls for training at European level of controllers and a single repository for control. It also stresses the importance of harmonizing sanctions.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fisheries sector is one of the first to be interested in sustainable management of the seas and oceans, which is why its full and active participation in the definition of control rules is crucial. All too often we see incidents which show that there is a belief among fishermen that there is discriminatory treatment with regard to the regularity, frequency, duration, rigour, accuracy, effectiveness and methods of fisheries controls in Europe and in particular in the various Member States. The Thomas report, which I supported today with my vote, addresses this issue by calling on the Commission to ensure uniform and correct transposition of existing legislation. We need closer cooperation between the Member States in order to achieve effective harmonisation of controls, we need to strengthen the mandate of the European Fisheries Control Agency and we need to ensure better training and information for fishermen. Only by acting on the different plans will it be possible to make the system more functional and fair.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the fact that I understand that the report calls for simplifying and improving Union legislation, as well as reducing the administrative burden, a historical vindication of our sea people, points out that closer cooperation between Member States requires that, in this review, the European institutions and the fisheries sector work together, especially the coastal fisheries sector , artisanal and traditional whose protection and promotion should be the objective of any new legislation. As it also advocates the imposition of the highest penalties in the case of illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing or the inclusion of the impact of recreational fishing in the revision of the Control Regulation, all of them the objectives of our fishermen, advocates effective control of the traceability of our products throughout the chain and greater control of imported fish , adapting to the parameters of the Union.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. This report addresses one of the Gordian knots faced by European fishermen: the marasm of standards, the heterogeneity in control and sanctions, the need to improve statistics in order to prevent the most common or pernicious illegal conduct with inspection campaigns and the need for the same violations to be sanctioned in the same way. Regulatory harmonization, shared training, better means and appropriate approaches for the different casuistics are the basis of improvements that we share and support.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report by Socialist MP Isabelle Thomas aims to make fishing controls in Europe homogeneous. At present, as fisheries control is not harmonised at European level, Member States have the freedom to organise the controls themselves. According to Ms Thomas, the Control Regulation is too complex and offers too many opportunities for Member States to adapt, interpret or make choices. It does not apply everywhere in the same way in Europe, which produces a sense of injustice among fishermen. For example, it wants to generalise the points licence and strengthen the budget of the European Fisheries Control Agency to recruit new agents. There are positives (points 55, 69, etc.) but many are unacceptable: generalized and harmonized points permits (point 15), AECP budgets up (point 45). There is a risk that binding proposals will be implemented but, as usual, not the right measures such as, for example, equivalent controls on imported products. As it stands, I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Thomas report on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform is well structured and acceptable. I think it is important to try to make bureaucracy clearer and less burdensome for fisheries operators, who have been experiencing a severe economic crisis in recent years. I therefore voted in favour of the text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Fisheries control in the Union differs from one Member State to another, with differences in the procedures and types of sanctions applied for the same type of infringements — in some cases administrative and other criminal in nature — differences in the level of resources used, lack of specialised inspectors, databases not always interchangeable between Member States Etc. To address this, inter alia, it is proposed to adopt common control criteria, strengthen the role of the European Fisheries Control Agency, the use of greater resources and more modern means to provide more effective inspections or the promotion of European training of inspectors and fishermen. In short, I support the rapporteur's approach to this report for the sake of homogenisation of fisheries controls in the Union, establishing a single framework of reference. And, in particular, that identical sanctions are applied in all Member States for identical infringements, thus ending the sense of inefficiency and injustice that arises in the sector.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which discusses the European Union strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and the storage of gas.  The European Parliament welcomes the Commission communication entitled 'An EU strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and storage of gas' and considers that the internal energy market integrating the full use of liquefied natural gas and storage will play an important role in achieving the ultimate objective of a resilient Energy Union. The EU strategy for the use of liquefied natural gas and storage is one element of the Energy Union, which aims to achieve the EU's ambition to move quickly towards a sustainable, secure and competitive energy system, and that one of its objectives is to no longer be dependent on external gas suppliers. Parliament stresses that one of the objectives of the Energy Union is to make the EU a world leader in renewable energy. In addition, Parliament is of the opinion that energy security can be ensured in the most efficient way through better coordination of national energy policies, through a genuine energy union with a single energy market and a common energy policy, and cooperation between Member States in this area, in accordance with the principles of solidarity and trust.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, which attaches the highest priority for fisheries control to achieve the CFP reform objectives. The forthcoming review must lay down effective rules that will prevent, detect and sanction CFP breaches, with a focus on greater harmonisation and increased cooperation in establishing transparent, standardised control procedures. The important role of the EFCA must also be recognised through sufficient allocation of resources.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report presents some interesting points, such as the introduction of the ban on going out to sea as a sanction in place of a criminal sanction, but, on the other hand, it highlights unacceptable elements such as the generalised points permit. Above all, it calls for a strengthening of the budget of the European Fisheries Control Agency to recruit new agents. All this is part of a logic of strengthening the control of European fishermen, who are already feeling very badly about the current controls. The report's intention to apply equivalent sanctions to imported products or third-country vessels operating in European waters is more like wishful thinking than effective proposals. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform because I think the current available data do not allow the EU institutions to review the Control Regulation. Indeed, some Member States have still to properly implement it and we still face different approaches in control activities. Moreover, the lack of transparency between Member States does not help to improve the control mechanisms. In this regard, I believe that control requirements should be complied with in an equivalent manner in the Member States in order to make these controls uniform as much as possible.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fisheries controls are key to achieving the objectives of cfp reform. There are, however, huge differences in the scope of control and procedures between Member States. The mandate of the European Fisheries Control Agency to carry out joint projects is limited, its budget is insufficient. The instruments and financial resources used to carry out controls vary from one Member State to another; regulations are transposed differently into national legislation; sanctions and prosecutions are very different; data is not always shared and accessible; training for fishermen and inspectors varies and needs to be strengthened. These are the main points of this important own-initiative report adopted by a large majority.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to harmonize fishing controls at European level. Until now, the complexity of the old regulation has given Member States the opportunity to interpret and adapt the rules governing fishing controls. To address this problem, the report calls for the generalising of the points licence and strengthening the budget of the European Fisheries Control Agency (ECPA), in particular with a view to recruiting new agents. This report is part of an ever-closer monitoring of fishermen. Although we are in favour of the creation of joint training for fisheries inspectors and the exchange of data between Member States, we are very concerned that this report will reinforce the constraints on our fishermen. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are a number of misunderstandings and dissatisfactions among fishermen in Europe, who feel discriminated against by other fishermen in other Member States, who are subject to less rigid controls. Thus, the issue of uniform application of legislation was raised in order to increase efficiency, but also to provide equal treatment to all fishermen in Europe. Thus, a number of obstacles to harmonisation have been found, such as: the diversity of the scope of controls, the different control procedures and methods for almost each Member State, but also penalties which differ significantly for the same provision infringed.  Consequently, this initiative aims to identify in an exhaustive manner gaps in the application of rules which generate feelings of injustice among fishermen, as well as to establish solutions to harmonise the control of the common fisheries policy. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to eliminate all differences in the implementation of fisheries controls in Europe, in order to ensure equal and non-discriminatory treatment among all fishermen.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Thomas report, which provides an overview of the controls of fishing activities. It highlights the significant progress made in harmonizing controls but highlights some limitations. The report calls for more cooperation between Member States to strengthen harmonisation of controls and sanctions. I believe that the diversity of sanctions across countries is a source of injustice for fishermen. The report also develops some avenues for improvement to make controls more homogeneous, including control technologies, controller training and data collection. The report further states that an in-depth reform of the Regulation Controls (EC) No. 1224/2009 is not desirable as this regulation is a solid basis. The improvements, while necessary, can only come from better cooperation between Member States. Moreover, a substantial revision would open the door to a weakening or even renationalization of existing rules, which is not desirable.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to ensure compliance with the requirements for the control of fishing activities, which must be equivalent in the various Member States. It is common to hear fishermen complain that fisheries control is much stricter in their own country than in their neighbours, whether it be another Member State or another fishing zone. This feeling of injustice raises a real problem: that of the homogeneity of the application of the legislation, and therefore of its effectiveness. In fact, the suspicion that the rules are not applied everywhere with the same rigour is accompanied by the risk of a situation in which the rule is no longer respected because it is not the same for everyone. The report adopted today makes it possible to identify in the application of the rules the shortcomings that lead to this feeling of injustice, proposing in particular to simplify and therefore rapidly revise European Regulation No 1224/2009 establishing a Community control system to ensure compliance with the common fisheries policy, focusing primarily on better implementation of the rules in the various Member States, in particular through the search for greater harmonisation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. It proposes real non-discriminatory treatment within the fisheries sector, more cooperation between Member States, expanding the controls (e.g. monitoring) to cover the entire production chain, increasing traceability. It calls for the standardisation of proportional and non-discriminatory sanctions to act as a deterrent, and states that preference should be given to incentives in order to prevent infringements, rather than sanctions. I support the majority of the content of the report but I oppose the call for a higher level of EU centralisation and an EU-level definition of the technical and political measures related to controls rather than cooperation between Member States. There are also references to the use of new technologies for monitorisation; the introduction of a points-based sanctions system, with implications for the fishing licences. The report opposes any mandatory video surveillance on board for all vessels, but Sinn Féin has called for increased surveillance regarding foreign operators of large-scale industrial vessels fishing in Irish waters, so I do not support that proposal. For these reasons I abstained on the final vote.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this non-legislative report because ‘one size does not fit all’ and it will extend the EU’s Kafkaesque fisheries bureaucracy to anglers and recreational fishing.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it stresses the importance of ensuring the effective control of fishing activities in order to guarantee sustainability of living marine resources and maintain a level playing field among EU fleets. This can only be achieved through the effective implementation of the EU Control Regulation. There has been significant improvement in the control regime, but more needs to be done especially in fisheries control operations and the sharing of data by Member States in real time in particular during control operations conducted by European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA).

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to iron out the profound differences between member states in the field of fisheries controls, this report proposes various measures, such as greater training of fishermen on the issues of control and sanctions, the need to make fisheries controls and sanctions more homogeneous, the importance of quality data collection and the use of new technologies to increase the effectiveness of controls. Many of the amendments tabled by the 5-Star Movement have been accepted in the text, among which the most important are the need to simplify the technical measures that are very spent make it difficult not only to understand them but also to control and apply them; the rules on simpler, more comprehensive and more consistent controls; the importance of strengthening and strengthening controls in order to combat illegal fishing and to strengthen the quality of the data collected. I voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The control of fishing activities must aim at the creation of an incisive and uniform system in this area. It is therefore imperative that the application of common rules and their monitoring be uniform throughout the Union in order to ensure uniformity in levels of controls and sanctions. I am pleased that the report has highlighted the importance of simplification and transparency in the control of fisheries activities. Only simplified and clear legislation on control procedures can ensure an effective fight against illegal fishing, which so damaging our precious marine ecosystem. I hope that the revision of the control regulation will be the result of constructive cooperation between the European Commission and the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA), whose role I believe needs to be strengthened. Finally, it is important to promote a modern monitoring system where the use of new information transmission and communication technologies in real time can improve maritime surveillance. On the basis of these comments, I have decided to support the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress the importance of ensuring effective control of fishing activities in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and to maintain a level playing field between EU fleets.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the commonly accepted need for better and more effective controls in the fisheries sector, the report on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform fails to analyse how new control techniques will be assimilated using new technologies and how Member States will be able to maintain the possibility of such controls. As there are gaps in the report, I have decided to abstain.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote on this report which aims to lighten and harmonise the bureaucratic aspects related to operators in the fisheries sector. The text also presents important measures for harmonising controls on illegal fishing.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The sharing of the measure stems from the desire for a breakthrough in the fisheries sector: all too often our fishermen are penalised by the poor regulations present in neighbouring countries. Our made in Italy represents not only a very large market, but a real excellence also thanks to the legislation, sometimes too stringent, to which we must submit. However, in order not to see penalties or distortions in competition, harmonisation of controls is essential to ensure sustainable development in line with a high level of protection and improvement of the quality of the environment. The achievement of regular, frequent, rigorous and accurate control methods is a priority, especially in view of the identified risks associated with the often denied access to inspection of foreign vessels. Not infrequently, the latter has made it difficult to control illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing as well as hinder inspections of infringements already detected (it has been estimated that infringement rates are significantly higher at sea than on land). Therefore, harmonisation of controls will seek greater safety for European producers and products, accompanied, in addition, by the sustainable exploitation of marine biological resources and the maintenance of a level playing field between European fleets.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because it stresses the importance of ensuring effective control of fishing activities in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources. It also reiterates the importance of strengthening the EFCA's mandate in order to create fisheries control operations that allow coordinated and effective action by local, regional, national and Community agencies acting as coastguards at European level, while also seeking to achieve real-time sharing of the data collected between the various competent authorities.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report submitted by the Committee on Fisheries for approval by the Plenary of the European Parliament contains many positive aspects: the recognition of discriminatory treatment in the conduct of controls within the sector, the non-adequacy of some of the European rules to reality, the defence of regional or autonomous community inspections for inland waters , national maritime fishing inspections in waters up to 12 nautical miles and Union inspections for the rest of the waters. However, I abstained since the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring; the introduction of a point-based sanctions system, with implications for fishing licences. At the same time, the report reflects high centralisation and a Definition at Community level of technical and policy measures related to controls rather than cooperation between Member States, so I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fisheries sector suffers from the lack of homogeneity in the application of control legislation in the individual Member States, which, fuelled by a feeling of injustice, undermines compliance with the rule itself. I believe that it is essential for the conservation of common resources to ensure that EU fisheries rules are properly respected, that national catch quotas are not exceeded and that Member States adopt a common approach to fisheries control. I therefore believe that, in view of the revision of the control regulation, it is necessary to establish effective rules aimed at preventing, detecting and penalising infringements of the regulation itself, focusing on greater harmonisation and increased cooperation establishing standardised control procedures.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Each Member State shall apply different control procedures. Even if there is a standard form for finding infringements on board a ship, control procedures vary. The instruments, equipment and financial means used to carry out checks also vary from one Member State to another. Fishermen often complain that they are subject to much stricter scrutiny than their neighbours in another Member State or even more rigorously than in any field. I voted for the implementation of a European programme for the training of inspectors to develop a single control framework, but also for standardisation of procedures.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the report on how to harmonise fisheries control in Europe, as the proposed solution on this issue respects national competences. There is a need to harmonise this issue, as fishermen point out, with regard to unequal treatment in terms of regularity, frequency, severity, duration, accuracy, effectiveness and methods of fisheries control in Europe. The aim of this report is ambitious. On the one hand, it is to identify shortcomings in the application of the rules that lead to a sense of inequality and to propose solutions to increase controls under the common fisheries policy. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it stresses the importance to enforce EU regulations where there is a lack of transparency between Member States that prevents the illegal importation of fish. I voted in favour of a more uniform fisheries controls in Europe which takes into consideration the environment and fish stocks.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report, which ensures a level playing field for fishermen in the EU. UK fishermen play by the rules and make sure that they fish their quota in the right place with the right equipment. When the rules are broken, the UK authorities can and do impose large fines or other penalties. When fishermen in other Member States break the rules, we expect that the same should happen.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the homogenisation of fishing controls in Europe. We must respond to the warning from fishermen who perceive European regulation as a source of injustice. Much more than European regulation, it is the non-homogeneity of its application that is at the root of this dysfunction. It is up to the European Parliament to overcome this situation by harmonising sanctions, ensuring their application and simplifying European regulations.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European fishing sector is the world's fourth largest producer with 6.4 million tonnes of fish per year and employs 350,000 people. While the Common Fisheries Policy is one of the most integrated policies in Europe, fisheries controls are not sufficiently harmonised. The scope, training of fishermen, procedures and sanctions differ from one Member State to another. Therefore, the existing framework needs to be simplified and standardised procedures developed. The Union must work to make fishing a sustainable sector.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to homogenise fishing controls, which are currently organised by the Member States themselves. Some proposals are positive, such as the idea of economic sanctions, such as the ban on going out to sea, rather than criminal ones. Similarly, equivalent controls on imported products and boats from third countries fishing in European waters, joint training of fishing inspectors, improved information for fishermen, exchange of data between member countries or the integration of a european Parliament representative into the AECP are positive. Other proposals are unacceptable, such as the generalization of a points permit, even if harmonized, and the increase of the AECP budget, mainly to recruit new officers. It is feared that many valid proposals will never be implemented while the most binding proposals will be implemented. This report is part of an ever-closer monitoring of fishermen, whether it is the multiple declarations, the use of electronic and satellite instruments, the checks on board or the landing. So I preferred to vote against this text.

name: Angel Dzhambazki (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report. I welcome the fact that it proposes to simplify and improve EU legislation in order to make it easier to enforce existing rules and tackle the current shortcomings. As it is, the current situation demands a number of improvements, especially when it comes to scope, training, control procedures and sanctions. Because the report correctly recognises the importance of Member States in all of these matters, I have voted in favour.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Controls on fisheries are of great importance in combating the negative phenomena of this vital activity. Illegal fishing, as well as uncontrolled fishing in breeding seasons, must be combated in order to preserve the offspring and marine populations. Under no circumstances, however, should recreational and coastal fishing be compared with professional mass-scale fishing.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This non-legislative report is primarily about the coordination of fisheries controls in EU countries with seas. The question of the uniform application of EU legislation and its effectiveness is of paramount importance to me. This is how it should be in all EU Member States. I voted in favour of the Thomas report.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report makes recommendations on how to control EU fisheries rules more uniformly across all Union fishermen. The recommendations also apply to recreational fishermen and this is important, because recreational fishing in some parts of the Union has a major impact on local fish stocks. The report calls on the Commission to take this into account in future legislation. This does not mean that the administrative burden on Swedish recreational fishermen will in any way increase.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishermen in the various EU countries should have equal treatment with a uniform application of inspections. Harmonisation of inspections so that there is a level playing field between all fishing activities, an extension of controls to the entire production chain and the creation of a 'basic curriculum' for training inspectors are some measures that I advocate should be adopted. I also agree with the establishment of financing mechanisms to increase the use of low-cost technologies in order to enable voluntary control and increase the monitoring and safety of fishermen, especially in small-scale artisanal fishing.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: in general, this report is part of an ever-closer monitoring logic for fishermen: these, between the multiple declarations, electronic and satellite instruments, on-board or landing checks, are closely monitored.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU fisheries controls aim at biological sustainability by combating illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing. The REVIEW of the CFP decontextualised some issues related to controls, which were outdated. Indeed, there are specific needs to make controlled fishing more uniform, in the sense that this sector is more controlled than any other sector or profession; and that the rules do not apply uniformly between different types of fishing or even between different Member States, creating various contradictions between fishermen as regards regularity, frequency, duration, severity, rigour, effectiveness and methods of fisheries control in Europe.  The report highlights a number of issues that can contribute to non-discriminatory treatment in the sector, the effectiveness of controls and the sustainability of marine resources. However, the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring; the introduction of a point-based sanctions system with implications for fishing licences.  At the same time, the report reflects a high centralisation and an EU-wide definition of control-related technical and political measures rather than cooperation between Member States and cannot be supported globally.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it aims to standardise controls on fisheries in Europe while respecting national competences. The report has the dual objective of identifying the limits of coherence and effectiveness of the control system for fisheries in the EU and of proposing solutions to improve its uniformity.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fisheries control in Europe is essential to achieve the common objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy. Unfortunately, there are very large differences in control, different procedures and strategies across Member States and regions. The mandate and funding of the European Fisheries Control Agency are insufficient, as a result of which it cannot carry out more ambitious projects. This report should therefore serve as a necessary minimum for the European Commission in the reform of the control regulation it is preparing for 2017. The European Commission should focus on simplifying legislation and on clearly and comprehensible setting of control standards and the application of modern technology, as well as better coordination and transparency.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report, which seeks to harmonise and lighten the bureaucratic aspects for operators.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform, as controls on fisheries are of great importance in combating the negative phenomena of this vital activity. Illegal fishing, as well as uncontrolled fishing in breeding seasons, must be combated in order to preserve the offspring and marine populations. Under no circumstances, however, should recreational and coastal fishing be compared with professional mass-scale fishing.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of this report which paves the way for a review of the legislation covering fishery controls. UK fishermen play by the rules and it is only right that Spanish, Portuguese and every other Member State implement the rules in the same way. If they don’t, there is no point in having a Common Fisheries Policy.  This report calls for a level playing field so that fishermen across the EU can safely know they are not being undermined by their neighbours. This is something that I strongly support.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We must attach utmost priority to fisheries controls in order to achieve the objectives of the CFP Reform. The forthcoming revision of the Control Regulation must set effective rules able to prevent, detect and sanction infringements of the CFP, focusing on greater harmonisation and increased cooperation establishing transparent, standardised control procedures. The important role of EFCA must be acknowledged, including through the allocation of sufficient resources. Member States are responsible for the implementation of the Control Regulation; closer cooperation between Member States as well as coordination with EFCA and the European Commission is thus crucial for the further harmonisation of effective controls.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report not because it does not agree with the approval of fishing controls in Europe, but because the differences between fishing in the Atlantic Ocean and fishing in the Mediterranean Sea have not been taken into account when adopting this type-approval. We cannot deal with realities so far removed together, we must keep in mind that problems in both areas are far from similar. The rules should be applied with the same rigour, but always bearing in mind that what is beneficial for Atlantic fishing must not necessarily be so in the Mediterranean.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The plan to harmonise the control systems of the Common European Fisheries Policy has introduced general measures of regulatory homogeneity, which are very important for this sector, but leaving a large number of optional provisions or which can be reinterpreted from country to country, giving rise to numerous and considerable differences in training, control procedures and even sanctions between the different Member States. Above all, there was a general lack of confidence in Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 because of the version of its application and interpretation. I therefore fully support a revision of the current legislation, based on clearer, more accessible and fairer principles, providing for greater certainty in the provisions, concrete harmonisation in the field of common instruments and technologies to which reference is made and, above all, uniformity in the field of training and sanctioning principles.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform because I think it is right to listen to the voices and concerns of fishermen about the difference in controls and I believe that the next revision of the control regulation is the right place to achieve greater homogeneity of the matter in the EU. In view of a regulation regulating this matter at European level, there are still too many differences between the Member States in the methods and implementation of controls, in the degree of depth of controls in relation to the fishing chain and in the type of sanctions provided for in the various systems. I therefore agree with the call to use the forthcoming revision of the control regulation to simplify legislation and reduce bureaucracy, to strengthen the fight against illegal fishing, to improve and standardise the training of fishermen and inspectors, including by involving GACs and local and regional authorities, to extend controls throughout the supply chain and to promote conscious consumption in restaurants. Uniform controls and sanctions across the EU will put an end to fishermen's concerns and allow us to take another step towards a truly single market.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As mep for Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, I voted today in favour of the 'Report on the possibilities for standardising fisheries control in Europe' because I am convinced that we can only guarantee the sustainable conservation of our fish stocks through effective controls.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. As rapporteur for the North Sea Plan, I am particularly concerned about the harmonisation of control activities in the fisheries sector. Joint operational control activities must be established and effective coordination of local, regional, national and supranational authorities must be implemented. This includes, in particular, harmonisation of data collection and the provision of data in real time. Furthermore, the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA) needs to be further strengthened so that this supranational authority can harmonise joint control activities.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament resolution on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform.  The report advocates harmonising the scope of controls, increasing training opportunities for inspectors and fishermen, standardising sanctions, and investing more in technologies and the EFCA budget. It will create a level playing field for fishermen across the EU and improve respect for controls.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it responds to the need to give concrete answers to fishermen, who are one of the categories most affected by the constraints imposed by European policies. Above all, however, fishermen complain that these constraints are not applied equally in all states. There are considerable differences in control systems or sanctions, for example, and this increases the sense of frustration and injustice. If the legislation is European, then it must be the same for everyone and must have the same effects on all fishermen. Europe must therefore make an extra effort to homogenise their application as well as their obligations.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the fact that I understand that the report calls for simplifying and improving Union legislation, as well as reducing the administrative burden, a historical vindication of our sea people, points out that closer cooperation between Member States requires that, in this review, the European institutions and the fisheries sector work together, especially the coastal fisheries sector , artisanal and traditional whose protection and promotion should be the objective of any new legislation. As it also advocates the imposition of the highest penalties in the case of illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing or the inclusion of the impact of recreational fishing in the revision of the Control Regulation, all of them the objectives of our fishermen, advocates effective control of the traceability of our products throughout the chain and greater control of imported fish , adapting to the parameters of the Union.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it will create a level playing field for fishermen across the EU and improve respect for controls.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to ensure effective control of fishing activities to ensure the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and to preserve the equal treatment of European fleets. To do this, it is important to better apply existing legislation. The text includes strengthening controls to prevent the importation of illegal, unreported and unregulated fish, improving training and information for fishermen, and establishing financing mechanisms to increase the use of new low-cost technologies.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It is important to ensure effective control of fisheries activities in order to guarantee sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and maintain a level playing field among EU fleets. Therefore it is necessary to clarify, classify and establish standards for fishing in the different maritime areas.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report looks at how to make fisheries controls more uniform in the EU while still taking into account national competences. Since the report comes up with good proposals, such as reduction of administrative burden and simplification of EU legislation, I have voted in favour of it.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which reflects the priorities for the demand for simpler, more comprehensive and more coherent rules. They are also for greater transparency, cooperation and innovation. In addition, emphasis has been placed on equal and non-discriminatory treatment, such as the protection of labour and environmental standards and the establishment of effective rules for the prevention, detection and sanctioning of CFP infringements, thereby creating greater harmonisation and cooperation, as well as transparent and standardised control procedures.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report "How to harmonise fisheries control in Europe?" with a view to improving inequalities occurring in European fisheries in terms of regularity, frequency, duration, rigour, thoroughness, effectiveness and fisheries control methods. Fisheries control efforts should include the full and active participation of the fisheries sector. This Report calls on Member States to ensure the effective implementation of the Control Regulation in order to ensure the efficient use of living marine resources and to maintain a level playing field for all EU fleets.  There is certainly room for improvement in simplifying and improving Union legislation and trying to reduce administrative burdens. The revision of the Council Regulation, expected soon, will focus on better implementation of standards in different Member States, in particular by advocating for greater coherence, provided that simplification is based on a robust existing control framework and does not lower the highest standards in terms of occupational safety, environmental protection, union or social protection.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. As usual, the good is here next door to the bad. If I support the preference for economic rather than criminal sanctions, or the control of non-EU fishing vessels operating in our waters, I find the proposals to strengthen the budget of the European Fisheries Control Agency and the generalisation of a points licence inadmissible. There is even some doubt about the application of the most beneficial ideas, such as equivalent controls on imported products, a fate that will obviously not be shared by the most restrictive proposals. All this logic goes in the direction of increased supervision of fishermen, without any real satisfactory consideration. I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the harmonisation of fisheries controls in view of the current lack of access by national inspections to relevant information. The current frustration of fishermen stems from the belief that the rules on fisheries controls are not applied equally in the Member States. Harmonisation will lead to an improvement in the competitive environment in fisheries and to the modernisation of high standards of EU fisheries policy.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Isabelle Thomas' report on the homogenisation of fishing controls in Europe. The current system is based on monitoring and analysis of fisheries management information. However, the lack of coordination between the data collected at the national level is a major hindrance. I support this text which aims to harmonize this data with real-time sharing for operations carried out by the competent authority (the European Fisheries Control Agency) in collaboration with the Member States. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I support the uniform application of the regulations and, consequently, the effectiveness of the rules on fisheries controls in Europe. It is absolutely essential to establish a European training of auditors and to develop a single reference framework in the field of audit. Training for fishermen should also be strengthened.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union has the same law for fishermen. However, they complain that the rules are not respected in the same way in every country and sometimes the control of catches takes place more and sometimes less rigorously. There are concerns that established procedures are not always followed, which may lead to inaccuracies. Appropriate measures should therefore be taken to improve the common fisheries policy. The main reason for the controversy is that in different countries the number of checks at different stages is not the same: in some regions they occur at every level, and in others there are situations where control on the road "from sea to plate" occurs only once.  The proposed solution in this case is to simplify the common law so that it is simple and understandable to everyone, so that there will be no discrepancies. Throughout the Community, both fishermen and inspectors should undergo comprehensive training. The creation of databases will allow to control the current status of fisheries and to gain knowledge in this regard. Action should also be taken to harmonise procedures across Europe and strengthen the role of the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA). Especially in all fishing areas where fishing includes species below maximum sustainable yield (MSY). On the other hand, in the event of non-compliance with the applicable rules, sanctions should be the same for all.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it will create a level playing field for fishermen across the EU and improve respect for controls.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Seafood and seafood are very important from a food point of view, which are a healthy source of protein for the EU population. However, there are a number of conditions for this, which is why, since 2009, a regulation regulating the EU fisheries control system has been in place, the unification of which and the same interpretation of its paragraphs in all Member States have so far failed. Commendably, the reporter gained direct experience, touring the ports and fishing institutions of the EU's most affected Member States. He also personally listened to fishermen and administrative professionals and, with the knowledge thus acquired, put on the table a very fair, pragmatic report, which can only be supported.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on how to standardise fisheries control in Europe. The importance of ensuring effective control of fishing activities should be emphasised in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and maintain a level playing field. Member States need to ensure the effective implementation of the Control Regulation. The introduction of European training for inspectors and the development of a single control model is key. The training of fishermen should also be strengthened. It could be promoted and conducted through their professional organisations in order to improve understanding of the meaning of the rules and their control and their usefulness and to enhance the culture of compliance. It is also necessary to create online databases that make the rules accessible and understandable to all. I believe that fish auctions play a vital role in the seafood industry and play a central role in controlling landed fish. The EU's ambitious fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing worldwide must be combined with the effective implementation of the Control Regulation in our own waters.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Fishing is an important source of income for many European countries. Sometimes, however, European legislation itself seems to be applied differently depending on the individual State. For example, in the area of controls, some States provide for controls throughout the supply chain, while in other States controls take place only at certain stages of the production chain. These differences may call into question both the EU's credibility and the effectiveness of the legislation itself. With today's vote, we have called for european fisheries rules to be standardised, such as mesh sizes, control procedures, catches and the same penalties in the event of infringements. In view of the forthcoming review of the control regulation, we have called for greater attention to be paid to this issue in order to eliminate the differences that exist between the EU Member States.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report entitled 'How to make fishing controls in Europe homogeneous?'. This text contains unacceptable proposals, such as the points permit, even harmonized, and the increase in the AECP budget to recruit new agents. There are some good proposals, but they will never be implemented, such as equivalent controls on imported products. More broadly, this report is part of an ever-closer monitoring of fishermen: declarations, electronic and satellite instruments, on-board or landing checks, etc.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The report proposes ways of thinking about the homogenisation of fishing at European level. It is found that the 'control' regulation is too complex and offers too many opportunities for member states to adapt. To remedy this, the rapporteur proposes a series of even more restrictive measures which are part of a logic of increased surveillance of fishermen who, in our opinion, are already sufficiently so. I logically voted against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it draws attention to the need to homogenise fisheries controls in the Union, establishing a single reference framework, and promoting identical sanctions in all Member States for identical infringements. The control of fisheries in the Union differs from one Member State to another, with differences in the procedures and types of sanctions applied for the same type of infringements , in some cases administrative and other criminal cases – differences in the level of resources used, lack of specialised inspectors, databases not always interchangeable between Member States Etc. The lack of approved treatment of fisheries controls creates a certain sense of inefficiency and injustice in the sector. To address this, inter alia, this report proposes the adoption of common control criteria, strengthening the role of the European Fisheries Agency, using greater resources and more modern means to provide more effective inspections or promoting European training of inspectors and fishermen.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report submitted by the Committee on Fisheries for approval by the Plenary of the European Parliament contains many positive aspects: the recognition of discriminatory treatment in the conduct of controls within the sector, the non-adequacy of some of the European standards to reality, the defence of regional or autonomous community inspections for inland waters , national maritime fishing inspections in waters up to 12 nautical miles and Union inspections for the rest of the waters. However, I abstained since the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring; the introduction of a point-based sanctions system, with implications for fishing licences. At the same time, the report reflects high centralisation and a Definition at Community level of technical and policy measures related to controls rather than cooperation between Member States, so I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution aims to address different proposals for methods or solutions to improve the harmonisation of control of the common fisheries policy, as well as to identify deficiencies in the application of the rules of the common fisheries policy. Currently, there is considerable diversity of the areas of application of the control, procedures and strategies of the common fisheries policy. An example is the fact that the same offence is punishable differently, as the penalty may have been classified as criminal or administrative. All this creates a sense of injustice in fishermen, and challenges the effectiveness of the regulations applied. I am voting in favour of the proposal because harmonising the scope reinforces the effectiveness of EU law and, consequently, helps to achieve the objective of ensuring the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and, on the other hand, that of the Union's fight against illegal fishing on a global scale.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report that addresses the lack of consistent information across the EU due to differences in collecting information in each Member State.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained because the Czech Republic does not have the sea and therefore left it to the representatives of the other states to decide on the regulation of fishing.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to ensure effective control of fisheries activities in order to guarantee sustainable exploitation of living marine resources. Control procedures must be transparent, even-handed and standardised, allowing Member States to be put on an equal footing as regards controls on their fishermen, and rules on control should be simpler, and more comprehensive and consistent.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fisheries control not only affects the economy, eonomics and budget of the Member States concerned. The report clearly shows the need to unify legislation in the area of the control reference framework, the training of fisheries inspectors, the introduction of a uniform methodology and control procedures, including the use of modern technologies and the setting of uniform sanctions. In doing so, it is important to proceed in a coordinated manner and rationalise operations from the point of view of data collection.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. With just a few months to go before the revision of the Fisheries Control Regulation, it was essential that the European Parliament take up the issue of harmonising the procedures of these controls within the Union. The aim of this report is to highlight the flaws in the application of the rules which lead to a sense of unfairness between fishermen from different EU countries and to propose solutions to harmonize the control of the common fisheries policy, one of the most integrated in Europe. In particular, the report calls for the creation of a European training of controllers, while stressing that the Fisheries Control Agency will need to be strengthened and its scope extended. Finally, the report highlights, in the context of judicial proceedings, the urgent need to harmonize penalties according to the offence and to introduce incentives. The implementation of these simple and homogeneous proposals contained in this report will, I am convinced, make controls more effective and acceptable to all. I therefore vote in favour of this text.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 October 2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. As it stands, the Member States themselves organise fishing controls because they are not harmonised at European level. There is a regulation, called "control," but it is too complex and suffers from many interpretations, creating several injustices. Some aspects of the text are positive (economic sanctions, more controls, training, etc.), but it generalisees the points permit and strengthens the budget of the European Fisheries Control Agency (ECPA), which we oppose.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform. Equal treatment is something fishermen have been complaining about in terms of application of regulations, and the EU should work on this issue to work on the feeling of injustice, giving also as always a relevant importance to transparency.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims at further harmonising fisheries controls in Europe, as the rules are not applied uniformly between types of fishing or even between Member States and highlighted a number of issues, which can contribute to more real and non-discriminatory treatment in the sector, the effectiveness of controls and the sustainability of marine resources. However, the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring, the introduction of a point-based sanctions system with implications for fishing licences, reflecting a high centralisation in the EU on the definition of technical and policy measures related to controls rather than cooperation between Member States. I abstained.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The common fisheries policy is one of the most integrated in Europe but still suffers from shortcomings, such as those caused as a result of differences in the implementation of controls by States, which creates a situation of injustice in the sector. I vote in favour of homogenisation of fisheries controls in Europe, which will also identify deficiencies in the application of the rules and improve the harmonisation of controls, both in terms of procedures and in training and sanctions.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on uniform fisheries controls in Europe which will allow the identification of common strategies, optimisation of efficiency and better targeting of fisheries, vessels or practices that pose the greatest risk. It is therefore necessary for States to collect compatible data and to ensure that they are transmitted on land.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on how to unify fisheries control in Europe, which has also been supported by the EP. EU rules vary substantially from one Member State to another, as each Member State has its own separate legal framework and their administrative structures are different, and these differences are inevitably reflected. It is therefore necessary to ensure a uniform level of control of fishing controls in all Member States, while at the same time, in order to strengthen the control of products entering the EU from illegal unreported fishing, while specifying the legal framework.  The EP calls on the Member States and their respective maritime fisheries control authorities to set up teams of specialised fisheries inspectors, and to promote greater cooperation between Member States with a view to exchanging information, control methods and data. The EP considers that the Member States, the European Fisheries Control Agency and the Commission need to cooperate more closely and coordinate their actions.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report points to the flaws in the common fisheries policy. Indeed, if the rules are the same for everyone, each Member State has different control procedures. And in the same way, judicial procedures and sanctions are different across the European Union: thus, for the same offence, the sanction can be administrative or criminal in nature. The report therefore aims to homogenize these control and sanctions procedures. It advocates making data exchange mandatory for illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. It promotes the use of new technologies to increase the effectiveness of controls while stating that it opposes mandatory video surveillance on ships. There are still some issues of debate, such as the establishment of a system of financial sanctions (via a temporary ban on fishing) at points, the terms of which do not allow for equal treatment between the different operators. Nevertheless, I am voting for this text, which goes in the direction of the fight against illegal and undeclared fishing.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report proposes ways of thinking about the homogenisation of fishing at European level. It is found that the 'control' regulation is too complex and offers too many opportunities for member states to adapt. To remedy this, the rapporteur proposes a series of even more restrictive measures which are part of a logic of increased surveillance of fishermen who, in our opinion, are already sufficiently so. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. It is very important to ensure effective monitoring of fishing activities in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and maintain a level playing field between EU fleets. The EU's fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing around the world must be accompanied by effective implementation of the Control Regulation in our own waters. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it call for the Union’s fisheries rules to be applied in a fair and just matter to all our citizens engaged in fishing activity through the elimination of disparities between Member States, a core curriculum for inspectors and sharing of information that is compatible across the Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this resolution on the homogenisation of fishing controls across Europe. Inspection procedures too often suffer from discrepancies that could lead to discrimination when implemented by Member States. Parliament therefore calls for a further standardising of national control methods. In particular, it proposes to harmonize penalties for offences (including the criminal or administrative nature of these sanctions) or to establish standardised training for fishing inspectors at European level. These recommendations from the European Parliament should be taken fully into account in order to avoid any feeling of discrimination in the head of some fishermen.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – There are major differences in the scope of control, procedures and fisheries strategy across EU Member States. It is necessary to identify shortcomings in the application of rules that create a sense of injustice among fishermen and to propose solutions to improve the harmonisation of the control of the common fisheries policy, which is one of the most integrated policies in Europe. The report contains a number of statements on obstacles to harmonisation, but it also contains proposals for the future that need to be put into practice in order for harmonisation to be effective. These proposals include simplification of Community legislation, development of a single control reference framework, training of inspectors and fishermen, which varies from one Member State to another. It is necessary to ensure effective consultation of advisory committees, which currently exists only pro forma, to provide financial support for research and innovation, thereby contributing to the overall modernisation of control policy. Last but not least, data collection is needed to carry out checks, as these make it possible to define strategies, optimise efficiency and better target fishing, vessels and practices posing the greatest risk.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. As fisheries control is not harmonised at European level, Member States are free to organise the controls themselves. The Thomas report proposes ways of thinking about homogenizing controls.  Some of the report's proposals are positive: this is the case, for example, the implementation of economic and non-criminal sanctions, such as the ban on going out to sea, equivalent controls on imported products and boats from third countries fishing in European waters, joint training of fishing inspectors, improved information for fishermen, data exchange in all member countries or the integration of a European Parliament representative into the Eu AECP.  Other proposals are, on the contrary, unacceptable: this is the case of the generalisation of a points permit, even harmonised, and the increase in the budget of the AECP, mainly to recruit new agents. It is feared that many valid proposals will never be implemented (for example, equivalent controls on imported products), while the most restrictive proposals will be. In general, this report is part of an ever-closer monitoring of fishermen. My vote is unfavorable.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite some good proposals such as equivalent controls on imported products (which will never be applied), this report is part of an ever closer monitoring of fishermen and damaging to their activity: declarations, electronic and satellite instruments and multiple controls. That is why I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which will create a level playing field for fishermen across the EU and improve respect for controls. Among other things, the report advocates harmonising the scope of controls, increasing training opportunities for inspectors and fishermen, standardising sanctions, and investing more into technologies and the EFCA budget. Advisory committees will be completely involved in this process.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on ways to make fishing controls in Europe homogeneous. The report stresses the importance of ensuring effective control of fishing activities in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and to preserve the equal treatment of European fleets. The text also reiterates the importance of strengthening the mandate of the European Fisheries Control Agency (ECAP) in order to set up joint operational fisheries control actions to effectively coordinate the activities of multiple local, regional, national and European agencies carrying out coastguard functions at European level.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas the effectiveness of Community legislation is directly proportional to the homogeneity of their implementation by the Member States; assess the concerns and complaints expressed by fishermen in this regard and, in particular, with regard to distortions of competition caused by different applications of the same standard; weighed up the seriousness of a potential internal rift in the common market; we share the hope that the European Commission, which is in the process of proposing a reform of the regulation on fisheries control, will identify any shortcomings in the application of existing legislation and promote effective harmonisation within the framework of the common fisheries policy, one of the areas that have benefited most from European integration. We also agree with the assumption that the integration objective cannot be separated from the joint training of representatives of the control agencies, greater transparency and availability of data, for example through the online provision of information sites and databases, and more effective consultation with trade associations. We also support a strengthening of the European Fisheries Agency, which, on the other hand, currently has too little money. We reiterate, in fact, that greater coordination can only involve a renewed centrality of the joint agency in charge.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion for a resolution that calls for the standardisation of fisheries controls among EU Member States. The controls will become more effective following investments of actors in compatible modern technologies such as satellite tracking of vessels. The motion for a resolution also stresses the need for the standardisation of sanctions through the creation of a judge specialising in maritime matters in each Member State.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European fishermen are the most interested party in the sustainable management of living marine resources in the seas and oceans, the reproduction of which is threatened in the current conditions of over-fishing. However, unfair market competition in the fishing sector, which translates into illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, makes the future of European fishermen's livelihoods uncertain. I therefore support this resolution, which aims to strengthen and standardise fisheries control in Europe by pushing for strengthening the mandate of the European Fisheries Control Agency. In order to reduce the risk of marine species extinction caused by illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, the European Fisheries Control Agency must be able to apply common control, inspection and surveillance standards and facilitate operational cooperation between Member States through joint deployment plans. This resolution takes a similar step, promoting the implementation of the Agency's "curriculum" for the training of fisheries inspectors, which standardises training and control procedures in this sector and will serve as a benchmark for countries that wish to subsequently train their fisheries inspectors.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this initiative report, which I worked on as shadow rapporteur, in today's vote, because I believe that the document underlines the importance of standardising certain aspects of fisheries controls in Europe. At the same time, it is very important that this uniformity allows a certain degree of flexibility for the authorities of the Member States, so that they can choose the most efficient and correct methods of control, depending on the specifics of the areas and types of fishing.  Given that these controls are intended to protect consumers, protect the environment and ensure fair competition in this area, I look forward to the European Commission's future report on the state of the fisheries control system in order to be able to work on improving it.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because some passages in the text are flawed and I cannot agree with it.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported, the rapporteur's aim was to identify shortcomings in the application of fisheries rules and to propose improvements in the harmonisation of the control of the common fisheries policy.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Major differences have been identified between national control methods, sanctions and the use of technologies. However, European fisheries rules must be applied uniformly in all Member States, so that all European fishermen are treated fairly. I voted in favour of the report, which raises the question of the uniform application of the regulations and, consequently, their effectiveness. Inspection procedures, e.g. for net and catch sizes, should be standardised at EU level, as should sanctions for similar infringements. The report stressed that European countries do not have the same training standards and calls for a single basic European training programme for fisheries inspectors to be implemented by the European Fisheries Control Agency and training institutions in the Member States. The ultimate objective is to improve the harmonisation of control of the common fisheries policy, which remains, however, one of the most comprehensive policies in Europe.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the recommendations will help to facilitate the work of European fishermen, in particular so that they can better understand the current European legislation. The report's main recommendations should be highlighted: the expansion of the role of the European Fisheries Control Agency, the homogenisation of procedures and sanctions, the better coordination of control bodies and the increased sharing of data, the creation of European training of controllers and the strengthening of training for fishermen, the simplification of EU legislation to be more accessible to professionals and avoid differences in interpretation between states and , strengthening controls on recreational fishing.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this non-legislative report because ‘one size does not fit all’ and it will extend the EU’s Kafkaesque fisheries bureaucracy to anglers and recreational fishing.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal, as I fully agree that it is necessary to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform. Given that, over and above possible regional variations, there are substantial differences between Member States in the application of European legislation and that the scope of Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 establishing a Community control system is the European Union. It is therefore essential to take action to ensure uniform application of controls throughout the Union. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the significant improvement in controls made possible by the adoption of the control regulation currently in force, together with the Regulation on illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. This improvement was achieved through the consolidation of many separate regulations, the introduction of the possibility of using new technologies, preliminary actions to harmonise sanctions, clarification of the role of the Commission and the Member States, improvements in traceability and other advantages.  Here I would like to stress how the adoption of EU legislation by fishermen is also influenced by their position on whether they consider the effects of the implementation of legislation fair and the imposed rules meaningful. Nor should we forget about the necessary compatibility between the Regulation and the traditional fishing patterns and the fishing practices carried out. This is why I am concerned about the sense of injustice shared by many fishermen in the EU. This raises a difficult question about the uniform application of the rules and consequently their effectiveness. It is questionable whether the rules apply with uniform rigour. If not, this is worrying, because then the same rules do not apply to everyone.  It is therefore necessary to identify deficiencies in the enforcement of rules leading to this sense of injustice and to propose solutions to improve the standardisation of common fishing policy control. In view of the report by which the rapporteur identified the very heart of the problem, and thanks to her work involving a wide range of different stakeholders, I supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. According to Isabelle Thomas, the 'control' regulation is too complex and offers too many opportunities for Member States to adapt it. It does not apply everywhere in the same way, which produces a sense of injustice.
