Some of the report's proposals are positive: the implementation of economic sanctions (ban on going out to sea) rather than criminal ones, equivalent controls on imported products and boats from third countries fishing in European waters, joint training of fishing inspectors, improved information for fishermen... Others are unacceptable: the generalization of a points permit, even harmonised, an increase in the AECP budget, mainly to recruit new agents. I am afraid that many valid proposals will never be implemented (e.g. equivalent controls on imported products), while the most restrictive proposals will be. In general, this report is part of an ever closer monitoring logic of fishermen: these, between the multiple declarations, electronic and satellite instruments, the checks on board or at the landing, are closely monitored. For these reasons, I am voting against the report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ We find significant differences in the application of European rules in the Member States. There is a real disparity, or it is felt by fishermen, in terms of fisheries control in Europe. If there is indeed a suspicion that the rules do not apply equally strictly everywhere, there are fears that we could find ourelves in a situation where they are no longer respected, because they do not apply to everyone equally.  The adoption of the regulation by fishermen is also influenced by their position on whether they consider the effects of implementation fair and the imposed rules meaningful and compatible with traditional fishing. The lack of trust and transparency between the Member States themses should also be removed, which is one of the main reasons for non-sharing of data. It is important to strengthen the role of the EFCA, in particular its budget, competences and human resources.  Homogeneous training of fisheries inspectors to be carried out by the EFCA and training institutions in the Member States must be introduced at EU level. The use of new technologies for real-time monitoring and transmission of data and communication are essential to improve maritime surveillance.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU fisheries controls aim at biological sustainability by combating illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing.  The REVIEW of the CFP decontextualised some issues related to controls, which were outdated. Indeed, there is a need for more uniform control, as the rules do not apply uniformly between different types of fishing or even between different Member States. This creates contradictions among fishermen as regards regularity, frequency, duration, severity, rigour, effectiveness and methods of fisheries control in Europe. However, the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring and the introduction of a point-based sanctions system with implications for fishing licences.  At the same time, the report reflects a high centralisation and an EU-wide definition of control-related technical and political measures rather than cooperation between Member States and cannot be supported globally.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fisheries controls are an important tool for achieving the objectives of the reform of the common fisheries policy. Despite the fact that fisheries policy is one of the most integrated EU policies, there are huge differences between Member States, in particular in the scope and procedures for controls. In addition, the funds and instruments used to carry out individual checks also differ, and penalties and legal proceedings are also different. The main responsibility for compliance with European standards in the field of controls and inspections and for coordinating activities between countries lies with the European Fisheries Control Agency. At present, however, its mandate is limited and its powers and funding are insufficient. I therefore very much appreciate the work of my colleague Isabelle Thomas, who is the rapporteur for this report, who has attended a number of meetings documenting the current situation in each country and has then defined the main obstacles to unifying fisheries control. I believe that direct talks with fishermen, representatives of the European Fisheries Control Agency, but also with national and regional inspectors are essential for a realistic assessment of the situation and the subsequent creation of an effective control framework.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report was drawn up in preparation for the next so-called "control regulation" (Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 establishing a Community control regime to ensure compliance with the rules of the common fisheries policy) which should be presented by the Commission in the second half of 2017. The text of the proposal stresses the importance of ensuring effective control of fishing activities in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and to maintain a level playing field between European fleets. The Member States of the European Union are also invited to ensure the effective implementation of the control regulation currently in force. Fishing is an activity of great importance, particularly for the Mediterranean islands. Fishermen are bearers of knowledge and traditions that deserve a great deal of attention from the European legislator. Having said that, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 This own-initiative report focuses on the issue of harmonising fisheries control while respecting national competences. The aim of this report is twofold: to identify shortcomings in the application of the rules that lead to this sense of inequality and to propose solutions to increase the degree of harmonisation of controls within the framework of the common fisheries policy.  The question of the inability to apply certain provisions of Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 in practice has been raised on several occasions, whether because it is not possible to adapt the provisions to reality or because of contradictions. This report contains a number of proposals on the factors hindering cohesion. The proposals contained in the final report include: a call for simplification and improvement of EU legislation, as well as a reduction of the administrative burden through the 2017 revision of Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 on fisheries control; to highlight the different scope of application of controls and the differences between the different control sites; call on the European Fisheries Control Agency to allocate more resources to ensure the application of common standards in the field of control, inspection and surveillance and to facilitate operational cooperation between Member States through joint deployment plans. For these reasons, I supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which refers to the lack of European harmonisation of criminal and administrative sanctions, which fall under national jurisdiction, when it comes to fisheries control in Europe. Although progress has been made since 2009 (the implementation date of Regulation (EC) 1224/2009), avenues for improvement through controller training, new control technologies and data collection need to be implemented.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Unfortunately, the doubt about the effectiveness and homogeneity of the application of some Community regulations still persists, and representatives of the fisheries sector are one of the frequent questioners.  This report precedes the forthcoming revision of the Fisheries Control Regulation and stresses the importance of ensuring effective control of fishing activities in order to ensure sustainable exploitation of maritime resources, equal procedures between the fleets of the different Members, and ensure the effective implementation of the Fisheries Control Regulation.  I would highlight three of the rapporteur's proposals: the first on simplifying Community legislation in order to end the 'matrioska effect' in this area, the second with regard to Europeanising procedures and strengthening the role of the EPCA (Fisheries Control Agency), in particular by strengthening its resources and scope of action. The third proposal, which I think is important, aims to make the data collected compatible and harmonised.  In advocating fair and equal treatment among European fishermen, I accept this motion for a resolution.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this non-legislative report because ‘one size does not fit all’ and it will extend the EU’s Kafkaesque fisheries bureaucracy to anglers and recreational fishing.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as the homogeneity of the application of the regulation and its effectiveness are fundamental for the fisheries sector. If it is possible to suspect that the rules are not applied with the same rigour, we fear that we will reach a situation where the rules are no longer respected because they are not the same for everyone. The modernisation of fleets would be an added value to the success of this measure, with the actors having useful capabilities for the control of irregularities. At the same time, it is urgent to defend fishermen in the Outermost Regions, because with their extensive EES and with the limitations of the Member States in taxing them, they are greatly harmed. Control and supervisory actions in the ORs' EEAs should therefore be increased, as I advocated in an amendment to this report and which was adopted by the European Parliament.  To this end, the budgetary resources available, in particular through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF), should be consistent with the objectives of the control and should foster research and innovation. It is through these instruments that the control policy as a whole can be modernised. Regrettably, the EMFF is clearly insufficient for the needs of the sector.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. How can fishing controls in Europe be made homogeneous? A broad question to which the European Parliament tried to provide an answer this afternoon by approving the Thomas report. The current situation is not satisfactory insofar as there is a real or perceived inequity of fishermen when it comes to factors as varied as regularity, rigour, duration, intensity, efficiency and methods of fishing controls in Europe. Among the obstacles to effective controls, the text appropriately points to the fact that some Member States organising checks of the machine at the plate and others only on certain links in the chain, excluding for example the transport or catering part. The solution advocated by MEPs is therefore to extend inspections to cover the entire production chain and to assign offshore controls to a single national administrative entity. Realistically, the European Parliament is also calling for the full implementation of Regulation (EC) 1224/2009 on fisheries control. It also insists on more flexibility in the application of the landing obligation, which constitutes a radical change for sinners.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The harmonisation of legislation on fisheries controls in Europe and control procedures must be transparent and uniform. The different control bodies should seek to coordinate their activities. Sanctions must be the same for everyone.  The first step is to create a role of judges specialising in marine affairs in each Member State. In the meantime for controls to become more effective, it is also necessary to make the means of financing, in particular the EMFF, more consistent with the objectives of the control.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Fisheries control in the Union differs from one Member State to another, with differences in the procedures and types of sanctions applied for the same type of infringements — in some cases administrative and other criminal in nature — differences in the level of resources used, lack of specialised inspectors, databases not always interchangeable between Member States Etc. To address this, among other measures, it is proposed to adopt common control criteria, strengthen the role of the European Fisheries Agency, use greater resources and more modern means that provide more effective inspections or the promotion of European training of inspectors and fishermen.  In short, I support the rapporteur's approach to this report for the sake of homogenisation of fisheries controls in the Union, establishing a single framework of reference. And, in particular, for identical infringements, identical sanctions are applied in all Member States. Thus ending the sense of inefficiency and injustice that arises in the sector.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this european Parliament's motion for a resolution, which puts forward several ways to make fisheries controls homogeneous. In the context of the revision of the regulation of fish control, this text proposes, for example, to harmonize the scope of existing EU legislation as well as sanctions or to set up genuine European training for controllers. These various recommendations are a good move: to establish true equality among all European fishermen.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of the unification of fisheries control is particularly relevant as it shows a divide between both North-South, i.e. richer and more advanced, and East-West, i.e. the old and new EU members. I am convinced that the rapid possible unification of these economic activities, while also ensuring an environmental component of fishing, such as compliance with and controlling the spawning regime, uniform regulation of nets and other fisheries, while providing for flexibility for specific areas and aquaculture, would make a significant contribution to building a more united Europe.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report has been drafted taking into account the preparation of the next fisheries control regulation.  The rapporteur stresses the importance of ensuring effective control of fishing activities in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of marine resources while maintaining a level playing field between fleets. To this end, Member States are urged to ensure the effective implementation of the control regulation. I welcome the significant improvement in the control regime thanks to the current regulation associated with the Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated Fisheries Regulation (IUU), but nevertheless forget the disparity between the different inspection sites and the discriminatory nature sometimes resulting in fisheries control. The text of this report reiterates the importance of strengthening the mandate of the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA) in order to set up joint fisheries control operations that will enable efficient coordinated action by (many) local, regional and national authorities, as well as by EU agencies performing similar functions. The lack of interoperability between data collected at Member States level has to be considered as a key element for this desired greater harmonisation, so it is important to share data in real time.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the fact that I understand that the report calls for simplifying and improving Union legislation, as well as reducing the administrative burden, a historical vindication of our sea people, points out that closer cooperation between Member States requires that, in this review, the European institutions and the fisheries sector work together, especially the coastal fisheries sector , artisanal and traditional whose protection and promotion should be the objective of any new legislation. As it also advocates the imposition of the highest penalties in the case of illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing or the inclusion of the impact of recreational fishing in the revision of the Control Regulation, all of them the objectives of our fishermen, advocates effective control of the traceability of our products throughout the chain and greater control of imported fish , adapting to the parameters of the Union.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the possibilities for standardising fisheries control in Europe. Effective controls on fishing activities need to be established to ensure the sustainable management of living marine resources. Parliament calls on the Member States to ensure effective implementation of the control regulation. The mandate of the EFCA is to be strengthened in order to be able to carry out joint operational control activities in the fisheries sector. This will also be promoted through harmonisation of data exchange between Member States.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report submitted by the Committee on Fisheries for approval by the Plenary of the European Parliament contains many positive aspects: the recognition of discriminatory treatment in the conduct of controls within the sector, the non-adequacy of some of the European standards to reality, the defence of regional or autonomous community inspections for inland waters , national maritime fishing inspections in waters up to 12 nautical miles and Union inspections for the rest of the waters. However, I abstained since the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring; the introduction of a point-based sanctions system, with implications for fishing licences. At the same time, the report reflects high centralisation and a Definition at Community level of technical and policy measures related to controls rather than cooperation between Member States, so I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the need to ensure uniform application of fisheries rules at European level. Unfortunately, the procedures for inspections and controls, the level of infringement and the penalties vary from one Member State to another. It is inevitable that this discrepancy will jeopardise not only the effectiveness of European legislation, but also the level playing field between EU fleets. I would like to stress that the differentiation on controls does not only concern fisheries, but the entire fisheries sector. I hope that, in this regard, the next revision of the regulation will also serve to provide the consumer with the appropriate information on the fish products that are served at the restaurant. At present, only a few Member States organise controls from vessel to table, while others only control certain links in the chain, excluding, for example, the transport or catering part. It is also important to understand whether the rules are not being complied with for non-compliance or because the current complexity and the high number of sometimes contradictory provisions undermine their actual applicability.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for a European Parliament resolution on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform. Among other things, the report advocates harmonising the scope of controls, increasing training opportunities for inspectors and fishermen, standardising sanctions, and investing more in technologies and the EFCA budget. It will create a level playing field for fishermen across the EU and improve respect for controls.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 This EP resolution stresses, inter alia, the need to ensure effective control of fishing activities in order to guarantee the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and to maintain a level playing field between EU fleets. It also calls for the development of a system for monitoring, transmitting information and analysing data that is compatible across the Union. I support this resolution. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although there has been a significant improvement under the current Control Regulation in combination with the Unreported and Unregulated Fisheries Regulation (IUU), there is a real or perceived injustice that, even taking into account possible regional differences, there are significant differences in the application of European legislation, in particular those based on the Control Regulation, even taking into account possible regional differences. Although each Member State has its own characteristic legal system, as well as different administrative and judicial structures, these systems in many cases lead to various irregularities and injustices between Member States. I supported the resolution because I think it is right for the Committee on Fisheries to address the shortcomings that give rise to a sense of injustice and, on the basis of the proposals and measures adopted, to improve the harmonisation of control of the common fisheries policy, which is one of the most integrated policies in Europe. I believe that by simplifying and improving Union legislation, as well as reducing the administrative burden, there will be better detection and sanctioning of infringements of the common fisheries policy.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report focuses on patchy practices on frequency, duration, rigour, thoroughness, effectiveness and methods of conducting fisheries control in the European Union and on the need for equal and non-discriminatory treatment in all Member States.  The fisheries sector represents a huge share of sustainable management of the sea and oceans and is thus of paramount importance for the future of our environment. This is why it is necessary to ensure effective control of fishing activities with a view to the sustainable use of living marine resources and to maintain a level playing field with regard to controls.  The report calls on the Member States to ensure the effective implementation of the Control Regulation and stresses that the European Union's fight against IUU fishing worldwide should be more ambitious and coincide with the effective implementation of the Regulation on controls in its waters.  Fishermen themselves adopt the rules if they consider them to be fair, sensible and compatible with fishing practices. It is from this point of view that the European Union must provide for rules that are aligned with both the fishing community and sustainable fishing. I believe that the report represents a step forward in this area, which is why I supported it.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on 'Opportunities for the unification of fisheries control in Europe'. I am opposed to uniform fisheries control. The aim is to coordinate control across Europe by standardising the structure of the authorities. The EU should not regulate how Member States enforce supervision by the authorities and whether this is done by one or more authorities, for example. The call for the creation of uniform training plans for fisheries inspectors within the EU is just one example of the excessive bureaucracy required in this report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is questionable whether the methods of fisheries control or the application of regulations in the European Union are the same and effective. Member States' different legal systems are the cause of unequal administrative or criminal sanctions for non-compliance with Common Fisheries Policy rules. This situation can cause great dissatisfaction among fishermen, which will result in their negative attitude about the honesty and meaningfulness of the imposed regulations and the feeling that their craft is controlled more than others. It is therefore important, inter alia, to simplify EUROPEAN Union legislation, reduce administrative burdens, enhance cooperation between Member States and implement legislation homogeneously. I support the report on how to harmonise fisheries control in Europe by the Fisheries Committee.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on how to unify fisheries control in Europe. We need control over fisheries activities to ensure the sustainable use of living marine resources and to maintain a level playing field for all fleets in the European Union. It is the Member States that need to implement the Control Regulation effectively.  The report rightly notes that the European Union's ambitious fight against IUU fishing worldwide should coincide with the effective implementation of the Regulation on controls in its waters, while clarifying, classifying and establishing standards for fishing in different maritime areas.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Controls on fisheries are of great importance in combating the negative phenomena of this vital activity. Illegal fishing and uncontrolled fishing in breeding seasons must be combated in order to preserve the offspring and marine populations. Under no circumstances, however, should recreational and coastal fishing be compared with professional mass-scale fishing.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report that we need simpler, more comprehensive and uniform rules in the common fisheries policy, particularly in the areas of transparency, cooperation, innovation and equal treatment. Currently, fisheries control varies from one Member State to another, from one fishery to another, and the report proposes to end this fragmentation. In the EU, we must ensure uniform application of legislation, as there are efficiency issues without it. In some Member States, for example, controls are carried out by a single supervisor, from fishing equipment to consumers, while in others there are several authorities at the same time to carry out these tasks. We must give priority to the single control system in order to achieve the objectives of the common fisheries policy. The forthcoming revision of the Control Regulation should set up effective rules to be able to prevent, detect and sanction abuses in a uniform way. I agree that the European Fisheries Control Office should play a greater role in this process. For all this, it is important to develop closer cooperation between the Member States, the Office and the European Commission.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with my colleague Isabelle Thomas on this issue. Fishermen often complain that fisheries control is much stricter at home than in their neighbours, either in another Member State or in another fishery. Fishermen also say everywhere that they practice the most controlled profession of all. This sense of injustice raises a real question: the homogeneity of the application of regulations and, therefore, its effectiveness. For if it is possible to suspect that the rules are not applied with the same rigour, it is to be feared that we will come to a situation where the rule is no longer respected on the grounds that it is not the same for all. The aim is twofold: to identify loopholes in the application of the rules that lead to this sense of inequity and to propose solutions to improve the harmonisation of control of the common fisheries policy, yet one of the most integrated policies in Europe.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU fisheries Control Regulation (2010) modernised the EU’s approach to fisheries by creating a common fisheries policy. In particular, it brought the system into line with the strong measures the Union had adopted at international level in 2008 to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. However, at the national level, Member States and their fisheries control authorities are responsible for the implementation of the policies. The report pointed to several areas for revision, including the necessity to respect the fishery rules, ensuring that all Member States are on a level playing field with regard to respecting the rules, the prevention of inequality or mistrust among the Member States, the creation of culture of compliance, and the need to improve uniformity. I voted in favour of the report because better implementation, cooperation and, where needed, homogenisation of control standards is a far better option that allowing further derogations from the current fisheries controls in the EU.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The adoption of my report by a very large majority sends a strong signal to the European Commission on the European Parliament's recommendations on the need for harmonisation of fisheries control in Europe. Solutions are being put forward in particular with regard to differences in transposition, repositories, sanctions, training, data and funding. The European Commission will have to take into account the points raised in its future proposal for a revision of the regulation. The issue of control of recreational fishing proposed in the report was the subject of a specific vote in plenary. This vote gathered a large majority to be included in the text. However, I regret that my colleagues in the Green Group abstained on this proposal because, today, recreational fishing accounts for more than a third of the volumes caught each year for some species. However, it is not controlled and the mortality caused is not taken into account in the annual assessment of the status of stocks. So it's a real measure to protect the resource.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fisheries controls are key to achieving the objectives of cfp reform. There are, however, huge differences in the scope of controls, the procedures and strategies of all Member States and regions are often different. The mandate of the European Fisheries Control Agency for the implementation of joint projects is limited and its budget is insufficient. The instruments and financial resources used to carry out controls vary from one Member State to another, regulations are transposed differently into national legislation, sanctions and judicial proceedings differ substantially, data are not always shared or accessible, and training for fishermen and inspectors is different and needs to be strengthened. These are the shortcomings highlighted in this own-initiative report, and it is therefore to be hoped that legislation will be simplified in a short time, single control rules will be drawn up, modern technologies will be used to enable better coordination, greater transparency and the creation of online databases and public websites. Finally, I support and give absolute priority to calling for improved European training for inspectors and for adequate training for fishermen.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The report respects the principle of subsidiarity – the focus of the report is on how to make fishing controls in Europe uniform while respecting national competences. There is a perception of injustice in the Union regarding the regularity, frequency, severity, duration, perseverance and effectiveness of fishing control methods in Europe, and that is why the aim of this report is to identify these shortcomings and enforce rules leading to this feeling of injustice and to propose solutions that will standardise controls within the Union's common fisheries policy. Since the proposals contained in the report are consistent with the principle of proportionality and that implementing them can potentially lead to a significant reduction in administrative burden, I voted yes.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on how to unify fisheries control in Europe. Fishermen often complain that they are much stricter in their fisheries control than their neighbours, be it another Member State or another fishing area.  They also claim to be the most controlled profession of all. This sense of injustice actually raises the question of the uniformity of the application of the rules and their effectiveness. Existing Union legislation should be simplified, firstly by revising Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009, which is foreseen in 2017. The structure of the current regulation is too complex.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the fact that I understand that the report calls for simplifying and improving Union legislation, as well as reducing the administrative burden, a historical vindication of our sea people, points out that closer cooperation between Member States requires that, in this review, the European institutions and the fisheries sector work together, especially the coastal fisheries sector , artisanal and traditional whose protection and promotion should be the objective of any new legislation. As it also advocates the imposition of the highest penalties in the case of illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing or the inclusion of the impact of recreational fishing in the revision of the Control Regulation, all of them the objectives of our fishermen, advocates effective control of the traceability of our products throughout the chain and greater control of imported fish , adapting to the parameters of the Union.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to homogenise fishing controls in Europe. It puts forward unacceptable proposals: the generalisation of a points permit, even harmonised, and the increase of the AECP budget, mainly to recruit new agents. Moreover, this report is part of an ever closer monitoring logic of fishermen: these, between the multiple declarations, electronic and satellite instruments, the checks on board or at the landing, are too monitored. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The burdens and controls faced by fishermen in Europe vary considerably from one Member State to another. Differences in frequency, duration and control methods lead to a feeling of unequal treatment in this sector. Past practice under Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 indicates that certain provisions are not being implemented sufficiently. This applies to m.in control procedures, the sanctions regime, the way in which data are collected.  The report identifies existing weaknesses and rightly proposes greater harmonisation of controls under the common fisheries policy. Simplification of legislation through common standards for control, inspection and supervision, reduction of the burden on fishermen, the intention to strengthen operational cooperation between Member States and the review of the application of the Regulation planned for 2017 are steps in the right direction. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fishermen are often heard complaining that fishing controls were much stricter than their neighbours, regardless of whether the latter occurred in another Member State or in another fishery. Fishermen everywhere also claim that they are the most controlled of all professions. This sense of injustice raises a real question: the question of the uniform application of legislation and thus its effectiveness. Since it can be assumed that the rules are not applied with the same rigour, it is feared that a situation may occur in which the rule, on the basis that it is not the same for all, will not be observed. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the fact that I understand that the report calls for simplifying and improving Union legislation, as well as reducing the administrative burden, a historical vindication of our sea people, points out that closer cooperation between Member States requires that, in this review, the European institutions and the fisheries sector work together, especially the coastal fisheries sector , artisanal and traditional whose protection and promotion should be the objective of any new legislation. As it also advocates the imposition of the highest penalties in the case of illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing or the inclusion of the impact of recreational fishing in the revision of the Control Regulation, all of them the objectives of our fishermen, advocates effective control of the traceability of our products throughout the chain and greater control of imported fish , adapting to the parameters of the Union.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of better controls on fisheries and equivalent levels of control for all fish (imported fish, EU-caught fish both inside the EU and elsewhere, etc.).

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on how to make fisheries controls in Europe uniform. The fisheries sector is a major stakeholder in the sustainable management of the seas and oceans. However, there is a need for stricter checks on products coming into the EU from illegal, unreported and unregulated fisheries and a need to guarantee an equivalent level of control on such fishing in all Member States. The report stresses the importance of ensuring effective control of fisheries activities in order to guarantee sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and maintain a level playing field among EU fleets. I voted in favour because I believe that it is necessary to clarify, classify and establish standards for fishing in the different maritime areas.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Within a few months of the revision of the Fisheries Control Regulation, this initiative opinion calls for progress towards an equal application of control establishing the same procedures and sanctions throughout the Union. To achieve this, it is crucial that Member States develop sufficient capacities to share information in real time. Because of the in-depth analysis of the subject throughout the text, I considered it appropriate to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report submitted by the Committee on Fisheries for approval by the Plenary of the European Parliament contains many positive aspects: the recognition of discriminatory treatment in the conduct of controls within the sector, the non-adequacy of some of the European standards to reality, the defence of regional or autonomous community inspections for inland waters , national maritime fishing inspections in waters up to 12 nautical miles and Union inspections for the rest of the waters. However, I abstained since the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring; the introduction of a point-based sanctions system, with implications for fishing licences. At the same time, the report reflects high centralisation and a Definition at Community level of technical and policy measures related to controls rather than cooperation between Member States, so I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU fisheries controls aim at biological sustainability by combating illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing.  The REVIEW of the CFP decontextualised some issues related to controls, which were outdated. Indeed, there is a need for more uniform control, as the rules do not apply uniformly between different types of fishing or even between different Member States. This creates contradictions among fishermen as regards regularity, frequency, duration, severity, rigour, effectiveness and methods of fisheries control in Europe. However, the report has several aspects that raise ambiguous concerns and interpretations, such as those related to the use of new technologies for monitoring and the introduction of a point-based sanctions system with implications for fishing licences.  At the same time, the report reflects a high centralisation and an EU-wide definition of control-related technical and political measures rather than cooperation between Member States and cannot be supported globally.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report has some good proposals, such as equivalent control of imported products, it ultimately aims at increasing the budget of the Fisheries Agency and, above all, at further tightening regulations with regard to fishermen, which also need to be significantly technologically upgraded here. As this step seems to me to be ill-considered and, above all, unworkable at the moment, I voted against the report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Mrs Thomas's report on fisheries controls in Europe. At present, due to inconsistent legislation, there are significant differences in the field of carrying out fisheries controls. It happens that in some countries these checks are carried out only surface-to-surface, they are carried out somewhere by different authorities and somewhere they are disproportionately strict. As a result, fishermen and fishing vessels are discriminated against and complaints about the practices of individual authorities. That is why the report dealt with the question of how these controls can be achieved so that these checks have a uniform level and that there are no significant differences. I also supported the resolution because it is necessary to control fishing activities in order to achieve the highest possible protection of the environment and sustainable fishing as such. Furthermore, I welcomed the call for the report to simplify European legislation and reduce the administrative burden.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Thomas report because I agree with the position on fisheries controls in Europe upstream of the fourth revision of the Common Fisheries Policy. This report already contains a preliminary opinion of what the European Parliament's position on this matter could be, focusing mainly on simplifying legislation, a single set of control standards, new technologies, better coordination between Member States, transparency, the creation of online databases and public websites and the training of fishermen and inspectors.  To this end, there is a call for increased controls to prevent the import of fish from illegal fishing, in particular by setting up national teams in the information area with specialised fisheries inspectors.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report 'How to unify fisheries control in Europe?'. The report stresses the importance of ensuring effective control of fishing activities in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and to maintain a level playing field for the EU fleet, and calls on the Member States to ensure the effective implementation of the Control Regulation. I agree that it is necessary to ensure the coherence of the single market in all Member States by establishing the same control requirements, with a uniform quality level in internal and external controls in the Member States, irrespective of the borders where products enter the EU.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because the role of the European Union is, among other things, to connect the different regions and countries of the EU. As far as transport infrastructure is concerned, this is logical, but I have taken the view that I have stayed at point 56, which refers to the complete navigability of the Elbe River. Its navigability is important for connecting the countries of Central Europe. As a Czech MEMBER, I must say that the subject is not as simple as the point seems. It is a more complex topic, in the public debate that takes place around the navigable Elbe, environmentalists stand on one side, on the other hand there are those who want to navigable the river. I think that the European Parliament cannot make such a clear decision on this matter without information. That is why I have abstained and I hope that in the Czech Republic this debate will continue on the basis not only of political but also of professional arguments, so as to provide sufficient protection for the Czech nature.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European Parliament has missed an important opportunity today. I voted against the final report, after they were voted on by a party that surprises me very much, Mr President, I would like to tell a little history: only one estimate does the Committee on Transport voted in favour of including the programming of corridors that would link that province of Belluno with the rest of Europe, but today in this House and yesterday afternoon the first voting report was in favour of the People's Party and then two hours later it changed it. But who voted against it? I cannot be angry with the rest of the countries that have legitimately done their best, Mr President. Prevent a lot of money from arriving in Italy, they arrive in the northeast of Italy that connects perfectly with the eastern center of European mobility. They celebrated. But who did all this? Mr Gardini. Coincidentally, the forza italia group leader and Forza Italia's European head of delegation, linked to the People's Party, voted against and worked to vote against Italy's legitimate interests. I believe that this is a very serious act. I am sorry, Mr President, because I know that my time is up, but this is not such a serious act in relation to my country and my land.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: We repeat until it happens. Transport infrastructure needs to be connected and accessible to create jobs, grow the economy and increase competition. I remind the Commission of the obligation to be laid down in the White Charter to transfer 30% of road transport over distances of more than 300 kilometres to rail and river transport by waterways, and that is by 2030. The potential for inland waterway transport to the region should be used more, especially along the Danube. The possibility of opening the Rhine-Danube corridor to the north through Via Carpathia should then be considered. And four, I call for the inclusion of this project, Via Carpathia, in the TEN-T core network in order to provide it with adequate funding from the European Union. Thanks.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report stresses the need to improve the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure allocated in the central and eastern regions of the Union. Priority is given to the road transport sector and its safety. With regard to rail transport, on the other hand, the priority importance of its modernisation is stressed in order to reduce, among others, the climate impact, air pollution and the number of accidents. As far as shipping is to be done, we are called for the northern Adriatic ports to be upgraded. The necessary financial instruments are also identified, including the CEF, the European Structural and Investment Funds, the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and the FUNDS of the EIB and the EBRD. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to reject this non-legislative resolution as the EU should not be making decisions that affect the transport policy of Member States.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Privatisation of infrastructure and the opening up of peripheral markets to products in central economies are the two main axes of the Union's transport policy. That is also the case in this report, so I voted against it.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report outlined a range of suggestions to modernise and enhance the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure from and within Central and Eastern parts of the EU. It has some positive features, including reiterating the TEN-T objectives of bridging missing links, removing bottlenecks, and ensuring seamless connections for long-distance and regional transport, particularly in cross-border regions, for passengers and freight.  However, attempts to improve the report in committee by including pro-social and pro-environment elements were rejected and overall the report is highly focused on economic growth and competitiveness, heavy infrastructure and subordinating all transport modes ‘without exception’ to the needs of competitiveness and the single market. The report also repeatedly promotes the use of Public-Private Partnerships in developing transport infrastructure, and its reference to TEN-T is limited to the core network, with a heavy focus on growth rather than meeting social need. For these reasons, we voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. Transport infrastructure in the Central and Eastern European region has greatly improved in recent years, but much remains to be done, particularly with regard to the development of the TEN-T base corridors and the global network.  This report covers all modes of transport and focuses on multimodal transport, stressing not only the need to complete major road infrastructure projects, but also high-speed rail transport, inland navigation and improved links between regional airports.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on improving the interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, because I believe that the restoration of missing links and the wider improvement of transport infrastructure will have tangible benefits both in passenger and freight mobility and in enhancing the security of the EU's eastern borders.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe has been significantly improved and modernised with EU support. However, there is still room for improvement in cross-border links in the north-south direction between these Member States. As improvements to transport infrastructures always require substantial investment, it is essential that the Member States in Central and Eastern Europe and the Commission continue to fully coordinate at all levels of transport policy and project planning. It is also essential to use all the synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds), the Connecting Europe Facility, the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) in financing. The same applies to the timely mobilisation of the Funds of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) which will be made available for the near future. I welcome this report because it can help to address certain problems that can be encountered in the development of the various modes of transport by land, sea and air in the eu's central and eastern regions.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe certainly presents positive points, such as the need for better use of European funding, greater transparency, administrative relief, more funds for the maintenance of existing infrastructure, a more logical distribution of regional airports, favouring local businesses when building infrastructure, making sure that the most isolated populations are not forgotten...  But at the same time, it advocates the enlargement of the Schengen area, is concerned with cycle paths and urban transport, praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the Commission, obscures Chinese participation and investments to develop central and eastern European transport infrastructure, remains evasive about the real effectiveness of European funds paid in Central and Eastern Europe and wants to involve Ukraine and the Western Balkans more in the eu's transport policy.  So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a report that does not directly affect the UK but it is the EU making decisions that will affect other Member States with minimal consultation of National Governments.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. High-quality transport links are fundamental to Europe's economic activities and to the quality of life of our citizens. This means that Member States must gather their resources and cooperate in order to further develop the trans-European transport network (TEN-T). That is why I have decided to approve this text.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Transport infrastructure connections and accessibility have a significant impact on economic growth, competitiveness, employment and territorial cohesion of the EU and its regions. I agree that the EP should support the process of developing this trans-European transport network (TEN-T) and continue to address the unresolved problems associated with transport infrastructure connections and accessibility in the EU part of Central and Eastern Europe by connecting Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria. One thing is clear that the Member States and the Commission must focus primarily on how to build missing connections, remove barriers and ensure seamless connections for both passengers and goods.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite some positives, this project advocates the enlargement of the Schengen area, is concerned with cycle paths and urban transport, praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the Commission, obscures Chinese investments to develop the transport infrastructure of Central and Eastern Europe, remains evasive about the real effectiveness of European funds paid in Central and Eastern Europe, wishes to involve Ukraine and the Western Balkans more with the TRANSPORT policy of the EU...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need to improve the network and accessibility of transport infrastructure to, to and from the central and eastern regions of the Union, taking into account the needs of the economy and the principles of sustainable development.  It recalls the objectives of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) which consists of establishing missing links, removing bottlenecks and ensuring seamless connections for regional and long-distance transport, particularly in cross-border regions, for passenger traffic and freight.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which seeks to achieve high-quality transport connections in central and eastern Europe. The text considers that easily accessible and well-connected transport networks covering the local, regional, national and cross-border dimensions of passenger and freight transport are essential to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion within the Member States and between the Member States of the Union. In this way, improving connections would facilitate the economic development of these European regions with the highest poverty rates in the Union. In this report, I voted against those points where the creation of a new European corridor that directly communicates Venice's port platform with northeastern Europe is prioritised. This new corridor is contrary to Spanish interests that focus on prioritizing the central corridor and the Mediterranean corridor, both necessary to improve connections with the rest of Europe and promote the economic development of our country.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I supported the Poręba report on improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. This is a crucial issue for the future of the Union, with the advanced networks of the central part of the continent coexisting today with the poorly developed networks of the eastern regions. The infrastructure deficit presents itself as a lack of opportunities for territories that actually have the potential to attract investment and contribute to economic growth across the EU. The text, reaffirming the objectives of the trans-European transport network, therefore stresses the need for the Union to create new infrastructures and to invest in the modernisation and completion of existing ones. Accessibility and connectivity are a crucial element for economic growth, competitiveness, employment and territorial cohesion, which is why we need project planning coordinated by the Member States and better use of existing policies and instruments for regional cooperation. The use of EU macro-regional strategies can provide an innovative governance framework to address the new challenges facing transport policy and to ensure that existing harmful disparities are definitively overcome.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the gaps and deficiencies that still persist in the Union's transport network in Central and Eastern Europe, despite the investments made and the progress made. Although there are some positive points — coherence between Union financial instruments, multimodality or cycling infrastructure development — I voted against it, because the only criterion proposed to identify and assess infrastructure gaps is to enhance the single market, economic development and the competitiveness of enterprises in transnational markets. Consequently, references to the criteria of social cohesion or environmental sustainability are merely testimonial. It also advocates relaunching some large cross-border infrastructures that have strong opposition from affected local communities.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on strengthening the network and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe provides an update on European funding for transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, and makes several recommendations to the Commission. Many transport infrastructure in Eastern Europe is dilapidated or dangerous. The EU has launched a call for projects of 7.6 billion euros (including 6.5 million euros for the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, and also for Portugal and Greece). Several negative points appear in this report: the INCREASEd EU interest in cycle paths (farewell principle of subsidiarity), the desire to save the non-viable Schengen area at all costs from the outset, and even to extend it to Romania and Bulgaria, the willingness to extend EU funding to non-EU Balkan countries and Ukraine, and the promotion of macro-regions , seen as ideal new forms of governance. Finally, the report also overlooks the expansion of Chinese influence in Central and Eastern Europe. Some points are certainly positive but, in view of the negative elements developed above, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text on improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe is largely acceptable. I believe it is essential to guarantee italian companies efficient connections with Eastern Europe, given the importance of trade between our industry and those territories. An improvement in the routes between Northern Italy, especially those in the Northeast, would encourage the activity of our companies, for which the territories of Central and Eastern Europe represent the natural export markets. For these reasons, I wanted to support the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report, by which Parliament asks the European Commission for greater EU attention to projects to improve connectivity and accessibility in Central and Eastern Europe, additional administrative assistance so that they can benefit from the Structural Funds and the Connecting Europe Facility; project funding is required to focus primarily on building outstanding links, eliminating bottlenecks and ensuring seamless connections for passengers and goods.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with improving the connectivity and access of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. Quality transport routes are essential for economic activity in Europe and for ensuring the quality of life of our citizens. Easily accessible and well-connected transport networks, which take into account local, regional, national and cross-border aspects of passenger transport and freight transport, are the basis for promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion within and between EU Member States. At European level, the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) aims to expand the integrated multimodal network across the EU, thereby promoting the interconnection and interoperability of national networks and access to this network. The ten-t guidelines and the Connecting Europe Facility set out the main pillars for the implementation of EU transport infrastructure policy by 2020, following the ten-t guidelines and the Connecting Europe Facility in 2013. In preparing and implementing projects, Member States and the EU will need to pool their resources and work closely together to complete the strategic core network by 2030 and to an overarching network by 2050. The European Parliament believes that this is precisely the time when Parliament should support the process of building this trans-European transport network and continue to address the unresolved problems associated with transport infrastructure connections and accessibility in the EU part of Central and Eastern Europe by connecting Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 From their accession to the present day, the transport infrastructure of the Member States in the eastern part of the Union has undoubtedly been significantly modernised and upgraded with the continued help of the EU. At the same time, for historical and geographical reasons, the focus has been on projects to rebuild connections to and from western Member States. This is to be changed and somewhat counterbalanced by the adopted report. However, in addition to the east-west transport axis, the development of the north-south link is of the utmost importance, which can lead primarily to the economic recovery of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe. The report is unique in its kind, as it deals with the challenges within the region and future opportunities in a single document in the field of road, rail, water and air traffic and interoperability. Hungary the fact that it raises the possibility of exploiting a number of opportunities affecting our country is also significant from the point of view of the hungarian economy. These include the further development of the Via Carpathia project and the construction of its route from north to south in the eastern part of the country, which was highlighted in the document. The report also highlights the development of relations with the candidate countries, be it Ukraine or the Western Balkan countries. The financial framework needed to achieve the ambitious targets will be provided by exploiting the resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the European Network Finance Facility (CEF), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), as well as the instruments of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the synergies between them. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report because the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure have a profound impact on economic growth and the competitiveness of the economy, as well as on employment and territorial cohesion in the EU and its regions.  However, the transport link system is in some cases static and causes restrictions. By further investing and developing transport infrastructure, we can provide important help to the people and businesses in these regions. However, effective absorption of these funds will require transparency and well-prepared projects. Eastern Europe in particular has serious difficulties in switching to railways, as it lags behind the creation of modern railway infrastructure. Here, the European Commission should continue to provide incentives and assistance to countries behind, otherwise we cannot expect the creation of an efficient European rail network in the next two decades.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this report, which states that transport infrastructure across Central and Eastern Europe has improved greatly over recent years, but much still needs to be done, especially on the development of TEN-T core corridors and a comprehensive network.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If I am aware of the need to improve the infrastructure of the ever-old Central European countries despite the considerable sums already swallowed up by European funds, I remain firmly opposed to the enlargement of the Schengen area and the macro-regional governance of the EU advocated by this report. Furthermore, I am opposed to the idea of involving the Balkan countries and Ukraine in EU transport policy. So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed the resolution on improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe bearing in mind that the transport infrastructures in most of these regions are still underdeveloped compared with those of other EU countries. Furthermore, I believe the macro-regional EU strategies offer an innovative governance framework for tackling these challenges by ensuring better transport conditions. As a matter of fact, this resolution recognises the role of regions in the development of transport infrastructures.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 High quality transport links are essential for European economic activities and for the quality of life of citizens. The aim of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) is to develop an integrated multimodal transport network at EU level. The European Parliament must maintain the momentum of this new TEN-T process and address the challenges of accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure in the Central and Eastern Member States, which have undergone improvements and modernisations since the pre-accession period, but where there are still serious gaps. These must be filled in order to stimulate economic growth and employment opportunities for citizens and businesses. In addition, the maintenance of sustainable transport links should be seen as an increasingly important factor in promoting the stability and security of the EU's eastern border and the Western Balkans. In this context, the Member States and the Commission must establish the missing links and ensure unindered links. It is essential that the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe and the Commission step up coordination at all stages of transport policy and project planning, as continued significant investment is required.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report provides an overview of European funding for transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe and sets out a series of recommendations for developing transport networks in these countries, whether they are EU members, candidates for membership or third countries benefiting from the neighbourhood policy.  The succession of wishful thinking expressed in this report, such as improving the use of funding, increasing transparency in the allocation of funds or easing administrative constraints, does not mask the harmfulness of certain proposals. The report praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the Commission while obscuring the scope of Chinese investment in the region.  So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic activities in Europe depend to a significant extent on existing high-quality transport links. Furthermore, in order to foster economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Member States, it is necessary to have well-connected and accessible transport networks. The Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) is a first step in promoting the interconnection and interoperability of national networks. The dynamics of this new TEN-T process need to be continued in order to address the problems relating to the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. As a result, I have expressed myself in favour of this report, because I believe it is an essential tool to improve the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe and will have a positive impact in terms of economic growth and investment stimulation.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Transport is the foundation of any economy. Market integration, economic growth and transport activity are closely linked activities. In the EU, effective transport links have facilitated the creation and integration of the internal market. However, efforts still need to be made to effectively link transport systems in western Europe with those in central and eastern Europe, in order to keep growth and employment opportunities for citizens and businesses as high as possible. I support the EP's motion for a resolution on the report to improve the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. In urban areas, facilitating walking and cycling should become an integral part of urban mobility and infrastructure projects. It should be recalled that, in order to improve transport infrastructure, all means provided by the European Fund for Strategic Investments must be used on time.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure have an important impact on economic growth, employment and territorial cohesion in the EU. Central and Eastern Europe is an essential part of the European single market and has the right potential to attract investment and thus contribute to economic growth across the EU. In order to contribute best to the development of the single market, modes of transport in full should contribute to strengthening competitiveness, intermodality and ecological transition. The use of EU funding must therefore reflect the real investment needs for the completion of the TEN-T central network in the region by 2030. In addition to the need to create new infrastructure, Europe must invest in the modernisation and completion of existing transport infrastructure. Thanks to its strategic geographical position, Central and Eastern Europe can become an important logistics centre and a key communication hub between Europe and Asia.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. It outlines a range of suggestions to modernise and enhance the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure from and within Central and Eastern parts of the EU. On the one hand, it reiterates the TEN-T objectives of bridging missing links, removing bottlenecks, and ensuring seamless connections for long-distance and regional transport, particularly in cross-border regions, for passengers and freight.  However, my GUE/NGL colleagues attempted to improve the report in committee by including pro-social and pro-environment elements but this was rejected and overall the report is highly focused on economic growth and competitiveness, heavy infrastructure and subordinating all transport modes ‘without exception’ to the needs of competitiveness and the single market. The report also repeatedly promotes the use of public-private partnerships in developing transport infrastructure, and its reference to TEN-T is limited to the core network (again a heavy focus on growth rather than social need). For these reasons I voted against.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject this non-legislative resolution as the EU should not be making decisions that affect the transport policy of Member States.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree that a further boost is necessary to improve the cross-border connectivity in the north-south direction between the EU Member States in Central and Eastern Europe. Although a lot has been done in terms of modernisation and improvements since membership, there is still room for further improvement. This can be achieved through a balance of using different modes of land, water and air transport, including the promotion of inter-modality through hubs, ports and reassessing cross-border rail connections.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Poręba's report aims to improve the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in the direction, from and within the central and eastern regions of the EU, by investing in the modernisation and completion of existing transport infrastructure. The different critical issues divided by mode of transport from road to road are addressed, which highlights the need for a better infrastructure network along the EU's eastern border. The road safety factor is taken into account. In the light of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 High quality and unnecessary transport links are essential for the economic development and quality of life of our European citizens. Transport infrastructure in the Territory of the Union has undoubtedly improved over the last few decades, contributing to the reconstruction of links in the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe. Nevertheless, much still needs to be done to fill the gaps in access and connection of certain regions. It is clear that these challenges require constant and significant investment plans as well as adequate coordination at all stages of transport and project planning policy. In this respect, I believe that the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) is an important instrument that can promote not only the interconnection and coordination of national networks but, more generally, relaunch growth and development on European territories, especially in rural and remote areas. I voted in favour of this report because it is geared towards principles of sustainability and accessibility in the development of transport infrastructure.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote in favour of the report and underline that economic activities in Europe and the quality of life of our citizens depend to a large extent on high-quality transport links. Transport networks – with good connections serving passenger and freight transport at local, regional, national and cross-border level – and easy access to them are a driving force for strengthening economic, social and geographical cohesion within and between Member States in the EU.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on improving the interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. It is a fact that we are called upon to support these sectors in this region, with a view to developing and improving infrastructure. However, the fact that this report focuses almost exclusively on economic issues, ignoring the need to examine the social implications and needs of citizens and, above all, of workers, has led me to the decision to vote against the report.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which deals with important infrastructure issues, including in the East of Padano.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is essential to ensure quality transport links, which are a resource for increasing economic activities and the quality of life of citizens. Networks should be easily accessible and well connected and should include a local, regional, national and cross-border dimension of passenger and freight transport. Thanks to EU help, transport infrastructure has undergone significant improvements and upgrades, but despite the progress made there are still gaps in the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure across Central and Eastern Europe. We therefore need to build the missing connections, remove bottlenecks and ensure unindered connections for both passengers and goods. I believe that cooperation within the EU's macro-regional strategies could be useful in addressing transport policy issues that cannot be resolved by individual Member States. All efforts should be made within the framework of a results and performance-oriented approach, seeking cost-effective and environmentally friendly transport solutions.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on improving the connection and accessibility of the transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe and noted no objections.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as I believe that it is essential to continue pursuing the TEN-T process with the aim of increasingly improving the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure in the Member States of the central and eastern part of the EU also in order to improve border stability and security.  Cooperation in the EU's macro-regional strategies can also help in this direction: the use of the innovative governance mechanism could facilitate the resolution of outstanding transport policy issues, which cannot be resolved by individual Member States.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Privatisation of infrastructure and the opening up of peripheral markets to products in central economies are the two main axes of the Union's transport policy. That is also the case in this report, so I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The accessibility and interconnection of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe is still underdeveloped compared to those in other European regions. However, the construction of new long-distance, regional and urban transport, and the modernisation of existing ones are priorities for the fair and sustainable development of European territories and the EU single market, in terms of employment, growth and economic competitiveness. They are therefore primary means of achieving the objectives of cohesion policy.  I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the points that have been made.
