These include, in particular, the need for the use of European funding in line with the objective of completing the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) in the region by 2030 and with the commitments resulting from the 2011 Transport White Paper until 2020; in particular, a more efficient use of existing policies and instruments for regional cooperation, such as European territorial cooperation (CTE), Interreg and European Territorial Cooperation Groups (EGTCs), to eliminate bottlenecks between regions in the cross-border transport system. It is also important to promote the potential of hybrid public-private partnership projects by linking European sources of funding with public and private resources.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring high-quality transport is essential for the quality of life of Union citizens, but also for economic activity. The interconnection of national networks is the future of transport within the Union. Projects to restore links to and from Western EU states must also be extended to countries such as Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria. In order to carry out this project, it is essential that the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe and the Commission step up their full coordination at all stages of transport policy development and project planning. I voted for the development of this project with benefits for both regional security and the mobility and well-being of citizens.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I supported the report on improving connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, as it is innovative and comprehensive and is fully dedicated to the development of transport infrastructure in Central and Central and Central and Eastern Europe (CEE). It is important that it contains specific guidelines and recommendations on the direction of infrastructure development, support areas and the need for specific projects in the CEE region (construction of Rail Baltica, Via Carpathia road, development of the eastern part of the EUSALP, creation of a new European corridor). For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report provides input for addressing the development of the different modes of land, water and air transport in the Central and Eastern EU, including the promotion of inter-modality through hubs and in ports and the need for redressing cross-border passenger rail connections. I am in favour of this report as it aims to improve the accessibility and connection of transport infrastructure which recognises the need of cycling provisions in new road development, protection of the environment and biodiversity while including measures to reduce road accidents.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on strengthening the mesh and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe.  The underdevelopment of transport networks in the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe is a hindrance to their economic growth as well as that of the internal market. In order to strengthen the convergence of economies and social cohesion between the Eu Member States, it is necessary to promote greater cooperation between the European Commission and the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe for the creation of an interconnected and accessible transport network throughout the country.  While the majority of efforts have so far focused on the East-West axis, I think it is particularly important to focus on the transport networks linking north to south of Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 From their accession to the present day, the transport infrastructure of the Member States in the eastern part of the Union has undoubtedly been significantly modernised and upgraded with the continued help of the EU. At the same time, for historical and geographical reasons, the focus has been on projects to rebuild connections to and from western Member States. The report is unique in its kind, as it deals with the challenges within the region and future opportunities in a single document in the field of road, rail, water and air traffic and interoperability. The financial framework needed to achieve the ambitious targets will be provided by exploiting the resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the European Network Finance Facility (CEF), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), as well as the instruments of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the synergies between them. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text presents positive points, such as the need for better use of European funding, greater transparency, administrative relief, increased funds for the maintenance of existing infrastructure, a more logical allocation of regional airports or support for local businesses when building infrastructure.  Nevertheless, it calls for the enlargement of the Schengen area and praises the macro-regional governance defended by the Commission. Similarly, it obscures the issue of Chinese investments to develop central and eastern European transport infrastructure, remains evasive about the real effectiveness of EU funds allocated to Central and Eastern European countries, and wishes to involve Ukraine and the Western Balkans more in EU transport policy. So I preferred to vote against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on improving the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. This is the first detailed document fully dedicated to transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. It is important to pay equal attention to all transport corridors, regardless of which area of Europe they are in, in order to stimulate their potential.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the report because it promotes the execution of projects in already developed countries, such as Germany, while giving very little weight to countries that really need to build infrastructure projects.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – From their accession to the present day, the transport infrastructure of the Member States in the eastern part of the Union has undoubtedly been significantly modernised and upgraded with the continued help of the EU. At the same time, for historical and geographical reasons, the focus has been on projects to rebuild connections to and from western Member States. This is to be changed and somewhat counterbalanced by the adopted report. The report is unique in its kind, as it deals with the challenges within the region and future opportunities in a single document in the field of road, rail, water and air traffic and interoperability. Hungary the fact that it raises the possibility of exploiting a number of opportunities affecting our country is also significant from the point of view of the hungarian economy. These include the further development of the Via Carpathia project and the construction of its route from north to south in the eastern part of the country, which was highlighted in the document. The report also highlights the development of relations with the candidate countries, be it Ukraine or the Western Balkan countries. The financial framework needed to achieve the ambitious targets will be provided by exploiting the resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the European Network Finance Facility (CEF), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), as well as the instruments of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the synergies between them. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The importance of improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure for economic activities in Europe and for the quality of life of our citizens is essential, so we must have high-quality, easily accessible and well-connected transport connections covering the local, regional, national and cross-border dimensions of passenger and freight transport.  Transport infrastructures in the Member States of this part of the Union have undoubtedly been the subject of considerable modernisation and improvement, and are essential to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion within the Member States and between the Member States of the Union.  Unfortunately, significant gaps persist in the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructures throughout the territory of the Central and Eastern Union which must be filled as much as possible in order to maintain sustainable transport connections, understanding them as an increasingly important factor in increasing the stability and security of the eastern border of the Union and in the Western Balkans.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Immediate access to transport networks with good connections covering the local, regional, national and cross-border dimensions of passenger and freight transport is at the heart of promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU Member States and among themselves. Member States and the EU will need to pool their resources and cooperate closely in the design and implementation of projects to complete the strategic main network by 2030 and the global network by 2050. Member States and the Commission should first concentrate on brimling missing links, eliminating bottlenecks and ensuring non-discontinuing links for both passenger and freight transport, thereby meeting ten-t objectives. However, these efforts to complete the main corridors should also stimulate the development of the global network by providing a link to neighbouring regions, particularly in cross-border regions, and thereby achieve the consolidation of network corridors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: he advocates the enlargement of the Schengen area, praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the Commission, obscures Chinese investments to develop transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, remains evasive about the real effectiveness of European funds paid in Central and Eastern Europe, wants to involve Ukraine and the Western Balkans more in EU transport policy...

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The existence of quality transport infrastructure and systems is a guarantee for the development of countries and for the improvement of the quality of life of the population. The connection and inter-operation between transport systems, within one country or between several countries, is also a facilitating element of development and the establishment of commercial relations and socio-cultural communication.  The countries of Central and Eastern Europe have every right to full development and to take advantage of the instruments available to ensure greater cohesion. This report, however, emphasises strategies and instruments that represent interests contrary to those of the peoples – of the various Member States and not only of those targeted. From the outset, at the heart of the objectives of the report is the intention to deepen the single market. More than improving transport operability in Central and Eastern Europe, the market for European monopolies should be extended to this macro-region. At the same time, it seeks to anticipate future enlargements (Western Balkans, Ukraine), by expanding the transport system so that entry into the single market is made fluidly. At the same time, it calls for the way in which infrastructure is materialised through the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), from the possibilities offered by hybrid projects in public-private partnerships. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe that it aims to improve and develop transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe alone, excluding, in fact, the same efforts for transport lines linking East-West and North-South, which would include the completion of the A27 motorway and the improvement of the Italian-Austrian road transport network.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Quality transport links are essential for promoting entrepreneurship, economic growth and related job creation. It is about improving the quality of life of our citizens. For years, for example, they have been listening to various governments about the need to complete motorway infrastructure. The situation has undoubtedly improved recently. However, this is still insufficient compared to neighbouring countries. Stronger support for better interconnection of transport networks between the V4 states, as well as throughout the Central and Eastern Europe region, is also essential. This requires intensifying cooperation and substantial investment. In addition to the Structural and Investment Funds, the European Union offers a number of financial mechanisms for this. These can be used, for example, through the European Investment Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development or the European Fund for Strategic Investments. In addition to connecting road and rail transport infrastructure or supporting local airports, the Central and Eastern European region also has significant potential in terms of water transport development.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because I agree with the need to improve the connection and accessibility of infrastructure.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on improving the interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, as it promotes the execution of projects in already developed countries, such as Germany, while giving very little weight to countries that really need the construction of infrastructure projects.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Transport infrastructure across the Central and Eastern Europe region has greatly improved over recent years but much more needs to be done, particularly on developing the TEN-T core corridors and comprehensive network. The benefits of bridging missing links and improving connectivity can extend to passengers and freight, supporting passenger mobility, trade, economic development, tourism and enhancing the security of the eastern border of the EU. This report covers all modes of transport and emphasises multimodal transport, stressing the need not only for major road infrastructure projects to be completed but high-speed rail, inland waterway navigation and improved connections between regional airports. Full use should be made of available financial support, particularly from CEF and EFSI. I voted in favour of the report.

Therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that high-quality transport connections for economic and social development in Europe are essential. Easily accessible and well-connected transport networks covering the local, regional, national and cross-border dimensions of passenger and freight transport are essential to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion within member states and between the Member States of the Union. It is therefore time to address the outstanding challenges in relation to the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructures in the Member States of the central and eastern part of the Union, linking Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion and economic and social development through a strengthening of the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure. Because a strong network of accessible and extensive freight transport links encourages business activities and therefore growth, promotes occupational and personal mobility, multiplies opportunities for social and professional integration and stimulates tourism and the economy. Investing in connectivity and mobility therefore means networking experience and knowledge, combating marginalisation and poverty, strengthening cooperation and breaking down physical obstacles to facilitate the mobility of people with disabilities as well. I therefore fully agree with the idea of inclusive and sustainable growth promoted by the report 'Improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe'.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe because I believe it is essential that Europe has links between high-quality and modern Member States, which will ensure that the quality of life of our citizens is improved on the one hand and that the EU's environmental objectives are achieved on the other. The Structural Funds have played a leading role in modernising rail, sea and road links in Central and Eastern Europe, enabling several States to make a significant leap forward in the quality and quantity of their transport infrastructure. However, there are still some gaps, and the EU must make efforts to build the missing links by investing as much as possible in modes of transport with a low environmental impact.  I remain convinced that the completion of the TEN-T programme and public investment in the transport sector are a very important key to smart and sustainable growth, because they create jobs in the short term, while at the same time having positive effects in several other sectors of the economy, and have an immediate impact on the EU's own image in the eyes of its citizens.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As a member of the parliamentary Disability Intergroup, I voted today in favour of the 'Report on improving the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe'. Accessibility is a challenge for the whole of Europe and must basically apply to the same standards across borders.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the improvement of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. Freedom of movement and freedom of movement of persons and goods is a central pillar of the European Union. We must work to ensure that this fundamental right benefits all people in our community. The development of transport infrastructure is an important first step in this regard.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for a European Parliament resolution on improving the connection and accessibility of the transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE). To date, most of the transport infrastructure projects planned to be financed by the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) are found in Western Europe. This report aims to address that imbalance, by stating that capacity building and technical assistance is required; and that the Commission should encourage investors to support project platforms that focus on CEE transport infrastructure projects.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote is in support of this report to improve the trans-European transport networks so that our countries are increasingly connected and inequalities between our regions are becoming smaller, while remaining consistent with the indications we are giving as the European Parliament for the review of cohesion policy.  2030, the year indicated as the deadline for the establishment of the central strategic network, must necessarily be the essential objective of our work both on the territories covered by this measure and in the European Parliament, where we must continue to urge the competent institutions to carry out projects agreed and supported by the Union, especially in border areas, which will otherwise continue to see the social and commercial benefits of integration at European level.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I am puzzled by reading the Poreba report. I admit I don't understand everything. The European Union has been providing funding for the past 30 years to the transport networks of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, now members of the EU. However, these networks are still dilapidated and incomplete. How much has been invested and for what efficiency? Given the limited resources, do we need to modernize the existing one or move into new links? Governments in these countries are told which projects they should prioritise, supposedly based on the needs of their economies. But in reality, the projects mentioned are less structuring for these territories than for the single market, where it is important to optimize the supply chain of a production dispersed according to costs. It is claimed that they want to favour SMEs, but they are silent on European regulatory constraints and the attractiveness of the Chinese for these public contracts, although it is true that the subject is less topical than it was four or five years ago. If we add references to Schengen, bike lanes, the association of non-EU countries and the small charge against Russia (the Nord Stream pipeline that would clog ports like sardine in Marseille), we will understand that I did not vote for this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the gaps and deficiencies that still persist in the Union's transport network in Central and Eastern Europe, despite the investments made and the progress made. Although there are some positive points — coherence between Union financial instruments, multimodality or cycling infrastructure development — I voted against it, because the only criterion proposed to identify and assess infrastructure gaps is to enhance the single market, economic development and the competitiveness of enterprises in transnational markets. Consequently, references to the criteria of social cohesion or environmental sustainability are merely testimonial. It also advocates relaunching some large cross-border infrastructures that have strong opposition from affected local communities.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because it is of particular importance for improving the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe.  Disparities in infrastructure development and quality between the Central and Eastern European region and the rest of Europe can only be reduced by a clear, concrete and integrated strategy at EU level. The needs of cyclists should also be taken into account when building and upgrading road infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, as the development of bicycle infrastructure in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe will increase safety, reduce the number of road accident victims and improve the quality of life and health of the population in the European Union.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it focuses on how EU funding can be better utilised to address disparities in infrastructure development between Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) countries and the rest of the EU. The report calls for Member States and the Commission to focus on completing TEN-T corridors, bridging missing links, removing bottlenecks and improving connections between different modes of transport in CEE countries.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It is the right time for the European Parliament to keep up the momentum of the new TEN-T process and further address open challenges regarding the accessibility and connectivity of the transport infrastructure in the Member States of the Central and Eastern European part of the EU, bringing together Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria. The transport infrastructure in Member States of this part of the EU has certainly undergone substantial modernisation and improvements, with constant help by the EU, from the pre-accession period to date.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 From their accession to the present day, the transport infrastructure of the Member States in the eastern part of the Union has been significantly modernised and upgraded with the continued help of the EU. At the same time, for historical and geographical reasons, greater emphasis has been placed on projects from and to rebuild connections from western Member States. This is to be changed and somewhat counterbalanced by the adopted report. However, in addition to the east-west transport axis, the development of the north-south link is of the utmost importance, which could lead primarily to the economic recovery of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe. The report is unique in its kind, as it addresses the challenges within the region and future opportunities in the field of road, rail, water and air traffic and interoperability in a uniform way. Hungary is also important for our citizens to raise the issue of exploiting a number of opportunities affecting our country. These include the further development of the Via Carpathia project and the construction of its route from north to south in the eastern part of the country, which was highlighted in the document. The report also highlights the development of relations with the candidate countries, be it Ukraine or the Western Balkan countries. The financial framework needed to achieve the ambitious targets will be provided by exploiting the resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the European Network Finance Facility (CEF), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), as well as the instruments of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the synergies between them.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The need to enhance the connectivity and accessibility of the infrastructure for transport to, from and within the Central and Eastern parts of the EU is central in facilitating the free movement of persons throughout the Union. Therefore, EU funding must reflect the real investment needs for completing the TEN-T core network by 2030 in the region. Moreover, the EU should not only create new infrastructure but also invest in the modernisation and completion of existing transport infrastructures. This should include investments in rail, road and marine transport. This would open up the enormous potential to further economic engagement in Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on improving the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe (2015/2347(INI)), as the connectivity and availability of transport infrastructure to the middle and eastern parts of the EU, as well as within those parts, needs to be improved. Transport connectivity is essential for economic development. In this regard, existing ten-t network development plans should be used, including the expansion of this network towards the Western Balkans.  In addition to building new infrastructure, the EU needs to invest in modernising and completing existing transport infrastructure. The positive effects of synergies between the available funds and instruments of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, EIB and EBRD funds should be exploited. European territorial cooperation as well as european group models for territorial cooperation should be strengthened more strongly. The positive activation of €11 billion of cohesion policy funding through the Connecting Europe Facility is positive.  I welcome the fact that the Report underlines the importance of European macro-regional strategies, both those under implementation and those planned with a view to better connectivity, as well as the need to reduce the difference in the quality of transport infrastructure of more developed regions and those of less developed REGIONS of the EU. I would like to recall that when preparing this document, an amendment was adopted that I proposed together with my colleague Jozo Radoš on the inclusion of the port of Rijeka in the TEN-T corridor Baltic-Adriatic.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report contains interesting and sensible proposals, such as better use of European funding, administrative simplification, attention to better infrastructure maintenance, and the integration of local businesses into projects.  These positive aspects are nullified by other much more questionable proposals promoting the enlargement of the Schengen area, macro-regional governance, the hidden solicitation of Chinese investments for infrastructure financing or the association of non-European states with Community transport policy, measures which I oppose. I chose to vote against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on improving the connection and accessibility of the transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe because high quality transport links are fundamental for the economic activities in Europe and for the quality of life of our citizens. Transport networks have to cover the local regional, national and cross-border dimensions, because only a well-connected Europe will achieve economic, social and territorial cohesion in and between Member States in the EU.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Tomasz Poreba's report on transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe.  The trans-European transport network is in fact part of the proper functioning of the internal market and the strengthening of economic and social cohesion.  However, serious gaps in accessibility and networking across Central and Eastern Europe remain, which is why the report calls for better linking cross-border regions. These measures help boost employment and create new opportunities for businesses in these regions, and more generally for European businesses.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Economic activities in Europe and the quality of life of our citizens depend to a large extent on high quality transport links. At EU level, the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) aims to develop a single multi-media transport network across the EU, promoting the interconnection and interoperability of national networks and their access to it. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. It believes that the time is right for the European Parliament to take up and maintain the momentum of the new TEN-T process and to go deeper into unresolved problems in the areas of accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure in the EU's Central and Eastern European Member States. It is true, however, that accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure across the central and eastern EU is still extremely patchy and links need to be closed in order to preserve economic growth and employment opportunities for citizens and businesses to the greatest extent possible.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it focuses on how EU funding can be better utilised to address disparities in infrastructure development between Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) countries and the rest of the EU. The report calls for Member States and the Commission to focus on completing TEN-T corridors, bridging missing links, removing bottlenecks and improving connections between different modes of transport in CEE countries.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on improving the interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe addressed a very important topic, but lacked the necessary balance. From the outset, it seemed that the Polish rapporteur wanted to celebrate Poland's achievements in the first place and to lobby for Polish national needs in this area. While I am glad that the report recalls that the development of cross-border roads is essential to facilitate cooperation between people and businesses in border regions, and that it calls on the Member States to continue to modernise roads, build missing connections and safe and accessible parking spaces, and strengthen regional and local TEN-T connectivity, as ten-t involvement is an important basis for the economic growth of regional centres , but I would expect much more from a similar report. That is why I abstained during the vote.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 From their accession to the present day, the transport infrastructure of the Member States in the eastern part of the Union has undoubtedly been significantly modernised and upgraded with the continued help of the EU. At the same time, for historical and geographical reasons, the focus has been on projects to rebuild connections to and from western Member States. This is to be changed and somewhat counterbalanced by the adopted report. However, in addition to the east-west transport axis, the development of the north-south link is of the utmost importance, which can lead primarily to the economic recovery of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe. The report is unique in its kind, as it deals with the challenges within the region and future opportunities in a single document in the field of road, rail, water and air traffic and interoperability. Hungary the fact that it raises the possibility of exploiting a number of opportunities affecting our country is also significant from the point of view of the hungarian economy. These include the further development of the Via Carpathia project and the construction of its route from north to south in the eastern part of the country, which was highlighted in the document.  The financial framework needed to achieve the ambitious targets will be provided by exploiting the resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the European Network Finance Facility (CEF), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), as well as the instruments of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the synergies between them. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on improving the connections and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. Improving connectivity in Central and Eastern Europe is not only necessary, but also mandatory, given the principles of sustainable development in the context of investment needs to complete the TEN-T core network by 2030 in the region. This will also help to make better use of existing regional cooperation policies and instruments such as European Territorial Cooperation (ETC), Interreg and the European Groupings of Territorial Cooperation (EGTC). Member States ensuring a high level of transparency and control over EU spending must also be encouraged to adopt or continue to implement measures to move towards greener transport options.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure have a major impact on the economic growth, economic competitiveness, employment and territorial cohesion of the EU and its regions. Unfortunately, nowadays Central and Eastern Europe’s transport infrastructure is still undeveloped and significantly lags behind the one in Western Europe. Undeveloped infrastructure is one of the reasons why Central and Eastern EU Member States have slow economic growth and have not been attractive for foreign investors. Therefore, the EU has been providing financial help to its Central and Eastern Member States in order to improve and develop transport infrastructure. In this regard, there are several important points and priorities that should be taken into account. Firstly, Member States in Central and Eastern Europe should foster coordination and synergy between European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds, the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF), Horizon 2020, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and EIB and EBRD resources when implementing projects. Secondly, Member States should develop North-South transparent corridors and extend TEN-T corridors, in particular projects such as Via Carpathia and Rail Baltica. Thirdly, Member States in Central and Eastern Europe should improve connections between different transport modes in order to reduce prices for passenger and freight transport and to take into account ecological and social concerns.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The promotion of cohesion policies (economic, social and territorial) begins precisely from the effective functioning of transport networks in the various Member States, which must offer accessible and well-connected networks for the transport of passengers and goods. Operational instruments include the project for a trans-European transport network "TEN-T" and the "Connecting Europe Mechanism" (CEF), which aims to develop an integrated multimodal transport network at European level and to implement EU policies on transport infrastructure.  These initiatives aim to complete the central strategic network by 2030 and the global network by 2050, projects that will only be possible through the contribution and collaboration of all Member States. Parliament therefore calls for continued support for this process and for the challenges of accessibility and connectivity of Member States' transport infrastructures, which have already improved significantly, but which still need further development in terms of economic and employment growth, as well as accessibility and connectivity of infrastructure, to be addressed.  Mobility is essential for development, and it is for these reasons that I welcome improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report 'Strengthening the mesh and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe'.  While this report has some positive points, it advocates the enlargement of the Schengen area, concerns itself with cycle paths and urban transport, praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the European Commission, obscures Chinese investments and participation in developing central and eastern European transport infrastructure, remains evasive about the real effectiveness of European funds paid in Central and Eastern Europe , wants to involve Ukraine and the Western Balkans more in EU transport policy...

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a milestone on European funding for transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. A series of recommendations to the Commission are made for the development of transport in the countries concerned, whether they are members of the EU or not. However, this text advocates the extension of the Schengen area, promotes macro-regional governance, omits the existence of Chinese investments in the regions concerned and does not make a precise point about the efficiency of European funds paid to Central and Eastern Europe. So I voted AGAINST this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, because transport infrastructure in most regions of the central and eastern parts of the Union has remained underdeveloped compared to those in other European regions. These infrastructures have been the subject of considerable modernisation and improvement with the constant assistance of the Union, but despite these developments, significant gaps remain in the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructures throughout the territory of the Central and Eastern Union. This report aims to provide a number of policy guidelines to the Commission on infrastructure and transport policy. It calls in particular for greater Union attention to projects in this area, additional administrative assistance so that they can benefit from the Structural Funds and EFC, that project funding should focus mainly on building outstanding links, eliminating bottlenecks and ensuring seamless connections for passengers and goods.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Privatisation of infrastructure and the opening up of peripheral markets to products in central economies are the two main axes of the Union's transport policy. That is also the case in this report, so I voted against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report seeks to promote the trans-European transport network (RTET-T) process, in particular with regard to the promotion of interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructures in the Member States of the central and eastern part of the Union, linking Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria. To this end, it advocates completing the main corridors and promoting the north-south cross-border connection between the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, which would provide new employment opportunities and businesses.  I welcome the report, because with high-quality transport links we will improve the standard of living of our citizens, as well as promote economic, social and territorial cohesion within and between Member States.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of improving accessibility and transport infrastructure to improve connections from one Member State to another.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The development of the road and rail network is a matter for individual Member States. I do not agree with the call for 'Member States to further promote the digitisation and automation of all modes of transport' and, in this context, 'investment infrastructure projects to include transport solutions that reduce the risk of death and serious injury as a result of road accidents'. I consider this to be a call for disproportionate control of drivers by the state. The EU should leave this to individual Member States. In my view, surveillance of drivers with cameras and digitisation can lead to greater bullying of drivers for low speeding and to drivers being more likely to monitor their own speed than the surrounding area and driving safety in constant fear.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We think that the EU needs to enhance the connectivity and accessibility of the infrastructure for transport to, from and within the central and eastern parts of the EU, taking into account the needs of the economy and the principles of sustainable development. Parliament considered that the use of EU funding must reflect the real investment needs for completing the TEN-T core network by 2030 in the region.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 For the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 October 2016, I abstained when voting on the report because the report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text takes stock of European funding for transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe and proposes several recommendations.  It presents some positive points (better use of European funding, increased transparency, administrative relief, favoured local businesses, etc.), but has too many negative points: more funding despite its inefficiency, a desire to save the Schengen area at all costs (yet in total failure).  This text even plans to extend it to Romania and Bulgaria, and stresses the need to extend EUROPEAN funding to non-EU Balkan countries, as well as to Ukraine, which we oppose.  Finally, this text does not address the question of the development of Chinese influence in Europe (except for a reference to point 26). This expansion in Central and Eastern Europe is gaining momentum through investments and cooperation policies in the area of transport infrastructure. The aim is to pour Asian products into the market of Member States, which we disapprove of.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe needs high-quality transport connections to develop its economic activity, maintain the quality of life of its citizens and promote the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Member States. My support for progress in the development of the trans-European transport network, in order to complete the main strategic network by 2030 and the overall one by 2050 through measures to correct gaps in accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructures in the Central and Eastern Union. I also share the need to have an urgent impact on rural areas, as well as to improve cross-border connectivity in a north-south direction.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report deals with improving the accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. I would vote in favour of this report if it did not include a number of critical points. That is why I abstained.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report on interconnections and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. Transport infrastructure connections and accessibility have a significant impact on economic growth and competitiveness. As significant investment will continue to be needed to improve transport infrastructure, it is important that Member States in Central and Eastern Europe and the Commission further strengthen the full coordination of transport policy and project planning at all stages. It is also important to exploit all synergies between the financing of the European Structural and Investment Funds and the Connecting Europe Facility and the European Investment Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report aims to strengthen the networking and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. To do this, it calls for better use of regional cooperation instruments and European funds in the implementation of transport infrastructure projects.  But the report remains focused on a goal of competitiveness and growth. Thus, it considers "priority for the socio-economic development of the eastern part of the Alpine region the completion of the Italian A27 motorway to Austria". It also encourages 'Member States to use public-private partnerships' to 'reduce risks to the private sector', although it takes the trouble to stress that 'the profitability of a transport route cannot be the sole criterion for assessing its usefulness'.  Finally, while some elements are conceded to non-polluting modes of transport, from cyclists to rail transport, the environmental dimension remains quite secondary.  I am voting against this report, which does not take into measure of the stakes.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a milestone on European funding for transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. A series of recommendations to the Commission are made for the development of transport in the countries concerned, whether they are members of the EU or not. However, this text advocates the extension of the Schengen area, promotes macro-regional governance, omits the existence of Chinese investments in the regions concerned and does not make a precise point about the efficiency of European funds paid to Central and Eastern Europe. So I voted against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The linkage and accessibility of transport infrastructure has a major impact on economic growth, employment and territorial cohesion of the EU and its regions.  Central and Eastern Europe are an essential part of the European single market, which have the potential to attract investment and contribute to economic growth across the EU.  All modes of transport, without exception, should contribute to strengthening competitiveness, intermodality and ecological transition, with a view to better serving the development of the single market.  Improving the linkand accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe is a means of achieving the objectives of cohesion policy, in particular as regards the desirable economic development of border regions.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which calls for the TEN-T network to continue to tackle the connectivity challenges of Central and Eastern European Member States. The report highlights gaps in the transport network that need to be overcome in order to facilitate economic growth in the region and across the Union. It also flags inland waterways as a transport network that should be used to a greater extent.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Strengthening the mesh and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe is essential for the new Member States. Interconnection would improve integration between Northern and Southern Europe to develop economic growth and employment. Moving towards more transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe means a marked improvement in the well-being of populations and the development of SMEs.  Nevertheless, I do not think that priority should be given to the creation of a new corridor directly linking the port hub of Venice to the North-East of Europe. Similarly, I do not consider the completion of the Italian A27 motorway to Austria a priority. On the other hand, I remain convinced of the need to focus our efforts on establishing missing links, removing bottlenecks and establishing seamless connections. This is how we can achieve the objectives of TEN-T.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe has undergone major modernisation since the pre-accession period. However, projects that restored links with Western countries in Europe were at the heart of the improvement. There are currently 5 transport corridors passing through this region: the North Sea-Baltic; Baltic-Adriatic; Mediterranean; Rhyming-Danube and Orient-Eastern Mediterranean. Quality transport links have a major impact on economic activity in Europe and the quality of life of its citizens. This is particularly important to highlight in the case of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, where labour migration to western countries is a frequent phenomenon. There is a need to overcome the shortcomings related to the availability and interconnection of transport infrastructure in order to preserve as much as possible economic growth and employment opportunities for citizens and businesses (especially in rural and border areas). Otherwise, there will continue to be an outflow of populations in these regions. Improving transport infrastructure is a costly process, so it is crucial to intensify coordination at all stages of transport policy and project planning between central and eastern European Member States and the European Commission and to make effective use of all available synergies in funding from the various funds offered by the EU (ESI Funds, EIB and EBRD, FSI). Those transport policy issues that Member States cannot manage on a case-by-case basis could be addressed by cooperation in macro-regional strategies. I am voting in favour in favour of this proposal.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft Committee on Transport and Tourism draws attention to the challenges of accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria. From the pre-accession period to the present day, the transport infrastructure of these Member States has been significantly modernised and upgraded with the continued help of the Union, yet there are serious deficiencies in the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure in the central and eastern parts of the Union. According to the report, Member States and the Commission should focus on building missing links, eliminating bottlenecks and ensuring accessible links. As the development of transport infrastructure requires large investments, central and eastern European Member States and the Commission should step up cooperation at all stages of transport policy and project planning. I supported the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe certainly presents positive points, such as the need for better use of European funding and greater transparency, administrative relief, more funds for the maintenance of existing infrastructure, a more logical distribution of regional airports, the need to favour local businesses when building infrastructure and to ensure that the most isolated populations are not forgotten. Etc. But, at the same time, it advocates the enlargement of the Schengen area, is concerned with cycle paths and urban transport, praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the Commission, obscures Chinese investments to develop the transport infrastructure of Central and Eastern Europe, remains evasive about the real effectiveness of European funds paid in Central and Eastern Europe, or, even, wishes to involve Ukraine and the Western Balkans more with the transport policy of the EU. Vote against it.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe presents positive points such as increased transparency, administrative relief, a more logical distribution of regional airports, the enhancement of local businesses when building infrastructure, the assurance of not forgetting the most isolated populations, etc. At the same time, however, he advocates the enlargement of the Schengen area, praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the Commission, etc. That is why I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which focuses on how EU funding can be better utilised to address disparities in infrastructure development between Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) countries and the rest of the EU. The report calls for Member States and the Commission to focus on completing TEN-T corridors, bridging missing links, removing bottlenecks and improving connections between different modes of transport in CEE countries.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on strengthening the network and accessibility of infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. The aim of this text is to continue the process already under way in terms of infrastructure and transport accessibility in Central and Eastern European countries, including Estonia, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia and Romania.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. "I very much welcomed the report, because this is about us. With this report, we have made significant progress in a direction that will have a direct impact on our home, Slovakia. The European Parliament is also making central and eastern European countries aware of the backlog of transport infrastructure. We are now trying to put an end to this and provide better connectivity with the rest of Europe, which will contribute equally to economic development, the recovery of tourism and the creation of new jobs. If we look back in the past, we recognize the reason for the backlog, the communist regimes supported the isolation of the country. The fundamental principle of the European Union is the complete opposite of this, the free borders and the physical connection between the Member States, which we now have all the necessary means to develop. This could not come at a better time, given the popular proposal to give all young people a free Interrail rail pass for the 18th birthday of the European Union. The idea is based on the idea of young people getting to know each Member State, gaining personal experience with different cultures and recognising the importance of the EU. Central and Eastern Europe cannot be left out of this either, we want to make transport here and here easy and convenient.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report that will address the challenges regarding the accessibility and connectivity of the transport infrastructure in the Member States of the Central and Eastern European part of the EU, that will bring together Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, and Bulgaria.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I stand by this report on improving the connections and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe because of the support it gives to the development of railway transport in the region of my country, Bulgaria. Given that the rail network in Central and Eastern Europe is significantly less developed than in other European regions, I believe that its modernisation must be a top priority for the EU. The development of rail transport in this part of the Old Continent will have a positive impact on industry, freight transport, the quality of public services and tourism. This in turn will create conditions for economic growth and many jobs in countries such as Bulgaria. Moreover, in addition to economic benefits, the improvement of railway infrastructure in the region will increase the mobility of European citizens from different Member States, which will favour the level of social cohesion in the EU. Finally, it is also important to note that rail transport is one of the most environmentally friendly modes of transport and its development must accompany any economy that strives to be sustainable.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because the interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructures between Central and Eastern Europe are essential elements for the development of the EU area. I think first of all about the advantages that my country can have. Important projects such as Via Carpatica, Rail Baltica and Baltic-Adriatic must continue to be supported from Brussels, as they will help all the communities they will interconnect and contribute substantially to the development of the regions and Member States. I also voted for the inclusion in this report of the amendments on the importance of accelerating and developing the Via Carpatica project, which I consider very important for Romania's development, by connecting to the Union's major infrastructures.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe is very necessary, as transport infrastructure in most central and eastern regions of the EU remains underdeveloped compared to transport infrastructure in other European regions. In this context, work on important projects such as Via Carpatia and Rail Baltica should be stepped up, as well as the construction of the Eastern and Eastern-Mediterranean corridors, the Baltic-Adriatic corridor and the Adriatic-Ionian corridor. However, I abstained in a separate vote on supporting the complete navigability of the Elbe, as I have considerable doubts about the environmental sustainability and economic meaningfulness of such a solution.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the report promises very good approaches in principle, but I cannot assess whether some European geographical areas covered by the EU strategy for the Alpine region have serious socio-economic problems due to their peripheral location in relation to the Scandinavian-Mediterranean corridor along the Brenner motorway.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Good connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure will have a significant impact on eu growth, competitiveness, employment and territorial cohesion. The report takes into account the economic situation and the principles of sustainable development in the Member States and focuses on the poorer interconnected areas of Central and Eastern Europe and on improving the situation, including road and rail transport, inland waterways, seaports and airports.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Economic activities in Europe and the quality of life of our citizens depend to a large extent on high quality transport links. Transport networks – with good connections serving passenger and freight transport at local, regional, national and cross-border level – and easy access to them are a driving force for strengthening economic, social and geographical cohesion within and between Member States in the EU. Despite this progress, there are still serious gaps in the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure throughout the central and eastern EU. These gaps should be filled in order to keep economic growth and employment opportunities for citizens and businesses as wide as possible. Such an intervention is particularly urgent for the (eastern) border regions, which would otherwise continue to lose their populations. In addition, the maintenance of sustainable transport links should be seen as an increasingly important factor in strengthening the stability and security of the EU's borders in eastern Europe and the Western Balkans. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject this non-legislative resolution as the EU should not be making decisions that affect the transport policy of Member States.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal bearing in mind the impact that connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure have on economic growth and economic competitiveness. Similarly, the existence of well-developed cross-border transport links is essential for regional competitiveness as well as for the expansion of SMEs in border areas and the social inclusion of the most vulnerable and isolated populations. In the belief that stricter measures are necessary in this area, I believe it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – As a European citizen and representative from Bulgaria I supported this INI report as I believe that there is a need for further boost to improve the cross-border connectivity along the north-south direction between the Member States in Central and Eastern Europe. Furthermore, it should also be recognized that the region’s potential for inland waterway transport ought to be further utilised, especially along the Danube river. There is also significant potential for further developing shipping to the maritime ports in the Baltic and Black Seas, not least in the energy sector.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The transport potential and development of transport infrastructure for the purpose of balanced and sustainable growth and development of the economy in these parts of the European Union is extremely important. The issue of the development of quality transport lanes and corridors with a compatible interstate network is also important for ensuring the security of external borders. Croatia must be involved in key transport flows, and this will become even more important in the perspective of enlargement of the European Union towards Southeast Europe, after which it has the opportunity to position itself as an important transit point.  What I think should be strengthened is an incentive for national governments to make as much use as possible and to design projects and strategies that follow the fundamental guidelines of EU transport policy. Croatia has made minimal efforts in this regard, it is necessary to strengthen cross-border cooperation in steps and motivate the competent ministries and agencies to deal more with this issue. The development of rail transport has a beneficial effect on the development of many other industries.  It is necessary to develop policies that will return passengers to rail transport and, in the bigger picture, work on the parallel development of all modes of transport of people and goods, and not focus on only one type of transport. In Croatia, road transport is dominant, little investment has been made for the purpose of restoring railway infrastructure, but in the wider European approach there is a positive perspective of future changes.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe has some positive points, as it calls for better use of European funding, increased transparency, administrative relief, funds for the maintenance of existing infrastructure, a more logical distribution of regional airports, an advantage for local businesses when building infrastructure, attention to the most isolated populations...  But at the same time, it advocates the enlargement of the Schengen area, is concerned with cycle paths and urban transport (against the principle of subsidiarity), praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the Commission, obscures Chinese investments to develop the transport infrastructure of Central and Eastern Europe, remains evasive about the real effectiveness of European funds paid in this area, wishes to involve Ukraine and the Western Balkans more with the transport policy of the EU.  It is for these reasons that I am voting against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Transport infrastructure in central and eastern European Member States has been largely modernised with constant EU assistance, but remains underdeveloped compared to that of other European regions. Improving transport infrastructure and connectivity in this part of the EU is important for stability, economic development, tourism sector development, passenger mobility, trade, regional cooperation, but also border security.  This report covers all types of traffic and highlights multimodal traffic. The report focuses precisely on projects that will restore links to the WEST of the EU and on the development of major TEN-T corridors. It recommends making better use of existing sources of financing for the development of transport infrastructure, such as the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI) and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF). Regarding rail transport, I believe it is necessary to highlight the Shift2Rail initiative to increase competitiveness and efficiency, especially in the field of freight transport.  In the construction and modernisation of road infrastructure, such solutions should go towards such solutions that reduce the risk of death or serious injury and which also take into account the needs of cyclists. On top of that, the environment should not be neglected either. Improving transport infrastructure can have a positive impact on the environment and on transport energy efficiency. Further developments in transport should include solutions that also take into account the environment.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The existence of quality transport infrastructure and systems is a guarantee for the development of countries and for the improvement of the quality of life of the population. The link between transport systems, within a country or between several countries, is also a facilitating element of development and the establishment of commercial relations and socio-cultural communication. The countries of Central and Eastern Europe have every right to full development and to take advantage of the instruments available to ensure greater cohesion. This report, however, emphasises strategies and instruments that represent interests that run counter to the interests of the peoples of the EU area, not just the countries concerned.  At the heart of the report's objectives, the need for greater inclusion of these countries in the single market, the need to ensure regional competitiveness and the rejection of the placing of barriers to the free movement of goods, is the need for greater inclusion of these countries. These objectives show that, more than improving transport operability in Central and Eastern Europe, privatisations, PPPs and the European monopolies market should be extended to this macro-region.  In view of the above, we cannot support this report.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report on the lack of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, as this is reflected in our daily lives. Well-connected transport networks are a key element in promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between Member States. Although great progress has been made in this area, in particular in restoring connections leading to and from western EU countries, there are still many shortcomings in the eastern and central European countries. The adopted report covers all modes of transport, but places particular emphasis on multimodal transport. It is crucial to complete major projects on road infrastructure, high-speed railways, inland waterways and improve connections between regional airports. I am glad that the European Parliament is aware of the need to pay close attention to Central and Eastern Europe, and I believe that it will also take these needs into account when setting priorities for European Structural and Investment Funds funding in the future.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of europe's objectives is undoubtedly to strengthen transport links. The promotion of economic, social and territorial cohesion within and between EU Member States is based on easily accessible and well-connected transport networks, including the local, regional, national and cross-border dimension of passenger and freight transport. At Union level, the objective of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) is to develop an integrated multimodal transport network at EU level, promoting the interconnection and interoperability of national networks and access to that network.  I think it is right to endorse the rapporteur's position, where he believes that the time has come for the European Parliament to continue to address the still-open challenges regarding the accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure in the Member States of the central and eastern area. Despite the progress that has been made, I believe that there are still serious gaps in terms of accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure throughout the Central and Eastern European Union. These gaps must therefore be filled in order to promote economic growth and employment opportunities for citizens and businesses as much as possible. For these reasons, I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Transport networks in the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe have been greatly developed with the support of the European Union, with the aim of linking all the territories of Europe ever more effectively.  This infrastructure-building strategy also allows for the maintenance and emergence of a stability zone east of the EU's borders.  Therefore, I voted for this report which stresses the need to strengthen the improvement of cross-border connectivity between Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, particularly in a north-south logic.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. It is a fact that the linkage and accessibility of transport infrastructure has a major impact on economic growth, employment and territorial cohesion of the EU and its regions. Central and Eastern Europe are an essential part of the European single market, which have the potential to attract investment and contribute to economic growth across the EU.  All modes of transport, without exception, should contribute to strengthening competitiveness, intermodality and ecological transition, with a view to better serving the development of the single market. It is therefore important to strengthen the linkand accessibility of transport infrastructure to or from the central and eastern areas of the EU, including within them, taking into account the needs of the economy and the principles of sustainable development.  Member States and the Commission should first concentrate on brimling missing links, eliminating bottlenecks and ensuring non-discontinuity links for both passenger and freight transport. Because I consider it important to implement transport projects with a view to completing the strategic main network by 2030 and the global network by 2050, I voted in this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject this non-legislative resolution as the EU should not be making decisions that affect the transport policy of Member States.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure has a major impact on economic growth, employment and territorial cohesion of the EU and its regions. Central and Eastern Europe are an essential part of the European single market, which have the potential to attract investment and contribute to economic growth across the EU.  All modes of transport, without exception, should contribute to strengthening competitiveness, intermodality and ecological transition, with a view to better serving the development of the single market. Good transport links, including rail links, which cross national borders in most central and eastern European Member States, continue to lack.  This inefficiency of the links between the different modes of transport and the lack of network structures between basic and general transport means that there is not enough interoperability between the different modes of transport, whereas such interoperability would not only reduce the prices of passenger and freight transport and improve the flexibility of transport services, but would also help to reduce ecological and social concerns.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The existence of high-quality transport links is essential for economic activities in Europe and for the quality of life of our citizens. Immediate access to well-connected transport networks covering the local, regional, national and cross-border dimensions of passenger and freight transport is at the heart of promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in and between MEMBER States. This is the right time for the EP to keep pace with this new trans-European Transport Network process and continue to address the open challenges of accessibility and connection of transport infrastructure in the Member States of the central and eastern areas of the EU, bringing Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia closer to , Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria.  Despite progress, there are still serious gaps in accessibility and linking of transport infrastructure along the central and eastern areas of the EU, especially in the most rural areas. These gaps need to be addressed in order to promote economic growth and employment opportunities for citizens and businesses.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 I voted in favour of this initiative report by which Parliament is asking the Commission for greater attention from the Union to projects to improve connectivity and accessibility in Central and Eastern Europe, additional administrative assistance so that they can benefit from the Structural Funds and the Connecting Europe Mechanism, that project funding should focus mainly on building the outstanding links , eliminate bottlenecks and ensure seamless connections for passengers and goods.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on strengthening the network and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. It is indeed important to enable European citizens to have a quality infrastructure to travel all over Europe.  Among the recommendations expressed in this report, I will stress the need for coordinated project planning by and between Member States or for better use of instruments for regional cooperation.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The text of the message is as if it is self-motivated to support it. Central and Eastern Europe, unfortunately, cannot yet boast of the quality of transport infrastructure that Western Europe has. And naturally, EU support here is extremely valuable. On the other hand, the reading of the report makes it clear that it proposes rather modified projects, such as the construction of motorways in well-developed Italy, the construction of highways through protected areas and many other activities that could lead to very uncertain prospects. I therefore abstain from supporting this report, while noting that it particularly correctly reflects the need to complete the transport connections currently under way, such as Rail Baltica, and its quality has been greatly reduced by the great enthusiasm for the construction of new motorways.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The existence of high-quality transport links is essential for European economic activities and for the quality of life of citizens. Access to transport networks with good local, regional, national and cross-border links for the transport of passengers and goods is essential for achieving greater economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Member States and within the European Union itself (EU).  The Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) aims to develop an integrated multimodal network at European level that promotes the interconnection and interoperability of national networks. Transport infrastructure in the Central and Eastern European Member States has been modernised and improved thanks to European aid since the pre-release period.  However, despite the progress made, there are still gaps in accessibility and infrastructure connection throughout these regions.
