These gaps need to be addressed in order to ensure economic growth and maximise employment opportunities, so Member States and the Commission must promote the implementation of missing links, eliminate bottlenecks and ensure non-discontinuity links for both passenger and freight transport, thereby meeting ten-t objectives.  By agreeing with the proposals on the ones, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the gaps and deficiencies that still persist in the Union's transport network in Central and Eastern Europe, despite the investments made and the progress made. Although there are some positive points — coherence between Union financial instruments, multimodality or cycling infrastructure development — I voted against it, because the only criterion proposed to identify and assess infrastructure gaps is to enhance the single market, economic development and the competitiveness of enterprises in transnational markets. Consequently, references to the criteria of social cohesion or environmental sustainability are merely testimonial. It also advocates relaunching some large cross-border infrastructures that have strong opposition from affected local communities.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on improving the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, as maintaining and developing transport links is an important factor for stability and security at the Eastern European borders and with the Western Balkans. The transport infrastructure in the Member States of this region has undergone a substantial modernisation and improvement, which has been consistently supported by the EU.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Mr Poręba's report. There is currently a lack of sufficient interconnection of transport infrastructure in central and eastern Europe, so I support the call for Member States to focus on removing bottlenecks and missing sections of the TEN-T core network, which is due to be completed by 2030. Furthermore, in his report, the rapporteur draws attention to the importance of a coordinated approach by Member States, which should consult their main transport plans with neighbouring Member States. In my opinion, this approach can help to link the missing cross-border sections. Sufficient funding is needed to complete the TEN-T core network, and I am therefore glad that the report calls on the Commission in this regard to ensure synergies and complementary replenishment of funds under European funds, as this is crucial for the Member States in our region.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Privatisation of infrastructure and the opening up of peripheral markets to products in central economies are the two main axes of the Union's transport policy. That is also the case in this report, so I voted against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for a European Parliament resolution on improving the connection and accessibility of the transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. To date, most of the transport infrastructure projects planned to be financed by European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) are found in Western Europe. In order to address this imbalance, the report states that capacity building and technical assistance is required and that the Commission should encourage investors to support project platforms that focus on CEE transport infrastructure projects.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructure has a significant impact on the economic growth, economic competitiveness, employment and territorial cohesion of the EU and its regions. There is an urgent need to improve the road network infrastructure along the EU's eastern border, i.e. from Estonia to Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Slovakia, Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria to Greece. In this context, adequate appropriations should also be allocated to the Via Carpatia project, which I fully support. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although transport infrastructure in the Central and Eastern EU Member States connecting Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria has undergone substantial modernisation from the pre-accession period to the present, it can still be considered insufficient compared to other European regions. I regret to admit that in many Central and Eastern European Member States there is still a lack of quality transport links, as well as inefficient interconnections between the various modes of transport. I believe that these shortcomings in cross-border transport links are substantially undersued by the lack of regional competitiveness and poorer economic performance of some Member States. I supported the resolution because I believe that only well-developed cross-border links in Central and Eastern Europe can ensure stability, economic development, regional cooperation and the security of transport conditions in the internal market. I believe that, also on the basis of these measures adopted, there will be an improvement in transport policy in Central and Eastern Europe, which cannot be managed individually by individual Member States.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the co-financing of transport projects in The Member States located in Central and Eastern Europe.  The focus is mainly on projects that are not sustainably oriented, such as the Alemania project, the road corridor, which is intended to link the north-east of Italy with northern Europe, or the Via Carpatica project in south-east Bulgaria, which is opposed by local communities, and the increase in funding for regional airports.  I believe that the coherence and accessibility of transport infrastructure in the central and eastern part of the European Union needs to be improved, but in a better and different way than the aforementioned report dictates. Local communities, the environment and sustainable development must be taken into account.  The development of transport hubs at all costs must not be an objective of the European Union, but must be designed sustainably, which in turn also results in long-term positive financial consequences. For the reasons set out above, I voted against the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Transport links have a major impact on economic activity within Europe. We must work closely together to develop and implement projects relating to the interconnection of the infrastructure of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe as widely as possible, especially in rural areas and border regions, in order to preserve economic growth and employment opportunities for citizens and businesses.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report on improving the connection and accessibility of the transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe.  In an alternative dimension the EU might actually be capable of effectively and efficiently redistributing wealth for infrastructure projects. And the alternate me might pause for a second to consider if the EU should be involved in such projects. Ultimately, the alternate me would reject such intervention because infrastructure spending is not the EU’s prerogative.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 High-quality transport infrastructure is one of the generators of economic growth, so the development of an integrated multimodal transport and trans-European transport network (TEN-T) across Europe is important. The European Structural and Investment Funds can be used to develop existing CENTRAL and Eastern European infrastructure to ensure full and equal access to the single market with a view to stimulating the economic activities of the European Union. It is also important to emphasise the development of corridors with the aim of connecting Northern and South East Europe and extending the TEN-T corridor to western Balkan candidate countries in order to create new business opportunities and foster trade. I support the report on improving the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe of the Transport and Tourism Committee.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on better connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. In improving the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, we must not forget the needs of the economy and the principle of sustainable development.  Deteriorating integration and accessibility of transport infrastructure have a negative impact on economic growth and the competitiveness of the economy, as well as on employment and territorial cohesion in the European Union and its regions.  I welcome the recommendation that existing regional cooperation policies and instruments be better used to strengthen cross-border traffic between regions and to eliminate bottlenecks.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on improving the interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, which stresses the need to improve the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure to, from and within the central and eastern parts of the EU. This report supports road modernisation, the building of missing links and safe and accessible parking spaces within the TEN-T network. The development of transport hubs is a key element for connecting long-distance, regional and urban transport and, consequently, for promoting efficiency, intermodality and business development at regional level, taking into account the extensive digitisation opportunities that can improve the performance of the entire logistics chain. It further stresses that the European Structural and Investment Funds can be used to build missing links in border areas in Central and Eastern Europe and calls on the Central and Eastern European Member States to ensure a high level of transparency and strict control over the spending of EU funds.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report promotes the execution of projects in already developed countries, such as Germany, while giving very little weight to countries that really need the construction of infrastructure projects.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 From their accession to the present day, the transport infrastructure of the Member States in the eastern part of the Union has undoubtedly been significantly modernised and upgraded with the continued help of the EU. At the same time, for historical and geographical reasons, the focus has been on projects to rebuild connections to and from western Member States. This is to be changed and somewhat counterbalanced by the adopted report. However, in addition to the east-west transport axis, the development of the north-south link is of the utmost importance, which can lead primarily to the economic recovery of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe. The report is unique in its kind, as it deals with the challenges within the region and future opportunities in a single document in the field of road, rail, water and air traffic and interoperability. Hungary the fact that it raises the possibility of exploiting a number of opportunities affecting our country is also significant from the point of view of the hungarian economy. These include the further development of the Via Carpathia project and the construction of its route from north to south in the eastern part of the country, which was highlighted in the document. The financial framework needed to achieve the ambitious targets will be provided by exploiting the resources of the European Structural and Investment Funds, the European Network Finance Facility (CEF), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), as well as the instruments of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the synergies between them. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the development of connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. I agree with the finding that high-quality transport links are essential for Europe's economic activity and for the quality of life of its citizens. Easily accessible, well-connected transport networks are indeed essential for promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion within and between the Member States of the Union. I welcome the fact that the report pays attention to the needs of cyclists and the populations of sparsely populated and hard-to-reach regions and to measures towards greener transport options. I also agree with the proposals to modernise railway lines and inland water water transport. Like the report, I support increasing the interconnection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in, from and within the central and eastern parts of the Union, taking into account economic needs and the principles of sustainable development, giving priority to coordination with the candidate countries.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Transport is a kind of bloodstream of the economy. Without a well-functioning system of movement of persons and goods and without the possibility of changing the location of the provision of services, there is no question of clear economic growth. Transport, through its specificity, also brings markets closer together, providing companies with the opportunity to exchange goods, services, but also experience with the external environment. Unfortunately, transport infrastructure in most central and eastern European countries, despite the investments made through the European Structural Funds, is still much less developed than in other parts of the European Union. Priority should be given to investments aimed in particular at completing missing connections, removing bottlenecks and ensuring smooth connections in long-distance and regional passenger and freight transport.  In order to facilitate the implementation of transport projects, the European Commission and individual Member States should seek to streamline and simplify tendering procedures, to issue guidelines on the formula for public-private partnerships, and to simplify authorisation procedures. Only under such conditions will it be possible to make effective use of the available funds.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 ALDE's line on the report was straightforward, so I voted in favour of it. It is important to create and maintain opportunities for mobility within the EU, thereby investing in high-quality and extensive infrastructure.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is known that in Central and Eastern Europe transport infrastructure in most regions is underdeveloped compared to that of other European regions and that there can be no talk of growth, sustainable development, economic competitiveness, territorial cohesion and increased employment without an improvement in the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure. Moreover, the achievement of cohesion policy objectives, in particular with regard to the desired economic development of border regions, is not possible without improving the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe.  Obviously, differences in the quantitative and qualitative development of infrastructure between the Central and Eastern European region and the rest of Europe can only be reduced by a clear, concrete and integrated strategy at EU level, thereby contributing to the development of tourism, the labour market, the goods and services market and, therefore, all economic sectors.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the situation of connectivity in Central and Eastern Europe is a first and major step towards reducing the significant disparities accumulated between this region and the west. It recognises that, despite efforts undertaken by the Commission through its Cohesion policy, several Eastern Member States are lagging behind in terms of infrastructure projects and attracting the EU funds available for these. In light of this, the report is proposing that the Commission comes with a strategy for Central and Eastern Europe, integrating all large infrastructure projects, taking into account both the differences between various regions and the long-term objectives of the EU. At the same time it proposes means by which European traffic can be diverted towards more transport modes, taking thus into consideration environmental concerns and congestion problems. Not least, the present report brings a new perspective to tourism by soliciting that European infrastructure projects be connected with tourism objectives, underlining the close relationship between this industry and transport.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. This is an opportune time for the European Parliament to build on the momentum of this new TEN-T process and to further address the existing challenges in terms of accessibility and networking of transport infrastructure in the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, bringing together Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary Slovenia, Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria. The report may provide answers to some questions relating to the development of different modes of land, water or air transport in the States of Central and Eastern Europe, including support for intermodality via hubs and ports or the need to re-establish cross-border rail links for passenger transport.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. The report points at the specific development of transport infrastructure in the region and underlines, among other things, the need to promote intermodality as well as cross-border connections in the region. In particular, I supported the provisions inviting the Member States and the Commission to ensure synergies and mutual complementarity of the funding instruments used in the region in order to improve their utilisation.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Report of the Mep, Poros, because he unequivocally recommends improving transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe, which also includes Lithuania. The development of transport is essential for the quality of life of our citizens and for the efficient movement of goods. The report rightly calls on the EP to increase the pace of the legislative process in order to improve existing and new links between Estonia and Lithuania to Romania and Bulgaria. The restoration of this area is necessary in order to improve the currently inefficient cross-border connections. At the same time, access and access to areas located in the eastern regions of the Union will be improved. Cooperation under macro-regional strategies will certainly help to solve many problems in the field of transport policy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report by a fellow European Conservatives and Reformists, as it also seeks to improve Central and Eastern European transport links with the north and west. It is also making efforts to improve the transport infrastructure of Eastern and Central Europe, which will have a potentially positive impact on Croatian roads. For the first time, the Report gave the European Parliament precise guidance and recommendations to the European Commission for the development of central and eastern European transport infrastructure, as well as its support for specific projects in the region where serious shortcomings remain in the availability and connectivity of transport infrastructure. When creating the instructions, no aspects were neglected and the report covered road transport, rail transport, inland waterways and sea and airports, and the construction and modernisation of road infrastructure stressed that the needs of cyclists, i.e. the importance of cycling infrastructure, should be taken into account. Given the state of Croatian roads, I think it is extremely important to overcome these shortcomings in order to strengthen stability and achieve economic development and regional cooperation in this area.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on better connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. High-quality transport links are fundamental to economic activities in Europe and to the quality of life of our citizens.  Easily accessible and well-connected transport networks with a local, regional, national and cross-border dimension of passenger and freight transport are the basis for promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in and between EU Member States.  At EU level, the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) aims to develop an integrated trans-European multimodal transport network, promote, and access to, the integration and interoperability of national networks. The TEN-T Network Development Guidelines and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF), established in 2013, already make the main pillars for implementing the EU's transport infrastructure policy by the mid-20th century.  Member States and the EU will need to pool their resources and work closely together to set up and implement projects to complete the strategic core network up to 2030 and the 2050 comprehensive network.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the gaps and deficiencies that still persist in the Union's transport network in Central and Eastern Europe, despite the investments made and the progress made. Although there are some positive points — coherence between Union financial instruments, multimodality or cycling infrastructure development — I voted against it, because the only criterion proposed to identify and assess infrastructure gaps is to enhance the single market, economic development and the competitiveness of enterprises in transnational markets. Consequently, references to the criteria of social cohesion or environmental sustainability are merely testimonial. It also advocates relaunching some large cross-border infrastructures that have strong opposition from affected local communities.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support and welcome infrastructure which has European added value and improves single market functioning. I have always fought for the removal of bottlenecks which are both physical and legal barriers to the completion of the EU single market. I am, however, asking the Commission to always submit all infrastructure projects for a cost benefit analysis; projects should be co—financed only if they pass that cost benefit test.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe has positive points, such as better use of EU funds, greater transparency of transport services, administrative relief and a more logical allocation of regional airports.  However, it advocates the enlargement of the Schengen area and praises the macro-regional governance promoted by the Commission. I voted AGAINST this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Parliament's activities so far lacked a document that comprehensively accounted for the development of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. I therefore welcomed the report on this subject.  The document to be reported not only discusses development directions and areas of support, but also identifies specific projects that need to be implemented. The necessary investments concern rail, road and water links, which will increase the transport and transport capacity of the whole region of Central and Eastern Europe. In this way, the strengthening and development of trans-European networks will enable Union citizens, economic operators and local and regional communities to fully benefit from the establishment of an area without internal borders, as referred to in Article 170 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 High-quality transport links are essential for Europe's economic activities and citizens' quality of life. Easily accessible, well-connected transport networks, including local, regional, national and cross-border dimensions of passenger and freight transport, are essential for promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion within and between the Member States of the Union. I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the gaps and deficiencies that still persist in the Union's transport network in Central and Eastern Europe, despite the investments made and the progress made. Although there are some positive points — coherence between Union financial instruments, multimodality or cycling infrastructure development — I voted against it, because the only criterion proposed to identify and assess infrastructure gaps is to enhance the single market, economic development and the competitiveness of enterprises in transnational markets. Consequently, references to the criteria of social cohesion or environmental sustainability are merely testimonial. It also advocates relaunching some large cross-border infrastructures that have strong opposition from affected local communities.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report, with promotes all possibilities for co-financing transport projects in CEEC Member States, with the focus on non-sustainable projects such as the Alemania project, a road corridor that should link North-East Italy with the North of Europe, or the Via Carpathica, with contested projects through natural areas in South-West Bulgaria, or more finances for regional airports.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on improving the connection and accessibility of the transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. The report stresses the need to enhance the connectivity and accessibility of the infrastructure for transport to, from and within the central and eastern parts of the EU, taking into account the needs of the economy and the principles of sustainable development. It equally underlines the importance of coordinated project planning by and among Member States, taking into account as far as possible national master transport plans and coordination with candidate countries. I voted in favour because I believe that this is the right time for the European Parliament to further address open challenges regarding the accessibility and connectivity of the transport infrastructure in the Member States of the Central and Eastern European part of the EU. Quality transport links are fundamental for the economic activities in Europe and for the quality of life of our citizens.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Transport infrastructures in the Member States of this area of the Union have undergone substantial modernisation and development, using a Community line of constant aid, extending from the years leading up to its accession to the Union to the present day. However, for both geographical and historical reasons, the focus has been on rebuilding the connections that connected these territories with Western Europe. In order to promote stability and security on the eastern border of the Union, as well as in the Western Balkans, effective transport routes need to be maintained. In support of the need to improve connectivity in this regard, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Privatisation of infrastructure and the opening up of peripheral markets to products in central economies are the two main axes of the Union's transport policy. That is also the case in this report, so I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I share many of the objectives set out in this text. These include the need to improve the networking and accessibility of transport infrastructure, the need to link this work to a deeper ecological transition and social integration of economically vulnerable populations, and the importance of establishing the missing links. I am therefore surprised that this text does not at any time denounce the logic of liberalisation of transport at work in the TEN-T. Because wherever it is at work, the search for profitability leads investors to reduce the mesh of public transport and thus to ignore the imperatives of accessibility for all, and even ecological transition (favoured modes of transport are often individual and always more polluting). There is also an urgent need to put an end and at a minimum to reassess some major projects whose relevance over time is less and less demonstrated. They can therefore prove useless or even dangerous, in addition to exorbitant costs incomprehensible in times of budgetary "restrictions". So I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The existence of quality transport infrastructure and systems is a guarantee for the development of countries and for the improvement of the quality of life of the population. The link between transport systems, within a country or between several countries, is also a facilitating element of development and the establishment of commercial relations and socio-cultural communication. The countries of Central and Eastern Europe have every right to full development and to take advantage of the instruments available to ensure greater cohesion. This report, however, emphasises strategies and instruments that represent interests that run counter to the interests of the peoples of the EU area, not just the countries concerned. At the heart of the report's objectives, the need for greater inclusion of these countries in the single market, the need to ensure regional competitiveness and the rejection of the placing of barriers to the free movement of goods, is the need for greater inclusion of these countries. These objectives show that, more than improving transport operability in Central and Eastern Europe, privatisations, PPPs and the European monopolies market should be extended to this macro-region.  In view of the above, we cannot support this report.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains some good approaches to unresolved problems in the areas of accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure in the EU's Central and Eastern European Member States. However, it also emphasises the absolute need for open internal borders, which is no longer acceptable in times of irregular migration and 'asylum shopping' within the EU. I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe.  Considering that the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructures greatly influence economic growth and competitiveness, employment and political and territorial cohesion, this report stresses the need to improve missing links in the regions of Central and Eastern Europe, ensuring the development of TEN-T corridors and promoting the extension of connectivity to passengers and freight.  The report takes into account all means of transport, calling not only for the creation of major infrastructure projects but also for the improvement of the internal, air and naval railway system. It also stresses the need to respect the protection of the environment and biodiversity and calls for useful and urgent measures to eliminate discrimination against persons with disabilities caused by architectural barriers in transport management.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the own-initiative report on improving the connection and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. At the heart of encouraging economic, social and territorial cohesion in and between EU Member States is easily accessible and well-connected transport networks, including the local, regional, national and cross-border dimension of freight and passenger transport.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report with my vote. The level of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe has clearly seen a clear step forward in recent decades, largely due to EU funding. However, there is certainly still room for improvement, in particular as regards the modernisation of existing infrastructure, the addition of missing connections and other elements within the TEN-T network. I consider the development of infrastructure in central and eastern Europe to be important not only because of the improvement of the situation at national level, but also because it is an important factor in strengthening the security and stability of the EU's eastern border.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Poręba report followed a meeting in Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) on improving the connectivity and accessibility of infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe. This is the first ever comprehensive document dealing with this subject, which also makes detailed recommendations to the European Commission. First of all, the report identifies the current state of availability of infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe and its shortcomings. Following these findings, it proposes possible solutions, highlights existing projects that would need to be expanded and supported, and the possibilities for financing these projects. Since I believe that the situation with regard to interconnection and accessibility of transport in the region, to which the Slovak Republic belongs, is currently lagging behind Western standards, as can be seen especially in remote areas, I have given my voice to the report. I believe that improving transport infrastructure and successfully completing projects will help to connect Europe better, but will also mean, among other things, greater opportunities in the field of employment and job creation.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Connectivity and access to transport infrastructure have a major impact on land growth and development, especially if well integrated into a seamless connection at European level. To date, however, there is a backwardness of infrastructure networks in Central and Eastern Europe compared to those in other regions of the EU.  It is therefore necessary to act, in the ultimate interest of the consumer, for the development of the infrastructure network where there are shortcomings, both at rail and road, air and air level, with the aim of achieving the TEN-T objectives and creating opportunities for SMEs and start-ups. Furthermore, the network must not only develop on the basis of profitability, but must also provide valuable logistical support for the seamless transport of people and goods across the European continent.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing.– The report highlights the need to improve the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in the direction, from and within the central and eastern regions of the EU, by investing in the modernisation and completion of existing transport infrastructure. The various critical issues divided by mode of transport, starting with the road sector, are addressed, which highlight the need to improve the infrastructure network along the EU's eastern border in such a way that it meets the requirements for road safety.  As far as rail transport is concerned, the importance of modernising and maintaining railway lines is stressed. The aim is to pursue coherent and sustainable growth in rail transport to help reduce the climate impact, air pollution and the number of road accidents.  For regional airports, it is called for the construction of new infrastructure to depend on traffic demand and for the use of EU funds to be strictly limited to economically viable and sustainable projects. These are the elements that led me to vote in favour of the report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on better connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe.  Transport infrastructure is still less developed in most regions of the central and eastern part of the EU compared to other European regions. As the integration and accessibility of transport infrastructure have a profound impact on economic growth and the competitiveness of the economy, as well as on employment and territorial cohesion in the EU and its regions, it is necessary to improve the connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure to, from, from, and within the central and eastern part of the EU.  At the same time, account must be taken of the needs of the economy and the principle of sustainable development and the link between missing links must be established, bottlenecks must be eliminated and smooth connections for long-distance and regional transport must be ensured.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I did not support this report after much thought. On the one hand, I consider the subject of human rights and democracy to be a key issue for the European Union, but the proposal as proposed is, in my opinion, bad and good intentions here, as they say, paving the way for hell. In short, the introduction of a new mechanism for national control and new ways of bureaucratically enforceing human rights and democracy on individual Member States will, in my view, not work in practice and will lead to the only thing that will weaken the cohesion of the European Union in the future. And I say this in the knowledge of how important the agenda of human rights and democracy is, and it is necessary to talk about it permanently here in Parliament and to do everything possible to improve democracy and human rights in Europe. But it's not supposed to be that way, it's not supposed to go the way of bureaucraticism, where anonymous officials evaluate individual sovereign states and then impose sanctions on them. This is against the sovereignty of individual Member States of the European Union.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, the report in 't Veld purports to put governments under guardianship in the name of protecting fundamental rights. In fact, it is based on Orwellian logic because it proposes exactly the opposite, in reality, of what it displays in the name of principles. The truth is that liberticidal laws have multiplied in Europe. There are hundreds of prisoners of conscience in Germany today. In my country, France, under the liberticidal laws, for example the Pleven law, anyone who talks about immigration to say anything other than good can be prosecuted for racism or xenophobia; anyone who claims to freely examine contemporary history can be prosecuted for revisionism or denialism; anyone who does not give in the adulation of lesbianism, homosexuality or transsexualism can be prosecuted for homophobia. This report is therefore a monument of hypocrisy. Before looking for the straw in the eyes of the Hungarians, we better look for the beam that is here, in the eye of most Members of this Parliament.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – We have been talking for a long time about a mechanism to verify the rule of law and respect for human rights, respect for the law in the Member States. Such a mechanism is necessary and I am totally in order to implement it. It is a monitoring mechanism, but also correction, obviously, because that is the aim, to correct what is wrong, and to sanction, if necessary. And we are talking about states where democracy is still fragile - such as post-communist states - mainly about them. I am glad that Parliament is not alone in this fight, that there will also be non-governmental organisations, that there will also be independent experts in respect for the law and in respect of human rights. Also, if the mechanism to penalise these states that do not comply with the standards of democracy and the rule of the law proposed by the Commission will also lead to money saving, as the report shows, then we will achieve two objectives.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against this report because of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Unlike most of those here, I come from a communist country, I am 74 years old, most of the time I lived in a communist country where I was forced to read Karl Marx. And since I read Karl Marx, I want to assure you that Karl Marx would say that the Charter of Fundamental Rights goes too far in the construction of communism. And because I don't like communism, I voted against it.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP firmly rejects the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. UKIP believe that this mechanism is a severe infringement of national sovereignty. UKIP also vehemently opposes calls in this report for the EU to accede to the ECHR.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The lack of guarantees of compliance with fundamental rights, as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, signed by all Member States, is a reality in all Member States. In the Spanish State, the Government repeatedly fails to comply with issues such as freedom of expression and protest, in the face of the passivity of the European institutions. I therefore support any mechanism that is in favour of the performance of these rights and allows the action of the Member States to be monitored, so I voted in favour. However, I understand that the proposed mechanism is clearly insufficient, and although I support the preparation of parliamentary reports on this and that the role of the Ombudsman is enhanced, I cannot believe that this will actually solve the current profound problem. The Union cannot today seek to wash its face and pose as a space where fundamental rights are guaranteed, so this mechanism will play an exclusively cosmetic role, unless it is accompanied by a political will for democratisation which does not exist today among the Community authorities.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report proposes creating a pact on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights across the EU prior to any future treaty change. While some of the language looks positive, with references to fundamental rights, its implementation would actually have serious consequences for national sovereignty as it empowers the Commission to further interfere in national affairs. For example, the report refers to protecting the ‘common values of the Union’, and suggests the Commission assumes responsibility to ‘correct breaches of Union values.’  The report also suggests that the European Court of Justice should monitor legislation from Member States, in addition to its remit of examining adherence to EU law in relation to the Treaties. The mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is described as ‘a tool for compliance with the enforcement of the Charter and Treaties’, and affords the Commission ‘appropriate binding and corrective mechanisms’ that go beyond Article 7 TEU. Attempts to have EU institutions included in such scrutiny also failed, securing only a voluntary opt-in. As the negative implications for sovereign governments are too great, we voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. The European Union is more than just a market: it is a community of values, enshrined in treaties! Among them, respect for the rule of law is the cornerstone of democracy and the protection of fundamental rights; it must be part of each of the measures taken by the EU and its Member States.  Finally, the Union must have democratic governance as strong as its economic governance. I therefore welcome this resolution, which proposes to establish an annual assessment mechanism for respect for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights by the Member States and the three main EU institutions.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, because I believe it is imperative to adopt a framework that allows the EU to address not only violations in its specific legislation, but also more serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this report, the EU Parliament is making recommendations to the Commission with a view to establishing a legally binding mechanism with annual reporting on Member States' compliance with EU values and fundamental rights. This mechanism should contain objective benchmarks and establish a clear and step-by-step procedure for redressing violations of fundamental rights or the rule of law. Parliament's proposal also aims to combine existing similar requirements into a single EU instrument. I support the creation of a mechanism at European level, because the mechanism can also be an effective instrument for monitoring the countries that wish to rejoin the EU.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of an EU mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. It is an EU mechanism to take political control of Member States that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  Each Member State will be subject to an annual review. A panel of experts (1 magistrate per Member State, plus 10 'experts' appointed by the European Parliament) will make a report which will then be adopted by the Commission.  The report calls for EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, which will strengthen the influence of the European Court of Human Rights and the Council of Europe (of which Turkey and Albania are members).  The text also calls for a revision of the Treaty which would allow a third of MEPs in the European Parliament to refer the matter to the Court of Justice after the final adoption of a text and before its implementation. This is an attack in good standing on the sovereignty of the Member States. Even the French government has declared that the proposal is not in accordance with the treaties!  I have, of course, objected to this dangerous text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative report. Member States have already handed over control of their laws, fisheries, defence and finances to unelected and unaccountable European bureaucrats. Is it really wise to hand over control of Member States mechanisms for democracy? I believe this is a dangerous proposal and an infringement of national sovereignty.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported Sophie in 't Veld's legislative initiative report calling on the Commission to submit a proposal for an objective and non-politicised mechanism to protect democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights (DEF).  I believe that Europeans were among the first to fight for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. This legacy obliges us to strengthen their protections throughout the Union, which is a community of principles and values.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Currently there are insufficient instruments to ensure that the core European values laid out in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union are upheld. When countries join the EU it is ensured that they adhere to the EU values, but as illustrated by the recent developments in Poland and Hungary, once they are members there is no mechanism to guarantee that these values continue to be maintained. Therefore, there is a need to establish a mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. This mechanism will oversee the implementation of EU values and will help prevent and correct any breaches made by Member States. This mechanism must be applied to all Member States equally, it should be a permanent mechanism, objective and evidence-based, and finally, there needs to be close involvement of Member State governments. This DRF pact will lead to a more united European Union as it will strengthen the common core values shared among the Member States.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The VVD delegation supports the principle and purpose of the mechanism but ultimately abstained because it incorporates a number of provisions that run counter to the functioning of the Dutch legal system. As far as we are concerned, the new agency cannot (co)determine what a European and what a national competence is (interpretation of Article 2 VWEU). We are opposed to granting direct and direct access to the European Court to all natural and legal persons. We want to maintain normal justice through the national courts. Finally, we do not support the idea of being able to halt a legislative process with only a third of the VOTES of the EP because of a preliminary ruling before the Court.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Although Europe has a deep tradition of democracy, the rule of law and civil liberties, the Commission,which is the guardian of the Treaties, has been reluctant to remind a Member State of its obligations or refuses to recognise commonly agreed rules and EU mandates, ensuring that these rules are complied with. The EU has a range of instruments to ensure respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, but the scope of the measures is limited and the measures themselves are ineffective. I therefore agree with the need to establish a system that enables the EU to address not only specific breaches of EU legislation, but also threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights (risks).

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report proposed a new form of political dominance of the EU over member states. They could be branded by a panel of "independent experts" if, for example, their populations defended themselves against decisions taken by eu institutions in sensitive areas by means of a referendum or constitutional amendment. The adoption of the motion indicates that the majority of the EP has learned nothing from Brexit and wants to continue to intervene in the internal affairs of sovereign countries. I voted against the report, of course.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP firmly rejects the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. UKIP believe that this mechanism is a severe infringement of national sovereignty. UKIP also vehemently opposes calls in this report for the EU to accede to the ECHR.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of an EU mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. In reality, it is an EU mechanism to take political control of Member States that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  I am opposed to this report, which also calls for EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, which will strengthen the influence of the European Court of Human Rights but also of the Council of Europe (which includes Turkey, Albania, etc.).

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have, of course, endorsed this initiative report which proposes the creation of an annual mechanism for monitoring the respect of fundamental freedoms and the rule of law by the Member States and the eu's institutions. To that end, the report calls on the Commission to present, before September 2017, a draft inter-institutional pact for the rule of law and fundamental freedoms which would include: - an annual report on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights including country-by-country recommendations, - an annual inter-parliamentary debate on the basis of this report, - modalities for dealing with potential risks or violations as set out in Article 7. The fundamental values contained in Article 2 of the Treaty are at the heart of the European project. Each Member State must respect them.  Current situations in Poland or Hungary demonstrate that ongoing monitoring of compliance with these values is necessary and the application of this report would allow this to be the case and therefore for rapid reactions to be made. This is a vital issue for the future of Europe.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution for the creation of a Union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Foundational values and principles must also be applied within our Union. At present, we do not have the necessary tools to achieve this in the same way that we demand compliance abroad. Given the weakening of democracy and the rule of law in countries such as Poland or Hungary, it is necessary to adopt mechanisms such as this one that strengthen the fulfilment of fundamental rights and avoid any kind of authoritarian drift within the Union. The mechanism included in this Resolution contains a number of instruments and provisions to achieve the annotated objectives. In particular, I stress the request to delete from Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights (CDFUE) and that the Charter become a Declaration of Rights of the Union. This would strengthen the implementation of the TFEU in all the Union's actions and regulatory body. Since my parliamentary activity, I have always advocated the adoption of an application of Article 51 enabling the Union to ensure compliance with fundamental rights.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights are founding values of the European Union, entered into the Treaties and promoted in the day-to-day action of the EU institutions. Recent developments in some Member States and the progress of the integration process itself have, however, demonstrated the existence of gaps in this field, which make it necessary to review and integrate the current mechanisms in order to ensure that the principles of the Treaties are observed, protected and promoted throughout the Union.  The report by my colleague Sophia in 't Veld, which I supported in my vote, calls for the conclusion of a Union Pact on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, in the form of an interinstitutional agreement, in order to facilitate the cooperation of the institutions and the Member States within the framework of Article 7 TEU. The Pact should provide for sanctions that can act as an effective deterrent to prevent infringements, as well as regular monitoring of the compatibility of international agreements ratified by states and the Union containing provisions of primary and secondary law. These measures should be taken with a view to an increasingly necessary reform of the Treaties which will deepen political integration and at the same time strengthen citizens' protections.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report, because I welcome most of the proposals contained in the report and the annex. I believe that although the final report has been weakened in its content relative to the original, the recommendations it issues are moving forward on the path of greater European cohesion in the maintenance and supervision of the fundamental rights of the Union.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. As in 1984, George Orwell's premonitory novel, the Union will finally have its ministry of truth. What is this about? We will create a mechanism for democracy in order to prosecute sovereign states that would have the addedcuidence to believe that, in the regal areas of politics, they would have the right to defend the interests of their peoples. This will require the abolition, as this report recommends, of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights on subsidiarity and national sovereignty. The report wants the EU to apply to join the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) when this Court is an institution of the Council of Europe (47 countries and not all 27 EU states). Thus, the ECHR would become the supreme legal body of the Union, with guardianship over the European Court of Justice. Moreover, this mechanism for democracy will include so-called experts, some of whom would be non-European judges (from Turkey? of Russia? of Morocco?) who, on the basis of anonymity, will be able to evaluate and condemn democratic and sovereign states. With the sole thought as supreme judge.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 A realistic, binding and objective mechanism is needed to correct democratic quality problems that occur in EU Member States that we would not admit to a candidate State to join our Union. If we want to be a reference in this area in the world, we have to be exemplary and now, unfortunately, in some States there are many opportunities for improvement in aspects such as judicial independence, media pluralism or respect for the rights of minorities. Eu membership is voluntary, but includes a catalogue of rights and freedom obligations which is one of our hallmarks. Let's keep it!

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have vehemently opposed this report which, contrary to its name, represents a real danger to democracy in the Member States. The European Union, which cannot stand the contradiction, seeks to muzzle any dissenting voices by the sacrosanct word of so-called "experts" who will be able to "judge" or even punish every European nation with the misfortune of not going in the direction of the Brussels institutions, as they are already trying to establish with the "sanctions" against Hungary and Poland. Worse, non-EU member states but integral parts of other institutions such as the Council of Europe will be able to become a great magistrate for the Member States: we will be delighted to receive the 'good advice' on democracy and respect for human rights on the part of Albania or Turkey... (sic!) When one thinks that even the French government, yet at the helm of this super-federal state which is not one, considers the proposal contrary to the European treaties, one understands that the time is serious.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree at all with yet another attempt by the European institutions to undermine the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which each Member State should be able to manage for itself. A serious Union which respects the sovereignty of its Member States does not attempt to exercise total control over them; on the contrary, it undertakes to guarantee the principle of subsidiarity, which is essential if the Member States are to carry out their duties in the service of their citizens. For these reasons, I did not intend to support the text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. The main idea of the report is that the European Commission should establish a binding mechanism that reports on an annual basis on the enforcement of democratic principles, the rule of law and human rights in EU countries. The aim is to monitor developments in EU countries so that democracy is not undermined. The new EU mechanism would also provide the possibility of recurrent debate within the EU institutions and national parliaments on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I would like to emphasise that it is only these core and structural issues of democracy that monitoring should apply. The intention is that no EU Member State should be able to restrict democracy and/or undermine the functioning of the rule of law.  On the other hand, each Member State must, of course, have full freedom to develop the economic and social policies that its government, after democratic and free elections, has been mandated to pursue.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Treaty establishes the EU's responsibility to promote and protect the constitutional bases shared by Member States in the field of fundamental rights. In practice, however, problems of effectiveness, competence and suitability have been identified when implementing them. Parliament raises the possibility of articulating existing instruments to make them effective and developing a legal mechanism to monitor compliance with the principles governing democracy in the EU through a system of monitoring, notification and sanctions, the current Framework on the Rule of Law of the Commission and Dialogue on the Rule of Law of the Council , in addition to strengthening the so-called 'scoreboard' and the inclusion of a Pact for Democracy. Penalties and infringement procedures resulting from possible non-compliance could contribute to the activation of Article 7 of the Treaty, which provides for a sanctioning mechanism enabling the Council to suspend certain rights arising from the application of the Treaties, including the right to vote in the Council where a 'serious infringement' is established. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which discusses the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Europe has a deep tradition in the area of democracy, the rule of law and civil liberties. In addition, democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are also the basic principles and objectives enshrined in the first articles of the Treaties of the European Union, as well as among the criteria for EU membership. On fundamental issues, the European Union has a number of measures in place to ensure compliance with its legislation and the Treaties. The European Commission may instruct Member States to adjust their budgets, public health systems or tax rulings to bring them into line with EU law. In such cases, Member States do not dispute that they are required to comply with EU law under the EU Treaties. However, when it comes to the obligations laid down in the Treaties in the areas of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, the situation is different. The efforts of the European Commission, which is the guardian of the Treaties, to remind a Member State of its obligations are reluctant or completely refuse to recognise commonly agreed rules and the EU's powers to ensure that these rules are complied with. So far, the Commission's actions on this issue have been timid and not always taken. It is therefore necessary to establish a framework that enables the EU to address not only specific breaches of EU legislation, but also cases of threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights (risks).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As long as there is no objective definition of the rule of law adopted by common consensus among all Member States, any rule of law mechanism will form part of party political games, which are currently in play, and will remain a breeding ground for double standards. Therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I voted against this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Since democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are of great importance to the population of the European Union, efforts must be made to protect the fundamental values and principles that enable democracy to be broken and ensure the protection of fundamental rights.  Therefore, the resolution adopted calls, inter alia, on the Commission to establish a constructive dialogue with civil society, welcomes the reform of the Court of Justice to gradually increase the number of judges in the Court of Justice and calls for a cash subsidy to be drawn up in relation to democracy at local level.  For these reasons, my support for the aforementioned REPORT on the EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report. European values have been given the greatest importance in treaties, and I think it is high time they also gained the greatest importance in practice.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of an EU mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. In reality, it is a mechanism of the Union to take political control of Member States that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Each Member State will be subject to an annual review. A panel of experts (one magistrate per member state plus ten "experts" appointed by the European Parliament) will make a report which will then be adopted by the Commission. This is an attack in good standing on the sovereignty of the Member States and democracy in general. This text is also contrary to the European treaties, which the French government has also noted. I have obviously objected to this incondic text.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this resolution that has the aim of listing our recommendations to the Commission upon the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Indeed, a proposal is expected from the Commission by September 2017 for the conclusion of a Union Pact on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. This is an interinstitutional agreement aimed at facilitating cooperation with regard to these matters. I voted in favour because I shared the recommendations listed in the resolution.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has enshrined democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights (DRF) in its treaties and in the criteria for EU membership. The Commission has the power to ensure that Member States comply with EU law under the EU Treaties. A number of instruments are provided for this task, even if they often have shortcomings, are inadequate or ineffective. It is therefore necessary to establish an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which is impartial and reliable and which is applied fairly by all Member States.  A European Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights can be adopted in the form of an interinstitutional agreement. This agreement should aim to establish ways for optimal cooperation between the EU institutions and the Member States, integrating and aligning existing mechanisms and providing an integrated review mechanism to prevent breaches and non-compliance with the DRF.  Respect for the rule of law is a prerequisite for the protection of fundamental rights and is of particular importance within the Union, as it is also a prerequisite for defending all rights and obligations arising from treaties and international law.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of a Union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. This mechanism would in fact allow the European Union to sanction or take political control of Member States whose governments would not respect its interpretation of democracy.  Thus, each Member State will be subject to an annual review carried out by experts, arbitrarily appointed by the European Parliament.  The report also calls for the European Union to join the European Convention on Human Rights, thereby strengthening the influence and weight of the European Court of Human Rights and the Council of Europe. This is once again an attack in good standing on the sovereignty of the Member States, which will now be forced to respect the sacrosanct European vision of democracy.  Finally, we stress that this proposal is not in full compliance with the European treaties. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. His intention is laudable, but his proposals are neither realistic nor reasonable. I am obviously in favour of a comprehensive mechanism of the Union for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, but it must be pragmatic and respect the principle of subsidiarity. This report opens a dangerous door by giving a great deal of weight to civil society organizations at the expense of representative democracy.  The report also proposes to remove Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which amounts to giving the Union a large part of the competence over fundamental rights and denies the principle of subsidiarity.  I consider that the mechanism provided for in Article 7 of the TUE is sufficient to find that there is a clear risk of a serious violation by a Member State of the values of democracy and the rule of law, and possibly put in place a wide range of sanctions. I would remind you that Parliament has the power to trigger this article by proposing to the Council that there is a clear risk of a serious violation by a Member State of the values of democracy and the rule of law.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report containing recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I believe that the principle of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights are values to be protected to a greater extent than is currently the case, in the face of possible violations of the same principles that are taking place precisely in our Western democracies. It should be stressed that the corollaries of legal certainty, the "substantial" protection of them and the effectiveness of protection are a joint and inherent expression of fundamental rights themselves. Aspiring to effective protection is therefore the task not only of the judiciary, but above all of the legislator, national and EU, who must lay fair and coherent legal bases to 'put fundamental rights back at the centre' of the Union's legal construction. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal for a Union pact to raise awareness on these issues and promote good governance, transparency and accountability in the areas of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report was initiated following the EP resolution on the situation in Hungary on 10 June 2015 that had called for a Commission proposal on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, as a tool for compliance with and enforcement of the Charter and Treaties as signed by all Member States.  The origin of this proposal is to tackle the limitations (or inoperability) of the current rule of law mechanism, mainly Article 7 TEU. This report recommends, until a possible Treaty change, that the Commission by September 2017 submit a proposal for the conclusion of an EU Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights (DRF). It will take the form of an interinstitutional agreement. The report also suggests that the ECJ should monitor legislation from Member States when the ECJ’s remit is to examine adherence to EU law in relation to the Treaties.   While I strongly support the promotion of fundamental rights in the EU, I am opposed to such a significant transfer of powers away from Member States towards the Commission, which is why I voted against the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP firmly rejects the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. UKIP believe that this mechanism is a severe infringement of national sovereignty. UKIP also vehemently opposes calls in this report for the EU to accede to the ECHR.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the mechanism which is being proposed within this report to monitor Member States’ compliance with democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights falls within the framework of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). Under the Treaty, the European Union has a duty to protect its constitutional basis and core values, shared among all its Member States. The failure of the EU to uphold its own rules, and the perception there are no common European values, are also undermining mutual trust and a reliable, stable legal framework, essential for a well-functioning EU in all policy areas.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report recommends the establishment of a European mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. To this end, the Commission is asked to present, by September 2017, a proposal for an interinstitutional agreement establishing a European Pact for Fundamental Rights in order to facilitate cooperation between the Institutions of the European Union and the Member States and to integrate and align the various existing mechanisms. I voted in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe there is a case for considering a mechanism through which democracy, rule of law and human rights are monitored. These are a very core value of the EU and should be duly respected, these are the values the EU is known for on international level. The Pact should prevent or correct potential breaches of these values and would allow much-needed discussion over it. I also believe there is room for imposing sanctions in case the democratic principles are not respected.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are the foundations for accession to the EU. Unfortunately, we see too often that Member States are slyly ly in favour of the requirements once they have been admitted. Principles such as freedom of expression, the press and assembly should not be able to choose on and off the basis of political conviction. That is the cornerstone of European cooperation. That is why the Danish Social Democrats have also supported the report. Such an EU mechanism or other instruments strengthening these rights must, of course, add value to the work already carried out by the UN, the Council of Europe and the EU and be within the competence of the EU. However, it is important that we find new tools without treaty change, as a treaty change is not realistic for the time being, nor do we fully agree with the proposed amendments. The legislative power lies with governments, parliaments and the European Commission. It does not lie with the European Court of Justice, which is why we do not support the fact that one third of MEPs should be able to submit adopted legislative proposals for review by the European Court of Justice. In addition, we would like to stress that we already have a system in which citizens of the European Union can bring cases of unfair measures to the courts, including the European Court of Justice. Today it is just going through the national judicial system, and that is how we think it should be in the future.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline that the European Union has incorporated democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights into its basic principles and objectives set out in the first articles of the Treaties, as well as in the criteria for ACCESSION to the EU.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights has a positive starting point in principle. However, further specialisation is needed as to the guarantees of impartiality of the proposed mechanism and the type of sanctions against Member States when they violate the fundamental rights of citizens. The issue of infringements arising from the requirements of the Institutions of the Union vis-à-vis the Member States must also be addressed. As I therefore consider that there are significant gaps in the proposal, I have decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this dossier. The text does not respect the principle of subsidiarity to the detriment of the Member States.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed a measure whose process has been somewhat troubled. Having a common mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights reflects the real needs of many Member States, especially the protection of these ideals is at the root of citizens' confidence in the institutions. Therefore, a monitoring mechanism is desirable at both national and European level, but it risks carrying with it twisted tangles as far as the committee of independent experts who will be called upon to make assessments is concerned. In any case, this report shows confidence in the Commission in achieving lean and clear analyses in order to fully implement the protection of the rule of law and the effectiveness of independent judicial systems. I would like to make it very much more important to stress that this will also make citizens fully aware of their rights as Europeans and, therefore, to restore their confidence in the institutions. Consequently, implementing structural reforms to overcome this time of crisis will become easier in a climate of calm dialogue.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report with recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights and noted no objections.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The opportunity of this proposal could not be greater. It is clear to everyone that there is a contradiction between the level of demands we place on the candidate countries and the fact that certain Member States call into question core elements of the rule of law. But what model to adopt? On the one hand, there are advantages to an institutional agreement: it would not require treaty changes, it could bring greater coherence and effectiveness to the actions of Parliament, council and commission (which today each have its own mechanism).
