On the other hand, there are issues relating to its operation that will need to be fine-tuned, starting with the composition of the expert panel. But it also points to solutions that can lead to an immediate improvement: to resume the process of the Union's union's union's agreement with the Council of Europe's Convention on Human Rights or to give more resources to the Court of Justice of the European Union, thereby increasing its capacity to respond. This is undoubtedly a good initiative, which defends good causes and now takes the first steps of what will be, given its sensitivity and complexity, a long process.  I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support this initiative. The EU is based on a common order of values. And we must defend these values– both externally and internally. Serious violations of the rule of law must not go unanswered. The proposed interinstitutional agreement is the right instrument here.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as the proposed agreement sets out useful ways to facilitate cooperation between the EU institutions and its Member States by integrating and harmonising some existing mechanisms. The new single framework to be implemented must be objective, evidence-based, addressed to all Member States in a fair and equitable manner and must include both the preventive and the corrective dimension.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report to make monitoring of fundamental rights and the rule of law across the EU more efficient, by building on existing tools and strengthening them, without a formal revision of the Treaties.  It is important to be able to react quickly when there is a serious risk of breach of fundamental rights or the rule of law in Member States. The interinstitutional agreement proposed allows a debate to be opened at a much earlier stage in order to find a solution, before having to arrive at the nuclear bomb of Article 7 of the Treaties. I also support that the Commission remains solely responsible for drafting the annual report on fundamental rights and the rule of law and for triggering any further step in the procedure against Member States. The European Parliament will also be able to play a role in the monitoring mechanism within its mandate and without becoming a Tribunal, differently from what we have seen in previous proposals.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 A mechanism that can devote itself entirely to safeguarding democratic values, the rule of law and fundamental rights could prove decisive in rying or, better still, preventing possible violations in this area. I therefore believe that we must at least try, making sure that the mechanism, once it has been launched, fully respects the ideas that led to its creation, without turning into an unnecessary supranational entity, but something that really manages to provide valuable support to which all the Member States can refer. It also ensures that it acts in parallel with and in conjunction with the state bodies specific to each Member State in a climate of harmonious and mutual cooperation, without one beating each other's feet. And of course, ensuring its integrity and impartiality, without lending itself to political exploitation of any kind. If all this is fully respected, I approve.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The lack of guarantees of compliance with fundamental rights, as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, signed by all Member States, is a reality in all Member States. In the Spanish State, the Government repeatedly fails to comply with issues such as freedom of expression and protest, in the face of the passivity of the European institutions. I therefore support any mechanism that is in favour of the performance of these rights and allows the action of the Member States to be monitored, so I voted in favour. However, I understand that the proposed mechanism is clearly insufficient, and although I support the preparation of parliamentary reports on this and that the role of the Ombudsman is enhanced, I cannot believe that this will actually solve the current profound problem. The Union cannot today seek to wash its face and pose as a space where fundamental rights are guaranteed, so this mechanism will play an exclusively cosmetic role, unless it is accompanied by a political will for democratisation which does not exist today among the Community authorities.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is founded on common values, such as democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights, which are a precondition for a well-functioning Union based on mutual trust. However, today, our fundamental values are not sufficiently protected by effective instruments that guarantee their protection throughout the European Union. In view of the lack of coherent action, it seems all the more necessary to establish a new and more effective EU mechanism. I therefore welcomed this proposal for a legislative initiative to establish an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which would monitor and report annually on violations of democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the Member States, including objective benchmarks and establishing a step-by-step approach to remedying violations.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe has a long tradition of democracy, the rule of law and citizens' rights, starting with Athenian democracy, followed by Roman law. Although the EU currently has several instruments to ensure respect for the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, there are still openings. It is imperative to adopt a framework that allows the EU to address not only certain violations of its laws, but also the serious risks to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I voted for the adoption of an EU Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights, which will lead to respect for the EU's fundamental values and in practical terms, not just in theory. A number of additional non-legislative measures, in order to ensure a global vision of respect for the values on which the EU is founded, are needed to complement this pact.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament's proposal for an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is essentially a positive idea, since it is in the interests of all of us to protect democracy and the rule of law and fundamental rights, but I believe that there is always a risk that they will not play their part properly in documents dealing with such an important and comprehensive subject. As a representative of a national minority, I am also pleased that the European Parliament has taken such a big axe and is proposing a comprehensive mechanism for the other institutions and the Member States, but on the other hand, I express my dissatisfaction with the way in which the EU is still closing its eyes to violations against indigenous minorities. I see no guarantee that this could change under any mechanism if it is driven only by political interests and non-professionally supported arguments and by a commitment to the protection of the rights contained in the Treaties.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the creation of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights because, in my opinion, this is incompatible with the principle of conferral of competences and the principle of subsidiarity. The aim of such a mechanism would be to control the application of democracy, the rule of law, fundamental rights in the Member States and institutions. It has been confirmed by experts that such actions go beyond the powers of Parliament which have been given to it by the Treaties. I will never support actions that are incompatible with the basis of the EXISTENCE of the EU, and I have therefore voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that every citizen in the European Union deserves a solid democracy safeguarded by rule of law and fundamental rights. However, I have reservations on particular aspects of the report which devalue and even impinge upon the principle of subsidiarity already enshrined within the European Union’s Treaty and Charter of Fundamental Rights. This is why I also voted against the deletion of article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights as the Charter and national systems of fundamental rights. Furthermore, in cases where national systems hold certain fundamental rights to a higher regard than the EU Charter, such a policy implication would decrease the level of protection for citizens.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite fully supporting the rule of law and protecting fundamental rights in the UK and across the EU, I am unable to support this report due to serious concerns that the proposed system would be overly bureaucratic, would make what should be an objective assessment into a political point—scoring exercise and because a political institution, such as the European Parliament, is not best placed to address issues related to fundamental rights in Member States.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, with no binding legislative value, on the creation of a mechanism of the Union for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights.  While recent events have shown us that it is essential for the European Union to strengthen its existing instruments to protect the rule of law in Europe, I have not been able to support the provisions of this text which run counter to the principle of sovereignty of the Member States and the principle of subsidiarity in Europe. Of particular concern are the proposals for a possible treaty change to change the way the EU Court of Justice is referral to the Court of Justice.  I regret that the negotiations between the political groups have not led to a realistic and balanced text in order to really protect the rule of law and fundamental rights in Europe.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to strengthen existing mechanisms to avoid human rights slippages. To this end, it wants to put in place tools that allow us to assess the respect of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the Member States and the European institutions every year.  This project is important to me, since it is a question of defending respect for the fundamental values of the Union, but I voted against this report because the methods it proposes are not able to respond to the project.  Indeed, in the proposal that is made, there is no separation of powers, since the European Parliament is both the legislator and at the same time in charge of monitoring and controlling the states.  Moreover, the main absentees from this process are national institutions, which is not acceptable. They have more powers for me to exercise this control and enjoy greater legitimacy in the eyes of citizens.  The developments proposed in this report are therefore relevant, but they lack realism.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As long as there is no objective definition of the rule of law adopted by common consensus among the 27 Member States, any rule of law mechanism will form part of the party political games that are currently in play and will remain a breeding ground for double standards. Therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I voted against this report.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. While the Commission is unreasing to those in the Union who do not respect, who, the dogma of free and undistorted competition, who, the convergence criteria, it remains singularly silent or unarmed in the face of infringements of fundamental rights. This report is a cornerstone of a mechanism to preserve democracy.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union ensures that the principles inherent in democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are respected, both within and on the international stage. These common values are enshrined in the Treaty and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.  Since 2009 there has been a procedure for the European Commission to challenge a Member State that violates these principles, but this mechanism is difficult to implement. In view of the recent breaches of the powers of the Constitutional Court in Poland or press freedom in Hungary and Croatia, the Union should adopt a more ambitious and flexible instrument.  The existing procedure must be more restrictive, have clearly defined criteria and its initiation must be based on concrete evidence of breaches of fundamental rights. This is the whole meaning of the European pact on fundamental rights that the European Parliament is calling for.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – As long as there is no objective definition of the rule of law adopted by common consensus among the 27 Member States, any rule of law mechanism will form part of the party political games that are currently in play and will remain a breeding ground for double standards. Therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation, I voted against this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of an EU mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. In reality, it is an EU mechanism to take political control of Member States that do not respect its own definition of these three principles.  Each Member State will be subject to an annual review. A panel of experts will produce a report which will then be adopted by the Commission. The text also calls for EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, which will strengthen the influence of the European Court of Human Rights and the Council of Europe, of which Turkey and Albania are part.  In particular, paragraph 20 calls for a revision of the Treaty which would allow a third of MEPs in the European Parliament to refer the matter to the Court of Justice, after the final adoption of a text and before its implementation.  This is an attack in good standing on the sovereignty of the Member States. Even the French socialist government has said that the proposal is not in accordance with the treaties. So I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support the Report with recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, because I believe that the ideas proposed therein for treaty changes are de facto contrary to the principle of subsidiarity. Furthermore, I have concerns that the mechanisms thus proposed could be used to put political pressure on sovereign Member States.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is invalid and illegal because, on the one hand, Article 7 of the Treaty, on the other, it violates the principle of interinstitutional agreements. It is another attempt by professional manipulators to guide the national policies of the Member States. It is unacceptable and undemocratic for a new authority to be given the power to control the Member States, and it is a waste of resources, since international organisations already exist which control violations of fundamental rights.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – The report establishing an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights underlines that the Union is based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. This is a prerequisite for mutual recognition and trust within the Union, the document states. Although this EU mechanism is not legally based, but given that it can provide an adequate framework for the protection of the minority and linguistic rights of Hungarian communities living outside Hungary borders, I voted in favour of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission shall submit by September 2017 a proposal for the establishment of a "Union Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights" which includes a preventive and corrective dimension, a cycle similar to the European Semester of coordination of budgetary policies and country-specific reports. The new European mechanism, which would integrate and complement existing mechanisms, should be based on concrete elements, assess in fair terms and should not be subject to external influence, particularly from a political point of view. It should apply to both Member States and the European institutions and be based on a gradual approach, including a preventive and corrective approach. The assessment of the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the Member States and the preparation of draft country-specific recommendations should be carried out by a panel of independent experts.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: in reality, it is an EU mechanism to take political control of Member States that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the form of an interinstitutional agreement providing for measures between the EU institutions and the Member States under Article 7 of the EU Treaty, the revision of which is proposed "in order to make sanctions against any Member State relevant and applicable". The proposal to revise Article 7 intends to go beyond the current measure of suspension of voting rights in the Council, so that "financial penalties or suspension of Union funding" can also be imposed. You'd laugh if it wasn't too serious. The EU to be emanating as a reference and, at the same time, as an arbiter with regard to democracy, the rule of law and human rights. Deplorable. We are faced with a monument to cynicism and hypocrisy. Obviously, we voted against it. We note, unsurprisingly, that PS and PSD voted in favour of this report, while CDS and BE abstained. In the vote on the proposal to revise Article 7 OF the ETU, which includes the possibility of imposing financial sanctions, PS, PSD, CDS and BE voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe that there is no solid legal basis in the existing Treaties for a mechanism relating to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Article 7 TEU is sufficient in this respect, as it gives the Council of the EU the power to assess the risks in this area. The proposed mechanism exceeds the mandate laid down in the Treaties and constitutes an abuse of the institution of interinstitutional agreements. These agreements are established to promote cooperation between the EU institutions within the framework of current competences, and not to create new powers (Article 295 TFEU).

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Thanks to the principle of solidarity, the European Union seeks to assist its Member States in meeting their economic, social or cultural objectives. At the same time, it should be a community which, despite persistent differences, combines respect for equal values. However, their observance by some countries, and especially their government officials, in an attempt to compete with increasing populism and extremism, seems to have ceased to be important. The fundamental values on which the EU stands include respect for human dignity, democracy, equality, the rule of law, respect for human rights and freedom. However, freedom does not mean, after all, the possibility of ruthlessly spreading fear and promoting the hateful ideologies for which millions of people have died in Europe in the past. Unfortunately, this is what some people mistakenly imagine today. However, freedom is all about responsibility and mutual tolerance. The European Union has its own concrete instruments for enforcing agreed legislation and treaties. There are no major problems with respect for practical matters, such as competition rules, trade or monetary policy. However, the situation is deteriorating in the case of democratic rules, the rule of law or respect for fundamental rights. However, questioning them does not weaken populism and extremism in Europe.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because further control and loss of sovereignty is required to the detriment of the Member States.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is invalid and illegal because, on the one hand, Article 7 of the Treaty, on the other, it violates the principle of interinstitutional agreements. I am therefore voting against this report, as it is yet another attempt by professional manipulators to guide the national policies of the Member States. It is unacceptable and undemocratic to grant competence to a new authority to control the Member States, and it is a waste of resources, since international organisations already exist which control violations of fundamental rights.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Even if the EU has several existing instruments at its disposal to ensure the principles on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are upheld, substantial gaps remain and in practice, such instruments are often limited in scope, inadequate and ineffective, or they are unlikely to be used. In some cases, their uneven application is perceived by many as politically motivated, arbitrary and unfairly targeting certain countries. There is no integrated mechanism for the systematic, impartial and complete monitoring of all EU Member States and institutions. Therefore it is imperative to adopt a framework that enables the EU to address not only infringements to specific EU laws, but also (risk of) serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  European values are given the highest importance in the Treaties, it is high time they also got the highest importance in practice.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As long as there is no objective definition of the rule of law adopted by common consensus among the 27 Member States, any rule of law mechanism will form part of the current party political games and remain a breeding ground for double standards. Therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ delegation to the People's Party, I voted against this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report establishing an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights underlines that the Union is based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. This is a prerequisite for mutual recognition and trust within the Union, the document states. Although this EU mechanism is not legally based, but given that it can provide an adequate framework for the protection of the minority and linguistic rights of Hungarian communities living outside Hungary borders, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that the Union has enshrined democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in its fundamental principles and objectives, in the first articles of the Treaties and in the criteria for accession to the Union. While the Union has at its disposal a number of instruments to ensure the defence of principles on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, significant gaps remain and, in practice, these instruments often have a limited scope. It is therefore imperative to adopt a framework that allows the Union to deal not only with cases of non-compliance with specific Union rules, but also on serious threats or risks of serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The proposed interinstitutional agreement aims to establish modalities to facilitate the cooperation of the Union institutions and their Member States within the framework of Article 7 of the ETE, by integrating, adapting and complementing existing mechanisms.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on today on the new mechanism for protecting human rights is very important. At the beginning of its term of office, the new European Commission undertook to present an instrument that would enable Europe to act to respond to the many episodes of human rights setbacks in some Member States. As with economic or environmental parameters, Europe must rightly be able to set up a system for monitoring compliance with the obligations arising for The Member States from compliance with the Treaty of Lisbon and the Annexed Charter on Fundamental Rights. European action has so far been very timid in this respect. Now the Commission, with the full support of Parliament's Committee on Citizens' Freedoms and Rights, Justice and Field, is introducing an observation and evaluation indicator with defined criteria, submitted to experts and independent entities appointed by the European Parliament. Parliament will be vigilant in ensuring that democracy and the rule of law are in line throughout Europe with the values on which the EU is founded.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights because I believe that it is necessary to create a politically neutral, impartial but effective and effective instrument to ensure respect for the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and the values of democracy, peace, freedom and human solidarity on which the EU is founded. Recent discussions between the Commission and some governments have shown that the EU, despite the provisions and procedures of the Treaties, has no real means, beyond diplomatic pressure, to sanction behaviour contrary to its values. This puts the values themselves in crisis and paves the way for the return of ideologies and phenomena that we thought had disappeared. Parliament's proposal, which will now have to be discussed with the Member States, is a good starting point. Practical indicators measuring compliance with European values analysed by independent experts will make it possible to avoid any accusation of politicisation on individual issues.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted very deliberately today against the 'Report with recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights', because this instrument means exactly the opposite: it undermines subsidiarity, disregards Member States and regions, disempowers national and regional parliaments – and is only good for those whose understanding of democracy already ends in the opinion of others. Europe has good, functioning and parliamentary-controlled instruments to counter really dangerous tendencies at national level. Furthermore, I do not know what justifies the instrument of an INL report in this case. It is obvious that abuses of power are being practised here at the expense of freedom, subsidiarity and the citizens. However, it is a disgrace, if I may say so, what My colleague in 't Veld has presented to us.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are three key pillars of the foundation on which the European Union is founded. These European values are irreversible, non-negotiable and irrefutable components of our community of values. It is therefore essential to establish a European framework, to protect these values and to penalise any violations of these fundamental rights.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour colleagues, I support efforts to promote and secure the rule of law across the EU. It is therefore very important that existing mechanisms are used effectively to promote better dialogue with Member States and the EU. This will contribute to a more streamlined approach to upholding fundamental rights and the rule of law. Furthermore, we support the role of the European Parliament in maintaining and continuing the debate on the rule of law and fundamental rights across the EU. As we believe that the focus should be on the improvement of existing mechanisms, I abstained from this vote.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I wanted to vote in favour of this report because it gives us the opportunity to reiterate once again what the European identity really means: it means respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which are set out among the objectives and principles on which our Union is founded. We cannot ignore these. We demand respect for our trading partners, for the states that make up the European neighbourhood; we cannot then renounce it. We call on all Member States to follow the instructions from the European Commission in this regard. To date, there is not even an agreement between us for the systematic, impartial and comprehensive monitoring of all EU Member States and their institutions. We must therefore ensure this and the development of a broader framework that will make it possible to counter, on our territory, in our democracies, the serious threats to the rule of law and to the fundamental rights that may exist.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes the conclusion of a pact of the Union for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights, which would be triggered by an annual report and inter-parliamentary debates in order to assess the respect of these values by the Member States. Given the european Union's highly ideologued view of these values and most of the political groups on them, this proposal appears to be yet another desire to interfere in the governance of the Member States. Concerned about the sovereignty of France, and because the European Union is arguably the greatest threat to democracy and fundamental rights today, I voted against this report, which even the French government considers to be contrary to the treaties.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report, because I welcome most of the proposals contained in the report and the annex. I believe that although the final report has been weakened in its content relative to the original, the recommendations it issues are moving forward on the path of greater European cohesion in the maintenance and supervision of the fundamental rights of the Union.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support efforts to promote and secure rule of law across the EU. It is important that the existing mechanisms in place are used effectively to promote better dialogue with Member States and the EU as this will contribute to a more streamlined approach to upholding fundamental rights and rule of law. In addition, Labour MEPs support the role of the European Parliament in maintaining the debate on rule of law and fundamental rights across the EU. Labour MEPs abstained from the vote, as we believe that efforts should focus on improving existing mechanisms.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The principle of subsidiarity that I want Europe to be effective is called into question. Of course, it is essential to guarantee democracy and fundamental freedoms in Europe, but the prescribed method is not the right one!  In this case, the establishment of a mechanism for assessing all Member States and sanctions in the area of fundamental rights goes beyond European competences. Each Member State has democratic control over its territory and the European Union has no mandate to impose its choices. Finally, the report recommends the possible modification of the treaties, in particular the modalities of referral to the EU Court of Justice: this request is excessive in view of the current functioning of the Court, which is satisfactory.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. To enter the EU, candidate countries must respect the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. However, within the EU, compliance with these principles is difficult to monitor and enforce. The tools created by the Union, such as Article 7 of the TUE or the rule of law mechanism, may intervene too late, be difficult to apply or even misunderstood. The Hungarian and Polish cases have shown us this.  The European Parliament therefore proposes that the EU should have a mechanism for regularly assessing respect for the rule of law, fundamental rights and democracy in the Member States and the three main EU institutions. Including relevant interlocutors and experts based on objective criteria, this pact is designed as a precondition for Article 7 and suggests easier activation of sanctions - especially financial ones.  I supported this report because it is essential not to compromise with the rules of the rule of law, especially when compliance with economic rules is subject to well-established and recurrent European controls. I also welcome the fact that this report proposes an awareness campaign aimed at European citizens and residents about their fundamental rights.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The new EU mechanism should ensure that all EU Member States respect the values enshrined in the EU Treaties and set clear, evidence-based and non-political criteria for assessing their records on democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights (DRF) in a systematic way and on an equal footing. Therefore the aim is to incorporate existing DRF tools in a single instrument and ensure that they are used to the full.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats supported the report on recommendations to the Commission for the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It is extremely important that we in the EUROPEAN Union have better tools to be able to act when a Member State systematically violates the values of the EU Treaties and violates fundamental rights. At the same time, we see problems with parts of the report proposing possible treaty changes. Two of these proposals would fundamentally change the constitutional order in Europe. The relationship between national constitutions and eu treaties would change and the EU's competences would be extended. Unfortunately, it was not possible to vote against these proposals alone, and we therefore abstained in the votes on paragraphs 20, indents 6 to 7 and paragraph 20, indents 1 to 3.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As long as there is no objective definition of the rule of law adopted by common consensus among the 27 Member States, any rule of law mechanism will form part of the party political games that are currently in play and will remain a breeding ground for double standards. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted against this report.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report provides for the establishment of an EU mechanism for the supervision of Member States in relation to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Although the mechanism is primarily aimed at preventing violations and non-compliance with the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, it is expressly provided that the means will be provided to impose corrective measures and sanctions against the Member States. The main weakness of the report is the fact that the exercise of supervision over the action of the EU institutions is neither sufficiently rigorous nor clearly defined, even in relation to the corresponding procedure structure proposed for the Member States. In addition to the three institutions, the other EU institutions and bodies are outside supervision and control. There is no provision for the possibility for the Court of Justice of the EU to intervene in decisions taken on the basis of Article 7 EES, and there are also no clear references to social rights as an integral part of fundamental rights. The whole issue of creating such a mechanism is approached through a more general position on the issue of granting further powers to the EU and shrinking the sovereignty of the Member States. For these reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion. The values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, are cornerstones of the functioning of the European Union and therefore should be protected at an institutional level. In particular, I believe that the European Parliament and the national parliaments should play a key role in measuring the progress of, and monitoring the compliance with, the shared values of the Union. The pact on DRF would allow for country-specific recommendations, an annual inter-parliamentary debate and arrangements for remedying possible risks and breaches in fundamental rights, all of which would strengthen the core principles that bind the Union.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report aims to show ways in which the EU can enforce its values against the Member States. According to this proposal, the European Union should be given oversight of the management of fundamental values. These values are human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, the rights of minorities. Equality and anti-discrimination are particularly highlighted and should be enforceable by majority decision after a future revision of the European Treaties. The aim is to explicitly extend the rights of the EU in order to be able to persuade Member States to give way by means of penalties or their threat of 'preventive and corrective'. In addition to the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity enshrined in this text, this text is based on the principle of 'necessity' on an equal footing. "Necessity" is a rubber term with which you can justify everything. I have rejected this report. The risk is very high that the EU will be able to enforce EU-compliant behaviour in this way. The ECJ already decides unilaterally pro-EU and pro-euro. By extending fundamental rights into more and more areas, such as labour markets, the EU is taking on further policy areas and the principle of subsidiarity is increasingly being damaged.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If, in principle, I share the concerns expressed about the excesses in some Member States such as Poland and am convinced that a reflection on the means of guaranteeing democracy and fundamental freedoms in Europe is necessary, I am more reserved about the prescribed method. The proposal voted today is legally "unbelievable". The European Parliament insists, for example, on the principle of the separation of powers, but at the same time it has the right to monitor and sanction Member States while continuing to exercise its role as a legislator.  In addition to the 'Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights', the report recommends possible treaty changes, in particular the terms of referral to the EU Court of Justice, which would weaken the role of national judicial authorities, hinder European decision-making and threaten the principle of subsidiarity. In my view, it is a fault to believe that citizens are demanding constant surveillance from institutions in which they do not recognize themselves very much. What we are being asked to do is to ensure that national institutions, especially national parliaments, function properly, not to replace them.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The VVD delegation supports the principle and purpose of the mechanism but abstained in the final vote because it included a number of provisions that run counter to the Dutch legal system. As far as we are concerned, the new agency cannot (co)determine what a European and what a national competence is (interpretation of Article 2 VWEU). We are opposed to granting direct and direct access to the European Court to all natural and legal persons. We want to maintain normal justice through the national courts. Finally, we do not support the idea of being able to halt a legislative process with only a third of the VOTES of the EP because of a preliminary ruling before the Court.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The institutions of the European Union do not have any treaty rights to judge sovereign Member States. Such rights are not available to Parliament and cannot be introduced without treaty amendments. You are mis-reading the records so far, as was clearly seen in the debates on my country, Polish.  After Brexit, there is more panic among EU federalists, they are afraid of losing their political power and total electoral defeats, so they are urgently looking for defence tools. They want to stop the tide that is engulfing Europe today and heralds the end of the reign of political correctness and corrupt financial and government caste. This is why flowers such as the voted report by Mrs in 't Veld are created. It proposes sanctions m.in an effective deterrent, and the EU institutions are growing into a guard, a policeman, a prosecutor and a judge to fight for eu rights. Script and language as from Orwell's book "1984".  The 2014 elections clearly showed that citizens of EU Member States are fed up with European integration and do not want a deeper EU project. The draft to be implemented by the report to be voted on.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Commission's Recommendations Report establishing an EU democracy mechanism, rule of law and fundamental rights (2015/2254(INL)) as it is necessary to adopt a framework that allows the Union to deal with breaches of EU law and serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights that the EU has included in its key principles and objectives in the first articles of the Treaties and in the criteria for EU membership.  This calls for the establishment of an EU mechanism for annual verification of the state of fundamental rights in the Member States and abolishes the current crisis 'ad hoc' approach in perceived violations of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Furthermore, the need to close the gap between surveillance in candidate countries and the lack of effective tools for EU member states.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. There is a certain danger that the report will embark on a path of greater political control of the EU over recalcitrant Member States in terms of its interpretation of fundamental rights and democracy. I will only point out that the French government itself rejected this proposal as not in accordance with the European treaties and being hostile to the sovereignty of States. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'In view of the need for respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, both inside and outside the EU, I voted in favour of the report. However, EU initiatives in this area should not undermine the jurisdiction of the European Court of Human Rights and the other work of the Council of Europe in this area.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against my colleague Sophie In't Veld's report requiring the European Commission to create a European mechanism for democracy and the rule of law, with the aim of putting states under permanent surveillance, with annual reports that could lead the Commission to impose sanctions against Member States.  I am opposed to this kind of moralising mechanism and contrary to EU law. Indeed, by insisting on the implementation of this mechanism, Parliament allows itself to monitor and punish states while being a legislator. It is an unbelievable interpretation of the principle of separation of powers. While the protection of fundamental rights is an important cause, the principle of subsidiarity is a fundamental principle that prevents me from supporting this report.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ EH Bildu voted in favour of the report with recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The main purpose of this report is to prevent and correct breaches of Union values and founding principles, namely democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. To this end, an annual report with country-specific recommendations is to be drawn up by the Commission, in consultation with a panel of independent experts.  EH Bildu welcomes the wide and varied composition of the panel, most of the aspects of the report and the enabling of citizens to bring actions before the CJEU for alleged violations of the Charter either by EU institutions or by a Member State. Nevertheless, the report could go further and include the monitoring of EU institutions and the assessment of economic and social rights. GUE/NGL tabled 6 amendments to contribute to improve the report but all of them were rejected in plenary. Every mechanism aiming to scrutinise and assess the situation of democracy in Member States is a step forward for EH Bildu since the Spanish State has often shown itself to be below EU standards.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's efforts, as guardian of the Treaties, to remind a Member State of its commitments are met with reluctance or a clear refusal to recognise the commonly agreed rules and the EU's jurisdiction to enforce those rules. To date, the Commission's intervention has proved inadequate and arbitrary. Moreover, the EU institutions themselves sometimes do not comply with basic principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It is therefore imperative to establish a framework allowing the EU to deal not only with violations of specific EU laws but also (the risk) of serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The proposed Interinstitutional Agreement aims to establish arrangements that facilitate cooperation between the EU institutions and its Member States under Article 7 EES by consolidating, aligning and complementing existing mechanisms. In addition, it will provide for an integrated examination mechanism, applicable in all Member States as well as in the three main EU institutions.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to this report. Not only does it call for a revision of the existing treaties, but it also advocates financial sanctions against Member States or the suspension of financial assistance by the Union if States fail to comply with the criteria of the various pacts. At the same time, however, it calls for the creation of a democracy fund for organisations that award scholarships to local actors that support projects on fundamental rights in the EU – a task that does not fall within the Commission's framework mandate.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support efforts to promote and secure rule of law across the EU. It is important that the existing mechanisms in place are used effectively to promote better dialogue with Member States and the EU as this will contribute to a more streamlined approach to upholding fundamental rights and rule of law. In addition, Labour MEPs support the role of the European Parliament in maintaining the debate on rule of law and fundamental rights across the EU. Labour MEPs abstained from the vote, as we believe that efforts should focus on improving existing mechanisms.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are the foundations for accession to the EU. Unfortunately, we see too often that Member States are slyly ly in favour of the requirements once they have been admitted. Principles such as freedom of expression, the press and assembly should not be able to choose on and off the basis of political conviction. That is the cornerstone of European cooperation. That is why the Danish Social Democrats have also supported the report. Such an EU mechanism or other instruments strengthening these rights must, of course, add value to the work already carried out by the UN, the Council of Europe and the EU and be within the competence of the EU. However, it is important that we find new tools without treaty change, as a treaty change is not realistic for the time being, nor do we fully agree with the proposed amendments. The legislative power lies with governments, parliaments and the European Commission. It does not lie with the European Court of Justice, which is why we do not support the fact that one third of MEPs should be able to submit adopted legislative proposals for review by the European Court of Justice. In addition, we would like to stress that we already have a system in which citizens of the European Union can bring cases of unfair measures to the courts, including the European Court of Justice. Today it is just going through the national judicial system, and that is how we think it should be in the future.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report aims to show ways in which the EU can enforce its values against the Member States. According to this proposal, the European Union should be given oversight of the management of fundamental values. These values are human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, the rights of minorities. Equality and anti-discrimination are particularly highlighted and should be enforceable by majority decision after a future revision of the European Treaties. The aim is to explicitly extend the rights of the EU in order to be able to persuade Member States to give way by means of penalties or their threat of 'preventive and corrective'. In addition to the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity enshrined in this text, this text is based on the principle of 'necessity' on an equal footing. However, "necessity" is a rubber term with which you can justify everything. I have rejected this report. The risk is very high that the EU can force such centralised behaviour. The ECJ already decides unilaterally pro-euro and eu-centralism. By extending fundamental rights into more and more areas, such as labour markets, the EU is taking on further policy areas and the principle of subsidiarity is increasingly being damaged.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the vote on the report recommending the Commission on the creation of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, I decided to abstain. I am not entirely convinced that the European Union needs additional expert groups paid for with taxpayers' money, and, moreover, I believe that this mechanism is supposed to be a kind of whiplash against states whose policies the EU institutions do not agree with. I am fully aware that, for example, the rule of law is being dismantled in Poland, but it believes that it is a manifestation of political weakness when we pay a group with public money to tell us what we already know, but thus to relieve ourselves of political responsibility. Moreover, the selection of these experts can become a highly politicized matter, which would rather hurt the whole thing.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As long as there is no objective definition of the rule of law adopted by common consensus among the 27 Member States, any rule of law mechanism will form part of the current party political games and remain a breeding ground for double standards. Therefore, as a member of the FIDESZ delegation to the People's Party, I voted against this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The interpretation of democracy in ultra-liberal circles is very specific, they believe that only referendums that produce the same result as their position are acceptable, but because such referendums are rare, it is best not to have referendums. With their predominance in the press, they often suppress critical voices and maintain opinions, grossly manipulating public opinion, as evidenced by the fact-finding works of the famous German zsurnaliszta Udo Ulfkotte. Such trends are impermissible. The Union must respect the national identity of the Member States, which is an integral part of their fundamental political and constitutional system.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, as the European Union has enshrined democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in its fundamental principles and objectives. The Community has a wide range of tools for the implementation of its laws and treaties when it comes to substantive issues, but this is not the case when it comes to the application of treaty obligations to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The Commission's attempts to remind a Member State of its commitments are often met reluctantly or directly with a refusal to recognise generally accepted rules and the EU's power to enforce their compliance, and so far its intervention has been timid and arbitrary. Although the EU has a number of existing instruments to safeguard fundamental principles and rights, significant gaps still exist and in practice these instruments often prove limited in scope, insufficient and ineffective, or their use is unlikely. Instead of creating new procedures, an interinstitutional agreement based on existing instruments is proposed, extending its scope through a reporting, notification and sanctioning mechanism.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, more than ever, the EU needs a comprehensive mechanism to ensure democracy, respect for human rights, the rule of law and the fundamental rights and freedoms of Union citizens. This need is dictated by the current level of integration in the EU and recent events in some Member States. In recent years, there has been a negative tendency for a number of countries to violate EU law, the de facto violating the fundamental rights and freedoms of European citizens, who are not always fully aware, and this is an even more serious problem. Unfortunately, my homeland Bulgaria is no exception. Because of an undemocratic legal restriction in the Bulgarian electoral code, I myself was fined for using several words in my mother tongue during an election campaign in Bulgaria. And the right of every citizen of the Union to express messages and opinions in the language of his or her chosen language should be guaranteed. In this context, I fully support the establishment of the EU mechanism in question, because it will ensure that European citizens are treated equally, but will also monitor the implementation of European law by the Member States.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. In the absence of a mechanism for systematic and impartial monitoring of Member States and institutions, a stable and effective legal framework is called for, allowing the defence of European rules and values, which are fundamental to the proper functioning of the Union in all policy areas. With today's vote, Parliament is proposing the adoption of an interinstitutional agreement that facilitates cooperation between the EU institutions and the Member States and complements the existing instruments. This agreement must be objective, preventive and corrective, and it must provide for a review mechanism to be applied equally to all Member States and institutions. The rights of our citizens and the values of the Union must be applied with a comprehensive approach without discrimination, and for these reasons I am voting in favour of Parliament's proposal on the EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. In the light of recent controversies, particularly over Hungary and Poland, over respect for the rule of law, we discussed an initiative report proposing an annual mechanism to verify Member States' respect for democracy and fundamental rights.  The measures proposed by the liberal Dutch rapporteur aim to impose permanent and widespread monitoring of Member States by a committee of appointed experts on the basis of criteria lacking clarity, such as 'state impartiality', which is not really defined.  This concept of a europe that is a lecturer and sanctimonious does not suit us, even if, of course, we are in favour of the rule of law and respect for the values of the European Charter of Fundamental Rights! This gas plant mechanism, the idea of which has nevertheless attracted a majority of parliamentarians, since the report of our Dutch colleague has been adopted, seems to us to be likely to violate the principle of subsidiarity and to be, as it stands, inadequate. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Hungary and now Poland have been the scene of worrying developments. The barely elected ultra-conservative governments have systematically begun to deconstruct institutional counter-powers and put the media on the move. However, the European Union is completely powerless in the face of these developments: the only tool at its disposal is the suspension of voting rights in the Council, i.e. to take away from a government its power to influence European decisions. But she is reluctant to use it because she considers it too strong.  Knowing this hesitation, the apprentice autocrates do not hesitate to multiply provocations and test European reactions. It is therefore important to change this impunity. The European Parliament's proposal to create a mechanism to monitor the rule of law goes in this direction. This mechanism would provide an annual report on the state of democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law, which would allow people to have an independent assessment of the evolution of their democracy. So I supported that proposal.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the creation of a union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In reality, it is an EU mechanism to take political control of Member States that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  Each Member State will be subject to an annual review. A panel of experts will make a report which will then be adopted by the Commission.  The report also calls for EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, which will strengthen the influence of the European Court of Human Rights and the Council of Europe, which includes Turkey, Albania, etc.  In particular, paragraph 20 calls for a revision of the Treaty which would allow a third of MEPs in the European Parliament to refer the matter to the Court of Justice after the final adoption of a text and before its implementation. This is an attack in good standing on the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This is an EU mechanism for taking political control of Member States, particularly those that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  Each Member State will be subject to an annual review by a panel of experts who will report back to the Commission.  Even the French government has stated that the proposal is not in accordance with the treaties. This is therefore an attack in good standing against the sovereignty of the Member States, I could only vote AGAINST.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims to develop at European level a legal mechanism to monitor compliance with the principles governing democracy in the Union, including sanctions and the application of which is at the level of the values which the Union claims to defend. To achieve this, the report raises the possibility of articulating existing instruments to make them effective in practice, to this end it would be complemented by a monitoring, reporting and sanctions system. The implementation of this integrated framework of action has stirred controversy, since those who reject it say they do so on the basis of their distrust of the procedure in terms of objectivity, equanimity and equal treatment. The Socialists are pleased with the inclusion of the so-called 'scoreboard' which aims to develop a preventive and early warning dimension, as well as objective and proven indicators, which allow the performance of the Member States to be assessed objectively, thus becoming an effective complement to existing instruments.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The lack of guarantees of compliance with fundamental rights, as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, signed by all Member States, is a reality in all Member States. In the Spanish State, the Government repeatedly fails to comply with issues such as freedom of expression and protest, in the face of the passivity of the European institutions. I therefore support any mechanism that is in favour of the performance of these rights and allows the action of the Member States to be monitored, so I voted in favour. However, I understand that the proposed mechanism is clearly insufficient, and although I support the preparation of parliamentary reports on this and that the role of the Ombudsman is enhanced, I cannot believe that this will actually solve the current profound problem. The Union cannot today seek to wash its face and pose as a space where fundamental rights are guaranteed, so this mechanism will play an exclusively cosmetic role, unless it is accompanied by a political will for democratisation which does not exist today among the Community authorities.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report recalls the importance that the Union has traditionally played and plays in the areas of democracy, the rule of law and the rights of citizens. Thus, he has enshrined them as the principles on which he settles, and the fundamental objectives he pursues. However, despite the existence of a number of instruments to ensure the defence of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, considerable gaps remain, adding to the limited or inefficient scope of these instruments. It should be noted that there is no integrated mechanism for the systematic, impartial and total monitoring of all Member States and their institutions. The Union itself has struggled to uphold its own rules, which frustrates mutual trust and hinders the existence of a reliable and stable legal framework. All of this denotes that it is important to adopt clear and objective benchmarks to address non-compliance with Union rules, as well as threats to democracy. I welcome the report as the interinstitutional agreement proposed there is a good step in achieving that objective.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This report aims to show ways in which the EU can enforce its values against the Member States. According to this proposal, the European Union should be given oversight of the management of fundamental values. These values are human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, the rights of minorities. Equality and anti-discrimination are particularly highlighted and should be enforceable by majority decision after a future revision of the European Treaties. The aim is to explicitly extend the rights of the EU in order to be able to persuade Member States to give way by means of penalties or their threat of 'preventive and corrective'. In addition to the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity enshrined in this text, this text is based on the principle of 'necessity' on an equal footing. "Necessity" is a rubber term with which you can justify everything. I have rejected this report. The risk is very high that the EU will be able to enforce EU-compliant behaviour in this way. The ECJ already decides unilaterally pro-EU and pro-euro. By extending fundamental rights into more and more areas, such as labour markets, the EU is taking on further policy areas and the principle of subsidiarity is increasingly being damaged.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the establishment of a mechanism to monitor Member States’ compliance with democratic values and the rule of law.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the call for 'the establishment of a foundation for democracy that will award grants and support local actors that promote democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights within the Union'. I consider this to be a further subsidy for human rights organisations, which often promote their political ideas. The basic framework for human and civil rights is the constitutions of individual Member States. We will not support democracy and human rights by subsidiseing certain entities.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In my view the most important part of the report is the recommendation to adopt a Union Pact for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights that consists of: an annual report on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights with country-specific recommendations incorporating the reporting by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, the Council of Europe, and other relevant authorities in the field; an annual inter-parliamentary debate on the basis of the European DRF Report; arrangements for remedying possible risks and breaches, as provided for by the Treaties, including the activation of the preventative or corrective arms of Article 7 TEU; DRF Policy Cycle within the Union institutions. But there is still a lack of enforcing mechanism. Without it effectiveness will be low.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States, together with the Union, subscribe to the rule of law, democracy and the protection and respect for fundamental rights. These values are enshrined in a number of international conventions and treaties which have different legal obligations. Some oblige all Member States, and some, such as the European Parliament, the Council, the Commission, the European Parliament, the European Parliament, the European The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights applies to certain Member States (the United Kingdom and Poland) only to the extent that they do not exceed their national standard of protection of human rights. Events in some Member States have rightly raised the issue of creating a minimum uniform legal protection for these values, including procedures for their possible infringement. I believe that such an arrangement must not interfere with the sovereignty of the Member States, must comply with the law in force and must be the result of consensus from all Member States. All the competent institutions, the Commission, the Council and other European and national authorities must be actively involved in tackling this fundamental problem.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The Union is struggling to ensure that its founding principles are respected within it. It has ineffective instruments to prevent human rights violations in its Member States. This is evidenced by the example of the situation in Poland, where the separation of powers is weakened by the position of the Constitutional Court, which is unable to monitor the compliance of laws in that country. If compliance with the Union's economic and fiscal rules is systematically and meticulously scrutinized, respect for the rule of law should deserve at least the same attention.  For example, this initiative report proposes to establish an annual assessment mechanism - by a panel of independent experts - of respect for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights by Member States and the three main EU institutions. I am voting in favour of this text, because the mechanism it proposes to create would represent an undeniable step forward for the protection of fundamental rights and democracy at EU level.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report containing recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 25 October 2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text proposes the creation of a Union mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. The European Parliament is thus seeking to give the Commission new tools to take political control of the Member States by positioning the Commission above national governments. Indeed, following the establishment of this mechanism, each Member State will be subject to an annual check to check whether it meets the conditions of democracy, but democracy according to the interpretation of European officials...  A report on each state will then be adopted by the Commission. This report is a direct attack on the sovereignty of the Member States or rather on this illusion of sovereignty that remains to us after decades of submission from the French governments to the technocrats in Brussels.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for a Union pact for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights to address not only cases of non-compliance with specific Union rules, but also serious threats that may arise. To this end, we must work on establishing modalities to facilitate the cooperation of the institutions of the Union and its Member States and to ensure the maintenance of Europe's long tradition in these areas.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution, because it is imperative to establish a framework that gives the EU the opportunity to deal with violations and threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In addition, additional non-legislative measures should be taken to ensure an integrated approach to respecting the principles on which the EU is based.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission scrupulously respects the austere economic rules, but there is no provision for respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which are enshrined as fundamental values in the treaties. There is section 7, but it is a long and complex procedure.  This report therefore proposes an inter-institutional agreement to enforce these principles. If, since the debates on Hungarian constitutional reform and the recent reforms in Poland, I am watching carefully the consequences, lest the European Commission be given discretionary powers once again, I welcome the fact that this assessment calls on legitimate and independent bodies (Council of Europe, UN...), in addition to the consultation of national parliaments.  In concrete terms, this report opens the possibility of legal action on the legality of an austerity cut by a state that would infringe on rights on access to health, for example. I regret that the agreement does not aim so assiduously at European bodies, and in particular the Eurogroup, but I nevertheless vote for this advance for citizens' rights should it come to light. The Commission has until September 2017 to bury or tamper with it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. It is an EU mechanism for taking political control of Member States, particularly those that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  Each Member State will be subject to an annual review by a panel of experts who will report back to the Commission. Even the French government has stated that the proposal is not in accordance with the treaties. This is therefore an attack in good standing against the sovereignty of the Member States, so I obviously objected to it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, enshrined in its principles and core objectives in the first articles of the ET, as well as on the criteria for joining the European Union. I look with good eyes at the creation of a comprehensive Union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights that includes all relevant stakeholders. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported Parliament’s call for a watchdog that will monitor the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights within the Union. It is essential that the EU’s core values are protected and respected.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this report on a mechanism for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. With this vote, Parliament makes a formal appeal to the Commission to present a proposal for the creation of such a mechanism by September 2017 at the latest.  This initiative makes perfect sense in view of the drifts in some Member States and the clear weakness of the various mechanisms already in place. I keep repeating this: the Union has a duty to monitor its Member States' respect for the fundamental rights and values of democracy and the rule of law enshrined in our treaties.  Such a mechanism has the merit of institutionalizing continuous and objective monitoring of the respect of our values and would therefore allow to systematically pinpoint any faults or deviations as soon as they appear. The Commission, as guardian of the treaties, must now respond to the expectations that have been expressed and finally launch the long-awaited work of the Union of Our Rights.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union is built on the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, it is a community of values, but it continues to be a community of sovereign states based on the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. I believe that the provisions of the proposed EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights violate the first principle. The proposal leaves the power to a new group of 'independent experts' to investigate Member States, which includes, inter alia, international organisations such as the UN, the OSCE and the OECD; they already have a mandate to monitor the human rights and democracy situation. Putting the mechanism into practice would be a duplication and unnecessary waste of money. Furthermore, the Pact can be an instrument for the EU's political dominance over the Member States. In his view, it should be possible for states to be penalised on the basis of the opinion of 'independent experts' if their populations want to protect themselves from decisions made by the EU institutions in particularly sensitive areas, through referendums or changes to the Constitution. The EU must respect the national identity of the Member States, which lies in their fundamental political and constitutional systems, including regional and local governments. I am therefore voting against the proposed report.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'In view of the need for respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, both inside and outside the EU, I voted in favour of the report. However, EU initiatives in this area should not undermine the jurisdiction of the European Court of Human Rights and the other work of the Council of Europe in this area.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs states that the European Union is a community of values; it has included democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which are also the conditions for EU membership, in the first articles of the Treaties. However, while the Union has a wide range of instruments at its disposal to implement its legislation and the Treaties, this is no longer the case with regard to the enforcement of the treaty obligations with regard to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The European Commission encounters resistance or explicit rejection when it comes to enforcing commonly agreed rules and acknowledging the union's right to enforce them.  The report therefore considers it essential to adopt a framework that will enable the EU to deal not only with violations of specific EU legislation, but also with serious threats (risks) to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It therefore proposes the adoption of an EU pact on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the form of an interinstitutional agreement, and the Annex to the proposal makes a concrete proposal for its text.  I was all the more pleased to vote in favour of this proposal because I myself have long felt the need to bring such an agreement to a head.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of an EU mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. In reality, it is a mechanism created to take political control of Member States that do not respect the interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights desired by Brussels.  Each Member State will be subject to an annual review. A panel of experts (one magistrate per Member State plus ten "experts" appointed by the European Parliament) will produce a report which will then be adopted by the Commission.  The report also calls for EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, which will strengthen the influence of the European Court of Human Rights and the Council of Europe (which includes Turkey, Albania, etc.).  In particular, paragraph 20 calls for a revision of the Treaty which would allow a third of MEPs in the European Parliament to refer the matter to the Court of Justice after the final adoption of a text and before its implementation. This is an attack in good standing on the sovereignty of the member states. Even the French government has stated that the proposal is not in accordance with the treaties. This report can only provoke strong disapproval.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of an EU mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. In reality, it is a mechanism of the Union to take political control of the Member States.
