The report also calls for EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, which will strengthen the influence of the European Court of Human Rights and the Council of Europe (which includes Turkey, Albania, etc.). This is therefore an attack in good standing against the sovereignty of the Member States and I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support efforts to promote and secure rule of law across the EU. It is important that the existing mechanisms in place are used effectively to promote better dialogue with Member States and the EU as this will contribute to a more streamlined approach to upholding fundamental rights and rule of law. In addition, Labour MEPs support the role of the European Parliament in maintaining the debate on rule of law and fundamental rights across the EU.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the creation of a union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Indeed, there are several provisions in this report aimed at amending the treaties, including the removal of Article 51 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which delimits the Union's judicial competence. This would seriously undermine the principle of subsidiarity and weaken the justice of the Member States.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We support the report containing recommendations to the Commission to establish a European mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Although these values are given fundamental importance in the Treaties, there are difficulties in their practical application today, as evidenced by some recent cases, in which some Member States, called on by the Commission to respect these values, have been reluctant to recognise them. This parliamentary initiative is very important, as it aims to provide the Community institutions with preventive, sanctioning and corrective instruments for possible infringements that may undermine fundamental European values such as democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In particular, given that these issues are not easily measurable, we believe that it is particularly important that the Group of Socialists and Democrats has succeeded in including in the text the idea of having a group of independent experts so as to ensure maximum impartiality in the context of the so-called Democracy Scoreboard, another instrument suggested in the report aimed at assessing and monitoring the compliance of the Member States. Full use of the instruments already in place, alongside the additions proposed in the text, would lead to a substantial improvement in respect for values that are so important for our future.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – In the European Union, it is extremely important to pay attention to the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights, so I welcome the report and am very pleased that we are also addressing this issue at EU level. However, we cannot ignore the fact that we cannot interfere with each Member State's own internal legal order, such as the functioning of national courts as an external force, or the laws issued and adopted by their legislative bodies, as this would be a serious breach of subsidiarity. I don't support that either.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report that calls for the adoption of a framework that will enable the EU to address infringements to specific EU laws, serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution establishing an interinstitutional agreement on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, as it will ensure compliance with these principles through a representative group of independent experts, based on a quantitative and qualitative review of the available data and information provided by all Member States. In addition, the EU Pact for Democracy also provides for the preparation of an annual annual report on democracy containing country-specific recommendations. The adoption of the report launches interparliamentary debates aimed at addressing the results of the European Democracy Report. On the basis of the report, the Commission may decide to initiate 'systemic infringement' proceedings under Article 2 TEU and Article 258 TFEU by joining several infringement proceedings. I stand by the resolution because I believe that the EU Pact will remove the scepticism directed towards my country as a reliable business partner and a critical view of current inconsistencies with EU law existing in other Member States.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I felt that it was very important that, in the context of the many, sometimes political debates on compliance with or non-compliance with certain democratic procedures in the Member States, it is normal to create a uniform EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. While I believe that, by bringing national themes to Brussels, we are forcing the European institutions to intervene in internal procedures of Member States that do not fall within the competence of the EU, in order to ensure an impartial analysis of the various situations and to ensure compliance with EU principles, I support the development of this mechanism applicable to all Member States.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The VVD delegation supports the principle and purpose of the mechanism but abstained in the final vote because it included a number of provisions that run counter to the Dutch legal system. As far as we are concerned, the new agency cannot (co)determine what a European and what a national competence is (interpretation of Article 2 VWEU). We are opposed to granting direct and direct access to the European Court to all natural and legal persons in all cases. We want to maintain normal justice through the national courts. Finally, we do not support the idea of being able to halt a legislative process with only a third of the VOTES of the EP because of a preliminary ruling before the Court.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the Treaty urgently needs to be revised. For example, it does not include financial sanctions against Member States that do not comply with the criteria of the EU package or suspension of financial assistance by the Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Given the developments in and around the EU in societies, it is important to be aware of the common values on which the EU is founded. The report recommends the creation of a mechanism to ensure that democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are also respected in practice.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report proposing the creation of a European binding mechanism providing for the annual reporting of the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in all EU Member States. The mechanism will ensure that all EU Member States respect the values enshrined in the European Treaties and set clear, documented and non-political criteria for assessing countries' track record in the areas of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The mechanism seeks to integrate existing tools into a single instrument and ensure their effective use. It also wants to bridge the gap between the monitoring of respect for these values by the candidate countries, on the one hand, and the lack, on the other, of effective means of monitoring respect for the same values as those already EU Member States. We don't want to stick to the theory. Recent events in Hungary and Poland have shown that the EU must have effective tools at its disposal to address threats to the EU's fundamental values, threats that undermine democracy in our countries.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report. Today, there is no mechanism for the systematic and complete monitoring of Member States and European institutions in the event of violations of European texts, democracy, the rule of law or fundamental rights.  I naturally support the proposal to establish an annual assessment mechanism for respect for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights by the Member States and the three main EU institutions. This system would thus continuously assess the state of the rule of law throughout the European Union.  This proposal represents a step forward for the protection of fundamental rights and democracy at EU level!

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP firmly rejects the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. UKIP believe that this mechanism is a severe infringement of national sovereignty. UKIP also vehemently opposes calls in this report for the EU to accede to the ECHR.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this proposal, as I fully agree with my colleague that the rule of law is the backbone of European liberal democracy and is one of the founding principles of the Union. Furthermore, all Member States and bodies of the Union have a duty to respect, protect and promote these principles and values. I am also convinced that it is up to the Union to promote the protection of democracies and fundamental rights.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Democracy and rule of law and fundamental rights are core values for the EU. Given the challenges ahead of the Union we have observed that some Member States have weakened their promotion of these values. For this reason I voted in favour of this report, in line with the EPP’s stance that the mechanism to be created must fit into the current Treaties’ framework and must be legally sound.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Comparing the version of the European Union Mechanism for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights we have before us today and the initial document tells us about the level of dissatisfaction this proposal has caused both across Europe and among MEPs. Many compromises have been reached, including those relating to the proposals I also sent as part of the amendments tabled, but I cannot help feeling that the objective of this report remains unchanged.  This attempt to interfere in member states' internal affairs is unacceptable. The Treaty on European Union clearly states that the Union respects member states' equality before the Treaties, as well as their national identities, which are inseparably linked to their fundamental political and constitutional structures, including regional and local self-government. I cannot support such a proposal from the European Union Mechanism for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights, since I consider it incompatible with that principle and thus the Treaty on European Union.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of an EU mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. In reality, it is an EU mechanism to take political control of Member States that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  Each Member State will be subject to an annual review. A panel of experts (1 magistrate per EM, plus ten "experts" appointed by the European Parliament) will make a report which will then be adopted by the Commission. The report also calls for EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, which will strengthen the influence of the European Court of Human Rights and the Council of Europe (which includes Turkey, Albania, etc.).  In particular, paragraph 20 calls for a revision of the Treaty which would allow a third of MEPs in the European Parliament to refer the matter to the Court of Justice after the final adoption of a text and before its implementation. This is an attack in good standing on the sovereignty of the Member States, and even the French government has stated that the proposal is not in accordance with the treaties.  It is clear that I am voting resolutely against this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has many instruments at its disposal to ensure compliance with its laws and treaties on economic and market issues. This is not the case when it comes to enforcing obligations relating to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The Commission may require Member States, for example, to adjust their budgets when they are not in line with European legislation, and no one disputes the fact that The Member States are obliged to follow up the Commission's recommendations. When it comes to respecting the fundamental principles on which the Union is founded, all too often the Member States are reluctant to follow the Commission's invitations, in its role as guarantor of the Treaties, or openly refuse. All this leads to an erosion of mutual trust and public confidence in the institutions. The time has therefore come to develop a systematic, impartial and comprehensive procedure that monitors and guarantees respect for the founding values of the Union, both by the Member States and by the European institutions themselves. Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are at the top of the priorities set out in the Treaties, and now that these priorities are also being defended in practice.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are key principles set out in both the treaty articles and eu membership criteria. The European Commission has the right to intervene to ensure that national legislation is compatibility with EU law, and Member States do not dispute the fact that EU treaties oblige them to ensure compliance.  However, when it comes to the implementation of the Treaties' obligations on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, the Interventions of the European Commission are cautious, arbitrary and encounters opposition or complete rejection by Member States. Another problem is that the EU institutions themselves sometimes failed to respect the key principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  This is why it was necessary to create an integrated mechanism for systematic, impartial and full monitoring of all Member States and institutions. It is time to create adequate conditions for the protection of fundamental European values in practice. I believe that the adoption of the EU Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights in the form of an interinstitutional agreement is an important step. The new single framework should be objective, evidence-based and apply equally and fairly to all Member States and include a preventive and corrective dimension. It will provide an integrated audit mechanism that will apply to all Member States, as well as to the three main EU institutions.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are facing an unacceptable assault on the sovereignty of states, from which we are firmly distancing ourselves. It aims to deepen the mechanisms of federalisation of the European Union and provides for the creation of a political cycle for democracy and the rule of law (in what is its meaning), similar to the European semester; make the EUe and the CDFUE the legal basis for legislative measures and revise Article 7 OF the ET, introducing relevant and applicable sanctions against any Member State; remove the principle of subsidiarity of the CDFUE; review the requirement for unanimity in the Council in decisions involving fundamental rights. These points legitimize the sanctions and unacceptable blackmail and pressure snare on Portugal. The EU institutions are no example when it comes to democracy and fundamental rights. Harmonisation of these is unacceptable negative pressure for countries such as Portugal, levelling the standards of social and labour rights. The plot of European treaties and legislation is, in fact, an obstacle to the legitimate sovereign decision of each people deciding on their destinies, an obstacle to the realization of the Portuguese Constitution and the achievements of the revolution that the Portuguese people, sooner than later, will know how to resume and impose, freeing themselves from the constraints of the treaties. We voted against it.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for the rule of law within the Union is an essential condition for the protection of fundamental rights and respect for all rights and obligations arising from treaties and international law. However, the approach proposed by the rapporteur seems to give rise to legitimate concerns regarding the application of a common EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which could be misused and to the detriment of some Member States. If this were the case, a large part of European public opinion would be opposed to the introduction of such a mechanism. Furthermore, systems of control of the rule of law are already an integral part of the constitutions of all the Member States. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union is inadequate because the preventive mechanism and the sanctions mechanism in question have never been activated before, Parliament, together with a team of experts composed of representatives of NGOs, lawyers and others, would be in favour of prosecuting Member States guilty of violating common European values. The proposal is accompanied by a detailed annex explaining which mechanism, in the EP's view, should be proposed in the Commission proposal, including amendments to the Treaties, which mainly delete the principle of subsidiarity.  The rapporteur says that savings of billions of euros will be achieved, but at the same time the proposal clearly violates the principle of subsidiarity and the principle of conferral of competences. The Head of the Legal Service of the European Parliament stated that the EP should not propose such a mechanism, as this goes beyond the powers of the Treaties. Nevertheless, the rapporteur continues the procedure, waiting for the Commission's lawyers to confirm or dispute this fact. I therefore could not support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. We must have the courage to say this: I am not critical of the principles that guide the drafting of this report, because these are fundamental values that we all share. This is really not about being against democracy, the rule of law, let alone fundamental rights. The choice to vote for or against this report must be guided by the consistency and respect of the European rules decided by the Member States.  Very clearly, the (liberal) rapporteur of this text has chosen to promote rules that would threaten the institutional balance of the European Union and impose widespread and permanent monitoring of The Member States. This goes against the principle of subsidiarity.  At a time when critics of the European Union are growing, it would be a pity to promote a Union seen as a lesson-giving to the Member States.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We can say, in a way that Europe has a long tradition in the field of democracy, the rule of law and citizens' rights. Basing its roots in Athenian democracy, the Magna Carta of 1215, the Declaration of Human and Citizen Rights of 1789, the European Convention on Human Rights and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the European Union enshrined democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights (EO) in its main principles and objectives inscribed in the first articles of the Treaties , as well as the CRITERIA for EU membership. In its external policies too, the EU stresses the importance of human rights and democratic governance, thereby promoting them in partnerships such as the ACP-EU. However, while the EU has a number of instruments to enforce its laws and treaties on material issues such as budgets, public health programmes or tax rulings, the same is no longer the case in the fulfilment of the Treaty's obligations on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It is important to adopt a structure that allows the EU to tackle both infringements of specific EU legislation and serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I vote in favor.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP firmly rejects the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. UKIP believe that this mechanism is a severe infringement of national sovereignty. UKIP also vehemently opposes calls in this report for the EU to accede to the ECHR.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the initiative report on the EU's rule of law mechanism. This vote of the European Parliament represents a victory for the Europe of values and democracy. Being a member of a team means following the rules. Otherwise, it is the integrity and legitimacy of the collective that are compromised. Also, joining the European Union implies 'the presence of stable institutions guaranteeing democracy, the rule of law and human rights'. These are criteria that must be met on a daily basis by the Member States. Unfortunately, the reality is quite different. For this reason, it is essential that the Union finally establishes a mechanism that continuously assesses the respect of the rule of law by Member States and the European institutions, impartially and independently, without the influence of political power. It is not just a question of reacting when the damage is done, but also and above all of preventing the risk of serious threats to democracy and fundamental rights.  The Union cannot remain only a large market for goods and services. It is a political space that carries at its heart an ideal and principles inherent in its existence.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the consecration of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the main principles and objectives set out in the first articles of the Treaties, as well as in the criteria for EU membership. Attempts to include in the Treaties a reference to Europe's Judeo-Christian roots have gone unfailed, but show that the European Union is seen as a community of values. In its external policies, the EU stresses the importance of human rights and democratic governance and immigrants residing in Europe are expected to respect and understand our common values. While the EU has a number of tools to ensure respect for the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, there are still substantial gaps and in practice these instruments show limited scope, are inadequate and inefficient, or their implementation is unlikely. In this way, it is essential to adopt a structure that allows the EU to combat both infringements of specific EU legislation and serious threats (and risks of threats) to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has a wide range of instruments to enforce its laws and treaties on material matters. In such cases, Member States do not question the fact that they are obliged to comply with EU law. The same is no longer the case when it comes to the fulfilment of the obligations laid down in the field of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. While the EU has a number of instruments to ensure compliance with these principles, there are still substantial gaps and, in practice, these instruments show limited scope. There is no integrated mechanism for systematic, impartial and complete monitoring of all Member States and their institutions. It is imperative to adopt a structure that allows the EU to combat both infringements of specific EU legislation and serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The EU's failures to defend its own standards and the perception that there are no common European values are also undermining mutual trust and the establishment of a stable and reliable legal framework, essential for the proper functioning of the EU in all policy areas.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Treaty establishes the Responsibility of the Union to promote and protect the constitutional bases shared by the Member States in the field of fundamental rights. In practice, however, problems of effectiveness, competence and suitability have been identified when implementing them. Parliament raises the possibility of articulating existing instruments to make them effective and developing a legal mechanism to monitor compliance with the principles governing democracy in the Union through a system of monitoring, reporting and sanctions, the current 'Rule of Law Framework of the European Commission' and the Council's 'Rule of Law Dialogue', as well as strengthening the so-called 'scoreboard' and the inclusion of a 'Democracy Pact'. Sanctions and infringement proceedings resulting from possible non-compliance could contribute to the activation of Article 7 of the Treaty, which provides for a sanctioning mechanism enabling the Council to suspend certain rights arising from the application of the Treaties, including the right to vote in the Council where a 'serious infringement' is established. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the In 't Veld report which calls on the European Commission to set up a binding mechanism to assess annual breaches of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms in the European Union, as it is imperative to adopt a framework that allows the Union to combat not only violations of specific European legislation , but also against serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  The values to which Member States subscribe to the EU must be respected in every respect. There has been too much misbehaviour lately. Attacks on democracy against NGOs, the independence of the press and the judiciary are simply unacceptable. Minimizing them would undermine the humanist vision and the European values that I intend to defend in Parliament.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the creation of a union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  More than a single market, the European Union is a community of values that has been able to establish a lasting place in respect for the rule of law, the cornerstone of democracy. However, while there are rules to ensure that it is followed, there is no systematic and impartial monitoring mechanism. This is the aim of this report, which proposes the establishment of an annual monitoring mechanism for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights.  In light of recent events in Poland or Hungary, such a mechanism would complement the existing framework and more effectively implement Article 7 of the Treaty. To do this, the report provides for corrective mechanisms and the inclusion of civil society, while respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is known to be a union governed by the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, expressly enshrined in its Treaties and constituting membership criteria. There are several instruments available to enforce laws and treaties on a wide range of material issues relating to the various areas of competence of the Union, namely in tax, budgetary, public health and employment. However, it is clear that this is not the case in the area of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, where Member States and the European institutions sometimes have difficulty in respecting the founding treaties and principles, and there are substantial gaps in their adequacy, efficiency, exemption, fairness and applicability. As the rapporteur points out, an integrated, integrated, impartial and complete monitoring mechanism for all Member States and their institutions should be established, capable of combating infringements of European legislation and threats to these principles and values of major importance. In view of the foregoing, I was in favour of the adoption of this report with a view to the adoption of an EU Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights, in the form of an interinstitutional agreement, as proposed.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report, because I welcome most of the proposals contained in the report and the annex. I believe that although the final report has been weakened in its content relative to the original, the recommendations it issues are moving forward on the path of greater European cohesion in the maintenance and supervision of the fundamental rights of the Union.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are the foundations for accession to the EU. Unfortunately, we see too often that Member States are slyly ly in favour of the requirements once they have been admitted. Principles such as freedom of expression, the press and assembly should not be able to choose on and off the basis of political conviction. That is the cornerstone of European cooperation. That is why the Danish Social Democrats have also supported the report. Such an EU mechanism or other instruments strengthening these rights must, of course, add value to the work already carried out by the UN, the Council of Europe and the EU and be within the competence of the EU. However, it is important that we find new tools without treaty change, as a treaty change is not realistic for the time being, nor do we fully agree with the proposed amendments. The legislative power lies with governments, parliaments and the European Commission. It does not lie with the European Court of Justice, which is why we do not support the fact that one third of MEPs should be able to submit adopted legislative proposals for review by the European Court of Justice. In addition, we would like to stress that we already have a system in which citizens of the European Union can bring cases of unfair measures to the courts, including the European Court of Justice. Today it is just going through the national judicial system, and that is how we think it should be in the future.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The lack of guarantees of compliance with fundamental rights, as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, signed by all Member States, is a reality in all Member States. In the Spanish State, the Government repeatedly fails to comply with issues such as freedom of expression and protest, in the face of the passivity of the European institutions. I therefore support any mechanism that is in favour of the performance of these rights and allows the action of the Member States to be monitored, so I voted in favour. However, I understand that the proposed mechanism is clearly insufficient, and although I support the preparation of parliamentary reports on this and that the role of the Ombudsman is enhanced, I cannot believe that this will actually solve the current profound problem. The Union cannot today seek to wash its face and pose as a space where fundamental rights are guaranteed, so this mechanism will play an exclusively cosmetic role, unless it is accompanied by a political will for democratisation which does not exist today among the Community authorities. That's why I abstained.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a Labour MEP, I support efforts to promote and secure the rule of law across the EU. It is important that the existing mechanisms in place are used effectively to promote better dialogue with Member States and the EU as this will contribute to a more streamlined approach to upholding fundamental rights and the rule of law. In addition, I support the role of the European Parliament in maintaining the debate on the rule of law and fundamental rights across the EU. Myself and other Labour MEPs abstained from the vote, as we believe that efforts should focus on improving existing mechanisms.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission agreed with me that this mechanism was not needed, was an ideological imposition on all Member States, and most fundamentally lacked any legal basis in the Treaties.  Having been adopted this has dealt a blow to true rule of law, because the mechanism itself ignores the Treaties and sovereign Member State competences.  At a time of fragile union, this is another reason euroscepticism is at an all-time high.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution with recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The European Union has enshrine democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights among its fundamental principles and objectives, which are in all treaties and are also among the criteria for EU membership.  At the same time, the EU has sufficient instruments to enforce its legislation and treaties. The Commission can arrange for Member States to adjust their budgets, public health systems or tax rulings in order to comply with EU law. Nevertheless, there are still large gaps, and in practice these instruments often have a limited scope, tend to be insufficient and ineffective. It is therefore essential to approve a framework that will enable the EU to address not only breaches of specific EU legislation, but also cases of serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The proposed interinstitutional agreement aims to set out measures that will facilitate the cooperation of the EU institutions and its Member States.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I myself have experienced a period of non-freedom, which is why I know that democratic values, the rule of law and human rights must be constantly protected and ensured that they are not violated.  Although the EU has legally enshrined mechanisms for upholding these values, a report by In't Veld has been submitted to the European Parliament on the creation of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I have not supported this report and its proposals for a number of reasons, and I will mention at least some of them.  In cases where we have indications that respect for democratic values may be jeopardised in a Member State, a constructive diplomatic dialogue must be established with that State and the existing instruments under the founding treaties should be used. This process is also ongoing, see the current situation in Poland. Faith and commitment to these principles must be cultivated continuously in the citizens of the Union, above all through education and exemplary action by the European institutions themselves. As a result, education, diplomatic dialogue, diplomatic pressure and leaving time for the development of existing contractual instruments for the protection of these values may be more effective than the creation of new and additional mechanisms. We can consider rationalising a procedure that is certainly not flawless, but not in the way proposed in this report.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, which are included in its core principles.  The institutions and bodies of the Union and the Member States should respect their obligations and set an example in meeting them and strive for a common culture of the importance of the rule of law. Until the Treaties are made, the European Parliament recommends the establishment of a comprehensive Union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights involving all relevant stakeholders.  In its report, Parliament therefore asks the Commission, on the basis of Article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, to submit a proposal for the conclusion of an EU Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights in the form of an interinstitutional agreement laying down arrangements to facilitate the cooperation of the institutions of the Union and its Member States in this area.  In view of the recent developments in Hungary and Poland, where there has been a persistent regression of certain fundamental freedoms and a failure to respect the rule of law, I supported the report.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'The EU must deal with all infringements of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, including those that happen in the Member States without a strict link with EU secondary law. However, recent events in Hungary, Poland and some other Member States show that there are gaps in European legislation. There is currently no instrument that meets Parliament's legitimate requirement that the existing procedures be able to be applied permanently to all Member States. This report therefore proposes a system of continuous monitoring of the situation in the Member States, with a prominent role for independent experts. This expert panel will be set up under the control of the Commission and will propose a report each year analysing the situation in all Member States. This report must then be approved by the Commission, after which the debate will be opened in the Council and Parliament. The Commission will then decide whether it is necessary to initiate the infringement procedure. The system proposed in this report is an appropriate starting point for proper negotiations with the Commission and the Council of Ministers. It is a first step in the right direction and that is why the report has my support.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This report aims to show ways in which the EU can enforce its values against the Member States. According to this proposal, the European Union should be given oversight of the management of fundamental values. These values are human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, the rights of minorities. Equality and anti-discrimination are particularly highlighted and should be enforceable by majority decision after a future revision of the European Treaties. The aim is to explicitly extend the rights of the EU in order to be able to persuade Member States to give way by means of penalties or their threat of 'preventive and corrective'. In addition to the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity enshrined in this text, this text is based on the principle of 'necessity' on an equal footing. "Necessity" is a rubber term with which you can justify everything. I have rejected this report. The risk is very high that the EU will be able to enforce EU-compliant behaviour in this way. The ECJ already decides unilaterally pro-EU and pro-euro. By extending fundamental rights into more and more areas, such as labour markets, the EU is taking on further policy areas and the principle of subsidiarity is increasingly being damaged.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its external policies, the European Union emphasises democratic governance, fundamental human rights and the rule of law. In the context of migration policy in Europe, the social values promoted here are expected to be respected and accepted. There is a need to adopt a framework that allows the European Union to deal not only with violations of European Union law, but also in cases of threats to democracy, fundamental human rights and the rule of law.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 This ALDE initiative report aims to create an EU mechanism for the protection of human rights in the form of an interinstitutional agreement. Although the N-VA may agree to the principle of such thorough monitoring, it abstained. This mechanism does not form a basis in the Treaties and cannot be found to be the basis for technical interinstitutional cooperation agreements. We refer, among other things, to Article 7 VEU, in particular as regards the Council's exclusive competence in this area, which is not taken into account in the resolution. In short, the way in which this resolution is shaped by this mechanism seriously damages the sovereign decision-making power of the Member States and constitutes an unauthorised extension of power for Parliament.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. In view of the marked lyant trends of direct democracy, the EU Parliament now wants to break the resistance of some Member States to European rules on values. To this end, an "integrated mechanism for the systematic, objective and full monitoring of all EU Member States and their institutions" was adopted on Tuesday. Now, "independent experts" and "non-governmental organisations" are ruling on "fundamental rights violations" before the European Court of Justice comes to court. In doing so, the European Parliament is replacing the ordinary infringement procedure with a politicised parallel mechanism. The EU's political elite cannot move further away from the peoples of Europe. All Member States must follow the same values that are politically set by the left-wing majority of the European Parliament, with the support of the Christian Democrats of the CDU and CSU. The EU motto 'United in diversity' no longer applies. In addition, the European Parliament, with the votes of the Christian Democrats, called for the principle of subsidiarity to be abolished: Member States should no longer independently regulate matters of value affecting them. The large unity coalition of the Greens, Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats has agreed to this undemocratic surveillance culture. Not me.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is based on the values of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, and should serve as an example for EU institutions and bodies. There is no unified mechanism for systematic and impartial monitoring of Member States and institutions in the European Union, although the EU has a number of instruments in place to ensure respect for the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  Therefore, the European Union needs an interinstitutional agreement integrating existing instruments with a view to adopting measures to improve cooperation between the institutions of the European Union and its Member States under Article 7 of the UEU. I support the report with recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report with recommendations to the Commission on the introduction of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  I support the call for the Commission to submit a proposal by September next year for the conclusion of an EU pact for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which must apply equally to all the institutions and the Member States, while respecting the principle of proportionality, subsidiarity and necessity.  The Commission's task is to monitor and assess the proper enforcement of Union law and to respect the principles and objectives of the Treaties. In addition to preventing and eliminating violations of the Values of the Union, we also need sanctions.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report provides for the establishment of an EU mechanism for the supervision of Member States in relation to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Although the mechanism is primarily aimed at preventing violations, it is expressly provided that the means will be provided to impose corrective measures and sanctions against Member States.  A key weakness of the report is that the exercise of supervision over the action of the EU institutions is neither sufficiently rigorous nor clearly defined, especially in relation to the corresponding structure-process proposed for the Member States. There is also no provision for the possibility for the Court of Justice of the EU to intervene in decisions taken on the basis of Article 7 EES. Nor are there clear references to social rights as an integral part of fundamental rights, recognised by international and European conventions and which generally go beyond the approach of the EU institutions to fundamental rights.  Finally, the whole issue of the creation of an EU mechanism for the supervision of states is part of the overall effort to grant further powers to the EU and shrink the sovereignty of the Member States. In addition, the parameter of political purposes and selectivity is also raised. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is invalid and illegal because, on the one hand, Article 7 of the Treaty, on the other, it violates the principle of interinstitutional agreements. It is another attempt by professional manipulators to guide the national policies of the Member States. It is unacceptable and undemocratic to grant competence to a new authority to control the Member States, and it is a waste of resources, since international organisations already exist which control violations of fundamental rights.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order not to be self-contradictory because of my obligation as Vice-President, in cases where the parliamentary group votes differently from the Hungarian Members in roll call ballots, I will not take part directly in the vote. In other words, I will not press the voting button, but I will put my hand on the voting position previously decided jointly by the PP group. That's how I did it in this case.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because I consider it important and timely, given that the European Parliament and the Commission have been ind haven't been ind payable since its instable form by creating a legal basis for effective action against member states' governments that violate common European democratic standards. Unfortunately, the lack of this has appeared most eerily in the EU's inertia towards the leadership of my country, since the EU is still unable to prevent and sanction a policy that disrefies the repeated violations of the Orban government, European standards and the fundamental rights of its own citizens, without an adequate EU legal basis and mechanism and, in some case, political will. With regard to this report, I hope and urge that the legislation and interinstitutional agreement establishing the proposed new mechanism should also provide an effective EU response to the legal trickery of the Orban regime: to deal with a situation where the government of a Member State uses its significant parliamentary majority for legislative and even constitutional amendments aimed at blocking or subsequently legalising infringements. The report that has just been adopted can provide an incentive to continue further European legislative work on this.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The rule of law is at the core of European liberal democracy and is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union resulting from the tradition of constitutionalism common to all Member States. Any country wishing to accede to the Community must meet the highest standards in this field. Unfortunately, the European Union does not have sufficient tools today to ensure that countries that are already members of the Community comply with the same standards. This is a difficult situation to accept and completely incomprehensible to Europeans.  The proposal in the European Parliament's report for the EU institutions to conclude a European Pact for Democracy, the Rule of Law and Fundamental Rights is an extremely important contribution to the ongoing debate on the need for new instruments, given that the existing mechanisms are limited in scope, inadequate and ineffective.  The adoption of a framework enabling the EU to address not only infringements of specific EU legislation, but also the risk of serious threats to the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights would respond to the existing gaps in the protection of the values and principles on which the Community is based.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Europe has a long tradition of democracy, the rule of law and citizens' rights. Born with Athenian democracy, these concepts are reflected in Roman law, the Magna Carta of 1215, the Declaration of Human and Citizen Rights of 1789, the European Convention on Human Rights and, finally, the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Moreover, the European Union enshrines them among its essential principles and objectives, set out in the first articles of the Treaties, and in the criteria for EU membership. While attempts to include in the treaties a reference to Europe's Judeo-Christian roots have been unsuccessful, they nevertheless claim that the Union is seen as a community that shares the same values. In its external actions, the Union emphasizes human rights and democratic governance, and migrants arriving in Europe are asked to respect and adopt our common values.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While the EU has a several existing instruments to ensure the principles on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are upheld, substantial gaps remain and in practice certain instruments are often limited in scope, inadequate and ineffective, or they are unlikely to be used. In some cases, their uneven application is perceived by many as politically motivated, arbitrary and unfairly targeting certain countries. Further, there is no integrated mechanism for the systematic, impartial and complete monitoring of all EU Member States and Institutions. The report outlines the establishment of a comprehensive Union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the form of an interinstitutional agreement aligning and complementing existing mechanisms. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that it is of primary importance to reaffirm the common values on which the European project is based upon and to adopt a mechanism that will guarantee democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights are upheld in practice, not only on paper.

name: Eleni Theocharous (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission should set up a binding EU mechanism to monitor and report annually on cases of breaches of human rights, democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights in EU Member States; a mechanism that should include objective benchmarks and lay down a gradual approach to remedying breaches. Our core values are currently not protected by instruments that are strong enough to make sure that these values are upheld throughout the entire European Union. This new EU mechanism should ensure that all EU Member States respect the values enshrined in the EU Treaties and set clear, evidence-based and non-political criteria for assessing their records on democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights in a systematic way and on an equal footing

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must aim to be at the forefront of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights. The creation of a comprehensive Union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights will only be effective if the institutions work together and with civil society to develop and implement an awareness-raising campaign that will enable citizens of the Union to fully appropriate their rights and inform them of their rights in the field of legal redress and legal action.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report establishing an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights underlines that the Union is based on the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. This is a prerequisite for mutual recognition and trust within the Union, the document states. Although this EU mechanism is not legally based, but given that it can provide an adequate framework for the protection of the minority and linguistic rights of Hungarian communities living outside Hungary borders, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I am strongly against a report that seeks to change the very heart of the Treaty on European Union with all its might, damming the principle of subsidiarity. The rapporteur seeks to grossly inducing the competences of individual Member States of the Union and is not even afraid to be called out as inappropriate articles in the Treaty on European Union, notably Article 7, because the sanctioning and punishment mechanism has never been activated in practice. The report also invested its efforts in proposing and explaining in detail the mechanisms appropriate to punish 'disobedient children', i.e. Member States that are presumed to violate fundamental European values. Or at least what certain groups in the European Parliament hold to core values. The report irresistibly smells to me of the possibility of punishing Poland and Hungary, sovereign Member States that have legitimate and legally elected representatives of their nations in power, which I consider absolutely intolerable.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution with recommendations to the Commission on the introduction of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  The European Union has included democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights among its central principles and objectives in the first articles of the Treaties and in the criteria for EU membership. The Union has a wide range of instruments for enforcing its legislation and treaties on important issues.  Although the EU has several instruments at its disposal to ensure respect for the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, there are still significant gaps and, in practice, these instruments often have a limited scope, are inadequate and ineffective or are unlikely to be used.  In some cases, their unequal use is considered by many to be politically motivated, arbitrary and unfairly targeted at certain countries. There is no comprehensive mechanism for systematic, impartial and full monitoring of all Member States and their institutions.  The aim of the proposed interinstitutional agreement is to establish arrangements to facilitate the cooperation of the EU institutions and Member States under Article 7 TEU and to bring together, coordinate and complement existing mechanisms. In addition, the agreement will provide an integrated review mechanism that applies to all Member States and to the three main EU institutions.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report, because I welcome most of the proposals contained in the report and the annex. I believe that although the final report has been weakened in its content relative to the original, the recommendations it issues are moving forward on the path of greater European cohesion in the maintenance and supervision of the fundamental rights of the Union.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. This report aims to show ways in which the EU can enforce its values against the Member States. According to this proposal, the European Union should be given oversight of the management of fundamental values. These values are human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, the rights of minorities. The areas of equality and anti-discrimination will be highlighted and will be enforceable by majority decision after a future revision of the European Treaties. The aim is to explicitly extend the rights of the EU in order to be able to persuade Member States to give way by means of penalties or their threat of 'preventive and corrective'. In addition to the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity enshrined in the EU Treaties, this text is based on the principle of 'necessity' on an equal footing. "Necessity" is a rubber term with which you can justify everything. I have rejected this report. The risk is very high that the EU will be able to enforce EU-compliant behaviour in this way. The ECJ already decides unilaterally pro-EU and pro-euro. By extending fundamental rights into more and more areas, such as labour markets, the EU is taking on further policy areas and the principle of subsidiarity is increasingly being damaged.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU needs to stand up and defend fundamental rights inside the EU as well as outside. Everyone complains about Hungary and Poland, but the real issue is if this House and the EU are ready to fight for fundamental rights in Western Europe. Spain is a case in point. During the past years, newspapers like Egunkaria have been closed; the former President of Catalonia is facing a political trial and disqualification from public office for organising a symbolic referendum on independence; and yesterday a pro-independence town hall member from Vic was asked to spend eight years in jail due to a pro-Indy speech in his own town hall. The Constitutional Tribunal of Spain is led by an ex-member of the PP, and judiciary independence is non-existent. I hope that a mechanism will be established and the EU reacts to defend democracy everywhere in the Union.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the creation of an EU mechanism for 'democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'.  In reality, it is an EU mechanism to take political control of Member States that do not respect its interpretation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  For this reason, the rapporteur proposes that the Commission appoint a group of non-European judges and experts.  This text is a direct attack on the Member States and I strongly opposed it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against this resolution. I am a supporter of the rule of law and the libertarian legal tradition. Indeed, the European Union needs real dialogue, including on democracy. However, it should be based on the exchange of experience between the Union and the Member States and the building of mutual trust. Such an objective would be well served by a voluntary joint conference between the EU institutions and the governments of the Member States. On the other hand, the report presents us with a different mechanism, arbitrary and supervisory, which not only grows out of a lack of trust in the Member States, but also has no treaty basis. Secondly, it creates the risk of a biased interpretation of the concept of the rule of law by entrusting an assessment to a committee of experts without a democratic mandate. Thirdly, there is already a binding mechanism in primary law that makes it possible for Member States to assess compliance with the fundamental values on which the Union is founded. Pursuant to Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, the Council has competence in this regard.  The mechanism, which is intended to control the rule of law and itself has no treaty basis or due legitimacy and creates a parallel procedure alongside the existing Article 7 TEU, is not worthy of approval.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 While the European Union has a number of instruments at its disposal to ensure compliance with the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, there are substantial shortcomings and, in practice, these instruments are limited in scope, inadequate, inefficient or unlikely to be used. The illiberal rule of the Orban government is a disgrace to Hungary and a shame for Europe. The enlightened European community needs mechanisms that give us the means to do so against governments in Member States that do not respect the core values. Even Fidesz once loudly advocated this. They were in opposition at the time, but now they prefer the opposition of Europe.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report, because I welcome most of the proposals contained in the report and the annex. I believe that although the final report has been weakened in its content relative to the original, the recommendations it issues are moving forward on the path of greater European cohesion in the maintenance and supervision of the fundamental rights of the Union.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which portrays the threats of fundamental rights in the Union.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report with recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Europe has a long tradition in the area of democracy, the rule of law and citizens’ rights. The European Union has a wide range of instruments for the enforcement of its laws and Treaties when it comes to material issues. While the EU has several existing instruments at its disposal to ensure the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are upheld, substantial gaps remain, and in practice such instruments are often limited in scope, inadequate and ineffective, or they are unlikely to be used. In some cases, their uneven application is perceived by many as politically motivated, arbitrary and unfairly targeting certain countries. There is no integrated mechanism for the systematic, impartial and complete monitoring of all EU Member States and institutions. Therefore, I believe, it is imperative to adopt a framework that enables the EU to address not only infringements to specific EU laws, but also (risk of) serious threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The lack of guarantees of compliance with fundamental rights, as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, signed by all Member States, is a reality in all Member States. In the Spanish State, the Government repeatedly fails to comply with issues such as freedom of expression and protest, in the face of the passivity of the European institutions. I therefore support any mechanism that is in favour of the performance of these rights and allows the action of the Member States to be monitored, so I voted in favour. However, I understand that the proposed mechanism is clearly insufficient, and although I support the preparation of parliamentary reports on this and that the role of the Ombudsman is enhanced, I cannot believe that this will actually solve the current profound problem. The Union cannot today seek to wash its face and pose as a space where fundamental rights are guaranteed, so this mechanism will play an exclusively cosmetic role, unless it is accompanied by a political will for democratisation which does not exist today among the Community authorities.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report, adopted by a large majority by the European Parliament, proposes the establishment of a comprehensive mechanism to ensure respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights at EU level, in the form of an inter-institutional agreement. This mechanism aims to monitor the compliance of the Union's democratic objectives by the Member States. It provides for elements of prevention and punishment against violations of fundamental rights, an annual European public report including country-specific recommendations, and an annual inter-parliamentary debate on the basis of that report. This report - if implemented - could mark a step forward in trying to ensure that EU Member States respect human rights and the rule of law, especially in light of the worrying developments in countries such as Hungary and Poland, which the FN has allowed itself to take as an example. I have little illusions about developments as the Council is more than ever closed to any internal control of Member States' policies in this area, but I have nevertheless chosen to support the position of the European Parliament.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is another unacceptable assault on the sovereignty of states. We do not recognise the European Union's legitimacy to lecture democracy on anyone. The concept of EU democracy is that of sanctions, which the report also defends and deepens, is blackmail and pressure. In the case of Portugal, with our legislation, this would be unacceptable negative pressure, levelling the standards of social and labour rights. This is truly the EU's objective, creating a minimum rights standard that excludes other fundamental rights such as the right to health, education or decent work.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report provides for a system of financial sanctions against Member States that violate the criteria of the EU Pact. This way is not an adequate or effective means of dealing with the nation states and certainly not compatible with the democratic understanding of our society. Rather, it aims to nip any criticism of EU institutions in the bud. I have therefore rejected the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing recommendations to the Commission on the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The report stresses that the EU has at its disposal a multiplicity of instruments for the application of its laws and treaties when it comes to material issues (such as the adjustment of Member States' budgets or the application of specific public health programmes), but has no influence on ensuring respect for democratic values and the rule of law that should be common to all Member States. Although the EU has several instruments to move in this direction and to try to monitor compliance with common principles, these are small, limited in scope and inadequate. The report considers it essential for the EU to have a regulatory framework enabling it to address and condemn, including through the application of sanctions, violations of fundamental rights and European principles (ex Articles 2, 3 and 7 TEU) and therefore calls on the Commission to submit a proposal for the creation of such a control mechanism by September 2017.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation of fundamental rights and democracy is under threat across Europe, with far-right populist movements gaining ground, including in the UK, and so the EU must mobilise to counter potential violations. I welcome Parliament’s call for the establishment of a European mechanism for fundamental rights and democracy, in order to ensure that these are upheld across the Union. Just as the European Semester aims to uphold common standards of economic policy, this mechanism must involve European institutions, national governments, and parliaments working to ensure that civil rights in the EU are upheld.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I agree that the Commission has to present by June 2017 a new draft agreement for the accession of the Union to the ECHR. I support the recommendation for Treaty changes. The Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, enshrined in its core principles and objectives. These are all values that, as a liberal, I defend and support. I also agree with the fact that Union citizens and residents are not always sufficiently aware of all their rights as Europeans, and this resolution aims to make those also more transparent and clear.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the Report by Mrs in ́t Veld. The report dealt with the establishment of a special EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. At the same time, the rapporteur has made concrete recommendations to the European Commission on what articles of the Treaties will need to be changed in order to establish the mechanism. In its view, the mechanism is intended to ensure that Member States that violate common European values are punished. In this case, however, I believe that the European Parliament does not in any way have the power to address such calls at all. At the same time, most of this report is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity, and since I do not agree with the proposals that thus affect the competences of the Member States, I also voted against this report as a whole.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Veld report for agreeing with the considerations concerning the implementation of the European values enshrined in the Treaties. In particular, I would like to call for the establishment of a democratic evaluation mechanism. This mechanism aims to monitor Member States' respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, just as candidate countries are assessed to join the EU.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report recommending to the Commission on the introduction of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. For a long time, I have been in favour of establishing an effective monitoring mechanism for the functioning of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the Member States. I believe that a politically independent mechanism is one of the key measures for the rule of law in the European Union, so as not to be abused again, especially in transitional, post-socialist countries. However, care must be taken not to be exploited for political purposes, as has been the case in the past in the case of Hungary and elsewhere. If we fail to ensure the impartiality of the application of this mechanism, the citizens of the European Union will reject such intervention by the European Union, and Euroscepticism will continue to be on the up.  Ensuring the rule of law and effective independent justice systems plays a key role in creating a positive political environment that can restore confidence in the institutions, as well as an investment-friendly environment and ensure greater regulatory predictability and sustainable growth.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have just come from the College, where we agreed our Work Programme for 2017, and I am pleased to be here to present it to you straightaway this afternoon. The Work Programme is the Commission’s commitment to you, and to Europeans, about what we will do in the coming year. There are no surprises in what we announce today. The Work Programme makes concrete the policy priorities that President Juncker set out in his State of the Union speech and which we confirmed in the letter of intent. This is a focused agenda centred on the big things, a principle this Commission has applied since the start of the mandate. It reflects our commitment to the ten priorities on the basis of which you appointed us. Like you, we have listened closely to people’s concerns. The challenges for our Union today are well known, and citizens feel them in their daily lives: jobs; inequality; the still nascent economic recovery that has yet to deliver for all; migration flows which have tested our external borders – and, I may add, our internal cohesion; the terrorist threat; ongoing instability in our neighbouring countries. Europe cannot be the answer to all the problems, but Europe certainly needs to be part of the solution to the biggest and most pressing issues. Together, we have a shared responsibility to deliver where it matters most and where only working together can make a real difference. To protect Europeans’ interests and quality of life, as well as the security, fairness and well—being of our societies; to empower citizens and give them a perspective for a sustainable future for themselves and their families and to defend people’s rights – we already had a debate about that this morning. The 21 new key initiatives we propose today are grounded on the ten priorities and the strategies we have presented to implement them. We commit to delivering on these proposals by the end of 2017. Our agenda has been enriched by our dialogue with this House, by the discussions we have had here in plenary and your resolution of July, as well as a day and a half of intensive and constructive exchanges between the College and the Conference of Committee Chairs, which I think was excellent. It is also in line with the priorities identified by 27 Heads of State or Government in Bratislava. This broad degree of consensus about what we should be doing is very welcome indeed, but announcements and proposals are not what matter. Results do. We are therefore committed to working intensively and constructively with you and with the Member States in the Council to reach timely and ambitious agreements on the many proposals that we have already presented. We have listed the most important proposals, as we see them, in the Work Programme. The new interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking includes a commitment by the three institutions to agree a joint declaration, to be signed by the three Presidents, on priorities for the coming year. We look forward to working with you to jointly agree to move ahead quickly on the proposals that can make the most difference on the ground. We have already seen, with the European Border and Coast Guard and with European Fund for Strategic Investments, what we can achieve when we all put our full efforts into negotiations. Agreeing proposals is just the start of the story. In the coming year, the Commission will put a particular emphasis on implementation and enforcement work, making sure that EU rules are properly applied and enforced across all policy areas, including the internal market and the environment. We will also continue our efforts to improve existing legislation and make it more fit for purpose, more proportionate, and better able to deliver on the policy goals it is supposed to achieve. In the next year we will integrate regulatory fitness in our key initiatives, as well as bring forward a further 18 refit proposals to improve existing law, taking into account the input we have had from stakeholders and Member States in the REFIT Platform. We have also published a short brochure which shows how REFIT is an integral part of delivering on our ten priorities. We are also proposing to withdraw some 19 pending proposals, which are outdated or are no longer needed for technical reasons, and to repeal 16 pieces of obsolete existing legislation. Let me end by recalling what I said at the start. The focus of this Commission is squarely on delivery, but we cannot do it alone. This is a joint responsibility, a responsibility to ensure that our Union makes a real impact and protects, empowers and defends Europeans. This Commission looks forward to working with you in the next weeks and months to make that a reality through the results we deliver together. The last couple of years have been really encouraging for our mutual cooperation in many areas that are very important today.

name: József Szájer
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, in thanking Vice-President Timmermans for his presentation of the Commission Work Programme 2017, I would like to follow from where he left off by saying that the Commission should not, and does not need to do it alone, because in Parliament this year there was an exemplary procedure for preparation of the Commission Work Programme 2017. Basically the Groups tabled in Parliament, in time to influence the Commission’s decisions this October, the joint resolution on the principles of the Work Programme 2017.  I think also there are some new elements in this process because the new modified or modernised interinstitutional agreement is also something which is aimed at making the cooperation between the three institutions much better. I would like to underline that we would agree with the content which you presented, Mr Timmermans, and which was based very much on what we have been bringing together here in Parliament among the different political Groups. I also agree, and my Group agrees too, with the method and the better law-making method, but in general, as well, that the Union should be big on big things and small on small things. The main important thing is that the single market is a great achievement and source of satisfaction but it still needs to be expanded and the digital dimension is where we should go the most. Economic recovery, as you have mentioned, is still fragile. The strategic investment plan has already shown results and should be managed in the future in a more effective way. Conditions to modernise the labour market and facilitate mobility. And here is the issue of migration where we are still here, discussing what to do about the distribution of migrants inside and how to stop this crisis and how to create the necessary conditions.  Safeguarding European values is a daily task; it should be embedded in every act we do and stability and revitalisation are the two keywords which we consider most important and we support the Commission in achieving these goals.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, European citizens are requesting a European Union able to protect them, to empower them, and this is the title of the Commission’s Work Programme. We believe that the Commission Work Programme this year cannot be defined as business as usual. Europe needs a new road map, and the Commission Work Programme is just a first step in this direction. We can recognise many of the concerns of the European Parliament strategic resolution adopted on 6 July, but let me underline the concerns which are not clear and not presented strongly enough in the Commission adopted document. First of all on the social pillar. It is not enough to have a social pillar updating social standards. We need to have the means to really deliver on these social standards. Secondly, when it comes to growth, investment and jobs, it is not enough to speak about the European Fund for Strategic Investment and the Youth Guarantee.
