We need to have a much more comprehensive investment strategy led by Europe 2020 and sustainable development goals, and this should be translated into industrial and trade policy to be updated in Europe. This should be translated into a pro-growth economic policy; it must be translated into a Community budget with higher ceilings; and it should be translated into a proper fiscal capacity ensuring convergence inside the Eurozone. So these points must be more clearly committed by the Commission before Parliament. Then of course, we believe that if we have strong internal cohesion with European citizens, it will be easier to deal with external challenges – hosting refugees, managing migration and addressing security concerns. We believe we do need these new tools for defence and security, but to have a proper road map in Rome, we need to go beyond the one which was sketched out in Bratislava. We need to put working and living conditions at the heart of a good road map for the European Union.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, this annual debate gives us the time to identify the issues we face, decide what actions we need to take and which of those actions we should take together. We need to focus on what is needed, not just on what is urgent, and there are many issues. On the borders of Europe we see war and violence, precarious relationships with our neighbours, especially Russia. Many European countries have witnessed the horror of terrorism and many people are still facing real economic hardships. Our leaders are changing too. We will soon have a new US President and then elections across much of Europe, so we will need new relationships. And then there is the issue of Brexit. A new relationship is needed between Britain and the EU. I hope it will be, I wish it to be, a cooperative one. There is a lot of work to be done. On behalf of the Conservative Reformists there are areas where we do not agree with other colleagues in this Chamber. We do not support calls for increases to the EU budget, for more EU taxes, for an EU army or for more centralisation of decisions. But there are areas where we agree we need to work together – on fighting terror, on working with NATO on security and defence, on tackling the causes of the refugee crisis, on confronting climate change and reducing our carbon footprint, on re-energising trade relations in the single market. In Europe we have spent 40 years tearing down barriers to trade. But now we face a real risk of a new era of protectionism. We must re-grab the conversation with the ordinary consumer on the benefits of trade and the single market for them, and not just focus on that border-crossing consumer elite. To the Commission I would say, please respect and reconsider where we disagree and work together where we agree. Recognise now that people do want greater control over the decisions that affect them, and some of our decisions are better left to national governments too.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report We are discussing the Commission's work programme here and you have had it in your e-mail inbox since 3.08 p.m.  I think we have to praise that. We now know what we are debating here. Thank you very much to the Commission for that.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I was much more privileged than that because I received it 13 minutes before the start of the debate, so I had much more time than you did to prepare for this debate.  I would like to start by noting that the Council, except for the honourable gentleman here, seems to be absent for the debate, although you refer specifically to the Bratislava declaration in the document on the priorities, so I think it would have been proper for the Council to be present in greater numbers. I always find this kind of debate very difficult because we talk about matters or issues that we all find very important, but for some reason I get the feeling that most citizens do not really care that much. I commend the European Commission for trying to cut red tape, focus on the essential, etc., but I wonder if that is really what citizens are lying awake over. Repealing a law for energy labels for vacuum cleaners, fine, but is that really what is keeping people awake at night? I think that people are terribly concerned about the way that the European Union is working and one of the things, I think, that should be at the top of the list is transparency and accountability. You mention it in the document and yet I know that in practice, when we ask for documents, when we want to get information – I am not talking about you personally, but within the Commission, the Council, and yes, the European Parliament too – there is still a culture of confidentiality and secrecy. If we really want to regain the trust of citizens, that is something that we should address and should, I think, really put at the top of our list. Secondly, better law-making, in my view, is not only about cutting red tape and repealing legislation that is considered unnecessary. It also means passing legislation that will stand up in court. Now we have seen safe harbours and data retention scrapped, and as regards PNR and Canada we do not know. We see that the Council is now making all kinds of agreements with Turkey and other countries, and these seem to have no basis whatsoever in the Treaties. We do not know who anyone is accountable to; we do not know who is exercising oversight. That is not better law-making: it is terrible law-making. It is neither democratic nor transparent nor accountable. So if we really want to regain trust, those are the issues that we should be focusing on, and that includes ourselves: we can be critical of ourselves rather about subject headings.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: gue/NGL Group. – (20) Mr President, the european institutions' response to the crisis in and of the European Union continues to be immersed in contradictions, with a common point being a deepening of divergence with the interests and aspirations of peoples and states. Rehearsing forward escapes, which deepen the neoliberal, federalist and militaristic aspects of the European Union, aiming to further increase the concentration of economic and political power within it. Your response highlights two undeniable realities, that the European Union is not reformable and the urgent need to break with our policies.  Ensure the reversibility of the treaties and the repeal of the Budgetary Treaty and the Treaty of Lisbon, establish a programme to support Member States wishing to negotiate exit from the euro, ending the submission and corset of the single currency, renegotiating largely illegitimate sovereign debts, repeal the banking union, regain public control of banking and sovereign instruments of regulation of the economy, recover for the public sector strategic sectors of the economy, defend and promote national production and the productive sectors, value labor and workers, defend a policy of fiscal justice that relieves the burden on the incomes of workers and the people, breaking with the scandalous favorof large capital, defending the democratic regime within the framework of the sovereignty of states.  Only a few proposals that the struggle of the peoples will achieve, enabling the construction of another Europe, of cooperation, of peace, of solidarity between sovereign and equal countries in rights.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for giving an overview of the Commission Work Programme for next year. Indeed, I also only received it 30 minutes before 3pm so I also had the privilege of a long reading time of more or less half an hour now.  Looking at what is on the table and what First Vice-President Timmermans was explaining to us in plenary, as to how we are going about things, I think we should just scrap this self-congratulatory tone. We are in a serious situation and still there are not so many people who feel involved and feel that the European Union is there on their behalf. I think that is still our biggest concern, for us all. We want a European Union that works for our citizens, for our consumers, and I think a lot of things need to be improved there. That is also why I get a bit tired when people say we have to focus on the big things: Europe should be big on the big things and small on the small things. Well let’s just conclude today that we all agree on that. The political discussion is what you call big, and what I call big, or what someone else calls small, which I call big. That is a political discussion. Let’s not hide as if a Commission work programme is a technical analysis. This is about priorities and political decisions, on where the European Union is focusing, and there are good things. If I look at what the Commission wants to do on the social pillar side, I think that looks good, but, how exactly is that going to look? Here I would like to subscribe to what my colleague from the S&D Group was saying. On the other and, if I look at the trade part, it is just business as usual, it is just continuing: ‘we are doing a great job so we continue’. Well sorry, but maybe some people have noticed that there is a huge debate on which direction the EU is going with its trade deals. We are not discussing trade deals more. CETA stands for Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement. It is more than just a trade deal. That is why you are now having discussions with national parliaments. That is why there is now such a huge discussion, and the Commission is saying, we will just continue with it because it is working fine, which is just turning a blind eye to what is going on outside. I think that should be mentioned far more in the work programme. The last point is on REFIT and this is a question to the Commissioner. I know there will be some discussions also on ecodesign and I know that you are a very good person who can convince people, so can you convince people also within your Commission how important it is to reduce our energy use? That is a big thing. With the vacuum cleaners we have saved energy equivalent to four coal-fired power plants. That is good for the environment, that is good for our economy, and it is good for our self-reliance on energy. That is what the Ecodesign Directive is about and I am sure that you can convey that message, rather than what a lot of tabloids are doing in portraying this as a regulatory burden, because I as a consumer do not mind what the rules are, but if in the end if I buy appliances that are much more energy efficient that is a good thing for us citizens.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after the attacks in Paris and Brussels, after Brexit, after what is happening on a daily basis in southern Europe, following the 'no' vote a few days ago at CETA, it is no longer possible to look at the action of the European institutions as before. The signal we received yesterday is not only a technical signal, limited to a trade agreement, it is above all a political signal and no one more than this Parliament should grasp its value among the European institutions. There is a desire for radical change in the European institutions, which more and more citizens want.  Whatever the final configuration of the 2017 working program, therefore, certain aspects cannot be disregarded. First of all, mass emigration: in recent weeks Italian ships have rescued twenty thousand people and the attack in Mosul will aggravate the emergency. The numbers leave no room for indecision, and even less can be shown indecision when internal security is at stake, because security is the first right and the first need that our citizens are asking us to protect.  Brexit teaches us that the gap between politics and institutions is not overcome either by proclamations or threats, by citizens assessing something else. Eight years of economic crisis are nailing the European institutions to their failure to rebuild the common European home on a stronger basis. Mr Vice-President, I hope that your commitment to an interinstitutional consensus will be successful, I really do say so, but I would like you to know that in that dialogue whole groups of Members were not able to participate fully because of the lack of respect for internal democracy on the part of the strongest groups and those who took responsibility for excluding them at the time know that the voice of the citizens , of all citizens, will always know how to be heard.

name: Marcus Pretzell
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In 2016, it was said that now is not the time for business as usual. The European Commission's response was: more European Union, more centralisation.  They have not found any answers to the migration crisis. They have not found any answers that would have really secured the external borders. You have not found any answers to the terror – which extends as far as Brussels – if you perhaps refrain from securing the entrances of the European Parliament now. They have not found an answer that would have satisfied the economy, especially the medium-sized ones in Europe. No. It continues to groan under ever-increasing bureaucracy. You have not found an answer to Brexit, except that you have insulted the British – from Brussels and Strasbourg. Nor have you found any answers to the justified concerns of the European people against CETA. Wallonia said no. What does the European Commission think about this? Ultimates, extortion and bribery. What is Wallonia's approval worth to you? What are you going to offer them in order to ultimately deceive millions of people in Europe? When Mr Timmermans says that the last few years have encouraged him, Europe's citizens should be afraid of it.  It's not the time for business as usual , even in 2017. But change doesn't go with people as usual. That is why Europe needs new ideas, needs new minds. In Germany, we will start with this in 2017. And this is just the beginning!

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The European Commission has a decisive role to play in solving two historically important tasks. One is to keep our continent as Europe. Because Europe is not just a geographical name: it means us, the people who live here, our past, our history, our identity. We may and may not have to respect the culture and religion of people on other continents, but we cannot accept the migration of millions of people who want to aggressively enforce their own customs and religious standards.  The other task after Brexit is to find a new form of cooperation between European countries, because it is quite clear that there is no alternative to this cooperation, but the process of moving more and more rapidly after Lisbon towards the creation of a centralised state must have an alternative, and if this is not recognised, it will lead to the disintegration of Europe.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to welcome the adoption of the 2017 work programme by the Commission and say that the title of this programme is particularly well chosen to reflect the challenges we are currently facing. In the field of external relations, European citizens must be reassured, their expectations must be met with coherent actions in the face of the instability and conflicts that are multiplying in our neighbourhood, in the East or in the South. More than ever, the defence and promotion of freedom, support for our allies and the prevention of atrocities must be at the heart of our actions in our neighbourhood.  At the same time, the enlargement process must continue. This process gives hope to the countries concerned and deters the desires of the powers which, like Russia in the Balkans or in Moldova, are working to destabilize our immediate neighbourhood.  Moreover, in the coming months, the implementation of the European External Investment Plan will be crucial. By recognising the central role of the private sector in job creation, economic growth and wider societal transformations, this plan is a very concrete embodiment of a Europe that empowers us. It also represents a hope of finally having a single and coherent framework to stimulate investment in Africa and our neighbourhood, as well as to combat war, poverty, lack of infrastructure and poor governance, which fundamentally threaten the security of our citizens.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Mr President, 2017 is going to be another year, but it shouldn't be any year. And it should not be any year because it is right in the middle of the political agenda and the legitimacy of the Commission and Parliament and therefore begins to be the fundamental element of our legacy. The legacy that should be positively recognized by citizens can only be based on a few points, such as providing security, which is a growing concern of citizens, and above all providing protection without protectionism. Protection without protectionism means working for growth, job creation and opportunities for young people. It seemed to me to read that, in view of next year's White Paper in Rome, the emphasis is placed on stability when it comes to reviewing the Stability and Growth Pact. I think where you have to put the emphasis is on growth, not so much on stability.  Secondly, it is also possible for citizens to improve their real life, their social life, their daily lives. And that implies concrete measures when it comes to social union. Mr Timmermans has previously made a certain set of concepts which I think is very appropriate, saying that 'in the face of emigration we have had to secure our borders and respond to internal cohesion'. But internal cohesion is above all also the cohesion of convergence.  If European citizens do not perceive that the European Union gives everyone opportunities to live without great inequality, the Union will lose legitimacy and therefore weaken its political project.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The pre-talker spoke of legitimacy. However, the European Parliament has a different legitimacy from the European Commission, because the European Parliament comes from elections, the Commission does not go through this procedure, and I think it should listen to the citizens all the more and its representatives speak with a little more modesty. I have a sense of a certain déjà vu, because I hear every move from the next Presidents of the European Commission further declarations on the fight against bureaucracy or with euro-bureaucracy. Part of this bureaucracy is the European Commission, maybe better? Nevertheless, it is a bit of a shadow fight. We are waiting for specifics on this issue, not for slogans and slogans. Today, for citizens who are increasingly critical of the European Union (unfortunately, yes, this can be said), these slogans are not enough.  Finally, really vacuum cleaners are not something that can kidnap the citizens of the European Union. As far as transparition is, I ask you, at the next meeting with the Representatives of the Council, to ask the Commission why the Council is not answering our questions, mePs' questions, about the Council budget. This has been happening for 7 years.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You're a historian, we know that, and here, too, you've hinted at certain historical perspectives, especially backwards. But let me also say something that Mr Juncker said in the spring of 2006, when he received the Charles Prize, that a social Europe would be achieved in 10 years, or that this integration would be over. Do you think Mr Juncker was wrong, or is this over?

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you for this question to Mr Szanyi, with whom we often have different views, but nevertheless I always listen attentively to what he says, because it is worth listening to. I think it is worth supporting President Juncker on this, but it is necessary to ask what this might mean in practice? There is a challenge especially for young people in Europe, including in my country, whose first job is to go to an unemployment office. But the question is, can the European Commission solve this problem in real terms? Finally, I remember the other words of Mr Juncker, who joked that when problems start, you have to lie. I think the opposite: problems begin, the truth must be told.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, Vice-President of the Commission. A few suggestions, maybe more Christmas.  First. This is overcoming the European Union's identity crisis. It is no longer possible to stand at a crossroads between the federalist European Union and the national States of the European Union. And self-determination must be swift and clear: it is necessary to forget any federalist challenges, to abandon the ideology of globalism and to push the bulldozer into decisions of dubious value for the citizens of European countries.  Second. Change attitudes towards migration policy. Abandon quotas by redistributing the countries of the European Union to the refugees. Strengthening the European Union's external borders by sending a clear message that economic migrants from third countries will be closed. And actually close them.  And third. Democracy is not the dictatorship of the Brussels institutions for the members of the Community, under the guise of supposedly worrying about its fate. Restoring trust in institutions, restoring trust in commissioners and making public benefit decisions would be the best that the European Commission could start doing even without waiting for 2017.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this European Union, which presents us with a vast programme, as General de Gaulle would have called it when the cartel died in cretins'. I think that we are talking about a rapid solution to the problem of immigration, about tackling the problem of relocation, when all the news throughout Europe through euronews, gives us pictures of what is happening even on the Italian coasts, where 4 000 of them landed yesterday and 500 to 700 to 1 000 disembark every day and Europe is incapable of seriously tackling it. So this is a completely illusory program starting with immigration. Moreover, if we move on to the international issue, let us see what the Commission intends to do with regard to Africa, we do not see any serious, incisive measures, for example for the implementation of the Cotonou Agreements, which require African countries exporting immigrants to take back their economic immigrants when they are not eligible. But that is not because Europe counts for nothing.  Mosul is being shot, Aleppo is being shot, there are important interests there in a strategic area, including economic and also military interests for the Member States of the European Union, but where is Europe? Mrs Mogherini is always on the road, she always lets us know that she has excellent relations, she calls all these peoples friends, but then when she speaks, and if she speaks, you do not see the results, you do not even hear the sound of her voice. Then stop this illegal immigration! Let us finally give a reality to the defence of the external borders! We don't want to be invading!

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, in the history of our continent, rarely have circumstances demanded so much from the European Union. Indeed, the greatest danger that threatens us is that of immobility, when every day seems to bring a new crisis and distrust is deeper and deeper. For this to happen, the work programme must be a combat programme, a fight for the re-industrialisation of our continent, the recovery of the economy and the fight against unemployment that undermines our societies.  I am pleased to see that the Commission is making the space sector one of its industrial priorities. The use of spatial data and the independence of our access to space are essential for our industrial fabric. I also put all my hopes in a European defence or in an ambitious digital plan. The fight must also be fought for the convergence of our economies and the protection of the euro area. In this area, we must make up for the chronic lack of investment, despite the Juncker plan on our continent, by strengthening the banking union and that of the capital markets.  I also advocate for more fiscal and social justice. The Commission's proposals to combat tax evasion and tax havens are in line with this.  Finally, I say that we must lead the fight to promote high standards of environmental and health protection. On this point, I end with regret because these are the most precious assets of our fellow citizens and, unfortunately, there is a glaring lack of positive health programme by the Commission, while so much remains to be done in the fight against cancer and antimicrobial resistance or to make Europe an innovative health champion. All of this contributes to growth.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I believe you have come to give us the European Commission's REFIT programme. That is part of your mandate, but it is clearly not what will convince our fellow citizens that the Commission is concerned about what concerns them or what concerns them. I will leave aside how you will manage the Brexit negotiation once Article 50 has been put on the table by Theresa May, but for this year 2017, no one can, of course, ignore the stakes of this negotiation. I would like to emphasize three priorities. The first is the logical continuation of the Paris conference and the need to over-de-establish an investment strategy for the ecological transition. For the year 2017, you have several tools in your hands that will allow you to act in accordance with this objective. First of all, of course, I am thinking of the EFSI investment plan renewal programme. This time you need to listen to the European Parliament to make it a tool for the ecological transition. It is a strategy that must also be found in the growth and stability pact. Second priority: the completion of economic and monetary union, of course; I won't surprise you. But the white paper for which the European Commission was blamed in the report of the five presidents has become a report on the future of the European Union. Don't forget the priority of economic and monetary union. Last but not, trade policy, as you can see... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, I would like to thank mr Timmermans for his work on this The Commission's work programme has been sent to Members at such short notice that none of us have been able to read the programme we are now debating. My question to you is: are you prepared, on behalf of the Commission, to apologise to Parliament for this contempt for Parliament? I believe that this would be very important for you to do so, because that is a disregard for Parliament if we do not get the documents we are to debate – documents as important as the Commission's programme – in good time. This kind of contempt is, in some respects, indicative of a democratic deficit that we have in many places in the European Union. Many countries, many people in Europe, are increasingly feeling that they are being decided over their heads without being able to have a say – and I am speaking for a country that does not want to have deposit insurance, that does not want to have a communitarised unemployment insurance, that does not want EU taxes, that does not want an EU army. But you and your Commission are working hard to achieve just that, and that is the contempt expressed by this Commission in the political sphere as well.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are discussing the Commission's 2017 Work Programme. Even though it has already been noted, it is a good thing that this programme consists of 50 pages: 20 pages of programming, 30 pages of annexes, and it was left to us exactly 10 minutes before the debate began. So we are talking about something that we do not know what is in it. Apart from that, the Commission's work programme should be at the heart of all the debates. It's about their government program. In principle, this space should be full, and where do we stand? We have a plenary - there are about 50 or 60 Members present, but 72 interpreters are translating here. 72 interpreters for about 50 or 60 Members!  You wonder why you lose people. You wonder why you are reaching people less and less: because ghost debates are being held here, with the same phrases, with the same phrases that are empty. And they are proven to be empty, because you do not know what you are talking about.  I'm the only one who doesn't have the program like everyone else here. I notice that I cannot talk about something that I do not have. I believe that if you want to see how you want to win people back, "get out of the way."

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This year has been and is a year of global challenges, including in the area of development policy, and it is important to be that it will be the same in 2017. The migration and refugee crisis is a complex phenomenon of increasing scale for the Union as well. There are problems with the poor humanitarian situation in refugee camps or the policy of readmission and reintegration of migrants and refugees in the countries of origin. It is therefore necessary to act at source, making development cooperation more effective and coordinated and complementary to other Union external action instruments.  September 2016 marks the first anniversary of the adoption of the 2030 Agenda, in which the SHAPING OF THE EU has played an important role through public consultation, negotiations and numerous studies. It is important that the Union further strengthens its efforts to implement and monitor this global commitment, which aims to eradicate poverty and guarantee sustainable development. 2017 also brings us closer to reviewing and concluding a new partnership with ACP countries after 2020. It is important that the negotiations highlight the crucial importance of political dialogue, which has hitherto been under-exploited and ineffective, and focus on improving the situation of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law in partner countries by involving and building the capacity of civil society. For current and future challenges, political borders do not matter, they are trans- and transnational in nature. The Union should therefore carefully build on the Community method, but on the other hand continue to cooperate with external partners.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work. Many people in the European Union are afraid of uncontrolled social development – be it globalization, digitalization, their social security, how banks handle money and how corporations determine their lives. That is why the Central Task of the European Union is also to restore security and creative power for these people for their future, because otherwise right-wing populists can play with the fears and bring forward developments that we all do not want. That is why I believe that it is right to focus on the key moments of the work. But they must focus on the social security of the people of the European Union, so that right-wing populists have no chance. Indeed, Europe is not the problem. The emerging nationalism in the Member States is the problem that we must tackle.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR).
text: – Mr President, some two and a half years ago I had a very pleasant surprise when the Commissioner/Vice-President wanted to sit with me and discuss what the Commission Work Programme should be at that time. I have many members from my committee here, where I have led on the subsidiarity and proportionality, better law—making brief. I have been very prescriptive in my approach throughout that time but I find, based upon my national position as a British MEP, that I cannot be so prescriptive now. Commissioner, you may recall that in the conversation we had at that time it was clear that the Europe and national state relationship was broken and that is what did it for us in the United Kingdom now. That is what must absolutely be fixed. I keep being told by colleagues that you Britishers cannot have à la carte Europe. Well, actually, colleagues, you have all got à la carte Europe. When Europe does something good, your national governments claim it for themselves. When Europe does something which is misreported, your national governments blame it on Europe, and unless you bridge that gap by making your parliaments directly a part of the decision—making process here in the European Union, I am afraid that bridge is going to get wider and wider and eventually, one by one, we will all fall in ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: Mr Timmermans is familiar with the cry 'without transport everything is at a standstill'. I thank him for the piece I was able to scan quickly. Much attention is rightly paid to the decarbonisation of the transport sector. We know mrs Bulc's proposals. They are now included in the work programme. We in the European Parliament will work with this.  Nevertheless, I miss a number of parts, although I understand, of course, that not everything can be in this letter. For the report of this meeting, I would therefore like to draw attention to the general economic significance of the transport sector, the social issues – after all, there is much to be done about social dumping in the transport sector – and border security. Schengen is more transport-free. The Calais problem, if all right, will be resolved with the French Government this month. But the transport sector also faces a lot of innovation, and in particular competition with Americans in self-driving cars and interconnected cars.  These are all the issues that need to be addressed. Finally, IMO and IKO. But we will continue to discuss this with the Trade Commissioner.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that in the face of the serious crisis that the Union is going through, the trauma of Brexit, the selfishness of European governments who think only of their own national debates and electoral deadlines, of those who want the benefits of staying in the EU, but who refuse to share responsibility for it, it seems to me that the Commission's work programme still has the flavour of business as usual. , too timid on the social dimension of the Union, to which the Commission also committed itself at the beginning of its term of office, but words have not yet been followed by concrete proposals to give citizens the answers they expect. On asylum and immigration, the securitarian approach that has already failed is confirmed and we are moving towards a progressive outsourcing of our borders, creating a worrying filter at the entrance. Where is the solidarity and common responses that this Parliament has repeatedly called for in order to better distribute responsibilities between Member States? It seems to me that we are chosen to support the selfishness of some of them. That is not how we are going to save the Union from disintegration. Some progress has been made on the fight against tax avoidance and evasion, but we still have to insist on a simple principle: that taxes are paid where profits are made.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work he has done. The Commission is having a hard time: the room for manoeuvre is narrow, the European states are holding back enormously – we know this in the European Parliament. All the more reason why we need the Commission to lead the way, and the magic word for this is social, with five call signs. People want security, social security. In other words, whatever we call it, you are fattening up the European social pillar as best you can. Do something! And then there is the one-person company on the REFIT list. Why? Letterbox companies must finally be put in a halt. We see this in all the Panama Papers, LuxLeaks, BahamasLeaks, etc. Put forward a proposal to relocate company headquarters so that we can finally solve this letterbox problem. The implementation and enforcement of EU law is important, but far from enough. Finally, please do not forget the whistleblowers.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the Commission for its efforts to focus its work on priorities that respond clearly to the needs of citizens. I would like to mention a few of them. Firstly, the work we are doing in Parliament with the three reports on the future of the Union, which is also aimed at opening the dialogue with the Commission on the day-to-day work of the five presidents' report. Secondly, I would like to mention another joint work that we should be doing in the next period, that of the transparency register and the implementation of the interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking and, lastly, the need to give strong answers to issues such as migration, defence, security, youth unemployment and the revival of investment on European territory.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – The Juncker Commission came up with the idea of the social pillar in the course of this year. That social AAA rating is indeed a good and important principle, especially in this day and age. But if we now delve deep into the Commission's work programme, we will not find much of it. It remains with short references to possible initiatives. But surely the idea was to embed our social model in the European acquis and guarantee that there would be social security for all Europeans and that all Europeans would also be entitled to a living income in all Member States? A Dutch expression reads: promising a lot and giving little makes the fool live in joy. I think we should prevent that. Let us deliver on this AAA promise to the people of Europe. This is possible, but the Commission must come up with concrete proposals for the social pillar.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, your Commission claims that SMEs are at the heart of its concerns. All the better, because a year ago this Parliament proposed a simple and effective measure to support them: the recognition of geographical indications for artisanal products. We have been waiting for a proposal from the Commission for a year now.  Textiles, ceramics, cutlery and stone are all sectors and SMEs that are waiting for effective protection from the European Commission. These are all local jobs that could be strengthened and unfair competition for products from outside the European Union that could be avoided. This is a recurring demand from consumers who are waiting for certainty about the products they buy. It is also a request from citizens who want the European Commission to really care about the situation of the territories and to show that it understands their expectations and that it is as close as possible to the daily lives of citizens and businesses. Mr Vice-President, we are waiting for a legislative proposal from the Commission. We are counting on you; so that hope does not become impatience or resentment.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, thank you for communicating your priorities for the coming period. In particular, I also consider the security you want to focus on to be a priority. I very much appreciate the direction of the Commission, which wants to focus on the implementation and implementation of existing directives. I think this is a very correct decision, which is why I would also like to ask you and point out that it is in the legislative process to revise the Posting of Workers Directive. Unfortunately, it is in this process just as the implementation of the directive implementing the 1996 Directive is underway and this implementation has not been completed. Mr Vice-President, I would like to ask the Commission to consider whether it is sensible to revise a directive whose implementation has not been finalised. I think this runs counter to your intention to focus on implementing, evaluating and then implementing new directives.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the Commission's work programme for 2017 includes measures to address the current challenges of the Member States of the Union in various areas, such as employment, growth and investment. Within the framework of the Commission's work programme, EUR 8.5 billion is expected to be provided for innovation and research, while measures will be taken to boost employment and tackle the economic and refugee crisis affecting the Member States.  However, as the 2016 work programme showed, Mr Timmermans, the Commission's growth targets have not paid off, with the result that in some Member States of the European South, and in particular in Greece, even higher levels of unemployment are recorded. The funds given by the European Union for Greece are crumbs in the face of the real needs that exist. So instead of the European Union meeting the objectives of the work programme and boosting growth and investment, it is unfortunately increasing unemployment rates in Europe with its action and its policy of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in a sense this is a programme for governance for 2017 and you would imagine that this place would be buzzing, alive with people. You would get more buzz out of a fly with one day to live! We have issues such as Brexit, we have trade deals – that you crave after, Mr Timmermans – that are falling apart all around your ears, we have a refugee crisis, we have a crisis in agriculture and we have a serious crisis of confidence within the EU institutions. So, what do you do? With the people who were elected in this Parliament to represent the views of the people? You supply us with your programme for governance 15 minutes before we come in here! That is a complete and utter joke. How on earth can anyone have a debate with only 15 minutes to go through the information? I think I have heard longer standing Members at this stage joke about this. This is not a joke! If you want people to take the European Union seriously, if you are going to have a programme, give it to us more than 13 minutes before – but you do not care what we think and that is why you have done what you have done.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would, of course, like to thank Vice-President Timmermans for his willingness to give some very, let us say, concise and strategic indications, but I think that 2017 really cannot be a normal year, it will be a very special year, I would not like it to be just the year of Brexit, it must be the 60th anniversary of the Treaties, and as such, I think what he is doing for the institutional relaunch is important. , political, economic. I would put young people at the centre. I would also ask the Commission to consider that next year it is two anniversaries, 60 years of the Treaty and 30 years of Erasmus. Let us put the Erasmus generation at the centre in order to make together a revival of confidence in the citizens of what Europe must be.  I believe that from this point of view, among the ten priorities, it will be necessary to include, today there is not even more, a subject without which there is no future in the European perspective, I am talking about the cultural policies of education policies and cohesion policies, therefore social inclusion and the social agenda. It also seems important to me that we also respect what Juncker said - and I will close - when he said that creativity, culture and authors are the crown jewels. Let us be consistent, let us include this aspect more, this strategic sector of culture heritage, of the creative cultural industry in industrial policies, growth policies and also innovation policies.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the spiral of the economic crisis into which Europe has fallen for over 8 years continues to bite and make the lives of millions of European citizens precarious. It is now clear that this is a structural crisis and as such requires immediate, concrete but also innovative action. The transition to a circular model must be speeded up. Employment remains the top priority, but targeted investment in research and new technologies is needed to foster sustainable growth, optimising the use of resources, launching a modern post-2020 cohesion policy that respects the true nature of an investment instrument and effectively applies to all regions of the European Union. Synergies between the European Structural and Investment Funds, EFSI and other financing instruments must be strengthened in order to optimise their use. Finally, access to capital by businesses, SMEs and the adoption of effective social protection measures must be facilitated so that the objective of combating poverty in the Europe 2020 strategy is not just a good one.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by making a comment on procedure. I came here immediately after the College decided on the Commission Work Programme. We immediately sent the Commission Work Programme to every single Member of Parliament and I immediately came here before going anywhere else – not talking to the press, not talking to anybody else – to make a statement on the Commission Work Programme out of respect for your Parliament and out of respect for your work. If you do not want that, just let us know and we will not do it. I will go and talk to the press and we can talk to each other later on. This is how I am trying to show respect for the European Parliament and give you, before anybody else, the Commission Work Programme. Of course this is not the moment that we go through every detail of the Commission’s Work Programme. I am not expecting you to have read everything in 15, 20 or 30 minutes. That is not the point. The point is that I believe that if we have a decision in the College on the Commission’s Work Programme, you should be the first to hear about this and to be informed about this. I think this is a sign of respect and certainly not a sign of disrespect. Secondly, on many of the things you said there will obviously be extensive debates in the months to come. But let me just pick up on some of the points that were made. This Commission is very much aware of the fact that people in Europe see Europe as a source of insecurity, as a source of injustice and as a source of globalisation that takes away their rights and that takes away the securities they had.  We need to change that paradigm into a different paradigm, where Europe can show that, by doing concrete things, we do indeed improve their lives, we do indeed improve employment, we do indeed improve Europe’s competitive position worldwide and we do provide protection by being very concrete in concrete measures there where we have a competence at European level. That is what the Commission Work Programme is focused upon again this year. My second point is that, in the preparation of the Commission Work Programme, we have gone extensively through debates with your Parliament, starting with the debate on and after the State of the Union address by President Juncker leading up to the letter of intent; comments were given and the discussion was held in the Conference of Committee Chairs. That went extremely well and what we see today is completely in line with what we have discussed before so there can be no huge surprises. Obviously, because you are a political institution with divergent political views, not everybody will be equally happy with the content of what we did. This is where we will come to the debate in the months to come with all my colleagues. On transparency, perhaps we could work, for instance, on the interinstitutional agreement on the mandatory Transparency Register to improve transparency. Perhaps Ms in 't Veld can then convince her Group to vote for the Giegold report on this, which would help us to bring it forward. So, in that sense, we can continue to work together to improve transparency.  Yes, we need a pro—growth policy and, yes, everybody would agree worldwide that what Europe lacks most is investment. That is why the Commission Work Programme for next year puts a lot of emphasis on increasing the possibilities of investment, of increasing the possibilities – especially for the younger generation – for getting people to take up a job, to take up an internship, to take up a course of study, which has been a successful approach and we need to expand on that. I can assure Mr Eickhout that I am not about self—congratulation. Frankly, I remove every sentence that says ‘oh, we are so great’ in any communication coming out of the Commission on my behalf. So do not worry about that. I know where we are. I think I was the first, also in my own country, to announce that I saw the extent of the problems that we are in. I have also said quite clearly that this is a project that could also fail if we are not very careful. So in that sense I am very far from being self-congratulatory. I think we have quite a number of issues we need to solve.  Indeed I believe eco—design makes a huge contribution to solving some of our issues and to getting our economy to where it is going to be completely sustainable and therefore very competitive in a world, in this fourth industrial revolution, which is changing very quickly to a sustainable economy. The quicker we do that and the more we invest in that, the better we will come out of this, also in terms of employment and competitiveness. Of course, the issue of migration will be first and foremost on our minds in the year to come. That is beyond any doubt but, there again, everybody needs to accept their responsibility. This is somewhere where we cannot have a European Union of à la carte solidarity. If we have a problem that is faced by the Union as a whole, every single Member State will have to take their share of the responsibility in solving the problem. That is the gist of the proposals the Commission, in close collaboration with your Parliament, has made and will be continuing to make.  And there I like the phrase ‘protection without protectionism’, which is something I think could be the core of what we need to do. Europeans want more protection. They want to regain control of their destinies. That was the core of the debate during the Brexit campaign. That is what we see in every single Member State and we, with the limited possibilities we have, based on the competences we derive from the Treaty, should offer some solutions for the protection people are looking for. That is, I believe, the gist of the Commission Work Programme.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – 2017 is going to be another year but it should not be any year, as it is in the middle of the political agenda of the European Commission and the European Parliament. It's going to mark the beginning of our legacy. A legacy that must take security into account, but not only. Above all, the Union must provide protection without protectionism through economic growth, job creation, and greater opportunities for young people. We must emphasize growth without stability to improve the daily lives of our citizens. This will only be achieved through social measures. The necessary internal cohesion is not only achieved by ensuring border control, but that cohesion must occur from within the Union by building a common internal project. We're on time. We call on the Commission to implement the measures it publishes in the Annual Work Programme for next year. But we also want more: in young initiative, in the circular economy, in the multiannual financial framework, in the digital single market, in the control of multinationals, in Economic and Monetary Union and, of course, in the social pillar.

text: in writing. – 2017 is going to be another year but it should not be any year, as it is in the middle of the political agenda of the European Commission and the European Parliament. name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – After repeated calls from Parliament that the Commission has so far ignored, it is a welcome development that the Commission’s 2017 Work Programme includes the commitment that the scope for EU level action to protect whistle—blowers will be assessed this coming year.  In our crisis-stricken societies, the credibility of democracy is of utmost importance. While more than three out of every four EU citizens think that corruption is widespread in their country, and while the EU proclaims of itself that it wants to lead the world in liberties and justice, we cannot drag our feet any longer when it comes to protecting those who speak up at high personal risk to protect the public interest.  Whistle—blowing is an essential tool for maintaining accountability and integrity in both public and private sectors. That society owes protection and support to whistle—blowers has been recognised by soft law instruments adopted by international organisations to which most EU countries are parties. Yet, the protection of whistle—blowers throughout the EU is very uneven and scarce. There has been no shortage of pledges in recent years to change this situation. Now it is time for action. It is high time the Commission presented a legislative proposal!

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Commission's work programme represents the sad note of the institution's unre interest in the concerns of the European people. Starting with the fact that not even this Parliament has received the document to be debated more than 10 minutes in advance: as if they were bothered that there was some kind of political debate about the proposals they are presenting to us. I do not see any really ambitious proposals in areas where a European response is most necessary: fiscal and social harmonisation on the continent. On the contrary, the EU proposes more financial liberalization, TTIP (TCI), deepening economic governance and the single market... In short, the same policies that have emptied European democracy and fuelled social dumping between states and the instability of the economic system until its current crisis. The EU has gone from recognising its democratic deficit to fueling a post-democratic agenda, and not just on its internal agenda. Its response to the migration crisis, based on denying rights to refugees and an increasingly aggressive imperialist agenda, is another side of the same currency, with which Europe fuels the xenophobic populism it claims to combat.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Commission has committed to focusing on important issues and listening more to the concerns of its citizens in 2017. The EU is going through the worst economic crisis since its inception, which also has a serious social dimension. Today, more than ever, there are unacceptably high levels of unemployment, poverty and social inequalities in the Union, and young people have no prospect of development. The recovery of the European economy must at all costs be balanced with the need for more social Europe. In this regard, I welcome the Commission's decision to establish a European Pillar of Social Rights. It is high time to pay due attention to the need to ensure a work-life balance for working families. However, the Commission must also consider concrete actions to reduce child poverty, ensure equal access to quality education and pre-school education. There are 26 million children at risk of poverty and social exclusion in the EU, and these statistics are absolutely incompatible with our claims to development and civility.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Commission Work Programme for 2017 has a high and a low point. The high point forms part of the Youth Initiative, in itself a most worthwhile priority. The proposal to establish a European Solidarity Corps merits full support. It seeks to engage young people in worthwhile public initiatives from which they could learn social and technical skills, while understanding better today’s realities in a changing Europe. One hopes that the scheme will operate on a devolved basis, drawing fully on national bodies involved in youth affairs. The worst that could happen to it is to be subsumed in the values and concerns of people living in the Brussels bubble. By contrast the proposal to work on a European Defence Action plan and a European Defence Fund is totally ill-advised. It is the kind of project that people in the Brussels bubble will dream of in their efforts to counter what they see as Europa fatigue. Besides having unintended consequences, some of them unknown, others dangerous, a so-called European defence capability, or even a start to it, will simply end up, sooner rather than later, reinforcing the wide scepticism about the European project that these people seek to contain.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – This is the year when, in the context of the same debate on the work programme, we have stressed the need to finally actively address imbalances in the food supply chain and called on the Commission to take action. Result? The Commission has repeatedly supported the idea of self-regulation. In June this year, 600 Members of this plenary supported the report by my colleague Czesak. According to her, trade practices between the various actors in the food chain are a serious problem that requires legislative action at European level. We have called on the Commission to put forward a proposal defining common principles in the fight against these practices. The Commission's response to this challenge with an unprecedented mandate? We will continue to monitor the market situation. Mr Vice-President, the Commission's position on this matter is unacceptable to me. It not only ignores the work of the European Parliament, but also prevents the establishment of a fair competitive environment and transparent relations between food producers, suppliers and distributors in the internal market.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – I appreciate that the European Commission wants to focus more on areas that will bring more jobs and more security to the European Union. It is particularly important to continue trade negotiations with our partners and to seek compromise and acceptable solutions. In the security area, I welcome the start of work on the European Union strategy for Syria and Africa. This means that Europe has the ambition to become a global actor and to intervene positively where there are sources of instability, migration and current security threats. As regards threats, I would expect the Commission to also put emphasis on the Eastern Vector and prepare a roadmap for relations with the Eastern Partnership countries and a strategic roadmap for action against Russia and its aggressive policy.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The European Commission's work programme presents policies that the European Commission will pay particular attention to in the coming year. It is certainly an important set of topics that I too think are right to be addressed in 2017.  However, I would like to point out that the programme is not ambitious enough in the area of demographic change, intergenerational cooperation and the rights of the elderly. These are areas that are hardly mentioned or given a far too small meaning by the programme.  I find it unacceptable that, at a time when Europe is facing major demographic changes, the European institutions are not prepared to pay more attention to the ageing population and to take measures that will help to ensure and preserve the basic dignity of older generations.  We are still missing a strategy that responds to demographic change at the level of Europe or the European Union. This is despite experts warning that without adequate policies in the area of intergenerational cooperation, we can expect a continuing conflict between young people and the elderly.  In view of the above, I believe that the institutions of the European Union are missing out on the necessary measures in the area of demographic change. I therefore expect the European Commission to pay more attention to these areas in 2017 than the 2017 work programme envisages, namely the problem of strategic force.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. This action programme for 2017 confirms the European Commission's alarming blindness to the pressing political, economic and social problems that have been destabilising Europe for years and its inability to find concrete and adequate solutions. Over and above the empty and pompous declarations of intent, this programme persists in reproposing the same brief and unsuccessful political strategy that has led the European Union into the deepest economic, political and social crisis since its inception, without in any way questioning its effectiveness and without admitting, against all the evidence, the serious mistakes made so far. It is alarming that the Commission does not give priority at all to the problems relating to excessive macroeconomic imbalances and asymmetric effects between Member States generated by the single currency, the technocratic drift of decision-making mechanisms, or the lack of democratic legitimacy in the instruments of economic coordination, or the failure to reform finance on the basis of lessons from the crisis, and the lack of consideration of the general interest of European citizens in decisions indirectly determining their lives.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, as you know, the Commission has tabled a proposal for mid-term review revision of the financial framework in mid-September. I would like to express our gratitude to Parliament and especially to the two rapporteurs for the own initiative report, Ms Thomas and Mr Olbrycht, as well as for the work you have done to prepare a draft resolution, which we are pleased to see incorporates many of the proposals the Commission has tabled. Thank you for that. We all recognise that we are taking on this task at a time of multiple, successive and overlapping crises, and in that environment it is absolutely paramount for the European Union to demonstrate the capacity to act. In our proposal we focused on two dimensions of this capacity to act: the financial dimension (additional financial resources) and the flexibility aspect. I will go through those two in some detail. In terms of beefing up our capacity to fund priorities with very strong focus on jobs and growth and dealing with migration, we are proposing to make EUR 6.3 billion available. This is funding for very important objectives. For example, more young people in regions affected by particularly high levels of unemployment to find targeted support for integrating or reintegrating into the labour market. For giving more young people the chance to participate in actions supported by Erasmus+. To allow the European Research Council to finance more high-quality projects in frontier research. They are also about achieving a more effective management of migration flows so we can help refugees to integrate in their host countries, secure a better control of our external borders, fight illegal immigration and address the root causes of migration. But in itself this amount does not reflect the full level of the proposed refocusing of EU spending, because we have also taken a very careful look at how we can realign financial resources, for example, in our support for the Connecting Europe Facility, which has very broad endorsement here in Parliament. We have topped it up with EUR 400 million but we also are proposing to shift EUR 1 billion from financial instruments to grants under the transport strand of this facility. A big share of the proposed top-ups goes to instruments that have a significant multiplier or leverage effect: COSME, EFSI, the new European fund for sustainable development, the increased EIB external lending mandate, the Union’s instrument for macro-financial assistance to our neighbouring countries. And we have done that looking into every possible source, but within the parameters agreed in the 2013 multiannual financial framework (MFF). Secondly, on flexibility. Given that we continue to face a particularly volatile international environment, opting for an extension of flexibility is the responsible thing to do so we can act swiftly in crisis situations. This MFF runs until the end of 2020. This means more than four years still to go, with our existing flexibility already stretched to its limits. So for this reason we are proposing to double the size of the flexibility instrument and the emergency aid reserve, as well as to establish a European Union crisis reserve financed from decommitments we have fully taken on board, and that is a proposal from Parliament. And just to say that, if we had had this crisis reserve in place at the beginning of this MFF, it would have allowed us to finance the refugee facility for Turkey entirely. In other words, it would have avoided seeking complex, off-budget satellite solutions; we would have had the resources available to us. Let me stress in closing that our proposals are not only about the tangible things I have described. We are making a very serious effort to simplify the rules by which the Union’s programmes are implemented so as to reduce administrative burden for beneficiaries and public administrations, to make the EU funds more predictable and more flexible and the results of their deployment more visible to our people. We are, of course, at your disposal – Parliament, the Council – to engage so we can make the mid-term review a very prudent and helpful for the Union exercise. Of course, we look forward to the debate. We will be listening very carefully to all of you.

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Multiannual Financial Perspective Regulation provides for the first time an obligation to carry out a post-election review of the entire financial perspective. This obligation is fixed for the duration of 2016 and we are therefore debating this today.  The Regulation provides that if the review shows the need for amendments, i.e. where necessary, a revision should be made, i.e. a revision of the multiannual financial perspective. Without waiting for its treaty commitments, the European Parliament has already decided to review it in order to construct its proposal for a financial perspective. I stress this because it is not only a question of the European Parliament's ambition that it wants to carry out a review, but the European Parliament, through its Committee on Budgets, has carried out a partial review, with the help of the European Commission. As a result of our debates, public hearings, but also information from the European Commission, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets has come to the conclusion that a revision is absolutely necessary, and that is how we constructed our proposal, which we submitted as an own-initiative report. In our proposal, we make it clear that there is a need for a review of concrete changes.  We were very pleased to learn that the Commission actually agreed with our opinion and, when presenting its proposal, also proposed a revision. While we would expect even bigger or significant proposals for change on some issues, we believe that this is a very good starting point for negotiations. We therefore expect the European Commission to also try to convince the Council that what the Commissioner has proposed and talked about, namely the changes that are contained both in the draft budget 2017 and in the so-called Omnibus, a set of legislative amendments, as well as in the proposal to change the financial perspective, that this whole complex of changes will find its place in the coming months.  We see that these changes are proposed in different places, we are ready to work in different areas also binding these matters together. We are therefore ready to discuss with the Council immediately the Council's position, which will be presented to Parliament. We are ready for these talks, we are prepared, we are full of goodwill in terms of the need to regulate the necessary changes in order for the budget to function properly.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – We are all aware of the pressures that the European Union is under and it is very important that these are met without asking the taxpayers for more money. Would Mr Olbrycht agree with me that the Court of Auditors has said that we would make a saving of EUR 110 million a year if this Parliament had only one seat, and would he agree with me that we should move as quickly as possible to having one seat and stop this foolish commute between Brussels and Strasbourg?

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Sir, I have not heard the question.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I am very happy to repeat it. What I said was: that we are aware of the pressures that the European Union is under and that we should accommodate this without asking the taxpayers for more money. Is Mr Olbrycht aware of the report by the Court of Auditors that says that, were this Parliament to sit in only one seat, we would save EUR 110 million a year, and would he further agree with me that we should stop this silly commute between Brussels and Strasbourg every month?

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – With all respect, of course I did understand you; I just didnʼt find the question in your statement. You presented a statement concerning the situation. If you want my advice and my opinion about Strasbourg and Brussels, I think this is the Treaty agreement made between very serious states and governments many years ago, and I don't know if all the Member States wants to re-open the debate about the different institutions being in different countries. Maybe one day, but I donʼt think this is really the issue. So sorry I didnʼt answer your question, but I thought that you would want to just to make the statement.

name: Isabelle Thomas
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to have been able to welcome the Council, because today we are debating a resolution that responds to the legislative package presented by the Commission on the revision of the multi-year financial framework, and because it will obviously be an essential partner. This draft revision of the Commission confirms Parliament's lucidity about the need for a genuine review. Thank you, Madam Vice-President. This is a first budgetary first in the history of the European Union and I welcome the position of the Commission, which, like Parliament, is finding after consideration that we cannot continue with the current framework. This is a first victory that calls for others. However, there is one notable absence: the Council, which should be with us to present its position and listen to that of parliamentarians.  The Council must quickly present its position to us without waiting for the last day of conciliation, at the risk of delaying the budgetary procedure. We therefore wish to be able, without delay, to sit together at the same table to open these negotiations. What is in the resolution presented tomorrow to the vote of parliamentarians? It highlights a certain convergence of views of the three institutions on the priorities of the European Union: the fight against youth unemployment, measures on migration and refugees, COP 21, agricultural crises, underinvestment and internal security. The debate is about the main European priorities. This debate is no longer to be said. Indeed, I believe that today we are speaking with one voice. The question now is whether we are left with statements or whether we are giving ourselves the financial means.  The Commission's draft revision provides some solutions, notably on flexibility, which allows for better use of all the means of the financial framework. These flexibility instruments, which were wrestled out of the European Parliament's 2013 negotiations, proved to be life-saving in the first years of the MFF's implementation in order to deal with the unforeseen events and crises we are going through. How could the current migration phenomenon, Brexit or the new internal security challenges be foreseen in 2013? These tools of flexibility have been very much in demand and, without revision, they will simply not be enough to deliver on the commitments we have made to our fellow Europeans.  Our resolution welcomes the Commission's proposals on flexibility extensions, although we believe that more needs to be done, particularly for the strengthening of the emergency aid reserve and the flexibility instrument. With regard to the Union's crisis reserve, we welcome the fact that this idea, proposed by Parliament, as you said, Madam Vice-President, is being taken up by the Commission. We will have to think again about its scope and its funding. Budgetary flexibility is neither a luxury nor a whim, as has been demonstrated. It is a powerful tool, in long-term budget programming, which aims to respond to situations that we cannot anticipate. We also support proposals for the use of statutory releases within the European budget. These appropriations to be spent under the EU budget must logically be maintained in this budget and not leave it. As for payments, as we said in July, the ostrich policy would lead us to serious disappointments at the end of the period. We have to take responsibility. The credibility of the European institutions, but, more seriously, the situation of the beneficiaries, whether it be local authorities, businesses or students with Erasmus mobility, would find themselves waiting for the European Union to be able to pay the bills due to them. This hidden deficit, if I may say so, is against the treaty. The revision should resolve this issue by calculating, outside the ceilings, special instruments and by re-flexibilizing the overall margin of payments.  The solutions are on the table and the discussion must now open with a common objective: every bill from the Union must be paid on time. However, let me still make a few criticisms. We regret in particular that the Commission's draft does not propose to raise the spending limits for heading 1a on Competitiveness for Growth and Employment, heading 1b on economic, social and territorial cohesion and headings 3 and 4. We must break the deadlock in the announcements without Funding. I will take just one example: the fight against youth unemployment. It's a shared priority. The Commission has just assessed positively the youth employment initiative, which is recognised as a success, not a total success, but it is never the case. However, while the six billion appropriations of this programme are exhausted, the Commission's proposal provides for only one billion euros to strengthen until 2020. This is notoriously inadequate in the face of the tragedy experienced by 25% of young Europeans under the age of 25. At a minimum, the same amount must be added, i.e. EUR 6 billion by the end of the budget period. The debate on the substance of the revision has only just begun. In Parliament, we are ready to open negotiations. We know that the Commission is, too. We are now waiting for the Council and, as we said in July, and as we reiterate in the resolution which I hope will be voted on tomorrow, Parliament wishes to conduct parallel negotiations on the 2017 budget and the revision of the multi-year financial framework. The amending letter No. 1 on the 2017 budget demonstrates that the revision will necessarily have an impact on the 2017 budget. These two files must therefore be negotiated at the same time.  Madam President, all I have left is my conclusion, if I may.  To this end, Parliament has set up a single negotiating team on both issues. We have our mandate, adopted in July, which we are completing today. It is now up to the Council to accelerate. There is no time to waste for our fellow citizens and for Europe.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A revision of the MFF is urgently needed. However, this must not lead us to reflexively call for more money. We must remember that both the Member States, and especially their citizens, are not prepared to want or be able to spend more money on the EU. We must also ask ourselves in principle: is it the right way to call for more money? Where is the proof that with more money and still more money, we are actually finding better solutions? Instead, we should ask ourselves: should we not really strengthen subsidiarity and only tackle the tasks in the EU that we can solve better than the Member States? If we do that, then we will have a lean budget, and we can also set new priorities that can respond to the new challenges. But not just more money. This will ultimately lead to state markets and will lead us away from a free market economy. We should prevent this. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you I have a very quick question: you are against talking about more money. Are you more money or are you going to put the question of the European Union's own resources elsewhere?

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for this demand. I do not think that own resources can be seen in isolation from the overall budget. Ultimately, the question of how the EU finances itself must be settled with the Member States. We want us to have a lean budget overall, no matter how we fund it. Citizens have a right to be much more results-oriented in future, that is to say, we must define measurable objectives, but then also check the achievement of the objectives.
