That is the decisive factor, not the question of how we finance anything.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I too want to congratulate the rapporteurs, our two colleagues Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, for the quality of their work. Like my colleagues, I would also like to welcome, Commissioner, the Commission's decision to propose a genuine review of the multi-year financial framework. In doing so, the Commission is at least easing some of the truly narrow corset of the current multi-year financial framework, which was negotiated in a time before the major challenges, particularly migration and security, that the Union is facing today.  Of course, on the substance, the Commission's proposals fall somewhat short of the expectations of the European Parliament, expressed in the resolution adopted on 6 July this year and included in the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow. I am thinking in particular of the absence of any reference to the increase in ceilings, which is central to the proposal of our two colleagues and which we support. Commissioner, you have talked about more flexibility. I hope you will be right, but I am not sure that will be enough. In any case, I note with satisfaction that the Commission's proposal provides for greater funding for investment, an extension of the fund for strategic investments, an extension of the youth employment initiative and an indispensable crisis reserve. Finally, I want to agree with the strategy defined by our two colleagues and supported by the Committee on Budgets, which is to link the negotiation of the multi-year financial framework to the negotiation of the 2017 budget.  Mr Schulz has just written to Mr Tusk and Mr Fico on this subject. We have to win. Unfortunately, the absence of the Council today is already a bad indicator of this will.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, you are trying to do better with nothing more. This is a desperate exercise in the constrained framework of the PSC. You have been driven, it is true, by the lack of ambition in the European Council, which, despite Brexit, the refugee crisis and the despair of the European peoples, remains convinced that nothing should change. You have also self-censored by putting on the table a minimum proposal that mourns your own European ambitions. As for the European Parliament, because it does not know how to create a real political balance of power with the European Council, it is also not very helpful to you. In the end, we will end up with a real false revision when we should have changed everything.  It is therefore up to my colleagues in the European Parliament that I also want to send a message to them that we must have the courage... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Ernest Maragall
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I thank Mr Olbrycht and Mrs Thomas very sincerely.  We all have a chance - Commission, Council and Parliament - a double chance. The revision of this financial framework may be, it must be the positive and visible turning point that European citizens understand as much as they expect. You must see, you must understand that Europe is reacting, that Europe faces the challenges that have just arisen and that Europe does not resign, does not retreat to its national borders, but works for the common interest.  But this means accepting, explicitly and addressing from the financial framework also – not only, but also – the great challenges, the great objectives clearly set: the stimulus of sustainable growth and convergence between Member States; the energy transition and commitments of the Paris Conference; internal social cohesion and care for immigrants and refugees; security and a common and powerful external action, with its own voice, that makes us respect.  Let us be clear, Madam Vice-President and Commissioner Georgieva: flexibility is not enough. Flexibility to the fullest is not synonymous with the revision we need. We said this in the report, we said it in July, we are saying it again now: we need more for these objectives, consistent with what Mr Timmermans has just explained to us in his work programme for this year.  So the condition is this: to work openly and together the three institutions to achieve an explicit and courageous review of the financial framework. To work together, we will not agree to enter the 2017 budget if we do not clearly agree on how we focus, how we guide the revision of the 2017-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. We will be there and this Parliament is fulfilling its role. He did it in July and he's doing it now. And we're going to take this goal to the end, to the last negotiation on the last day of this year, if appropriate.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, any politician has to be an amazing contortionist because they have to be able to simultaneously sit on the fence and keep both ears to the ground. Well the European Union certainly knows how to tap dance.  Back in 2014 David Cameron came back from Brussels waving a piece of paper saying he had got a cut in the EU’s long-term financial plan, the multiannual financial framework, but as usual it came with all sorts of caveats, and all sorts of ways were found to get around it: add to the EU’s income by levying fines on Member States and create a flexibility instrument whose flexibility would put the best gymnast to shame.  Over the period of this framework, in real terms we are now talking about over one trillion euro – one trillion with a T – of taxes going to this monolith and spent so inefficiently. They are bending over backwards to get more of your money, but I cannot mix any more metaphors, because I am afraid my minute is up.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Mr President, the debate on budgetary frameworks in the European Parliament is not democratic accountability, as you pride yourself. It is legitimising huge redistribution, theft of popular toil, with budgets by definition and demonstrably unpopular ones, such that Juncker has also confessed to launching unemployment and poverty. You make fun of it when you talk about money that supposedly gives away the European Union. The source of EU and national budgets is the taxes paid by the people. The winners are the monopolies, which are exempt from taxes, are given billions as incentives and for their interests there are wars with millions of refugees. The contrasts concern which state, which monopolies will be strengthened the most. Increased or reduced budgets, one or the other targeting profitable sectors, a strict or flexible stability pact, all have one condition for restructuring. For every euro that goes to monopolies, wage, pension, social rights. Anyone, like SYRIZA, who has claimed that the European Union is changing has proved equally unpopular. It is only overthrown, along with the monopolies that created it.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner and congratulate her on the proposal she has put forward to us, and also welcome the work done by the rapporteurs.  This proposal from the European Commission is a good starting point for us to start negotiations with the Council and this review of the Multiannual Financial Framework is urgent. It proves this the poor implementation of the European Funds.  Regions and local authorities need it, young people are waiting, the economy needs it and the funds do not reach the Member States. We have complexity, we have bureaucracy that prevents normal implementation, planned implementation. We need flexibility, we need simplicity.  This year alone, eur 7.3 billion has not been implemented and will be returned to the Member States. For our part we are ready, but where is the Council that should be sitting on this important discussion here in this Chamber?  It's urgent, we can't wait any longer, that's enough! Just! We can't postpone it. We have one single objective, which is to fulfil, and for this we have to invest, we have to do with companies, with researchers, with farmers, with businesses and small and medium-sized enterprises, with local authorities, with young people.  It is for the economy that we want the revision, but also for the credibility and respect for the citizens of the European Union.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D).
text: – Madam President, a number of crises have been added to the already protracted economic crisis resulting from a lack of public investment and high unemployment, especially youth, a number of crises have been added in recent years: agriculture, refugee investment, internal security... During the negotiation of this financial framework we already warned that we were going to need a review and unfortunately the weather and these crises have given us the reason. In this regard, we welcome the Commission's proposal for a review, which is on the right track. I think it contains interesting proposals, but - it has also been said here - it falls a little short.  And in the meantime, where's the Council? In fact, he's not even present at the debate. Don't you consider the situation of the European Union serious enough to already have a proposal to negotiate on? Because, of course, they will not intend to finance new needs, to continue to meet previous needs and not to change a single comma of the financial framework. I don't know what calculator they use, but of course with my calculator we don't get the bills.  It is urgent that we start negotiating the financial framework now. And it is urgent that we start negotiating it with the 2017 budget. And this is not a whim, it's not even a threat, it's a no-brainer. We cannot negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate. And in case this was not obvious to some, especially the Council, the Commission's letter of correction clarifies this further.  So far the Council has asked us for goodwill and the European Parliament has always had it. I ask myself: Where is the goodwill of the Council? Even today he has not come to debate or listen to Parliament's proposals.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Speaking in this debate, I would like to draw attention to three points. Firstly, I would like to make it clear that the Commission's failure to put forward proposals to increase the ceilings in the current MFF is likely to cause difficulties in financing EU action, mainly in headings 3 and 4, in view of the ongoing immigration crisis. Secondly, the Commission's proposals for rebuilding horizon 2020, Connecting Europe, Erasmus+, COSME and the Youth Employment Initiative, totaling €2.2 billion, or additional funding for the extension of the ESI Funds, as well as external investment plans under the €1.6 billion Migration Partnership, should be welcomed. Finally, thirdly, it is with disapproval that measures should be adopted to reduce the level of payments in 2016 by as much as EUR 7.3 billion in the Commission's amending budget No 4 for 2016, as I believe that this will lead to a build-up of a backlog of outstanding accounts.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I, in turn, am surprised at the absence of the Council. I would like to acknowledge the outstanding work of our co-staff, Isabelle Thomas and Jan Olbrycht. Here, by resolution, they set out the fundamental principles of negotiation with the Council. My feeling is that we are coming to the end of a cycle and that the revision of the multi-year financial framework must put an end to two hypocrisies. The first is the levers of flexibility, the famous special instruments. During the negotiations on the financial outlook for 2014-2020, it was agreed that these special instruments, facing exceptional circumstances and crises, would be above the ceilings. Then, on the test, we found that the Council did not want to admit that, if there was a inclusion above the ceilings for commitments, there would have to be a corresponding inscription above the ceilings for payments. The Council refuses this version and that is how we dig the rest to liquidate and we will find ourselves tomorrow facing a major difficulty.  The second hypocrisy concerns the practice of hiding our impecuniousness by multiplying budget satellites: Juncker funds for strategic investments, facilities for Turkey and other trust funds. This practice insults the principle of fiscal unity and creates a blind spot for parliamentary control. The resulting galaxy is a mirage.  The revision of the multi-year financial framework is an opportunity to restore order to the budgetary house and to infuse sincerity into a budget that has lost all legibility. Let us beware: a Union whose budget is not comprehensible by its citizens is a Union in danger. There is therefore an urgent need to give substance to the Commission's intelligent proposal for revision.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cé go gcuirim fáilte roimh sholúbthacht agus simpliú an CAI (an Creat Airgeadais Ilbhliantúil), fós féin caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuilim imníoch. Ba chóir do chuspóirí agus tosaíochtaí na Parlaiminte díriú isteach ar chomhionannas agus ar chothromaíocht, chun tacú leo siúd is mó atá i mbaol inár sochaí.  Ní féidir linn leanúint ar aghaidh gan dealramh agus sinn ag dul ó ghéarchéim go géarchéim. Táim ag labhairt mar gheall ar Ghéarchéim na dTeifeach agus ar an nGéarchéim Dhéiríochta. Ní imeachtaí gan choinne a bhí sa dá scéal seo. Tá dualgas ar an gComhairle agus ar na rialtais fiú díriú isteach ar réitigh agus tá deis acu anois leis an athbhreithniú seo. Tá dualgas orthu a bheith freagrach agus éisteacht a thabhairt don Pharlaimint atá tar éis a rá arís agus arís eile go bhfuil riachtanas ann acmhainní fónta a chur ar fáil.  Níl aon infheistiú ann i dtaobh fostaíocht do dhaoine óga mar shampla, cé gur tosaíocht atá ann ag an gComhairle. Ar a laghad, tá dlúthpháirteachas á thaispeáint ag an bParlaimint i dtaobh glacadh leis na riachtanais atá ann chun leanúint ar aghaidh de bheith ag tacú leis an bPróiseas Síochána i dTuaisceart Éireann ag féachaint d’impleachtaí an Bhreatimeachta. Tá dualgas orainn anois dul i ngleic leis na mórphointí atá ag cruthú éagothromaíochta agus míchothromaíochta agus tá dualgas orainn stad a chur leo siúd a dteastaíonn uathu buiséad an Aontais Eorpaigh a ísliú.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, you have been dealing with two difficult situations for the European budget in recent times: crises, both the economic and the refugee crisis, and, at the same time, the lack of money to make payments to the Member States. The proposal you made is trying to solve some of these problems. It is a brave proposal and I congratulate you on that. Let's see if that chair over there, which isn't occupied, will agree. You have taken a step forward to resolve the current crisis and other possible crises by bringing the disengaged money back into the budget, which we have been asking for for a very long time. And you've probably managed to make a situation easier. But not entirely - you have been told here before, now it's just commitments, you have to solve the problem of payments. The lack of money crisis will be repeated because cohesion policy will end up in this situation again. So you must also solve this problem in the future by imposing the principle very simple but very clear: the Council must pay the money, all the money it committed to pay when the budget was set years ago.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Europe has faced many challenges and crises in recent years and is now facing many challenges and crises. We have the migration crisis, the refugee crisis and also the challenges of terrorist attacks, so the fight against terrorism. An adequate response to these crises and challenges obviously requires a rethinking of the budget and a responsible review of those funding from the Union budget. We must also give a signal of responsibility to European citizens and also reduce our spending in the European institutions. I, too, welcome the Commission's proposal to make the money left in the former financial year available, to make it available now for these challenges for which there was no money in the budget. And I also call on the Council to take responsibility and ensure a realistic, credible and coherent budget for the coming years in which to foresee all these crises that could have been foreseen in their time.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would first like to pay tribute to the rapporteurs, Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, for the quality of their work. We knew that in 2013 and we said it right here. In deciding to reduce the Community budget for seven years, the European Council has refrained from funding any new policy and has decided that there will be no unforeseen events for seven years. This will remain in the annals as a summit of political short-sightedness.  We are reviewing this framework mid-term. Will we confirm that the world has stopped until 2020 and that mass emigration, terrorist massacres, Brexit, the digital revolution, COP21 and soon the 22nd, the Ukraine war, the agricultural crises have not taken place? This revision will be useful if it allows at least gradually to return to European common sense and common sense at all. Firstly, European policies must be financed by the European budget alone; President Arthuis has said this forcefully. Secondly, the European budget must be financed by its own resources. The Monti Group, in which we work, Commissioner, will finalise its proposals in the coming days. Thirdly, when Member States appeal to the Union, everyone in Brussels and at home must ensure that European action translates not into more spending, but less total public spending and therefore less tax. Mutualization allows for greater efficiency at an equal or lower cost; this is called subsidiarity.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear Kristalino! And the European Parliament knows, and the Commission knows, that this revision of the budget is both an opportunity and a problem. The opportunity is that a revision is indeed needed, for example, in order to finance new needs that are well recognised, generally as a result of new promises made by the Council without indicating the sources of money, but also in order to avoid the budgetary drama that we remember from the end of the previous financial perspective. But this is also a problem because the Commission, forced to submit proposals in mid-2016, knows little about what implementation will look like in the years to come. All we know is that this time we have more delay than ever. One billion euros paid so-called interim payments last year, very modest assumptions about payments next year, that is a greater delay in implementation than ever before, and therefore there is still some trouble in this.  I would therefore like to make it clear, and to this end, that this revision is not only about finding money for new identified needs, because the Commission has proved very creative in this. It is also about preventing these dramas, and I say this as a participant and witness to this budget drama of 2013-14, later 2015. This is an important task at the same time, but I do not know how the Commission will deal with it, because it is not only a question of investment, but also of the credibility of the European Union.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE).
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. The financing of exceptional expenditure must not be at the expense of the European Union's fundamental policies, cohesion and agriculture. It is essential to maintain a balance between long-term priorities and new challenges.  Competitiveness, growth, employment, security, protection of external borders are important issues. It is therefore necessary both to maintain and to find additional resources in these areas. 92% of the total European Fund for Strategic Investments has reached "old" European countries : Germany, France, Great Britain, Italy, Spain. This further increases inequalities. It is also necessary to ensure that funds are brought to Eastern Europe, including the Baltic States. The use of financial instruments must be encouraged, but it is essential to maintain grants, which is particularly important for small countries. I would also like to expect the Commission to inform Parliament about the possible impact of Brexit on the European budget.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Madam President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, the revision of the financial framework 2014 to 2020, without changing the amounts attributable to the Member States, is called upon to respond to challenges that have arisen since the budget was drawn up. Simply put, with the same money we must take exceptional actions. The European Parliament adopts the Commission's proposal to create the crisis reserve as a specific tool with obvious objectives of the humanitarian crisis and filling security gaps. However, the need for efficiency in the allocation of funds is imperative and we must respond to it. Interestingly, the Commission incorporates our idea of using unspent funds to deal with crises – and here I would especially like to refer to the contribution of the rapporteur, Mr Olbricht – but it seems that funding is not enough. We need to check how European taxpayers' money is not lost on the way and ultimately heal, as far as possible, the effects of the refugee crisis.  The question of effectiveness is also at the disposal of resources to tackle youth unemployment. Indeed, Interrail is a great way, but it seems not enough. The direction to reduce insurance contributions for the companies they hire... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to call for greater responsibility for a fairer distribution of the resources offered by the European Union. The latest Commission communiqué on the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative clearly shows that we need to make much greater efforts to reach people who are struggling with poverty, social exclusion, disability and discrimination. Included Roma. According to a FRA study, 58% of young Roma are excluded from the labour market, vocational training and the education system. However, the European fund that exists to give these young people a chance at jobs and education does not reach this group. Halfway through the MFF, it is crucial to examine all the important financial tools, such as the ESF, ERDF, Erasmus+ and Creative Europe, to ensure that those in dire need of these programmes do not face obstacles. I would also like us to respect the court's new report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union needs to revise the multiannual financial framework in order to be able to meet the challenge of economic and crisis recourse. In particular, in the multiannual financial framework 2014 -2020 the expenditure ceiling for strengthening the development of the Member States of the Union is EUR 125.61 billion, while the ceiling for security and citizenship issues is EUR 15.69 billion.  However, Mrs Georgieva, the scale of the current economic and refugee crisis affecting Europe requires greater amounts of spending and active solutions in order to be adequately addressed. It calls for an immediate abandonment of austerity in order to end the armies of the unemployed and poverty in the countries of the European South, as well as the immediate implementation of relocations, in order to tackle the refugee crisis. Finally, the revision of the multiannual financial framework should also be reflected in the Union budget and the funds should be increased to deal with the current economic and recourse crisis.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it makes total sense, obviously, to carry out a mid-term review with all that has happened in the last few years, much of it unexpected, some of it predictable, but in a lot of cases people did not listen. But the first thing you have got to do is to do the simple things. I think it says a lot about the European Union that it has become so complicated that apparently it is impossible not to do the simple thing of not travelling down here once every month, wasting time, wasting money, and, most importantly, wasting our ability to think, because while we are travelling all over Europe, we are not getting time to think about the problems of Europe and how to solve them. If we cannot solve something that is pretty much a drip in comparison to the flood that we are facing, then we would want to think about where we are going. We have got to stop travelling down here, because you cannot preach to anyone how they spend their money if you repeatedly do something stupid like this.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, the multiannual financial framework as a means of expressing the Union's economic policy is a failed model. The existing multiannual financial framework has failed to address challenges that emerged in the first half of its implementation. Despite its visible failure, the heads of the European institutions, unfortunately, continue to support and implement it. It is, if anything, foolish to plan the allocation of financial resources over seven years, using ceilings and enforcing their observance, while at the same time pursuing growth and innovation. This tactic leads to distortions of political priorities and strategic objectives, but also to the sluggish response to emerging threats. The existing multiannual financial framework does not have the flexibility and structure to deal with an armed conflict, for example, between a member country with a acceding third country. Obviously, even after Brexit, it does not have a mechanism to deal with an additional exit of a Member State from the Union, but also the collapse of solidarity within NATO, situations that are possible and not just possible.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Madam Vice-President, I think that with the proposed review of the multiannual financial framework, the European budget is finally coming out of the emergency lane in which it was. We cannot pass on the proposed increase – 400 million more for Horizon, 400 million more for Connected Europe, 200 million for COSME, 200 million for Erasmus, 1 billion for Employment.  But as we keep our eyes open to all these good things that have been offered, we must also look at the dangers that hang over us. The programming period started a year and a half later and in 2020 either regions will be in doubt with lost money or with bad projects that have rushed not to lose the money.  I think in this review we need to propose a mechanism to give them time and room to manoeuvre so that they don't lose a penny of the money we agreed as early as 2013. Otherwise, money that we have agreed to go to the most deprived, in europe's poorest regions, will find themselves in nowhere to be taken because of shortened deadlines.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate my fellow rapporteurs on this excellent report and I am also happy with the Commission's openings, in particular on the flexibility and reserve of uns spent funds, although I believe it is necessary to bring the 2017 budget negotiations into line with the MFF negotiations in order to have an overall picture. Well that there is a strong focus on young people. Three points: too little 1 billion for aid to the employment initiative and 200 million for Erasmus, welcome, but they are certainly not a huge contribution. Secondly, why are we going to increase the badget of Cosmos and Erasmus and not two programmes which are extraordinarily important for innovation, growth and work, particularly for young people? I am talking about creative Europe, thinking of all the cultural and audiovisual industries and also the cultural sector, and Europe for citizens. I think it is important at this time to emphasise how important inclusive policies and strengthening innovation and citizenship are as important as other programmes.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I believe that the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework presented by the European Commission is a good starting point for further work. Undoubtedly, the difficult period of crisis facing the European Union has made us clear about the need for budget flexibility to respond quickly and to tackle adverse phenomena. I therefore consider it important, inter alia, to double the flexibility instrument and the emergency aid reserve. I also welcome the announcement of further simplification of the rules or the mobilisation of additional resources of more than EUR 6 billion, including for boosting growth and jobs, migration and security. I would also like to remind you that the revision of the MFF does not allow violations of national envelopes and the agreed amounts for individual countries must remain unchanged.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the revision of the multiannual financial framework provides a unique opportunity to respond to budgetary difficulties that currently jeopardise Europe's credibility. The problems of migration, internal security, the crisis in the agricultural sector, the persistently high rate of unemployment, especially among young people, require the adoption of appropriate measures and a considerable amount of additional funds from the European Union budget which, in the early years of the current multiannual financial framework, were not foreseen because of the limited resources available. The Council must now move from words to deeds, ensuring a realistic, credible, coherent and sustainable budget for the next few years of the multiannual financial framework. The review should aim to ensure a balance between meeting the Union's long-term priorities and responding to new emerging challenges by introducing measures that make the budget more transparent and accessible to European citizens.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Madam President, I, in turn, would like to congratulate both the rapporteurs, Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, and Vice-President Georgieva for responding to what I consider to be a democratic requirement, since the elected representatives of this Parliament did not participate in the very constitution of the multi-year financial framework. Therefore, it seemed normal, it seemed to me, that we could now vote on the amendment of this framework.  In any case, I hope that the Council will follow the example of both Parliament and the Commission in order for the revision to be effective. We need it; Europe needs it; European policies need it. Today, we must not only revise this financial framework, but also place ourselves in the perspective of a multi-year financial framework beyond 2020 with its own resources, as Mr Lamassoure rightly said earlier.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all who have taken part in this debate. It is a moment in the implementation of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) that we cannot possibly miss in terms of introducing adjustments that would allow us in the next four years to respond to priorities. We all agree on those priorities. I heard in the debate those who say that our proposals go too far and I also heard in the debate those – and actually there were more voices in this category – who said that we are not going far enough. It is true that, when we look at the capacity to operate in a very tight budgetary environment in Member States, we know the restrictions that unanimity places on us when we go forward for the revision. The notion that some may have that we are going too far is understandable, but let me just remind all of us that our budget is just one percent of GNI and yet it has such a massively important purpose, especially in these very turbulent times. Those who think that we are not going far enough have, of course, very legitimate reasons for saying that. It is true that we are still struggling to overcome the impact of a prolonged economic crisis, especially as it affects our youth. I just want to flag that, in addition to what we have in our proposal to address the most pressing needs of recovery and employment, we also have been able to provide three of the most affected countries – Italy, Greece and Spain – with a boost coming out of the adjustment of EUR 4.6 billion. I certainly hope that these countries will indeed direct as much as possible of this funding to tackle unemployment and all three also need to deal with the impact of migration. Beyond the proposal there are some other elements that we should take into account. When we look into the viability of what we have put forward, actually we are convinced that it is possible to reach an agreement between the Council, Parliament and the Commission on a way forward. It is not only possible but is of paramount necessity, so that we can continue to function in a way that delivers to people. I want to respond to two points that were made: one by Mrs Thomas on the importance of putting forward a more detailed proposal on how the new reserve could be created and what the implications may be. We agree with that and we have actually already offered during a presentation in a meeting of the General Affairs Council that we might elaborate a bit further on the link between the decommitments – how they may be made, how we guarantee that there would be no perverse incentive to have more decommitments – and, on the other hand, how high a limit would we set in order for the reserves to be used when it is indeed absolutely necessary? We will of course share this proposal with Parliament as well. Secondly, a number of points were made with regard to payments. I could not agree more that, while we have got on top of the issue of insufficient payment appropriations in the past and we have cleared the bills that were to be paid, we are now unfortunately facing this year – and we expect the same next year – insufficient payments coming our way. Mr Novakov also made that point. We can only work as hard as possible to accelerate implementation and call on all of us to push all the buttons there are for this to happen.  We do have enough payment credits should we apply all the flexibility of the global margin for payments and should we reach an agreement on where the payment for the special instruments belongs – above the ceilings, as Parliament and the Commission have been arguing for, or under the ceilings? But this is work to be done in a pragmatic way to bring everybody together so we can have a review and revision that results in a more potent budget for the next four years in front of us.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament formulate its position on two budgetary issues. It is regrettable that both EP proposals stand by the parliamentary report adopted in the July plenary vote, which pre-commented on the review of the 2014-2020 MPM. In this case, despite the unified opposition of the MEMBERS of the People's Party, MEPs from the Hungarian left-wing parties voted against the interests of the country, and all Hungarian citizens were attacked in the back with their decision in support of forced resettlement. MePs from hungary's left-wing parties voted in favour of forced resettlement and harsh financial sanctions against countries that rejected it by voting in favour of the European Parliament proposal. At the same time, the overwhelming majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only accept a financial framework review and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of an idea. In the review, the European Commission proposes an increase of EUR 12.8 billion. This is only partly a new resource, much of it an unused budgetary margin in the framework and the draining of reserves. We must avoid the liquidity crisis under the previous seven-year financial framework, when the Commission was unable to pay the invoices submitted to the Member States for the projects implemented. We can only support all proposals if we have adequate guarantees that there will be sufficient resources in the annual budgets for payments of catch-up programmes already in place and agricultural subsidies.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Three years after the start of the current programming period, Europe is in a very different situation, characterised by new challenges and priorities. Today, the multiannual financial framework is implemented in the context of the migration crisis, threats to internal security and still unacceptably high levels of youth unemployment, which require significant additional funding from the European budget. Special instruments have been mobilised to address these challenges in recent years, ing to the limit the possibilities of the current multiannual financial framework. All this shows that the mid-term review of the framework is extremely timely and necessary. The current budgetary difficulties further threaten citizens' trust in the European Union, which is already badly shaken. It is therefore important that Member States assume their responsibility and support their words with deeds, ensuring a predictable and reliable EU budget for the remaining years of the current programming period. In this context, the mid-term review should also seriously address the issue of replenishing the European budget with truly autonomous own resources to replace the current system of national contributions.

name: Jens Geier
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Vice-President Georgieva, Kristalina, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs President-in-House, who has been a mazed at the work she has done. Minister Lesay, welcome to the European Parliament! You have been sorely missed in the debate on the medium-term financial framework. Do you know what I'm really fed up with? I really am fed up with the attitude of the governments of the Member States when it comes to financing the European Union. Either we follow the finance ministers, then we would cut the Commission's budget estimates so that the EU saves and does not spend as much money. Or we can follow the other members of the same governments of the Member States, who are constantly demanding more from the EU and therefore also from the EU budget, and who are garnishing this with the demand that the EU must be big on the major problems. To add the krona, the Member States have already agreed to the current budgetary situation. The medium-term financial framework sets the ceilings and the objectives to be financed. And because all this is the case, President Schulz is so right to say that hypocrisy in the capitals cannot be surpassed when it comes to the European budget – agree in Brussels and then criticise these decisions in the capitals, euroscepticism is produced. So no matter what we do, we always get it wrong. Because we are not following the finance ministers at the reading of the budget, we must now again accept the accusation that we were too generous with taxpayers' money. No, Minister, we do not deal with the money too generously, we just want the EU to be really big – and as big as possible – when it comes to the problems that the Council of the European Union sees as central as we are: the creation of growth and jobs and the resolution of the refugee crisis. And because we are in the process of doing so, I have looked at the figures for the last five budgets and compared the Council's proposal with the figures that we actually needed at the end of the year in the financial year, and five times the Council was too short. We needed a lot more money. In the sixth year, finance ministers still do not know better.  The EP will adopt an ambitious draft budget tomorrow. We want to show what can be done by mobilising the budget and making full use of the available opportunities. We propose mobilising the money needed to guarantee the Juncker Plan as part of the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework. And for that we are reusing all the sums that have been used for the guarantee.  In this way, we are funding research and the financing of cross-border transport routes. We provide money for small and medium-sized enterprises. While others here in the Chamber are making colourful balloons rise and promising every young person an interrail ticket for their 18th birthday, we are increasing the funding for the Erasmus programme so that more Europeans can get to know the neighbouring countries. So that I am not misunderstood, I am very much in favour of young people in the EU being mobile and able to gain experience abroad. But it should be financially viable.  So, if we really get more extra money from the Council under the MFF revision, I can imagine ten better things that can be done with around EUR 1.5 billion than distributing interrail tickets. For example, strengthen the European Youth Initiative. After start-up difficulties, this has a positive effect. 70% of young people who have taken part in measures find follow-up employment, youth unemployment is falling and the programme is working. Let's make it stronger!

name: Indrek Tarand
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the 2017 budget as proposed by the co—rapporteurs is stronger, greener and more democratic. Stronger because it includes several targeted top-ups: restore the EFSI, related cuts, move forward Horizon 2020, SMEs, Erasmus, LIFE+, the Youth Employment initiative and DCI, and more to tackle the migration crisis. Greener because it includes some targeted and specific increases for sustainable programmes such as LIFE+. After the ratification of the Paris Agreement, the EU should go much beyond these increases, but it is a first step in the right direction and I thank everyone who was involved. It is more democratic because it includes a reserve in the budget of the Commission in order to force the Commission to come up with a stricter code of conduct. After both Barrosogate and Kroesgate, EU citizens cannot simply accept that ex-Commissioners are not bound by strict rules and are not accountable anymore. Colleague Geier mentioned Inter-rail and foresaw some other good uses for the money. I am obliged here to bring you the words of my honoured colleagues Rebecca Harms and Michael Cramer who think that mobility across borders is one of Europe’s biggest tangible successes. We want to ensure that all European people can equally benefit from mobility across Europe and explore Europe first hand. To this end, we are asking the Commission to issue a competition for free Inter—rail vouchers that young people can apply for in European projects. Basically, I agree with Michael Cramer that there are better ways than that of spending EUR 1.5 billion, but for youngsters to see different European corners, to travel freely to meet each other, make love, not war, that is a good idea, I think. I will skip the parts of the European Parliament’s own budget because it is a delicate matter covered by a gentlemen’s agreement which no one has ever seen and whose text no one has ever held in their hands – and I must say, Barroso was a gentleman, please don’t interrupt me. The thing is, we have here a problem of calculation of the establishment plan which we agreed to reduce, and then we have the increase in political group staff which we do not count as staff, but to whom we apply the Staff Regulations. I must say that I was warned not to stick my nose too deeply into this issue if I want to have a political career, so let it be. Let’s close my political career but I am against it. A few words about other sections. As you know, we tried to take a position, and we will vote on it, to restore the budget line on other sections. However, I witnessed very recently a presentation of the Annual Report by the Court of Auditors in Brussels in the Committee on Budgetary Control, and I was absolutely pleased to see all of the national Members of the Court of Auditors sitting there in three rows, with their only duty being to applaud after Mr Lehne’s presentation. That is not a well spent working day even though it is a very festive one, and if I see them here tomorrow, I will make a proposal to cut their budget. Thank you for giving me the floor and I will come back in the closing remarks.

name: Ivan Lesay
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it is my pleasure to attend the European Parliament’s debate on the draft budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. We have already had the occasion to exchange our views on the draft budget for 2017 on 13 September, when the Presidency had the honour to present to you the Council’s position on the draft budget proposed by the Commission. On that occasion it was underlined that the main thrust of the Council’s position was the prioritisation of EU expenditure. This means that we have to finance adequately investments to spur growth and jobs and to provide sufficient funding to tackle the still ongoing refugee, migration and security crisis. At the same time, it was the Council’s explicit wish to create sufficient margins to enable us to cope with the unforeseen situations that we will certainly have to face in the course of the next year.  I take due note of the various amendments to the Council’s position that you will probably debate today and intend to vote tomorrow. Please allow me to make just some preliminary remarks in this context. First of all, the Council is very concerned at the significant increases of appropriations proposed by Parliament, in some cases going beyond the ceilings fixed in the MFF. If we look at the details, the Council notes that substantial reinforcements are proposed for Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. These would bring us one year back, actually, to when negotiating the regulation establishing the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and this is not consistent with the agreement we reached together on this. As for the strengthening of the Youth Employment Initiative, the Council prefers not to pre—empt the Commission’s examination on the best way to give continuity to the initiative, which indeed has made good progress this year.  As you are all aware, 2017 will be the last year to reach a target of reducing the staff of all institutions and other EU bodies by 5%. I am confident that Parliament also shares the same objective and agrees that it should be reflected in the next year’s budget for every section. Overall, the difference between our respective positions totals EUR 6 billion in commitment appropriations and 4.2 billion in payment appropriations. We do need to work constructively during the conciliation procedure in order to bridge this gap. The Council is ready to stick to the calendar agreed between our institutions on the budget negotiations and to reach an agreement within the deadlines set out by the Treaty. The Council will do so in good faith and without setting any preconditions for these negotiations.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Geier and Mr Tarand, and Minister Lesay, for their opening comments. As we all know, the budget proposal for 2017 was tabled back in June. It is a disciplined proposal focused on the two priorities that are defining the parameters of what we do: jobs, growth and investment, and migration, refugees and security. I want to thank Parliament and the Council for aligning with the Commission’s proposal on the package of measures for migration and security. I would also like to welcome the amendments proposed by the Committee on Budgets to restore the cuts made by the Council in the readings. I hope that this will give us a chance to make progress in the negotiations to have the funding that is necessary. I also want to recognise that, on a number of items, the Parliament has gone further than the Commission’s proposal – to reinforce appropriations to promote jobs and growth and also actions in the external domain. This lifts us up above the ceilings and, from the perspective of the Commission, it would be important to address these amendments in the executability letter so that, ahead of the vote, we can make a sound judgment on how far it is practically possible to go.  I want to say a couple of words about Amending letter number one, since this has a direct relation to the draft 2017 budget. This has three main objectives. Firstly, to apply the assessment under the mid—term review and revision for reinforcement of some spending programs under Heading 1a. These are successful programmes. They contribute, in our view, to more dynamism in our economy, and the amount proposed is EUR 200 million plus EUR 500 million for the Youth Employment Initiative to be integrated in the course of the year. Secondly, to step up action on the external front to address the root causes of migration, and here we have EUR 750 million to support the partnership framework process – these are the so-called compacts – and EUR 250 million to provision the European Fund for Sustainable Development. We also, on the internal front, have proposed some adjustments in increased staffing for the European Counter Terrorism Centre within Europol. Thirdly, to update agriculture expenditure. We have announced EUR 500 million for our dairy sector. This is in addition to EUR 100 million that is already in the budget for certain fruits and vegetables. So we have these actions proposed. What would they mean? They would mean a recourse to the contingency margin for an amount of about EUR 1 billion, which would allow us to make use of the flexibility available in the current financial framework. We have in this Amending letter a great deal of convergence with the amendments that were proposed by the Parliament. I will not list them, as I am sure you have recognised where this alignment has taken place. We believe that the necessity to apply judgment on the 2017 Budget, as we also debate on a separate, formally independent, track the midterm review and revision. This necessity is very obvious when we read the Amending letter number one.  What it means for us in the Commission is to state clearly that, while these two processes are separate, we have to be sure that they go on a parallel track in time so we can complete during the conciliation period our negotiations on the 2017 Budget. Let me say just a word on payment appropriations: we provided you with the latest state of play just last week. Our best estimate is that the proposal from Parliament to restore most of the appropriations to the level of our draft budget are actually aligned with this most recent clear estimate. In conclusion, we have work to do; so we will do our part to be available to provide detailed information to answer any requests that may come from Parliament and the Council. I hope that, as we do so, Parliament would be able to agree with the 2017 Budget without reserves. That would be very helpful, so as not to hinder implementation. Finally, the clock is ticking and 16 November is approaching, so let us use this discussion productively to get a budget for our economy, for our people.

name: Neena Gill
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, I rise as the AFET rapporteur for the 2017 budget. The challenges we are facing across the globe are truly unprecedented. Whether it is about the struggle for democracy on our borders or conflict in Africa or increasing tensions in the South China Sea, these issues are closer to home than many realise, directly impacting our stability, trade relations and our jobs and growth.  No one country can tackle these on their own. So therefore I welcome that the Commission is focusing on stabilising our neighbourhood, tackling the root causes of migration in Africa and reinforcing its funding for Asia. Thank you for your presentation Commissioner. Let us not forget that these investments, if implemented with full respect for human rights, make a real difference in ensuring people have a future in their own region and managing the refugee crisis. The reason why the EU sometimes does not always make the impact is that Member States are constantly robbing Peter to pay Paul, and I would like the Presidency to take this message to Member States, that it is important that we work together to tackle many of the challenges that have been outlined.

name: Nirj Deva
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Madam President, I will speak on behalf of the Committee on Development. Less than six months ago, this House backed my proposals to establish stronger ties between the EU development community, the DCI and the private sector, legislating a revolution in development financing and one not reliant on the age-old method of simply spending more of the taxpayers’ money. At a stroke we turned 4.8 billion into 68 billion through leveraged finance with the private sector. Yet this budget, I seem to think, takes no account either of my report or of the state and aspirations of the Juncker plan. Far from encouraging public-private sector partnerships, we have chosen just to increase spending by a further 2.8 billion.  We have chosen – or it would appear that we have chosen – to ignore the manifest potential of the private sector to bridge an admittedly daunting funding gap, and to bring local expertise to our project. If the Juncker plan is to be anything but a fantasy in Mr Juncker’s head, then the Commission must embrace fully the potential of private—public partnerships and the financial potential this begets. While recognising that increases to the migration asylum budget may help migrants, it will not stop migration. Migration will only be stopped by investing in those countries and eliminating poverty, and for that we need an enormous amount of money. And knowing that the Commissioner, Vice-President Georgieva’s background is in development ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: rapporteur for the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, Commissioner, I see 2017 as a landmark year from the point of view of the European Union budget. First and foremost, it will be the year of balancing the seven-year programming period. We will be able to collect relevant data and evaluate it. We must look for real added value for European projects and, when checking, I consider it necessary to learn from any errors and shortcomings and to draw concrete consequences from them.  Secondly, this will be the year when the Brexit negotiations begin, the budget must also respond to other challenges such as the migration challenge, related cooperation with Turkey, the need for an investment recovery in Europe or the risk of a break-up of the single internal market.  In addition to these policy priorities, we must focus both the budget and its control in a balanced way on performance, added value and simplification.  The focus on budgetary performance is the main recommendation of the Committee on Budgetary Control. So let us try to see 2017 as an opportunity to show us which direction the EU budget should take in the coming years.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has only a very small part of the budget to do. However, we paid particular attention to the three supervisory authorities that we have to examine in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. It was interesting to me, as rapporteur in the ECON, that banking supervision and insurance supervision demanded more money, while the securities regulator was satisfied with the funds proposed here. I am somewhat surprised, Commissioner, that, despite repeated requests, the Commission has so far been unable to clarify how the proposed 2017 budget will be on the long-term development plan of these three authorities. I would still be grateful if we were to be presented with figures. And I would like to point out that we at the EBA must ensure that it will eventually have to leave London and that this is already taken into account in the work. This, too, should be mentioned in the budget.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, as chairman and rapporteur of the ENVI Committee, I would like to mention the importance of implementing multiannual programmes that fall under our responsibility: the Third Union Action Programme in the field of health, the environment and climate action programme, expenditure on combating climate change, also in the light of the Paris Agreement and subsequent implementation. I believe it is essential to restore the cuts made by the Council's reading and to ensure that these programmes and lines of action have adequate resources, both in terms of commitment and payment. I would also like to mention the importance of Horizon 2020 for research projects in the fields of the environment, climate and health in order to stimulate innovation and develop the green economy that is essential in terms of employment and development. Finally, I would like to stress the important role of the decentralised agencies, which are essential for the implementation of the Union's policies and programmes and for which we call for the restoration of resources, both human and financial, in order to guarantee the means necessary to achieve the objectives set by the Union's rules.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, the European Union is at risk as a result of these many crisis. The latest is the crisis in free trade. Now everyone should realise that there is a certain uncertainty behind these crises. Now we should be investing in the internal market, growth and employment. As draftsman of the IMCO opinion, I am very pleased that the Committee on Budgets has accepted many of IMCO's ideas. Firstly, we do not accept cuts in growth, as it were, in terms of basics, engines. We do not accept cuts affecting SMEs and entrepreneurship. I am also pleased that the Committee on Budgets has approved IMCO's innovative pilot projects, such as the algorithm project, the package distribution project and the Internet accessibility project. I hope that these will pass in the Council and the Commission.

name: Isabella De Monte
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the current priorities of the Union's transport policy, such as the elimination of ten-T bottlenecks and the completion of missing links, require a strengthening of the connecting mechanism for Europe within the framework of the annual budgetary procedure to compensate for the cuts decided during the negotiations on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. It deserves to emphasise the need to support EU spending on efficient infrastructure and sustainable modes of transport, while also paying attention to reducing noise. The development of rail, sea and inland waterway traffic must be promoted as an alternative to road transport, supporting the integration and interconnection of modes of transport. The role of tourism, for which a direct budget line should be introduced, should also be of fundamental importance, given the importance of this sector for small and medium-sized enterprises and for employment.

name: Derek Vaughan
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – Madam President, the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) believes that cohesion policy is still the best and most effective tool the EU has in terms of investment, so we were concerned when the Commission proposed cutting heading 1B by EUR 37.3 billion or 23.5%. The Commission argues that this is based on estimates coming from Member States, although I was surprised at those estimates because in 2017 I really believed that cohesion policy and the programmes would reach cruising speed after a very slow start.  We certainly believe that the additional EUR 199 million cut proposed by the Council is not helpful. Therefore the Committee on Regional Development would propose putting the draft budget level back as it was, as proposed by the Commission. We also feel that there is a need to monitor Member States and to help those Member States which have difficulty in reaching a decent absorption level.

name: Peter Jahr
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her On the content of our opinion. Firstly, European agricultural policy needs reliability. That is why our aim was to keep the agricultural budget stable. It is a pity that there is a sign of agreement between the European bodies. Secondly, we wanted to make an additional EUR 600 million available for the crisis package. The Commission is talking about EUR 500 million. So I could say that an agreement may be emerging here too. The third question, which is very important to us, is that the dispute is always with society. If society were to make even more demands on agriculture, such as additional requirements in greening or higher standards, then more finances would also have to be made available. Fourthly, we must fight to maintain any margins in the agricultural budget, because in the voting that is now taking place, we need the margin in order to be able to help ourselves. Thank you for your cooperation.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. – Madam President, I can explain. I was the rapporteur on the Committee on Fisheries (PECH) and, at the same time, I was the shadow for Parliament’s budget in the Committee on Budgets (BUDG). Therefore you have to give me almost two minutes. First, about the fisheries policies: the common fisheries policy is going into action, so we need a decent budget. Therefore it is very important that the fisheries budget is up and running. Then, about the parliamentary part of the budget: on 14 April we voted in this room, and everybody should have known that we were about to vote – also the Secretary-General of Parliament. But what happened? On the same day we can see in the official paper of the European Union that he is disregarding the democratic procedures of this House and going his own way. That is, of course, an old German sickness – der Wille zur Macht – so apparently he has read too much of Nietzsche in his youth. We think this is scandalous. This is not the way in which it should be done. So 14 April is not a good day for democracy; it has never been. If you check, Abraham Lincoln was shot on 14 April, and the guy who is building a Titanic bureaucracy for his own sake should remember that on 14 April the Titanic ran into an iceberg. Mr Welle: remember history.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Thank you very much for your vote. I will say two things: firstly, I wanted to express my satisfaction – after dealing with the payment arrears and after dealing with a crisis concerning Erasmus+ at the end of the culture debate, we have a reasonably good situation. There is no backlog of payments, erasmus+ has received good support as well as pilot schemes have passed nicely in the Committee on Budgets. I would like to thank you very much for this. Secondly, the first programme, the Juncker Investment Programme, did not take into account those industries that were linked to creativity. Today we can say that both the youth labour market, the creative industries, that is, the one that is in the cultural area, have been taken into account. I hope that pilot programmes will be developed and that the Erasmus+ programme, after overcoming the barrier it has overcome this year, will not have to overcome the next ones.

name: Monica Macovei
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, committee on civil liberties, justice and home affairs. Thank you, thank you. I hope that we will send a message to European citizens today and with tomorrow's vote that we are lucid, that we are responsible - especially as we are talking about their money - and that is in the context of setting priorities for 2017. We are talking about budgetary priorities. I have listened to my colleagues and, of course, everyone has an interest in various creative industries, jobs for young people, and I have these, infrastructure and so on. But we only have one pie, which is one fund of money, and we can't make it bigger no matter how much we pull it. So I think we all need to come to agreement on how we use money better and what the priorities are. There was also the need to mobilise more money for 2017 for an immediate response to the migration crisis, for the fight against terrorism, for the security of citizens. That means new funds and the reorganisation of existing funds. And here I want to say very briefly that we too need to make savings in the European institutions, including in Parliament, and demonstrate transparency for all the expenditure and for every euro we use.

name: György Schöpflin
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, the perspective of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) on the budget is overwhelmingly focused on aspects of governance, as you would expect. More support for the Europe for Citizens programme was one aspect of this. It is or should be common ground that the citizens of Europe are and feel themselves to be remote from the institutions of the EU. This is regrettable, given that the EU exercises considerable power in the citizen’s name. More information, better communication, fostering participation, are steps in the right direction.  E-government is another area that demands attention as part of the Digital Agenda. An online EU citizenship offers considerable promise in enhancing civic activism and identification, not least with regard to the younger age cohorts. So overall, the financing of these activities can generate positive outcomes in European governance.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, dear Commissioner colleagues, the Parliament’s position on the EU budget 2017 reflects two key priorities of the EPP Group. It is a budget which promotes growth and jobs through investment in innovation and infrastructure. We will only have more jobs if our economy is competitive, strong and trustworthy in the eyes of investors. At the same time, this budget will address the current migratory and security challenges that we are facing. How will we make Europe safer? How will we manage the refugees that came to Europe over the course of the past two years? And how will we stop illegal migration through, of course, making our external borders safer? No matter how pressing these new challenges are, we will not compromise on the longstanding priorities of the Union, which are jobs and growth. This is why we proposed to restore the cuts made to Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, and we expect the Council to follow suit on this. We allocate more money for students, for researchers, for youth and for SMEs through the programmes Erasmus, COSME and the European Research Centre. We are glad to see that the Commission proposes exactly this in its amending letter number one – to allocate more money to these very categories which I just mentioned. The amending letter from the Commission shows that our reading anticipates the real needs of the EU budget. If new challenges which were not anticipated in 2013 when the MMF was agreed are to be addressed, new money is needed. New priorities should be financed with new money.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr. President, as head of the other sections on behalf of the S and D group, my contributions and those of my colleagues have gone in the direction of a balanced but politically offensive budget. Budgetary resources are, in a way, the political fuel of the European Parliament. I therefore ask all my colleagues to support this approach to give the European Parliament weight in European governance. Parliament will be awakened at this price and our institution will thus play the democratic role that must be its own.  Of course, on administrative issues, reduction commitments will have to be kept, but not jeopardize the various representative institutions. I am thinking in particular of the Economic and Social Council, which oversees social issues; The Committee of the Regions, which oversees territorial issues; Court of Justice and others. Finally, security issues will indeed have to be provided with the necessary funds for the protection of both persons and property. As a member of the Committee on Budgets, I would like to remind you that the budget should not be a matter of specialists, but must be at the heart of European policies. Neglecting the budget means neglecting community policies, deserting the public sphere; it is, in the end, abandoning European citizens and the very idea of Europe. The draft 2017 budget as adopted by the Committee on Budgets, which uses all the flexibilities, including the revision of the MFF, is a budget that could suit us in the current context and must be taken into account in its entirety by the Council - and I stress this very much. If this were not the case, we would jeopardise the holders of cohesion projects, the farmers, concerned by the common agricultural policy, but also the very existence of Europe in the world, especially in view of the issue of migrants. Finally, we would not take into account the problems of employment, particularly youth employment. However, we must not lose sight of the need for new resources. We cannot put new policies in place forever without funding them. The budget cannot be a common pot in which everyone uses but which no one wants to feed.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the There are many positive areas in this draft budget. For example, it is good that we are spending more money on migration, but also on security. Nevertheless, we in the ECR Group do not agree that the budget should be increased, contrary to the proposals of the Commission and the Council. Parliament's proposals now even provide for spending limits to be exceeded in some lines, contrary to the 2013 agreements. We have made proposals for savings of more than EUR 500 million, which, unfortunately, were not approved in the Committee on Budgets. In particular, we believe that some of the funds for the EU's agreement with Turkey on the migration crisis should be re-entered into the reserves, because we must first see that this agreement is implemented in the same way as it is envisaged. That is not the case at the moment. If that is not the case, however, then we should not simply pay for these funds indefinitely, as originally envisaged. What we also need, in particular, is greater transparency for our budget. It is not right that we should make more and more financing through special funds, which will then no longer be under Parliament's control. Nor is it right that we should make financing slated to make a eur five, ten or even twenty euros out of one euro, through any leverage effect of the European Investment Bank. This does not lead to more transparency, but – on the contrary – to greater transparency. We must also ensure that the co-financing we do is genuine co-financing and that we do not have so-called 100% co-financing. That is completely inconclusive in the word in itself. Finally, we must also see that the reduction in payment methods can lead us to get back to the point of having unpaid invoices. We have more than EUR 25 billion gaps between payment obligations and means of payment. That is far too much.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I extend, above all, my congratulations to our two fellow rapporteurs, Mr Geier and Mr Tarand. Having said that, I would like to briefly explain why the ALDE Group will give its support to the European Union's draft budget for 2017. We believe that the draft before us proposes significant budgetary improvements to address the major challenges facing the European Union, which are necessary objectives.  There is a need to boost growth and investment, in particular by strengthening support for Horizon 2020, the Interconnection Mechanism in Europe and the COSME programme, which is strategic for SMEs.  It is necessary to support dairy farmers, victims of lower prices and the Russian embargo.  It is necessary to send a positive message to European youth by strongly supporting the extension of the youth employment initiative and by increasing Erasmus' resources.  It is necessary to deal effectively and humanely with the migration crisis. That is why we strongly support the strengthening of the AMIF Fund's resources and the creation of the instrument to provide emergency humanitarian aid within the Union itself. There is a need for better control of the Union's external borders. That is why we support the strengthening of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency.  More intervention is needed to address the root causes of migration flows and to sustainably stabilize peripheral regions experiencing violent convulsions.  Finally, we need to increase our vigilance to prevent and neutralize terrorist threats. That is why we support strengthening the resources allocated to the Internal Security Fund. We also call for strengthening the human and material resources available to Europol. I personally believe that, if we want to make it as effective as possible, no less than 90 additional people should be able to be hired in the course of this year.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, mo bhuíochas leis an mbeirt rapóirtéirí chomh maith. Táimíd ag glaoch ar an gComhairle éisteacht leis an méid atá á rá sa teach seo le tamall fada anois. Cé go dtuigimid na dúshláin nua, ní féidir linn neamhaird a thabhairt ar an ngéarghá lenar dtosaíochtaí a neartú; is iad sin cruthú fostaíochta agus fás, infheistíocht phoiblí, tiomantas i dtaobh chuspóirí COP 21 agus aire a thabhairt do na glúine atá romhainn.  Deirtear go minic go bhfuil an Eoraip ag druidim i dtreo atá níos sóisialaí agus níos forchéimnithí. Ach is léir nach bhfuil. Tacaím leis an bplean chun cur le COSME, taighde agus fostaíocht don aos óg. Fós deir an Chomhairle go bhfuil an t-aos óg mar thosaíocht, ach níl aon mhaoiniú curtha ar fáil acu.  Táim ag glaoch ar an gComhairle a seasamh a athrú maidir leis an EMFF a ghearradh. Tá go leor ciorruithe déanta acu ar an EMFF cheana féin, agus tá ár bpobail cois cósta ag fáil bháis agus brostóidh na ciorruithe seo lena mbás. Tuigeann gach éinne anseo gur dhíoladar ár bpobal iascaireachta mar phraghas ar bhallraíocht in AE. Ba cheart é seo a aithint, agus cúram agus tacaíocht a chur ar fáil don earnáil agus do na pobail.  Táim ag glaoch ar an gComhairle na ciorruithe seo a chealú agus gach uirlis gur féidir a úsáid le dul i ngleic leis na riachtanais éagsúla. Ba chóir do na rialtais aitheantas a thabhairt don ghá a bhaineann le hinfheistíocht phoiblí, le cruthú fostaíochta, agus le tacú lenar gcomhlachtaí beaga. Ba chóir don gComhairle dul i ngleic leis na  drochimpleachtaí atá agus a bheidh ag an mBreatimeacht. Ba chóir don gComhairle tacú leis an bpróiseas Síochána in Éirinn, agus le Comhaontú Aoine an Chéasta, atá anois faoi bhrú de dheasca an Bhreatimeachta. Is deis é seo dóibh seasamh i ndlúthpháirtíocht ar son síochána, cobhsaíochta agus forbairt eacnamaíochta.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the two rapporteurs for their work, but I have to say that, unfortunately, this year too, the European Union's budget is full of promises and good intentions, but they will not be kept, as I believe they have all too often done in the past. I do not believe and do not think that the instruments proposed against the various crises that the European Union is facing today are decisive. I am talking, for example, about the billions of euros that we are guaranteeing the failed Juncker plan or the hundreds of millions of euros that we have secured for the dictator Erdogan for a migrant agreement that has proved to say the least inefficient, not to mention the costs of the immense bureaucracy in Brussels and the European Parliament that we do not want to cut. Well, I do not believe that this is the right approach to use in the definition of the budget and the example that we must give to the citizens of Europe.

name: Stanisław Żółtek
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by When people have freedom, parents have power in their families. When people know that their future depends on themselves, that officials do not interfere in their lives, then the economy develops, children are born, and countries become rich and strong. But most Members, Commissioners and officials do not notice this. I'm not saying there are bad intentions at all – no, most want to do well. The problem is that people get dazzled as soon as they are elected or appointed, suddenly they are smart and find others too stupid to decide for themselves. That's why this huge budget and increasing the administration. That is why my and my group's budget-reducing amendments are rejected. Hence the orders, the bans, hence the demoralising aid programmes. These programs will not benefit the honest working, but only the cwani. Those who know how to fill out papers and count down power will benefit. We don't see that we're taking people away from wanting to work. We don't see that we are taking away people's desire to have children. We do not see Europe dying. In a few years there will be no European Union, only Islamic State. This budget is really just a testament to the pride and contempt for the hard-working decent people who have to pay for it.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, no wonder that nationalist movements are strengthening year after year in most Member States and will soon be not only a dominant trend but a dominant force.
