The proof is before you today: a budget based on failed policies, such as those of the famous Juncker Plan, the violent relocation and assimilation of migrants from Union countries, the submission to Turkey's blackmail and its financing, in order to drown human souls in the Aegean by promoting jihadists on European soil, the recognition of Cyprus' occupying forces as a Turkish Cypriot community and the recruitment of personnel for the benefit of the political groups here in this Parliament. , while at the same time imposing a horizontal reduction of 5% on the remaining staff. It is a budget doomed to fail and to drag the entire flimsy edifice of the Union. Unfortunately, the ones who are suffering from your wrong policies are ordinary people. To them you first say a big apology and then leave, for their own good. From then on, the nationalists will take over.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Madam Vice-President, sometimes we try to answer the question: should we give more funding to new challenges like refugees or terrorism, or to our long-term priorities? But they are not alternatives. We need to focus on both. Long-term strategy will give us tools to better tackle the challenges of today. From the point of the committee I chair, it is first of all competitiveness, growth and jobs. Secondly, innovative digitalised economy and energy security. It means, from the point of view of the budget, COSME for competitive SMEs – very important; Horizon 2020; leadership in technological progress; excellence; and the Connecting Europe Facility, digital progress and secure, affordable and clean energy. And let us underline that they are not just costs; they are our investment in the best future. So from the point of view at least of my committee, three of them are of crucial importance.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D). –
text: Four years ago, youth unemployment in Europe reached a ceiling. As socialists and democrats, we then launched a successful campaign for the Youth Employment Guarantee. In order for every young person to receive, within four months of leaving school or losing his/her job, either an opportunity and an offer of employment, or a domestic or foreign traineeship, or the possibility to train in a field necessary in the labour market or to continue further education. In my country, Slovakia, up to 86% of those who participated remained in employment even after it was completed, and we reduced youth unemployment by more than one third! In the EU, it was the millions of young people we helped in this way. Last November, at the budgetary conciliation procedure, we managed to reach an agreement in a joint declaration by the EP, the Council and the Commission that the Council would support the continuation of the project if the project was evaluated and proven to be successful. I was on the phone at the time, directly from the conciliation procedure, to my Minister for Labour: 'How much time do you need to evaluate?' "By Christmas!," he said. Europe ended up evaluating this 10 months longer than individual countries were actually able to do. Today we have the result of an evaluation – it confirmed the success of the project. In a speech in September, President Juncker expressed support for young people. Thank you, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, that you, too, are really taking a very positive approach to this and are looking for a way to implement this. Last week, the European Council also supported the strengthening of EU programmes aimed at supporting young people. I therefore believe that, in conciliation, the Council will also support the European Parliament's proposal and that the youth employment project will continue next year. After all, employment is indeed our top priority.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this budget rightly prioritises jobs, growth, migration and security, and it will also give valuable help to farmers struggling with the effects of the Russian trade ban. That is both timely, appropriate and welcome. But I voice two concerns. First, while I support this additional expenditure, we do need greater clarity in some of the objectives of some of the programmes, and we certainly need greater reassurance of value for money. Second, we are answerable to the European taxpayers for the way we spend their money. So, rather than using this additional expenditure as a reason to demand a bigger budget, we ought to be maximising the use of flexibility and redeployment.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Minister, I believe that the budget that the Commission has put on the table has been the subject of proposals from the Committee on Budgets. I would like to commend the outstanding work of our rapporteurs, Mr Geier and Mr Tarand, whom I thank and congratulate. However, let us be careful not to try to make the budget promise what it cannot afford to do. Having said that, Minister, you have the presidency of the ECOFIN Council and it has not escaped your attention that the draft budget for 2017, as presented, takes into account a revision of the multi-year financial framework. It is the first tranche of this review. How, then, is it that the review is the responsibility of another Council, that of general affairs? I would like to warn you and the Slovak Presidency against a risk, a threat of schizophrenia. It is imperative that we know the Council's position on the revision of the multi-year financial framework.  Don't get me wrong. Let us ensure that this budget is sincere and that priorities are served by appropriate means. Let us be wary, because this budgetary galaxy no longer represents anything and is illegible to our fellow citizens. This situation can no longer last, because it weakens the European Union. Minister, a mock budget would be the expression of a mock Europe. We must be preserved.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, as we know, Europe is facing an immense crisis of employment and investment, an embarrassing humanitarian crisis and an environmental crisis which is also very urgent. A situation which, in our view, requires rething the model of Europe that we want. But, for that, you need to react and you also need new air. This ambition and needs must be reflected in the end, too, in the budget of the European Union.  Faced with the proposal to cut 6.2% of payment commitments by the European Commission, Parliament proposes to cut by 5%, a proposal that is obedient to the powerful and which only dares to cut a little less and, unfortunately, bent on investing more in 'securing' than solidarity and rights, as we are seeing in the Mediterranean Sea.  And this is also a message to the European Council: we need more budgetary ambition, new fiscal figures that promote equality and new investment figures that promote employment and transition to a fairer model for all countries. Next time, let's come with the build padel racket and not the trim scissors.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, Parliament wants to reverse cuts to the EU budget and spend even more taxpayers’ money on the European Union, but this is not rocket science, this is not like national budgets where cuts mean less money spent on services that actually matter and where austerity means harming the citizens of a country. What we are actually talking about here is victimless cuts. We have a chance to cut nonsense spending. We have proposed savings of three billion euro a year across 33 amendments, not one of which would harm the citizens of Europe one iota.  Scrap the funding for pan-European political parties, scrap the funding for pan-European political foundations. Let us stop sending taxpayers’ money to Turkey to help it join the European Union. How about cutting our own pay and expenses here? Let us cut the budget for the ego trip that is the EU Jean Monnet Professors programme, and stop funding the propagandist House of History for which costs are still spiralling out of control and it has not even opened yet. We are proposing victimless cuts here but I am predicting that not one of them is going to pass.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF).
text: Every parliament in the world has a comment on the general budget every year. Depending on your political color and your degree of blindness to reality, you have a comment or two. Because the result is disappointing, or it is not quite what the intention was, or there is a better use of the money. But there is one exception in the world and that is the European Parliament. This Parliament has decided in committee that no expenditure can go down! Everything is apparently perfect, nothing is spent wrong. So don't touch it anymore! That, Mr President, is a sign of mental laziness from a Committee on Budgets that is not doing its job and of the belief that everything the EU does is well done. And, of course, a widely held idea in this House that taxpayers' money is free. Mr President, that money is not free. Ordinary people have to work hard for that... before it is taken away.  The EU is wasting money as water and recognising that is a first step. But that is a step that this Parliament does not seem to be in a way of doing.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, on 23 June the British people voted to leave the European Union. It was a decision that sent shockwaves across the world and should have sprung these institutions into action. Instead, in relation to this budget, it is a signal for just more of the same. Even though this budget will raise spending and reverse cuts, it is not sufficient for some of those in this House today that I have heard call for even more spending. The reality is that it will see hardworking families bear the pain of such decisions. There is no capacity for change. As my colleague Mr Torvalds indicated, it increases spending on administration and agencies and it cuts staff jobs only to create other jobs in new areas. However, I do find the commitment to provide new funding for victims of terrorism positive. Just for the record of this House, since Mr Torvalds did mention the Titanic in his speech, I come from the constituency and represent the town that actually built the Titanic ship. It was a fine and noble idea to build the largest, most luxurious liner in the world and it was fine when it left Belfast, but it was poor guidance and lack of awareness that saw it hit an iceberg and sink with such disastrous consequences.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, next year's budget has an additional task: to restore confidence. And that means recovering the huge delay in payments, the huge delay that exists in the implementation, rather, of the multiannual financial framework. It should be noted that amending budget 4 returns EUR 7 300 million to Member States, but commitments are still there and this amount must be returned later to the Eu budget. This means that we need flexibility, this also means that special instruments, and the name "special" indicates this, have to be accounted for outside and above the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework.  This is a logical understanding and the unique and possible understanding, the legal understanding that the Council should also follow. This is clear that the 2017 budget proposal involves revising the multiannual financial framework. And we cannot waste a single euro, nor can we waste more time. And it is not acceptable that the Council is not yet ready to begin the discussion of the multiannual financial framework and its review, nor is it ready to start work with Parliament on amending letter 1, i.e. to begin with the negotiation of the 2017 Budget.  We want growth, we want jobs, we want solidarity and for that we need a budget that respects the commitments that have been made. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, you mentioned in fact the very important necessity to use the existing flexibility instruments under the current MFF, and I am asking you, do you not think that we should have even looked for a revision of the MFF in order to make the European Parliament priorities more clear?

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. "Thank you so much for the question. It is clear that the proposal we have on the table from the Commission is extremely positive. It is an important starting point for the revision of the multiannual financial framework precisely in order to seek more flexibility, so that we can fulfil what the Council has already approved and so often proclaims, so that concrete actions for employment, solidarity, so that COSME can move forward, so that research moves forward, to help young people in their first employment. , to help small and medium-sized enterprises, farmers and so that none of the amounts that were available are lost.  We cannot waste a single euro and to do so we need flexibility in the financial framework, and to do so we need to review the multiannual financial framework.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking Mr Geier immediately for the work, the committee and the Commissioner who allow us, through their work, the rapporteur and the Commission, to vote tomorrow on a good budget that recovers funds on Horizon 2020 and therefore for our companies, for our businesses, for our universities and for research bodies. , public administrations, recover funds on youth employment, recover funds, go to the top of the budget itself, on the subject of immigration and migrants, recover, in spite of everything, the money also for humanitarian aid, cooperation and development. In short, we did our utmost, the rapporteur and the committee did their utmost with what they had, with what was available. As we have heard, as we have seen, however, what was there and the resources that are there were not enough.  We're running the paper. That's the problem. We risk managing everyday life and having no prospects, no vision, no scenario. In fact, in this House, between the Commission and Parliament, perspectives, scenarios and visions are there and are intended to keep the debate on the 2017 budget together with the revision of the multiannual financial framework. So go until 2020. My question, the question I am asking, is whether the Council is ready, whether the Heads of State or Government are prepared to face together with us not only the daily newspaper, but a broader scenario. I would say that we are not condominium administrators who have to decide on the costs of annual heating, we have a little higher task, we are trying to renovate this building that is Europe, from the foundations. So is the Council going to do this hard work with us or not to give new prospects, particularly to the younger generation?

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Speaking in the debate on the 2017 budget on behalf of the Polish delegation in the ECR, I would like to support the position of Parliament's Committee on Budgets on the need to reverse the cuts made by the Council, and calling for an increase of more than EUR 4 billion in commitments and payments of almost two billion euros compared to the Commission's proposal. In our opinion, the resources for Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe, previously reduced in connection with the financing of the so-called Juncker Plan, should be rebuilt, additional funding should be provided to increase funding for young people, including Erasmus+, to finance job creation and growth, to significantly increase funding for migration, asylum and security measures, and finally to allocate additional funds to the package of emergency measures in the dairy sector. We also support the inclusion of the negotiations on the 2017 budget in the context of the ongoing revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework, as this means a budgetary debate taking into account the broader challenges facing the European Union.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are once again present in a budget that is completely out of place with the reality and real needs of the European Union. In a European Union in an increasingly unequal crisis, high rates of poverty and unemployment persist, we have a short budget, deeply shaken in its distributive aspect and increasingly tied to the aggressive and militaristic course of the European Union's foreign policy.  It is therefore important to strengthen this budget, but that is not enough. It is necessary to put this budget at the service of development and social and territorial cohesion and to strengthen the special instruments aimed, it should be said, to remedy the mistakes of our foreign policy, which are at the root of the Russian embargo or the refugee crisis. Unfortunately, this proposal does not point in this direction. Rather, it goes towards the continuity of previous budgets, all of which are conditioned by a short multi-annual framework and at the service of the neoliberal policies of the European Union and its security drift.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if I had a magic handset like in a well-known Czech children's fairy tale, I would not hesitate to call for the abolition of the vast majority of expenditure in the European Union budget, because I consider it wasted or unnecessary. When I talk to farmers, they say: we do not want subsidies, we just need no one to have them, and we will be able to compete in fair competition with our agricultural products. Why should we have regional subsidies? Take a look at the competing organisation of the European Free Trade Association. They are countries of different economic levels, they also have remote regions. Do you think they need something like regional, cohesion or structural subsidies? Need.  But I am aware that I do not have a magic button or handset, that most of you will probably see it differently in that vote, so our group is putting forward at least a certain minimum that I think you might at least think about. Why should we give money to promote monetary union and the euro? Everyone knows what the euro is and how it is doing or not doing well. We propose to abolish these expenditures, we propose to abolish the expenditure on guarantees in the Fund for Strategic Investments, companies have to decide for themselves whether to invest, not the European Parliament and so on.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF).
text: Mr President, the draft budget you are submitting to us is not lacking in paradoxes.  You want to increase the effort towards youth employment, but it is precisely your policies that make the euro area the highest rate of youth unemployment in the world.  You want to help the agricultural sector, but it is precisely your policies, between the end of milk quotas and unbridled competition, that cause a farmer to commit suicide every two days in France.  You also want to put some rubbish on the migration disaster that you have caused by leaving open the borders of Europe. We even note that you are pushing the vice to the point of providing a budget for the integration of migrants when they, we were told, were not intended to stay with us.  Finally, the embryo of a European defence is sketched. However, this latest attack on the most fundamental element of a state's sovereignty is never just the last jolt of a dying institution. The European Union is dying. Long live France!  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Madam Montel, you said the budget is full of paradoxes. Can you explain me something? You made about 200 amendments to reduce the paradoxes, but as we in the Budget Committee voted for them, you left the Committee. So you didn’t care – or do you?

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. Sir, the meeting of the Committee on Budgets, which I attended yesterday, went on and on because you thought it appropriate to have a meeting of the coordinators in the middle of a vote. Excuse me, I had urgent appointments, so I was not able to attend the vote on my amendments.  However, I will continue to produce amendments to reduce the inconsistent spending you make in this budget.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, firstly, I want to thank the rapporteurs for their excellent work and Madam Vice-President for her constructive role. But I will donate my speaking time to the Council.  I have to say in all honesty that the Member States’ attitude towards the European Union’s budget is unsustainable during the times in which we are living. While the migration crisis, weak economic growth and the unpredictable security situation require concrete action, the Council is acting as if the world had never changed. It wants to cut next year’s budget without giving much strategic consideration to our priorities and this simply does not make sense, especially now when money is tighter than ever before.  Budget negotiations should be seen as an opportunity to discuss what the EU really wants to achieve, to think about measurable goals and provide resources to achieve them. Our current situation needs therefore funding and cooperation, particularly in three areas. Jobs and growth cannot be achieved without research, development and innovation funding. The migration crisis is a reality, we simply have to deal with it and solve it. And thirdly defence – we have to start thinking seriously about it now, and the 25 million is just the beginning.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The draft budget, which includes a 2.6% increase in commitments and a 1.4% increase in payments compared to the previous project, is a bad solution for Eu citizens. The budgetary discipline to be applyes and applies to individual Member States does not apply to the Union budget. The question is , why? Why are we not looking for savings in bureaucracy expenditure, in the current expenditure on the functioning of the two houses of Parliament, the agencies of the European Union, the European Parliament in different places, the costs associated with the various missions of the Staff of the European Parliament? I would also be happy to take a closer look at the representative costs of the President of the European Parliament. In the context of the recent report by the European Court of Auditors, which mentions the mis spending of part of the budget, I would like to express my hope that the ECA's comments will be taken into account in the next budgets.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the So Mr Geier has had enough, he let us know today at the beginning of the debate. The rapporteur is fed up with the fact that the Member States keep whining when they are to put more and more money into the Union's budget. Mr Geier, do you know who can have enough? In Europe, the people who pay for this waste of money here can have enough. Enough can be done by the people who work outside every day, pay taxes and pay all that. And you may not know, but in the budgets of the individual Member States – I can speak of Austria, both in the federal and the national budget – every penny has to be turned over three times in order for a budget to be achieved at all. And you are allowing yourself to ask for more and more money in this 2017 budget, which is intended to meet the needs of migration and the lack of economic growth. What does "the needs of migration" mean? Is this the Commission's resettlement policy, which promises EUR 10 000 for every resettled person, that is, every refugee? Do you think that we are going to fight smuggling, Mr Geier? Lack of economic growth: Why not focus on the continent instead of negotiating gag contracts like TTIP and Ceta? Why don't we do that? Efficient use of funds would be the right word. We are fed up with the waste of money. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jens Geier (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Mayer, can it be that you were not present at the beginning of the debate? I have pointed out that the approach of the governments of the Member States towards the budget is contradictory, that the finance ministers are arguing that we are spending too much money here, while other ministers – in Germany, for example.B for development aid, for agricultural policy and some others – keep demanding more of this budget without the necessary resources being followed. I believe that you have adopted an approach typical of your group: to pick out a quote, to polemicise, but not to listen.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank the I do not quite know where the question was. Nevertheless, I will try to respond to what Mr Geier has said here. Mr Geier, I know this argument – from Mr Schulz, the President, also from home – as we all know. In the end, Mr Geier, you and the rest, on the other hand, are upset that this Union has too little resources. Where is efficiency? Each Member State must act efficiently with the means, must act economically with the means that people make available. We are not even thinking about this here – in this House or in the context of the Commission. I repeat: ten thousand euros of resettlement for everyone who settles in Europe, instead of pulling the problem on the right side.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, at a time when populism and nihilism really prevail, even for the European Union itself, we must give credit and congratulations to the two rapporteurs and the Vice-President of the European Commission, Mrs Georgieva, for the truly excellent work, but also hard work to make the budget a growth budget, an employment budget. All of us, and we have proved this in the European Parliament, want a budget that responds to new jobs, to young people, to those actions that have to do with research, with innovation, that really bring Europe forward. We want a budget that responds to a more social and humane Europe. We also want there to be, Madam Vice-President, a real campaign and a strong effort to abolish red tape. Bureaucracy is currently also affecting the European Union budget, but it is particularly affecting citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises and the system itself. Too many millions are lost on the altar of bureaucracy, as are the hopes and dreams of many people. It is this European Union, which many blame from morning to night, that has implemented the revolutionary measure of the youth card for In interail. And I believe that it can go one step further and implement the card for free Wi-Fi, with which young people can also enjoy this right. I would like to stress that for small and isolated countries and isolated areas which are at an unfavourable and disadvantage compared to all other countries, such as my own country Cyprus, there must be special provision, special support and special support because their businesses and people, but also the countries themselves are disadvantaged compared to others which are in more central places. I support this budget effort, because it responds to the hopes and dreams, especially of young people, because there has been an increase for youth employment, for youth actions, for Erasmus+, for the world and for all that really gives impetus to a growth and employment budget, to a budget for social and human Europe.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – A budget is a summary of political choices. When I look at this budget, I see that 2.7% is spent on security and citizenship and 6.2% on Europe and the world. Together, that's less than 9 percent. Less than 9% of the total European budget goes to themes that should be the priority of today and tomorrow! How do we deal with the security crisis? How do we get the migration crisis under control? How do we ensure that people feel and feel protected in this European Union again? I note that very few European pennies go to this, at least not enough. I would therefore call on this Parliament to focus more on the priorities that are really important and with which we can really make a difference. Unfortunately, I find that here it is often, or sometimes, lacking the will and the strength to choose change.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Minister: let me make one point. You brought back the backlog from EUR 25 billion to some EUR 3.9 billion now. That is an enormous success, but my reflection today is that solving is one thing, but prevention is another. This is what brought us in the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) to an initiative to look deeper now, because now we have the first results of the partnership agreements and the new programme and we can see exactly what will happen in 2018, 2019 and 2020. We cannot go back to the Member States and say that they have to pay more money in later years. Now you are getting money back from the decommitments, and the net payers book in this money. So getting interest from our citizens needs a sustainable approach, and that is why a resolution is now being prepared in the Committee on Regional Development which will be brought to the plenary at the end of this year or the beginning next year. I would like to invite the Commissioner to come and debate in depth what is really happening. It is a late start, but the programmes will be there and the bills will be there. I thank you very much if you want to accept this invitation for this investment policy – one third of the EU budget: cohesion.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to express my sincere thanks to my fellow Members for the package that we have put together, which, I believe, brings optimism back to our future. What the European Union needs is again confidence, hope and policies that will take us forward. Of course, the issue of growth and employment is a priority for us. If we take the fact that we have now put the Horizon 2020 programme at the centre of the Horizon 2020 programme with EUR 10.6 billion for research and innovation, we see that we are currently reflecting the real world in the virtual world. Here it is necessary for the next generation to learn to deal with coding and algorithms and new possibilities. From this point of view, I very much welcome the fact that an absolute focus has been placed here. As with the Erasmus+ programme, where we have succeeded in applying the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs, i.e. for self-employment, for small and medium-sized enterprises, not only in Europe, but also beyond the borders of Europe – to the growth areas – so that our young people can learn how to create jobs and generate growth accordingly. The last and most important point for me is actually: Connecting Europe Facility. We simply need 5G preparation by 2018. We need fibre rollout and we need frequency harmonisation.  This can happen with this budget. I congratulate the Slovak Presidency when it enters into negotiations with us. Together we shape the future. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I just wanted to ask Mr Rübig, as he mentioned the importance of coding and digital skills, how important that is for our citizens? I wonder if he would like to expand about the importance of EU code week that happened last week and how many of us in this Chamber took part in that, promoting digital skills and coding skills, the skills of just now and for our future?

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, thank you Mrs Stihler, I think that is exactly what we want – the coding week – but we have to do more in this area. So in this package which we have now on the table, we also have the science / media app, and I think we should come together with the young people and learn together with them – with young journalists, with opinion leaders, how to get the right framework for the next future. I think it should start immediately, and I thank you very much for supporting this activity.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – We have a draft budget that, despite limited resources, covers all political priorities in a balanced way and ensures synergies between the different areas. The first is investment for jobs through the EFSI, which is already delivering the first good results, and through the Youth Employment Initiative. The second is to tackle the migrant crisis and ensure security, such as €7.5 million of additional funding for Europol and a €25 million pilot project to improve defence research capabilities and cooperation between members. It is an important project with synergy effects in the field of defence and research.  And third more funding for knowledge in Horizon 2020. That the European Union will be innovative and competitive in the long term. So we have a draft budget for the challenges of the present and the future. It's about restoring trust in people.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the 2017 budget includes, through the European Commission's amending letter, an additional budget for a package of aid for the dairy sector in Europe. It is a small step towards rebalancing the milk market, but we cannot stand by the palliatives. Milk producers have been lowered in price below the threshold for production costs, which has been exacerbated by the end of milk quotas and the Russian embargo. Effective measures are urgent ly needed to prevent and mitigate the increasing price volatility of the dairy sector and to enable producers to ensure the viability of production by paying a fair ly remunerative price for the activity. Acting on this matter is so much more important if we are to avoid corrupting the basis of the social and economic fabric in rural areas, such as the mountain areas and the outermost region of the Azores, with a dominant presence of milk production and where alternative economic activities are scarce.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, it is certain that the European Union budget for 2017 must meet the needs of the economic and refugee crisis. In practice, the budget provides for appropriations of EUR 1.5 billion for the youth employment initiative and appropriations of EUR 5.2 billion to deal with the refugee crisis. But, Mrs Georgieva, you know that, the problems are insurmountable and these amounts are crumbs in the face of the real needs that exist.  Take, for example, the refugee crisis. We have enormous refugee pressures. Take, for example, Greece. There are over 60,000 stranded refugees and illegal immigrants in Greece. Greece as a state has so far spent 2.5 billion euros. The sums given by the European Union are not enough. There needs to be an increase in funds.  Take the issue of growth and unemployment, the issues of the South. Employment must be strengthened. There are armies of unemployed throughout the European South and in Greece. You understand that there needs to be an increase in funds and, in particular, there needs to be a change of strategy, an end to the policy of austerity and, above all, an end to this violent fiscal adjustment.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Minister. I sincerely doubt whether I prefer the Council's absent silence in the debate on the financial framework to not almost everything you transfer to us. As Mrs Georgieva said, the multiannual financial framework and the 2017 budget must move forward in parallel and as good parallel lines must end up converging. But not in infinity, this year, in a month. 156 billion at Council reading, 162 000 at Parliament's reading. 6 billion euros. Less than 0.1% of total European public expenditure (European Union and Member States). Less than 0.1%. Are you convinced that the current economic situation, the refugee crisis, security, meeting the objectives, climate change or the 2020 European Strategy do not deserve this 0.1%? Do you really think this? Don't you need this 0.1%? Of course, they need this and much more, but at least this for sure. With the European Parliament's proposal we are at the lowest acceptable, and we are not going to give that up. Horizon 2020 and COSME and the MEC must be recovered. The Youth Empelo Initiative must be continued. The 2017 budget must be the first of the new European hope, not confirmation of frustration accumulated over the years.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is pleasant to hear general approval for what has been proposed here for the 2017 budget and rightly so, I think, especially homing in on areas that will make a big difference to people’s lives and promote jobs and growth, such as the Connecting Europe Facility, Erasmus+, Horizon 2020, which is vital of course, Cosme and indeed also, as mentioned just recently, coding and digital skills. I joined those hosting CoderDojo, a group of young people volunteering around Europe who are developing those necessary skills and that obviously is something that is going to be hugely beneficial as we become more digitised as a society.  One other point I would make though. All the good work that the European Union does is often not recognised where it matters most: among citizens. So maybe if we had a line there to counteract populism and promote what the European Union is actually doing, so that citizens will get the real picture and appreciate it, this would be a good idea.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 2017 budget must reflect and support priorities such as reviving investment, in particular for innovation, growth and employment, pursuing the structural reforms necessary to modernise the European economy, conducting responsible policies, increasing competitiveness and promoting the growth of small and medium-sized enterprises. The Union is now facing unpredictable emergencies and challenges when drawing up the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. Additional appropriations must therefore be secured. The 2017 budget must meet, for example, the needs linked to the migration challenge and the slow growth of the economy due to the economic crisis. The persistence of high levels of youth unemployment is worrying, for which effective and concrete responses must be developed, and it is only a first step to increase the budget of the Youth Employment Initiative, IOG, in order to allow the initiative to continue and accelerate.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: Mr. President, I welcome the Commissioner and the Council representatives. The proposed changes in the European budget for 2017 are very good and really show that the budget can and must be flexible and I congratulate you Commissioners on this, because despite the very limited resources you have managed to put nevertheless and show how much we can respond to the challenges that await us in 2017.  Security has been put at the forefront, a significant acceleration of investment in preventing the causes of the migrant crisis is being achieved and that is why payments have increased by as much as 25.1%. The amounts have also increased, we have heard from our erasmus+ colleagues, COSME, for the new European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is of course important for boosting competitiveness, youth employment and everything else.  Personally, and many of my colleagues who spoke today, I am concerned about the proposed 23.5% reduction in cohesion policy payments. There's nothing we can do about it. These are projects in which we must invest immediately and we must do everything to accelerate their implementation in practice because they guarantee employment, growth and development.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, allow me to make four points in closure from the side of the Commission. First, what I heard is broadly support for the priorities of the budget and clarity that we do need to stick to priorities to use money where it would matter the most. I can pledge that this is exactly what we intend to do. Secondly, a concern expressed – and actually it came with the very last speaker as well – that what we see in budget 2017 in terms of speed of implementation of the new programmes is not going to be a satisfactory outcome unless actions are taken early. I agree very much that prevention is better than cure – much better to act early. I would be happy to come and engage in a debate. I can tell you that in the Commission we are spending quite a lot of time to see what more we can do to unleash the implementation of some programmes, working with Member States. We are very keen to see that especially those programmes where there is direct likely impact on jobs and growth are given a strong focus. Thirdly, we are very mindful of the necessity to demonstrate impact and results. There was a mention of 86% of people getting into and staying in jobs in Slovakia. That is exactly what we concentrate on, and this is what the whole point of the budget focus on results is, and that is certainly having a transformative impact in the way we work. Last but not least, we are very open to be critical of how we work, and this is why the focus on, for example, revision of the financial regulation, simplification, cutting red tape, making the budget more transparent – this is why we are so engaged with that. We are also constantly working on modernising the administration. For example, we carried out the synergies and efficiencies review that allowed us to identify over 600 posts in the Commission that, with a better organisation of work, can be then dedicated to top priorities and still meet our goal of 5% staff reduction completed by 2017. Of course – sorry, I’ve run over time. I will stop right here with the hope that we will be able to deliver budget 2017 as scheduled on 16 November or 17 November in the morning at the latest.

name: Ivan Lesay
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you, honourable Members of the European Parliament, for all the comments made. I will try to quickly take at least some of them. First of all, I will say a few words on the treatment of the mid—term review or revision of the multiannual financial framework in the context of the negotiations related to the annual budget procedure. First of all, I would like to stress that the multiannual financial framework on the one hand, and the annual budget procedure of the EU on the other hand, are governed by different Treaty articles, establishing notably different decision-making processes. The Council is fully aware that, pursuant to Article 312 of the Treaty, the consent of Parliament is required before any modification of the MFF regulation. Concerning the review or revision of the MFF, the Council is diligently examining the various Commission proposals, and as far as the annual budgetary procedure is concerned – this being the file I am tasked to conduct – the Council is currently examining, besides the amendments of Parliament to the position of the Council, amending letter No 1 to the draft budget for 2017, adopted by the Commission last week. The Council will certainly have a position on all these various elements during the forthcoming conciliation procedure. The Council is aware that Parliament wishes to reach an agreement on the review or revision of the MFF before concluding the negotiations on the draft budget for 2017, and the Council is for keeping these two procedures separate. We should avoid any linkages that could render timely agreement of the draft budget for 2017 more difficult. The second point I would like to make is on the amending letter. This was only presented by the Commission on Monday 17 October. The Council preparatory bodies are currently analysing the proposal in detail, but at the current stage there is no political agreement on it. The Presidency will endeavour to get a position on this letter of amendment before the first conciliation meeting with Parliament. Having analysed the mood of Member States on the letter of amendment, it is very likely that the Council will strongly distinguish between its regular components on the one hand, which address, for instance, Heading 2, and on the other hand, top-ups for 2017. These can be materialised only once we have a deal on the MFF mid—term review or revision. The Council is of the view that we cannot prejudge the outcome of the MFF mid—term review or revision, and thus top—ups stemming from MFF revision could be addressed through a draft amending budget once there is a legal basis for additional appropriations. By way of conclusion – I am running out of time – we have been listening carefully to the arguments raised during this debate, and I will inform my colleagues in the Council accordingly. The debate has certainly helped clarify the European Parliament’s position and the issues that are the most important to you. The Council will do its utmost in order to engage in fruitful negotiations, allowing us to come to an agreement on the 2017 Budget and all open budgetary questions within the deadlines foreseen by the Treaty. Finally, let me stress that for the Council, the 2017 EU budget negotiations and the mid—term review or revision of the MFF are two different exercises which should be dealt with separately. As far as the mid—term review or revision of the MFF is concerned, the negotiations in the Council are held by the General Affairs Council.

name: Jens Geier
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank all my fellow Members who have had constructive discussions on the European Union budget. Above all, I would like to thank the Members who have supported the approach I have taken as general rapporteur. I would like to return to a point which, I believe, has played a somewhat too little role in the debate. Colleagues from the Committee on Foreign Affairs and Development have mentioned it, and I will come back to this. One priority was a little too short in the debate. That is the question: how do we combat the refugee crisis? In this context, I very much welcome the amendment proposed by the Commission. Mrs Georgieva, I believe that this amendment contains a great many positive approaches and that important instruments of foreign and development policy have been strengthened. However, I would like to make it quite clear once again that what is not possible is that two important instruments of the EU's foreign and development policy are negligible as a matter of this amendment. The one thing that is particularly close to our hearts is the UN Refugee Agency for the Palestinians. In other words, we have called for a significant increase in this; the Commission's amendment does not take this into account.  I believe it is important that we also look at the situation of the Palestinian refugees in their camps, because if the children there can no longer be educated, these people will lose their perspective and will head towards Europe. This is a situation that we want to avoid. That is why we believe that strengthening UNRWA is essential. This also applies comparatively to humanitarian aid. So, as Commissioner, you are also responsible for this. I know that this is close to your heart. I am very concerned that if we limit the EU's humanitarian aid resources to the emergency reserve that already exists, we will actually cut ourselves off in terms of humanitarian aid. In this house, the European Parliament will certainly not give in to supporting its request. We are ready for the negotiations. Let's talk!

name: Indrek Tarand
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, thanks to everyone who has been participating in this debate which has perhaps been very critical and that is why I would like to conclude with two more optimistic remarks. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Slovak Presidency, which has taken a huge step towards understanding the complicated nexus between revision of the MFF and the 2017 budget. A week ago we were not that far advanced; now we are. Of course I agree that these are parallel processes but each railway has two parallel rails, otherwise the train cannot be driven on them.  Secondly, there is some good news I read in the Politico newspaper, where they say the parliament budgetary authorities are doing the right thing: hitting former Commissioners where it hurts, in the pocketbook. I am sorry, really, that it took so long and the involvement of bigwigs like Barroso and others to take us that far because I have for more than two years now been dealing with Mr Kallas’s breaches – minor breaches – of the code of conduct: being a former Commisioner, being a special advisor to Commissioner Dombrovskis and being the lobbyist of a software company – all simultaneously. Of course, who would know better than he, because he was proud of presenting the transparent lobby register many years ago and, as an author, he obviously knows where the loopholes, the dark shades and all those areas are.  That is why I am absolutely confident that putting this money to reserve encourages the Commission, and Vice-President Georgieva is definitely made of different material from the above-mentioned. But you should look at it like the space programme. There are hundreds of useless satellites travelling around the Earth, many of them not functioning, many of them not taking signals anymore. So let us bring them down. That is the aim of a budget.

name: Bas Belder (ECR)
text: Written. – The EU budget will again be higher in 2017 than in previous years. This time it rises by 4.4%. The institutions rely on new priorities, including the economy to be boosted by public spending, cunningly characterised as investment. In addition, the migration crisis, which understandably requires sufficient resources, is coming. However, prioritisation does not automatically lead to a higher budget? Is it not in reason to reduce non-priority expenditure? The European Court of Auditors called for this thematic concentration. We find very little of that in the budget. The European Commission, like most EU institutions, has been working on the agreed staff reduction of 1% per year. The European Parliament pretends to abide by it, but makes an exception for different categories of staff that are growing in size. The fact that the 3.4% increase in the budget is obscured by the veiled use of language in the resolution does not give a good picture of how the majority thinks it can package it. Unfortunately, such tricks give the impression that the EU institutions are not prepared to make reforms that citizens recognise themselves in. Something the British have undoubtedly encountered over the past year. The Union must not confirm the image that it is unreformable if it is to be prepared for the future.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D)
text: Writing. I am pleased that the 2017 budget has increased the budget for humanitarian aid and migration. I consider it particularly good that a total of 4% of the humanitarian aid funds have already been spent in education in crisis regions and refugee camps in 2016. This was once a demand of the European S&D Group, which we maintain. Only in this way can we prevent a lost generation that otherwise has no prospect of training or work. Education is the key against radicalisation. That is why I call for the 4% to be at least respected and increased in 2017. I also call on the Member States to immediately recommit themselves to the target of 0.7% of GNI for official development assistance and to present a timetable for gradually increasing the funds so that the 0.7% can be achieved by 2030 at the latest. If we use funds for development cooperation quickly and efficiently, while not undermining existing long-term programmes, we will make a significant contribution to reducing poverty in the least developed countries. The money must not, of course, go into the hands of the dictators, but must benefit hospitals, schools and non-governmental organisations on the ground.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework must not jeopardise the credibility of the European Union and must strike the necessary balance between achieving the Union's long-term political priorities and responding to new challenges. I believe that the Union budget must also find ways to finance new initiatives, without affecting the ongoing programmes. Some pilot projects in the areas of research and the common security and defence policy need additional funding. Sustainable funding is needed for the implementation of European space policy and the putting into use of galileo and Copernicus satellites in order to be able to provide services as soon as possible. There is also a need to take full account of the Commission's analysis of the start-up of pilot projects on innovative space technologies (deorbiting and innovative materials in the space sector) and the feasibility of a space joint venture. This new joint venture would contribute to the development of revolutionary technologies for the next generations of satellites, as well as satellite infrastructure in general, and therefore to a clear outline of the future European space strategy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EU budget needs to be more flexible in order to be able to respond promptly to challenges such as high youth unemployment, the refugee crisis, terrorism or the agriculture crisis. Fortunately, the Cohesion Fund is not affected and, by implication, neither is the European funds available to Romania. The only condition is that Romania also access this money, as, for the time being, the national authorities are taking the plunge, which has serious consequences for our economy. I am pleased that, as part of next year's budget, EUR 3 million is also foreseen for two pilot projects, which we have started, aimed at the development of the digital sector and the modernisation of the industry: the Digital Hubs Network and the Digital Transformation of European Industry. The digital sector is the main pillar for the future economic development of the EU, but also of Romania. The projects initiated by me are intended to support this area and I believe that they can lead to the efficiency of European industry, as well as to the development of start-ups and digital hubs. Despite the high potential in this sector, Romania and Eastern Europe in general are in a gap with western Europe that can be reduced by implementing these projects.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. – In recent weeks, more than 62 000 people have signed the "EU: Don't invest in weapons" petition against subsidies for a European military research programme, the so-called preparatory action on defence research. The European Greens will indeed vote against money for this programme tomorrow in the vote on the 2017 budget. It is not known which projects will be subsidised. Who will get the property rights is also unbeknownst to you. These crucial decisions will not be taken until the European Parliament has given its approval. Moreover, subsidies for the arms industry do not lead to greater security. European Member States accounted for 28% of the world's arms exports in the period 2014-2015, according to SIPRI figures. These weapons perpetuate bloody conflicts in countries such as Yemen and Syria and create insecurity worldwide. I therefore call on colleagues to vote against this subsidy programme for the arms industry and therefore in favour of Amendments 974 and 975 of Item 02 04 77 03.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Alfred Santa, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementing the priorities for 2016 (2016/2102(INI)) (A8-0309/2016).

name: Alfred Sant
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, may I start by thanking the shadow rapporteurs, assistants and all staff involved in the preparation of this draft report for the very good work. Even when they disagreed with the compromises reached, they all made extremely valid contributions to the work at hand. The draft report presents the latest reflection on the state of European economies from the perspective of the European Commission’s recommendations to Member States on how to run their national economic systems so as to deliver growth and stability. During the last two years, the Commission streamlined its recommendations in parts by making them leaner and more focused. The change in approach was commendable. The aim here has been to follow up on it by concentrating on a few themes rather than to stretch over the whole width of policy concerns that the European semester covers. For, with a few exceptions, the state of the European economy still remains less than satisfactory. While growth has now emerged, it remains uneven and sluggish, even as doubts persist about European competitiveness. While unemployment is retreating overall and new jobs are being created, the situation on the jobs market remains bleak, not least for young people. While the pessimism about the future that was prevalent a few years ago has retreated, investment still is at historically low levels. The draft report considers this last concern as critical to the situation that we face. No matter what policies are adopted, if the investment that is generated remains insufficient, economic performance will lag on all fronts. For this reason we have concentrated in this report on investment issues. It is true that on many areas of economic management, we have among us divergent views, but at the level of a desire to encourage greater investment in Europe, we all share a commitment to make this happen. The situation as of now is that there is a very significant shortfall in investment, both public and private, compared to what were used to in the not so distant past. To be sure, this investments debt is not happening just in Europe, but across the capitalist world. Still, it is of interest to us all to reflect about what can be done to reverse the trend. Now personally I acknowledge the intellectual validity of arguments made by those who believe that current European governance structures, especially at the level of the eurozone, are sub-optimal. In and of themselves they serve to inhibit investment. So long as they prevail it is illusory to believe that significant long-term investment can be generated, so such arguments go. Nevertheless, the reality is that with the same existing governance structures, the European system has succeeded in the past to generate much higher levels of investment than at present. There is every reason, therefore, to seek to attain at least those past investment levels since experience shows they are attainable. We have therefore sought to highlight those Commission recommendations, as well as the Commission’s own initiatives, that focus on investment issues; there are quite a number. Naturally, within the boundary conditions for our discussions, these issues have to be framed coherently, with adherence to the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, such as budgetary discipline, implemented with the appropriate flexibility that the same rules allow. Meanwhile, the need for ongoing structural reforms has to be underlined, on the understanding that such reforms must be sustainable and socially fair. Beyond these considerations the need remains to show support for all growth-centred proposals that will increase the propensity to invest across the Union as a whole. Among others there are: proposals relating to access to equity and bank lending; to research and innovation; to education and training; to the promotion of SMEs; to EFSI and other funds that mobilise capital for new investment with a renewed structure aiming for a complete regional outreach of such funding; and on such lines also, the concept of green investment with environmental protection at its core.  However, one cannot avoid making a remark that has become almost ritualistic in Parliament reports on the Commission’s country-specific recommendations, which is that these recommendations will remain less than effective if governments and stakeholders in the respective national economies do not feel committed to them – if they do not own them as the jargon goes. On this point, the draft report emphasises that in order to arrive at such a sense of ownership, sub—national and regional authorities should be brought fully into the process by which country-specific recommendations are envisaged. On the ground, these bodies are now responsible for 60% of public investment proposals. They also have an extensive interface with private investment across a wide range of economic sectors. I will surely be most interested, Mr President, to hear the views of all colleagues on the challenge of using investment that Europe faces.

name: Sofia Ribeiro
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, this Parliament has been defending the social primacy in the European Semester process. The process of coordinating the Union's fiscal and economic policies must put the economy at the service of citizens, so it is extremely important that we have introduced three new indicators in the field of employment into the macroeconomic scoreboard.  But we have gone even further, arguing that these indicators are on an equal footing with existing economic indicators, ensuring that internal imbalances are better assessed and increasing the effectiveness of structural reforms.  This whole process should aim at creating jobs and the prosperity of the population, guided by the necessary budgetary responsibility that guarantees the sustainability of social Europe, not putting at risk the younger generations in a process of good economic governance oriented towards growth, which is incompatible with the application of sanctions on Portugal and Spain that jeopardise their investment capacity.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you very much for holding this debate. I want to begin by reiterating the importance of the European Semester. It is indeed the framework within which we are coordinating our economic and fiscal policies. The challenges are clear and you have identified them in your report: a deteriorating international environment, the legacy of the crisis, with high levels of debt and unemployment, and diverging economic and social performances amongst Member States.  An economically strong Europe is first of all a Europe that invests in infrastructure, in innovation, but of course, above all, in its people. The Council is now examining the proposal to extend the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), to agree promptly on its position in light of the evaluation expected next month.  It is a Europe that embraces the digital age to ensure that our industries are seizing the new opportunities of the digital world. It is also, of course, a Europe that is designed to meet the aspirations of its young generation. Therefore the Presidency intends to present the Council conclusions on youth employment in December, following the Commission Communication on the Youth Guarantee and Youth Employment Initiative. Furthermore, I should mention other areas that are key, like the need to match the current needs of labour markets for a suitable set of skills and of course we are striving to ensure the rebuilding of trust in the future of the economic and monetary union. It is needless to stress, as the rapporteur has mentioned, that stability comes, of course, from respect for fiscal rules. A lot can be achieved at European Union level, but what matters at the end of the day is the delivery by Member States. I want to underscore that the implementation of the country—specific recommendations is therefore critical. Like you, I fully support efforts to ensure greater national ownership, including the Commission’s engagement with capitals to create a shared understanding of the challenges facing Member States.  The Council discussions at political level on the implementation of recommendations are very important in that respect. But it is through the involvement of a broad range of stakeholders that we can truly strengthen ownership. To that effect, discussions with national parliaments and today’s debate are all essential contributions to build a common vision of a Europe that delivers hope and prosperity.  It is obvious that the reforms called for by the country-specific recommendations are substantial ones. They cannot be achieved in one year, even under the best economic conditions. But what matters is that all the stakeholders, as I have mentioned, are committed to these reforms so that they can yield long-term benefits. Finally, I would like to recall that the revamp of the Semester introduced last year was also aimed at facilitating the implementation of the recommendations, for instance by focusing on a limited number of key priority areas. The early publication of country reports also allows for more comprehensive discussions at national level.  So I would end on a positive note by commending the Commission for this.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Sant, the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteurs from the committees for their engagement and dedication on this comprehensive report. The Commission welcomes this constructive contribution to the European Semester. Democratic debate is an important element of the European Semester and today’s debate is very timely as we will soon launch the next Semester and set out the economic policy priorities for the year ahead. The Commission shares many of the findings and concerns mentioned in the report. Indeed the recovery in the EU and the euro area is still fragile and large divergences persist across Member States. Our autumn forecast, coming at the beginning of November, will provide a detailed update of the economic situation and outlook. It is clear that the EU needs stronger and more inclusive growth. To achieve this we have to progress with our three policy priorities: boosting investment, continuing structural reforms and pursuing responsible fiscal policies. These three policy priorities will again be at the heart of the Annual Growth Survey which will be presented by mid-November.  Now I will come briefly to the topics of the three priorities. First, on investment, we fully agree that a resurge of investment is crucial to support the economic recovery and reap the EU’s full growth potential. Despite low interest rates and ample liquidity, investment in Europe remains subdued. In that context, the Commission’s investment plan provides a most needed boost for Europe’s capacity to invest in future prosperity.  The projects so far approved for financing under the European Fund for Strategic Investment are expected to have mobilised around EUR 138 billion across 27 EU Member States. The Commission proposes to extend the duration of the Fund and to increase the financial capacity to at least half a trillion euro in investments by 2020. This would provide the necessary certainty to promoters and thus continued mobilisation of strategic investment. The Commission is also working to improve the overall investment environment, but it cannot succeed in this alone. All Member States must deliver on their side by stepping up their efforts to remove national obstacles to investment, as also stated in your report. The Member States should improve their business and investment environment in areas like insolvency, public procurement, judicial systems and the efficiency of public administration or sector—specific regulations. These priorities are well reflected in the 2016 country reports and the subsequent country—specific recommendations (CSRs). The Commission shares your assessment that further measures are needed to increase financing opportunities for businesses and to reduce the levels of non—performing loans. The latter weigh on banks’ earnings and their ability to finance new investment projects. The Commission is set to present a proposal on business restructuring and second chance, key elements of an appropriate insolvency framework.  I welcome your encouragement to address employment and social challenges and count on your support in delivering on these objectives. Structural reforms are essential to sustain the recovery and boost long-term growth. Economic change and reforms are not detrimental for our welfare: the opposite is true. Yet we need to pay attention not only to the benefits of reforms, but also the distribution of their impact across society. Increasing fairness and addressing inequalities is important, as significant employment and social challenges remain in spite of recent welcome improvements. Let me recall that employment in the EU has increased; since its lowest level in mid-2013, almost 8 million people found jobs with 4.5 million in the euro area. The EU employment rate for those aged 20 to 64 years is now at about 71% – back to its 2008 level – but there are still very large disparities among Member States like Greece. In Greece it stands at 56% versus Sweden where it is 81%. Unemployment in the EU is at the lowest rate since March 2009 and stays at 8.6% with 1.6 million fewer unemployed people in the EU compared to the same time last year. Long-term unemployment and youth unemployment also continue to decrease. Nevertheless, in August 2016, more than 4.2 million young people were unemployed and there were around 10 million long-term unemployed (unemployed for more than one year). While we are far from the Europe 2020 target of lifting at least 20 million people out of poverty or social exclusion by 2020, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion is falling to the level of 2008 where we started off. Only last year, 3.5 million people came out of poverty.  Against this background, we emphasise the balance between flexibility and security in labour markets and we encourage the Member States to modernise their social safety nets and give a stronger role to activation measures. And we believe we need to go further. This is why we have launched a broad consultation on the European Pillar of Social Rights aimed at screening our acquis to see how we can modernise our labour market and social security systems and make sure that there are not only better opportunities for job creation but also better support for citizens. A third element of our policy triangle is responsible fiscal policies, balancing the need to avoid pro-cyclicality on the one hand and reduce public debt on the other. The EU’s average government deficit is forecast to continue decreasing this year and next. It is expected to stand at 2.1% of GDP in 2016 compared with 2.4% last year. The EU’s average public debt to GDP ratio is forecast to stabilise at around 86% of GDP in the EU this year and to start to decline gradually in 2017. Here I am referring to the spring economic forecast; as I said, the autumn economic forecast will be available in the first half of November. At the same time, when the economic cycle is taken into account, the fiscal stance in the EU is considered to be slightly expansionary: the right balance between keeping public finances healthy, while also recognising the subdued economic context.  The Commission values your support for the changes and improvements introduced in the European Semester since 2015. We have streamlined and simplified it, improved its democratic accountability and strengthened its social dimension.    We now present country reports much earlier than in the past, allowing a substantial discussion with the Member States. Fewer country—specific recommendations compared to the past result from better prioritisation on areas that require urgent attention. Social priorities, including two issues linked to unemployment and social inclusion, now occupy a greater place. The same is true for education and its links with the labour market. We now publish country-specific recommendations for the euro area at the same time as the Annual Growth Survey, allowing all euro area countries to develop a common understanding of the key macroeconomic challenges.  We have strengthened the dialogue with the Member States, the European Parliament, national parliaments and social partners. Personally, I systematically visit Member States and engage in discussions with all key actors at the national level and my colleagues do the same.  But even if the Semester has been improved over the past years, the degree of implementation of CSRs remains low. In the spring we found that the Member States made ‘limited to some progress’ in addressing the issues identified in the CSRs issued in 2015. And this progress varied across policy fields: most significant progress was observed in the areas of financial services and actual labour market policies, while definitely much more was expected to ensure a business and employment-friendly environment. In order to support a stronger reform implementation, the Commission’s Structural Reform Support Service stands ready to provide technical support upon request from a Member State. Our proposal for the Structural Reform Support Programme is now being discussed in the European Parliament. I trust in your support to bring it swiftly into place and make it available to all Member States in need.  The report we are discussing today also touches upon the Stability and Growth Pact and the ‘flexibility’ contained in its rules. The Commission will continue to use the ‘flexibility’ built into the Pact. This means, for example, taking into account the budgetary impact of the exceptional inflow of refugees or exceptional security needs. Let me also stress that a number of Member States benefit already from the ‘flexibility’ granted in relation to the implementation of major structural reforms and investment. The Commission will continue to apply these provisions where the conditions are fulfilled. However, all Member States should pursue responsible fiscal policies, in compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact, putting public finances on a sustainable track and addressing the still high public debt in many Member States.  All Member States could still step up efforts to achieve a more growth—friendly composition of public finances: make their tax systems fairer, more transparent and effective in providing incentives for job creation, and also ensure that the money is spent in the most effective way. The high tax wedge on labour should be addressed as it weighs on labour costs and reduces the net take-home pay for employees. Your report also points to this issue. Euro area Member States have submitted their draft budgetary plans as planned, by mid-October. The Commission is now analysing these plans and will come up with an assessment as required by the regulation.  We will table a comprehensive policy package in November. I am confident that it will provide an answer to many of your concerns. We will publish the Annual Growth Survey accompanied by a Draft Joint Employment Report and the Euro Area Recommendations. Under the macroeconomic imbalances procedure we will publish the Alert Mechanism Report. It will identify the Member States for an in-depth review in the context of the country reports.  Finally, as announced in President Juncker’s State of the Union speech in March 2017, in time for the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, the Commission will set out a vision for the long term on how to strengthen and reform our economic and monetary union. You will, of course, be continuously involved in the European Semester, as will the national parliaments.

name: Catherine Stihler
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, thank you to our rapporteur, who mentioned the issues around investment and training, in particular digital skills, and then to the Council, who were saying about implementation. In particular I hope that will also involve infringement proceedings against Member States that do not implement rules that they have already signed up to. I want to concentrate my time on the importance of the single market, critical to our economic success and therefore critical to European semester process. And why does this matter? Because we create one set of rules that covers 28 countries, that covers 500 million people. One set of rules, 28 countries, 500 million people, and that could be as diverse from public procurement to standardisation to mutual recognition of qualifications, to just mention a few issues. And why is that important? It is important to business because it creates certainty, and it is important to consumers because it guarantees quality. And that is why I find myself as a UK politician representing Scotland, it is such a tragedy at the moment that my country, the United Kingdom, could see itself pull itself out of the single market, a single market that it developed and shaped and helped to produce. And in Scotland alone – let me finish – the single market, our access to the single market guarantees 80 000 jobs in Scotland. 80 000 jobs are reliant on our access to the single market. That is why the single market matters. It matters to citizens to make it better, fairer and effective for all.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There is undoubtedly a big problem – more than four million young people without a job, many many millions with temporary work and many more who have unsatisfactory jobs. But the emergence of an instrument for young people is enjoying. It is pleased that if we see a problem, we will be able to solve it. I would also like to thank you for taking the opinion of the Committee on Culture into account in this debate, because it shows that the elements of education, the elements related to market creativity are simply noticed, perceived and not underestimated. What do we need? Firstly, measures to make it easier for young people to start their careers, as well as apprenticeships. Funding, including programmes such as Erasmus+, should be increased. It is also necessary to increase the attractiveness of programmes and studies in science, technology, engineering, mathematics, that is, everything that builds opportunities for greater, better economic development in Europe.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has What is the European Semester all about? It is quite trivial – to put it this way – to recognise at an early stage whether there are any aberrations in the Member States that could lead to states being unable to carry out their own tasks in the long term.
