That is why I am very grateful to the Commission for taking up, in the context of the country-specific recommendations, what we as a Parliament have also called for, namely a focus on really few points, and also to address them clearly. I would like to express my thanks to our rapporteur, Mr Sant, who has also taken up this idea of focusing on what can really be achieved in the context of the semester process, and to do so. For us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, the triad is important in achieving structural reforms for greater competitiveness. I believe that this is vital if we want to create permanent employment not only for young people, but for all people in the European Union. It is about creating an environment that triggers investment. I am very grateful, Mr Vice-President, for pointing out once again that the European Central Bank has done its job. But in a number of Member States, not everything has been fulfilled, so that the central bank's low interest rates flow into the real economy as low interest rates, thereby triggering investment and creating jobs. That is a very important point. We cannot solve this by creating more investment by the public authorities alone. That is why, Mr Sant, the dual tone of private and public investment is important, not just public investment. Thirdly, it is important for us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats to have a responsible budgetary policy, which is the core element of the European Semester. And it is important to measure one's against the strong, not against the weak. Then we are on the right track. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You are, by the way, rightly calling for economic policy cooperation between Member States, but what could be the magic reason why the European Union cannot move forward with regard to one of the most important policies, tax policy? Here, after all, we leave a distorting element in the system that actually almost makes sense for the whole of the European Semester. In other word, do you see a chance for us to move forward with regard to tax harmonisation?

name: Markus Ferber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I come from a Member State where you are opening your doors when it comes to making further progress on tax policy, so that the tax loopholes that we have in a number of Member States in Europe are also plugged. In this respect, this is a process that we very much welcome. The next item on the agenda will be the single tax base for corporation tax, where the Commission presents its decisions today.  I myself have been involved in these very things, both in the two TAXE committees and now in the Committee of Inquiry into Panama. I just don't see the context of the European Semester.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, before speaking in this debate I reviewed last year's notes of the same debate on country-specific recommendations. And, with slight differences, one has the feeling of being the protagonist of Bill Murray's film Trapped in Time because, with nuances, from year to year, we continue to live in the same reality in which millions of citizens live: a recovery that remains fragile, that remains slow, that does not reach the vast majority of citizens , which persists and causes inequalities to endure throughout the European Union, especially in the euro area.  And this is because the European Semester has to consist of more than just coordinating a list of good wishes, of things that we will have to implement. It must truly be a set of measures that we implement quickly, forcefully and effectively and, moreover, fairly because, in the end, the biggest problem we have identified and have been detecting in this European Parliament is inequality, which is also the common cause of almost all the ills we analyse from the European institutions: populism, Euroscepticism , even protectionism — which is now increasing in the European Union in the rejection, for example, of trade agreements — of inequalities that produce fear, inequalities that cause paralysis and inequalities that produce Europhobia.  And we therefore need to do many more things than are in the hands of the Member States, mainly in terms of three aspects: reducing inequalities by improving the quality of employment, not only by creating jobs, but by improving quality, mainly wages.  We are living at a time when we are also seeing growth from exports slow in the coming times. And so it is not a question of social justice, but also of economic efficiency, raising wages to improve domestic demand and to increase recovery.  We also need a fairer taxation which, as I say, is serious not only to middle and working income but also to capital incomes and to redistribute wealth more, by the way, also combating poverty.  That is why we are telling the Member States again today that it is essential that they already set a minimum income at Member State level in order to take out of poverty the 120 million people who are now at risk of social exclusion. By fighting poverty, fighting inequalities, we will do a better economic semester, because not only will we be increasing the recovery but we will make it fairer and more decent.

name: Joachim Starbatty
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The eurozone is the area with the lowest growth rate and the highest unemployment. That is the central problem, and we have also discussed it with Mr Sant. Mr Sant was a very fair and open rapporteur. But there was a central conflict, which he himself named. Namely, that the eurozone is a suboptimal currency area, or as I put it, the euro is driving eurozone members apart. In some countries the euro is overvalued, in others it is undervalued. In the undervalued countries, exports are subsidised. It is taxed in countries with an overvalued currency. It is clear that nothing neat can come out of this. It is necessary that we devalue or upgrade it. This is not possible, but instead the labour market must provide compensation. The labour market is the toughest adjustment instrument we know. That is why we need to move on to a different policy. We must no longer try to save the eurozone, but to save countries. What is necessary for this? Countries that have no growth, no employment should leave the monetary union. We need a debt cut and we need start-up financing.  I am glad that the GUE Group has tabled an amendment to this effect, Amendment No 19. I am curious to see who in this House will vote in favour of this amendment. I ask the PPE Group, who are in favour of the economy and freedom, whether they support this. Or the ALDE Group. I am curious to see who in this House tomorrow will vote in favour of this amendment tabled by the GUE Group.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, I would like to thank Professor Starbatty for his explanation, which seems to me to be very authoritative, and I wanted to ask him – since he is also a German representative and therefore very honest intellectually not to defend monetary economic union – whether it would not be appropriate at this point, rather than moving towards a very difficult integration that continues to present the same problems, to agree together on a disintegration before it happens in a disorderly manner. Thank you.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Valli, you yourself have tabled amendments which describe exactly where the problem of the euro area lies. If we simply carry on like this and do not face the facts, then the end of the eurozone will be bad. We must be prepared – as you did in your amendments – to sort the eurozone in an orderly manner, precisely in order to stabilise Europe and monetary union in the long term. Thank you for your contribution.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in my Group we see with increasing preoccupation how the European Semester sinks into irrelevance. Our attitude as a European Chamber is not helping. We believe that this report is too inconcrete and too general – with nice words, yes, but nothing else. Today, the European Semester is complied with just as much as the OECD recommendations, which are morally voluntary. The European Semester’s rate of success at fully implementing recommended reforms is only 6%, an embarrassingly low figure. Moreover, the report refuses to signal what problems each Member State has. Without name and shame, or name and price, Member States will not react and will care even less about our reports. As long as the European Semester is not reformulated to be more specific, doing real country-by-country analyses, these reports have no point and do not give added value to the EU. This is why, while agreeing with some of the nice words referred to above, my Group abstained in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) vote two weeks ago. For the vote of tomorrow I have recommended that my Group abstain again. However, as many amendments of my Group have not been included and considered in the compromises, some members of my Group will vote against this report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, these are times of paradoxes when many want to convince us of one thing and its opposite: that it is possible to defend labour rights while precarrating employment; that is in favour of public services when cuts are applied; that you can be opposed and at the same time courageous of governments and austerity policies.  His group, the Social Democratic Group, has been dancing on these contradictions for some time, but it is not possible to reform the irreformable, to clothe the anti-democratic norms of European governance with a halo of legitimacy.  An iron cage that blames peripheral countries for their economic problems, forging them to impoverish their own population, while exempting the European framework, and its enormous concentration of resources in the central countries, from any responsibility in the current crisis.  A mechanism at the service of European national capital, as the degradation of labour rights in any country spreads rapidly from one side of the continent to the other, forcing workers to compete with each other.  Current austerity policies threaten not only the European Union, but democracy itself, and cooperation and harmonisation of social rights between different European countries is necessary to emerge from them. That's probably it. We agree with the rapporteur. Where we differ is where that is possible within European governance. This permanent blackmail for which my country, Spain, risks losing European funds necessary for its development.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all, thank Mr Sant, rapporteur of the report. The most serious thing about the whole European Semester process I think is, at the moment, the lack of democratisation, which partly explains its poor results. I think we have a very serious problem and we need to associate more with national parliaments and, of course, to associate more with social actors, other words this will always be seen as an imposition with very poor results. The results are in those countries where there has been a memorandum and absolutely insane reforms have been forced. But the European Semester obviously has a relatively low level of compliance. First problem. Second problem. The economic policy approach of recent years has been totally wrong. From the triad that is always presented to us: investment, structural reforms and fiscal consolidation, we have in recent years had fiscal consolidation at suicidal levels. It has only now been reduced in the end by the policies of the European Central Bank. These are devaluative reforms that have also had a very high social cost and totally non-existent investment.  I think the report is right here to say that we need to put the focus on investment because the investment ratio for GDP, which fell a lot between 2008 and 2013, has only fallen slightly since 2014, but we are still at still very low levels: in the European Union 2.6%, below pre-crisis levels. And FEIE hasn't been an answer to that. I therefore believe that here, of course, there is a call to increase public investment to those countries with a large trade surplus: to boost their domestic demand. The report says that, and I am glad, and also a very important thing, which is that we have to make an aggregate calculation of the whole euro area, of what is the fiscal situation of the whole euro area, not of the countries one by one. I think that's extremely important. We must invest in education, human capital, innovation and R&D, because if the only competitiveness strategy in the euro area is to compete for low wages, this is a real disaster.  I would like to point out here that it is very important to defend collective bargaining and minimum income, and to stop wage competition at once , as the report also points out. And I just add to what the President of the European Central Bank himself said: "It's time to raise wages in the European Union." I think that should be clear. And finally, the last thing I would like to point out is that the report has not included any of the amendments that my group had tabled in relation to the Semester environmental indicators that this House has voted on, and I would like to call for these amendments to be voted on in favour tomorrow, because those indicators are extremely important.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to take advantage of the presence of the Commission and the Commissioner to ask them what they are waiting for to enforce European rules with regard to the trade surplus, given that in the Union, in this report it is also sanctioned, there are imbalances due to economic and monetary union, which is not complete. These imbalances generate an excessive trade surplus, sanctioned and also highlighted by the reports of the Monetary Fund and the OECD. Well, Germany and the Netherlands have repeatedly violated these rules, but you continue to be strong with the weak countries: let us block the funds from Spain and Portugal, let us break the boxes for Italy, but Germany and the Netherlands continue to make this distortion. In addition, also with regard to the deficit, if we look at it, there is Mr Juncker who goes to say that France is France and therefore can do what he wants with the rules. So the rules don't work, just like the semester doesn't work. And I can understand the position of germans like Ferber, the colleague who has dealt with this report with me, who are in favour of austerity, in favour of the Stability and Growth Pact, but I really cannot understand why the Socialists are still in favour of what is written in this report, because always the usual mantra for two years now : more rigour, more austerity, more reforms, liberalisations of services, the labour market, private investment, wage devaluations, protests. But you have taken the votes to change this dogma relating to the Stability and Growth Pact, you have taken the votes to do one thing, instead you have rulers like Renzi, in Italy, who go around saying that they want to change the rules, then there is they put it in the Constitution in 2012 supporting a budget balance. Further constitutional reform now in 2016 still the European constraints stressed in the Constitution. But what do you want to change? You are unique in this European project which, if it does not put the debate on the euro and imbalances at the centre, as Stiglitz said, will unfortunately founder and founder unfortunately not neatly. We have to agree to find a solution to do it in an orderly way, otherwise it will be a big problem for everyone.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The messages that have come from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs are clear, in my view: we support the priorities that the European Commission has given to this European Semester 2016. And we stress that the coordination of budgetary policies in Europe must work better. We would like to remind you that this is the very essence of the European Semester, and that this core also determines how credible Europe is in economic policy. We also make it clear that more coordination does not mean less responsibility. The national responsibility of the Member States is and remains a key in Europe's management of the economic crisis. Control and personal responsibility are inextricably linked. Anyone who is currently calling for more Europeanisation in fiscal policy is at odds with the member states' claim to sovereignty. That is the reality. This is the reality of our current European treaties, and it is therefore important to strengthen the existing system, namely the system of ownership and control. The European Semester must play a more important role here in the future. We have long criticised the lack of the binding effect of the European Semester. The new cycle of this semester is about to begin. As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we are counting on the European Commission to apply the instruments it has at its disposal consistently and consistently. Yes! Europe is in difficult economic times. But neither distractions nor delaying tactics will bring us any further. We must therefore specify the challenges, even if this is often an unpleasant task. And we need to tackle the root causes of the problems. Only then will we be able to resolve them permanently in the end. I would argue for this: for the independent evaluation of the Member States' budgets, which is now to be carried out.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, the report by our colleague Alfred Sant is right in essence. Investment in Europe falls short of what is needed for sustainable and inclusive growth. It is time for the European Central Bank's monetary policy to be accompanied by a more growth-friendly fiscal policy.  There are three messages in this report that the European Parliament directs to the Commission. The first is that the Commission should make the most of the flexibility allowed by the rules of the euro. The second is that we need to strengthen the Juncker Plan, but also ensure that it benefits the less developed regions, rather than aggravating divergences in Europe. And the third is that the Commission should take into account parliament's position when deciding on the suspension of funds for Portugal and Spain.  The majority of this Parliament has already spoken clearly against this suspension which would be unfair, contradictory and counterproductive. In the case of Portugal, European funds now account for 78% of public investment. Suspending funds is therefore suspending growth. It would be an injustice, but it would also be a grave mistake against the economy and against the European project.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, according to the 2016 European Semester package, each Member State of the Union must aim to strengthen its economy and combat unemployment. However, the European Union's attitude to the countries of the European South so far does nothing to achieve the objectives of the European Semester. On the contrary, the European Union, with its austerity policies, has led to the dismantling of industrial relations, the reduction of wages and pensions, the dismantling of employment and the social state. The implementation of the objectives of the European Semester is therefore far from reality. In order for the objective of economic development of the Member States of the Union to succeed, the Mercelic austerity and the draconian stability pact governing all the policies of the European Union, as well as the fiscal policies imposed on countries such as Greece, must be abandoned and, on the contrary, the financial support of European countries with decent wages and working conditions and measures to strengthen the triple social Alpha must be promoted.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE).
text: – Appointment is appointment and rules are rules. If we agree that we are going to put our household books back in order and that we need structural reforms to compete globally, then we all have to do so. If Member States do not comply, it will be bad for European support, but especially for those countries themselves, because that is actually going to pass the bill on to your children. In this sense, I agree with what Commissioner Dombrovskis has said about investment. But I do want to give a warning: investing is different from spending more. Recently, for example, I saw that a Member State is buying additional train sets that it does not actually need, just to keep an ailing company from its own country going. As far as I am concerned, that is not an investment. That is simply more spending and perhaps even a form of state aid.  I would therefore call on the Commissioner to continue to look very critically at everything that is meant by investment.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, for us, the European Semester represents the main obstacle to our development. It was the demands of the euro imposed through the European Semester that undertook the basis of an austerity policy that represented for Portugal a decades-long regression in terms of investment, income and social rights. It was the rules of the euro that undertook a debt that became unsustainable and prevented policies to relaunch our economy with effective support for key productive sectors. It is the European Semester that is the basis of an ongoing operation of intolerable blackmail around our budgetary policy. The report speaks a lot of country recommendations, but these are very clear: more flexibility in labour laws, more privatisation in transport and wage freezes. There is no economic rationality in this European Semester. The European Semester, with the false purpose of supporting countries in their budgetary policy, is rather an instrument to impose a neoliberal agenda at the service of capital and which peoples will reject sooner or later.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I must say that I consider the European Semester, and especially country-specific recommendations, as one of the key economic policies of the European Union, the policy that should contribute to the stability and growth of our economies. But this is also a policy that does not work properly. The policy is not delivering the goals and again I am speaking especially about country- specific recommendations.  I guess we all know the numbers. More than two thirds of recommendations are just ignored by the government. As a consequence we have economic growth that is too sluggish and below potential, we have unemployment that is too high, we have a lack of confidence in the economy and also a lack of confidence in the European Union. Last time, a year ago, when I was talking here, I had some doubts about the structure of the recommendations. This year I must say that I appreciate the work that has been done by the Commission. I reviewed a country-specific recommendation for countries that I know and I must say it is well done.  So where do we stand? We are in what is a quite a usual position for the European Union: we have a good, or at least reasonable, policy; we have all respect for that, and we have weak enforcement. The consequence is damage for all of us. I know it is a matter of subsidiarity but there is something we can do about it. We should focus on existing policy and implementation, and not invent more regulation, new policies and new reports. This will make life better for all of us.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Mr President, this new European Semester opens in a special atmosphere. Will there be a free trade treaty with Canada? We're wondering. We know that Wallonia is blocking and questioning itself. What economic development do we want for the European Union? This is exactly the same question that we ask ourselves semester after semester, often unfortunately in a vacuum, as the economic creed seems unperturbed in its certainties and cements a European economy at the service of multinationals under the sacrosanct dogma of austerity. In Belgium, we have felt the results of this way of thinking and doing. Caterpillar cut off thousands of jobs in Charleroi in one day to increase its comfortable profits. Same way of doing things for ING. The Dutch banker has cut thousands of jobs in Belgium to pay its shareholders even better. Meanwhile, what has been done for European citizens? Public services are being reduced by the day, there is a lack of productive public investment all over Europe and I am not saying that, for example, Matteo Renzi. In Italy, since 2008, public investment has fallen by 43% and this is a problem. In France, local authorities are investing as much as they did in 2006, a decline of ten years; and in Belgium, the same phenomenon is observed. It is therefore more than urgent to revive productive public investment that benefits citizens above all, but also and above all the economy. My colleague Sant said that, as more and more actors are calling for, the 2010 SEC accounting standards, which prevent public authorities from investing, must be reviewed. We need to create an ambitious investment programme based on innovation and real needs such as energy transition, mobility, employment, health or education and, finally, to put in place a harmonised tax system in Europe to combat tax evasion. That's how we're going to get out of this.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I welcome the Vice-President, representatives of the European Commission and the Council. Year after year we repeat the same and know that the preconditions for growth and investment are structural reforms, smart fiscal consolidation that leaves room for innovation, research and development through thoughtful policies that help entrepreneurial projects and raise competitiveness. We also note that specific recommendations are not implemented, that more synergies and coordination need to be needed between European policies and instruments and also with national policies and budgets. What's missing? What does it take for better results and better implementation?  I believe that for better implementation and concrete results in practice, we need: 1. more concrete examples of successful changes and development projects in the Member States that we highlight and encourage all Member States to make similar steps; 2: more benchmarks by which we will monitor the performance of coordination between national policies and EU objectives; 3: More exchange of knowledge and experience, not only between Member States, but also the use of successful examples outside the European Union.  That is why I am pleased with the Commission's proposal and the introduction of support programmes for the implementation of structural reforms. This is an important step to help Member States respond to the question of how to design and implement reforms. We need more practical instruments and incentive measures, but within the framework of the existing regulation, which will build trust and clarify the desire and will to change.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Madam President. Indeed, we are striving for growth, jobs and quality jobs, and the aim is one that enables our Citizens of the European Union to maintain themselves and their children in quality, normally paid jobs. But is that the case? I very much want to draw attention to one recommendation that is absolutely necessary as we fight child poverty. As many as twenty-six million children in the European Union are in poverty. And for this, we urgently need to create a guarantee for children that every child in our child has adequate health care, that they have adequate education, adequate access to education, proper accommodation and proper nutrition. This is a very specific proposal.  Second concrete proposal. Overcoming women's poverty. The Commission really has to make recommendations to the Member States so that women get the same salary as men in their work, because they suffer greatly from this. These are two specific recommendations that I am very pleased to evaluate.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, because we recognise the effort made to reach a compromise text. But we have to repeat some issues: What is the goal that we are here and especially in the eurozone? To arrive at an economic convergence of economies and to involve the Member States in the design of structural reforms. And those who claim that managing a Member State's economy is like managing a company, this - not to say it is naive or deliberate misrepresentation - is oversimplification. This leads me to the next point which is of particular concern to the Commission: we are talking about accountability and irregularities. Since the Commission considers the deficits of the Member States to be an anomaly, it should, in a similar way, also regard the surpluses of the Member States as an anomaly. And one final point, Mr President. Access to the Structural Funds cannot be tantamount to punishment since the principles governing them are the principle of solidarity and the objective of social cohesion.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – Europe is still recovering from the protracted economic crisis, economic growth is still not what we would like, and unemployment, especially in some areas, remains very high. Swift and effective action is needed, particularly in those areas specifically highlighted by this report. In my opinion, Member States are still understaffing, some at least, taking advantage of the opportunities offered by investment funds, especially the EFSI. This would enable a large number of new jobs and a more dynamic labour market, a better life for our citizens and citizens.  I therefore call on the Commission to take even more of a stand to encourage such investments and for the Member States to put an end to bureaucratic obstacles. However, I would like to draw attention only to one more thing, namely that I say time and time again that the Commission does not have enough good levers to also control the country's promises for reform measures.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European semester at the process has prevented public investment at a time in Europe when we needed quite the opposite. We needed a Marshall Plan. We needed money put into our economies. We have an opportunity but were prevented from doing anything with this opportunity, and the opportunity is low interest rates. But there is another problem with this system, and when it comes to Ireland, the rules are enforced by the European Union, but when it comes to France and when it comes to Germany (and surpluses were mentioned earlier), there is nothing done, and this causes more problems than it solves. We have a homelessness problem in Ireland – we need massive public investment. As I have said already, we have low interest rates, so we are being forced to leave people homeless in Ireland, for children to live in car, for children to have to urinate in Coca Cola bottles and leave them outside the car, to be chased away by a parking attendant in the morning, because our government tells us: because of this abomination, we cannot break these rules. Break them – they are not good.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank you for this debate and as I said in my introductory remarks, from your report too we see that actually we share a number of concerns and a number of ways to address them.  A number of issues were raised during this debate, including how to facilitate investment and this is indeed one of the three priorities in our European Semester. The intention of the Commission is to continue to follow up on how we can promote investment through the Investment Plan for Europe, but also through the rules in the Stability and Growth Pact, which specifically allows for deviation from budgetary targets to promote more investment.  Issues related to the social dimension, dealing with the problems of poverty, of inequality, addressing the issues in our labour markets, are also featuring more prominently in the European Semester than was the case in previous years and the Commission intends to continue and follow up on this. The question of current account surpluses was raised and this is indeed also the question which is being addressed by the Commission to countries like Germany and the Netherlands. It is something which is the reason why the Commission is pursuing in-depth reviews of the economies of those countries and also finding them to be experiencing macroeconomic imbalances. So this is certainly part of the picture.  In any case, the Commission intends to continue its work along the priority lines which have been set up, promoting investment, structural reforms and fiscally responsible policies.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, many thanks for this debate. This was indeed quite a valuable stock-taking where we could hear your views on how the European Semester is functioning and, above all, what we can achieve together within the European Semester when it comes to our common efforts to work on jobs and growth and economic prosperity.  Now we know where we are finding ourselves. First of all I would like to once again recall how much we value the revamped European Semester. I think that the changes the Commission introduced in 2015, last year, are very good because they help us better transform what we agree in the European Semester and then transform it into action at national level. I remember when the Semester started; it can hardly be compared in quality with the Semester that we are having right now.  Secondly, many of you have rightly pointed and appealed to Member States to better implement. This is once again well understood and legitimate. Nevertheless, I represent the Member States and you would agree with me that implementation is not a bureaucratic exercise. At the end of the day, it is hard to convince our people – our voters – to support reforms and structural reforms, how to observe fiscal rules that we have established ourselves, and this is very painful. So please understand why we have committed to better implement. At the same time, bear in mind that this is a very demanding process back home.  Lastly, I hope we will be able in the Council to draw on lessons from this year, this 2016 Semester, when preparing the next one. And the next one, I would like to announce, will be for the first time on the agenda of General Affairs Council in November.

name: Alfred Sant
text: rapporteur. –  Mr President, I thank all participants in this debate for their very interesting contributions, as well as once again my friends and colleagues all the shadow rapporteurs. If anything, I hope that our work together in preparing for this report, as well as the debate in plenary, have served to underline once more the challenge of investment in Europe. When we talk about investment we are really talking about the future, for investment builds the foundations for future progress and for new achievements. We are also talking, however, about the present, for investment replaces and renews those resources which we need now to maintain the living standards of people. When we say resources we mean material ones, human ones and those resources that relate to knowledge and techniques. The sad truth is that in Europe, as elsewhere, but certainly in Europe, investment in real terms has fallen well below the levels that it had reached, let us say, ten years ago. The shortfall covers both investment to replace what has been used up, as well as investment in new resources and utilities. Whatever our views about the available policy options, we have shown that we care about investment, that we consider it to be a priority. Perhaps there is also agreement that more must be done to promote and enhance it, though there is disagreement about how this challenge can be achieved.  I would like to acknowledge and support the emphasis that the Commission, in its initiatives and in its country-specific recommendations, has given to the topic of investment. Still, the Commission needs to do more, perhaps much more, and not simply by widening the EFSI instrument. It also needs, in my view, to affirm the need for more public investment that is sharper, better focused, better planned, better implemented. However, about this, not all agree.  Finally, I would think that from the debate that we have held on the country-specific recommendations, two other main issues can be underlined. First, there is the importance of allocating more resources to create a European investment culture, to renew investments in education and knowledge-based activities, not least in the digital field but also in the basic sciences, all tying into research and development as well as the quest for innovation. Secondly, there is the need to ensure that the country-specific recommendations are meaningful to all relevant actors so that they also own them. A central involvement should be given to subnational and to regional authorities.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 26 October 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – The annual growth survey on the coordination of economic policies presented highlights some useful and useful observations in its stocktaking of the economic situation in the Member States. The European Semester will now set out three main priorities on which both the Commission and the Member States are concentrating in order to relaunch economic growth. It is about promoting investment, particularly in innovation and research, as well as for SMEs, creating sustainable jobs to counter persistent unemployment, and socially balanced structural reforms combined with responsible fiscal policies. In this context, the report explicitly emphasises that the number of recommendations made by the Commission to the Member States should in future be limited to priority issues of macroeconomic and social impact. It also calls for national ownership through the involvement of national parliaments and regional and local authorities, and the claim to subject the individual national reform programmes to proper democratic control in the respective parliaments of the Member States. There are criticisms of this report in the area of priority setting, where the rapporteur calls, for example, for the completion of the Banking Union, in the implementation of the country-specific recommendations, where he gives the European Commission further powers, and on the migration issue, through which labour migration strikes a balance with the negative effects of ageing populations in the Member States.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. – There can be no economic and financial union without a social union in the long term. The social dimension is crucial for the future of Europe. The high number of precarious employment and unemployment, as well as the lowering of social standards, have dug deep divisions in Europe. Poverty and social exclusion are still at historic highs. Precarious working conditions are the rule rather than the exception. The mere coordination of economic and financial policy is not enough to counteract these problems. We need to anchor a strong social pillar in the European Semester. Social and employment policy needs exactly the same commitment as fiscal policy. To this end, we need to define social standards that apply to all types of employment. The social pillar must bring social convergence back up. That is why, with the social pillar, we must not just be content with a summary of existing rules. The Commission must also finally include the principle of 'equal pay for equal work in the same place'. If we give top priority to the creation of good jobs and thus to the fight against poverty, then we will regain the confidence of the people of Europe.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Semester has become an instrument for coordinating the economic policies of the Member States of the European Union. The European Semester, as a process, is going well until implementation. That's where the trouble starts. Recently, the European Commission decided not to propose sanctions for the non-inclusion of two Member States in the budget deficit reduction schedule. Unfortunately, indebted Member States, with levels of public debt around one hundred percent of gross domestic product, and some well over one hundred percent, such as Greece, Italy, Portugal, do not yet want to act decisively to reduce indebtedness. In this way, I maintain the state of instability for the whole euro area. While economic growth is still anemic, reducing public debt requires clear measures to restructure public expenditure, bringing budget deficits under control. The theory that if you spend more, increasing public debt, you'll get economic growth that will help you then reduce debt doesn't work when you're over-indebted. The financial situation in some Member States is still sustainable only as long as the European Central Bank keeps the two quantitative easing and negative or very low interest rates policies unchanged.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on the corporate tax package (2016/2953(RSP)).

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament and the Commission are strong allies in the drive to reform corporate taxation in Europe and to do so with ambition and determination.  The strength with which you have seized on this subject, combined with our initiatives, which I believe are ambitious, have already made very significant changes. Today, we are closer to fair and effective taxation in the European Union than we were two years ago and, indeed, more than ever.  We have pushed tax transparency step by step on the practices of Member States as well as those of multinationals. We have built new barriers against the manipulation of taxable bases and the transfer of profits through new anti-abuse rules that will become binding throughout the European Union.  The package, which the Commission adopted today, is much more than just a package of new measures. It is more than an extension of what we have already done together. It is a comprehensive, structural and structuring framework for corporate taxation in Europe, a new framework that looks to the future and in which corporate taxation will by definition be fair and pro-growth. This framework will enable companies and investors to develop their activities in the European Union, not through selective tax breaks or secret tax rulings but simply because they will benefit from a tax environment that will be simple, readable, stable and also, of course, favourable to economic activity. For me, transparency and competitiveness go hand in hand. Finally, it is a framework in which all businesses, large and small, pay their taxes where they make their profits and create wealth.  At the heart of the package adopted today is a project which is, I know, strongly supported and even wanted by this House: the relaunch of the consolidated common corporate tax base, namely the ACCIS. The CGTA aims to tax businesses in a way that reflects the true spirit of the single market, namely, first, uniform rules for calculating taxable profits; second, a one-time tax return to be completed through a one-stop shop; and a system of distribution of profits between Member States, which can then tax them at their national rates. Businesses will also be rewarded for their growth-oriented activities with important new elements in this version of the ICSC, because we have chosen - and I think it was rational - not to represent the same text that was rejected by the Council, given the debates that took place and also the new context in which we are working. We have put in place a great deduction for research and development. I want to emphasize this point because we are really making a tremendous effort in this area and we are making a very powerful commitment to research and development. In other words, companies that invest in research and development will be able to deduct one and a half times what they have spent from their taxable base. This incentive will be even more generous and will go up to 200% for start-ups, which will be able to deduct the amount of costs exposed to this height. We have also introduced a measure in the CTAis that will promote corporate financing in the capital markets, which is consistent with our search for a single capital market, by correcting the debt bias that exists today in the majority of corporate tax regimes. The goal is to promote and promote healthier financing, stronger capital markets and greater economic stability. The VAC WILL also have the advantage of eliminating many cases of double taxation. However, until this consolidated common base is in place, we will still need an effective solution for non-CSA companies. There are more than 900 cases of double taxation currently being disputed in the European Union, which of course generates huge costs and a lot of legal uncertainty for the companies concerned. That is why today we are also proposing an improved system for resolving double taxation disputes. We want to guarantee companies a predictable and definitive solution in the long run when they are taxed more than once on the same income.  THE ACCIS is a powerful tool to prevent and counter corporate tax evasion. As the As the European Parliament has asked us, we have proposed that the ACCIS be mandatory for the largest multinationals. The ACCIS will incorporate the measures already adopted by the Member States in the Directive against Tax Evasion and today we are adding to these provisions a final measure to combat hybrid schemes with third countries and therefore outside the European Union. Why relaunch the CSA? I know that this Parliament has waited a long time for this project and has long supported the benefits that must flow from it. I also know that companies are looking forward to implementing this scheme as quickly as possible. And I can understand that some people doubt the chances of success of the CCTA, given the lack of agreement on the previous proposal.  Let me try to instil a little optimism on this point because this time it is different. It is different because we have a better proposal, a better approach, a more favourable political environment as well, given all the events that have taken place in recent years and the progress that has already been made in corporate taxation.  Our proposal is strengthened. Its obligatory nature makes it a powerful tool in the fight against tax evasion, while the incentives, which I have already mentioned, improve the ability of our taxation to support jobs, growth and stability.  Our approach is not only strengthened, it is also more pragmatic. We propose a two-step approach. First, Member States need to define the common base in order to start quickly reaping the benefits it offers. Second, consolidation will also need to be implemented quickly. Nevertheless, I would like to stress forcefully - because I know that this is a subject that can be questioned and that it may be a temptation in the forthness of the coming discussions in the Council - that these two stages are closely linked. For the Commission, there is no question of abandoning or delaying the consolidation which, on its own, will give full scope to the common base. It is indeed a comprehensive agreement in two phases that we want and not a first phase, and then another which would be postponed to the Greek calendars and could be split.  My goal is that this consolidation will be in place by 2021 at the latest. I am counting on the European Parliament to continue to put pressure on our Member States to achieve this goal because, as I said, we have your support, that of businesses and NGOs, but the ball is, as usual, in the Member States' court. I'm getting to my very last point. Today, I believe that we have the ideal, if not ideal, environment to revive the ACCIS. Given all the benefits of this project, we expect Member States to work quickly to adopt this proposal. I will conclude by thanking this House for this long-standing support of the ACCIS project and inciting you - but is it necessary? I am well known that it is not to play your full role and to weigh in the adoption of the proposals presented today.  Today we have the opportunity to build a fairer and more stable Europe and a more competitive corporate tax system in Europe for the good of our citizens, our businesses and our Union as a whole. At a time when Europe is under attack and populism is soaring, this is a project that is part of a more transparent and just tax approach that our citizens understand both the necessity and the usefulness of. This is one more good proof of Europe that I invite you to support.

name: Dariusz Rosati
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome the Commission’s proposal for a single set of corporate tax rules for doing business in the EU. The present situation with 28 different corporate tax systems co-existing within one single market is untenable. It puts an unnecessary administrative burden on companies, reduces their international competitiveness and creates ample opportunities for them to engage in aggressive tax planning practices. Why would you oppose the harmonisation of national tax rates across the EU? There is clearly a need to harmonise national regulations in the area of corporate tax base. Firstly, we want to be serious about fighting tax avoidance and tax evasion in the EU. We want to make sure that taxes are paid where the value is created. That is why we need a common framework for corporate taxation that is simple, effective and transparent.  Secondly, we all want our companies to fully exploit the enormous potential of the single market. For that we need common European rules on corporate taxation, which would facilitate trade and investment across the EU, and eliminate unfair tax competition. That is why a European directive on common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB) is urgently needed. Let me draw your attention to three interesting novelties that were mentioned by the Commissioner here. The first is the very generous tax treatment on R&D expenditure, the second is the preferential treatment of innovative start—ups, and the third is a rule against the debt-bias. All of them deserve our support. Commissioner, we are ready to work with you on this proposal.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, you have said that this Parliament is committed to this project and you are right. We wish you more luck than your predecessors who, on March 16, 2011, put the previous proposal on the table.  As you pointed out, the context may have changed. The idea that tax evasion must be tackled and that the lack of a consolidated corporate tax base promotes tax evasion has made its way. The idea that, basically, between our economies, since we are always told about competition between our economies, it is better to know what taxes are paid, which is not the case today. The proposal you are putting on the table seems to us to be a good basis for discussion, but you have anticipated the three or four points on which, of course, in the eyes of the European Parliament, there could be debate. You insisted that consolidation would take place in parallel. However, it is the essence of the project, because it is the one that effectively fights tax evasion. I therefore hope that this Parliament will be as firm as possible to ensure that the two go hand in hand.  As far as research and development is concerned, you have put in place - perhaps on the drawings of existing examples in some Member States - an innovative project which I believe can foster a dynamic investment strategy at European level. We will, of course, ensure that this is not a new pocket of escape.  You have set a turnover threshold of EUR 750 million, a mandatory threshold, but you may be able to expect that some in this Parliament will want to lower this turnover in order to broaden the consolidated base of this tax.  Finally, of course, at some point, the issue of the minimum corporate tax rate will come up, as you know. Be sure that this Parliament, at least the Group of Socialists and Democrats, will do everything possible to accompany this proposal in the most fruitful way possible, which meets a real need for both businesses, states and our fellow citizens.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, according to OECD studies, aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance and tax evasion practices that many businesses follow cost the world economy losses of $100 billion to $240 billion a year. In the European Union, losses as a result of this process are estimated at EUR 50 to 70 billion per year. So it is time to create a fair tax system without grey areas and tax ruling practices at pan-European level. All Member States of the Union should take measures to ensure that multinational companies are taxed in the country where they make their profits and to stop turning to tax havens such as the Netherlands or Luxembourg. They should also stop using the practice of intra-group transactions by avoiding tax avoidance and depriving state budgets of huge tax revenues. The countries of Europe will not go down the path of development as long as there are companies that avoid and avoid tax.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, when it comes to the issue of companies paying their fair share of corporation tax, we have made some progress at European level. We have the administrative cooperation directive and the anti—tax avoidance directive. Personally, I have supported country-by-country reporting since I came to this Parliament 12 years ago.  We also have BEPS, and today we have the latest proposals on CCCTB. Indeed, there are positive aspects to this proposal and it will help to further tackle tax evasion, but there is a price. Yes, tax rates will be untouched, but tax sovereignty will be eroded. Member States will no longer be able to decide what is deductible and what is non-deductible, for example. Ministers for finance will not be able to change certain tax provisions during budgets, even if they believe it will benefit their economy. So this proposal asks Member States to hand over significant new powers to the Commission.  The other issue that concerns me is where corporation tax will be paid. Has any analysis been done to see what countries will lose corporation tax revenue and what countries will gain corporation tax revenue under your apportionment model? This model means that Member States with small domestic markets like my own, Ireland, or the Netherlands, who have secured significant foreign direct investment, will lose out on corporation tax revenue. It is absolutely essential that figures are produced so that Member States know the extent of the changes. This proposal has merit, but there will be winners and losers. If you want agreement, Commissioner, I believe this issue has to be dealt with head on.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), question with "blue card". – We must make it clear that we are all against tax evasion and avoidance. None of us want to defend all those who escape tax. But will the European Union cease to be a financial centre? Will we abolish countries that legally provide financial services and compete with countries outside the European Union? How can we control the system of rules and laws outside the European Union and to what fate will the small countries, such as my own country and others, that have invested in financial services by legal means and legal means be found? And if you abolish the possibility of setting tax rates, which is perfectly legal, how can you compete with even Great Britain or other countries outside the European Union? Are we not interested in the European Union remaining competitive in financial matters?

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – My reading certainly is that these proposals from the Commission do not touch our tax rates whatsoever. They have no impact on them. Member States are absolutely free to set their tax rates, and I think we are all happy about that. You talk about how to make Europe a more attractive place. I think one of the issues that we have to face is that there are mismatches between different tax systems outside Europe and the European tax system, and we have to deal with that. I know the Commission have proposals on that. I have not had time to study them deeply but I hope they will work. I suppose my issue here is that we are giving up a certain amount of tax sovereignty and, if we do that, we have to be sure that the outcomes that are in place are fair to Member States and that Member States can live with them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Madam Harkin, just a quick question: surely the Irish Republic is making a great deal of money out of their differential tax rates? Would it not be in the best interests of the Irish Republic to join Great Britain in their Brexit with an Irexit?

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think one of the reasons that the Irish economy is doing as well as it is at the moment is because those who invest in it know that we have 500 million customers that we can sell our goods to, and those 500 million customers reside in the EU. I think that is the reason why most Irish people, and indeed a majority in Northern Ireland, when they had an opportunity to vote, voted to remain in the EU. The EU has its challenges and I have articulated some of them here tonight. But I believe, for my country, access to that single market will help to drive our economic success, and I would not agree with Irexit.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has McDonald's and Co, for example, move profits to tax havens through artificial loans or licenses. The EU is therefore a paradise for tricksters, with free movement of capital and 28 different tax laws. Corporations are a unit, no matter how many mailboxes or daughters they have. It is therefore undoubtedly useful to determine their profits at EU level, to distribute consolidation, and by real economic activity. However, with this proposal for a CCCTB, the Commission does not create tax justice. For example, a company can continue to receive up to 74% of the profits of another company without them being part of the group. Tax havens outside the EU are not touched by this proposal, and this proposal also excludes sensible defences such as withholding taxes or barriers to royalties that go beyond the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive. Without minimum taxes, competition over rates threatens to be further inflamed. A CCCTB without the second C of consolidation also allows loss offsetting without profit allocation. There should be one only with the other.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are delighted that the Commission has finally revived the project of a common and consolidated corporate tax base. This project has been in the works for more than five years, although it is probably the best way to ensure that corporate profits are paid in the countries where they are made. We are particularly pleased that, in line with the will of this Parliament since 2012, the Commission has planned to make this system compulsory for the largest companies. I hope that the Commission will put all its energy into bringing this whole issue to a conclusion as soon as possible, including the mechanism for objective allocation of profits between Member States. This is a crucial step in the european Union's fiscal harmonisation.  However, we have reason to be concerned, because it seems that within our union, ladies and gentlemen, there is a kind of hierarchy of priorities. Indeed, when it comes to the conclusion of free trade treaties, the Commission and the Council show an unwavering determination to move as quickly as possible, even if it means using intimidation to bring back into line those States that would be a little too recalcitrant. But when it comes to combating tax evasion, the pressure suddenly drops, as if by some miracle, by at least ten notches. The forced march, which is de rigueur in trade treaties, suddenly gives way to a kind of optional hike. Wallonia is now under maximum pressure because it is vetoing the signing of a trade treaty tailor-made for the interests of multinationals, but it has been almost five years since Ireland, Malta, Cyprus and the United Kingdom blocked without any pressure the project we are talking about this evening. It is as if, when a blockade serves the interests of multinationals, it is kept low profile, whereas when a blockade is opposed to the interests of multinationals, all means are allowed to lift it. Colleagues, I think it is high time to reverse this hierarchy.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), question with "blue card". – We must finally make a distinction: Cyprus and Malta fully and fully apply all tax and transparency rules to a much higher degree than other countries of the European Union apply them. They specialized in financial services. Everything is done in a legitimate way. Will we come to strangle these countries and, in fact, to strangle the European Union by harming its financial sector in the name of combating tax evasion? We are against tax evasion and avoidance. One another, the other. And I think we have to be very careful, because in the end we will destroy both these countries, but also the European Union itself, which will no longer be a competitive financial partner.

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. Ladies and gentlemen, I think that when a state decides to base its competitiveness on the sole argument of tax competition, it risks, in the end, losing on all counts. This cannot be the selling point to attract multinationals. On the other hand, I am convinced that if we need rate harmonization, the solution cannot be the same for everyone. In other words, some countries, such as Ireland or Cyprus, are disadvantaged by geography, must be able to compensate, if only partially, for this geographical disadvantage with a tax advantage. However, this needs to be done in a concerted way between member states

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, Mr Moscovici is coming out again with the same old idea that was criticised in the past: to install a common consolidated corporate tax base. The Commission says this base is necessary to create a fairer taxation system with more transparency, but what it really means is the first step to supranational fiscal union.  Secondly, the Commission wants a common EU list of so—called non—cooperative tax jurisdictions. This is a system for blackmailing more competitive countries and making them fall into line. If you reduce tax competition between states there is no incentive to keep the public services efficient and the government will continue to plunder taxpayers’ hard—earned money.  The good news for the UK taxpayer is that with a hard Brexit, out of the single market and fiscal union, the UK can reduce corporate tax to 10%, making us massively more competitive than the sclerotic overtaxed EU. Our Irish brethren are already doing this and may join us in our exit. I hope that Ms Harkin will perhaps see the logic of my argument.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to first congratulate the Commissioner and the Commission and then thank them for keeping the commitments made today and for tomorrow on consolidation. Having the same definition of taxable profit throughout the Union is not a revolutionary idea, nor even a new one. The principle was accepted almost twenty years ago by all governments, including, dear Coburn, by the British government of the day. This seemed obvious to the smooth functioning of the large market. But it took the Lux Leaks scandal and the pressure of public opinion for this evidence to come out of oblivion.  We say yes to tax competition within the European Union itself but in transparency, fairness and loyalty. This is the goal of your project. The experience gained in the TAXE committee leads me to make two recommendations. I address the first to our Parliament: let us build on the relationship we have had with the relevant committees of both houses of the United States Congress. On taxation, it is Congress that decides, not the administration. However, U.S. legislation is the primary source of tax optimization schemes. Second, I give advice to our governments: our direct taxation is a century behind. Designed for the industrial economy of the mid-20th century, it is unsuitable for the era of globalization and digitization. All our countries are encouraged today to focus taxes on people and businesses that cannot move easily, it is an economic mistake and a serious social injustice.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate you and welcome this new initiative which will take a further step towards this indispensable improvement of the European tax system, in particular to combat tax competition between Member States and, therefore, against massive tax avoidance practices. I believe that this directive is crucial, because in the future a multinational will be able to comply with a single regime within the Union to calculate its taxable result rather than different schemes specific to each of the Member States in which it operates. THE ACCIS provides a comprehensive solution to the current problem of corporate taxation in the European Union and contributes to improving the business environment in our single market by making it simpler and cheaper for cross-border activities. The ACCIS is above all a powerful instrument to combat corporate tax evasion by removing disparities between national systems and establishing common provisions to combat tax evasion. I will add a few points, Commissioner. Having said that, the Commission now wants large groups to subscribe to the CSA on a mandatory way. This is a first step forward, but unfortunately, as my colleague Pervenche Berès has said, the threshold for defining large groups is EUR 750 million. We are obviously arguing for it to be reduced to EUR 40 million, as is the case for banks. If this threshold is not lowered, large companies such as, for example, Jeff de Bruges, a well-known chocolatier in France, would not be considered a large group, although it is well known that this company makes more than 600 million profits per year and is established all over the world. I don't think our citizens would understand.  I am also a little sad that the consolidation of the tax base is only done in a second phase. One text would have been more coherent, but we are obviously counting on you to have these two texts voted together. Finally, it is clear that for tax rates, we must have a European reflection, as we do in other parts of the world, for example in the United States. We could very well consider a European fixed rate and a limited variable rate.  We are counting on you, Commissioner, and we hope that the Council will follow you in this and all the good proposals you put on the table.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the tax burden cannot only be on the side of workers and small and medium-sized enterprises and this Commission already has a very strong mark of compromises on multinationals.  A common tax base like the one it presents for multinationals in Europe may be a good idea, but it is only a good idea if, and only if, the aim is to set a decent minimum rate as well. Otherwise, this rule could offer a tax model to large corporations that allows them to compare the different countries even better and promote even more tax dumping and even more tax evasion. That is why I ask you, Commissioner, if it is to be done seriously and that it also deal with the free movement of capital, and therefore by regulating it, and to deal with tax havens, ending with them.  Do not pretend, Commissioner, to be consistent, to finally put citizens ahead of large corporations, whether in tax policy or in major trade agreements such as CETA or TTIP. Citizens would surely thank you for not having more... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, so far, the campaign for tax justice has been largely reactive. As politicians, we have reacted to the news about laughably small tax payments from companies like Apple, IKEA and McDonalds and we have been reacting to the outrage from those we represent about the way multinationals gain an unfair advantage in competitive markets, and that this deprives governments of revenue they need for public investment. For many years, the Green Group has been campaigning for strong political action to achieve tax justice, so we are delighted to welcome the re-launch of the Commission’s proposal for a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base and we welcome the message it sends: that the political institutions are listening to people again, and that they are not continuing to chase after corporations who are always one step ahead. This is the sort of action we need if we are to rebuild people’s confidence, both in the European institutions and in our democratic politicians. The way we currently tax companies, treating subsidiaries from the same company as if they are completely independent entities, does not reflect the reality of their operations. Implementing a common and consolidated system for taxing companies across the Union would be a crucial step towards ending tax avoidance by global corporations. But I would also stress, as other colleagues have done, the importance of moving towards a minimum corporate tax rate across our continent, bringing an end to the race to the bottom on tax rates. My own country, the UK, is now at a crossroads. Will we follow Europe in promoting action to end corporate tax avoidance or follow the route being pushed by some hard—Brexit supporters and become one of the world’s leading tax havens?  It is clear that the public interest is best served by following the EU’s ambitious lead on tax policy, and we must all work to ensure that Brexit does not encourage further tax competition between Member States.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Finally, we are a big step closer to implementing our demands. On the one hand, we want taxes to be paid where the economic activity takes place. We therefore welcome, as a first step, the proposal for a single corporate tax base and, as a second step, group taxation. We need more common tax policy at all. Only with more common tax policy, more transparency, country-by-country reporting and common tax bases can we close the tax loopholes that benefit businesses and some Member States and prevent tax evasion. I appeal to the Member States not to continue to block, to implement them at last and to show us that they are prepared to do what the citizens demand and that the internal market needs. Turn away from unanimity and take the double majority as the basis for the decision on this package!

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the Commissioner very much for this very important corporate tax reform package. Tax should be paid where profits are made, and I think that is a really good guiding principle. In our single market, the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) is fundamental to an effective non—bureaucratic tax cooperation for our Member States, for our companies, and for growth and jobs in Europe. We need to get rid of the 28 Member States’ different national systems that blur up things. It is also a crucial step to end big corporations’ tax dodging in the EU and to deliver more tax justice for our citizens. Tax avoidance and evasion is threatening our welfare state in Europe today by eroding the tax base. Tax dodging, illuminating massive tax injustices for our citizens and SMEs that pay their fair taxes, is destroying jobs and growth in Europe because of unfair competition and an unlevel playing field for companies in our single market. SMEs create more than eight out of ten jobs and should not be punished but rewarded in our market. We have witnessed numerous scandals – LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, Bahamas Leaks – and this has revealed a corrupt and unfair tax system. This is only the tip of the iceberg. Therefore transparency, simple and better rules and effective cooperation need to replace this broken tax system. The European Parliament has applied real pressure to ensure this and several times asked for an effective CCCTB. This means that both the common corporate tax base and consolidation should be adopted as one package, and the threshold of EUR 750 million should be lowered to make the system more comprehensive and more effective. I also very much welcome the simple and clear rules regarding R&D that in particular support SMEs and start—ups. It is really important that we should avoid the artificial profit shifting that we have seen in patent box systems in Europe. Finally, the European Parliament is ready to move fast on CCCTB, and Member States should support us and the Commission in that endeavour.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we need to see maximum tax powers remain with national governments to ensure that they are held accountable for their decisions by their electorates. We also need to see effective international action against tax avoidance, one of the great global injustices of our time. But Commissioner, your proposal falls short. This proposal may, in fact, actually intensify the race to the bottom on corporate tax in the EU; it will not end international transfer pricing or the shifting of profits offshore. Governments or the Commission saying that they are tackling tax avoidance is not the same thing as actually doing it. For example, many people believe that the infamous double Irish scam used by Google and Facebook and Microsoft is to be phased out by 2020, but reports of its death have been greatly exaggerated. Despite the spin, it is still in place for companies who set up a subsidiary in certain countries that Ireland has a tax treaty with, such as Malta, as these treaties override domestic law. This notorious tax loophole and all such vehicles need to end immediately as a first step to delivering tax justice.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, moving forward to prevent multinationals from doing intergroup tax tricks to avoid paying taxes is good news. You have to be ambitious about that and let multinationals pay their dues. On the proposal you are presenting to us, Commissioner, a few things. First, you make it mandatory for multinationals with revenues of more than 750 million euros. We believe that cap is too high; we're probably going to ask you to take that down. Second, the deductions in some cases are too broad: the deductions for debt and equity financing costs, too broad; deductions for start-ups from 200% to 20 million, too broad; and R&D&I deductions up to 150% to 20 million, too broad as well. I believe that these deductions should be reduced in a much more important way. And finally, Commissioner, a minimum corporate tax rate. That battle, the Commission cannot give it up, and Parliament and many of the groups in this House are going to demand it. Without a minimum corporate tax rate, we will not be able to deal with the hole that is now corporation tax in the European Union.

name: Peter Simon (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is interesting to see who is worried about fair corporate taxation here today. It is also interesting to see where the Members come from. However, I can only say against all of them: anyone who wants fair tax competition must support exactly what the European Commission has proposed today. We need transparency, we need a single Community corporate tax base as the basis for all competition. Those who are opposed to this transparency can really only be concerned with maintaining the lack of transparency – the shaming that enables artificial small-scale calculation of corporate profits. Anyone who is serious about fairness in tax competition cannot be against transparency. In this respect, what we have been presented with today is the very first step towards fair tax competition. The question of the level of tax rates, which comes as a follow-up question, and that is where we must then discuss. However, consolidation will be required as an intermediate step. As a signal, I think we must send out today to the Member States that we will not let this second project be put on the back burner by them. I think that we are jointly called upon to keep up the pressure on the Member States. The only thing I would like to see in this dossier, where we should go much deeper, is the question: who are we subjecting to a common corporate tax base? I find the approach of taking only the 1 900 largest companies with an annual turnover of EUR 750 million too short.  I would like to call for more ambitious people here. We should stick to the uniform definition of large EU companies – EUR 40 million of annual turnover – and then we have all the relevant players ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Madam President; I join, ladies and gentlemen, in congratulating the Commissioner and I in addition to the support that the Socialist Group wants to give him, because I believe that harmonising the foundations is fundamental in tax justice.
