But let's be honest: we have two very important problems. The first is that this Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, has no decision-making power. We are only required to make a consultation, because the council will decide. Parliament only gives an opinion and the Council, we know, has been paralyzing for five years. And although there is a social alarm, there is an opportunity — we agree on this – but I believe that we run the risk that the Council will interpret taxation as being nationally sovereignty and that no European intervention is allowed. Unanimity is considered necessary for any rule in this area, and this is a very serious problem.  And the second problem is that right here, ladies and gentlemen, we have to recognise that there are many voices calling for taxation to be a legitimate factor of competition between countries, that businesses can be attracted and economies with lower taxes can be attracted. This is here, a lot of people think so. And until we unify and effectively harmonise taxation and give up national sovereignty, there will be no harmonization of a single kind, there will be no single market that works well and there will be no tax justice.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – At an annual level, as we have all noted, we lose billions of euros that could be spent on more useful purposes, for education, for health, for creating new jobs and for strengthening the economy.  We must do everything to ensure that companies pay taxes where they actually carry out an economic activity and that they contribute their fair share to the tax treasury. However, in order to have a comprehensive overview of where companies actually pay taxes, it is important that Europe takes a coordinated approach, not through twenty-eight different approaches.  The new measures covered by the Commission package will allow member states to work more coherently and to exchange the necessary information. I particularly welcome today's proposal from the Commission, which has finally proposed a consolidated tax base. It's a small victory, but a step in the right direction.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the truth is that some of us have experienced astonished how the Council left this House just as this debate began. The Commissioner entered the chamber and the representative of the Council left this debate. This really is disgraceful and I hope it's not a bad omen for what's ahead of us. Commissioner, you have the strong and solid support of the entire Socialist Group. We hope that this House will be able to study, reflect and contribute new ideas to this initiative in the coming months to make a common corporation tax in Europe truly possible. And I also hope that this effort by this House and that support for the Commission will mean that the Council will come here to face it and that the Council will accept this initiative which we so desperately need to build the true Europe of citizens, the true future of the European Union. So, let us hope to have this improvement in Parliament and then discuss that minimum rate, that minimum rate for a European corporation tax as well.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the interesting thing about coming in here today was that this particularly affects Ireland. It is no secret that it is a cornerstone of our economic policy for successive governments. Stone, though, is a bit of a strong word for it, because that stone is starting to be worn away. When I came in here today I was expecting to see members of our government – MEPs from that party – coming in here to defend it, because it is a cornerstone of their policy. It was interesting to hear the Commissioner say at the beginning that we have a more favourable political environment. Well, Ireland and Irish people are seen as supportive of the EU project. It’s strange, because a Member of the EPP has said that if you go ahead any further with this, they will get Ireland to pull out of the EU. So it’s interesting you say it is a more political favourable environment. I was wondering, until the President turned up, had we already Irexited, because none of them were here.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, this proposal which you say is better and different is the 2011 consolidated common corporate tax base, then buried by the United Kingdom and Ireland. As the Lux Leaks and Panama Papers scandals and others demonstrate, the transfer of profits from multinationals deprives Member States, such as mine, Portugal, of important tax revenues with large companies relocating holding companies to the Netherlands, Luxembourg and other tax havens to avoid paying taxes.  Fiscal pseudo-sovereignty in the internal market for free movement has exacerbated economic divergence in the euro area and made fiscal and social injustice unbearable. Member States can no longer block an agreement on this matter which should include the consolidation 'C' and the determination of a minimum rate applicable throughout the European Union.  We are with you, Commissioner, ahead.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this package is part of the wider objective of linking taxation to the place where the real business of the company takes place. Tax avoidance practices directly affect the functioning of the internal market and create harmful tax competition, while the aim of the package is precisely to realign corporate taxation with the relevant corporate revenues of the corporate taxpayer, while today it is the news that Apple continues to expand its tax activities in Ireland. In the knowledge that the relaunch of the CCTB and the further attempt to legislate on corporation tax – I am convinced of this – is a necessary means of harmonising the rules by which companies calculate their tax bases throughout the European Union. Of course, the consolidation element is the most sensitive aspect of the proposal, but I agree with the methodology of profit-sharing based on work, activity and sales.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for this debate which has shown that our objectives are the same. I have listened to everything that has been said here and I really take your remarks as an encouragement.  Together we want to put in place a fair and effective corporate tax system within the Union. THE ACCIS - and you all measure it - is really a revolutionary project that will achieve the much-needed single business tax market. I really look forward to your support to move this issue forward and I thank you for showing it here.  Some of you have raised the issue of the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States. That is precisely what we are trying to do with the package presented today, which is to restore the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States.  With the ACCIS, the European Union, which remains the world's leading trading power, will be able to impose its tax rules on these economic giants that are multinationals rather than to be satisfied, at best, with their alms. Thus, the fiscal sovereignty of all Member States will be restored. It must not be a word, it must be a truth. There will be no winner or loser. The consolidated base will be distributed according to objective criteria that reflect the economic activity of the companies. The principle that we defend - you know that I am pushing it methodically in all the texts I propose - is that of effective taxation whereby profits must be taxed where they are created. It is on this principle that we have structured this proposal.  I hear what you are saying, both of which, about rates. Some want us to harmonize them, others fear them. As such, I have to do the desirable and the possible. I do not comment on the desirable, but I know what is possible given the unanimity rule. I would therefore like to say that we will not touch the rates , and I say this in the clearest way - and that we will never touch them until the Member States themselves want to do so or as long as the rule does not change, but I do not see a fierce appetite for treaty changes at this time. Therefore, the most important instrument, which allows states to manage their tax revenues, will remain intact. This proposal, whether we welcome it or not, is not hostile to tax competition, which is also one of the elements of attractiveness, but it sets up, once again, major rules of solidarity.  This assembly is called, alongside us, to play a great role, its usual role, not only as a counterweight but really as a political impulse vis-à-vis the Council. I therefore count on your continued and effective action to quickly reach this issue. I say "quick" but I also know that the discussion will surely be quite difficult, if not a little long. However, we have deadlines that have been set (2019-2021) and will come quickly if the countdown is triggered.  I'm counting on you the way you can count on me.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – This corporate tax package, which it proposes through two directives, must be welcomed, harmonised and consolidated. The original proposal, from 2011, has been blocked in the Council by certain Member States, which is truly unacceptable. The internal market cannot be built and fiscal justification ensured if some States continue to think about using their tax regimes to artificially attract profits generated in another jurisdiction. The Commission is right to separate BICCIS into two directives, since the consolidation of the basis and the attribution formula are undoubtedly the most controversial elements. But it is sufficient to harmonise the basis (mainly deductions), because if the same calculation formula is not applied to settle the tax, the artificial transfer of profits will be maintained. It is also important to reduce the applicable threshold from EUR 750 million to EUR 40. We must ensure that the Council does its job, so that one or two countries do not block these measures. For the Spanish Socialists the fight against tax evasion and avoidance is an absolute priority, which should not be undermined on the basis of an anachronistic claim of national sovereignty.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I hereby wish to endorse the European Commission's proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB). It is an important step in the right direction to combat tax avoidance. Personally, however, I would be in favour of lowering the turnover limit for companies that would be subject to the rules below the proposed EUR 750 million. I believe that the current system is unfair because it allows large multinational corporations to shift profits where the lowest tax rates apply, and taxes are being pulled from companies that do not have that option.

text: in writing. – This corporate tax package, which it proposes through two directives, must be welcomed, harmonised and consolidated. name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. The Commission's proposal for a uniform method of calculating profits is a first important step towards tax justice. Taxes must finally be paid where profits are made. In order to achieve this objective, I see a need for improvement: the separation of the tax base from consolidation into two separate directives must not lead to consolidation being postponed until the last day. This is the only way to impute profits to the Member State in which they are created. The common tax base must also go hand in hand with EU-wide minimum tax rates. Currently, corporation tax is 25% in Austria, but only 12.5% in Ireland, for example. Without minimum tax rates, we cannot put an end to tax dumping. Only companies with a turnover of more than EUR 750 million per year will be affected. This would affect only 1.6% of multinationals. Last but not least, this threshold must therefore be set much lower. In order to ensure fair taxation of companies, this proposal still needs a clear social democratic signature.

text: in writing. – This corporate tax package, which it proposes through two directives, must be welcomed, harmonised and consolidated. name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The decision to combat fraud and tax evasion is to be welcomed. However, it cannot fail to bring a strong halt to hypocrisy.  Fraud and tax evasion are largely legal. They use instruments that have been deliberately designed by EU governments to serve the interests of multinational companies. Such is the example of the Netherlands, Luxembourg or the United Kingdom, among many others, which have focused their economic policies on creating conditions to attract fictitious capital, favouring tax piracy operations with other national states.  The European Commission's major announcements in the face of the Lux Leaks scandal are now following minimalist measures, the scope of which is dubious and which will be a frustration among those who are tired of this scandal and demand firm action.  But it's important to say it. There will be no change if the foundations of the capitalist system that promotes the freedom of movement of capital and the deregulation of the financial system are not questioned.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, today marks a day when we can say that we are one step closer to dignity and respect for all of our citizens, including those with disabilities. This is because of the hard work of this House and thanks to the true leadership of the Dutch Presidency, which understood that this piece of legislation is vital.  Europe is now not only on the cusp of a digital revolution, but we are in the middle of it. It is the policy of the Union that every sector, both private and public, should be digital, and that by going digital we will renew growth in Europe and make life easier for our citizens. If our digital services are not accessible to all of our citizens, we are not helping them but are instead holding many back and introducing new barriers. There are more than 80 million Europeans with a disability. As we age, every one of us will have either a temporary or permanent disability at some point. This is as true for those digital natives among us as it is for those born before the internet. Making digital information accessible is as much in our own individual interest as that of society as a whole. I am proud that, as of tomorrow, web accessibility will be the law of the land in Europe. Every government website and – maybe more importantly – every government application will have to be accessible. This law applies not only to the public, but also to internal government websites, meaning that it will help the millions of government employees with disabilities and help open new job opportunities for others. This law means that all online and digital forums and all payment systems will have to be accessible. It will end the outlandish situation whereby we require people to pay their taxes online, only to create a website that not all people can use. Today, we are saying that e—government must be open and service all citizens. For this reason, I am proud. Is this the final step? No, Mr Commissioner, it is not. There are still some limitations to making this law proportional, but, if something is not accessible, governments will now be accountable to give a clear reason why it is not, and that reason cannot be that it would simply cost too much. Every citizen will have a right to challenge such a decision. It is also not the last step because the digital world is more than government websites alone. We still need a strong European Accessibility Act that covers both the digital and physical worlds. Parliament has a good voice for this in my colleague, Mr Løkkegaard. We need to adopt the Accessibility Act as soon as possible. When it has been adopted, the two combined will mean that we can say that we have served our citizens well and done everything we can to help all of them. I am proud to have my name attached to this legislation, and I look forward to its adoption tomorrow.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me thank those who made it possible from Parliament and the Council to get this directive finally close to adoption. The Web Accessibility Directive is a major step towards an inclusive digital single market and digital society. As the European Union population ages and the number of people with disability is expected to increase to 120 million by 2020, the internet is an essential way to access and provide information and services. It is therefore more important than ever to make sure that everyone can benefit from it. The directive will make the internet more accessible, especially for people with disabilities. It will help people left behind in the digital society to have the same opportunities online to participate to a fuller extent in the digital society, and it will lead to a more independent life. It will make websites and mobile apps easier to navigate, interact and use. People with disabilities, such as those with visual or hearing impairments, will be able to better access, perceive and understand digital information and services, for example through subtitles or audio descriptions. the directive will not only benefit citizens, it will bring economic benefits to our societies as a whole. In particular the directive will benefit to market this with positive spill-over or effect, not only for public sector bodies but also for other players producing products and services relating to the accessibility of websites and mobile applications. The directive shows the commitment of the European Union and its Member States to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in promoting access to new information and communications technologies and systems of public sector bodies. Since the adoption of the Commission’s proposal four years ago, technological development has in the meantime required some adaptation. We welcome the work of Parliament and the Council to give a wider scope to the directive. Extending it to nearly all public sector bodies’ websites and also covering mobile applications will make the directive more pervasive and future-proof. The Commission will work to support the effective implementation of the directive. They count on the cooperation with Member States, a cooperation that has already been proven to be efficient in the past. President, honourable Members, that you very much indeed for such excellent cooperation and for your attention.

name: Sabine Verheyen
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Accessible access to public sector websites is of great importance to our citizens as more and more services are offered online in the public sector. I am therefore very pleased that we can finally vote on this issue tomorrow. The agreement, after almost four years of deliberations and negotiations, is more than overdue. Public institutions and municipalities are already doing a lot to improve barrier-free access to information and eGovernment services in the course of digitalisation. But much more needs to be done to give people with disabilities equal access to public services and websites. With the text now before us, we have found a balanced compromise that requires a great deal, but also offers sufficient flexibility. For example, all public sector websites fall within the scope of the Directive. It was also very important to fully integrate public sector apps, because people with disabilities in particular are increasingly using their smartphones and therefore need accessible apps. In return, a clear and unambiguous list of exceptions was negotiated and a disproportionate clause was introduced. It was important to ensure that excessive demands are not placed, because a reduction in online content and services due to disproportionately high requirements would have had a negative impact on all European citizens and would not have led to an improvement in the situation and fair participation. The outcome of the negotiations was a way of taking account of all sides. In the area of public broadcasting, we in Parliament will be pushing for the arising of accessibility requirements to be enshrined and swiftly implemented in the AVMSD directive, and for us to take a significant step forward here – in the interests of people with disabilities.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A life without the Internet is no longer conceivable for us today. Of course, it is not available to everyone in the same way; this is called the digital gap. It is also not enough to have Internet access if, for various reasons, one is not able to use the offers accordingly. Disabled people are particularly affected. For them, the Internet is also often particularly essential. It is incomprehensible that our directive has been blocked in the Council for so long. I am very grateful to the Dutch Presidency at the time for taking the initiative, and I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Charanzova, in particular for her negotiating skills and tenacity. The new Directive obliges public authorities, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries to design their web services in such a way that they are accessible and usable for all. This would meet the four criteria of the barrier-free Internet: perceptibility, usability, comprehensibility and robustness.  It is just as important as access to websites to be able to use apps without discrimination. That was one of Parliament's successes in the trialogue negotiations.  Once implemented, the directive means a great relief to everyday life and an improvement in their participation opportunities for more than 80 million people who are physically or age-related. Particular mention should also be made of the establishment of a feedback mechanism through which users can notify the public authorities of shortcomings in the accessibility of websites or mobile applications. Member States must designate a competent authority to monitor and enforce compliance. This also guarantees that the whole thing is more than a nice declaration of intent. Our directive is also an important point of reference for the further development of the Digital Single Market. This is particularly true of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, in a digital age we need to make sure that online content and services are accessible to all, and ensure equality of access to the digital world, just as we have endeavoured to do in the physical world.  I would like to thank all my colleagues, especially the rapporteur, for their work on this file. I am pleased that we managed to get a more coherent text and a forward—looking approach, including a pathway to introduce the mobile apps into the scope. It is important that legislation does not unnecessarily become a burden on public sector bodies, which is why we also brought in the ability in certain cases for the on-demand system. It was very important that, where there are complaints, these are actually answered. I would like to thank the Commissioner for that. In our Group, Helga Stevens MEP has been doing some incredibly impressive work to make sure that Parliament thinks very hard about accessibility in everything we do. I would like to thank the many organisations that helped with their advice on this work, and particularly, from the UK, the RNIB, the organisation for blind people. Thank you so much for your assistance.

name: Morten Løkkegaard
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would first of all like to thank our rapporteur for the excellent work. As a rapporteur myself for the Accessibility Directive, I now have something good to build on, and, of course, I will try to do that. I will make the rest of my comments in Danish, since I also have a Danish audience. Thank you to the rapporteur for his work. As I said, I will try to build on this in the further work on the Accessibility Directive. It is about, as has also been said earlier by others, a well-functioning digital single market. After all, we all spend the majority of our time on the Internet, which is why, of course, it is also a top priority for the Liberal Group that all people get something out of the Digital Single Market. For example, everyone has equal access to government websites and apps, as has been described. In this way, the proposal is an important piece in achieving an even greater objective, namely that we are all given accessibility, including as disabled people, not only to the network, but also to physical activities throughout Europe. Now work continues on accessibility for people with disabilities. It is important that we strike the delicate balance between a well-functioning internal market and accessibility for the many millions of citizens who are currently struggling with a lack of accessibility. I will do my part to strike this delicate balance. I am very much looking forward to the work in the coming days.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, we are particularly interested in this proposal for a directive because it concerns eighty million people. We are asking for it to be implemented quickly, because we, people with disabilities, need to have access to the electronic pages of public bodies to ask for a certificate, to plan a hospital visit, to submit a tax return without hassle. For many, all this is self-evident, but to us, people with disabilities, the simpler things look like luxury. I suggest that the Members of the Commission come to our position a little to understand how long they have delayed the directive we have been waiting for since 2012. If they felt our needs, we would live in a better Europe.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Dear Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. In the age of the digital society, it is essential that information and online services available on the Internet, especially in the public sector, are accessible and provided to all. I could say they're insured without hindrance. Unfortunately, there are around 80 million EU citizens who cannot benefit from this advantage, cannot benefit from the digital society, and I can even say that it will be cumulatively disadvantaged from not being able to achieve these benefits. We should have a goal of being accessible to everyone. In 2016, talking about the fact that there are people who cannot enjoy these benefits – I think – is a task that needs to be solved very urgently. I therefore congratulate the reporter, and I also regret that it took so long for this report to be complete, and we include this performance as one of the tasks already solved instead of the tasks to be solved.  However, there are still tasks to be carried out. I know that we have taken the right step and are taking this step in the right direction, but it is often also necessary to see that there is little hardware, software, professionals who are able to help these fellow human beings. There are still tasks that we need to do. I think that's the next step.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – We take access to information and services for granted in today's digitising society. However, only a third of public sector websites in the EU meet international standards of internet accessibility. In practice, it is therefore impossible for many people with disabilities, but also, for example, for the elderly to use many public services online. The adoption of this proposal will significantly simplify the accessibility and use of services for disadvantaged people and improve their quality of life. I would like to highlight the EP's role in the legislative process. We have managed to make websites managed by the public sector, including mobile applications, fully accessible.  As shadow rapporteur for the European Accessibility Act, I believe that by confirming this text, our commitment to enabling the use of ordinary services and goods to European citizens does not end in any way and on an equal basis. It is access to some of the key products and services that the act brings that is another equally important prerequisite for the full participation of all citizens in society. Let us not forget that we must create a digital internal market for all EU citizens.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: – First of all, I would like to thank Dita for all the good work on this dossier. I believe that with this legislation we have succeeded in demonstrating that Europe can indeed offer added value.  I think the two main successes are the following. Firstly, it is a forward-looking proposal. We have succeeded in ensuring that not only the websites but also the applications, the apps, will be more accessible. Secondly, I believe that we have struck a good balance between accessibility on the one hand and, on the other hand, avoiding disproportionate burdens on public authorities. Accessibility does have a cost. For example, it is not reasonable to ask a museum to make all its archives accessible online. That's why we've been working with an on-demand system. People who would like certain information online can ask for it.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I will be following up on my pre-spokes, my colleague Sehnalová from the committee, etc., when, like them, I perceive the great positives of this proposal. In short, if the main agenda of the IMCO committee for this parliamentary term is the question of the possibility of setting up a digital market, then it is necessary to ask how to set up that market in order to make it accessible to citizens. Address the issue of accessibility, especially for people who suffer from certain defects or have certain health problems. This is what this proposal is about, this is what this directive is about, and I very much welcome and support it, because if the directive is adopted, it will make disabled people more accessible to the Internet and mobile applications created by public institutions. In my opinion, this is extremely important because the disability of disabled and elderly people needs to be removed, because, according to statistics, around 80 million people in the EU are currently suffering from health problems, but up to 120 million people are expected to suffer from certain disabilities by 2020, i.e. it makes sense.  In my opinion, the only thing I would like to reproach myself for is excessive bureaucratisation as regards the mandatory reports that Member States must send to the Commission in Brussels, which will evaluate whether or not countries comply with this directive.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Equal access for citizens to public power, to public institutions is the foundation of democracy and civil society. This is extremely important both in the real world and in the virtual world, but it is particularly important nowadays, in the age of information society, and particularly important when it comes to people with disabilities. For some of them, contact with public authorities, with public institutions via the internet is the only chance at all to have a connection with their state, their power or with a public institution. Therefore, the idea that is implemented in the project is extremely important and worthy of support. It must also be remembered that this virtual world nowadays – and probably even more so in the future – will be one of the main planes of self-realization of the citizen, so the finale of this work is important.  However, it is also worth remembering that the responsibilities of the State, public institutions and the private sector must not be equated and the issues we are discussing today must be implemented, and effectively, as far as the institutions and the public sector are concerned, but should not be imposed on the private sector.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – There are 40 times more people with special needs in Europe than my country has. As the population ages, however, we can expect their numbers to continue to increase in the coming years.  In today's age, when the Internet has become our main tool for accessing information, for communication and services on the Internet, I believe that in terms of accessibility for all users, including people with disabilities, we should no longer talk about it at all, this should no longer be an issue.  In the development that we have experienced and which we are still witnessing, it is unacceptable that such a large group of people do not yet have the same access to digital products and services. This, of course, prevents them from living on an equal life, equal participation in education in the digital society and, of course, also in the labour market.  I therefore very nicely, very warmly welcome the fact that the provisions of this Directive will make websites and mobile applications of public authorities comply with common European accessibility standards. This is one of the essential steps to ensure equality and prevent discrimination.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, information and service providers, such as public bodies, are increasingly relying on the Internet. It is therefore necessary to respect certain principles in the design, construction and maintenance of websites, as well as mobile applications, in order to make them more accessible to users. In addition, each Member State should rely on agreed accessibility requirements in order to benefit public sector organisations from the cheaper provision of products and services related to Internet accessibility. Finally, small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the suppliers of accessible websites and applications, should also benefit and thus contribute to economic growth and job creation within the European Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I have many years of experience working with citizens with disabilities and with special needs or with their associations and I must say, I remember the time when the first phones came and after when the smartphones came, how much joy and happiness it was for many of them. Likewise, experience related to public sector service, related to e-payment or e-communication is something that has proven to be extremely valuable.  To combine this in one of these reports is something that I strongly support and want to say as a person who has for twenty years really tried to make life easier and without barriers, because with this present way in which we intend to create a new quality of life through this directive, to create an inclusive society for eighty million people who have special needs in Europe, this is something that requires the complete and strong support of all of us.  In the end, I just want to add this: the next step must be free wi-fi for everyone. That's what Juncker announced, we need to give him complete support to make it happen.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, of course I agree with those very sensitive words said to us by Madam Kuneva. It is of course regrettable that our legislative process takes time but, as I already mentioned earlier, the web accessibility directive is a cornerstone of an inclusive digital single market.  Of course it demonstrates once more that co-legislators can work together to create a better Europe, enhancing social inclusion and eliminating barriers hampering competition, competitiveness and economic growth. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Dita Charanzová, and the shadow rapporteurs, for their dedicated and hard work to get the directive to this stage.  We look forward to the vote of adoption by Parliament and assure you that we are fully committed to helping and facilitating the implementation of the directive.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner Andriukaitis, I think this debate has confirmed what I said at the beginning. We all believe that each individual must be treated with dignity and respect by our governments and our society. This will be endorsed tomorrow when both this legislation and a pilot project that supports it are adopted. EUR 600 000 will be available to make the web accessible, thanks to the Members of this House. I hope that the Commission will use this money wisely. Let me end by thanking all the shadows and colleagues who expressed their views today. I would also like to thank everyone in this House who made this possible, especially the policy adviser of the ALDE Group, Thierry Masson, and my assistant Andrew Hillman, as well as the whole IMCO Secretariat and our Chair, Vicky Ford. I look forward to our Parliament continuing to be a voice for all the people of Europe, including persons with disabilities.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I am very pleased that, finally, all the Member States have agreed on this extremely important directive. Websites and mobile applications for disabled people and the elderly will become more accessible to ministries, hospitals, courts and other public bodies. They'll be helped by helpers like screen readers, alternative text, or audio information to browse the web. We in the European Parliament have achieved that the new rules also include mobile apps. Websites will have to publish information about their compliance with the new EU rules, as well as which content does not comply with them and why. Viewers will have the opportunity to notify website authors of non-compliance with accessibility requirements. Some of the content on the sites, such as software file formats, pre-recorded video or audio clips or archived content, may not match them, but this information will have to be provided to the user in an appropriate manner and format upon request. This provision has also emerged in the document thanks to Parliament. As the rules have already been agreed with the Council of the EU, there are no longer any obstacles to their entry into force. EU countries will have almost two years to transpose these rules into their own law. Until then, the websites created will have to be adapted to the new requirements within two years, newly created web pages within one year and all mobile applications within almost three years.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. – With the adoption of this directive, known as the Web Directive, from now on, all websites and mobile applications, including electronic and multimedia documents, of public authorities in Europe have to be accessible to a wide range of users, including 80 million persons with disabilities. This is a crucial milestone in achieving an inclusive digital society, in which people with disabilities and other users have access to online services on an equal footing with others, which is a right enshrined in the UN CDPD. The Union must ensure its implementation at national level and that the exceptions provided for in the text are not abused. By monitoring and reporting to the Commission and an expert group of stakeholders at European level, the Union can more easily address implementation problems and work more effectively. In addition, other relevant or complementary Union legislation, including the European Accessibility Act and the revision of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, should continue to be advocated to ensure that what is not covered by the Web Directive will be adequately addressed.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – I am pleased to conclude today that a 4-year work can be completed and, in line with my report adopted by the European Parliament on 25 October 2011, innovative and knowledge-based economies can no longer develop without content and forms introduced by mandatory legislation accessible to people with disabilities. As is memorable, the European Commission initially put a much more limited proposal on the table, which we in This House have significantly expanded. In addition to the public sector services originally proposed, a wide range of public services are now covered. Not only web pages, but also mobile apps will be subject to accessibility regulations, as the use of standards will also be required by law. Finally, advocacy bodies for people with disabilities also play a role in implementation, for which there are plenty of two years, about 21 months. The work is not over: the audiovisual package and the European Accessibility Act are on the way.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The digital single market aims at bringing people together. For many of us, going online is the quickest and most convenient way of getting informed. However this is not a reality for around one fifth of the EU population. A great deal of the public sector bodies’ websites are not fit for use by people with disabilities, such as hearing and vision impairment. The swift implementation of the Accessibility of public sector bodies’ websites Directive will empower European consumers with disabilities to access information and public services available online. I invite the European Commission to keep a close eye on the process of implementation. At the same time, however this process should not pose disproportionate burden on EU Member States. The European Parliament managed to keep the text realistic and reasonable, which I believe will help the smooth work-on-the-ground of this Directive. I would like to thank all colleagues involved in the negotiations, who managed to widen the scope to all public sector bodies and also to include the mobile sites and applications. This is a step towards enabling people with disabilities to access the public sector bodies’ websites anywhere at any time and also a key step to future-proof this Directive.

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, plant health is a very important issue across the whole of Europe and the agreement that we have reached on protective measures against pests of plants is a really significant achievement. I would particularly like to pay tribute to my shadows and thank them for all their work, for their positive approach and for their cooperation over many months. This regulation will strengthen our phytosanitary security and our biodiversity through a proportionate and risk-based approach that provides quicker decision-making, faster action and better collaboration between Member States.  Our problem is that pests and diseases do not respect national borders. That is why it is so important to have an EU-wide agreement. At its most basic, this regulation aims first to prevent the entry of plant pests into the EU, then to eradicate harmful organisms when they are found to be present and, finally, to contain the spread of any outbreak when the first aim fails.  So this agreement updates rules that date back to 2000, in order to provide a modern, responsive and effective regime for plant health. It provides better protection at import, against high-risk trades, it provides increased surveillance and financial support, including better prioritisation of the most harmful of organisms, it introduces stricter eradication measures, it harmonises plant passports and it gives clearer rules for protected zones.  In 2015, the value of crop output in the EU amounted to over EUR 200 billion. It is a key sector for European agriculture and it represents the livelihood of thousands of farmers. We need only look at the devastation caused by Xylella fastidiosa to see both the socioeconomic and the environmental damage which can be caused by pests. Xylella has affected thousands of acres of olive groves in southern Member States and caused severe economic losses for farmers. Another example is Chalara or Ash dieback, which has spread rapidly across continental Europe. In the UK, this fungus was first confirmed in 2012 in trees growing in nurseries or in recently established plantations. It has spread so rapidly that it is estimated that 80 million ash trees could be affected.  It is crucial to protect EU agriculture, horticulture and forestry and as a continent our defences are only as strong as the weakest link. New pests and diseases are emerging all the time as a result of globalisation, climate change and the increasing volume of imports from new parts of the world. All this increases the risk of future outbreaks of harmful organisms. So the challenge of how best to respond to these risks has led to significant political differences amongst the Member States and across Parliament.  I believe the compromise we reached represents the best agreement possible to bridge these differences. It strikes the right balance between facilitating legitimate trade, on the one hand, and protecting the EU from pests from third countries, on the other. A new article was inserted, introducing the possibility of a preliminary assessment on the basis of which high-risk plants, plant products or other objects would be prevented from entering Union territory until a full risk assessment was carried out. Presuming the safeguards for defining high risk are appropriately applied, then the scope for introducing a closed system via the back door is negligible. I really strongly recommend this agreement to Parliament.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very pleased to appear before the plenary here today with a view to successfully concluding our work on the regulation on protective measures against pests of plants, more commonly referred to as the plant health regulation. This is a very important piece of legislation. It is the result of a great deal of hard work by Parliament, the Council and the Commission. Its outcome is, I believe, a credit to all three institutions. We all share a deep and common understanding of the fundamental importance of plant health and its link to the protection of our people’s health, agriculture, food chain and environment. Furthermore, we collectively recognise that outbreaks of plant pest will occur from time to time. This is inevitable due to the intensification of global trade as well as climate change. The case of the outbreak of xylella fastidiosa in Italy, France and, to a small extent, in Germany, is the most recent reminder of the serious threat that pests pose for our farmers, agricultural production, environment and the livelihoods of so many producers. Another example is the pine nematode outbreak in Portugal, affecting our forestry industry. We must ensure we are best prepared to deal with future outbreaks of plant pests and also make sure that our territory remains protected from the entry of non—European pests. The new regulation has been drafted and negotiated while taking into account all of those concerns. In this view it will introduce more protective rules for the early detection and eradication of dangerous plant pests, if found present in EU territory, and more proactive tools and actions such as the prioritisation of pest action plans for eradication. Contingency plans and simulation exercises allow the European Union to adopt a more proactive policy against the entry of pests from other countries and the import of high—risk plants and plant products; harmonise and simplify the rules concerning certification of plants and plants products, thus facilitating their production, marketing and controls; and specify the responsibilities of the producers through legislation and authorisation before they produce, market and certify the health of their plants. All those new provisions are based on the concept that we have to do more in order to suffer less from the devastating effects of some plant diseases. I take the opportunity to recall that Member States remain responsible for import controls and surveillance in their territories to avoid the presence of those pests. Therefore more resources need to be allocated by the Member States to cope with those important tasks. Otherwise this EU law will not bring the expected benefits. In the coming years the Commission will focus its inspection programme on import control audits and will check whether European Union plant health rules are implemented in the Member States in an effective and harmonised manner. All the elements included in this new framework are well thought out and have been thoroughly discussed with all interested parties. I therefore look forward with both hope and expectation to a broad agreement and endorsement of this file. Our work will, of course, continue with the development of dedicated and implementing acts and through the practical implementation of new rules once agreed.

name: Pilar Ayuso
text: PPE Group. – Madam President; Commissioner; I would first of all like to thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs and all those who have collaborated on this report because it was really the best agreement we could reach.  This Regulation has a clear objective, which is to protect European productions from harmful organisms imported from other countries. The history of plant pathology is full of examples of plants that bear no symptoms —disease carriers—but that, when imported to other latitudes, wreak havoc on other species and other genera. This risk is compounded by the single market, as the Commissioner has very well said, because one country is imported and another crop suffers the damage. As an example we have the annoying Xylella, which you have also mentioned, which continues to dramatically affect Italy, France, and also Germany. By all indications, this plague arrived in Europe through an ornamental coffee plant imported through the port of Rotterdam in the Netherlands. That is precisely what we are trying to avoid with preventive measures to combat imported pests.  The new Regulation introduces a new mechanism to combat the emerging risks of epidemics unknown to the European Union through temporary action applications. For all the above, the text we are going to adopt is a very important improvement and I ask all the components of Parliament to support this text, because it is the best of all possible.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the progressive opening up of markets, while it can produce positive economic and commercial results, unfortunately also brings with it an inevitable globalisation of diseases and harmful organisms. Diseases that seriously endanger the health of our plants, posing serious risks to biodiversity and consequently to the competitiveness of our agricultural and forestry sector. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur, Anthea McIntyre, on behalf of my colleague Viorica Dăncilă, for her excellent work and the important result she has achieved.  The text we are about to adopt guarantees a high level of protection and safety for the whole Union against the import of organisms harmful to plant products. A protection of our borders which is becoming increasingly indispensable, also in view of the latest real epidemics that have broken out in Europe, as has been mentioned in the case of the pesky zylella, which risks destroying an invaluable part of the priceless olive heritage of southern Italy, as well as the problems related to the red tree weevil or chestnut cynic, all consequences of an uncontrolled import of infected plants and organisms from third countries that have found fertile soil in our territory. We can therefore no longer wait. This new regulation is all the more necessary in order to establish a plant health regime in Europe capable of preventing and effectively combating the spread of harmful organisms.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and my fellow shadow rapporteurs for the constructive work we have done in the European Parliament. However, I would also like to briefly explain our position as an ALDE Group, because trade brings prosperity but is under pressure in every way possible. The debate is being conducted with a lot of rhetoric, with no proper look at the content.  Since the 1970s, we have been assessing imports of plants from third countries for the possible risks involved. That's what we call an open import system. This allows us to strike a healthy balance between protecting against plant diseases and protecting our important commercial interests. As early as May 2013, the European Commission wanted to address weaknesses in the current system without jeopardising the open import system. The European Parliament wanted the same thing in April 2014.  However, the outcome of the negotiations now jeopardises this: tightened rules and vaguely formulated criteria allow the possibility of banning imports of plants and plant products from third countries, without adequately assessing the risks. In other words, we may be at the mercy of member states that block imports for political reasons. I find this unacceptable! That is why, on behalf of the Liberals in the European Parliament, I have tabled an amendment not to support this agreement. Traders in import ports such as Schiphol and Antwerp will also face red tape and higher costs. Unfortunately, closed borders will not completely exclude plant diseases in the EU, nor will they be prevented.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, globalisation of trade and climate change are causing new pests and diseases to appear in vegetables. Xylella fastidiosa was just one example of what's happening. Strict control and follow-up of plant material entering the European Union is essential, and we therefore support this text. But we also need mechanisms to detect the presence and development of pests of invasive species entering the European Union with imports of other agricultural products, as happened with Vespa velutina. That is why we are asking for a European strategy in which farmers and farmers are recalled for early detection, monitoring and research, and to establish the necessary actions to prevent, eradicate and prevent pests of invasive species from extending. At the same time, we believe that it is necessary to define protocols for action in the fight against pests and invasive species that protect health, the environment and waters.

name: Florent Marcellesi
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the spread of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa is destroying millennial olive trees in Puglia and has now spread to Corsica and Germany. As you know, it is one of the most destructive plant pests that have come to Europe from outside our borders, but it is not the only one.  It was necessary to update the Regulation that prevents the entry of pests and, therefore, we welcomed this proposal on which we have worked, especially my colleague Jordi Sebastio, which I replace, to make it as safe as possible. However, we call on the Commission not to take a decade to draft the implementing acts of the new Regulation to exempt low-risk seeds, the exchange of seeds between farmers and the conservation of genetic biodiversity.  The consequences of pests such as black spot or citrus chancro are incalculable and we are very concerned that lately the Commission will try, through an implementing act, to amend Directive 2000/29/EC, to limit controls on citrus fruits from third countries, which would leave our producers helpless.  I therefore ask that the intention of the Regulation which we are going to vote on in this session be respected and that the Commission does not seek subterfuge to limit controls on the importation of citrus fruits. Don't forget that we must work to protect our producers. That is what they expect from a European Union so that this time it does not fail them.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, we are talking here about an EU-wide attempt to control pests of plants. Failure to control threats to plants and imported produce is well documented. WTO rules allow countries to ban imports on this basis. Member States have different priorities when it comes to deciding on invasive species control. Northern Finland and Cyprus are unlikely to sing from the same song sheet in this respect; the EU will, however, expect them to do so. Controlling pests requires pesticides. The EU institutions are doing their best to reduce the active ingredients that may be used. The latest victim are the endocrine disruptors, and their demise will reduce the number of materials available from 400 to a little over 300, creating more pressure on those that remain to succumb to increasing resistance from the target pest. Whilst the green lobby might be happy with the situation, they have yet to demonstrate that endocrine disruptors are a proven hazard when used correctly. I have personally handled these products for very many years and, to the great disappointment the green lobby, I am still here.

name: Philippe Loiseau
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the European Union is now a sieve open to the four winds. In this open area, how can we monitor if organisms are slipping into import products? This dogmatic refusal to control has in fact allowed the entry of plant pests. In the past, the tomato miner, then the Asian gnat and, more recently, the Xylella fastidiosa have been able to colonize our territories. However, we continue to import products from countries that do not have our trust, have neither our standards nor our requirements, and whose management is more than opaque. So let the states decide!  The risk of isolation and the spirit of cooperation should be sufficient, in my opinion, for everyone to put in place an intelligent and secure health policy. We say 'yes' to increased controls, to the traceability obligation we keep asking for, to the establishment of a list of potentially at-risk countries, and to all these precautionary measures, especially if they are decided by sovereign states in a spirit of cooperation. On the other hand, we do not want the Commission to rule by distributing the right points and punishments to the states or regions. Alas, as is often the case with UERSS, the worst is expected. It is expected, in fact, that States will be sidelined at the time of the debate, stripped of their sovereignty for the benefit, of course, of the Commission. It is the Commission that decrees the problem and decides the solution. In the case of Xylella fastidiosa, it forced the removal of diseased trees from the Puglia region, their neighbours and their neighbours. It never ends. Welcome to the best of worlds where the unelected European Commission, I say, is the alpha and omega of health policy.  With the Commission, it is in fact always the same: some hope for the best, others prepare for the worst.

name: Albert Deß (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mairead McGuinnes, Commissioner Vytenis Andriukaitis, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr After many meetings and trialogue negotiations, we can vote here tomorrow on European legislation on plant health, so that it can enter into force in 2017. I would like to thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs, and in particular Mrs Ayuso from my group, for having worked on this dossier.  Within two years, we in the Committee on Agriculture and the European Parliament have succeeded in getting targeted and balanced legislation on plant health in place. The new Article 41a is intended to address pest risks through precautionary measures. It will be possible to suspend the dangerous imports after a preliminary assessment, taking into account certain criteria, pending the full risk assessment. It was important to require professional operators importing plants and plant products, as well as customers of postal services, internet customers and passengers who import risky plants in their luggage, to obtain a certificate.  We have the opportunity, Commissioner, to continue to participate through the delegated acts. I would ask you to ensure that this proposal – where I expect it to be adopted here tomorrow by a large majority – is also implemented without bureaucracy. Above all, we must also ensure that criteria are not applied to non-professional end users such as domestic gardeners so that they too can obtain their plants in the future.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to join in the congratulations of our rapporteur, Mrs McIntyre, and that of all the shadow rapporteurs, in particular my colleague, Mrs D'ncil, who has been working together to bring about this good agreement, the best possible agreement.  I would have liked to have been able to reach a positive list on plant matters, but I understand that a comprehensive agreement was needed for all the countries of the European Union and, therefore, this is my agreement and this is a great agreement.  The checks must now be carried out by the Member States. This requires means. There I do not agree with Mr Huitema, who says that this will cost us money; of course it costs money, but it is for the protection of plants in the European Union. I therefore hope that the Member States will take care of this new Regulation.  And tell you one thing, Commissioner: let us not change, via annexes, some criteria which are now improved by this Regulation. I say this by the amendment provided for in Directive 2000/29/EC in the case of oranges for juice. Let's not change the rules of the game.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we have new rules to stem the influx of parasites such as xylella, perhaps also resulting from increased trade and climate change. This regulation has passed, it is a step forward for the protection of agriculture, its traditions and the environment. This is thanks to defined preventive measures, tighter import regimes, compensations proportional to the true value of destroyed plants and restrictive conditions for the protection of the environment.  But the Xylella emergency has shown the Contradictions of the Commission: on the one hand, the evil measures imposed on Italy, without solid scientific evidence, and on the other hand the answer to a question of mine by Commissioner Vella, which makes it clear that, although imposed by Brussels, Italy's phytosanitary plan had to provide for a strategic environmental assessment. All this has never been done in Puglia, showing that Italy has not been able to defend its territory and the Commission has not been the guarantor of its directives. I would like to thank the Commission for its answer and like France, which does not intend to cut down the olive trees in Menton, thus confirming the impracticability of the European decision, we are making stronger progress in defending our olive trees.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I, in turn, would like to thank the negotiating team which, around Mrs McIntyre, has shown a great deal of patience because we have been negotiating this text for a long time.  This text seems necessary to me because we and the public want less use of pesticides to protect our crops. The best way to protect crops is not to expose them to primary infection. However, in order for there to be no primary infection, we must have controls that are more active in the different circulations.  Colleague Huitema, but you have already left, I would rather have effective controls at Antwerp airport than farmers who stand idly by in front of infected crops, unable to treat them because we will not have a product to do so and because the research is not going fast enough. You can see it with Xylella. The time of search is unfortunately not the time of infection, it is much longer. We need more research to find solutions, but the globalization of trade facilitates infection. Several cases have already been cited. There are many other examples, including cherry flys and the Asian hornet problem, which also carries a number of diseases.  Therefore, it seems to me that we will have effective legislation, starting tomorrow. It must be voted on as it was negotiated.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to thank Mrs McIntyre, who has really done a very good job, and I hope that Mr Andriukaitis will take up this work in the Commission and implement it successfully. It has already been stressed several times in this House that climate change, globalisation and, of course, people's active travel activities have brought an unintended consequence: imported plant pests from third countries can be seen in many parts of Europe. We are talking about alien plant pests, plant pests that have no natural enemies here. It is about plants that do not have defence mechanisms to deal with these pests. We have a clear objective, and I believe that the objective in the Committee on Agriculture is clear: we want a balance in nature, we want natural health. This means that we have to act on all corners. Tomorrow, we – the EU, Parliament and the Commission – will make the legal framework. It is the responsibility of the Member States to ensure that import controls actually work.  We call on forestry and agriculture to cooperate. We really must also ask private individuals for understanding here from this House when felling swells sometimes occur – including in the private sector – for example, when trees fall.  Plant health concerns us all. We must not set any limits here.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, tomorrow's vote is a great achievement for Europe, as the risk of an invasion of pathogens from third countries is increasing. In recent years we have seen the destruction of part of our ornamental productive heritage due to strict controls and the non-blocking of imports, sometimes when necessary. I am thinking, for example, of what happened with xylella fastidiosa, what happened with the red weevil of palm trees, what is likely to happen with citrus black spot on citrus fruits. The time has come to change gears and I am sure that only through a more serious analysis of the plant material entering the European Union can we avoid further cases of invasion. The new plant passport, a new instrument of the regulation, will ensure that plant material entering the European Union is free from pathogens and will therefore significantly reduce the risk of importing harmful organisms from third countries, organisms which, it is worth remembering, pose a real threat to our production process and cause harm to European consumers and producers.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new regulation represents an important step forward in combating organisms harmful to plants and therefore in protecting biodiversity. The definition of the most dangerous harmful organisms, known as quarantine organisms, the better division between priority harmful organisms, i.e. subject to stricter rules on eradication and public information, and the obligation to register professional operators will make it possible to guarantee more effective controls and better traceability. With this regulation, therefore, trade-related activities both within the Union and with third countries are being adapted by a risk-based assessment. These rules are therefore designed to stem the growing influx of organisms harmful to plants into the European Union, such as xylella fastidiosa or cynicitis for chestnut. Finally, a sufficient interconnection, which is not currently provided for, between the regulation in question and the international standards resulting from the agreements of the International Convention for the Protection of Plants must be promoted.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, plant health is a key factor for sustainable and competitive agriculture, forestry and, more generally, for the biodiversity of the Member States of the Union. The current Union regulatory framework for plant health aims to prevent the entry and spread of harmful organisms, which can destroy European agriculture and forestry. However, to date, we have not seen the desired results of this policy. The high volume of imports of plant species from other continents implies a high probability of creating outbreaks of harmful organisms, while climate change allows these organisms to survive in Europe and makes crops and ecosystems more vulnerable to new harmful organisms. A classic example of Xylella, which destroyed thousands of olive trees in Greece and Italy. It is therefore necessary for the Union to take measures to comply with specific restrictions and requirements on the import and movement of plant products.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, plant health is a key factor in promoting the sustainable and competitive agricultural sector. We are all aware of the importance of making the EU better protected from the possible entrance of new pests that have devastating effects, such as those we have seen recently in Italy and Spain.  However, the result of negotiations is a system where it becomes so easy for Member States to impose bans on plants and plant products based on weak preliminary assessment. I firmly believe that it will make imports more difficult, will lead to the substantial increase of costs, trade distortions, threatening the EU trade in plants worth an estimated EUR 30 billion. There must be a balance between import restrictions and the protection of trade interests, otherwise we risk putting in force legislation which can be a clear signal of protectionism.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this process of drawing up a regulation on measures to protect plant pests contains contradictory aspects. The prevention and combat of pests is a matter of fire. Dominant agricultural models based on export-intensive monocultures reduce the resistance of agricultural systems to pests and enhance their devastating effects, which is why we must first of all question and abandon these models, along side the rejection of any form of privatisation of genetic resources, including through seed patenting. To claim, on the pretext of combating pests, to impose registration and certification measures which, in practice, make the activity of smallfarmers, traditional agriculture impossible, traditional forms of propagation, not acceptable. On the contrary, it would mean jeopardising a sustainable response to the pest problem in the long term. As regards the import of plant material from third countries, strict plant control is justified in the whole that eliminates risks of future outbreaks of plant diseases, with potentially devastating agronomic and ecological consequences.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, plant health is an important factor in the conservation of forests, woodlands and public and private greenery and contributes both to the development of agriculture and to the maintenance of the jobs associated with these activities. We must protect our producers from the introduction, especially from other continents, of harmful organisms affecting European trees which are not so resistant to them. So if the trees are destroyed, agriculture, forestry and horticulture will be destroyed. The European Union must therefore take the necessary measures to ensure that there is both legal cover and practical treatment of this phenomenon. That is why I will support the proposal by voting in favour of the proposed regulation as it meets these conditions and is moving in the right direction.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much indeed for all your remarks. I would like to react to Florent Marcellesi, who asked about the Commission’s timelines. The Commission is aware of the acts that it has to adopt after the regulation enters into force and also all the legal deadlines to adopt those acts. The Commission services are currently working on a timeline to ensure that all those acts are adopted in a timely manner. One of those acts will be a list of priority pests, which will be a delegated act. I agree that we should prevent the entry of high-risk plants. The Commission, indeed, will have to adopt, within two years of the adoption of the regulation, a list of plants, including fruits and vegetables, the import of which will be banned until a full risk assessment proves that they are safe. It is still too early for the Commission to indicate the content of such a list. Of course, as I said, the Member States will have the essential role in controlling borders and putting the necessary resources in place. Honourable Members, I am grateful to Parliament for its important contribution, its hard work and its constructive approach in the development of this file. In particular, I wish to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Fajmon under the previous term, and Ms McIntyre under the current term of the European Parliament, for reaching an agreement in the political negotiation. I also thank the shadow rapporteurs of the previous and current terms of the European Parliament and the teams involved in the negotiations for all the strenuous efforts they have made. I hope that we can now take the final step in bringing this important file to a successful and satisfactory conclusion.

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, let me thank everyone who has participated in this debate. I think we all recognise the importance of bio-security to the EU. This agreement modernises the regime, both for imports from third countries and for intra-EU movements of plants and plant products. It strengthens surveillance, eradication and containment and improves prevention at import. And it does this without needlessly burdening growers or the horticulture trade. The strengthened surveillance elements in this agreement are particularly important.  Currently, co-financing is limited to costs for eradication and containment but not surveillance. The new regime introduces annual surveys to check for the presence of pests and also the listing of a new category of union quarantine pests. For trade, the delegation of responsibilities to private operators to issue plant passports has been a major step forward. The new rules aim to restore trust in the system by harmonising the format for passport information and extending the scope to cover all plants for planting except for certain seeds. This agreement has undergone years of negotiations. We adopted a first reading position in April 2014 and, thanks to the tireless work of the shadows, over seven trilogues, we finally reached agreement just before Christmas. The agreement we reached strikes the right balance: protecting trade while allowing us to respond to threats in a coordinated and effective way across the EU. It is crucial to protect European agriculture and forestry from pests and diseases, and it is essential to put in place this legislative framework with its new stronger provisions without further delay.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. – Pests on the inn know no borders. It is known that many chestnut forests in Europe are infected, the disaster of olive trees in the south of Italy is known and the action of pests on many imported plants is known. Inadequately controlled imports of infected plants to pests that do not have a natural enemy in Europe are a great danger to our biodiversity. I support measures that will introduce more controls and more obligations for importers in terms of stronger phytosanitary security.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on trans fats (TFAs) by Renate Sommer, Daciana Octavia Sârbu, Nikolay Barekov, Anneli Jäätteenmäki, Lynn Boylan, Martin Häusling, Piernicola Pedicini, and Mireille D'Ornano, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000105/2016 - B8-1801/2016), – the oral question to the Commission on trans fats (TFAs) by Renate Sommer, Daciana Octavia Sârbu, Nikolay Barekov, Anneli Jäätteenmäki, Lynn Boylan, Martin Häusling, Piernicola Pedicini, and Mireille D'Ornano, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000106/2016 - B8-1802/2016). Before I give the floor to our speakers, may I just say that time is not on our side. I would ask every speaker to respect their speaking time, because it is an important debate and we want to make sure you have your point.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner Andriukaitis, ladies and gentlemen, Minister, I am speaking on behalf of the 7 co-signatories of the resolution tabled following two questions with a request for a written reply. Trans fat acids are unsaturated fats found in many industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils. TFA legislation is one of the priorities for the European Parliament, which reiterates here its concern about the risks posed by TFA to human health. The consumption of these oils is in fact associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. Recently, in fact, a study has been published showing a significant correlation between the consumption of trans fatty acids and cerebral ischemic events. There are also strong suspicions that such acids may contribute to a large extent to arteriosclerosis processes and thus increase the risk of myocardial infarction.  Who and FAO recommend reducing intake below 1% of daily calorie intake through diet, while EFSA, the European Food Safety Authority, recommends that as little as possible be taken. Parliament therefore considers that it is not appropriate to act only at national level and that action by the European Union is needed to reduce the average intake of trans acids significantly. Trans fatty acids are used by the food industry for their characteristics, giving the products the desired consistency and ensuring a long shelf life, but above all they represent an inexpensive production factor. Foods currently produced with these acids are mainly foods consumed widely among young people. It is precisely the lack of consumer awareness of the negative health effects of TFA that makes mandatory labelling for these acids an important, albeit incomplete, tool. We call on the European Commission to introduce a legal limit in the European Union as soon as possible on the content of industrial TFA, both as ingredients and as end products in all food products, in order to reduce intake by the entire population. We also call for this proposal to be accompanied by an impact assessment introducing the costs of industrial reformulation to be incurred in the event of the introduction of a mandatory limit and the potential spill-over of these costs onto consumers. Finally, we call on the Commission to work with Member States to improve nutritional literacy, encouraging consumers and enabling them to make healthier food choices and engaging industry to promote healthy product reformulation.
