As representatives of the citizens, we have an obligation to call for the adoption of useful tools to enable consumers to make healthier choices about the foods they consume and the diet in general and which could promote the provision of healthier food options to consumers, including, in this case, the provision of information on trans fats or restrictions on their use.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, let me thank Parliament for the interest it has shown in this issue. You have been involved in highlighting all the scientific, practical and political aspects, and the consequences of an excessive consumption of trans-fatty acids or trans fats in the Union. The Council fully agrees that the risks entailed by excessive consumption of trans fats in the Union, and in particular the increased risk of coronary heart disease among the population, raises a serious public health problem. Preventive measures aimed at avoiding chronic diseases and at promoting healthy lifestyles, including incentives to healthier diets and processed food reformulation, are topics that have been the subject of many discussions by the Union health ministers in recent years. Again, a few days ago at the meeting organised by the Presidency in Bratislava and in the presence of Commissioner Andriukaitis, ministers had an opportunity to highlight their concerns related to an excessive consumption of trans-fatty acids in the Union.  I would like to remind you that, as early as 2011, during the negotiations on the Regulation on food information for consumers, the issue of informing consumers about the presence and levels of trans fats in foods was raised. At that time, however, we were faced with a technical obstacle: the absence of a calculation method that would allow us to determine the amounts of natural or ruminant and industrial trans fats in foods. Against that background, there was a risk of condemning foods that are an essential part of a balanced diet. On the other hand, certain Member States have indicated their preference for other measures to reduce the consumption of trans fats, namely the introduction of a legal limit for the presence of industrial trans fats in food. In that context, the legislator felt the need for a more thorough analysis which would enable us to find the most appropriate method to achieve the intended purpose, namely reducing the consumption of industrial trans fats. The Commission was therefore asked to prepare a report on the presence of trans fats in foods and in the overall diet of the Union population. In this report, the Commission concluded in December last year the need to continue and expedite work in this area by collecting more information and by developing a fuller analysis of the magnitude of the problem to be addressed and the different possible solutions, in particular the option of legal limits for industrial trans fats. Another issue raised was the effectiveness of labelling and the appropriate nutrition literacy of consumers. The Commission stated that it intended to launch a public consultation and carry out a fully-fledged impact assessment, which would allow an informed policy decision in the near future. On 7 December 2015, the Council agreed with the report’s conclusions, in particular as regards the need for further research aimed at finding a more adequate solution to attain the desired objective. Based on the results of the impact assessment it is currently conducting, it will be up to the Commission to determine which measures would be the most appropriate in order to reduce the consumption of industrial trans fats. It should, in particular, consider the opportunity to propose any necessary amendments to legal provisions in force. To answer your question, the Council will only be able to assess how best to reduce the consumption of industrial trans fats once the impact assessment has been finalised and the Commission has submitted concrete proposals to achieve the intended objective.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, trans fats are a particular type of unsaturated fatty acids that are present in foods. It is undisputed that they have a negative effect on human health. Their consumption increases the risk of heart diseases more than any other nutrients. Given that heart diseases are the leading cause of death in the EU, it is no surprise that trans fats generate deep concerns not least here in the European Parliament, and I share these concerns.  Let me briefly recollect the content of the report on trans fats adopted last year by the Commission. Trans fats can be produced industrially and their primary source is partly hydrogenated oils. They can also be naturally present in foods derived from animals, in dairy or meat products for example. Industrial trans fats are present at levels of concern in certain foods, and their intake is excessive in certain Member States and for particular population groups such as low-income citizens or students.  Our report reviewed different policy options to reduce trans fats intake in the EU. A limit applied to industrial trans fats in foods emerged as the most promising solution. In that same report, however, the Commission acknowledged that further investigation was required to implement the better regulation principle. I am sure you would criticise the Commission if it proposed an initiative without looking at its impact. Similarly, honourable Members would raise concern if actions on partly hydrogenated oils pushed operators towards alternatives that are not environmentally sustainable. This is why we are carrying out an impact assessment on trans fats. Only at the end of this process will I be in a position to tell you exactly how the Commission intends to proceed. But please be reassured: the impact assessment will now finally start, and we can build on all the data already collected for last year’s report.  Earlier this month the Commission published an inception impact assessment on its Better Regulation portal and in invited feedback from stakeholders. This document is a preliminary version of the impact assessment. It contains a first analysis of the policy options under consideration. I can confirm that one of these options is indeed the establishment of a limit on industrial trans fats in food. The other options are: mandatory trans fats labelling; a ban on partly hydrogenated oils; and self-regulatory instruments.  In the coming weeks we will launch an external study on the impact of these policy options on operators, consumers and the environment. Special attention will be paid to small and medium enterprises. In addition, in the coming months, we will open a public consultation, giving the opportunity for everyone to provide their views. I am fully aware of the need for urgent action on trans fats and I am grateful to the European Parliament keeping this topic high on the agenda. I trust I can count on your cooperation and support in order to advance this file as quickly as possible.

name: Renate Sommer
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The content of trans fatty acids in food has already been significantly reduced on a voluntary basis in recent years – but unfortunately not everywhere. Even where it has been reduced, consumption is still far too high in some population groups – as has already been said – for example among young people or even among people on low incomes. However, the purpose of our resolution is not to talk badly about the staple foods of milk and meat. It has been said, and this is true: milk and meat from ruminants also contain natural trans fatty acids, but of course this cannot be prevented. Consumption of these natural trans fatty acids is so low that it does not pose a health risk. No, we do not want to talk badly about these staple foods or even warn against their consumption. To be quite clear, my group has withdrawn Amendment No 1. But it is important for me to say that Ees must not be about misanely talking about the food industry either. In the resolution, we simply state that we are now aware of the negative effects of trans fatty acids and that it is time to act, and that is why we are calling for this limit value. Incidentally, this is also a requirement of the internal market, because four Member States already have these limit values, and I am convinced that the food industry will cope well with this, because it is already coping well with the limit values in these four Member States.

name: Christel Schaldemose
text: for the S&D Group. Madam President! Industrially produced trans fat is an incredibly dangerous substance for the heart. It's scientifically proven. Trans fat significantly increases the risk of blood clots. There is therefore no good reason to add this to food or cakes. We in the Socialist Group in the European Parliament have been calling for years for action to be taken against this form of trans fat, and that is why it is also a step in the right direction when the European Commission is finally considering taking action. So what needs to be done? In the Socialist Group, we propose that we should have EU legislation that significantly reduces the permitted amount of trans fat in our food. We call for consumers throughout Europe to be immediately protected from this industrially produced trans fat, and we call on the Commission to bring forward such a legislative proposal. Is that possible? Yes! I come from Denmark and for many years we have had a law that has reduced the use of industrially produced trans fats, and this has saved lives, and it has not had any negative effect on business. So our call is: get in the workclothes and get this legislation done! We need to protect European consumers from this dangerous substance.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I support the resolution before us. You are right, Commissioner. Scientific research has shown that excessive intakes of trans fatty acids significantly increase the risk of cardiovascular disease. Although the intake of trans fatty acids in the EU is generally quite low, we find a particularly high concentration in certain foods. A thoughtful approach is therefore permeated. Experience from Denmark, among others, as we heard earlier, shows that a binding limit value is an effective instrument. The Danish measure has a demonstrable positive effect on public health, without a negative impact on the food sector. I also think a limit value is a realistic measure. After all, it is not about zero tolerance. By allowing a minimum, natural trans fats are completely excluded.  Finally, I would like to stress that a trans fat measure must, of course, be part of an integrated approach to healthy eating and be compatible with other agreements, such as voluntary agreements. I am also convinced that constructive dialogue with the sector is essential and necessary to achieve a good result.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. Madam President, science is very exact. Science has proven that trans fats are dangerous for human health, that they worsen the state of health, and unfortunately this is especially present in young people who, due to their diet, often fast food products, ingest large amounts of trans fats, which certainly later affects their health.  The science is completely clear about this, but the market is something else. Trans fats are cheap, but they are harmful. We would say that trans fats can also be delicious because they give the product firmness, but they are harmful. We, your honored commissioner, must start with the fact that trans fats are harmful. How to replace them? Palm oil is one of the possible sources of saturated acids. However, we know about the problem of palm oil and everything that happens in terms of environmental damage. I wonder if we could invest enough funds to use olive oil which we know is very healthy and we have a lot of it today in Europe and the market is saturated with that product as well. I think the European Commission should think in that direction.

name: Lynn Boylan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I am pleased that we are debating this issue. What I am not pleased about is the fact that, despite the Commissioners accepting the urgency tonight, they have not come forward with legislative proposals to tackle these dangerous fats, in spite of the clear evidence which we are hearing tonight of the health risks that they pose, and especially for heart disease. So not only did we have a year’s delay in coming forward with the legally required study into different policy options, but we have also failed to make the proposals which the Commission themselves acknowledge would be the most effective for public health. It is now well overdue that the Commission comes forward with legal mandatory limits as the best option for minimising trans fats in food, which we have seen been so successful in Denmark.  So I call on the Commissioner to listen to this motion, and indeed its own study which showed that mandatory limits were clearly the most effective measure in reducing the risk posed by trans fats to citizens, including those on lower incomes. We have to make it easier for consumers to make the healthier choice, and mandatory limits are the best way to do so for trans fats.

name: Martin Häusling
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work on this I am somewhat surprised that we agree that trans fats – or let us call them industrial fats – are harmful to health. But what do you do? We need an impact assessment. I find that irresponsible. Who do you really need an impact assessment for? Is the industry affected? So here it is quite clear that the consumer must be protected here. For once, WHO and EFSA agree on this: action must be taken. That is why I do not understand why we are now letting more time pass in order to finally get an effective regulation. Nor is it enough just to get labelling, because three out of four consumers do not even know what trans fats are. Trans fats are the cheap-makers in junk food, as my colleague has just said quite rightly. We can replace them without major problems. Therefore, as I said, let me explain, dear Commission and dear Council, why you refuse to act at that point and allow even more years to pass. The United States is fooling us. In fact, they decided in 2015 to ban this from food in the next few years. Why are we not finally following suit?

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you spoke about the impact assessment. We invite you to do it early because it is scientifically proven that taking trans fat increases cardiovascular risk, obesity and even diabetes. It goes without saying that these types of non-communicable diseases are the leading cause of death in the world. Yet trans fatty acids are found in industrially produced partially hydrogenated oils used in biscuits, cakes, popcorn, crackers and many other supermarket products. All foods that for the most part are eaten by children.  At that time, the World Health Organisation reported that 1 in 3 children between the age of 6 and 9 in the European Union is obese and around 7 % of European health expenditure is engaged in the treatment of obesity-related diseases, such as diabetes and cardiovascular diseases. That is why we are calling on the Commission to introduce this legal limit on TFA in order to reduce the recruitment of EU citizens. We call for action to ensure that the food industry is obliged to obtain treatment of trans fats that comply with health standards. We also ask to replace TFA with palm oils. Finally, we call for consumers to be able to make more informed food choices by informing them of the health risks of their products.

name: Mireille D'Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, there is a proven risk of developing cardiovascular disease or certain cancers due to the over-consumption of trans fatty acids. Modest social categories are at the forefront, given the concentration of these substances in some cheap foods. Member States cannot remedy this situation, exacerbated by the crisis and austerity, by the control of imported goods, in view of the dogma of free movement. I wanted to be associated with the work of the European Parliament, because limiting trans fatty acids is a public health emergency. However, the regulatory response must be measured and adapted. It must first be adapted to consumer habits and national gastronomy. (The President interrupts the speaker) It must then be measured because, bearing in mind the distinction between trans fatty acids of natural origin and those of industrial origin, we cannot penalize the dairy sector in chronic difficulties. Finally, in times of economic stagnation, it would be inappropriate to increase the regulatory and administrative burden on businesses. This is all the more true since incentives have demonstrated their effectiveness where they have been introduced. So let us be absolutely repressive at a time when corporate social responsibility may be enough to meet our ultimate goals.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I think it is important that we discuss trans fatty acids, because both EFSA and WHO have made recommendations to reduce their intake.  It is a proven fact the association between these trans fatty acids and cardiovascular diseases, and we must do our best to reduce their intake. But we cannot forget that certain products of animal origin naturally contain these trans fatty acids and that they are necessary products in our daily diet and, therefore, we should not prohibit in any case these fats that are natural and not added. The important thing is to have a varied and balanced diet. In Spain, the Food Safety and Nutrition Act already requires economic operators to reduce these fatty acids in production processes. However, it is important to harmonise legislation at European level. What is essential is that there are awareness campaigns, information and nutritional education on trans fatty acids within a framework that encourages balanced diets and healthy lifestyles. The involvement of the agri-food industry is necessary to reformulate and improve products with the ultimate goal of eliminating or decreasing the content of trans fatty acids added in food.  Commissioner, I know that the Commission is aware that action is needed at European level to harmonise legislation on trans fatty acids and I believe that this motion for a resolution is a good means of promoting it.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In Austria, too, young people are storming fast food restaurants, and in Austria there are also shelves full of baked goods. But we have legislation, and yet the industry is still working. In other words, it is possible to set ceilings by law. Mrs McGuinness and I have already addressed you as representatives of the MEP Heart Group, just as we have now drafted this resolution together with my fellow Members. We believe, above all, that the question of inaction, the impact assessment, if no action is taken, is one that needs to be answered. Every day, people in the European Union fall ill and die because we have this patchwork of legislation, because we have only four countries that have set ceilings; some other Member States have voluntary commitments. We cannot pass it on to the citizens to decide for themselves which oil is good for their health or not. We need ceilings here. Commissioner, I know you are very committed to this issue. I hope that we will be presented with legislation here as soon as possible.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: I am also speaking on behalf of my colleague Werner Kuhn. As politicians, it is our job to take good care of the people. That also means that we are working on people's health. Most citizens eat far too many bad fats, the so-called industrial trans fatty acids from cookies, for example. The consequences can be seen: obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases.  The European Commission and the food industry must therefore get to work quickly: a limit of 2%. I would now like to warn against the attempts of some groups in this House to also cast natural, animal trans fatty acids from normal products, such as butter and milk, in a bad light. Incorrectly. Recent research has even shown that some trans fatty acids in meat and dairy, as in human breast milk, have positive medical properties. U.S. nutrition scientists and the World Health Organization confirmed this in 2015. Of course everything in moderation and in natural proportions, including our healthy European cheeses and meats. Healthy diet in an appropriate diet with the knowledge of today and the experience of the past.  That is why tomorrow, like probably the entire CDA group, I am voting against paragraphs D and E, because it states that natural fats are just as dangerous as industrial fats. And, Commissioner, you don't want that, do you?

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to stress the urgent need for stronger action at European level to limit the amount of trans-industrial fatty acids present in food. Given that there are no good foods and bad foods, only good diets and bad diets and, therefore, food information and education are a central issue in limiting the risks to human health and the emergence of serious diseases, especially cardiovascular diseases, I believe that in this case the choice of compulsory labelling would be only a partial response. In the meantime, it would only apply to pre-packaged foods, and the majority of European citizens are not able to distinguish between good and bad fats, but base their choices mainly on price and, finally, would place an excessive burden on small producers. The solution, which is an invitation to the Commission, can therefore only be to set a single harmonised limit on the quantity of TFA of industrial origin at EU level, which avoids the fragmentation of the single market and facilitates trade with non-EU countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the higher intake of trans fatty acids, which are highly harmful to our organism, is mainly linked to the consumption of partially hydrogenated vegetable oils produced by industry. The WHO considers that the consumption of these acids present in nature, particularly in dairy products and meat, is so low that it represents an unlikely risk to human nature. On the other hand, high intake of industrial TFA, especially in bakery products, increases the risk of developing heart disease, diabetes and obesity. This is all the more alarming when we consider that the people most inclined to consume foods with a high TFA content are children and citizens with socio-economic status and lower education. Pending the impact study, I hope, also in the light of the positive Danish experience, that legal limits will be introduced to the content of trans-industrial fatty acids in order to reduce their intake by the entire population.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the food industry is now increasingly using trans fatty acids as they are a cheap ingredient in the production process and their use guarantees a long duration in products. However, high consumption of trans fatty acids has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and is a risk factor for the development of coronary heart disease which is responsible for around six hundred and sixty thousand deaths per year in the European Union. At the same time, in the Member States of the Union, most of the population does not have adequate information on trans fats and their health effects while, at the same time, european countries' action to reduce the consumption of trans fatty acids is limited. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to propose mandatory limit values for trans fatty acids in order to enhance the health of the citizens of the European Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, trans fatty acids are used in the food industry for various reasons, guarantee a longer shelf life for products, allow them to manipulate their consistency and, above all, are a cheap raw material. But the consumption of this type of fats has been associated with the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, obesity and some types of cancer.  We are therefore in favour of limiting the use and consumption of trans fatty acids, but attention to promote healthy food and fresh, low-processed products is not just legislating to improve labelling, consumer information or even limiting certain ingredients. All this is necessary but not enough.  The consumption of processed foods is now associated with situations of economic insufficiency, which prevents access to quality and healthy products. The cheapest products are usually the most industrially processed ones. No strategy to promote healthy eating should ignore this; on the contrary, it must actively combat it.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to agree with almost all the people who have intervened in the need that we need to have harmonisation of the rules in order to take action on hydrogenated fatty acids — trans fats — especially in industrial processes.  It is noted by international organizations and EFSA that limitations on consumption must be established. I therefore agree with Mr Housling. So many environmental impact studies are not bad, but I think the result is clear.  Let us therefore already take the initiative and take the initiative of the Commission. Tell us a timetable today, here, in response to this debate and tomorrow's resolution, tell us the timetable in which the Commission is already going to introduce legislation as required and as we have all demanded.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone who participated in this lively and stimulating debate. I am pleased to know that Parliament shares the Commission’s concerns, and that there is cross-party support for the European Union to act quickly to reduce intakes of industrial trans fats.  I have listened carefully to the discussions and have taken careful note of your specific views and concerns. First of all I would like to say once again the limits must be introduced only speaking about industrial trans fats, not about ruminants. Second, I think that some of you mentioned that the United States have just introduced some measures, but I would like to draw your attention once again to the fact that the Jean-Claude Juncker Commission has made a strong commitment to better regulation, which means evidence-based policy making. Today’s debate show that many aspects still need to be carefully considered before acting. Members of the European Parliament mentioned: the economic impact on small and medium enterprises; the environmental impact related to use of palm oil; the increased cost for consumers; and so on and so on. The impact assessment is aimed at taking all of these aspects into consideration.  It would be irresponsible to act before having systematically analysed all the evidence available. I fully agree with you that the quicker we act on trans fats the higher the benefit will be for European Union consumers. At the same time quick action should not come at the detriment of proportionate action.  And of course I can assure you that this will be considered in detail in the context of the impact assessment, and I agree that the quicker we act on trans fats the higher the benefits will be for European consumers. At the same time, however, I would like to say that we will do our best as we see possibilities – as you asked about the timetable – to conclude our impact assessment at the end of 2017 to help you sum up our legal proposals.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, actually I have nothing to add to what the Commissioner has said. The honourable Member Mr Häusling has a point: there are obviously risks entailed by the excessive consumption of industrial trans fats in the European Union. That is true; I do not think anybody in this House, and the debate has clearly shown this, questions that. At the same time the Commission is absolutely right, we are operating within a framework, but clearly we have to assess the impact of our regulation on the internal market, on SMEs, on everything – in other words on better regulation. So the Council can only say that we are waiting for a serious impact assessment and, once you come to the conclusion that we have to regulate here, the Council is ready to act.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. – A crucial amount of scientific evidence demonstrates the adverse health effects of trans fatty acids produced by industry. Their excessive consumption not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but is also associated with morbid obesity, as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labelling and voluntary commitments by industry alone do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. Similar conclusions have been reached in the European Commission's report published in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention may be to limit the content of industrial trans fats by law. Hungary was one of the first to act when, in 2014, denmark and Austria by regulation regulated the highest acceptable levels of trans fatty acids in foodstuffs. It is not possible to place on the market food which, in 100 grams of its total fat content, has a quantity of trans fatty acids exceeding 2 grams. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. Following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fatty acids in quantities above the legal limit in the countries concerned has decreased significantly in a short period of time, with significant public health benefits.  It is noteworthy that the food industry is playing an increasingly important role in reducing trans fatty acids, recognising its social responsibility. Taking advantage of the consensual situation, it is therefore important that the European Commission proposes EU limits for these artificial fats as soon as possible. On this basis, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. – I welcome the initiative of my colleagues and support the reduction of industrially produced fats containing trans fatty acids in food. Since the adoption of Regulation 1169/2011, it has been confirmed that such a restriction has a positive impact on the health of the population. Moreover, the Commission's December 2015 report assessed that this is a quick and effective way to achieve this. This is certainly good news in a situation where intake of fats containing trans fatty acids continues to be one of the main risk factors, particularly in terms of the development of coronary artery disease, but prevention needs to continue to improve. The disease is estimated to cause around 660,000 deaths a year in the EU, about 14% of the total. In the EU, 4 million people die from cardiovascular disease every year, which continues to represent almost half of all deaths. It is therefore striking that, within the framework of its mandate, the Commission has not assessed the need to put forward a legislative proposal aimed at excluding in the long term fats containing trans fatty acids from the food supply chain in the EU by introducing either a mandatory marketing of these fats or an EU legal upper limit for industrially produced trans-fatty acid fats for all foods. The immediate introduction of EU-wide legislation has long been supported by leading experts, especially associations of European cardiologists, consumer organisations, but manufacturers also agree on it.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Trans fats are found naturally in food derived from ruminant, in some plants and in human breast milk. However, most of the trans fats consumed are produced in an industrial way. Thus, the intake of trans fats is mainly associated with the consumption of industrial food products.  There are data on the health risks resulting from the consumption of trans fats and are the cause of human obesity. I believe that the European institutions should take certain measures to protect the health of European citizens, which primarily relates to better information through the education system. I also believe that a policy aimed at limiting the proportion of trans fats in foodstuffs should be implemented.  I see this resolution proposal as a step closer to more efficiently informing about the harmful consequences of consuming industrial trans fats and starting a strategy aimed at limiting their use. I am convinced that decision-making on trans fats at EU level would have a positive impact on public health.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – In a consumption economy and in the age of speed, consumption of fast food, semi-prepared and processed foods is increasing exponentially, as such it is necessary to regulate the AGT, harmonised at European Union level, taking into account all existing regulations within the Member States, but also those existing in the USA (on 16 June 2015, the FDA, based on scientific evidence , prohibits the use of trans fatty acids in processed foods with a term of 3 years for producers). In this way, low-income or 18-year-olds will no longer be at risk of exceeding the WHO's 1% threshold. Obviously, the labelling of trans fats becomes necessary in the context where medical specialists and nutritionists consider trans fats to be the most dangerous type of fat, because they increase the level of bad cholesterol (LDL) in the body and decrease the good one (HDL). However, there is also a need for a system for reading and interpreting labels of processed foods so that, knowingly, Europe's citizens can improve their diet by developing appropriate nutrition and nutrition programmes.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Cardiovascular diseases, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and obesity: these are the risks that European citizens consume excessively of trans fatty acids in their diet. The problem is that only 30% of consumers know what trans fatty acid (TRANS) is, which exposes the other two thirds of Europeans to potentially serious medical problems. That is why, by the vote this afternoon, we want clear labelling, but this is not enough: we must also limit the presence of these acids. Consumption of TFAs increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, particularly coronary heart disease, with an estimated 660,000 deaths in Europe each year, or 14% of European mortality. Through the text voted today, we therefore support the imposition of mandatory limits on trans fatty acids produced industrially and excessively present in the diet. We cannot accept that citizens are putting their health at risk any longer. Given the lack of national legislation in many countries, it is up to Europe to take the lead.
